Sanskrit Shloka: यथा वदत्येष विहीनयोनिः शालावृको वाममुपेत्य पार्श्वम्। सुव्यक्तमस्मानवमन्य पापैः कृतोऽभिमर्दः कुरुभिः प्रसह्य॥
English Translation: was Then with other arrows cutting off his bow, Arjuna began to career over the field. Thereat the ruler of the Ambashthas, with eyes rolling in rage, took up his mace.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्येव ते तद् वनमाविशन्तो महत्यरण्ये मृगयां चरित्वा। बालामपश्यन्त तदा रुदन्ती धात्रेयिकां प्रेष्यवधू प्रियायाः॥
English Translation: And assaulted in that battle Pritha's son and also the mighty car-warrior Keshava. Then O Bharata that hero, up-lifting and striking with his mace.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तामिन्द्रसेनस्त्वरितोऽभिसृत्य रथादवप्लुत्य ततोऽभ्यधावत्। प्रोवाच चैनां वचनं नरेन्द्र धात्रेयिकामन्तितरस्तदानीम्॥
English Translation: Checked the progress of Arjuna's car and with it began to strike Keshava; beholding Keshava struck with the mace, that slayer of hostile heroes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किं रोदिषि त्वं पतिता धरण्यां किं ते मुखं शुष्यति दीनवर्णम्। कच्चिन्न पापैः सुनृशंसकृद्भिः प्रमाथिता द्रौपदी राजपुत्री॥
English Translation: Arjuna, O Bharata, excited to the highest pitch of anger, showered over that foremost of car-warriors viz., the ruler of the Ambasthas wielding the mace, numerous shafts furnished with golden wings, like the mass of clouds enshrouding the risen sin. Thereafter with other arrows, Pritha's son splintered into pieces the mace of that illustrious warrior; indeed this feat appeared to be marvellous. Then beholding that mace of his cut down and taking up another heavy one.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अचिन्त्यरूपा सुविशालनेत्रा शरीरतुल्या कुरुपुङ्गवानाम्। यद्येव देवी पृथिवीं प्रविष्टा दिवं प्पपन्नाप्यश्चवा समुद्रम्॥ तस्या गमिष्यन्ति पदे हि पार्था यथा हि संतप्यति धर्मपुत्रः।
English Translation: The ruler of the Ambashthas began to strike Vasudeva's son and Arjuna, incessantly. Thereat Arjuna with a couple of razor-headed arrows cut-off his upraised arms weilding the pole of Indra; and then with another winged shaft be cut off his head. Then that king, O monarch, fell down on the earth creating a loud noise.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: को हीदृशानामरिमर्दनानां क्लेशक्षमानामपराजितानाम्॥ दनुत्तमं रत्नमिव प्रमूढः।
English Translation: Like a standard raised in honour of Indra falling down, when the ropes tying it to the engine (on which it is posted) are cut-off. Then plunging deep into the division of cars and surrounded by hundreds upon hundreds of elephants and steeds, the son of Pritha looked like the sun covered with thick masses of clouds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न बुध्यते नाथवतौमिहाद्य बहिश्चरं हृदयं पाण्डवानाम्॥ कस्याद्य कायं प्रतिभिद्य घोरा महीं प्रवेक्ष्यन्ति शिताः शराग्र्याः।
English Translation: Vaishampayana said, Hearing these words of Arjuna, O chastiser of foes, the mighty-armed and broad chested, Nakula, temperate in speech and possessed of great wisdom, with copper coloured face, looked at the king, that foremost of all righteous persons, and spoke the these words, assailing his brother's heart (with reason).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मा त्वं शुचस्तां प्रति भीरु विद्धि यथाद्य कृष्णा पुनरेष्यतीति॥ निहत्य सर्वान् द्विषतः समग्रान् पार्थाः समेष्यन्त्यथा याज्ञसेन्या।
English Translation: Nakula said Even the gods had placed their fires in the reign called Vishakha-yupa, Know, therefore, O king, that the gods themselves depend upon the fruits of action!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथाब्रवीच्चारु मुखं प्रमृज्य धात्रेयिका सारथिमिन्द्रसेनम्॥ जयद्रथेनापहृता प्रमथ्य पञ्चेन्द्रकल्पान् परिभूय कृष्णा। तिष्ठन्ति वानि नवान्यमूनि वृक्षाश्च न म्लान्ति तथैव भग्नाः॥
English Translation: Observing the Vedic ordinances (of the Creator as declared in the Vedas), the Pitris, who support (by rain) the lives of even all disbelievers, are, O king, engaged in action.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आवर्तयध्वं ह्यनुयात शीघ्रं न दूरयातैव हि राजपुत्री। संनह्यध्वं सर्व एवेन्द्रकल्पा महान्ति चारूणि च दंशनानि॥
English Translation: They are, indeed, consummate atheists who do not accept the injunction of the Vedas (which inculcate action). By following Vedic injunctions in all his acts, the person that is learned in the Vedas, attains, O Bharata, to the highest region of heaven by the way of the deities. All persons acquainted with Vedas have declared the life of a householder to be superior to all the (other) modes of life.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गृणीत चापानि महाधनानि शरांश्च शीघ्रं पदवीं चरध्वम्। पुरा हि निर्भर्त्सनदण्डमोहिता प्रमोहचित्ता वदनेन शुष्यता॥ ददाति कस्मैचिदनर्हते तनुं वराज्यपूर्णामिव भस्मनि स्रुचम्। पुरा तुषाग्नाविव हूयते हविः पुरा श्मशाने स्रगिवापविद्ध्यते॥ पुरा च सोमोऽध्वरगोऽवलिाते शुना यथा विप्रजने प्रमोहिते। महत्यरण्ये मृगयां चरित्वा पुरा शृगालो नलिनी विगाहते॥
English Translation: O king, the person who in sacrifices give away his fairly acquired wealth to these Brahmanas who are well conversant with the Vedas, and contracts his soul, is, O monarch, regarded as the true Renouncer.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मा वः प्रियायाः सुनसं सुलोचनं चन्द्रप्रभाच्छं वदनं प्रसन्नम्। स्पृश्याच्छुभं कश्चिदकृत्यकारी श्वा वै पुरोडाशमिवाध्वरस्थम्। एतानि वान्यनुयात शीनं मा वः कालः क्षिप्रमिहात्यगाद् वै॥
English Translation: He, however, who, disregarding the life of a householder, the source of much happiness, adopts the next mode of life,-Renunciation, O monarch, is Renouncer possessed by the quality of darkness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच भद्रे प्रतिक्राम नियच्छ वाचं मास्मत्सकाशे परुषाण्यवोचः। राजानो वा यदि वा राजपुत्रा बलेन मत्ता वञ्चनां प्राप्नुवन्ति॥
English Translation: That man who is houseless, who roves over the world like a mendicant who has the foot of a tree for his refuge, who observes the vow of silence, never cooks for himself, and tries to control his senses, is, O Partha, a Renouncer observing the vow of mendicancy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच एतावदुक्त्वा प्रययुर्हि शीघ्रं तान्येच वान्यनुवर्तमानाः। मुहुर्महालवदुच्छ्वसन्तो ज्यां विक्षिपन्तश्च महाधनुर्यः॥
English Translation: That Brahmana who, disregarding anger and joy, and especially deceitfulness, always devotes his time to the study of the Vedas, is a Renouncer observing the vow of mendicancy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मुद्भूतं वै वाजिखुरप्रणुन्नम्। पदातीनां मध्यगतं च धौम्यं विक्रोशन्तं भीममभिद्रवेति॥
English Translation: The four different modes of life were at one time weighed in the balance. The wise have said, O king, that when the life of a householder was placed on one scale, it required the three others to balance it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते सान्त्व्य धौम्यं परिदीनसत्त्वाः सुखं भवानेत्विति राजपुत्राः। श्येना यथैवामिषसम्प्रयुक्ता जवेन तत् सैन्यमथाभ्यधावन्।॥
English Translation: Marking the result of this examination by scales, O Partha, and seeing further, O Bharata, that the life of a householder alone contained both heaven and pleasure, the great Rishis and the persons conversant with the ways of the world followed it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषां महेन्द्रोपमविक्रमाणां संरब्धानां धर्षणाद् याज्ञसेन्याः। क्रोधः प्रजज्वाल जयद्रथं च दृष्ट्वा प्रियां तस्य रथे स्थितां च॥
English Translation: He, therefore,O foremost of Bharata's race, who follows this mode of life, thinking it to be his duty and abandoning all desire for fruit, is a true Renouncer, and not that man who having clouded understanding goes to the forest abandoning home.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रचुकुशुश्चाप्यथ सिन्धुराज वृकोदरश्चैव धनंजयश्च। स्ततो दिशः सम्मुमुहुः परेषाम्॥
English Translation: A person, again, who, putting on the external marks of righteousness, fails to conquer his desires even while living in the forest, is bound by Death with his deadly fetters round the neck.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच भगवन् नाहमप्येतद् रोचये द्यूतसम्भवम्। मन्ये तद्विधिनाऽऽकृष्य कारितोऽस्मीति वै मुने॥
English Translation: Acts which are the outcome of vanity product no fruit. Those acts however, O monarch, which are the outcome of the spirit of Renunciation, always bear abundant fruits.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नैतद् रोचयते भीष्मो न द्रोणो विदुरो न च। गान्धारी नेच्छति द्यूतं तत्र मोहात् प्रवर्तिमम्॥
English Translation: Tranquillity, self-restraint, fortitude, truth, purity, simplicity, sacrifices, perseverance, and righteousness,-these are always the virtues recommended by the Rishis.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: परित्यक्तुं न शक्नोमि दुर्योधनमचेतनम्। पुत्रस्नेहेन भगवञ्जानन्नपि प्रियव्रत॥
English Translation: The householder performs acts intended for Pitris, gods, and guests, this mode of life alone, O monarch, contains the threefold objects.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यास उवाच वैचित्रवीर्य नृपते सत्यमाह यथा भवान्। दृढं विद्मः परं पुत्रं परं पुत्रान्न विद्यते॥
English Translation: The Renouncer that rigidly follows this mode of life, in which one is free to do all acts, has not to meet ruin either here or hereafter.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इन्द्रोऽप्यश्रुनिपातेन सुरभ्या प्रतिबोधितः। अन्यैः समृद्धैरप्यर्थैर्न सुतान्मन्यते परम्॥
English Translation: The holy Lord of all creatures, of righteous soul, created creatures with the purpose that they would worship him by sacrifices with profuse presents.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अत्र ते कीर्तयिष्यामि महदाख्यानमुत्तमम्। सुरभ्याश्चैव संवादमिन्द्रस्य च विशाम्पते।॥
English Translation: Creepers, trees, deciduous herbs, and clean animals, and clarified butter, were created as materials of sacrifice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्रिविष्टपगता राजन् सुरभी प्रारुदत् किल। गवां माता पुरा तात तामिन्द्रोऽन्वकृपायत॥
English Translation: To a householder the performance of sacrifice is fraught with impediments. For this, that mode of life is described as exceedingly difficult and unattainable.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इन्द्र उवाच किमिदं रोदिषि शुभे कच्चित् क्षेमं दिवौकसाम्। मानुषेष्वथ वा गोषु नैतदल्पं भविष्यति॥
English Translation: The householders, who, possessed of wealth and corn and animals, do not perform sacrifices commit, o king, eternal sin.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुरभिरुवाच विनिपातो न वः कश्चिद् दृश्यते त्रिदशाधिप। अहं तु पुत्रं शोचामि तेन रोदिमि कौशिक॥
English Translation: Amongst Rishis, there are some who consider the study of the Vedas to be a some sacrifice; and who consider contemplation to be a great sacrifice which they perform in their minds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पश्यैनं कर्षकं क्षुद्रं दुर्बलं मम पुत्रकम्। प्रतोदेनाभिनिघ्नन्तं लागलेन च पीडितम्॥ निषीदमानं सोत्कण्ठं वध्यमानं सुराधिप। कृपाविष्टास्मि देवेन्द्र मनश्चोद्विजते मम। एकस्तत्र बलोपेतोधुरमुद्वहतेऽधिकाम्॥ अपरोऽप्यबलप्राणः कृशोधमनिसंततः। कृच्छ्रादुद्वहते भारं तं वै शोचामि वासव॥ वध्यमानः प्रतोदेन तुद्यमानः पुनः पुनः। नैव शक्नोति तं भारमुद्वोढुं पश्य वासव॥
English Translation: The very gods, O king, seek the companionship of such a holy person, who on account of his following such a way which consists in the concentration of the mind, has become equal to Brahma.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽहं तस्य शोकार्ता विरौमि भृशदुःखिता। अश्रूण्यावर्तयन्ती च नेत्राभ्यां करुणायती॥
English Translation: By refusing to spend in Sacrifice the various kinds of wealth which you have collected from your enemies, you are only displaying your want of faith!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शक्र उवाच तव पुत्रसहस्रेषु पीड्यमानेषु शोभने। किं कृपायितवत्यत्र पुत्र एकत्र हन्यति॥
English Translation: I have never seen O monarch, a king living as a householder renouncing his wealth in any other way except 'in the Rajasuya, the Ashvamedha, and other kinds of Sacrifice!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुरभिरुवाच यदि पुत्रसहस्राणि सर्वत्र समतैव मे। दीनस्य तु सतः शक्र पुत्रस्याभ्यधिका कृपा॥
English Translation: Like Shakra, the king of gods, O sire, perform those other sacrifices that are lauded by the Brahmanas!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यास उवाच तदिन्द्रः सुरभीवाक्यं निशम्य भृशविस्मित;। जीवितेनापि कौरव्य मेनेऽभ्यधिकमात्जम्॥
English Translation: The king, through whose negligence the subjects are plundered by robbers, and who does not offer protection to those whom he is called upon to rule is said to be the personated Kali.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रववर्ष च तत्रैव सहसा तोयमुल्बणम्। कर्षकस्याचरन् विघ्नं भगवान् पाकशासनः॥
English Translation: If, without giving away horses and kine, and female slaves and elephants adorned with trappings, and villages, and populous countries, and fields, and houses, to Brahmanas, we retire into the forest with hearts not overflowing with friendly feelings towards kinsmen, even we shall be, O king, like so many Kali Kshatriyas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तद् यथा सुरभिः प्राह समवेतास्तु ते तथा। सुतेषु राजन् सर्वेषु हीनेष्वभ्यधिका कृपा॥
English Translation: Kshatriyas who do not practise charity and give protection (to others), commit sin. Woe to thein hereafter and not bliss.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यादृशो मे सुतः पाण्डुस्तादृशो मेऽसि पुत्रका विदुरश्च महाप्राज्ञः स्नेहादेतद् ब्रवीम्यहम्॥
English Translation: If, O lord, without celebrating great sacrifices and the rites in honour of your deceased manes, and if, without bathing in sacred waters, you lead the life of a mendicant, you will then meet with destruction like a sinall cloud, separated from a mass and driven by the winds. You will then fall off from both worlds and will be born in the Pishacha order.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चिराय तव पुत्राणां शतमेकश्च भारत। पाण्डोः पञ्चैव लक्ष्यन्ते तेऽपि मन्दाः सुदुःखिताः।
English Translation: A person becomes a true Renouncer by casting off internal and external attachments, and not simply by leaving home for dwelling in the forest,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कथं जीवेयुरत्यन्तं कथं वर्धयुरित्यपि। इति दीनेषु पार्थेषु मनो मे परितप्यते॥
English Translation: A Brahmana who follows all the ordinances in which there are no obstacles, does not fall off from this or the other world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदि पार्थिव कौरव्याञ्जीवमानानिहेच्छसि। दुर्योधनस्तव सुतः शमं गच्छतु पाण्डवैः॥
English Translation: Observing the duties of one's own order, respected by the ancients and practised by the best of men,-who is there, ( Partha, that would grieve, o king, for having killed in battle his enemies elated with prosperity, like Shakra killing the forces of the Daityas?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच ततः पूर्वापरे सैन्ये समीक्ष्य भगवानृषिः। सर्ववेदविदां श्रेष्ठो व्यासः सत्यवतीसुतः॥ भविष्यति रणे घोर भरतानां पितामहः। प्रत्यक्षदर्शी भगवान् भूतभव्यभविष्यवित्॥ वैचित्रवीर्यं राजानं स रहस्यं ब्रवीदिदम्। शोचन्तमार्तं ध्यायन्तं पुत्राणामनयं तदा॥
English Translation: Having, while observing Kshatriya duties, subjugated the world by the help of your prowess, and having made presents unto persons conversant with the Vedas, you can, O king, go to regions higher than heaven itself. You should not, O Partha, indulge in grief.'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यास उवाच राजन् परीतकालास्ते पुत्राश्चान्ये च पार्थिवाः। ते हिंसन्तीव संग्रामे समासाद्येतरेतरम्॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : O great monarch, that damsel observant of vows, began with a pure heart, to propitiate that vow observing Brahmana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषु कालपरीतेषु विनश्यत्स्वेव भारत। कालपर्यायमाज्ञाय मा स्म शोके मनः कृथाः॥
English Translation: O king of kings, that foremost of Brahmanas sometimes saying “I will come in the morning" made his appearance in the evening or at night.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदि चेच्छसि संग्रामे द्रष्टुमेतान् विशाम्पते। चक्षुर्ददानि ते पुत्र युद्धं तत्र निशामय॥
English Translation: (But) that damsel at all hours entertained him with excellent food, drink and bed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच न रोचये ज्ञातिवधं द्रष्टुं ब्रह्मर्षिसत्तम। युद्धमेतत् त्वशेषेण शृणुयां तव तेजसा॥
English Translation: And her hospitality towards him as regards his food, seat and bed increased rather than decreased day by day.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच एतस्मिन् नेच्छति द्रष्टुं संग्रामं श्रोतुमिच्छति। वराणामीश्वरो व्यासः संजयाय वरं ददौ॥
English Translation: Even if the Brahmana reproved, found fault with and spoke harsh words, to her, Pritha did not do anything disagreeable to him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एष ते संजयो राजन् युद्धमेतद् वदिष्यति। एतस्य सर्वसंग्रामे न परोक्षं भविष्यति॥
English Translation: At several times the Brahmana came after the appointed time or did never come at all and (on many occasions) asked for food when it could only be procured with utmost difficulty.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चक्षुषा संजयो राजन् दिव्येनैव समन्वितः। कथयिष्यति ते युद्धं सर्वज्ञश्च भविष्यति॥
English Translation: (But at all these times) Pritha said "everything is ready," and placed the meal before him. And like a disciple, like a daughter or like a sister, with a pure heart.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रकाशं वाप्रकाशं वा दिवा वा यदि वा निशि। मनसा चिन्तितमपि सर्वं वेत्स्यति संजयः॥
English Translation: That faultless jewel of a damsel, O king of kings, caused the satisfaction of that foremost of the Brahmanas as he liked.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नैनं शस्त्राणि छेत्स्यन्ति नैनं बाधिष्यते श्रमः। गावल्गणिरयं जीवन् युद्धादस्माद् विमोक्ष्यते॥
English Translation: That most exalted of the twice-born ones was highly pleased with her manners and character and on account of her ministrations tried his very best for her welfare.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अहं तु कीर्तिपेतेषां कुरूणां भरतर्षभ। पाण्डवानां च सर्वेषां प्रथयिष्यामि मा शुचः॥
English Translation: And O Bharata, her father asked her every morning "O daughter, is the Brahmana satisfied with your ministrations?”
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दिष्टमेतन्नरव्याघ्र नाभिशोचितुमर्हसि। न चैव शक्यं संयन्तुं यतो धर्मस्ततो जयः॥
English Translation: And that renowned damsel replied “yes very much". Thereupon, the high-minded Kuntibhoja felt a great joy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच एवमुक्त्वा स भगवान् कुरूणां प्रपितामहः। पुनरेव महाभागो धृतराष्ट्रमुवाच ह॥
English Translation: When on the expiration of a whole year, that best of devotees could not find any cause to be dissatisfied with Pritha, devoted to his service.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इह युद्धे महाराज भविष्यति महान् क्षयः। तथेह च निमित्तानि भयदान्युपलक्षये॥
English Translation: That Brahmana, then, with a joyful heart said to her “O gentle and graceful maid, I have been highly pleased with your ministrations.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्येनागृध्राश्च काकाश्च कङ्काश्च सहिता बकैः। सम्पतन्ति नगाग्रेषु समवायांश्च कुर्वते॥
English Translation: O auspicious girl, ask for (such) a boon as is very difficult for men to receive in this word, by virtue of which you will be able to ecclipse all the ladies in fame.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभ्यग्रं च प्रपश्यन्ति युद्धमानन्दिनो द्विजाः। क्रव्यादा भक्षयिष्यन्ति मांसानि गजवाजिनाम्॥
English Translation: Kunti said: O best of those versed in the Vedas, all my desires have been gratified in as much as you as well as my father are pleased with me. So, O Brahmana, I think I have already received boons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निर्दयं चाभिवाशन्तो भैरवा भयवेदिनः। कङ्काः प्रयान्ति मध्येन दक्षिणामभितो दिशम्॥
English Translation: The Brahmana said: O gentle girl of sweet smiles, if you do not desire for boons from me, then take this Mantra for invoking the gods.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उभे पूर्वापरे संध्ये नित्यं पश्यामि भारत। उदयास्तमने सूर्य कबन्धैः परिवारितम्॥
English Translation: Whatever god you may invoke by (uttering) this Mantra, he will be, O gentle girl, quite under your control.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्वेतलोहितपर्यन्ताः कृष्णग्रीवा: सविद्युतः। विवर्णाः परिघाः संधौ भानुमन्तमवारयन्।॥
English Translation: Whether he desires or not, that god, (whom you may invoke) by virtue of the mantra (will come to you) in a gentle guise and like a slave will be subject to you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ज्वलितार्केन्दुनक्षत्रं निर्विशेषदिनक्षयम्। अहोरात्रं मया दृष्टं तद् भयाय भविष्यति॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Then O king, afraid of being cursed by that foremost of the twice-born ones, that faultless girl could not refuse him a second time.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अलक्ष्यः प्रभयाहीनः पौर्णमासी च कार्तिकीम्। चन्द्रोऽभूदग्निवर्णश्च पद्मवर्णनभस्तले॥
English Translation: Then, O monarch, that Brahmana initiated that girl of faultless proportions into the Mantras, placed in the beginning of the Atharvaveda.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्वप्स्यन्ति निहता वीरा भूमिमावृत्य पार्थिवाः। राजानो राजपुत्राश्च शूराः परिघबाहवः॥
English Translation: O lord of kings, having thus initiated her (into the mantras), he said to Kuntibhoja, “O Monarch, being always duly worshipped and gratified by your daughter I have lived happily in your house. I will now depart". Saying this he vanished away.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्तरिक्षे वराहस्य वृषदंशस्य चोभयोः। प्रणादं युद्ध्यतो रात्रो रौद्रं नित्यं प्रलक्षये॥
English Translation: The king was wonder-struck at beholding him vanish at that very spot. He then properly adored Pritha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: देवताप्रतिमाश्चैव कम्पन्ति च हसन्ति च। वमन्ति रुधिरं चास्यैः खिद्यन्ति प्रपतन्ति च॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said Thereupon the troops on your side who were most invincible in battle, having placed Karna in the front part (of the army) and returning back, engaged in a battle that looked like the war between the celestials and the Asuras.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनाहता दुन्दुभयः प्रणदन्ति विशाम्पते। अयुक्ताश्च प्रवर्तन्ते क्षत्रियाणां महारथाः॥
English Translation: Then the multitudes of elephant-warriors, the car-warriors, the foot-soldiers and the horsemen, who were roused by the sound of conches, as well as by the roars of elephants, men, cars and horses and filled with great rage, stood on the face of the antagonists and continued to slaughter them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कोकिलाः शतपत्राश्च चाषा भासाः शुकास्तथा। सारसाश्च मयूराश्च वाचो मुञ्चन्ति दारुणाः॥
English Translation: In that fierce battle, numerous elephants, cars and horses, as well as slaughtered by the foremost of horses with their sharp battle axes, scimitars, axes and men were several sorts of shafts, as also with their conveyances.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गृहीतशस्त्राः क्रोशन्ति चर्मिणो वाजिपृष्ठगाः। अरुणोदये प्रदृश्यन्ते शतशः शलभव्रजाः॥
English Translation: The earth looked most resplendent with the severed heads of persons scattered over her, that resembled either the lotus, or the sun, or the moon in splendour and also that were furnished with the white teeth, excellent faces, eyes and noses and that and ornamented with beautiful ear-rings, upon their ears.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उभे संध्ये प्रकाशन्ते दिशां दाहसमन्विते। पर्जन्यः पांसुवर्षी च मांसवर्षी च भारत॥
English Translation: Thus thousands of elephants and men and horses were slaughtered by means of hundreds of spiked maces, short bludgeons, arrows, called Shakti and lances, as also by the hooks, Bhushandis and clubs which caused the torrents of a river of blood flow down.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: या चैषा विश्रुता राजंस्त्रैलोक्ये साधुसम्मता। अरुन्धती तयाप्येष वसिष्ठः पृष्ठतः कृतः॥
English Translation: Then that entire body of slain car-warriors, men, horses and elephants, that were all slaughtered by the antagonists and thus were most terrific to look at, lying (upon the field) with their gaping wounds, seemed to be like the kingdom of the prince of the Dead at the time of the utter destruction of all creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रोहिणी पीडयन्नेष स्थितो राजशनैश्चरः। व्यावृत्तं लक्ष्म सोमस्य भविष्यति महद् भयम्॥
English Translation: Thereupon, O god among men, your troops and your sons, those foremost of the Kuru race, who are like the sons of the celestials, having placed at the front of the battle the heroes of immeasurable prowess, all rushed against that descendant of the Shini race (Satyaki).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनभ्रे महाघोरः स्तनितः श्रूयते स्वनः। वाहनानां च रुदतां निपतन्त्यश्रुबिन्दवः॥
English Translation: Then that force, which was filled with men, the best of horses, cars and innumerable elephants and that sent forth an uproar resembling the roar of a vast ocean of salt and also that looked like the army of the Asuras or of the celestials and again, that was most terrifying to look at, looked most resplendent with extraordinary beauty.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच धन्या धन्या इति जनाः सर्वेऽस्मान् प्रवदन्त्युत। न दुःखिततरः कश्चित् पुमानस्माभिरस्ति ह॥
English Translation: Thereupon the son of Ravi (Sun), who was like the chief of the celestials (Indra) in prowess, struck that best of the Shini race, who also resembled the younger brother of the Tridashas (celestials), by means of arrows, that had the splendour of the rays of the sun, in the field of battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: लोकसम्भावितैर्दुःखं यत् प्राप्तं कुरुसत्तम। प्राप्य जाति मनुष्येषु देवैरपि पितामह॥ कदा वयं करिष्यामः संन्यासं दुःखसंज्ञकम्। दुःखमेतच्छरीराणां धारणं कुरुसत्तम॥
English Translation: Thereafter that foremost one of the Shini race, with threat activity, wholly covered, in the field of battle, that chief among men, along with his car, horses and charioteer, with numerous arrows, that were as fierce as the virulent poison of the snake, in that dreadful field of battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विमुक्ताः सप्तदशभिर्हेतुभूतैश्च पञ्चभिः। इन्द्रियार्थैर्गुणैश्चैव अष्टाभिश्च पितामह॥ न गच्छन्ति पुनर्भावं मुनयः संशितव्रताः। कदा वयं गमिष्यामो राज्यं हित्वा परंतप॥
English Translation: Then the most expert car-warriors, who are your friends, being attended by their elephants, cars, horses and the foot-soldiers, with immense activity, rushed against Vasusena, that foremost of car-warriors, who was then highly oppressed with the shafts, shot by that chief of the Shini race.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच नास्त्यनन्तं महाराज सर्वं संख्यानगोचरः। पुनर्भावोऽपि विख्यातो नास्ति किंचिदिहाचलम्॥
English Translation: That army, which was like a vast ocean and dispersed in all directions, was wholly inade to run away from the battle by the Pandava heroes, headed by the sons of Drupada, with extraordinary quickness. On this occasion, a great slaughter of men, cars, horses and elephants took place.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न चापि मन्यसे राजन्नेष दोषः प्रसङ्गतः। उद्योगादेव धर्मज्ञा कालेनैव गमिष्यथ।॥
English Translation: Thereupon those two best of all persons, Arjuna and Keshava, who were resolved upon slaughtering all their antagonists, after having finished the worship of lord Bhava, according to the ordained rites and also having performed their daily prayer ceremonies, with great rapidity proceeded against your force.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नरेशेऽयं सततं देही नृपते पुण्यपापयोः। तत एव समुत्थेन तमसा रुध्यतेऽपि च॥
English Translation: Then their antagonists, namely the Kuru warriors, highly gratified at heart, looked upon that car, that had its rattle resembling the uproar of the masses of clouds and also whose banners and standards were being by the air and to which again, beautiful white horses were yoked and moreover, that was proceeding towards them like the very Death himself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथाञ्जमनयो वायुः पुनर्मानःशिलं रजः। अनुप्रविश्य तद्वर्णो दृश्यते रञ्जयन् दिशः॥ तथा कर्मफलैर्देही रञ्जितस्तमसाऽऽवृतः। विवर्णो वर्णमाश्रित्य देहेषु परिवर्तते॥
English Translation: Thereupon Arjuna, after having stretched his bow, called Gandiva, as if dancing upon the car, spread showers of arrows all over the firmament and the different points of the horizon, as well as all the subsidiary points of the compass.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ज्ञानेन हि यदा जन्तुरज्ञानप्रभवं तमः। व्यपोहति तदा ब्रह्म प्रकाशति सनातनम्॥
English Translation: After this, he (the son of Pandu, Arjuna) smote down numerous cars, that resembled the celestial balloons and that were furnished with all their equipments and also that were adorned with the weapons and standards, along with the charioteers themselves, by means of diverse kinds of arrows even as the great tempest disperses the congregated masses of clouds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अयत्नसाध्यं मुनयो वदन्ति ये चापि मुक्तास्त उपासितव्याः। त्वया च लोकेन च सामरेण तस्मान्नमस्यामि महर्षिसङ्घान्॥
English Translation: He then led, to the abode of Death by means of his numerous arrows, large numbers of elephants, along with their riders, that were equip with the most beautiful flags, weapons and standards, as also numerous horsemen and horses and many foot-soldiers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अस्मिन्नर्थे पुरा गीतं शृणुष्वैकमना नृप। यथा दैत्येन वृत्रेण भ्रष्टैश्वर्येण चेष्टितम्॥
English Translation: Thereupon Duryodhana, unattended by any body else, rushed against that most powerful car-warrior, who was like the very Death himself and who was filled with great wrath and who, again, was most invincible in battle, smiting him with his numerous straight arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निर्जितेनासहायेन हृतराज्येन भारत। अशोचता शत्रुमध्ये बुद्धिमास्थाय केवलाम्॥
English Translation: Arjuna, on the other hand, after having destroyed his (antagonist's) bow, charioteer, horses and the standard by means of seven sharp shafts, severed his (foe's) umbrella by means of another winged arrow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भ्रष्टैश्वर्यं पुरा वृत्रमुशना वाक्यमब्रवीत्। काचित् पराजितस्याद्य न व्यथा तेऽस्ति दानव।१५।।
English Translation: Then he (Arjuna), finding an opening in his antagonist, shot the foremost of his arrows, that was powerful enough to take away the very life itself (of the person struck with it), at Duryodhana. This the son of Drona severed into seven fragments.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वृत्र उवाच सत्येन तपसा चैव विदित्वासंशयं ह्यहम्। न शोचामि न हृष्यामि भूतानामागतिं गतिम्॥
English Translation: Thereupon the son of Pandu, having first cut-off the bow of the son of Drona and slaughtered his horses, that were the best of their species, by means of his arrows, again, shattered that formidable bow belonging to Kripa.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कालसंचोदिता जीवा मज्जन्ति नरकेऽवशाः। परितुष्टानि सर्वाणि दिव्यान्याहुर्मनीषिणः॥
English Translation: Then he (the son of Pandu), having severed into pieces the bow, owned by the son of Hridika, cut-off his standard and slaughtered his horses. Again, he, cutting off the bow of Dushasana, rushed against the son of Radha,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क्षपयित्वा तु तं कालं गणितं कालचोदिताः। सावशेषेण कालेन सम्भवन्ति पुनः पुनः॥
English Translation: Thereupon Karna, having abandoned Satyaki and penetrated Arjuna with three sharp shafts most activity, pierced Krishna with twenty other arrows; and again, penetrated the son of Pritha often and often.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तिर्यग्योनिसहस्राणि गत्वा नरकमेव च। निर्गच्छन्त्यवशा जीवाः कामबन्धनबन्धनाः॥
English Translation: Karna, resembling Indra himself, when he is greatly filled with wrath, felt no fatigue while he was shooting large numbers of arrows in the field of battle, slaughtering the antagonists.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं संसरमाणानि जीवान्यहमदृष्टवान्। यथा कर्म तथ लाभ इति शास्त्रनिदर्शनम्॥
English Translation: Thereupon Satyaki, having advanced to him, pierced Karna with ninety-nine sharpheaded and dreadful arrows and again, struck him with one hundred others.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तिर्यग् गच्छन्ति नरकं मानुष्यं दैवमेव च। सुखदुःखे प्रिये द्वेष्ये चरित्वा पूर्वमेव ह॥ कृतान्तविधिसंयुक्तः सर्वो लोकः प्रपद्यते। गतं गच्छन्ति चाध्वानं सर्वभूतानि सर्वदा॥ कालसंख्यानसंख्यातं सृष्टिस्थितिपरायणम्। तं भाषमाणं भगवानुशना प्रत्यभाषत। धीमान् दुष्टप्रलापांस्त्वं तात कस्मात् प्रभाषसे॥
English Translation: Afterwards all the best heroes among the Parthas continued to oppress Karna greatly. Thus Yudhamanyu, Shikhandin, the sons of Draupadi, as well as all the Prabhadrakas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वृत्र उवाच प्रत्यक्षमेतद् भवतस्तथान्येषां मनीषिणाम्। मया यज्जयलुब्धेन पुरा तप्तं महत् तपः॥
English Translation: And also Uttamanjas and Yuyutsu along with the twin brothers and the several divisions of the Chedis, the Karushas, the Matsyas and the Kaikeyas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गन्धानादाय भूतानां रसांश्च विविधानपि। अवर्धं त्रीन् समाक्रम्य लोकान् वै स्वेन तेजसा॥
English Translation: And Chekitana, who was possessed of immense prowess and the king of righteousness (Yudhishthira), observing the most excellent vows, all these heroes, perfectly aggrandised them by their cars, horses and elephants, as well as by their foot-soldiers, possessing fierce strength.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ज्वालामालापरिक्षिप्तो वैहायसचरस्तथा। अजेयः सर्वभूतानामासं नित्यमपेतभीः॥
English Translation: They all, having surrounded Karna on all sides, poured forth showers of numerous kinds of arrows upon him; and they, then having addressed him in a very harsh language, all deterinined to bring about the fall of Karna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ऐश्वर्यं तपसा प्राप्तं भ्रष्टं तच्च स्वकर्मभिः। धृतिमास्थाय भगवन् न शोचामि ततस्त्वहम्॥
English Translation: Then Karna, having severed into several fragment that shower of weapons by means of his sharp-headed arrows, cast away his foes with the help of his prowess in the use of weapon even as the wind uproots the tree that stands in its way.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युयुत्सुना महेन्द्रेण पुंसा सार्धं महात्मना। ततो मे भगवान् दृष्टो हरिर्नारायणः प्रभुः॥ वैकुण्ठः पुरुषोऽनन्तः शुक्लो विष्णुः सनातनः। मुञ्जकेशो हरिश्मश्रुः सर्वभूतपितामहः॥
English Translation: Karna, who was highly enraged, was found to slaughter large numbers of car-warriors, elephants along with their riders, horses with men riding upon them, as well as throngs of foot-soldiers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नूनं तु तस्य तपसः सावशेषमिहास्ति वै। यदहं प्रष्टुमिच्छामि भगवन् कर्मणः फलम्॥
English Translation: Then the entire army of the Pandavas, being thus slain by the prowess of those weapons belonging to Karna and being deprived of wcapons and also having had their limbs torn and shattered, almost fled away from the field of battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ऐश्वर्यं वै महद् ब्रह्म वर्णे कस्मिन् प्रतिष्ठितम्। निवर्तते चापि पुनः कथमैश्वर्यमुत्तमम्॥
English Translation: Thereupon Arjuna, smiling for a time and smiting down in return the weapons of Karna by means of the weapons of his own, shrouded the different points of the horizon, the entire firmament and the earth will the showers of arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कस्माद् भूतानि जीवन्ति प्रवर्तन्ते तथा पुनः। किंवा फलं परं प्राप्य जीवस्तिष्ठति शाश्वतः॥
English Translation: Some of the arrows, shot by Arjuna, dropped down upon the earth like the maces; and some, like the spiked clubs; and other fell like the Shataghnis; whereas several other shafts fell down upon the ground like the most dreadful thunderbolt.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: केन वा कर्मणा शक्यमथ ज्ञानेन केन वा। तदवाप्तुं फलं विप्र तन्मे व्याख्यातुमर्हसि॥
English Translation: That force, belonging to the Kauravas, that consisted of numerous foot-soldiers, horses, cars and elephants and that were being slaughtered with the above weapons, that seemed to shut up the eyes, roved about (in the field of battle) ceaselessly and roared most loudly.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इतीदमुक्तः स मुनिस्तदानीं प्रत्याह यत्तच्छृणु राजसिंह। मनन्यचित्तः सह सोदरीयैः॥
English Translation: Thereupon the battle became most dreadful, as numerous horses, men and elephants were continually slaughtered. Then, again, a large number of them, highly afflicted with the arrows and struck with terror, fled away from the field of battle,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इतीदमुक्तः स मुनिस्तदानीं प्रत्याह यत्तच्छृणु राजसिंह। मनन्यचित्तः सह सोदरीयैः॥
English Translation: Thus whilst the battle raged most fearfully amongst your troops, who most were enthusiastic with the desire of victory, the Sun, approaching the setting mountain, entered into it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच
English Translation: O great monarch, we could not behold anything in the field, either favourable or unfavourable, owing to the thick darkness and especially on account of the dust,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हते सुदक्षिणे राजन् वीरे चैव श्रुतायुधे। जवेनाभ्यद्रवन् पार्थं कुपिताः सैनिकास्तव॥
English Translation: O descendant of the Bharata race, then the most powerful bowman (belonging to the Kuru army), being afraid of a battle that would take place in the night, made retreat from the field of battle, accompanied by all their combatants.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभीषाहाः शूरसेनाः शिबयोऽथ वसातयः। अभ्यवर्षेस्ततो राजशरवर्षेर्धनंजयम्॥
English Translation: Thereupon, O monarch, at the fall of night when the Kaurava divisions had all field away (from the field), the sons of Pritha, highly gratified to attain the victory, retired to their own cainps.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषां षष्टिशतानन्यान् प्रामथ्नात् पाण्डवः शरैः। ते स्म भीताः पलायन्ते व्याघ्रात् क्षुद्रमृगा इव॥
English Translation: And they (the Pandava troops) continued to mock at the antagonists by raising various sorts of sounds with all their musical instruments and also by sending froth leonine-roars and uproars; and moreover, they praised both Achyuta and Arjuna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते निवृत्ताः पुनः पार्थं सर्वतः पर्यवारयन्। रणे सपनान् निघ्नन्तं जिगीषन्तं परान् युधि॥
English Translation: Thus when that force of the Kauravas was routed by those heroic warriors, all the troops, as well as the lords of men, began to utter benedictions upon the Pandavas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषामापततां तूर्णं गाण्डीवप्रेषितैः शरैः। शिरांसि पातयामास बाहूंश्चापि धनंजयः॥
English Translation: Thereupon, when the hostile army had made their retreat from the field, the Pandava warriors as well as the lords of men, became highly gratified and having retired to their camps, passed the night most cheerfully.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शिरोभिः पातितैस्तत्र भूमिरासीनिरन्तरा। अभ्रच्छायेव चैवासीत् ध्वाक्षगृघ्रबलैयुधि॥
English Translation: Thereafter large numbers of Rakshasas and Pisachas, as well as numerous other beasts, came to that dreadful field of battle, the looked like the sporting ground of Rudra himself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषु तूत्साद्यमानेषु क्रोधामर्षसमन्वितौ। श्रुतायुश्चाच्युतायुश्च धनंजयमयुध्यताम्॥
English Translation: Bhishma said Again, laughing at Vali who was sighing like a snake, Shakra addressed him for saying something more painful than what he had said before.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बलिनो स्पर्धिनौ वीरो कुलजौ बाहुशालिनौ। तावेनं शरवर्षाणि सव्यदक्षिणमस्यताम्॥
English Translation: Shakra said Formerly, attended by a train consisting of thousands of vehicles and kinsmen, you used to march, burning all the worlds with your splendour and disregarding us all.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वरायुक्तौ महाराज प्रार्थयानौ महद् यशः। अर्जुनस्य वधप्रेप्सू पुत्रार्थ तव धन्विनौ॥
English Translation: You are now, however, deserted by both kinsmen and friends. Beholding this miserable condition of yours, do you or do you not indulge in grief?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तावर्जुनं सहस्रेण पत्रिणां नतपर्वणाम् । पूरयामासतुः क्रुद्धौ तटागं जलदौ यथा॥
English Translation: Formerly all the worlds were under your sway and great was your joy. I ask, do you or you not grieve now, for this loss of your splendour?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रुतायुश्च ततः क्रुद्धस्तोमरेण धनंजयम्। आजघान रथश्रेष्ठः पीतेन निशितेन च॥
English Translation: Vali said Regarding all this as transitory,-due, indeed, to the course of time,-I do not, O Shakra, grieve. These things have an end.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सोऽतिविद्धो बलवता शत्रुणा शत्रुकर्शनः। जगाम परमं मोहं मोहयन् केशवं रणे॥
English Translation: These bodies of creatures, O king of the celestials, are all transitory. Therefore, 0 Shakra, I do not grieve. Nor is this form due to any fault of mine.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतस्मिन्नेव काले तु सोऽच्युतायुर्महारथः। शूलेन भृशतीक्ष्णेन ताडयामास पाण्डवम्॥
English Translation: The animating principle and the body come into existence simultaneously for their own nature. They grow together and meet with destruction together.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क्षते क्षारं स हि ददौ पाण्डवस्य महात्मनः। पार्थोऽपि भृशंसंविद्धो ध्वजयष्टिं समाश्रितः॥
English Translation: Having obtained this form of birth I have not been enslaved by it for good. Since I know this, I have no cause for sorrow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः सर्वस्य सैन्यस्य तावकस्य विशाम्पते। सिंहनादो महानासीद्धतं मत्वा धनंजयम्॥
English Translation: As the final place of all rivers is the ocean, so the end of all embodied creatures is death. Those persons that know this well are never stupefied, O holder of the thunder-bolt. 10. They, however, who, overwhelmed with Darkness and loss of judgement, do not know this, they whose understanding is lost, sink under the load of misfortune.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृष्णश्च भृशसंतप्तो दृष्ट्वा पार्थं विचेतनम्। आश्वासयत् सुहृद्याभिर्वाग्भिस्तत्र धनंजयम्॥
English Translation: A person wins a keen understanding, succeeds in dissipating all his sins. A sinless person acquires the quality of Goodness, and having acquired it becomes cheerful.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्तौ रथिनां श्रेष्ठौ लब्धलक्ष्यौ धनंजयम्। वासुदेवं च वार्ष्णेयं शरवर्षेः समन्ततः॥ सचक्रकूबररथं साश्वध्वजपताकिनम्। अदृश्यं चक्रतुर्युद्धे तदद्भुतमिवाभवत्॥
English Translation: They, however, that deviate from the quality of Goodness, and go through repeated re-births, are obliged to indulge in sorrow and grief, led on by desire and the objects of the senises,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रत्याश्वस्तस्तु बीभत्सुः शनकैरिव भारत। प्रेतराजपुरं प्राप्य पुनः प्रत्यागतो यथा॥१९
English Translation: I neither dislike nor like success or defeat, regarding the attainment of all objects of desire, life, or death, the fruits of action that are represented by pleasure or pain.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संछन्नं शरजालेन रथं दृष्ट्वा सकेशवम्। शत्रु चाभिमुखौ दृष्ट्वा दीप्यमानाविवानलौ॥
English Translation: When one kills another, he kills only that other's body. That man who thinks that it is he who kills another, is himself killed. Indeed, both of then do not know the truth, viz., he who kills and he who is killed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रादुश्चक्रे ततः पार्थः शाक्रमस्त्रं महारथः। तस्मादासन् सहस्राणि शराणां नतपर्वणाम्॥
English Translation: O Maghavat, that person, who having killed or defeated any one brags of his manliness, should know that he is not the actor, but that the act has been performed by another who is the real agent.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते जघ्नुस्तौ महेष्वासौ ताभ्यां मुक्तांश्च सायकान्। विचेरुराकाशगताः पार्थबाणविदारिताः॥
English Translation: When it is asked that who is it that brings about the creation and destruction of things in the world, it is generally thought that some person has caused it. Know, however, that the person who is so known has a creator.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रतिहत्य शरांस्तूर्णं शरवेगेन पाण्डवः। प्रतस्थे तत्र तत्रैव योधयन् वै महारथान्॥
English Translation: Earth, light or heat, ether, water, and wind form the fifth-from these do all creatures originate. (When I know this) what sorrow can I feel?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तौ च फाल्गुनबाणौधैर्विबाहुशिरसौ कृतौ। वसुधामन्वपद्येतां वातनुन्नाविव दुभौ॥
English Translation: One who is endued with great learning, one who is not much learned, one who is strong, one who is destitute of strength, one who is beautiful, and one who is very ugly, one who is lucky, and one who is not blessed by fortune, are all carried away by Time, which is too deep to be measured by its own energy. When I know that I have been defeated by Time what sorrow can I feel.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रुतायुषश्च निधनं वधश्चैवाच्युतायुषः। लोकविस्मापनमभूत् समुद्रस्येव शोषणम्॥
English Translation: One that burns anything burns a thing that has been already burnt. One who kills, only kills, a victim already killed. One who is destroyed, has been before destroyed. A thing that is acquired by a person is what is already arrived and intended for his acquirement.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततयोः पदानुगान् हत्वा पुनः पञ्चाशतं रथान्। प्रत्यगाद् भारती सेनां निघ्नन् पार्थो वरान् वरान्॥
English Translation: This Time is like an ocean. There is no island in it. Its other shore is beyond reach. Its boundary cannot be seen. Thinking even deeply, I do not see the end of this continuous steam that is the great ordainer of all things and that is, forsooth celestial.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रुतायुषं च निहतं प्रेक्ष्य चैवाच्युतायुषम्। नियतायुश्च संक्रुद्धो दीर्घायुश्चैव भारत॥ पुत्रौ तयोर्नरश्रेष्ठौ कौन्तेयं प्रतिजग्मतुः। किरन्तोविविधान् बाणान् पितृव्यसनकर्शितौ॥
English Translation: If I did not know that it is Time which destroys all creatures, then, perhaps, I would have experienced the emotions of joy, pride and anger, O husband of Shachi.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तावर्जुनो मुहूर्तेन शरैः संनतपर्वभिः। प्रेषयत् परमकुद्धो यमस्य सदनं प्रति॥
English Translation: Have you come here to condemn me, having come to know that I am now assuming the form of an ass that lives upon chaff and that is now passing his days in a lonely spot remote from the dwellings of men.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: लोडयन्तमनीकानि द्विपं पद्मसरो यथा। नाशक्नुवन् वारयितुं पार्थं क्षत्रियपुङ्गवाः॥
English Translation: If I wish, even now I can assume various dreadful forms, seeing any one of which you would immediately fly away from my presence.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अङ्गास्तु गजवारेण पाण्डवं पर्यवारयन्। क्रुद्धाः सहस्रशो राजशिक्षिता हस्तिसादिनः॥
English Translation: It is Time that gives every thing and again takes away everything. It is Time that ordains all things. Do not, O Shakra, brag of your manliness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुर्योधनसमादिष्टाः कुञ्जरैः पर्वतोपमैः। प्राच्याश्च दाक्षिणात्याश्च कलिङ्गप्रमुखा नृपाः॥
English Translation: Formerly, O Purandara, whenever, I used to be angry everything used to become agitated. I know, however, O Shakra, that eternal attributes of all things in the world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषामापततां शीघ्रं गाण्डीवप्रेषितैः शरैः। निचकर्त शिरांस्युग्रो बाहूनपि सुभूषणान्॥
English Translation: Do you also know the truth. Do not allow yourself to be filled with wonder. Prosperity and its origin are not under one's control.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तैः शिरोभिर्मही कीर्णा बाहुभिश्च सहाङ्गदैः। वभौ कनकपाषाणा भुजगैरिव संवृतां॥
English Translation: Your mind is like that of a child. It is the same as it was before. Open your eyes, O Maghavat and acquire an understanding which is sure and true.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बाहवोविशिखैश्छिन्नाः शिरांस्युन्मथितानि च। पतमानान्यदृश्यन्त दुमेभ्य इव पक्षिणः॥
English Translation: In days gone by, that gods, men, the Pitris, the Gandharvas, the Nagas, and the Rakshasas, were all under my control. You know this, O Vasava.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शरैः सहस्रशो विद्धा द्विपाः प्रसृतशोणिताः। अदृश्यन्ताद्रयः काले गौरिकाम्बुस्रवा इव॥
English Translation: Having their understandings overcome by ignorance, all creatures used to flatter me, saying,-Salutations to that cardinal point where Virochana's son Vali may now be living, O husband of Sachi, I do not at all grieve when I think of that honour. I am not sorry for this fall of mine. My understanding is very strong here, viz., that I will abide by the sway of the Ordainer.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निहताः शेरते स्मान्ये बीभत्सोर्निशितैः शरैः। गजपृष्ठगता म्लेच्छा नानाविकृतदर्शनाः॥
English Translation: It is seen that some one of nobly born highly beautiful and powerful, lives in misery, with all his counsellors and friends. This happens because it has been so ordained.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नानावेषधरा राजन् नानाशस्त्रौघसंवृताः। रुधिरेणानुलिप्ताङ्गा भान्ति चित्रैः शरैर्हताः॥
English Translation: Likewise, some one born in an ignoble race, devoid of knowledge, and with even a stain on his birth, is seen, O Shakra, to live happily with all his counsellors and friends. This also happens because it has been so oridained.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शोणितं निर्वमन्ति स्म द्विपाः पार्थशराहताः। सहस्रशश्छिन्नगात्राः सारोहाः सपदानुगाः॥
English Translation: An auspicious and beautiful woman, O Shakra, is seen to pass her life miserably. Likewise, ugly woman with every inauspicious mark is seen to live in great happiness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चुक्रुशुश्च निपेतुश्च बभ्रमुश्चापरे दिशः। भृशं त्रस्ताश्व बहवः स्वानेव प्रमृदुर्गजाः॥
English Translation: That we have now become so is not owing to any act of ours, O Shakra. That you are now so is not owing, O holder of the thunderbolt, to any act of yours?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सान्तरायुधिनश्चैव द्विपास्तीक्ष्णविषोपमाः। विदन्त्यसुरमायां ये सुघोरा घोरचक्षुषः॥ यवनाः पारदाश्चैव शकाश्च सह बाह्निकैः। काकवर्णा दुराचाराः स्त्रीलोकाः कलहप्रियाः॥ द्राविडास्तत्र युध्यन्ते मत्तमातङ्गविक्रमाः। गोयोनिप्रभवाम्लेच्छा: कालकल्पाः प्रहारिणः॥
English Translation: You have not done anything, O you of a hundred sacrifices, for which you are now an enjoying this prosperity. Nor have I done anything for which I have now been shorn of prosperity. Prosperity and adversity come in succession.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दातिसारा दरदाः पुण्ड्राश्चैव सहस्रशः। तेन शक्याः स्म संख्यातुं व्रात्याः शतसहस्रशः॥
English Translation: I now see you blazing with splendour, endued with prosperity, possessed of beauty, placed at the head of all the gods, and thus roaring at me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभ्यवर्षन्त ते सर्वे पाण्डवं निशितैः शरैः। अवाकिरंश्च के म्लेच्छा नानायुद्धविशारदाः॥
English Translation: This would never be but for the Time standing near after having attacked me. Indeed, if Time had not attacked me I would have today slain you with only a blow of my fists albeit you are armed with the thunder.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषामपि ससर्जाशु शरवृष्टिं धनंजयः। सृष्टिस्तथाविधा ह्यासीच्छलभानामिवायतिः॥
English Translation: This, however, is not the time for displaying my prowess. On the other hand, the time that has come when I should conduct myself with peace and tranquillity. It is Time which establishes all things. Time acts upon all things and brings about their final consummation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभ्रच्छायामिव शरैः सैन्ये कृत्वा धनंजयः। मुण्डार्धमुण्डाञ्जटिलानशुचीञ्जटिलाननान्॥ म्लेच्छानशातयत् सर्वान् समेतानस्त्रतेजसा।
English Translation: I was the adored king of the Danavas. Consuming all with my energy, I used to roar in strength and pride. When Time has attacked even myself, who is there whom he will not attack.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शरैश्च शतशो विद्धास्ते संघा गिरिचारिणः। प्राद्रवन्त रणे भीता गिरिगह्वरवासिनः॥
English Translation: Formerly, O king of the gods, singly I bore the energy of all the twelve illustrious Adityas with yourself amongst them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गजाश्वसादिम्लेच्छानां पतितानां शितैः शरैः। बलाः कंका वृका भूमावपिबन् रुधिरं मुदा॥
English Translation: It was I that used to bear up water and then to shower it as rain. O Vasava! It was I who used to give both light and heat to the three worlds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पत्त्यश्वरथनागैश्च प्रच्छन्नकृतसंक्रमाम्। शरवर्षप्लवां घोरां केशशैवलशाद्वलाम्। प्रावर्तयन्नदीमुग्रां शोणितौघतरङ्गिणीम्॥ छिन्नाङ्गुलीक्षुद्रमत्स्यां युगान्ते कालसंनिभाम्। प्राकरोद् गजसम्बाधां नदीमुत्तरशोणिताम्॥ देहेभ्यो राजपुत्राणां नागाश्वरथसादिनाम्।
English Translation: It was I who used to protect and it was I that used to destroy. It was I who gave and it was I who took. It was I who used to bind and it was I who used to unbind. In all the worlds I was the one powerful master.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथास्थलं च निम्नं च न स्याद् वर्षति वासवे॥ तथासीत् पृथिवी सर्वा शोणितेन परिप्लुता।
English Translation: That sovereign control which I had, O king of the gods, is now gone. I am now attacked by the foreces of Time. Those things, therefore, are no longer seen to shine in me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: षट्सहस्रान् हयान् वीरन् पुनर्दशशतान् वरान्॥ प्राहिणोन्मृत्युलोकाय क्षत्रियान् क्षत्रियर्षभः।
English Translation: I am not the actor. You are not the actor. None else, O husband of Sachi, is the doer. It is Time, O Shakra, that protects or destroys all things.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शरैः सहस्रशोविद्धा विधिवत्कल्पिता द्विपाः॥ शेरते भूमिमासाद्य शैला वज्रहता इव। सवाजिरथमातङ्गान् निजन् व्यचरदर्जुनः॥ प्रभिन्न इव मातङ्गो मृद्गन् नलवनं यथा।
English Translation: Persons well-read in the Vedas say that me is Brahma. The fortnights and months are his body. That body is clothed with days and nights as its dresses. The seasons are his senses. The year is his mouth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भूरिदुमलतागुल्मं शुष्केन्धनतृणोलपम्॥ निर्दहेदनलोऽरण्यं यथा वायुसमीरितः। सेनारण्यं तव तथा कृष्णानिलसमीरितः॥ शरार्चिरदहत् क्रुद्धः पाण्डवाग्निर्धनंजयः।
English Translation: Some people, on account of their superior intelligence, say that the entire universe should be conceived as Brahma. The Vedas, however, teach, that the five sacs that cover the Soul should be known as Brahma.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शून्यान् कुर्वन रथापस्थान् मानवै: संस्तरन् महीम्॥५८ प्रानृत्यदिव सम्बाधे चापहस्तो धनंजयः।
English Translation: Brahma is deep and inaccessible like a deep ocean. It is said that it has neither beginning nor end, and that it is both indestructible and destructible.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वज्रकल्पैः शरैर्भूमिं कुर्वन्नुत्तरशोणिताम्॥ प्राविशद् भारती सेनां संकुद्धो वै धनंजयः। तं श्रुतायुस्तथाम्बष्ठो व्रजमानं न्यवारयत्॥
English Translation: Though it is by nature without attributes yet it enters all existent objects and as such is clothed with attributes. Those persons who know truth consider Brahma as eternal.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्यार्जुनः शरैस्तीक्ष्णैः कङ्कपत्रपरिच्छदैः। न्यपातयद्धयाशीघ्रं यतमानस्य मारिष॥
English Translation: Through the force of Ignorance, Brahma makes the attribute of materiality to invest the Chit or Soul which is immaterial spirit. Materiality, however, is not the true attribute of the Soul.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धनुश्चास्यापरैश्छित्त्वा शरैः पार्थो विचक्रमे। अम्बष्ठस्तु गदां गृह्य कोपपर्याकुलेक्षणः॥
English Translation: Brahma in the form of Time is the refuge of all creatures. Where can you go transcending that Time? Time or Brahma, indeed, cannot be shunned by running nor by standing still.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आससाद रणे पार्थे केशवं च महारथम्। ततः सम्प्रहरन् वीरो गदामुद्यम्य भारत॥
English Translation: All the five senses cannot perceive Brahma. Some have said that Brahma is Fire ; some that he is Prajapati, some that he is the Seasons; some that he is the Month; some that he is the Fortnight; some that he is the Days; some that he is the Hours; some that he is the Morning; some that he is the Noon; some that he is the Evening, and some that he is the Moment. Thus various people speak variously of him, who is one. Know that he is Eternity, under whose control exist all things.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रथमावार्य गदया केशवं समताडयत्। गदया ताडितं दृष्ट्वा केशवं परवीरहा॥
English Translation: Many thousands of Indras have gone away, O Vasava, cach of whom was endued with great strength and prowess. Similarly you also, O lord of Shachi, shall have to pass away.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्जुनोऽभृशं क्रुद्धः सोऽम्बष्ठं प्रति भारत। तत शरैर्हेमपुकैः सगदं रथिनां वरम्॥ छादयामास समरे मेघः सूर्यमिवोदितम्। अथापरैः शरैश्चापि गदां तस्य महात्मनः॥ अचूर्णयत् तदा पार्थस्तदद्भुतमिवाभवत्। अथ तां पतितां दृष्ट्वा गृह्यान्यां च महागदाम्॥
English Translation: The omnipotent Time will destroy you too, O Shakra, who are endued with swelling might and that are the chief of the deities, when your hour comes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्जुनं वासुदेवं च पुनः पुनरताडयत्। तस्यार्जुनः क्षुरप्राभ्यां सगदावुद्यतौ भुजौ॥ चिच्छेदेन्द्रध्वजाकारौ शिरश्चान्येन पत्रिणा। स पपात हतो राजन् वसुधामनुनादयन्।॥
English Translation: Time carries away all things. Therefore, O Indra, do not brag! Time cannot be quieted by either you or me or by those gone before us.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इन्द्रध्वज इवोत्सृष्टो यन्त्रनिर्मुक्तबन्धनः। स्थानीकावगाढच वारणाश्वशतैर्वृतः। अदृश्यत तदा पार्थो धनैः सूर्य इवावृतः॥
English Translation: This kingly prosperity which you have acquired and which you consider incomparable, had formerly been possessed by me. It is unsubstantial and unreal. She does not live long in one place.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच अर्जुनस्य वचः श्रुत्वा नकुलो वाक्यमब्रवीत्। राजानमभिसम्प्रेक्ष्य सर्वधर्मभृतां वरम्॥ अनुरुथ्य महाप्राज्ञो भ्रातुश्चित्तमरिन्दम। व्यूढोरस्को महाबाहुस्ताम्रास्यो मितभाषिता॥
English Translation: Indeed, she had lived in thousands of Indras before you, all of whom, again, were, very much superior to you! Unstable as she is, leaving me she has now approached you, O king of the gods.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नकुल उवाच विशाखयूपे देवानां सर्वेषामग्नयश्चिताः। तस्माद् विद्धि महाराज देवाः कर्मफले स्थिताः॥
English Translation: Do not, O Shakra, brag again! You should become tranquil! Knowing you to be full of vanity, she will very soon leave you.'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनास्तिकानां भूतानां प्राणदाः पितरश्च ये। तेऽपि कर्मैव कुर्वन्ति विधि सम्प्रेक्ष्य पार्थिव॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said After the heroic Shalya, that flower of the court, had been killed your ariny were dispersed like a huge tree broken by the force of the storm.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वेदवादापविद्धांस्तु तान् विद्धि भृशनास्तिकान्। न हि वेदोक्तमुत्सृज्य विप्रः सर्वेषु कर्मसु॥ देवयानेन नाकस्य पृष्ठमाप्नोति भारत। अत्याश्रमानयं सर्वानित्याहुर्वेदनिश्चयाः॥
English Translation: Seeing the army routed, the great carwarrior, Kritavarına, opposed the hostile force in that battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणाः श्रुतिसम्पन्नास्तान् निबोध नराधिप। वित्तानि धर्मलब्धानि ऋतुमुख्येष्ववासृजन्॥ कृतात्मा स महाराज स वै त्यागी स्मृतो नरः॥
English Translation: Seeing the Satwata hero, O king, standing in battle like a hill though struck with arrows (by the foe), the Kuru heroes, who had fled away, rallied and came back.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनवेक्ष्य सुखादानं तथैवोर्ध्वं प्रतिष्ठितः। आत्मत्यागी महाराज स त्यागी तामसो मतः॥
English Translation: Then, O king, an encounter which took place between the Pandavas and the Kurus who were determined upon meeting with death.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनिकेतः परिपतन् वृक्षमूलाश्रयो मुनिः। अपाचकः सदा योगी स त्यागी पार्थ भिक्षुकः॥
English Translation: Wonderful was that fierce encounter which took place between the Satwata hero and his foes, since alone hc opposed the invincible ariny of the Pandavas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क्रोधहर्षावनादृत्य पैशुन्यं च विशेषतः। विप्रो वेदानधीते यः स त्यागी पार्थ उच्यते॥
English Translation: Seeing this most difficult feat friends, filled with delight, set up leonine shouts that sceined to reach the very heavens.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आश्रमांस्तुलया सर्वान् धृतानाहुर्मनीषिणः। एकतश्च त्रयो राजन् गृहस्थाश्रम एकतः॥
English Translation: At those sounds and Panchalas, O foremost of Bharata's race, were filled with fear. Then Satyaki, the grandson of Shini, came there.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: समीक्ष्य तुलया पार्थ कामं स्वर्गं च भारत। अयं पन्था महर्षीणामियं लोकविदां गतिः॥
English Translation: Approaching the powerful king Kshemakirti, Satyaki killed him with seven keen arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इति यः कुरुते भावं स त्यागी भरतर्षभ। न य: परित्यज्य गृहान् वनमेति विमूढवत्॥
English Translation: Then the intelligent son of Hridika, rushed quickly against the best of Shinis, that mightyarmed warrior, as the latter came discharging his whetted shafts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदा कामान् समीक्षेत धर्मवैतंसिको नरः। अथैनं मृत्युपाशेन कण्ठे बध्नाति मृत्युराट्॥
English Translation: Those two bowmen, those two foremost of car-warriors roared like lions and met each other, both being armed with best of weapons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभिमानकृतं कर्म नैतत् फलवदुच्यते। त्यागयुक्तं महाराज सर्वमेव महाफलम्॥
English Translation: The Pandavas, the Panchalas and the other warriors, witnessed that terrible encounter between the two heroes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शमो दमस्तथा धैर्यं सत्यं शौचमथार्जवम्। यज्ञो धृतिश्च धर्मश्च नित्यमा! विधिः स्मृतः॥
English Translation: Those two Vrishni and Andhaka heroes, like two elephants filled with delight, struck each other with long arrows and arrows with calf-toothed heads.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पितृदेवातिथिकृते समारम्भोऽत्र शस्यते। अत्रैव हि महाराज त्रिवर्गः केवलं फलम्॥
English Translation: Moving about in various ways the son of Hridika and that foremost of Shini's race soon covered each other with showers of arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतस्मिन् वर्तमानस्य विधावप्रतिषेधिते। त्यागिनः प्रसृतस्येह नोच्छित्तिर्विद्यते क्वचित्॥
English Translation: The arrows discharged forcibly from the bows of the two Vrishni heroes were seen by us in the sky to resemble fights of quickcoursing insects.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: असृजद्धि प्रजा राजन् प्रजापतिरकल्मषः। मां यक्ष्यन्तीति धर्मात्मा यज्ञैर्विविधदक्षिणैः॥
English Translation: Approaching the powerful Satyaki of true prowess, the son of Hridika struck the four horses of the former with four keen arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वीस्थश्चैव वृक्षांश्च यज्ञार्थं वै तथौषधीः। पशृंश्चैव तथा मेध्यान् यज्ञार्थानि हवींषि च॥
English Translation: Enraged at this like an elephant struck with a lance, the long-armed Satyaki struck Kritavarman with eight best arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गृहस्थाश्रमिणस्तच्च यज्ञकर्म विरोधकम्। तस्माद् गार्हस्थ्यमेवेह दुष्करं दुर्लभं तथा॥
English Translation: Then Kritavarman struck Satyaki with three arrows whetted on stone and shot off his bow drawn to its fullest stretch and then cut of his bow with another arrow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत् सम्प्राप्य गृहस्था ये पशुधान्यधनान्विताः। न यजन्ते महाराज शाश्वतं तेषु किल्बिषम्॥
English Translation: Casting off his broken bow, that Shini hero quickly took up another with an arrow set on it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्वाध्याययज्ञा ऋषयो ज्ञानयज्ञास्तथा परे। अथापरे महायज्ञान् मनस्येव वितन्वते॥
English Translation: Having taken up that best of bows and stringed it, that foremost of all bowmen, that warrior of great energy, intelligence and strength, unable to bear the cutting of his bow by Kritavarman, quickly and furiously rushed against the latter.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं मनःसमाधानं मार्गमातिष्ठतो नृप। द्विजातेर्ब्रह्मभूतस्य स्पृहयन्ति दिवौकसः॥
English Translation: With ten keen arrows that Shini chief then struck the driver, the horses and the standard of Kritavarman.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स रत्नानि विचित्राणि संहृतानि ततस्ततः। मखेष्वनभिसंत्यज्य नास्तिक्यमभिजल्पसि॥
English Translation: At this, O king, the great bowinan and carwarrior Kritavarman, beholding his golddecked car made driverless and horseless, was filled with rage. Taking up a pointed lance, he discharged it with all might at that best of Shini's race, desirous of killing him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कुटुम्बमास्थिते त्यागं न पश्यामि नराधिप। राजसूयाश्वमेधेषु सर्वमेधेषु वा पुनः॥
English Translation: Striking that lance with many keen arrows, Satyaki sundered it off into pieces and caused it to fall down. Stupefying Kritavarinan of Madhu's race with another broad-headed arrow he then struck Kritavarman on the chest.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ये चान्ये ऋतवस्तात ब्राह्मणैरभिपूजिताः। तैर्यजस्व महीपाल शक्रो देवपतिर्यथा॥
English Translation: Deprived of his horses and driver in that battle by Yuyudhana, skilled in weapons, Kritavarınan came down on the Earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राज्ञः प्रमाददोषेण दस्युभिः परिमुष्यताम्। अशरण्यः प्रजानां यः स राजा कलिरुच्यते॥
English Translation: The heroic Kritavarman, having been deprived of his car by Satyaki in that single combat, all the (Kaurava) soldiers were possessed by a great fear.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अश्वान् गाश्चैव दासीश्च करेणूश्च स्वलंकृताः। ग्रामाजनपदांश्चैव क्षेत्राणि च गृहाणि च॥ अप्रदाय द्विजातिभ्यो मात्सर्याविष्टचेतसः। वयं ते राजकलयो भविष्याम विशाम्पते॥
English Translation: A mighty fear overtook your sons, when Kritavarman was thus made steedless and driverless and carless.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अदातारो शरण्याश्च राजकिल्विषभागिनः। दोषाणामेव भोक्तारो न सुखानां कदाचन॥
English Translation: Beholding that chastiser of foes made steedless and driverless, Kripa, O king, rushed at that best of Shini's race, desirous of killing him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनिष्ट्वा च महायज्ञैरकृत्वा च पितृस्वधाम्। तीर्थेष्वनभिसम्लुत्य प्रव्रजिष्यसि चेत् प्रभो॥ छिन्नाभ्रमिव गन्तासि विलयं मारुतेरितम्। लोकयोरुभयोर्धष्टो ह्यन्तराले व्यवस्थितः॥
English Translation: Taking Kritavarman upon his car before all the bowmen, the mighty-armed Kripa took him away from the battlefield.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्तर्बहिश्च यत् किंचिन्मनोव्यासङ्गकारकम्। परित्यज्य भवेत् त्यागी न हित्वा प्रतितिष्ठति॥
English Translation: After Kritavarman had been made carless and the grandson of Shini had grown powerful on the field, the entire army of Duryodhana took to their heels.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतस्मिन् वर्तमानस्य विधावप्रतिषेधिते। ब्राह्मणस्य महाराज नोच्छित्तिर्विद्यते क्वचित्॥
English Translation: The enemy, however, did not see it for the Kuru army was then covered with a cloud of dust. All your warriors fled, O king, except king Duryodhana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निहत्य शत्रूस्तरसा समृद्धान् शक्रो यथा दैत्यबलानि संख्ये। कः पार्थ शोचेन्निरतः स्वधर्मे पूर्वैः स्मृते पार्थिव शिष्टजुष्टे॥
English Translation: Beholding his own army thus routed he quickly rushed and assailed the victorious enemy, alone opposing them all.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क्षात्रेण धर्मेण पराक्रमेण जित्वा महीं मन्त्रविद्ध्यः प्रदाय। नाकस्य पृष्ठेऽसि नरेन्द्र गन्ता न शोचितव्यं भवताद्य पार्थ॥
English Translation: Filled with rage, that invincible warrior assailed with keen arrows all the Pandus and Dhrishtadyumna the son of Prishata and Shikhandin and the son of Draupadi and the large numbers of the Panchalas and the Kaikeyas and the Somakas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच सा तु कन्या महाराज ब्राह्मणं संशितव्रतम्। तोषयामास शुद्धेन मनसा संशितव्रता॥
English Translation: With strong determination your powerful son stood in battle. even as blazing and mighty fire on the sacrificial platform purified with mantras, king Duryodhana moved in the field, in that battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रातरेष्याम्यथेत्युक्त्वा कदाचिद् द्विजसत्तमः। तत आयाति राजेन्द्र सायं रात्रावथो पुनः॥
English Translation: His enemies could not approach him then, like creatures unable to approach the Death. Then the son of Hridika came there, on another car.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं च सर्वासु वेलासु भक्ष्यभोज्यप्रतिश्रयैः। पूजयामास सा कन्या वर्धमानैस्तु सर्वदा॥
English Translation: Narada said O Srinjaya, we heard that Nabhaga's son Ambarisha, who, single-handed, fought a thousand times against thousand kings, was also carried away by Death.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्नादिसमुदाचाराः शय्यासनकृतस्तथा। दिवसे दिवसे तस्य वर्धते न तु हीयते॥
English Translation: He simultaneously attacked his enemies who desired to obtain victory over him, who were accomplished in fighting with weapons and who had assaulted him with fierce yells.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निर्भर्त्सनापवादैश्च ततैवाप्रियया गिरा। ब्राह्मणस्य पृथा राजन् न चकाराप्रियं तदा॥
English Translation: Subduing them with his prowess and by the strength of his weapons, he cut-off their umbrellas, weapons, standards and chariots and deprived them of their lives. Thus he relieved himself of all his anxieties.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यस्ते काले पुनश्चैति न चैति बहुशो द्विजः। सुदुर्लभमपि ह्यन्नं दीयतामिति सोऽब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: Then desirous of saving their lives, those defeated king, putting off their coats of mail implored the mercy of that compassionate monarch and sought his protection saying, “We surrender ourselves."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृतमेव च तत् सर्वं यथा तस्मै न्यवेदयत्। शिष्यवत् पुत्रवच्चैव स्वसृवच्च सुसंयता॥
English Translation: Thus having brought them under his control and having conquered this world, he celebrated a hundred desirable sacrifices, in accordance with the ordinances of the Shastras, O sinless one.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथोपजोषं राजेन्द्र द्विजातिप्रवरस्य सा। प्रीतिमुत्पादयामास कन्यारत्नमनिन्दिता।॥
English Translation: At those sacrifices of his, people partook of edibles possessed of all delicate qualities. Therefore most of the Brahmanas were greatly gratified and were most excellently worshipped.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्यास्तु शीलवृत्तेन तुतोष द्विजसत्तमः। अवधानेन भूयोऽस्याः परं यत्नमथाकरोत्॥
English Translation: Sweetmeat, Purikas, Pupas, Saskulis of excellent taste and large size, Karambhas, Prithumridikas and various kinds of wellprepared edibles, various sorts of Supas, Maireyas, Pupas, Ragakhandavas and diverse king of confectionery, well-dressed, delicate and savoury and clarified butter and honey and milk and water and tasteful curds and fruits and esculent roots-these things were there eaten by the regenerate castes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तां प्रभाते च सायं च पिता पप्रच्छ भारत। अपि तुष्यति ते पुत्रि ब्राह्मणः परिचर्यया॥
English Translation: And men who were addicted to drink wines, drank, in proper time, various kinds of intoxicating drinks, for the sake of the pleasures they produced and then sang and played upon their musical instruments.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं सा परममित्येव प्रत्युवाच यशस्विनी। तत: प्रीतिमवापायां कुन्तिभोजो महामनाः॥
English Translation: Some perfectly toxicated sang songs and were greatly delighted; and some reeled on the ground; some applauded the son of Nabhaga in panegyrics and some danced in thousands.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः संवत्सरे पूर्णे यदासौ जपतां वरः। नापश्यद् दुष्कृतं किंचित् पृथायाः सौहृदे रतः॥
English Translation: In those sacrifices, Ambarisha gave as gifts the kingdoms of hundreds and thousands of kings to the ten million priests engaged in his sacrifice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तः प्रीतमना भूत्वा स एनां ब्राह्मणोऽब्रवीत्। प्रीतोऽस्मि परमं भद्रे परिचारेण ते शुभे॥
English Translation: Having celebrated diverse sacrifices the king gave unto the Brahmanas as sacrificial presents numerous princes and kings whose coronal locks had been purified by the sacred bath, all furnished with golden armours, all having white umbrellas held over their heads, all mounted on golden chariots, vested in superb garments and having large retinues and all bearing their scepters and possessing their treasuries. 'None amongst the men of olden times did, nor those to come will do.'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वरान् वृणीष्व कल्याणि दुरापान् मानुषैरिह। यैस्त्वं सीमन्तिनी: सर्वा यशसाभिभविष्यसि॥
English Translation: What king Ambarisha, profuse in his sacrificial present's has done. Even thus did the mighty sages, gratified with him, applauded him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कुन्त्युवाच कृतानि मम सर्वाणि यस्या मे वेदवित्तम। त्वं प्रसन्नः पिता चैव कृतं विप्र वरैर्मम॥
English Translation: O Srinjaya, when even such a king who was superior in respect of the four cardinal virtues to you and consequently to your son, had to undergo death, you should not lament for your son who performed no sacrifices and made no sacrificial gifts, saying, 'O Shvaitya.'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मण उवाच यदि नेच्छसि मत्तस्त्वं वरं भद्रे शुचिस्मिते। इमं मन्त्रं गृहाण त्वमाह्वानाय दिवौकसाम्॥
English Translation: Sauti said : O ascetic Rishi, about this time the two sisters one day saw Uchaishrava approaching towards them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यं यं देवं त्वमेतेन मन्त्रेणावाहयिष्यसि। तेन तेन वशे भद्रे स्थातव्यं ते भविष्यति॥
English Translation: (It was the horse) who was worshipped by the celestials, who was the gem among all horses, who rose at the churning of the ocean for the Ambrosia,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अकामो वा सकामो वा स समेष्यति ते वशे। विबुधो मत्रसंशान्तो भवेद् भृत्य इवानतः॥
English Translation: Who was divine, graceful, ever-young, irresistible, vigorous, who was creator's masterpiece and who was blessed with all the auspicious marks.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच न शशाक द्वितीयं सा प्रत्याख्यातुमनिन्दिता। तं वै द्विजातिप्रवरं तदा शापभयानृप॥
English Translation: Why and where did the celestial churn the ocean for the Ambrosia, in which did rise, as you say, this best of steeds, so powerful and resplendent? Tell me this.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्तामनवद्याङ्गीं चाहयामास स द्विजः। मन्त्रग्राम तदा राजन्नथर्वशिरसि श्रुतम्॥
English Translation: Sauti said: There is a very great mountain, called Meru of blazing and effulgent appearance. The rays of the sun are scattered away when they fall on its golden summit.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं प्रदाय तु राजेन्द्र कुन्तिभोजमुवाच ह। उषितोऽस्मि सुखं राजन् कन्यया परितोषितः॥ तव गेहेषु विहितः सदा सुप्रतिपूजितः। साधयिष्यामहे तावदित्युक्त्वान्तरधीयत।२२।।
English Translation: Decked with gold and exceedingly beautiful, this mountain is frequented by the Devas and Gandharvas; it is immeasurable and unapproachable by men of many sins.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तु राजा द्विजं दृष्ट्वा तत्रैवान्तर्हितं तदा। बभूव विस्मयाविष्टः पृथां च समपूजयत्॥
English Translation: It is illuminated with many medicinal plants and fearful beasts of prey roam on its heights.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच ततः कर्ण पुरस्कृत्य त्वदीया युद्धदुर्मदाः। पुनरावृत्य संग्रामं चक्रुर्देवासुरोपमम्॥
English Translation: It is unapproachable even by mind; it is graced with many trees and stream-lets and resounds with the sweet melody of innumerable birds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्विरदनरथाश्वशङ्खशब्दैः परिहृषिता विविधैश्च शस्त्रपातैः। द्विरदरथपदातिसादिसंघाः परिकुपिताभिमुखाः प्रजजिरे ते॥
English Translation: It stands high for infinite ages. Once did the celestials sit on its golden summit and held a conclave.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रिषुभिरनेकविधैश्च सूदिताः। द्विरदरथहया महाहवे वरपुरुषैः पुरुषाश्च वाहनैः॥
English Translation: They, who had practised penances and observed vows, came in quest of the Ambrosia. They consulted together about the possession of the Ambrosia and seeing them in this mood Narayana addressed Brahma saying;
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कमलदिनकरेन्दुसंनिभैः सितदशडनैः सुमुखाक्षिनासिकैः। रुचिरमुकुटकुण्डलैर्मही पुरुषशिरोभिरुपस्तृता बभौ॥
English Translation: Churn the ocean with both the Devas and the Asuras. By doing so, the Ambrosia and all drugs and gems will be obtained. O celestials, churn the ocean and you will get the Ambrosia.
Vaishampayana said The powerful chief of the Yadus, having gone to Indra's Tirtha, bathed there according to due rites and distributed wealth and gems amongst the Brahmanas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नखरभुशुण्डिगदाशतैर्हताः। द्विरदनरहयाः सहस्रशो रुधिरनदीप्रवहास्तदाभवन्॥
English Translation: There the chief of the celestials had performed a hundreds horse-sacrifices and given immense wealth to Brihaspati.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रहतरथनराश्वकुञ्जरं प्रतिभयदर्शनमुल्बणव्रणम्।ष तदहितहतमाबभौ बलं पितृपतिराष्ट्रमिव प्रजाक्षये॥
English Translation: Indeed, through the assistance of Brahmanas conversant with the Vedas, Shakra performed all those sacrifice there, according to rites sectioned by the scriptures. Those sacrifices were performed on a liberal scale. Horses of all breeds were brought there. The gifts to Brahmanas were immense.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्तव च सुताः सुरसूनुसंनिभाः। अमितबलपुरः सरा रणे कुरुवृषभाः शिनिपुत्रमभ्ययुः॥
English Translation: Having duly completed those hundred sacrifices, O chief of the Bharatas, Shakra passed by the name of Shatakratu.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदतिरुधिरभीममावभौ पुरुषवराश्वरद्विपाकुलम्। लवणजलसमुद्धतस्वनं बलमसुरामरसैन्यसप्रभम्॥
English Translation: That auspicious and sacred Tirtha, capable of dissipating every sin. came to be called after his name as Indra-Tirtha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्त्रिदशवरावरजोपमं युधि। दिनकरकिरणप्रभैः पृषत्कै रवितनयोऽभ्यहनच्छिनिप्रवीरम्॥
English Translation: Having duly bathed there, Baladeva worshipped the Brahmanas with excellent food and raiments. He then went to that auspicious and foremost of Tirthas called after the name of Rama.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमपि सरथवाजिसारथि शिनिवृषभो विविधैः शरैस्तवरना भुजगविषसमप्रभै रणे पुरुषवरं समवास्तृणोत् तदा॥
English Translation: The highly blessed and ascetic Rama of Bhrigu's race, repeatedly conquered the Earth and killed all the foremost of Kshatriyas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शिनिवृषभशरैर्निपीडितं तव सुहृदो वसुषेणमभ्ययुः। त्वरितमतिरथा रथर्षभं द्विरदरथाश्वपदातिभिः सह॥
English Translation: Then Rama performed in that Tirtha a Vajapeya sacrifice and a hundred horse sacrifices through the assistance of his preceptor Kashyapa. There, as sacrificial fee, Rama gave to his preceptor the whole Earth with her oceans.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदुदधिनिभमाद्रवद् बलं त्वरिततरैः समभिद्रुतं परैः। दुपदसुतमुखैस्तदाभवत् पुरुषरथाश्वगजक्षयो महान्॥
English Translation: The great Rama, having duly bathed there, made presents to the Brahmanas, O Janamejaya and adored them. Having made diverse presents consisting of various kinds of gems, kine, elephants, female slaves, sheep and goats, he then retired into the woods.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ पुरुषवौर कृताह्निको भवमभिपूज्य यथाविधि प्रभूम्। अरिवधकृतनिश्चयौ दुतं तव बलमर्जुनकेशवौ सृतौ॥
English Translation: Having bathed in that sacred and foremost of Tirthas that was the resort of gods and Rishis. Baladeva duly adored the ascetics there, and then went to the Tirtha called Yamuna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जलदनिनदनि:स्वनं रथं पवनविधूतपताककेतनम्। सितहयमुपयान्तमन्तिकं कृतमनसो ददृशुस्तदाऽरयः॥
English Translation: The highly effulgent and blessed son of Aditi, Varuna, had in days of yore performed in that Tirtha the Rajasuya sacrifice, O king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ विस्फार्य गाण्डीवं रथे नृत्यनिवार्जुन:। शरसम्बाधमकरोत् खं दिशः प्रदिशस्तथा॥
English Translation: Having in battle subjugated both men and celestials and Gandharvas and Rakshasas, Varuna, O king, that slayer of hostile heroes, celebrated his grand sacrifice in that Tirtha. Upon the commencement of that foremost of sacrifices a baitle took place between the gods and the Danavas, terrorising the three worlds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रथान् विमानप्रतिमान् मजयन् सायुधध्वजान्। ससारथींस्तदा बाणैरभ्राणीवानिलोऽवधीत्॥
English Translation: After the termination of that foremost of sacrifices, viz., the Rajasuya (of Varuna), a terrible battle, O Janamejaya, ensued amongst the Kshatriyas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गजान् गजप्रयन्तुंश्च वैजयन्तायुधध्वजान्। सादिनोऽश्वांश्च पत्तीश्च शरैर्निन्ये यमक्षयम्॥
English Translation: Having worshipped the Rishis there, the ever liberal and powerful Baladeva, inade many presents to those that desired them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमन्तकमिव क्रुद्धमनिवार्य महारथम्। दुर्योधनऽभ्ययादेको निनन् बाणैरजिह्मगैः॥
English Translation: Filled with joy and lauded by the great Rishis, Baladeva, that hero ever decked with garlands of wild flower and possessed of eyes like lotus leaves, then went to the Tirtha called Aditya.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्यार्जुनो धनुः सूतमश्वान् केतुं च सायकैः। हत्वा सप्तभिरेकेन छत्रं चिच्छेद पत्रिणा॥
English Translation: There, O best of kings, having performed a sacrifice, the worshipful and effulgent Sun, obtained the sovereignty of all luminous bodies (in the universe) and acquired also his great energy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नवमं च समाधाय व्यसृजत् प्राणघातिनम्। दुर्योधनायेषुवरं त द्रौणिः सप्ताच्छिनन्त्॥
English Translation: There, in that Tirtha situate on the bank of that river, all the gods with Vasava at their head, the Vishvedevas, the Maruts, the Gandharvas, the Apsaras, the Island-born Vyasa, Shuka, Krishna the slayer of Madhu, the Yakshas, the Rakshasas and the Pisachas, O king and various others. thousands in numbers, all crowned with ascetic success, always live. Indeed, in that auspicious and sacred Tirtha of the Sarasvati, Vishnu himself having in days of yore slain the Asuras, Madhu and Kaitabha, had, O chief of the Bharatas, performed his ablutions.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो द्रौणिर्धनुश्छित्त्वा हत्वा चाश्वरथाशरैः। कृपस्यापि तदत्युग्रं धनुचिच्छेद पाण्डवः॥
English Translation: The Island-born Vyasa also, O Bharata, having bathed in that Tirtha, acquired great Yoga powers and Siddhi.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हार्दिक्यस्य धनुश्छित्त्वा ध्वजं चाश्वांस्तदावधीत्। दुःशासनस्येष्वसनं छित्त्वा राधेयमभ्ययात्॥
English Translation: Having bathed in that very Tirtha with a concentrated mind, the Rishi Asita-Deval also obtained great Yoga powers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ सात्यकिमुत्सृज्य त्वरन् कर्णोऽर्जुनं त्रिभिः। विद्ध्वा विव्याध विंशत्या कृष्णं पार्थं पुनः पुनः॥
English Translation: Shuka said While living satisfying duly the duties of the forest life, how should one, who tries to attain to that which is the highest object of knowledge, set his soul on Yoga according to be best of his power?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न ग्लानिरासीत् कर्णस्य क्षिपतः सायकान् बहून्। रणे विनिघ्नतः शत्रून् क्रुद्धस्येव शतक्रतोः॥
English Translation: Vyasa said Having acquired purity by the practice of the first two modes of life, viz., Brahmacharya and domesticity, one should, thereafter, set his mind on Yoga in the third mode of life. Listen now with rapt attention to what should be done for attaining to the highest object of acquisition.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ सात्यकिरागत्य कर्ण विद्ध्वाशितैः शरैः। नवत्या नवभिश्चोग्रैः शतेन पुनरार्पयत्॥
English Translation: Having conquered all shortcomings of the mind of heart by easy means in the practice of the first three modes of life, one should pass into the best and the highest of all the modes, viz., Sannyasa or Renunciation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः प्रवीरा पार्थानां सर्वे कर्णमपीडयन्। युधामन्युः शिखण्डी च द्रौपदेयाः प्रभद्रकाः॥
English Translation: Do you then pass your days, having acquired the purity. Listen also to me. One should, alone and without anybody to help him or bear him company, practise Yoga for achieving success.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उत्तमौजा युयुत्सुश्च यमौ पार्घत एव च। चेदिकारूषमत्स्यानां केकयाना च यद् बलम्॥
English Translation: One who practises Yoga without any one in his company, who sees everything as repetition of his own self, and who never discard anything, never falls away from Liberation.
