Without keeping the sacrificial fires and without a fixed dwelling, such a person should enter a village for only begging his food.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चेकितानश्च बलवान् धर्मराजश्च सुव्रतः। एते रथाश्वद्विरदैः पत्तिभिश्चोग्रविक्रमः॥
English Translation: He should provide himself for the day without keeping any thing in store for the morrow. He should practise penances, with heat fixed on the Supreme. Eating little and that even under proper restrictions, he should not take more than one meal in a day.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: परिवार्य रणे कर्ण नानाशस्त्रैवाकिरन्। भाषन्तो वाग्भिस्याभिः सर्वे कर्णवधे घृताः॥
English Translation: The other marks of a mendicant are the human skull, protection under trees, rags for wearing, companionless solitude, and indifference to all creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तां शस्त्रवृष्टि बहुधा कर्णश्छित्त्वा शितैः शरैः। अपोवाहास्त्रवीर्येण द्रमं भक्त्वे मारुतः॥
English Translation: That person into whom words enter like terrified elephants into a well, and from whom they never return to the speaker, is fit to lead this mode of life which had Libcration for its end.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रथिन: समहामात्रान् गजानश्वान् ससादिनः। पत्तिव्रातांश्च संक्रुद्धो निघ्नन् कर्णो व्यदृश्यत॥
English Translation: The mendicant should never mind the evil deeds of any person. He should never hear vilifications of others. He should especially guard against reviling a Brahmana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तद् वध्यमानं पाण्डूनां बलं कर्णास्त्रतेजसा। विशस्त्रपत्रदेहासु प्राय आसीत् पराङ्मुखम्॥
English Translation: He should always say only what is pleasant to the Brahmanas. When anything is said against him, he should remain perfectly silent. Such silence is the medical treatment prescribed for him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ कर्णास्त्रमस्त्रेण प्रतिहत्यार्जुन। दिशं खं चैव भूमिं च प्रावृणोच्छरवृष्टिभिः॥
English Translation: That person for whose single self the spot he occupies becomes like the eastern sky, and who can regard as perfectly lonely a spot teeming with thousands of men and things, is considered by the gods to be a true Brahmana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मुसलानीव सम्पेतुः परिधा इव चिषवः। शतघ्य इव चाप्यन्ये वज्राण्युग्राणि चापरे॥
English Translation: The gods know him for a Brahmana who puts on whatever comes by the way, who lives upon whatever he gets, and who sleeps on what ever spot he finds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तैर्वध्यमानं तत् सैन्यं सपत्तश्वरथद्विपम्। निमीलिताक्षमत्यर्थं बभ्राम च ननाद च॥
English Translation: The gods regard him as a Brahmana who fears company like a snake; the full measure of gratification (from foods and drinks) as of hell; and women as a corpse.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निष्कैवल्यं तदा युद्धं प्रापुरश्वनरद्विपाः। हन्यमानाः शरैरार्तास्तदा भीताः प्रदुद्रुवः॥
English Translation: The gods know him as a Brahmana who is never glad when honoured and never angry when insulted, and who has given assurances of mercy to all creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वदीयानां तदा युद्धे संसक्तानां जयैषिणाम्। गिरिमस्तं समासाद्य प्रत्यपद्यत भानुमान्॥
English Translation: One following the last mode of life should not regard death with joy. Nor should he regard life with joy. He should only wait for his hour like a servant waiting for his master's command.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमसा च महाराज रजसा च विशेषतः न किंचत् प्रत्यपश्याम शुभं वा यदि वाशुभम्॥
English Translation: He should purify his heart of all shortcomings. He should purify his speech of all faults. He should purge himself of all sins. Shorn as he is of enemies what fear can attack him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते त्रसन्तो महेष्वासा रात्रियुद्धस्य भारत। अपयानं ततश्चकुः सहिताः सर्वयोधिभिः॥
English Translation: He who fears no creature and whom no creature fears, can have no fear from any quarter, freed as he is from every form of mistake.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कौरवेष्वपयातेषु तदा राजन् दिनक्षये। जयं सुमनसः प्राप्य पार्थाः स्वशिबिरं ययुः॥
English Translation: As the foot-prints of all other creatures moving upon legs are engulfed within those of elephants, likewise all ranks and conditions are absorbed within Yoga.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वादित्रशब्दैर्विविधेः सिंहनादैः सगर्जितैः। परानुपहसन्तश्च स्तुवन्तश्चाच्युतार्जुनौ॥
English Translation: Similarly, every other duty and observance is encompassed within the one duty of abstention froin injury. He who avoids injuring other creatures, lives an eternal life of joy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृतेऽवहारे तैवीरैः सैनिकाः सर्व एव ते। आशीर्वाचः पाण्डवेषु प्रायुञ्जन्त नरेश्वराः॥
English Translation: One who abstains from injury, who regards all creatures impartially, who is devoted to truth, who is gifted with fortitude, who has his senses under restraints, and who extends protection to all beings, attains to a peerless end.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः कृतेऽवहारे च परदृष्टास्तत्र पाण्डवाः। निशाया शिविरं गत्वा न्यवसन्त नरेश्वराः॥
English Translation: The state of death cannot with selfknowledge, who is shorn of fear, desire and expectancy. On the other hand, such a person conquers death.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो रक्षः पिशाचाच श्वापदाश्चैव संघशः। जग्मुरायोधनं धोरं रुद्रस्याक्रीडासंनिभम्।॥
English Translation: The gods know him for a Brahmana who is freed from attachments of every kind, who practises penances, who lives like space which while containing everything is yet unattached to all things, who has nothing which he can call his own, who reads a lonely life, and who possesses equanimity of soul.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच पुनरेव तु तं शक्रः प्रहसन्निदमब्रवीत्। निःश्वसन्तं यथा नागं प्रव्याहाराय भारत॥
English Translation: The gods regard him as a Brahmana whose life is for the practice of righteousness, whose righteousness is for the behoof of them who wait dutifully upon him, and whose days and nights exist only for acquiring religious merit.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शक्र उवाच यत् तद् यानसहस्रेण ज्ञातिभिः परिवारितः। लोकान् प्रतापयन् सर्वान् यास्यस्मानवितर्कयन्॥
English Translation: The gods regard him as a Brahmana who is shorn of desire, who never struggles (for worldly emoluments), who never lowers his head to any one, who never flatters another, and who is shorn of all sorts of attachment.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दृष्ट्वा सुकृपणां चेमामवस्थामात्मनो बले। ज्ञातिमित्रपरित्यक्तः शोचस्याहो न शोचसि॥
English Translation: All creatures are filled with pleasure at the prospect of happiness or miserable at the prospect of grief. The man of faith, therefore who should feel sorry at the prospect of afflicting other other creatures, must abstain absolutely from all acts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रीतिं प्राप्यातुलां पूर्वं लोकांश्चात्मवशे स्थितान्। विनिपातमिमं बाह्यं शोचस्याहो न शोचसि॥
English Translation: The gift of assurances of harmlessness to all creatures is superior in point of merit all other gifts. He who, at the beginning, promises abstention from injury, acquires Liberation whence is the assurance of harınlessness to all creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बलिरुवाच अनित्यमुपलक्ष्येह कालपर्यायधर्मतः। तस्माच्छक न शोचामि सर्वं ह्येवेदमन्तवत्॥
English Translation: That man who does not put into his open mouth even the five or six inouthfuls which are sanctioned for the forest recluse, is said to be the navel of the world, and the refuge of the universe. The fire occupies the head and other limbs, as also the acts good and bad.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्वन्त इमे देहा भूतानां च सुराधिप। तेन शक न शोचामि नापराधादिदं मम॥
English Translation: Such a man, who performs a sacrifice in his own self, makes a libation of his senses and mind into the fire which lives within the limited space of his own heart. On account again of his pouring such a libation into such a fire within his own self, the universe with all creatures including the very celestials, becomes pleased.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जीवितं च शरीरं च जात्यैव सह जायते। उमे सह विवर्धते उभे सह विनश्यतः॥
English Translation: They, who know the Sentiency which is endued with effulgence, which is covered with T: three sheaths, which has three qualities for its characteristics, to be Ishvara partaking of that which is highest, viz., the nature of the Supreme Soul, are respected of all the worlds. They very gods with all human beings applaud their merits.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न हीदृशमहं भावमवशः प्राप्य केवलम्। यदेवमभिजानामि का व्यथा मे विजानतः॥
English Translation: He who succeeds is seeing in the Soul which lives in his own body all the Vedas, ether and the other objects of perception, the rituals of the scriptures, all those entities which are perceptible in sound only, and the superior nature of the Supreme Soul, adored of the very gods as the foremost of all beings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भूतानां निधनं निष्ठा स्रोतसामिव सागरः। नैतत् सम्यग्विजानन्तो नरा मुह्यन्ति वज्रधृक्॥ य त्वेवं नाभिजानन्ति रजोमोहपरायणाः। ते कृच्छं प्राप्य सीदन्ति बुद्धिर्येषां प्रणश्यति॥
English Translation: He who sees in the Soul which lives within his body that foremost of beings which is not attached to the Earth, which is not attached to the Earth, which is immeasurable in even the limitless sky, which is made of gold, which is begotten of the egg and lives within the egg, which is equipped with many feathers, and which has two wings like a bird, and which is rendered effulgent by many rays of light is adored of the very gods as the foremost of all beings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बुद्धिलाभात् तु पुरुषः सर्वं तुदति किल्बिषम्। विपाप्मा लभते सत्त्वं सत्त्वस्थः सम्प्रसीदति॥
English Translation: The very gods adore him in whose understanding is set the wheel of Time, which is constantly revolving, which knows no deterioration, which devours the span of existence of every creature, which has the six seasons for its naves, which is equipped with twelve radii consisting of the twelve months, which has excellent joints, and towards whose gaping mouth goes on this universe.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्तु ये निवर्तन्ते जायन्ते वा पुनः पुनः। कृपणाः परितप्यन्ते तैरथैरभिचोदिताः॥
English Translation: The Supreme Soul is the huge unconsciousness of dreamless sleep. That Unconsciousness form the body of the universe. It pervades all created things. Sentiency occupying a portion of that capacious unconsciousness, pleases the gods. These last, being pleased, gratify the open mouth of the unconsciousness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्थसिद्धिमनर्थं च जीवितं मरणं तथा। सुखदुःखफले चैव न दृष्मि न च कामये॥
English Translation: Endued with effulgence as also with the principle of eternity, Sentiency is without a beginning. It wins infinite regions of eternal happiness. He whom no creature fears, has never to fear any creature.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हतं हन्ति हतो ह्येव यो नरो हन्ति कञ्चन। उभौ तौ न विजानीतो यश्च हन्ति हतश्च यः॥
English Translation: He who never does anything blameable and who never censures another, is said to be a truly twice-born one. Such a man succeeds in seeing the Supreme Soul. He whose ignorance has been removed and whose sins have been washed away, never enjoys either here or hereafter the happiness that is enjoyed by others.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हत्वा जित्वा च मघवन् यः कश्चित् पुरुषायते। अकर्ता होव भवति कर्ता ह्येव करोति तत्॥
English Translation: A person following the fourth mode of life wanders on the Earth like one not attached to anything. Such a person is shorn of anger and crror. Such a person regards equally a clod of earth and a lump of gold. such a man never keeps anything in store for his use. Such a person has no friends and enemies. Such a person does not care praise or blame, and the agreeable and the disagreeable.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: को हि लोकस्य कुरुते विनाशप्रभवावुभौ। कृतं हि तत् कृतेनैव कर्ता तस्यापि चापरः॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said Then, O mighty monarch, all those warriors accomplished in smiting down the foe and united together, began to fight with Yuyudhana quickly discharging numerous arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पृथिवी ज्योतिराकाशमापो वायुश्च पञ्चमः। एतद्योनीनि भूतानि तत्र का परिदेवना॥
English Translation: Then Drona pierced Satyaki with seven and seventy shafts of great sharpness; Durmursana pierced him with twelve and Dussaha with ten shafts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महाविद्योऽल्पविद्यश्च बलवान् दुर्बलश्च यः। दर्शनीयो विरूपश्च सुभगो दुर्भगश्च यः॥ सर्वं काल: समादत्ते गम्भीरः स्वेन तेजसा। तस्मिन् कालवशं प्राप्ते का व्यथा मे विजानतः॥
English Translation: Vikarna pierced Satyaki with thirty whetted shafts furnished with wings of Kanka feather, on his lift side and on the centre of his chest.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दग्धमेवानुदहति हतमेवानुहन्यते। नश्यते नष्टमेवाग्रे लब्धव्यं लभते नरः॥
English Translation: o sire, Durmukha then pierced Sini's grandson with ten shafts, Dushasana pierced him with eight and Chitrasena with a couple of arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नास्य द्वीप: कुतः पारो नावारः सम्प्रदृश्यते। नान्तमस्य प्रपश्यामि विधेर्दिव्यस्य चिन्तयन्॥
English Translation: Then with a mighty shower of arrows Duryodhana, O king, afflicted that mighty carwarrior the descendant of Madhu's race. O king, other heroic warriors followed his example.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदि मे पश्यतः कालो भूतानि न विनाशयेत्। स्यान्मे हर्षश्च दर्पश्च क्रोधश्चैव शचीपते॥
English Translation: Thus opposed on all sides by your sons, all mighty car-warriors, he of the Vrishni race began to pierce them all in return with distinct groups of straight-going shafts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तुषभक्षं तु मां ज्ञात्वा प्रविविक्तजने गृहे। बिभ्रतं गार्दभं रूपमागत्य परिगर्हसे॥२३॥
English Translation: Satyaki pierced the son of Bharadvaja with three arrows, Dussaha with nine, Vikarna with twenty-five, Chitrasena with seven.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इच्छन्नहं विकुर्यां हि रूपाणि बहुधाऽऽत्मनः। विभीषणानि यानीक्ष्य पलायेथास्त्वमेव मे॥
English Translation: Durmarsena with twelve, Vivinsati with eight, Satyavrata with nine and Vijaya with ten shafts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कालः सर्वं समादत्ते कालः सर्वं प्रयच्छति। कालेन विहितं सर्वं मा कृथाः शक्र पौरुषम्॥
English Translation: Then that mighty car-warrior Satyaki, having pierced Rukmangada, stretching his bow quickly assailed your son Duryodhana who also was a mighty car-warrior.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुरा सर्वं प्रव्यथितं मयि क्रुद्धे पुरंदर। अवैमि त्वस्य लोकस्य धर्मं शक्र सनातनम्॥
English Translation: Then with his arrows Satyaki deeply pierced the king of all creatures who is regarded as he best car-warrior in all the worlds. Thereupon a battle commenced between them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वमप्येवमवेक्षस्व माऽऽत्मना विस्मयं गमः। प्रभवश्च प्रभावश्च नात्मसंस्थः कदाचन।॥
English Translation: Then those two mighty car-warriors discharging sharp arrows and placing other arrows on the bow-string, rendered each other invisible in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कौमारमेव ते चित्तं तथैवाद्य यथा पुरा। समवेक्षस्व मघवन् बुद्धिं विन्दस्व नैष्ठिकीम्॥
English Translation: Satyaki then pierced sore by the king of the Kurus, appeared highly beautiful. He shed blood copiously like a sandal tree discharging its sap.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: देवा मनुष्याः पितरो गन्धर्वोरगराक्षसाः। आसन् सर्वे मम वशे नत् सर्वं वेत्थ वासव॥
English Translation: r'ierced with myriads of shafts by him of the Satvata race, your son appeared beautiful like a golden stake set up at a sacrifice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नमस्तस्यै दिशेऽप्यस्तु यस्यां वैरोचनो बलिः इति मामभ्यपद्यन्त बुद्धिमात्सर्यमोहिताः॥ । नाहं तदनुशोचामि नात्मभ्रंशं शचीपते। एवं मे निश्चिता बुद्धिः शास्तुस्तिष्ठाम्यहं वशे॥
English Translation: Thereafter, Oking, that descendant of Madhu's race, with a razor-headed shaft, cutoff in battle the bow of the Kuru king that best wielder of the bow, smiling all the while.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दृश्यते हि कुले जातो दर्शनीयः प्रतापवान्। दुःखं जीवन् सहामात्यो भवितव्यं हि तत् तथा॥
English Translation: Then he pierced the king whose bow had been severed, with numerous shafts. Thereat mangled with the arrows of his light-handed enemy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दौष्कुलेयस्तथा मूढो दुर्जातः शक्र दृश्यते। सुखं जीवन् सहामात्यो भवितव्यं हि तत् तथा॥
English Translation: m In that battle, he could not bear this sign of the success of his enemy. Then taking up another bow of great toughness and golden staff.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कल्याणी रूपसम्पन्ना दुर्भगा शक्र दृश्यते। अलक्षणा विरूपा च सुभगा दृश्यते परा॥
English Translation: He pierced Satyaki quickly with a group of hundred arrows. Pierced deeply by that great bowman endued with might, viz., your son, Satyaki.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नैतदस्मत्कृतं शक्र नैतच्छक त्वया कृतम्। यत् त्वमेवंगतो जिन् यच्चाप्येवंगता वयम्॥
English Translation: Under the influence of wrath began to afflict your son severely. Beholding the king thus afflicted, your other sons all mighty carwarriors.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न कर्म भविताप्येतत् कृतं मम शतक्रतो। ऋद्धिर्वाप्यथवा नद्धिः पर्यायकृतमेव तत्॥
English Translation: Covered Satyaki with a shower of mighty arrows. Thus covered by your sons, all mighty car-warriors.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पश्यामि त्वां विराजत्वं देवराजमवस्थितम्। श्रीमन्तं द्युतिमन्तं च गर्जमानं ममोपरि॥
English Translation: Satyaki piercing each with five arrows, again pierced each with seven shafts. He then quickly pierced Duryodhana with eight swiftcoursing arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं नैव न चेत् कालो मामाक्रम्य स्थितो भवेत्। पातयेयमहं त्वाद्य सवज्रमपि मुष्टिना॥
English Translation: Then smiling he cut-off Duryodhana's bow that used to inspire terror into the hearts of the enemy. Then with his arrows, he cut down the latter's standard and the elephant of pearls embossed thereon.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न तु विक्रमकालोऽयं शान्तिकालोऽयमागतः। कालः स्थापयते सर्वं काल: पचति वै तथा॥
English Translation: Then slaying with four sharp arrows the four horses of Duryodhana, that illusirious warrior felled the charioteer of the latter with a razor-headed arrow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मां चेदभ्यागतः कालो दानवेश्वरपूजितम्। गर्जन्तं प्रतपन्तं च कमन्यं नागमिष्यति॥
English Translation: After this, filled with delight he began to cover the king of the Kurus, that mighty carwarrior, with numerous arrows, all capable of penetrating to the very vitals.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्वादशानां तु भवतामादित्यानां महात्मनाम्। तेजांस्येकेन सर्वेषां देवराज धृतानि मे॥
English Translation: Thus pierced by the excellent shafts of the grandson of Sini, Oking, your son Duryodhana suddenly fled away from the field of battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अहमेवोद्वहाम्यापो विसृजामि च वासव। तपामि चैव त्रैलोक्यं विद्योताम्यहमेव च॥
English Translation: He then ascended the car of Chitrasena that great bowman. Then cries of Alas and Oh were uttered by your troops as they beheld the king in that battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संरक्षामि विलुम्पामि ददाम्यहमथाददे। संयच्छामि नियच्छामि लोकेषु प्रभुरीश्वरः॥
English Translation: Devoured by Satyaki, like Soma in the skies devoured by Rahu. Then hearing that woeful exclamation, the mighty car-warrior Kritavarman.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदद्य विनिवृत्तं मे प्रभुत्वममराधिप। कालसैन्यावगाढस्य सर्वं न प्रतिभाति मे॥
English Translation: Quickly proceeded to the spot where that mighty-descendant of Madhu's race, was fighting. He came stretching his bow and urging his steeds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नाहं कर्ता न चैव त्वं नान्यः कर्ता शचीपते। पर्यायेण हि भुज्यन्ते लोकाः शक्र यदृच्छया॥
English Translation: And encouraging his charioteer with the words. Proceed in haste, Proceed in haste. Beholding him come like the Destroyer himself with mouth wide open.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मासमासार्धवेश्मानमहोरात्राभिसंवृतम्। ऋतुद्वारं वर्षमुखमायुर्वेदविदो जनाः॥
English Translation: O mighty Monarch, Yuyudhana addressed his charioteer saying-Yonder is the heroic Kritavarman rushing at me on his chariot.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आहुः सर्वमिदं चिन्त्यं जनाः केचिन्मनीषया। अस्याः पञ्चैव चिन्तायाः पर्येष्यामि च पञ्चधा॥
English Translation: Encounter this foremost all wielder of bow and drive your car before him.” Then urging to the top of their speed those horses duly equipped.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गम्भीरं गहनं ब्रह्म महत्तोयार्णवं यथा। अनादिनिधनं चाहुरक्षरं क्षरमेव च॥
English Translation: The charioteer drove the car towards the king of the Bhojas held in high honor by all bowmen. Then highly excited and looking like two blazing fires.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सत्त्वेषु लिङ्गमावेश्य निर्लिङ्गमपि तत् स्वयम्। मन्यन्ते ध्रुवमेवैनं ये जनास्तत्त्वदर्शिनः॥
English Translation: Those two foremost of men encountered one another like two tigers endued with great agility. Then Kritavarman wounded the grandson of Sini with twenty-six.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भूतानां तु विपर्यासं कुरुते भगवानिति। न ह्येतावद् भवेद् गम्यं न यस्मात् प्रभवेत् पुनः॥
English Translation: Sharp arrows all well-whetted; and his charioteer with five shafts. With four excellent shafts he pierced the four steeds of the Satvata hero, steeds whose teeth were graceful and that were of the Sindhu breed. Then stretching his mighty-bow of golden back, that one of golden standards.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गतिं हि सर्वभूतानामगत्वा क्व गमिष्यति। यो धावता न हातव्यस्तिष्ठन्नपि न हीयते॥
English Translation: Decked with golden Angadas and clad in a golden mail, covered Satyaki with arrow of golden wings. Thereafter the grandson of Sini quickly sped numerous shafts at Kritavarman, as he was longing to have a sight of Dhananjaya. Pierced deeply by his powerful adversary, that scorcher of foes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमिन्द्रियाणि सर्वाणि नानुपश्यन्ति पञ्चधा। आहुश्चै केचिदग्नि केचिदाहुः प्रजापतिम्॥ ऋतून् मासार्धमासांश्च दिवसांश्च क्षणांस्तथा। पूर्वाह्लमपराहं च मध्याह्नमपि चापरे॥ मुहूर्तमपि चैवाहुरेकं सन्तमनेकधा। तं कालमिति जानीहि यस्य सर्वमिदं वशे॥
English Translation: Began to tremble like a mountain during an earth-quake. Then Stayaki of prowess incapable of being baffled quickly pierced his four steeds with sixty-three and his charioteer with seven sharp arrows. Then Satyaki placed on his bow string a shaft furnished with golden wings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बहूनीन्द्रसहस्राणि समतीतानि वासव। बलवीर्योपपन्नानि यथैव त्वं शचीपते।॥
English Translation: That emitted great effulgence and looked like an enraged snake; that arrow that resembled the the dart of Death, wounded Kritavarman sorely.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वामप्यतिबलं शक्र देवराज बलोत्कटम्। प्राप्ते काले महावीर्यः कालः संशमयिष्यति॥
English Translation: Then that fierce arrow, penetrating through the effulgent and gold-decked armour of Kritavarman, fell down on the ground, steeped completely in blood.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: य इदं सर्वमादत्ते तस्माच्छक स्थिरो भव। मया त्वया च पूर्वेश्च न स शक्योऽतिवर्तितुम्॥
English Translation: Covered all over with blood and afflicted with the arrows of the of the Satvata hero, Kritavarman, throwing aside his bow and arrow, feil upon his niche on the chariot.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: योमतां प्राप्य जानीषे राज्यश्रियमनुत्तमाम्। स्थिता मयीति तन्मिथ्या नैषा होकत्र तिष्ठति॥
English Translation: That one of infinite prowess and of teeth resembling those of the lion, that foremost of men, then fell on his knees on the terrace of his car, being afflicted by arrows of Satyaki.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्थिता हीन्द्र सहस्रेषु त्वद्विशिष्टतमेष्वियम्। मां च लोला परित्यज्य त्वामगाद् विबुधाधिप॥
English Translation: Thereafter Satyaki having successfully checked Kritavarman who reseinbled the thousand-armed Arjuna or the unagitable ocean itself, quickly advanced onwards.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मैवं शक्र पुनः कार्षीः शान्तो भवितुमर्हसि। त्वामप्येवंविधं ज्ञात्वा क्षिप्रमन्यं गमिष्यति॥
English Translation: Then passing through the division of Kritavarman, bristling with swords, lances and javelins and teeming with elephants, steeds and cars and shedding blood copiously, before the very eyes of all the troops that foremost of the descendants of Sini moved forwards like the slayer of Vritra passing through the Asura host.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच तस्मिंस्तु निहते शूरे शाल्वे समिति शोभने। तवाभज्यद् बलं वेगाद् वातेनेव महाद्रुमः॥
English Translation: Meanwhile the son of Hridika regaining his composure and grasping another mighty bow, stood on the field of battle checking the mighty Pandava hosts. cars and shedding blood copiously, before the very eyes of all the troops that foremost of the descendants of Sini moved forwards like the slayer of Vritra passing through the Asura host.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत् प्रभग्नं बलं दृष्ट्वा कृतवर्मा महारथः। दधार समरे शूरः शत्रुसैन्यं महाबलः॥
English Translation: Meanwhile the son of Hridika regaining his composure and grasping another mighty bow, stood on the field of battle checking the mighty Pandava hosts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सन्निवृत्तास्तु ते शूरा दृष्ट्वा सात्वतमाहवे। शैलोपमं स्थिरं राजन् कीर्यमाणं शरैर्युधि॥
English Translation: Markandeya said : The night having come to a close, when the sun's disc had appeared (on the horizon), all th 'se ascetius, whose only wealth devotion, having performed their mations, congregated (at the asylum of Dyumatsena).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः प्रववृते युद्धं कुरूणां पाण्डवैः सह। निवृत्तानां महाराज मृत्युं कृत्वा निवर्तनम्॥
English Translation: was Those great sages were never satisfied in relating again and again of the high fortune of Savitri, to Dyumatsena.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्राश्चर्यमभूद् युद्धं सात्वतस्य परैः सह। यदेको वारयामास पाण्डुसेनां दुरासदाम्॥
English Translation: Then, O king, it so chanced that all the subjects came from Shalva and informed Dyumatsena of the death of his enemy at the hands of his own minister.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषामन्योन्यसुहृदां कृते कर्मणि दुष्करे। सिंहनादः प्रहृष्टानां दिविस्पृक् सुमहानभूत्॥
English Translation: And they related to him all that had taken place saying "hearing the death of the usurper together with his friends and allies at the hands of his own minister and of the dispersion of his troops, all the subjects have in one voice declared for you, their legitimate king and they have also said whether you are blind or not you shall be (their) king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेन शब्देन वित्रस्ताः पञ्चालान् भरतर्षभ। शिनेर्नप्ता महाबाहुरन्वपद्यत सात्यकिः॥
English Translation: O king, we have been dispatched to you on the strength of this determination (on the part of your subjects to install you king). These cars and these four kinds of troops have arrived for you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स समासाद्य राजानं क्षेमधूर्ति महाबलम्। सप्तभिर्निशितैर्बाणैरनयद् यमसादनम्॥
English Translation: (Therefore), O monarch, do set out. May you prosper. Your restoration has been proclaimed in the city. May you for ever occupy the portion filled by your sire and grandsire."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमायान्तं महाबाहुं प्रवपन्तं शिताशरान्। जवेनाभ्यपतद् धीमान् हार्दिक्यः शिनिपुङ्गवम्॥
English Translation: And seeing the king restored to sight and healthy, they with their eyes expanded in wonder, bowed down their heads to him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सात्वतौ च महावी? धन्विनौ रथिनां वरौ। अन्योन्यमभिधावेतां शस्त्रप्रवरधारिणौ॥
English Translation: Then the king having greeted all the aged Brahmanas inhabiting the hermitage and in his turn being greeted by them, set out for his capital.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पाण्डवाः सहपञ्चाला योधाश्चान्ये नृपोत्तमाः। प्रेक्षकाः समपद्यन्त तयोघरि समागमे॥
English Translation: And Shaivya together with Savitri surrounded by troops, went in a palanquin, adorned with splendid sheets and carried by men.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नाराचैर्वत्सदन्तैश्च वृष्ण्यन्धकमहारथौ। अभिजघ्नतुरन्योन्यं प्रहृष्टाविव कुञ्जरौ॥
English Translation: Then the priests joyfully installed Dyumatsena as king and his high-souled son as prince regent.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चरन्तौ विविधान् मार्गान् हार्दिक्यशिनिपुङ्गवौ। मुहुरन्तर्दधाते तौ बाणवृष्ट्या परस्परम्॥
English Translation: After a long time Savitri was deliver of a hundred heroic and illustrious sons who never retreated from battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चापवेगबलोद्धृतान् मार्गणान् वृष्णिसिंहयोः। आकाशे समपश्याम पतङ्गानिव शीघ्रगान्॥
English Translation: She had also one hundred highly powerful uterine brothers begotten by Ashvapati, the king of Madra, on Malavi.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमेकं सत्यकर्माणमासाद्य हृदिकात्मजः। अविध्यन्निशितैर्बाणैश्चतुर्भिश्चतुरो हयान्॥
English Translation: Thus Savitri rescued from misfortune, her own self, her father, mother-in law, father-inlaw and her husband's line.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स दीर्घबाहुः संक्रुद्धस्तोत्रादित इव द्विपः। अष्टभिः कृतवर्माणमविद्ध्यत् परमेषुभिः॥
English Translation: Similarly, the auspicious Draupadi of excellent character, will deliver you all from your misfortune as the virtuous Savitri did.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः पूर्णायतोत्सृष्टैः कृतवर्मा शिलाशितैः। सात्यकि त्रिभिराहत्य धनुरेकेन चिच्छिदे॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Thus, O monarch, instructed by that highsouled one ((Markandeya), the Pandava (Yudhishthira) devoid of grief and affliction continued to dwell in Kamyaka.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निकृत्तं तद् धनुः श्रेष्ठमपास्य शिनिपुङ्गवः। अन्यदादत्त वेगेन शैनेयः सशरं धनुः॥
English Translation: The man who listens with a devout spirit, to the excellent history of Savitri ever meets with happiness and success and never experiences sorrow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदादाय धनुः श्रेष्ठं वरिष्ठः सर्वधन्विनाम्। आरोग्य च धनुः शीघ्रं महावीर्यो महाबलः॥ अमृष्यमाणो धनुषश्छेदनं कृतवर्मणा। कुपितोऽतिरथः शीघ्रं कृतवर्माणमभ्ययात्॥
English Translation: Janamejaya said "Why did the worshipful Arshtishena practise the severest of penances? How also did Sindhudvipa acquire the dignity of a Brahmana?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः सुनिशितैर्बाणैर्दशभिः शिनिपुङ्गवः। जघान सूतं चाश्वांश्च ध्वजं च कृतवर्मणः॥
English Translation: How also did Devapi, O Brahmana and how did Vishvamitra, O best of men, become Brahmanas. Tell me all this, O worshipful One! Great is my curiosity to hear of all this."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो राजन् महेष्वासः कृतवर्मा महारथः। हताश्वसूतं सम्प्रेक्ष्य रथं हेमपरिष्कृतम्॥ रोषेण महताऽऽविष्टः शूलमुद्यम्य मारिष। चिक्षेप भुजवेगेन जिघांसुः शिनिपुङ्गवम्॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said "Formerly, in the Krita age, O king, there was a great Rishi called Arshtishena. Living in his preceptor's house, he attended to his lessons every day.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तच्छूलं सात्वतो ह्याजौ निर्भिद्य निशितैः शरैः। चूर्णितं पातयामास मोहयन्निव माधवम्॥
English Translation: Although, O king, he lived long in the residence of his preceptor, he could not master any branch of learning or the Vedas, O monarch.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽपरेण भल्लेन हृद्येनं समताडयत्। स युद्धे युयुधानेन हताश्वो हतसारथिः॥
English Translation: Greatly disappointed, O king, the great ascetic practised very rigid penances. By his penances he afterwards acquired the mastery of the Vedas which is best of all forms of learning.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृतवर्मा कृतस्तेन धरणीमन्वपद्यत। तस्मिन् सात्यकिना वीरे द्वैरथे विरथीकृते॥ समपद्यत सर्वेषां सैन्यानां सुमहद् भयम्।
English Translation: Acquiring great learning and a mastery of the Vedas, that best of Rishis became highly successful in that tirtha. He then conferred three boons on that place.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुत्रस्य तव चात्यर्थं विषादः समजायत॥ हतसूते हताश्वे तु विरथे कृतवर्मणि।
English Translation: He said-"From this day, a person, by bathing in this tirtha of the great river Sarasvati, shall reap the great fruit of a horse sacrifice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हताश्वं च समालक्ष्य हतसूतमरिंदम॥ अभ्यधावत् कृपो राजञ्जिघांसुः शिनिपुङ्गवम्।
English Translation: From this day there will be no fear in this tirtha from serpents and wild beasts. By the slightest of endeavours, again, one shall reap great results here."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमारोप्य रथोपस्थे मिषतां सर्वधन्विनाम्॥ अपोवाह महाबाहुं तूर्णमायोधनादपि।
English Translation: Having said these words, that energetic Rishi proceeded to heaven. Thus the worshipful Arshtishena became successful.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शैनेयेऽधिष्ठिते राजन् विरथे कृतवर्मणि॥ दुर्योधनबलं सर्वं पुनरासीत् पराङ्मुखम्।
English Translation: In that very tirtha, in the Krita age th greatly energetic Sindhudvipa and Devapi also, had acquired the dignity of Brahman-hood.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत् परे नान्वबुध्यन्त सैन्येन रजसा वृताः॥ तावकाः प्रद्रुता राजन् दुर्योधनमृते नृपम्।
English Translation: Similarly Kushika's ascetic son, having controlled his senses and practised austerities became a Brahmana.

Sanskrit Shloka: दुर्योधनस्तु सम्प्रेक्ष्य भग्नं स्वबलमन्तिकात्॥ जवेनाभ्यपत् तूर्णं सर्वांश्चैको न्यवारयत्।
English Translation: There was a great Kshatriya, celebrated over the world, by the name of Gadhi. He had a son by the name of Vishvamitra of great prowess.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पाण्डूंश्च सर्वान् संक्रुद्धो धृष्टद्युम्नं च पार्षतम्॥ शिखण्डिनं द्रौपदेयान् पञ्चालाना च ये गणाः। केकयान् सोमकांश्चैव सृञ्जयांश्चैव मारिष॥ असम्भ्रमं दुराधर्षः शितैर्वाणैरवाकिरत्। अतिष्ठदाहवे यत्तः पुत्रस्तव महाबलः॥
English Translation: King Kaushika became a great ascetic. Possessed of great ascetic merit, he wished to place his son Vishvamitra on his throne, himself having made up his mind to renounce his body. His subjects, bowing unto him, said-You should not go away, O you of great wisdom and protect us from a great fear.'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथा यज्ञे महानग्निमन्त्रपूतः प्रकाशवान्। तथा दुर्योधनो राजा संग्रामे सर्वतोऽभवत्॥
English Translation: Thus addressed, Gadhi replied to his subjects, saying-"My son will be the protector of the vest universe.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं परे नाभ्यवर्तन्त मा मृत्युमिवाहवे। अथान्यं रथमास्थाय हार्दिक्यः समपद्यत॥
English Translation: Having said these words and placed Vishvamitra on the throne, Gadhi, O king ascended heaven and Vishvainitra became king. He could not, however, protect the earth even trying his level best.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नारद उवाच नाभागमम्बरीषं च मृतं सृञ्जय शुश्रुम यः सहस्रं सहस्राणां राज्ञां चैकस्त्वयोधयत्॥
English Translation: The king then heard of the fear of Rakshasa in his kingdom. With his fourfold forces, he went out of his capital.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जिगीषमाणाः संग्रामे समन्ताद् वैरिणोऽभ्ययुः। अस्त्रयुद्धविदो घोराः सृजन्तश्चाशिवा गिरः॥
English Translation: Having proceeded far on his way, he reached the hermitage of Vashishtha. His troops, O king, caused immense mischief there.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बललाघवशिक्षाभिस्तेषां सोऽस्त्रबलेन च। छत्रायुधध्वजरथांश्छित्त्वा प्रासान् गतव्यथः॥
English Translation: The worshipful Brahman Vashishtha, when he came to his hermitage, saw the vast forest devastated.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त एनं मुक्तसंनाहाः प्रार्थयन् जीवितैषिणः। शरण्यमीयुः शरणं तवास्म इति वादिनः॥
English Translation: That best of Rishis, viz., Vashishtha O king, became angry with Vishvamitra. He commanded his own sacrificial cow, saying "Create a number of terrible Shavaras.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तु तान् वशगान् कृत्वा जित्वा चेमां वसुन्धराम्। ईजे यज्ञशतैरिष्टैर्यथाशास्त्रं तथाऽनध॥
English Translation: Thus addressed the cow created a number of men of terrific visages. These fought with the army of Vishvamitra and made a great onslaught.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बुभुजुः सर्वसम्पन्नमन्नमन्ये जनाः सदा। तस्मिन् यज्ञे तु विप्रेन्द्राः संतृप्ताः परमार्चिताः॥
English Translation: Seeing this, the troops fled away. Regarding ascetic austerities highly efficacious, Vishvamitra, the son of Gadhi made up his mind to practise the same.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मोदकान् पूरिकापूपान् स्वादुपूर्णाश्च शष्कुलीः। करम्भान् पृथुमृद्वीका अन्नानि सुकृतानि च॥ सूपान् मैरेयकापूपान् रागखाण्डवपानकान्। मृष्टान्नानि सुयुक्तानि मृदूनि सुरभीणि च॥ घृतं मधु पयस्तोयं दधीनि रसवन्ति च। फलं मूलं च सुस्वादु द्विजास्तत्रोपभुञ्जते॥
English Translation: In this best of tirthas of the Sarasvati, O king, he began to emaciate his own body by Vows and fasts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मादनीयानि पापानि विदित्वा चात्मनः सुखम्। अपिबन्त यथाकामं पानया गीतवादितैः॥
English Translation: He lived on water, air and the fallen leaves of trees. He slept on the naked earth and practised other vows of the ascetics.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्र स्म गाथा गायन्ति क्षीबा हृष्टाः पठन्ति च। नाभागस्तुतिसंयुक्ता ननृतुश्च सहस्रशः॥
English Translation: The celestials repeatedly attempted for obstructing the observance of his vows. He, however, did not desist from practising his promised vow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषु यज्ञेष्वम्बरीषो दक्षिणामत्यकालयत्। राज्ञां शतसहस्राणि दश प्रयुतयाजिनाम्॥
English Translation: Then having practised various austerities with great devotion, the son of Gadhi became effulgent like the Sun himself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हिरण्यकवचान् सर्वाश्वेतच्छत्रप्रकीर्णकान्। हिरण्यस्यन्दनारूढान् सानुयात्रपरिच्छदान्॥ ईजानो वितते यज्ञे दक्षिणामत्यकालयत्। मूर्धाभिषिक्तांश्च नृपान् राजपुत्रशतानि च॥ सदण्डकोशनिचयान् ब्राह्मणेभ्यो ह्ममन्यत। नैवं पूर्वे जनाचकुर्न करिष्यन्ति चापरे॥
English Translation: The boon-giving Brahmana, of great energy, resolved to grant Vishvamitra, when he had succeeded in his ascetic observances, the boon the latter wanted.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदम्बरीषो नृपतिः करोत्यमितदक्षिणः। इत्येवमनुमोदन्ते प्रीता यस्य महर्षयः॥
English Translation: The boon that Vishvamitra prayed for was that he should be permitted to become a Brahmana. Brahmana, the grandfather of all the worlds, said to him-"So be it.'

Sanskrit Shloka: स चेन्ममार सृञ्जय चतुर्भद्रतरस्त्वया। पुत्रात् पुण्यतरस्तुभ्यं मा पुत्रमनुतप्यथाः। अयजवानमदाक्षिण्यमभि श्वैत्येत्युदाहरत्॥

Sanskrit Shloka: सूत उवाच एतस्मिन्नेव काले तु भगिन्यौ ते तपोधन। अपश्यतां समायाते उच्चैःश्रवसमन्तिकात्॥

Sanskrit Shloka: यं तं देवगणाः सर्वे हृष्टरूपमपूजयन्। मथ्यमानेऽमृते जातमश्वरत्नमनुत्तमम्॥

Sanskrit Shloka: अमोघबलमश्वानामुत्तमं जगतां वरम्। श्रीमन्तमजरं दिव्यं सर्वलक्षणपूजितम्॥

Sanskrit Shloka: शौनक उवाच कथं तदमृतं देवैर्मथितं क्व च शंस मे। यत्र जज्ञे महावीर्यः सोऽश्वराजो महाद्युतिः॥

Sanskrit Shloka: सौतिरुवाच ज्वलन्तमचलं मेलं तेजोराशिमनुत्तमम्। आक्षिपन्तं प्रभां भानो:स्वशृंगैःकाञ्चनोज्वलैः॥

Sanskrit Shloka: कनकाभरणं चित्रं देवगन्धर्वसेवितम्। अप्रमेयमनाधृष्यमधर्मबहुलैर्जनैः॥
English Translation: In consequence of the illustrious Pandavas being virtuous, all the Kurus, being free from sin and becoming very happy, grew in prosperity.

Sanskrit Shloka: अगम्यं मनसाऽप्यन्यैर्नदीवृक्षसमन्वितम्। नानापतगसबैश्च नादितं सुमनोहरैः॥
English Translation: When his wealth (kine) was thus stolen, the Brahmana lost his senses in anger; and coming to Khandavaprastha, he thus reproved the Pandavas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य शृङ्गमुपारुह्य बहुरत्नाचितं शुभम्। अनन्तकल्पमुद्विद्धं सुरा: सर्वे महौजसः।॥
English Translation: The Brahmana said: O Pandavas, despicable and wicked wretches are robbing away my kine in your dominion. Parsue the robbers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते मन्त्रयितुमारब्धास्तत्रासीना दिवौकसः। अमृताय समागम्य तपोनियमसंयुताः॥ तत्र नारायणो देवो ब्रह्माणमिदमब्रवीत्। चिन्तयत्सु सुरेष्वेवं मन्त्रयत्सु च सर्वशः॥

Sanskrit Shloka: देवैरसुरसंड्बैश्च मथ्यतां कलशोदधिः। भविष्यत्यमृतं तत्र मथ्यमाने महोदधौ॥ सर्वोषधी: समावाप्य सर्वरत्नानि चैव ह। मन्यध्वमुदधिं देवा वेत्स्यध्वममृतं ततः॥
English Translation: A king, who takes the sixth part of the produce, but does not protect his subjects, is called by all men as the most sinful in all the worlds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच इन्द्रतीर्थं ततो गत्वा यदूनां प्रवरो बलः। विप्रेभ्यो धनरत्नानि ददौ स्नात्वा यथाविधि॥
English Translation: The wealth of a Brahmana is being taken away by thieves; virtue is going to be destroyed. Take me up by the hand, for I am in great grief.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्र ह्यमरराजोऽसावीजे ऋतुशतेन च। बृहस्पतेश्च देवेशः प्रददौ विपुलं धनम्॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Thus were the Pandavas reproved by the Brahmana weeping in bitter grief. The son of Kunti, Dhananjaya (Arjuna) heard his (weeping) words.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निरन्लान् सजारूथ्यान् सर्वान् विविधदक्षिणान्। आजहार क्रतूंस्तत्र यथोक्तान् वेदपारगैः॥
English Translation: As soon as he heard it, the mighty-armed hero told the Brahmana, "Don't fear". Sanskrit Shloka: तान् क्रतून् भरतश्रेष्ठ शतकृत्वो महाद्युतिः। पूरयामास विधिवत् ततः ख्यातः शतक्रतुः॥
English Translation: Being repeatedly urged by the weeping words of the Brahmana, the son of Kunti (Arjuna) pondered in sorrow.

Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य नाम्ना च तत् तीर्थं शिवं पुण्यं सनातनम्। इन्द्रतीर्थमिति ख्यातं सर्वपापप्रमोचनम्॥
English Translation: Arjuna said : "Alas, this ascetic Brahmana's wealth is being rubbed! It is certainly my duty to dry up his tears.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उपस्पृश्य च तत्रापि विधिवन्मुसलायुधः। ब्राह्मणान् पूजयित्वा च सदाच्छादनभोजनैः॥ शुभं तीर्थवरं तस्माद् रामतीर्थं जगाम ह
English Translation: If I do not protect him who is weeping at our gate, the king (Yudhishthira) will be touched by sin for my indifference.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यत्र रामो महाभागो भार्गवः सुमहातपाः॥ असकृत् पृथिवीं जित्वा हतक्षत्रियपुङ्गवाम्।
English Translation: Our own irreligiousness will also be talked all over the kingdom and we shall certainly incur a great sin.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उपाध्यायं पुरस्कृत्य कश्यपं मुनिसत्तमम्॥ अयज वाजपेयेन सोऽश्वमेधशतेन च। प्रददौ दक्षिणां चैव पृथिवीं वै ससागराम्॥
English Translation: There is no doubt that if I enter (the room) disregarding the king, I shall not truthfully behave towards that enemiless monarch.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दत्त्वा च दानं विविधं नानारत्नसमन्वितम्। सगोहस्तिकदासीकं साजावि गतवान् वनम्॥
English Translation: If I enter (the room) where the king is, an exile in the forest will be my lot. But I must overlook every thing. I do not care if I am to incur sin by disregarding the king. ---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुण्ये तीर्थवरे तत्र देवब्रह्मर्षिसेविते। मुनींश्चैवाभिवाद्याथ यमुनातीर्थमागमत्॥
English Translation: O king, having resolved this, the son of Kunti Dhananjaya (Arjuna) entered the room and talked with the king (Yudhishthira).

Sanskrit Shloka: यत्रानयामास तदा राजसूयं महीपते। पुत्रोऽदितेर्महाभागो वरुणो वै सितप्रभः॥

Sanskrit Shloka: तत्र निर्जित्य संग्रामे मानुषान् देवतास्तथा। वरं क्रतुं समाजहे वरुणः परवीरहा॥ तस्मिन् क्रतुवरे वृत्ते संग्राम: समजायत। देवानां दानवानां च त्रैलोक्यस्य भयावहः॥
English Translation: He then went away, armed with bow-cased in mail, riding on the chariot and holding the standard. Piercing those thieves with arrows, he took back that wealth (kine).

Sanskrit Shloka: राजसूये ऋतुश्रेष्ठे निवृत्ते जनमेजय। जायते सुमहाघोर: संग्रामः क्षत्रियान् प्रति॥

Sanskrit Shloka: तत्रापि लागली देव ऋषीनभ्यर्च्य पूजया। इतरेभ्योऽप्यदाद् दानमर्थिभ्यः कामदो विभुः॥

English Translation: I shall go into exile to the forest, for we made this rule.” Suddenly hearing those most painful words uttered (by Arjuna), Yudhishthira, was afflicted with grief and sad in agitated voice, “Why?" Sanskrit Shloka: यत्रेष्टवा भगवाज्योतिर्भास्करो राजसत्तम। ज्योतिषामाधिपत्यं च प्रभावं चाभ्यपद्यत॥
English Translation: O hero, I know full well why you entered the room and did what you thought would be disagreeable to me. But I have not felt any displeasure for it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्या नद्यास्तु तीरे वै सर्वे देवाः सवासवाः। विश्वेदेवाः समरुतो गन्धर्वाप्सरसश्च ह। द्वैपायनः शुकश्चैव कृष्णाश्च मधुसूदनः। यक्षाश्च राक्षसाश्चैव पिशाचाश्च विशाम्पते॥ एते चान्ये च बहवो योगसिद्धाः सहस्रशः। तस्मिंस्तीर्थे सरस्वत्याः शिवे पुण्ये परंतप॥ तत्र हत्वा पुरा विष्णुरसुरौ मधुकैटभौ। आप्लुत्य भरतश्रेष्ठ तीर्थप्रवर उत्तमे॥
English Translation: The younger brother may enter the room in which his elder brother sits with his wife. There is no fault to be found in this. If the elder brother enters the room where his younger brother is with his wife, then he acts against the rules of propriety.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्वैपायनश्च धर्मात्मा तत्रैवाप्लुत्य भारत। सम्प्राप्य परमं योगं सिद्धिं च परमां गतः॥
English Translation: O mighty-armed hero, therefore, desist from your purpose. Do what I say. Your virtue has suffered no diminution and you have not also shown any disregard towards me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: असितो देवलश्चैव तस्मिन्नेव महातपाः। परमं योगमास्थाय ऋषिर्योगमवाप्तवान्॥
English Translation: Arjuna said : I have heard from you that the virtue should not be practiced by quibbling. I shall not waver from truth. Truth is my weapon.

Sanskrit Shloka: शुक उवाच वर्तमानस्थैवात्र वानप्रस्थाश्रमे यथा। योक्तव्योऽऽत्मा कथं शक्त्या वेद्यं वै कासता परम्॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Having obtained the king's permission, he made preparations to live in the forest. He went away to dwell in the forest for twelve years.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यास उवाच प्राप्य संस्कारमेताभ्यामाश्रमाभ्यां ततः परम्। यत्कार्यं परमार्थ तदिहैकमनाः शृणु॥ तु
English Translation: Yudhishthira said O you who know the truths of religion, I wish to hear of the merits of religion, I wish to hear of the merits of mercy, and of the marks of devout men! Do you, O sire, describe them to me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कषायं पाचयित्वाऽऽशु श्रेणिस्थानेषु च त्रिषु। प्रव्रजेच्च परं स्थानं पारिवाज्यमनुत्तमम्॥
English Translation: Bhishma said “Regarding it, this ancient legend, the story of Vasava and the great Shuka, is cited as an illustration.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तद् भवानेवमभ्यस्य वर्ततां श्रूयतां तथा। एक एव चरेद् धर्मं सिद्ध्यर्थमसहायवान्॥
English Translation: In the dominion of the king of Kashi, a fowler, having poisoned arrows with him, went out of his village on hunting expedition in search of antelopes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एकश्चरति यः पश्यन् न जहाति न हीयते। अनग्निरनिकेतश्च ग्राममन्नार्थमाश्रयेत्॥
English Translation: Desirous of getting meat, when in a big forest in pursuit of the chase, he saw a drove of antelopes near at hand, and shot his arrow at one of them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अश्वस्तनविधाता स्यान्मुनिर्भावसमाहितः। लध्वाशी नियताहारः सकृदन्ननिषेविता॥
English Translation: The arrow of that fowler of irresistible arms, shot for the destruction of the antelope, missing its aim, pierced a powerful foresttree.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कपालं वृक्षमूलानि कुचैलमसहायता। उपेक्षा सर्वभूतानामेतावद् भिक्षुलक्षणम्॥
English Translation: The tree, pierced with that arrow covered with dreadful poison, withered away, shedding its leaves and fruits.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यस्मिन् वाचः प्राविशन्ति कूपे त्रस्ता द्विपा इव। न वक्तारं पुनर्यान्ति कैवल्याश्रमे वसेत्॥
English Translation: The tree having thus withered, a parrot which had lived in a hollow of its trunk all his life, did not leave his nest out of affection for that lordly tree.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नैव पश्येन्न शृणुयादवाच्यं जातु कस्यचित्। ब्राह्मणानां विशेषेण नैव ब्रूयात् कथंचन॥
English Translation: Motionless starving, silent and sorrowful, that grateful and virtuous parrot also withered away with the tree.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यद् ब्राह्मणस्य कुशलं तदेव सततं वदेत्। तूष्णीमासीत निन्दायां कुर्वन् भैषज्यमात्मनः॥
English Translation: The conqueror of Paka (Indra) was filled with wonder upon seeing that great and generous bird thus uninfluenced by misery or happiness and possessing extraordinary resolution.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: येन पूर्णमिवाकाशं भवत्येकेन सर्वदा। शून्यं येन जनाकीर्णं तं देवा ब्राह्मणं विदुः॥
English Translation: Then Shakra thought, How could this bird come to possess such humane and generous feelings which cannot be seen in one of the lower animal creation?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: येन केनचिदाच्छन्नो येन केनचिदाशितः। यत्र क्वचन शायी च तं देवा ब्राह्मणं विदुः॥
English Translation: There is nothing wonderful in the matter, for all crcatures are seen to show kindly and generous feelings towards others.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अहेरिव गणाद् भीतः सौहित्यानरकादिव। कुणपादिव च स्त्रीभ्यस्तं देवा ब्राह्मणं विदुः॥
English Translation: Assuming then the shape of a Brahmana, Shakra went on the Earth and addressing the bird, said:
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न क्रुद्ध्येन प्रहृष्येच्च मानितोऽमानितश्च यः। सर्वभूतेष्वभयदस्तं देवा ब्राह्मणं विदुः॥
English Translation: O Suka, O best of birds, the granddaughter of Daksha has become blessed (by having you as her offspring)! I ask you, why do you not leave this withered tree?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नाभिनन्देत मरणं नाभिनन्देत जीवितम्। कालमेघ प्रतीक्षते निदेशं भृतको यथा॥
English Translation: Thus accosted, the Shuka bowed to him and thus replied: Welcome to you, O king of the gods, I have recognised you by the merit of my austere penances.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनभ्याहतचित्त स्यादनभ्याहतवाग् भवेत्। निर्मुक्तः सर्वपापेभ्यो निरमित्रस्य किं भयम्॥
English Translation: Well-done, well-done! said the thousandeyed god. Then the latter lauded him in his mind, saying 0, how wonderful is the knowledge which he possesses.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभयं सर्वभूतेभ्यो भूतानामभयं ततः। तस्य मोहाद् विमुक्तस्य भयं नास्ति कुतश्चन॥
English Translation: Although the destroyer of Vala knew that parrot to be of a greatly virtuous character and meritorious in action, he still enquired of him about the reason of his love for the tree.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथा नागपदेऽन्यानि पदानि पदगामिनाम्। सर्वाण्येवापिधीयन्ते पदजातानि कौञ्जरे॥
English Translation: This tree is withered and it is without leaves and fruits, and is unfit to be the refuge of birds. Why do you then cling to it? This forest too is vast and in this wilderness there are numberless other good trees whose hollows are covered with leaves and which you can choose freely and to your heart's content.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं सर्वमहिंसायां धर्मार्थमपिधीयते। अमृतः स नित्यं वसति यो हिंसां न प्रपद्यते॥
English Translation: patient one, displaying proper discrimination in your wisdom, do you leave this old tree that is dead and useless and shorn of all its leaves and no longer capable of any good.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अहिंसकः समः सत्यो धृतिमान् नियतेन्द्रियः। शरण्यः सर्वभूतानां गतिमाप्नोत्यनुत्तमाम्॥
English Translation: Bhishma said Hearing these words of Shakra, the virtuous Shuka, heaved a deep sigh, and sorrowfully replied to him, saying O husband of Sachi, and chief of the gods, the ordinances of the gods should always be obeyed. Do you hear of the reason of the thing about which you have asked me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं प्रज्ञानतृप्तस्य निर्भयस्य निराशिषः। न मृत्युरतिगो भावः स मृत्युमधिगच्छति॥
English Translation: Here, within this tree, was I born and here in this tree have all the good traits of my character been developed, and here in this tree was I protected in my infancy from the attacks of my enemies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विमुक्तं सर्वसङ्गेभ्यो मुनिमाकाशवत् स्थितम्। अस्वमेकचरं शान्तं तं देवा ब्राह्मणं विदुः॥
English Translation: O sinless one, why are you, in your kindness, interfering with the principle of my conduct in life? I am merciful and devoutly intent on virtue, and firm in conduct.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जीवितं यस्य धर्मार्थं धर्मो हर्यर्थमेव च। अहोरात्राश्च पुण्यार्थं तं देवा ब्राह्मणं विदुः॥
English Translation: Kindliness of feeling is the highest test of virtue amongst the good, and this same merciful and humane feeling is the source of eternal happiness to the virtuous,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निराशिषमनारम्भं निर्नमस्कारमस्तुतिम्। निर्मुक्तं बन्धनैः सर्वैस्तं देवा ब्राह्मणं विदुः॥
English Translation: All the gods ask you to remove their doubts in religion, and for this reason, O lord, you have been elected their king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वाणि भूतानि सुखे रमन्ते सर्वाणि दुःखस्य भृशं त्रसन्ते। तेषां भयोत्पादनजातखेदः कुर्यान्न कर्माणि हि श्रद्दधानः॥
English Translation: You should not, O thousandeyed one, advise me now to leave this tree for good. When it was capable of good, it supported my life. How can I leave it now? Pleased with these wellmeant words of the parrot, the virtuous destroyer of Paka, thus said to him:I am pleased with your humane and merciful disposition.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दानं हि भूताभयदक्षिणायाः सर्वाणि दानान्यधितिष्ठतीह। तीक्ष्णां तनुं यः प्रथमं जहाति सोऽऽनन्त्यमाप्नोत्यभयं प्रजाभ्यः॥
English Translation: Do you ask a boon of me. At this, the merciful parrot craved this boon of him, saying Let this tree revive.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उत्तान आस्येन हविर्जुहोति लोकस्य नाभिर्जगतः प्रतिष्ठा। तस्याङ्गमङ्गानि कृताकृतं च वैश्वानरः सर्वमिदं प्रपेदे॥
English Translation: Knowing the great attachment of the parrot to that tree and great high character, Indra, wellpleased, caused the tree to be quickly sprinkled over with nectar.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रादेशमाने हृदि निःसृतं यत् तस्मिन् प्राणानात्मयाजी जुहोति। तस्याग्निहोत्रं हुतमात्मसंस्थं सर्वेषु लोकेषु सदेवकेषु॥
English Translation: Then that tree became revived and grand through the penanres of the parrot, and the latter, too, O great king, at the end of his life, acquired the companionship of Shakra by virtue of that act of mercy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: देवं त्रिधातुं त्रिवृतं सुपर्णं ये विद्युरग्रयां परमात्मतां च। ते सर्वलोकेषु महीयमाना देवाः समाः सुकृतं वदन्ति॥
English Translation: Thus, o king, by communion and companionship with the pious, people acquire all the objects of their desire even as the tree did through its companionship with the parrot."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मथो निरुक्तं परमार्थतां च। सर्वं शरीरात्मनि यः प्रवेद तस्यैव देवाः स्पृहयन्ति नित्यम्॥
English Translation: Shishupala said The greatly powerful king Jarasandha, who did not desire to fight with Krishna, saying that he was but a “servant”, was (surely) worthy of my greatest esteem.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भूमावसक्तं दिवि चाप्रमेयं हिरण्मयं योऽण्डजमण्डमध्ये। पतत्रिणं पक्षिणमन्तरिक्ष यो वेद भोग्यात्मनि रश्मिदीप्तः॥
English Translation: Who will consider praiseworthy the act of killing Jarasandha which was done by Keshava (Krishna), as also by Bhima and Arjuna?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आवर्तमानमजरं विवर्तनं षण्णाभिकं द्वादशारं सुपर्व। यस्येदमास्ये परियाति विश्वं तत्कालचक्रं निहितं गुहायाम्॥
English Translation: Entering (the city) by a way which was not the (public) gate, and disguised as a Vedaknowing (Brahmana), this Krishna saw the prowess of king Jarasandha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यः सम्प्रसादो जगतः शरीरं सर्वान्स लोकानधिगच्छतीह। स्ते वै तृप्तास्तर्पयन्त्यास्यमस्य॥
English Translation: When that illustrious king offered this wretch water to wash his feet, it was then he said from seeming motives of virtue that he was not a Brahmana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेजोमयो नित्यमयः पुराणो लोकाननन्तानभयानुपैति। भूतानि यस्मान्न वसन्ते कदाचित्स भूतानां न त्रसते कदाचित्॥
English Translation: O descendant of Kuru, when Bhima, Dhananjaya and Krishna were asked by Jarasandha to eat, that request was refused by this Krishna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अगर्हणीयो न च गर्हतेऽनयान्स वै विप्रः परमात्मानमीक्षेत्। विनीतमोहो व्यपनीतकल्मषो न चेह नामुत्र च सोऽन्नमृच्छति॥
English Translation: If this one (Krishna) is the lord of the universe, as this fool thinks himself to be, why does he not then consider himself a Brahmana?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अरोषमोहः समलोष्टकाञ्चनः प्रहीणकोशो गतसंधिविग्रहः। श्वरन्नुदासीनवदेष भिक्षुकः॥
English Translation: It is greatly surprising that though you often lead the Pandavas away from the path of the pious, yet they consider you (Bhima) to be honest.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच ते किरन्तः शरवातान् सर्वे यत्ताः प्रहारिणः। त्वरमाणा महाराज युयुधानमयोधयन्॥
English Translation: Odescendant of Bharata (Bhishma), there is nothing to be surprising (perhaps) in those who have got you, who is no better than a woman and who is old, to be their counsellor in all things.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं द्रोणः सप्त सप्तत्या जघान निशितैः शरैः। दुर्मर्षणो द्वादशभिर्दुःसहो दशभिः शरैः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said Hearing his these harsh words-harsh both in import and sound, that foremost of all strong men, the powerful Bhimasena, became angry.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विकर्णश्चापि निशितैस्त्रिंशद्भिः कङ्कपत्रिभिः। विव्याध सव्ये पार्श्वे तु स्तनाभ्यामन्तरे तथा॥
English Translation: Under the influence of anger, his lotus-like eyes, naturally large and expanding, became still more extended, and also as red as the copper.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुर्मुखो दशभिर्बाणैस्तथा दुःशासनोऽष्टभिः। चित्रसेनश्च शैनेय द्वाभ्यां विव्याध मारिष॥
English Translation: The assembled kings saw on his forehead three lines of wrinkles like the Ganges with her three currents on the three peaked mountain.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुर्योधनश्च महता शरवर्षेण माधवम्। अपीडयद्रणे राजशूराश्चान्ये महारथाः॥
English Translation: When he began to grind his teeth in anger, the kings saw his face resemble like that of the Death preparing to swallow every creature at the end of the Yuga.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वतः प्रतिविद्धस्तु तव पुत्रैर्महारथैः। तान् प्रत्यविध्यद्वाष्णैयः पृथक् पृथगजिह्मगैः॥
English Translation: As the strong-minded (hero) was about to jump up with great impetuosity, the mighty armed Bhishma caught him (by the hand), as if Mahadeva seized Mahasena.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भारद्वाजं त्रिभिर्बाणैर्दुःसहं नवभिः शरैः। विकर्णे पञ्चविंशत्या चित्रसेनं च सप्तभिः॥
English Translation: O descendant of Bharata, Bhima's anger was soon appeased by Bhishma with various words of sound counsels.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुर्मर्षणं द्वादशभिरष्टाभिश्च विविंशातेम। सत्यव्रतं च नवभिर्विजयं दशभिः शरैः॥
English Translation: That chastiser of foes could not disobey Bhishma's words, as the ocean never goes beyond its shore, though swollen with the waters of the rainy season.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो रुक्मांगदं चारं विधुन्वानो महारथः। अभ्ययात् सात्यकिस्तूर्णं पुत्रं तव महारथम्॥
English Translation: O king, though Bhima was angry, the heroic Shishupala, depending on his own valour, did not tremble in fear.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजानं सर्वलोकस्य सर्वलोकमहारथम्। शरैरभ्याहनगढं ततो युद्धमभूत्तयोः॥
English Translation: Though Bhima every moment jumping up (from his seat) with great impetuosity, yet Shishupala did not bestow a single thought on him, as a lion does not mind a small animal who leaps up in rage.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विमुञ्चन्तौ शरांस्तीक्ष्णान् संदधानौ च सायकान्। अदृश्यं समरेऽन्योन्यं चक्रतुस्तौ महारथौ॥
English Translation: Seeing Bhima of terrible prowess in such great rage, the mighty kings of Chedi laughingly spoke thus. was
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सात्यकिः कुरुराजने निर्विद्धो बह्वशोभत। अस्रवदुधिरं भूरि स्वरसं चन्दनो यथा॥
English Translation: O Bhishma, release his. Let all these kings see him burnt down by my prowess like an insect by fire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सात्वतेन च बाणौधैर्निर्विद्धस्तनयस्तव। शातकुंभमयापीडो बभौ यूप इवोच्छ्रितः॥
English Translation: Having heard these words of the king of the Chedis, that foremost of the Kurus, that best of all intelligent men, Bhishma thus spoke to Bhima.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: माधवस्तु रणे राजन् कुरुराजस्य धन्विनः। धनुश्चिच्छेद समरे क्षुरप्रेण हसन्निव॥
English Translation: The people who lived in the Kuru kingdom could not mark any difference in the cordiality which existed between king Yudhishthira and the father of Duryodhana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथैनं छिन्नधन्वानं शरैर्बहुभिराचिनोत्। निर्भिन्नश्च शरैस्तेन द्विषता क्षिप्रकारिणा॥
English Translation: When the Kuru king recollected his wicked son, he then could not but feel unfriendly, in his heart, towards Bhima.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नामृष्यत रणे राजा शत्रोविजयलक्षणम्। अथान्यद्धनुरादाय हेमपृष्ठं दुरासदम्॥-
English Translation: Bhiimasena also, O king, moved by a wicked heart, was unable to put up with king Dhritarashtra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विव्याध सात्यकिं तूर्णे सायकानां शतेन ह। सोऽतिविद्धो बलवता तव पुत्रेण धन्विना॥
English Translation: Vrikodara secretly did many deeds that were disagreeable to the old king. Through deceitful servants he caused the commands of his uncle to be disobeyed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अमर्षवशमापन्नस्तव पुत्रमपीडयत्। पीडितं नृपतिं दृष्ट्वा तव पुत्रा महारथाः॥
English Translation: Recollecting the evil advice of the old king and some deeds of his, Bhima, one days, in the midst of his friends, slapped his armpits, in the hearing of Dhritarashtra and of Gandhari. The angry Vrikodara, recollecting his enemies Duyrodhana and Karna and Dushasana, gave way to a fit of passion, and said these harsh words :-'The sons of the blind king, capable of fighting with various kinds of weapons, have all been dispatched by me to the other world with these arms of mine which resemble a pair of iron clubs.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सात्यकि शरवर्षेण छादयामासुरोजसा। स च्छाद्यमानो बहुभिस्तव पुत्रैर्महारथैः॥
English Translation: Indeed, these are those two arms of mine, loO king like maces of iron, and invincible by cnemies, coming within whose clasp the sons of Dhritarashtra have all been killed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एकैकं पञ्चभिर्विद्ध्वा पुनर्विव्याध सप्तभिः। दुर्योधनं च त्वरितो विव्याधाष्टभिराशुगैः॥
English Translation: These are those two well-developed and round arms of mine, resembling a pair of elephantine trunks. Coming within their clasp, the foolish sons of Dhritarashtra have all been killed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रहसंश्चास्य चिच्छेद कार्मुकं रिपुभीषणम्। नागं मणिमयं चैव शरैर्ध्वजमपातयत्॥
English Translation: Smeared with sandal-paste and deserving of that adornment are those two arms of mine by which Duryodhana has been sent to the other world along with all his sons and kinsmen.'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हत्वा तु चतुरो वाहांश्चतुर्भिनिशितैः शरैः। सारथिं पातयामास क्षुरप्रेण महायशाः॥
English Translation: Hearing these and many other words, O king, of Vrikodara, which were so many darts, king Dhritarashtra gave way to cheerlessness and sorrow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतस्मिन्नन्तरे चैव कुरुराजं महारथम्। अवाकिरच्छरैर्हष्टो बहुभिर्मर्मभेदिभिः॥
English Translation: Queen Gandhari, however, who conversant with every duty and endued with great intelligence, and who knew what Time brings on its course, considered them as untrue.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स वध्यमानः समरे शैनेयस्य शरोत्तमैः। प्राद्रवत् सहसा राजन् पुत्रो दुर्योधनस्तव॥
English Translation: Then, after fifteen years had passed away, o monarch, king Dhritarashtra, afflicted (constantly) by the wordy arrows of Bhima, became stricken with despair and sorrow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आप्लुतश्च ततो यानं चित्रसेनस्य धन्विनः। हाहाभूतं जगश्चासीद् दृष्ट्वा राजानमाहवे॥
English Translation: King Yudhishthira thc son of Kunti, however, knew it not; nor Arjuna of white horses; nor Kunti; nor Draupadi possessed of great fame; nor the twin sons of Madri, knowing every duty and who were always engaged in acting after the wishes of Dhritarashtra. was to
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ग्रस्यमानं सात्यकिना खे सोममिव राहुणा। तं तु शब्दमथ श्रुत्वा कृतवर्मा महारथः॥
English Translation: Employed in doing the behest's of the king, the twins never said anything that was disagreeable the old king. Then Dhritarashtra one day honoured his friends by his confidence. Addressing them with tearful eyes, he said these words.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभ्ययात् सहसा तत्र यत्रास्ते माधवः प्रभुः। विधुन्वानो धनुः श्रेष्ठं चोदयंश्चैव वाजिनः॥
English Translation: Dhritarashtra said You know how the destruction of Kurus has happened. All that was brought about by my fault, though the Kauravas approved of all my counsels.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भर्त्सयन् सारथिं चाग्रे याहि याहीति सत्वरं। तमापतन्तं संप्रेक्ष्य व्यादितास्यमिवान्तकम्॥
English Translation: Fool that I was, I installed the wickedminded Duryodhana, that enhancer of the terrors of kinsmen, to rule over the Kurus.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युयुधानो महाराज यन्तारमिदमब्रवीत्। कृतवर्मा रथेनैष द्रुतमापतते शरी॥
English Translation: Vasudeva had said to me, 'Let this sinful wretch of wicked understanding be slain along with all his friends and counselors.' I did not listen to those words of great significance. All wise men gave me the same beneficial advice. Vidura, Bhishina, Drona, and Kripa said the same thing. The holy and great Vyasa repeatedly said the same, as also Sanjaya and Gandhari. Overwhelmed, however, by filial affection, I could not follow that advice. Bitter repentance is now my lot for my neglect.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रत्युद्याहि रथेनैनं प्रवरं सर्वधन्विनाम्। ततः प्रजविताश्वेन विधिवत् कल्पितेन च॥
English Translation: I also repent for not having bestowed that blazing prosperity, derived from sires and grandsires on the great Pandavas possessed of every accomplishment.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आससाद रणे भोज प्रतिमानं धनुष्मताम्। ततः परमसंक्रुद्धौ ज्वलिताविव पावकौ॥
English Translation: The eldest brother of Gada foresaw the destruction of all the king; Janardana, however, considered that destruction as highly beneficial.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: समेयातां नरव्याघ्रौ व्याघ्राविव तरस्विनौ। कृतवर्मा तु शैनेयं षड्विशत्या समार्पमत्॥
English Translation: So many battalions of troops belonging to me, have been destroyed! Alas, my heart is pierced with thousands of darts on account of all these results.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निशितैः सायकैस्तीक्ष्णैर्यन्तारं चास्य पञ्चभिः। चतुरश्चतुरो वाहांश्चतुर्भिः परमेषुभिः॥ अविध्यत् साधुदान्तान् वै सैन्धवान् सात्वतस्य हि। रुक्मध्वजो रुक्मपृष्ठं महद् विस्फार्य कार्मुकम्॥
English Translation: Of wicked understanding as I am, now, after the lapse of fifteen years, I am trying to expiate my sins.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रुक्माङ्गदी रुक्मवर्मा रुक्मपुङ्खरवारयत्। ततोऽशीतिं शिनेः पौत्रः सायकान् कृतवर्मणे॥ प्राहिणोत् त्वरया युक्तो द्रष्टकामो धनंजयम्। सोऽतिविद्धो बलवता शत्रुणा शत्रुतापनः॥
English Translation: Now at the fourth division of the day or sometimes at the eighth division, with the regularity of a vow, I eat a little food for simply satisfying my thirst. Gandhari knows this.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: समकम्पत दुर्घर्षः क्षितिकम्पे यथाचलः। त्रिषष्ट्या चतुरोऽस्याश्वान् सप्तभिः सारथिं तथा॥ विव्याध निशितैस्तूर्णं सात्यकिः सत्यविक्रमः। सुवर्णपुङ्ख विशिखं समाधाय च सात्यकिः॥
English Translation: All my attendants believe that I eat as usual. Through feat of Yudhishthira alone I concealed my deeds, for if the eldest son of Pandu came to know of my vow, he would feel great pain.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यसृजत् तं महाज्वालं संक्रुद्धमिव पन्नगम्। सोऽविध्यत् कृतवर्माणं यमदण्डोपमः शरः॥
English Translation: Clad in deer-skin, I lie down on the Earth, spreading a small quantity of Kusha grass, and pass the time in silent recitations. The illustrious Gandhari, also, passes her time in the observance of similar vows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जाम्बूनदविचित्रं च वर्म निर्भिद्य भानुमत्। अभ्यगाद धरणीमुनो रुधिरेण समुक्षितः॥
English Translation: Thus do we both act, we who have lost a hundred sons none of whom ever retreated from battle. I do not, however, grieve for those children of mine. They have all died while performing Kshatriya duties.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजातरुधिरश्चाजौ सात्वतेषुभिरर्दितः। सशरं धनुरुत्सृज्य न्यपतत् स्यन्दनोत्तमात्॥
English Translation: Having said these words, the old king then addressed Yudhishthira in particular and said, 'Blessed by you, O son of the princess of Yudu's race! Listen now to what I say.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स सिंहदंष्ट्रो जानुभ्यां पतितोऽमितविक्रमः। शरादितः सात्यकिना रथोपस्थे नरर्षभः॥
English Translation: Cherished by you, O son, I have lived these years very happily. I have (with your help) made large gifts and performed Sharaddhas repeatedly.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सहस्रबाहुसदृशमक्षोभ्यमिव सागरम्। निवार्य कृतवर्माणं सात्यकिः प्रययौ ततः॥
English Translation: I have, O son, to the best of my power, acquired merit largely. This Gandhari, though destitute of sons, has lived with great fortitude, loO king all the while at me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: खङ्गशक्तिधनुःकीर्णो गजाश्वरथसंकुलाम्। प्रवर्तितोग्ररुधिरां शतशः क्षत्रियर्षभैः॥ प्रेक्षतां सर्वसैन्यानां मध्येन शिनिपुङ्गवः। अभ्यगाद्वाहिनीं हित्वावृत्रहेवासुरींचमूम्॥
English Translation: They who inflicted great wrongs on Draupadi and robbed you of your affluence, those cruel men-have all left the world, killed in battle according to the practice of their order.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: समाश्वस्य च हार्दिक्यो गृह्य चान्यन्महद् धनुः। तस्थौ स तत्र बलवान् वारयन् युधि पाण्डवान्॥
English Translation: I have nothing to do for them, O delighter of the Kurus! Killed with their faces towards battle, they have attained to those regions which reserved for the wielders of weapons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: समाश्वस्य च हार्दिक्यो गृह्य चान्यन्महद् धनुः। तस्थौ स तत्र बलवान् वारयन् युधि पाण्डवान्॥
English Translation: I should now, do what is bencficial and meritorious for me as also for Gandhari. O great king, you should grant mc permission. are
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मार्कण्डेय उवाच तस्यां रात्र्यां व्यतीतायामुदिते सूर्यमण्डले। कृतपौर्वाणिकाः सर्वं समेयुस्ते तपोधनाः॥
English Translation: You are the foremost of all righteous persons. You are always devoted to virtue. The king is the preceptor of all creatures. It is for this that I say so.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदेव सर्वं सावित्र्या महाभाग्यं महर्षयः। धुमत्सेनाय नातृप्यन् कथयन्तः पुनः पुनः॥
English Translation: With your permission, O hero, I shall retire into the forest, clad in rags and darks, O king, along with this Gandhari.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः प्रकृतयः सर्वाः शाल्वेभ्योऽभ्यागता नृप। आचख्युनिहतं चैव स्वेनामात्येन तं द्विषम्॥
English Translation: I shall live in the forest, always blessing you. It is proper, O son, for the members of our family, to make over sovereignty, when old age comes, to children and lead the forest mode of life. Living there on air alone, or abstaining froin all food, I shall, with this wife of mine, O hero, practice severe austeities.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं मन्त्रिणा हतं श्रुत्वा ससहायं सबान्धवम्। न्यवेदयन् यथावृत्तं विद्रुतं च द्विषद्बलम्॥ ऐकमत्यं च सर्वस्य जनस्याथ नृपं प्रति। सचक्षुर्वाप्यचक्षुर्वा स नो राजा भवत्विति॥
English Translation: You shall be a sharer of those penances, o son, for you are the king. Kings are sharers of both auspicious and inauspicious acts done in their kingdom.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनेन निश्चयेनेह वयं प्रस्थापिता नृप। प्राप्तानीमानि यानानि चतुरङ्गं च ते बलम्॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said When you, O king, are thus subject to grief, sovereignty does not please me at all. Fie on me who am of wicked understanding, devoted o the pleasures of own and absolutely negligent of my true concerns.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रयाहि राजन् भद्रं ते घुष्टस्ते नगरे जयः। अध्यास्स्व चिररात्राय पितृपैतामहं पदम्॥
English Translation: Alas, I, with all my brothers, was ignorant of yourself having so long been stricken with grief, emaciated with fasts, abstaining from food, and lying on the naked earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चक्षुष्मन्तं च तं दृष्ट्वा राजानं वपुषान्वितम्। मूर्धा निपतिताः सर्वे विस्मयोत्फुल्ललोचनाः॥
English Translation: Alas, foolish that I am, I have been deceived by you who have great intelligence, inasmuch as, having filled me with confidence at first you have latterly undergone such grief.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽभिवाद्य तान् वृद्धान् द्विजानाश्रमवासिनः। तैश्चाभिपूजितः सर्वैः प्रययौ नगरं प्रति॥
English Translation: What need have I of kingdom or of articles of enjoyment, what need of sacrifices or of happiness, when you, O king, have undergone so much affliction.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शैब्या च सह सावित्र्या स्वास्तीर्णेन सुवर्चसा। नरयुक्तेन यानेन प्रययौ सेनया वृता॥
English Translation: I consider my kingdom as a disease, and myself also as afflicted. Plunged though I am in sorrow, what however, is the sue of these words that I am addressing you?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽभिषिषिचुः प्रीत्या धुमत्सेनं पुरोहिताः। पुत्रं चास्य महात्मानं यौवराज्येऽभ्यषेचयन्॥
English Translation: You are our father, you are our mother; you are our foremost of superiors. Deprived of your presence, how shall we live.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः कालेन महता सावित्र्याः कीर्तिवर्धनम्। तद् वै पुत्रशतं जज्ञे शूराणामनिवर्तिनाम्॥
English Translation: O best of kings, let Yuyutsu, the son of your loins, be made king, or indeed, anybody else whom you may wish.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भ्रातृणां सौदराणां च तथैवास्याभवच्छतम्। मद्राधिपस्याश्वपतेर्मालब्यां सुमहद् बलम्॥
English Translation: I shall go into the forest. Do you rule the kingdom You should not burn me who am already burned by infamy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमात्मा पिता माता श्वश्रूः श्वशुर एव च। भर्तुः कुलं च सावित्र्या सर्वं कृच्छ्रात् समुद्भुतम्॥
English Translation: I am not the king. You are the king. I am dependent on your will. How can I dare grant permission to you who are my preceptor?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथैवैषा हि कल्याणी द्रौपदी शीलसम्मता। तारयिष्यति वः सर्वान् सावित्रीव कुलाङ्गना॥
English Translation: O sinless one, I cherish no resentment in my heart on account of the wrongs done to us by Suyodhana. It was ordained that it should be so. Both ourselves and others were stupefied (by fate).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच एवं स पाण्डवस्तेन अनुनीतो महात्मना। विशोको विज्वरो राजन् काम्यके न्यवसत् तदा॥
English Translation: We are your children as Duryodhana and others were. My conviction is that Gandhari is as much my mother as Kunti.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यश्चेदं शृणुयाद् भक्त्या सावित्र्याख्यानमुत्तमम्। स सुखी सर्वसिद्धार्थो न दुःखं प्राप्नुयानरः॥
English Translation: If you, O king of kings, go to the forest leaving me, I shall then follow you. I swear by iny soul.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जनमेजय उवाच कथमार्टिषेणो भगवान् विपुलं तप्तवांस्तपः। सिन्धुद्वीपः कथं चापि ब्राह्मण्यं लब्धवांस्तदा॥
English Translation: This Earth, with her belt of seas, so full of riches, will not be a source of joy to me when I am deprived of your presence.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: देवापिश्च कथं ब्रह्मन् विश्वामित्रश्च सत्तम। तन्ममाचक्ष्व भगवन् परं कौतूहलं हि मे॥
English Translation: All this belongs to you. Bending my head low I make my obeisance. We are all dependent on you, O king of kings. Let the fever of your heart be removed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच पुरा कृतयुगे राजन्नार्टिषेणो द्विजोत्तमः। वसन् गुरुकले नित्यं नित्यमध्ययने रतः॥
English Translation: I think, O king, that all this that has come upon you is due to destiny. By good luck, I had thought, that waiting upon you and executing your commands obediently, I would rescue you from the fever of your heart.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य राजन् गुरुकुले वसतो नित्यमेव च। समाप्ति नागमद् विद्या नापि वेदा विशाम्पते।॥
English Translation: Dhritarashtra said-Odelighter of the Kurus, my mind is fixed, O son, on penances. O powerful one, it is proper for our family that I should retire into the forest.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स निर्विणस्ततो राजंस्तपस्तेपे महातपाः। ततो वै तपसा तेन प्राप्य वेदाननुत्तमान्॥
English Translation: I have lived long under your protection, O son. I have for many years been served by you with respect. I am now old. You should, O king, grant me permission.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वरान् प्रादात् त्रीनेव स विद्वान् वेदयुक्तश्च सिद्धश्चाप्यषिसत्तमः। तत्र तीर्थे सुमहातपाः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said Having said these words to king Yudhishthira the just, king Dhritarashtra, the son of Ambika, trembling all the while and with hands joined together, further said to the great Sanjaya and the great car-warrior Kripa, these words: I wish to solicit the king through you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अस्मिंस्तीर्थे महानद्या अद्यप्रभृति मानवः। आप्लुतो वाजिमेधस्य फलं प्राप्स्यति पुष्कलम्॥
English Translation: My mind has become dispirited, my mouth has become dry, through the weakness of age and the exertion of speaking.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अद्यप्रभृति नैवात्र भयं व्यालाद् भविष्यति। अपि चाल्पेन कालेन फलं प्राप्स्यति पुष्कलम्॥
English Translation: Having said so, that perpetuator of Kuru's race, viz., the pious old king, blessed with prosperity, leaned to Gandhari and suddenly looked like one dcad.

Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्त्वा महातेजा जगाम त्रिदिवं मुनिः। एवं सिद्धः स भगवानार्टिषेणः प्रतापवान्॥
English Translation: Seeing him thus seated like one shom of consciousness, that destroyer of hostile heroes, viz., the royal son of Kunti, became penetrated by a piercing grief.

Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मिन्नेव तदा तीर्थे सिन्धुद्वीपः प्रतापवान्। देवापिश्च महाराज ब्राह्मण्यं प्रापतुर्मह ॥
English Translation: on me am Yudhishthira said Alas, he whose strength was equal to that of a hundred thousand elephants, alas, that king sits today, learning on a woman.

Sanskrit Shloka: तथा च कौशिकस्तान् तपोनित्यो जितेन्द्रियः। तपसा वै सुतप्तेन ब्राह्मणत्वमवाप्तवान्॥
English Translation: Alas, he by whom the iron image of Bhima on a former occasion was reduced to pieces, leans today on a weak woman.

Sanskrit Shloka: गाधिर्नाम महानासीत् क्षत्रियः प्रथितो भुवि। तस्य पुत्रोऽभवद् राजन् विश्वामित्रः प्रतापवान्॥
English Translation: Fic who exceedingly unrighteous. Fie on my understanding. Fie on my knowledge of the scriptures. Fie on me for whom this king lies today in a manner that is not worthy of him.

Sanskrit Shloka: स राजा कौशिकस्तात महायोग्यभवत् किला स पुत्रमभिषिच्याथ विश्वामित्रं महातपाः॥ देहन्यासे मनश्चक्रे तमूचुः प्रणताः प्रजाः। न गन्तव्यं महाप्राज्ञ त्राहि चास्मान् महाभयात्॥
English Translation: I also shall fast even as my preceptor. Indeed, I shall fast if this king and Gandhari of great fame abstain from food.

Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्तः प्रत्युवाच ततो गाधिः प्रजास्ततः। विश्वस्य जगतो गोप्ता भविष्यति सुतो मम॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said The Pandava king, knowing every duty, using his own hand, then softly rubbed with cold water the breast and the face of the old king.

Sanskrit Shloka: इत्युक्त्वा तु ततो गाधिर्विश्वामित्रं निवेश्य च। जगाम त्रिदिवं राजनं विश्वामित्रोऽभवन्नृपः॥ न स शक्नोति पृथिवीं यत्नवानपि रक्षितुम्।
English Translation: At the touch of the king's hand which was auspicious and fragrant, and on which were jewels and medicinal herb's, Dhritarashtra regained his consciousness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः शुश्राव राजा स राक्षसेभ्यो महाभयम्॥ निर्ययौ नगराचापि चतुरङ्गबलान्वितः।
English Translation: Dhritarashtra said Do you, again, touch me, O son of Pandu, with your hand, and do you embrace me. O you having eyes like lotus petals, I am restored to my senses through the auspicious touch of your hand.

Sanskrit Shloka: स गत्वा दूरमध्वानं वसिष्ठाश्रममभ्ययात्॥ तस्य ते सैनिका राजंश्चक्रुस्तत्रानयान् बहून्।
English Translation: O king, I wish to smell your head. The clasp of your arms is highly gratifying to me.

Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्तु भगवान् विप्रो वसिष्ठोऽऽश्रममभ्ययात्॥ ददृशोऽथ ततः सर्वं भज्यमानं महावनम्।
English Translation: This is the eighth division of the day and therefore, the hour for taking may food. For not having taken my food, O scion of Kuru's race, I am so weak that I cannot move.

Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य क्रुद्धो महाराज वसिष्ठो मुनिसत्तमः॥ सृजस्व शवरान् घोरानिति स्वां गामुवाच ह।
English Translation: Great has been my exertion while soliciting you. Rendered cheerless by it, O son, I had fainted.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथोक्ता साऽसृजद् धेनुः पुरुषान् घोरदर्शनान्॥ ते तु तद्बलमासाद्य बभञ्जुः सर्वतोदिशम्।
English Translation: O perpetuator of Kuru's race, I think that receiving the touch of your hand, which is like nectar in its vivifying effects I have been restored to my senses.

Sanskrit Shloka: तच्छुत्वा विद्रुतं सैन्यं विश्वामित्रस्तु गाधिजः॥ तपः परं मन्यमानस्तपस्येव मनो दधे।

Sanskrit Shloka: जलाहारो वायुभक्षः पर्णाहारश्च सोऽभवत्॥ तथा स्थाण्डिलशायी च ये चान्ये नियमाः पृथक्।

Sanskrit Shloka: ततः परेण यत्नेन तप्त्वा बहुविधं तपः॥ तेजसा भास्कराकारो गाधिजः समपद्यत।

Sanskrit Shloka: तपसा तु तथा युक्तं विश्वामित्रं पितामहः॥ अमन्यत महातेजा वरदो वरमस्य तत्।

English Translation: By speaking repeatedly, O son, my mind becomes weakened. You should not, O son, afflict me after this.

Sanskrit Shloka: स लम्वा तपसोग्रेण ब्राह्मणत्वं महायशाः॥ विचचार महीं कृत्स्नां कृतकामः सुरोपमः।

Sanskrit Shloka: पयस्विनीस्तथा धेनूर्यानानि शयनानि च। ययौ राजंस्ततो रामो बकस्याश्रममन्तिकात्। यत्र तेपे तपस्तीव्र दाल्भ्यो बक इति श्रुतिः॥
English Translation: a state O foremost of men, I do not wish for life and the Earth! O scorcher of enemies, I shall engage myself in doing what is pleasant to you.

Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच एवं ते समयं कृत्वा न्यवसंस्तत्र पाण्डवाः। वशे शस्त्रप्रतापेन कुर्वन्तोऽन्यान् महीक्षितः॥

Sanskrit Shloka: वर्तमानेषु धर्मेण पाण्डवेषु महात्मसु। व्यवर्धन् कुरवः सर्वे हीनदोषा: सुखान्विताः॥

Sanskrit Shloka: ह्रियमाणे धने तस्मिन् ब्राह्मणः क्रोधमूर्च्छितः। आगम्य खाण्डवप्रस्थमुद क्रोशत् स पाण्डवान्॥

Sanskrit Shloka: ह्रियते गोधनं क्षुदैर्नृशंसैरकृतात्मभिः। प्रसह्य चास्मद्विषयादभ्यधावत पाण्डवाः॥
English Translation: Kept there by the king (of the Danavas) who killed with it all his foes in battle. It is hard and strong and variegated with golden knobs, it is capable of standing great weight.

Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणस्य प्रशान्तस्य हविर्ध्वाक्षैः प्रलुप्यते। शार्दूलस्य गुहां शून्यां नीचः क्रोष्टाभिमर्दति॥
English Translation: It can kill all focs, and it is equal in strength to one hundred thousand clubs. It is a fit weapon for Bhima as the Gandiva (bow) is yours.

Sanskrit Shloka: अरक्षितारं राजानं बलिषड्भागहारिणम्। तमाहुः सर्वलोकस्य समग्रं पापचारिणम्॥
English Translation: (There is also in that lake) a large conchshell of loud sound, named Devadatta which was produced by Varuna (Ocean). There is no doubt I shall give all these to you."

Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणस्वे हृते चौरेर्धर्मार्थे च विलोपिते। रोरूयमाणं च मयि क्रियतामस्त्रधारणम्॥
English Translation: Having said this to Partha, that Asura (Maya) went away in a north-eastern direction. On the north of the Kailasa near the Mainaka mountains.
