Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच रोरूयमाणस्याभ्याशे भृशं विप्रस्य पाण्डवः। तानि वाक्यानि शुश्राव कुन्तीपुत्रो धनंजयः॥
English Translation: There is a great peak full of many gems and jewels, called Hiranya Shringa. (There is) a charming lake named Bindusara where (once dwelt) king Bhagiratha.

Sanskrit Shloka: श्रुत्वैव च महाबाहुर्मा भैरित्याह तं द्विजम्। आयुधानि च यत्रावसन् पाण्डवानां महात्मनाम्॥ कृष्णया सह तत्रास्ते धर्मराजो युधिष्ठिरः। सम्प्रवेशाय चाशक्तो गमनाय च पाण्डवः॥
English Translation: He lived there for a long period with the desire of seeing the Ganges which is called Bhagirathi (after him). Here the illustrious lord of all creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य चार्तस्य तैर्वाक्यैश्चोद्यमानः पुनः पुनः। आक्रन्दे तत्र कौन्तेयश्चिन्तयामास दुःखितः॥
English Translation: O best of the Bharata race, performed one hundred great sacrifices. There were placed at this spot for beauty, many sacrificial stakes made of gems, and many sacrificial ultras made of gold though not according to the ordinance. Here after performing those sacrifices the deity of one thousand eyes, the husband of Sachi, acquired Siddhi (final success).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ह्रियमाणे धने तस्मिन् ब्राह्मणस्य तपस्विनः। अश्रुप्रमार्जनं तस्य कर्तव्यमिति निश्चयः॥
English Translation: Here the greatly effulgent lord of spirits (Shiva), the eternal lord of all creatures lived after creating all the worlds and here he was worshipped by all the sprites.

Sanskrit Shloka: उपक्षेपणजोऽधर्मः सुमहान् स्यान्महीपतेः। यद्यस्य रुदतां द्वारि न करोम्यद्य रक्षणम्॥
English Translation: Here Nara and Narayana, Brahma, Yama and the fifth Sthanu performed sacrifices after the expiration of one thousand Yugas.

Sanskrit Shloka: अनास्तिक्यं च सर्वेषामस्माकमपि रक्षणे। प्रतितिष्ठेत लोकेऽस्मिन्नधर्मश्चैव नो भवेत्॥
English Translation: Here for the establishment of virtue and religion Vasudeva with with pious devotion performed his sacrifices with extended for many long years.

Sanskrit Shloka: अनादृत्य तु राजानं गते मयि न संशयः। अजातशत्रोर्नृपतेर्मम चैवानृतं भवेत्॥

Sanskrit Shloka: अनुप्रवेशे राज्ञस्तु वनवासो भवेन्मम। सर्वमन्यत् परिहतं धर्षणात् तु महीपतेः॥ अधर्मो वै महानस्तु वने वा मरणं मम। शरीरस्य विनाशेन धर्म एव विशिष्यते॥

English Translation: Going there thereat Asura, Maya, took all the great wealth which was guarded by the Takshas and Rakshasas and Kinkaras.

Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणागम्यतां शीघ्रं यावत् परधनैषिणः॥ न दूरे ते गताः क्षुद्रास्तावद् गच्छावहे सह। यावनिवर्तयाम्यद्य चौरहस्ताद् धनं तव॥
English Translation: Bringing them away, the Asura (Maya) built with them a matchless assembly-hall. It was celebrated throughout the three worlds, it was beautiful, it was celestials, and it was full of gems and jewels.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सोऽनुसृत्य महाबाहुर्धन्वी वर्मी रथी ध्वजी। शरैर्विध्वस्य तांश्चौरानवजित्य च तद् धनम्॥
English Translation: He gave to Bhimasena that best of clubs (that was in the lake) he also gave to Arjuna that excellent and the best conch.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणं समुपाकृत्य यशः प्राप्य च पाण्डवः। ततस्तद् गोधनं पार्थो दत्त्वा तस्मै द्विजातये॥ आजगाम पुरं वीरः सव्यसाची धनंजयः। सोऽभिवाद्य गुरून् सर्वान् सर्वैश्चाप्यभिनन्दितः॥
English Translation: The sound of that conch used to make all creatures tremble in feat. O great king, the assembly-hall that Maya built, stood on golden pillars, and it occupied an area of five thousand cubits square, possessing an most beautiful form. It (the liall) shone in great splendour like the fire, the sun or the moon. By its great effulgence it seemed to darken even the rays of the sun.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धर्मराजमुवाचेदं व्रतमादिश मे प्रभो। समयः समतिक्रान्तो भवत्संदर्शने मया।॥ वनवासो गमिष्यामि समयो ह्येष नः कृतः।
English Translation: With its effulgence which was the mixture of both celestials and terrestrial light, it appeared as if it was on fire. Like a mass of new clouds rising in the sky, it filled the whole of the view. It was spacious large, charming, soothing, full of celestials effulgence, and filled with all sorts of excellent things, it was adorned with jeweled walls and gates, with many pictures and much wealth. It appeared like the work of Vishvakarma himself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्युक्तो धर्मराजस्तु सहसा वाक्यमप्रियम्॥ कथमित्यब्रवीद् वाचा शोकार्तः सज्जमानया। युधिष्ठिरो गुडाकेशं भ्राता भ्रातरमच्युतम्॥ उवाच दीनो राजा च धनंजयमिदं वचः। प्रमाणमस्मि यदि ते मत्तः शृणु वचोऽनघ॥
English Translation: The Sudharma (the assembly-hall) of the Dasharhas (Vrishnis)-nay even the abode of Brahma was not so grand and endued with so much beauty as this assembly-hall built by the intelligent Maya.

Sanskrit Shloka: अनुप्रवेशे यद् वीर कृतवांस्त्वं मम प्रियम्। सर्वं तदनुजानामि व्यलीकं न च मे हृदि॥
English Translation: Being appointed by Maya, eight thousand Rakshasas, named Kinkaras, guarded and supported this assembly-hall.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गुरोरनुप्रवेशो हि नोपघातो यवीयसः। यवीयसोऽनुप्रवेशो ज्येष्ठभ्य विधिलोपकः॥
English Translation: They were capable of ranging the sky, they were fearful, huge-bodied, and greatly strong; they had blood-like red and coppery eyes and arrowy-ears, they were all well-armed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निवर्तस्व महाबाहो कुरुष्व वचनं मम। न हि ते धर्मलोपोऽस्ति न च ते धर्षणा कृता॥
English Translation: In that assembly-hall Maya built a matchless tank, and in that tank were lilies with leaves made of dark-coloured gems and with stalks made of brilliant gems; there were also other aquatic flowers of golden leaves. Various kinds of water-fowls played in its water; it was adorned with full-blossomed lotuses; its water was transparent; and golden-coloured tortoises and fishes played in its bottom which was without mud. A flight of crystal steps rose from the edge of the water to the banks,

Sanskrit Shloka: अर्जुन उवाच न व्याजेन चरेद् धर्ममिति मे भवतः श्रुतम्। न सत्याद् विचलिष्यामि सत्येनायुधमालभे॥
English Translation: The gentle breeze shook the flowers that sudden its waters; its banks were adorned with costly marble slabs set with pearls.

Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच सोऽभ्यनुज्ञाय राजानं वनचर्याय दीक्षितः। वने द्वादश वर्षाणि वासायानुजगाम ह॥
English Translation: Seeing that tank thus adorned with jewels and precious stones, many kings that came there mistook it for land, and they fell into it with their eyes open.

Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच आनृशंस्यस्य धर्मज्ञ गुणान् भक्तजनस्य च। श्रोतुमिच्छामि धर्मज्ञ तन्मे ब्रूहि पितामह॥
English Translation: The assembly-hall was adorned with many charming, large and ever blossoming trees with green foliage and cool-shade.

Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच अत्राप्युदाहरन्तीममितिहासं पुरातनम्। वासवस्य च संवादं शुकस्य च महात्मनः॥
English Translation: And with many gardens, emitting a delicious fragrance. There was many tanks adorned with swans, Karandavas and Chakravakas. The breezes carried the fragrance of lotuses that grew in the waters and flowers that grew in the land and ministered to the pleasures of the Pandavas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विषये काशिराजस्य ग्रामानिष्क्रम्य लुब्धकः। सविषं काण्डमादाय मृगयामास वै मृगम्॥
English Translation: O king, having built such an assembly-hall in fourteen months, Maya informed Dharmaraja (Yudhishthira) that it had been completed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्र चामिषलुब्धेन लुब्धकेन महावने। अविदूरे मृगान् दृष्ट्वा बाणः प्रतिसमाहितः॥
English Translation: Bhishma said Thus addressed by Indra, Matanga refused to hear what he was commanded. On the other hand, with regulated vows and purified soul, he practised austerer penances by standing on one foot for a thousand years, being deeply engaged in Yoga-meditation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेन दुर्वारितास्त्रेण निमित्तचपलेषुणा। महान् वनतरुस्तत्र विद्धो मृगजिघांसया॥
English Translation: After a thousand years had passed away, Shakra once more came to see him. Indeed the destroyer of Vala and Vritra laid to him the same words.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तीक्ष्णविषदिग्धेन शरेणातिवलात् क्षतः। उत्सृज्य फलपत्राणि पादपः शोषमागतः॥
English Translation: Matanga said I have passed these thousand years, standing on one foot, with soul engaged in meditation and in the observance of the vow of celibacy. Why is it that I have not yet succeeded in acquiring the dignity of a Brahmana?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मिन् वृक्षे तथाभूते कोटरेषु चिरोषितः। न जहाति शुको वासं तस्य भक्त्या वनस्पतेः॥
English Translation: Shakra said One born as a Chandala cannot, by any means, acquire the dignity of a Brahmana. Do you, therefore, name some other boon so that all this labour of yours may not prove futile! Thus addressed by the king of the celestials, Matanga became filled with grief. He went to Gaya, and passed there a century of years, standing all the while on one foot.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निष्प्रचारो निराहारो ग्लान: शिथिलवागपि। कृतज्ञः सह वृक्षण धर्मात्मा सोऽप्यशुष्यत॥
English Translation: On account of the observance of such Yoga which was extremely difficult to bear, he became very much emaciated and his arteries and veins became swollen and visible. He was reduced to only skin and bones. We have heard that righteous person, while practising those austerities at Gaya, dropped down on the ground from sheer exhaustion.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमुदारं महासत्त्वमतिमानुषचेष्टितम्। समदुःखसुखं दृष्ट्वा विस्मित: पाकशासनः॥
English Translation: Seeing him falling down the lord and giver of boons, engaged in the behoof of all creatures viz., Vasava, speedily came to that spot and held him fast.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततश्चिन्तामुपगतः शक्रः कथमयं द्विजः। तिर्यग्योनावसम्भाव्यमानृशंस्यमवस्थितः॥
English Translation: Shakra said It seems, O Matanga , that the dignity of a Brahmana which you seek is illsuited to you. That dignity is incapable of being acquired by you. Indeed in your case, it is beset with many dangers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथवा नात्र चित्रं हि अभवद् वासवस्य तु। प्राणिनामपि सर्वेषां सर्वं सर्वत्र दृश्यते॥
English Translation: A person by adoring a Brahmana acquires happiness; while by abstaining from such worship, he gets grief and misery. The Brahmana is as regards all creatures, the giver of what they prize or covet and the protector of what they already have.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो ब्राह्मणवेषेण मानुषं रूपमास्थितः। अवतीर्य महीं शक्रस्तं पक्षिणमुवाच ह॥
English Translation: It is through the Brahmanas that the departed manes and the deities become pleased. The Brahmana, O Matanga, is said to be the foremost of all created Beings. The Brahmana grants all objects which are desired and in the way they are desired.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शुक भो पक्षिणां श्रेष्ठ दाक्षेयी सुप्रजा त्वया। पृच्छे त्वां शुकमेनं त्वं कस्मान्न त्यजसि दुमम्॥
English Translation: Passing through numberless orders of being and undergoing repeated rebirths, one succeeds in some subsequent birth in acquiring the dignity of a Brahmana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ पृष्टः शुकः प्राह मूर्धा समभिवाद्य तम्। स्वागतं देवराज त्वं विज्ञातस्तपसा मया॥
English Translation: That dignity is really incapable of being obtained by persons of impure souls. Do you, therefore, relinquish the idea Do you name some other boon. The particular boon which you seek is incapable of being granted to you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो दशशताक्षेण साधु साध्विति भाषितम्। अहो विज्ञानमित्येवं मनसा पूजितस्ततः॥
English Translation: Matanga said Stricken as I am with grief, why, O Shakra, do you afflict me further? You are striking one that is already dead, by this conduct. I do not pity you who having acquired the dignity of a Brahmana fail to retain it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमेवं शुभकर्माणं शुकं परमधार्मिकम्। विजानन्नपि तां प्रीतिं पप्रच्छ बलसूदनः॥
English Translation: Those who having won the dignity of a Brahmana that, like wealth, is so difficult to acquire, do not seek to keep it up, must be considered as the most wretched in this world. Indeed, they are the most sinful of all creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निष्पत्रमफलं शुष्कमशरण्यं पतत्रिणाम्। किमर्थं सेवसे वृक्षं यदा महदिदं वनम्॥ अन्येऽपि बहवो वृक्षाः पत्रसंच्छन्नकोटराः। पर्याप्तसंचारा विद्यन्तेऽस्मिन् महावने॥
English Translation: Forsooth, the dignity of a Brahmana is highly difficult to attain, and being attained, is difficult to maintain, it is capable of removing every sort of grief. Alas, having got it men do not always seek to keep it up.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गतायुषमसामर्थ्य क्षीणसारं हतश्रियम्। विमृश्य प्रज्ञया धीर जहीमं स्थविरं दुमम्॥
English Translation: When even such persons are considered as Brahmanas, why is it that I, who am pleased with my own self, who am superior to all pairs of opposites, who am dissociated from all worldly objects, who am observant of the duty of mercy towards all creatures and of selfcontrol of conduct, should be considered worthy of that dignity?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच तदुपश्रुत्य धर्मात्मा शुकः शक्रेण भाषितम्। शुभाः पर्या सुदीर्घमतिनिःश्वस्य दीनो वाक्यमुवाच ह॥ अनतिक्रमणीयानि दैवतानि शचीपते। यत्राभवत् तव प्रश्नस्तन्निबोध सुराधिप॥
English Translation: not How unfortunate I am, O Purandara, that through the sin of my mother I have been reduced to this plight, although I am not unrighteous in my conduct?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अस्मिन्नहं दुमे जातः साधुभिश्च गुणैर्युतः। बालभावेन संगुप्तः शत्रुभिश्च न धर्षितः॥
English Translation: Forsooth, Destiny is incapable of being warded off or conquered by individual exertion since, O lord, I am unable to acquire, despite these.persistent attempts of mine the object for the acquisi.ion of which I am trying.

Sanskrit Shloka: त्वमेव दैवतैः सर्वैः पृच्छसे धर्मसंशयात्। अतस्त्वं देवदेवानामाधिपत्ये प्रतिष्ठितः॥
English Translation: Matanga said Gifted with the power of assuming any form at will, let me be able to journey through the skies and let me enjoy whatever pleasures I may wish for. And let me also have the willing worship of both Brahmanas and Kshatriyas.

Sanskrit Shloka: नार्हसे मां सहस्त्राक्ष दुमं त्याजयितुं चिरात्। समर्थमुपजीव्येमं त्यजेयं कथमद्य वै॥ तस्य वाक्येन सौम्येन हर्षित: पाकशासनः। शुकं प्रोवाच धर्मात्मा आनृशंस्येन तोषितः॥

English Translation: You may thus see, O Bharata that the dignity of a Brahmana is very high. That dignity is incapable of being acquired here as said by the great Indra himself.

Sanskrit Shloka: एवमेव मनुष्येन्द्र भक्तिमन्तं समाश्रितः। सर्वार्थसिद्धिं लभते शुकं प्राप्य यथा द्रुमः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : O Janamejaya, having received information of the assent (of Yudhishthira) and learning that the maiden had gone on the Raivataka (hill), Dhananjaya (Arjuna). That best of the Bharata race, obtained the assent of Vasudeva (Krishna) and also settled in consultation with him all that was to be done.

Sanskrit Shloka: शिशुपाल उवाच स मे बहुमतो राजा जरासंधो महाबलः। योऽनेन युद्धं नेयेष दासोऽयमिति संयुगे॥
English Translation: That best of men (Arjuna), attired in armour and armed with the sword and his figures encased in leather fences, set out as if in a hunting excursion on his (Krishna's) wellbuilt golden car, adorned with rows of small bells and equipped with every kind of weapon. The clatter of its wheels resembled the roars of clouds; its splendour was as that of a blazing fire; it struck terror into the hearts of all foes; and the two horses yoked with it were named Sugriva and Shaivya.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: केशवेन कृतं कर्म जरासंधवधे तदा। भीमसेनार्जुनाभ्यां च कस्तत् साध्विति मन्यते॥
English Translation: Subhadra, having worshipped that king of hills, Raivataka and the celestials and having been blessed by all the Brahmanas, and having walked round the hill, was returning towards Dwarka. The son of Kunti, struck by the arrows of the god of love, suddenly rushed towards that faultless featured Subhadra and forcibly took her upon his chariot.

Sanskrit Shloka: अद्वारेण प्रविष्टेन छद्मना ब्रह्मवादिना। दृष्टः प्रभावः कृष्णेन जरासंधस्य भूपतेः॥
English Translation: Thereupon that best of men, having seized that lady of sweet-smiles, proceeded (in haste) on his golden car towards his own city (Indraprastha).

English Translation: Seeing Subhadra thus forcibly carried away, her armed attendants all ran crying towards the city of Dvarka.

Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच तस्य तद् वचनं श्रुत्वा रूक्षं रूक्षाक्षरं बहु। चुकोप बलिनां श्रेष्ठो भीमसेनः प्रतापवान्॥
English Translation: When they were all seated like an assembly of celestials, the Sabhapala with his followers narrated all about the conduct of Jishnu (Arjuna).

Sanskrit Shloka: त्रिशिखां भृकुटीं चास्य ददृशुः सर्वपार्थिवाः। भूयः ललाटस्थां त्रिकूटस्थां गङ्गां त्रिपथगामिव॥

English Translation: While their cars, their armours and their standards were being brought, the uproars of those heroes became exceedingly great.

Sanskrit Shloka: उत्पतन्तं तु वेगेन जग्राहैनं मनस्विनम्। भीष्म एव महाबाहुर्महासेनमिवेश्वरः॥
English Translation: Then proud and intoxicated with wine, Baladeva, who was like the Kailasa mountain, adorned with the garlands of wild flowers and attired in blue robes, thus spoke to all.

Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य भीमस्य भीष्मेण वार्यमाणस्य भारत। गुरुणा विविधैर्वाक्यैः क्रोधः प्रशममागतः॥
English Translation: O senseless men, what are you doing when Janardana (Krishna) is sitting silent? Without knowing what is in his heart, you are vainly roaring in wrath.

English Translation: Silence have been restored by the words of the intelligent Baladeva, they again all took their seats in that court.

English Translation: Is there a man born of a respectable family who will break the very plate after having dined off it?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततश्चेदिपतेर्वाक्यं श्रुत्वा तत् कुरुसत्तमः। भीमसेनमुवाचेदं भीष्मो मतिमतां वरः॥
English Translation: Even if one desires to have such an alliance, who is there who desiring happiness will act so rashly remembering the services he has received?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच युधिष्ठिरस्य नृपतेर्दुर्योधनपितुस्तदा। नान्तरं ददृशू राज्ये पुरुषाः प्रणयं प्रति॥
English Translation: By insulting us and disregarding Keshava (Krishna) he has carried away Subhadra by force wishing to compass his own death.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदा तु कौरवो राजा पुत्रं सस्मार दुर्मतिम्। तदा भीमं हृदा राजन्नपध्याति स पार्थिवः॥
English Translation: He has placed his foot on my head. O Govinda, how shall I bear it, (shall I not resent it) like a snake trodden by foot?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथैव भीमसेनोऽपि धृतराष्ट्र जनाधिपम्। नामर्षयत राजेन्द्र सदैव दुष्टवद्धदा॥
English Translation: I shall alone to-day make the earth free of all Kauravas. Never shall I put up with this insult offered to us by Arjuna."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अप्रकाशान्यप्रियाणि चकारास्य वृकोदरः। आज्ञा प्रत्यहरच्चापि कृतज्ञैः पुरुषैः सदा॥
English Translation: Thereupon all the Bhojas, Vrishnis and the Andhakas, assembled there approved of every thing that Baladeva said and they roared like the sounds of kettledrum or the clouds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्मरन् दुर्मन्त्रितं तस्य वृत्तान्यप्यस्य कानिचित्। अथ भीमः सुहृन्मध्ये बाहुशब्दं तथाकरोत्॥ संश्रवे धृतराष्ट्रस्य गान्धार्याश्चाप्यमर्षणः। स्मृत्वा दुर्योधनं शत्रु कर्णदुःशासनावपि॥ प्रोवाचेदं सुरंब्धो भीमः स परुषं वचः।
English Translation: How should a righteous king, who wishes to follow the ways of righteousness, behave? I ask you this, O foremost of men! Answer me, O grand-father!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्धस्य नृपतेः पुत्रा मया परिघबाहुना॥ नीता लोकममुं सर्वे नानाशस्त्रास्त्रयोधिनः।
English Translation: Regarding it is cited the old story of what the highly intelligent Vamadeva acquainted with the true import of everything sang in days of yore.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इमौ तौ परिघप्रख्यौ भुजौ मम दुरासदौ॥ ययोरन्तरमासाद्य धार्तराष्ट्राः क्षयं गताः।
English Translation: Once upon a time, king Vasumanas, endued with knowledge, fortitude, purity of conduct, asked the great Rishi Vamadeva of great ascetic merit, sayingधर्मार्थसहितैर्वाक्यैर्भगवन्ननुशाधि माम्।
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ताविमौ चन्दनेनाक्तौ चन्दना) च मे भुजौ॥ याभ्यां दुर्योधनो नीतः क्षयं ससुतबान्धवः।
English Translation: Instruct me, O holy one, in words fraught with fairness and great significance as to what that conduct is by observing which I may not deviate from the duties prescribed for me!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एताश्चान्याश्च विविधाः शल्यभूता नराधिपः॥ वृकोदरस्य ता वाचः श्रुत्वा निर्वेदमागमत्।
English Translation: To him having a golden hue and seated at his ease like Yayati the son of Nahusha, that foremost of ascetics, viz., Vamadeva of great energy, said as follows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सा च बुद्धिमती देवी कालपर्यायवेदिनी॥ गान्धारी सर्वधर्मज्ञा तान्यलीकानि शुश्रुवे।
English Translation: Vamadeva said Do you act righteously. There is nothing superior to Righteousness. The righteous kings succeed in conquering the whole Earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः पञ्चदशे वर्षे समतीते नराधिपः॥ राजा निर्वेदमापेदे भीमवाग्बाणपीडितः।
English Translation: That king who considers Righteousness as the most effectual instrument for accomplishing his objects, and who follows the advice of the righteous, shines with righteousness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नान्वबुध्यत तद् राजा कुन्तीपुत्रो युधिष्ठिरः॥ श्वेताश्वो वाथ कुन्ती वा द्रौपदी वा यशस्विनी। माद्रीपुत्रौ च धर्मज्ञौ चित्तं तस्यान्ववर्तताम्॥
English Translation: That king who neglects Righteousness and wishes to act with brute force, soon falls away from Righteousness and loses both Virtue and Profit.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राज्ञस्तु चित्तं रक्षन्तौ नोचतुः किञ्चिदप्रियम्। ततः समानयामास धृतराष्ट्रः सुहृज्जनम्॥ वाष्पसंदिग्धमन्यर्थमिदमाह च तान् भृशम्।
English Translation: That king who follows the advice of a vicious and sinful minister becomes a destroyer of righteousness and deserves to be killed by his subjects with all his family. Indeed, he very soon meets with destruction,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच विदितं भवतामेतद् यथा वृत्तः कुरुक्षयः॥ ममापराधात् तत् सर्वमनुज्ञातं च कौरवैः।
English Translation: That king who cannot satisfy his royal duties, who is governed by caprice in all his acts, and who vaunts, soon meets with destruction even if he happen to be the king of whole Earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: योऽहं दुष्टमतिं मन्दो ज्ञातीनां भयवर्धनम्॥ दुर्योधनं कौरवाणामाधिपत्यऽभ्यषेचयम्।
English Translation: That king, however, who seeks prosperity, who is shorn of malice, who has his senses under restraint, and who is endued with intelligence, rolls in wealth like the ocean swelling with the waters put into it by a hundred rivers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यच्चाहं वासुदेवस्य नाश्रौषं वाक्यमर्थवत्॥ वध्यतां साध्वयं पापः सामात्य इति दुर्मतिः। पुत्रस्नेहाभिभूतस्तु हितमुक्तो मनीषिभिः॥ विदुरेणाथ भीष्मेण द्रोणेन च कृपेण च। पदे पदे भगवता व्यासेन च महात्मना॥ संजयेनाथ गान्धार्या तदिदं तप्यते च माम्।
English Translation: He should never consider himself as possessing enough of Virtue, enjoyment, wealth, intelligence, and friends.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यच्चाहं पाण्डुपुत्रेषु गुणवत्सु महात्मसु॥ न दत्तवाश्रियं दीप्तां पितृपैतामहीमिमाम्।
English Translation: Upon these depends the word. By listening to this advice, a king acquires fame, great deeds, prosperity and subjects.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विनाशं पश्यमानो हि सर्वराज्ञां गदाग्रजः॥ एतच्छ्रेयस्तु परमममन्यत जनार्दनः।
English Translation: Being virtuous that king, who tries to acquire virtue and wealth by such means, and who undertakes all his measures after thinking upon their objects, succeeds in acquiring great prosperity.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सोऽहमेतान्यलीकानि निवृत्तान्यान्मनस्तदा।।२३। हृदये शल्यभूतानि धारयामि सहस्रशः।
English Translation: That king, who is illiberal, and shorn of affection, who oppresses his subjects by undue punishment, and who is rash in his acts, soon meets with destruction.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विशेषतस्तु पश्यामि वर्षे पञ्चदरोऽद्य वै॥ अस्य पापस्य शुद्ध्यर्थं नियतोऽस्मि सुदुर्मतिः।
English Translation: That king, who is not intelligent, fails to see his own faults. Best with infamy here, he sinks into hell hereafter.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चतुर्थे नियते काले कदाचिदपि चाष्टमे॥ तृष्णाविनयनं भुजे गान्धारी वेद तन्मम।
English Translation: If the king honours them properly that deserve it, makes gifts, and recognises the value of sweet speeches by himself uttering them always, his subjects then remove the calamities that overtake him as if these had fallen upon themselves.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: करोत्याहारमिति मां सर्वः परिजनः सदा॥ युधिष्ठिरभयादेति भृशं तप्यति पाण्डवः।
English Translation: The king, who has none to instruct him in the ways of righteousness and who never seeks advice from others, and who seeks to acquire wealth by means that caprice suggests, never enjoys happiness long.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भूमौ शये जप्यपरो दर्भेष्वजिनसंवृतः॥ नियमव्यपदेशेन गान्धारी च यशस्विनी।
English Translation: That king, on the other hand, who follows the advice of his preceptors in matters of virtue, who supervises the affairs of his kingdom himself, and who in all his acquisitions follows virtue, succeeds in enjoying happiness for a long time.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हतं शतं तु पुत्राणां ययोर्युद्धेऽपलायिनाम्॥ नानुतप्यामि तच्चाहं क्षत्रधर्म हि ते विदुः।
English Translation: Dhritarashtra said Our army is possessed of many excellencies; and it is composed of various kinds of troops; its efficiency is great. O Sanjaya, it is disposed of in order in perfect accordance to the rules of military science and it is strong in numbers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्युक्त्वा धर्मराजानमभ्यभाषत कौरवः॥ भद्रं ते यादवीमातर्वचश्चेदं निबोध मे।
English Translation: The warriors therein are ever well-treated by us and they are attached to us very much. The army is not newly recruited and its aspect is wonderful. Its efficiency has been tested previously.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुखमसम्युषितः पुत्र त्वया सुपरिपालितः॥ महादानानि दत्तानि श्राद्धानि च पुनः पुनः।
English Translation: The warriors belonging to it are neither very old, nor very young; they are neither lean nor very corpulent. They are of active habits, well-built, strong-bodied and free from any disease. They are clad in cuirasses and wellequipped with offensive weapons. They are accomplished in the use of various weapons and are well practised in the exercise of all kinds of weapons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रकृष्टं च यया पुत्र पुण्यं चीर्णं यथाबलम्॥ गान्धारी हतपुत्रेयं धैर्येणोदीक्षते च माम्।
English Translation: They are experts in mountain upon and descending from vehicles, in moving forward and in falling back, in striking down effectually and in advancing and retreating.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्रौपद्या ह्यपकर्तारस्तव चैश्वर्यहारिणः॥ समतीता नृशंसास्ते स्वधर्मेण हता युधि।
English Translation: They have before been examined in the management of steeds, elephants and cars; and after due examination, they have been employed on pay.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न तेषु प्रतिकर्तव्यं पश्यामि कुरुनन्दन॥ सर्वे शस्त्रभृतां लोकान् गतास्तेऽभिमुखं हताः।
English Translation: And no for the sake of family relationship, nor from favour, nor from kinship. They have not come uncalled for, nor are they unpaid soldicrs.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आत्मनस्तु हितं पुण्यं प्रतिकर्तव्यमद्य वै॥ गान्धार्याश्चैव राजेन्द्र तदनुज्ञातुमर्हसि।
English Translation: They are high-born, respectable, evercontented, well-fed and submissive. They have been duly honoured and rewarded by ourselves. They are all endued with fame and intelligence.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वं तु शस्त्रभृतां श्रेष्ठः सततं धर्मवत्सलः॥ राजा गुरुः प्राणभृतां तस्मादेतद् ब्रवीम्यहम्।
English Translation: They again, O sire, are defended by our best warriors and other's of pious practices, all of whom are foremost men and resemble the Lokapalas themselves.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनुज्ञातस्त्वया वीर संश्रयेयं वनान्यहम्॥ चीरवल्कलभृद् राजन् गान्धार्या सहितोऽनया।
English Translation: Numerous kings solicitous of our welfare, who have, out of their own accord, joined us with all their forces and followers, also defend them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तवाशिषः प्रयुञ्जानो भविष्यामि वनेचरः॥ उचितं नः कुले तात सर्वेषां भरतर्षभ। पुत्रेष्वैश्वर्यमाधाय वयसोऽन्ते वनं नृप॥ तत्राहं वायुभक्षो वा निराहारोऽपि वा वसन्। पल्या सहानया वीर चरिष्यामि तपः परम्॥
English Translation: Truly our army is like the vast ocean swelling with the waters of various stream flowing into it from all sides. It teems with chariot and steeds, which though devoid of wings are still capable of moving through the air like the winged rangers of the sky.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वं चापि फलभाक् तात तपसः पार्थिवो ह्यसि। फलभाजो हि राजानः कल्याणस्येतरस्य वा॥
English Translation: My army abounds in elephants with the temporal juice flowing down their cheeks. Then to what else, but Destiny, can the slaughter of such an army be attributed?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच न मां प्रीणयते राज्यं त्वय्येवं दुःखिते नृप। धिङ्नामस्तु सुदुर्बुद्धिं राज्यसक्तं प्रमादिनम्॥
English Translation: (Ocean-like as our arrmy is), numerous warriors constitute its waters; and the various vehicles constitute its dreadful and surging waves. Innumerable maces, swords, darts, shafts and javelins constitute the oars plied on it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: योऽहं भवन्तं दुःखार्तमुपवासकृशं भृशम्। जिनाहारं क्षितिशयं न विन्दे भ्रातृभिः सह॥
English Translation: Teeming with standards and ornaments, the combatants form the lotuses on it. The swiftmoving steeds and elephants and chargers constitute the tempest that lashes in into fury.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अहोऽस्मि वञ्चितो मूढो भवता गूढबुद्धिना। विश्वासयित्वा पूर्वं मां यदिदं दुःखमश्नुथाः॥
English Translation: Drona forms its fathomless cave, Kritavarman its minghty lake and Jalasandha its dreadful alligator and Karna, the rising of the moon that makes it swell with pride and energy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किं मे राज्येन भोगैर्वा किं यज्ञैः किं सुखेन वा। यस्य मे त्वं महीपाल दुःखान्येतान्यवाप्तवान्॥
English Translation: O Sanjaya, on a single car that foremost of the Pandavas viz., Arjuna has gone piercing through my ocean-like host and Yuyudhana also has followed him;
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पीडितं चापि जानामि राज्यमान्मानमेव च। अनेन वचसा तुभ्यं दुःखितस्य जनेश्वर॥
English Translation: And O Sanjaya, when Savyasachin has thus penetrated into my host and also that excellent car-warrior Satyaki of the Satvata race has done so, I do not think that any one of my troops will be able to escape with his life.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भवान् पिता भवान् माता भवान् नः परमो गुरुः। भवता विप्रहीणा वै क्व नु तिष्ठामहे वयम्॥
English Translation: Beholding those two heroes dash with speed through the vanguards of my troops and seeing the ruler of the Sindhus come within range of arrows shot from the Gandiva bow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: औरसो भवतः पुत्रो युयुत्सुनृपसत्तम। अस्तु राजा महाराज यमन्यं मन्यते भवान्॥
English Translation: What course of action did the Kurus, goaded on to destruction by Fate then adopt? What became of them at that hour when the battle raged with fury?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अहं वनं गमिष्यामि प्रशासतु। न मामयशसा दग्धं भूयस्त्वं दग्धुमर्हसि॥
English Translation: O son, I consider the assembled Kaurava host already within the jaws of Death. Their prowess in battle is no longer seen to be what it once was.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नाहं राजा भवान् राजा भवतः परवानहम्। कथं गुरुं त्वां धर्मज्ञमनुज्ञातुमिहोत्सहे॥
English Translation: Krishna and the son of Pandu have both entered into our troops, receiving not even the slightest wound. O Sanjaya, there is none also who can resist them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भवान् राज्य न मन्युर्हदि नः कश्चित् सुयोधनकृतेऽनघ। भवितव्यं तथा तद्धि वयं चान्ये च मोहिताः॥
English Translation: Many mighty car-warriors and combatants have been admitted into our army after due examination. They all have been gratified by us with due remunerations and agreeable speeches.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वयं पुत्रा हि भवतो यथा दुर्योधनादयः। गान्धारी चैव कुन्ती च निर्विशेषे मते मम॥
English Translation: There is none among my troops who has been maltreated. Every one receives his pay and ration, according to his abilities.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स मां त्वं यदि राजेन्द्र परित्यज्य गमिष्यसि। पृष्ठतस्त्वनुयास्यामि सत्यमात्मानमालभे॥
English Translation: O Sanjaya, there is none who is not a good warrior, none who receives remuneration less then what he deserves or none who receives no pay.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इयं हि वसूसम्पूर्णा मही सागरमेखला। भवता विप्रहीणस्य न मे प्रीतिकरी भवेत्॥
English Translation: The soldiers are honoured by me to the best of my resources, with gifts, honors and seats. My sons, relatives and my kinsmen, O son, all treat them in the same respectful manner as I do.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भवदीयमिदं सर्वं शिरसा त्वां प्रसादये। त्वदधीनाः स्म राजेन्द्र व्येतु ते मानसो ज्वरः॥
English Translation: Even such troops, encountering Savayasachin in battle, are being vanquished by him; they are also being crushed by the grand son of Sini; what can it be but Destiny?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भवितव्यमनुप्राप्तो मन्ये त्वं वसुधाधिप। दिष्ट्या शुश्रूषमाणस्त्वां मोक्षिष्ये मनसो ज्वरम्।।५५
English Translation: Those who are protecting and those who are protected, are following the same road, the dcfender and the defended!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच तापस्ये मे मनस्तात वर्तते कुरुनन्दन। उचितं च कुलेऽस्माकमरण्यगमनं प्रभो॥
English Translation: Beholding Arjuna stand before the ruler of the Sindhus in hostile attitude, what measure did my highly foolish son adopt?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चिरमसम्युषितः पुत्र चिरं शुश्रूषितस्त्वया। वृद्धं मामप्यनुज्ञातुमर्हसि त्वं नराधिप॥
English Translation: Beholding also Satyaki dash through his troops like one fearless, what measures also did Duryodhana consider to be suitable to the situation?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच इत्युक्त्वा धर्मराजानं वेपमानं कृताञ्जलिम्। उवाच वचनं राजा धृतराष्ट्रोऽम्बिकासुतः॥ संजयं च महात्मानं कृपं चापि महारथम्। अनुनेनुमिहेच्छामि भवद्भिर्वसुधाधिपम्॥
English Translation: Beholding those two foremost of carwarriors, both beyond the reach of all weapons, thus penetrate into my host, what resolution did my troops then form
---
Sanskrit Shloka: म्लायते मे मनो हीदं मुखं च परिशुष्यति। वयसा च प्रकृष्टेन वाग्व्यायामेन चैव ह॥
English Translation: Meseems, beholding Krishna of the Dasarha race and that foremost of the Sinis, both exerting for the sake of Arjuna, my sons are giving way to grief.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्युक्त्वा स तु धर्मात्मा वृद्धो राजा कुरुद्वहः। गान्धारी शिश्रिये धीमान् सहसैव गतासुवत्॥
English Translation: Beholding him of the Satvata race and Arjuna pass through my divisions and beholding the Kurus fly in all directions, Meseems, my sons are giving way to grief.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं तु दृष्ट्वा समासीनं विसंज्ञमिव कौरवम्। आर्ति राजागमत् तीव्रां कौन्तेयः परवीरहा॥
English Translation: Meseems my sons are giving way to grief, beholding the car-warriors routed and hopeless of conquering their foes and exert themselves in flying away.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच यस्य नागसहस्रेण शतसंख्येन वै बलम्। सोऽयं नारी व्यपाश्रित्य शेते राजा गतासुवत्॥
English Translation: Meseems my sons are giving way to grief, beholding the terraces of cars made empty by Satvata and Arjuna and also beholding the warriors slain (by thousands).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आयसी प्रतिमा येन भीमसेनस्य सा पुरा। चूर्णीकृता बलवता सोऽबलामाश्रितः स्त्रियम्॥
English Translation: Meseems my sons are lamenting, beholding the steeds, the chariots, the elephants and thousands of heroic soldiers flying away in haste from the field of battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धिगस्तु मामधर्मज्ञं धिग् बुद्धिं धिक् च मे श्रुतम्। यत्कृते पृथिवीपाल: शेतेऽयमतथोचितः॥
English Translation: Meseems my sons are lamenting beholding the huge elephants of my army fly away smitten by the arrows of Arjuna and also beholding them fallen and falling.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अहमप्युपवत्स्यामि यथैवायं गुरुर्मम। यदि राजा न भुङ्क्तेऽयं गान्धारी च यशस्विनी॥
English Translation: Meseems my sons are lamenting seeing steeds deprived of riders and warriors deprived of chariots, by Arjuna and Satyaki.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच ततोऽस्य पाणिना राजन् जलशीतेन पाण्डवः। उरो मुखं च शनकैः पर्यमार्जत धर्मवित्॥
English Translation: Mescems my sons are lamenting seeing large bodies of steeds slain and routed in all directions in battle, by the son of Pritha and the descendant of Madhu's race.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेन रत्नौषधिमता पुण्येन च सुगन्धिना। पाणिस्पर्शन राज्ञः स राजा संज्ञामवाप ह॥
English Translation: Meseems my sons are lamenting, hopeless of their victory, by seeing the divisions of infantry fly with haste in all direction.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच स्पृश मां पाणिना भूयः परिष्वज च पाण्डव। जीवामीवातिसंस्पर्शात् तव राजीवलोचन॥
English Translation: Meseems my sons are lamenting beholding those two invincible heroes pass in a moment through the division of Drona.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मूर्धानं च तवाघ्रातुमिच्छामि मनुजाधिप। पाणिभ्यां हि परिस्प्रष्टुं प्रीणनं हि महन्मम॥
English Translation: O son, I am indeed overwhelmed with a stupor upon hearing that Krishna and Arjuna of unfading glory together with Satyaki of the Satvata race, have entered into my divisions.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अष्टमो ह्यद्य कालोऽयमाहारस्य कृतस्य मे। येनाहं कुरुशार्दूल शक्नोमि न विचेष्टितुम्॥
English Translation: When that foremost of car-warriors among the Sinis had plunged into my host and when he had passed through the Bhoja division, what, O Sanjaya, did the Kurus do?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यायामश्चायमत्यर्थे कृतस्त्वामभियाचता। ततो ग्लानमनास्तात नष्टसंज्ञ इवाभवम्॥
English Translation: O Sanjaya, relate to me also how the battle raged there where Drona began to crush the Pandava host in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तवामृतरसप्रख्यं हस्तस्पर्शमिमं प्रभो। लब्धा संजीवितोऽस्मीति मन्ये कुरुकुलोद्वह॥
English Translation: Drona was a warrior of superior skill; he was endued with strength, accomplished in the use of weapons and indomitable in battle. How was it then possible for the Panchalas to pierce that hero in battle?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच एवमुक्तस्तु कौन्तेयः पित्रा ज्येष्ठेन भारत। पस्पर्श सर्वगात्रेषु सौहार्दात् तं शनैस्तदा॥
English Translation: Solicitious of Dhanajaya's victory, the Panchalas were Drona's implacable foes, so also that mighty car-warrior the son of Bharadvaja was an inveterate enemy of theirs.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उपलभ्य ततः प्राणान् धृतराष्ट्रो महीपतिः। बाहुभ्यां सम्परिष्वज्य मूर्ध्याजिघ्रत पाण्डवम्॥
English Translation: O Sanjaya, skilful as you are in narration, tell me all that in detail which Arjuna did for bringing about the slaughter of the Sindhu king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विदुरादयश्च ते सर्वे रुरुदुदुःखिता भृशम्। अतिदुःखात् तु राजानं नोचुः किंचन पाण्डवम्॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said O foremost of the Bharatas, it behoves you not to lament like an ordinary person, when you are overtaken, O hero, by a calamity which owes its origin to your own misconduct.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गान्धारी त्वेव धर्मज्ञा मनसोद्वहती भृशम्। दुःखान्यधारयाद् राजन् मैवमित्येव चाब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: Formerly, many of your well-wishers including the wise Vidura, advised you saying, "O king, do not forsake the sons of Pandu's but to those advices you paid no heed."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इतरास्तु स्त्रियः सर्वाः कुन्त्या सह सुदुःखिताः। नेत्रैरागतविक्लेदैः परिवार्य स्थिताऽभवन्॥
English Translation: He that sets at nought the advices of wellwishing friends, weeps like yourself when a calamity overtakes him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथाब्रवीत् पुनर्वाक्यं धृतराष्ट्रो युधिष्ठिरम्। अनुजानीहि मां राजस्तापस्ये भरतर्षभ॥
English Translation: O king, the descendant of the Dasarha race entreated you for the conclusion of peace. But the highly-renowned Krishna then did not obtain that boon at your hands.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ग्लायते मे मनस्तात भूयो भूयः प्रजल्पतः। न मामतः परं पुत्र परिक्लेष्टुमिहार्हसि॥
English Translation: Knowing your worthlessness, your partiality for your sons, your duplicity in virtue, your animosity against the sons of Pandu and ascertaining your crooked intentions against them and listening to many of your incoherent and delirious bewailings, 0 foremost of kings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मिंस्तु कौरवेन्द्रे तं तथा ब्रुवति पाण्डवम्। सर्वेषामेव योधानामार्तनादो महानभूत्॥
English Translation: That puissant lord of all the worlds, that one conversant with the truth of everything in the worlds, namely, the son of Vasudeva, caused the drums of war to be sounded among the Kurus.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दृष्ट्वा कृशं विवर्णं च राजानमतथोचितम्। उपवासपरिश्रान्तं त्वगस्थिपरिवारणम्॥ धर्मपुत्रः स्वपितरं परिष्वज्य महाप्रभुम्। शोकजं बाष्पमुत्सृज्य पुनर्वचनमब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: This awful destruction has overtaken you through your own faults; O giver of honour, it behoves you not to lay all blames on the shoulders of Duryodhana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न कामये नरश्रेष्ठ जीवितं पृथिवीं तथा। यथा तव प्रियं राजंश्चिकीर्षामि परंतप॥
English Translation: As these incidents developed themselves, no good action was performed by you either in the beginning, in the middle or in the end, O Bharata. The defeat that can be anticipated now, is entirely owing to your fault.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदि चाहमनुग्राह्यो भवतो दयितोऽपि वा। क्रियतां तावदाहारस्ततो वेत्स्याम्यहं परम्॥
English Translation: Therefore, knowing as you do, the fate of this world, quietly and attentively hear how the battle that resembled that between the gods and the Asuras, took place.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽब्रवीन्महातेजा धृतराष्ट्रो युधिष्ठिरम्। अनुज्ञातस्त्वया पुत्र भुजीयामिति कामये॥
English Translation: When Sini's grandson of invincible prowess had entered into your troops, the troops of the Parthas headed by Bhimasena, fell upon your troops.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इति ब्रुवति राजेन्द्र धृतराष्ट्रे युधिष्ठिरम्। ऋषिः सत्यवतीपुत्रो व्यासोऽभ्येत्य वचोऽब्रवीत्।।८७।
English Translation: Then the mighty car-warrior Kritavarman, single-headed, received in that battle, the enraged Pandava troops who had been rushing to the battle with their followers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच अथाब्रवीन्मयः पार्थमर्जुनं जयतां वरम्। आपृच्छे त्वां गमिष्यामि पुनरेष्यामि चाप्यहम्॥
English Translation: Just as the banks resist the surging waves of the sea, so did the son of Hridika resist the Pandava troops in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उत्तरेण तु कैलासं मैनाकं पर्वतं प्रति। यियक्षमाणेषु पुरा दानवेषु मया कृतम्॥ चित्रं मणिमयं भाण्डं रम्यं बिन्दुसरः प्रति। सभायां सत्यसंधस्य यदासीद् वृषपर्वणः॥
English Translation: Then we beheld the wonderful prowess of Hridika's son inasmuch as the united divisions of the Parthas were unable to bear him down in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आगमिष्यामि तद् गृह्य यदि तिष्ठति भारत। ततः सभां करिष्यामि पाण्डवस्य यशस्विनीम्॥ मनः प्रह्लादिनी चित्रां सर्वरत्नभूषिताम्। अस्ति बिन्दुसरस्युग्रा गदा च कुरुनन्दन॥
English Translation: Thereupon the mighty-armed Bhima piercing Kritavarman with three swift-coursing arrows, blew his conch-shell, imparting thereby delight unto the Pandava troops.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निहिता भावयाम्येवं राज्ञा हत्वा रणे रिपून्। सुवर्णबिन्दुभिश्चित्रा गुर्वी भारसहा दृढा॥
English Translation: Then Sahadeva pierced Hridika's son with twenty, Yudhishthira the virtuous with five and Nakula with a hundred shafts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सा वै शतसहस्रस्य सम्मितां शत्रुघातिनी। अनुरूपा च भीमस्य गाण्डीवं भवतो यथा॥
English Translation: The son of Draupadi pierced him with three and seventy, Ghatotkacha with seven and Dhristadyumna pierced Kritavarman with three arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वारुणश्च महाशङ्खो देवदत्त: सुघोषवान्। सर्वमेतत् प्रदास्यामि भवते नात्र संशयः॥
English Translation: Virata, Drupada and Yajnaseni each pierced him with five shafts, Sikhandin also pierced Hridika's son with five swift flying arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्युक्त्वा सोऽसुरः पार्थं प्रागुदीची दिशं गतः। अथोत्तरेण कैलासान्मनाकं पर्वतं प्रति॥
English Translation: He then once more smilingly pierced him with twenty shafts. Thereupon, Oking, Kritavarman piercing each of these mighty carwarriors separately with five shafts, pierced Bhima with another seven shafts. Then he felled from the latter's car his standard and cutoff his bow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हिरण्यशृङ्गः सुमहान् महामणिमयो गिरिः। रम्यं बिन्दुसरो नाम यत्र राजा भगीरथः॥
English Translation: Then that mighty car-warrior making haste and burning with rage, pierced Bhima whose bow had been severed, on the breast, with seventy sharp arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्रष्टुं भागीरथीं गङ्गामुवास बहुलः समाः। यत्रेष्टं सर्वभूतानामीश्वरेण महात्मना॥
English Translation: That hero (Bhima) endued with prowess, thus deeply pierced by the excellent shafts of Hridika's son, began to tremble in the terrace of his car, like a mountain shaking during an earthquake.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आहृताः क्रतवो मुख्याः शतं भरतसत्तम। यत्र यूपा मणिमयाश्चैत्याश्चापि हिरण्मयाः॥ शोभार्थं विहितास्तत्र न तु दृष्टान्ततः कृताः। अष्ट्वा स गतः सिद्धिं सहस्राक्षः शचीपतिः॥
English Translation: Beholding Bhima thus involved in a dangerous situation, O king, the Pandava warriors headed by Yudhishthira, began to afflict Kritavarman by shooting numerous arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यत्र भूतपतिः सृष्ट्वा सर्वान् लोकान् सनातनः। उपास्यते तिग्मतेजाः स्थितो भूतैः सहस्रशः॥
English Translation: Then impaling Kritavarman within a circle of chariots, the Pandava warriors, O sire, filled with delight, began to wound him with their arrows, out of a desire for rescuing the son of Maruta.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नरनारायणौ ब्रह्मा यमः स्थाणुश्च पञ्चमः। उपासते यत्र सत्रं सहस्रयुगपर्यये॥
English Translation: Thereafter the highly puissant Bhimasena regaining his senses, grasped, in that battle, a dreadful lance of golden staff and iron head.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यत्रेष्टं वासुदेवेन सत्रैर्वर्षगणान् बहून्। श्रद्दधानेन सततं धर्मसम्प्रतिपत्तये॥
English Translation: Then he huried from his own car that lance at the car of Kritavarman, with great force. That lance hurled by the arm of Bhima and resembling a snake that had recently cast off its slough.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुवर्णमालिनो युपाश्चैत्याश्चाप्यतिभास्वराः। ददौ यत्र सहस्राणि प्रयुतानि च केशवः॥
English Translation: began to burn dreadfully as it coursed towards Kritavarman. Then as that lance, effulgent like the fire that appears at the end of a Yugu, was coursing swiftly towards.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्र गत्वा स जग्राह गदां शङ्ख च भारत। स्फाटिकं च सभाद्रव्यं यदासीद् वृषपर्वणः॥
English Translation: The son of Hridika, he cut it in twain with a couple of arrows. That dart decked with golden ornaments, thus severed, fell down on the earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किंकरैः सह रक्षोभिर्यदरक्षन्महद् धनम्। तदगृहणान्मयस्तत्र गत्वा सर्वं महासुरः॥
English Translation: And, O king, it there began to illumine the points of the compass like a mighty meteor dropping from the heavens. Thereat Bhima beholding his lance baffled, became excited to the highest pitch of fury.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदाहृत्य च तां चक्रे सोऽसुरोऽप्रतिमा सभाम्। विश्रुतां त्रिषु लोकेषु दिव्यां मणिमयीं शुभाम्॥
English Translation: Thereafter, taking up another bow of great toughness and emitting loud twang, the enraged Bhimasena in that battle began to resist the son of Hridika.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदां च भीमसेनाय प्रवरां प्रददौ तदा। देवदत्तं चार्जुनाय शङ्खप्रवरमुत्तमम्॥
English Translation: Then, Oking, Bhima of awful prowess, pierced Kritavarman, on the centre of his breast, with five arrows. All this is the result of your wicked policy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यस्य शङ्खस्य नादेन भूतानि प्रचकम्पिरे। सभा च सा महाराज शातकुम्भमयदुमा॥ दशकिष्कुसहस्राणि समन्तादायताभवत्। यथा वह्नर्यथार्कस्य सोमस्य च यथा सभा॥ भ्राजमाना तथात्यर्थं दधार परमं वपुः। अभिघ्नतीव प्रभया प्रभामर्कस्य भास्वराम्॥
English Translation: Then, O sire, the ruler of the Bhojas wounded on all parts of his body, appeared on the field of battle like a red Ashoka tree covered with blossoms.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रबभौ ज्वलमानेव दिव्या दिव्येन वर्चसा। नवमेघप्रतीकाशा दिवमावृत्य विष्ठिता। आयता विपुला रम्या विपाप्मा विगतक्लमा॥ उत्तमद्रव्यसम्पन्ना रत्नप्रकारतोरणा। बहुचित्रा बहुधना सुकृता विश्वकर्मणा।॥
English Translation: Thereafter Kritavarman inflamed with rage, smilingly striking Bhimasena with three arrows, began, in return, to pierce the other warriors (with his arrows).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न दाशार्ही सुधर्मा वा ब्रह्मणो वाथ तादृशी। सभा रूपेण सम्पन्ना यां चक्रे मतिमान् मयः॥
English Translation: That mighty bowman then pierced those car-warriors exerting their best in battle, each with three shafts. They then also pierced him in return, each with seven shafts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तां स्म मयेनोक्ता रक्षन्ति च वहन्ति च। सभामष्टौ सहस्राणि किंकरा नाम राक्षसाः॥
English Translation: Then that mighty car-warrior of the Satvata race, inflamed with rage, smilingly cut-off the bow of Sikhandin with a razor-headed arrow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्तरिक्षचरा घोरा महाकाया महाबलाः। रक्ताक्षाः पिङ्गलाक्षाश्च शुक्तिकर्णाः प्रहारिणः॥
English Translation: Thereupon on the severance of his bow, Sikhandin burning with rage and hastening as much as possible, took up a sword and a buckler decked with hundreds of moons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्यां सभायां नलिनी चकाराप्रतिमां मयः। वैदूर्यपत्रविततां मणिनालमयाम्बुजाम्॥ पद्मसौगन्धिकवतीं नानाद्विजगणायुताम्। पुष्पितैः पङ्कजैश्चित्रां कूतैर्मत्स्यैश्च काञ्चनैः। चित्रस्फटिकसोपानां निष्पङ्कसलिलां शुभाम्॥
English Translation: Whirling that mighty sword decked with gold, Sikhandin hurled it at the chariot of Kritavarman.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मन्दानिलसमुद्भूतां मुक्ताबिन्दुभिराचिताम्। महामणिशिलापट्टबद्धपर्यन्तवेदिकाम्॥
English Translation: O king, then that mighty sword, cutting off his bow with arrows placed on its string, dropped, O king, on the ground like a luminous body falling down from the skies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मणिरत्नचितां तां तु केचिदभ्येत्य पार्थिवाः। दृष्ट्वापि नाभ्यजानन्त तेऽज्ञानात् प्रपतन्त्युत॥
English Translation: Meanwhile many mighty car-warriors, making haste began to pierce Kritavarman deeply and quickly with their arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तां सभामभितो नित्यं पुष्पवन्तो महाद्रुमाः। आसन् नानाविधा लोलाः शीतच्छाया मनोरमाः॥३४
English Translation: Then, O foremost of the Bharatas, taking up a fresh bow and leaving the one cut-off, that slayer of hostile heroes, namely Hridika's son.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: काननानि सुगन्धीनि पुष्करिण्यश्च सर्वशः। हंसकारण्डवोपेताश्चक्रवाकोपशोभिताः॥ जलजानां च पद्यानां स्थलजानां च सर्वशः। मारुतो गन्धमादाय पाण्डवान् स्म निषेवते॥
English Translation: Pierced the Pandavas in battle, each with three straight-flying arrows. He then pierced Sikhandin at first with three and then with five arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ईदृशीं तां सभां कृत्वा मासैः परिचतुर्दशैः। निष्ठितां धर्मराजाय मयो राजन् न्यवेदयत्॥
English Translation: Then the highly renowned Sikhandin also, taking up another bow, covered the son of Hridika with swift-flying arrows. Furnished with heads resembling the mouth of tortoises.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच एवमुक्तो मतङ्गस्तु संशितात्मा यतव्रतः। सहस्रमेकपादेन ततो ध्याने व्यतिष्ठत॥
English Translation: Then, O king, the son of Hridika, excited with wrath, in that battle, quickly rushed upon that mighty car-warrior that son of Yajnasena.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं सहस्रावरे काले शक्रो द्रष्टुमुपागमत्। तदेव च पुनर्वाक्यमुवाच बलवृत्रहा॥
English Translation: Who had been, Oking, the cause of death of the illustrious Bhima. Then the heroic Kritavarman displaying his prowess fell upon Sikhandin like a tiger falling upon an elephant.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मतङ्ग उवाच इदं वर्षसहस्रं वै ब्रह्मचारी समाहितः। अतिष्ठमेकपादेन ब्राह्मण्यं प्राप्नुयां कथम्॥
English Translation: Then those to subduers of foes, resembling two elephants guarding the points of the compass and looking like two blazing fires, attacked each other with their showers of arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शक्र उवाच चण्डालयोनौ जातेन नावाप्यं वै कथंचन। अन्यं कामं वृणीष्व त्वं मा वृथा तेऽस्त्वयं श्रमः॥ एवमुक्तो मतङ्गस्तु भृशं शोकपरायणः। अध्यतिष्ठद्गयां गत्वा सोऽङ्गुष्ठेन शतं समाः॥
English Translation: They stretched their two excellent bows and placed many arrows on their bow-strings. Like two suns shooting numerous rays, they also shot myriad arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुदुर्वहं वहन् योगं कृशो धमनिसंततः। त्वगस्थिभूतो धर्मात्मा स पपातेति नः श्रुतम्॥
English Translation: Those two mighty car-warriors afflicting one another with their sharp-arrows, appeared beautiful like two suns that rise at the end of a Yuga.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं पतन्तमभिदुत्य परिजग्राह वासवः। वराणामीश्वरो दाता सर्वभूतहिते रतः॥
English Translation: In that battle then, Kritavarman pierced that mighty car-warrior the son of Yajanasena at first with seventy three and then again with seven arrowS.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शक्र उवाच मतङ्ग ब्राह्मणत्वं ते विरुद्धमिह दृश्यते। ब्राह्मण्यं दुर्लभतरं संवृतं परिपन्थिभिः॥
English Translation: Thus deeply pierced and extremely pained, the latter squatted down on the terrace of his car; and he lost hold of his arrows and bow and was overwhelmed with a swoon.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पूजयन् सुखपाप्नोति दुःखमाप्नोत्यपूजयन्। ब्राह्मणः सर्वभूतानां योगक्षेमसमर्पिता॥
English Translation: Then your troops, O foremost of men, beholding Sikhandin cheerless in battle, began to applaud Hridika's son and they waived their garments in the air.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणेभ्योऽनुतृप्यन्ते पितरो देवतास्तथा। ब्राह्मणः सर्वभूतानां मतङ्ग पर उच्यते॥
English Translation: Then knowing Sikhandin to be afflicted sore with the arrows of the son of Hridika, his driver, in all haste, carried that mighty carwarrior away from the field of battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणः कुरुते तद्धि यथा यद् यच्च वाञ्छति। बह्वीस्तु संविशन् योनीर्जायमानः पुनः पुनः॥
English Translation: Beholding Sikhandin overthrown on the terrace of his car, the Parthas in that battle quickly surrounded Kritavarman with their chariots.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पर्याये तात कस्मिंश्चिद् ब्राह्मण्यमिह विन्दति। तदुत्सृज्येह दुष्प्रापं ब्राह्मण्यमकृतात्मभिः॥
English Translation: Then the mighty car-warrior Kritavarman filled his enemies with wonder, in asmuch as the alone succeeded in resisting the sons of Pritha and their followers in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मतङ्ग उवाच अन्यं वरं वृणीष्व त्वं दुर्लभोऽयं हि ते वरः। किं मां तुदसि दुःखार्तं मृतं मारयसे च माम्॥
English Translation: Conquering the Parthas, the mighty carwarrior Kritavarman vanquished the Chedis, the Panchaias, the Srinjayas and the valourous Kekayas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वां तु शोचामि यो लब्वा ब्राह्मण्यं न बुभूषसे। ब्राह्मण्यं यदि दुष्प्रापं त्रिभिर्वर्णैः शतक्रतो॥ सुदुर्लभं सदावाप्य नानुतिष्ठन्ति मानवाः। यः पापेभ्यः पापतमस्तेषामधम एव सः॥
English Translation: Thus slaughtered by Hridika's son in battle, the Pandavas began to run hither and thither and they could not then fight steadily.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मण्यं यो न जानीते धनं लब्वेव दुर्लभम्। दुष्प्रापं खलु विप्रत्वं प्राप्तं दुरनुपालनम्॥
English Translation: Conquering the son of Pandu viz., Bhimasena in battle, Hridika's son then remained on the field, like a blazing fire free from even a single curl of smoke.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुरावापमवाप्यैतन्नानुतिष्ठन्ति मानवाः। एकारामो ह्यहं शक्र निर्द्वन्द्वो निष्परिग्रहः॥
English Translation: Those mighty car-warriors routed by the son of Hridika, were compelled to turn their faces leack, afflicted as they were with incessant showers of arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अहिंसादममास्थाय कथं नार्हामि विप्रताम्। दैवं तु कथमेतद् वै यदहं मातृदोषतः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said: After the departure of the Pandavas to the forest, the son of Ambika (Dhritarashtra) whose knowledge was his eye, became exceedingly sorrowful. The King, seated at his case, thus spoke to the virtuous minded and highly intelligent Vidura.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतामवस्थां सम्प्राप्तो धर्मज्ञः सन् पुरंदर। नूनं दैवं न शक्यं हि पौरुषेणातिवर्तितुम्॥
English Translation: Dhritarashtra said: Your intelligence is as great as that of Bhargava (Shukra), you know all the subtleties of holy Dharma. You look on all the Kurus with and equal eye. Tell me what is good for me and for them (the Kurus).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदर्थे यत्नवानेव न लभे विप्रतां विभो। एवंगते तु धर्मज्ञ दातुमर्हसि मे वरम्।॥
English Translation: O Vidura, things having taken this course, what should be done by us? I low can we secure the adoration of the citizens? How can we avoid the danger of total annihilation? Tell us what we should do); for you are conversant with all excellent expedients.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच यदि तेऽमनुग्राह्यः किंचिद् वा सुकृतं मम। वृणीष्वेति तदा प्राह ततस्तं बलवृत्रहा॥
English Translation: Vidura said: O king, Trivarga (Dharma, Artha and Kama) has its foundation on virtue and the sages says that a kingdom also stands on virtue as its basis. O king, therefore cherish with virtue and to your best power on your own sons and those of Pandu.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मतङ्ग उवाच चोदितस्तु महेन्द्रेण मतङ्गः प्राब्रवीदिदम्। यथा कामविहारी स्यां कामरूपी विहङ्गमः॥
English Translation: Virtue was destroyed by the wicked souls (the Kuru princes) with Subala's son (Shakuni) at their head when your sons invited the virtuous Yudhishthira to play and defeated him at dice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्रह्मक्षत्राविरोधेन पूजां च प्राप्नुयामहम्। यथा ममाक्षया कीर्तिर्भवेच्चापि पुरंदर॥
English Translation: I see this expiation of this dead of utter iniquity. O chief of the Kurus, your son (Duryodhana) may win by it a praise among good men.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शक्र उवाच कर्तुमर्हसि तद् देव शिरसा त्वां प्रसादये। छन्दोदेव इति ख्यातः स्त्रीणां पूज्यो भविष्यसि॥
English Translation: Let the Pandavas have what is to may given to them by you. The king's morality is that a king should remain content with his own and never covet the possessions of others.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कीर्तिश्च तेऽतुला वत्स त्रिषु लोकेषु यास्यति। एवं तस्मै वरं दत्त्वा वासवोऽन्तरधीयत॥
English Translation: Your good name would not thus suffer; family dissension's would not thus ensue; you will have then no unrighteous act. This is your first duty, (namely) to grace the Pandavas and to disgrace Shakuni.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्राणांस्त्यक्त्वा मतङ्गोऽपि सम्प्राप्तः स्थानमुत्तमम्। एवमेतत् परं स्थानं ब्राह्मण्यं नाम भारत। तच्च दुष्प्रापमिह वै महेन्द्रवचनं यथा॥
English Translation: O king, if you wish to restore to you sons the good fortune they have lost this speedily act as I say, O king, if you do not act thus, the Kurus will be soon destroyed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच ततः संवादिते तस्मिन्ननुज्ञातो धनंजयः। गतां रैवतके कन्यां विदित्वा जनमेजयः॥शा वासुदेवाभ्यनुज्ञातः कथयित्वेतिकृत्यताम्। कृष्णस्य मतमादायः प्रययौ भरतर्षभः॥
English Translation: For neither Bhimasena nor Arjuna, if angry, will leave any of the enemies unslain. What is there in the world which is unattainable to those who have amongst their warriors Savyasachi Arjuna well-skilled in war, who possesses the Gandiva, the most powerful of all weapons in the world and who have the mighty Bhimasena warrior.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रथेन काञ्चनाङ्गेन कल्पितेन यथाविधि। शैव्यसुग्रीवयुक्तेन किरूिणीजालमालिना॥ सर्वशस्त्रोपपन्नेन जीमूतरवनादिना। ज्वलिताग्निप्रकाशेन द्विषतां हर्षघातिना॥ संनद्धः कवची खड्गी बद्धगोधाङ्गुलित्रवान्। मृगयाव्यपदेशेन प्रययौ पुरुषर्षभः॥
English Translation: I told you formerly as soon as the son was born, “Abandon this inauspicious child of yours. The good of your race is in it (abandoning).” But you did not accept my advice, if you did as I advised to do, you would not have repented.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुभद्रा त्वथ शैलेन्द्रमभ्ययैव रैवतम्। दैवतानि च सर्वाणि ब्राह्मणान् स्वस्ति वाच्य च॥ प्रदक्षिणं गिरेः कृत्वा प्रययौ द्वारका प्रति। तामभिदुत्य कौन्तेयः प्रसह्यारोपयद् स्थम्। सुभद्रां चारुसर्वाङ्गी कामबाणप्रपीडितः॥
English Translation: If your son consent to reign just and in peace with the sons of Pandu, you will thus pass your days in happiness and you will not have to repent.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः स पुरुषव्याघ्रस्तामादाय शुचिस्मिताम्। रथेन काञ्चना न प्रययौ स्वपुरं प्रति॥
English Translation: Putting aside Duryodhana invite the son of Pandu (Yudhishthira) in the sovereignty. Let Ajatashatru (Yudhishthira) who is free from passion, rule the earth virtuously.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ह्वियमाणां तु तां दृष्ट्वा सुभद्रां सैनिका जनाः। विक्रोशन्तोऽद्रवन् सर्वे द्वारकामभितः पुरीम्॥
English Translation: O king, all the monarchs of the world then like Vaisyas will pay homage to us. O king, let Duryodhana, Shakuni and Suta's son (Karna) gladly wait upon the sons of Pandu.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते समासाद्य सहिताः सुधर्मामभितः सभाम्। सभापालस्य तत् सर्वमाचख्युः पार्थविक्रमम्॥
English Translation: Let Dushasana ask pardon of Bhimasena and of the daughter of Draupada (Draupadi) in open court. After pacifying Yudhishthira, place him on the throne with all respects.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषां श्रुत्वा सभापालो भेरी सांनाहिकी ततः। समाजघ्ने महाघोषां जाम्बूनदपरिष्कृताम्॥
English Translation: O king, asked by you, who else can I advise? If you do this, you will do what is proper.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क्षुब्धास्तेनाथ शब्देन भोजवृष्ण्यन्धकास्तदा। अन्नपानमपास्याथ समापेतुः समन्ततः॥
English Translation: Dhritarashtra said: O Vidura, the worlds you have spoken in this assembly with reference to the Pandavas and myself are for their and not my good. My mind does not approve this.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्र जाम्बूनदाङ्गानि स्पर्ध्यास्तरणवन्ति च। मणिविदुमचित्राणि ज्वलिताग्निप्रभाणि च॥ भेजिरे पुरुषव्याघ्रा वृष्ण्यन्धकमहारथाः। सिंहासनानि शतशो धिष्ण्यानीव हुताशनाः॥
English Translation: How have you settled all this in your mind. When you have spoken all this on behalf of the Pandavas. I perceive you are not at all friendly to me. How can I leave my son for the sake of sons of Pandu?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषां समुपविष्टानां देवानामिव संनये। आचख्यौ चेष्टितं जिष्णोः सभापाल: सहानुगः॥
English Translation: There is no doubt they (the Pandavas) too are my sons, but Duryodhana has spring from my (own) body. Speaking partially how will you advise me to replace my own body for the sake of others?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तच्छ्रुत्वा वृष्णिवीरास्ते मदसंरक्तलोचनाः। अमृष्यमाणाः पार्थस्य समुत्पेतुरहंकृताः॥
English Translation: Vidura, though I hold you in great esteem, (yet I must say) all that you have said is crooked. Stay (here) or go (away) as you please. However an unchaste wife is assured, she forsakes her husband.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: योजयवं रथानाशु प्रासानाहरतेति च। धनूंषि च महार्हाणि कवचानि बृहन्ति च॥ सूतानुच्चुक्रुशुः केचिद् रथान् योजयतेति च। स्वयं च तुरगान् केचिदयुञ्जन् हेमभूषितान्॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : O king, having said this, Dhritarashtra suddenly rose and went into the inner apartments. Saying "this race is doomed", Vidura (also) went away where the sons of Fandu were.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रथेष्वानीयमानेषु कवचेषु ध्वजेषु च। अभिक्रन्दे नृवीराणां तदासीत् तुमुलं महत्॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said : O child, why do you speak these cruel words to these frightened Kurus who are now in adversity and who have come to us for protection?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वनमाली ततः क्षीबः कैलासशिखरोपमः। नीलवासा मदोसिक्त इदं वचनमब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: O Vrikodara, dissensions and disputes often take place among those that are connected in blood. Such hostilities always exist, but for it family honour is never suffered to be destroyed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किमिदं कुरुथाप्रज्ञास्तूष्णीभूते जनार्दने। अस्य भावमविज्ञाय संक्रुद्धा मोघगर्जिताः॥
English Translation: If any stranger seeks to destroy the honour of a family, they that are good never tolerate such insult to be offered by the stranger.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एष तावदभिप्रायमाख्यातु स्वं महामतिः। यदस्य रुचिरं कर्तुं तत् कुरुध्वमतन्द्रिताः॥
English Translation: The wretched minded one (Gandharva king) knows that we are living here for some time. (Even knowing this), he has disregarded us and has done this which is disagreeable to us.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्ते तद् वचः श्रुत्वा ग्राह्यरूपं हलायुधात्। तूष्णीम्भूतास्ततः सर्वे साधु साध्विति चाब्रुवन्॥
English Translation: O exalted one, from this forcible seizure of Duryodhana and from this insult offered to the ladies of our family by a stranger, our family honour is destroyed,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: समं वचो निशम्यैव बलदेवस्य धीमतः। पुनरेव सभामध्ये सर्वे ते समुपाविशन्॥
English Translation: O foremost of men, arise and arm yourselves without the least delay to rescue those that have sought protection and also to save the honour of our family.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽब्रवीद् वासुदेवं वचो रामः परंतपः। किमवागुपविष्टोऽसि प्रेक्षमाणो जनार्दन॥
English Translation: Let Arjuna and the twins (Nakula and Sahadeva) and yourself and also those that are brave and invincible (at once go and) rescue Duryodhana who is even now being taken away as a prisoner.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सत्कृतस्त्वत्कृते पार्थः सर्वैरस्माभिरच्युत। न च सोऽर्हति तां पूजां दुर्बुद्धिः कुलपांसनः॥
English Translation: These blazing cars with golden flag-staffs belonging to the son of Dhritarashtra are now all ready (before you). With Indrasena and other charioteers who are all skilled in arms, ride all of you these ever furnished cars with deep rattling noise. Ride on them and fight to your utmost power with the Gandharvas to rescue Duryodhana. Even an ordinary Kshatriya would try his best to protect one who has come to him for protection. What then, O Vrikodara, shall I speak to you?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: को हि तत्रैव भुक्त्वान्नं भाजनं भेत्तुमर्हसि। मन्यमानः कुले जातमात्मानं पुरुषः क्वचित्॥
English Translation: Entreated for assistance in such words as these, “O hasten to my help,” who is there that is so mean as not to help even his enemy when he see him to crave for protection with joined hands? The bestowal of a boon, a sovereignty and the birth of a son are sources of great happiness. But to rescue an enemy from distress is equal to all three.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इच्छन्नेव हि सम्बन्धं कृतं पूर्वं च मानयन्। को हि नाम भवेनार्थी साहसेन समाचरेत्॥
English Translation: What could be greater joy to you than that Duryodhana now in distress seeks his very life which now depends on the strength of your arms?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सोऽवमन्य तथास्माकमनादृत्य च केशवम्। प्रसह्य हृतवानद्य सुभद्रां मृत्युमात्मनः॥
English Translation: O Vrikodara, O hero, if the vow which I am engaged in observing were over, I would have certainly myself run to his assistance.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कथं हि शिरसो मध्ये कृतं तेन पदं मम। मर्षयिष्यामि गोविन्द पादस्पर्शमिवोरगः॥
English Translation: Try by all means, O Bhima, O Kuru prince, to rescue Duryodhana (first) by the act of conciliation. If however the Gandharva king cannot be managed by the act of conciliation, then you must try to rescue Duryodhana by light fighting.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अद्य निष्कौरवामेकः करिष्यामि वसुंधराम्। न हि मे मर्षणीयोऽयमर्जुनस्य व्यतिक्रमः॥
English Translation: If the Gandharvas do not let off the Kurus, even then, O Bhima, you must then rescue them by crushing the enemy by all means.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं तथा गर्जमानं तु मेघदुन्दुभिनिःस्वनम्। अन्वपद्यन्त ते सर्वे भोजवृष्ण्यन्धकास्तदा॥
English Translation: O Vrikodara, all this I can tell you now, for my vow has begun, but it has not ended as yet."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच कथं धर्मे स्थातुमिच्छन् राजा वर्तेत धार्षिकः। पृच्छामि त्वं कुरुश्रेष्ठ तन्मे ब्रूहि पितामह॥
English Translation: Having heard these words of Ajatshatru, Dhananjaya (Arjuna) at the command of his Guru, vowed to rescue the Kurus.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच अत्राप्युदाहरन्तीममितिहासं पुरातनम्। गीतं दृष्टार्थतत्त्वेन वामदेवेन धीमता॥
English Translation: “If the Gandharvas do not peacefully let off the Dhritarashtra people, the earth shall this day drink the blood of the Gandharvas." Hearing the vow of the truthful Arjuna, O king, the Kurus were fully cheered up.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजा वसुमना नाम ज्ञानवान् धृतिमाशुचिः। महर्षि परिपप्रच्छ वामदेवं तपस्विनम्॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Thereupon one day, knowing that the Pandavas had been comfortably seated and Krishna was taking her rest after meal the ascetic entered the forest surrounded by ten thousand disciples.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: येन वृत्तेन वै तिष्ठन् न हीयेयं स्वधर्मतः॥
English Translation: Beholding that guest arrive there the king Yudhishthira graceful and honest, proceeded with his brothers. Joining his hands and making him sit on an excellent seat. And adoring him duly he treated him with hospitalicy. He said, “Come back soon, O venerably sir, after performing your ablutions and reciting your prayers."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमब्रवीद् वामदेवस्तेजस्वी तपतां वरः। हेमवर्णं सुखासीनं ययातिमिव नाहुषम्॥
English Translation: That innocent ascetic went to bathe along with his disciples, thinking "how will he feed me and my disciples.” Those ascetics of controlled minds went into the water.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वासुदेव उवाच धर्ममेवानुवर्तस्व न धर्माद् विद्यते परम्। धर्मे स्थिता हि राजानो जयन्ति पृथिवीमिमाम्॥
English Translation: In the interval, O king, Draupadi, the best of women ever devoted to her husband, began to think how she could provide food.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्थसिद्धेः परं धर्मं मन्यते यो महीपतिः। वृद्ध्यां च कुरुते बुद्धिं स धर्मेण विराजते॥
English Translation: While she was thus thinking she could not find any means. She then thought in mind of Krishna, the slayer at Kansa.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अधर्मदर्शी यो राजा बलादेव प्रवर्तते। क्षिप्रमेवापयातोऽस्मादुभौ प्रथममध्यमौ॥
English Translation: (She said) O Krishna, O Krishna of mighty arms, O eternal, O son of Devaki.O Vasudeva, O lord of the universe, O you the killer of the difficulties of those that bow to you, O soul of the universe, O creator of the universe, O destroyer, O lord O inexhaustible. Oh the protector of the afflicted, O the saviour of kine and subjects, O the highest of the high, O the source of the mental perceptions such as faculties of knowledge and moral sense, I bow to you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: असत्पापिष्ठसचिवो वध्यो लोकस्य धर्महा। सहैव परिवारेण क्षिप्रमेवावसीदति॥
English Translation: O worshipful one, O endless giver of boons, you are the refuge of the helpless; You are the ancient Purusha, the vital breath, beyond the perception of mental faculties. Oh lord of all, the most excellent lord, I seek your refuge; O lord, O you fond of your votaries, kindly protect me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्थानामननुष्ठाता कामचारी विकत्यनः। अपि सर्वां महीं लब्ध्वा क्षिप्रमेव विनश्यति॥
English Translation: O you having complexion dark as the leaves of the blue lotus having eyes red as the corola of the lilly, O you clad in yellow raiment, O you adorned with the brilliant Kaustava. You are the beginning and the end of creation; the great refuge of all, you are the supreme light and essence of the universe with your face directed towards all directions.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथाददानः कल्याणमनसूयुर्जितेन्द्रियः। वर्धते मतिमान् राजा स्त्रोतोभिरिव सागरः॥
English Translation: They call you the supreme germ and the depository of all wealth; O king of gods, being protected by you all will lose their terrors.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न पूर्णोऽस्मीति मन्येत धर्मतः कामतोऽर्थतः। बुद्धितो मित्रतश्चापि सततं वसुधाधिपः॥
English Translation: You did save me before from Dushasana in the assembly; it behoves you now to save me from this difficutly.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतेष्वेव हि सर्वेषु लोकयात्रा प्रतिष्ठिता। एतानि शृण्वल्लभते यशः कीर्ति श्रियं प्रजाः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Then thus eulogised by Krishna the lord, fond of his votaries, the god of gods, the lord of the universe, Kesava of mysterious movements, percieving Draupadi's difficulty and leaving Rukmani on the bed him, came there quickly.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं यो धर्मसंरम्भी धर्मार्थपरिचिन्तकः। अर्थान् समीक्ष्य भजते स ध्रुवं महदश्नुते॥
English Translation: Thereupon beholding him arrived there Draupadi, in great delight, bowed to him and communicated to Vasudeva the coming of the ascetic and every other thing,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अदाता ह्यनतिस्नेहो दण्डेनावर्तयन् प्रजाः। साहसप्रकृती राजा क्षिप्रमेव विनश्यति॥
English Translation: “Thereupon Krishna said to her, I am greatly stricken with hunger; soon feed me, O Krishna and afterwards I shall do all.” Hearing his words Krishna, ashamed, said, The vessel given by the sun remains full till I take my meals. O lord, I have taken my meals and there is no food.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ पापकृतं बुद्ध्या न च पश्यत्यबुद्धिमान्। अकीर्त्याभिसमायुक्तो भूयो नरकमश्नुते॥
English Translation: Thereupon the lotus-eyed god said to Krishna. This is not the time for joke, O Krishna; I am assailed with hunger and fatigue; soon go, fetch the vessel and show me. Having thus got persistently the vessel brought, the ornament of the Yadu race, Keshava, saw a particle of rice and vegetable sticking at a corner. Eating it up he said to her "May the lord Hari, the soul of the universe, be pleased with it and may the God who partakes at sacrifices be satiated with it."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ मानयितुर्दाम्नः श्लक्ष्णस्य वशवर्तिनः। व्यसनं स्वमिवोत्पन्नं विजिघांसन्ति मानवाः॥
English Translation: Then the long-armed Krishna, the destroyer of miseries said to Sahadeva, “soon bring the ascetics here and feed them."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यस्य नास्ति गुरुर्धर्मे न चान्यानपि पृच्छति। सुखतन्त्रोऽर्थलाभेषु न चिरं सुखमश्नुते॥
English Translation: O foremost of kings, thereupon the mighty illustrious Sahaveda soon went to invite them to repast. The ascetic Durvasa and others, who had gone to the nearest river to cool and transparent water to bath, all having plunged into the river, were rubbing their persons. And they were all feeling their stomachs to be full. Coming out of the water they began to eye each other. Then turning their faces towards Durvasa they all said, "Having asked the king to get our meals ready we have come here to bathe. Our stomachs have been filled to the throat; how can we eat anything now, O Brahmana Rishi? The food has been uselessly prepared for us, what shall we do now?"
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गुरुप्रधानो धर्मेषु स्वयमर्थानवेक्षिता। धर्मप्रधानो लाभेषु स चिरं सुखमश्नुते॥
English Translation: Durvasa said : By uselessly making him prepare our food we have done a great wrong to that royal sage. Will not the Pandavas distroy us by looking down upon us with angry eyes? I know, the royal sage is endued with great ascetic power; O Brahmana, I am afraid of those man who are devoted to Hari's feet. All those Pandavas are high-souled, pious, heroic, learned, observant of vows and of devout panances. They always observe the rules of good conduct and are devoted to Vasudeva; if angry, they can consume us with their anger as fire does a bale of cotton. So O disciples, you all run away quickly without seeing them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच एवं बहुगुणं सैन्यमेवं प्रविचितं बलम्। व्यूढमेवं यथान्यायमेवं बहु च संजय॥
English Translation: Vaishampnyana said : Being thus addressed by their ascetic preceptor, all those Bramhanas, greatly afraid of the Pandavas, fled away in all directions.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नित्यं पूजितमस्माभिरभिकामं च नः सदा। प्रौढमत्यद्भुताकारं पुरस्ताद् दृष्टविक्रमम्॥
English Translation: Not beholding those best ascetics in the celestial river. Sahadeva searched them here, there and at all the landing places.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नातिवृद्धमबालं च नाकृशं नातिपीवरम्। लघुवृत्तायतप्रायं सारगात्रपनामयम्॥ आत्तसंनाहसंछन्नं बहुशस्त्रपरिच्छदम्। शस्त्रग्रहणविद्यासु बह्वीषु परिनिष्ठितम्॥
English Translation: Then learning from the other ascetics there that they had all fled away he came and communicated the news to Yudhishthira.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आरोहे पर्यवस्कन्दे सरणे सान्तरप्लुते। सम्यक्प्रहरणे याने व्यपयाने च कोविदम्॥
English Translation: Thereupon all the self-controlled Pandavas, awaiting their arrival, remained in expectation for some time.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नागेष्वश्वेषु बहुशो रथेषु च परीक्षितम्। परीक्ष्य च यथान्यायं वेतनेनोपपादितम्॥
English Translation: Yudhisthira said: Coming in the dead of night the ascetics will impose on us; Oh, how can we escape from this difficulty created by destiny.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न गोष्ठ्या नोपकारेण न सम्बन्धनिमित्ततः। नानाहूतं नाप्यभृतं मम सैन्यं बभूव ह॥
English Translation: Seeing them thus stricken with anxiety and breathing long deep sighs frequently the graceful Krishna suddenly appeared before them and said,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कुलीनार्यजनोपेतं तुष्टपुष्टमनुद्धतम्। कृतमानोपचारं च यशखि च मनखि च॥
English Translation: Krishna said: O son of Pritha, knowing your difficulty from the highly wrathful Rishi implored by Draupadi I soon came here.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सचिवैश्चापरैर्मुख्यैर्बहुभिः पुण्यकर्मभिः। लोकपालोपमैस्तात पालितं नरसत्तमैः॥
English Translation: Now you have not the least fear from the ascetic Durvasa; afraid of your ascetic powers, he has already fled away.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बहुभिः पार्थिवैर्गुप्तस्मत्प्रियचिकार्युभिः। अस्मानभिसृतैः कामात् सबलैः सपदानुगैः॥
English Translation: Those who always abide by virtue never suffer. I now ask your permission to return home; may good always betide you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महोदधिमिवापूर्णमापगभिः समन्ततः। अपक्षैः पक्षिसंकाशे रथैरश्वैश्च संवृतम्॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Hearing Kashava's words the sons of Pritha along with Draupadi became easy in mind and relieved from anxiety they said, O lord, O Govinda, as persons drowning in the vast deep, reach shore by means of a boat, so have we, by your protection, overcome this great difficulty.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रभिन्नकरटैश्चैव द्विरदैरावृतं महत्। यदहन्यत मे सैन्यं किमन्यद् भागधेयतः॥
English Translation: Now go in peace; may good betide you. Thus commanded he repaired to his own city and the Pandavas too, O great king, O lord, long with Draupadi.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: योधाक्षय्यजलं भीमं वाहनोर्मितरङ्गिणम्। क्षेपण्यसिगदाशक्तिशरप्रासझषाकुलम्॥
English Translation: Delightedly spent their days wandering from forest to forest. O king, I have thus, as asked by you, recounted the story.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ध्वजभूषणसम्बाघरत्नोपलसुसंचितम्। वाहनैरभिधावद्भिर्वायुवेगविकम्पितम्॥
English Translation: It was in this way the evil desires of the wicked sons of Dhritarastra about the Pandavas in the forest, were baffled.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्रोणगम्भीरपातालं कृतवर्ममहाह्रदम्। जलसंधमहाग्राहं कर्णचन्द्रोदयोद्धतम्॥
English Translation: Dhritarashtra said Do you relate to me how the battle of Arjuna waged with the Samsaptakas and that of other lords of the earth with the Pandavas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गते सैन्यार्णवं भित्त्वा तरसा पाण्डवर्षभे। संजयैकरथेनैव युयुधाने च मामकम्॥
English Translation: Moreover describe to me, O Sanjaya, how that battle of Arjuna took place with Ashvatthaman; and also that of other supporters of the earth with the sons of Pritha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्र शेषं न पश्यामि प्रविष्टे सव्यसाचिनि। सात्वते च रथोदारे मम सैन्यस्य संजय॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said O monarch, do you hear me, who am describing to you how that battle, which was destructive of the bodies, sins and lives of persons, waged between the heroes (on our side) and the enemies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तौ तत्र समतिक्रान्तौ दृष्ट्वातीव तरखिनौ। सिन्धुराजं तु सम्प्रेक्ष्य गाण्डीवस्येषुगोचरे॥
English Translation: The son of Pritha, that slayer of enemies, having entered into the army of the Samsaptakas, that was like the great ocean, afflicted it most highly; even as the dreadful tempest agitates the vast ocean.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किं नु वा कुरवः कृत्यं विदधुः कालचोदिताः। दारुणैकायने कालं कथं वा प्रतिपेदिरे॥
English Translation: Dhananjaya, after having severed the heads of the heroic warriors by broad-headed and sharp-edged arrows, that (viz. the heads) had faces, as resplendent as the full moon and also very handsome eyes, eye-brows and teeth, immediately scattered the earth over with these heads, as if with lotuses severed from their stalks.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ग्रस्तान् हि कौरवान् मन्ये मृत्युना तात संगतान्। विक्रमोऽपि रणे तेषां न तथा दृश्यते हि वै॥
English Translation: Arjuna cut-off the arms of his antagonists with keen arrows, that were like the razors, which, viz. the arms were excellently round, long and muscular and also were rubbed over with soft sandal and other perfumes and again, were furnished with weapons and fingers protected with leathern cases and resembled the five-headed snakes, in that dreadful battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अक्षतौ संयुगे तत्र प्रविष्टौ कृष्णपाण्डवौ। न च वारयिता कश्चित् तयोरस्तीह संजय॥
English Translation: The son of Pandu, again and again, cut-off with his broad-faced arrows the horses and horsemen, the drivers of cars and standards, bows and arrows, as well as arms, that were ornamented with valuable jewels.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भृताश्च बहवो योधाः परीक्ष्यैव महारथाः। वेतनेन यथासोगं प्रियवादेन चापरे॥
English Translation: O monarch, in that battle Arjuna, sent away innumerable car-warriors, elephants, horses and cavalry to the abode of Death, by striking them with several thousands of arrows.
---
