Sanskrit Shloka: असत्कारभृतस्तात मम सैन्ये न विद्यते। कर्मणा ह्यनुरूपेण लभ्यते भक्तवेतनम्॥
English Translation: The foremost of heroes, who became very wrathful and who roared most loudly and who, again, like bulls, were highly excited as if for a cow in season, proceeded most rapidly against him (Arjuna) with great uproars. Then those warriors began to strike him (Arjuna) with their shafts who at that time continued to slay his (Arjuna's) antagonist, even as the bulls strike another of their kind with the horns.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न चायोधोऽभवत् कश्चिन्मम सैन्ये तु संजय। अल्पदानभृतस्तात तथा चाभृतको नरः॥
English Translation: Thus the battle, which caused the hairs to stand on points, waged between him (Arjuna) and them (other warriors); even as there had taken place a battle of the Daityas with the wielder of the thunder-bolt (Indra) at the conquest of the three worlds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पूजितो हि यथाशक्त्या दानमानासनैर्मया। तथा पुत्रैश्च मे तात ज्ञातिभिश्च सबान्धवैः॥
English Translation: That Arjuna, after having restrained the weapons of his antagonists, coming from all sides, by the weapons of his own and also having pierced the foes with a large number of shafts most rapidly, had taken away their lives.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते च प्राप्यैव संग्रामे निर्जिताः सव्यसाचिना। शैनेयन परामृष्टाः किमन्यद् भागधेयतः॥
English Translation: That impersonation of victory (Jaya), that enhancer of the fears of his antagonists, after having broken into minute pieces, like the tempest breaking the vast masses of clouds into fragments, the cars, which had their poles, wheels and axes already shattered (by him) and which had their warriors, horses and drivers slain and which also had their weapons and quivers dislodged and which had their standards smitten down and which had their traces and reins of horses broken into pieces and which had their wooden fences already shattered into pieces (by him) and which had their arrows (deposited in them) struck down and moreover after having astonished every body, worked out deeds, like those of a thousand mighty car-warriors, fighting together, that were worth seeing.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रक्ष्यते यश्च संग्रामे ये च संजय रक्षिणः। एकः साधारणः पन्था रक्ष्यस्य सह रक्षिभिः॥
English Translation: The assemblage of the Siddhas and the divine Rishis, as well as the Charanas, began to praise them highly. The celestial kettle-drums also begun to be sounded; and showers of flowers continued to fall upon the heads of both Keshava and Arjuna. Meanwhile a voice,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्जुनं समरे दृष्ट्वा सैन्धवस्याग्रतः स्थितम्। पुत्रो मम भृशं मूढः किं कार्य प्रत्यपद्यत॥
English Translation: Those two heroes, Keshava and Arjuna, are always said to be possessed of the splendour of the moon, the light of the fire, the strength of the wind and the brilliancy of the sun. Those two are as invincible as Brahman and Ishana. They are seated on the same car. They are the best of all creatures. They are most heroic. And the both are equal to Nara and Narayana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सात्यकिं च रणे दृष्ट्वा प्रविशन्तमभीवत्। किं नु दुर्योधनः कृत्यं प्राप्तकालममन्यत॥
English Translation: Thus hearing and beholding this wonderful event, O descendant of the Bharata race, Ashvatthaman, firmly resolved upon, rushed towards the two Krishnas, viz. Arjuna and Keshava, in that battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वशस्त्रातिगौ सेनां प्रविष्टौ रथितसत्तमौ। दृष्ट्वा कां वै धृति युद्धे प्रत्यपद्यन्त मामकाः॥
English Translation: Having invited to battle the son of Pandu, who was pouring forth showers of arrows, that had the power of slaying the antagonists, with his arm holding an arrow within its reach, the
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दृष्ट्वा कृष्णं तु दाशार्हमर्जुनार्थे व्यवस्थितम्। शिनीनामृषभं चैव मन्ये शोचन्ति पुत्रकाः॥
English Translation: 'O hero, if you consider me to be your worthy guest, who am arrived here, then allow me, with your entire soul, the hospitality of battle today.'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दृष्ट्वा सेनां व्यतिक्रान्तां सात्वतेनार्जुनेन च। पलायमानांश्च कुरून् मन्ये शोचन्ति पुत्रकाः॥
English Translation: Having been thus invited by the son of the Preceptor out of desire for battle, Arjuna considered himself to be highly respected and
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विदुतान् रथिनो दृष्ट्वा निरुत्साहान् द्विषजये। पलायनकृतोत्साहान् मन्ये शोचन्ति पुत्रकाः॥
English Translation: The army of the Samasaptakas should be slaughtered by me; but, again, the son of Drona is inviting me to battle. O Madhava, do you order me really what should be performed first. If you consider it proper, that the work of hospitality should be given Ashvatthama first after rising.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शून्यान् कृतान् रथोपस्थान् सात्वतेनार्जुनेन च। हतांश्च योधान् संदृश्य मन्ये शोचन्ति पुत्रकाः॥
English Translation: Having been thus addressed (by Arjuna), Krishna carried, to the near presence of the son of Drona, the son of Pritha, who was invited to battle according to the prescribed maxims of triumphant challenge; even as the God of wind carries Indra to the sacrificial place.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यश्वनागरथान् दृष्ट्वा तत्र वीरान् सहस्रशः। धावमानान् रणे व्यग्रान् मन्ये शोचन्ति पुत्रकाः॥
English Translation: Keshava, after having invited (to battle) him, who had his whole heart directed upon one thing, addressed the son of Drona, saying-'O Ashvatthaman, having been still (in the field), do you begin to strike without hesitation, as also do you bear (patiently).'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महानागान् विद्रवतो दृष्ट्वार्जुनशराहतान्। पतितान् पततश्चान्यान् मन्ये शोचन्ति पुत्रकाः॥
English Translation: This, indeed, is the fit occasion for those, who support their lives with the food of their masters, to repay obligation to their supporters. The struggle between the Brahmanas is most insignificant; but the war between two Kshatriyas is a grand and decisive one, resulting either in victory or defeat.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विहीनांश्च कृतानश्वान् विस्थांश्च कृतान् नरान्। तत्र सात्यकिपार्थाभ्यां मन्ये शोचन्ति पुत्रकाः॥
English Translation: You, who are most willing to receive, out of foolishness, those celestial rites of hospitality at the hands of the son of Pritha, after having becalmed yourself this day, continue to fight with the son of Pandu.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हयौधान् निहतान् दृष्ट्वा द्रवमाणांस्ततस्ततः। रणे माधवपार्थाभ्यां मन्ये शोचन्ति पुत्रकाः॥
English Translation: Having been thus addressed by Vasudeva, the best of the twice-born persons said-"So be it." He also pierced Keshava with sixty arrows and penetrated Arjuna with three other shafts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पत्तिसंघान् रणे दृष्ट्वा धावमानांश्च सर्वशः। निराशा विजये सर्वे मन्ये शोचन्ति पुत्रकाः॥
English Translation: Having been highly wrathful, Arjuna broke asunder his (antagonist's) bow with three powerful arrows. The son of Drona, on the other hand, took up another bow, more dreadful than the first.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्रोणस्य समतिक्रान्तावनीकमपराजितौ। क्षणेन दृष्ट्वा तौ वीरौ मन्ये शोचन्ति पुत्रकाः॥
English Translation: Having stretched his bow within so short a time as the twinkling of the eye, he (the son of . Drona) pierced both Arjuna and Keshava-Vashudeva with three hundred shafts and the son of Pandu with one thousand arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सम्मूढोऽस्मि भृशं तात श्रुत्वा कृष्णधनंजयौ। प्रविष्टौ मामकं सैन्यं सात्वतेन सहाच्युतौ॥
English Translation: Thereupon, the son of Drona, after having rendered Arjuna wholly stupid with the greatest care in the field of battle, shot thousands and tens of thousands and millions of shafts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मिन् प्रविष्टे पृतनां शिनीनां प्रवरे रथे। भोजानीकं व्यतिक्रान्ते किमकुर्वत कौरवाः।।
English Translation: Innumerable shafts continued to be poured forth from the quiver, the bow, the bow-string, the fingers, the arms, the two hands, the breast, the face, the rose, the two eyes, the two cars, the head, the different limbs and pores of the body, the car and its standards, of the professor of Brahmana, O sirc.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथा द्रोणेन समरे निगृहीतेषु पाण्डुषु। कथं युद्धमभूत् तत्र तन्ममाचक्ष्व संजय॥
English Translation: The son of Drona, after having pierced Madhava and the son of Pandu with a heavy shower of shafts, became highly gratified and sent forth a great up-roar like the loud roar of a vast congregated mass of clouds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्रोणो हि बलवाश्रेष्ठः कृतास्त्रो युद्धदुर्मदः। पञ्चालास्ते महेष्वासं प्रत्यविध्यन् कथं रणे॥
English Translation: Having heard this great uproar of him (the son of Drona), the son of Pandu, addressed that Eternal One, saying-O Madhava, observe this great oppression of the son of the preceptor towards me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पद्धवैरास्ततो द्रोणे धनंजयजयैषिणा। भारद्वाजसुतस्तेषु दृढवैरो महारथः॥
English Translation: This warrior considers us to be slaughtered, who have entered into the house of thick arrows (i.e. the arrowy shower). But we will surely frustrate his aim by means of our learning and energy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्जुनश्चापि यचक्रे सिन्धुराजवधं प्रति। तन्मे सर्व समाचक्ष्व कुशलो ह्यसि संजय॥
English Translation: The most excellent of the Bharata race, after having severed every one of the shafts of Ashvatthaman into three pieces, destroyed the power of those arrows even as the sun does away with the mist.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उताच आत्मापराधात् सम्भूतं व्यसनं भरतर्षभ। प्राप्य प्राकृतवद् वीर न त्वं शोचितुमर्हसि॥
English Translation: Thereupon the son of Pandu pierced with dreadful arrows the army of the Samsaptakas, with their horses, drivers, cars and elephants and with their standards, infantry and carwarriors repeatedly.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुरा यदुच्यसे प्राज्ञैः सुहृद्भिर्विदुरादिभिः। मा हार्षीः पाण्डवान् राजनिति तन्न त्वया श्रुतम्॥
English Translation: Then these persons, who having posted there in any way they liked, witnessed the battle, considered themselves to be wholly covered over with the showers of arrows, as if closing themselves by themselves.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुहृदां हितकामानां वाक्यं यो न शृणोति ह। समहद् व्यसनं प्राप्य शोचते वैयथाभवान्॥
English Translation: Those arrows of innumerable forms furnished with the wings, having been shot from the Gandiva bow, had slaughtered the elephants, horses and men, either stationed there or at the distance of two miles, in that (dreadful) battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: याचितोऽसि पुरा राजन् दाशार्हेण शमं प्रति। न च तं लब्धवान् कामं त्वत्तः कृष्णोमहायशाः॥
English Translation: The trunks of the elephants, that had been pouring forth their juice (as the mark of their excitement) having been thus cut-off by the broad-headed arrows, began to fall down; even as the pretty-well gigantic trees, having been hewn down by axes in the forest, fall down upon the earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तव निगुर्णतां ज्ञात्वा पक्षपातं सुतेषु च। द्वैधीभावं तथा धर्मे पाण्डवेषु च मत्सरम्॥५ तव जिह्ममभिप्रायं विदित्वा पाण्डवान् प्रति। आप्रिलापांश्च बहून् मनुजाधिपसत्तम॥
English Translation: After a short while, the elephants that resembled hill, along with those riding upon them, tumbled down upon the ground even as the large mountains broken down by the thunder-bolt fall upon the ground.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वलोकस्य तत्त्वज्ञः सर्वलोकेश्वरः प्रभुः। वासुदेवस्ततो युद्धं कुरूणामकरोन्महत्॥
English Translation: Having severed into minute fragments the cars that appcared like the dissolving columns of vapour in the evening sky and also that were well-furnished with all its equipment's and that were yoked to well-trained horses and again, that were occupied by the warriors, invincible in battle, by powerful arrows, (he the son of Pandu) began to pour forth shower of shafts upon the enemies. Moreover Dhananjaya slew both the horsemen and the infantry, welladorned with the ornaments.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आत्मापराधात् सुमहान् प्राप्तस्ते विपुलः क्षयः। नैनं दुर्योधने दोषं कर्तुमर्हसि मानद॥
English Translation: Dhananjaya, like the sun appearing at the end of the Yuga, had soaked away the vast deep of the Samsaptaka army, that was most difficult to be dried up, by means of his sharpheaded arrows, that constituted his rays.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न हि ते सुकृतं किंचिदादौ मध्ये च भारत। दृश्यते पृष्ठतश्चैव त्वन्मूलो हि पराजयः॥
English Translation: Then again he (Dhananjaya) without hesitation perfectly penetrated the son of Drona, who was like a huge mountain with straight arrows, that had great force and also that were as resplendent as the sun; even as the wielder of the thunder-bolt pierces a mountain (by thunder).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मादवस्थितो भूत्वा ज्ञात्वा लोकस्य निर्णयम्। शृणु युद्धं यथावृत्तं घोरं देवासुरोपमम्॥
English Translation: The most wrathful son of the Preceptor, desiring to fight, proceeded against him (Arjuna) with a view to pierce hiin along with his horses and drivers with swift arrows. The son of Pritha, on the other hand, sundered those arrows shot at him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रविष्टे तव सैन्यं त शैनेय सत्यविक्रमे। भीमसेनमुखाः पार्थाः प्रतीयुर्वाहिनीं तव॥
English Translation: Thereupon he (the son of Pandu), having been highly wrathful, continued to shower forth quivers of the arrows upon the person of Ashvatihaman; even as one serves a guest with things upon things in his house.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आगच्छतस्तान् सहसा क्रुद्धरूपान् सहानुगान्। दधारैको रणे पाण्डून् कृतवर्मा महारथः॥
English Translation: Then the son of Pandu, after having forsaken the army of the Samsaptakas ran towards the son of Drona; even as the doner, after having abandoned the unworthy quests, rushes towards the worthy one with his gifts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथोद्वत्तं वारयते वेला वै सलिलार्णवम्। पाण्डुसैन्यं तथा संख्ये हार्दिक्यः समवारयत्॥
English Translation: Rama said: O father, for my fault you have been killed like a deer in the forest with arrows by those mean and foolish wretches, the sons of Kirtavirya.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्राद्भुतमपश्याम हार्दिक्यस्य पराक्रमम्। यदेनं सहिताः पार्था नातिचक्रमुराहवे॥
English Translation: O father, virtuous and ever steady in the honest path as you were, how can fate permit that you should die in this way?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो भीमस्त्रिभिर्विद्धवा कृतवर्माणमाशुगैः। शङ्ख दध्मौ महाबाहुर्हर्पयन् सर्वपाण्डवान्॥
English Translation: What an awful sin must have been committed by them who have with hundreds of arrows killed you who were ever engaged in asceticism, who were old and who were averse to fight with them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सहदेवस्तु विंशत्या धर्मराजश्च पञ्चभिः। शतेन नकुलश्चापि हार्दिक्यं समविध्यत॥
English Translation: How can those shameless men speak of their (shameful) deed to their friends and relatives that they have killed virtuous man who was averse to fight.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्रौपदेयास्त्रिसप्तत्या सप्तभिश्च घटोत्कचः। धृष्टद्युम्नस्त्रिभिश्चापि कृतवर्माणमार्दयत्॥
English Translation: Avitavarna Said: O king, thus did he lamentin piteous manner; and then that great ascetic performed all the obsequies of his (deceased) father. That conqueror of hostile cities, Rama, then set fire (to the funeral pyre) of his, father, O descendant of Bharata and then took an oath to destroy all Kshatriyas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विराटो द्रुपदश्चैव याज्ञसेनिश्च पञ्चभिः। शिखण्डी चैव हार्दिक्यं विद्धवा पञ्चभिराशुगैः॥
English Translation: That mighty hero, greatly powerful in battle, equal to god of death himself, then took up weapons in anger; and alone he killed the sons of Kirtavirya.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुनर्विव्याध विंशत्या सायकानां हसन्निव। कृतवर्मा ततो राजन् सर्वतस्तान् महारथान्॥ एकैकं पञ्चभिर्विद्धवा भीमं विव्याध सप्तभिः। धनुर्ध्वजं चास्य तथा रथाद् भूमावपातयत्॥
English Translation: O best of Kshatriyas, that foremost of all wielders of arms, Rama, destroyed all those Kshatriyas who were their followers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथैनं छिन्नधन्वानं त्वरमाणो महारथः। आजघानोरसि क्रुद्धः सप्तत्या निशितैः शरैः॥
English Translation: Twenty-one times that lord made the earth Kshatriya-less. With their blood he made five lakes in Samantapanchaka.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स गाढविद्धो बलवान् हार्दिक्यस्य शरोत्तमैः। चचाल स्थमध्यस्थः क्षितिकम्पे यथाचलः॥
English Translation: That perpetuator of the Bhrigu race then offered there oblations to his ancestors. Then Rechika appeared to him in a visible form and stopped him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीमसेनं तथा दृष्ट्वा धर्मराजपुरोगमाः। विसृजन्तः शरान् राजन् कृतवर्माणमार्दयन्॥
English Translation: Then the mighty son of Jamadagni offered libations to the lord of the celestials in a great sacrifice, in which he bestowed the earth of the Ritvijas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं कथा कोष्ठकीकृत्य रथवंशेन मारिष। विव्यधुः सायकैईष्टा रक्षार्थ मारुतेर्पधे॥
English Translation: O king, he built an altar made of gold which was ten vyamas (2O yards) in breadth and nine in height. He made a gift of it to the illustrious Kashyapa.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रतिलभ्य ततः संज्ञां भीमसेनो महाबलः। शक्तिं जग्राह समरे हेमदण्डामयस्मयीम्॥
English Translation: O king, then at the request of Kashyapa, the Brahmanas divided it into a number of shares and thus they came to be called the Khandavayanas (share-takers).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चिक्षेप च रथात् तूर्ण कृतवर्मरथं प्रति। सा भीमभुजनिर्मुक्ता निर्मुक्तोरगसंनिभा॥
English Translation: O king, having bestowed the earth on the illustrious Kashyapa, he engaged in severe austerities on the Mahendra, the foremost of mountains.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृतवर्माणमभितः प्रजज्वाल सुदारुणा। तामापतन्ती सहसा युगान्ताग्निसमप्रभाम्॥
English Translation: Thus did hostility arise between him and the Kshatriyas that lived on the earth. The entire world was thus conquered by the imineasurably effulgent Rama.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्वाभ्यां शराभ्यां हार्दिक्यो निजघान द्विधा तदा। सा छिन्ना पतिता भूमौ शक्तिः कनकभूषणा॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Then on the fourteenth day of noon, the high-souled Rama at the proper hour appeared before the Brahinanas and Dharınaraja (Yudhishthira) with his younger brothers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्योतयन्ती दिशो राजन् महोल्केव नभश्चयुता। शक्तिं विनिहतां दृष्ट्वा भीमश्चुक्रोध वैभृशम्॥
English Translation: O king of kings, that foremost of kings, that lord, then with his brothers offered highest worship to the Brahmanas; and they also worshipped him (Rama).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽन्यद् धनुरादाय वेगवत् सुमहास्वनम्। भीमसेनो रणे क्रुद्धो हार्दिक्यं समवारयत्॥
English Translation: Having worshipped the son of Jamadagni and having received due respect from him, he (Yudhishthira) spent a night on the Mahendra (mountain) and he then started towards the south.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथैनं पञ्चभिर्बाणैराजधान स्तनान्तरे। भीमो भीमबलो राजंस्त्व दुर्मत्रितेन च॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said Having listened to those words suitable to the hour and place, of his subjects, king Yudhishthira answered them saying,-"Great indeed must be the son of Pandu, whose merits, true or false, are thus recited by such foremost of Brahmanas assembled together.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भोजस्तु क्षतसर्वाङ्गो भीमसेनेन मारिष। रक्ताशोक इवोत्फुल्लो व्यभ्राजत रणाजिरे॥
English Translation: Forsooth, we are all your favourites, since you so freely describe us as possessing those accomplishment
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः क्रुद्धस्त्रिभिर्बाणैभीमसेनं हसन्निव। अभिहत्य दृढं युद्धे तान् सर्वान् प्रत्यविध्यत॥
English Translation: King Dhritarashtra, however, is our father and god. If you wish to do what is pleasing to me, always obey him and do what he likes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्रिभिस्त्रिभिर्महेष्वासो यतमानान् महारथान्। तेऽपि तं प्रत्यविध्यन्त सप्तभिः सप्तभिः शरैः॥
English Translation: Having killed all my kinsmen, I live for him alone. My great duty is to always serve him with particular care.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शिखण्डिनस्ततः क्रुद्धः क्षुरप्रेण महारथः। धनुश्चिच्छेद समरे प्रहसन्निव सात्वतः॥
English Translation: If you, as also my friends, think that I should be a favourite with you and them, let me then request you all to treat Dhritarashtra as you used to do before.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शिखण्डी तु ततः क्रुद्धश्छिन्ने धनुषि सत्वरः। असिं जग्राह समरे शतचन्द्रं च भाखरम्॥
English Translation: He is the master of the world, of yourselves, and of myself. The whole world with the Pandavas, is his.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भ्रामयित्वा महचर्म चामीकरविभूषितम्। तमसिं प्रेषयामास कृतवर्मरथं प्रति॥
English Translation: You should always remember those words of mine.' The king then asked them to go where they liked.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तस्य सशरं चापं छित्त्वा राजन् महानसिः। अभ्यगाद् धरणी राजंश्च्युतं ज्योतिरिवाम्बरात्॥
English Translation: Having sent away the citizens and the people of the provinces, the Kuru king appointed his brother Bhimasena as Yuvaraja.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतस्मिन्नेव काले तु त्वरमाणं महारथाः। विव्यधुः सायकैर्गाढं कृतवर्माणमाहवे॥
English Translation: And he gladly appointed the highly intelligent Vidura for helping him with his advice and for looking after the sixfold requirements of the state.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथान्यद् धनुरादाय त्यक्त्वा तच महद् धनुः। विशीर्ण भरतश्रेष्ठ हार्दिक्याः परवीरहा॥
English Translation: And he appointed the old Sanjaya endued with every accomplishment, the superintendent of finances. He appointed Nakula superintendent of the forces, for giving them food and pay and for looking after other affairs of the army.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विव्याध पाण्डवान् युद्धे त्रिभिस्त्रिभिरजिह्मगैः। शिखण्डिनं च विव्याध त्रिभिः पञ्चभिरेव च॥
English Translation: King Yudhishthira appointed Phalguna for resisting hostile forces and punishing the wicked.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धनुरन्यत् समादाय शिखण्डी तु महायशाः। अवारयन् कूर्मनखैराशुगैर्हकित्मजम्॥
English Translation: He appointed Dhaumya, the foremost of priests to attend daily to the Brahmanas and perform all rites in honour of the gods and all other religious rites.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः क्रुद्धो रणे राजन् हृदिकस्यात्मसम्भवः। अभिदुद्राव वेगेन याज्ञसेनिं महारथम्॥
English Translation: He appointed Sahadeva to always remain by his side, for the king thought, O king, that he should always be protected by that brother of his. as
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्मस्य समरे राजन् मृत्योर्हतुं महात्मनः। विदर्शयन् बलं शूरः शार्दूल इव कुञ्जरम्॥
English Translation: The king cheerfully supported others in various other affairs according to their gratification.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तौ दिशां गजसंकाशौ ज्वलिताविव पावकौ। समापेततुरन्योन्यं शरसङ्घररिंदमौ॥
English Translation: That destroyer of hostile heroes, viz., the righteous-souled king Yudhishthira, devoted to virtue, commanded Vidura and the high-souled Yuyutsu, saying,-'You should always with attention and care do everything that my royal father Dhritarashtra desires.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विधुन्वानौ धनुःश्रेष्ठे संदधानौ च सायकान्। विसृजन्तौ च शतशो गभस्तीनिव भास्वरौ॥
English Translation: Everything for the citizens and the residents of the provinces should be done by you in your respective departments, after the king's permission. ever
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तापयन्तौ शरैस्तीक्ष्णैरन्योन्यं तौ महारथौ। युगान्तप्रतिमौ वीरौ रेजतुर्भास्कराविव॥
English Translation: Having saluted the Supreme Deity (Narayana) and the highest of all male beings (Nara) and also the Goddess of Learning (Sarasvati), let us cry success!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृतवर्मा च समरे याज्ञसेनिं महारथम्। विद्ध्वेषुभिस्त्रिसप्तस्या पुनर्विव्याघ सप्तभिः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said Then the heroic sons of Kuru belonging to the party of Abhimanyu pleased at having celebrated his (Abhimanyu's) nuptials and having rested during the night, awoke at break of day and went to the court of Virata.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स गाढविद्धो व्यथितो रथोपस्थ उपाविशत्। विराज्य सशरं चापं मूर्च्छयाभिपरिप्लुतः॥
English Translation: The court of the Lord of the Matsyas was richly decorated and adorned with a collection of precious stones and choice gems, with seats arranged in it, having garlands and filled with fragrance. Those aged kings among men came there.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं विषण्णं रणे दृष्ट्वा तावकाः पुरुषर्षभ। हार्दिक्यं पूजयामासुर्वासांस्यादुधुवुश्च ह॥
English Translation: On the front seats sat the two kings Virata and Drupada, aged and revered among the rulers of the earth and Rama and Janardana also along with their father.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शिखण्डिनं तथा ज्ञात्वा हार्दिक्यशरपीडितम्। अपोवाह रणाद् यन्ता त्वरमाणो महारथम्॥
English Translation: Near the king of Panchala sat the brave ruler of Shini along with the son of Rohini and next to the king of Matsya (sat) Janardana and Yudhishthira.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सादितं तु रथोपस्थे दृष्ट्वा पार्थाः शिखण्डिनम्। परिव्रवू रथैस्तूर्णं कृतवर्माणमाहवे॥
English Translation: (There sat) also all the sons of king Drupada, Bhima and Arjuna, the two sons of Madri, Pradyumna and Samba, who were valiant in battle and Abhimanyu in company with the son of Virata.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्राद्भुतं परं चक्रे कृतवर्मा महारथः। यदेकः समरे पार्थान् वारयामास सानुगान्॥
English Translation: And on the best seats wrought in gold sat the heroic sons of Draupadi who were equal to their fathers in valour, beauty and strength.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पार्थाञ्जित्वाजयचेदीन् पञ्चालान् सृञ्जयानपि। केकयांश्च महावीर्यान् कृतवर्मा महारथः॥
English Translation: Those mighty heroes, shining in ornaments and clothes, being seated, that assemblage of kings shone like the firmament studded with beautiful stars.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते वध्यमानाः समरे हार्दिक्येन स्म पाण्डवाः। इतश्चेतश्च धावन्तो नैव चक्रुतिं रणे॥
English Translation: Then those kings, heroes among men, having engaged in conversation with one another on various topics, remained for a moment gazing pensively on Krishna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जित्वा पाण्डुसुतान् युद्धे भीमसेनपुरोगमान्। हार्दिक्यः समरेऽतिष्ठद् विधूम इव पावकः॥
English Translation: Those lions among kings, having reached the end of their talk and their attention having been called by Madhava to the affairs of the Pandavas, listened to his lofty speech which conveyed deep meaning. Krishna said
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते द्राव्यमाणाः समरे हार्दिक्येन महारथाः। विमुखाः समपद्यन्त शरवृष्टिभिरार्दिताः॥
English Translation: It is known to you all how this Yudhishthira was defeated by a trick at a game of dice by the son of Subala, how he was robbed of his kingdom and how he made a stipulation regarding his exile in the forest.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच वनं प्रविष्टष्वथ पाण्डवेषु प्रज्ञाचक्षुस्तप्यमानोऽम्बिकेयः। धर्मात्मानं विदुरमगाधबुद्धिं सुखासीनो वाक्यमुवाच राजा॥
English Translation: The sons of Pandu, who are capable of subjugating the word by sheer force of arms, whose chariots go unrestrained to the celestial or the terrestrial regions and who are true of their words, have fulfilled that austere vow for thirteen years.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच प्रज्ञा च ते भार्गवस्येव शुद्धा धर्म च त्वं परमं वेत्थ सूक्ष्मम्। समश्च त्वं सम्मतः कौरवाणां पथ्यं चैषां मम चैव ब्रवीहि॥
English Translation: The thirteenth year in the forest has been very hard, but this these great men have passed, unknown to you and suffering various sorts of unbearable hardships.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवंगते विदुर यदद्य कार्य पौराश्च मे कथमस्मान् भजेरन्। स्तत्त्वं ब्रूयाः साधु कार्याणि वेत्सि॥
English Translation: Even they who have been engaged in the menial service of others seek their family and their kingdom; such being the case, consider what is best for the son of Dharma (Yudhishthira) and for king Duryodhana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विदुर उवाच त्रिवर्गोऽयंधर्ममूलो नरेन्द्र राज्यं चेदंधर्ममूलं वदन्ति। धर्मे राजन् वर्तमानः स्वशक्त्या पुत्रान सर्वान् पाहि पाण्डोः सुतांश्च॥
English Translation: (Consider) also what is right, suitable and calculated to redound to the glory of the illustrious Kauravas. The virtuous king Yudhishthira does not want even the kingdom of the gods wrongfully.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स वैधर्मो विप्रलब्धः सभायां पापात्मभिः सौबलेयप्रधानैः। आहूय कुन्तीसुतमक्षवत्यां पराजैषीत् सत्यसंधं सुतस्ते॥
English Translation: He would rather prefer the rightful lordship of some single village. It is known to all the kings (assembled here) how he has been robbed of his ancestral kingdom with the help of a mean trick by the sons of Dhritarashtra by whom the son of Pritha has not been vanquished through prowess borne by him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: छेषस्याहं परिपश्याम्युपायम्। मुक्तो लोके प्रतितिष्ठेत साधु॥
English Translation: Still the king Yudhishthira with his friends wishes them prosperity. The sons of Kunti, heroes among men and the two sons of Madri, seek only what has been earned by the sons of Pandu by overthrowing the king and winning victory over him. It is also well know to you how, when they were mere boys, their enemies who were cruel, dishonest and who sought to get the kingdom, attempted by several means to kill them. Consider their greediness and also the extreme piety of Yudhishthira.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तद् वै सर्वं पाण्डुपुत्रा लभन्तां यत् तद् राजन्नभिसृष्टं त्वयाऽऽसीत्। एषधर्मः परमो यत् स्वकेन राजा तुष्येन्न परस्वेषु गृध्येत्॥
English Translation: Consider also the relationship between them; consult together and also think each of you yourself. They have always been attached to truth and have always fulfilled their promises.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यशो न नश्येज्ज्ञातिभेदश्च न स्याद् धर्मो न स्यानैव चैवं कृते त्वाम्। एतत् कार्यं तव सर्वप्रधान तेषां तुष्टिः शकुनेश्चावमानः॥
English Translation: If they are now wrongfully treated let them slay all the sons of Dhritarashtra or let their friends who see the unworthy treatment they get in this matter make them (the sons of Dhritarashtra) desist.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: देतद् राजंस्त्वरमाणः कुरुष्व। तथैतदेवं न करोषि राजन् ध्रुवं कुरूणां भविता विनाशः॥
English Translation: If they (the sons of Dhritarashtra) oppose them (the Pandavas) in battle the letter thus opposed will kill them; and if you are of opinion that the Pandavas, owing to insufficiency of numbers, will not be able to win victory over them let them combine with all their friends and try to overthrow them. The intentions of Duryodhana are not known nor what he is going to do.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न हि क्रुद्धो भीमसेनोऽर्जुनो वा शेषं कुर्याच्छात्रवाणामनीके। येषां योद्धा सव्यसाची कृतास्त्रो धनुर्येषां गाण्डिवं लोकसारम्॥ येषां भीमो बाहुशाली च योद्धा तेषां लोके किं नु न प्राप्यमस्ति। उक्तं पूर्वं जातमात्रे सुते ते मया यत् ते हितमासीत् तदानीम्॥
English Translation: The intentions of the other side not being known, how can you determine on what to do yourself. Therefore let a man virtuous, holy, of good parentage and wifeless go from here-a capable ambassador who will be able to pursuable them into surrendering half of Yudhishthira's kingdom.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुत्रं त्यजेममहितं कुलस्य हितं परं न च तत् त्वं चकर्थ। मेवं कर्ता परितप्तासि पश्चात्॥
English Translation: Hearing this speech of Janardana which was pregnant with meaning and virtue, interesting and impartial, his elder brother accepted the suggestions and after praising the speech addressed him O king, thus.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यद्येतदेवमनुमन्ता सुतस्ते सम्प्रीयमाणः पाण्डवैरेकराज्यम्। न चेन्निगृहणीष्व सुतं सुखाय॥
English Translation: Lomasha said : Living in the ocean, the abode of Varuna, the Kalkeyas began their operations for the destruction of the worlds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुर्योधनं त्वहितं वै निगृह्य पाण्डोः पुत्रं कुरुष्वाधिपत्ये। अजातशत्रुर्हि विमुक्तरागो धर्मेणेमां पृथिवीं शास्तु राजन्॥ दुःशासनो
English Translation: They began to devour in the night in anger the Rishis (they found) in the hermitages and in the holy spots.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो राजन् पार्थिवाः सर्व एव वैश्या इवास्मानुपतिष्ठन्तु सद्यः। दुर्योधनः शकुनिः सूतपुत्रः प्रीत्या राजन् पाण्डुपुत्रान् भजन्तु॥
English Translation: Those wicked-minded Daityas devoured one hundred and eighty Brahmanas and also ascetics in the hermitage of Vasishtha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: याचतु भीमसेनं सभामध्ये दुपदस्यात्मजां च। युधिष्ठिरं त्वं परिसान्त्वयस्व राज्ये चैनं स्थापयस्वाभिपूज्य॥
English Translation: Going to the sacred hermitage hermitage of Chayavana, frequented by the Brahmanas, they devoured one hundred Rishis who lived on fruits and roots.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मेतत् कृत्वा कृतकृत्योऽसि राजन्॥
English Translation: They thus acted during the night and during the day they entered into the sea. They devoured in the hermitage of Bharadvaja two Brahmanas of subdued soul and of Brahmachari life, living on air and water only. In this way did the Danavas one after another (invade) all the hermitages.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच मिह प्रोक्तं पाण्डवान् प्राप्य मां च। मेतत् सर्वं मम नावैति चेतः॥
English Translation: Being intoxicated with prowess of arms and their lives nearly run out, the Kalkeyas destroyed many Brahmanas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इदं त्विदानी गत एव निश्चितं तेषामर्थे पाण्डवानां यदास्थ! तेनाद्य मन्ये नासि हितो ममेति कथं हि पुत्रं पाण्डवार्थे त्यजेयम्॥
English Translation: O foremost of men, the Danavas acted in this way towards the ascetics in their ascetic retreats. Yet men could not discover them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: असंशयं तेऽपि ममैव पुत्रा दुर्योधनस्तु मम देहात् प्रसूतः। स्वं वै देहं परहेतोस्त्यजोत को नु ब्रूयात् समतामन्ववेक्ष्य॥
English Translation: Every morning people saw lying on the ground the dead bodies of Rishis who were emaciated for living on frugal diet.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स मां जिह्यं विदुर सर्वं ब्रवीषि मानं च तेऽहमधिकंधारयामि। यथेच्छकं गच्छ वा तिष्ठ वा त्वं सुसान्त्व्यमानाप्यसती स्त्री जहाति॥
English Translation: Many of those bodies were without flesh or blood. without entrails and with limbs separated from one another. Here and there lay heaps of bones like heaps of conch-shells.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच दन्तर्वेश्म सहसोत्थाय राजन्। नेदमस्तीत्यथ विदुरो भाषमाणः सम्प्राद्रवद् यत्र पार्था बभूवुः॥
English Translation: The earth was scattered over with the (sacrificial) contents of broken jars and shattered ladles for pouring libations of ghee and with the sacred fires kept with care by the ascetics.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच अस्मानभिातांस्तात भयार्ताञ्छरणैषिणः। कौरवान् विषमप्राप्तान् कथं ब्रूयास्त्वमीदृशम्॥
English Translation: The universe, being afflicted with the terror of the Kalkeyas and being destitute of the Vedic studies, of the Vashats and the sacrificial festivals and religious rites, became very fearless.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदा तु भवन्ति भेदा ज्ञातीनां कलहाश्च वृकोदर। प्रसक्तानि च वैराणि कुलधर्मो न नश्यति॥
English Translation: O ruler of men, when men began to perish in this way, the survivors fled for their lives in all directions.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कश्चिज्ज्ञातीनां बाह्यः पोथयते कुलम्। न मर्षयन्ति तत् सन्तो बाह्येनाभिप्रधर्षणम्॥
English Translation: Some fled to caverns and some behind mountain streams and springs and some through fear of death gave up their lives.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जानात्येष हि दुर्बुद्धिरस्मानिह चिरोषितान्। स एवं परिभूयास्मानकादिदमप्रियम्॥
English Translation: Those among them who were bow-men and heroes cheerfully went out and took great trouble of find out the Danavas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुर्योधनस्य ग्रहणाद् गन्धर्वेण बलात् प्रभो। स्त्रीणां बाह्याभिमर्शाच्च हतं भवति नः कुलम्॥
English Translation: Failing to find them, for the Asuras had taken shelter in the bottom of the ocean, they came back to their homes greatly aggrieved.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शरणं च प्रपन्नानां त्राणार्थं च कुलस्य च। उत्तिष्ठत नरव्याघ्राः सज्जीभवत मा चिरम्॥
English Translation: O ruler of men, when the universe was being thus destroyed and when sacrificial festivals and religious rites were all destroyed, the celestials were filled with great afflictions.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्जुनश्च यमौ चैव त्वं च वीरापराजितः। मोक्षयध्वं नरव्याघ्रा ह्रियमाणं सुयोधनम्॥
English Translation: Assembling all together with Indra in their midst, they consulted with one another out of fcar. They asked protection from the increate and exalted deity, Narayana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एते रथा नरव्याघ्राः सर्वशस्त्रसमन्विताः। धृतराष्ट्रस्य पुत्राणां विमलाः काञ्चनध्वजाः॥ सस्वनानधिरोहध्वं नित्यसज्जानिमान् रथान्। इन्द्रसेनादिभिः सूतैः कृतशस्त्रैरधिष्ठितान्॥ एतानास्थाय वै यत्ता गन्धर्वान् यो माहवे। सुयोधनस्य मोक्षाय प्रयतध्वमतन्द्रिताः॥ य एव कश्चिद् राजन्यः शरणार्थमिहागतम्। परं शक्त्याभिरक्षेत किं पुनस्त्वं वृकोदर॥
English Translation: Going to that unvanquished lord of Vaikuntha and bowing to that slayer of Madhu, the celestials thus addressed him,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क इहार्यो भवेत् त्राणमभिधावेति नोदितः। प्राञ्जलिं शरणापन्नं दृष्ट्वा शत्रुमपि ध्रुवम्॥ वरप्रदानं राज्यं च पुत्रजन्म च पाण्डवाः। शत्रोच मोक्षणं क्लेशात् त्रीणि चैकं च तत्समम्॥
English Translation: “O lord, you are the creator, the protector and the destroyer of the universe as well as of ourselves. It is you who have created this universe with all its mobile creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किं चाप्यधिकमेतस्माद् यदापन्नः सुयोधनः। त्वद्वाहुबलमाश्रित्य जीवितं परिमार्गते॥
English Translation: O lotus-eyed deity, it is you who in the days of yore assuming the form of a boar raised the sunken earth from the sea for the benefit of all creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्वयमेव प्रधावेयं यदि न स्याद् वृकोदर। विततो मे क्रतुर्वीर न हि मेऽत्र विचारणा॥
English Translation: O foremost of Purushas, assuming the form of Narasimha (half man and half lion) you killed in the days of yore the ancient and greatly powerful Daityas, called Hiranayakashipu.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: साम्नैव तु यथा भीम मोक्षयेथाः सुयोधनम्। तथा सर्वैरुपायैस्त्वं यतेथाः कुरुनन्दन॥ न साम्ना प्रतिपद्येत यदि गन्धर्वराडसौ। पराक्रमेण मृदुना मोक्षयेथाः सुयोधनम्॥
English Translation: There was a great Asura named Bali, incapable of being killed by any crcature. Assuming the form of a dwarf, you exiled him from the three worlds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथासौ मृदुयुद्धेन न मुञ्चेद् भीम कौरवान्। सर्वोपायैविमोच्यास्ते निगृह्य परिपन्थिनः॥
English Translation: It is by you that wicked Asura called Jambha who was a powerful bow-man and v.ho always obstructed sacrifices was killed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतावद्धि मया शक्यं संदेष्टुं वै वृकोदर। वैताने कर्मणि तते वर्तमाने च भारत॥
English Translation: Your acts are like those which, O slayer of Madhu, cannot be counted. You are the refuge of all who are afflicted with fear.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच अजातशत्रोर्वचनं तच्छ्रुत्वा तु धनंजयः। प्रतिजज्ञे गुरोर्वाक्यं कौरवाणां विमोक्षणम्॥
English Translation: O god of gods, it is for this we tell you what is our present trouble. Save the worlds, the celestials and Indra also from this great fear.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्जुन उवाच यदि साम्ना न मोक्ष्यन्ति गन्धर्वा धृतराष्ट्रजान्। अद्य गन्धर्वराजस्य भूमि: पास्यति शोणितम्॥ अर्जुनस्य तु तां श्रुत्वा प्रतिज्ञां सत्यवादिनः। कौरवाणां तदा राजन् पुनः प्रत्यागतं मनः॥
English Translation: Dhritarashtra said “Alas great was the misery of that person and very painful his life. Tell me, O best of speakers, whence his attachment to life and whence his happiness was.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच ततः कदाचिद् दुर्वासाः सुखासीनांस्तु पाण्डवान्। भुक्त्वा चावस्थितां कृष्णां ज्ञात्वा तस्मिन् वने मुनिः।१ अभ्यागच्छत् परिवृतः शिप्यैरयुतसम्मितैः।
English Translation: Where is that region, so inimical to the practice of virtue, where that person lives, Oh, tell me how that man will be freed from all those great dangers?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दृष्ट्वाऽऽयान्तं तमतिथिं स च राजा युधिष्ठिरः॥ जगामाभिमुखः श्रीमान् सह भ्रातृभिरच्युतः। तस्मै बद्धवाञ्जलिं सम्यगुपवेश्य वरासने॥ विधिवत् पूजयित्वा तमातिथ्येन न्यमन्त्रयत्। आह्निकं भगवन् कृत्वा शीघ्रमेहीति चाब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: Tell me all this. We shall then try our best for him. I am stricken with pity on account of the difficulties that lie in the way of his release."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जगाम च मुनिः सोऽपि स्नातुं शिष्यैः सहानघः। भोजयेत् सहशिष्यं मां कथमित्यविचिन्तयन्॥ न्यमज्जत् सलिले चापि मुनिसङ्घः समाहितः।
English Translation: Vidura said O king, they that are conversant with the religion of Moksha cite this as a simile. Understanding this properly, a person may attain to blissful regions hereafter.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतस्मिन्नन्तरे राजन् द्रौपदी योषितां वरा॥ चिन्तामवाप परमामन्नहेतोः पतिव्रता।
English Translation: That which is described as the forest is the great world. The inaccessible forest within it is the limited sphere of a man's life.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सा चिन्तयन्ती च यदा नान्नहेतुमविन्दत॥ मनसा चिन्तयामास कृष्णं कंसनिषूदनम्।
English Translation: Those described as beasts of prey are the diseases. The huge woman living in the forest, is identified by the wise with Decrepitude which destroys complexion and beauty. The pit is the body of embodied creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृष्ण कृष्ण महाबाहो देवकीनन्दनाव्यया॥ वासुदेव जगन्नाथ प्रणतातिविनाशन। विश्वात्मन् विश्वजनक विश्वहर्तः प्रभोऽव्यय॥ प्रपन्नपाल गोपाल प्रजापाल परात्पर। आकृतीनां च चित्तीनां प्रवर्तक नतास्मि ते॥
English Translation: The huge snake living in the bottom of that pit is Time, the destroyer of all embodied beings. It is, indeed, the universal destroyer.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वरेण्य वरदानन्त अगतीनां गतिर्भव। पुराणपुरुष प्राणमनोवृत्त्याद्यगोचर॥ सर्वाध्यक्ष पराध्यक्ष त्वामहं शरणं गता। पाहि मां कृपया देव शरणागतवत्सल॥
English Translation: The cluster of creepers growing in that pit and by whose spreading stems the man hangs down is the man hangs down is the desire for life which every creature entertains.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नीलोत्पलदलश्याम पद्मगर्भारुणेक्षण। पीताम्बरपरीधान लसत्कौस्तुभभूषण॥ त्वमादिरन्तो भूतानां त्वमेव च परायणम्। परात्परतरं ज्योतिर्विश्वात्मा सर्वतोमुखः॥
English Translation: The six-faxed elephant, O king, which runs towards the tree standing at the mouth of the pit is the year. Its six faces are the seasons and its twelve feet are the twelve months.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वामेवाहुः परं बीजं निधानं सर्वसम्पदाम। त्वया नाथेन देवेश सर्वापद्भ्यो भयं न हि॥
English Translation: The rats and the snakes that are eating up the tree are the days and nights that are continually lessening the periods of life of all creatures. The bees are our desires.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुःशासनादहं पूर्व सभायां मोचिता यथा। तथैव संकटादस्मान्मामुद्धर्तुमिहार्हसि॥
English Translation: The numerous jets that are pouring honey are the pleasures derived from the gratification of our desires and to which men and strongly addicted.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच एवं स्तुतस्तदा देवः कृष्णया भक्तवत्सलः। द्रौपद्याः संकटं ज्ञात्वा देवदेवो जगत्पतिः॥ पार्श्वस्थां शयने त्यक्त्वा रुक्मिणी केशवः प्रभुः। तत्राजगाम त्वरितो ह्यचिन्त्यगतिरीश्वरः॥
English Translation: The wise know life's course to be such. Through that knowledge they succeed in snapping its fetters.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्तं द्रौपदी दृष्ट्वा प्रणम्य परया मुदा। अब्रवीद् वासुदेवाय मुनेरागमनादिकम्॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said In the thick of that awe-inspiring fray, Bhima, fighting single-handed, against tremendous odds, addressed his charioteer and said-"drive towards the centre of the Dhartarashtra force."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्तामब्रवीत् कृष्णः क्षुधितोऽस्मि भृशातुरः। शीघ्रं भोजय मां कृष्णे पश्चात् सर्वं करिष्यसि॥ निशम्य तद्वचः कृष्णा लज्जिता वाक्यमब्रवीत्। स्थाल्यां भास्करदत्तायामन्नं मद्भोजनावधि॥ भुक्तवत्यस्म्यहं देव तस्मादन्नं न विद्यते।
English Translation: Spur your horses, O charioteer and I will hasten the departure of all these Dhartarashtras to the region occupied by the King of Death." The charioteer, being thus desired by Bhimasena, drove, at a furious speed, towards the spot against the whole hosts of your sons and from whence Bhima wished to fight them out and then, from all sides, a large retinue of Kaurava force, consisting of elephant and carwarriors and cavalry and infantry, hemmed him in.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः प्रोवाच भगवान् कृष्णां कमललोचनः॥ कृष्णे न नर्मकालोऽयं क्षुच्छ्रमेणातुरे मयि। शीघ्रं गच्छ मम स्थालीमानीय त्वं प्रदर्शय॥ इति निर्बन्धतः स्थालीमानाय्य स यदूद्वहः। स्थाल्याः कण्ठेऽथ संलग्नं शाकानं वीक्ष्य केशवः॥ उपयुज्याब्रवीदेनामनेन हरिरीश्वरः। विश्वात्मा प्रीयतां देवस्तुष्टश्चास्त्विति यज्ञभुक्॥
English Translation: And they all poured down their arrows on that best of chariots occupied by Bhima from every direction, whereupon the high-souled Bhima, with his own gold-feathered shafts, scattered to the winds, all those weapons hurled against him by his enemies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आकारय मुनीन् शीघ्रं भोजनायेति चाब्रवीत्। सहदेवं महाबाहुः कृष्णः कलेशविनाशनः॥
English Translation: And those gold-winged arrows of his enemies, thus broken into tatters of two or three fragments by the shafts of Bhima, fell upon the ground. Then, O King, there arose one long loud cry of woe from amidst the throng of those valiant chiefs of the Kshatriya race, as they, with their mounts of elephants and steeds and their chariots and body infantry, got afflicted with the arrows thrust hard by Bhima, like thunders rolling in mountains. Those pride of the Kshatriya race, being thus assailed by Bhima, and his powerful shafts smiting them hip and thigh, flew at him (Bhima) from every side of the plain, like the new-fledged family of the feathered tribes thickening around a tree. And as your troops fell back upon him, Bhima, of infinite prowess and strength, repulsed them with the full display of all his might, like the mighty King of Terrors, dealing destruction, at the end of time, with his mace, unto the creation. And your hosts, in that battle, could not repel the fearful impetuosity of Bhima, himself the personation of fire and fury, like the great Destroyer himself rushing, at the end of the cycle, with wide-open mouth for the extermination of all living beings. O Bharata, the whole troops, comprising the Bharata force, thus ruthlessly torn as under in battle, by the noble-minded Bhima, dispersed from the field in a state of panic, like a strong gust of wind scattering thick clouds in a tempest. Then the powerful Bhimasena, endowed with great sagacity, addressing his charioteer once more, said unto him in full glee. "Just know, O Suta, whether do all those chariots, which are advancing towards us, belong to our party, or to that of the enemy. As I, with this battle raging, can make no distinction between the two, see that I do not besiege my own hosts with my shafts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो जगाम त्वरितः सहदेवो महायशाः। आकारितुं तु तान् सर्वान् भोजनार्थं नृपोत्तम॥ स्नातुं गतान् देवनद्यां दुर्वासः प्रभृतीन् मुनीन्। ते चावतीर्णाः सलिले कृतवन्तोऽघमर्षणम्॥ दृष्ट्वोद्गारान् सान्नरसांस्तृप्त्या परमया युताः। उत्तीर्य सलिलात् तस्माद् दृष्टवन्तः परस्परम्॥ दुर्वाससमभिप्रेक्ष्य ते सर्वे मुनयोऽब्रुवन्। राज्ञा हि करायित्वान्नं वयं स्नातुं समागताः॥ आकण्ठतृप्ता विप्रर्षे किंस्विद् भुञ्जामहे वयम्। वृथा पाकः कृतोऽस्माभिस्तत्र किं करवामहे॥
English Translation: I am greatly mortified, O Vishoka, to see around me these leaders of war in hostile array and also with the sight of their cars and the tops of their standards. The king lies wounded and the diadem-decked Arjuna is not yet come to take the field. All these, O Suta, are preying heavily on me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुर्वासा उवाच वृथा पाकेन राजर्षेरपराधः कृतो महान्। मास्मानधाक्षुर्दृष्ट्वैव पाण्डवाः क्रूरचक्षुषा॥ स्मृत्वानुभावं राजर्षेरम्बरीषस्य धीमतः। बिभेमि सुतरां विप्रा हरिपादाश्रयाज्जनात्॥ पाण्डवाश्च महात्मानः सर्वे धर्मपरायणाः। शूराश्च कृतविद्याश्च वतिनस्तपसि स्थिताः॥ सदाचाररता नित्यं वासुदेवपरायणाः। क्रुद्धास्ते निर्दहेयुर्वै तूलराशिमिवानलः। तत एतानपृष्ट्वैव शिष्याः शीघ्रं पलायत॥
English Translation: O charioteer, that the pious king Yudhishthira should have gone away from the field, leading me alone in the midst of the enemy, is in itself hear-rending. Then again I am quite in the dark as to his fate. Nor do I know whether Vibhatsu is still alive or not. All these add to my grief.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच इत्युक्तास्ते द्विजाः सर्वे मुनिना गुरुणा तदा। पाण्डवेभ्यो भृशं भीता दुद्रुवुस्ते दिशो दश॥
English Translation: And though dejected and disspirited, I will play the hell with all these troops inspite of their strength. And thus making the vast army in hostile array pay the penalty in the wager of battle, let me rejoice with you today.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सहदेवो देवनद्यामपश्यन् मुनिसत्तमान्। तीर्थेष्वितस्ततस्तस्या विचचार गवेषयन्॥
English Translation: O Suta, examine closely all the quivers of my arrows and see the numbers still left and then let me know decidedly the quantity and variety of each.”
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्रस्थेभ्यस्तापसेभ्यः श्रुत्वा तांश्चैव विद्रुतान्। युधिष्ठिरमथाभ्येत्य तं वृत्तान्तं न्यवेदयत्॥
English Translation: Vishoka said Being thus addressed, Vishoka replied-"O hero, you have full sixty thousand arrows still left, while your shafts, both razor-shaped and broad-pointed, number ten thousand each. O hero, you have still two thousand cloth-yard shafts, while the Pradaras, O Partha, number three thousand.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्ते पाण्डवाः सर्वे प्रत्यागमनकाक्षिणः। प्रतीक्षन्तः कियत्कालं जितात्मानोऽवतस्थिरे॥
English Translation: To speak candidly, O son of Pandu, the quantity that is still left is quite unmanageable even by half-a-dozen bullocks, if placed on carts. O skillful one, throw off your weapons in no measured number, for your maces, swords and scimitars, as also your lances darts and spears and other weapons of the arms, number thousands upon thousands. So be of good cheer and pray do not be misapprehensive of your weapons running short."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निशीथेऽभ्येत्य चाकस्मादस्मान् स छलयिष्यति कथं च निस्तरेमास्मात् कृच्छ्राद् दैवोपसादितात्॥
English Translation: Bhima said Mark, O Suta, in this day's fearful engagement the plains will present the aspect of the dismal regions, of Death, when the field will be shrouded with thick sets of my irresistible arrows, furiously let loose from off my bow, tearing into pieces the entire body of the trainbands of my enemy and making the Sun, as it were, disappear from view.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इति चिन्तापरान् दृष्ट्वा निःश्वसन्तो मुहुर्मुहुः। उवाच वचनं श्रीमान् कृष्णः प्रत्यक्षतां गतः॥
English Translation: Today, O Suta, it will be known to all the Kshatriyas, even unto the last generation, that either Bhimasena has given himself up in battle, or, singly, he has got the better of all the Kurus.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रीकृष्ण उवाच भवतामापदं ज्ञात्वा ऋषेः परमकोपनात्। द्रौपद्या चिन्तितः पार्था अहं सत्वरमागतः॥
English Translation: Today, either let the Kauravas fall in battle, or, let all the world sound my death knell. Alone, encountering them all, I will either overmatch them, or, let them, all combined, put an extinguisher upon Bhimasena.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न भयं विद्यते तस्मादृषेर्दुर्वाससोऽल्पकम्। तेजसा भवतां भीतः पूर्वमेव पलायितः॥
English Translation: May the guardian angels, who further the course of all righteous action, shower down their blessing on me; and let Arjuna, the victor of enemies, come here speedily (to my relief), like the invoked Sakra appearing in the sacrificial ground.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धर्मनित्यास्तु ये केचिन्न ते सीदन्ति कहिचित्। आपृच्छे वो गमिष्यामि नियतं भद्रमस्तु वः॥
English Translation: Look there and see the disbanded Bharata force! Why are all these chiefs taking to their flight. Surely it seems to me inevitable that Savyasachin, that best of human beings has been shrouding that force with a heavy downpour of his arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच श्रुत्वेरितं केशवस्य बभूवुः स्वस्थमानसाः। द्रौपद्या सहिताः पार्थास्तमूचुर्विगतज्वराः॥ त्वया नाथेन गोविन्द दुस्तरामापदं विभो। तीर्णाः प्लवमिवासाद्य मज्जमाना महार्णवे॥
English Translation: Look there, O Vishoka, (and see how) the mounted soldiers riding on their steeds or elephants and standard-bearers and footsoldiers and beating their retreat. Look, also, at these war-chariots, (and see how) they with their warriors on, are getting scattered by the darts, shafts and arrows, O Suta.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्वस्ति साधय भद्रं ते इत्याज्ञातो ययौ पुरीम्। पाण्डवाश्च महाभाग द्रौपद्या सहिताः प्रभो॥
English Translation: Charged with the gold-winged and peacock-feathered arrows of Dhananjaya and bursting like the bolts from the blue, those Kaurava forces, falling fast in numbers, as often swell the ranks of their file.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ऊषुः प्रहष्टमनसो विहरन्तो वनाद् वनम्। इति तेऽभिहितं राजन् यत् पृष्टोऽहमिह त्वया॥
English Translation: Those steed yoked on war-chariots and elephants trampling down the vast array of foot-soldiers are fleeting away. In sooth, the whole host of the Kauravas, seized with consternation, are beating a hasty retreat, as do the terrified elephants in the midst of a flaming forest. The elephants are roaring furiously in the field and their savage cries, O Vishoka, make, one and all, utter cries of woe and alas!'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवंविधान्यलीकानि धार्तराष्ट्रैर्दुरात्मभिः। पाण्डवेषु वनस्थेषु प्रयुक्तानि वृथाभवन्॥
English Translation: Vishoka said Can't you, O Bhima, hear the awful sound of the Gandiva? (or), have those ears of yours lost their sensibility from the effects of the thunder produced by Partha, while out stretching it with fire and fury?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच यथा संशप्तकैः सार्धमर्जुनस्याभवद् रणः। अन्येषां च महीपानां पाण्डवैस्तद् ब्रवीहि मे॥
English Translation: All your wishes, O son of Pandu, have been gratified, yonder is seen the standard of Ape (of Arjuna) wafting aloft. Look there the bowstring (of Gandiva) is emitting incessantly rays of light, like the flashes of lightning from amidst the blue regions of ethereal space.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अश्वत्थाम्नस्तु यद् युद्धमर्जुनस्य च संजय। अन्येषां च महीपानां पाण्डवैस्तद् ब्रवीहि मे॥
English Translation: That Ape wafting aloft from the standard of Dhananjaya, is seen to strike terror, all along the line of the enemy, (and to speak freely) even I myself am stricken with awe at that (august) sight.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच शृणु राजन् यथा वृत्तं संग्राम ब्रुवतो मम। वीराणां शत्रुभिः सार्धं देहपाप्मासुनाशनम्॥
English Translation: There, the resplendent beauty of Dhananjaya's diadem is shedding its effulgence brightly and the bright luster of the gem-studded on it. Sparkling with the radiancy of the Sun, is looking much more resplendent.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पार्थः संशप्तकबलं प्रविश्यार्णवसंनिभम्। व्यक्षोभयदमित्रधो महावात इवार्णवम्॥
English Translation: Alongside him, behold, there, his conch Devadatta to thundering blare and resembling a white sheet of cloud. Behold there, Janaradana, reins in hand, making his way into the centre of the hostile divisions.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शिरांस्युन्मथ्य वीराणां शितैर्भल्लैर्धनंजयः। पूर्णचन्द्राभवक्त्राणि स्वक्षिभूदशनानि च ॥ संतस्तार क्षितिं क्षिप्रं विनालैनलिनैरिव।
English Translation: Behold, there, O hero, by the side of Janardana his discus, radiant like the Sun, nave like thunder and sharp like razor-that discus which enhances the fame of Keshava and which is always worshipped by the Yadus. son
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुवृत्तानायतान् पुष्टांश्चंदनागुरुभूषितान्॥ सायुधान् सतलत्रांश्च पञ्चचास्योरगसंनिभान्। बाहून् क्षुरैरमित्राणां चिच्छेद समरेऽर्जुनः॥
English Translation: There, large trunks of huge elephants, resembling the lofty yew trees, dissevered by Kiritin are falling fast. There, also, huge elephants and their riders, pierced with shafts all through, are falling down like mountains riven with thunder.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धुर्यान् धुर्यगतान् सूतान ध्वजाश्चापानि सायकान्। पाणीन् सरत्नानसकृद भल्लैश्चिच्छेद पाण्डवः॥
English Translation: Behold, there, O of Kunti, the Panchajanya (conch) of Krishna, resplendent like the moon, the Kaustabha, (pearl) dazzling on his breasts and his garland of victory.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रथान् द्विपान् हयांश्चैव सारोहानर्जुनो युधि। शरैरनेकसाहौनिन्ये राजन् यमक्षयम्॥
English Translation: There cannot be any mistake in the fact that Partha, the glory of car-warriors-the best and foremost of them, carried by those precious steeds of his, the best of their kind, and in color as white as the white clouds of the sky, with Krishna as their driver, is rushing in the field, routing the enemy all through.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं प्रवीराः सुसंरब्धा नर्दमाना इवर्षभाः। वासितार्थमिव क्रुद्धमभिद्रुत्य मदोत्कटाः॥ निघ्नन्तमभिजनुस्ते शरैः शृङ्गैरिवर्षभाः।
English Translation: Behold there, your younger, resembling in energy the deity of the celestials, is piercing with his shafts those cars, steeds and bands of foot-soldiers and they are falling down as if a forest over-thrown by the tempest caused by the wings of Garuda.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य तेषां च तद् युद्धमभवल्लोमहर्षणम्॥ त्रैलोक्यविजये यद्वद् दैत्यानां सह वज्रिणा।
English Translation: Behold, Kiritin, with his powerful shafts, to outstrip in battle four hundred car-warriors with their steeds and drivers and seven hundred elephants, as also numberless infantry and cavalry.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अस्त्रैरस्त्राणि संवार्य द्विषतां सर्वतोऽर्जुनः॥ इषुभिर्बहुभिस्तूर्णं विद्ध्वा प्राणाञ्जहार सः।
English Translation: Shedding his effulgence like the constellation of Chirta, the all-powered Arjuna, after having massacred the Kuru forces, is speeding towards you. All your wishes have been gratified-your enemies, thrown overboard. May your prowess and the span of your life continue to increase for ever and ever.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: छिन्नत्रिवेणुतक्राक्षान् हययोधान्ससारथीन्॥ विद्ध्वस्तायुधतूणीरान् समुन्मथितकेतनान्। संछिन्नयोक्ररश्मीकान् विवरूथान विकूबरान्॥ विस्त्रस्तबन्धुरयुगान् विस्त्रस्ताक्षप्रमण्डलान्। रथान् विशकलीकुर्वन् महाभ्राणीव मारुतः॥ विस्मापयन् प्रेक्षणीयं द्विषतां भयवर्धनम्। महारथसहस्रस्य समं कर्माकरोज्जयः॥
English Translation: Bhima said For this welcome news, O charioteer, with unfeigned pleasure I grant you fourteen choice villages; and O Vishoka, as you bring me the tidings of Arjuna, I also present you a hundred female slaves and twenty chariots.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सिद्धदेवर्षिसंघाश्च चारणाश्चापि तुष्टुवुः। देवदुन्दुभयो नेदुः पुष्पवर्षाणि चापतन्॥ केशवार्जुनयोर्मूनि प्राह वाचशरोरिणी।
English Translation: Yudhishthira said Tell us, O destroyer of Madhu, the prosperity which originates from the worship of the Brahmanas. You are a master of this subject. Indeed, our grandfather knows you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चन्द्राग्न्यनिलसूर्याणां कान्तिदीप्तिबलद्युतीः॥ यौ सदा बिभ्रतुर्वीराविमौ तौ केशवार्जुनौ। ब्रह्मेशानाविवाजय्यौ वीरावेकरथे स्थितौ॥ सर्वभूतवरौ वीरौ नरनारायणाविमौ।
English Translation: Vasudeva said Hear me, O king, with attention, O chief of Bharata's race, as I recite to you what the merits of the Brahmanas are, O foremost one of Kuru's race.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्येतन्महदाश्चर्य दृष्ट्वा श्रुत्वा च भारत॥ अश्वत्थामा सुसंयत्तः कृष्णावभ्यद्रवद् रणे।
English Translation: Once on a time while I was scated at Dvaravati, O delighter of the Kurus, my son Pradyumna, enraged by certain Brahmanas, came to me and said, O destroyer of Madhu, what mcrit is there for adoring the Brahmanas. Whence is their lordship derived both in this world and in the next.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ पाण्डवमस्यन्तममित्रघ्नकराज्छरान्॥ सेषुणा पाणिनाऽऽहूय प्रहसन द्रौणिरब्रवीत्।
English Translation: O giver of honours, what rewards are gained by constantly adoring the Brahmanas? Kindly explain this clearly to me, for my mind is disturbed by doubts about this.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदि मा मन्यसे वीर प्राप्तमर्हमिहातिथिम्॥ ततः सर्वात्मना त्वद्य युद्धातिथ्यं प्रयच्छ मे।
English Translation: When Pradyuinna said, these words to me, I answered him as follows. Do you hear, O king, with rapt attention, what those words were.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमाचार्यपुत्रेण समाहूतो युयुत्सया॥ बहु मेनेऽर्जुनीऽऽत्मानमिति चाह जनार्दनम्
English Translation: O child of Rukmini, listen to me as I tell you what prosperity one may acquire by adoring the Brahmanas. When one tries to acquire the threefold objects of life (viz., Virtue, Profit and Pleasure). or Emancipation, or fame and prosperity, or the treatment and cure of disease, or the worship of the deities and the departed manes, he should take care to please the twiceborn ones. They are each a king Soma. They are the dispensers of happiness and misery.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संशप्तकाश्च मे वध्या द्रौणिराह्वयते च माम्॥ यदत्रानन्तरं प्राप्तं शंस मे तद्धि माधव। आतिथ्यकर्माभ्युत्थाय दीयतां यदि मन्यसे॥
English Translation: O child of Rukmini, whether in this or in the next world, O son, everything agrecable has originated from the Brahmanas. I have no doubt in this.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्तोऽवहत् पार्थं कृष्णो द्रोणात्मजान्तिके। जैत्रेण विधिनाऽऽहूतं वायुरिन्द्रमिवाध्वरे॥
English Translation: From the adoration of the Brahinanas originate achievements and fame and strength. Men and the Regents of the universe, adore the Brahmanas. We should satisfy the Brahmanas for the sake of accomplishment on holy deeds, wealth and desires, for attainment of emancipation, fame, grace and health as also at the time of offering pray to gods and Pitris.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमामन्त्र्यैकमनसं केशवो द्रौणिमब्रवीत्। अश्वत्थामन् स्थिरो भूत्वा प्रहराशु सहस्व च॥
English Translation: How then, O son, can we disregard them, thinking that we are lords of the Earth? O mighty armed onc, do not allow your anger to embrace the Brahmanas as its objeci.,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निर्वेष्टुं भर्तृपिण्डं हि कालोऽयमुपजीविनाम्। सूक्ष्मो विवादो विप्राणां स्थूलौ क्षात्रौ जयाजयौ॥२८
English Translation: In this as also the next world, Brahmanas are considered as great Beings. They have direct knowledge of everything in the universe. Verily, they are capable of reducing everything into ashes, if angry.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यामभ्यर्थयसे मोहाद् दिव्यां पार्थस्य सक्रियाम्। तामाप्नुमिच्छन युध्यस्व स्थिरो भूत्वाद्य पाण्डवम्।। २९
English Translation: They are capable of creating other worlds and other Regents of worlds. Why then should not persons gifted with energy and true knowledge treat thein with obcdience and respect?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्युक्तो वासुदेवेन तथेत्युक्त्वा द्विजोत्तमः। विव्याध केशवं षष्ट्या नाराचैरर्जुनं त्रिभिः॥
English Translation: Formerly in my house, O son, lived the Brahmana Durvasas whose complexion was green and tawny. Clad in rags, he had a stick made of the Bilva tree. His bcard was long and he was greatly emaciated.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्यार्जुनः सुसंक्रुद्धस्त्रिभिर्बाणैः शरासनम्। चिच्छेद चान्यदादत्त द्रौणिर्घोरतरं धनुः॥
English Translation: He was taller in stature than the tallest man on Earth. Wandering over all the worlds of human beings and of the deities and other superior beings, he sang constantly among assemblies and in public squares. Who is there who would cause the Brahmana Durvasas to live in his house, doing the duties of hospitality towards him?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सज्यं कृत्वा निमेषाच विव्याधार्जुनकेशवो। त्रिभिः शतैर्वासुदेवं सहस्रेण च पाण्डवम्॥
English Translation: He becomes wroth with cvery one if he finds even the slightest transgression! Hearing this about my nature, who is there who will give me refuge?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः शरसहस्राणि प्रयुतान्यर्बुदानि च। ससृजे द्रौणिरायस्तः संस्तभ्य च रणेऽर्जुनम्॥
English Translation: Indeed, he who would give me shelter as a guest should not do anything to anger me! When I saw that no one ventured to give him shelter in his house, I invited him and made him live in my abode.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इषुधेर्धनुषश्चैव ज्यायाश्चैवाथ मारिष। बाह्वोः कराभ्यामुरसो वदनघ्राणनेत्रतः॥ कर्णाभ्यां शिरसोऽङ्गेभ्यो लोमवर्मभ्य एव च। रथध्वजेभ्यश्च शरा निष्पेतुर्ब्रह्मवादिनः॥
English Translation: On certain days hic would cat the food sufficient for the needs of thousands of persons. On other days he would eat very little. On some days he would go out of my house and would not return.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शरजालेन महता विद्ध्वा माधवयाण्डवौ। ननाद मुदितो द्रौणिर्महामेघौघनिःस्वनम्॥
English Translation: He would sometimes laugh without any reason and sometimes cry uselessly At that time there was nobody on Earth a old as he.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य तं निनदं श्रुत्वा पाण्डवोऽच्युतमब्रवीत्। पश्य माधव दौरात्म्यं गुरुपुत्रस्य मां प्रति॥
English Translation: One day, entering the quarters which were given to him, he burnt all the beds and coveriets and all the welladorned damsels who were there for serving him. Doing this, he went Out.

Sanskrit Shloka: वधं प्राप्तौ मन्यते नौ प्रावेश्य शरवैश्मनि। एषोऽस्मि हन्मि संकल्प शिक्षया च बलेन च॥
English Translation: Of highly praiseworthy vows, he met me shortly after this and addressing me, said, O Krishna, I wish to cal frumenty forthwith.

Sanskrit Shloka: अश्वत्थाम्नः शरानस्तान् छित्त्वैकैकं त्रिधा त्रिधा। व्यधमद् भरतश्रेष्ठो नीहारमिव मारुतः॥
English Translation: Having understood his mind previously. I had set my servams to prepare every kind of food and drink.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत: संशप्तकान् भूयः साश्वसूतस्थद्विपान्। ध्वजपत्तिगणानुग्रैर्बाणैवर्विव्याध पाण्डवः॥
English Translation: Indeed, many excellent viands had been kept ready. As soon as I was asked, I caused hot frumenty to be brought and offered to the ascetic.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ये ये दद्दशिरे तत्र यद्यद्रूपास्तदा जनाः। ते ते तत्र शरैर्व्याप्त मेनिरिऽऽत्मानमात्मना॥
English Translation: Having eaten some, he quickly said to me, O Krishna, take some of this frumenty and smear all your limbs with it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते गाण्डीवप्रमुक्तास्तु नानारूपाः पतत्रिणः। क्रोशे साग्रे स्थितान् प्रन्ति द्विपाश्चं पुरुषान् रणे॥४२
English Translation: Unhesitatingly I did as directed. Indeed, with the residuc of that frumenty I smeared my body and head.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भल्लैश्छिन्नाः करा: पेतुः करिणां मदवर्षिणाम्। यथा वने परशुभिर्निकृत्ता: सुमहाद्रुमाः॥
English Translation: The ascetic at that time saw your beautiful mother standing near. Laughing the while, he sineared her body also with that frumenty.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पश्चात्तु शैलवत् पेतुस्ते गजाः सह सादिभिः। वज्रिवज्रप्रमथिता यथैवाद्रिचयास्तथा॥
English Translation: The ascetic then caused your mother, whose body was sicared over with frumenty, to be yoked to a car without any delay. Ascending that car he started from my house.

Sanskrit Shloka: गन्धर्वनगराकारान् रथांश्चैव सुकल्पितान्। विनीतैर्जनैयुक्तानास्थितान् युद्धदुर्मदैः॥ शरैर्विशकलीकुर्वन्नमित्राभ्यवीवृषत्। स्वलंकृतानश्वसादीन् पत्तींश्चाहन धनंजयः॥
English Translation: Highly intelligent that Brahmana shone with effulgence like fire, and struck, before, me, my youthful Rukmini, as if she were an animal born to drag the cars of human beings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धनंजययुगान्तकः संशप्तकमहार्णवम्। व्यशोषयत दुःशोषं तीक्ष्णैः शरगभस्तिभिः॥
English Translation: Secing this, I did not feel the slightest grief bom of malice or the desire to injure the Rishi. Having yoked Rukmini to the car, he went out, desirous of passing along the high road of the city.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुनद्रौणि महशैलं नाराचैर्वज्रसंनिभैः। निर्बिभेद महावेगेस्त्वरन् वज्रीस पर्वतम्॥
English Translation: Secing that extraordinary spectacle, some Dasharhas, filled with anger, addressed one another and began to converse thus; Who else is there on Earth who would live afier having yoke Rukmini to a car! Indeed, let the world be filled with Bralımanas only! Let no other orders take birth here!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमाचार्यसुतः क्रुद्धः साश्वयन्तारमाशुगैः। युयुत्सुरागमद्योढुं पार्थस्तानच्छिनच्छरान्॥
English Translation: The poison of a virulent snake greatly powerful. More powerful thc poison is a Brahmana. There is no physician for a person who has been bit or burn by the virulent snake of a Brahmana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः परमसंक्रुद्धः पाण्डवेऽस्त्राण्यवासृजत्। अश्वत्थामाभिरूपाय गृहानतिथये यथा।॥
English Translation: As the irresistible Durvasas proceeded on the car, Rukmini tottered on the road and frequently dropped down. At this the twiceborn Rishi became angry and began to urge Rukmini on by striking her with the whip.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ संशप्तकांस्त्यक्त्वा पाण्डवो द्रौणिमभ्ययात्। अपाडक्तेयानिव त्यक्त्वा दाता पाडक्तेयमर्थिनम्॥
English Translation: At last, filled with an irresistible passion, the Brahmana leaped down from the car, and fled towards the south, running on foot, over a pathless ground.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राम उवाच ममापराधात् तैः क्षुदैर्हतस्त्वं तात बालिशैः। कार्तवीर्यस्य दायादैर्वने मृग इवेषुभिः॥
English Translation: Seeing that foremost of Brahmanas, flying along the pathless ground, we followed him, although we were smeared with frumenty, exclaiming behind him, Be pleased with us, O holy onc.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धर्मज्ञस्य कथं तात वर्तमानस्य सत्पथे। मृत्युरेवंविधो युक्तः सर्वभूतेष्वनागसः॥
English Translation: Gifted with great energy, the Brahmana, seeing me, said, O mightyarmed Krishna, you have subdued anger by the strength of your nature.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किं नु तैर्न कृतं पापं यैर्भवास्तपसि स्थितः। अयुध्यमानो वृद्धः सन् हतः शरशतैः शितैः॥
English Translation: O you of excellent vows, I have not found the slightest fault in you. O Govinda, I have been highly pleased with you. Do you solicit the fruition of such desires as you please.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किं नु ते तत्र वक्ष्यन्ति सचिवेषु सुहृत्सु च। अयुध्यमानं धर्मज्ञमेकं हत्वानपत्रपाः॥
English Translation: Behold duly, O son, what the power is of myself when I become pleased with any one. As long as celestials and human beings will continue to entertain a liking for food, so long will every one among them cherish the same liking for you that they cherish for their food. As long, again as there will be Virtue in the several worlds, so long will the fame of your deeds last.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विलप्यैवं सकरुणं बहु नानाविधं नृप। प्रेतकार्याणि सर्वाणि पितुश्चक्रे महातपाः॥ ददाह पितरं चाग्नौ रामः परपुरंजयः। प्रतिजज्ञे वधं चापि सर्वक्षत्रस्य भारत॥
English Translation: Indeed, your distinction will last so long in the three worlds. O Janardana, agreeable you will be to all persons.

Sanskrit Shloka: संक्रुद्धोऽतिबलः संख्ये शस्त्रमादाय वीर्यवान्। जनिवान् कार्तवीर्यस्य सुतानेकोऽन्तकोपमः॥
English Translation: Whatever articles of yours have been broken or burnt or otherwise destroyed (by me). you will see restored, O Janardana, to their former state or they will reappear even in a better forin.

English Translation: As long again, O) you of unfading glory, as you will wish to live, so long will you have no fear of death attacking you through such parts of your body as have been smeared with the frumenty I gave you.

Sanskrit Shloka: त्रिःसप्तकृत्वः पृथिवीं कृत्वा निःक्षत्रियां प्रभुः। समन्तपञ्चके पञ्च चकार रुधिरहदान्॥
English Translation: O son, why did you not smear that frumenty on the soles of your feet as well? By not doing it, you have acted in a way that is not approved by me. These were the words that he said, well pleased with me on that occasion. After he had ceased speaking, I saw that my body became gifted with great beauty and splendour.

Sanskrit Shloka: स तेषु तर्पयामास भृगुन् भृगुकुलोद्वहः। साक्षाद् ददर्श चर्चीकं स च रामं न्यवारयत्॥
English Translation: To Rukmini also, the Rishi, well pleased with her, said, O beautiful lady, you will be the foremost one of they sex in fame, and you will enjoy great glory, and achievements. You will never suffer from decrepitude or disease or loss of complexion.

Sanskrit Shloka: ततो यज्ञेन महता जामदग्न्यः प्रतापवान्। तर्पयामास देवेन्द्रमृत्विग्भ्यः प्रददौ महीम्॥
English Translation: Every one will see you engaged in waiting upon Krishna, possessed as you already are with a fragrant odor which is always present in you.

Sanskrit Shloka: वेदी चाप्यददद्वैमी कश्यपाय महात्मने। दशव्यामायतां कृत्वा नवोत्सेधां विशाम्पते॥
English Translation: You will become the foremost of all wives, numbering sixteen thousand, of Keshava. At last, when the time comes for your departure from the world, you will acquire the inseparable companionship of Krishna hereafter.

Sanskrit Shloka: तां कश्यपस्यानुमते ब्राह्मणाः खण्डशस्तदा। व्यभजस्ते तदा राजन् प्रख्याताः खाण्डवायनाः॥
English Translation: Having said these words to your mother, the Rishi once more addressed me and uttering the following words, left the spot. Indeed, the Rishi Durvasa, shining like a fire, said, ) Keshava, may you be so disposed always towards the Brahmanas. After uttering these words, that Brahmana disappeared there and then before my eyes.

Sanskrit Shloka: स प्रदाय महीं तस्मै कश्यपाय महात्मने। अस्मिन् महेन्द्रे शैलेन्द्रे वसत्यमितविक्रमः॥

Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच ततश्चतुर्दशी रामः समयेन महामनाः। दर्शयामास तान् विप्रान्धर्मराजं च सानुजम्॥

Sanskrit Shloka: स तमानर्च राजेन्द्र भ्रातृभिः सहितः प्रभुः। द्विजानां च परां पूजां चक्रे नृपतिसत्तमः॥
English Translation: Seeing those new articles, which had besides become more durable, I became stricken with wonder. O son of Rukmini, from that day forth I have always adored the Brahmanas in my mind.

Sanskrit Shloka: अर्चित्वा जामदग्न्यं स पूजितस्तेन चोदितः। महेन्द्र उष्य तां रात्रि प्रययौ दक्षिणामुखः॥
English Translation: This, O chief of Bharata's race, is what I said on that occasion about the greatness of those Brahmanas who are the foremost of their order.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच प्रकृतीनां च तद् वाक्यं देशकालोपबृंहितम्। श्रुत्वा युधिष्ठिरो राजा चोत्तरं प्रत्यभाषत॥ धन्याः पाण्डुसुता नूनं येषां ब्राह्मणपुङ्गवाः। तथ्यान् वाप्यथवातथ्यान् गुणानाहुः समागताः॥
English Translation: Do you also, O son of Kunti, adore the highly blessed Brahmanas every day with gifts of wealth and kind, O powerful one.

Sanskrit Shloka: अनुग्राह्या वयं नूनं भवतामिति मे मतिः। यदेवं गुणसम्पन्नानस्मान् बूथ विमत्सराः॥
English Translation: It was thus that I won the prosperity I enjoy, the prosperity that is born of the favour of Brahmanas. Whatever, again, Bhishma has said of me, O chief of the Bharatas, is all true.

Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्रो महाराजः पिता मे दैवतं परम्। शासनेऽस्य प्रिये चैव स्थेयं मत्प्रियकाक्षिभिः॥
English Translation: Markandey said : When that powerful, mighty and high-souled one (Mahasena) was born, various kinds of fearful evil omens appeared.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतदर्थं हि जीवामि कृत्वा ज्ञातिवधं महत्। अस्य शुश्रूषणं कार्यं मया नित्यमतन्द्रिणा॥
English Translation: The nature of male and female, of heat and cold and of such other pairs of contraies was reversed. The planets, the cardinal points and the firmaments became radient with light and the earth began to roar.

Sanskrit Shloka: यदि चाहमनुग्राह्यो भवतां सुहृदां तथा। धृतराष्ट्रे यथापूर्वं वृत्तिं वर्तितुमर्हथ॥
English Translation: The Rishis who always sought the welfare of the world, seeing these fearful omens on all sides, began with anxious hearts to restore tranquility in the universe.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एष नाथो हि जगतो भवतां च मया सह। अस्यैव पृथिवी कृत्स्ना पाण्डवाः सर्व एव च॥
English Translation: Those men who lived in that Chaitraratha forest said, “All this disasters have fallen on us in consequence of Agni holding intercourse with the six wives of the seven Rishis."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतन्मनसि कर्तव्यं भविद्भर्वचनं मम। अनुज्ञाप्याथ तान् राजा यथेष्टं गम्यतामिति॥
English Translation: Others who saw her (Svaha) as a bird said, “This has been brought about by a bird.” None ever thought that Svaha was the cause of all this mischief.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पौरजानपदान् सर्वान् विसृज्य कुरुनन्दनः। यौवराज्येन कौन्तेयं भीमसेनमयोजयत्॥
English Translation: Having heard that the child was hers, Svaha slowly went to Skanda and told him, “I am your mother.”
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मन्त्रे च निश्चये चैव षाड्गुण्यस्य च चिन्तने। विदुरं बुद्धिसम्पन्न प्रीतिमान् स समादिशत्॥
English Translation: The seven Rishis, hearing that a greatly powerful son was born (to them), abandoned their six wives except the adorable lady Arundhuti.
