Sanskrit Shloka: कृताकृतपरिज्ञाने तथाऽऽयव्ययचिन्तने। संजयं योजयामास वृद्धं सर्वगुणैर्युतम्॥ बलस्य परिमाणे च भक्तवेतनयोस्तथा। नकुलं व्यादिशद् राजा कर्मणां चान्ववेक्षणे॥
English Translation: Because all the dwellers of that forest said that those six women were the cause of the birth of that child. O king, Svaha also said again and again to the seven Rishis, "O Rishis, this child is mine. Your wives are not its mother."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: परचक्रोपरोधे च दुष्टानां चावमर्दने। युधिष्ठिरो महाराज फाल्गुनं व्यादिदेश ह॥
English Translation: The great Rishi Vishwamitra, after performing the sacrifice of the seven Rishis, had followed unseen Agni when he had been afflicted with desire and therefore he knew all as then happened.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्विजानां देवकार्येषु कार्येष्वन्येषु चैव हा धौम्यं पुरोधसां श्रेष्ठं नित्यमेव समादिशत्॥
English Translation: Vishwamitra was first to seek the protection of Kumara. He offered excellent prayers in honour of Mahasena.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सहदेवं समीपस्थं नित्यमेव समादिशत्। तेन गोप्यो हि नृपतिः सर्वावस्थो विशाम्पते॥
English Translation: All the thirteen auspicious rites of childhood such as the birth and other ceremonies were all performed by the great Rishi in respect of that child.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यान् यानमन्यद् योग्यांश्च येषु येष्विह कर्मसु। तांस्तास्तेष्वेव युयुजे प्रीयमाणो महीपतिः॥
English Translation: For the good of the world, he promulgated the virtues of the six-faced Skanda and performed ceremonies in hour of the cock, the goddess Shakti and the first followers of Skanda. For this reason Vishwamitra became a great favourite of Kumara.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विदुरं संजयं चैव युयुत्सुं च महामतिम्। अब्रवीत् परवीरघ्नो धर्मात्मा धर्मवत्सलः॥ उत्थायोत्थाय तत् कार्यमस्य राज्ञः पितुर्मम। सर्वं भवद्भिः कर्तव्यमप्रमत्तैर्यथायथम्॥
English Translation: That great Rishi told the seven Rishis all about the transformation of Svaha (as their wives) and also told them that their wives are perfectly innocent. (Even) having heard this, the seven Rihsis abandoned their wives,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पौरजानपदानां च यानि कार्याणि सर्वशः। राजानं समनुज्ञाप्य तानि कर्माणि भागशः॥
English Translation: Hearing of Skanda, the celestial then all spoke thus to Vasava (Indra), "O Shakra, soon kill Skanda, for his prowess is unbearable. If you do not destroy him, he will conquer us with all the three worlds. Vanquishing you, he will become the mighty lord of the celestial.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नारायणं नमस्कृत्य नरं चैव नरोत्तमम्। देवी सरस्वतीं व्यासं ततो जयमुदीरयेत्।।
English Translation: Thus spoke Indra to those who were afflicted, 'This child possesses great prowess. He can himself destroy (even) the creator of universe in battle with his prowess. I therefore do not dare to destory him.' Thus said Shakra again and again.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच स्तदाभिमन्योर्मुदिताः स्वपक्षाः। विश्रम्य रात्रावुषसि प्रतीताः सभां विराटस्य ततोऽभिजग्मुः॥
English Translation: They (the celestial) said, “You have no heroism in you, therefore you speak thus. Let the mothers of the universe go today to Skanda. They can muster at will any power they like. Let them kill this child. Saying, “So be it,” they (mothers) went away.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सभा तु सा मत्स्यपतेः समृद्धा मणिप्रवेकोत्तमरत्नचित्रा। न्यस्तासना माल्यवती सुगन्धा तामभ्ययुस्ते नरराजवृद्धाः॥
English Translation: But seeing him matchlessly powerful, they became dispirited. Considering him to be invincible, they sought his protection and said to him, "O greatly powerful one, become our son.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुभौ विराटदुपदौ नरेन्द्रौ। वृद्धौ च मान्यौ पृथिवीपतीनां पित्रा समं रामजनार्दनौ च॥
English Translation: We are full of affection for you. We are desirous of giving you our breasts (to be sucked). The milk oozes out from our breasts." Having heard these words, the mighty Mahasena desired to suck their breasts. He received them with due respect and complied with their request. Then that mightiest of mighty ones saw that his father Agni was coming towards him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पाञ्चालराजस्य समीपतस्तु शिनिप्रवीरः सहरौहिणेयः। मत्स्यस्य राज्ञस्तु सुसंनिकृष्टो जनार्दनश्चैव युधिष्ठिरश्च॥
English Translation: That Sive (the doer of good) was duly honoured by his son; and he with the mothers stayed there near Mahasena to tend him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुताश्च सर्वे दुपदस्य राज्ञो भीमार्जुनौ माद्रवतीसुतौ च। प्रद्युम्नसाम्बौ च युधि प्रवीरौ विराटपुत्रैश्च सहाभिमन्युः॥
English Translation: That lady amongstst the mothers who was born of anger kept watch over Skanda with a spike in hand as a mother guards her own child.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वे च शूराः पितृभिः समाना वीर्येण रूपेण बलेन चैव। उपाविशन् द्रौपदेयाः कुमारा: सुवर्णचित्रेषु वरासनेषुः॥
English Translation: That irascible daughter of blood who lived in blood embraced Mahasena in her breast and nursed him like a mother. And Agni, transforming himself as a teacher with a goat's mouth and followed by numerous children, began to gratify that child with toys on his that mountain abode.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथोपविष्टेषु महारथेषु विराजमानाभरणाम्बरेषु। रराज सा राजवती समृद्धा ग्रहैरिव द्यौर्विमलैरुपेता॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said Seeing that army of yours thoroughly routed in battle, O monarch, Vrishasena endued with prowess, single-handed, began to protect it by means of the illusion of this weapons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत: कथास्ते समवाययुक्ताः कृत्वा विचित्राः पुरुषप्रवीराः। तस्थुर्मुहूर्तं परिचिन्तयन्तः कृष्णं नृपास्ते समुदीक्षमाणाः॥
English Translation: In that battle numerous shafts discharged by Vrishasena flew in all the ten directions of the compass, piercing men, horses, cars and elephants.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कथान्तमासाद्य च माधवेन संघट्टिताः पाण्डवकार्यहेतोः। ते राजसिंहाः सहिता ह्यशृण्वन् वाक्यं महार्थं सुमहोदयं च॥
English Translation: Like the rays of the sun, o king, mighty arrows of blazing effulgence shot by him, began to fly (on all sides).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रीकृष्ण उवाच सर्वैर्भवद्भिर्विदितं यथायं युधिष्ठिरः सौबलेनाक्षवत्याम्। जितो निकृत्यापहृतं च राज्यं वनप्रवासे समयः कृतश्च।॥
English Translation: O monarch, pierced by him car-warriors and cavalry began to fall down suddenly on the ground, like trees broken by the hurricane.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शक्तैविजेतुं तरसा महीं च सत्ये स्थितैः सत्यरथैर्यथावत्। पाण्डोः सुतैस्तग्र व्रतमग्ररूपं वर्षाणि षट् सप्त च चीर्णमग्र्यैः॥
English Translation: That mighty car-warrior felled in battle, O monarch, large divisions of steeds, car-warriors and elephants, by hundreds and thousands.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मज्ञायमानैर्भवतां समीपे। महात्मभिश्चापि वने निविष्टम्॥
English Translation: Seeing him career along through the field of battle, like one fearless, all the monarchs uniting together encompassed him on all sides.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतैः परप्रेष्यनियोगयुक्त रिच्छद्भिराप्तं स्वकुलेन राज्यम्। एवंगते धर्मसुतस्य राज्ञो दुर्योधनस्यापि च यद्धितं स्यात्॥
English Translation: The son of Nakula by name Shatanika charged Vrishasena and pierced the latter with ten Narachas that could penetrate into the very vitals.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तच्चिन्तयध्वं कुरुपुङ्गवानां धर्म्यं च युक्तं च यशस्करं च। अधर्मयुक्तं न च कामयेत राज्यं सुराणामपि धर्मराजः॥
English Translation: The son of Karna, in return, sundered his bow and cut down his standard. The sons of Draupadi desiring to rescue their brother, rushed towards him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धर्मार्थयुक्तं तु महीपतित्वं ग्रामेऽपि कस्मिंश्चिदयं बुभूषेत्। पित्र्यं हि राज्यं विदितं नृपाणां यथापकृष्टं धृतराष्ट्रपुत्रैः॥ मिथ्योपचारेण यथा ह्यनेन कृच्छ्रे महत् प्राप्तमसह्यरूपम्। न चापि पार्थो विजितो रणे तैः स्वतेजसा धृतराष्ट्रस्य पुत्रैः॥
English Translation: Soon with their arrowy showers they made the son of Karna disappear from the view. Thereupon car-warriors headed by the son of Drona charged them, removing the shower of their arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रभीप्सतेऽनामयमेव तेषाम्। यत् तु स्वयं पाण्डुसुतैर्विजित्य समाहृतं भूमिपतीन् प्रपीड्य॥ तत् प्रार्थयन्ते पुरुषप्रवीराः कुन्तीसुता माद्रवतीसुतौ च। बालास्त्विमे तैर्विविधैरुपायैः सम्प्रार्थिता हन्तुममित्रसंघैः॥ राज्यं जिहीर्षद्भिरसद्भित्रैः सर्वं च तद् वो विदितं यथावत्। तेषां च लोभं प्रसमीक्ष्य वृद्धं धर्मज्ञतां चापि युधिष्ठिरस्य॥
English Translation: o monarch, these warriors (headed by Drona's son) speedily covered over the mighty car-warriors namely the sons of Draupadi, with arrows of various description like clouds pouring their contents on a mountain.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सम्बन्धितां चापि समीक्ष्य तेषां मर्ति कुरुध्वं सहिताः पृथक् च। इमे च सत्येऽभिरताः सदैव तं पालयित्वा समयं यथावत्॥
English Translation: Prompted by their affection for their sons, the Pandavas quickly encountered them (assailants), being followed by the Panchalas, Kaikayas, Matsyas and Srinjayas, with their arms uplifted.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अतोऽन्यथा तैरुपचर्यमाणा हन्युःसमेतान् धृतराष्ट्रपुत्रान्। तैर्विप्रकारं च निशम्य कार्ये सुहृज्जनास्तान् परिवारयेयुः॥
English Translation: Then commenced a fierce and sanguinary and hair-stirring engagement between your army and the army of the sons of Pandu like that between the celestials and the Danavas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युद्धेन बाधेयुरिमांस्तथैव तैर्बाध्यमाना युधि तांश्च हन्युः। स्तेषां जयोयेति भवेन्मतं वः॥ स्तेषां विनाशाय यतेयुरेव। न ज्ञायते किं न करिष्यतीति॥
English Translation: Thus the heroes among the Kuru and the Pandava hosts, wrought up with wrath, fought with one another looking furiously at one another and nourishing (deadly) hatred for one another.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अज्ञायमाने च मते परस्य किं स्यात् समारभ्यतमं मतं वः। तस्मादितो गच्छतु धर्मशील: शुचिः कुलीनः पुरुषोऽप्रमत्तः॥ दूतः समर्थः प्रशमाय तेषां राज्यार्धदानाय युधिष्ठिरस्य।
English Translation: The bodies of those warriors of immeasurable prowess in consequence of their being inspired with wrath, appeared like those of the feathered chief (Garuda) and of the mighty serpents fighting in the skies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निशम्य वाक्यं तु जनार्दनस्य धर्मार्थयुक्तं मधुरं समं च॥ समाददे वाक्यमथाग्रजोऽस्य सम्पूज्य वाक्यं तदतीव राजन्॥
English Translation: The scene of action with Bhima. Karna, Kripa, Drona and Drona's son and Parshata and Satyaki, appeared effulgent like the alldestructive sun that rises (at the time of the universal annihilation).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: लोमश उवाच समुद्रं ते समाश्रित्य वारुणं निधिसम्भसः। कालेयाः सम्प्रवर्तन्त त्रैलोक्यस्य विनाशने॥
English Translation: Then there ensued a dreadful battle, like that between the celestials and the Danavas, in which mighty warriors engaged with mighty antagonists smote down one another.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते रात्रौ समभिक्रुद्धा भक्षयन्ति सदा मुनीन्। आश्रमेषु च ये सन्ति पुण्येष्वायतनेषु च॥
English Translation: Thereafter the host of Yudhishthira, setting up a noise loud as that of the (agitated) ocean, fell to slaughter your host, of which the mighty car-warriors have fled.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वसिष्ठस्याश्रमे विप्रा भक्षितास्तैर्दुरात्मभिः। अशीतिः शतमष्टौ च नव चान्ये तपस्विनः॥
English Translation: Then seeing the (Kaurava) host thoroughly shattered and excessively mutilated by the enemy, Drona exclaimed-'You need not fly, Oheroes.'

Sanskrit Shloka: च्यवनस्याश्रमं गत्वा पुण्यं द्विजनिषेवितम्। फलमूलाशनानां हि मुनीनां भक्षितं शतम्॥
English Translation: Thereafter that hero owning chest-nut steeds, inflamed with rage, like an elephant bearing four tusks, penetrated into the Pandava ranks and rushed at Yudhishthira.

Sanskrit Shloka: एवं रात्रौ स्म कुर्वन्ति विविशुश्चार्णवं दिवा। भरद्वाजाश्रमे चैव नियता ब्रह्मचारिणः॥ वाय्वाहाराम्बुभक्षाश्च विंशतिः संनिषूदिताः। एवं क्रमेण सर्वांस्तानाश्रमान् दानवास्तदा॥
English Translation: Thereupon Yudhishthira pierced him with shafts, keen-pointed and furnished with feathers of the Kanka bird, Drona also cutting his bow in two charged him with great impctus.

Sanskrit Shloka: निशायां परिबाधन्ते मत्ता भुजबलाश्रयात्। कालोपसृष्टाः कालेया घ्नन्तो द्विजगणान् बहून्॥
English Translation: Thereat the protectors of Yudhishthira's car-wheels namely Kumara, the glory of the Panchala races, resisted the rushing Drona, like the beach opposing the swelling sea.

Sanskrit Shloka: न चैनानन्वबुध्यन्त मनुजा मनुजोत्तम। एवं प्रवृत्तान् दैत्यांस्तांस्तापसेषु तपस्विषु॥
English Translation: When Drona the foremost of the regenerated ones was seen to be held in check by Kumara, there were heard sounds of carcries and exclamations of Excellent, excellent etc.

Sanskrit Shloka: प्रभाते समदृश्यन्त नियताहारकर्शिताः। महीतलस्था मुनयः शरीरैर्गतजीवितैः॥
English Translation: Then in that baitle, fierce Kumara. wrought up with ire, pierced, with a shaft, Drona on the chest; and then repeatedly uttered roars like those of the lion.

Sanskrit Shloka: क्षीणमांसैविरुधिरैर्विमज्जान्त्रैविसंधिभिः। आकीर्णैराबभौ भूमिः शङ्खानामिव राशिभिः॥
English Translation: Then that highly puissant and indefatigable Kumara of great lightness of hands, having held Drona at bay in that battle, pierced him with thousands of shafts.

Sanskrit Shloka: कलशैविप्रविबैश्च सुवैर्भग्नैस्तथैव च। विकीर्णैरग्निहोत्रैश्च भूर्बभूव समावृता॥
English Translation: Thereafter the foremost of the twice-born one (Drona) slew Kumara that protector of Yudhishthira's car-wheels who was brave, of illustrious vows and well-versed in the use of weapons and mantras.

Sanskrit Shloka: नि:स्वाध्यायवषट्कारं नष्टयज्ञोत्सवक्रियम्। जगदासीनिरुत्साहं कालेयभयपीडितम्॥

Sanskrit Shloka: एवं संक्षीयमाणाश्च मानवा मनुजेश्वर। आत्मत्राणपराभीताः प्राद्रवन्त दिशो भयात्॥
English Translation: Piercing Sikhandin with twelve arrows, Uttamaujas with twenty, Nakula with five and Sahadeva with seven. Yudhishthira with twelve and the sons of Draupadi each with three, Satyaki with five and the ruler of the Matsyas with ten arrows.

Sanskrit Shloka: केचिद् गुहा: प्रविविशुर्निर्झरांश्चापरे तथा। अपरे मरणोद्विग्ना भयात् प्राणान् समुत्सृजन्॥

Sanskrit Shloka: केचिदत्र महेष्वासाः शूराः परमहर्षिताः। मार्गमाणाः परं यत्नं दानवानां प्रचक्रिरे॥
English Translation: Thereupon, 0 monarch, Yugandhara opposed the mighty car-warrior, the son of Bharadvaja, who was inflamed with rage like the ocean swelling with the tempest.

Sanskrit Shloka: न चैतानधिजग्मुस्ते समुद्रं समुपाश्रितान्। श्रमं जग्मुश्च परममाजग्मुः क्षयमेव च॥
English Translation: But Drona, having pierced Yudhishthira with close-jointed shafts, overthrew Yugandhara from his niche in the car with a broad-headed arrow.

Sanskrit Shloka: जगत्युपशमं याते नष्टयज्ञोत्सवक्रिये। आजग्मुः परमामाति त्रिदशा मनुजेश्वर॥

---
Sanskrit Shloka: समेत्य समहेन्द्राश्च भयान्मन्त्रं प्रचक्रिरे। शरण्यं शरणं देवं नारायणमजं विभुम्॥
English Translation: Vyaghradatta, the prince of the Panchalas, pierced Drona with fifty whetted arrows; as thereupon, O monarch, the Pandava host uttered a loud shout.

Sanskrit Shloka: तेऽभिगम्य नमस्कृत्य वैकुण्ठमपराजितम्। ततो देवाः समस्तास्ते तदोचुर्मधुसूदनम्॥
English Translation: Sinhasena also having quickly pierced the mighty car-warrior Drona, suddenly, out of delight, broke out into a laugh, inspiring terror into the hearts of the mighty car-warriors.

Sanskrit Shloka: त्वं न स्रष्टा च भर्ता च हर्ता च जगतः प्रभो। त्वया सृष्टमिदं विश्वं यच्चेङ्गं यच् नेङ्गति॥
English Translation: Thereupon expanding his eyes and twanging his bow-string and making a loud sound by striking his arms with his palms, Drona rushed upon him (Sinhasena).

Sanskrit Shloka: त्वया भूमिः पुरा नष्टा समुद्रात् पुष्करेक्षण। वाराहं वपुराश्रित्य जगदर्थे समुद्धृता॥
English Translation: Then Drona of great prowess putting forth his energy, severed the head of Sinhasena decked with ear-rings also that of Vyaghradatta, with a pair of broad-headed shafis.

English Translation: Then with the shower of his arrows having crushed the inighty car-warriors of the Pandava host, he stood near the chariot of Yudhishthira like the all-destroying Death himself.

Sanskrit Shloka: अवध्यः सर्वभूतानां बलिश्चापि महासुरः। वामनं वपुराश्रित्य त्रैलोक्याद् भ्रंशितस्त्वया॥
English Translation: When Drona of regulated vows reached the vicinity of Yudhishthira, O monarch, loud cries of 'The king is slain' were uttered by the warriors of Yudhishthira's army.

Sanskrit Shloka: असुरश्च महेष्वासो जम्भ इत्यभिविश्रुतः। यज्ञक्षोभकरः क्रूरस्त्वयैव विनिपातितः॥
English Translation: Then the soldiers, beholding the prowess of Drona said, "Today the royal son of Dhritarashtra will attain the fruition of his desire.

Sanskrit Shloka: एवमादीनि कर्माणि येषां संख्या न विद्यते। अस्माकं भयभीतानां त्वं गतिर्मधुसूदन॥
English Translation: This very moment Drona, having captured in battle the son of Pandu, will, being transported with joy, surely return to us and to the son of Dhritarashtra.
