Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मात् त्वां देवदेवेश लोकार्थं ज्ञापयामहे। रक्ष लोकांश्च देवांश्च शक्रं च महतो भयात्॥
English Translation: When your soldiers had been thus conversing, the mighty car-warrior, the son of Kunti (Arjuna) rushed there with impetuosity, resounding the welkin with the rattle of his car and
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच अहो खलु महद् दुःखं कृच्छ्रवासश्च तस्य ह। कथं तस्य रतिस्तत्र तुष्टिर्वा वदतां वर॥
English Translation: Creating, by the carnage he caused, a river, of which the water consisted of blood and the eddies of cars; which was stagnant with bones and corpses of brave warriors and which conveyed creatures to the regions of the departed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स देशः क्व नु यत्रासौ वसते धर्मसंकटे। कथं वा स विमुच्येत नरस्तस्मान्महाभयात्॥
English Translation: Having crossed that river having the myriad shafts for its forth and abounding in fishes consisting of lances the son of Pandu came there crushing the Kurus with his speed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतन्मे सर्वमाचक्ष्व साधु चेष्टामहे तदा। कृपा मे महती जाता तस्याभ्युद्धरणेन हि॥
English Translation: Thereafter the diadem-decked Arjuna suddenly charged Drona's division, covering it with net-work of mighty arrows and stupefying therewith the warriors that followed Drona. Nobody was able to perceive any interval between the swift placing of the arrows on the bow-string and their discharge by the wellrenowned son of Kunti.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विदुर उवाच उपमानामिदं राजन् मोक्षविद्भिरुदाहृतम्। सुकृतं विन्दते येन परलोकेषु मानवः॥
English Translation: Neither the cardinal quarters, not the welkin, nor the conclave dome, nor the earth, could be seen any longer, O monarch; everything then appeared to be a continuous mass of arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उच्यते यत् तु कान्तारं महासंसार एव सः। वनं दुर्गं हि यच्चैतत् संसारगहनं हि तत्॥
English Translation: Then when the wielder of the Gandiva had caused a 'palpable darkness' in the field of the battle with his shafts, nothing, O monarch, could be distinguished.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ये च ते कथिता व्याला व्याधयस्ते प्रकीर्तिताः। या सा नारी बृहत्काया अध्यतिष्ठत तत्र वै॥ तामाहुस्तु जरां प्राज्ञा रूपवर्णविनाशिनीम्। यस्तत्र कूपो नृपते स तु देहः शरीरिणाम्॥
English Translation: At the setting of the sun at that moment, and at the enveloping of the earth with dusk, neither foe nor friend could be distinguished any longer.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यस्तत्र वसतेऽधस्तान्महाहिः काल एव सः। अन्तकः सर्वभूतानां देहिनां सर्वहार्यसौ॥
English Translation: Thereupon Drona and Duryodhana and others began to withdraw their forces. Considering his enemies to be inspired with terror and unwilling to carry on the fight.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कूपमध्ये च या जाता वल्ली यत्र स मानवः। प्रताने लम्बते लग्नो जीविताशा शरीरिणाम्॥
English Translation: Vibhatsu also slowly withdrew his own divisions; then the Pandus and the Srinjayas and the Panchalas highly delighted began to praise the son of Pritha (Arjuna), with agreeable words, like the Rishis praising the Sun. Thus having vanquished his foes Dhananjaya, filled with rapture and accompanied by Keshava, retired to his own camp, bringing up the rear of his whole army.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स यस्तु कूपवीनाहे तं वृक्षं परिसर्पति। षड्वक्त्रः कुञ्जरो राजन् स तु संवत्वरः स्मृतः॥
English Translation: Seated in the terrace of his excellent chariot adorned with emeralds and rubies and diamonds of the first water and with the costliest specimens of gold, silver, corals and crystal, the son of Pandu shone like the moon in the heavens adorned with the stars. costliest specimens of gold, silver, corals and crystal, the son of Pandu shone like the moon in the heavens adorned with the stars.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मुखानि ऋतवो मासाः पादा द्वादश कीर्तिताः। ये तु वृक्षं निकृन्तन्ति मूषिकाः सततोत्थिताः॥ रात्र्यहानि तु तान्याहुर्भूतानां परिचिन्तकाः।
English Translation: Sanjaya said At mid day, 0 mighty monarch, commenced a combat between the Somakas and Bhishma, that become dreadful and destructive of many creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ये ते मधुकरास्तत्र कामास्ते परिकीर्तिताः॥ यास्तु ता बहुशो धाराः स्रवन्ति मधुनिस्रवम्। तांस्तु कामरसान् विद्याद् यत्र मन्जन्ति मानवाः॥
English Translation: That foremost of car-warriors viz., the son of Ganga began to consume the ranks of the Pandava host, with his sharp shafts discharged by hundreds and thousands.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं संसारचक्रस्य परिवृत्तिं विदुर्बुधाः। येन संसारचक्रस्य पाशांश्छिन्दन्ति वै बुधाः॥
English Translation: Then your father Devavrata crushed that army like a herd of heifer grinding (under their tread) a heap of paddy sheaves.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच अथ त्विदानीं तुमले विमर्दे द्विषद्भिरको बहुभिः समावृतः। महारणे सारथिमित्युवाच भीमश्चमूं वाहय धार्तराष्ट्रीम्॥
English Translation: Then Dhrishtadyumna, Shikhandin, Virata and Draupada, encountering Bhishma in battle began to pierce that mighty car-warriors with numerous shafts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वं सारथे याहि जवेन वाहैनृयाम्येतान् धार्तराष्ट्रान् यमाय। संचोदितो भीमसेनेन चैवं स सारथिः पुत्रबलं त्वदीयम्॥ प्रायात् ततः सत्वरमुग्रवेगो यतो भीमस्तद् बलं गन्मुमैच्छत। ततोऽपरे नागरथाश्वपत्तिभिः प्रत्युद्ययुस्तं कुरवः समन्तात्॥
English Translation: Thereat, 0 Bharata, piercing Dhrishtadyumna and Virata with three shafts, Bhishma discharged a Naracha at Draupada.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीमस्य वाहाण्यमुदारवेगं समन्ततो बाणगणैर्निजघ्नुः। ततः शरानापततो महात्मा चिच्छेद बाणैस्तपनीयपुखैः॥
English Translation: Then those pierced by Bhishma that girder of foes, waxed worth, O king, in battle like a snake trampled under the feet.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते वै निपेतुस्तपनीयपुङ्खा द्विधा त्रिधा भीमशरैर्निकृताः। ततो राजन् नगरथाश्वयूनां भीमहतानां वरराजमध्ये॥ घोरो निनादः प्रबभौ नरेन्द्र वजाहतानामिव पर्वतानाम्। ते वध्यमानाश्च नरेन्द्रमुख्या निर्भिद्यन्तो भीमशरप्रवेकैः॥ भीमं समन्तात् समरेऽभ्यरोहन् वृक्षं शकुन्ता इव जातपक्षाः। ततोऽभियाते तव सैन्ये स भीमः प्रादुश्चके वेगमनन्तवेगः॥ भूतान्तकृत काल इवात्तदण्डः। तस्यातिवेगस्य रणेऽतिवेगं नाशक्नुवन् वारयितुं त्वदीयाः॥ व्यात्ताननस्यापततो यथैव कालस्य काले हरतः प्रजा वै। ततो बलं भारत भारतानां प्रदह्यमानं समरे महात्मना॥ भीतं दिशोऽकीर्यत भीमनुन्नं महानिलेनाभ्रगणा यथैव। ततो धीमान् सारथिमबभीद् बली स भीमसेनः पुनरेव हृष्टः॥ सूताभिजानीहि स्वकान् परान् वा रथान् ध्वजांश्चापततः समेतान्। न्मा सैन्यं स्वं छादयिष्ये पृषत्कैः॥
English Translation: Then Shikhandin pierced the grand father of the Bharatas, but the latter of undeteriorating renown struck him not, remembering his femininity.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अरीन् विशोकाभिनिरीक्ष्य सर्वतो मनस्तु चिन्ता प्रदुनोति मे भृशम्। राजाऽऽतुरो नागमद् यत् किरीटी बहूनि दुःखान्यभियातोऽस्मि सूत॥
English Translation: Then Dhrishtadyumna blazing up with rage like fire, pierced the grandsire, with three shafts on the breast and the arms.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतद् दुःखं सारथे धर्मराजो यन्मां हित्वा यातवाशत्रुमध्ये। नैनं जीवं नाद्य जानाम्यजीवं बीभत्सुं वा तन्ममाद्यातिदुःखम्॥
English Translation: Drupada with twenty five, Virata with ten, Shikhandin with twenty five arrows pierced Bhishma.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सोऽहं द्विषत्सैन्यमुदग्रकल्पं विनाशयिष्ये परमप्रतीतः। एतत्रिहत्याजिमध्ये समेतं प्रीतो भविष्यामि सह त्वयाद्य॥
English Translation: That hero (Bhishma) thus deeply pierced, O mighty monarch, and bathed in copiously flowering blood, appeared beautiful like flowering red Ashoka tree in the spring.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वांस्तूणान् सायकानामवेक्ष्य किं शिष्टं स्यात् सायकानां रथे मे। का वा जातिः किं प्रमाणं च तेषां ज्ञात्वा व्यक्तं तत् समाचक्ष्व सूत॥
English Translation: Then the son of Ganga pierced them in return each with three straight going shafts; and O sire, he bust open the bow of Drupada with a broad headed arrow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विशोक उवाच षण्मार्गणानामयुतानि वीर क्षुराश्च भल्लाश्च तथायुताख्याः। नाराचानां द्वे सहस्रे च वीर त्रीण्येव च प्रदराणां स्म पार्थ॥
English Translation: The latter then taking up another bow pierced Bhishma with five arrows and his charioteer with three whetted shafts on the field of battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अस्तायुधं पाण्डवेयावशिष्टं न यद् वहेच्छकटं षड्गवीयम्। एतद् विद्वन् मुञ्च सहस्रशोऽपि गदासिबाहुद्रविणं च तेऽस्ति॥ प्रासाश्च मुद्गरा शक्तयस्तोमराश्च मा भैषीस्त्वं सङ्ख्यादायुधानाम्॥
English Translation: Thereupon, O monarch, Bhima, the five sons of Draupadi, the five Kaikeya brothers, and Satyaki of the Satvata race,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीमसेन उवाच सूताद्यैनं पश्य भीमप्रयुक्तैः संछिन्दद्धिः पार्थिवानां सुवेगैः। छन्नं बाणैराहवं घोररूपं नष्टादित्यं मृत्युलोकेन तुल्यम्॥
English Translation: Headed by king Yudhishthira himself rushed at the son of Ganga, desirous of rescuing the Panchalas headed by Dhrishtadyumna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अद्यैतद् वै विदितं पार्थिवानां भविष्यति ह्याकुमारं च सूत। निमग्नो वा समरे भीमसेन एकः कुरून् वा समरे व्यजैषीत्॥
English Translation: So also, O ruler of men, your warriors anxious for protecting Bhishma, rushed against the Pandava host, supported by their respective divisions.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वे संख्ये कुरवो निष्पतन्तु मां वा लोकाः कीर्तयन्त्वाकुमारम्। सर्वानेकस्तानहं पातयिष्ये ते वा सर्वे भीमसेनं तुदन्तु॥
English Translation: Thereupon ensued a fierce and sanguinary engagement between your army and theirs both teeming with men, steeds chariots and elephants-engagement that considerably swelled the population of Death's domain.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आशास्तारः कर्म चाप्युत्तमं ये तन्मे देवाः केवलं साधयन्तु। आयात्विहाद्यार्जुनः शस्त्रघाती शकस्तूर्णं यज्ञ इवोपहूतः॥
English Translation: Car-warriors meeting car-warriors dispatched them to the abode of Death; so also others, men, horse-soldiers, elephant riders encountering one another,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मेते कस्माद् विद्रवन्ते नरेन्द्राः। व्यक्तं धीमान् सव्यसाची नराग्र्यः सैन्यं ह्येतच्छादयात्याशु बाणैः॥
English Translation: Conveyed one another to the abode of Death, with their straight knotted shafts; and in that field of battle, O ruler of men, many cars deprived of their riders with numerous dreadful arrows, and with their drivers slain, careered on the being dragged on all sides.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पश्य ध्वजांश्च द्रवतो विशोक नागान् हयान् पत्तिसंघांश्च संख्ये। रथान् विकीर्णाशरशक्तिताडितान् पश्यस्वैतान् रथिनश्चैव सूत॥
English Translation: Crushing, O king, innumerable men and steeds in that battle, those cars of the velocity of wind appeared beautiful like aerial castles.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आपूर्यते कौरवी चाप्यभीक्ष्णं सेना ह्यसौ सुभृशं हन्यमाना। प्रेस्ता शरैः काञ्चनबर्हिबाजैः॥
English Translation: Many car-warriors deprived of their cars, clad in armour and possessed of strength all decked with ear-rings and turbans and with bracelets and garlands,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एते द्रवन्ति स रथाश्वनागाः पदातिसङ्घातिमर्दयन्तः। सम्मुह्यमानाः कौरवाः सर्व एव द्रवन्ति नागा इव दाहभीताः२६॥ हाहाकृताश्चैव रणे विशोक मुञ्चन्ति नादान् विपुलान् गजेन्द्राः॥
English Translation: All resembling sons of the gods and equal to Shakra in prowess in battle, prosperous as Vaishravana himself and wise in polity as Brihaspati himself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विशोक उवाच किं भीम नैनं त्वमिहाशृणोषि विस्फारितं गाण्डिवस्यातिघोरम्। क्रुद्धेन पार्थेन विकृष्यतोऽद्य कचिन्नेमौ तव की विनष्टौ॥
English Translation: Ruling over vast dominions, and all heroic warriors, O ruler of men, flying hither and thither, were slain like ordinary men.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वे कामाः पाण्डव ते समृद्धाः कपिसी दृश्यते हस्तिसैन्ये। नीलाद घनाद् विद्युतमुचरन्तीं तथा पश्य विस्फुरन्ती धनुाम्॥
English Translation: Huge tusked elephants also, O foremost of men, deprived of their excellent riders, fell down crushing their own ranks and uttering distressful cries,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कपिसौ वीक्षते सर्वतो वै ध्वजाग्रमारुद्य धनंजयस्य। वित्रासयन् रिपुसघान् विमर्दे बिभेम्यस्मादात्मनैवाभिवीक्ष्य॥
English Translation: With their armours, variegated standards, chamaras, white umbrellas with golden staves, and lances shattered, O sire,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विभ्राजते चातिमात्रं किरीटं विचित्रमेतच्च धनंजयस्य। दिवाकराभो मणिरेष दिव्यो विभ्राजते चैव किरीटसंस्थः॥
English Translation: The huge elephants ran in all the ten points of the compass, resembling newly-risen clouds.। and roaring also like them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पार्श्वे भीमं पाण्डुराभ्रप्रकाशं पश्यस्व शङ्ख देवदत्त सुघोषम्। अभीषुहस्तस्य जनार्दनस्य विगाहमानस्य चमूं परेषाम्॥
English Translation: So also, O ruler of men, elephant riders, deprived of their elephants, were seen to run in all directions in that general engagement between your army and theirs.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रविप्रभं वज्रनाभं क्षुरान्तं पार्थे स्थितं पश्य जनार्दनस्य। चक्रं यशोवर्धनं केशवस्य सदार्चितं यदुभिः पश्य वीर॥
English Translation: We also beheld steeds born in various regions, decked with golden caparisons, and fleet as the wind itself, by hundreds and by thousands.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महाद्विपानां सरलट्ठमोपमाः करा निकृत्ताः प्रपतन्त्यमी क्षुरैः। किरीटिना तेन पुनः ससादिनः शरैर्निकृत्ताः कुलिशैरिवाद्रयः॥
English Translation: We also beheld horse soldiers, deprived of their charges chase and chased by, one another in that battle, with swords in their grasp.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथैव कृष्णस्य च पाञ्चजन्यं महार्हमेतं द्विजराजवर्णम्। कौन्तेय पश्योरसि कौस्तुभं च जाज्वल्यमानं विजया स्त्रजं च॥
English Translation: An elephant meeting a flying compeer in that great battle, rushed with velocity crushing foot soldiers and steeds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ध्रुवं रथाय्यः समुपैति पार्थो विद्रावयन् सैन्यमिदं परेषाम्। हयैर्महाहै रथिनां वरिष्ठः॥
English Translation: Also, o king, in that battle one elephant crushed many cars, and car also, passing over fallen steeds, crushed them in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विदारितान् पश्य पतन्त्यमी यथा। तवानुजेनामरराज तेजसा महावनानीव सुपर्णवायुना॥
English Translation: And also, O king, horses again crushed the foot-soldiers in that battle. Thus, o king, they crushed one another in various modes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चतुःशतान् पश्य रथानिमान् हतान् सवाजिसूतान् समरे किरीटिना। महेषुभिः सप्तशतानि दन्तिनां पदातिसादींश्च रथाननेकशः॥
English Translation: When that awful and fierce battle was thus raging, there started up into existence on the field of battle a hideous river, having blood for its stream,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अयं समभ्येति तवान्तिकं बली निघ्नन् कुरूंचित्र इव ग्रहोऽर्जुनः। समृद्धकामोऽसि हतास्तवाहिता बलं तवायुश्च चिराय वर्धताम्॥
English Translation: Choked with piles of bones, and having the hair (of slain warriors) for its moss and weeds. It had cars for its lakes arrows for its eddies and horses for its fishers; and it was inaccessible.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीमसेन उवाच ददानि ते ग्रामवरांश्चतुर्दश प्रियाख्याने सारथे सुप्रसन्नः। दासीशतं चापि रथांश्च विंशति यदर्जुनं वेदयसे विशोक॥
English Translation: It abounded in pebbles consisting of the heads of warrior; as also in sharks &c formed by the elephants. It had armours and headgears for its froth and bows for its current and swords for its tortoises;
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच ब्रूहि ब्राह्मणपूजायां व्युष्टिं त्वं मधुसूदन। वेत्ता त्वमस्य चार्थस्य वेद त्वां हि पितामहः॥
English Translation: The trees on its banks were formed of the numerous standards; it had men for its banks which it ate away constantly. It was infested by swans consisting of cannibals, and it considerably increased the population of Death's domain.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वासुदेव उवाच शृणुष्वावहितो राजन् द्विजानां भरतर्षभ। यथा तत्त्वेन वदतो गुणान् वै कुरुसत्तम॥
English Translation: Many heroic Kshatriyas all mighty carwarriors crossed that river on their rafts consisting of cars, steeds and elephants, totally driving away fear their hearts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्वारवत्यां समासीनं पुरा मां कुरुनन्दन। प्रद्युन्म: परिपप्रच्छ ब्राह्मणैः परिकोपितः॥ किं फलं ब्राह्मणेष्वस्ति पूजायां मधुसूदन। ईश्वरत्वं कुतस्तेषामिहैव च परत्र च॥
English Translation: Just as the river Vaitarani conveys all departed spirits to the dominions of the ruler of spirits, so, in that afternoon, that river carried away (with its bloody currents) all cowards that became overwhelmed with a swoon.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सदा द्विजातीन् सम्पूज्य किं फलं तत्र मानद। एतद् ब्रूहि स्फुटं सर्वे सुमहान् संशयोऽत्र मे॥
English Translation: Then in that battle the Kshatriyas beholding that awful carnage, exclaimed saying. Through the folly of Duryodhana, Kshatriyas are being thus destroyed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्युक्ते वचने तस्मिन् प्रद्युम्नेन तथा त्वहम्। प्रत्यब्रुवं महाराज यत् तच्छृणु समाहितः॥
English Translation: Why did Dhritarashtra of wicked soul, that ruler of men, infatuated by covetousness, harbor feelings of envy against the sons of Pandu, all endued with many virtues."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्युष्टिं ब्राह्मणपूजायां रौक्मिणेय निबोध मे। एते हि सोमराजान ईश्वराः सुखदुःखयोः॥
English Translation: Various exclamations of this kind, purporting to be applause to the Pandavas and censures to your sons, were heard there addressed to one another.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अस्मिल्लोकै रौक्मिणेय तथामुष्मिंश्च पुत्रका ब्राह्मणप्रमुखं सौम्यं न मेऽत्रास्ति विचारणा॥
English Translation: Hearing these exclamations vociferated by all the warriors, your son Duryodhana, that offender of all men,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणप्रतिपूजायामायुः कीर्तिर्यशो बलम्। लोका लोकेश्वराश्चैव सर्वे ब्राह्मणपूजकाः॥ त्रिवर्गे चापवर्गे च यश:श्रीरोगशान्तिषु। देवतापितृपूजासु संतोष्याश्चैव नो द्विजाः॥
English Translation: Addressing Bhishma, Drona, Kripa and Shalya said, O Bharata “Do you go on fighting with self-confidence? Why do you tarry at all?”
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्कथं वै नाद्रियेयमीश्वरोऽस्मीति पुत्रका मा ते मन्युर्महाबाहो भवत्वत्र द्विजान् प्रति॥
English Translation: Then ensued a battle between the Kurus and the Pandavas. O king, that owed its origin to that game at dice and that brought about awful carnage.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणा हि महद्भूतमस्मिल्लोके परत्र चा भस्म कुयुर्जगदिदं क्रुद्धाः प्रत्यक्षदर्शिनः॥
English Translation: Now do you see, O son of Vichitravirya, the dreadful fruit of your refusal to accept the salutary advice (of your friends), though warned against it by many high souled heroes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्यानपि सृजेयुश्च लोकालोकेश्वरांस्तथा। कथं तेषु न वर्तेरन् सम्यग् ज्ञानात् सुतेजसः॥
English Translation: Neither the sons of Pandu, O king, with their soldiers and followers, nor the Kauravas pay any the least head to their lives in that battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अवसन्मद्गृहे तात ब्राह्मणो हरिपिङ्गलः। चीरवासा बिल्वदण्डी दीर्घश्मश्रुः कृशो महान्॥
English Translation: For this reason, O foremost of men, a dreadful destruction of men is taking place, brought about by Destiny or by your wicked policy, O king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दीर्धेभ्यश्च मनुष्येभ्यः प्रमाणादधिको भुवि। स स्वैरं चरते लोकान् ये दिव्या ये च मानुषाः॥ इमां गाथां गायमानश्चत्वरेषु सभासु च। दुर्वाससं वासयेत् को ब्राह्मणं सत्कृतं गृहे।॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Having heard from the highly exalted Markandeya the story of the royal sage Indradyumna's regaining heaven, the king Yudhishthira, the great monarch, again asked the Rishi,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रोषणः सर्वभूतानां सूक्ष्मेऽप्यपकृते कृते। परिभाषां च मे श्रुत्वा को नु दद्यात् प्रतिश्रयम्॥
English Translation: “O great Rishi, tell me how a man should practice charity to go to the regions of Indra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यो मां कश्चिद् वासयीत न स मां कोपयेदिति। यस्मान्नाद्रियते कश्चित् ततोऽहं समवासयम्॥
English Translation: Is it by practicing charity when leading the domestic life or in boyhood or in youth or in the old age (that one goes to Indra's abode)? Tell me the respective merits of charity in different stages of life.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स सम्भुङ्क्ते सहस्राणां बहूनामन्नमेकदा। एकदा सोऽल्पकं भुङ्क्ते न चैवैति पुनर्गृहान्॥
English Translation: Markandeya said : The life, that is useless, is of four kinds and the charity which is useless is of sixteen kinds. That life is useless in which there is no son born, in which one has no virtue. In which one lives on food given by another and in which one cook (food) for himself only, without giving to the Pitris, the celestials and the guests and one who eats before all these.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अकस्माच्च प्रहसति तथाकस्मात् प्ररोदिति। न चास्य वयसा तुल्यः पृथिव्यामभवत् तदा॥
English Translation: The gift to one who has fallen away from the path of virtue and the gift of wealth which has been earned wrongly and dishonestly are both useless. The gifts to a fallen Brahmana, to a thief to a false preceptor, are also useless.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ स्वावसथं गत्वा स शय्यास्तरणानि च। कन्याश्चालंकृता दग्ध्वा ततो व्यपगतः पुनः॥
English Translation: The gift to an untruthful man, to one who officiates at sacrifices performed by all classes of people residing in a village, to one that sells the Vedas to a Brahmana who cooks for a Shudra, to one who is by birth a Brahmana, but who does not perform the duties of his order, is all in vain. The gift to one who has married a girl already in her puberty, to a woman, to one who sports with a snake and to one who is engaged in minimal services, is also in vain. These are the sixteen useless charities.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ मामब्रवीद् भूयः स मुनिः संशितव्रतः। कृष्ण पायसमिच्छामि भोक्तुमित्येव सत्वरः॥
English Translation: He who gives away wealth out of fear or anger. Enjoys the fruits of that charity when he remains in the womb of his mother. The man who gives away (wealth) to the Brahmanas, enjoys its fruits while he is in old age.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदैव तु मया तस्य चित्तज्ञेन गृहे जनः। सर्वाण्यन्नानि पानानि भक्ष्याश्चोच्चावचास्तथा॥
English Translation: O king, therefore, the man who desires to get to the path of heaven should under all conditions give away (wealth) to the Brahmanas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भवन्तु सत्कृतानीह पूर्वमेव प्रचोदितः। ततोऽहं ज्वलमानं वै पायसं प्रत्यवेदयम्॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said : By what means do the Brahmanas, who receive gifts from all the four orders, save others as well as themselves?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं भुक्त्वैव स तु क्षिप्रं ततो वचनमब्रवीत्। क्षिप्रमङ्गानि लिम्पस्व पायसेनेति स स्म ह॥
English Translation: Markandeya said: By Japa, by Mantras by Homa and by the study of the Vedas, they (Brahmanas) build a Veda boat and with it they save others as well as themselves.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अविमृश्यैव च ततः कृतवानस्मि तत् तथा। तेनोच्छिष्टेन गात्राणि शिरश्चैवाभ्यमक्षयम्॥
English Translation: The celestials themselves are gratified with that man who gratifies the Brahmanas. At the command of a Brahmana a man obtains heaven.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स ददर्श तदाभ्याशे मातरं ते शुभाननाम्। तामपि स्मयमानां स पायसेनाभ्यलेपयम्॥
English Translation: O king, you will certainly go to heaven for your worshipping the Pitris and the celestials and for your showing great reverence to the Brahmanas,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मुनिः पायसदिग्धाङ्गी रथे तूर्णमयोजयत्। तमारुह्य रथं चैव निर्ययौ स गृहान्मम॥
English Translation: Even if your body be dull and weak and full of phlegm. He who desires to obtain virtue and heaven should worship the Brahmanas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अग्निवर्णो ज्वलन् धीमान् स द्विजो रथधुर्यवत्। प्रतोदेनातुदद् वाला रुक्मिणी मम पश्यतः॥
English Translation: One should with great care feed them at the time of Shraddha ceremonies, but those among them (Brahmana) that are cursed or fallen, that are either exceeding handsome or excessively black, that have diseased nails, that are lepers, that are deceitful, that are bastards, born of widows or of women with their husbands in exile and that support themselves by the profession of arms, all these should be excluded. A censurable Shraddha consumes the performer as fire consumes the wood.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न च मे स्तोकमप्यासीद् दुःखीमीर्ष्याकृतं तदा। तथा स राजमार्गेण महता निर्ययौ बहिः॥
English Translation: If those that are to be employed in a Shraddha happen to be dumb, blind or deaf, care should be taken to employ them with the Brahmanas who are learned in the Vedas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तद् दृष्ट्वा महदाश्चर्ये दाशार्हा जातमन्यवः। तत्राजल्पन् मिथः केचित् समाभाष्य परस्परम्॥ ब्राह्मणा एव जायेरन् नान्यो वर्णः कथंचन। को ह्येनं रथमास्थाय जीवेदन्यः पुमानिह॥
English Translation: O Yudhishthira, hear now what you should give away. He who knows the Vedas should give away to only those Brahmanas who are able to save both the giver and himself, for he only is to be considered a competent (Brahmana) who can save the giver and himself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आशीविषविषं तीक्ष्णं ततस्तीक्ष्णतरो द्विजः। ब्रह्माशीविषदग्धस्य नास्ति कश्चिच्चिकित्सकः॥
English Translation: O son of Pritha, the sacred fire does not become so much gratified in receiving the libations of Ghee, the offering of flowers and sandal paste and other perfumes as by the entertainment of guests.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मिन् व्रजति दुर्धर्षे प्रास्खलद् रुक्मिणी पथि। तन्नामर्षयत श्रीमांस्ततस्तूर्णमचोदयत्॥
English Translation: Therefore with all care entertain guests. O king, those that give to his guests water to wash his feet, butter to rub over his tired legs, light in darkness and food and shelter, do not (at all) go before Yama.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः परमसंक्रुद्धो रथात् प्रस्कन्ध स द्विजः। पदातिरुत्पथेनैव प्राद्रवद् दक्षिणामुखः॥
English Translation: The removal of garlands of flowers offered to the gods, the removal of the remnant of a Brahmana's food, serving with prepared pastes, the shampooing of a Brahmana's legs, O foremost of kings, each of these gives better fruits than the giving away of kine.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमत्पथेन धावन्तमन्वधावं द्विजोत्तमम्। तथैव पायसादिग्धः प्रसीद भगवन्निति॥
English Translation: A man certainly rescues himself (from hell) by giving away Kapila cow, therefore a Kapila cow, decked with ornaments, should be given to a Brahmana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो विलोक्य तेजस्वी ब्राह्मणो मामुवाच ह। जितः क्रोधस्त्वया कृष्ण प्रकृत्यैव महाभुज॥
English Translation: One should make gifts to a person nobly born, one who is learned in the Vedas, one that is fair, one who leads a domestic life, but who is burdened with wife and children, one who duly worships the sacred fire and one who has done you no service.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न तेऽपराधमिह वै दृष्टवानस्मि सुव्रत। प्रीतोऽस्मि तव गोविन्द वृणु कामान् यथेप्सितान्।।३८
English Translation: O best of the Bharata race, O descendant of Bharata, you should always give away to such men and not to those who are wealthy. What merit is there to give (wealth) to one who is wealthy?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रसन्नस्य च मे तात पश्य व्युष्टिं यथाविधि। यावदेव मनुष्याणामन्ने भावो भविष्यति॥ यथैवान्ने तथा तेषां त्वयि भावो भविष्यति। यावच्च पुण्या लोकेषु त्वयि कीर्तिर्भविष्यति॥
English Translation: One cow must be given to one Brahmana. One single cow must not be given to many Brahmanas. If that cow is sold, three generations of the giver's family would be lost. Such a gift will neither rescue the giver nor the Brahmana who takes it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्रिषु लोकेषु तावच्च वैशिष्ट्यं प्रतिपत्स्यसे। सुप्रियः सर्वलोकस्य भविष्यसि जनार्दन॥
English Translation: He who gives away eighty Ratis of pure gold, obtains the everlasting fruit of giving away one hundred pieces of gold.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यत्ते भिन्नं च दग्धं य यच्च किंचिद् विनाशितम्। सर्वं तथैव द्रष्टासि विशिष्टं वा जनार्दन॥
English Translation: He who gives away a strong bull capable of drawing the plough, does not certainly meet with any calamity; he finally goes to heaven.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यावदेतत् प्रलिप्तं ते गात्रेषु मधुसूदन। अतो मृत्युभयं नास्ति यावदिच्छसि चाच्युत॥
English Translation: He who gives away land to a learned Brahmana, has all his desires fulfilled.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न तु पादतले लिप्ते कस्मात्ते पुत्रकाद्य वै। नैतन्मे प्रियमित्येवं स मां प्रीतोऽब्रवीत् तदा॥ इत्युक्तोऽहं शरीरं स्वं ददर्श श्रीसमायुतम्।
English Translation: The tired traveller, with weakened limbs and with feet besmeared with dust, asks for the name of him who gives him food. There are men who answer him by telling him the name. That wise man who informs the toil-worn travellers the name of the persons who give them food is certainly considered equal in virtue as the giver of food himself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रुक्मिणी चाब्रवीत् प्रीत: सर्वस्त्रीणां वरं यश:।४५ कीर्ति चानुत्तमां लोके समवाप्स्यसि शोभने।
English Translation: O Yudhishthira, Therefore (even) abstaining from other kinds of gifts, give away food. There is no virtue so great as that of giving well-cooked and pure food to the Brahmanas according to one's ability. That man by his this act obtains the companionship of Prajapati.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न त्वां जरा वा रोगो वा वैवयं चापि भाविनि।।४६ स्प्रक्ष्यन्ति पुण्यगन्धा च कृष्णमाराधयिष्यसि।
English Translation: There is no gift superior to that of food. The food is the foremost and the first of all things. It is said that food is Prajapati. Prajapati (again) is considered as year and the year is sacrifice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: षोडशानां सहस्राणां वधूनां केशवस्य ह॥ वरिष्ठा च सलोक्या च केशवस्य भविष्यसि।
English Translation: From sacrifice all mobile and immobile creatures take their birth. For this reason it has been heard by us that food is the foremost of all things.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तव मातरमित्युक्त्वा ततो मां पुनरब्रवीत्॥ प्रस्थितः सुमहातेजा दुर्वासाग्निरिव ज्वलन्। एषैव ते बुद्धिरस्तु ब्राह्मणान्प्रति केशव॥ इत्युक्त्वा स तदा पुत्र तत्रैवान्तरधीयत।
English Translation: Those, that give away lakes and large tanks, wells and ponds, shelter and food with sweet words, have not to bear the up-braiding of Yama.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मिन्नन्तर्हिते चाहमुपांशुव्रतमाचरम्॥ यत्किचिद् ब्राह्मणो ब्रूयात् सर्वं कुर्यामिति प्रभो।
English Translation: Earth is always satisfied with that man who gives rice and wealth earned by his own labour to the Brahmanas whose behaviour is good. She pours upon such a man showers of wealth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतद् व्रतमहं कृत्वा मात्रा ते सह पुत्रक॥ ततः परमहष्टात्मा प्राविशं गृहमेव च।
English Translation: The giver of food walks first, then follows the speaker of truth; and then the man who gives away to a person who does not ask. But all these three go to the same place.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रविष्टमात्रश्च गृहे सर्वं पश्यामि तनवम्॥ यद् भिन्नं यच्च वै दग्धं तेन विप्रेण पुत्रका
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Being filled with curiosity, Yudhishthira, with his brothers, again asked the illustrious Markandeya.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽहं विस्मयं प्राप्तः सर्वे दृष्ट्वा नवं दृढम्॥ अपूजयं च मनसा रौक्मिणेय सदा द्विजान्।
English Translation: Yudhishthira said: O great Rishi, what is the distance of the region of Yama from that of men? What is its measurement? How does a man pass over it and by what meant? Tell me all this.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्यहं रौक्मिणेयस्य पृच्छतो भरतर्षभ॥ माहात्म्यं द्विजमुख्यस्य सर्वमाख्यातवांस्तदा।
English Translation: Markandeya said : O king, O foremost of all virtuous men, your this question relates to a great mystery. It is sacred and it is much praised by the Rishis. I shall speak to you about this Dharma.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथा त्वमपि कौन्तेय ब्राह्मणान् सततं प्रभो॥ पूजयस्व महाभागान् वाग्भिर्दानैश्च नित्यदा।
English Translation: O ruler of men, the distance of the region of Yama from the abode of men is eighty-six thousand yojanas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं व्युष्टिमहं प्राप्तो ब्राह्मणस्य प्रसादजाम्। यच्च मामाह भीष्मोऽयं तत्सत्यं भरतर्षभ॥
English Translation: The way is over space. There is no water there and it is terrible to look at. There is nowhere in that region any shade of any tree, any water and any resting place, in which the traveller when fatigued, may take rest for some time.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मार्कण्डेय उवाच तस्मिञ्जाते महासत्त्वे महासेने महाबले। समुत्तस्थुर्महोत्पाता घोररूपाः पृथग्विधाः॥
English Translation: Along this path are forcibly taken by messenger of Yama, obedient to his command, all men and women and all creatures that have life.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्त्रीपुंसोर्विपरीतं च तथा द्वन्द्वानि यानि च। ग्रहा दीप्ता दिशः खं च ररास च मही भृशम्॥
English Translation: O ruler of earth, O king, those that have given horses and other good conveyances to the Brahmanas, go along (this path) on those animals and conveyances. Those that have given. umbrellas thus (to the Brahmanas) go along this path with umbrellas, warding off the sun's rays.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ऋषयश्च महाघोरान् दृष्ट्वोत्पातान् समन्ततः। अकुर्वञ्छान्तिमुद्विग्ना लोकानां लोकभावनाः॥
English Translation: Those that have given food go along without any hunger and those that have not given food go along afflicted with (great) hunger. Those that have given cloths go along attired in cloths and those that have not given cloths go along naked,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निवसन्ति वने ये तु तस्मिश्चैत्ररथे जनाः। तेऽब्रुवन्नेष नोऽनर्थः पावकेनाहितो महान्॥ संगम्य षड्भिः पत्नीभिः सप्तर्षिणामिति स्म ह।
English Translation: Those that have given gold go along in happiness, well adorned in ornaments. And those that have given land go along with their every desire completely gratified.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपरे गरुडीमाहुस्त्वयानर्थोऽयमाहृतः॥ यैर्दृष्टा सा तदा देवी तस्या रूपेण गच्छती। न तु तत् स्वाहया कर्म कृतं जानाति वै जनः॥
English Translation: Those that have given grains go along without being afflicted with any want; and those that have given houses go along on cars.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुपर्णी तु वचः श्रुत्वा ममायं तनयस्तिवति। उपगम्य शनैः स्कन्दमाहाहं जननी तव॥
English Translation: Those that have given king go along with cheerful hearts without ever being afflicted by thirst. Those that have given lights go along in great happiness lighting the way before them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ सप्तर्षयः श्रुत्वा जातं पुत्रं महौजसम्। तत्यजुः षट् तदा पत्नीविना देवीमरुन्धतीम्॥
English Translation: Those that have given kine go along in happiness, their sins being all destroyed. Those that have fasted for a month, go along on cars drawn by swans.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: षड्भिरेव तदा जातमाहुस्तद्वनवासिनः। सप्तर्षीनाह च स्वाहा मम पुत्रोऽयमित्युत॥ अहं जाने नैतदेवमिति राजन् पुनः पुनः।
English Translation: O son of Pandu, those that have fasted for six nights, go on cars drawn by peacocks. O son of Pandu, he who fasts for three nights taking only one meal without a second goes to a region free from disease and anxiety. The water has this excellent property that it produces happiness in the region of the dead.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विश्वामित्रस्तु कृत्वेष्टिं सप्तर्षीणां महामुनिः॥ पावकं कामसंतप्तमदृष्टः पृष्ठतोऽन्वगात्। तत् तेन निखिलं सर्वमवबुद्धं यथातथम्॥
English Translation: There they see a river named Pushpodaka. They there drink cool water which is like the very ambrosia.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विश्वामित्रस्तु प्रथमं कुमारं शरणं गतः। स्तवं दिव्यं सम्प्रचक्रे महासेनस्य चापि सः॥
English Translation: He who is of evil deed drinks there puss which is the thing that has been ordained for him. O great king, that river fulfills one's all desires.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मङ्गलानि च सर्वाणि कौमाराणि त्रयोदश। जातकर्मादिकास्तस्य क्रियाश्चक्रे महामुनिः॥
English Translation: O king of kings, worship there these (Brahmanas) in all due form. Weakened with travelling and besmeared with the dust on this way, the traveller asks for the name of him who gives food and comes in hope to his house to worship him with all care, for he is a great Brahmana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: षड्वक्त्रस्य तु माहात्म्यं कुक्कुटस्य तु साधनम् शक्त्या देव्याः साधनं च तथा पारिषदामपि॥ विश्वामित्रश्चाकारैतत् कर्म लोकहिताय वै। तस्मादृषिः कुमारस्य विश्रामित्रोऽभवत् प्रियः॥
English Translation: As he proceeds all the celestials with Vasava (Indra) follow him. If he is worshipped, they are gratified; and if he is not worshipped they become cheerless.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्वजानाच्च स्वाहाया रूपान्यत्वं महामुनिः। अब्रवीच्च मुनीन् सर्वान् नापराध्यन्ति वै स्त्रियः॥ श्रुत्वा तु तत्त्वतस्तस्मात् ते पत्नीः सर्वतोऽत्यजन्
English Translation: O king of kings, therefore duly worship these (Brahmanas). I have thus spoken to you on one hundred subjects. What do you desire to hear from me more?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मार्कण्डेय उवाच स्कन्दं श्रुत्वा तदा देवा वासवं सहिताऽब्रुवन्॥ अविषाबलं स्कन्दं जहि शक्राशु माचिरम्। यदि वा न निहंस्येनं देवेन्द्रोऽयं भविष्यति॥ त्रैलोक्यं संनिगृह्यास्मांस्त्वां च शक्र महाबल।
English Translation: Yudhishthira said : O lord, O virtuous man, I desire to hear you again and again on sacred subjects relating to virtue and morals.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तानुवाच व्यथितो बालोऽयं सुमहाबलः॥ स्रष्टारमपि लोकानां युधि विक्रम्य नाशयेत्। न बालमुत्सहे हन्तुभिति शक्रः प्रभाषते॥
English Translation: Markandeya said: O king, I shall now speak on another sacred subject relating to eternity which destroys all sins. Listen to me with all others.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेऽब्रुवन् नास्ति ते वीर्यं यत् एवं प्रभाषसे। सर्वास्त्वद्याभिगच्छन्तु स्कन्दं लोकस्य मातरः॥ कामवीर्या जन्तु चैनं तथेत्युक्त्वा च ता ययुः।
English Translation: O best of the Bharata race, the merit equal to that of giving away a Kapila cow in Pushkara (Tirtha) is obtained by washing the feet of the Brahmanas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमप्रतिबलं दृष्ट्वा विषण्णवदनास्तु ताः॥ अशक्योऽयं विचन्त्यैवं तमेव शरणं ययुः। ऊचुश्चैनं त्वमस्माकं पुत्रो भव महाबल॥
English Translation: As long as the earth remains moist with the water touched by the feet of a Brahmana, so long do the Pitris drink water from the lotus leaves.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभिनन्दस्व नः सर्वाः प्रस्नुताः स्नेहविक्लवाः। तासां तद् वचनं श्रुत्वा पातुकाम: स्तनान् प्रभुः॥ ताः सम्पूज्य महासेन: कामांश्चासां प्रदाय सः। अपश्यदग्निमायान्तं पितरं बलिनां बली॥
English Translation: If a guest is welcomed, Agni is gratified. If he is offered a seat, Indra is gratified. If his feet are washed, it is the Pitris who are delighted. If he is fed, it is Prajapati (Brahma) himself who is gratified.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तु सम्पूजजितस्तेन सह मातृगणेन ह। परिवार्य महासेनं रक्षमाणः स्थितः शिवः॥
English Translation: One should with subdued soul give away a cow when the feet and the head of her calf are visible. Before her delivery is complete, a cow with her calf in the air in the course of falling from the uterus to the earth is to be considered as equal to the earth herself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वासां या तु मातृणां नारी क्रोधसमुद्भवा। धात्री स्वपुत्रवत् स्कन्दं शूलहस्ताभ्यरक्षत॥
English Translation: O Yudhishthira, he is adored in the celestials region as many thousand Yugas as there are hairs on the bodies of that cow and the calf.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: लोहितस्योदधेः कन्या क्रूरा लोहितभोजना। परिष्वज्य महासेनं पुत्रवत् पर्यरक्षत॥ अग्निर्भूत्वा नैगमेयश्छागवक्त्रो बहुप्रजः। रमयामास शैलस्थं बालं क्रीडनकैरिव॥
English Translation: The person who donets a black cow duly ornamented with jwels including nose-ring made of gold and the hoof made of silver.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच तद् बलं सुमहद् दीर्णं त्वदीयं प्रेक्ष्य वीर्यवान्। दधारैको रणे राजन् वृषसेनोऽस्त्रमायया॥
English Translation: O descendant of Bharata, he who, having accepted a gift, gives it away immediately to a person who is virtuous and honest, obtains great merit. He certainly obtains the fruit of giving away the whole earth to her utmost limits with her oceans, seas and caves, her mountains and forests and woods.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शरा दश दिशो मुक्ता वृषसेनेन संयुगे। विचेरुस्ते विनिर्भिद्य नरवाजिरथद्विपान्॥
English Translation: The Brahmana, who eats in silence from a plate, keeping his hands between his knees, succeeds in saving others.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य दीप्ता महाबाणा विनिश्चेरुः सहस्रशः। भानोरिव महाराज धर्मकाले मरीचयः॥
English Translation: Those Brahmanas who abstain from drink and who are never spoken by others as having any fault and who daily read the Samhitas are capable of saving others,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेनार्दिता महाराज रथिनः सादिनस्तथा। निपेतुरुवा॒ सहसा वातभग्ना इव द्रुमाः॥
English Translation: Havya (libation of ghee) and Kavya (edible offerings) should all be presented to a Brahmana who is learned in the Vedas. As an offering of ghee to Agnis is never in vain, so a gift to the Brahmanas learned in the Vedas is never in vain.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हयौघांश्च रथौघांश्च गजौघांश्च महारथः। अपातयद् रणे राजशतशोऽथ सहस्रशः॥
English Translation: The Brahinanas have anger as their weapon; they never fight with weapons made of iron or steel. The Brahmanas kill their enemies with anger, as the wielder of thunder killed the Asuras.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दृष्ट्वा तमेकं समरे विचरन्तमभीतवत्। सहिताः सर्वराजानः परिवठ्ठः समन्ततः॥
English Translation: O sinless one, the theme relating to virtue and morality is now over. Having heard them, the Rishis, in the Naimisha forest, greatly delighted.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नाकुलिस्तु शतानीको वृषसेनं समभ्ययात्। विव्याध चैनं दशभिनौराचैर्मर्मभेदिभिः॥
English Translation: O king, (hearing them) they were freed from grief, fear and anger and they were cleansed of their sins. Those men who hear them are freed from the bondage of rebirth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य कर्णात्मजश्चापं छित्त्वा केतुमपातयत्। तं भ्रातरं परीप्सन्तो द्रौपदेयाः समभ्ययुः॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said : O greatly wise one, O foremost of virtuous men, what purification is there by which a Brahmana might always be pure. I desire to hear it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्णात्मजं शरवातैरदृश्यं चक्रुरञ्जसा। तान् नदन्तोऽभ्यधावन्त द्रोणपुत्रमुखा रथाः॥
English Translation: Markandeya continued There are three kinds of purity, namely purity in speech, purity in deed and purity by water. He who takes to these certainly obtains heaven.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: छादयन्तो महाराज द्रोपदेयान् महारथान्। शरैर्नानाविधै स्तूर्णं पर्वताञ्जलदा इव॥
English Translation: That Brahmana who adores (the goddess) Sandhya in the morning and in the evening and who recites the sacred Gayatri, who is the mother of the Vedas, is cleansed from all his sins after being sanctified by the latter. Even if he accepts in gift the entire earth with her oceans, he does not suffer the least unhappiness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तान् पाण्डवाः प्रत्यगृहंस्त्वरिताः पुत्रगृद्धिनः। पञ्चाला: केकया मत्स्याः सृञ्जयाचोद्यतायुधाः॥
English Translation: Those planets in the sky including the sun that may be inauspicious and hostile towards him soon become favourable and auspicious towards him for his these acts. And those that are auspicious and favourable become more auspicious and favourable.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तद् युद्धमभवद् घोरं सुमहल्लोमहर्षणम्। त्वदीयैः पाण्डुपुत्राणां देवानामिव दानवैः॥
English Translation: The terrible Rakshasas who feed on animal food and who have gigantic and fearful appearances, all become incapable of doing any injury to a Brahmana who practises these purifications.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं युयुधिरे वीराः संरब्धाः कुरुपाण्डवाः। परस्परमुदीक्षन्तः परस्परकृतागसः॥
English Translation: They incur no fault in consequence of teaching, of officiating at sacrifice and of accepting gifts from others. The Brahmanas are like the blazing fire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषां दशरे कोपाद् वपूंष्यमिततेजसाम्। युयुत्सूनामिवाकाशे पतत्रिवरभोगिनाम्॥
English Translation: Whether learned in the Vedas or not, whether pure or impure, they should never be insulted, for Brahmanas are like fires, 'covered with ashes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीमकर्णकृपद्रोणद्रोणिपार्षतसात्यकैः। बभासे स रणोद्देश: कालसूर्य इवोदितः॥
English Translation: A fire that blazes forth in a place of cremation is never impure, so is a Brahmana either learned or ignorant is always pure. He is superior to a celestials.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदाऽऽसीत् तुमुलं युद्धं निघ्नतामितरेतरम्। महाबलानां बलिभिर्दानवानां यथा सुरैः॥
English Translation: Cities adorned with walls and gates and palaces lose their beauty if they are not inhabited by Brahmanas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो युधिष्ठिरानीकमुद्धतार्णवनि:स्वनम्। त्वदीयमवधीत् सैन्यं सम्प्रदुतमहारथम्॥
English Translation: O king, that is really a city in which live Brahmanas learned in the Vedas, who duly observe the duties of their order and who possess learning and ascetic merit.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत् प्रभग्नं बलं दृष्ट्वा शत्रुभि शमर्दितम्। अलं द्रुतेन वः शूरा इति द्रोणोऽभ्यभाषत॥
English Translation: O son of Pritha, whether it be a forest or a pasture ground where learned Brahmanas live is called a city. It is also a Tirtha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः शोणहयः क्रुद्धश्चतुर्दन्त इव द्विपः। प्रविश्य पाण्डवानीकं युधिष्ठिरमुपाद्रवत्॥
English Translation: By going to a king who protects (his subjects) and to a Brahmana who possesses ascetic merits and also by worshipping them both, one may be immediately cleansed off all his sins.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमाविध्यच्छितैर्बाणैः कङ्कपत्रैर्युधिष्ठिरः। तस्य द्रोणो धनुश्छित्त्वा तं द्रुतं समुपाद्रवत्॥
English Translation: The learned men have said that ablutions in the sacred Tirthas, recitations of the names of holy ones and conversations with the good and the virtuous are all praiseworthy acts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चक्ररक्षः कुमारस्तु पञ्चालानां यशस्करः। दधार द्रोणमायान्तं वेलेव सरितां पतिम्॥
English Translation: Those that are virtuous and honest always consider themselves sanctified by the holy companionship of persons like themselves and also by the water of pure and sacred conversation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्रोणं निवारितं दृष्ट्वा कुमारेण द्विजर्षभम्। सिंहनादरवो ह्यासीत् साधु साध्विति भाषितम्॥
English Translation: Carrying of the three stays, the vow of silence, matted locks (on head), shaving of the head, wearing barks and deer skins, observing vows, practicing ablutions, worshipping of fire and living in the forest emaciating the body, all these are useless to one if his heart be not pure.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कुमारस्तु ततो द्रोणं सायकेन महाहवे। विव्याधोरसि संक्रुद्धः सिंहवच्च नदन् मुहुः॥
English Translation: O king of kings, the indulgence of the six senses is (very) easy if purity be not its aim. Abstinence is itself difficult to acquire and it is more so if purity be not its aim. Among all the senses mind is the most dangerous.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संवार्य च रणे द्रोणं कुमारस्तु महाबलः। शरैरनेकसाहौः कृतहस्तो जितश्रमः॥
English Translation: These high-souled, men who do not commit sin in word, in deed, in heart or in soul, are said (really) to perform asceticism; but not those who make their bodies emaciated by fasts and penances.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं शूरमार्यव्रतिनं मन्त्रास्त्रेषु कृतश्रमम्। चक्ररक्षं परामृनात् कुमारं द्विजपुङ्गवः॥
English Translation: He who has no feeling of kindness for his relatives even if his body be pure cannot be free from sin. That hard-heartedness of his mind is his great enemy to asceticism.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: समध्यं प्राप्य सैन्यानां सर्वा:प्रविचरन् दिशः। तव सैन्यस्य गोप्ताऽऽसीद् भारद्वाजोद्विजर्षभः॥
English Translation: He who is always pure, who is endued with virtue and who practice virtue all his life, even if he leads a domestic life, is a (real) Rishi. He is freed from all sins.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शिखण्डिनं द्वादशभिर्विंशत्या चोत्तमौजसम्। नकुलं पञ्चभिर्विद्ध्वा सहदेवं च सप्तभिः॥ युधिष्ठिरं द्वादशभिद्रौपदेयांस्त्रिभिस्त्रिभिः। सात्यकि पञ्चभिर्विद्ध्वा मत्स्यं च दशभिः शरैः॥
English Translation: Fasts and other penances, however they may weaken and dry up the body which is made of flesh and blood, cannot destroy sins.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यक्षोभयद् रणे योधान् यथा मुख्यमभिद्रवन्। अभ्यवर्तत सम्प्रेप्सुः कुन्तीपुत्रं युधिष्ठिरम्॥
English Translation: The man whose heart is without holiness suffers torture by undergoing penances only being ignorant of their meaning. He is never freed from sins of such acts. The fire he worships does not consume his sins.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युगन्धरस्ततो राजन् भारद्वाजं महारथम्। वारयामास संक्रुद्धं वातोद्धतमिवार्णवम्॥
English Translation: Through holiness and virtue alone men can go to the regions of bliss and their vows and fasts can become efficacious. Living on fruits and roots, observing the vow of silence, living on air, shaving one's head, abandoning a fixed home, having matted locks on head, lying under the sky, observing daily fasts, worshipping the fire, bathing in water and lying on the ground, these alone cannot lead one to heaven.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिरं स विद्ध्वा तु शरैः संनतपर्वभिः। युगन्धरं तु भल्लेन रथनीडादपातयत्॥
English Translation: Those only that are endued with holiness succeed by knowledge and by (virtuous) deeds to conquer disease, decrepitude and death and they alone obtain a very high state.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो विराटद्रुपदौ केकया: सात्यकिः शिबिः। व्याघ्रदत्तश्च पाञ्चाल्य: सिंहसेनश्च वीर्यवान्॥ एते चान्ये च बहवः परीप्सन्तो युधिष्ठिरम्। आवब्रुस्तस्य पन्थानं किरन्तः सायकान् बहून्॥
English Translation: As seeds that have been scorched by fire do not produce the plant, so the pains that have been burnt by knowledge cannot affect the soul.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्याघ्रदत्तस्तुपाञ्चाल्योद्रोणं विव्याघ मार्गणैः। पञ्चाशता शितै राजंस्तत उच्चुक्रुशुर्जनाः॥
English Translation: The inert body, which is like a block of wood when destitute of soul, is certainly very short-lived like the forth in the ocean.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वरितं सिंहसेनस्तु द्रोण विद्ध्वा महारथम्। प्राहसत् सहसा हृष्टस्त्रासयन् व महारथान्॥
English Translation: He who obtains a view of his soul that dwells within every one's body by the help of one or the half of a rhythmic line (of the Vedas) has no need for anything else.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो विस्फार्य नयने धनुर्ध्यामवमृज्य च। तलशब्दं महत् कृत्वा द्रोणस्तं समुपाद्रवत्॥
English Translation: Some, by obtaining a knowledge of the identity of the supreme soul from but two letters (of the Vedas) and some, from hundreds and thousands of slokas, acquire salvation; for the knowledge of one's identity with the supreme soul is the sure sign of salvation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्तु सिंहसेनस्य शिरः कायात् सकुण्डलम्। व्याघ्रदत्तस्य चाक्रम्य भल्लाभ्यामाहरबली॥
English Translation: The learned old men have said that neither this world, nor that hereafter, nor bliss can come to one who is full of doubts. Faith is the certain sign of salvation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तान् प्रमथ्य शरवातैः पाण्डवानां महारथान्। युधिष्ठिररथाभ्याशे तस्थौ मृत्युरिवान्तकः॥
English Translation: He who knows the true meaning of the Vedas also understands their true use. He is frightened at the Vedic rites as man at a conflagration.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽभवन्महाशब्दो राजन् यौधिष्ठिरे बले। हतो राजेति योधानां समीपस्थे यतव्रते॥
English Translation: Abandoning dry discussion, take to Smriti and Shruti. Seek with the help of your reason the knowledge of the undying one who is without a second. One's search (for a thing) becomes in vain from the defect of means.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अब्रुवन् सैनिकास्तत्र दृष्ट्वा द्रोणस्य विक्रमम्। अद्य राजा धार्तराष्ट्रः कृतार्थो वै भविष्यति॥
English Translation: Therefore one should carefully try to obtain knowledge by means of the Vedas. The Vedas are the supreme soul, they are his body, they are the truth. The soul, that is bound by the animal organism belonging to a man in whom all the Vedas are manifest, can (only) know Him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अस्मिन् मुहूर्ते द्रोणस्तु पाण्डवं गृह्य हर्षितः। आगमिष्यति नो नूनं धार्तराष्ट्रस्य संयुगे॥
English Translation: The existence of the celestials as stated in the Vedas, the efficacy of (religious) acts and the capacity for action of beings furnished with bodies are noticeable in every Yuga.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं संजल्पतां तेषां तावकानां महारथः। आयाज्जवेन कौन्तेयो रथघोषेण नादयन्॥
English Translation: Independence from and the annihilation of these are to be sought by means of the purity of the senses. Therefore the suspension of the function of the senses is the true fasting.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शोणितोदां रथावर्ती कृत्वा विशसने नदीम्। शुरास्थिचयसंकीर्णां प्रेतकूलापहारिणीम्॥
English Translation: One may obtain heaven by asceticism, one may obtain objects of enjoyments by the practice of charity, one may have his sins all destroyed by bathing in Tirthas, but complete emancipation cannot be obtained without knowledge.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तां शरौघमहाफेनां प्रासमत्स्यसमाकुलाम्। नदीमुत्तीर्थ वेगेन कुरून् विद्राव्य पाण्डवः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : O king of kings, having been thus addressed, the greatly illustrious (Yudhishthira) replied, "O exalted one, I desire to hear about the rules of charity which is (really) meritorious.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः किरीटी सहसा द्रोणानीकमुपाद्रवत्। छादयन्निषुजालेन महता मोहयन्निव॥ शीघ्रमभ्यस्यतो बाणान् संदधानस्य चानिशम्। नान्तरं ददृशे कश्चित् कौन्तेयस्य यशस्विनः॥
English Translation: Markandeya said : O king of kings, O Yudhishthira, O monarch, the rules of charity which you desire to hear from me are highly valued by him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न दिशो नान्तरिक्षं च न द्यौर्नेव च मेदिनी। अदृश्यन्त महाराज बाणभूता इवाभवन्॥
English Translation: Hear about the mysteries of charity as they have been expounded in the Shrutis and Smritis. O Yudhishthira, he who performs a Shraddha in the conjunction of Gajachhaya at a place fanned by the leaves of an Ashvattha tree enjoys its fruits one hundred thousand Kalpas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नादृश्यत तदा राजंस्तत्र किंचन संयुगे। बाणान्धकारे महति कृते गाण्डीवधन्वना॥
English Translation: O ruler of earth, he who gives food to one who is dying of hunger and he who founds a home of charity with a person to look after it both acquire the fruits of (performing) all sacrifices.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सूर्ये चास्तमनुप्राप्ते तमसा चाभिसंवृते। नाज्ञायत तदा शत्रुर्न सुहन च कश्चन॥
English Translation: He who gives away a horse at a Tirtha where the current of the water runs in an opposite direction obtains merits that are inexhaustible. A guest who comes for food is Indra himself. If he is entertained with food, Indra confers on the feeder merits that are inexhaustible. As men cross rivers and seas by boats, so is he saved from all his sins (by giving board to guests).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽवहारं चक्रुस्ते द्रोणदुर्योधनादयः। तान् विदित्वा पुनस्त्रस्तानयुद्धमनसः परान्॥
English Translation: Therefore what is given to the Brahmanas produces, like the gift of curds, inexhaustible merits. A gift on a particular festive day produces twice the merit and on a particular season produces ten times the merit.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्वान्यनीकानि बीभत्सुः शनकैरवहारयत्। ततोऽभितुष्टुवुः पार्थे प्रहृष्टाः पाण्डुसंजयाः॥ पञ्चालाश्च मनोज्ञाभिर्वाग्भिः सूर्यमिवर्षयः। एवं स्वशिबिरं प्रायाज्जित्वा शत्रून् धनंजयः॥ पृष्ठतः सर्वसैन्यानां मुदितो वै सकेशवः॥
English Translation: And in a particular year produces one hundred times the merit (than gifts made at any other time). A gift made on the last day of the month produces inexhaustible merit. A gift made when the sun is on the solicit points, a gift made on the last day of the sun's path through Ubra, Asris, Gemini, Vrigo and Pisces and a gift made during the eclipses of the sun and the moon produce merits that are inexhaustible.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वज्रप्रवालस्फटिकैश्च मुख्यैः। चित्रे रथे पाण्डुसुतो बभासे नक्षत्रचित्रे वियतीव चन्द्रः॥
English Translation: The learned men say that gifts made during the seasons produce merit that is ten times, those made during the change of seasons one hundred times and those made during the day when Rahu is visible one thousand times greater than what is produced at other times. A gift made on the last day of the sun's course though Libra and Aria produces merit that is everlasting.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच मध्यन्दिने महाराज संग्रामः समपद्यत। लोकक्षयकरो रौद्रो भीष्मस्य सह सोमकैः॥
English Translation: O king, no one can enjoy landed property who does not give away lands; no one can drive on cars and conveyances who does not give them away. With whatever, desire one gives away to the Brahmanas, one enjoys the fruition of that gift in the next birth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गाङ्गेयो रथिनां श्रेष्ठः पाण्डवानामनीकिनीम्। व्यधमन्निशितैर्बाणैः शतशोऽथ सहस्रशः॥
English Translation: Gold has been produced from fire, the earth from Vishnu and the kine from the sun. Therefore he who gives away gold, land and kine obtains all the regions of Agni, Vishnu and the Sun.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सम्ममर्द च तत् सैन्यं पिता देवव्रतस्तव। धान्यानामिव लूनानां प्रकरं गोगणा इव॥
English Translation: There is nothing so everlasting as a gift. Is there any thing in the three worlds that is more auspicious? It is therefore that they who are greatly intelligent say that there is nothing higher in the three worlds than making gifts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृष्टद्युम्नः शिखण्डी च विराटो द्रुपदस्तथा। भीष्ममासाद्य समरे शरैर्जघ्नुर्महारथम्॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said It is thus, on account of his Ignorance and his association with others who are invested with Ignorance, that Individual Soul passes through millions and millions of births every one of which has dissolution in the end.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृष्टद्युम्नं ततो विध्वा विराटं च शरैस्त्रिभिः। दुपदस्य च नाराचं प्रेषयामास भारत॥
English Translation: On account of his transformation into Intelligence invested with Ignorance, Individual Soul goes to millions of abodes, every one of which is liable to end in Jostruction, among intermediate beings and men and the gods.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेन विद्धा महेष्वासा भीष्मेणामित्रकर्षिणा। चुक्रुधुः समरे राजन् पादस्पृष्टा इवोरगाः॥
English Translation: On account of Ignorance, Individual Soul like the Moon, has to wax and wane thousands and thousands of times. This is truly the nature of Individual Soul when invested with Ignorance. Know that the Moon has in reality full sixteen portions. Only fifteen of these are subject to increase and decrease. The sixteenth remains constant. after the manner of the Moon, Individual Soul too has full appear and disappear. The sixteenth is subject to no change.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शिखण्डी तं च विव्याध भरतानां पितामहम्। स्त्रीमयं मनसा ध्यात्वा नास्मै प्राहरदच्युतः॥
English Translation: Invested with Ignorance, Individual Soul repeatedly and continually takes birth in the fifteen portions, named above. With the etemai and immutable portion of Individual Soul the principal elements become united and this union takes place repeatedly.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृष्टद्युम्नस्तु समरे क्रोधेनाग्निरिव ज्वलन्। पितामहं त्रिभिर्बाणैर्वाह्वोरुरसि चार्पयत्॥
English Translation: That sixteenth portion is subtile. It should be known as Soma. It is never upheld by the senses. On the other hand, the senses are upheld by it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्रुपदः पञ्चविंशत्या विराटो दशभिः शरैः। शिखण्डी पञ्चविंशत्या भीष्मं विव्याध सायकैः॥
English Translation: Since those sixteen portions are the cause of the birth of creatures, creatures can never, O king, take birth without their help. They are called Nature. The destruction of Jiva's liability to be united with nature is called Liberation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सोऽतिविद्धो महाराज शोणितौघपरिप्लुतः। वसन्ते पुष्पशबलो रक्ताशोक इवाबभौ॥
English Translation: The Principle of Greatness, which is the twenty-fifth, if it regards that body of sixteen portions called the Unmanifest, has to assume it repeatedly. On account of not knowing. That which is stainless and pure, and for its devotion to what is the outcome of a combination of both Pure and Impure, the Soul, which is, in reality, pure, becomes, O king, Impure. Indeed, on account of its devotion to ignorance, Individual soul though characterised by Knowledge, becomes repeatedly associated with Ignorance.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तान् प्रत्यविध्यद् गाङ्गेयस्त्रिभिस्त्रिभिरजिह्मगैः। द्रुपदस्य च भल्लेन धनुचिच्छेद मारिष॥
English Translation: Though, O king, free from error of every sort, yet on account of its devotion to the three qualities of Nature, it becomes endued with those attributes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सोऽन्यत् कार्मुकमादाय भीष्मं विव्याध पञ्चभिः। सारथिं च त्रिभिर्बाणैः सुशितै रणमूर्धनि॥
English Translation: Bhishma said: O mother, listen to me, I shall point out the means by which the Bharata dynasty may be perpetuated. Let an accomplished Brahmana be invited with the offer of wealth; let him beget offspring on the wives of Vichitravirya.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथा भीमो महाराज द्रौपद्याः पञ्च चात्मजाः। केकया भ्रातरः पञ्च सात्यकिश्चैव सात्वतः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Then Satyavati thus spoke to Bhishma, smiling softly and speaking in bashful voice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभ्यद्रवन्त गाङ्गेयं युधिष्ठिरपुरोगमाः। रिरक्षिषन्तः पाञ्चाल्यं धृष्टद्युम्नपुरोगमाः॥
English Translation: Satyavati said : O descendant of the Bharata race, what you say is true. From my confidence in you, I shall now point my confidence in you, I shall now point out the means of perpetuating our dynasty.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथैव तावकाः सर्वे भीष्मरक्षार्थमुद्यताः। प्रत्युद्ययुः पाण्डुसेनां सहसैन्या नराधिप॥
English Translation: You shall not be able to reject it, learned as you are in the practices permitted in the time of distress. You are Virtue, you are Truth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्रासीत् सुमहद् युद्धं तव तेषां च संकुलम्। नराश्वरथनागानां यमराष्ट्रविवर्धनम्॥
English Translation: Therefore, hearing what I say, do what is proper. My father was a virtuous man and for virtue's sake he had kept a boat (for crossing people.)
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रथी रथिनमासाद्य प्राहिणोद् यमसादनम्। तथेतरान् समासाद्य नरनागाश्वसादिनः॥
English Translation: In the prime of my youth, I went one day to ply that boat. It so happened that the great and wise Rishi Parashara, the foremost of all virtuous men, came on my boat for crossing the Yamuna. As I was taking him across the river, that best of Rishis became full of desire and began to address me in soft words.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनयन् परलोकाय शरैः संनतपर्वभिः। शरैश्च विविधैर्पोरैस्तत्र तत्र विशाम्पते॥ रथास्तु रथिभि_ना हतसारथयस्तथा। विप्रदुताश्चाः समरे दिशो जग्मुः समन्ततः॥
English Translation: O descendant of Bharata, I was afraid of my father, but I was also greatly afraid of the Rishi's curse. Therefore, having got from him a great boon, I could not refuse his request.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मृदन्तस्ते नरान् राजन् हयांश्च सुबहून् रणे। वातायमाना दृश्यन्ते गन्धर्वनगरोपमाः॥
English Translation: O descendant of the Bharata race, he overpowered me, a mere girl, by his great effulgence and he also enveloped the region with a thick fog. There was in my body a revolting odour of fish before, but the Rishi dispelled it and gave me my this fragrance.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रथिनश्च स्थैींना वर्मिणस्तेजसा युताः। कुण्डलोष्णीषिणः सर्वे निष्काङ्गदविभूषणाः॥
English Translation: The Rishi told me, "After bringing forth this child on the island of this river, you will remain a virgin."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: देवपुत्रसमाः सर्वे शौर्ये शक्रसमा युधि। ऋद्ध्या वैश्रवणं चाति नयेन च बृहस्पतिम्॥
English Translation: The son of Parashara, thus born of me in my maiden-hood, has becomes great ascetic, named Dvaipayana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वलोकेश्वराः शूरास्तत्र तत्र विशाम्पते। विप्रद्रुता व्यदृश्यन्त प्राकृता इव मानवाः।।२३।
English Translation: That illustrious Rishi, having divided by his ascetic power the Vedas into four parts, has become known on earth as Vyasa and for his black colour as Krishna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दन्तिनश्च नरश्रेष्ठ हीनाः परमसादिभिः। मृदन्तः स्वान्यनीकानि निपेतुः सर्वशब्दगाः॥
English Translation: He is truthful, free from passions and a great ascetic who has destroyed all his sins; he went away with his great father as soon as he was born.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चर्मभिश्चामरैश्चत्रैः पताकाभिश्च मारिष। छत्रैः सिहतैर्हमदण्डैश्चामरैश्च समन्ततः॥
English Translation: Asked by me and also by you, that Rishi of incomparable effulgence will surely beget excellent offspring on the wives of your brother.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विशीर्णैविप्रधावन्तो दृश्यन्ते स्म दिशो दश। नवमेघप्रतीकाशा जलदोपमनिःस्वनाः॥
English Translation: He told me, "Mother, think of me (mentally call me) when you will be in difficulty. O mighty-armed Bhishma, if you wish, I can now think of him."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथैव दन्तिभिहींना गजारोहा विशाम्पते। प्रधावन्तोऽन्वदृश्यन्त तव तेषां च संकुले॥
English Translation: O Bhishma if you are willing and if you appoint him, I am sure that great ascetic will beget children on the wives of Vichitravirya.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नानादेशसमुत्थांतुरगान हेमभूषितान्। वातायमानानद्राक्षं शतशोऽथ सहस्रशः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : When the great Rishi was the mentioned, Bhishma with joined hands said. "That man is truly intelligent who fixes his eyes judiciously on Dharma, Artha and Kama and who, after reflecting with patience, acts in such a way as virtue (Dharma) may lead to future virtue, profit (Artha) to future profit and pleasure (Kama) to future pleasure. Therefore, that which has been said by you and that which, besides being beneficial to us is consistent with virtue, is certainly the best advice and it has my full approval."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अश्वारोहान् हतैरश्चैर्ग्रहीतासीन् समन्ततः। द्रवमाणानपश्याम द्राव्यमाणांश्च संयुगे॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : O descendant of the Kuru race, when Bhishma said this, Kali (Satyavati) thought of the Rishi Krishna Dvaipayana Dvaipayana, who was then interpreting the Vedas, came at once to his mother without any body knowing it, as soon as he found that he had been thought of. She (Satyavati), having welcomed her son in all due forms, embraced him with her arms and bathed him with her breast milk. The daughter of the fisherman (Satyavati) shed much tears to see her son after a long time.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गजो गजं समासाद्य द्रवमाणं महाहवे। ययौ प्रमृद्य तरसा पादातान् वाजिनस्तथा॥
English Translation: Having seen her weep, the great Rishi, Vyasa, her eldest son, washed her (face) with cool water; and bowing to his mother, he said-
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथैव च रथान् राजन् प्रममर्द रणे गजः। रथाश्चैव समासाद्य पतितांस्तुरगान् भुवि॥
English Translation: O mother, I have come to fulfill your wishes. Therefore, o virtuous lady, command me without delay. I shall accomplish what you desire.”
The priest (of the Bharatas) then worshipped the great Rishi in the proper form and the Rishi accepted the offerings of the worship with uttering the usual Mantras.
Being pleased with the due worship with the proper Mantras, he took his seat. His mother, Satyavati, seeing him conformably seated, asked his welfare and made the usual enquiries.
She then said, O Kavi, (learned man), the sons derive their birth from both the father and the mother. There is no doubt that their proprietors are both the father and the mother. You are my eldest son according to the ordinances. O Brahmarshi, Vichitravirya was my youngest son. As he was the brother of Bhishma by father's side, so you are by the mother's side. This is my opinion, I do not know what is your opinion, I do not know what is your opinion. This Bhishma, the son of Shantanu, who is devoted to truth, does not, for the sake of truth, wish to beget children or to rule the kingdom.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यमृद्न् समरे राजंस्तुरगाश्च नरान् रणे। एवं ते बहुधा राजन् प्रत्यमृद्न् परस्परम्॥
English Translation: Therefore, O sinless one, for the sake of the affection you bear for your brother (Vichitravirya), for the sake of perpetuating the dynasty of Shantanu, for the sake of Bhishma and my request. For the sake of the kindness you bear for all creatures, for the sake of the protection of people and for the sake of the liberality of your heart you should do what I say. Your younger brother has left two young wives, like the daughters of the celestials. They possess beauty and youth and they wish to have sons from the desire of getting virtue. O son, therefore, beget on them sons worthy of our dynasty and for the continuance of our line.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मिन् रौद्रे तथा युद्धे वर्तमाने महाभये। प्रावर्तत नदी घोरा शोणितान्त्रतरङ्गिणी॥
English Translation: Vyasa said: O (mother) Satyavati, you know what is virtue, both as regards this world and the next. O lady of great wisdom, your mind is also fixed on virtue. Therefore, making virtue my motive, I shall, at your command, do what you desire, knowing (as I do) that this practice is conformable to the true and eternal religion. I shall produce for my brother sons that will be like Yama and Varuna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अस्थिसंघातसम्बाधा केशशैवलशाद्वला। रथह्रदा शरावर्ता हयमीना दुरासदा॥
English Translation: Therefore, let the ladies observe the vow I indicate for one full year. They will be then purified. No woman must come to me without having observed a rigid vow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शीर्षोपलसमाकीर्णा हस्तिग्राहसमाकुला। कवचोष्णीषफेनौघा धनुर्वेगासिकच्छपा॥
English Translation: Satyavati said : Take such steps as the ladies may conceive today. The people perish in a kingdom where there is anarchy. Sacrifices and other holy acts are destroyed, the rains and the celestial disappear from that place.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पताकाध्वजवृक्षाढ्या महँकूलापहारिणी। क्रव्यादहंससंकीर्णा यमराष्ट्रविवर्धनी॥
English Translation: O Lord, how can a kingdom be protected without a king? Therefore, see that the ladies conceive. Bhishma will watch over the children in their womb.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तां नदी क्षत्रियाः शूरा रथनागहयप्लवैः। प्रतेरुर्बहवो राजन् भयं त्यक्त्वा महारथाः॥
English Translation: Vyasa said: If I am to produce sons for my brother so unseasonably then let the ladies tolerate my ugliness. That will be to them a great penance.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपोवाह रणे भीरून् कश्मलेनाभिसंवृतान्। यथा वैतरणी प्रेतान् प्रेतराजपुरं प्रति॥
English Translation: If the princess of Kosalya (Ambika) can bear my strong odour, my ugly and grim visage, my attire and body, she will then conceive an excellent son.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्राक्रोशन् क्षत्रियास्तत्र दृष्ट्वा तद् वैशसं महत्। दुर्योधनापराधेन गच्छन्ति क्षत्रियाः क्षयम्॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Having thus spoken to Satyavati, the greatly effulgent Vyasa said to her, “Let the princess of Kosalya adorned with ornaments wait for me in her bed room in clear attire. (so saying) he (immediately) disappeared. Satyavati then went to her daughter-in-law and in private, spoke to her these words of beneficial and virtuous import, “O princess of Kosalya, hear what I say. It is consistent with virtue.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गुणवत्सु कथं द्वेषं धृतराष्ट्रो जनेश्वरः। कृतवान् पाण्डुपुत्रेषु पापात्मा लोभमोहितः॥
English Translation: On account of my bad fate, the Bharata dynasty has become extinct. Seeing me grieved and the extinction of his paternal line. The wise Bhishma, with the desire of perpetuating our race has made to me a suggestion. But, O daughter, its accomplishment depends on you. Accomplish it and restore the lost line of the Bharatas. O beautiful girl, bring forth a son as effulgent as the king of the celestials. He will bear the heavy burden of our this hereditary kingdom.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं बहुविधा वाचः श्रूयन्ते स्म परस्परम्। पाण्डवस्तवसंयुक्ताः पुत्राणां ते सुदारुणाः॥
English Translation: She (Satyavati,) having succeeded somehow in getting the consent of that virtuous lady to her proposal which was consistent to religion, fed Brahmanas, Devarshis and guests.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ता निशम्य ततो वाचः सर्वयोधैरुदाहृताः। आगस्कृत् सर्वलोकस्य पुत्रो दुर्योधनस्तव॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Those best of Brahmanas (present there), shaking their deer-skins and coconut shell water pots, exclaimed, “Fear not; we shall fight with the foes."

English Translation: Arjuna smilingly told those Brahmanas who spoke to him “Stand aside as spectators,

Sanskrit Shloka: ततः प्रववृत्ते युद्धं कुरूणां पाण्डवैः सह। अक्षद्यूतकृतं राजन् सुघोरं वैशसं तदा॥
English Translation: I shall check all these kings, like snakes by. Mantras, showering on them arrows furnished with sharp points.”
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यत् पुरा न निगृह्णासि वार्यमाणो महात्मभिः। वैचित्रवीर्य तस्येदं फलं पश्य सुदारुणम्॥
English Translation: Having said this, the mighty Arjuna took up the bow he had obtained as the dower and accompanied by his brother Bhima, stood immovable as a mountain.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न हि पाण्डुसुता राजन् ससैन्याः सपदानुगाः। रक्षन्ति समरे प्राणान् कौरवा वापि संयुगे॥
English Translation: Seeing the Kshatriyas, ever furious in battle, with Karna at their head, the two heroic brothers rushed at them like two elephants rushing against a herd of hostile elephants.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतस्मात् कारणाद् घोरो वर्तते स्वजनक्षयः। दैवाद् वा पुरुषव्याघ्र तव चापनयानृप॥
English Translation: Then those kings, eager for battle, fiercely exclaimed, Killing a Brahmana desirous of fighting in battle is permitted.“
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच श्रुत्वा स राजा राजर्षेरिन्द्रद्युम्नस्य तत् तदा। मार्कण्डेयान्महाभागात् स्वर्गस्य प्रतिपादनम्॥ युधिष्ठिरो महाराज पुनः पप्रच्छ तं मुनिम्।
English Translation: Saying this, the monarchs at once rushed upon the Brahmanas and the greatly powerful Karna rushed against Jishnu (Arjuna) to fight.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कीदृशीषु ह्यवस्थासु दत्त्वा दानं महामुने॥ इन्द्रलोकं त्वनुभवेत् पुरुषस्तद् द्रवीहि मे।
English Translation: The mighty! king of the Madras, Shalya rushed against. Bhima like one elephant rushing against another for a female one.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गार्हस्थ्येऽप्यथवा बाल्ये यौवने स्थविरेऽपि वा। यथा फलं समश्याति तथा त्वं कथयस्व मे॥
English Translation: Duryodhana and others all fought with the Brahmanas, but they skirmished with them lightly and carelessly.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मार्कण्डेय उवाच वृथा जन्मानि चत्वारि वृथा दानानि षोडश। वृथा जन्म ह्यपुत्रस्य ये च धर्मबहिष्कृताः॥ परपाकेषु येऽश्नन्ति आत्मार्थं च पचेत् तु यः। पर्यश्नन्ति वृथा ये च तदसत्यं प्रकीर्त्यते।५॥
English Translation: Then the illustrious Arjuna, seeing the son of Vikartana, Karna, coming towards him, drew his tough bow and pierced him with his sharp arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आरूढपतिते दत्तमन्यायोपहृतं च यत्। व्यर्थंतु पतिते दानं ब्राह्मणे तस्करे तथा॥
English Translation: The son of Radha (Karna), being much pestered by his swift, powerful and effulgent arrows, attacked Arjuna with more care (than before).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गुरौ चानृतिके पापे कृतघ्ने ग्रामयाजके। वेदविक्रयिणे दत्तं तथा वृषलयाजके॥ ब्रह्मबन्धुषु यद् दत्तं यद् दत्तं वृषलीपतौ। स्त्रीजनेषु च यद् दत्तं व्यालग्राहे तथैव च॥ परिचारकेषु यद् दत्तं वृथा दानानि षोडश।
English Translation: Then Karna and Arjuna, both foremost of all warriors, fought madly on, each eager to vanquish the other. Such was the lightness of hand they displayed that they both became invisible (on account of the incessant showers of arrows).”
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमोवृतस्तु यो दद्याद् भयात् क्रोधात् तथैव च।॥ भुङ्क्ते च दानं तत् सर्वं गर्भस्थस्तु नरः सदा। ददद् दानं द्विजातिभ्यो वृद्धभावेन मानवः॥
English Translation: “Behold the strength of my arms, “Mark how I have counteracted your feats, they addressed each other in such words, intelligible only of the heroes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मात् सर्वास्ववस्थासु सर्वदानानि पार्थिव दातव्यानि द्विजातिभ्यः स्वर्गमार्गजिगीषया॥
English Translation: Enraged on seeing the strength and energy of Arjuna's arms as matchless in the earth, the son of Surya, Karma, fought with greater vigour.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच चातुर्वर्ण्यस्य सर्वस्य वर्तमानाः प्रतिग्रहे। केन विप्रा विशेषेण तारयन्ति तरन्ति च॥
English Translation: Parrying all the swift and strong arrows shot at him by Arjuna, Karna sent up a laud shout. And his great feat was applauded by all the warriors.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मार्कण्डेय उवाच जपैर्मन्त्रैश्च होमैश्च स्वाध्यायाध्ययनेन च। नावं वेदमयीं कृत्वा तारयन्ति तरन्ति च॥
English Translation: Karna said: O foremost of the Brahmanas, I am pleased to see the strength of your arms, that know no relaxation in battle. Your weapons are worthy of achieving victory.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणांस्तोषयेद् यस्तु तुष्यन्ते तस्य देवताः। वचनाच्चापि विप्राणां स्वर्गलोकमवाप्नुयात्॥
English Translation: Is the science of arms personified in you, or are you that best of Brahmanas (Parashu) Rama or Indra himself or Vishnu, or Achyuta himself?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पितृदैवतपूजाभिर्ब्राह्मणाभ्यर्चनेन च। अनन्तं पुण्यलोकं तु गन्तासि त्वं न संशयः॥
English Translation: In order to conceal your personality have you assumed the forin of a Brahmana and mastering all the strength of arms are you now fighting with me?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्लेष्मादिभिर्व्याप्ततनुम्रियमाणो विचेतनः। ब्राह्मणा एव सम्पूज्याः पुण्यं स्वर्गमभीप्सता।१६।।
English Translation: None except Sachi's husband (Indra) or Kiriti (Arjuna), the son of Pandu is capable of fighting with me when I am angry on the field of battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्राद्धकाले तु यत्नेन भोक्तव्या ह्यजुगुप्सिताः। दुर्वर्णः कुनखी कुष्ठी मायावी कुण्डगोलकौ॥ वर्जनीयाः प्रयलेन काण्डपृष्ठाश्च देहिनः। जुगुप्सितं हि यच्छ्राद्धं दहत्यग्निरिवेन्धनम्॥

Sanskrit Shloka: ये ये श्राद्धे न युज्यन्ते मूकान्धबधिरादयः। तेऽपि सर्वे नियोक्तव्या मिश्रिता वेदपारगैः॥
English Translation: I am only a Brahmana who is the foremost of all wielders of arms. By the grace of my preceptor, I have become expert in the Brahma and Paurandra weapons. I am here to-day to vanquish you in battle. O hero, wait a little.”

Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मात् त्वं सर्वयत्नेन यतस्वातिथिभोजने। पादोदकं पादघृतं दीपमन्नं प्रतिश्रयम्॥ प्रयच्छन्ति तु ये राजन् नोपसर्पन्ति ते यमम्।
English Translation: Challenged one another and fought like two mad elephants, striking each other with their clenched fists and knees.

Sanskrit Shloka: देवमाल्यापनयनं द्विजोच्छिष्टावमार्जनम्॥ आकल्प: परिचर्या च गात्रसंवाहनानि च। अत्रैकैकं नृपश्रेष्ठ गोदानाद्ध्यतिरिच्यते॥
English Translation: Sometimes pushing each other to distance, sometimes dragging each other near; sometimes throwing each other down with their faces down-wards and sometimes on their sides, they fought on, striking each other at times with the clenched fists.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कपिलायाः प्रदानात् तु मुच्यते नात्र संशयः। तस्मादलंकृतां दद्यात् कपिलां तु द्विजातये॥
English Translation: As they fought each other with blows hard as the clash of two pieces of stones, the arena rang with the sound of their combat.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रोत्रियाय दरिद्राय गृहस्थायाग्निहोत्रिणे। पुत्रदाराभिभूताय तथा ह्यनुपकारिणे॥
English Translation: Fighting thus in the battle for a few minutes, Bhima, the best of the Kurus, then taking up Shalya on his arms, hurled him to a distance and the best of men Bhimasena surprised all (by his feat), for though he threw the powerful Shalya on the ground, he did not hurt him much.
---
