English Translation: When Shalya was thus thrown down by Bhima and Karna was struck with fear, all the other kings were filled with awe and they surrounded Vrikodara (Bhima from all sides), of
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एकस्यैका प्रदातव्या न बहूनां कदाचन। सा गौर्विक्रयमापन्ना हन्यात् त्रिपुरुषं कुलम्॥ न तारयति दातारं ब्राह्मणं नैव नैव तु।
English Translation: They said, "Surely these best Brahmanas are excellent (warriors). Ascertain in what tribe they have been born and when they live.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुवर्णस्य विशुद्धस्य सुवर्णं यः प्रयच्छति॥ सुवर्णानां शतं तेन दत्तं भवति शाश्वतम्।
English Translation: Who is capable of fighting with the son of Radha, Karna, in battle except Rama, Drona or Kiriti, the son of Pandu (Arjuna)?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनड्वाहं तु यो दद्याद् बलवन्तं धुरंधरम्॥ स लिस्तरति दुर्गाणि स्वर्गलोकं च गच्छति।
English Translation: Who is capable of fighting in battle with Duryodhana except the son of Devaki Krishna and son of Sharadvan, Kripa?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वसुन्धरां तु यो दद्याद् द्विजाय विदुरात्मने।॥ दातारं ह्यनुगच्छन्ति सर्वे कामाभिवाञ्छिताः।
English Translation: Who is capable of overthrowing in battle the king of Madra, Shalya, the foremost of great warriors, except Baladeva, the heroic Vrikodra, the son of Pandu and the heroic Duryodhana? Therefore, let as desist from this fight with the Brahmanas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पृच्छन्ति चात्र दातारं वदन्ति पुरुषा भुवि॥ अध्वनि क्षीणगात्राश्च पांसुपादावगुण्ठिताः। तेषामेव श्रमार्तानां यो ह्यन्नं कथयेद् बुधः॥ अन्नदातृसमः सोऽपि कीयंते नात्र संशयः।
English Translation: Brahmanas, if they be offending, should still ever be protected. First let us ascertain who these (heroes) are. After we have learnt it, we my cheerfully fight with them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मात् त्वं सर्वदानानि हित्वान्नं सम्प्रयच्छ हा॥ न हीदृशं पुण्यफलं विचित्रमिह विद्यते। यथाशक्ति च यो दद्यादन्नं विप्रेषु संस्कृतम्॥ स तेन कर्मणाऽऽमोति प्रजापतिसलोकताम्।
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Seeing that feat of Bhima, Krishna believed them both to be the sons of Kunti. Gently addressing the assemble monarch by saying, “ This maiden has been greatly won (by the Brahmanas)” he induced them to desist from the fight.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्नमेव विशिष्टं हि तस्मात् परतरं न च॥ अन्नं प्रजापतिश्चोक्तः स च संवत्सरो मतः। संवत्सरस्तु यज्ञोऽसौ सर्वं यज्ञे प्रतिष्ठितम्॥
English Translation: Having thus desisted from the battle, those best of monarchs, those (heroes) well (skilled in battle, returned to their respective kingdoms, all becoming exceedingly surprised.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मात् सर्वाणि भूतानि स्थावराणि चराणि च। तस्मादन्नं विशिष्टं हि सर्वेभ्य इति विश्रुतम्॥
English Translation: Those that assembled there went away saying that the Brahmanas had become victorious to-day; the princess of Panchala had become the bride of a Brahmana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: येषां तटाकानि महोदकानि वाप्यश्च कूपाश्च प्रतिश्रयाश्च। अन्नस्य दानं मधुरा च वाणी यमस्य ते निर्वचना भवन्ति॥
English Translation: Surrounded by Brahmanas attired in skins of deed and other wild animals, Bhima and Dhananjaya passed through the crowd with good deal of difficulty.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धान्यं श्रमेणार्जितवित्तसंचितं विप्रे सुशीले च प्रयच्छते यः। वसुन्धरा तस्य भवेत् सुतुष्टा धारां वसूनां प्रतिमुञ्चतीव॥
English Translation: Those heroes among men, mangled by the enemies and followed by Krishna, at last came out of the crowd and they looked like the full moon or the sun emerged from the clouds. And their mother (Kunti in her lodging) began to think of various evils having overtaken her sons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्नदाः प्रथमं यान्ति सत्यवाक् तदनन्तरम्। अयाचितप्रदाता च समं यान्ति त्रयो जनाः॥
English Translation: Seeing that her sons were late in returning from their begging tour, she was filled with anxiety. At one time she thought that the sons of Dhritarashtra had recognised and killed them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच कौतूहलसमुत्पन्नः पर्यपृच्छद् युधिष्ठिरः। मार्कण्डेयं महात्मानं पुनरेव सहानुजः॥
English Translation: Next she feared that some cruel and strong Rakshasas, endued with the prowess of deception, had killed them. And she asked herself, “Could the illustrious Vyasa himself have been guided by perverse intelligence?"
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यमलोकस्य चाध्वानमन्तरं मानुषस्य च। कीदृशं किम्प्रमाणं वा कथं वा तन्महामुने। तरन्ति पुरुषाश्चैव केनोपायेन शंस मे॥
English Translation: Thus Pondered Pritha out of her affection for her children. Then in the stillness of the late afternoon, Jishnu (Arjuna), accompanied with many Brahmanas, entered the potter's house like the cloud-covered sun emerged from the clouds in a cloudy day.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मार्कण्डेय उवाच सर्वगुह्यतमं प्रश्न पवित्रमृषिसंस्तुतम्। कथयिष्यामि ते राजन् धर्म्य धर्मभृतां वर॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said Hearing the loud rattles of chariots and the lion like roars (of warriors) in the field, Arjuna, addressing Govinda, said, “Clap spurs to the chargers."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: षडशीतिसहस्राणि योजनानां नराधिप। यमलोकस्य चाध्वानमन्तरं मानुषस्य च॥
English Translation: Hearing these words of Arjuna, Govinda replied him (thus)-"Off I go towards the spot where Bhima has taken his post.”
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आकाशं तदपानीयं घोरं कान्तारदर्शनम्। न तत्र वृक्षच्छाया वा पानीयं केतनानि च॥ विश्रमेद् यत्र वै श्रान्तः पुरुषोऽध्वनि कर्शितः।
English Translation: Then, like the king of the celestials, proceeding in great wrath and with thunder in his arms, to strike down Jambha (the Asura), Jaya (Arjuna) rushed (in the field), to obtain victory, borne by horses white as snow or conchs and with housings laid with gold, pearls and gems.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नीयते यमदूतैस्तु यमस्याज्ञाकरैर्बलात्॥ नराः स्त्रियस्तथैवान्ये पृथिव्यां जीवसंज्ञिताः।
English Translation: Many warriors, (of the other side), representing lions in prowess all boiling with rage and followed by a large retinue him and making the Earth resound and rending the skies with the whizz of their arrows, the rattling sound of the wheels of their war-chariots and the noise of the tread of their horses' hoofs.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणेभ्यः प्रदानानि नानारूपाणि पार्थिव॥ हयादीनां प्रकृष्टानि तेऽध्वानं यान्ति वै नराः। संनिवार्यातपं यान्ति छत्रेणैव हि छत्रदाः॥
English Translation: Then, there ensued, O sire, a mortal conflict between them (the train-bands of the Kaurava forces) and Partha, a conflict carrying death and destruction in its train to body, life and sin alike, like the great battle between the Asuras and Vishnu, the greatest of all great conquerors, for the (sovereignty of the) three worlds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तृप्ताश्चैवान्नदातारो ह्यतृप्ताश्चाप्यनन्नदाः। वस्त्रिणो वस्त्रदा यान्ति अवस्त्रा यान्त्यवस्त्रदाः॥
English Translation: Alone and unaided, the diadem-decked and garland-necked Arjuna, rent asunder all the powerful weapons flung (against him) by them (his adversaries) and struck off their heads and arms in many and varied forms, with his razoredged and crescent shaped shafts, as also with his broad-pointed arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हिरण्यदाः सुखं यान्ति पुरुषास्त्वभ्यलंकृताः। भूमिदास्तु सुखं यान्ति सर्वैः कामैः सुतर्पिताः॥
English Translation: Umbrellas, banners, horses, chariots, elephants and foot soldiers, shattered and mutilated, fell down on the Earth, like a forest uprooted by a violent wind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यान्ति चैवापरिक्लिष्टा नराः सस्यप्रदायकाः। नराः सुखतरं यान्ति विमानेषु गृहप्रदाः॥
English Translation: Mighty elephants caparisoned with goldlaid trappings and equipped with banners of triumphs and adorned with riders (on their back), wore a majestic look and shed a lustur all round as they were encompassed with goldwinged shafts, like blazing mountains.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पानीयदा ह्यतृषिताः प्रहृष्टमनसो नराः। पन्थानं द्योतयन्तश्च यान्ति दीपप्रदाः सुखम्॥
English Translation: With excellent shafts piercing elephants, horses and war chariots and resembling thunder of Vasava, Dhananjaya winged his way to strike down Karna, like Indra, in days of yore, proceeding to rend in twain (the Asura) Bala.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गोप्रदास्तु सुखं यान्ति निर्मुक्ताः सर्वपातकैः। विमानैर्हससंयुक्तैर्यान्ति मासोपवासिनः॥
English Translation: Then that mightiest of men, the terror of enemies, rushed headlong into the midst of your vast array as does the Makar while plunging into the deep sea.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथा बर्हिप्रयुक्तैश्च षष्ठरात्रोपवासिनः। त्रिरात्रं क्षपते यस्तु एकभक्तेन पाण्डव॥ अन्तरा चैव नाश्नाति तस्य लोका ह्यनामयाः। पानीयस्य गुणा दिव्याः प्रेतलोकसुखावहाः॥
English Translation: Seeing Pandu's sun so advance, O king, your warriors, with a long line of cars and a retinue of elephant, horse and foot soldiers, pressed upon him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्र पुष्पोदका नाम नदी तेषां विधीयते। शीतलं सलिलं तत्र पिबन्ति ह्यमृतोपमम्॥
English Translation: And while rushing against Partha, they raised a tumultuous cry like the roarings of the surging waves in a tempest.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ये च दुष्कृतकर्माणः पूयं तेषां विधीयते। एवं नदी महाराज सर्वकामप्रदा हि सा॥
English Translation: Those great warriors, powerful like tigers, reckless of their life, rushed in battle to face that mighty man, careering like a tiger.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मात् त्वमपि राजेन्द्र पूजयनान् यथाविधि। अध्वनि क्षीणगात्रश्च पथि पांसुसमन्वितः॥ पृच्छते ह्यन्नदातारं गृहमायाति चाशया। तं पूजयाथ यत्नेन सोऽतिथिर्ब्राह्मणश्च सः॥
English Translation: With a heavy down-pour of arrows they advanced towards him, but Arjuna dispersed them like vapours before the gushing wind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं यान्तमनुगच्छन्ति देवाः सर्वे सवासवाः। तस्मिन् सम्पूजिते प्रीता निराशा यान्त्यपूजिते॥
English Translation: Those mighty warriors-all good shots and of unfailing aim-in a body and with a long line of war-chariots following them, advanced against Arjuna and began to pierce him with their sharp weapons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मात् त्वमपि राजेन्द्र पूजयैनं यथाविधि। एतत् ते शतशः प्रोक्तं किं भूयः श्रोतुमिच्छसि॥
English Translation: Arjuna, then, (rendering asunder) with his arrows, chariots, elephants and horses by thousands, dispatched (them) off to the region of Pluto.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच पुनः पुनरहं श्रोतुं कथां धर्मसमाश्रयाम्। पुण्यामिच्छामि धर्मज्ञ कथ्यमानां त्वया विभो॥
English Translation: Thus afflicted in action with shots flung from Arjuna's bow, those mighty car-warriors, terrified and panic-stricken, began gradually to melt away.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मार्कण्डेय उवाच धर्मान्तरं प्रति कथां कथ्यमानां मया नृप। सर्वपापहरां नित्यं शृणुष्वावहितो मम॥
English Translation: Among those great car-warriors four hundred valiantly kept the field; and Arjuna, with his keen shafts, sent them, one and all, to their last account.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कपिलायां तु दत्तायां यत् फलं ज्येष्ठपुष्करे। तत् फलं भरतश्रेष्ठ विप्राणां पादधावने॥
English Translation: (And those that held the rear) afflicted, in that battle, with keen shafts and sharp arrows of all kinds, dispersed themselves in all directions-far away from Arjuna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्विजपादोदकक्लिन्ना यावत् तिष्ठति मेदिनी। तावत् पुष्करपर्णेन पिबन्ति पितरो जलम्॥
English Translation: The shouting noise made at the van by the retreating army was as furious as the grumbling roars of the breakers of the surging seas when dashing against rocks.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्वागतेनाग्नयस्तृप्ता आसनेन शतक्रतुः। पितरः पादशौचेन अन्नाद्येन प्रजापतिः॥
English Translation: Thus, with his arrows, dispersing the panicstricken army, O sire, Arjuna, the son of Pritha, advanced against the column commanded by the son of Suta.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यावद् वत्सस्य वै पादौ शिरश्चैव प्रदृश्यते। तस्मिन् काले प्रदातव्या प्रयत्नेनान्तरात्मना॥ अन्तरिक्षगतो वत्सो यावद् योन्यां प्रदृश्यते। तावद् गौ पृथिवी ज्ञेया यावद् गर्भं न मुञ्चति॥
English Translation: The great noise made by Arjuna while advancing towards his enemies, was like that of Garuda, in days of yore, while swooping down upon snakes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यावन्ति तस्या रोमाणि वत्सस्य च युधिष्ठिर। तावद् युगसहस्राणि स्वर्गलोके महीयते॥
English Translation: The mighty Bhimasena, anxious as he was to have a look of Partha, became highly gratified with that sound.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुवर्णनासां यः कृत्वा सुखुरां कृष्णधेनुकाम्। तिलैः प्रच्छादितां दद्यात् सर्वरत्नैरलंकृताम्॥
English Translation: Hearing that Partha is come, the redoubtable Bhimasena, O king, began to afflict your troops, fearless of his own life.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रतिग्रहं गृहीत्वा यः पुनर्ददति साधवे। फलानां फलमश्नाति तदा दत्त्वा च भारत॥ ससमुद्रगुहा तेन सशैलवनकानना। चतुरन्ता भवेद् दत्त पृथिवी नात्र संशयः॥
English Translation: Bhima, the son of the Wind-god and himself possessing the prowess and impetuousity of the wind, that valiant Bhima began to career in that battle like that of the wind itself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्तर्जानुशयो यस्तु भुङ्क्ते संसक्तभाजनः। यो द्विजः शब्दरहितं स क्षमस्तारणाय वै॥
English Translation: Your army, O king, being thus hard pressed by him, O ruler of the universe, began to roll and tumble like a shattered vessel in the high seas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपानपा न गदितास्तथान्ये ये द्विजातयः। जपन्ति संहितां सम्यक् ते नित्यं तारणक्षमाः॥
English Translation: Bhima then, with his deadly weapons and with great dexterity of hands, waging a ruthless slaughter amongst that body of troops, dispatched them to the region of Pluto.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हव्यं कव्यं च यत् किंचित् सर्वं तच्छ्रोत्रियोऽर्हति। दत्तं हि श्रोत्रिये साधौ ज्वलितेऽग्नौ यथा हुतम्॥
English Translation: Your warriors, O Bharata, seeing the wonderful exploits of Bhima in that battle, careering like the King of Terrors at the end of time, became greatly agitated.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मन्युप्रहरणा विप्रा न विप्राः शस्त्रयोधिनः। निहन्युर्मन्युना विप्रा वज्रपाणिरिवासुरान्॥
English Translation: King Duryodhana, seeing his best soldiers, O Bharata, thus worsted by Bhimasena, gave vent to the following expression, addressing his whole hosts, generals and other great warriors, O best of the Bharata race, "All of you in a body engaged Bhima in action and fell him down (inasmuch as on him hinges the fate of the Pandavas).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धर्माश्रितेयं त कथा कथितेयं तवानघ। यां श्रुत्वा मुनयः प्रीता नैमिषारण्यवासिनः॥
English Translation: When he (Bhimasena) is felled, well may I count upon the Pandu forces as if already slain. Following the behest of your son, all the vassal chiefs (hitting) from all sides, covered Bhima with a thick shower of arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वीतशोकभयक्रोधा विपाप्मानस्तथैव च। श्रुत्वेमां तु कथां राजन् न भवन्तीह मानवाः॥
English Translation: Hosts of elephants, O monarch and men, eager for victory, as also war-chariots and horses, O King of Kings, thickened around Vrikodara.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच किं तच्छौचं भवेद् येन विप्रः शुद्धः सदा भवेत्। तदिच्छामि महाप्राज्ञ श्रोतुं धर्मभृतां वर॥
English Translation: That chef of the Bharata race, endued with heroic qualities, being thus hemmed in by those brave bands of heroes, looked resplendent like the radiant Moon shedding its effulgence amidst myriads of glowing stars.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मार्कण्डेय उवाच वाक् शौचं कर्मशौचं च यच्च शौचं जलात्मकम्। त्रिभिः शौचैरुपेतो यः स स्वर्गी नात्र संशयः॥
English Translation: O monarch, that foremost of men, was looking, during that fight, so beautiful, like the full Moon in the midst of his corona. He look like Arjuna. There is no difference between him and Arjuna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सायं प्रातश्च संध्यां यो ब्राह्मणोऽभ्युपसेवते। प्रजपन् पावनी देवीं गायत्री वेदमातरम्॥ स तया पावितो देव्या ब्राह्मणो नष्टकिल्बिषः। न सीदेत् प्रतिगृहणनो महीमपि ससागराम्॥
English Translation: All those kings with eyes flamed with wrath and bent upon slaying Vrikodara, began to shower down their weapons upon him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ये चास्य दारुणाः केचिद् ग्रहाः सूर्यादयो दिवि। ते चास्य सौम्या जायन्ते शिवाः शिवतराः सदा॥
English Translation: As the fish frees itself from the net, so did Bhima cutting their shafts straight free himself from the pressure of the battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चैनं दारुणाः पिशिताशनाः। घोररूपा महाकाया धर्षयन्ति द्विजोत्तमम्॥
English Translation: O Bharata slaying ten thousand elephants that faced him, two lakhs two hundred men, hundred car-warriors and five thousand horses Bhima actually made a river of blood to flow there.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नाध्यापनाद् याजनाद् वा अन्यस्माद् वा प्रतिग्रहात्। दोषो भवति विप्राणां ज्वलिताग्निसमा द्विजाः॥
English Translation: In that carnage blood flowed like water and the war-cars forming its eddies, elephants, its alligators, horses and men, its sharks and fishes and the hair of animals, its herbs and moss, were all floating on it. Arms severed from bodies floated like snakes and precious stones were abundant in the bloody current; thighs and marrows formed its gavials and mud and human heads, its mountain. Iron bound bludgeous and maces were also floating there like snakes, and bows and arrows formed its rafts by means of which persons tried to cross that fearful and bloody stream, banners and umbrellas drifted on it like swans and costly head-dresses its foam. The dust rising from the earth were like the waves of the stream and jeweled necklaces were looking like so many lotuses; the brave could alone cross that stream while the faint hearted sunk within to navigate it. That gushing current, with hands of sturdy soldiers forming its alligators and crocodiles, streamed its course towards the realm of Death. (and) and that man with tiger-like ferocity made its course flew on. (And) as the Vaitarani is unnavigable by persons of fifth and inequity, even so was that awful stream of blood to men wanting in valour and intrepidity, making their heart quail with shudder.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वे नानुगतं दुर्वेदा वा सुवेदा वा प्राकृताः संस्कृतास्तथा। ब्राह्मणा नावमन्तव्या भस्मच्छन्ना इवाग्नयः॥
English Translation: (And) there that son of Pandu, the best of car-warriors, rushed in, slaying hundred thousands of enemy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथा श्मशाने दीप्तौजाः पावको नैव दुष्यति। एवं विद्वानविद्वान् वा ब्राह्मणो दैवतं महत्॥
English Translation: Duryodhana seeing Bhimasena thus career in battle, ( king said unto Shakuni the following words-
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्राकारैश्च पुरद्वारैः प्रासादैश्च पृथग्विधैः। नगराणि न शोभन्ते हीनानि ब्राह्मणोत्तमैः॥
English Translation: Overpower in the battle, O uncle, the allpowerful Bhimasena. The victory over the vast array of the Pandava forces hinges on his final overthrow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वेदाढ्या वृत्तसम्पन्ना ज्ञानवन्तस्तपस्विनः। यत्र तिष्ठति वै विप्रास्तन्नाम नगरं नृप॥
English Translation: Being thus desired, O king, the powerful son of Subala, the peer of great warriors marshaled in array, marched on-his brothers surrounding him. That hero, affronting the fiercely powerful Bhima in that battle, checked his intrepidity, as if a continent resisting the tides of an ocean.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्रजे वाप्यथवारण्ये यत्र सन्ति बहुश्रुताः। तत् तन्नगरमित्याहुः पार्थ तीर्थं च तद् भवेत्॥
English Translation: And despite he resistance of the keen shafts, (which the powerful son of Subala hurled against him,) Bhima approached him (in formidable array). Whereupon Shakuni, O king of kings, flung a number of cloth-yard shafts, bedecked with wings of gold and sharpened on stone and assailed Bhima at the seat of his heart.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रक्षितारं च राजानं ब्राह्मणं च तपस्विनम्। अभिगम्याभिपूज्याथ सद्यः पापात् प्रमुच्यते॥
English Translation: Those fearful shafts, feathered with the plumes of Kankas and peacocks, O monarch, piercing the coat of mail of the high-souled son of Pandu, sunk deep into his vital parts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुण्यतीर्थाभिषेकं च पवित्राणां च कीर्तनम्। सद्भिः सम्भाषणं चैव प्रशस्तं कीर्त्यते बुधैः॥
English Translation: Being thus smitten in battle, O Bharata, Bhima, then flung, all of a sudden, a shaft laid with gold upon the son of Subala.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: साधुसङ्गमपूतेन वाक्सुभाषितवारिणा। पवित्रीकृतमात्मानं सन्तो मन्यन्ति नित्यशः॥
English Translation: And the powerful Shakuni, the inflictor of woes on his enemies and O king, skillful in the manipulation of hands, rent that fearful weapon in seven fragments as it was coursing its way towards him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्रिदण्डधारणं मौनं जटाभारोऽथ मुण्डनम्। वल्कलाजिन संवेष्टं व्रतचर्याभिषेचनम्॥ अग्निहोत्रं वने वासः शरीरपरिशोषणम्। सर्वाण्येतानि मिथ्या स्युर्यदि भावो न निर्मलः॥
English Translation: His weapon thus falling adrift on the ground, O king, Bhima, inflamed with rage, without any strain rent in twain with a broadpointed arrow the bow of the son of Subala.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न दुष्करमनाशित्वं सुकर ह्यशनं विना। विशुद्धिं चक्षुरादीनां षण्णामिन्द्रियगामिनाम्॥
English Translation: Whereupon the mighty son of Subala, throwing away that bow, rendered useless, with the greatest alacrity seized a new one, as also sixteen broad-edged shafts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विकारि तेषां राजेन्द्र सुदुष्करकरं मनः। ये पापानि न कुर्वन्ति मनोवाक्कर्मबुद्धिभिः। ते तपन्ति महात्मानो न शरीरस्य शोषणम्॥
English Translation: And the son of Subala, O king, hit the chariot-driver with two and Bhima with seven; struck off the banner with one and the umbrella with two; and pierced, O lord of the universe, the four chargers with the remaining four chargers with the remaining four of those broad-headed shafts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न ज्ञातिभ्यो दया यस्य शुक्लदेहोऽविकल्मषः। हिंसा सा तपसस्तस्य नानाशित्वं तपः स्मृतम्॥
English Translation: Enraged at this, O king, the powerful Bhima, in that battle, threw down a weapon made of iron and the staff of which was decked with gold.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तिष्ठन् गृहे चैव मुनिर्नित्यं शुचिरलंकृतः। यावज्जीवं दयावांश्च सर्वपापैः प्रमुच्यते॥
English Translation: That weapon, resembling in activity the tongue of a snake, being thus cast from the arms of Bhima came speedily down upon the chariot of the noble son of Subala.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न हि पापानि कर्माणि शुद्ध्यन्त्यनशनादिभिः। सीदत्यनशनादेव मांसशोणितलेपनः॥
English Translation: (And) he (the son of Subala) seized that weapon, adorned with gold and O lord of the universe, hurled it back against Bhimasena with a fierce countenance,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अज्ञातं कर्म कृत्वा च क्लेशो नान्यत् प्रहीयते। नाग्निर्दहति कर्माणि भावशून्यस्य देहिनः॥
English Translation: That weapon, piercing through the left arm of the noble son of Pandu, fell down like flashes of lightning coursing on the ground.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुण्यादेव प्रव्रजन्ति शुद्ध्यन्त्यनशनानि च। न मूलफलभक्षित्वान्न मौनान्नानिलाशनात्॥ शिरसो मुण्डनाद् वापि न स्थानकुटिकासनात्। न जटाधारणाद् वापि न तु स्थण्डिलशय्यया॥ नित्यं ह्यनशनाद् वापि नाग्निशुश्रूषणादपि। न चोदकप्रवेशेन न च क्षमाशयनादपि॥
English Translation: Then the Dhartarashtras began to rent the air from all sides with their loud out-crics, but, O king, Bhima could not brook the lion-like roars of the enemy, all of great intrepidity.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ज्ञानेन कर्मणा वापि जरामरणमेव च। व्याधयश्च प्रहीयन्ते प्राप्यते चोत्तमं पदम्॥
English Translation: That extraordinarily powerful man (Bhima) taking hold of another bow fitted with string, almost in no time, O best of kings, covered the mighty son of Subala and his forces, who were fighting valiantly without caring the least for their lives, with showers of arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बीजानि ह्यग्निदग्धानि न रोहन्ति पुनर्यथा। ज्ञानदग्धैस्तथा क्लेशैर्नात्मा संयुज्यते पुनः॥
English Translation: That mighty man (Bhimasena) with utmost intrepidity stricking off his (Shakuni's) four horses and then sending his charioteer to his eternal rest, O ruler of the universe, rent asunder his adversary's banner with a broadedged arrow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आत्मना विप्रहीणानि काष्ठकुड्योपमानि च। विनश्यन्ति न संदेहः फेनानीव महार्णवे॥
English Translation: Speedily bounding out of that steedless chariot, Shakuni, the best of men, with eyes flaming with wrath and stretched bow, took his stand on the ground, breathing all the while heavy breaths.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आत्मानं विन्दते येन सर्वभूतगुहाशयम्। श्लोकेन यदि वार्धेन क्षीणं तस्य प्रयोजनम्॥
English Translation: And then, O king, he covered Bhima with numberless arrows from all sides. Then the mighty Bhima rending asunder Shakuni's arrows with great wrath hit him with a host of sharp arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यक्षरादभिसंधाय केचिच्छ्लोकपदाङ्कितैः। शतैरन्यैः सहस्रश्च प्रत्ययो मोक्षलक्षणम्॥
English Translation: Being thus afflicted by his powerful assailant, that destroyer of enemies, O king, dropped down on the Earth almost dead.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नायं लोकोऽस्ति न परो न सुखं संशयात्मनः। ऊचुर्ज्ञानविदो वृद्धाः प्रत्ययो मोक्षलक्षणम्॥
English Translation: Seeing him (Shakuni) in such a woeful plight, your son, O supreme ruler of the universe, putting him in his own chariot carried him off from the scene of action before the very face of Bhimasena.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विदितार्थस्तु वेदानां परिवेद प्रयोजनम्। उद्विजेत् स तु वेदेभ्यो दावाग्नेरिव मानवः॥
English Translation: Seeing that foremost of men, Shakuni, thus knocked down and borne away on Duryodhana's chariot, the Imperial hosts began to beat a hasty retreat from the field and flew in all directions from the very fear of Bhimasena.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शुष्कं तर्कं परित्यज्य आश्रयस्व श्रुतिं स्मृतिम्। एकाक्षराभिसम्बद्धं तत्त्वं हेतुभिरिच्छसि। बुद्धिर्न तस्य सिद्ध्येत साधनस्य विपर्ययात्॥
English Translation: When the son of Subala was thus discomfited and defeated, O monarch, by that excellent archer (Bhimasena) your son Duryodhana, left the field in a state of trepidation and out of his concern for the life of his uncle Shakuni, urged his fiery chargers to a furious speed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वेदपूर्वं वेदितव्यं प्रयत्नात् तद् वै वेदस्तस्य वेदः शरीरम्। वेदस्तत्त्वं तत्समासोपलब्धौ क्लीबस्त्वात्मा तत् स वेद्यस्य वेद्यम्॥
English Translation: Seeing the king thus flee away from the battle, all his troops, O foremost of the line of Bharata, who were each engaged in fierce struggle with a hand-to-hand fight, began to disperse themselves in all directions.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वेदोक्तमायुर्देवानामाशिषश्चैव कर्मणाम्। फलत्यनुयुगं लोके प्रभावश्च शरीरिणाम्॥
English Translation: Observing the whole hosts of the Dhritarasthra force thus dispersing themselves in every direction, Bhima, with great impetuosity rushed against them and attacked them with innumerable arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इन्द्रियाणां प्रसादेन तदेतत् परिवर्जयेत्। तस्मादनशनं दिव्यं निरुद्धेन्द्रियगोचरम्॥
English Translation: Thus afflicted by Bhima, O monarch, the retreating bands of Dhritarashtra's army (all in a body moved towards Karna's flank).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तपसा स्वर्गगमनं भोगो दानेन जायते। ज्ञानेन मोक्षो विज्ञेयस्तीर्थस्नानादधक्षयः॥
English Translation: And coming thither and with them (General Karna) in their centre, they once more held there ground. As the ship-wrecked mariners become comforted in reaching in island, so your distressed army stood cheerfully on finding that mighty Karna. O foremost of the Bharata race, O inightiest of men, O lord of the universe, they then proceeded having death for their ultimate end.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच एवमुक्तस्तु राजेन्द्र प्रत्युवाच महायशाः। भगवन् श्रोतुमिच्छामि प्रधानविधिमुत्तमम्॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said Having said these words, Partha started, following the horse which roamed at will. The sacrificial horse then turned towards the road leading to the city of Hastinapur.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मार्कण्डेय उवाच यत् त्वमिच्छसि राजेन्द्र दानधर्मं युधिष्ठिर। इष्टं चेदं सदा मह्यं राजन् गौरवतस्तथा॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira heard from his intelligencebearers that the horse had turned back. And hearing also that Arjuna was hale and hearty, he became filled with joy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शृणु दानरहस्यानि श्रुतिस्मृत्युदितानि च। छायायां करिणः श्राद्धं तत् कर्णपरिवीजिते। दश कल्पायुतानीह न क्षीयेत युधिष्ठिर॥
English Translation: Hearing also the feats, performed by Vijaya in the country of the Gandharas as also in other kingdoms, the king became highly pleased.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जीवनाय समाक्लिन्नं वसु दत्त्वा महीयते। वैश्यं तु वासयेद् यस्तु सर्वयज्ञैः स इष्टवान्॥
English Translation: In the meantime, seeing that the twelfth day of the lighted fortnight in the month of Magha had come, and marking also that the constellation was favourable, high Yudhirshthira the just summoned all his brothers, viz., Bhima and Nakula and Sahadeva. Gifted with great energy, the king, o you of Kuru's race, that foremost of all persons knowing duties, said these words in proper time, Indeed, that foremost of all speakers, addressing Bhima, the first of all smiters, said,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रतिस्रोतश्चित्रवाहाः पर्जन्योऽन्नानुसंचरन्। महाधुरि यथा नावा महापापैः प्रमुच्यते॥
English Translation: Your younger brother (Arjuna), O Bhimasena, is returning with the horse. I have learnt this from those men who had followed Arjuna.

Sanskrit Shloka: विप्लवे विप्रदत्तानि दधिमस्त्वक्षयाणि च। पर्वसु द्विगुणं दानमृतौ दशगुणं भवेत्॥
English Translation: The time is come. The sacrificial horse is near. The day of full moon of the month of Magha is also near. The month is about to expire. O Vrikodara.

Sanskrit Shloka: अयने विषुवे चैव षडशीतिमुखेषु च। चन्द्रसूर्योपरागे च दत्तमक्षयमुच्यते॥
English Translation: Let, therefore, learned Brahmanas knowing the Vedas look for a sacrificial spot for the celebration of the Horse-Sacrifice.

Sanskrit Shloka: ऋतुषु दशगुणं वदन्ति दत्तं शतगुणमृत्वयनादिषु ध्रुवम्। र्विषुवति चाक्षयमश्नुते फलम्॥
English Translation: Thus addressed, Bhima obeyed the royal command He became very glad upon hearing that Arjuna of curly hair was about to retum.

Sanskrit Shloka: नाभूमिदो भूमिमश्नाति राजन् नायानदो यानमारुह्य याति। यान् यान् कामान् ब्राह्मणेभ्यो ददाति तांस्तान् कामान् जायमानः स भुङ्क्ते॥
English Translation: Then Bhimna went out with a number of men knowing the rules of laying out sacrificial grounds and constructing buildings. And he took with him many Brahmanas well-versed in all the rites of sacrifices.

Sanskrit Shloka: अग्नेरपत्यं प्रथमं सुवर्ण भूवैष्णवी सूर्यसुताश्च गावः। लोकास्त्रयस्तेन भवन्ति दत्ता यः काञ्चनं गाश्च महीं च दद्यात्॥
English Translation: Bhima selected a beautiful place and caused it to be duły measured out for laying the sacrificial compound. Numberless houses and mansions were constructed on it and high and broad roads also were laid cut.

English Translation: Soon enough the Kaurava hero filled that ground with hundreds of excellent palaces. The surface was levelled and made smooth with jewels and gems, and adorned with various golden structures.

Sanskrit Shloka: वसिष्ठ उवाच एवमप्रतिबुद्धत्वादबुद्धजनसेवनात्। सर्गकोटिसहस्राणि पतनान्तानि गच्छति॥
English Translation: Columns were raised, ornamented with bright gold an high and wide triumphal arches also were made on that sacrificial compound. All these were made of pure gold.
