Sanskrit Shloka: धाम्ना धामसहस्राणि मरणान्तानि गच्छति। तिर्यग्योनिमनुष्यत्वे देवलोके तथैव च।॥
English Translation: The righteous-souled prince also caused apartments to be duly constructed for the accommodation of ladies and of the numerous kings who, coming from many kingdoms, were expected to grace the sacrifice with their presence.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चन्द्रमा इव भूतानां पुनस्तत्र सहस्रशः। लीयतेऽप्रतिबुद्धत्वादेवमेष ह्यबुद्धिमान्॥ कला पञ्चदशी योनिस्तद्धाम प्रतिबुध्यते। नित्यमेतद् विजानीहि सोमं वै षोडशी कलाम्॥
English Translation: The son of Kunti also caused many palaces to be duty erected for Brahmanas who were expected to come from various kingdoms.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कलायां जायतेऽजस्रं पुनः पुनरबुद्धिमान्। धाम तस्योपयुञ्जन्ति भूय एवोपजायते॥
English Translation: Then the mighty-armed Bhimasena, at the command of the king, sent out messengers to the great kings of the Earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: षोडशी तु कला सूक्ष्मा स सोम उपधार्यताम्। न तूपयुज्यते देवैर्देवानुपयुनक्ति सा॥
English Translation: Those best of kings came to the HorseSacrifice of the Kuru king for doing what was agreeable to him. And they brought many gems with them and many female slaves and horses and weapons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतामक्षपयित्वा हि जायते नृपसत्तम। सा ह्यस्य प्रकृतिर्दृष्टा तत्क्षयान्मोक्ष उच्यते॥
English Translation: The sounds which arose from those great kings who lived within those pavilions touched the very heavens and resembled the noise made by the roaring ocean.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदेव षोडशकलं देहमव्यक्तसंज्ञकम्। ममायमिति मन्वानस्तत्रैव परिवर्तते॥ पञ्चविंशो महानात्मा तस्यैवाप्रतिबोधनात्। विमलस्य विशुद्धस्य शुद्धाशुद्धनिषेवणात्॥ अशुद्ध एव शुद्धात्मा तादृग् भवति पार्थिव। अबुद्धसेवनाच्चापि बुद्धोऽऽप्यबुद्धतां व्रजेत्॥
English Translation: King Yudhishthria, the delighter of the Kurus, assigned to the monarchs who thus came to his sacrifice various kinds of food and drink, and beds also of celestial beauty.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथैवाप्रतिबुद्धोऽपि विज्ञेयो नृपसत्तम। प्रकृतेस्त्रिगुणायास्तु सेवनात् त्रिगुणो भवेत्॥
English Translation: The chief of the Bharatas, viz., king Yudhishthria the just, assigned several stables well-filled with different kinds of corn and sugar-cane and milk to the animals.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच पुनर्भरतवंशस्य हेतुं संतानवृद्धये। वक्ष्यामि नियतं मातस्तन्मे निगदतः शृणु॥ ब्राह्मणो गुणवान् कश्चिद् धनेनोपनिमन्त्र्यताम्। विचित्रवीर्यक्षेत्रेषु यः समुत्पादयेत् प्रजाः॥
English Translation: To that great sacrifice of king Yudhishthira the just who was gifted with high intelligence, there also came a large number of ascetics all of whom were utterers of Brahma.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच ततः सत्यवती भीष्मं वाचा संसजमानया। विहसन्तीव सनीडमिदं वचनमब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: Indeed, O king, all the foremost ones among the twice born class that were then alive, came to that sacrifice, accompanied by their disciples. The Kuru king received them all.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सत्यवती उवाच सत्यमेतन्महाबाहो यथा वदसि भारत। विश्वासात् ते प्रवक्ष्यामि संतानाय कुलस्य नः॥
English Translation: King Yudhishthira of great energy, renouncing all pride, himself followed all his guests to the pavilions that had been assigned for this residence.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न ते शक्यमनाख्यातुमापद्धर्मं तथाविधम्। त्वमेव नः कुले धर्मस्त्वं सत्यं त्वं परा गतिः॥
English Translation: Then all the mechanics and engineers, having completed the arrangements of the sacrifice, informed king Yudhishthira of it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मानिशम्य सत्यं मे कुरुष्व यदनन्तरम्। धर्मयुक्तस्य धर्मार्थं पितुरासीत् तरी मम॥
English Translation: Hearing that everything was ready, king Yudhishthira the just, full of alertness and attention, became highly pleased along with his brothers all of whom honoured him duly.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सा कदाचिदहं तत्र गता प्रथमयौवनम्। अथ धर्मविदां श्रेष्ठः परमर्षिः पराशरः॥ आजगाम तरी धीमांस्तरिष्यन् यमुना नदीम्। स तार्यमाणो यमुनां मामुपेत्याब्रवीत् तदा॥ सान्त्वपूर्वं मुनिश्रेष्ठः कामार्तो मधुरं वचः। उक्तं जन्म कुलं मह्यमस्मि दाशसुतेत्यहम्॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said When the great sacrifice of Yudhishthira began, many eloquent dialecticians started diverse propositions and disputed thereon, desirous of defeating one another.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमहं शापभीता च पितुर्भीता च भारत। वरैरसुलभैरुक्ता न प्रत्याख्यातुमुत्सहे॥
English Translation: The (invited) kings saw the excellent preparations of that sacrifice, resembling those of the king himself of the celestials, made, O Bharata, by Bhimasena.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभिभूय स मां बालां तेजसा वशमानयत्। तमसा लोकमावृत्य नौगतामेव भारत॥ मत्स्यगन्धो महानासीत् पुरा मम जुगुप्सितः। तमपास्य शुभं गन्धमिमं प्रादात् स मे मुनिः॥
English Translation: They saw many triumphal arches made of gold, and many beds and seats and other articles of enjoyment and luxury, and crowds of men collected at different parts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो मामाह स मुनिर्गर्भमुत्सृज्य मामकम्। द्वीपेऽस्या एव सरितः कन्यैव त्वं भविष्यसि॥
English Translation: There were also many jars and vessels and cauldrons and jugs and lids and covers. The invited kings saw nothing there that was not made of gold.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पाराशर्यो महायोगी स बभूव महानृषिः। कन्यापुत्रो मम पुरा द्वैपायन इति श्रुतः॥
English Translation: Many sacrificial stakes also were set up, made, according to he directions of the scriptures, of wood, and adorned with gold. Gifted with great effulgence, these were duly planted and dedicated (with (with scriptural Mantras).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यो व्यस्य वेदांश्चतुरस्तपसा भगवानृषिः। लोके व्यासत्वमापेदे कार्यात् कृष्णत्वमेव च॥
English Translation: The kings, again, saw all animals of land and water, collected there on the occasion.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सत्यवादी शमपरस्तपस्वी दग्धकिल्बिषः। समुत्पन्नः स तु महान् सह पित्रा ततो गतः॥
English Translation: And they also saw many kine and many buffaloes and many old women, and many aquatic animals, many beasts of prey, and many species of birds, and many specimens of viviparous and oviparous creatures, and many that are fifth-born, and many belonging to the vegetable kingdom and many-animals and plants which live or grow on mountains.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स नियुक्तो मया व्यक्तं त्वया चाप्रतिमद्युतिः। भ्रातुः क्षेत्रेषु कल्याणमपत्यं जनयिष्यति॥
English Translation: Seeing the sacrificial compound thus adorned with animals and kine and corn, the invited kings became filled with wonder.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स हि मामुक्तवांस्तत्र स्मरेः कृच्छ्रेषु मामिति। तं स्मरिष्ये महाबाहो यदि भीष्म त्वमिच्छसि॥
English Translation: Large masses of costly sweetmeats were kept ready for both the Brahmanas and the Vaishyas. And when the feeding was over of a hundred thousand Brahmanas, drums and cymbals were beat.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तव हनुमते भीष्म नियतं स महातपाः। विचित्रवीर्यक्षेत्रेषु पुत्रानुत्पादयिष्यति॥
English Translation: And so large was the number fed that the sounds of drums and cymbals were heard again and again. Indeed, those sounds continued from day to day.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच महर्षेः कीर्तने तस्य भीष्मः प्राञ्जलिरब्रवीत्। धर्ममर्थं च कामं च त्रीनेतान् योऽनुपश्यति॥ अर्थमर्थानुबन्धं च धर्मं धर्मानुबन्धनम्। कामं कामानुबन्धं च विपरीतान् पृथक् पृथक्॥ यो विचिन्त्य धिया धीरो व्यवस्यति स बुद्धिमान्। तदिदं धर्मयुक्तं च हितं चैव कुलस्य नः॥ उक्तं भवत्या यच्छ्रेयस्तन्मह्यं रोचते भृशम्।
English Translation: Thus was performed that sacrifice of the intelligent king Yudhishthira. Many hills of food. O king, were dedicated on the occasion. Many large tanks were seen of curds and many lakes of clarified butter.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच ततस्तस्मिन् प्रतिज्ञाते भीष्मेण कुरुनन्दन॥ कृष्णद्वैपायनं काली चिन्तयामास वै मुनिम्। स वेदान् विब्रुवन् धीमान् मातुर्विज्ञाय चिन्तितम्॥ प्रादुर्बभूवाविदितः क्षणेन कुरुनन्दन। तस्मै पूजां ततः कृत्वा सुताय विधिपूर्वकम्॥ परिष्वज्य च बाहुभ्यां प्रस्रवैरभ्यषिञ्चता मुमोच बाष्पं दाशेयी पुत्रं दृष्ट्वा चिरस्य तु॥
English Translation: In that great sacrifice, O monarch, was seen the entire population of Jamvudvipa, with all its kingdoms and provinces, collected together.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तामद्भिः परिषिच्यार्ता महर्षिरभिवाद्य च। मातरं पूर्वज: पुत्रो व्यासो वचनमब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: Thousands of nations and races were there. A large number of men. O chief of Bharata's race, adorned with garlands and wearing bright ear-rings made of gold, taking numberless vessels in their hands, distributed the food to the twice-born classes by hundreds and thousands.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भवत्या यदभिप्रेतं तदहं कर्तुमागतः। शाधि मां धर्मतत्त्वज्ञे करवाणि प्रियं तव॥
English Translation: The attendants of the Pandavas gave away to the Brahmanas various kinds of food and drink which were, besides, so costly as to be worthy of being eaten and drunk by kings themselves. In that great sacrifice, O monarch, was seen the entire population of Jamvudvipa, with all its kingdoms and provinces, collected together.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मै पूजां ततोऽकार्षीत् पुरोधाः परमर्षये। स च तां प्रतिजग्राह विधिवन्मन्त्रपूर्वकम्॥
English Translation: Thousands of nations and races were there. A large number of men. O chief of Bharata's race, adorned with garlands and wearing bright ear-rings made of gold, taking numberless vessels in their hands, distributed the food to the twice-born classes by hundreds and thousands.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पूजितो मन्त्रपूर्वं तु विधिवत् प्रीतिमाप सः। तमासनगतं माता पृष्ट्वा कुशलमव्ययम्॥ सत्यवत्यथ वीक्ष्यैनमुवाचेदमनन्तरम्।
English Translation: The attendants of the Pandavas gave away to the Brahmanas various kinds of food and drink which were, besides, so costly as to be worthy of being eaten and drunk by kings themselves.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मातापित्रोः प्रजायन्ते पुत्राः साधारणाः कवे॥ तेषां पिता यथा स्वामी तथा माता न संशयः। विधानविहितः सत्यं यथा मे प्रथमः सुतः॥ विचित्रवीर्यो ब्रह्मर्षे तथा मेऽवरजः सुतः। यथैव पितृतो भीष्मस्तथा त्वमपि मातृतः॥ भ्राता विचित्रवीर्यस्य यथा वा पुत्र मन्यसे। अयं शान्तनवः सत्यं पालयन् सत्यविक्रमः॥ बुद्धिं न कुरुतेऽपत्ये तथा राज्यानुशासने। स त्वं व्यपेक्षया भ्रातुः संतानाय कुलस्य च॥
English Translation: Kapila said The Vedas are considered as an authority by all. People never disobey them. Brahma is of two kinds, viz., Brahma is represented by sound, and Brahma as Supreme.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्मस्य चास्य वचनानियोगाच्च ममानघ। अनुक्रोशाच भूतानां सर्वेषां रक्षणाय च॥ आनृशंस्याच यद् ब्रूयां तच्छुत्वा कर्तुमर्हसि। यवीयसस्तव भ्रातुर्भार्ये सुरसुतोपमे॥ रूपयौवनसम्पन्ने पुत्रकामे च धर्मतः। तयोरुत्पादयापत्यं समर्थो ह्यसि पुत्रक॥ अनुरूपं कुलस्यास्य संतत्याः प्रसवस्य च।
English Translation: One conversant with Brahma of sound succeeds in attaining to Supreme Brahma. Beginning with the rites of Garbhadhana, that body which the father creates with the help of Vedic Mantras is purified (after birth) by Vedic Mantras.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यास उवाच वेत्थ धर्मं सत्यवति परं चापरमेव च॥ तथा तव महाप्राज्ञे धर्मे प्रणिहिता मतिः। तस्मादहं त्वन्नियोगाद् धर्ममुद्दिश्य कारणम्॥ ईप्सितं ते करिष्यामि दृष्टं ह्येतत् सनातनम्। भ्रातुः पुत्रान् प्रदास्यामि मित्रावरुणयोः समान्॥
English Translation: When the body, has been purified with purificatary rites, the owner thereof is called a Prahmana and becomes a vessel fit for receiving knowledge of Brahma. Know that the meed of acts is purity of heart which only brings on Liberation. I shall now speak to you of that.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्रतं चरेतां ते देव्यौ निर्दिष्टमिह यन्मया। संवत्सरं यथान्यायं ततः शुद्धे भविष्यतः॥ न हि मामव्रतोपेता उपेयात् काचिदङ्गना।
English Translation: Whether purity of heart has been acquired or not, is what can be known to the person himself who has acquired it. It can never be known with the help of either the Vedas or inference. They who have no expectations, who discard every sort of riches by not keeping anything for future use, who are not covetous, and who are free from every sort of affection and aversion, celebrate sacrifices believing only that their performance is a duty. To make gifts to deserving persons is the end of all riches.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सत्यवत्युवाच सद्यो यथा प्रपद्येते देव्यौ गर्भं तथा कुरु॥ अराजकेषु राष्ट्रेषु प्रजानाथा विनश्यति। नश्यन्ति च क्रियाः सर्वा नास्ति वृष्टिर्न देवता॥
English Translation: Never addicted at any time to sinful deeds, observant of rites sanctioned by the Vedas, capable of fructifying all their wishes, gifted with certain conclusions through pure knowledge, never giving way to anger,-never indulging in envy, free from pride and malice, firm in Yoga, of unsullied conduct, and unsullied learning, given to the behoof of all creatures, there were in days of yore many men living like householders and thoroughly devoted to the their own duties, there were many kings also of the same accomplishment, devoted to Yoga, and many Brahmanas also of the same character.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कथं चाराजकं राष्ट्र शक्यं धारयितुं प्रभो। तस्माद् गर्भ समाधत्स्व भीष्मः संवर्धयिष्यति॥
English Translation: They treated all creatures equally and were gifted with perfect sincerity. They had contentiment, certainty of knowledge. The rewards of their righteousness were apparent, and they were pure in conduct and heart. They were endued with faith in Brahma of both forms.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यास उवाच यदि पुत्रः प्रदातव्यो मया भ्रातुरकालिकः। विरूपतां मे सहतां तयोरेतत् परं व्रतम्॥
English Translation: At first making their hearts pure, they duly observed all vows. They observed the duties of righteousness on even occasions of distress and great difficulty, without deviating in any particular.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदि मे सहते गन्धं रूपं वेषं तथा वपुः। अद्यैव गर्भ कौसल्या विशिष्टं प्रतिपद्यताम्॥
English Translation: Uniting together they used to celebrate meritorious acts. In this they found great happiness. And inasmuch as they never transgressed, they had never to perform any expiatory rite.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच एवमुक्त्वा महातेजा व्यासः सत्यवतीं तदा। शयने सा च कौसल्या शुचिवस्त्रा ह्यलंकृता॥ समागमनमाका दिति सोऽन्तर्हितो मुनिः। ततोऽभिगम्य सा देवी स्नुषां रहसि संगताम्॥ धर्म्यमर्थसपायुक्तमुवाच वचनं हितम्। कौसल्ये धर्मतन्त्रं त्वां यद् ब्रवीमि निबोध तत्॥
English Translation: Depending upon the true course of virtue, they became gifted with irresistible energy. They never followed their own understandings while acquiring merit but followed the injunctions of the scriptures along for that end. Accordingly they were never guilty of guile in performing acts of righteousness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भरतानां समुच्छेदो व्यक्तं मद्भाग्यसंक्षयात्। व्यथितां मां च सम्प्रेक्ष्य पितृवंशं च पीडितम्॥ भीष्मो बुद्धिमदान्मह्यं कुलस्यास्य विवृद्धये। सा च बुद्धिस्त्वय्यधीना पुत्रि प्रापय मां तथा॥ नष्टं च भारतं वंशं पुनरेव समुद्धर। पुत्रं जनय सुश्रोणि देवराजसमप्रभम्॥ स हि राज्यधुरं गुर्वीमुद्वक्ष्यति कुलस्य नः।
English Translation: On account of their observing unitedly the perfect ordinances of the scriptures without following the rites laid down in the alternative, they were never compelled to perform any expiation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सा धर्मतोऽनुनीयैनां कथंचिद् धर्मचारिणीम्। भोजयामास विप्रांश्च देवर्षीनतिथींस्तथा॥
English Translation: There is no expiation for men who follow the ordinances laid down in the scriptures. The Shruti says that expiation exists for only men who are weak and unable to follow the absolute provisions of the sacred law.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच अजिनानि विधु-वन्तः करकांश्च द्विजर्षभाः। ऊचुस्ते भीर्न कर्तव्या वयं योत्स्यामहे परान्॥
English Translation: Many Brahmanas of this kind in days of yore, devoted to the celebration of Vedas, endued with purity, good conduct and fame.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तानेवं वदतो विप्रानर्जुनः प्रहसन्निव। उवाच प्रेक्षका भूत्वा यूयं तिष्ठथ पार्श्वतः॥
English Translation: They always adored Brahma in the sacrifices, and were free from desire. Endued with learning they got over all the bonds of life. The sacrifices of these men, their Vedic knowledge, their acts performed according to the ordinances, their study of the scriptures at the proper hours, and the wishes they formed, freed as they were from lust and anger, observant as they were of pious conduct and acts despite all difficulties, famous as they were for performing the duties of their own castes and mode of life, purified as their souls were on account of their very nature, characterised as they were by thorough sincerity, devoted as they were to tranquillity, and attentive as they were to their own practises, were at one with Infinite Brahma. This is the eternal Shruti we have heard. The penances of men who were so noble, of men whose conduct and acts were so difficult of observance and accomplishment, of men those wishes were crowned with success on account of the strict satisfaction of their duties, became potent instruments for the destruction of all worldly desires. The Brahmanas hold that that Good conduct, which is wonderful, whose origin may be traced to very old times, which is eternal, and whose marks are unchangeable, which differs from the practices which even the good follow in time of distress and represents their acts in other situations, which is at one with carefulness, over which lust, anger, and other evil passions have no control, and on account of which there was no transgression in all mankind, subsequently became divided into four sub-divisions, agreeing with the four modes of life, by person unable to follow its duties in ininute detail and entirety.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अहमेनानजिह्मात्रैः शतशो विकिरज्छरैः। वारयिष्यामि संक्रुद्धान् मन्त्रैराशीविपानिव॥
English Translation: By properly following that course of Good Conduct after adoption of the Sanyasa mode of life, the good attain to the highest end. They also who become forest recluses, reach the same high end.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इति तद् धनुरानम्य शुल्कावाप्तं महाबलः। भ्रात्रा भीमेन सहितस्तस्थौ गिरिरिवाचलः॥
English Translation: They also who observe the domestic mode of life, attain to the highest end; and lastly, those who lead the Brahmacharya mode, attain to the same end. Those Brahmanas are seen to shine in the sky as luminaries shedding beneficent rays of light all around.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः कर्णमुखान् दृष्ट्वा क्षत्रियान् युद्धदुर्मदान्। सम्पेततुरभीतौ तौ गजौ प्रतिगजानिव॥
English Translation: Those countless Brahmanas have become stars and constellations set in their fixed roads. By virtue of contentment they have all acquired Infinity as the Vedas say.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ऊचुश्च वाचः परुपास्ते राजानो युयुत्सवः। आहवे हि द्विजस्यापि वधो दृष्टो युयुत्सतः॥
English Translation: If such men have to return to the world through the wombs of living creatures, they are never sullied by sins which have the unexhausted remnant of pristine deeds for their originating cause.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्येवमुक्त्वा राजानः सहसा दुद्रुबुद्धिजान्। ततः कर्णो महातेजा जिष्णुं प्रति ययौ रणे॥
English Translation: Indeed, one who has lived like a Brahmacharin and served dutifully his preceptor, who has arrived at fixed conclusions, and who has devoted hiinself to Yoga thus, is truly a Brahmana. Who else is worthy of being called a Brahmana?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युद्धार्थी वासिताहेतोर्गजः प्रतिगजं यथा। भीमसेनं ययौ शल्य मद्राणामीश्वरो बली॥
English Translation: When acts alone settle who is a Brahmana and who is not; acts must be held to point out the happiness or misery of a person. About those who have by conquering all evil passions acquired purity of heart, we have heard the eternal Shruti that, on account of the Infinity which they acquire and of the knowledge of Brahma (they acquire through the declarations of Shrutis), they see everything as Brahma. The duties followed by those pure-hearted men, who are shorn of desire, and who have Liberation only for their object, for acquisition of the knowledge of Brahma, are equally sanctioned for all the four castes and all the four modes of life. That knowledge is always gained by Brahmanas of pure hearts and controlled soul.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुर्योधनादयः सर्वे ब्राह्मणैः सह संगताः। मृदुपूर्वमयत्नेन प्रत्ययुध्यंस्तदाहवे॥
English Translation: One whose soul is for Renunciation based upon contentment, is considered as the refuge of true knowledge. Renunciation, wherein exists the knowledge leading to Liberation, and which is highly necessary for a Brahmana, is eternal.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽर्जुनः प्रत्यविध्यदापतन्तं शितैः शरैः। कर्णं वैकर्तनं श्रीमान् विकृष्य बलवद् धनुः॥
English Translation: Renunciation is sometimes found mixed with the duties of other modes. But whether existing in that state or by itself, one practises it according to his power. Renunciation is the root of great benefit to every sort of person. Only he who is weak, fails to pursue it. That pure-hearted man who seeks to attain to Brahma becomes saved from the world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषां शराणां वेगेन शितानां तिग्मतेजसाम्। विमुह्यमानो राधेयो यत्नात् तमनुधावति॥
English Translation: Of them who are given up to enjoyment, they who make gifts, they who celebrate sacrifices, they who are given to the study of the Vedas, and they who follow the life of Renunciation after having acquired and enjoyed riches and all its pleasures, when they depart from this world, who is it who gets the foremost place in heaven? I ask you this, O
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तावुभावप्यनिर्देश्यौ लाघवाज्जयतां वरौ। अयुध्येतां सुसंरब्धावन्योन्यविजिगीषिणौ॥
English Translation: Those who live like householders are surely auspicious and gain every sort of excellence. They are unable, however, to enjoy the happiness of Renunciation. Even you may see this.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृते प्रतिकृतं पश्य पश्य बाहुबलं च मे। इति शूरार्थवचनैरभाषेतां परस्परम्॥
English Translation: You depend upon knowledge as the means. Those who live like householders, have placed their faith in acts. It has, however, been said that the end of all modes of life is Liberation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽर्जुनस्य भुजयोर्वीर्यमप्रतिमं भुवि। ज्ञात्वा वैकर्तनः कर्णः संरब्धः समयोधयत्॥
English Translation: No difference, therefore, is seen between them about either their superiority or inferiority of power. O illustrious one do you, then, clear out the mystery and enlighten me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्जुनेन प्रयुक्तांस्तान् बाणान् वेगवतस्तदा। प्रतिहत्य ननादोच्चैः सैन्यानि तदपूजयन्॥
English Translation: Kapila said-Acts only purify the body, Knowledge, however, is the highest end. When all defects of the heart are cured, and when the happiness of Brahma becomes established in knowledge. benevolence, forgiveness, tranquillity, mercy, truthfulness, and open-mindedness, abstention from injury, absence of pride, modestry, renunciation, and abstention from work are acquired.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्ण उवाच तुष्यामि ते विप्रमुख्य भुजवीर्यस्य संयुगे। अविषादस्य चैवास्य शस्त्रास्त्रविजयस्य च॥
English Translation: These form the path of Brahma. By those one acquires the Highest. A wise man when he acquires these qualities, understands that the cure of all defects of the heart is the result of acts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किं त्वं साक्षाद् धनुर्वेदो रामो वा विप्रसत्तम। अथ साक्षाद्धरिहयः साक्षाद् वा विष्णुरच्युतः॥
English Translation: That, indeed, is considered as the highest end which is acquired by Brahmanas gifted with wisdom, withdrawn from all acts, possessed of purity and the surety of knowledge.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आत्मप्रच्छादनार्थं वै बाहुवीर्यमुपाश्रितः। विप्ररूपं विधायेदं मन्ये मां प्रतियुध्यसे॥
English Translation: One who acquires a knowledge of the Vedas, of that which is taught by the Vedas, and the details of acts, is said to be conversant with the Vedas. Any other man is only a bag of wind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न हि मामाहवे क्रुद्धमन्यः साक्षाच्छचीपतेः। पुमान् योधयितुं शक्तः पाण्डवाद् वा किरीटिनः॥
English Translation: One who is master of the Vedas, knows everything, for everything is established on the Veda. The present, past, and future all exist in the Vedas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच तमेवं वादिनं तत्र फाल्गुनः प्रत्यभाषत। नास्मि कर्ण धनुर्वेदो नास्मि रामः प्रतापवान्॥
English Translation: This is the one conclusion of all the scriptures viz., that this universe exists and does not exist. To the man of knowledge this is both existent and non-existent. To him this all is both the end and the middle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणोऽस्मि युधां श्रेष्ठः सर्वशस्त्रभृतां वरः। ब्राह्मे पौरंदरे चास्त्रे निष्ठितो गुरुशासनात्॥
English Translation: This truth depends upon all the Vedas, viz., that when complete Renunciation takes place one acquires what is sufficient. Then, again, the highest contentment follows and depends upon Liberation, which is absolute, which exists as the soul of all moral and immortal things, which is well-known as such universal soul, which is the highest object of knowledge as being at one with all mobile and immobile objects, which is full, which is perfect happiness, which is without duality, which is the foremost of all things, which is Brahma, which is Unmanifest and the cause also of the Unmanifest, and which is without any sort of decay.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्थितोऽस्म्यद्य रणे जेतुं त्वां वै वीर स्थिरो भव। एवमुक्तस्तु राधेयो युद्धात् कर्णो न्यवर्तत॥
English Translation: Power to control the senses, forgiveness and abstention from work owing to the absence of desire,-these three are the cause of perfect happiness. With the help of these three qualities, men having understanding for their eyes, succeed in reaching that Brahma which is increate, which is the supreme cause of the universe, which is unchangeable, and which is beyond destruction. I bow to that Brahma, which is at one with him that knows it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्यं तेजस्तदाजय्यं मन्यमानो महारथः। अपरस्मिन् वनोद्देशे वीरौ शल्यवृकोदरौ॥
English Translation: The Danavas said: O king of kings, O perpetuator of the Bharata race, O Duryodhana, you are always surrounded by heroes and illustrious men.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बलिनौ युद्धसम्पन्नौ विद्यया च बलेन च। अन्योन्यमाह्वयन्तौ तु मत्ताविव महागजौ॥
English Translation: Why have you then taken this rash step such as this vow of starvation? Suicide always leads (a man) to hell. It becomes the subject of calumnious speech.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मुष्टिभिर्जानुभिश्चैव निघ्नन्तावितरेतरम्। प्रकर्षणाकर्षणयोरभ्याकर्षविकर्षणैः॥
English Translation: Intelligent men like you never engage in acts that are sinful and opposed to their best interests and which strike at the very root of their purposes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आचकर्षतुरन्योन्यं मुष्टिभिश्चापि जघ्नतुः। ततश्चटचटाशब्दः सुघोरो ह्यभवत् तयोः॥
English Translation: O king, therefore restrain your this resolve. It is destructive of morality, profit and happiness and of fame, prowess and energy. It enhances the joy of one's enemies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पाषाणसम्पातनिभैः प्रहारैरभिजघ्नतुः। मुहूर्तं तौ तदान्योन्यं समरे पर्यकर्षताम्॥ ततो भीमः समुक्षिप्य बाहुभ्यां शल्यमाहवे। अपातयत् कुरुश्रेष्ठो ब्राह्मणा जहसुस्तदा॥ तत्राश्चर्यं भीमसेनश्चकार पुरुषर्षभः। यच्छल्यं पातितं भूमौ नावधीद् बलिनं बली॥
English Translation: O king, of lord, know the truth, the celestials origin of your birth and the make up of your body; and then assume patience.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पातिते भीमसेनेन शल्ये कर्णे च शरूिते। शरूिताः सर्वराजानः परिवर्तृकोदरम्॥
English Translation: O king, in the days of yore, we obtained you from Maheshvara by ascetic austerities. The upper part of your body is wholly made of Vajra (thunder).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ऊचुश्च सहितास्तत्र साध्विमौ ब्राह्मणर्षभौ। विज्ञायेतां क्वजन्मानौ क्वनिवासौ तथैव च॥
English Translation: On sinless one, therefore it is invincible to weapons of every description. The lower part of your body, capable of captivating the female heart by its comeliness, was made of flowers by the goddess herself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: को हि राधासुतं कर्णं शक्तो योधयितुं रणे। अन्यत्र रामाद् द्रोणाद्वा पाण्डवाद्वा किरीटिनः॥
English Translation: O foremost of kings, thus your body was created by Ishvara himself and the goddess. Therefore, O best of kings, your origin is celestials and not human.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृष्णाद् वा देवकीपुत्रात् कृपाद् वापि शरद्वतः। को वा दुर्योधनः शक्तः प्रतियोधयितुं रणे॥
English Translation: Other greatly powerful Kshatriyas headed by Bhagadatta, all learned in the celestials weapons, will kill your enemies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथैव मद्राधिपति शल्यं बलवतां वरम्। बलदेवादृते वीरात् पाण्डवाद् वा वृकोदरात्॥ वीराद् दुर्योधनाद् वान्यः शक्तः पातयितुं रणे। क्रियतामवहारोऽस्माद् युद्धाद् ब्राह्मणसंवृतात्॥
English Translation: Therefore there is not need for you grief. You have no cause for fear. In order to help you, many heroic Danavas have been born on earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणा हि सदा रक्ष्याः सापराधापि नित्यदा। अथैनानुपलभ्येह पुनर्योत्स्याम हृष्टवत्॥ तांस्तथावादिनः सर्वान् प्रसमीक्ष्य क्षितीश्वरान्। अथान्यान् पुरुषांश्चापि कृत्वा तत् कर्म संयुगे॥
English Translation: Other Asura will possess Bhishma, Drona and Karna and others. Possessed by the Asuras, those heroes will cast away their kindness and fight with your enemies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच तत् कर्म भीमस्य समीक्ष्य कृष्ण: कुन्तीसुतौ तौ परिशरूमानः। निवारयामास महीपतींस्तान् धर्मेण लब्धेत्यनुनीय सर्वान्॥
English Translation: When the Danavas will enter their heart and completely possess them flinging all affection to a distance and becoming hard-hearted, those heroes will then strike every one opposed to them without sparing sons, brothers, fathers, friends, disciples, relatives, even children and old men.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं ते विनिवृत्तास्तु युद्धाद् युद्धविशारदाः। यथावासं ययुः सर्वे विस्मिता राजसत्तमाः॥
English Translation: Blinded by ignorance and wrath and impelled by destiny which has been ordained by the creator, those foremost of men with hearts steeped in sin will. O foremost of the Kurus, depopulate the earth by hurling all kinds of weapons with great manliness and strength and always boastfully addressing one another with words such as these, “You will not escape from me today with life.” The five illustrious sons of Pandu will fight with these (heroes).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वृत्तो प्रह्मोत्तरो रङ्गः पाञ्चाली ब्राह्मणैर्वृता। इति ब्रुवन्तः प्रययुर्ये तत्रासन् समागताः॥
English Translation: Possessing great strength and favoured by the fate, they would bring about the destruction of all. Many Daityas and Yakshas, that have been born in the Kshatriya order, will fight with great prowess in battle with your enemies using maces, clubs, lances and various weapons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणैस्तु प्रतिच्छन्नौ रौरवाजिनवासिभिः। कृच्छ्रेण जग्मतुस्तौ तु भीमसेनधनंजयौ॥
English Translation: O hero, as for the fear of Arjuna in your heart, we have already settled the means of killing Arjuna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विमुक्तौ जनसम्बाधाच्छत्रुभिः परिवीक्षितौ। कृष्णयानुगतौ तत्र नृवीरौ तौ विरेजतुः॥ पौर्णमास्यां घनर्मुक्तौ चन्द्रसूर्याविवोदितौ। तेषां माता बहुविधं विनाशं पर्यचिन्तयत्॥
English Translation: The soul of the killed Naraka has assumed the form of Karna. Recollecting. O hero, his former enmity, he will kill both Keshava (Krishna) and Arjuna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनागच्छत्सु पुत्रेषु भैक्षकालेऽभिगच्छति। धार्तराष्ट्रर्हता न स्युर्विज्ञाय कुरुपुङ्गवाः॥
English Translation: That great car-warrior, that foremost of all wielders of weapons, proud of his prowess, will vanquish Arjuna in battle, as also all your enemies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मायान्वितैर्वा रक्षोभिः सुघोरैर्दृढवैरिभिः। विपरीतं मतं जातं व्यासस्यापि महात्मनः॥
English Translation: The wielder of thunder (Indra), knowing all this and desirous of saving Savyasachi (Arjuna), will in disguise take away from Karna his ear-rings and armour.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्येवं चिन्तयामास सुतस्नेहावृता पृथा। ततः सुप्तजनप्राये दुर्दिने मेघसम्प्लुते॥ महत्यथापराहणे तु घनैः सूर्य इवावृतः। ब्राह्मणैः प्राविशत् तत्र जिष्णुर्भार्गववेश्म तत्॥
English Translation: We have therefore appointed hundreds upon hundreds and thousands upon thousand of Daityas and Rakshasas; they are known by the name of Samshaptakas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच श्रुत्वा तु रथनिर्घोषं सिंहनादं च संयुगे। अर्जुनः प्राह गोविन्दं शीघ्र नोदय वाजिनः॥
English Translation: These illustrious warriors will kill the heroic Arjuna. Do not therefore grieve. O king, you will rule the whole earth without a rival.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्जुनस्य वचः श्रुत्वा गोविन्दोऽर्जुनमब्रवीत्। एष गच्छामि सुक्षिप्रं यत्र भीमो व्यवस्थितः॥
English Translation: Do not give way to despondency. O descendant of Kuru, this conduct does not suit you. If you die, our party will become weak.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं यान्तमश्चैर्हिमशङ्खवणैः सुवर्णमुक्तामणिजालनद्धैः। जम्भं जिघासुं प्रगृहीतवज्रं जयाय देवेन्द्रमिवोगमन्युम्॥
English Translation: O hero, go, you should never direct your mind in any other course. You are our refuge.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रथाश्वमातङ्गपदातिसंघा बाणस्वनैमिखुरस्वनैश्च। संनादयन्तो वसुधां दिशश्च क्रुद्धा नृसिंहा जयमभ्युदीयुः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Having thus addressed him, the Daityas embraced that foremost of kings; and those best of the Danavas then cheered that irrepressible hero like a son.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषां च पार्थस्य च मारिषसीद् देहासुपापक्षपणं सुयुद्धम्। त्रैलोक्यहेतोरसुरैर्यथाऽऽसीद् देवस्य विष्णोर्जयतां वरस्य॥
English Translation: O descendant of Bharata, cheering his mind by soft speeches, they permitted him to depart saying, “Go and attain victory."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: देकः प्रचिच्छेद किरीटमाली। क्षुरार्धचन्द्रैर्निशितैश्च भल्लैः शिरांसि तेषां बहुधा च बाहून्॥
English Translation: When they had given leave to the mighty armed one, (to-depart), that very goddess carried him back to the spot where he had sat down intent upon putting an end to his life.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नश्वान् रथान् पत्तिगणान् द्विपांश्च। ते पेतुरुवा॒ बहुधा विरूपा वातप्रणुन्नानि यथा वनानि॥
English Translation: Having set that hero down and paid him homage, the goddess vanished with the king's permission.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुवर्णजालावतता महागजाः सवैजयन्तीध्वजयोधकल्पिताः। श्चकाशिरे प्रज्वलिता यथाचलाः॥
English Translation: O descendant of Bharata, when she disappeared, the king considered all this to be a dream. (He thought), “I shall defeat the Pandavas in battle."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विदार्थं नागाश्वरथान् धनंजयः शरोत्तमैर्वासववज्रसंनिभैः। द्रुतं ययौ कर्णजिघांसया तथा यथा मरुत्वान् बलभेदने पुरा॥
English Translation: Duryodhana considered that Karna and the Samshaptaka army were both able to kill that chastiser of foes Partha (Arjuna).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः स पुरुषव्याघ्रस्तव सैन्यमरिंदमः। प्रविवेश महाबाहुर्मकरः सागरं यथा॥
English Translation: Thus was strengthened the hope of the wicked-minded son of Dhritarashtra, to conquer the Pandavas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं हृष्टास्तावका राजन् स्थपत्तिसमन्विताः। गजाश्वसादिबहुलाः पाण्डवं समुपाद्रवन्॥
English Translation: O foremost of Bharatas, Karna also, his soul and mind possessed by Naraka and influenced by the qualities of emotion and darkness, became cagerly desirous of killing Falguni (Arjuna).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषामापततां पार्थमारावः सुमहानभूत्। सागरस्येव क्षुब्धस्य यथा स्यात् सलिलस्वनः॥
English Translation: Thus those Shanshaptaka various being surrounded by monsters came under sheer infuence of Rajas and Tamas property and intedned to kill Arjuna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते तु तं पुरुषव्याघ्रं व्याघ्रा इव महारथाः। अभ्यद्रवन्त संग्रामे त्यक्त्वा प्राणकृतं भयम्॥
English Translation: Bhishma, Drona, Kripa and others, their mind possessed by the Danavas. O king, were not so affectionate towards the Pandavas as they were before. The king Suyodhana did not tell this to any one.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषामापततां तत्र शरवर्षाणि मुञ्चताम्। अर्जुनो व्यधमत् सैन्यं महावातो घनामिव॥
English Translation: At the end of the night, the son of the sun, Karna, thus smilingly spoke to Duryodhana with joined hands.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेऽर्जुन सहिता भूत्वा रथवंशैः प्रहारिणः। अभियाय महेष्वासा विव्यधुर्निशतैः शरैः॥
English Translation: “No dead man can conquer his foes, it is when he is alive that he can see his good. Where is the good of the dead person and O descendant of Kuru, where is his victory?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽर्जुनः सहस्राणि रथावारणवाजिनाम्। प्रेषयामास विशिखैर्यमस्य सदनं प्रति॥
English Translation: Therefore this is no time for grief or fear or death.” Having with his arms embraced that mighty armed hero,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते वध्यमाना समरे पार्थचापच्युतैः शरैः। तत्र यत्र स्म लीयन्ते भये जाते महारथाः॥
English Translation: He further said, "O king, rise up. Why do you lie down? O slayer of foes, why do you wish to die?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषां चतुःशतान् वीरान् यतमानान् महारथान्। अर्जुनो निशितेर्बाणैरनयद् यमसादनम्॥
English Translation: Fear has possessed you at the sight of Arjuna. I truly promise to you that I will kill Arjuna in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते वध्यमानाः समरे नानालिङ्गै शितैः शरैः। अर्जुनं समभित्यज्य दुद्रुवुर्वे दिशो दश॥
English Translation: O ruler of men, I swear by my weapons that when thirteen years have passed away, I will bring the sons of Pritha under your subjection."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषां शब्दो महानासीद् द्रवतां वाहिनीमुखे। महौघस्येव जलधेर्गिरिमासाद्य दीर्यतः॥
English Translation: Having been thus addressed by Karna and having (also) remembered the words of the Daityas and the supplications made by (his brothers), Duryodhana rose up.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तां तु सेनां भृशं विद्ध्वा द्रावयित्वार्जुनः शरैः। प्रायादभिमुखः पार्थः सूतानीकं हि मारिष॥
English Translation: Having heard the words of the Daityas, that foremost of men with a firm resolve in his heart arrayed his army full of horses, elephants, chariots and foot soldiers. O king, as it moved on like the waters of the Ganga.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य शब्दो महानासीत् परानभिमुखस्य वै। गरुडस्येव पततः पन्नगार्थे यथा पुर॥
English Translation: With numerous white umbrellas and pennons and white Chamaras and chariots and elephants and foot soldiers that great army, as is moved on like the waters of the Ganga looked as beautiful as the sky at a season when the clouds have been dispersed and the signs of autumn have been but partially developed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं तु शब्दमभिश्रुत्य भीमसेनो महाबलः। भभूव परमप्रीतः पार्थदर्शनलालसः॥
English Translation: O king of kings, eulogised as a monarch by the foremost of Brahmanas who all prayed for his victory, that king, Suyodhana, the son of Dhritarashtra, received honours paid to him by innumerable men) with joined hands.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रुत्वैव पार्थमायान्तं भीमसेनः प्रतापवान्। त्यक्त्वा प्राणान् महाराज सेनां तव ममर्द ह॥
English Translation: Blazing in great splendour he went in front (of the army) accompanied by Karna, Subala's son, the gambler (Shakuni), Dushashana and all his other brothers, Bhurishrava, Somadatta, the great king Bahlika followed that foremost of kings with various sorts of chariots, horses and excellent elephants. O foremost of kings, within a short time all those perpetuators of the Kuru race entered their own city.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स वायुवीर्यप्रतिमो वायुवेगसमो जवे। वायुवद् व्यचरद् भीमो वायुपुत्रः प्रतापवान्॥
English Translation: Ashtaka said: Those that are learned in the Vedas differ in opinions as regards the respective methods which should be practised by the Grihastas, Brahmacharis, Bhikshus and Vanaprasthas, so that they may acquire religious merits.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेनार्धमाना राजेन्द्र सेना तव विशाम्पते। व्यभ्रश्यत महाराज भिन्ना नौरिव सागरे॥
English Translation: Yayati said: A Brahmachari must do the following. When he will live in the house of his preceptor, he must receive lessons only when his preceptor will call him to do it. He must serve his preceptor without waiting for his command. He must rise before his preceptor from his bed and go to bed after him. He must be humble, self-controlled, patient, vigilant and devoted to study.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तां तु सेनां तदा भीमो दर्शयन् पाणिलाघवम्। शरैरवचकतॊग्रैः प्रेषयिष्यन् यमक्षयम्॥
English Translation: It is said in the oldest Upanishad that he must perform sacrifices after acquiring wealth by honest means. He should spend it in charity; he should be hospitable to all that would come to his house; he should never use anything without giving a portion to others.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्र भारत भीमस्य बलं दृष्ट्वाऽतिमानुषम्। व्यभ्रमन्त रणे योधाः कालस्येव युगक्षये॥
English Translation: A Muni (Brahmachari) should live in the forest, depending on his own vigour and without searching for food. He should abstain from all vicious acts; he should give away in charity; he should never inflict pain upon any creatures. It is then only that he can gain success.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथादितान् भीमबलान् भीमसेनेन भारत। दृष्ट्वा दुर्योधनो राजा इदं वचनमब्रवीत्॥ सैनिकांश्च महेष्वासान् योधांश्च भरतर्षभ। समादिशन् रणे सर्वान् हत भीममिति स्म ह॥
English Translation: He is a true Bhikshu, who does not support himself by any manual labour, who possesses many accomplishments, who has his passions under complete control, who is thoroughly unconnected with all worldly concerns, who does not sleep under the shelter of a householder's roof, who is without wife and who travels over many countries, going some distance every day.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मिन् हते हतं मन्ये पाण्डुसैन्यमशेषतः। प्रतिगृह्य च तामाज्ञां तव पुत्रहस्य पार्थिवाः॥ भीमं प्रच्छादयामासुः शरवर्षेः समन्ततः।
English Translation: A learned should adopt the Vanaprastha mode of life, after the performance of the necessary rites. He should adopt it when he has been able to control his thirst for enjoyments and desire of acquiring wealth. When a man dies in the forest, leading the Vanaprastha mode of life, he mixes his ancestors and grand-children, numbering ten generations including himself, with the divine man essence.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गजाश्च बहुला राजन् नराश्च जयगृद्धिनः॥ रथे स्थिताश्च राजेन्द्र परिवब्रुर्वृकोदरम्।
English Translation: Ashtaka said : How many kinds of Munis are there and how many kinds of Munis (observers of vows)? We desire to hear all this.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तैः परिवृतः शरैः राजन् समन्ततः॥ शुशुभे भरतश्रेष्ठो नक्षत्रैरिव चन्द्रमाः।
English Translation: Yayati said: O king, he is a true Muni, who possesses all things pertaining to a village though living in the forest and also possesses all things pertaining to the forest though living in a village.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: परिवेषी यथा सोमः परिपूर्णो विराजते॥ स रराज तथा संख्ये दर्शनीयो नरोत्तमः। निर्विशेषो महाराज यथा हि विजयस्तथा।॥
English Translation: Ashtaka said : How is it possible to possess all things pertaining to a village when living in the forest and all things pertaining to a forest when living in a village?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य ते पार्थिवाः सर्वे शरवृष्टिं समासृजन्। क्रोधरक्तेक्षणाः शूरा हन्तुकामा वृकोदरम्॥
English Translation: Yayati said : A Muni lives in the forest after withdrawing himself from all worldly objects. But though he never seeks to possess things pertaining to a village, he may yet get them by his ascetic powers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तां विदार्य महासेनां शरैः संनतपर्वभिः। निश्चकाम रणाद् भीमो मत्स्यो जालादिवाम्भसि॥३७
English Translation: A true Muni, withdrawn from all earthly objects, might live in a village, leading the life of a hermit. Chad in Kaupina (scantiest of robes,) he considers himself attired in the richest robe. He is content with food just sufficient to support life. He who abandons all desires, who has all his passions under complete control and who has given up all actions, is the man who attains success.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हत्वा दशसहस्राणि गजानामनिवर्तिनाम्। नृणां शतसहस्रे द्वे द्वे शते चैव भारत॥ पञ्च चाश्वसहस्राणि रथानां शतमेव च। हत्वा प्रास्यन्दयद् भीमो नदी शोणितवाहिनीम्॥
English Translation: Why should you not revere the man who lives on pure food, who refrains from injuring others, whose heart is ever holy, who is effulgent in his ascetic merits, who is free from the leaden weight of desire and who abstains from injury even when it is sanctioned by the scriptures?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शोणितोदां रथावर्ता हस्तिग्राहसमाकुलाम्। नरमीनाश्वनक्रान्तां केशशैबलशाद्वलाम्॥ संछिन्नभुजनागेन्द्रां बहुरत्नापहारिणीम्। ऊस्याहां मजपङ्का शीर्षोपलसमावृताम्॥ धनुष्काशां शरावापां गदापरिधकेतनाम्। हंसच्छत्रध्वजोपेतामुष्णीषवरफेनिलाम्॥ हारपद्माकरां चैव भूमिरेणूर्मिमालिनीम्। आर्यवृत्तवतां संख्ये सुतरां भीरुदुस्तराम्॥ योधग्राहवतीं संख्ये वहन्तीं यमसादनम्। क्षणेन पुरुषव्याघ्रः प्रावर्तयत निम्नगाम्॥ यथा वैतरणीमुग्रां दुस्तरामकृतात्मभिः। तथा दुस्तरणी घोरां भीरूणां भयवर्धिनीम्॥
English Translation: Emaciated by hard asceticism and reduced in marrow, blood and flesh, such a Muni not only conquers this world, but the highest world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यतो यतः पाण्डवेयः प्रविष्टो रथसत्तमः। ततस्ततोऽघातयत योधाशतसहस्रशः॥
English Translation: The Muni who sits in Yoga mediation and who becomes indifferent to happiness and misery, honour and insult, conquers this world and conquering it, he conquers the highest world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं दृष्ट्वा कृतं कर्म भीमसेनेन संयुगे। दुर्योधन महाराज शकुनि वाक्यमब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: The Muni who eats like the kine and other animals, without providing for it beforehand and without any relish, becomes identified with the whole universe.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जहि मातुलं संग्रामे भीमसेनं महाबलम्। अस्मिञ्जिते जितं मन्ये पाण्डवेयं महाबलम्॥
English Translation: Sauti said: O Brahmana, Chyavana, the son of Bhrigu begot a son on his wife, named Sukanya. And son of Sukanya was the illustrious and the resplendently energetic Pramati.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः प्रायान्महाराज सौबलेयः प्रतापवान्। रणाय महते युक्तो भ्रातृभिः परिवारितः॥ स समासाद्य संग्रामे भीमं भीमपराक्रमम्। वारयामास तं वीरो वेलेव मकरालयम्॥
English Translation: Pramati begot a son called Ruru on Ghritachi. Ruru begot a son called Sunaka on his wife, Pramadvara.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संन्यवर्तत तं भीमो वार्यमाण: शितैः शरैः। शकुनिस्तस्य राजेन्द्र वामपार्श्वे स्तनान्तरे॥ प्रेषयामास नाराचान् रुक्मपुङ्खाशिलाशितान्।
English Translation: I shall tell you at length, O Brahmana, the history of the resplendently energetic Ruru. Listen to it in detail.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वर्म भित्वा तु ते घोराः पाण्डवस्य महात्मनः॥ न्यमञ्जन्त महाराज कङ्कबर्हिणवाससः।
English Translation: In the days of yore, there was a Rishi, named Sthulakesha, who was possessed of ascetic powers and learning and engaged in doing good to all creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सोऽतिविद्धो रणे भीमः शरं रुक्मविभूषितम्॥ प्रेषयामास स रुषा सौबलं प्रति भारत।
English Translation: At this time, O Brahmana Rishi, Menaka became quick with child by the king of the Gandharvas, named Vishvavasu.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमायान्तं शरं घोरं शकुनिः शत्रुतापनः॥ चिच्छेद सप्तधा राजन् कृतहस्तो महाबलः।
English Translation: O Descendant of Bhrigu, the Apsara Menaka, when the time came, delivered her child near the herinitage of Sthulakesha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मिन् निपतिते भूमौ भीमः क्रुद्धो विशामप्ते॥ धनुश्चिच्छेद भल्लेन सौबलस्य हसन्निव।
English Translation: And, O Brahmana, the cruel and shameless Apsara Menaka, after leaving the child on the banks of the river, went away.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदपास्य धनुश्छिन्नं सौबलेयः प्रतापवान्॥ अन्यदादाय वेगेन धनुर्भल्लांश्च षोडश।
English Translation: The great Rishi saw the girl lying forsaken in a lonely place on the banks of the river, blazing in beauty; she was as beautiful as a child of an immortal. And the great Brahmana, Sthulakesha, the chief of Munis, finding that female child.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तैस्तस्य तु महाराज भल्लैः संनतपर्वभिः॥ द्वाभ्यां स सारथिं ह्या द् भीमं सप्तभिरेव च। ध्वजमेकेन चिच्छेद द्वाभ्यां छत्रं विशाम्पते॥ चतुर्भिश्चतुरो वाहान् विव्याध सुबलात्मजः।
English Translation: Out of compassion, took it home and brought it up. The lovely child grew up in the hermitage of the great Rishi.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः क्रुद्धो महाराज भीमसेनः प्रतापवान्॥ शक्तिं चिक्षेप समरे रुक्मदण्डामयस्मयीम्।
English Translation: The great Rishi, the blessed Sthulakesha, performed for her in succession all the ceremonies with that of her birth, as ordained in the Shastras.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सा भीमभुजनिर्मुक्ता नागजिह्वेव चञ्चला॥ निपपात रणे तूर्णं सौबलस्य महात्मनः।
English Translation: As the surpassed all other ladies in beauty in goodness and in every good quality, the gave her the name as Pramadvara.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्तामेव संगृह्य शक्तिं कनकभूषणाम्॥ भीमसेनाय चिक्षेप क्रुद्धरूपो विशाम्पते।
English Translation: Ruru saw her in the hermitage and the pious man fell in love with her.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सा निर्भिद्य भुजं सव्यं पाण्डवस्य महात्मनः॥ निपपात तदा भूमौ यथा विद्युन्नभश्च्युता।
English Translation: He made his father Pramati, the son of Bhrigu, acquainted with his love through his companions. Thereupon Pramati asked the illustrious Sthulakesha to give Pramadvara to his son.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथोत्क्रुष्टं महाराज धार्तराष्ट्रः समन्ततः॥ न तु तं ममृषे भीमः सिंहनादं तरस्विनाम्।
English Translation: The Rishi betrothed Pramadvara to Ruru, fixing the day of marriage when the star Bhaga Daivata would be in ascendant. great Rishi
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्यद् गृह्य धनुः सज्यं त्वरमाणो महाबलः॥ मुहूर्तादिव राजेन्द्र च्छादयामास सायकैः। सौबलस्य बलं संख्ये त्यक्त्वाऽऽत्मानं महाबलः॥६५
English Translation: A few days before the date fixed for the nuptials, while the lovely girl was playing with her companions.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्याश्वांश्चतुरो हत्वा सूतं चैव विशाम्पते। ध्वजं चिच्छेद भल्लेन त्वरमाणः पराक्रमी॥
English Translation: Her time having come and impelled by Fate, she trod upon a snake. She did not perceive it, as it lay coiled.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हताश्वं रथमुत्सृज्य त्वरमाणो नरोत्तमः। तस्थौ विस्फारयंश्चापं क्रोधरक्तेक्षणः श्वसन्॥
English Translation: The snake, to fulfil the will of Fate, bit the heedless girl with its venomous fangs.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शरैश्च बहुधा राजन् भीममार्च्छत् समन्ततः। प्रतिहत्य तु वेगेन भीमसेनः प्रतापवान्॥ धनुश्चिच्छेद संक्रुद्धो विव्याध च शतैः शरैः।
English Translation: Bitten by the snake, she suddenly fell senseless on the ground with her colour faded all her beauties gone and all her ornaments scattered.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सोऽतिविद्धो बलवता शत्रुणा शत्रुकर्शनः॥ निपपात तदा भूमौ किंचित्प्राणो नराधिपः।
English Translation: Her hair dishevelled, a spectacle of woe to her friends and companions. She, who was so handsome when alive, became in death what was too painful to look at.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्तं विह्वलं ज्ञात्वा पुत्रस्तव विशाम्पते॥ अपोवाह रथेनाजी भीमसेनस्य पश्यतः।
English Translation: The slender-waisted girl, as she lay on the ground as one asleep, looked more beautiful than she was when alive.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रथस्थे तु नरव्याने धार्तराष्ट्राः पराङ्मुखाः॥ प्रदुद्रुवुर्दिशो भीता भीमाजाते महाभये।
English Translation: Her father and other ascetics, who were present, saw her lying motionless on the ground with the beauty of a lotus.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सौबले निर्जिते राजन् भीमसेनेन धन्विना॥ भयेन महताऽऽविष्टः पुत्रो दुर्योधनस्तव। अपायाजवनैरश्वैः सापेक्षो मातुलं प्रति॥
English Translation: Then there came all the noted Brahmanas, filled with compassion. Svastyatreya, Mahajanu, Kushika, Shankhamekhala.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पराङ्मुखं तु राजानं दृष्ट्वा सैन्यानि भारत। विप्रजग्मुः समुत्सृज्य द्वैरथानि समन्ततः॥
English Translation: Uddalaka, Katha and the renowned Shveta, Bharadvaja, Kaunakutsya, Arshtishena, Goutama,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तान् दृष्ट्वा विद्रुतान् सर्वान् धार्तराष्ट्रान् पराङ्मुखान्। जवेनाभ्यापतद् भीमः किरशरशतान् बहून्॥
English Translation: Pramati and Pramati's son Ruru and other inhabitants of the forest were filled with compassion and they all wept when they saw the maiden lying on the ground overcome by the poison of the snake. And Ruru, being exceedingly pained, left the scene. A
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते वध्यमाना भीमेन धार्तराष्ट्राः पराङ्मुखाः। कर्णमासाद्य समरे स्थिता राजन् समन्ततः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said Having quickly routed the enemy's host and recovered the kine, that foremost of bowmen, with a view to fight again, proceeded towards Duryodhana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स हि तेषां महावीर्यो द्वीपोऽभूत सुमहाबलः। भिन्ननौका यथा राजन् द्वीपमासाद्य निर्वृताः॥ भवन्ति पुरुषव्याघ्र नाविकाः कालपर्यये। तथा कर्णं समासाद्य तावकाः पुरुषर्षभ॥ समाश्वस्ता: स्थिता राजन् सम्प्रहृष्टाः परस्परम्। समाजग्मुश्च युद्धाय मृत्यु कृत्वा निवर्तनम्॥
English Translation: Seeing the kine run towards the city of Matsya's and considering Kiritin successful, the heroic Kurus all on a sudden withstood him who was proceeding towards Duryodhana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच इत्युक्त्वानुपयौ पार्थं हयं कामविहारिणम्। न्यवर्तत ततो वाजी येन नागाह्वयं पुरम्॥
English Translation: Beholding their army and various well arranged divisions as well as numberless flags, that destroyer of enemies, addressing the son of Virata, the king of Matsya's, said,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं निवृत्तं तु शुश्चाव चारणैव युधिष्ठिरः। श्रुत्वार्जुनं कुशलिनं स च हृष्टमनाऽभवत्॥
English Translation: Soon take these white horses by this way, governed by golden reins. Do you quickly and carefully take me to the row of the leading Kuru heroes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विजयस्य च तत् कर्म गान्धारविषये तदा। श्रुत्वा चान्येषु देशेषु स सुप्रीतोऽभवत् तदा॥
English Translation: The wicked-souled son of the charioteer (Karna) wishes to fight with me as an elephant does with another (elephant). Do you take me to him, O prince, who has grown insolent for the protection afforded to him by Duryodhana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतस्मिन्नेव काले तु द्वादशी माघमासिकीम्। इष्टं गृहीत्वा नक्षत्रं धर्मराजो युधिष्ठिरः॥ समानाय महातेजाः सर्वान् भ्रातृन् महीपतिः। भीमं च नकुलं चैव सहदेवं च कौरव॥ प्रोवाचेदं वचः काले तदा धर्मभृतां वरः। आमत्र्य वदतां श्रेष्ठो भीमं प्रहरतां वरम्॥
English Translation: Then breaking through the array of carwarriors with big horses fleet as the wind the son of Virata took Arjuna to the middle of the battle field.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आयाति भीमसेनासौ सहाश्वेन तवानुजः। यथा मे पुरुषाः प्राहुर्ये धनंजयसारिणः॥
English Translation: Seeing this, those powerful car-warriors, Chitrasena, Sangramajit, Shatrusaha and Jaya with a view to help Karna, rushed towards the advancing Arjuna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उपस्थितश्च कालोऽयमभितो वर्तते हयः। मार्य च पौर्णमासीयं मास: शेषो वृकोदर॥
English Translation: Thereupon worked up with anger that foremost of men began to consume, with blazing shafts, discharged from his bow, the cars of the leading Kurus like fire consuming the forest.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रस्थाप्यन्तां हि विद्वांसो ब्राह्मणा वेदपारगाः। वाजिमेधार्थसिद्ध्यर्थं देशं पश्यन्तु यज्ञियम्॥
English Translation: When the battle grew dreadful, Vikarana, a leading Kuru hero, getting upon his own chariot, moved towards that mighty carwarrior, Partha, the younger brother of Bhima with a dreadful downpour of shafts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्युक्तः स तु तच्चक्रे भीमो नृपतिशासनम्। हृष्टः श्रुत्वा गुडाकेशमायान्तं पुरुषर्षभम्॥
English Translation: Then cutting off his bow with a strong string and having its tops covered with gold he sundered-his Flag-staff. Then with his Flagstaff broken down he quickly took to heels.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो ययौ भीमसेनः प्राज्ञैः स्थपतिभिः सह। ब्राह्मणानग्रतः कृत्वा कुशलान् यज्ञकर्मणि॥
English Translation: Unable to check his anger, Shatruntapa, with a downpour of shafts, began to afflict Partha-the obstructor of the enemies and the author of superhuman deeds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं स शालचयं श्रीमत् सप्रतोलीसुघट्टितम्। मापयामास कौरव्यो यज्ञवाट यथाविधि॥
English Translation: Then wounded by that king a mighty carwarrior and drowned as it were in the Kuru army he wounded Shatruntapa with five arrows and then killed his charioteer with ten.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रासादशतसम्बाधं मणिप्रवरकुट्टिमम्। कारयामास विधिवद्धरत्नविभूषितम्॥
English Translation: Then wounded by that foremost of Bharatas with a greatly piercing shaft the king leaving his armour fell down dead on the ground like a rock from the mountain summit clapped by the wind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्तम्भान् कनकचित्रांश्च तोरणानि बृहन्ति च। यज्ञायतनदेशेषु दत्त्वा शुद्धं च काननम्॥
English Translation: Assailed by the foremost of men, a greater hero, those heroic leaders of the Kurus began to tremble in battle like a huge forest shaken by the wind at the time of the universal dissolution.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्तःपुराणां राज्ञां च नानादेशसमीयुषाम्। कारयामास धर्मात्मा तत्र तत्र यथाविध॥
English Translation: Vanquished in battle and slain by Partha, the son of Indra, those heroes, givers of wealth and endued with the prowess of Vasava and well-dressed, slept on the ground, deprived of their lives,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणानां च वेश्मानि नानादेशसमीयुषाम्। कारयामास कौन्तेयो विधिवत् तान्यनेकशः॥
English Translation: Like huge Himalaya elephants dressed with armours made of black steel decked with gold. Thus slaying his enemies in battle that heroic man, the holder of Gandiva bow,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथा सम्प्रेषयामास दूतान् नृपतिशासनात्। भीमसेनो महाबाहो राज्ञामक्लिष्टकर्मणाम्॥
English Translation: Began to move about in the field in all direction like fire consuming a forest at the end of summer. As the wind blows in the spring scattering the withered leaves and clouds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते प्रियार्थं कुरुपतेराययुर्नृपसत्तम। रत्नान्यने कान्यादाय स्त्रियोऽश्वानायुधानि च॥
English Translation: So the mighty car-warrior Kiritin ranged in the battle field in his chariot dispersing his enemies. Then killing the horses of the brother of Vikartana's son, that one of undeteriorating energy. Ever victorious in battle and decked with a brilliant diadem, with one shaft, speedily cut off his head.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषां निविशतां तेषु शिबिरेषु महात्मनाम्। नर्दतः सागरस्येव दिवस्पृगभवत् स्वतः॥
English Translation: His brother being slain, the son of Suta, Vikartana's son, gathering his energy. Rushed towards that foremost of men like an elephant chief, with the two tusks out or like a tiger. And Vikartana's son quickly wounded Arjuna with twelve arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषामभ्यागतानां च स राजा कुरुवर्धनः। व्यादिदेशान्नपानानि शय्याश्चाप्यतिमानुषाः॥
English Translation: All the horses on their bodies, and the son of Virata on the hand. Furiously hastening towards Vikartana's son who was quickly proceeding towards him, Kiritin attacked him with great force like Garuda of variegated plumage falling upon snakes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वाहनानां च विविधाः शाला: शालीक्षुगोरसैः। उपेता भरतश्रेष्ठो व्यादिदेश स धर्मराट्॥
English Translation: Both of them were best of bowmen, were greatly powerful and capable of killing all enemies. Understanding that an encounter was soon to take place between Karna and Partha, the Kurus, wishing to witness it, stood at a distance.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथा तस्मिन् महायज्ञे धर्मराजस्य धीमतः। समाजग्मुर्मुनिगणा बहवो ब्रह्मवादिनः॥
English Translation: Seeing the iniquitous Karna, Arjuna, excited with anger, in great pleasure, quickly made him, his horses and his charioteer invisible by a thick downpour of arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ये च द्विजाति प्रवरास्तत्रासन् पृथिवीपते। समाजग्सुः सशिष्यास्तान् प्रतिजग्राह कौरवः॥
English Translation: The warriors of the Bharatas, headed by Bhishma, with their horses, elephants and chariots rendered invisible and pierced and having their cars broken by Kiritin with shafts, began to bewail.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वोश्च ताननुययौ यावदावसथान् प्रति। स्वयमेव महातेजा दम्भं त्यक्त्वा युधिष्ठिरः॥
English Translation: Then baffaling with his own arrows those shot by the hands of Arjuna the hero, the highsouled Karna, all on a sudden came into view with his bow and arrow like fire with scintillations.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः कृत्वा स्थपतयः शिल्पिनोऽन्ये च ये तदा। कृत्स्नं यज्ञविधिं राज्ञो धर्मज्ञाय न्यवेदयन्॥
English Translation: Then there arose the sound of the clapping of hands and that of conchs, trumpets and bugles while the Kurus spoke highly of Vikartana's son who filled the welkin with the sound of his bow-string striking against his gloves.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तच्छ्रुत्वा धर्मराजस्तु कृतं सर्वमतन्द्रितः। हृष्टरूपोऽभवद् राजा सह भ्रातृभिरादृतः॥
English Translation: Then seeing Kiritin fill the sky with the twang of his Gandiva bow, the upraised tail of the monkey that was on his Flag-staff and the dreadful creatures yelling hideously from the Flag-staff, Karna sent up a shout.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच तस्मिन् यज्ञे प्रवृत्ते तु वाग्मिनो हेतुवादिनः। हेतुवादान् बहूनाहुः परस्परजिगीषवः॥
English Translation: Then assailing with his arrows Vikartana's son, together with his horses, car and charioteer, Arjuna showered a downpour of shafts on him, casting his looks on Bhishma, Drona and Kripa Vikartana's son too covered Partha with a downpour of shafts like a cloud.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ददृशुस्तं नृपतयो यज्ञस्य विधिमुत्तमम्। देवेन्द्रस्येव विहितं भीमसेनेन भारता॥
English Translation: And he too, decked with a diadem, covered Karna with sharp arrows. Creating clouds of sharp arrows in a battle rendered furious by huge weapons and shafts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ददृशुस्तोरणान्यत्र शातकुम्भमयानि ते। शय्यासनविहारांश्च सुबहून् रत्नसंचयान्॥
English Translation: The two, stationed on cars, appeared to men like the sun and the moon covered by clouds. Then the light-handed and intelligent Karna wounded the horses of Partha with shafts,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: घटान् पात्री: कटाहानि कलशान् वर्धमानकान्। न हि किंचिदसौवर्णमपश्यन् वसुधाधिपाः॥
English Translation: Assailed his driver with three arrows and struck down his Flag-staff with three. Thus struck like a sleeping lion awaking, that repressor of enemies in battle,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यूपांश्च शास्त्रपठितान् दारवान् हेमभूषितान्। उपक्लृप्तान् यथाकालं विधिवद् भूरिवर्चसः॥
English Translation: The holder of Gandiva, the heroic Vishnu, assailed Karna with straight shafts, And assailed with a downpour of arrows and weapons the high-souled performer of superhuman deeds displayed (mighty feats).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्थलजा जलजा ये च पशवः केचन प्रभो। सर्वानेव समानीतानपश्यंस्तत्र ते नृपाः॥
English Translation: He covered Karna's car with shafts like the sun covering the regions with its rays. Like a lion attacked by an elephant he, taking out sharpened arrows from the quiver.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पाश्चैव महिषीश्चैव तथा वृद्धस्त्रियोऽपि च। औदकानि च सत्त्वानि श्वापदानि वयांसि च॥ जरायुजाण्डजातानि स्वेदजान्युद्धिदानि च। पर्वतानूपजातानि भूतानि ददृशुश्च ते११३४॥
English Translation: And drawing the bow to his ear wounded the charioteer's son on every part of his body. Then that repressor of enemies pierced Karna's arms, thighs, head, forehead and other parts of his body with sharpened arrows fleet as the thunderbolt, shot from his Gandiva bow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं प्रमुदितं सर्वे पशुगोधनधान्यतः। यज्ञवाटं नृपा दृष्ट्वा परं विस्मयमागताः॥
English Translation: Thus wounded by the arrows shot by Partha, the son of Pandu, Vikartana's son lef the battle-field and took to his heels like a elephant defeated by another.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणानां विशां चैव बहुमृष्टान्नमृद्धिमत्। पूर्णे शतसहस्त्रे तु विप्राणां तत्र भुञ्जताम्॥
English Translation: Thus accusted, Janamejaya replied to the sage, saying,-You chastise one who deserves to be chastised. You censure one who is worthy of being censured.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुन्दुभिर्मेघनिर्घोषो मुहुर्मुहुरताड्यत। विननादासकृच्चापि दिवसे दिवसे गते॥
English Translation: You blame me and my acts. I beg you to be kind to me! All my acts have been sinful. I burn, however, with repentance as if I am in the midst of burning fire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं स ववृते यज्ञो धर्मराजस्य धीमतः। अन्नस्य सुबहून् राजनुत्सर्गान् पर्वतोपमान्॥
English Translation: Remembering my deeds, I am cheerless. Indeed, I am much afraid of Yama.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दधिकुल्याश्च ददृशुः सर्पिषश्च ह्रदान् जनाः। जम्बूद्वीपो हि सकलो नानाजनपदायुतः॥
English Translation: How can I live without taking out that dart from my heart! O Shaunaka, suppressing all your anger, instruct me now!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजन्नदृश्यतैकस्थो राजस्तस्य महामखे। जत्र जातिसहस्राणि पुरुषाणां ततस्ततः॥ गृहीत्वा भाजनान् जग्मुर्बहूनि भरतर्षभ। स्रग्विणश्चापि ते सर्वे सुमृष्टमाणकुण्डला:॥ पर्यवेषन द्विजातीस्ताशतशोऽथ सहस्रशः।
English Translation: Formerly I used to show a great reverence to Brahmanas. I solemnly say that I shall once more show.the same respect to them. Let not my family be extinct. Let not the family in which I am born be reduced to the dust.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विविधान्यन्नपानानि पुरुषा येऽनुयायिनः। ते वै नृपोपभोज्यानि ब्राह्मणानां ददुश्च ह॥
English Translation: It is not proper that they who have injured Brahmanas and have for that, on account of Védic injunctions, forfeited all claim to the I arn respect of the world and to social intercourse with their fellowmen, should have any one who will continue the name of their family.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजन्नदृश्यतैकस्थो राजस्तस्य महामखे। जत्र जातिसहस्राणि पुरुषाणां ततस्ततः॥ गृहीत्वा भाजनान् जग्मुर्बहूनि भरतर्षभ। स्रग्विणश्चापि ते सर्वे सुमृष्टमाणकुण्डला:॥ पर्यवेषन द्विजातीस्ताशतशोऽथ सहस्रशः।
English Translation: I am overwhelmed with despair. I, therefore, repeat my promises. I pray you to protect me like sages who always protect the poor.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विविधान्यन्नपानानि पुरुषा येऽनुयायिनः। ते वै नृपोपभोज्यानि ब्राह्मणानां ददुश्च ह॥
English Translation: Abstaining from sacrifices, sinful persons never attain to heaven. Leaving (this world), they have to pass their time in hell like the degraded tribes of Pulindas and Khasas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कपिल उवाच वेदाः प्रमाणं लोकानां न वेदाः पृष्ठतः कृताः। द्वे ब्रह्मणी वेदितव्ये शब्दब्रह्म परं च यत्॥
English Translation: Ignorant as I am, give me wisdom like a learned preceptor to his pupil or like a father to his son. Be pleased with ine, O Shaunaka!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शब्दब्रह्मणि निष्णातः परं ब्रह्माधिगच्छति। शरीरमेतत् कुरुते यद् वेदे कुरुते तनुम्॥
English Translation: Shaunaka said What wonder is there that an ignorant wight should do many improper acts? Knowing this, a really wise person is never angry with foolish creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृतशुद्धशरीरो हि पात्रं भवति ब्राह्मणः। आनन्त्यमत्र बुद्ध्यदं कर्मणां तद् ब्रवीमि ते॥
English Translation: By getting upon the top of wisdom's palace, one grieves for others, his own self being then too pure to be grieved by others. For his wisdom one surveys all creatures in the world like a person on a mountain-top seeing people below.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनागममनैतिचं प्रत्यक्षं लोकसाक्षिकम्। धर्म इत्येव ये यज्ञान् वितन्वन्ति निराशिषः॥ उत्पन्नत्यागिनोऽलुब्धाः कृपासूयाविवर्जिताः। धनानामेष वै पनास्तीर्थेषु प्रतिपादनम्॥
English Translation: The person who is censured by good men, who hates good men and who hides himself from their view, never acquires any blessing and never understands the fitness of acts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनाश्रिताः पापकर्म कदाचित् कर्मयोगिनः। मन:संकल्पसंसिद्धा विशुद्धज्ञाननिश्चयाः॥ अक्रुध्यन्तोऽनसूयन्तो निरहङ्कारमत्सराः। ज्ञाननिष्ठास्त्रिशुक्लाश्च सर्वभूतहिते रताः॥ आसन् गृहस्था भूयिष्ठा अव्युत्क्रान्ताः स्वकर्मसु। राजानश्च तथा युक्ता ब्राह्मणाश्च यथाविधि॥
English Translation: You know the energy and the nobility of the Brahmana as laid down in the Veda and other scriptures. Act now in such a way that you may have tranquillity of heart and let Brahmanas be your refuge. If the Brahmanas do not be angry with you, you will, forsooth, enjoy happiness in heaven. If, again, you repent for sins, your sight will be clear and you will succeed in seeing righteousness.

Sanskrit Shloka: समा ह्यार्जवसम्पन्नाः संतुष्टा ज्ञाननिश्चयाः। प्रत्यक्षधर्माः शुचयः श्रद्दधानाः परावरे॥
English Translation: Janamejaya said, I am repenting for my sins. I will never again try to suppress virtue. I wish to obtain blessedness. Be you pleased with me.

Sanskrit Shloka: पुरस्ताद् भावितात्मानो यथावच्चरितव्रताः। चरन्ति धर्म कृच्छेऽपि दुर्गे चैवापि संहताः॥
English Translation: Shaunaka said Removing arrogance and pride, O king, I wish you to respect me. Do good to all creatures, always remembering the dictates of virtue.

Sanskrit Shloka: संहत्य धर्मं चरतां पुराऽऽसीत् सुखमेव तत्। तेषां नासीद् विधातव्यं प्रायश्चित्तं कथंचन॥
English Translation: I am not blaming you from fear or narrowness of mind or covetousness. Listen now, with these Brahmanas here, to the words of truth.

Sanskrit Shloka: सत्यं हि धर्ममास्थाय दुराधर्षतमा मताः। न मात्रामनुरुध्यन्ते न धर्मच्छलमन्ततः॥
English Translation: I do not ask for anything. I shall, however, instruct you in the ways of virtue. All persons will croak and bray and cry fie on me.

English Translation: They will even call me sinful. My kinsmen and friends will renounce me. However, hearing the words I speak, my kinsmen and friends will surely succeed in vigorously crossing the difficulties of life.

Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मिन् विधौ स्थितानां हि प्रायश्चित्तं न विद्यते। दुर्बलात्मन उत्पन्न प्रायश्चित्तमिति श्रुतिः॥
English Translation: The wise will understand me aright. Know, O child, what are my views, O Bharata, regarding the Brahmanas. Do you act in such a way that they may, through my efforts, obtain every blessing! Do you also, O king, promise that you will not again injure the Brahmanas.

Sanskrit Shloka: एवं बहुविधा विप्राः पुराणा यज्ञवाहनाः। विद्यवृद्धाः शुचयो वृत्तवन्तो यशस्विनः॥
