English Translation: Then Karna, with three crescent-like shafts, severed his head and arms from the body and like a Sala tree cut down by an axe he (Ugrakarman) fell down lifeless from his car.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अस्त्रैरभेद्यः शस्त्रैश्चाप्यधः कायश्च तेऽनघ। कृतः पुष्पमयो देव्या रूपतः स्त्रीमनोहरः॥
English Translation: Then Prasena, if dancing with excitement, assailed the steedless grandson of Shini (Satyaki) with many straight arrows, by was in return killed by the grandson of Shini.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमोश्वरसंयुक्तस्तव देहो नृपोत्तम। देव्या च राजशार्दूल दिव्यस्त्वं हि न मानुषः॥
English Translation: Karna, filled with vengeance at the death of his son and wishing to slay that foremost of Shinis addressed him, “consider yourself a dead man" and struck him with a deadly arrow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क्षत्रियाच महावीर्या भगदत्तपुरोगमाः। दिव्यास्त्रविदुषः शूराः क्षपयिष्यन्ति ते रिपून्।॥
English Translation: as But Shikhandin severed that arrow with three shafts and with three other distressed Karna; then the wrathful son of Suta with two razor-like shafts struck off the bows, arrows and banners of Shikhandi.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदलं ते विषादेन भयं तव न विद्यते। साहाय्यार्थं च ते वीराः सम्भूता भुवि दानवाः॥
English Translation: With six other powerful arrows hit Shikhandi himself and killed Dhristadyumna's son; and the noble son of Adhiratha also struck Sutasoma with a very sharp arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्मद्रोणकृपादींश्च प्रवेक्ष्यन्त्यपरेऽसुराः। यैराविष्टा घृणां त्यक्त्वा योत्स्यन्ते तव वैरिभिः॥
English Translation: O most powerful of monarchs, in that terrible fight loud lamentations were heard as the son of Dhristadumnya fell down and Krishna, hearing that, addressed Partha and said, “Partha go and kill Karna for he is destroying the whole Panchala race."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नैव पुत्रान् न च भ्रातृन् न पितॄन् न च बान्धवान्। नैव शिष्यान् न च ज्ञातीन् न बालान् स्थविरान् न च।। युधि सम्प्रहरिष्यन्तो मोक्ष्यन्ति कुरुसत्तम। नि:स्नेहा दानवाविष्टाः समाक्रान्तेऽन्तरात्मनि॥
English Translation: Then in order to save the Panchalas from the fear of that great car-warrior, Karna, he (Arjuna) advanced on his car towards the chariot of the son of Adhiratha with a smile in his lips.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रहरिष्यन्ति विवशा: स्नेहमुत्सृज्य दूरतः। हृष्टाः पुरुषशार्दूला: कलुषीकृतमानसाः। अविज्ञानविमूढाश्च दैवाच्च विधिनिर्मितात्॥ व्याभाषमाणाश्यान्योन्यं न मे जीवन् विमोक्ष्यसे सर्वे शस्त्रास्त्रमोक्षेण पौरुषे समवस्थिताः॥ श्लाघमानाः कुरुश्रेष्ठ करिष्यन्ति जनक्षयम्। तेऽपि पञ्च महात्मानः प्रतियोत्स्यन्ति पाण्डवाः॥
English Translation: Then rubbing his palm on the bow-string with a very loud twang he stretched out the Gandiva and suddenly made the Earth look dark by covering the sun with showers of arrows and also killed hosts of men, horses and elephants and destroyed many banners.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वधं चैषां करिष्यन्ति दैवयुक्ता महाबलाः। दैत्यरक्षोगणाश्चैव सम्भूताः क्षत्रयोनिषु॥ योत्स्यन्ति युधि विक्रम्य शत्रुभिस्त्व पार्थिव। गदाभिर्मुसलैः शूलैः शस्त्रैरुच्चावचैस्तथा॥
English Translation: At that fearful moment, when Kiritin (the diadem-decked Arjuna) greatly excited, with the Gandiva in his hands, bent almost to a circle, assailed his enemies the loud twang of his bow resounded through the skies and the birds being afraid took refuge in caves and mountains.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यच्च तेऽन्तर्गतं वीर भयमर्जुनसम्भवम्। तत्रापि विहितोऽस्माभिर्वधोपायोऽर्जुनस्य वै॥
English Translation: The redoubtable Bhimasena followed Arjuna on his car guarding the rear and both the princes fighting their way on their respective cars advanced fast towards Karna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हतस्य नरकस्यात्मा कर्णमूर्तिमुपाश्रितः। तद् वैरं संस्मरन् वीर योत्स्यते केशवार्जुनौ॥
English Translation: In the meantime the son of Suta had been fighting terribly-he repeatedly thrashed the Somakas and and killed killed large numbers of elephants, horses and car-warriors; in fact he covered the atmosphere with his shafts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स ते विक्रमशौटीरो रणे पार्थं विजेष्यति। कर्णः प्रहरतां श्रेष्ठः सर्वांश्चारीन् महारथः॥
English Translation: Then Uttamaujas, Janamejaya, the wrathful Yudhamanyu, Shikhandin and Prishatha's son Dhristadumnya all in a body fiercely attacked Karna with many weapons and with loud roars.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ज्ञात्वैतच्छद्मना वली रक्षार्थं सव्यसाचिनः। कुण्डले कवचं चैव कर्णस्यापहरिष्यति॥
English Translation: As the objects of senses cannot extract the purity out of a holy man, so those five best Panchala warriors, though they tried their utmost, could not shake Vaikartana (Karna) from off his car.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मादस्माभिरप्यत्र दैत्याः शतसहस्रशः। नियुक्ता राक्षसाश्चैव ये ते संशप्तका इति॥
English Translation: Karna, with his arrows very soon rending asunder their bows, arrows, drivers and banners and striking each of them with five arrows, gave vent to a loud shout that resembled the roar of a lion.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रख्यातास्तेऽर्जुनं वीरं हनिष्यन्ति च मा शुचः। असपत्ना त्वया हीयं भोक्तव्या वसुधा नृप॥
English Translation: When Karna was thus distressing his enemies with his bow and arrows in hand the whole world, with its mountains and trees, seemed to spilt into pieces by the loud twang of his bow and people became afraid.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मा विषादं गमस्तस्मान्नैतत्त्वय्युपपद्यते। विनष्टे त्वयि चास्माकं पक्षो हीयेत कौरव॥
English Translation: The son of Adhiratha, with his large bow like that of Shakra fully drawn, went on throwing his arrows; indeed in that fight he looked brilliant like the sun with his firing rays in the midst of his corona.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गच्छ वीर न ते बुद्धिरन्या कार्या कथञ्चन। त्वमस्माकं गतिर्नित्यं देवतानां च पाण्डवाः॥
English Translation: Suta's son then struck Shikhandin with twelve keen shafts, Uttamaujas with six and Yudhamanyu, Janmeyaya and Dhristadyumna with three each.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच एवमुक्त्वा परिष्वज्य दैत्यास्तं राजकुञ्जरम्। समाश्वास्य च दुर्धर्षं पुत्रवद् दानवर्षभाः॥
English Translation: O respected king, as the objects of senses are conquered by a holy man of abstinence, so those five great warriors, overpowered by Suta's son in that dreadful fight, became confounded and inactive to the great delight of their enemy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्थिरां कृत्वा बुद्धिमस्य प्रियाण्युक्त्वा च भारत। गम्यतामित्यनुज्ञाय जयमाप्नुहि चेत्यथ॥
English Translation: As ship-wrecked merchants are saved from drowning in a deep sea by means of other ships, so did the sons of Draupadi, with the help of their cars, save their maternal uncles from sinking under the pressure of Karna's weapons who resembled the sea.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तैर्विसृष्टं महाबाहुं कृत्या सैवानयत् पुनः। तमेव देशं यत्रासौ तदा प्रायमुपाविशत्॥
English Translation: Then the most powerful of the Shinis (Satyaki) cut-off all the sharp arrows of Karna and struck him with many sharp arrows purely made of iron and your eldest son, Duryodhana, with eight.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रतिनिक्षिप्य त वीरं कृत्या समभिपूज्य च। अनुज्ञाता च राज्ञा सा तथैवान्तरधीयत॥
English Translation: Then Kripa, the Bhoja king, your son and Karna himself assaulted Satyaki in return with many sharp arrows, but that best of Yadu's race fought with those four great warriors as did the king of Daityas with the regents of the four quarters.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गतायामथ तस्यां तु राजा दुर्योधनस्तदा। स्वप्नभूतमिदं सर्वमचिन्तयत भारत॥ विजेष्यामि रणे पाण्डूनिति चास्याभवन्मतिः।
English Translation: As in autumn the Sun shines brilliantly in the sky, so with his outstretched bow, which was sounding loudly and sending forth arrows unrestrainedly, Satyaki became hard to face.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्ण संशप्तकांश्चैव पार्थस्यामित्रघातिनः॥ अमन्यत वधे युक्तान् समर्थांश्च सुयोधनः।
English Translation: As the Maruts helped Shakra (Indra) when he distressed his enemies, so the great Panchala car-warriors-the distressers of their enemies-all clothed in coats of mail, collected together, getting back upon their cars and protected that greatest man of the line of Shini.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमाशा दृढा तस्य धार्तराष्ट्रस्य दुर्मतेः॥ विनिजये पाण्डवानामभवद् भरतर्षभ।
English Translation: Many elephants, horses and men were then killed in that fight that took place between your enemies and your troops and it caged as hot and fierce as was the great battle which ensued between the Gods and the Asuras, in days of yore.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्णोऽप्याविष्टचित्तात्मा नरकस्यान्तरात्मना॥ अर्जुनस्य वधे क्रूरां करोति स्म तदा मतिम्।
English Translation: All the infantry, car-warriors, elephants and steeds distressed with various weapons and struck by each other they began to move about sending forth dolorous cries of woe; some tumbled while other dropped down dead as they moved.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संशप्तकाच ते वीरा राक्षसाविष्टचेतसः॥ रजस्तमोभ्यामाक्रान्ता: फाल्गुनस्य वधैषिणः।
English Translation: At that time your son Dushasana, the younger brother of the king, boldly going up to Bhimasena, shot hosts of shafts against him and Vrikodara like a lion taking his leap upon a big Ruru (deer) swiftly made a rush towards him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्मद्रोणकृपाद्याश्च दानवाक्रान्तचेतसः॥ न तथा पाण्डुपुत्राणां स्नेहवन्तो विशाम्पते। न चाचचक्षे कस्मैचिदेतद् राजा सुयोधनः॥
English Translation: As in days of yore Shakra and Shamvara fight with each other, so did those two brave warriors, both panting for revenge, fight with each other making their very lives the wager of the fight.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुर्योधनं निशान्ते च कर्णो वैकर्तनोऽब्रवीत्। स्मयन्निवाञ्जलिं कृत्वा पार्थिवं हेतुमद् वचः॥
English Translation: As two lustful elephants fight for a sheelephant with fatty secretions streaming down their bodies, so did they strike each other with powerful and piercing shafts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न मृतो जयते शत्रूञ्जीवन् भद्राणि पश्यति। मृतस्य भद्राणि कुतः कौरवेय कुतो जयः॥
English Translation: Then Vrikodara with two razor-like shafts struck off the banner and the bow and the arrows of your son and with another winged arrow he hurt him on the forehead and with a fourth, he severed the head his charioteer.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न कालोऽद्य विषादस्य भयस्य मरणस्य वा। परिष्वज्याब्रवीच्चैनं भुजाभ्यां स महाभुजः॥
English Translation: Prince Dushasana, taking up another bow, hit Bhima with twelve arrows and taking hold of the reins of his horses rained upon Bhima hosts of shafts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उत्तिष्ठ राजन् किं शेषे कस्माच्छोचसि शत्रुइन्। शत्रुन् प्रताप्य वीर्येण स कथं मृत्युमिच्छसि॥
English Translation: Then Dushasana sent against Bhima an arrow worked with gold, diamond and other valuable gems and brilliant as the sun's rays, deadly and powerful as Indra's thunder.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथवा ते भयं जातं दृष्ट्वार्जुनपराक्रमम्। सत्यं ते प्रतिजानामि वधिष्यामि रणेऽर्जुनम्॥
English Translation: Vrikodara being struck by that weapon with outstretched arms fell down on his car like one dead and powerless, but again regaining his senses he began to roar like a lion.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गते त्रयोदशे वर्षे सत्येनायुधमालभे। आनयिष्याम्यहं पार्थान् वशं तव जनाधिप॥
English Translation: Markandeya said : Mudita, the favourite wife of the fire named Svaha, live in water. Svaha who was the lord of the sky, begot on his that wife a greatly sacred fire named Adbhuta. There is a tradition among the Brahmanas, namely that this fire is the ruler and the inner soul of all creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्तस्तु कर्णेन दैत्यानां वचनात् तथा। प्रणिपातेन चाप्येषामुदतिष्ठत् सुयोधनः॥
English Translation: That fire is adorable and effulgent, he is the lord of all the Bhutas here. And that fire under the name of Grihapati is always worshipped at all sacrifices and conveys all the oblations that are made in this world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दैत्यानां तद् वचः श्रुत्वा हदि कृत्वा स्थिरां मतिम्। ततो मनुजशार्दूलो योजयामास वाहिनीम्॥ रथनागाश्वकलिला पदातिजनसंकुलाम्। गगौघप्रतिमा राजन् सा प्रयाता महाचमूः॥
English Translation: That great son of Svaha, the great Adbhuta fire, is the soul of the waters and the prince and the regent of the sky and the lord of everything great.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्वेतच्छत्रैः पताकाभिश्चामरैश्च सुपाण्डुरैः। स्थैर्नागैः पदातैश्च शुशुभेऽतीव संकुला॥ व्यपेताभ्रघने काले द्यौरिवाव्यक्तशारदी।
English Translation: His son, the Bharata fire, consumes the dead bodies of all creatures. His first Kratu is known as Niyata at the performance of Agnishtoma.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जयाशीभिर्द्विजेन्द्रैः स स्तूयमानोऽधिराजवत्॥ गृहणन्नञ्जलिमालाश्च धार्तराष्ट्रो जनाधिपः। सुयोधनो ययावचे श्रिया परमया ज्वलन्।॥
English Translation: That mighty chief fire (Svaha) is always missed by the celestials, for when he sees Niyata coming towards him, he hides himself in the sea for fear.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्णेन सार्धं राजेन्द्र सौबलेन च देविना। दुःशासनादयश्चास्य भ्रातरः सर्व एव ते॥ भूरिश्रवाः सोमदत्तो महाराजश्च बाह्निकः। स्थैर्नानाविधाकारैर्हयैर्गजधरैस्तथा॥ प्रयान्तं नृपसिंहं तमनुजग्मुः कुरूद्वहाः। कालेनाल्पेन राजेन्द्र स्वपुरं विविशुस्तदा॥
English Translation: Seeing him in every direction, the celestials could not find him out and seeing Atharvan, the fire thus spoke to him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अष्टक उवाच चरन् गृहस्थः कथमेति धर्मान् कथं भिक्षुः कथमाचार्यकर्मा। वानप्रस्थः सत्पथे संनिविष्टो बहून्यस्मिन् सम्प्रति वेदयन्ति॥
English Translation: O hero, carry the oblations for the celestials. I am unable to do it for the want of strength. Becoming the red-eyed fire, be good enough to do me this favour.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ययातिरुवाच आहूताध्यायी गुरुकर्मस्वचोद्यः पूर्वोत्थायी चरमं चोपशायी। मृदुर्दान्तो धृतिमानप्रमत्तः ध्यायशील: सिध्यति ब्रह्मचारी॥
English Translation: Having thus spoken to Atharvan, the fire went away to some other place. But his place of concealment was divulged by the fish, Upon them he passed this course in anger.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धर्मागतं प्राप्य धनं यजेत दद्यात् सदैवातिथीन् भोयजेच्च। अनाददानश्च परैरदत्तं सैषा गृहस्थोपनिषत् पुराणी॥
English Translation: You shall be the food of all creatures in various ways." Then the fire spoke to Atharvan (again as he did before).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्ववीर्यजीवी वृजिनान्निवृत्तो दाता परेभ्यो न परोपतापी। तादृङ्मुनिः सिद्धिमुपैति मुख्यां वसन्नरण्ये नियताहारचेष्टः॥
English Translation: Though entreated by the celestials, he did not agree to continue to carry the oblations. He then became insensible and abandoned his body.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अशिल्पजीवी गुणवांश्चैव नित्यं जितेन्द्रियः सर्वतो विप्रयुक्तः। श्चरन् देशानेकचरः स भिक्षुः॥
English Translation: Leaving his material body, he entered into the nether world. Coming in contact with the earth, he created different force and perfume arose from his puss, the Deodar tree from his bones, grass from this phlegm, the Marakata jewel from his bile and the black iron from his liver. All the worlds have been established with these three substances. The clouds were made from his nails and corals from his arteries,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रात्र्या यया वाभिजिताच लोका भवन्ति कामाभिजिताः सुखाचा नरण्यसंस्थो भवितुं यतात्मा॥ दशैव पूर्वान् दश चापरांश्च ज्ञातीनथात्मानमथैकविंशम्। अरण्यवासी सुकृते दधाति विमुच्यारण्ये स्वशरीरधातून्॥
English Translation: O King, various other metals were produced from his body. Thus leaving his material body, he lay absorbed in meditation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अष्टक उवाच कतिस्विदेव मुनयः कति मौनानि चाप्युत। भवन्तीति तदाचक्ष्व श्रोतुच्छिामहे वयम्॥
English Translation: He was roused by the penance of Bhrigu and Angirasa. The mighty Agni, thus gratified by their penance, blazed forth in great effulgence.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ययातिरुवाच अरण्ये वसतो यस्य ग्रामो भवति पृष्ठतः। ग्रामे वा वसतोऽरण्यं स मुनिः स्याजनाधिप॥
English Translation: But seeing the Rishi, he in fear again entered the great ocean. When he thus disappeared, all the worlds were filled with fear and came to Atharvan for protection. The celestials and others then began to adore Atharvan.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अष्टक उवाच कथंस्विद् वसतोऽरण्ये ग्रामो भवति पृष्ठतः। ग्रामे वा वसतोऽरण्यं कथं भवति पृष्ठतः॥
English Translation: Atharvan overhauled the whole sea and (at last) finding Agni, he himself (then) began the creation. Thus the fire was destroyed and rescued from the sea. thus was he revived by the exalted Atharvan; and thus from that time he always carries the oblations of all creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ययातिरुवाच न ग्राम्यमुपयुञ्जीत य आरण्यो मुनिर्भवेत्। तथास्य वसतोऽरण्ये ग्रामो भवति पृष्ठतः॥
English Translation: Living in the sea and travelling in various countries, he produced the various fires mentioned in the Shastras.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनग्निरनिकेतश्चाप्यगोत्रचरणो मुनिः। कौपीनाच्छादनं यावत् तावदिच्छेच चीवरम्॥ यावत् प्राणाभिसंधानं तावदिच्छेच भोजनम्। तथास्य वसतो ग्रामेऽरण्यं भवति पृष्ठतः॥ यस्तु कामान् परित्यज्य त्यक्तकर्मा जितेन्द्रियः। आतिष्ठेच मुनिर्मीनं स लोके सिद्धिमाप्नुयात्॥
English Translation: The river Sindhu, the five rivers, the Devika, the Sarasvati, the Ganga, the Shatakumbha, the Sarayu, the Gandaki, the Charmnavati, the Mahi, the Medhya, the Medhatithi, the three rivers Tamravati, the Vetravati, the Kaushiki, the Tamasa, the Narmada, the Godavari, the Vena, the Upavena, the Bhima, the Vadava, the Bharati, the Suprayoga, the Kaveri, the Murmura, the Tungavena, the Krishnavena, the Kapila and the Sonabhadra, these rivers are said to be the mothers of the fires.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धौतदन्तं कृत्तनखं सदा स्नातमलंकृतम्। असितं सितकर्माणं कस्तमर्हति नार्चितुम्॥
English Translation: Adbhuta had a wife named Priya and Vibhurasi was his eldest son. There are as many kinds of Soma sacrifices as the number of fires mentioned. All these fires were first born from the spirit of Brahma, but they also sprung from the race of Atri.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तपसा कर्शितः क्षामः क्षीणमांसास्थिशोणितः। स च लोकमिमं जित्वा लोकं विजयते परम्॥
English Translation: He in his own mind conceived these sons in order to extend the creation. These fires all sprung from his Brahmic body.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदा भवति निर्द्वन्द्वो मुनिर्मौनं समास्थितः। अथ लोकमिमं जित्वा लोकं विजयते परम्॥
English Translation: I have thus narrated to you the history of the origin of the (different) fires. They are great, effulgent and matchless in prowess; and they are the destroyer of darkness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आस्येन तु यदाहारं गोवन्मृगयते मुनिः। अथास्य लोकः सर्वोऽयं सोऽमृतत्वाय कल्पते॥
English Translation: Know that the prowess of all fires is the same as that of the Adbhuta fire as described in the Vedas. All these fires are one and the same.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सौतिरुवाच स चापि च्यवनो ब्रह्मम्भार्गवोऽजनयत्सुतम्। सुकन्यायां महात्मानं प्रमतिं दीप्ततेजसम्॥
English Translation: This adorable and exalted being, the firstborn fire, must be considered as all the fires, for like the Jyotishtoma sacrifice, he came out of Angira's body in various forms.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रमतिस्तु रुरुं नाम घृताच्यां समजीजनत्। रुरुः प्रमद्वरायां तु शुनकं समजीजनत्॥
English Translation: I have thus told you the history of the great Agni race. When duly worshipped with hymns they carry the oblations of all creatures to the celestials.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य ब्रह्मन् रुरोः सर्वं चरितं भूरितेजसः। विस्तरेण प्रवक्ष्यामि तच्छृणु त्वमशेषतः॥
English Translation: Krishna said : O king of kings, the lord of Saubha Shalva, came to the city of Dvarka with numerous men, elephants and soldiers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ऋषिरासीन्महान्पूर्वं तयोविद्यासमन्वितः। स्थूलकेश इति ख्यातः सर्वभूतहिते रतः॥
English Translation: The army, headed by king Shalva, consisting of four kinds of troops, occupied a level ground where there was plentiful supply of water.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतस्मिन्नेव काले तु मेनकायां प्रजज्ञिवान्। गन्धर्वराजो विप्रर्षे विश्वावसुरिति स्मृतः॥
English Translation: Avoiding cremation-grounds, temples of gods, sacred trees and grounds covered with ant-hills, his army occupied every other places.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अप्सरा मेनका तस्य तं गर्भं भृगुनन्दन। उत्ससर्ज यथाकालं स्थूलकेशाश्रमं प्रति॥
English Translation: O king, the roads (leading to Dvarka) were all blocked up by the (various) divisions of his army and the secret passages (from the city) were also all blocked up by the encampment of Shalva's troops.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उत्सृज्य चैव तं गर्भ नद्यास्तीरे जगाम सा। अप्सरा मेनका ब्रह्मन्निर्दया निरपत्रपा॥
English Translation: O descendant of Kuru, O best of men, like the king of birds (Garuda), he rushed upon Dvarka, with his army, equipped with every kind of weapons, skilled in all arms, furnished with numerous chariots, elephants and cavalry, full of pennons and banners and strengthened with well-paid, well-fed and greatly powerful foot soldiers who bore every mark of heroism and who used wonderful chariots and bows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कन्यामरगर्भाभा ज्वलन्तीमिव च श्रिया। तां ददर्श समुत्सृष्टां नदीतीरे महानृषिः॥ स्थूलकेशः स तेजस्वी विजने बन्धुवर्जिताम्। स तां दृष्ट्वा तदा कन्यां स्थूलकेशो महाद्विजः॥
English Translation: Seeing the army of the king Shalva approached, the youthful princes of the Vrishni race sallied out with the desire of giving him battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जग्राह च मुनिश्रेष्ठः कृपाविष्टः पुपोष च। ववृधे सा वरारोहा तस्याश्रमपदे शुभे॥
English Translation: O descendant of Kuru, without being able to bear the pride of king Shalva, Charudeshna, Samba and the great car-warrior, Pradyumna. Clad in armour and adorned with ornaments with color flying, sallied out on their chariots, with the desire of meeting the numerous great warriors of king Shalva.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जातकाद्याः क्रियाश्चास्या विधिपूर्वं यथाक्रमम्। स्थूलकेशो महाभागश्चकार सुमहानृषिः॥
English Translation: Samba, taking up his bow, eagerly attacked on the field of battle Kshemavriddhi, the minister and the commander of Shalva's army.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रमदाभ्यो वरा सा तु सत्त्वरूपगुणान्विता। ततः प्रमद्वरेत्यस्या नाम चक्रे महानृषिः॥
English Translation: O best of the Bharata race, as Indra shower down rain, so did the son of Jambhavati (Samba) showers down arrows in a continuous stream. O great king, the commander of (Shalva's) forces, Kshemavriddhi, bore that shower of arrows (and stood) as immovable as the Himalayas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तामाश्रमपदे तस्य रुरुर्दृष्ट्वा प्रमद्वराम्। बभूव किल धर्मात्मा मदनोहतस्तदा॥
English Translation: O king of kings, thereupon Kshemavriddhi, aided by his power of illusion, poured a great shower of arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पितरं सखिभिः सोऽथ श्रावयामास भार्गवम्। प्रमतिश्चाभ्ययाचत्तां स्थूलकेशं यशस्विनम्॥
English Translation: Then dispersing by counter illusion that shower of arrows aided by illusion, Samba showered on his (adversary's) car one thousand arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः प्रादात्पिता कन्यां रुरवे तां प्रमद्वराम्। विवाहं स्थापयित्वाऽग्रे नक्षत्रे भगदैवते॥
English Translation: Then pierced and overwhelmed by the arrows of Samba, the commander of (Shalva's) forces, Kshemavriddhi fled from the field with the help of his fleet steeds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः कतिपयाहस्य विवाहे समुपस्थिते। सखीभिः क्रीडती सार्धं सा कन्या वरवर्णिनी॥
English Translation: When the crooked-minded commander of Shalva's army fled from the field, a powerful Daitya, named Vegavan, rushed at my son.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नापश्यत्संप्रसुप्तं वै भुजंगं तिर्यगायतम्। पदा चैनं समाक्रामन्मुमूर्षुःकालचोदिता॥
English Translation: O king of kings, thus attacked the heroic Samba, the perpetuator of the Vrishni race, withstanding the attack of Vegavan, kept his ground.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तस्याः संप्रमत्तायाश्चोदितः कालधर्मणा। विषोपलिप्तान्दशनाम्भृशमङ्गे न्यपातयत्॥
English Translation: O son of Kunti, the heroic and irresistibly powerful Samba, whirling a swift-going club, soon hurled it at Vegavan.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सा दष्टा तेन सर्पण पपात सहसा भुवि। विवर्णा विगतश्रीका भ्रष्टाभरणचेतना॥
English Translation: O king, thus struck with it, Vegavan fell on the ground like a faded, weather beaten and decayed-rooted lord of the forest (banian tree).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निरानन्दकरी तेषां बधूनां मुक्तमूर्धजा। व्यसुरप्रेक्षणीया सा प्रेक्षणीयतमाऽभवत्॥
English Translation: When that heroic and great Asura was killed with the club, my son rushed into (enemy's) troops and began to fight with all.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रसुप्तेवाभवच्चापि भुवि सर्पविषार्दिता। भूयो मनोहरतरा बभूव तनुमध्यमा॥
English Translation: O great king, a well-known Danava, named Vivindha, a great car-warrior and a great bowman, then rushed upon Charudeshna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ददर्श तां पिता चैव ये चैवान्ये तपस्विनः। विचेष्टमानां पतितां भूतले पद्मवर्चसम्॥
English Translation: O king, the battle between Charudeshna and Vivindha was as fierce as that in the days of yore between Vitra and Vasava (Indra).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः सर्वे द्विजवराः समाजग्मुः कृपान्विताः। स्वस्त्यात्रेयो महाजानुः कुशिकः शंखमेखलः॥
English Translation: Enraged with each other, the combatants pierced each other with their arrows and uttered loud roars like two powerful lions.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उद्दालकः कठश्चैव श्वेतश्चैव महायशाः। । भरद्वाजः कौणकुत्स्य आर्टिषेणोऽथ गौतमः॥
English Translation: Having first vivified it with incantations the son of Rukmini fixed on his bow-string a powerful weapon which possessed possessed the splendour of the sun or the fire and which was capable of destroying all foes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रमति: सहपुत्रेण तथाऽन्ये वनवासिनः। तां ते कन्यां व्यसुं दृष्ट्वा भुजंगस्य विषार्दिताम्।। रुरुदुः कृपयाविष्टा रुरुस्त्वार्तो बहिर्ययौ। ते च सर्वे द्विजश्रेष्ठास्तत्रैवोपाविशंस्तदा।॥
English Translation: O king, that great car-warrior, my son, inflamed with anger, challenged Vivindha and discharged the weapon at him. He (thus struck) fell dead.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच स शत्रुसेनां तरसा प्रणुद्य गास्ता विजित्याथ धनुर्धरा. गोषु प्रयातासु दुर्योधनायाभिमुखं प्रयातो भूयो रणं सोऽभिचिकीर्षमाणः॥
English Translation: Seeing Vivindha killed and his army (very much) agitated, Shalva came back again on his (car) Saubha, capable of going everywhere at will.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जवेन मत्स्यान् किरीटिनं कृतकार्यं च मत्वा। दुर्योधनायाभिमुखं प्रयातं कुरुप्रवीराः सहसा निपेतुः॥
English Translation: O mighty-armed king, thereupon seeing Shalva seated on his (car) Saubha, the warriors of Dvarka became very much alarmed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषामनीकानि बहूनि गाढं व्यूढानि दृष्ट्वा बहुलध्वजानि। मत्स्यस्य पुत्रं द्विषतां निहन्ता वैराटिमामन्त्र्य ततोऽभ्युवाच॥
English Translation: O descendant of Kuru, Pradyumna sallied out and asked the Anarthas not to lose courage. He then thus spoke.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतेन तूर्णं प्रतिपादयेमान् श्वेतान् हयान् काञ्चनरश्मियोक्त्रान्। जवेन सर्वेण कुरु प्रयत्नमासादयेऽहं कुरुसिंहवृन्दम्॥
English Translation: (O warriors), do not lose courage; stay and see me fight. I shall repel with force (the car) Saubha with the king (Shalva) on it.
O Yadavas, I shall this day destroy the army of the lord of Saubha with my serpent-like weapons discharged from my bow with my hand.
Be of good cheer, Fear not. I shall today kill him. Attacked by me, the wicked-minded (Shalva) with (his car) SAubha will be destroyed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गजो गजेनेव मया दुरात्मा योद्धं समाकाङ्क्षति सूतपुत्रः। तमेव मां प्रापय राजपुत्र दुर्योधनापाश्रयजातदर्पम्॥
English Translation: O son of Pandu, O hero, when Pradyumna thus spoke with a cheerful heart, the Yadava warriors stood on the field and began to fight cheerfully.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तैर्हयैर्वातजवैर्वृहद्धिः पुत्रो विराटस्य सुवर्णकः। व्यध्वंसयत् तद् रथिनामनीकं ततोऽवहत् पाण्डवमाजिमध्ये॥
English Translation: Bhishma said That best of all persons conversant with the Vedas, viz., Utatthya of Angirasa's family, discoursed gladly to Yuvanashva's son Mandhatri.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं चित्रसेनो विशिखैर्विपाठः संग्रामजिच्छत्रुसहो जयश्च। प्रत्युद्ययुर्भारतमापतन्तं महारथाः कर्णमभीप्समानाः॥
English Translation: I shall now, O Yudhishthira, relate to you every thing that Utatthya, that foremost of all perscns conversant with the Vedas, had said to that king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः स तेषां पुरुषप्रवीरः शरासनार्चिः शरवेगतापः। वातं रथानामदहत् समन्युर्वनं यथाग्निः कुरुपुङ्गवानाम्॥
English Translation: Utatthya said One becomes a king for advancing the cause of virtue and not for acting capriciously. Know this, O Mandhatri; the king is, indeed, the protector of the world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मिंस्तु युद्धे तुमुले प्रवृत्ते पार्थ विकर्णोऽतिरथं रथेन। विपाठवर्षेण कुरुप्रवीरो भीमेन भीमानुजमससाद॥
English Translation: If the king acts piously, he attains to the dignity of a god. If, however, he acts unrighteously, he sinks into hell.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो विकर्णस्य धनुर्विकृष्य जाम्बूनदाङ्मयोपचितं दृढज्यम्। च्छिन्नध्वजः सोऽप्यपयाज्ज्वेन।॥
English Translation: All cri itures depends upon righteousness. Righteousness again depends upon the king. men That king, therefore, who maintains righteousness, is truly a king, that king who has a pious soul and posseses every kind of accomplishments is said to be an embodiment of virtue. If a king fails to punish iniquity, the god leave his palace and he incurs disreputation among men.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं शात्रवाणां गणबाधितारं कर्माणि कुर्वन्तममानुपाणि। शत्रुतपः पार्थममृष्यमाण: समार्दयच्छर वर्षेण पार्थम्॥
English Translation: The endeavours of men who observe their own duties are always successful. Therefore all try to obey the injunctions of righteousness which yield prosperity.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तेन राज्ञातिरथेन विद्धो विगाहमानो ध्वजिनी कुरूणाम्। शतपं पञ्चभिराशु विद्धा 'ततोऽस्य सूतं दशभिर्जघान॥
English Translation: When sin is not restrained righteousness disappears and unrighteousness multiplies itself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः स विद्धो भरतर्षभेण बाणेन गात्रावरणातिगेन। गतासुराजौ निपपात भूमौ नगो नगाग्रादिव वातरुग्णः॥
English Translation: When sin is not restrained, no one can, in view of the rights of property as sanctioned by the scriptures, say,-This thing is mine and this is not mine.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नरर्षभास्तेन नरर्षभेण वीरा रणे वीरतरेण भग्नाः। चकम्पिरे वातवशेन काले प्रकम्पितानीव महावनानि॥
English Translation: When sinfulness reigns rampant in the world, men cannot own and enjoy their own wives and animals and fields and houses.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तास्तु पार्थेन नरप्रवीरा गतासवोर्त्यां सुषुपुः सुवेषाः। वसुप्रदा वासवतुल्यवीर्याः पराजिता वासवजेन संख्ये॥
English Translation: When sin is not restrained the deities get no adorations, the Pitris no offerings in Shraddhas, and guests no hospitality.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुवर्णकार्णायसवर्मनद्धा नागा यता हैमवता: प्रवृद्धाः। तथा स शत्रून् समरे विनिघ्नन्। गाण्डीवधन्वा पुरुषप्रवीरः॥
English Translation: When sinfulness is not restrained, the twice-born ones do not study the Vedas, or practise high vows, or perform sacrifices.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चचार संख्ये विदिशो दिशश्च दहन्निवाग्निर्वनमातपान्ते। प्रकीर्णपर्णानि यथा वसन्ते विशातयित्वा पवनोऽम्बुदांश्च॥
English Translation: When sin is not restrained, the minds of men, O king, become weak and bewildered like those of persons wounded with weapons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथा सपत्नान् विकिरन् किरीटी चचार संख्येऽतिरथो रथेन। शोणाश्ववाहस्य हयान् निहत्य वैकर्तनभ्रातुरदीनसत्त्वः। एकेन संग्रामजितः शरेण किरीटमाली।॥
English Translation: Looking on both the worlds, the Rishis made the king, that best of men, with a view that he should be righteousness incarnate on Earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मिन् हते भ्रातरि सूतपुत्रो वैकर्तनो वीर्यमथाददानः। प्रगृह्य दन्ताविव नागराजो महर्षभं व्याघ्र इवाभ्यधावत्॥ (कर्तनः शीघ्रमथो जघान। शिरो जहाराथ
English Translation: He is called Rajan in whom righteousness predominates. That king, again, in whom there is no righteousness, is called a Vrishala.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विव्याध गात्रेषु हयांश्च सर्वान् विराटपुत्रं च करे निजघ्ने॥ तमापतन्तं सहसा किरीटी वैकर्तनं वै तरसाभिपत्य। प्रगृह्य वेगं न्यपतज्जवेन नागं गरुत्मानिव चित्रपक्षः॥
English Translation: Righteousness has another name, viz., Vrisha. He who weakens Vrisha passes by the name of Vrishala. A king should, therefore, further the cause of Righteousness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तावुत्तमौ सर्वधनुर्धराणां महाबलौ सर्वसपत्नसाहौ। कर्णस्य पार्थस्य निशम्य युद्धं दिदृक्षमाणाः कुरवोऽभितस्थुः॥
English Translation: All creatures prosper by the growth of righteousness and deteriorate with its decay. Righteousness, therefore, should never be suffered to decay.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स पाण्डवस्तूर्णमुदीर्णकोपः कृतागसं कर्णमुदीक्ष्य हर्षात्। मन्तर्दधे घोरशरौघवृष्ट्या॥
English Translation: Righteousness is called Dharma, because it helps the acquisition and preservation of wealth. The sages, O king, have declared that the Dharma restrains and limits all evils acts of men.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः सुविद्धाः सरथाः सनागा योधा विनेदुर्भरतर्षभाणाम्। अन्तर्हिता भीष्ममुखाः सहाश्वाः किरीटिना कीर्णरथाः पृषत्कैः॥
English Translation: The Self-create created Dharma for the aggrandisement and growth of creatures. Therefore, a king should follow the dictates of Dharma for benefiting his people.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: छराज्छरौघैः प्रतिहत्य वीरः। तस्थौ महात्मा सधनुः सबाणः सविस्फुलिङ्गोऽग्निरिवाशु कर्णः॥
English Translation: Therefore also, O foremost of kings' Dharma has been said to be the highest of all things. That best of men who governs his subjects righteously is called a king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्त्वभूद् वै तलतालशब्दः सशङ्खभेरीपणवप्रणादः। प्रक्ष्वेडितज्यातलनिस्वनं तं वैकर्तनं पूजयतां कुरूणाम्॥
English Translation: Disregarding lust and anger follow the dictates of righteousness. Of all things, O chief of Bharata's race, which secure the prosperity of kings, righteousness is the foremost.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ध्वजोत्तमांसाकुलभीषणान्तम्। गाण्डीवनिर्हादकृतप्रणादं किरीटिनं प्रेक्ष्य ननाद कर्णः॥
English Translation: Dharma, again, has originated from the Brahmana. Therefore, the Brahmana should always be adored. You, should, O Mandhatri, satisfy humbly the wishes of Brahmanas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स चापि वैकर्तनमर्दयित्वा साश्वं ससूतं सरथं पृषत्कैः। तमाववर्ष प्रसभं किरीटी पितामहं द्रोणकृपौ च दृष्ट्वा॥ (कर्तनो मेघ इवाभ्यवर्षत्। तथैव कर्णं च किरीटमाली संछादयामास शितैः पृषत्कैः॥
English Translation: Neglecting to please Brahmanas the king brings danger on himself, for such neglect, he cannot acquire friends while his enemies multiply.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तयोः सुतीक्ष्णान् सृजतोः शरौधान् महाशरौघास्त्रविवर्धने रणे। रथे विलग्नाविव चन्द्रसूर्यो घनान्तरेणानुददर्श लोकः॥
English Translation: For entertaining malice out of folly towards the Brahmanas, the goddess of prosperity who had formerly lived with him became irate and deserted the Asura Vali the son of Virochana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथाशुकारी चतुरो हयांश्च विव्याध को निशितैः किरीटिनः। त्रिभिश्च यन्तारममृष्यमाणो विव्याध तूर्णं त्रिभिरस्य केतुम्॥
English Translation: Deserting the Asura she went to Indra the king of gods. Seeing the goddess living with Purandara, Vali regretted idly.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽभिविद्धः समरावमर्दी प्रबोधितः सिंह इव प्रसुप्तः। मजिह्मगैः कर्णमियाय जिष्णुः॥
English Translation: This, O powerful one, is the outcome of malice and pride. Be you awakened, O Mandhatri, so that the goddess of prosperity ! may not in anger desert you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शरास्त्रवृष्ट्या निहतो महात्मा प्रादुश्चकारातिमनुष्यकर्म। र्लोकानिमान् सूर्यं इवांशुजालैः॥
English Translation: The Shrutis say that unrighteousness beget a son named Pride upon the goddess of prosperity. This Pride, O king, brought ruin upon many among the gods and the Asuras.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स हस्तिनेवाभिहतो गजेन्द्रः प्रगृह्य भल्लान् निशितान् निषङ्गात्। आकर्णपूर्णं च धनुर्विकृष्य विव्याध गात्रेष्वथ सूतपुत्रम्॥
English Translation: Many royal sages were ruined for him. Do you, therefore, awaken, O king, He who can conquer him becomes a king. He, however, who suffers himself to be conquered by him, becomes a slave.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अंथास्य बाहूरुशिरोललाट ग्रीवां वराङ्गानि परावमर्दी। शितैश्च बाणैर्युधि निर्बिभेद गाण्डीवमुक्तैरशनिप्रकाशैः॥
English Translation: If, O Mandhatri, you wish to enjoy a life of perpetual happiness, live as a king should who does not indulge these two, viz., Pride and Unrighteousness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स पार्थमुक्तैरिषुभिः प्रणुन्नो गजो गजेनेव जितस्तरस्वी। विहाय संग्रामशिरः प्रयातो वैकर्तनः पाण्डवबाणतप्तः॥
English Translation: Do not associate with him,—who is intoxicated with pride, who does not follow honesty, who scoffs at religion, who is insensate and negligent in paying homage to all of them even when united.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच एवमुक्तः प्रत्युवाच तं मुनि जनमेजयः। गीं भवान् गर्हयते निन्द्यं निन्दति मां पुनः॥
English Translation: Keep yourself aloof from the company of ministers whom you have once punished and especially of women, as also from mountains and uneven lands and inaccessible forts and elephants and horses and reptiles. You should never wander in the night, and avoid stinginess, vanity, boastfulness, and anger.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धिक्कार्यं मां धिक्कुरुते तस्मात् त्वाहं प्रसादये। सर्वं हीदं दुष्कृतं मे ज्वलाम्यग्नाविवाहितः॥
English Translation: You should never know unknown women, or the eunuchs, or those who are lewd, or those who are the wives of other men, or those who are unmarried.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्वकर्माण्यभिसंधाय नाभिनन्दति मे मनः। प्राप्यं घोरं भयं नूनं मया वैवस्वतादपि॥
English Translation: When the king does not restrain vice, an intermixture of castes follows, and sinful Rakshasas, eunuchs, children destitute of limbs or possessed of thick tongues, and idiots, begin to take birth in even respectable families,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्तु शल्यमनिर्हत्य कथं शक्ष्यामि जीवितुम्। सर्वं मन्यु विनीय त्वमभि मां वद शौनक॥
English Translation: Therefore, the king should take particular care to act righteously for the behoof of his people.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महानासं ब्राह्मणानां भूयो वक्ष्यामि साम्प्रतम्। अस्तु शेषं कुलस्यास्य मा पराभूदिदं कुलम्॥
English Translation: If a king acts heedlessly, it produces a great evil. Unrighteousness multiplies causing an intermixture of castes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न हि नो ब्रह्मशप्तानां शेषं भवितुमर्हति। स्तुतीरलभमानानां संविदं वेदनिश्चितान्॥
English Translation: Cold appears during the summer months, and disappears in its proper season. Drought and flood and pestilence attack the people.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निर्विद्यमानः सुभृशं भूयो वक्ष्यामि शाश्वतम्। भूयश्चैवाभिरक्षन्तु निर्धनान् निर्जना इव॥
English Translation: Evil stars arise and dreadful comets appear on such occasions. Various other portents, presaging destruction of the kingdom, appear.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न ह्ययज्ञा अमुं लोकं प्राप्नुवन्ति कथञ्चन। आपातान् प्रतितिष्ठन्ति पुलिन्दशबरा इव॥
English Translation: If the king does not take steps for his own safety and does not protect his subjects, the latter first meet with destruction which ultimately overtakes the king himself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अविज्ञायैव मे प्रज्ञा बालस्येव स पण्डितः। पुत्रस्य प्रीतिमान् भव शौनक॥
English Translation: Two persons in unision take away the wealth of one, and many acting together rob the two. The virginity of maidens is destroyed. Such a state of things originate from the king's faults.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शौनक उवाच किमाश्चर्यं यदप्राज्ञो बहु कुर्यादसाम्प्रतम्। इति वै पण्डितो भूत्वा भूतानां नानुकुप्यते॥ ब्रह्मन् पितेव
English Translation: All rights of property are destroyed among men, when the king, forsaking righteousness, acts heedlessly.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रज्ञाप्रासादमारुह्य अशोच्यः शोचते जनान्। जगतीस्थानिवांद्रिस्थः प्रज्ञया प्रतिपत्स्यति॥
English Translation: Dhritarashtra said Tell me about the Varsha called Bharata in which these foolish men have assembled (to fight), for which my son Duryodhana has become so very covetous, which the Pandavas also are desirous of obtaining and in which even my mind sinks. Tell me all this, for you are, in my opinion endued with great intelligence.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न चोपलभ्यते तेन न चाश्चर्याणि कुर्वते। निविण्णात्मा परोक्षो वा धिक्कृतः पूर्वसाधुषु॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said O king, hear my words. The Pandavas are not covetous about this country. It is Duryodhana who is covetous. It is the son of Subala, Shakuni.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विदितं भवतो वीर्यं माहात्म्यं वेद आगमे। कुरुष्वेह यथाशान्ति ब्रह्मा शरणमस्तु ते॥ तद् वै पारत्रिकं तात ब्राह्मणानामकुप्यताम्। अथवा तप्यसे पापे धर्ममेवानुपश्य वै॥
English Translation: And also many other Kshatriyas who are rulers of countries and who being covetous of this country cannot tolerate one another,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जनमेजय उवाच अनुतप्ये च पापेन न च धर्मं विलोपये। बुभूधू भजमानं च प्रीतिमान् भव शौनक॥
English Translation: O descendant of Bharata, I shall now speak to you about the country named after Bharata, It is the beloved land of Indra. O king, this land called after Bharata, is also the beloved land of Manu, the son of Vivasvat, of Pritha, of Vainya, of the illustrious Ikshvaku, of Yayati, of Ambarisha, of Mandhata, of Nahusha, of Muchukunda, of Shibi, the son of Ushinaras of Rishabha, of Ila, of king Nriga, of Kushika, of the illustrious Gadhi, of Somaka, and of Dilipa and of many other kings. O chastiser of foes, I shall now describe to you the country as I have heard of it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शौनक उवाच छित्त्वा दम्भं च मानं च प्रीतिमिच्छामि ते नृप। सर्वभूतहितं तिष्ठ धर्मं चैव प्रतिस्मरन्॥
English Translation: O king, hear as I speak of what you have asked me. Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच स गत्वा हास्तिनपुरं नकुलः समितिंजयः। भीष्ममामन्त्रयाञ्चक्रे धृतराष्ट्रं च पाण्डवः॥
English Translation: Besides this country is the abode of many Kshatriyas, Vaishyas and Shudra. There are the Shudraviras, the Daradas, the Kashmiras, the Paitis, the Khashiras, the Atreyas, the Bharadvaja, the Stanopi Shikas, the Poshakas, the Kalingas, and many other Kiratas, the Tomaras, the Hansamargas, and Karamanjakas. These and other kingdoms are in the east and in the north.

Sanskrit Shloka: सत्कृत्यामन्त्रतास्तेन आचार्यप्रमुखास्ततः। प्रययुः प्रीतमनसो यज्ञं ब्रह्मपुरः सराः॥
English Translation: O lord, I have briefly mentioned them. If the resources of the earth are properly developed, she is then like an all-yielding cow, from which the threefold objects of Dharma, Artha and Kama might be linked. Brave kings learned in Dharma and Artha have become covetous of earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संश्रुत्य धर्मराजस्य यज्ञं यज्ञविदस्तदा। अन्ये च शतशस्तुष्टैर्मनोभिर्भरतर्षभ॥ द्रष्टकामाः सभां चैव धर्मराजं च पाण्डवम्। दिग्भ्यः सर्वे समापेतुः क्षत्रियास्तत्र भारत॥
English Translation: From the thirst of wealth, they would even abandon their lives in battle. Earth is the stay of creatures endued with celestial bodies as well as human bodies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: समुपादाय रत्नानि विविधानि महान्ति च। धृतराष्ट्रश्च भीष्मश्च विदुरश्च महामतिः॥
English Translation: O foremost of the Bharata race, with the desire of enjoying earth they have become like dogs that snatch meat from one another.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुर्योधनपुरोगाश्च भ्रातरः सर्व एव ते। गान्धारराजः सुबलः शकुनिश्च महाबलः॥
English Translation: O descendant of Bharata, their ambition is unlimited; it is for this the Kurus and the Pandavas are trying, to get possession of the earth by negotiations, by disunion, by gift and by battle. O foremost of men, if earth be properly treated, she becomes the father, the mother, the children, the sky and the heaven of all creatures.

Sanskrit Shloka: सोमदत्तोऽथ कौरव्यो भूरिभूरिश्रवाः शलः। अश्वत्थामा कृपो द्रोणः सैन्धवश्च जयद्रथः॥
English Translation: Hear, 0 highly intelligent king, the description of that hair-stirring battle that then took place between Drona on the one hand and the Pandavas headed by Yuyudhana on the other.

Sanskrit Shloka: यक्षसेनः सपुत्रश्च शाल्वश्च वसुधाधिपः। प्राग्ज्योतिषश्च नृपतिर्भगदत्तो महारथः॥
English Translation: Then, O sire, beholding the troops slaughtered by Yuyudhana, Drona himself assailed Satyaki of prowess incapable of being baffled.

Sanskrit Shloka: स तु सर्वैः सहम्लेच्छैः सागरानूपवासिभिः। राजानो राजा चैव बृहद्बलः॥ पर्वतीयाच
English Translation: Thereupon Satyaki pierced with five and twenty short arrows that mighty car-warrior the son of Bharadvaja, who had been advancing furiously against him.

Sanskrit Shloka: पौण्ड्रको वासुदेवश्च वङ्गः कालिङ्गकस्तथा। आकर्षाः कुन्तलाश्चैव मालवाश्चान्ध्रकास्तथा॥
English Translation: Drona also, fighting heedfully and putting forth his prowess, quickly pierced Yuyudhana, with five sharp arrows furnished with wings of gold.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्राविडाः सिंहलाश्चैव राजा काश्मीरकस्तथा। कुन्तिभोजो महातेजाः पार्थिवो गौरवाहनः॥
English Translation: These arrows piercing through the tough armour of Satyaki, drank the blood of Drona's enemy; and, O king, they then penetrated into the earth like snakes breathing furiously.

Sanskrit Shloka: वालिकाश्चापरे शूरा राजानः नः सर्व एव ते। विराटः सह पुत्राभ्यां मावेल्लश्च महाबलः॥
English Translation: Then the long-armed Satyaki, like an elephant struck with the hook, became filled with fury; and he then pierced Drona with fifty Narachas, all resembling fire itself.

English Translation: Pierced quickly by Yuyudhana in battle, the son of Bharadvaja, pierced Satyaki who had been fighting vigorously, with countless shafts.

Sanskrit Shloka: गदप्रद्युम्नसाम्बाश्च चारुदेष्णश्च वीर्यवान्। उल्मुको निशद्दश्चैव वीरश्चाङ्गावहस्तथा॥
English Translation: Then again excited to the highest pitch of fury, that fierce bowman endued with great might, once more began to afflict him of the Satvata race, with arrows of depressed knots.

English Translation: Thus repeatedly wounded by Bharadvaja's son in battle, O ruler of men, Satyaki could not decide as to what he should then do.

English Translation: Then, O king Yuyudhana's face became cheerless, as he saw Drona discharge numerous sharp arrows in battle.

English Translation: This fierce bowman Drona is playing with Yuyudhana in battle, like a boy playing with a bird bound with a string.

English Translation: Let every one of my troops headed by Bhimasena and others and accompanied by yourself, rush to the spot where Yuyudhana's chariot is stationed.

English Translation: Supported by my divisions, I will follow behind you. Do you all rescue Satyaki today who is now within the very teeth of death."

English Translation: May good betide you; the din that then arose there, when the Pandavas and the Srinjaya rushed against the single-handed Drona, was indeed very tremendous.

English Translation: They could not then behold the son of Bharadvaja, even as men cannot look at the midday sun of thousand rays, O lord.

English Translation: Then that foremost of all wielders of weapons, viz., Drona afflicted all of them with his myriad shafts, even as the sun afflicts the objects of his earth with his myriad rays.

Though his voice was choked with the vapour of grief and though he was constantly overwhelmed with swoons, yet the king (Yudhishthira) then did not lose sight of what should be done next; and addressing that foremost of the Sinis he then spoke thus
