Sanskrit Shloka: निमज्जतस्तानथ कर्णसागरे विपन्ननावो वणिजो यथार्णवे। उद्दधिरे नौभिरिवार्णवाद् स्थैः सुकल्पितैद्रौपदिजाः स्वमातुलान्॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said O grandson of Sini, the hour for that duty which sages of the past have enjoined to be done towards a friend by a friend in times of nced, has now arrived.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निकृत्य कर्णप्रहितानिघून बहून। स्तवात्मजं ज्येष्ठमविध्यदष्टभिः॥
English Translation: O foremost of the Sinis, thinking within inyself, I cannot find out any one, among all my troops, who is a greater well-wisher of ours than yourself, O Satyaki.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृपोऽथ भोजश्च तवात्मजस्तथा स्वयं च कर्णो निशितैरताडयत्। स तैश्चतुर्भिर्युयुधे यदूत्तमो दिगीश्वरैर्दैत्यपतिर्यथा तथा॥
English Translation: He that is always well-affected, ha that is always obedient, in my opinion, only he should be entrusted with the commission of a serious duty.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: समाततेनेष्वसनेन कूजता भृशायतेनामितबाणवर्षिणा। बभूव दुर्धर्षतरः स सात्यकिः शरन्नभोमध्यगतो यथा रविः॥
English Translation: Just as Keshava is ever devoted to the interests of the Pandavas, so also are you, O you of the Vrishni race, who are equal to Keshava himself in prowess.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुनः समास्थाय रथान् सुदंशिताः शिनिप्रवीरं जुगुपुः परंतपाः। समेत्य पाञ्चालमहारथा रणे मरुद्गणाः शक्रमिवारिनिग्रहे॥
English Translation: I am now going to place a heavy burden on you; and it befits you to bear that burden; it behoves you not to disappoint my hopes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽभवद् युद्धमतीव दारुणं तवाहितानां तव सैनिकैः सह। रथाश्चमातङ्गविनाशनं तथा यथा सुराणामसुरैः पुराभवत्॥
English Translation: O foremost of men, do you now assist Arjuna involved in great distress, who is your friend, brother and your preceptor.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रथा द्विपा वाजिपदातयस्तथा भवन्ति नानाविधशस्त्रवेष्टिताः। विनेदुराती व्यसवोऽपतंस्तथा॥
English Translation: You are ever true to your vows and are endued with heroism and the giver of assurances to you friends. In consequence of your feats, you are renowned in the worlds as one devoted to truthful speech.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथागते भीममभीस्तवात्मजः ससार राजावरजः किरशरैः। तमभ्यधावत् त्वरितो वृकोदरो महारुरुं सिंह इवाभिपोदिवान्॥
English Translation: O grandson of Sini, he that casts off this mortal frame in fighting for the cause of friends, becomes equal to him that gives away the earth as a gift to the twice born ones.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्तयोयुद्धमतीव दारुणं प्रदीव्यतोः प्राणदुरोदरं द्वयोः। रूदग्रयोः शम्बरशक्रयोर्यथा॥
English Translation: We have heard of numerous monarchs who attained to heaven having duly given away this earth as a gift to the Brahmanas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निजघ्नतुस्तावितरेतरं भृशम्। सकृत्प्रभिन्नाविव वासितान्तरे महागजौ मन्मथसक्तचेतसौ॥
English Translation: O virtuous-souled one, with folded palms, I do beg of you even this, viz., that you attain, O master, the merit of giving away the earth as a gift or of something better than that (by incurring the risk of being killed for the sake of Arjuna, you friend).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तवात्मजस्याथ वृकोदरस्त्वरन् धनुः क्षुराभ्यां ध्वजमेव चाच्छिनत्। ललाटमप्यस्य बिभेद पत्रिणा शिराश्च कायात् प्रजहार सारथेः॥
English Translation: There is only one person, namely Krishna, that giver of assurances of safety to his friends, who is ever prepared to lay down his life for the sake of his friends. You, O Satyaki, are the second.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स राजपुत्रोऽन्यदवाय कार्मुकं वृकोदरं द्वादशभिः पराभिनत्। स्वयं नियच्छंस्तुरगानजिह्मगैः शरैश्च भीमं पुनरष्यवीवृषत्॥
English Translation: None but a hero volunteers to render help to another hero fighting courageously from a desire of winning fame. An ordinary man cannot do so.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः शरं सूर्यमरीचिसप्रभं सुवर्णवज्रोत्तमरत्नभूषितम्। महेन्द्रवज्राशनिपातदुःसहं मुमोच भीमाङ्गविदारणक्षमम्॥
English Translation: Odescendant of Madhu's race, when this is the course to be followed, I do not find any one else save yourself, who can become a help to Arjuna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तेन निर्विद्धतनुर्वृकोदरो निपातितः स्त्रस्ततनुर्गतासुवत्। प्रसार्य बाहू रथवर्यमाश्रितः पुनः स संज्ञामुपलभ्य चानदत्॥
English Translation: On one occasion, Arjuna applauding your achievements and repeatedly reciting them afforded me great pleasure.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मार्कण्डेय उवाच आपस्य मुदिता भार्या सहस्य परमा प्रिया। भूपतिर्भुवभर्ता च जनयत् पावकं परम्॥ भूतानां चापि सर्वेषां यं प्राहुः पावकं पतिम्। आत्मा भुवनभर्तेति सान्वयेषु द्विजातिषु॥
English Translation: He said-"Satyaki is endued with great lightness of hands; he is versed in all modes of warfare; he is very agile, prudent, acquainted with the use of all weapons and downed with bravery. He is never confounded in the course of a fight.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महतां चैव भूतानां सर्वेषामिह यः पतिः। भगवान् स महातेजा नित्यं चरति पावकः॥ अग्निहपति म नित्यं यज्ञेषु पूज्यते। हुतं वहति यो हव्यमस्य लोकस्य पावकः॥
English Translation: That high-souled and mighty car-warriors possesses broad shoulders, bread chest, long arms, large jaws, great strength and unrivalled prowess.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपां गर्भो महाभागः सत्त्वभुग् यो महाद्भुतः। भूपतिर्भुवभर्ता च महतः पतिरुच्यते॥
English Translation: He is both my pupil and friend. I am dear to him and he is dear to me. And if Yuyudhana renders me help, I can then crush the whole Kuru host completely.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दहन् मृतानि भूतानी तस्याग्निर्भरतोऽभवत्। अग्निष्टोमे च नियतः क्रतुश्रेष्ठो भरस्य तु॥
English Translation: or
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स वह्निः प्रथमो नित्यं देवैरन्विष्यते प्रभुः। आयान्तं नियतं दृष्ट्वा प्रविवेशार्णवं भयात्॥
English Translation: O foremost of kings, even if Keshava dons the armour for rendering us aid or if Rama, Aniruddha the mighty car-warrior Pradyumna or Gada or Sarana or Samva with the Vrishnis does so, O mighty Inonarch, to assist us in battle. Yet I shall select that foremost of men, that grandson of Sini of unbaffled prowess to assist me, in exclusion of the others, for, there is none equal to him."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: देवास्तत्रापि गच्छन्ति मार्गमाणा यथादिशम्। दृष्ट्वा त्वग्निरथर्वाणं ततो वचनमब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: This is what Dhananjaya said to me in your absence in the Dvaita forest while applauding your virtue's truly in an assembly of the righteous.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: देवानां वह हव्यं त्वमहं वीर सुदुर्बलः। अथ त्वं गच्छ मध्वक्षं प्रियमेतत् कुरुष्व मे॥
English Translation: O descendant of the Vrishni race, it behoves you not to disappoint Dhananjaya and myself and Bhima.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रेष्य चाग्निरथर्वाणमन्यं देशं ततोऽगमत्। मत्स्यास्तस्य समाचख्युः क्रुद्धस्तानग्निरब्रवीत्। भक्ष्या वै विविधैर्भावैर्भविष्यथ शरीरिणाम्॥
English Translation: When, returning from a sojourn to all the sacred places, I went to Dvaraka, I saw your reverence for Arjuna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथर्वाणं तथा चापि हव्यवाहोऽब्रवीद् वचः।११।।
English Translation: When at Upaplava, O grandson of Sini, I did not mark any one else who showed us greater love and affection, than yourself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनुनीयमानो हि भृशं देववाक्याद्धि तेन सः। नैच्छद् वोढुं हविः सोढुं शरीरं चापि सोऽत्यजत्॥
English Translation: For showing kindness, therefore, to one who is your friend and preceptor, O mightyarmed hero, it behoves you, who are of noble lineage and who cherish reverence for us, to act in a way, O great bowman, worthy of your friendship, prowess, nobility of birth and devotion to truth, O descendant of Madhu's race.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तच्छरीरं संत्यज्य प्रविवेश धरां तदा। भूमिं स्पृष्टासृजद् धातून पृथक् पृथगतीव हि॥ पूयात् स गन्धं तेजश्च अस्थिभ्यो देवदारु च। श्लेष्मणः स्फाटिकं तस्य पित्तान्मारकतं तथा॥ यकृत् कृष्णायसं तस्य त्रिभिरेव वभुः प्रजाः। नखास्तस्याभ्रपटलं शिराजलानि विदुमम्॥
English Translation: Accoutered in armour by Drona himself, Suyodhana has suddenly gone behind Arjuna. Ere this, the other mighty car-warriors of the Kauravas have pursued Arjuna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शरीराद् विविधाश्चान्ये धातवोऽस्याभवन् नृप। एवं त्यक्त्वा शरीरं च परमे तपसि स्थितः॥
English Translation: We can also hear the defiant roars that the enemy is uttering against Arjuna. Therefore, O honoured hero, O grandson of Sini, it behoves you to hie yourself to Arjuna without delay.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भृग्वङ्गिरादिभिर्भूयस्तपसोत्थापितस्तदा। भृशं जज्वाल तेजस्वी तपसाऽऽप्यायित: शिखी।॥
English Translation: Ourselves and Bhimasena supported by our troops, shall hold Drona in check if he tries to pursue you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दृष्ट्वा ऋषि भयाच्चापि प्रविवेश महार्णवम्। तस्मिन् नष्टे जगद् भीतमथर्वाणमथाश्रितम्। अर्चयामासुरेवैनमथर्वाणं सुरादयः॥
English Translation: Behold, O grandson of Sini, the Bharata troops are broken and flying away; and as they fly, hear the loud wails they utter.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथर्वा त्वसृजल्लोकानात्मनाऽऽलोक्य पावकम्। मिषतां सर्वभूतानामुन्ममाथ महार्णवम्॥ एवमग्निर्भगवता नष्टः पूर्वमथर्वणा। आहूतः सर्वभूतानां हव्यं वहति सर्वदा॥
English Translation: Like the very ocean in a Parva day agitated by a mighty tempest, the army of Dhritarashtra, O sire, is being agitated by Savyasachin.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं त्वजनयद् धिष्ण्यान् वेदोक्तान् विबुधान् बहून्। विचरन् विविधान् देशान् भ्रममाणस्तु तत्र वै॥
English Translation: The dust raised by the swiftly moving chariots, horses and foot soldiers, is gradually enveloping the entire army.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सिन्धुनदं पञ्चनदं देविकाथ सरस्वती। गङ्गा च शतकुम्भा च सरयूर्गण्डसाह्वया॥ चर्मग्वती मही चैव मेध्या मेधातिथिस्तदा। ताम्रवती वेत्रवती नद्यस्तिस्रोऽथ कौशिकी॥ तमसा नर्मदा चैव नदी गोदावरी तथा। वेणोपवेणा भीमा च वडवा चैव भारत॥ भारती सुप्रयोगा च कावेरी मुर्मुरा तथा। तुड़वेणा कृष्णवेणा कपिला शोण एव च॥ एता नद्यस्तु धिष्ण्यानां मातरो याः प्रकीर्तिताः।
English Translation: Behold the mighty Phalguna that destroyer of hostile heroes surrounded by the SindhuSouviras armed with lances and javelins and numbering countless heroes among their ranks.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अद्भुतस्य प्रिया भार्या तस्य पुत्रो विभूरसिः॥ यावन्तः पावकाः प्रोक्ताः सोमास्तावन्त एव तु। अत्रेचाप्यन्वये जाता ब्रह्मणो मानसाः प्रजाः॥
English Translation: Without defeating this army it will not be possible (for Arjuna) to vanquish the ruler of the Sindhus. All these warriors again are prepared to lay down their lives for the sake of the Sindhu king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अत्रिः पुत्रान् स्रष्टुकामस्तानेवात्मन्यधारयत्।२८॥ तस्य तद्ब्रह्मणः कार्यान्निर्हरन्ति हुताशनाः।
English Translation: Behold the invincible army of the Dhartarashtras, teeming with lances, arrows, excellent standards, heroes and elephants!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमेते महात्मानः कीर्तितास्तेऽग्नयो मया।॥ अप्रमेया यथोत्पन्नाः श्रीमन्तस्तिमिरापहाः।
English Translation: Hear the roar of their drums and the full blasts of their conchs, the uproar of war-cries and the rattle of their car-wheels!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अद्भुतस्य तु माहात्म्यं यथा वेदेषु कीर्तितम्॥ तादृशं विद्धि सर्वेषामेको ह्येषु हुताशनः।
English Translation: Hear also the roars of elephants the yells of infantry and the cries of hoses-men, as they proceed causing the earth to tremble underneath their tread.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एक एवैष भगवान् विज्ञेयः प्रथमोऽङ्गिराः॥ बहुधा निःसृतः कायाज्ज्योतिष्टोमः क्रतुर्यथा।
English Translation: In the front of Arjuna is the division of the Sindhus and in his rear is the division of Drona. The foes are so strong in number, O foremost of men, that they can even afflict the lord of the celestials.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्येष वंशः सुमहानग्नीनां कीर्तितो मया। योऽर्चितो विविधैर्मन्त्रैर्हव्यं वहति देहिनाम्॥
English Translation: Sunk in his fathomless ocean of troops, Arjuna may be deprived of his life. And if he be slain in battle, how can I live?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वासुदेव उवाच तां तूपयातो राजेन्द्र शाल्व: सौभपतिस्तदा। प्रभूतनरनागेन बलेनोपविवेश ह॥
English Translation: Is this great catastrophe, in the shape of Arjuna's death, to overtake me when you are alive? Of blue complexion, youthful in years, of curly locks and exceedingly beautiful is that son of Pandu.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: समे निविष्टा सा सेना प्रभूतसलिलाशये। चतुरङ्गबलोपेता शाल्वराजाभिपालिता॥
English Translation: Light-handed in using the weapons, acquainted with various modes of warfare, that mighty armed hero, O sire, has entered into the ranks of the Bharata troops at the hour of sunrise; and the hour of sun-set is approaching fast.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वर्जयित्वा श्मशानानि देवताऽऽयतनानि च। वल्मीकांश्चैत्यवृक्षांश्च तन्निविष्टमभूद् बलम्॥
English Translation: 0 you of Vrishni's race, I do not know whether he lives or not. The host of the Kurus is like the mighty ocean itself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनीकानां विभागेन पन्थानः संवृताऽभवन्। प्रवणाय च नैवासञ्छाल्वस्य शिविरे नृप।॥
English Translation: O sire, single-handed has the mighty-armed Vibhatsu entered into the Bharata army which cannot be encountered even by the celestials themselves in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वायुधसमोपेतं सर्वशस्त्रविशारदम्। रथनागाश्वकलिलं पदातिध्वजसंकुलम्॥ तुष्टपुष्टबलोपेतं वीरलक्षणलक्षितम्। विचित्रध्वजसन्नाहं विचित्ररथकार्मुकम्॥ संनिवेश्य च कौरव्य द्वारकायां नरर्षभ। अभिसारयामास तदा वेगेन पतगेन्द्रवत्॥
English Translation: In this day's battle, my heart misgives me. Yonder also is Drona sorely afflicting my troops in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदापतन्तं संदृश्य बलं शाल्वपतेस्तदा। निर्याय योधयामासुः कुमारा वृष्णिनन्दनाः॥
English Translation: You can see, O mighty-armed hero, how his twice-born one is careering in battle. When several tasks present themselves, you know perfectly which of them should be first attended to.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: असहन्तोऽभियानं तच्छाल्वराजस्य कौरव। चारुदेष्णश्च साम्बश्च प्रद्युम्नश्च महारथः॥ ते रथैर्दशिताः सर्वे विचित्राभरणध्वजाः। संसक्ताः शाल्वराजस्य बहुभिर्योधपुङ्गवैः॥
English Translation: O bestower of honour, it behoves you to accomplish first that task which is the most serious, with great activity. Of all these tasks therefore, I do think the task of aiding Arjuna should be accomplished first.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गृहीत्वा कार्मुकं साम्बः शाल्वस्य सचिवं रणे। योधयामास संहृष्टः क्षेमवृद्धिं चमूपतिम्॥
English Translation: The rescue of Arjuna a therefore should be at first effected. I do not grieve for him of the Dasharha race, who is the protector and the Lord of the universe.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य बाणमयं वर्ष जाम्बवत्याः सुतो महत्। मुमोच भरतश्रेष्ठ यथा वर्ष सहस्रदृक्॥ तद् बाणवर्षं तुमुलं विषेहे स चमूपतिः। क्षेमवृद्धिर्महाराज हिमवानिव निश्चलः॥
English Translation: I tell you truly that foremost men, is capable of vanquishing in battle all the three worlds united against him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः साम्बाय राजेन्द्र क्षेमवृद्धिरपि स्वयम्। मुमोच मायाविहितं शरजालं महत्तरम्॥
English Translation: What to speak of this weak host of the sons Dhritarashtra? But, O you of Vrishni's race, Arjuna is sorely pressed by numerous odds in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो मायामयं जालं माययैव विदीर्य सः। साम्बः शरसहस्रेण रथमस्याभ्यवर्षत॥
English Translation: He may lose his life. For this reason it is that I am so cheerless. Therefore do you follow in his track, even as men like you should do.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः स विद्धः साम्बेन क्षेमवृद्धिश्चमूपतिः। अयायाज्जवनैरश्वैः साम्बबाणप्रपीडितः॥
English Translation: For men like Arjuna, being urged on by men like myself. Of all the Vrishni heroes, two are reckoned as Atirathas in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मिन् विप्रदुते क्रूर शाल्वस्याथ चमूपतौ। वेगवान् नाम दैतेयः सुतं मेऽभ्यद्रवद् बली॥
English Translation: One among them is the mighty armed Pradyumna and the other is yourself, O Satvata hero, who both are well-known in the world. Equal to Narayana himself in the use of weapons, so Samkarshana in physical strength.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभिपन्नस्तु राजेन्द्र साम्बो वृष्णिकुलोद्बहः। वेगं वेगवतो राजस्तस्थौ वीरो विधारयन्॥
English Translation: You are equal, O foremost of men, to Dhananjaya in bravery. You surpass Bhishma and Drona and others versed in all modes of warfare.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स वेगवति कौन्तेय साम्बो वेगवती गदाम्। चिक्षेप तरसा वीरो व्याविद्ध्य सत्यविक्रमः॥
English Translation: The wise speak of you, O foremost of all male beings, saying-There is nothing unachievable by Satyaki, O descendant of Madhu's race.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तया त्वभिहतो राजन् वेगवान् न्यपतद् भुवि। वातरुग्ण इव क्षुण्णो जीर्णमूलो वनस्पतिः॥
English Translation: Thereupon, O mighty hero, do you perform what I say to you, viz., carry out the wishes of myself and of Arjuna and of all present here.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मिन् विनिहते वीरे गदानुन्ने महासुरे। प्रविश्य महतीं सेनां योधयामास मे सुतः॥
English Translation: O mighty-armed one, it behoves you not to falsify our expectations. Disregardful of your dear life, do you begin to career like a hero in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चारुदेष्णोन संसक्तो विविन्थ्यो नाम दानवः। महारथः समाज्ञातो महाराज महाधनुः॥
English Translation: O grandson of Sini, the descendants of the Dasharha race never care for their lives in the course of fight. Avoidance of fight, indecision or hesitation to fight and flying away from fight.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः सुतुमुलं युद्धं चारुदेष्णविविध्ययोः। वृत्रवासवयो राजन् यथा पूर्वं तथाभवत्॥
English Translation: These practices of the coward and the mean, are never resorted to by the scions of the Dasharaha race. O foremost of the Shinis, the illustrious Arjuna is your preceptor, O sire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्योन्यस्याभिसंक्रुद्धावन्योन्यं जनतुः शरैः। विनदन्तौ महारावान् सिंहाविव महाबलौ॥
English Translation: Vasudeva again is superior both to yourself and to Arjuna of great intelligence. Knowing this, I speak to you these words.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रौक्मिणेयस्ततो बाणमग्न्यर्कोपमवर्चसम्। अभिमन्त्र्य महास्त्रेण संदधे शत्रुनाशनम्॥
English Translation: Do not disregard iny words, for I am superior to all your superiors. Whatever I say to you, know that to be approved of by Vasudeva and by Arjuna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स विविन्ध्याय सक्रोधः समाहूय महारथः। चिक्षेप मे सुतो राजन् स गतासुरथापतत्॥
English Translation: All this I have spoken to you in right earnestness. Proceed where Dhananjaya is, 0 you of prowess incapable of being baffled, following these words of command uttered by me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विविध्यं निहतं दृष्ट्वा तां च विक्षोभितां चमूम्। कामगेन स सौभेन शाल्वः पुनरुपागमत्।॥
English Translation: Do you, O sire, penetrate into this army of the wicked-minded sons of Dhritarashtra. Entering into it and meeting duly with mighty car-warrior in. battle, display ( you of the Satvata race, the feats that you are capable of achieving and that are worthy of yourself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो व्याकुलितं सर्वं द्वारकावासि तद् बलम्। दृष्ट्वा शाल्वं महाबाहो सौभस्थं नृपते तदा॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said Visited by the sins of discontent, heedlessness, attachment to earthly objects, the absence of tranquillity, power, folly, vanity, and anxiety, O Bhima, you covet sovereignty. Freed from desire, overcoming joy and grief and acquiring tranquillity, try to be happy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो निर्याय कौरव्य अवस्थाप्य च तद् बलम्। आनर्तानां महाराज प्रद्युम्नो वाक्यमब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: That matchless king who will govern this unbounded Earth, will have but one stomach. Why do you then speak highly of this course of life?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वे भवन्तस्तिष्ठन्तु सर्वे पश्यन्तु मां युधि। निवारयन्तं संग्रामे बलात् सौभं सराजकम्॥
English Translation: One's desires, O foremost of Bharata's race, cannot be satisfied in a day, or in many months. Desire, which cannot be satisfied, is not satisfied in one's whole life.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अहं सौभपतेः सेनामायसैर्भुजगैरिव। धनुर्भुजविनिर्मुक्तैर्नाशयाम्यद्य यादवाः॥
English Translation: Fire, when fed with fuel, is lighted up; when not so fed, it is put out. Do you, therefore, put out with little food the fire in your stomach when it appears.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आश्वसध्वं न भी: कार्या सौभराडद्य नश्यति। मयाभिपन्नो दुष्टात्मा ससौभो विनशिष्यति॥
English Translation: He who is shorn of wisdom seeks much food for his stomach. Govern your stomach first (After conquering the Death, you will acquire what is for your permanent good.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं ब्रुवति संहृष्टे प्रद्युम्ने पाण्डुनन्दन। विष्ठितं तद् बलं वीर युयुधे च यथासुखम्॥
English Translation: You speak highly of your worldly desires and enjoyinents and prosperity. But those who have renounced all enjoyments and reduced their bodies by penances obtain blissful regions.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच यानङ्गिराः क्षत्रधर्मानुतथ्यो ब्रह्मवित्तमः। मान्धात्रे यौवनाश्वाय प्रीतिमानभ्यभाषत॥
English Translation: The acquisition and preservation of kingdom is attended with both fair and foul of your means. The desire for them is in you. Free yourself, however, from your great burdens, and practise Renunciation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स यथानुशशासैनमुतथ्यो ब्रह्मवित्तमः। तत् ते सर्वं प्रवक्ष्यामि निखिलेन युधिष्ठिर॥
English Translation: The tiger, for filling one stomach of his, kills many animals. Other weak animals moved by covetousness live upon the tiger's prey.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उतथ्य उवाच धर्माय राजा भवति न कामकरणाय तु। मान्धातरिति जानीहि राजा लोकस्य रक्षिता॥
English Translation: If kings, accepting worldly possessions, practise Renunciation, they can never acquire contentinent. Mark the Joss understanding.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजा चरति चेद् धर्मं देवत्वायैव कल्पते। स चेदधर्मं चरति नरकायैव गच्छति॥
English Translation: They, however, who live no leaves of trees, or use two stones only at their teeth alone for husking their grain, or live upon water only or air alone, can conquer hell.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धर्मे तिष्ठन्ति भूतानि धर्मो राजनि तिष्ठति। तं राजा साधु यः शास्ति स राजा पृथिवीपतिः॥ राजा परमधर्मात्मा लक्ष्मीवान् धर्म उच्यते। देवाश्च नहीं गच्छन्ति धर्मो नास्तीति चोच्यते॥
English Translation: Of the two, the king who rules this wide unbounded Earth, and the person who regards gold and pebbles in the same light, the latter is said to have attained the object of his life and not the former.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्वधर्मे वर्तमानानामर्थसिद्धिः प्रदृश्यते। तदेव मङ्गलं लोकः सर्वः समनुवर्तते॥
English Translation: Relying, therefore, upon that which is the eternal source of joy both here and hereafter, leave off all actions and attachment thereto.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उच्छिद्यते धर्मवृत्तमधर्मो वर्तते महान्। भयमाहुर्दिवारानं यदा पापो न वार्यते॥
English Translation: They who have given up desire and enjoyment have never to grieve. You, however, grieve for enjoyments. Abandoning desire and enjoyment, you may succeed in freeing yourself from false specch.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ममेदमिति नैवैतत् साधूनां तात धर्मतः। वै व्यवस्था भवति यदा पापो न वार्यते॥
English Translation: There are but two well-known roads (for : us), viz., the road of the Pitris and that of the celestials. They who celebrate sacrifices go by the Pitri-path, while they who want salvation, go by the celestial path.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नैव भार्या न पशवो न क्षेत्रं न निवेशनम्। संदृश्येत मनुष्याणां यदा पापबलं भवेत्॥
English Translation: By penances, by Brahmacharya, by study, the great Rishis, casting off their bodies, go to regions which are above the power of Death.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: देवा: पूजां न जानन्ति न स्वधां पितरस्तदा। न पूज्यन्ते ह्यतिथयो यदा पापो न वार्यते॥
English Translation: Worldly enjoyments are called fetters. They have also been called Action Freed from the sinful fetters of action, one attains to the highest end.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न वेदानधिगच्छन्ति व्रतवन्तो द्विजातयः। न यज्ञांस्तन्वते विप्रा यदा पापो न वार्यते॥
English Translation: A verse was sung (of old) by Janaka who was liberated from the pairs of opposites, from desire and enjoyments, and observed the religion of Moksha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वृद्धानामिव सत्त्वानां मनो भवति विह्वलम्। मनुष्याणां महाराज यदा पापो न वार्यते॥
English Translation: The verse is,-My wealth is boundless, yet I have nothing. If the whole of Mithila were burnt to ashes, nothing of mine will be burnt.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उभौ लोकावभिप्रेक्ष्य राजानमृषयः स्वयम्। असृजन् सुमहद् भूतमयं धर्मो भविष्यति॥
English Translation: As a person from the summit of a hill looks down upon men on the plain below, so he that has got up on the top of the edifice of knowledge, sees people grieving for things which are not worth mourning for. He, however, who is of foolish understanding, does not mark this.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यस्मिन् धर्मो विराजेत तं राजानं प्रचक्षते। यस्मिन् विलीयते धर्मस्तं देवा वृषलं विदुः॥
English Translation: He who, really sees all visible things, is said to have eyes and understanding. The faculty of understanding is known as such, because of the knowledge and comprehension it gives of unknown and incomprehensible things.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वृषो हि भगवान् धर्मो यस्तस्य कुरुते ह्यलम्। वृषं तं विदुर्देवास्तस्माद्धर्मं विवर्धयेत्॥
English Translation: He who understands the sayings of persons who are learned, who are of purified souls, and who have attained to a state of Brahma, secures great honours.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धर्मे वर्धति वर्धन्ति सर्वभूतानि सर्वदा। तस्मिन् ह्रसति ह्रीयन्ते तस्माद् धर्मं न लोपयेत्॥
English Translation: When a person regards creatures of innumerable varieties to be all of one and the same and to be but various emanations of the same essence, he is then said to have attained Brahma.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धनात् स्त्रवति धर्मो हि धारणाद् वेति निश्चयः। अकार्याणां मनुष्येन्द्र स सीमान्तकरः स्मृतः॥
English Translation: Those who have acquired this high state of culture attain to that supreme and blissful end, and not they who have not acquired knowledge, or they who are of weak understanding, or they who are bereft of understanding, or they who do not practise penances. Indeed, everything rest on the understanding.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रभवार्थं हि भूतानां धर्मः सृष्टः स्वयम्भुवा। तस्मात् प्रवर्तयेद् धर्म प्रजानुग्रहकारणात्॥
English Translation: Hotravahana said “You will see Rama, the son of Jamadagni, devoted to truth and endued with great strength in the great forest, practicing hard asceticism.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्माद्धि राजशार्दूल धर्मः श्रेष्ठतरः स्मृतः। स राजा यः प्रजाः शास्ति साधुकृत् पुरुषर्षभ॥
English Translation: Rama ever dwells on that highest among the mountains, called Mahendra. Rishis conversant with the Vedas and Gandharavas and Apsaras also live there.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कामक्रोधावनादृत्य धर्ममेवानुपालय। धर्मः श्रेयस्करतमो राज्ञां भरतसत्तम॥
English Translation: Go there and may you fare well. Tell him these words of mine after saluting that old devotee of firm vows by bowing down your head.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धर्मस्य ब्राह्मणो योनिस्तस्मात् पूजयेत् सदा। ब्राह्मणानां च मान्धातः कुर्यात् कामानमत्सरी॥
English Translation: Tell him what you want, gentle ladyhearing my name Rama will do all you ask of him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषां ह्यकामकरणाद् राज्ञः संजायते भयम्। मित्राणि न च वर्धन्ते तथामित्रीभवन्त्यपि॥
English Translation: Rama is my friend, child, and he is my well-wisher and is highly pleased with me that hero, the son Jamadagni and the foremost of all wielders of weapons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणानां सदासूयाद् बाल्याद् वैरोचनो बलिः। अथास्माच्छीरपाक्रामद् यास्मिन्नासीत् प्रतापिनी॥
English Translation: While Hotravahana that ruler of the earth was thus speaking to that girl, the devoted follower of Rama, Akritavrana, presented himself there.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्तस्मादपाक्रम्य सागच्छत् पाकशासनम्। अथ सोऽन्वतपत् पश्चाच्छ्रियं दृष्ट्वा पुरन्दरे॥
English Translation: Then did all those Rishis by thousands as also Hotravahana, the king of the Srinjayas, old in years, stand up.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतत् फलमसूयाया अभिमानस्य वा विभो। तस्माद् बुध्यस्व मान्धातर्मा त्वां जह्यात् प्रतापिनी॥
English Translation: Seeing him those dwellers of the forest united together did him the rites of hospitality and then sat down surrounding him, O chief among the Bharatas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दर्पो नाम श्रियः पुत्रो जज्ञेऽधर्मादिति श्रुतिः। तेन देवासुरा राजन् नीता: सुबहवो व्ययम्॥
English Translation: Then they began to converse cheerfully and delightfully on subjects that delighted one's heart and which were blessed and divine, O chief among kings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजर्षयश्च बहवस्तथा बुध्यस्व पार्थिव। राजा भवति तं जित्वा दासस्तेन पराजितः॥
English Translation: Then at the end of the conversation, the royal sage Hotravahana, endued with a large soul, asked Akritavrana about Rama the foremost among the great Rishis.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स यथा दर्पसहितमधर्मं नानुसेवते। तथा वर्तस्व मान्धातश्चिरं चेत् स्थातुमिच्छसि॥
English Translation: “Where can I see at present the mighty son of Jamadagni, O you of long arms, 0 Akritavrana, that foremost among those conversant with the Vedas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मत्तात्प्रमत्तात् पौगण्डादुन्मत्ताच्च विशेषतः। तदभ्यासादुपावर्त संहितानां च सेवनात्॥
English Translation: Akritavrana said Rama ever speaks of you, my lord, saying: The royal sage Srinjaya, that ruler of the earth, is my dear friend.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निगृहीतादमात्याच्च स्त्रीभ्यश्चैव विशेषतः। पर्वताद् विषमाद् दुर्गाद्धस्तिनोऽश्वात् सरीसृपात्॥ एतेभ्यो नित्ययत्तः स्यान्नक्तंचर्यां च वर्जयेत्। अत्यागं चाभिमानं च दम्भं क्रोधं च वर्जयेत्॥
English Translation: I think Rama will be here on the morrow. You will see him come here owing to your desire for seeing him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अविज्ञातासु च स्त्रीषु क्लीबासु स्वैरिणीषु च। परभार्यासु कन्यासु नाचरेन्मैथुनं नृपः॥
English Translation: O royal sage, why is the lady come to the forest, whose daughter is she and what is she to you? I desire to know it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कुलेषु पापरक्षांसि जायन्ते वर्णसंकरात्। अपुमांसोऽङ्गहीनाश्च स्थूलजिह्वा विचेतसः॥
English Translation: Hotravahana said She is my grand child, my lord, the beloved daughter of the king of the Kashis. O sinless one, she was desirous of choosing her own husband along with her two sisters.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एते चान्ये च जायन्ते यदा राजा प्रमाद्यति। तस्माद् राज्ञा विशेषेण वर्तितव्यं प्रजाहिते॥
English Translation: This eldest daughter of the ruler of the Kashis is known as Amba and, O you whose only wealth is devotion, his two younger daughters are called Ambika and Ambalika.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क्षत्रियस्य प्रमत्तस्य दोषः संजायते महान्। अधर्माः सम्प्रवर्धन्ते प्रजासंकरकारकाः॥
English Translation: Then was there assembled in the city of Kashi, the entire body of Kshatriya rulers of the earth and there were great rejoicing there, O regenerate Rishi of those princes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अशीते विद्यते शीतं शीते शीतं न विद्यते। अवृष्टिरतिवृष्टिश्च व्याधिश्चाप्याविशेत् प्रजाः॥
English Translation: Then did Bhishma, the son of Shantanu, endued with great heroism and energy overthrowing all those rulers of the earth, take away the three girls by force.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नक्षत्राण्युपतिष्ठन्ति ग्रहा घोरास्तथागते। उत्पाताश्चात्र दृश्यन्ते बहवो राजनाशनाः॥
English Translation: Bhishma of sinless soul, having conquered those rulers of the earth came to the city called after the elephant in company with those girls, OBharata.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अरक्षितात्मा यो राजा प्रजाश्चापि न रक्षति। प्रजाश्च तस्य क्षीयन्ते ततः सोऽनुविनश्यति॥
English Translation: That lord after submitting the case to Satyavati ordered for the wedding of his brother Vichitravirya.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्वावाददाते ह्येकस्य द्वयोः सुबहवोऽपरे। कुमार्यः सम्प्रलुप्यन्ते तदाहुपदूषणम्॥
English Translation: This girl, seeing all the arrangements made for the wedding, said there to the son of Ganga in the midst of his councillors, O best among the twice-born.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ममेदमिति नैकस्य मनुष्येष्ववतिष्ठति। त्यक्त्वा धर्मं यदा राजा प्रमादमनुतिष्ठति॥
English Translation: The heroic king of Shalva has been chosen by me as my husband; O you conversant with virtue, it is not proper that you should give me, who am desirous of another, up in your brother.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच यदिदं भारतं वर्षं यत्रेदं मूर्च्छितं बलम्। यत्रातिमात्रलुब्धोऽयं पुत्रो दुर्योधनो मम॥ यत्र गृद्धाः पाण्डुपुत्रा यत्र मे सज्जते मनः। एतन्मे तत्त्वमाचक्ष्व त्वं हि मे बुद्धिमान् मतः॥
English Translation: Bhishma, hearing those words and consulting with his ministers, came to a decision and following the opinion of Satyavati sent her away,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच न तत्र पाण्डवा गृद्धाः शृणु राजन् वचो मम। गृद्धो दुर्योधनस्तत्र शकुनिश्चापि सौबलः॥
English Translation: Permitted by Bhishma this girl rejoicing went to Shalva the lord of Saubha in due time and said these words:
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपरे क्षत्रियाश्चैव नानाजनपदेश्वराः। गृद्धा भारते वर्षे न मृष्यन्ति परस्परम्॥
English Translation: I have been dismissed by Bhishma; act righteously towards me for you had before been chosen by me as my husband, O best among the rulers of the earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ये अत्र ते कीर्तयिष्यामि वर्ष भारत भारतम्। प्रियमिन्द्रस्य देवस्य मनोवैवस्वतस्य च॥ पृथोस्तु राजन् वैन्यस्य तथेक्ष्वाकोर्महात्मनः। ययातेरम्बरीषस्य मान्धातुर्नहुषस्य च॥ तथैव मुचुकुन्दस्य शिबैरौशीनरस्य च। ऋषभस्य तथैलस्य नृगस्य नृपतेस्तथा॥ कुशिकस्य त दुर्धर्ष गाधेश्चैव महात्मनः। सोमकस्य त दुर्धर्ष दिलीपस्य तथैव च॥ अन्येषां च महाराज क्षत्रियाणां बलीयसाम्। सर्वेषामेव राजेन्द्र प्रियं भारत भारतम्॥
English Translation: Shalva, however being suspicious about her character, rejected her and she, coming to this hermitage, has become greatly bent on practicing asceticism.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत् ते वर्षं प्रवक्ष्यामि यथायथमरिन्दम। शृणु मे गदतो राजन् यन्मां त्वं परिपृच्छसि॥ महेन्द्रो मलयः सह्यः शुक्तिमानृक्षवानपि। विध्यश्च पारियात्रश्च सप्तैते कुलपर्वताः॥ तेषां सहस्रशो राजन् पर्वतास्ते समीपतः। अविज्ञाताः सारवन्तो विपुलाचित्रसानवः॥
English Translation: She was recognized by me owing to her describing her parentage and she thinks Bhishma as the origin of this calamity of hers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्ये ततोऽपरिज्ञाता ह्रस्वा ह्रस्वोपजीविनः। आर्या म्लेच्छाश्च कौरव्य तैर्मिश्राः पुरुषा विभो॥ नदी पिबन्ति विपुलां गङ्गां सिन्धुं सरस्वतीम्। गोदावरी नर्मदां च बाहुदां च महानदीम्॥ शतदूं चन्द्रभागां च यमुनां च महानदीम्। दृषद्वतीं विपाशां च विपापां स्थूलवालुकाम्॥ नदीं वेत्रवतीं चैव कृष्णवेणां च निम्नगाम्। इरावती वितस्तां च पयोष्णीं देविकामपि॥ वेदस्मृतां वेदवती त्रिदिवामिक्षुलां कृमिम्। करीषिणी चित्रवाहां चित्रसेनां च निम्नगाम्॥ गोमती धूतपापां च वन्दनां च महानदीम्। कौशिकीं त्रिदिवां कृत्या निचितां लोहितारणीम्॥ रहस्यां शतकुम्भां च सरयूं च तथैव च। चर्मण्वतीं वेत्रवती हस्तिसोमां दिशं तथा॥ शरावती पयोष्णीं च वेणां भीमरथीमपि। कावेरी चुलुकां चापि वाणीं शतबलामपि॥ नीवारामहितां चापि सुप्रयोगां जनाधिप। पवित्रां कुण्डली सिन्धुं राजनीं पुरमालिनीम्॥ पूर्वाभिरामां वीरां च भीमामोघवती तथा। पाशाशिनी पापहरां महेन्द्रां पाटलावतीम्॥ करीषिणीमसिक्नी च कुशचीरां महानदीम्। मकरी प्रवरां मेनां हेमां घृतवतीं तथा॥ पुरावतीमनुष्णां च शैब्यां कापी च भारत। सदानीरामधृष्या च कुशधारां महानदीम्॥ सदाकान्तां शिवां चैव तथा वीरमतीमपि। वस्त्रां सुवस्त्रां गौरी च कम्पनां सहिरण्वतीम्॥ वरां वीरकरां चापि पञ्चमी च महानदीम्। रथचित्रां ज्योतिरथां विश्वामित्रां कपिञ्जलाम्॥ उपेन्द्रा बहुलां चैव कुवीरामम्बुवाहिनीम्। विनदी पिञ्जलां वेणा तुङ्गवेणां महानदीम्॥ विदिशां कृष्णवेणां च ताम्रां च कपिलामपि। खलु सुवामां वेदाश्वां हरिश्रावां महापगाम्॥
English Translation: Amba said O lord, it is even as this ruler of the earth has said; the progenitor of my mother's self is this Hotravahana of the Srinjaya race.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शीघ्रां च पिच्छिलां चैव भारद्वाजी च निम्नगाम्। कौशिकी निम्नगां शोणां बाहुदामथ चन्द्रमाम्॥ दुर्गा चित्रशिलां चैव ब्रह्मवेध्यां बृहद्वतीम्। यवक्षामथ रोहीं च तथा जाम्बूनदीमपि।॥ सुनसां तमसां दासी वसामन्यां वराणसीम्। नीलां घृतवतीं चैव पर्णाशां च महानदीम्॥
English Translation: I do not desire to go back to my father's city, O you whose wealth consists in asceticism, from fear of disgrace and out of shame, O great Muni.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मानवीं वृषभां चैव ब्रह्ममेध्यां बृहनीम्। एताश्चान्याश्च बहुधा महानद्यो जनाधिप॥ सदा निरामयां कृष्णां मन्दगां मदवाहिनीम्। ब्राह्मणी च महागौरी दुर्गामपि च भारत॥ चित्रोपलां चित्ररथां मञ्जुलां वाहिनी तथा। मन्दाकिनी वैतरणी कोषां चापि महानदीम्॥ शुक्तिमतीमनङ्गां च तथैव वृषसाह्वयाम्। लोहित्यां करतोयां च तथैव वृषकाह्वयाम्॥ कुमारीमृषिकुल्यां च मारिषां च सरस्वतीम्। मन्दाकिनीं सुषुण्यां च सर्वां गङ्गां च भारत॥
English Translation: 0 best among the twice-born, it is my opinion that what the lord Rama points out to me would be my supreme duty, my lord.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विश्वस्य मातरः सर्वाः सर्वाश्चैव महाफलाः। तथा नद्यस्त्वप्रकाशाः शतशोऽथ सहस्रशः॥ इत्येताः सरितो राजन् समाख्याता यथास्मृति।
English Translation: Dhritarashtra said What heroes of my army resisted the mighty Bhimasena when he was thus roaring like clouds surcharged with thunder?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अत उर्ध्वं जनपदान् निबोध गदतो मम॥ तत्रेमे कुरुपाञ्चाला: शाल्वा माद्रेयजाङ्गलाः। शूरसेनाः पुलिन्दाश्च बोधा मालास्तथैव च॥ मत्स्याः कुशल्या: सौशल्या:कुन्तयः कान्तिकोसलाः। चेदिमत्स्यकरूषाश्च भोजाः सिन्धुपुलिन्दकाः॥ उत्तमाश्वदशार्णाश्च मेकलाश्चोत्कलैः सह। पञ्चाला: कोसलाश्चैव नैकपृष्ठा धुरंधराः॥ गोधा मद्रकलिङ्गाश्च काशयोऽपरकाशयः। जठराः कुक्कुराश्चैव सदशार्णाश्च भारत॥ कुन्तयोऽवन्तयश्चैव तथैवापरकुन्तयः। गोमन्ता मण्डकाः सण्डा विदर्भा रूपवाहिकाः॥ अश्मकाः पाण्डुराष्ट्राश्च गोपराष्ट्राः करीतयः। अधिराज्यकुशाद्याश्च मल्लराष्ट्रं च केवलम्॥ वारवास्यायवाहाश्चचक्राश्चक्रातयः शकाः। विदेहा मगधाः स्वक्षा मलजा विजयास्तथा॥ अङ्गा वङ्गा कलिङ्गाश्च यकृल्लोमान एव च। मल्ला: सुदेष्णाः प्रह्लादामाहिकाः शशिकास्तथा।।४६। बाह्निका वाटधानाश्च आभीराः कालतोयकाः। अपरान्ताः परान्ताश्च पञ्चालाश्चर्ममण्डलाः॥ अटवीशिखराश्चैव मेरुभूताश्च मारिष। उपावृत्तानुपावृत्ताः स्वराष्ट्राः केकयास्तथा॥ कुन्दापरान्ता माहेयाः कक्षा सामुद्रनिष्कुटाः। अन्ध्राश्च बहवो राजन्नन्तगिर्यास्तथैव च॥ बहिगिर्याङ्गमलजा मगधा मानवर्जकाः। समन्तराः प्रावृषेया भार्गवाश्च जनाधिप॥ पुण्ड्रा भर्गाः किराताश्च सुदृष्टा यामुनास्तथा। शका निषादा निषधास्तथैवानर्तनैर्ऋताः॥ दुर्गाला: प्रतिमत्स्याश्च कुन्तलाः कोसलास्तथा। तीरग्रहाः शूरसेना ईजिकाः कन्यकागुणाः॥ तिलभारा मसीराश्च मधुमन्तः सुकन्दकाः। काश्मीराः सिन्धुसौवीरा गान्धारा दर्शकान्तथा॥ अभीसारा उलूताश्च शैवला बालिकास्तथा। दार्वी च वानवा दर्वा वातजामर थोरगाः॥ बहुवाद्याश्च कौरव्य सुदामानः सुमल्लिकाः। वध्राः करीषकाश्चापि कुलिन्दोपत्यकास्तथा॥ वनायवो दशापार्श्वरोमाणः कुशबिन्दवः। कच्छा गोपालकक्षाश्च जाङ्गलाः कुरुवर्णकाः॥ किराता बर्वराः सिद्धा वैदेहास्ताम्रलिप्तकाः। ओण्ड्राम्लेच्छाः सैसिरिध्राः पार्वतीयाश्च मारिष॥ अथापरे जनपदा दक्षिणा भरतर्षभ। द्रविडाः केरलाः प्राच्या भूषिका वनवासिकाः॥ कर्णाटका महिषका विकल्पा मूषकास्तथा। शिल्लिकाः कुन्तलाश्चैव सौहृदा नभकाननाः॥ कौकुट्टकास्तथा चोलाः कोङ्कणा मालवा नराः। समङ्गाः करकाश्चैव कुकुराङ्गारमारिषाः॥ ध्वजिन्युत्सवसंकेतास्त्रिगर्ताः शाल्वसेनयः। व्यूका: कोकबकाः प्रोष्ठाः समवेगवशास्तथा॥ तथैव विन्ध्यचुलिकाः पुलिन्दा वल्कलैः सह। मालवा बल्लवाश्चैव तथैवापरबल्लवाः॥ कुलिन्दाः कालदाश्चैव कुण्डलाः करटास्तथा। मूषकाः स्तनबालाश्च सनीपा घटसुंजयाः॥ अठिदाः पाशिवाटाश्च तनयाः सुनयास्तथा। ऋषिका विदभाः काकास्तङ्गणाः परतङ्गणाः॥ उत्तराश्चापरम्लेच्छा: क्रूरा भरतसत्तम। यवनाचीनकाम्बोजा दारुणा म्लेच्छजातयः॥ सकृद्ग्रहा: कुलत्थाश्च हूणाः पारसिकैः सह। तथैव रमणाश्चीनास्तथैव दशमालिकाः॥
English Translation: O Sanjaya, I do not find that warrior in the three worlds, who can, stand before Bhimasena when he is excited with rage.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क्षत्रियोपनिवेशाश्च वैश्यशूद्रकुलानि च। शूद्राभीराश्च दरदाः काश्मीराः पशुभिः सह॥ खाशीराश्चान्तचाराश्च पल्हवा गिरिगह्वराः। आत्रेयाः सभरद्वाजास्तथैव स्तनपोषिकाः॥ प्रोषकाश्च कलिङ्गाश्च किरातानां च जातयः। तोमरा हन्यमानाश्च तथैव करभञ्जकाः॥ एते चान्ये जनपदाः प्राच्योदीच्यास्तथैव च।
English Translation: I do not, O son, find that warrior who can stand before Bhima when in battle with his mace uplifted, he stands like Death incarnate.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उद्देशमात्रेण मया देशाः संकीर्तिता विभो॥ यथागुणबलं चापि त्रिवर्गस्य महाफलम्। दुह्येत धेनुः कामधुग् भूमिः सम्यगनुष्ठिताः॥ तस्यां गृद्ध्यन्ति राजानः शूरा धर्मार्थकोविदाः।
English Translation: He that slays elephants with elephants, destroys cars with cars, who will stand before that Bhima not excepting Indra of hundredsacrifices?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते त्यजन्त्याहवे प्राणान् वसुगृद्धास्तरस्विनः॥ देवमानुषकायानां कामं भूमिः परायणम्।
English Translation: Who amongst those devoted to the interests of Duryodhana, would withstand Bhimasena in battle, excited as he was with wrath and engaged in slaughtering my sons?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्योन्यस्यावलुम्पन्ति सारमेया यथाऽमिषम्॥ राजानो भरतश्रेष्ठ भोक्तुकामा वसुंधराम्।
English Translation: Or What persons, stood before the Bhimaconflagration when it was engaged in consuming the heaps of straw and grass constituted by my sons?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न चापि तृप्ति: कामानां विद्यतेऽद्यापि कस्यचित्।।७४। तस्मात् परिग्रहे भूमेर्यतन्ते कुरुपाण्डवाः। साम्ना भेदेन दानेन दण्डेनैव च भारत॥ पिता भ्राता च पुत्राश्च खं द्योश्च नरपुङ्गव। भूमिर्भवति भूतानां सम्यगच्छिद्रदर्शना॥
English Translation: Who were they that surrounded Bhima in battle, beholding him crush my sons one after another, like Death's self-destroying all creatures?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच भरद्वाजं कथं युद्धे युयुधानो न्यवारयत्। संजयाचक्ष्व तत्त्वेन परं कौतुहलं हि मे॥
English Translation: I do not fear Arjuna or Krishna or Satyaki him born of the sacrificial fire (Dhrishtadyumna) so much as I do Bhimasena.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शृणु राजन् महाप्राज्ञ संग्राम लोमहर्षणम्। द्रोणस्य पाण्डवैः सार्धं युयुधानपुरोगमैः॥
English Translation: O Sanjaya relate to me, what heroes advanced against the blazing Bhima-fire which so greatly consumed by sons?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वध्यमानं बलं दृष्ट्वा युयुधानेन मारिष। अभ्यद्रवत् स्वयं द्रोणः सात्यकिं सत्यविक्रमम्॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said When the mighty car-warrior Bhimasena was thus roaring, the mighty Karna rushed at him, himself uttering a loud shout (in response).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमापतन्तं सहसा भारद्वाजं महारथम्। सात्यकिः पञ्चविंशत्या क्षुद्रकाणां समार्पयत्॥
English Translation: Unable to bear the roar of Bhima, he began to twang his bow capable of withstanding a great strain. Then the mighty Karna, out of a । desire for battle displaying his strength.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्रोणोऽपि युधि विक्रान्तो युयुधानं समाहितः। अविध्यत् पञ्चभिस्तूर्णं हेमपुङ्खैः शरैः शितैः॥
English Translation: Checked the career of Bhima; then beholding the son of Vikartana stand before him with hostile intentions, Vrikodara.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते वर्म भित्त्वा सुदृढं द्विषत्पिशितभोजनाः। अभ्ययुर्धरणी राजश्वसन्त इव पन्नगाः॥
English Translation: Became inflamed with wrath; and that mighty hero discharged at him numerous shafts whetted on stone. Karna received all those shafts and sped many in return.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दीर्घबाहुरभिक्रुद्धस्तोत्रादित इव द्विपः। द्रोणं पञ्चशताविध्यन्नाराचैरग्निसंनिभैः॥
English Translation: In that battle between Bhima and Karna, hearing the sound of their Palm-strokes, the limbs of on-looking and fighting warriors and horsemen and elephants, began to tremble. Hearing the deafening roars uttered by Bhimasena on the field of battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भारद्वाजो रणे विद्धो युयुधानेन सत्वरम्। सात्यकि बहुभिर्बाणैर्यतमानमविध्यत॥
English Translation: The foremost of the Kshatriyas regarded the welkin and the earth to be filled completely by its echo. Then again at the dreadful cries uttered by the illustrious son of Pandu.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः क्रुद्धो महेष्वासो भूय एव महाबलः। सात्वतं पीडयामास शरेणानतपर्वणा॥
English Translation: The bows of all the warriors fell down on the earth. Then, O mighty monarch, seized with, panic and dejected, the steeds and elephants, repeatedly discharged urine and excreta. Numerous dreadful omens of evil then appeared to view.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स वध्यमानः समरे भारद्वाजेन सात्यकिः। नान्वपद्यत कर्तव्यं किञ्चदेव विशाम्पते॥
English Translation: During that fierce fight between Karna and Bhimasena, the sky became covered with flights of vultures and Kankas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विषण्णवदनश्चापि युयुधानोऽभवननृप। भारद्वाजं रणे दृष्ट्वा विसृजन्तं शिताशरान्॥
English Translation: Karna then pierced Bhima with twenty arrows and next swifty pierced the latter's charioteer with five arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं तु सम्प्रेक्ष्य ते पुत्राः सैनिकाश्च विशाम्पते। प्रहृष्टमनसो भूत्वा सिंहवद् व्यनदन् मुहुः॥
English Translation: Then the highly puissant Bhimasena endued with great activity smilingly sped at Karna in that battle a set of sixty-four arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं श्रुत्वा निनदं घोरं पीड्यमानं च माधवम्। युधिष्ठिरोऽब्रवीद् राजा सर्वसैन्यानि भारत॥
English Translation: Then at him, O mighty monarch, Karna shot four arrows. But before these arrows could reach him, with nine arrows of depressed knots, Bhima.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एष वृष्णिवरो वीरः सात्यकिः सत्यविक्रमः। ग्रस्यते युधि वीरेण भानुमानिव राहुणा॥
English Translation: Cut them in numerous parts, displaying at the same time his great lightness of hands. Karna then shrouded him in a net-work of numerous arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभिद्रवत गच्छध्वं सात्यकिर्यत्र युध्यते। धृष्टद्युम्नं च पाञ्चाल्यमिदमाह जनाधिपः॥
English Translation: Thus although shrouded by Karna on all sides, that mighty car-warrior that son of Pandu, cut-off the bow of Karna near his grasp.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभिद्रव दुतं द्रोणं किमु तिष्ठसि पार्षत। न पश्यसि भयं द्रोणाद् घोरं नः समुपस्थितम्॥
English Translation: He then pierced him with many arrows of close knots. Then taking up another bow and stringing it, the son of the charioteer.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: असौ द्रोणो महेष्वासो युयुधानेन संयुगे। क्रीडते सूत्रवद्धन पक्षिणा बालको यथा॥
English Translation: That mighty car-warrior of dreadful deeds, pierced Bhima in battle (with many arrows). Thereat highly enraged, with three arrows of depressed knots, Bhima..
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्रैव सर्वे गच्छन्तु भीमसेनपुरोगमाः। तत्रैव सहिताः सर्वे युयुधानरथं प्रति॥
English Translation: Struck with force on the breast of the son of the charioteer. With those arrows struck on the centre of his breast, Karna appeared beautiful like.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पृष्ठतोऽनुगमिष्यामि त्वामहं सहसैनिकः। सात्यकिं मोक्षयस्वाद्य यमदंष्ट्रान्तरं गतम्॥
English Translation: A mighty mountain with its three peaks towering high. Pierced as he was with those excellent arrows, streams of blood began to flow down his person.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्त्वा ततो राजा सर्वसैन्येन भारत। अभ्यद्रवद् रणे द्रोणं युयुधानस्य कारणात्॥
English Translation: Like streams of liquefied red chalk flowing down the sides of a mountain. Afflicted with that might wound inflicted by Bhima, Karna was a little flurried.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्रारावो महानासीद् द्रोणमेकं युयुत्सताम्। पाण्डवानां च भद्रं ते सृञ्जयानां च सर्वशः॥
English Translation: Then fixing an arrow on his bow, O sire, he pierced Bhima therewith; and then shot arrows by hundreds and thousands.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते समेत्य नरव्याघ्रा भारद्वाजं महारथम्। अभ्यवर्षशरैस्तीक्ष्णैः कङ्कबर्हिणवाजितैः॥
English Translation: Thus through then quickly covered with arrows by that resolute bowman namely Karna, yet that son of Pandu smilingly cut-off the bow-string of the former.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्मयन्नेव तु तान् वीरान् द्रोणः प्रत्यग्रहीत् स्वयम्। अतीथीनागतान् यद्वत् सलिलेनासनेन च॥
English Translation: Then with a broad-headed shaft, Bhima dispatched Karna's charioteer to the abode of Death; then that mighty car-warrior deprived the latter's steeds of their lives.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तर्पितास्ते शरैस्तस्य भारद्वाजस्य धन्विनः। अतिथेयं गृहं प्राप्य नृपतेऽतिथयो यथा॥
English Translation: Jumping down from the car of which the steeds were slain, O ruler of men, the mighty car-warrior Karna ascended the chariot of Vrisasena.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भारद्वाजं च ते सर्वे न शेकुः प्रतिवीक्षितुम्। मध्यंदिनमनुप्राप्तं सहस्रांशुमिव प्रभो॥
English Translation: Then the valiant Bhima, having defeated Karna uttered a loud war-cry, that resembled the roar of the rain-cloud Parjannya.

Sanskrit Shloka: तांस्तु सर्वान् महेष्वासान् द्रोणः शस्त्रभृतांवरः। अतापयच्छरव्रातैर्गभस्तिभिरिवांशुमान्॥
English Translation: Hearing that roar of his, Yudhishthira became filled with delight, as he thought that Karna had been defeated, O Bharata by Bhimasena.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वध्यमाना महाराज पाण्डवाः सृञ्जयास्तथा। त्रातारं नाध्यगच्छन्त पङ्कमग्ना इव द्विपाः॥
English Translation: Then the Pandava troops simultaneously blew their conchs. Hearing that sound of challenge emitted by the enemy, your own troops shouted aloud.

Sanskrit Shloka: द्रोणस्य च व्यदृश्यन्त विसर्पन्तो महाशराः। गभस्तय इवार्कस्य प्रतपन्तः समन्ततः॥

Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मिन् द्रोणेन निहताः पञ्चालाः पञ्चविंशतिः। महारथाः समाख्याता धृष्टद्युम्नस्य सम्मताः॥
English Translation: Was heard by all your troops, O sire. Then those two combatants, viz., Karma and Bhima each struck the other with straight-flying arrows. The son of Radha shot his shaft mildly, but the son of Pandu shot those of his with great vehemence.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पाण्डूनां सर्वसैन्येषु पञ्चालानां तथैव च। द्रोणं स्म ददृशुः शूरं विनिघ्नन्तं वरान् वगन्।॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said Approaching Bhishma venerable in years viz., Bhishma, who was then lying on his bed of arrows, the highly wise Yudhishthira put the following questions.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: केकयानां शतं हत्वा विद्राव्य च समन्ततः। द्रोणस्तस्थौ महाराज व्यादितास्य इवान्तकः॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said How, O grandfather does one acquire beauty of form and prosperity and sweetness of disposition? How, indeed, does one acquire religious meril and wealth and pleasure? How does one win happiness?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पञ्चालान् सृञ्जयान् मत्स्यान् केकयांश्च नराधिप। द्रोणोऽजयन्महाबाहुः शतशोऽथ सहस्रशः॥
English Translation: Bhishma said In the month of Margashira, when the inoon comes in conjunction with the asterism called Mula, when his two feet are united with that very asterism, O king, when Rohini is in his calf, when his knee-joints are in Ashvini, and his thighs are in the two Ashadas when Phalguni makes his anus, and Krittika his waist, when his navel is in Bhadrapada, his ocular region in Revati, and his back on the Dhanishthas, when Anuradha makes his belly, when with his two arms he reaches the Vishakhas, when his two hands are indicated by Hasta, when Punarvasu, O king, makes his fingers, Ashlesha his nails when Jyeshtha makes his neck when Shravana makes his ears, and Pushya his mouth when Svati is said to make his teeth and lips, when Shatabhisha is his smile and Magha his nose, when Mrigashiras is known to be in his eye, and Chitra in his forehead, when his head is in Bharani, when Ardra forms his hair, o king, the vow called Chandravrata should be taken in hand. Upon the termination of that vow, gifts of clarified butter should be made 10 Brahmanas conversant with the Vedas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषां समभवच्छब्दो विद्धानां द्रोणसायकैः। वनौकसामिवारण्ये व्याप्तानां धूम्रकेतुना॥
English Translation: As the fruit of that vow one acquires prosperity, personal beauty and that good luck which brings about knowledge. Indeed, onc becomes on account of such a vow, as full of attribute as the full Moon hiinself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्र देवाः सगन्धर्वाः पितरश्चाब्रुवन् नृप। एते द्रवन्ति पञ्चलाः पाण्डवाश्च ससैनिकाः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said: When the fire blazed up the Sharangakas became very much distressed. Afflicted with anxiety, they did not fine any means of escape.
