Sanskrit Shloka: तं तथा समरे द्रोणं निघ्नन्तं सोमकान् रणे। न चाप्यभिययुः केचिदपरे नैव विव्यधुः॥
English Translation: Their ascetic mother Jarita, full of grief and sorrow, seeing that her sons were too young to escape, wept and lamented in grief.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वर्तमाने तथा रौद्रे तस्मिन् वीरवरक्षये। अशृणोत् सहसा पार्थः पाञ्चजन्यस्य निःस्वनम्॥
English Translation: Jarita said : Alas, the terrible fire, the enhancer of my misery, is coming towards us, illuminating the whole universe and burning the forest.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पूरितो वासुदेवेन शङ्खराट् स्वनते भृशम्। युध्यमानेषु वीरेषु सैन्धवस्याभिरक्षिषु॥
English Translation: I am filled with sorrow for the sake of these infants with immature understanding and without feathers and feet, who are the sole refuge of our deceased ancestors.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नदत्सु धार्तराष्ट्रेषु विजयस्य रथं प्रति। गाण्डीवस्य च निषि विप्रणष्टे समन्ततः॥
English Translation: The fire is rushing towards us, licking with its tongue the tallest trees and spreading fear all around. My unfledged children are incapable of effecting their escape.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कश्मलाभिहतो राजा चिन्तयामास पाण्डवः। न नूनं स्वस्ति पार्थाय यथा नदति शङ्खराट्॥
English Translation: I myself am incapable of escapingspecially taking all these (my children) with me. I am incapable of abandoning them; my heart is distressed for their sake.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कौरवाश्च यथा हृष्टा विनदन्ति मुहुर्मुहुः। एवं स चिन्तयित्वा तु व्याकुलेनान्तरात्मना॥
English Translation: Whom amongst my sons shall I leave behind and whom shall I carry with me? What should I do which is consistent with duty? O my infant sons, what is your opinion?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अजातशत्रुः कौन्तेयः सात्वतं प्रत्यभाषत। वाष्पगद्गदया वाचा मुह्यमानो मुहुर्मुहुः। कृत्यस्यानन्तरापेक्षी शैनेयं शिनिपुङ्गवम्॥
English Translation: Even after good deal of reflection, I do not see any way of escape for you. I shall now cover you with my wings and die with you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच यः स धर्मः पुरा दृष्टः सद्भिः शैनेय शाश्वतः। साम्पराये सुहृत्कृत्ये तस्य कालोऽयमागतः॥
English Translation: Your cruel father went away saying, “O Jarita, my race will depend on this Jaritari, because he is the eldest of my sons. My second son Sarisrikka will beget offsprings for the spread of my forefather's race; my third son Stambamitra will be devoted to asceticism; and my youngest son Drona will be the foremost of all the learned men in the Vedas."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वेष्वपि च योधेषु चिन्तयशिनिपुङ्गव। त्वत्तः सुहृत्तमं कञ्चिन्नाभिजानामि सात्यके॥
English Translation: Now this great calamity has befallen on us, whom shall I take with me? I am deprived of my judgement. What should I do consistent with duty? By exercising my judgement, I do not find any means of escape for my children from this fire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यो हि प्रीतमना नित्यं यश्च नित्यमनुव्रतः। स कार्ये साम्पराये तु नियोज्य इति मे मतिः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : The young Sharangakas thus spoke to their mother who was thus lamenting, “O mother, giving up all affection for us, go to the place where there is no fire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथा च केशवो नित्यं पाण्डवानां परायणम्। तथा त्वमपि वार्ष्णेय कृष्णतुल्यपराक्रमः॥
English Translation: If we are killed, you might have other children born to you, but, O mother, if you are killed, we shall have no children in our race.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सोऽहं भारं समाधास्ये त्वयि तं वोढुमर्हसि। अभिप्रायं च मे नित्यं न वृथा कर्तुमर्हसि॥
English Translation: O mother, taking into your consideration both these two calamities, the time has come for you to do that which will be for the good of our race.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स त्वं भ्रातुर्वयस्यस्य गुरोरपि च संयुगे। कुरु कृच्छ्रे सहायार्थमर्जुनस्य नरर्षभ॥
English Translation: Do not perform anything out of affection for your children. If you are saved, our father who is desirous of acquiring regions of felicity will have his wishes fulfilled.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वं हि सत्यव्रतः शूरो मित्राणामभयङ्करः। लोके विख्यायसे वीर कर्मभिः सत्यवागिति॥
English Translation: Jarita said: There is a hole here in the ground near to this tree; enter this hole without any delay; you shall then have no fear from fire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यो हि शैनेय मित्रार्थे युध्यमानस्त्यजेत् तनुम्। पृथिवीं च द्विजातिभ्यो यो दद्यात् स समा भवेत्।।४९
English Translation: O children, when you will enter it, I shall then cover its mouth with dust. This is the only means that I see for your escape from this blazing fire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रुताश्च बहवोऽस्माभी राजानो ये दिवं गताः। दत्त्वेमां पृथिवीं कृत्स्नां ब्राह्मणेभ्यो यथाविधि॥
English Translation: When the fire will be out, I shall then come back here to remove the ashes. If you want to escape from the fire, follow my advice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं त्वामपि धर्मात्मन् प्रयाचेऽहं कृताञ्जलिः। पृथिवीदानतुल्यं स्यादधिकं वा फलं विभो॥
English Translation: The Sharangakas said : We are but so many balls of flesh without having our feathers. if we enter the hole, there is no doubt the carnivorous mouse will destroy us all. Seeing this fear before us, we cannot enter the hole.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एक एव सदा कृष्णो मित्राणामभयङ्करः। रणे संत्यजति प्राणान् द्वितीयस्त्वं च सात्यके॥
English Translation: We do not know how we may escape from the fire, or from the mouse. We do not see how our father's act of procreation may not be in vain and how our mother may be saved.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विक्रान्तस्य च वीरस्य युद्धे प्रार्थयतो यशः। शूर एव सहाय: स्यान्नेतरः प्रकृतो जनः॥
English Translation: If we enter the hole, the mouse will kill us. If we remain where we are, the sky-ranger Agni will destroys us. Taking both the (two) calamities into our consideration, (we think) death from the fire is preferable to the death by being eaten up.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ईदृशे तु परामर्दै वर्तमानस्य माधव। त्वदन्यो हि रणे गोप्ता विजयस्य न विद्यते॥
English Translation: To be eaten up by the mouse in the hole is a most ignoble death. But destruction of the body by fire is praised by the wise.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्लाघन्नेव हि कर्माणि शतशस्तव पाण्डवः। मम संजनयन् हर्षं पुनः पुनरकीर्तयत्॥
English Translation: There took place a great battle between the diadem decked Arjuna and the hundreds of Saindhavas who still lived after the destruction of their clan.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: लघुहस्तश्चित्रयोधी तथा लघुपराक्रमः। प्राज्ञः सर्वास्त्रविच्छूरो मुह्यते न च संयुगे।॥
English Translation: Hearing that he of white horses had entered their territories, those Kshatriyas came out against him, unable to bear that foremost one of Pandu's race.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महास्कन्धो महोरस्को महाबाहुर्महाहनुः। महाबलो महावीर्यः स महात्मा महारथः॥
English Translation: Those warriors who were as terrible as dreadful poison, finding the horse within their dominion, seized it without being filled with any fear of Partha who was the younger brother of Bhimasena.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शिष्यो मम सखा चैव प्रियोऽस्याहं प्रियश्च मे। युयुधानः सहायो मे प्रमथिष्यति कौरवान्॥
English Translation: Advancing against Bibhatsu who waited on foot, armed with his bow, upon the sacrificial horse, they attacked him from a near point.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अस्मदर्थं च राजेन्द्र संनह्येद् यदि केशवः। रामो वाप्यनिरुद्धो वा प्रद्युम्नो वा महारथः॥ गदो वा सारणो वापि साम्यो वा सह वृष्णिभिः। सहायार्थं महाराज संग्रामोत्तममूर्धनि॥
English Translation: Defeated in battle before, those Kshatriyas of great energy, moved by the desire of victory, surrounded that foremost of men.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथाप्यहं नरव्याघ्रं शैनेयं सत्यविक्रमम्। साहाय्ये विनियोक्ष्यामि नास्ति मेऽन्यो हि तत्समः।।६१
English Translation: Proclaiming their names and families and their various feats, they showered their arrows on Partha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इति द्वैतवने तात मामुवाच धनंजयः। परोक्षे त्वद्गुणांस्तथ्यान् कथयन्नार्यसंसदि॥
English Translation: Pouring showers of arrows of such fierce energy as were capable of obstructing the course of hostile elephants, those heroes surrounded the son of Kunti, desirous of defeating him in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य त्वमेवं संकल्पं न वृथा कर्तुमर्हसि। धनंजयस्य वार्ष्णेय मम भीमस्य चोभयोः॥
English Translation: Themselves seated on cars, they fought Arjuna of dreadful feats who was on foot,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यच्चापि तीर्थानि चरन्नगच्छं द्वारकां प्रति। तत्राहमपि ते भक्तिमर्जुनं प्रति दृष्टवान्॥
English Translation: From every side they began to strike that hero, that destroyer of the Nivatakavachas, that destroyer of the Samsaptakas, that destroyer of the king of the Sindhus.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न तत् सोहृदमन्येषु मया शैनेय लक्षितम्। यथा त्वमस्मान् भजसे वर्तमानानुपप्लवे॥
English Translation: Surrounding him on all sides as within a cage by means of a thousand cars and ten thousand horse, those brave warriors expressed their joy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सोऽभिजात्या च भक्त्या च सख्यस्याचार्यकस्य च। सौहृदस्य च वीर्यस्य कुलीनत्वस्य माधव॥ सत्यस्य च महाबाहो अनुकम्पार्थमेव च। अनुरूपं महेष्वास कर्म त्वं कर्तुमर्हसि॥
English Translation: Recollecting the destruction by Dhananjaya of Jayadratha in battle, O you of Kuru's race, they poured heavy showers of arrows on that hero like a mass of clouds showering a heavy downpour. Overwhelmed with that arrow shower, Arjuna looked like the sun covered by a cloud.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुयोधनो हि सहसा गतो द्रोणेन दंशितः। पूर्वमेवानुयातास्ते कौरवाणां महारथाः॥
English Translation: That foremost son of Pandu, in the midst of that cloud of arrows, resembled a bird in the midst of an iron cage, O Bharata.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुमहान् निनदश्चैव श्रूयते विजयं प्रति। स शैनेय जवेनाशु गन्तुमर्हसि मानद॥
English Translation: Seeing the son of Kunti thus afflicted with arrows, cries of oh and alas were uticred by the three worlds, and the Sun himself became shorn of his splendour.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीमसेनो वयं चैव संयत्ताः सहसैनिकाः। द्रोणमावारयिष्यामो यदि त्वां प्रति यास्यति॥
English Translation: Then, O king, a terrible wind began to blow, and Rahu swallowed up both the Sun and the Moon simultaneously.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पश्य शैनेय सैन्यानि द्रवमाणानि संयुगे। महान्तं च रणे शब्दं दीर्यमाणां च भारतीम्॥
English Translation: Many meteors struck the solar disc and then shot in different directions. The prince of mountains, viz., Kailasa, began to tremble.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महामारुतवेगेन समुद्रमिव पर्वसु। धार्तराष्ट्रबलं तात विक्षिप्तं सव्यसाचिना॥
English Translation: The seven (celestial) Rishis, as also the other Rishis of Heaven, stricken with fear, and afflicted with grief and sorrow, breathed hot sights.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रथैर्विपरिधावद्भिर्मनुष्यैश्च हयैश्च ह। सैन्यं रज:समुद्भूतमेतत् सम्परिवर्तते॥
English Translation: Piercing through the sky, those meteors fell on the Lunar disc as well. All the points of the compass became filled with smoke and assumed a strange aspect.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संवृतः सिन्धुसौवीरैर्नखरप्रासयोधिभिः। अत्यन्तोपचितैः शूरैः फाल्गुनः परवीरहा॥
English Translation: Reddish clouds, with flashes of lightning laying in their midst and the bow of Indra measuring them from side to side, suddenly covered the sky and poured flesh and bloods on the Earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नैतद् बलमसंवार्य शक्यो जेतुं जयद्रथः। एते हि सैन्धवस्यार्थे सर्वे संत्यक्तजीविताः॥
English Translation: Such was the aspect which all nature assumed when that hero was overwhelmed with showers of arrows. Indeed, when Phalguna, that foremost one among the Bharatas, was thus afflicted, those marvels were witnessed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शरशक्तिध्वजवरं हयनागसमाकुलम्। पश्यैतद् धार्तराष्ट्राणामनीकं सुदुरासदम्॥
English Translation: Overwhelmed by that dense cloud of arrows, Arjuna became stupefied. The bow, Gandiva, fell down from his relaxed grip and his leathern hence also dropped down.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शृणु दुन्दुभिनिर्घोषं शङ्खशब्दांश्च पुष्कलान्। सिंहनादरवांश्चैव रथनेमिस्वनांस्तथा॥
English Translation: When Dhananjaya became stupefied, the Saindhava warriors once more shot forthwith at that senseless warrior, numberless other arrOWS.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नागानां शृणु शब्दं च पत्तीनां च सहस्रशः। सादिनां द्रवतां चैव शृणु कम्पयतां महीम्॥
English Translation: Understanding that the son of Pritha was insensible, the celestials, with hearts stricken with fear, began to seek his well-being by uttering various benedictions.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुरस्तात् सैन्धवानीकं द्रोणानीकं च पृष्ठतः। बहुत्वाद्धि नरव्याघ्र देवेन्द्रमपि पीडयेत्॥
English Translation: Then the celestial Rishis, the seven Rishis, and the twice-born Rishis, became engaged in silent recitations from desire of giving victory to the highly intelligent son of Pritha's.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपर्यन्ते बले मग्नो जह्यादपि च जीवितम्। तस्मिंश्च निहते युद्धे कथं जीवेत मादृशः॥
English Translation: When at last the energy of Partha blazed forth through those deeds of the dwellers of the celestial region, that hero, who was conversant with celestial weapons of great efficacy, stood immovable like a hill.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वथाहमनुप्राप्तः सुकृच्छं त्वयि जीवति। श्यामो युवा गुडाकेशो दर्शनीयश्च पाण्डवः॥
English Translation: The delighter of the Kurus then drew his celestial bow. And as he repeatedly stretched the bowstring, the twang that followed resembled the loud sound of some strong machine.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: लघ्वस्त्रश्चित्रयोधी च प्रविष्टस्तात भारतीम्। सूर्योदये महाबाहुर्दिवसश्चातिवर्तते॥
English Translation: Like Purandara pouring rain, the powerful Arjuna then, with that bow of his, poured incessant showers of arrows on his enemies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तन्न जानामि वार्ष्णेय यदि जीवति वा न वा। कुरूणां चापि तत् सैन्यं सागरप्रतिमं महत्॥
English Translation: Pierced by those arrows, the Saindava warriors with their cuels became invisible like trees covered with locusts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एक एव च बीभत्सुः प्रविष्टस्तात भारतीम्। अविषह्यां महाबाहुः सुरैरपि महाहवे॥
English Translation: Terror-stricken at the very sound of Gandiva and filled with consternation they fled away. In grief of hear they shed tears and cried aloud.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न हि मे वर्तते बुद्धिरद्य युद्धे कथंचन। द्रोणोऽपि रभसो युद्धे मम पीडयते बलम्॥
English Translation: The powerful warrior moved a midst that host of enemies with the celerity of a fiery wheel, all the time piercing those warriors with his arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रत्यक्षं ते महाबाहो यथाऽसौ चरति द्विजः। युगपच्च समेतानां कार्याणां त्वं विचक्षणः॥
English Translation: Like the great Indra, the holder of the thunder-bolt, that destroyer of enemies viz., Arjuna, shot from his bow in every direction that shower of arrows which resembled a sight produced by magic.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महार्थं लघुसंयुक्तं कर्तुमर्हसि मानद। तस्य मे सर्वकार्येषु कार्यमेतन्मतं महत्॥
English Translation: The Kaurava hero, piercing the hostile army with showers of arrows looked resplendent like the autumnal Sun when he disperses the clouds with his powerful rays. once
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्जुनस्य परित्राणं कर्तव्यमिति संयुगे। नाहं शोचामि दाशार्ह गोप्तारं जगतः पतिम्॥
English Translation: Krishna said Bending low my head with a controlled soul to that mass of energy and effulgence, I said to the great god, with a joyous heart, these words
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स हि शक्तो रणे तात त्रील्लोकानपि संगतान्। विजेतुं पुरुषव्याघ्रः सत्यमेतद् ब्रवीमि ते॥
English Translation: I ask for these boons from you, namely firmness in virtue, the destruction of enemies in battle, the highest glory, the greatest power, devotion to Yoga, your nearness, and hundreds upon hundreds of children.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किं पुनर्धार्तराष्ट्रस्य बलमेतत् सुदुर्बलम्। अर्जुनस्त्वेष वार्ष्णेय पीडितो बहुभिर्युधि॥
English Translation: Whereto Shankara said, so be it, repeating the words I had said. After this, the mother of the universe, the upholdress of all things, she who purifies all things, viz., the wife of Sarva that huge receptacle of penances, said with controlled soul, these words to me: The powerful Mahadeva has granted you, O sinless one, a son who shall be named Shamba.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रजह्यात् समरे प्राणांस्तस्माद् विन्दामि कश्मलम्। तस्य त्वं पदवीं गच्छ गच्छेयुस्त्वादृशा यथा॥
English Translation: Do you take from me also eight boons which you choose. I shall, indeed, grant them to you. Bowing her with my head bended, I said to her, O son of Pandu!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तादृशस्येदृशे काले कादृशेनाभिनोदितः। रणे वृष्णिप्रवीराणां द्वावेवातिरथौ स्मृतौ॥
English Translation: I pray from you uniform affection for the Brahmanas, the favour of my father, a hundred sons, the highest enjoyments, love for my family, the favour of my mother, the attainment of tranquility and peace, and cleverness in every deed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रद्युम्नश्च महाबाहुस्त्वं च सात्वत विश्रुतः। अस्त्रे नारायणसम: संकर्षणसमो बले॥
English Translation: Uma Said You will have them, O you, who are endued with prowess equal to that of a celestial. I never say what is untrue. You will have sixteen thousand wives. Your love for them and theirs also for you shall be limitless.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वीरतायां नरव्याघ्र धनंजयसमो ह्यसि। भीष्मद्रोणावतिक्रम्य सर्वयुद्धविशारदम्॥
English Translation: From all your kinsmen also, you will get the highest affection. You will have a most beautiful person. Seven thousand guests will daily feed at your palace.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वामेव पुरुषव्याघ्रं लोके सन्तः प्रचक्षते। नाशक्यं विद्यते लोके सात्यकेरिति माधव॥
English Translation: Vasudeva continued Having thus granted me boons both the god and the goddess, O Bharata, disappeared there and then with their associates, O elder brother of Bhima.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत् त्वां यदभिवक्ष्यामि तत् कुरुष्व महाबल। सम्भावना हि लोकस्य मम पार्थस्य चोभयोः॥
English Translation: All those wonderful deeds I described fully, O best of kings, to that highly energetic Brahmana Upamanyu. Bowing down to the great God, Upamanyu said these words to me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नान्यथा तां महाबाहो सम्प्रकर्तुमिहार्हसि। परित्यज्य प्रियान् प्राणान् रणे चर विभीतवत्॥
English Translation: Upamanyu said There is no god like Sarva. There is no end or refuge like Sarva. There is none who can grant so inany or so high boons. There is none who is his equal in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न हि शैनेय दाशार्हा रणे रक्षन्ति जीवितम्। अयुद्धमनवस्थानं संग्रामे च पलायनम्॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said Ordered by Dhritarashtra, those foremost of Kuru's race, viz., the Pandava brothers, accompanied by Keshava, then went to see Gandhari.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीरूणामसतां मार्गो नैष दाशार्हसेवितः। तवार्जुनो गुरुस्तात धर्मात्मा शिनिपुङ्गव॥
English Translation: The innocent Gandhari, stricken with grief on üccount of the death of her hundred sons, thought that king Yudhishthira the just had killed all his enemies, and wished to curse him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वासुदेवो गुस्श्चापि तव पार्थस्य धीमतः। कारणद्वयमेतद्धि जानंस्त्वामहमब्रुवम्॥
English Translation: Knowing her evil intentions towards the Pandavas, the Vyasa made himself ready for counteracting them at the very beginning.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मावमंस्था वचो मह्यं गुरुस्तव गुरोर्बाहम्। वासुदेवमतं चैव मम चैवार्जुनस्य च॥
English Translation: Having cleansed himself by the sacred and fresh water of the Ganges, the Great Rishi, capable going everywhere at will as quickly as the mind, came there.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सत्यमेतन्मयोक्तं ते याहि यत्र धनंजयः। एतद् वचनमाज्ञाय मम सत्यपराक्रम॥
English Translation: Capable of seeing the heart of everyone with his spiritual vision and desirous of doing the same, the sage came there.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रविशैतद् बलं तात धार्तराष्ट्रस्य दुर्मतेः। प्रविश्य च यथान्यायं संगम्य च महारथैः। यथार्हमात्मनः कर्म रणे सात्वत दर्शय॥
English Translation: Endued with great ascetic merit and ever intent on saying what was for the good of creatures, the Rishi said to his daughter-in-law at the proper moment. Do not at this time imprecate a curse! Rather make a good use of this hour for showing your forgiveness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच असंतोषः प्रमादश्च मदो रागोऽप्रशान्तता। बलं मोहोऽभिमानश्चाप्युद्वेगश्चैव सर्वशः॥ एभिः पाप्मभिराविष्टो राज्यं त्वमभिकाङ्क्षसे। निरामिषो विनिर्मुक्तः प्रशान्तः सुसुखी भव॥
English Translation: Thou should not be angry with the Pandavas, O Gandhari! Set your heart on peace! Restrain the words that are about to drop from your lips! Listen to my advice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: य इमामखिलां भूमि शिष्यादेको महीपतिः। तस्याप्युदरमेकं वै किमिदं त्वं प्रशंससि॥
English Translation: Your son, seeking victory had requested you every day for the eighteen days of the battle, saying,-'O mother bless me who am fighting with my foes!' Solicited thus every day by your son desirous of victory, you always answered him saying,-'victory' is there where righteousness is.' I do not, O Gandhari, remember that your words, have ever been falsified! Those words, therefore, which you, requested by Duryodhana, said to him could not be false. You are always engaged in the well being of all creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नाह्ना पूरयितुं शक्यां न मासैर्भरतर्षभ। अपूर्यां पूरयन्निच्छामायुषापि न शक्नुयात्॥
English Translation: Having undoubtedly reached the other shore in that dreadful battle of Kshatriyas, the sons of Pandu have certainly gained the victory and greater a righteousness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथेद्धः प्रज्वलत्यग्निरसमिद्धः प्रशाम्यति।। अल्पाहारतया त्वग्निं शमयौदर्यमुत्थितम्॥
English Translation: You formerly observed the virtue of forgiveness. Why would you not observe it now? Restrain unrighteousness, O you who are ever righteousness. There is victory where righteousness is.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आत्मोदरकृतेऽप्राज्ञः करोति विघसं बहु। जयोदरं पृथिव्या ते श्रेयो निर्जितया जितम्॥
English Translation: Remembering your own righteousness and the words spoken by your self, check your wrath, O Gandhari! Do not act otherwise, O beautiful speeches lady!' hearing these words, Gandhari said,-'O holy one, I don not entertain any ill feelings towards the Pandavas, nor do I wish that they should die. Out of grief for the death of my sons, my heart is greatly shaken.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मानुषान् कामभोगांस्त्वमैश्वर्यं च प्रशंससि। अभोगिनोऽबलाश्चैव यान्ति स्थानमनुत्तमम्॥७॥
English Translation: I know that I should protect the Pandavas with as much care as Kunti does, and that Dhritarashtra also should protect them as I should.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: योगः क्षेमश्च राष्ट्रस्य धर्माधर्मों त्वयि स्थितौ। मुच्यस्व महतो भारात् त्यागमेवाभिसंश्रय॥
English Translation: For the holly of Duryodhana and of Shakuni the son of Subala, and through the action of Karna and Dushasana, this extinction of the Kurus has taken place.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एकोदरकृते व्याघ्रः करोति विघसं बहु। तमन्येऽप्युपजीवन्ति मन्दा लोभवशा मृगाः॥
English Translation: In this matter Vibhatsu of Pritha's son Vrikodara, or Nakula Or Sahadeva, Or Yudhishthira himself is not to blame in the least.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विषयान् प्रतिसंगृह्य संन्यासं कुरुते यतिः। न च तुष्यन्ति राजानः पश्य बुद्ध्यन्तरं यथा॥
English Translation: While engaged in battle. the Kauravas, puffed up with arrogance and pride have perished with many others who helped them. I am not grieved at this.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पत्राहारैरश्मकुट्टैर्दन्तोलूखलिकैस्तथा। अब्भक्षैर्वायुभक्षैश्च तैरयं नरको जितः॥
English Translation: But there has been one act done by Bhima in the very presence of Vasudeva that excites my anger. Having challenged Duryodhana to a dreadful mace encounter, and having come to know that my son, while making diverse kinds of motion in the battle, was superior to him in skill, the great Vrikodara struck the latter below the navel,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यस्त्विमां वसुधां कृत्स्ना प्रशासेदखिलां नृपः। तुल्याश्मकाञ्चनो यश्च स कृतार्थो न पार्थिवः॥
English Translation: It is this that excites my anger. Why should heroes, for the sake of their lives, forget their duties that have been determined by great persons conversant with every duty?'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संकल्पेषु निरारम्भो निराशो निर्ममो भव। अशोकं स्थानमातिष्ठ इह चामुत्र चाव्ययम्॥
English Translation: Karna said We have not heard of such an act performed by any woman who are noted in this world for their beauty.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निरामिषा न शोचन्ति शोचसि त्वं किमामिषम्। परित्यज्यामिषं सर्वं मृषावादात् प्रमोक्ष्यसे॥
English Translation: When the sons of Pandu and Dhritarashtra were excited with anger, this Krishna, the daughter of Drupada, become their salvation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पन्थानौ पितृयानश्च देवयानश्च विश्रुतौ। ईजानाः पितृयानेन देवयानेन मोक्षिणः॥
English Translation: The sons of Pandu were sinking boatless in an ocean of distress, this Panchali, becoming a boat to them, brought them safely to the shore.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तपसा ब्रह्मचर्येण स्वाध्यायेन महर्षयः। विमुच्य देहांस्ते यान्ति मृत्योरविषयं गताः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said Hearing the words, "A woman is the refuge for the sons of Pandu, "uttered in the midst of the Kurus (by Karna), the angry Bhima in great affliction said:
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आमिषं बन्धनं लोके कर्मेहोक्तं तथामिषम्। ताभ्यां विमुक्तः पापाभ्यां पदमाप्नोति तत् परम्॥
English Translation: Bhima said (O Arjuna), Devala has said that offspring, acts and learning, these are the three lights that is in every person, for from these (three) has sprung the creation,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपि गाथां पुरा गीतां जनकेन वदन्त्युत। निर्द्वन्द्वेन विमुक्तेन मोक्षं समनुपश्यता॥
English Translation: When life becomes extinct and the body becomes impure and is cast off by the relatives, these three (offspring, acts and learning) become of service to every person,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनन्तं बत मे वित्तं यस्य मे नास्ति किञ्चन। मिथिलायां प्रदीप्तायां न मे दह्यति किञ्चन॥
English Translation: But the light that is in us has been dimmed by this act of insult done to our wife. O Dhananjaya, how can a son born from this insulted wife of ours prove serviceable to us?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रज्ञाप्रासादमारुह्य अशोचशोचतो जनान्। जगतीस्थानिवाद्रिस्थो मन्दबुद्धीनवेक्षते॥
English Translation: Arjuna said O descendant of Bharata, great men never care about the harsh words that may or may not be uttered by inferior men. Persons that have earned respects for themselves, even if they are able to retaliate, do not remember the acts of hostility done by their enemies, but they treasure up only their good deeds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दृश्यं पश्यति यः पश्यन् स चक्षुष्मान् स बुद्धिमान्। अज्ञातानां च विज्ञानात् सम्बोधाद् बुद्धिरुच्यते।।२शा
English Translation: Bhima said O king of kings, shall I here at once kill all these foes assembled together, or o descendant of Bharata, shall I destroy them all by the roots outside the palace?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यस्तु वाचं विजानाति बहुमानमियात् स वै। ब्रह्मभावप्रपन्नानां वैद्यानां भावितात्मनाम्॥
English Translation: O descendant of Bharata, what need is there for discussion in this matter) or what need is there for (your) command? I shall kill all these (men) even now, and O king, (then) rule the whole earth without a rival,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदा भूतपृथग्भावमेकस्थमनुपश्यति। तत एव च विस्तारं ब्रह्म सम्पद्यते तदा॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said Having said this Bhima with his younger brothers repeatedly cast his angry glances around as a lion does towards a herd of small animals.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते जनास्तां गतिं यान्ति नाविद्वांसोऽल्पचेतसः। नाबुद्धयो नातपसः सर्वं बुद्धौ प्रतिष्ठितम्॥
English Translation: Partha (Arjuna) of pure deeds pacified him with appealing looks, but the mighty armed and powerful (Bhima) began to burn in the fire of his anger.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: होत्रवाहन उवाच रामं द्रक्ष्यसि भद्रे त्वं जामदग्न्यं महावने। उग्रे तपसि वर्तन्तं सत्यसंधं महाबलम्॥
English Translation: O king, fire with smokes, sparks and flames began to issue out of his ears and other senses, so much angry he became.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महेन्द्रं वै गिरिश्रेष्ठं रामो नित्यमुपास्ति ह। ऋषयो वेदविद्वांसो गन्धर्वाप्सरसस्तथा।।
English Translation: His face became terrible to look at in consequence of his furrowed brows as that of Yama himself at the time of universal destruction.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्र गच्छस्व भद्रं ते ब्रूयाश्चैनं वचो मम। अभिवाद्य च तं मूर्धां तपोवृद्धं दृढव्रतम्॥
English Translation: O descendant of Bharata, thereupon Yudhisthira embracing him with his arms asked the mighty armed hero to forbear, telling him “Be not so. Remain in silence and peace." And
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्रूयाचैनं पुनर्भद्रे यत् ते कार्यं मनीषितम्। मयि संकीतिते रामः सर्वं तत् ते करिष्यति॥
English Translation: Having pacified the mighty armed (Bhima) with eyes red in anger, the king (Yudhisthira) approached his sire Dhritarashtra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मम रामः सखा वत्से प्रीतियुक्तः सुहृच्च मे। जमदग्निसुतो वीरः सर्वशस्त्रभृतां वरः॥
English Translation: Dhritarashtra said After that arrows shot by Drona had been severed and Dhristadyumna rescued by Yuyudhana that foremost of the Vrishnis, o Sanjaya.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं ब्रुवति कन्यां तु पार्थिवे होत्रवाहने। अकृतव्रणः प्रादुरासीद् रामस्यानुचरः प्रियः॥
English Translation: What did the fierce bowman Drona, that foremost of all wielders of weapons, inflamed with wrath, do to the grandson of Sini that foremost of men?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्ते मुनयः सर्वे समुत्तस्थुः सहस्रशः। स च राजा वयोवृद्धः सृञ्जयो होत्रवाहनः॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said Then Drona, like a huge snake having wrath for his poison, the stretched bow for his wide open mouth, sharp Narachas for his teeth, whetted arrows for his fangs, with woves coppery in rage and breathing like a furnacethat undaunted warrior, borne by his fleet steeds of crimson hue that appeared to soar high into the heavens or get at the summit of the highest of mountains, advanced against Yuyudhana, scattering right and left his arrows furnished with golden wings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो दृष्ट्वा कृतातिथ्यमन्योन्यं ते वनौकसः। सहिता भरतश्रेष्ठ निषेदुः परिवार्य तम्॥
English Translation: Beholding the irresistible Drona-cloud having showers of arrows for its watery downpour, the rattle of Chariot-wheels for its rumbling noise, the stretched bow for its volume, numerous Narachas for its flashes of lightning, darts and scimitars for its thunder, wrath for the violent wind going before it and steeds for the hurricane driving it forward.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्ते कथयामासुः कथास्तास्ता मनोरमाः। धन्या दिव्याश्च राजेन्द्र प्रीतिहर्षमुदा युताः॥
English Translation: Make towards himself, that subjugator of hostile towns, the invincible and heroic grandson of Sini, smilingly addressing his charioteer said
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः कथान्ते राजर्षिर्महात्मा होत्रवाहनः। राम श्रेष्ठं महर्षीणामपृच्छदकृतव्रणम्॥
English Translation: Against this heroic Brahmana fallen off from all his duties, who is the refuge of the Dhritarashtras and the despeller of the sorrow and anxiety of their king,

Sanskrit Shloka: क्व सम्प्रति महाबाहो जामदग्न्यः प्रतापवान्। अकृतव्रण शक्यो वै दुष्टुं वेदविदां वरः॥
English Translation: Who is also he preceptor of all the princes and is ever boastful of his prowess, do rush cheerfully and quickly, being borne by steeds urged to the top of their speed?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अकृतव्रण उवाच भवन्तमेव सततं रामः कीर्तयति प्रभो। सृञ्जयो मे प्रियसखो राजर्षिरिति पार्थिव॥
English Translation: Thereupon those best of steeds of argentine hue and of the fleetness of the wind, belonging that descendant of Madhus race, flew in all haste, towards Drona in that battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इह रामः प्रभाते श्वो भवितेति मतिर्मम। द्रष्टास्येनमिहायान्तं तवं दर्शनकाझ्या॥
English Translation: Then those two afflicters of foes Drona and Yuyudhana began to fight with each other, striking each other with many a thousand shafts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इयं च कन्या राजर्षे किमर्थं वनमागता। कस्य चेयं तव च का भवतीच्छामि वेदितुम्॥
English Translation: Those two foremost of men enshrouded the Welkin in a net-work of arrows and those two heroes filled the ten points of the compass with their arrowy discharges.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: होत्रवाहन उवाच दौहित्रीयं मम विभो काशिराजसुता प्रिया। ज्येष्ठा स्वयंवरे तस्थौ भगिनीभ्यां सहानघ॥
English Translation: Like two clouds at the expiration of summer pouring their contents on the Earth, they poured their showers of arrows on each other; the sun did not shine then, nor did the wind bow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इयमम्बेति विख्याता ज्येष्ठा काशिपतेः सुता। अम्बिकाम्बालिके कन्ये कनीयस्यौ तपोधन॥
English Translation: In consequence of these showers of arrows filling the firmament, in impenetrable and deep gloom created there that became unbearable to the other warriors.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: समेतं पार्थिवं क्षत्रं काशिपूर्यां ततोऽभवत्। कन्यानिमित्तं विप्रर्षे तत्रासीदुत्सवो महान्॥
English Translation: was
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः किल महावीर्यो भीष्मः शान्तनवो नृपान्। अधिक्षिप्य महातेजास्तिस्रः कन्या जहारताः॥
English Translation: When the arrows of those two foremost of those accomplished in the use of weapons, viz., Drona and Shini's grandson, had covered the world with that gloom. None could find any interval in the shooting of arrows by those two best of warriors.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निर्जित्य पृथिवीपालानथं भीष्मो गजाह्वयम्। आजगाम विशुद्धात्मा कन्याभिः सह भारतः॥
English Translation: The sound produced by the clashing of the showers of arrows shot by them, was heard there to resemble the rumble of the thunderbolt hurled by Indra himself,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सत्यवत्यै निवेद्याथ विवाहं समनन्तरम्। भ्रातुर्विचित्रवीर्यस्य समाज्ञापयत प्रभुः॥
English Translation: The appearances of heroic warriors pierced with Narachas looked, O Bharata, like those of snakes of virulent poison, bit by other snakes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं तु वैवाहिकं दृष्ट्वा कन्येयं समुपार्जितम्। अब्रवीत् तत्र गाङ्गेयं मन्त्रिमध्ये द्विजर्षभ॥
English Translation: The sound produced by the palm-strokes and twanging bows of those two accomplished warriors, was heard there. To resemble the sound that is produced by the incessant striking of the bolt of heaven on mountain summits.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मया शाल्वपतिर्वीरो मनसाभिवृतः पतिः। न मामर्हसि धर्मज्ञ दातुं भ्रात्रेऽन्यमानसाम्॥
English Translation: The chariots of both those heroes, O king and their horses and charioteers being pierced with shafts of golden wings, became beautiful to look at.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तच्छ्रुत्वा वचनं भीष्मः सम्मन्त्र्य सह मन्त्रिभिः। निश्चित्य विससर्जेमां सत्यवत्या मते स्थितः॥
English Translation: O ruler of men, of effulgent and straightgoing Narachas, the down-pour was terrible and it resembled a shower of snakes of virulent poison, that have just cast off their slough.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनुज्ञाता तु भीष्मेण शाल्वं सौभपतिं ततः। कन्येयं मुदिता तत्र काले वचनमब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: The umbrellas of both those warriors were felled and their standards were also cut down. Both of them were bespattered with blood and both were desirous of obtaining victory.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विसर्जिताऽस्मि भीष्मेण धर्मं मां प्रतिपादय। मनसाभिवृतः पूर्वं मया त्वं पार्थिवर्षभ॥
English Translation: With bodies steeped in blood and looking like two elephants in rut. They began to pierce each other with arrows capable of destroying life.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रत्याचख्यौ च शाल्वोऽस्याश्चारित्रस्याभिशङ्कितः। सेयं तपोवनं प्राप्ता तापस्येऽभिरता भृशम्॥
English Translation: The din of battle caused by war-cries, shouts, roars and the sound of drums and the blare of conchs ceased, O mighty monarch, for none then uttered anything.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मया च प्रत्यभिज्ञाता वंशस्य परिकीर्तनात्। अस्य दुःखस्य चोत्पत्तिं भीष्ममेवेह मन्यते॥
English Translation: The troops became silent and warriors withdrew from the fight, filled with curiosity, men began to behold that single combat between those two heroes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अम्बोवाच भगवन्नेवमेवेह यथाऽऽह पृथिवीपतिः। शरीरकर्ता मातुर्मे सृञ्जयो होत्रवाहनः॥
English Translation: Car-warriors, elephant-drivers, horsemen and foot-soldiers surrounding those two foremost of men, began to witness that combat with fixed eyes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न झुत्सहे स्वनगरं प्रतियातुं तपोधन। अपमानभयाच्चैव व्रीडया च महामुने॥
English Translation: The elephant-division as also the horse division stood still, so also the car-divisions stood still, arranging themselves in battle array.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यत् तु मां भगवान् रामो वक्ष्यति द्विजसत्तम। तन्मे कार्यतमं कार्यमिति मे भगवन् मतिः॥
English Translation: Adorned with diverse kinds of pearls and corals, decked with jewels and gold adorned with standards and ornaments, with armour made of gold, with flags and pennons, with the precious caparisons of elephants, with fine blankets with effulgent and whetted weapons, with Chamaras decked with gold and silver, with warriors on the backs and necks of horse and elephants with garlands round the frontal globes of elephants and with circlets round their tusks, ( Bharata, the Kuru and the Pandava troops then looked like masses of clouds at the close of the summer seasons, decked with rows of cranes and numerous fireflies underneath them and beautified with rainbows and flashes of lightning.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच निनदन्तं तथा तं तु भीमसेनं महाबलम्। मेघस्तनितनिर्घोष के वीराः पर्यवारयन्॥
English Translation: O king, Our troops, as also those belonging to Yudhishthira, beheld that combat between Yuyudhana and the illustrious Drona.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न हि पश्याम्यहं तं वै त्रिषु लोकेषु कंचन। क्रुद्धस्य भीमसेनस्य यस्तिष्ठेदग्रतो रणे॥
English Translation: Coming there on their sky-ranging cars, the gods headed by Brahma and Soma and hosts of Siddhas and Charanas and Vidyadharas and mighty reptiles, all saw that combat.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गदां युयुत्समानस्य कालस्येवेह संजय। न हि पश्याम्यहं युद्धे यस्तिष्ठेदग्रतः पुमान्॥
English Translation: The backward and forward movements and the modes of fighting, o king, of those two foremost of heroes, filled all of them with wonder.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रथं रथेन यो हन्यात् कुञ्जरं कुञ्जरेण च। कस्तस्थ समरे स्थाता साक्षादपि पुरंदरः॥
English Translation: Displaying great lightness of hands, those two mighty heroes, namely Drona and Satyaki, pierced each other with each other's arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क्रुद्धस्य भीमसेनस्य मम पुत्रान् जिघांसतः। दुर्योधनहिते युक्ताः समतिष्ठन्त केऽग्रतः॥
English Translation: Thereafter in that battle he of the Dasharha race cut-off the arrows shot by Drona with his strong and winged shafts; as also the bow of that highly effulgent warrior.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीमसेनदवाग्नेस्तु मम पुत्रांस्तृणोपमान्। प्रधक्षतो रणमुखे केऽतिष्ठन्नग्रतो नराः॥
English Translation: But in a wink's time, the son of Bharadvaja fixed the string on another bow; but that also Satyaki cut-off quickly. But again Drona stood ready with a bow in hand. As often however Drona strung his bow so often did Satyaki cut it off and this he did for full sixty-three times.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: काल्यमानांस्तु पुत्रान् मे दृष्ट्वा भीमेन संयुगे। कालेनेव प्रजाः सर्वाः के भीमं पर्यवारयन्॥
English Translation: Satyaki with his formidable bow cut-off one hundred bows of Acharya. However, it was strange to guess the difference between two functions i.e. when Acharya shoot the arrow and when Satyaki cut-off it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न मेऽर्जुनाद् भयं तादृक् कृष्णान्नापि च सात्वतात्। हुतभुग्जन्मनो नैव यादृग्मीमाद् भयं मम॥
English Translation: Thereupon in that battle, Drona beholding that superhuman feat thought in his mind thus.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीमवह्नेः प्रदीप्तस्य मम पुत्रान् दिधक्षतः। के शूराः पर्यवर्तन्त तन्ममाचक्ष्व संजय॥
English Translation: Achieved by Yuyudhana, O king-'This force of weapon that I see in this foremost of the Satvata race is possible only in Rama, in Kartavirya, in Dhananjaya and in Bhishma'. So, Drona praised the prowess of that hero in his mind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच तथा तु नर्दमानं तं भीमसेनं महाबलम्। तुमुलेनैव शब्देन कर्णोऽप्यभ्यद्रवद्बली॥
English Translation: Then that foremost of the regenerate ones, that best of all wielders of weapons, namely Drona, as also the celestials with Indra himself at their head, were highly gratified at seeing the lightness of hands displayed by Satyaki, which resembled that of Vasava himself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्याक्षिपन् सुमहचातमतिमात्रममर्षणः। कर्णः सुयुद्धमाकाङ्क्षन् दर्शयिष्यन् बलं मृधे॥
English Translation: O ruler of men neither the gods nor the Gandharvas ever before beheld the like of that lightress of hands now displayed by the swiftly-moving Yuyudhana. Although they, the Siddhas and the Charanas, were cognisant of the feats of which Drona was capable.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रुरोध मार्ग भीमस्य वातस्येव महीरुहः। भीमोऽपि दृष्ट्वा सावेगं पुरो वैकर्तनं स्थितम्॥
English Translation: Then taking up another bow, Drona that crusher of Kshatriyas that foremost of those acquainted with the use of weapons, O Bharata, placed some weapons on its string.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चुकोप बलवद्वीरश्चिक्षेपास्य शिलाशितान्। तान् प्रत्यगृह्णात् कर्णोऽपि प्रतीपं प्रापयच्छरान्॥
English Translation: But repulsing Drona's weapons with the illusion of his own weapons, Satyaki pierced Drona with exceedingly sharp arrows; that indeed appeared marvellous.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्तु सवर्याधानां यततां प्रेक्षतां तदा। प्रावेपन्निव गात्राणि कर्णभीमसमागमे॥ रथिनां सादिनां चैन तयोः :श्रुत्वा तलखनम्। भीमसेनस्य निनदं श्रुत्वा घोरं रणाजिरे॥
English Translation: Beholding that superhuman feat achieved by him in battle-feat which was incapable of being achieved by others and which displayed great tact, those amongst your warriors who were judges of skill, highly praised it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: खं च भूमिं च संरुद्धां मेनिरे क्षत्रियर्षभाः। पुनरिण नादेन पाण्डवस्य महात्मनः॥
English Translation: Whatsoever weapon Drona discharged, Satyaki also discharged the same. Beholding this, scorcher of foes namely the preceptor fought with Satyaki diffidently.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: समरे सर्वयोधानां धनूंष्यभ्यपतन् क्षितौ। शस्त्राणि न्यपतन् दोर्थ्यः केषांचिचासवोऽद्रवन्॥ वित्रस्तानि च सर्वाणि शकृन्मूत्रं प्रसुस्रवुः। वाहनानि च सर्वाणि बभूवुर्विमनांसि च॥ प्रादुरासन् निमित्तानि घोराणि सुबहून्युत।
English Translation: Thereupon, O mighty monarch, that one who had reached the end of all military sciences, being inflamed with wrath invoked into existence a celestial weapon slaughtering Yuyudhana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गृध्रकङ्कबलैश्चासीदन्तरिक्षं समावृतम्॥ तस्मिन् सुतुमले राजन् कर्णभीमसमागमे।
English Translation: Beholding that dreadful and fiery dart capable of slaying the foe and of celestial make, that fierce bowman Satyaki invoked into existence the Varuna weapon.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः कर्णस्तु विंशत्या शराणां भीममार्दयत्।॥ विव्याध चास्य त्वरितः सूतं पञ्चभिराशुगैः।
English Translation: Beholding them both using celestial weapons, the troops uttered loud cries of Alas weapon for and Oh; then the denizens of the air ceased to range through the sky.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रहस्य भीमसेनोऽपि कर्ण प्रत्याद्रवद् रणे॥ सायकानां चतुःष्ट्या क्षिप्रकारी महायशाः।
English Translation: When the Varuna and Agneva weapons were placed on their bow strings just at that moment, the lustrous orb of day went below the horizon.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य कर्णो महेष्वासः सायंकाश्चतुरोऽक्षिपत्॥ असम्प्राप्तांश्च तान् भीमः सायकैर्नप्तपर्वभिः।
English Translation: Thereupon, king Yudhishthira and Bhimasena and the son of Pandu, (Arjuna) and Nakula and Sahadeva, rushed to the rescue of Satyaki.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चिच्छेद बहुधा राजन् दर्शयन् पाणिलाघवम्॥ तं कर्णश्छादयामास शरवातैरनेकशः।
English Translation: Other warriors headed by Dhristadyumna and accompanied by Virata and his divisions so also the Matsyas and Shalvas quickly advanced upon Drona.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संछाद्यमानः कर्णेन बहुधा पाण्डुनन्दनः॥ चिच्छेद चापं कर्णस्य मुष्टिदेशे महारथः।
English Translation: Thousands of princes, on the other hand, headed by Dushasana proceeded to help Drona who had been thoroughly encompassed by the foe.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विव्याध चैनं बहुभिः सायकैर्नतपर्वभिः॥ अथान्यद् धनुरादाय सज्यं कृत्वा च सूतजः।
English Translation: Thereat, O king, the fight between your warriors and those of the Pandava, commenced anew. Then the earth became enveloped in a cloud of dust and in a net-work of arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विव्याध समरे भीमं भीमकर्मा महारथः॥ तस्य भीमो भृशं क्रुद्धस्त्रीशरान् नतपर्वणः।
English Translation: Everything being covered, nothing could any longer be distinguished. Thus when the troops were overwhelmed with dust, the battle raged in utter disregard of all rules of combat.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निचखानोरसि क्रुद्धः सूतपुत्रस्य वेगतः॥ तैः कर्णोऽराजत शरैरुरोर्मध्यगतैस्तदा।
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : When Dushyanta went away from the hermitage, making the (above) promises to Shakuntala, she gave birth to a boy of immeasurable energy. When the child grew only three years old, he became in splendour as blazing as the blazing fire. O Janamejaya, he was endued with great beauty, magnanimity and all accomplishments.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महीधर इवोदग्रस्त्रिशृङ्गो भरतर्षभ।॥ सुस्राव चास्य रुधिरं विद्धस्य परमेषुभिः।
English Translation: The best of pious men, Kanvas, performed all the rites ordained by the scriptures on that intelligent boy who began to grow up day by day.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धातुप्रस्यन्दिनः शैलाद् यथा गैरिकधातवः॥ किंचिद् विचलितः कर्णः सुप्रहाराभिपीडितः।
English Translation: The boy was gifted with sharp, strong and pearly teeth; he was strong enough to kill lions, he had all auspicious signs on his palms, he had a broad forehead, he was beautiful and strong.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आकर्णपूर्णमाकृष्य भीमं विव्याध सायकैः॥ चिक्षेप च पुनर्बाणाशतशोऽथ सहस्रशः।
English Translation: Like a celestial child, he began daily to grow up. When he grew six years old, he was so strong that he seized and bound tigers, boars, buffaloes and elephants to the trees that stood near the hermitage.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स शरैरर्दितस्तेन कर्णेन दृढधन्विना। धनुर्ध्यामच्छिनत् तूर्ण भीमस्तस्य क्षुरेण ह॥
English Translation: He rode on some of these wild beasts; he seized some of them and sometimes he pursued some of them in playful mood. The dwellers of the hermitage of Kanva, (finding all this), gave him a name. (They said,) “As he subjugated all beasts, let him be called Sarvadamana". Thus the prince came to be called Sarvadamana, endued as he was with great strength, energy and powers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सारथिं चास्य भल्लेन रथनीडादपातयत्। वाहांश्च चतुरस्तस्य व्यंसूश्चक्रे महारथः॥
English Translation: Seeing the extraordinary acts of the boy, the Rishi (Kanva) told Shakuntala that the time had come when he should be installed as the heir-apparent.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हताश्वात् तु रथात् कर्णः समाप्लुत्य विशाम्पते। स्यन्दनं वृषसेनस्य तूर्णमापुप्लुवे भयात्॥
English Translation: Seeing the great strength of the boy, Kanva spoke to his disciples thus, "Take Shakuntala with her son from the hermitage to the house of her husband, blessed with all auspicious signs."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निर्जित्य त रणे कर्ण भीमसेनः प्रतापवान्। ननाद बलवान् नादं पर्जन्यनिनदोपमम्॥
English Translation: It is not fit for women to live for ever in the house of their paternal or maternal relations. Such residence destroys their good name, good conduct and virtue. Therefore, take her to her husband's house without delay.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य तं निन्दं श्रुत्वा प्रहृष्टोऽभूद् युधिष्ठिरः। कर्ण पराजितं मत्वा भीमसेनेन संयुगे॥
English Translation: The greatly effulgent disciples (of Kanva), having promised to do it, started with Shakuntala and her son towards the city of Hastinapur.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: समन्ताच्छङ्कुनिनदं पाण्डुसेनाकरोत् तदा। शत्रुसेनाध्वनि श्रुत्वा तावका ह्यनदन् भृशम्॥
English Translation: That beauty of fair eye-brows, taking her lotus-eyed son of celestial beauty with her, left the forest where she had first met Dushyanta.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स शङ्खबाणनिनदैर्हर्षाद् राजा स्ववाहिनीम्। चक्रे युधिष्ठिरः संख्ये हर्षनादैश्च संकुलाम्॥ गाण्डीवं व्याक्षिपत् पार्थः कृष्णोऽप्यन्जमवादयत्। तमन्तर्धाय निनदं भीमस्य नदतो ध्वनिः। अश्रूयत तदा राजन् सर्वसैन्येषु दारुणः॥
English Translation: Having sent words, she entered the royal court with her son, as effulgent as the morning sun. And she was then introduced to him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो व्यायच्छतामस्त्रैः पृथक् पृथगजिह्मगैः। मृदुपूर्व तु राधेयो दृढपूर्व तु पाण्डवः॥
English Translation: The disciples of the Rishi, having told the king everything, returned to the hermitage. And Shakuntala, after duly worshipping the
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच शरतल्पगतं भीष्मं वृद्धं कुरुपितामहम्। उपगम्य महाप्राज्ञः पर्यपृच्छद् युधिष्ठिरः॥
English Translation: Shakuntala said : O King, this is your son. Let him be installed as your heir-apparent. O King, this god-like boy was begotten by you on me. O best of men, fulfil now the promise you made of me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच अङ्गानां रूपसौभाग्यं प्रियं चैव कथं भवेत्। धर्मार्थकामसंयुक्तः सुखभागी कथं भवेत्॥
English Translation: O illustrious man, call to your mind the agreement you made with me on the occasion of our marriage at the hermitage of Kanva.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच मार्गशीर्षस्य मासस्य चन्द्रे मूलेन संयुते। पादौ मूलेन राजेन्द्र जंघायामथ रोहिणीम्॥ अश्चिन्यां सक्थिनी चैव उरू चाषाढयोस्तथा। गुह्यं तु फाल्गुनी विद्यात् कृत्तिका कटिकास्तथा।॥ नाभिं भाद्रपदे विद्याद् रेवत्यामक्षिमण्डलम्। पृष्ठमेव धनिष्ठासु अनुराधोत्तरास्तथा॥ बाहुभ्यां तु विशाखासु हस्तौ हस्तेन निर्दिशेत्। पुनर्वस्वङ्गुली राजन्नाश्लेषासु नखास्तथा॥ ग्रीवां ज्येष्ठा च राजेन्द्र श्रवणेन तु कर्णयोः। मुखं पुष्येण दानेन दन्तोष्ठौ स्वातिरुच्यते॥ हासं शतभिषां चैव मघां चैवाथ नासिकाम्। नेत्रे मृगशिरो विद्याल्ललाटे मित्रमेव तु॥ भरण्यां तु शिरो विद्यात् केशानार्दो नराधिप। समाप्ते तु घृतं दद्याद् ब्राह्मणे वेदपारगे॥
English Translation: Having heard her words, the King remembered everything, but he said, “I remember nothing. O wicked ascetic woman, to whom do you belong?"
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुभगो दर्शनीयश्च ज्ञानभाग्यथ जायते। जायते परिपूर्णाङ्गः पौर्णमास्येव चन्द्रमाः॥
English Translation: I do not remember to have any connection with you with regard to (either) Dharma, Artha and Kama. Go or stay or do whatever you please.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच ततः प्रज्वलिते वह्नौ शाईकास्ते सुदुःखिताः। व्यथिताः परमोद्विग्ना नाधिजग्मुः परायणम्॥
English Translation: Thus being addressed, the beautiful ascetic lady was filled with shame. She lost her consciousness from grief and she stood like a wooden post.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निशम्य पुत्रकान् बालान् माता तेषां तपस्विनी। जरिता शोकदुःखाती विललाप सुदुःखिता॥
English Translation: Soon became her eyes red like copper; her lips began to quiver; she cast upon the king her (angry) glances which seemed to burn him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जरितोवाच अयमग्निर्दहन् कक्षमित आयाति भीषणः। जगत् संदीपयन् भीमो मम दुःखविवर्धनः॥
English Translation: Her rising anger and blazing fire of her asceticism she kept down with a great effort.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इमे च मां कर्षयन्ति शिशवो मन्दचेतसः। अबर्दाश्चरङ्गीनाः पूर्वेषां नः परायणाः॥
English Translation: Collecting her thought in a moment, she thus addressed her husband looking straight at him in grief and in anger. “O great king, knowing everything, how can you, like a mean and inferior man, say that you know nothing'?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्रासयंश्चायमायाति लेलिहानो महीरुहान्। अजातपक्षाश्च सुता न शक्ताः सरणे मम॥
English Translation: Your heart is the witness to the truth or to the falsehood of my words. Therefore, speak the truth and do not degrade yourself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आदाय च न शक्नोमि पुत्रांस्तरितुमात्मना। न च त्यक्तुमहं शक्ता हृदयं दूयतीव मे॥
English Translation: He, who has one thing in his mind, but represents another thing to others, is a thief and a robber of his own self. What sin is he not capable of committing?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कं तु जह्यामहं पुत्रं कमादाय व्रजाम्यहम्। किं न मे नु मे स्यात् कृतं कृत्वा मन्यध्वं पुत्रकाः कथम्।७।।
English Translation: You think that you alone know what you did. But do you not know that the great Omniscient One dwells in your heart. He knows all your sins and you sin in his presence.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चिन्तयानां विमोक्षं वो नाधिगच्छामि किंचन। छादयिष्यामि वो गात्रैः करिष्ये मरणं सह॥
English Translation: Man, when sinning, thinks that no one sees him. But he is seen by the celestials and by the Deity who dwells in every heart.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जरितारौ कुलं ह्येतज्ज्येष्ठत्वेन प्रतिष्ठितम्। सारिसृक्कः प्रजायेत पितॄणां कुलवर्धनः॥ स्तम्बमित्रस्तपः कुर्याद् द्रोणो ब्रह्मविदां वरः। इत्येवमुक्त्वा प्रययौ पिता वो निर्वृणः पुरा॥
English Translation: The sun, the moon, the air, the fire, the earth, the sky, the water, the heart, Yama, the day, the night, the twilight and Dharma see every act of man.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कमुपादाय शक्येयं गन्तुं कष्टापदुत्तमा। किं नु कृत्वा कृतं कार्यं भवेदिति च विह्वला। नापश्यत् स्वधिया मोक्षं स्वसुतानां तदानलात्॥
English Translation: Yama, the son of Vivasvata, takes no account of the sins of that man with whom the Deity, the witness of all acts, remains pleased.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच एवं ब्रुवाणां शास्तेि प्रत्यूचुरथ मातरम्। स्नेहमुत्सृज्य मातस्त्वं पत यत्र न हव्यवाट॥
English Translation: But that sinner, with whom the great Deity is not pleased, is punished by Yama for his wicked deeds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अस्मास्विह विनष्टेषु भवितारः सुतास्तव। त्वयि मातर्विनष्टायां न नः स्यात् कुलसंततिः॥
English Translation: He, who falsely represents his self and thus degrades himself, is never blessed by the celestials. Even his own soul does not bless him. I have come of my own accord, but I am a devoted wife to my husband. Do not disrespect me. I am your wife and deserve to be treated respectfully.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्ववैश्यैतदुभयं क्षेमं स्याद् यत् कुलस्य नः। तद् वै कर्तुं परः कालो मातरेष भवेत् तव॥
English Translation: Why do you treat me before all these men like an ordinary woman? I am certainly not crying in the wilderness. Do you not hear me?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मा त्वं सर्वविनाशाय स्नेहं कार्षीः सुतेषु नः। न हीदं कर्म मोघं स्याल्लोककामस्य नः पितुः॥
English Translation: O Dushyanta, If you refuse what I ask you to do, your head will to day be divided into a thousand pieces.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जरितोवाच इदमाखोर्बिलं भूमौ वृक्षस्यास्य समीपतः। तदाविशध्वं त्वरिता वढेरत्र न वो भयम्॥
English Translation: The learned men of old say that the husband himself, entering into the womb of his wife, comes out as the son. Therefore, the wife is called Jaya.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽहं पांसुना छिद्रमपिधास्यामि पुत्रकः। एवं प्रतिकृतं मन्ये ज्वलतः कृष्णवर्त्मनः॥
English Translation: The son, that is born to a wise man, rescues the spirits of his deceased ancestors.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत एष्याम्यतीतेऽग्नौ विहन्तुं पांसुसंचयम्। रोचतामेष वो वादो मोक्षार्थं च हुताशनात्॥
English Translation: Because the son rescues his ancestors from the hell, called Put, therefore he has been called by the self-created (Brahma) himself as Putra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शाईका ऊचुः अबर्हान् मांसभूतान् नः क्रव्यादाखुर्विनाशयेत्। पश्यमाना भयमिदं प्रवेष्टुं नाा शक्नुमः॥
English Translation: A man conquers the world by the birth of a son; he enjoys eternity by that of a grandson; the great grandfathers enjoy eternal happiness by the birth of a grandson's son.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कथमग्निर्न ने धक्ष्येत् कथमाखु नाशयेत्। कथं न स्यात् पिता मोघः कथं माता ध्रियेत नः॥
English Translation: She is a true wife who is a good housewife; she is a true wife whose heart is devoted to her husband; she is a true wife who is faithful to her husband,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बिल आखोर्विनाशः स्यादग्नेराकाशचारिणाम्। अन्ववेक्ष्यैतदुभयं श्रेयान् दाहो न भक्षणम्॥
English Translation: A man's half is his wife, the wife is her husband's best of friends; the wife is the source of Dharma, Artha and Kama; the wife is the source of salvation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गर्हितं मरणं नः स्यादाखुना भक्षिते बिले। शिष्टादिष्टः परित्यागः शरीरस्य हुताशनात्॥
English Translation: Those that have wives can perform religious acts; those that have wives lead domestic lives. Those that have wives can be happy and those that have wives can achieve good fortune.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच सैन्धवैरभवद् युद्धं ततस्तस्य किरीटिनः। हतशेषैर्महाराज हतानां च सुतैरपि॥
English Translation: The sweet-speeched wives their husband's friends on the occasion of joy; they are as fathers on occasions of religious acts; they are as mothers in the hours of illness and are woe.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेऽवतीर्णमुपश्रुत्य विषयं श्वेतवाहनम्। प्रत्युद्ययुरमृष्यन्तो राजानः पाण्डवर्षभम्॥
English Translation: Even in the deep forest, the wife is the refreshment and solace to her roaming husband. He who has a wife, is trusted by all. The wife, therefore, is man's great means of salvation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अश्वं च तं परामृश्य विषयान्ते विषोपमाः। न भयं चक्रिरे पार्थाद् भीमसेनादनन्तरात्॥
English Translation: When the husband goes to the land of Yama, leaving this world, it is the devoted wife only that accompanies him there.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेऽविदूराद् धनुष्पाणिं यज्ञियस्य हयस्य च। बीभत्सुं प्रत्यपद्यन्त पदातिनमवस्थितम्॥
English Translation: The wife, gone before (dying before her husband), waits for the spirit of her husband and if the husband goes before, the chaste wife soon follows him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्ते तं महावीर्या राजानः पर्यवारयन्। जिगीषन्तो नरव्याघ्र पूर्वं विनिकृता युधि॥
English Translation: O king, for all these reasons, marriage exists (in this world). The husband enjoys the company of his wife, both here in this world and hereafter.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते नामान्यपि गोत्राणि कर्माणि विविधानि च। कीर्तयन्तस्तदा पार्थं शरवषैरवाकिरन्॥
English Translation: The learned men have said that a man himself is born as his son; therefore, a man whose wife has given birth to a son, should look upon her as his mother.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते किरन्तः शरवातान् बारणप्रतिवारणान्। रणे जयमभीप्सन्तः कौन्तेयं पर्यवारयन्॥
English Translation: Looking at the face of the son, begotten on his wife, a man sees his own face as he does in a mirror; and feels himself as happy as a virtuous man attaining to heaven.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते समीक्ष्य च तं कृष्णमुग्रकर्माणमाहवे। सर्वे ययुधिरे वीरा रथस्थास्तं पदातिनम्॥
English Translation: Men, burnt out by mental grief or afflicted by disease, feel as much relieved in the company of their wives as a perspiring man does in a cool bath.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते तमाजन्जिरे वीरं निवातकवचान्तकम्। संशप्तकनिहन्तारं हन्तारं सैन्धवस्य च।॥
English Translation: No man, even in anger, should even do any thing that is disagreeable to his wife; for happiness, joy, virtue and everything depend on the wife.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो रथसहस्रेण हयानामयुतेन च। कोष्ठकीकृत्य बीभत्सुं प्रहृष्टमनसोऽभवन्॥
English Translation: Wife is the sacred soil in which the husband is born again. Even Rishis cannot create men without women.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं स्मरन्तो वधं वीरा: सिन्धुराजस्य चाहवे। जयद्रथस्य कौरव्य समरे सव्यसाचिना॥ ततः पर्जन्यवत् सर्वे शरवृष्टीरवासृजन्। तै: कीर्णः शुशुभे पार्थो रविर्मेघान्तरे यथा॥
English Translation: What is a greater happiness to a father than what the father feels when his son, running to him, clasps him with his (tiny little) arms, though his body is full of dust and dirt?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स शरैः समवच्छन्नश्चकाशे पाण्डवर्षभः। पञ्जरान्तरसंचारी शकुन्त इव भारत॥
English Translation: Why are you treating with indifference this your son who has himself come to you and who is wistfully casting his glances towards you? Even ants support their off-spring and do not destroy their eggs. Why then should you not, being learned in the rules of piety, support your own child?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो हाहाकृतं सर्वं कौन्तेये शरपीडिते। त्रैलोक्यमभवद् राजन् रविरासीच्च निष्प्रभः॥
English Translation: The touch of the sandal-paste, that of women and water, is not so pleasing as that of one's own infant son, locked in his embrace.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो ववौ महाराज मारुतो लोमहर्षणः। राहुरग्रसदादित्यं युगपत् सोममेव च॥
English Translation: As the Brahmana is the best among bipeds (men), as cow is the best among quadrupeds, as preceptor is the best among all superiors, so is the son among all objects pleasing to the touch.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उल्काश्च जधिरे सूर्यं विकीर्यन्त्यः समन्ततः। वेपथुश्चाभवद् राजन् कैलासस्य महागिरेः॥
English Translation: Let this handsome son touch you in your embrace. There is nothing in the world more pleasing to the touch than that of a son.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मुमुचुः श्वासमत्युष्णं दुःखशोकसमन्विताः। सप्तर्षयो जातभयास्तथा देवर्षयोऽपि च॥
English Translation: O chastiser of foes, O great king, I gave birth to this boy, the dispeller of your grief, after the completion of three years. O descendant of the Puru race, when I was in the lying-in room, the following words were uttered in the sky, He shall perform one hundred horse-sacrifices.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शशं चाशु विनिर्भिद्य मण्डलं शशिनोऽपतत्। विपरीता दिशश्चापि सर्वा धूमाकुलास्तथा॥
English Translation: Men, going to places remote from their homes, take up other men's sons on their laps and smelling their heads, feel great happiness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रासभारुणसंकाशा धनुष्मन्तः सविद्युतः। आवृत्य गगनं मेघा मुमुचुर्मोसशोणितम्॥
English Translation: You know that the Brahmanas utter the following Vedic Mantras at the birthday, ceremony of the child.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमासीत् तदा वीरे शरवर्षेण संवृते। फाल्गुने भरतश्रेष्ठ तद्युतमिवाभवत्।॥
English Translation: “You are born of my body; you have sprung from my heart. You are myself in the form of my son. Live for one hundred years."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य तेनावकीर्णस्य शरजालेन सर्वतः। मोहात् पपात गाण्डीवमावापश्च करादपि।॥
English Translation: My life depends on you. The continuation of my race also depends on you. Therefore, live in happiness for one hundred years.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मिन् मोहमनुप्राप्ते शरजालं महत् तदा। सैन्धवा मुमुचुस्तूर्णं गतसत्त्वे महारथे॥
English Translation: He (this boy) has sprung from your body, he is a second being begotten from you. Behold your own self in your own son, as you see your image in the clear waters of the lake.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो मोहसमापन्नं ज्ञात्वा पार्थं दिवौकसः। सर्वे वित्रस्तमनसस्तस्य शान्तिकृतोऽभवन्॥
English Translation: As the sacrificial fire is kindled from the domestic fire, so has this one (your son), sprung from you. Though you are one, you have divided yourself in two. O king, in your hunting expedition, I was approached by you when I was a virgin in my father's hermitage.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो देवर्षयः सर्वे तथा सप्तर्षयोऽपि च। ब्रह्मर्षयश्च विजयं जेपुः पार्थस्य धीमतः॥
English Translation: Urvashi, Purvachitti, Sahajanya, Menaka, Vishvachi and Ghritachi, these are the six foremost Apsaras.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः प्रदीपिते देवैः पार्थतेजसि पार्थिव। तस्थावचलवद् धीमान् संग्रामे परमास्त्रवित्॥
English Translation: Amongst them again, Menaka, born of a Brahmana, is the first. Descending from heaven on earth, she gave me birth from her association with Vishvamitra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विचकर्ष धनुर्दिव्यं ततः कौरवनन्दनः। यन्त्रस्येवेह शब्दोऽभून्महांस्तस्य पुनः पुनः॥
English Translation: The Apsara Menaka gave me birth in a valley of the Himalayas. Devoid of affections, she went away, leaving me there, as if I was a child of some others.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः स शरवर्षाणि प्रत्यमित्रान् प्रति प्रभुः। ववर्ष धनुषा पार्थो वर्षाणीव पुरंदरः॥
English Translation: What great sin did I commit of old in some other life that I was cast away by my parents in my infancy and now I am cast away by you?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्ते सैन्धवा योधाः सर्व एव सराजकाः। नादृश्यन्त शरैः कीर्णाः शलभैरिव पादपाः॥
English Translation: Cast off from you, I am ready to go back to the hermitage. But you should not cast off this child who is your own son.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य शब्देन वित्रेसुर्भयार्ताश्च विदुद्रुवुः । मुमुचुश्चाश्रु शोकार्ताः शुशुचुश्चापि सैन्धवाः॥
English Translation: Dushyanta said : O Shakuntala, I do not know that I begot this child on you. Women generally speak falsehood. Who will believe your words? Your mother is lewd Menaka, destitute of affection; she cast off you in the valley of the Himalayas as one casts off the flowers after offering them to the gods.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तांस्तु सर्वान् नरव्याघ्रः सैन्धवान् व्यचरत् बली। अलातचक्रवद् राजशरजालैः समार्पयत्॥
English Translation: Your father also is lustful Vishvamitra of the Kshatriya race, destitute of all affection, the ! man who was tempted to become a Brahmana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदिन्द्रजालप्रतिम बाणजालममित्रहा। विसृज्य दिक्षु सर्वासु महेन्द्र इव वज्रभृत्॥
English Translation: But (if you say), Menaka is the foremost of Apsaras and Vishvamitra is the foremost of Rishis, why then do you, being their daughter, speak like a lewd woman?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मेघजालनिभं सैन्यं विदार्य शरवृष्टिभिः। विबभौ कौरवश्रेष्ठः शरदीव दिवाकरः॥
English Translation: Your these words deserve no credence. Are you not ashamed to utter them, specially before me? Go away, O wicked ascetic woman.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृष्ण उवाच मूर्जा निपत्य नियतस्तेजःसंनिचये ततः। परमं हर्षमागत्य भगवन्तमथाब्रुवम्॥
English Translation: Where is now that best of great Rishis (Vishvamitra) and that best of Apsaras Menaka? And where are you, (though) in the humble garb of ascetics.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धर्मे दृढत्वं युधि शत्रुघातं यशस्तथाग्र्यं परमं बलं च। योगप्रियत्वं तव संनिकर्ष वृणे सुतानां च शतं शतानि॥
English Translation: Your this son is very big and appears to be very strong. How has he, within so short time, grown up like a Sala sprout?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमस्त्विति तद्वाक्यं मयोक्तः प्राह शङ्करः। ततो मां जगतो माता धारिणी सर्वपावनी॥ उवाचोमा प्रणिहिता शर्वाणी तपसां निधिः। दत्तो भगवता पुत्रः साम्बो नाम तवानघ।॥
English Translation: You are born very low, you speak also like a lewd woman. You were lustfully conceived by Menaka.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मत्तोऽप्यष्टौ वरानिष्टान् गृहाण त्वं ददामि ते। प्रणम्य शिरसा सा च मयोक्ता पाण्डुनन्दन।॥
English Translation: O ascetic woman, all that you say is quite unknown to me. I do not know you. Go away wherever you please.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्विजेष्वकोपं पितृतः प्रसाद शतं सुतानां परमं च भोगम्। कुले प्रीतिं मातृतश्च प्रसाद शमप्राप्तिं प्रवृणे चापि दाक्ष्यम्॥
English Translation: Shakuntala said: O king, you (can) see the faults of others, though they may be as small as the mustard seed. But you can not see your own faults, though they are as big as the Bilva fruit.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उमा उवाच एवं भविष्यत्यमरप्रभाव नाहं मृषा जातु वदे कदाचित्। भार्यासहस्राणि च षोडशैव तासु प्रियत्वं च तथाक्षयं च॥
English Translation: Menaka is a celestial, (nay) Menaka is considered to be the best of celestial. O Dushyanta, my birth is noble than your own.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रीतिं चाग्र्यां बान्धवानां सकाशाद् ददामि तेऽहं वपुषः काम्यतां च। भोक्ष्यन्ते वै सप्ततिं वै शतानि गृहे तुभ्यमतिथीनां च नित्यम्॥
English Translation: O great king, you walk on earth, but I roam in the sky. Know that the difference between you and me is like that of a mustard seed and the Meru (mountain).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं दत्त्वा वरान् देवो मम देवी च भारत। अन्तर्हितः क्षणे तस्मिन् सगणो भीमपूर्वज॥
English Translation: O king, behold, I can go to the abodes of Indra, Kubera, Yama and Varuna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतदत्यद्भुतं पूर्वं ब्राह्मणायातितेजसे। उपमन्यवे मया कृत्स्नं व्याख्यातं पार्थिवोत्तम। नमस्कृत्वा तु स प्राह देवदेवाय सुव्रत॥
English Translation: O sinless man, there is a proverb which I am going to mention to you; (but I am not doing it) from any evil motive, but only as an example. Therefore, kindly pardon me for referring to it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उपमन्युरुवाच नास्ति शर्वसमो देवो नास्ति शर्वसमा गतिः। नास्ति शर्वसमो दाने नास्ति शर्वसमो रणे॥
English Translation: The ugly man, until he sees his face in a mirror, considers himself more handsome than others.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच धृतराष्ट्राभ्यनुज्ञातास्ततस्ते कुरुपाण्डवाः। अभ्ययुर्धातरः सर्वे गान्धारी सह केशवाः॥
English Translation: But when he sees his own face in the mirror, it is then that he perceives the difference between himself and others.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो ज्ञात्वा हतामित्रं युधिष्ठिरमुपागतम्। गान्धारी पुत्रशोकार्ता शप्तुमैच्छदनिन्दिता॥
English Translation: He, who is really very handsome, never taunts others. He, who too much vilifies others, is only considered to be a reviler.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्याः पापमभिप्रायं विदित्वा पाण्डवान् प्रति। ऋषिः सत्यवतीपुत्रः प्रागेव समबुध्यत॥
English Translation: As the swine seeks for the dirt and filth even when it is in a flower-garden, so does a wicked man chose only evil out of the evil and the good that others speak.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स गङ्गायामुपस्पृश्य पुण्यगन्धि पयः शुचि। तं देशमुपसम्पेदे परमर्षिर्मनोजवः॥
English Translation: But as the geese always extract milk, though inixed with water, so does a wise man accept only what is good from the speech that is intermixed with both good and evil.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दिव्येन चक्षुषा पश्यन् मनसा तद्गतेन च। सर्वप्राणभृतां भावं स तत्र समबुध्यत॥
English Translation: Honest men always feel pain to speak ill of others, but wicked men always derive pleasure in doing it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स स्नुषामब्रवीत् काले कल्यवादी महातपाः। शापकालमवाक्षिप्य शमकालमुदीरयन्॥
English Translation: Honest men always feel pleasure in showing respect towards the old (good men), but the fools always feel pleasure in abusing them. Honest men are happy in not seeking others' fault, but the fools are happy in doing it. The wicked always speak ill of honest men, but honest men never injure the wicked, even if injured by them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न कोपः पाण्डवे कार्यो गान्धारि शमभाप्नुहि! वचो निगृह्यतामेतच्छृणु चेदं वचो मम॥
English Translation: What could be more ridiculous in the world than this, that those that are wicked should represent really honest men as wicked.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उक्तास्यष्टादशाहानि पुत्रेण जयमिच्छता। शिवमाशास्व मे मातयुध्यमानस्य शत्रुभिः॥ सा तथा याच्यमाना त्वं काले काले जयैषिणा। उक्तवत्यसि गान्धारि यतो धर्मस्ततो जयः॥ न चाप्यतीतां गान्धारि वाचं ते वितथामहम्। स्मरामि भाषमाणायास्तथा प्राणिहिता ह्यसि॥
English Translation: Even atheists are afraid of those who have fallen from truth and virtue, as all men are afraid of the snakes of virulent poison. (When such is the case with an atheist), what shall I speak of me who is atheist?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विग्रहे तुमुले राज्ञां गत्वा पारमसंशयम्। जितं पाण्डुसुतैर्युद्धे नूनं धर्मस्ततोऽधिकः॥
English Translation: The man, who having begotten a son who is his own image, does not look after him, never gains the higher worlds. The celestial destroy his good fortune an wealth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क्षमाशीला पुरा भूत्वा साद्य न क्षमसे कथम्। अधर्मं जहि धर्मज्ञे यतो धर्मस्ततो जयः॥
English Translation: The Pitris (ancestors) have said that the son continues the race and supports the relations; therefore, to give birth to a son is the best of all pious acts. Therefore, your this son should not be abandoned.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्वं च धर्म परिस्मृत्य वाचं चोक्ता मनस्विनि। कोपं संयच्छ गान्धारि मैवं भूः सत्यवादिनि॥ भगवन्नाभ्यसूयामि नैतानिच्छामि नश्यतः। पुत्रशोकेन तु बलान्मनो विह्वलतीव मे॥
English Translation: Manu has said that there are five kinds of sons, namely those begotten by one on his wife, those obtained from others, those purchased for a price, those reared out of affection and those begotten on other women.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथैव कुन्त्या कौन्तेया रक्षितव्यास्तथा मया। तथैव धृतराष्ट्रेण रक्षितव्या यथा त्वया॥
English Translation: Sons support the religion and achievements of men; they increase their happiness; they rescue the dead ancestor from hell.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुर्योधनापराधेन शकुनेः सौबलस्य च। कणंदुःशासनाभ्यां च कृतोऽयं कुरुसंक्षयः॥
English Translation: Therefore, O best of kings, it is not proper for you to abandon your son. O king of the earth, cherish your own self, truth and virtue, more more (by cherishing your this son). () best of the kings, it is not proper for you to play hypocrite's in this matter.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नापराध्यति बीभत्सुर्न च पार्थो वृकोदरः। नकुलः सहदेवश्च नैव जातु युधिष्ठिरः॥
English Translation: The dedication of a tank is meritorious than that of one hundred wells. A sacrifice is meritorious than the dedication of a tank. But (to beget a son) is inore meritorious than the celebration of sacrifices. Truth (however) is more meritorious than the birth of one hundred sons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युध्यमाना हि कौरव्याः कृन्तमानाः परस्परम्। निहताः सहिताश्चान्यैस्तच नास्त्यप्रियं मम॥
English Translation: If one thousand horse-sacrifices and truth were weighed, truth would be found heavier than one thousand horse-sacrifices.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किं तु कर्माकरोद् भीमो वासुदेवस्य पश्यतः। दुर्योधनं समाहूय गदायुद्धे महामनाः॥ शिक्षयाभ्यधिकं ज्ञात्वा चरन्तं बहुधा रणे। अधो नाभ्याः प्रहतवांस्तन्मे कोपमवर्धयत्॥
English Translation: O king, I tell you, truth is equal to the study of the entire Vedas and ablutions in all the sacred pilgrimages.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कथं नु धर्म धर्मज्ञैः समुद्दिष्टं महात्मभिः। त्यजेयुराहवे शूराः प्राणहेतोः कथंचन॥
English Translation: There is no virtue equal to truth, there is nothing (in this world) superior to truth. And there is nothing (again) more sinful than falsehood.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्ण उवाच या नः श्रुता मनुष्येषु स्त्रियो रूपेण सम्मताः। तासामेतादृशं कर्म न कस्याश्चन शुश्रुम॥
English Translation: O king, truth is the great Brahma, truth is the great vow; therefore, O king, do not violate your pledge. Let truth and yourself be ever united.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क्रोधाविष्टेषु पार्थेषु धार्तराष्ट्रेषु चाप्यति। द्रौपदी: पाण्डुपुत्राणां कृष्णा शान्तिरिहाभवत्॥
English Translation: If, however, you are united with falsehood, li you do not place any credence on my word, I shall go away from this place of my own accord. Your companionship should not be sought after.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अप्लवेऽम्भसि मग्नानामप्रतिष्ठे निमज्जताम्। पाञ्चाली पाण्डुपुत्राणां नौरेषा पारगाभवत्॥
English Translation: But, ( Dushyanta, (know this for a certainty), that when you are dead, my this son shall rule the whole earth, surrounded by the four seas and adorned by the king of mountains.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच तद् वै श्रुत्वा भीमसेनः कुरुमध्येऽत्यमर्षणः। स्त्रीगतिः पाण्डुपुत्राणामित्युवाच सुदुर्मनाः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Having said all this to the king, Shakuntala turned her back. Thereupon a voice from the sky, coming from one who had no visible shape, addressed Dushyanta who was sitting, surrounded by his ministers, priests and Ritvikas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीम उवाच त्रीणि ज्योतींषि पुरुष इति वै देवलोऽब्रवीत्। अपत्यं कर्म विद्या.च यतः सृष्टाः प्रजास्ततः॥
English Translation: (It said), “O Dushyanta, the mother is but a sheath of flesh (within which the son dwells). The son, sprung from the father, is the father himself. Therefore, cherish your son and do not insult Shakuntala. O best of men, the son begotten by one's own self, rescues him from the abode of Yama. You are the father of this son. Shakuntala has spoken the truth. The husband divides his body in two parts and is born in the womb of his wife as the son.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अमेध्ये वै गतप्राणे शून्ये ज्ञातिभिरुज्झिते। देहे त्रितयमेवैतत् पुरुषस्योपयुज्यते॥
English Translation: O king, O Dushyanta, therefore, cherish your this son, born of Shakuntala. To forsake one's own son and to live thereafter is a great misfortune.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तन्नो ज्योतिरिहतं दाराणामभिमर्शनात्। धनंजय कथंस्विन् स्यादपत्यमभिमृष्टजम्॥
English Translation: Therefore, O descendant of the Puru race, cherish your this high-souled son, born of Shakuntala. As you will cherish this child at our word, therefore, your this son will be known by the name of Bharata.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्जुन उवाच न चैवोक्ता न चानुक्ता हीनत: परुषाः गिरः। भारत प्रतिजल्पन्ति सदा तूत्तमपूरुषाः॥ स्मरन्ति सुकृतान्येव न वैराणि कृतान्यपि। सन्तः प्रतिविजानन्तो लब्धसम्भावनाः स्वयम्॥
English Translation: Having heard these words of the dwellers of heaven, the king of the Puru race was much pleased and addressing his priests and ministers, he said : “Hear all of you the words of the messenger of heaven."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीम उवाच इहैवैतांस्त्वहं सर्वान् हन्मि शत्रून् समागतान्। अथ निष्क्रम्य राजेन्द्र समूलान् हन्मि भारत॥
English Translation: I myself know that this boy is my son. If I had accepted him as my son at Shakuntala's words, my people would have been suspicious and my son also would not have been considered to be pure (of pure birth).”
Vaishampayana said : O descendant of the Virata race, the king was exceedingly pleased, because the purity of the birth of his son was established by the messenger of heaven.
He then performed with joy all those rites which a father should perform for his son.
He smelt his son's head; he embraced him with affection. The Brahmanas uttered blessings on him and the bards began to applaud him. The king then enjoyed the great pleasure that one feels at the touch of one's own son.
Dushyanta also received his wife (Shakuntala) with all honour and affection. Affectionately pacifying her, he spoke to her thus,
“O lady, my union with you took place in private. None knew of it and therefore, it is natural that people should have thought that our union was only out of lust and that we were not husband and wife. This son, installed as my heir-apparent, would have been considered as a man of impure birth. Therefore, I was thinking how best to establish your purity.
O dearest, O lady of beautiful eyes, I have forgiven you for all the hard words you have uttered in anger. You are my darling.”
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किं नो विवदितेनेह किमुक्तेन च भारत। अद्यैवैतान् निहन्मीह प्रशाधि पृथिवीमिमाम्॥
English Translation: O descendant of the Bharata race, having spoken thus to his dear queen (Shakuntala), the royal sage Dushyanta, received her with the presents of perfume, food and drink.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्युक्त्वा भीमसेनस्तु कनिष्ठैर्धातृभिः सह। मृगमध्ये यथा सिंहो मुहुर्मुहुरुदैक्षत॥
English Translation: The king Dushyanta, thereupon, installed the son of Shakuntala as his heir-apparent bestowing upon him the name of Bharata.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सान्त्व्यमानो वीक्षमाणः पार्थेनाक्लिष्टकर्मणा। खिद्यत्येव महाबाहुरन्तर्दाहेन वीर्यवान्॥
English Translation: From that day the invincible car of Bharata, like the car of the celestials, with its famous and bright wheels, traversed the whole earth, filling it with its rattle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क्रुद्धस्य तस्य स्रोताभ्यः कर्णादिभ्ये नराधिप। सधूमः सस्फुलिङ्गज्रिर्चः पावकः समजायत॥
English Translation: The son of Dushyanta (Bharata) brought under his sway all the kings of the world. He ruled his subjects virtuously and gained great fame.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भृकुटीकृतदुष्प्रेक्ष्यमभवत् तस्य तन्मुखम्। युगान्तकाले सम्प्राप्ते कृतान्तस्येव रूपिणः॥
English Translation: That king (Bharata) was known by the name of Chakravarti and Sarvabhauma. He performed many sacrifices like Indra, the lord of the Marutas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिरस्तमावार्य बाहुना बाहुशालिनम्। मैवमित्यब्रवीच्चैनं जोषमास्स्वेति भारत॥
English Translation: Kanva was the chief priest in those sacrifices and great offerings were made to the Brahmanas. The fortunate king performed both the cow and the horse-sacrifices. Bharata gave one thousand gold coins to Kanva as his sacrificial fee.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निवार्य च महाबाहुं कोपसंरक्तलोचनम्। पितरं समुपातिष्ठद् धृतराष्ट्रं कृताञ्जलिः॥
English Translation: From this Bharata has followed this, "achievement of Bharata," from him has sprung this great race (of Bharata.) All kings that were born after him are called after his name.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच बाणे तस्मिन् निकृत्ते तु धृष्टद्युम्ने च मोक्षिते। तेन वृष्णिप्रवीरेण युयुधानेन संजय॥
English Translation: And in this Bharata race were many godlike and greatly powerful best of monarchs. They were like Brahma himself. Their names are countless. O descendant of the Bharata race, I shall name only the chief ones, who were all blessed with great fortune and devoted to truth and honesty. They were all like the celestial.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अमर्षितो महेष्वासः सर्वशस्त्रभृतां वरः। नरव्याघ्रः शिनेः पौत्रे द्रोणः किमकरोद् युधि॥
English Translation: How great was the love of virtue possessed by Vritra of incomparable energy, whose knowledge was incomparable and whose devotion to Vishnu was so great.
---
