Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच सम्प्रद्रुतः क्रोधविषो व्यादितास्यशरासनः। तीक्ष्णधारेषुदशनः शितनाराचदंष्ट्रवान्॥ संरम्भामर्षताम्राक्षो महोरग इव श्वसन्। नरवीरः प्रमुदितः शौणैरश्वैर्महाजवैः॥ उत्पतद्भिरिवाकाशे क्रामद्भिरिव पर्वतम्। रुक्मपुङ्खाञ्छरानस्यन् युयुधानमुपाद्रवत्॥
English Translation: The position occupied by Vishnu of immeasurable energy is difficult, of being perceived. How, O foremost of kings, could Vritra comprehend it?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शरपातमहावर्षं रथघोषबलाहकम्। कार्मुकाकर्षविक्षेपं नाराचबहुविद्युतम्॥ शक्तिखड्गाशनिधरं क्रोधवेगसमुत्थितम्। द्रोणमेघमनावार्य हयमारुतचोदितम्॥
English Translation: You have described Vritra's acts. I too have heard you in full faith. Because, on account of my seeing that one point is unintelligible that my curiosity has been roused for asking you again.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दृष्ट्वैवाभिपतन्तं तं शूरः परपुरंजयः। उवाज सूतं शैनेयः प्रहसन् युद्धदुर्मदः॥
English Translation: How, indeed, was Vritra, who was virtuous, devoted to Vishnu, gifted with knowledge of truth derivable from a just comprehension of the Upanishads and Vedanta, defeated by Indra, O foremost of men.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एनं वै ब्राह्मणं शूरं स्वकर्मण्यनवस्थितम्। आश्रयं धार्तराष्ट्रस्य राज्ञो दुःखभयापहम्॥
English Translation: O king of the Bharatas, remove this my doubt! Indeed, tell me, O foremost of kings, how Vritra was defeated by Shakra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शीघ्रं प्रजवितैरश्वैः प्रत्युद्याहि प्रहृष्टवत्। आचार्यं राजपुत्राणां सततं शूरमानिनम्॥
English Translation: O grandfather, O you of mighty arms, tell me fully how the battle took place. Great is my curiosity to hear it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो रजतसंकाशा माधवस्य हयोत्तमाः। द्रोणस्याभिमुखाः शीघ्रमगच्छन् वातरंहसः॥
English Translation: Bhishma said-In days of yore, Indra, accompanied by the celestial army, proceeded on his car, and saw the Asura Vritra stationed before him like a mountain.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्तौ द्रोणशैनेयो युयुधाते परंतपौ। शरैरनेकसाहस्रेस्ताडयन्तौ परस्परम्॥
English Translation: He was full five hundred Yojanas in height, 0 chastiser of enemies and three hundred Yojanas in circumference.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इषुजालावृतं व्योम चक्रतुः पुरुषर्षभौ। पूरयामासतुर्वीरावुभौ दश दिशः शरैः॥
English Translation: Seeing that form of Vritra, which was incapable of being defeated by the three worlds united together, the celestials became stricken with fear and full of anxiety.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मेघाविवातपायाये धाराभिरितरेतरम्। न स्म सूर्यस्तदा भाति न ववौ च समीरणः॥
English Translation: Indeed, suddenly beholding that huge form of his enemy, O king, Indra was paralysed in the lower extremities.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इषुजालावृतं घोरमन्धकारं समन्ततः। अनाधृष्यमिवान्येषां शूराणामभवत् तदा॥
English Translation: Then, on the eve of that great battle between the gods and the demons, there arose loud peals from both sides, and drums and other musical instruments were beaten and blown.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्धकारीकृते लोके द्रोणशैनेययोः शरैः। तयोः शीघ्रास्त्रविदुषोोणसात्वतयोस्तदा॥
English Translation: Seeing Indra stationed before him, you of Kuru's race, Vritra felt neither awe nor fear, nor was he disposed to collect all his energies for the battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नान्तरं शरवृष्टीनां ददृशे नरसिंहयोः।
English Translation: Then the battle took place filling the three worlds with fear, between Indra the king of the gods and Vritra of great energy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इपूणां संनिपातेन शब्दो धाराभिघातजः॥ शुश्रुवे शक्रमुक्तानामशनीनामिव स्वनः।
English Translation: The entire sky was covered by the warriors of both sides with swords, axes, lances, darts, spears and heavy clubs and rocks of various sizes and bows of loud sound and various sorts of celestial weapons and fires and burning brands.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नाराचैर्व्यतिविद्धानां शराणां रूपमाबभौ॥ आशीविषविदष्टानां सर्पाणामिव भारत।
English Translation: All the deities led by the Grand-father, and all the highly-blessed Rishis, came to see the battle, on their best of cars; and the Siddhas, also, O foremost of Bharata's family, and the Gandharvas, with the Apsaras, on their own beautiful and foremost of cars, came there.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तयोर्ध्यातलनिर्घोषः शुश्रुवे युद्धशौण्डयोः॥ अजस्रं शैलशृङ्गाणां वज्रेणाहन्यतामिव।
English Translation: Then Vritra, that foremost of virtuous persons, speedily overwhelmed the sky and the king of gods with a thick shower of rocks.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उभयोस्तौ रथौ राजंस्ते चाश्वास्तौ च सारथी॥ रुक्मपुकैः शरैश्छिन्नाश्चित्ररूपा बभुस्तदा।
English Translation: Thereat, filled with ire the celestials dispelled with their showers of arrows that thick down-pour of rocks showered by Vritra in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निर्मलानामजिह्यानां नाराचानां विशाम्पते॥ निर्मुक्ताशीविषाभानां सम्पातोभूत् सुदारुणः।
English Translation: Then Vritra, O foremost of Kurus, endued with mighty strength and large powers of illusion, stupefied the king of illusion. was
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उभयोः पतिते छत्रे तथैव पतितो ध्वजौ॥ उभौ रुधिरसिक्ताङ्गावुभौ च विजयैषिणौ।
English Translation: When the god of hundred sacrifices, thus afflicted by Vritra, possessed by stupefaction, the sage Vashishtha restores him to his senses by chanting Samans.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नवद्भिः शोणितं गात्रैः प्रस्रुताविव वारणौ॥ अन्योन्यमभ्यविध्येतां जीवितान्तकरैः शरैः।
English Translation: Vashishtha said You are the foremost of the gods, O chief of the gods, O destroyer of Daityas and Asuras! The strength of the three worlds lies in you! Why, then, O Shakra, do you languish so!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गर्जितोत्कृष्टसंनादाः शङ्खदुन्दुभिनिःस्वनाः॥ उपारमन् महाराज व्याजहार न कश्चन।
English Translation: See, there are Brahma and Vishnu, and Shiva, that lord of the universe, the illustrious and divine Soma, and all the great Rishis.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तूष्णीम्भूतान्यनीकानि योधा युद्धादुपारमन्॥ ददर्श द्वैरथं ताभ्यां जातकौतूहलो जनः।
English Translation: Do not, O Indra, yield to weakness, like an ordinary mortal! Firmly determined on battle, kill your enemies, O king of the gods.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रथिनो हस्तियन्तारो हयारोहा: पदातयः॥ अवैक्षन्ताचलैत्रः परिवार्य नरर्षभौ।
English Translation: There, that lord of all the worlds, viz., the Three-eyed (Shiva), worshipped of all the worlds, is seeing you! Shake off this stupefaction, O king of the gods.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हस्त्यनीकान्यतिष्ठन्त तथानीकानि वाजिनाम्॥ तथैव रथवाहिन्यः प्रतिव्यूह्य व्यवस्थिताः।
English Translation: There, those twice-born Rishis, headed by Brihaspati, are lauding you for your victory, in celestial hymns.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मुक्ताविद्रुमचित्रैश्च मणिकाञ्चनभूषितैः॥ ध्वजैराभरणैश्चित्रैः कवचैश्च हिरण्मयैः। वैजयन्तीपताकाभिः परिस्तोमाङ्गकम्बलैः॥ विमलैर्निशितैः शस्त्रैर्हयानां च प्रकीर्णकैः। जातरूपमयीभिश्च राजनीतिभश्च मूर्धसु॥ गजानां कुम्भमालाभिर्दन्तवेष्टैश्च भारत। सबलाकाः सखद्योताः सैरावतशतह्रदाः॥ अदृश्यन्तोष्णपर्याये मेघानामिव वागुराः।
English Translation: Bhishma said-While the highly energetic Vasava was thus being restored to senses by the great Vashishtha, his strength became greatly increased.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपश्यन्नस्मदीयाश्च ते च यौधिष्ठिराः स्थिताः॥ तद् युद्धं युयुधानस्य द्रोणस्य च महात्मनः।
English Translation: The illustrious punisher of Paka then, depending upon his intelligence, had recourse to high Yoga and with its help removed these illusions of Vritra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विमानाग्रगता देवा ब्रह्मसोमपुरोगमाः॥ सिद्धचारणसंघाश्च विद्याधरमहोरगाः।
English Translation: Then Brihaspati, the son of Angiras, and those greatest of Rishis endued with great prosperity, seeing the prowess of Vritra, went to Mahadeva, and moved by the desire of benefiting the three worlds, urged him to kill the great Asura.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गतप्रत्यागताक्षेपैश्चिौरस्त्रविघातिभिः॥ विविधैर्विस्मयं जग्मुस्तयोः पुरुषसिंहयोः।
English Translation: The energy of that illustrious lord of the universe thereupon assumed the nature of a fierce fever and entered the body of Vritra the lord of Asuras.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हस्तलाघवमस्त्रेषु दर्शयन्तौ महाबलौ॥ अन्योन्यमभिविध्येतां शरैस्तौ द्रोणसात्यकी।
English Translation: The illustrious and divine Vishnu, worshipped of all the worlds, bent upon protecting the universe, entered the thunderbolt of Indra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो द्रोणस्य दाशार्हः शरांश्चिच्छेद संयुगे॥ पत्रिभिः सुदृढराशु धनुश्चैव महाद्युतेः।
English Translation: Then the highly intelligent Brihaspati and Vashishtha of great energy and all the other foremost of Rishis, going to the God of hundred sacrifices, viz., the boon-giving Vasava, the worshipped of all the worlds, said to him kill forthwith Vritra, O powerful one.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निमेषान्तरमात्रेण भारद्वाजोऽपरं धनुः॥ सज्यं चकार तदपि चिच्छेदास्य च सात्यकिः। ततस्त्वरन् पुनर्दोणो धनुर्हस्तो व्यतिष्ठत॥ सज्यं सज्यं धनुश्चास्य चिच्छेद निशितैः शरैः।
English Translation: Maheshvara said There, O Shakra, stands the great Vritra, accompanied by a great army. He is the soul of the universe, capable of going everywhere, gifted with great powers of illusion, and highly illustrious.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमेकशतं छिन्नं धनुषां दृढधन्विना॥ न चान्तरं तयोर्दृष्टं संधाने छेदनेऽपि च।
English Translation: This foremost of Asuras is, therefore incapable of being defeated by even the threeworlds in a body. Helped by Yoga, do you kill him, O king of the celestials. Do not neglect him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽस्य संयुगे द्रोणो दृष्ट्वा कर्मातिमानुषम्॥ युयुधानस्य राजेन्द्र मनसैतदचिन्तयत्।
English Translation: O king of the celestials, Vritra had practised, for full sixty thousand years, the severest penances for acquiring strength. Brahma gave him the boons he had prayed for, viz., the greatness that belongs to Yogins, large powers of illusion, enough of might, and superabundant energy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतदस्त्रबलं रामे कार्तवीर्ये धनंजये॥ भीष्मे च पुरुषव्याघ्र यदिदं सात्वतां वरे। तं चास्य मनसा द्रोणः पूजयामास विक्रमम्॥
English Translation: I give you my energy, O Vasava! The Danava has now lost his coolness. Do you, therefore, kill him now with your thunderbolt.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: लाघवं वासवस्येव सम्प्रेक्ष्य द्विजसत्तमः। तुतोषास्त्रविदां श्रेष्ठस्तथा देवाः सवासवाः॥
English Translation: Shakra said Before your eyes, O foremost of gods, I shall, through your favour kill with my thunderbolt this invincible son Diti.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न तामालक्षयामासुर्लघुतां शीघ्रचारिणः। गन्धर्वाश्च विशाम्पते॥ सिद्धाचारणसंघाश्च विदुयॊणस्य कर्म तत्।
English Translation: Bhishma said. When the great Asura or Daitya was possessed by that fever, the gods and the Rishis, filled with joy, sent up loud cheers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: देवाश्च युयुधानस्य ततोऽन्यद् धनुरादाय द्रोणः क्षत्रियमर्दनः॥ अस्त्रैरस्त्रविदां श्रेष्ठो योधयामास भारत।
English Translation: At the same time drums, and conchs of loud blare, and kettle-drums and tabors in thousands began to beat and blow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्यास्त्राण्यस्त्रमायाभिः प्रतिहत्य स सात्यकिः॥ जघान निशितैर्बाणैस्तदद्भुतमिवाभवत्।
English Translation: Suddenly all the Asuras lost in a body their memory. At that moment their powers of illusion, also, disappeared.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्यातिमानुषं कर्म दृष्ट्वान्यैरसमं रणे॥ युक्तं योगेन योगज्ञास्तावकाः समपूजयन्।
English Translation: Knowing the enemy to be thus possessed, the Rishis and gods lauded both Shakra and Ishana, and began to urge the former.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदस्त्रमस्यति द्रोणस्तदेवास्यति सात्यकिः॥ तमाचार्योऽप्यसम्भ्रान्तोऽयोधयच्छत्रुतापनः
English Translation: The form that Indra assumed on the eve of the battle, while seated on his car and while his praises were being lauded by the Rishis, became such that none could look at it without dread.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः क्रुद्धो महाराज धनुर्वेदस्य पारगः॥ वधाय युयुधानस्य दिव्यमस्त्रमुदैरयत्।
English Translation: Bhishina said Regarding it is cited the old history of the oaths on the occasion of a sojourn to the sacred waters.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदाग्नेयं महाघोरं रिपुघ्नमुपलक्ष्य सः॥ दिव्यमस्त्रं महेष्वासो वारुणं समुदैरयत्।
English Translation: O best of the Bharatas, the act of theft had been committed by Indra, and the oaths were taken by many royal and twiceborn Rishis.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हाहाकारो महानासीद् दृष्ट्वा दिव्यास्त्रधारिणौ॥ न विचेरुस्तदाकाशे भूतान्याकाशगाम्यपि।
English Translation: Once upon a time, the Rishis, having assembled together, proceeded to the western Prabhasa. They held a consultation there which resulted in a determination on their part to sojourn to all sacred waters on Earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अस्त्रे ते वारुणाग्नेये ताभ्यां बाणसमाहिते॥ न यावदभ्यपद्येतां व्यावर्तदथ भास्करः।
English Translation: There were Shakra, Angirasa the highly learned Kavi, Agastya, Narada and Parvata; and Bhrigu and Vasishtha and Kashyapa and Gautama and Vishvamitra and Jamadagni, O king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो युधिष्ठिरो राजा भीमसेनश्च पाण्डवः॥ नकुलः सहदेवश्च पर्यरक्षन्त सात्यकिम्।
English Translation: There were also the Rishi Galava, and Ashtaka and Bharadvaja and Arundhati and the Valakhilyas, and Shibi and Dilipa and Nahusha and Ambarisha and the royal Yayati and Dhundhumara and Puru.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृष्टद्युम्नमुखैः सार्ध विराटश्च सकेकयः॥ मत्स्याः शाल्वेयसेनाश्च द्रोणमाजग्मुरञ्जसा।
English Translation: These foremost of men, headed the great performer of hundred sacrifices, the slayer of Vritra, sojourned to all the sacred waters one after another, and at last reached the highly sacred Kaushiki on the day of the full moon in the month of Magha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्रोणमभ्युपपद्यन्त दुःशासनं पुरस्कृत्य राजपुत्राः सहस्रशः॥ सपनैः परिवारितम्।
English Translation: Having purified themselves of all sins by ablutions performed in all the sacred waters, they at last proceeded to the very sacred Brahmasara. Bathing in that lake, those Rishis gifted with fiery energy began to gather and eat the stalks of the lotus.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो युद्धमभूद् राजेस्तेषां तव च धन्विनाम्॥ रजसा संवृते लोके शरजालसमावृते।
English Translation: Amongst those Brahmanas, some had extracted the stalks of the louts and some the stalks of the Nymphoca stellata. Soon they found that the stalks extracted by Agastya had been taken away by somebody.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वमाविग्नमभवन्न प्राज्ञायत किंचन। सैन्येन रजसा ध्वस्ते निर्मर्यादमवर्तत॥
English Translation: The foremost of Rishis, Agastya, addressing them all, said, Who has taken away good stalks which I had extracted and deposited here? I suspect some one amongst you must have taken them. Let him who has taken them away return them to me. You should not thus misappropriate my stalks.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच प्रतिज्ञाय तु दुष्यन्ते प्रतियाते शकुन्तलाम्। गर्भं सुषाव वामोरू: कुमारममितौजसम्॥ त्रिषु वर्षेषु पूर्णेषु दीप्तानलसमद्युतिम्। रूपौदार्यगुणोपेतं दौष्यन्ति जनमेजय॥
English Translation: It is heard that Time attacks the energy of virtue. That Time has come upon us. Hence, virtue is afflicted. It is proper that I should go to Heaven for good, before sin assails the world and establishes itself fully here.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जातकर्मादिसंस्कारं कण्वः पुण्यकृतां वरः। विधिवत् कारयामास वर्धमानस्य धीमतः॥
English Translation: Before the time comes when Brahmanas, loudly uttering the Vedas, within the precincts of villages and inhabited places, cause the Shudras hear them, before the time comes when kings offered against the rules of virtue from motives of policy, I shall go to the celestial region for good.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दन्तैः शुकैः शिखरिभिः सिंहसंहननो महान्। चक्राङ्कितकरः श्रीमान् महामूर्धा महाबलः॥
English Translation: Before men cease to regard the distinctions between the lower, the middle, and the higher classes, I shall go to the celestial region for good. Before Ignorance attacks the world and covers all things in darkness, I shall go to the celestial region for good.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कुमारो देवगर्भाभः स तत्राशु व्यवर्धत। षड्वर्ष एव बालः स कण्वाश्रमपदं प्रति॥ सिंहव्याघ्रान् वराहांश्च महिषांश्च गजांस्तथा। बबन्ध वृक्षे बलवानाश्रमस्य समीपतः॥
English Translation: Before the time comes when the strong begin to oppress the weak and treat them as slaves, I shall go to the celestial region for ever. Indeed, I dare not remain on Earth for seeing these things.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आरोहन् दमयंश्चैव क्रीडंश्च परिधावति। ततोऽस्य नाम चक्रुस्ते कण्वाश्रमनिवासिनः॥ अस्त्वयं सर्वदमनः सर्वं हि दमयत्यसौ। स सर्वदमनो नाम कुमारः समपद्यत॥ विक्रमेणौजसा चैव बलेन च समन्वितः।
English Translation: The Rishis, much concerned at what he said, addressed that great ascetic and said-We have not stolen your stalks! You should not cherish these suspicions against us, O great Rishi, we shall take the most dreadful oaths.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं कुमारमृषिर्दृष्ट्वा कर्म चास्यातिमानुषम्॥ समयो यौवराज्यायेत्यब्रवीच शकुन्तलाम्।
English Translation: Having said these words, conscious as they were of their own innocence, and desirous of upholding the cause of virtue, those Rishis and royal sages then began to swear, one after another, the following oaths.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य तद् बलमाज्ञाय कण्वः शिष्यानुवाच ह॥ शकुन्तलामिमां शीघ्रं सहपुत्रामितो गृहात्। भर्तुः प्रापयतागारं सर्वलक्षणपूजिताम्॥
English Translation: Bhrigu said Let him who has stolen your stalks censure when censured, assail when assail, and eat the flesh that is attached to the backbone of animals.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नारीणां चिरवासो हि बान्धवेषु न रोचते। कीर्तिचारित्रधर्मजस्तस्मान्नयत मा चिरम्॥
English Translation: Vasishtha said Let him who has stolen your stalks neglect his Vedic studies, leash hounds, and having taken himself to the mendicani order live in a city or town.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथेत्युक्त्वा तु ते सर्वे प्रातिष्ठन्त महौजसः। शकुन्तलां पुरस्कृत्य दुष्यन्तस्य पुरं प्रति॥
English Translation: Kashyapa said Let him who has stolen your stalks sell all things in all places, misappropriate trusts, and give false evidence!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गृहीत्वामरगर्भाभं पुत्रं कमललोचनम्। आजगाम ततः सुभूर्दुष्यन्तं विदिताद् वनात्॥
English Translation: Gautama said Let him who has stolen your stalks live, all things, with an understanding that does not see all creatures with an equal eye, and always giving way to the influence of desire and anger. Let him be a cultivator of the soil, and let him be moved by malice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभिसृत्य च राजानं विदिता च प्रवेशिता। सह तेनैव पुत्रेण बालार्कसमतेजसा॥
English Translation: Angirasa said Let him who has stolen your stalks be always impure! Let him be a censurable Brahmana. Let him leash hounds. Let him be guilty of Brahmanicide. Let him be averse to expiations after having committed sin.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निवेदयित्वा ते सर्वे आश्रमं पुनरागताः। पूजयित्वा यथान्यायमब्रवीच शकुन्तला॥
English Translation: Dhundhumara said Let him who has stolen your stalks be ungrateful to his friends! Let him take birth in a Shudra woman! Let him eat alone any good food.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शकुन्तलोवाच अयं पुत्रस्त्वया राजन् यौवराज्येऽभिषिच्यताम्। त्वया ह्ययं सुतो राजन् मय्युत्पन्नः सुरोपमः। यथासमयमेतस्मिन् वर्तस्व पुरुषोत्तम॥
English Translation: Puru said Let him who has stolen your stalks practise as a physician! Let him be supported by the earnings of his wife! Let him draw his maintenance from his fatherinlaw!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथा मत्सङ्गमे पूर्वं यः कृतः समयस्त्वया। तं स्मरस्व महाभाग कण्वाश्रमपदं प्रति॥
English Translation: Dilipa said Let him who has stolen your stalks attain to those regions of misery an infamy which are reserved for that Brahmana who lives in a village having but one well and who knows a Shudra woman.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सोऽथ श्रुत्वैव तद् वाक्यं तस्या राजा स्मरन्नपि। अब्रवीन्न स्मरामीति कस्य त्वं दुष्टतापसि॥
English Translation: Shukra said Let him who has stolen your stalks eat the flesh of animals not killed in sacrifices! Let him have sexual union at daytime! Let him be a servant of the king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धर्मकामार्थसम्बन्धं न स्मरामि त्वया सह। गच्छ वा तिष्ठ वा कामं यद् वापीच्छसि तत् कुरु॥
English Translation: Jamadagni said Let him who has stolen your stalks study the Vedas of forbidden days or occasions. Let him feed friends at Shraddhas performed by him! Let him eat at the Shraddha of a Shudra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सैवमुक्ता वरारोहा वीडितेव तपस्विनी। नि:संज्ञेव च दुःखेन तस्थौ स्थूणेव निश्चला॥
English Translation: Shibi said Let him who has stolen you stalks die without having established a fire (for daily worship)! Let him be guilty of obstructing the celebration of sacrifices by others! Let him fall out with those who practise penances!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संरम्भामर्षताम्राक्षी स्फुरमाणौष्ठसम्पुटा। कटाक्षैर्निर्दहन्तीव तिर्यग् राजानमैक्षत॥
English Translation: Yayati said Let him who has stolen your stalks be guilty of having sexual union with his wife when she is not in her season and when he is himself in the observance of a vow and bears matted locks on his head! Let him also disregard the Vedas!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आकारं गूहमानां च मन्युना च समीरिता। तपसा सम्भृतं तेजो धारयामास वै तदा।॥
English Translation: Nahusha said Let him who has stolen your stalks live in domesticity after having betaken himself to the vow of mendicancy! Let him act in whatever way he pleases, after having performed the initiatory rites in view of a sacrifice or some solemn observance! Let him take pecuniary satisfaction for teaching his disciples.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सा मुहूर्तमिव ध्यात्वा दुःखामर्षसमन्विता। भर्तारमभिसम्प्रेक्ष्य क्रुद्धा वचनमब्रवीत्॥ जानन्नपि महाराज कस्मादेवं प्रभाषसे। न जानामीति निःशङ्कं यथान्यः प्राकृतो जनः॥
English Translation: Ambarisha said Let him who has stolen your stalks be cruel and sinful in his conduct towards women and kinsmen and kine! Let him be guilty also of Brahmanicide!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अत्र ते हृदयं वेद सत्यस्यैवानृतस्य च। कल्याणं वद साक्ष्येण माऽऽत्मानमवमन्यथाः॥
English Translation: Narada said Let him who has stolen your stalks be one who identifies the body with the soul! Let him study the scriptures with an unworthy preceptor. Let him chaunt the Vedas, violating at each step the rules of orthoepy! Let him disregard all his elders.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: योऽन्यथा सन्तमात्मानमन्यथा प्रतिपद्यते। किं तेन न कृतं पापं चौरेणात्मापहारिणा॥
English Translation: Nabhaga said Let him who has stolen your stalks always speak untruth and quarrel with those who are pious. Let him bestow his daughter in marriage after accepting a pecuniary satisfaction offered by his soninlaw.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एकोऽहमस्मीति च मन्यसे त्वं न हृच्छयं वेत्सि मुनि पुराणम्। यो वेदिता कर्मणः पापकस्य तस्यान्तिके त्वं वृजिनं करोपि॥
English Translation: Kavi said Let him who has stolen your stalks be guilty of striking a cow with his foot. Let him pass urine, facing the sun! Let him renounce the person who seeks shelter at his hands.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मन्यते पापकं कृत्वा न कश्चिद् वेत्ति मामिति। विदन्ति चैनं देवाश्च यश्चैवान्तरपूरुषः॥
English Translation: Vishvamitra said Let him who has stolen your stalks become a servant who acts deceitfully towards his master! Let him be the priest of a king! Let him officiate as the sacrificial priest of one who should not be assisted at his sacrifices!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आदित्यचन्द्रावनिलानलौ च द्यौर्भूमिरापो हृदयं यमश्च। अहश्च रात्रिश्च उभे च संध्ये धर्मश्च जानाति नरस्य वृत्तम्॥
English Translation: Parvata said Let him who has stolen your stalks be the head of a village. Let him make journeys on asses. Let him leash hounds for maintenance.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यमो वैवस्वतस्तस्य निर्यातयति दुष्कृतम्। हृदि स्थितः कर्मसाक्षी क्षेत्रज्ञो यस्य तुष्यति॥
English Translation: Bharadvaja said Let him who has stolen your stalks be guilty of all the transgressions of him who is cruel in conduct and untruthful in speech.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न तु तुष्यति यस्यैष पुरुषस्य दुरात्मनः। तंयमः पापकर्माणं वियातयति दुष्कृतम्॥
English Translation: Ashtaka said Let him who has stolen your stalks be a king shorn of wisdom, capricious and sinful in his conduct, and disposed to rule the Earth impiously.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: योऽवमन्यात्मनाऽऽत्मानमन्यथा प्रतिपद्यते। न तस्य देवाः श्रेयांसो यस्यात्मापि न कारणम्॥ स्वयं प्राप्तेति मामेवं मावमंस्थाः पतिव्रताम्। अर्चाहीं नार्चयसि मां स्वयं भार्यामुपस्थिताम्॥
English Translation: Galava said Let him who has stolen your stalks be more infamous than a sinful man. Let him be sinful in his deeds towards his kinsmen and relatives. Let him proclaim the gifts he makes to others.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किमर्थं मां प्राकृतवदुपप्रेक्षसि संसदि। न खल्वहमिदं शून्ये रौमि किं न शृणोषि मे॥
English Translation: Arundhati said Let her who has stolen your stalks speak ill of her motherinlaw. Let her dislike her husband. Let her eat alone any good food that comes to her house.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदि मे याचमानाया वचनं न करिष्यसि। दुष्यन्त शतधा मूर्धा ततस्तेऽद्य स्फुटिष्यति॥
English Translation: The Balakhilyas said Let him who has stolen your stalks stand on one foot at the entrance of a village. Let him, while knowing all duties, be guilty of every transgression.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भार्यां पतिः सम्प्रविश्य स यस्माजायते पुनः। जायायास्तद्धि जायात्वं पौराणाः कवयो विदुः॥
English Translation: Shunasakha said Let him who has stolen your stalks be a Brahmana who sleeps happily having neglected his daily Homa. Let him, after becoming a religious mendicant, act in any way he likes, without observing any control.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदागमवतः पुंसस्तदपत्यं प्रजायते। तत् तारयति संतत्या पूर्वप्रेतान् पितामहान्॥
English Translation: Surabhi said Let her who has stolen your stalks be milked, with he, (hind) legs bound with a rope of human hair, and with the help of a calf not her own, and, while milked, let her be held in vessel of white brass.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुत्राम्नो नरकाद् यस्मात् पितरं त्रायते सुतः। तस्मात् पुत्र इति प्रोक्तः स्वयमेव स्वयम्भुवा॥
English Translation: Bhishma said After the Rishis and the royal sages had taken various oaths, O Kuru king, the thousand eye chief of the celestials, filled with joy, looked at the angry Rishi Agastya.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: (पुत्रेण लोकाञ्जयति पौत्रेणानन्त्यमश्नुते। अथ पौत्रस्य पुत्रेण मोदन्ते प्रपितामहः।।)
English Translation: Addressing the Rishi who was very angry at the disappearance of his lotus stalks, Indra thus declared what was passing in his mind. Hear, O king, the words Indra spoke in the midst of those twiceborn and celestial Rishis and royal sages.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सा भार्या या गृहे दक्षा सा भार्या या प्रजावती। सा भार्या या पतिप्राणा सा भार्या या पतिव्रता॥
English Translation: Shakra said Let him who has stolen your stalks acquire the merit of him who bestows his daughter in marriage upon a Brahmana who has duly observed the vow of Brahmacharya or who has duly studied the Samans and the Yajushes. Let him also have the merit of one who takes the final bath after completing his study of the Atharva Veda.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्धं भार्या मनुष्यस्य भार्या श्रेष्ठतमः सखा। भार्या मूलं त्रिवर्गस्य भार्या मूलं तरिष्यतः॥
English Translation: Let him who has stolen your stalks acquire the mcrit of having studied all the Vedas. Let him be observant of all duties and rightcous in his conduct. Indeed, let him go to the region of Brahman.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भार्यावन्त: क्रियावन्तः सभार्या गृहमेधिनः। भार्यावन्तः प्रमोदन्ते भार्यावन्तः श्रियान्विताः॥
English Translation: Agastya said You have, O destroyer of Vala, uttered a benediction instead of a course. Give them to me, for that is eternal duty.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सखायः प्रविविक्तेषु भवन्त्येताः प्रियंवदाः। पितरो धर्मकार्येषु भवन्त्यार्तस्य मातरः॥
English Translation: Indra said O holy one, I did not remove your stalks, moved by cupidity. Indeed, I removed them from desire of hearing this assembly recite what the duties are that we should observe. You should not yield to anger.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कान्तारेष्वपि विश्रामो जनस्याध्वनिकस्य वै। यः सदारः स विश्वास्यस्तस्माद् दाराः परागतिः॥४४।
English Translation: Duties are the foremost of Shrutis. Duties form the eternal path. I have listened to this discourse of the Rishis (on duties) that is eternal and immutable, and that is above all change.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संसरन्तमपि प्रेतं विषमेष्वेकपातिनम्। भावान्वेति भर्तारं सततं या पतिव्रता॥
English Translation: Do you then, foremost of learned Brahmanas, take back these stalks of yours. O holy one, you should forgive my transgression, (you who are free from every fault.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रथमं संस्थिता भार्या पतिं प्रेत्य प्रतीक्षते। पूर्वं मृतं च भर्तारं पश्चात् साध्व्यनुगच्छति॥
English Translation: Bhishma said Thus addressed by the king of the celestials, the ascetics viz., Agastya, who had been very angry, took back his stalks. Gifted with intelligence, the Rishi became cheerful.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतस्मात् कारणाद् राजन् पाणिग्रहणमिष्यते। यदाप्नोति पतिर्भार्यामिहलोके परत्र च॥
English Translation: After this, those dwellers of the forest went to various other sacred waters. Indeed, going to those sacred waters they performed their ablutions everywhere.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आत्माऽऽत्मनैव जनितः पुत्र इत्युच्यते बुधैः। तस्माद् भार्यां नरः पश्येन्मातृवत् पुत्रमातरम्॥
English Translation: The man who reads this discourse with rapt attention on every Parva day, will not beget an ignorant and wicked son. He will never be shorn of fearing
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भार्यायां जनितं पुत्रमादर्शेष्विव चाननम्। ह्लादते जनिता प्रेक्ष्य स्वर्गं प्राप्येव पुण्यकृत्॥
English Translation: No calamity will ever befall him. He will, besides, be free from every sort of sorrow. He will never suffer from decrepitude and decay. Freed from stains and evil of every sort, and gifted with merit, he is sure to acquire Heaven,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दह्यमाना मनोदुःखैर्व्याधिभिश्चातुरा नराः। ह्लादन्ते स्वेषु दारेषु धर्मार्ताः सलिलेष्विव॥
English Translation: He who studies this Shastra observed by the Rishis, is sure, O king, to attain to the eternal region of Brahman that is full of happiness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुसंरब्धोऽपि रामाणां न कुर्यादप्रियं नरः। रतिं प्रीतिं च धर्मं च तास्वायत्तमवेक्ष्य हि॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said Beholding his own army carnaged by highsouled warriors, your son, O ruler of men, was excited to the highest pitch of fury.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आत्मनो जन्मनः क्षेत्रं पुण्यं रामाः सनातनम्। ऋषीणामपि का शक्तिः स्रष्टुं रामामृते प्रजाम्॥
English Translation: Then quickly approaching Karna and Drona that foremost of victorious heroes and burning with rage, he eloquent in speech, spoke these wordsभवद्भ्यामिह संग्रामः क्रुद्धाभ्यां सम्प्रवर्तितः।
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रतिपद्य यदा सूनुर्धरणीरेणुगुण्ठितः। पितुराश्लिष्यतेऽङ्गानि किमस्त्यभ्यधिकं ततः॥
English Translation: Beholding the ruler of the Sindhus slain in battle by Savyasachin, you two, filled with rage, caused this battle to go on.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स त्वं स्वयमभिप्राप्तं साभिलाषमिमं सुतम्। प्रेक्षमाणं कटाक्षेण किमर्थमवमन्यसे॥ अण्डानि बिभ्रति स्वानि न भिन्दन्ति पिपीलिकाः। न भरेथाः कथं न त्वं धर्मज्ञः सन् स्वमात्मजम्॥
English Translation: Though competent to slay the Pandava troops, still you are beholding the slaughter of my troops by them with great in-difference.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न वाससां न रामाणां नापां स्पर्शस्तथाविधः। शिशोरालिङ्ग्यमानस्य स्पर्शः सूनोर्यथा सुखः॥
English Translation: If you now abandon me, you should have told me of it in the beginning. We two shall vanquish the sons of Pandu in battle even these were the words, you said to me, o you givers of honor. Hearing those words of yours, I then allowed these proceedings. Otherwise I would never have provoked these hostilities with the Parthas-hostilities that are so destructive of heroic combatants.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणो द्विपदां श्रेष्ठो गौर्वरिष्ठा चतुष्पदाम्। गुरुर्गरीयसां श्रेष्ठः पुत्रः स्पर्शवतां वरः॥
English Translation: If, O foremost of men, I do not deserve to be forsaken by you, then do you fight according to the measure of your prowess, O you that are possessed of great prowess.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्पृशतु त्वां समाश्लिष्य पुत्रोऽयं प्रियदर्शनः। पुत्रस्पर्शात् सुखतरः स्पर्शो लोके न विद्यते॥
English Translation: Thus pierced with the goad of speech by your son, those two heroes once more engaged in battle like two snakes poked with sticks.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्रिषु वर्षेषु पूर्णेषु प्रजाताहमरिंदम। इमं कुमारं राजेन्द्र तव शोकविनाशनम्॥ आहर्ता वाजिमेधस्य शतसंख्यस्य पौरव। इति वागन्तरिक्षे मां सूतकेऽभ्यवदत् पुरा॥
English Translation: Then those two foremost of car-warriors, the best of all human bowmen, rushed against the Parthas headed by the grandson of Shini and others.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ननु नामाङ्कमारोप्य स्नेहाद् ग्रामान्तरं गताः। मूर्ध्नि पुत्रानुपाघ्राय प्रतिनन्दन्ति मानवाः॥
English Translation: Similarly the Parthas supported by their own troops, rushed upon those two heroes, who were roaring repeatedly.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वेदेष्वपि वदन्तीमं मन्त्रग्रामं द्विजातयः। जातकर्माणि पुत्राणां तवापि विदितं तथा॥
English Translation: Then the enraged Drona that best of all wielders of weapons, quickly pierced that foremost of the descendants of Shini with ten sharp arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अङ्गादङ्गात् सम्भवसि हृदयादधिजायसे। आत्मा वै पुत्रनामासि स जीव शरदः शतम्॥
English Translation: Karna pierced him with ten shafts, your son with seven, Vrishasena with ten and Subala's son with seven arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जीवितं त्वदधीनं मे संतानमपि चाक्षयम्। तस्मात् त्वं जीव मे पुत्र सुसुखी शरदां शतम्॥
English Translation: Those hosts of the Kurus together with those warriors, began to shower arrows on the grandson of Shini. Then beholding Drona slaughter the Pandava hosts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वदङ्गेभ्यः प्रसूतोऽयं पुरुषात् पुरुषोऽपरः। वै सरसीवामलेऽऽत्मानं द्वितीयं पश्य सुतम्॥
English Translation: The Somakas from all side began to pierce him with showers of arrows. Then Drona snatched out of the Kshatriyas their lives, O ruler of men.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथा ह्याहवनीयोऽग्निर्गार्हपत्यात् प्रणीयते। तथा त्वत्तः प्रसूतोऽयं त्वमेकः सन् द्विधा कृतः॥ मृगावकृष्टेन पुरा मृगयां परिधावता। अहमासादिता राजन् कुमारी पितुराश्रमे॥
English Translation: Like the sun dispelling darkness with his rays. O ruler of men, when the Panchalas were being slaughtered by Drona.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उर्वशी पूर्वचित्तिश्च सहजन्या च मेनका। विश्वाची च घृताची च षडेवाप्सरसां वराः॥
English Translation: A dreadful sound was heard as they challenged one another aloud. Some leaving their sons, some their fathers, some their brothers and some their uncles.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तासां सा मेनका नाम ब्रह्मयोनिर्वराप्सराः। दिवः सम्प्राप्य जगतीं विश्वामित्रादजीजनत्॥
English Translation: Some their nephews, their companions and their friends and some their relatives, fled in all quickness, desirous of saving their own lives.

Sanskrit Shloka: सा मां हिमवतः प्रस्थे सुषुवे मनेकाप्सराः। अवकीर्य च मां याता परात्मजमिवासती॥
English Translation: Others, on the other hand, were confounded that they rushed even towards Drona himself. Indeed many warriors of the Pandava host were then dispatched to the other world.

English Translation: The brothers Krishna and Arjuna are ever engaged in achieving your good; O best of all kings, know me also to be devoted to your welfare.

English Translation: I will follow from behind the track laid open by Savyasachin. Those other elephants, O monarch, full seven hundred in number.

Sanskrit Shloka: यच्च कोपितयात्यर्थं त्वयोक्तोऽस्म्यप्रियं प्रिये। प्रणयिन्या विशालाक्षि तत् क्षान्तं ते मया शुभे॥

Sanskrit Shloka: तामेवमुक्त्वा राजर्षिर्दुष्यन्तो महिषीं प्रियाम्। वासोभिरन्नपानैश्च पूजयामास भारत॥

Vaishampayana said Through the kings present there saw the lady (Draupadi) crying piteously in affliction like a female osprey, yet they, out of the fear for the son of Dhritarashtra (Duryodhana), did not utter a word good or evil.
Seeing the sons and grandsons of kings sitting silent, the son of Dhritarashtra (Duryodhana) smiled and spoke thus to the daughter of the Panchala king.
Duryodhana said O Yajnaseni, the question you have asked depends on the greatly powerful Bhima, on Arjuna, on Nakula and on Sahadeva. Let them answer your question.
O Panchali, let them for them for your sake declare in the midst of these most noblemen (present here) that Yudhisthira is not their lord and that he is a liar; you will then be freed from the slavery.
Let the illustrious son of Dharma (Yudhisthira), ever devoted to virtue, who is like Indra himself, declare whether he is or is not your lord. At his words, accept us or accept the Pandavas without (further) delay.
All the Kurus present in this assembly are floating in the sea of your affliction. They are endued with magnanimity and looking at your husbands they are unable to answer your question.
Vaishampayana said Hearing these words of the Kuru king (Duryodhana), all persons present in the assembly loudly applauded him. Some shouting approvingly made signs to one another by motions of their eyes and lips and some made sounds of distress such as Oh," "Alas."
