Sanskrit Shloka: पूर्ण वर्षसहस्रं च एवंवृत्तिरभूनृपः। अब्भक्षः शरदस्त्रिंशदासीनियतवाङ्गनाः॥ ततश्च वायुभक्षोऽभूत् संवत्सरमतन्द्रितः। तथा पञ्चाग्निमध्ये च तपस्तेपे स वत्सरम्॥ एकपादः स्थितश्चासीत् षण्मासाननिलाशनः। पुण्यकीर्तिस्ततः स्वर्गे जगामावृत्य रोदसी॥
English Translation: You always live, ogod, in the Ocean, that home of Makaras. This Ocean the lord of rivers, will then be under you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीमसेन उवाच पौरोगवो ब्रुवाणोऽहं बल्लवो नाम भारत। उपस्थास्यामि राजानं विराटमिति मे मतिः।।।।
English Translation: You will then increase the decreases with Soma!-Varuna answered them saying-"Let it be so.'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सूपानस्य करिष्यामि कुशलोऽस्मि महानसे। कृतपूर्वाणि यान्यस्य व्यञ्जनानि सुशिक्षितैः॥ तान्यप्यभिभविष्यामि प्रीतिं संजनयन्त्रहम्। आहरिष्यामि दारूणां निचयान् महतोऽपि च॥ यत् प्रेक्ष्य विपुलं कर्म राजा संयोक्ष्यते स माम्। अमानुषाणि कुर्वाणस्तानि कर्माणि भारत॥ राज्ञस्तस्य परे प्रेष्या मंस्यन्ते मां यथा नृपम्। भक्ष्यान्नरसपानानां भविष्यामि तथेश्वरः॥
English Translation: All the celestials then assembled together, made Varuna living in the Ocean the Lord of all the waters, according to the rites sanctioned by the Scriptures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्विपा वा बलिनो राजन् वृषभा वा महाबलाः। विनिग्राह्या यदि मया निग्रहीष्यामि तानपि॥ ये च केचिन्नियोत्स्यन्ति समाजेषु नियोधकाः। तानहं हि नियोत्स्यामि रतिं तस्य विवर्धयन्॥ न त्वेतान् युद्ध्यमानान् वै हनिष्यामि कथञ्चन। तथैतान् पातयिष्यामि यथा यास्यन्ति न क्षयम्॥
English Translation: Having installed Varuna as the Lord of all aquatic animals and worshipping him duly, the celestials, returned their respective habitations.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आरालिको गोविकर्ता सूपकर्ता नियोधकः। आसं युधिष्ठिरस्याहमिति वक्ष्यामि पृच्छतः॥ आत्मानमात्मना रक्षश्चरिष्यामि विशाम्पते। इत्येतत् प्रतिजानामि विहरिष्याम्यहं यथा॥
English Translation: Installed by the celestials, the illustrious Varuna began to duly protect seas and lakes and rivers and others reservoirs of water as Indra protects the gods.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच यमग्निर्ब्राह्मणो भूत्वा समागच्छन्नृणां वरम्। दिधक्षुः खाण्डवं दावं दाशार्हसहितं पुरा॥ महाबलं महाबाहुमजितं कुरुनन्दनम्। सोऽयं किं कर्म कौन्तेयः करिष्यति धनंजयः॥
English Translation: Bathing in that Tirtha also and giving away various kinds of presents, Baladeva, the destroyer of Pralamba, endued with great wisdom, then proceeded to Agni Tirtha, where to the cater of the clarified butter, disappearing from the view, became concealed within the entrails of the Shami word.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: योऽयमासाद्य तं दावं तर्पयामास पावकम्। विजित्यैकरथेनेन्द्रं हत्वा पन्नगराक्षसान्॥ वासुकेः सर्पराजस्य स्वसारं हृतवांश्च यः। श्रेष्ठो यः प्रतियोधानां सोऽर्जुनः किं करिष्यति॥
English Translation: When the light of the words thus disappeared, O sinless one, the gods then went to the Grandsire of the universe.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सूर्यः प्रतपतां श्रेष्ठो द्विपदां ब्राह्मणो वरः। आशीविषश्च सर्पाणामग्निस्तेजस्विनां वरः॥ आयुधानां वरं वज्रं ककुद्मी च गवां वरः। ह्रदानामुदधिः श्रेष्ठः पर्जन्यो वर्षतां वरः॥ धृतराष्ट्रश्च नागानां हस्तिष्वैरावणो वरः। पुत्रः प्रियाणामधिको भार्या च सुहृदां वरा॥ यथैतानि विशिष्टानि जात्यां जात्यां वृकोदर। एवं युवा गुडाकेश: श्रेष्ठः सर्वधनुष्मताम्॥
English Translation: And they said-"The worshipful Agni has disappeared. We do not know the reason. Let not creation go to destruction. Create fire, O powerful Lord?"
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सोऽयमिन्द्रादनवरो वासुदेवान्महाद्युतिः। गाण्डीवधन्वा बीभत्सुः श्वेताश्वः किं करिष्यति॥
English Translation: Janamejaya said "For what reason did Agni, the Creator of all the worlds, disappear? How also was he found out by the celestials? Tell me all this fully."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उषित्वा पञ्च वर्षाणि सहस्राक्षस्य वेश्मनि। अस्त्रयोगं समासाद्य स्ववीर्यान्मानुषाद्भुतम्। दिव्यान्यस्त्राणि चाप्तानि देवरूपेण भास्वता॥ यं मन्ये द्वादशं रुद्रमादित्यानां त्रयोदशम्। वसूनां नवमं मन्ये ग्रहाणां दशमं तथा॥ यस्य बाहू समौ दी? ज्याघातकठिनत्वचौ। दक्षिणे चैव सव्ये च गवामिव वहः कृतः॥ हिमवानिव शैलानां समुद्रः सरितामिव। त्रिदशानां यथा शक्रो वसूनामिव हव्यवाट्॥ मृगाणामिव शार्दूलो गरुडः पततामिव। वरः संन्यमानानां सोऽर्जुनः किं करिष्यति॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said The highly powerful Agni became very much frightened at the curse of Bhrigu, Concealing himself within the entrails of the Shami wood, that worshipful god disappeared from the view.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्जुन उवाच प्रतिज्ञा घण्ढकोऽस्मीति करिष्यामि महीपते। ज्याघातौ हि महान्तौ मे संवर्तुं नृप दुष्करौ॥
English Translation: Upon the disappearance of Agni, all the gods led by Vasava, in great affliction, searched for the missing god.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वलयैश्छादयिष्यामि बाहू किणकृताविमौ। कर्णयोः प्रतिमुच्याहं कुण्डले ज्वलनप्रभे॥
English Translation: Finding Agni then, they saw that god lying within the entrails of the Shami wood,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पिनद्धकम्बुः पाणिभ्यां तृतीयां प्रकृतिं गतः। वेणीकृतशिरा राजन् नाम्ना चैव बृहन्नला।॥ पठन्नाख्यायिकाश्चैव स्त्रीभावेन पुनः पुनः। रमयिष्ये महीपालमन्यांश्चान्तःपुरे जनान्॥
English Translation: The celestials, O foremost of kings, with Brihaspati at their head, having found out the god, became very glad with Vasava amongst them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गीतं नृत्यं विचित्रं च वादिनं विविधं तथा। शिक्षयिष्याम्यहं राजन् विराटस्य पुरस्त्रियः॥
English Translation: They then returned to their respective abodes. Agni also, from Bhrigu's curse, became an cater of everything as said by the Brahmavadin.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रजानां समुदाचारं बहु कर्म कृतं वदन। छादयिष्यामि कौन्तेय माययाऽऽत्मानमात्मना॥
English Translation: The intelligent Balarama, having bathed there, then went to Bramhayoni where the worshipful Grandsire of all the worlds had created the world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिरस्य गेहे वै द्रौपद्याः परिचारिका। उषितास्मीति वक्ष्यामि पृष्टो राज्ञा च पाण्डव॥
English Translation: Formerly the Lord Bramhan having with all the gods bathed in that Tirtha, created all the Tirthas according to due rites, for the celestials.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतेन विधिना छन्नः कृतकेन यथानलः। विहरिष्यामि राजेन्द्र विराटभवने सुखम्॥
English Translation: Bathing there and distributing various kinds of gifts, Baladeva then proceeded to the Tirtha called Kaurava where the powerful Ailavila, having practised severe austerities, became the king of riches.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सनत्सुजात उवाच शोकः क्रोधश्च लोभश्च कामो मानः परासुता। ईर्ष्या मोहो विधित्सा च कृपाऽसूया जुगुप्सुता॥ द्वादशैते महादोषा मनुष्यप्राणनाशनाः।
English Translation: While he dwelt there (practising austerities), all kinds of wealth and all the precious gems, came to him of their own accord. Baladeva, having gone to that Tirtha and bathed in its waters, distributed immense wealth amongst the Brahmanas with due rites.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एकैकमेते राजेन्द्र मनुष्यान् पर्युपासते। यैराविष्टो नरः पापं मूढसंज्ञो व्यवस्यति॥
English Translation: Rama saw at that spot the excellent woods of Kuvera. In days of yore, the great Kuvera the king of the Yakshas, having practised the severest austerities there, obtained many boons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्पृहयालुरुचः पुरुषो वा वदान्यः क्रोधं बिभ्रन्मनसा वै विकत्थी। नृशंसधर्माः षडिमे जना वै प्राप्याप्यर्थं नोत सभाजयन्ते।॥
English Translation: There were the lordship of all riches, the friendship of powerful Rudra, the status of a god, the rcgency over a particular quarter (the north) and a son named Nalakuvara. These the king of the Yakshas speedily obtained there.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सम्भोगसंविद् विषमोऽतिमानी दत्त्वा विकत्थी कृपणो दुर्बलश्च। बहुप्रशंसी वन्दितद्विट् सदैव सप्तैवोक्ताः पापशीला नृशंसाः॥
English Translation: The Maruts, coming there, installed him duly (in his sovereignty). He also obtained for a vehicle a well-equipt cclestial car, fleet as thought, as also as all the prosperity of a god.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धर्मश्च सत्यं च तपो दमश्च अमात्सर्यं ह्रीस्तितिक्षाऽनसूया। दानं श्रुतं चैव धृतिः क्षमा च महाव्रता द्वादश ब्राह्मणस्य॥
English Translation: Bathing in that Tirtha and giving away immense wealth, Vala using white unguents thence went speedily to another Tirtha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यो नैतेभ्यः प्रच्यवेद् द्वादशभ्यः सर्वामपीमां पृथिवीं स शिष्यात्। त्रिभिभ्यिामेकतो वाऽर्थितो यो नास्य स्वमस्तीति च वेदितव्यम्॥
English Translation: Abounding in various creatures, that Tirtha is known by the name of Badarapachana. There the fruits of every reason are always available and flowers and fruits of every kind always abundant."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दमस्त्यागोऽथाप्रमाद इत्येतेष्वमृतं स्थितम्। एतानि ब्रह्ममुख्यानां ब्राह्मणानां मनीषिणाम्॥
English Translation: Narada said: Thereupon the tranquil and self-restrained celestials Rishi, Siddhas and the Paramhansas, became exceedingly sorry on seeing that great massacre.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सद् वासद् वा परीवादो ब्राह्मणस्य न शस्यते। नरकप्रतिष्ठास्ते वै स्युर्य एव कुर्वते जनाः॥
English Translation: Being moved by compassion, they with their passions, senses and souls under complete control, went to the abode of the Grandsire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मदोऽष्टादशदोषः स स्यात् पुरा योऽप्रकीर्तितः। लोकद्वेष्यं प्रातिकूल्यमभ्यसूया मृषा वचः॥
English Translation: They then saw the Grandsire seated with the celestials, surrounded by the Siddhas and the Brahmarshis.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कामक्रोधौ पारतन्त्र्यं परिवादोऽथ पैशुनम्। अर्थहानिर्विवादश्च मात्सर्यं प्राणिपीडनम्॥
English Translation: There was the Deity Mahadeva (Shiva), there was Agni with Vayu. There were Chandra, Aditya, Indra and the Rishis devoted to the contemplation of the Supreme. (There were) the Vaikhanasas, the Balkhilyas, the Vanaprasthas, the Marichipas, the Ajanma, the Avimudas and many other greatly effulgent ascetics. All the Rishis came to the Grandsire and those great Rishis all approached him with sorrowful hearts. They represented to him all the acts of Sunda and Upasunda. The celestials and the great Rishis told the Grandsire of the universe in details what they had done and how and in what order they had done it. They all pressed the matter to the Grandsire and the Grandsire, having heard what they said, reflected for a moment and settled what ought to be done. Resolving to kill them, he summoned Vishvakarma.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ईर्ष्या मोदोऽतिवादश्च संज्ञानाशोऽभ्यसूयिता। तस्मात् प्राज्ञो न माद्येत सदा ह्येतद् विगर्हितम्॥
English Translation: Seeing Vishvakarma, the Grandsire commanded him saying, “O great ascetic, create a damsel who will be captivating to all hearts?"
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सौहृदे वै षड् गुणा वेदितव्याः प्रिये हृष्यन्त्यप्रिये च व्यथन्ते। स्यादात्मनः सुचिरं याचते यो ददात्ययाच्यमपि देयं खलु स्यात्। नभ्यर्थितश्चार्हति शुद्धभावः॥
English Translation: Bowing down to the Grandsire and receiving his command with reverence, he created a celestials damsel after good deal of thought.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्यक्तद्रव्यः संवसेन्नेह कामाद् भुङ्क्ते कर्म स्वाशिषं बाधते च॥
English Translation: Vishvavita (Vishvakarma) first collected whatever handsome there was in mobile or immobile things in the three worlds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्रव्यवान् गुणवानेव त्यागी भवति सात्त्विकः। पञ्च भूतानि पञ्चभ्यो निवर्तयति तादृशः॥
English Translation: He placed millions of gems on the body of the damsel. The celestials beauty that he created was a mass of gems and jewels.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतत् समृद्धमप्यूर्ध्वं तपो भवति केवलम्। सत्त्वात् प्रच्यवमानानां संकल्पेन समाहितम्॥
English Translation: She was created by Vishvakarma with good deal of care. She became matchless in beauty amongst the women of the three worlds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यतो यज्ञाः प्रवर्धन्ते सत्यस्यैवावरोधनात्। मनसान्यस्य भवति वाचान्यस्याथ कर्मणा॥
English Translation: There was not the minutest part of her body which by its wealth of beauty did not rivet the gaze of the beholder directed towards it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संकल्पसिद्धं पुरुषमसंकल्पोऽधितिष्ठति। ब्राह्मणस्य विशेषेण किञ्चान्यदपि मे शृणु॥
English Translation: She was like Lakshmi himself; and that extraordinarily beautiful damsel captivated the eyes and hearts of all creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अध्यापयेन्महदेतद् यशस्यं वाचो विकाराः कवयो वदन्ति। अस्मिन् योगे सर्वमिदं प्रतिष्ठितं ये तद् विदुरमृतास्ते भवन्ति॥
English Translation: Because she was created with the portions of every gem in every minute portion, the Grandsire gave her the name of Tilottama.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न कर्मणा सुकृतेनैव राजन् सत्यं जयेज्जुहुयाद् वा यजेद् वा। नैतेन बालोऽमृत्युमभ्येति राजन् रति चासौ न लभत्यन्तकाले॥
English Translation: She bowed down to Brahma and spoke to him with joined hands, “O lord of creatures, what task am I to accomplish and for what purpose am I created?"
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तूष्णीमेक उपासीत चेष्टेत मनसाऽपि न। तथा संस्तुतिनिन्दाभ्यां प्रीतिरोषौ विवर्जयेत्॥
English Translation: The Grandsire said : O Tilottama, go to the Asuras, Sunda and Upasunda. O amiable girl, tempt them with your desirable beauty.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अत्रैव तिष्ठन् क्षत्रिय ब्रह्माविशति पश्यति। वेदेषु चानुपूर्येण एतद् विद्वन् ब्रवीमि ते॥
English Translation: Act in such a way that as soon as they saw you they may quarrel with each other in consequence of your wealth of beauty.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मनुरुवाच अक्षरात् खं ततो वायुस्ततो ज्योतिस्ततो जलम्। जलात् प्रसूता जगती जगत्यां जायते जगत्॥
English Translation: She promised to do it; and bowing down to the Grandsire, she walked round the celestials assembly.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतैः शरीरैर्जलमेव गत्वा जलाच्च तेजः पवनोऽन्तरिक्षम् खाद् वै निवर्तन्ति न भाविनस्ते मोक्षं च ते वै परमाप्नुवन्ति॥
English Translation: The illustrious Deity (Brahma) was then sitting facing eastwards; Mahadeva (Shiva) also was sitting facing eastwards; all the other celestials with their faces northwards and the Rishis with their faces towards all directions.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नोष्णं न शीतं मृदु नापि तीक्ष्णं नाम्लं कषायं मधुरं न तिक्तम्। न्न रूपवत्तत् परमस्वभावम्॥
English Translation: When she was walking round the assembly, Indra and the illustrious Sthanu (Shiva) alone succeeded in preserving their tranquility of mind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्पर्श तनुर्वेद रसं च जिह्वा घ्राणं च गन्धान् श्रवणौ च शब्दान्। रूपाणि चक्षुर्न च तत्परं यद् गृह्णन्त्यनध्यात्मविदो मनुष्याः॥
English Translation: Because he (Shiva) was very much desirous of seeing her, therefore when she came at his side, another face came out on the southern side of his body with eyes like fullblossomed lotuses.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निवर्तयित्वा रसनां रसेभ्योः घ्राणं च गन्धाच्छ्रवणौ च शब्दात्। स्ततः परं पश्यति स्वं स्वभावम्॥
English Translation: When she came behind him, another face appeared on his western side; and when she came on the northern side, a fourth face appeared on his northern side. Indra also came to have one thousand eyes before, behind and on his flanks, each large and reddish.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यतो गृहीत्वा हि करोति यच्च यस्मिश्च तामारभते प्रवृत्तिम्। यस्मिश्च यद् केन च यश्च कर्ता यत् कारणं ते समुदायमाहुः॥
English Translation: Thus in days of yore, Sthanu (Shiva) the great Deity, came to have four faces and the slayer of Vala (Indra) one thousand eyes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यद् व्याप्यभूद् व्यापकं साधकं च यन्मन्त्रवत् स्थास्यति चापि लोके। यः सर्वहेतुः परमात्मकारी तत् कारणं कार्यमतो यदन्यत्॥
English Translation: All the celestials and the Rishis turned their faces to that direction where Tilottama went in her walking round the assembly.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथा हि कश्चित् सुकृतैर्मनुष्यः शुभाशुभं प्राप्नुतेऽथाविरोधात्। एवं शरीरेषु शुभाशुभेषु स्वकर्मजैनिमिदं निबद्धम्॥
English Translation: Except those of the Deity, the divine Grandsire, the eyes of all those illustrious begins fell on her body.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथा प्रदीप्तः पुरतः प्रदीपः प्रकाशमन्यस्य करोति दीप्यन्। तथेह पञ्चेन्द्रियदीपवृक्षा ज्ञानप्रदीप्ताः परवन्त एव॥
English Translation: When that great beauty went away, the celestials and the great Rishis regarded the task already accomplished.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथा च राज्ञा बहवो ह्यमात्याः पृथक् प्रमाणं प्रवदन्ति युक्ताः। तद्वच्छरीरेषु भवन्ति पञ्च ज्ञानैकदेशः परमः स तेभ्यः॥
English Translation: After Tilottama had departed, the First Cause of the creation (Brahma) sent away all the celestials and the Rishis.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथार्चिषोऽग्नेः पवनस्य वेगो मरीचयोऽर्कस्य नदीषु चापः। स्तद्वच्छरीराणि शरीरिणां तु॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said Sanjaya, having heard the words of king Dhritarashtra, to Upaplavya to see the sons of Pandu of illimitable strength.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथा च कश्चित् परशुं गृहीत्वा धूमं च पश्येज्ज्वलनं च काष्ठे। तद्वच्छरीरोदरपाणिपादं छित्त्वा न पश्यन्ति ततो यदन्यत्॥
English Translation: And having reached the presence of king Yudhishthira the son of Kunti, the son of Suta (caste) first made his obeisance and then said-
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तान्येव काष्ठानि यथा विमथ्य धूमं च पश्येज्ज्वलनं च योगात्। तद्वत् सबुद्धिः सममिन्द्रियात्मा बुधः परं पश्यति तं स्वभावम्॥
English Translation: And Sanjaya the son of Gavalgana and the son of a Suta (caste) cheerfully said to him who had created no enemies. It is fortunate, O king, that I see you without decease, having friends and equal to the great Indra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथात्मनोऽङ्गं पतितं पृथिव्यां स्वप्नान्तरे पश्यति चात्मनोऽन्यत्। र्लिङ्गात्तथा गच्छति लिङ्गमन्यत्॥
English Translation: The aged and wise king Dhritarashtra the son of Ambika, asks about your health. Is Bhima the foremost among the sons of Pandu well and is Dhananjaya so are these two sons of the king of Madri,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न युज्यतेऽसौ परमः शरीरी। अनेन लिङ्गेन तु लिङ्गमन्यद् गच्छत्यदृष्टः फलसंनियोगात्॥
English Translation: How is the princess Krishna, the daughter of Drupada, who is truthful, wife of a hero, with her sons, that spirited lady for whose benefit you pray for (the accomplishment of your fondest wishes) O son of Bharata, O you of good desires?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न चक्षुषा पश्यति रूपमात्मनो न चापि संस्पर्शमुपैति किंचित्। न चापि तैः साधयते तु कार्य ते तं न पश्यन्ति स पश्यते तान्॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said O son of Gavalgana, O Sanjaya, you are welcome. We are delighted at seeing you. In return to know about your health. I am well with my younger brothers. O you learned man.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथा समीपे ज्वलतोऽनलस्य संतापजं रूपमुपैति कश्चित्। न चान्तरं रूपगुणं बिभर्ति तथैव तद् दृश्यति रूपमस्य॥
English Translation: Having after a long time, heard the news of the health of the aged king of the Kurus, O Suta and having seen you, O Sanjaya, am I so pleased that regard as having seen the king himself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मदृश्यमन्यद् विशते शरीरम्। विसृज्य भूतेषु महत्सु देहं तदाश्रयं चैव बिभर्ति रूपम्॥
English Translation: Our grandsire is aged, wise, great in wisdom and endued with every virtue. Is this Bhishma, the son of Kunti, in health? Is he of the same habits, as in days of old?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: खं वायुमग्नि सलिलं तथोर्वी समन्ततोऽभ्याविशते शरीरी। नानाश्रयाः कर्मसु वर्तमानाः श्रोत्रादयः पञ्च गुणान् श्रयन्ते।॥
English Translation: Is the large-minded king Dhritarashtra, the son of Vichitravirya, well along with his sons. Is the great king Balhika, the son of Pratipa, O you learned son of Suta (caste).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्तेजोमयं रूपमथो विपाकः। जलाश्रयं स्वेदमुक्तं रसं च वाय्वात्मकः स्पर्शकृतो गुणश्च॥
English Translation: Is Somadatta, well? How are Bhurishrava, Satyasandha, Shalya, Drona and Kripa, the twice born with his sons, all endued with great qualities? How are these? Are they without illness?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महत्सु भूतेषु वसन्ति पञ्च पञ्चेन्द्रियार्थाश्च तथेन्द्रियाणि। सर्वाणि चैतानि मनोऽनुगानि बुद्धिं मनोऽन्वेति मतिः स्वभावम्॥
English Translation: All the foremost bowmen in the world have, O Sanjaya, side with the Kurus and so have the foremost of all those who are endued with great wisdom and know all sciences and can wield the bow in the world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शुभाशुभं कर्म कृतं यदन्यत् तदेव प्रत्याददते स्वदेहे। मनोऽनुवर्तन्ति परावराणि जलौकसः स्रोत इवानुकूलम्॥
English Translation: Do these wielders of the bow get honours? Are they without disease in whose kingdom worth seeing lives the well-behaved son of Drona endued with great qualities?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चलं यथा दृष्टिपथं परति सूक्ष्मं महद रूपमिवाभिभाति। स्वरूपमालोचयते च रूपं परं तथा बुद्धिपथं परैति॥
English Translation: Is the very wise prince Yuyutsu, the son of (Dhritarashtra by) the Vaishya lady in health? Is the minister Karna in health whose advice the dull-headed Suyodhana follows?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच गृहस्थो ब्रह्मचारी वा वानप्रस्थोऽथ भिक्षुकः। य इच्छेत् सिद्धिमास्थातुं देवतां कां यजेत सः॥
English Translation: Are the aged ladies the mothers of the sons of Bharata and the slave-wives of the great one, O Suta and daughter-in law, sons, sister' sons and daughter' sons in peace?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कुतो ह्यस्य ध्रुवः स्वर्गः कुतो नैःश्रेयसं परम्। विधिना केन जुहुयाद् दैव पित्र्यं तथैव च॥
English Translation: Dose the king grant suitable annuities to the Brahmanas as in former days? Have the sons of Dhritarashtra discontinued the annuities granted by me the twice-born, O Sanjaya?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मुक्तश्च कां गतिं गच्छेन्मोक्षचैव किमात्मकः। स्वर्गतश्चैव किं कुर्याद् येन न च्यवते दिव॥
English Translation: Dose the king Dhritarashtra, with his sons, treat with contempt the Brahmanas when they commit breaches of law? Dose he treat with lightness the provision for Brahmanas which is the road to heaven?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: देवतानां च को देवः पितॄणां च पिता तथा। तस्मात् परतरं यच्च तन्मे ब्रूहि पितामह॥
English Translation: This light has been instituted by Providence for the good of beings in this world. If those dull-headed ones do not treat with forbearance their short-comings will the sons of Kuru meet with ruin.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच गूढं मां प्रश्नवित् प्रश्नं पृच्छसे त्वमिहानघ। न ह्येतत् तर्कया शक्यं वक्तुं वर्षशतैरपि॥
English Translation: Dose the king Dhritarashtra with his sons make provisions for his group of ministers. Are there no enemies in the disguise of well wishers combined for their ruin?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ऋते देवप्रसादाद् वा राजन् ज्ञानागमेन वा। गहनं ह्येदाख्यानं व्याख्यातव्यं तवारिहन्॥
English Translation: Do all those sons of Kuru tall of crimes committed by the sons of Pandu? Do Drona and hero Kripa with his sons speak of our crimes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अत्राप्युदाहरन्तीममितिहासं पुरातनम्। नारदस्य च संवादमृषेर्नारायणस्य च॥
English Translation: Do all the sons of Kuru speak of Dhritarashtra, with his sons as their king? Do they, when they see a band of highway men assembled, remember in battle (Arjuna).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नारायणो हि विश्वात्मा चतुर्मूर्तिः सनातनः। धर्मात्मजः सम्बभूव पितैवं मेऽभ्यभाषत॥ कृते युगे महाराज पुरा स्वायम्भुवेऽन्तरे। नरो नारायणश्चैव हरिः कृष्णः स्वयम्भुवः॥
English Translation: Do they remember, the arrows shot from the Gandiva bow by means of the string of the bow and dexterity of the hands, the former shaking often and again and making a noise like the roaring of the clouds and flying swiftly.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषां नारायणनरौ तपस्तेपतुरव्ययौ। बदर्याश्रममासाद्य शकटे कनकामये॥
English Translation: I have not seen in this world any warrior who is superior to Arjuna or even equal to him, who with single effort, can send out sixty one whetted arrows with good feathers and with sharp edges.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अष्टचक्रं हि तद् यानं भूतयुक्तं मनोरमम्। तत्राद्यौ लोकनाथौ तौ कृशौ धमनिसंततौ॥ तपसा तेजसा चैव दुर्निरीक्ष्यौ सुरैरपि। यस्य प्रसादं कुर्वाते स देवौ द्रष्टुमर्हति॥
English Translation: Bhimasena is strong indeed with the mace in hand and makes a large number of enemies in an army tremble with fear as an elephant does in a place abounding with reeds. Do they remember him?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नूनं तयोरनुमते हृदि हृच्छयचोदितः। महामेरोगिरेः शृङ्गात् प्रच्युतो गन्धमादनम्॥
English Translation: Sahadeva, the son of the king of Madri, conquered the combined Kalingas and Dantakura by (shooting arrows with) his right and left hands; do they remember this strong one?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नारदः सुमहद्भूतं सर्वलोकानचीचरत्। तं देशमगमद् राजन् बदर्याश्रममाशुगः॥
English Translation: In days of was Nakula sent to conquer the Shibis and the Trigartas. This is within your knowledge. O Sanjaya, they subjugated the western countries. Do they remember these sons of the king of Madri.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तयोराह्निकवेलायां तस्य कौतूहलं त्वभूत्। इदं तदास्पदं कृत्स्नं यस्मिल्लोकाः प्रतिष्ठिताः॥ सदेवासुरगन्धर्वाः सकिन्नरमहोरगाः।
English Translation: The defeat that they met with in the forest named when ill advised they went there and when Bhimasena and Arjuna faced these dull headed ones who were imprisoned by the enemy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एका मूर्तिरियं पूर्वं जाता भूयश्चतुर्विधा॥ धर्मस्य कुलसंताने धर्मादेभिर्विवर्धितः।
English Translation: Where I protected Arjuna, in the rear and Bhimasena protecting the rear of the two sons of the king of Madri and where the wielder of the Gandiva bow issued out uninjured after rendering the enemy depressed do they remember?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अहो ह्यनुगृहीतोऽद्य धर्म एभिः सुरैरह॥ नरनारायणाभ्यां च कृष्णेन हरिणा तथा।
English Translation: It is not by a single good deed that we can be happy in this world, O Sanjaya, when with all our endeavors are we unable to win over the son of Dhritarashtra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अत्र कृष्णो हरिश्चैव कस्मिंश्चित् कारणान्तरे॥ स्थितौ धर्मोत्तरौ होतो तथा तपसि धिष्ठितौ।
English Translation: Bhishma said After the expiration of that night, and that best of Brahmanas had left the house, Gautama issuing from his house, began to proceed towards the sea, O Bharata.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतौ हि परमं धाम कानयोराह्निकक्रिया॥ पितरौ सर्वभूतानां दैवतं च यशस्विनौ। कां देवतां तु यजतः पितॄन् वा कान् महामती॥
English Translation: On the way he saw some sea-faring merchants. With that caravan of merchants he proceeded towards the sea.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इति संचिन्त्य मनसा भक्त्या नारायणस्य तु। सहसा प्रादुरभवत् समीपे देवयोस्तदा॥
English Translation: It so took place, however, O king, that large caravan was attacked, while passing through a mountain valley, by an infuriate elephant. Almost all the persons were killed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृते दैवे च पित्र्ये च ततस्ताभ्यां निरीक्षितः। पूजितश्चैव विधिना यथाप्रोक्तेन शास्त्रतः॥
English Translation: Somehow escaping from the great danger, the Brahmana fled towards the north for saving his life, not knowing where he went.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तद् दृष्ट्वा महदाश्चर्यमपूर्वं विधिविस्तरम्। उपोपविष्टः सुप्रीतो नारदो भगवानृषिः॥
English Translation: Separated from the caravan and gone to a great distance, he began to travel alone in a forest, like a Kimpurusha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नारायणं संनिरीक्ष्य प्रसन्नेनान्तरात्मना। नमस्कृत्वा महादेवमिदं वचनमब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: At last coming upon a road leading towards the ocean, he travelled on till the reached a charming and heavenly forest filled with blossoming trees.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नारद उवाच वेदेषु सपुराणेषु साङ्गोपाङ्गेषु गीयसे। त्वमजः शाश्वतो धाता मातामृतमनुत्तमम्॥ प्रतिष्ठितं भूतभव्यं त्वयि सर्वमिदं जगत्।
English Translation: It was adorned with mango trees which carried flowers and fruits throughout the year. It appeared like the garden of Nandana (in heaven) and was inhabited by Yakshas and Kinnaras.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चत्वारो ह्याश्रमा देव सर्वे गार्हस्थ्यमूलकाः॥ यजन्ते त्वामहरहर्नानामूर्तिसमास्थितम्।
English Translation: It was also decked with Shalas Palmyras, Tamalas, and with clusters of black aloes, and many large sandal trees.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पिता माता च सर्वस्य जगतः शाश्वतो गुरुः। कं त्वद्य यजसे देवं पितरं कं न विद्महे॥
English Translation: Upon the charming tablelands that he beheld there, fragrant with perfumes of various kinds, birds of the best species were always heard to send out their sweet notes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्री भगवानुवाच अवाच्यमेतद् वक्तव्यमात्मगुह्यं सनातनम्। तव भक्तिमतो ब्रह्मन् वक्ष्यामि तु यथातथम्॥
English Translation: Other birds, called Bharundas and having faces like human beings, and those called Bhulingas, and others belonging mountainous regions and to the sea, poured forth their sweet notes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यत् तत् सूक्ष्ममविज्ञेयमव्यक्तमचलं ध्रुवम्। इन्द्रियैरिन्द्रियार्थश्च सर्वभूतैश्च वर्जितम्॥ स ह्यन्तरात्मा भूतानां क्षेत्रज्ञश्चेति कथ्यते। त्रिगुणव्यतिरिक्तो वै पुरुषश्चेति कल्पितः॥
English Translation: Gautama went through that forest, listening, as he went, to those delightful and charming notes of nature's songsters.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मादव्यक्तमुत्पन्नं त्रिगुणं द्विजसत्तम। अव्यक्ता व्यक्तभावस्था या सा प्रकृतिरव्यया॥
English Translation: On his way he saw a very charming and level spot of land covered with golden sands and resembling heaven itself, O king, in its beauty.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तां योनिमावयोर्विद्धि योऽसौ सदसदात्मकः। आवाभ्यां पूज्यतेऽसौ हि दैवे पित्र्ये च कल्प्यते॥

Sanskrit Shloka: नास्ति तस्मात् परोऽन्यो हि पिता देवोऽथवा द्विज। आत्मा हि नः स विज्ञेयस्ततस्तं पूजयावहे॥
English Translation: The spot underneath that beautiful tree was drenched with water perfumed with the most fragrant sandal. Highly beautiful and abounding with sweet flowers all around, the spot appeared like the court of the Grandfather himself.

Sanskrit Shloka: तेनैषा प्रथिता ब्रह्मन् मर्यादा लोकभाविनी। दैवं पित्र्यं च कर्तव्यमिति तस्यानुशासनम्॥
English Translation: Seeing that charming and peerless spot, filled with blossoming trees, sacred, and looking like the house of a very god, Gautama was highly pleased.

Sanskrit Shloka: ब्रह्मा स्थाणुर्मनुर्दक्षो भृगुर्धर्मस्तपो यमः। मरीचिरङ्गिराऽत्रिश्च पुलस्त्यः पुलहः क्रतुः॥ वसिष्ठः परमेष्ठी च विवस्वान् सोम एव च। कर्दमश्चापि यः प्रोक्तः क्रोधो विक्रीत एव च॥ एकविंशतिरुत्पन्नास्ते प्रजापतयः स्मृताः। तस्य देवस्य मर्यादां पूजयन्तः सनातनीम्॥
English Translation: Arrived there, he sat himself down with a delighted mind. Sanskrit Shloka: दैवं पित्र्यं च सततं तस्य विज्ञाय तत्त्वतः। आत्मप्राप्तानि च ततः प्राप्नुवन्ति द्विजोत्तमाः॥
English Translation: Fanned by that sweet-scented breeze, the Brahmana became refreshed, and for the pleasure he felt ho soon fell asleep. Meanwhile the sun set behind the setting hills.

Sanskrit Shloka: स्वर्गस्था अपि ये केचित् तान् नमस्यन्ति देहिनः। ते तत्प्रसादाद् गच्छन्ति तेनादिष्टफलां गतिम्॥

English Translation: Decorated with the many ornaments that he wore and that were as brilliant as the sun himself, that child of a celestial girl shone in great beauty.

Sanskrit Shloka: ये तु तद्भाविता लोके ह्येकान्तित्वं समास्थिताः। एतदभ्यधिकं तेषां यत् ते तं प्रविशन्त्यत्॥

Sanskrit Shloka: इति गुह्यसमुद्देशस्तव नारद कीर्तितः। भक्त्या प्रेम्णा च विप्रर्षे अस्मद्भक्त्या च ते श्रुतः॥
English Translation: Having come to my house you are to-day my dear and excellent guest! Having received my adorations according to the rites laid down in the scriptures, you may go where you like tomorrow morning.

Sanskrit Shloka: इति गुह्यसमुद्देशस्तव नारद कीर्तितः। भक्त्या प्रेम्णा च विप्रर्षे अस्मद्भक्त्या च ते श्रुतः॥

English Translation: Is ever watchful for capturing the very virtuous king Yudhishthira. O son of Prisata, when I am gone, there should be no other duty of yours.

English Translation: Then as that mighty-armed one proceeded onwards, the Panchalas together with the Somakas, all endued with heroism, followed him from behind, like the celestials following Maghavat.

Sanskrit Shloka: यत्र ते नृपशार्दूल संदेहो वै भविष्यति। श्वः प्रभाते हि वक्ष्यामि संध्या हि समुपस्थिता॥
English Translation: Those foremost of car-warriors, those heroes and their following troops fighting heedfully and falling upon Bhimasena appeared highly beautiful.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच उत सन्तमसन्तं वा बालं वृद्धं च संजय। उताबलं बलीयांसं धाता प्रकुरुते वशे॥
English Translation: Then that mighty car-warrior endued with heroism was surrounded by those warriors. Beholding them, the son of Kunti the highly powerful Bhimasena.

Sanskrit Shloka: उत बालाय पाण्डित्यं पण्डितायोत बालताम्। ददाति सर्वमीशानः पुरस्ताच्छुक्रमुच्चरन्॥
English Translation: Furiously fell upon them like a lion attacking other inferior animals. Then those heroes displaying mighty weapons of celestial make.

Sanskrit Shloka: बलं जिज्ञासमानस्य आचक्षीथा यथातथम्। अथ मन्त्रं मन्त्रयित्वा याथातथ्येन हृष्टवत्॥
English Translation: Covered Bhima with their arrows like the clouds covering the sun. Passing through all those divisions, Bhima then rushed against that of Drona.

English Translation: Then he poured his arrowy shower on the elephant division that was stationed in the front.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्रूयाश्चैनं त्वमासीनं कुरुभिः परिवारितम्। तवैव राजन् वीर्येण सुखं जीवन्ति पाण्डवाः॥
English Translation: The son of the wind-god, mangling in no time that division of elephants, with his shafts, caused it to give way in all directions. Like beasts terrified at the roar of a Sarabha in the forest.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तव प्रसादाद बालास्ते प्राप्ता राज्यमरिंदम्। राज्ये तान् स्थापयित्वाग्रे नोपेक्षस्व विनश्यतः॥
English Translation: Those elephants began to fly away uttering distressful cries. Transgressing that division, he quickly assailed that of Drona.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वमप्येतदेकस्य नालं संजय कस्यचित्। तात संहत्य जीवामो द्विषतां मा वशं गमः॥
English Translation: Him then the preceptor checked like the continent checking the surging waves of the ocean; and then the latter smilingly pierced the former on the forehead with a Naracha.
