Sanskrit Shloka: तथा भीष्मं शान्तनवं भारतानां पितामहम्। शिरसाभिवदेथास्त्वं मम नाम प्रकीर्तयन्॥
English Translation: Thereupon that son of Pandu appeared beautiful like the sun shooting his rays only in an upward direction. Then the Preceptor considering that, like Phalguna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभिवाद्य च वक्तव्यस्ततोऽस्माकं पितामहः। भवता शन्तनोवंशो निमग्नः पुनरुद्धृतः॥
English Translation: Bhima would also worship him, addressed the latter saying-'O Bhimasena, you shall never succeed in penetrating into the host of your enemies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स त्वं कुरु तथा तात स्वमतेन पितामह। यथा जीवन्ति ते पौत्राः प्रीतिमन्तः परस्परम्॥
English Translation: Without, in the first instance defeating myself, O mighty one, who is now your foe. It was with my permission that your younger brother, with Krishna, has penetrated into this array.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथैव विदुरं ब्रूयाः कुरूणां मन्त्रधारिणम्। अयुद्धं सौम्य भाषस्व हितकामो युधिष्ठिरे॥
English Translation: But you shall never be able (of allowed) to enter into this division of mine." Thereupon the dauntless Bhima, hearing those words of the preceptor.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ दुर्योधनं ब्रूया राजपुत्रममर्षणम्। मध्ये कुरूणामासीनमनुनीय पुनः पुनः॥
English Translation: And waxing worth, quickly replied to Drona with his eyes looking like burnished copper-"O vilest of Brahmanas, it cannot be that Arjuna has entered this array with your permission. He is invincible and is competent even to penetrate through the army of Shakra himself. It was only for honoring you that he offered you worship.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपापां यदुपैक्षस्त्वं कृष्णामेतां सभागताम्। तद् दुःखमतितिक्षाम मा वधीष्म कुरूनिति॥
English Translation: But, O Drona, I am no lament Arjuna. I am Bhimasena your enemy. We used to regard you as our father, preceptor and friend and we were like your sons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं पूर्वापरान् क्लेशानतितिक्षन्त पाण्डवाः। बलीयांसोऽपि सन्तो यत् तत् सर्वं कुरवो विदुः॥
English Translation: Thinking thus we used to humble ourselves to you. But as you speak such words today, it seems that all that has been changed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यन्नः प्रव्राजयः सौम्य अजिनैः प्रतिवासितान्। तद् दुःखमतितिक्षाम मा वधिष्म कुरूनिति॥
English Translation: If you take yourself to be our enemy, let it be as you think. Myself am Bhima and shall do towards you what should be done towards you what should be done towards a foe."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यत् कुन्ती समतिक्रम्य कृष्णां केशेष्वधर्षयत्। दुःशासनस्तेऽनुमते तच्चास्माभिरुपेक्षतम्॥
English Translation: Then Bhima whirling his mace that resembled the mace of the Destroyer, let it go, O king, at Drona; but Drona had quickly jumped down from his car.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथोचितं स्वकं भागं लभेमहि परंतप। निवर्तय परद्रव्याद् बुद्धिं गृद्धां नरर्षभ॥
English Translation: The mace then crushed Drona's chariot with his horses, charioteer and standard; then Bhima grinded numerous warriors, like the tempest crushing mighty trees.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शान्तिरेवं भवेद् राजन् प्रीतिश्चैव परस्परम्। राज्यैकदेशमपि नः प्रयच्छ शममिच्छताम्॥
English Translation: But once more your sons surrounded that foremost of car warriors. Meanwhile that foremost of smiters, Drona mounting on another car.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अविस्थलं वृकस्थलं माकन्दी वारणावतम्। अवसानं भवत्वत्र किंचिदेकं च पञ्चमम्॥
English Translation: Stationed himself at the gate of the array ready to fight with Bhima. O mighty monarch, thereupon the puissant Bhimasena waxing worth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भ्रातृणां देहि पञ्चानां पञ्च ग्रामान् सुयोधन। शान्ति!ऽस्तु महाप्राज्ञ ज्ञातिभिः सह संजया॥
English Translation: Covered the car division that was then placed before him, with a downpour of arrows. Then those mighty car-warriors, your sons, thus wounded in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भ्राता भ्रातरमन्वेतु पिता पुत्रेण युज्यताम्। स्मयमानाः समायान्तु पाञ्चालाः कुरुभिः सह।॥
English Translation: Endued as they were with great strength, fought on with Bhima, inspired with the hope of victory. Then Dushasana excited with wrath, hurled a lance at Bhima. Desirous of slaying the son of Pandu, he then threw that lance at the former-lance that was made entirely of steed and that was exceedingly sharp. Then the mighty lance hurled by your son when it was coursing towards Bhima.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अक्षतान् कुरुपाञ्चालान् पश्येयमिति कामये। सर्वे सुमनसस्तात शाम्याम भरतर्षभ॥
English Translation: Was cut in twain by the latter and that appeared indeed very wonderful. Then the son of Pandu endued with great prowess, with three sharp arrows, slew the three warriors, Kundavedhin, Susena and Dirghanetra. Then again he slew the heroic Manduraka the bravest of your sons and the enhancer of the glory of the Kurus, then Bhima with another three arrows slew three other of your sons viz., Abhaya, Rudrakarman and Durvimochana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अलमेव शमायास्मि तथा युद्धाय संजय। धर्मार्थयोरलं चाहं मृदवे दारुणाय च॥
English Translation: Thus slaughtered by the puissant Bhima, your sons, O mighty monarch. Once more surrounded Bhima that foremost of smiters,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अकृतव्रण उवाच स वेदाध्ययने युक्तो जमदग्निर्महातपाः। तपस्तेपे ततो देवान् नियमाद् वशमानयत्॥
English Translation: Then they poured their arrows of Pandu's son of fearful deeds like clouds drenching the mountain breast with their contents at the end of summer. Like a mountain receiving a shower of stones, the son of Pandu then received that arrowy shower and that slayer of foes was none the less worse for it. Then the son of Kunti, as if smiling, dispatched with his arrows, Vinda and Anuvinda together with Suvarman to the abode of death. Then, O foremost of the Bharatas, he pierced in battle, your heroic son Sudarsana, who fell down and died on the spot. Then in no time, the son of Pandu, casting his eyes on all directions, began to agitate that car-host with his (fierce) arrows. Then like a herd of deer, terrified at the loud clatter of ear-wheels.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स प्रसेनजितं राजन्नधिगम्य नराधिपम्। रेणुकां वरयामास स च तस्मै ददौ नृपः॥
English Translation: Your sons, O ruler of men, began to desert their ranks; and afflicted with the fear of Bhima, they fled with all the speed at their command.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रेणुकां त्वथ सम्प्राप्य भार्यां भार्गवनन्दनः। आश्रमस्थस्तया सार्धं तपस्तेपेऽनुकूलया॥
English Translation: The son of Kunti pursued that mighty army of your sons from behind and, O king, he began to pierce the Kaurava hosts right and left.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्याः कुमाराश्चत्वारो जज्ञिरे रामपञ्चमाः। सर्वेषामजघन्यस्तु राम आसीज्जघन्यजः॥
English Translation: O mighty monarch, your soldiers then thus slaughtered by Bhima, shunning him began to fly away, urging their excellent steeds to the top of their speed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: फलाहारेषु सर्वेषु गतेष्वथ सुतेषु वै। रेणुका स्नातुमगमत् कदाचिन्नियतव्रता॥
English Translation: Vanquishing them in battle, the highly puissant Bhimasena that son of Pandu, sent up a loud war-cry and began to strike his palms against his arms.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सा तु चित्ररथं नाम मार्तिकावतकं नृपम्। ददर्श रेणुका राजन्नागच्छन्ती यदृच्छया।॥ क्रीडन्तं सलिले दृष्ट्वा सभार्यं पद्ममालिनम्। ऋद्धिमन्तं ततस्तस्य स्पृहयामास रेणुका॥
English Translation: The mighty Bhima then having caused that great slapping sound and there by striking terror into the host of the enemy and slaying many best warriors and passing through that division, hied towards of division of Drona.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यभिचाराच्च तस्मात् सा क्लिन्नाम्भसि विचेतना। प्रविवेशाश्रमं त्रस्ता तां वै भर्तान्वबुध्यत॥
English Translation: This Being is not the god of the fire, he is not an Asura. Nor is he a Naga. he is a Brahmana who has attained to heaven on account of his having been crowned with success in the observance of the vow called Unccha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तां दृष्ट्वा च्युतां धैर्याद् ब्राह्मया लक्ष्म्या विवर्जिताम्। धिकछब्देन महातेजा गर्हयामास वीर्यवान्॥
English Translation: This person had lived upon fruit and roots and upon the fallen leaves of trees. He had sometimes lived upon water, and sometimes upon air alone, passing his devas with concentrated soul.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो ज्येष्ठो जामदग्न्यो रुमण्वान् नाम नामतः। आजगाम सुषेणश्च वसुर्विश्वावसुस्तथा॥
English Translation: The god Mahadeva had been propitiated by him with constant recitation of the Samhitas. he had tried to perform those deeds which lead to heaven. Through the merits of those acts he had now attained to heaven.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तानानुपूर्व्याद् भगवान् वधे मातुरचोदयत्। न च ते जातसंस्नेहाः किंचिदूचुर्विचेतसः॥
English Translation: Without riches and without desire of any king he had observed the vow called Unccha with regard to his food. This learned Brahmana, ye Nagas, had been devoted to the good of all creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः शशाप तान् क्रोधात् ते शप्ताश्चेतना जहुः। मृगपक्षिसधर्माणः क्षिप्रमासञ्जडोपमाः॥
English Translation: Neither gods, nor Gandharvas, nor Asuras, nor Nagas, can be considered as superior to those creatures who attain to this excellent end of coming into the solar disc. Even such, 0 twice-born one, was the wonderful incident that I saw on that occasion.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो रामोऽभ्ययात् पश्चादाश्रमं परवीरहा। तमुवाच महाबाहुर्जमदग्निर्महातपाः॥
English Translation: That Brahmana, who was crowned with success by the observance of the Unccha vow and who thus obtained an end that persons crowned with ascetic success gain. to this day, Otwice-born one, goes round the Earth, staying in the disc of the Sun. crowned with ascetic success gain. to this day, Otwice-born one, goes round the Earth, staying in the disc of the Sun.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जहीमां मातरं पापां मा च पुत्र व्यथां कृथाः। तत आदाय परशुं रामो मातुः शिरोऽहरत्॥
English Translation: Arjuna said You should explain Brahma to me, that which is the highest object of knowledge. Through your favour, my mind is delighted with these subtle disquisition's.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्तस्य महाराज जमदग्नेर्महात्मनः। कोपोऽभ्यगच्छत् सहसा प्रसन्नश्चाब्रवीदिदम्॥
English Translation: Vasudeva said Regarding it is recited the old discourse between a preceptor and his disciple on the subject of Brahma.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ममेदं वचनात् तात कृतं ते कर्म दुष्करम्। वृणीष्व कामान्धर्मज्ञ यावतो वाञ्छसे हृदा॥ स वव्रे मातुरुत्थानमस्मृतिं च वधस्य वै। पापेन तेन चास्पर्श भ्रातृणां प्रकृति तथा॥ अप्रतिद्वन्द्वतां युद्धे दीर्घमायुश्च भारत। ददौ च सर्वान् कामांस्ताञ्जमदग्निर्महातपाः॥
English Translation: Once on a time, O destroyer of enemics, an intelligent disciple questioned certain Brahmana of rigid vows who was preceptor, as a he was scated, saying-What, indeed, is the highest good?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कदाचित् तु तथैवास्य विनिष्क्रान्ताः सुताः प्रभो। अथानूपपतिर्वीरः कार्तवीर्योऽभ्यवर्तत॥
English Translation: Desirous of acquiring that which forms the highest good, I throw myself at your fect, O holy one! O learned Brahmana, I solicit you, bending my head, to explain to me what I ask.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमाश्रमपदं प्राप्तमृर्भार्या समार्चयत्। स युद्धमदसम्मत्तो नाभ्यनन्दत् तथार्चनम्॥ प्रमथ्य चाश्रमात् तस्माद्धोमधेनोस्तथा बलात्। जहार वत्सं क्रोशन्त्या बभञ्ज च महादुमान्॥
English Translation: To that disciple, O son of Pritha, who said So, the preceptor said, O twice-born one, I shall explain to you everything about which you may have any doubts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आगताय च रामाय तदाचष्ट पिता स्वयम्। गां च रोरुदतीं दृष्ट्वा कोपो रामं समाविशत्॥
English Translation: Thus addressed, O foremost one of Kuru's race, by his preceptor, that disciple who was greatly devoted to his preceptor, spoke as follows, with joined hands. Do you hear what he said, O you of great intelligence.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स मृत्युवशमापन्नं कार्तवीर्यमुपाद्रवत्। तस्याथ युधि विक्रम्य भार्गवः परवीरहा॥ चिच्छेद निशितैर्भल्लैर्वाहून् परिघसंनिभान्। सहस्रसम्मितान् राजन् प्रगृह्य रुचिरंधनुः॥
English Translation: Whence aim I? Whence are you? Explain that which is the highest truth. From what source have originated all creatures mobile and immobile?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभिभूतः स रामेण संयुक्तः कालधर्मणा। अर्जुनस्याथ दायादा रामेण कृतमन्यवः॥
English Translation: By what do creatures live? What is the limit of their life? What is truth? What is penance, O learned Brahmana? What are called qualities by the good?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आश्रमस्थं विना रामं जगदग्निमुपाद्रवन्। ते तं जघ्नुर्महावीर्यमयुध्यन्तं तपस्विनम्॥
English Translation: What paths are to be called auspicious? What is happiness? What is sin? O holy one, O you of excellent vows, you should answer these questions of mine, O learned Rishi, correctly, truly, and accurately. Who else is there in this world than you who is capable of answering these questions?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: असकृद् रामरामेति विक्रोशन्तमनाथवत्। कार्तवीर्यस्य पुत्रास्तु जमदग्निं युधिष्ठिर।॥ पीडयित्वा शरैर्जग्मुर्यथागतमरिदमाः। अपक्रान्तेषु वै तेषु जमदग्नौ तथा गते॥ समित्पाणिरुपागच्छदाश्रमं भृगुनन्दनः। स दृष्ट्वा पितरं वीरस्तथा मृत्युवशं गतम्। अनर्हन्तं तथाभूतं विललाप सुदुःखितः॥
English Translation: Do you answer them, o foremost of all persons knowing duties! My curiosity is great. you are celebrated in all the worlds as one well-skilled in the duties about liberation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच एवमुक्त्वा युधां श्रेष्ठः सर्वयादवनन्दनः। सर्वायुधवरोपेतमारुरोह रथोत्तमम्॥
English Translation: There is none else save you who can remove all kinds of doubts. Afraid of worldly life, we have become desirous of acquiring Liberation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युक्तं परमकाम्बोजैस्तुरगैर्हेममालिभिः। आदित्योदयवर्णस्य धुरं रथवरस्य तु॥
English Translation: Vasudeva said To that disciple who had humbly sought his instruction and put the questions duly. Who was devoted to his preceptor and endued with tranquillity, and who always acted in a manner that was agreeable (to his instructor), who lived so constantly by the side of his instructor as to have almost become his shadow, who was selfcontrolled and who had the life of a Yati and a Brahmacharin, O son of Pritha, that preceptor gifted with intelligence and observant of vows, duly explained all the questions, O foremost of Kuru's race, O chastiser of all enemies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दक्षिणामवहच्छब्यः सुग्रीवः सव्यतोऽभवत्। पाणिवाहौ तु तस्यास्तां मेघपुष्पबलाहकौ॥
English Translation: All this was declared by Brahman himself. Applauded and practised by the foreinost of Rishis, and depending on Vedic knowledge it involves a consideration of what forms the real entity.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विश्वकर्मकृता दिव्या रत्नधातुविभूषिता। उच्छ्रितेव रथे माया ध्वजयष्टिरदृश्यत॥
English Translation: We regard knowledge to be that highest object, and renunciation as the best penance. He who, certainly, knows the true object of knowledge which is incapable of being modified by circumstances, viz., the soul living in all creatures, succeeds in going wherever he likes and comes to be considered as the highest. That learned man who sees the residence of all things in one place and their severance as well, and who sees unity in diversity, succeeds in freeing himself from misery. He who does not long for anything and does not cherish the idea of mineness abut any thing, comes to be considered, although living in this world, as being at one with Brahina. He who knows the truth about the qualities of Nature, acquainted with the creation of all existent objects, divested of egoism, and without pride, succeeds, forsooth, in freeing himself. Understanding properly that great tree which has the unmanifest for its seed-sprout and the understanding for its trunk, and high consciousness of self for its branches, and the senses for the cells whence its twigs issue and the (five) great elements for its flower-buds, and the gross elements for its smaller boughs, which has leaves, which always puts forth flowers, and upon which all existent objects depend, whose seeds is Brahma, and which is eternal, and cutting all subjects with the sharp sword of knowledge, one acquires immortality and renounces birth and death.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैनतेयः स्थितस्तस्यां प्रभामण्डलरश्मिवान्। तस्य सत्यवतः केतुर्भुजगारिरदृश्यत॥
English Translation: The conclusions about the past, present, and future, etc., and religion, pleasure, and profit, which are all well known to Siddhas, which belong to remote ages, and which are, indeed, eternal, I shall declare to you. O you of great wisdom! These form what is called Good, Wise Men, understanding them in this world, acquire success.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथारोहद्धृषीकेशः केतुः सर्वधनुष्मताम्। अर्जुनः सत्यकर्मा च कुरुराजो युधिष्ठिरः॥
English Translation: Formerly, the Rishis Brihaspati Bharadvaja, Gautama Bhargava, Vasishtha, Kashyapa, Vishvamitra and Atri, assembled together for the purpose of asking one another. They thus assembled together after having travelled over all paths and after they had got tired with the deeds each of them had done.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अशोभेतां महात्मानौ दाशार्हमभितः स्थितौ। रथस्थं शार्ङ्गधन्वानमश्विनाविव वासवम्॥
English Translation: Those twice-born persons, headed by the sage son of Angirasa, proceeded to the region of the Grandfather. There they saw Brahman perfectly purged of all sin.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तावुपारोप्य दाशार्हः स्यन्दनं लोकपूजितम्। प्रतोदेन जवोपेतान् परमाश्चानचोदयत्॥
English Translation: Bowing their heads to that great one who was seated at their ease, the great Rishis, gifted with humility, asked him this grave question about the highest good.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते हयाः सहसोत्पेतुर्गृहीत्वा स्यन्दनोत्तमम्। आस्थितं पाण्डवेयाभ्यां यदूनामृषभेण च॥
English Translation: How should a good man act? How would one be freed from sin? What paths are: auspicious for us? What is truth, and what is sin?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वहतां शार्ङ्गधन्वानमश्वानां शीघ्रगामिनाम्। प्रादुरासीन्महाशब्दः पक्षिणां पततामिव॥
English Translation: By what action are the two paths, northern and southern, obtained? What is destruction? What, Liberation? What is birth and what death of all existent objects?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते समाईनरव्याघ्राः क्षणेन भरतर्षभ। भीमसेनं महेष्वासं समनुद्रुत्य वेगिताः॥
English Translation: I shall tell you. O disciple, what the Grandfather, thus addressed, said to them, according to the scriptures. Do you listen.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क्रोधदीप्तं तु कौन्तेयं द्विषदर्थे समुद्यतम्। नाशक्नुवन् वारयितुं समेत्यापि महारथाः॥
English Translation: It is from Truth that all creatures, mobile and immobile, have been born. They live by penance (or action). Understand this, O you of excellent vows! On account of their own actions they live, transcending their own origin.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तेषां प्रेक्षतामेव श्रीमतां दृढधन्विनाम्। ययौ भागीरथीतीरं हरिभि शवेगितैः॥
English Translation: For Truth when united with qualities becomes always possessed of five marks. Brahman is Truth. Penance is truth. Prajapati is truth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यत्र स्म श्रूयते द्रौणिः पुत्रहन्ता महात्मनाम्। स ददर्श महात्मानमुदकान्ते यशस्विनम्॥
English Translation: It is from Truth that all creatures have originated. Truth is the universe of being. It is for this that Brahmanas who are always devoted to Yoga, who have got over anger and sorrow, and who always consider Religion as the causeway, take refuge in Truth. I shall now speak of those Brahmanas who are controlled by one another and endued with knowledge, of the orders, and of those who belong to the four modes of life.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृष्णद्वैपायनं व्यासमासीनमृषिभिः सह। तं चैव क्रूरकर्माणं घृताक्तं कुशचीरिणम्॥ रजसा ध्वस्तमासीनं ददर्श द्रौणिमन्तिके।
English Translation: The wise say that Rcligion or duty is one, having four quarters. You twice born ones, I shall speak to you now of that path which is auspicious and yields good.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमभ्यधावत् कौन्तेयः प्रगृह्य सशरं धनुः॥ भीमसेनो महाबाहुस्तिष्ठ निष्ठेति चाब्रवीत्।
English Translation: That path has constantly been trod over by wise men in order to acquirc an identity with Brahmana. I shall speak now of that path which is the highest and which is highly difficult of being understood.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स दृष्ट्वा भीमधन्वानं प्रगृहीतशरासनम्॥ भ्रातरौ पृष्ठतश्चास्य जनार्दनरथे स्थितौ। व्यथितात्माभवद् द्रौणिः प्राप्तं चेदममन्यत॥ स तद् दिव्यमदीनात्मा परमास्त्रमचिन्तयत्।
English Translation: Do you understand, in all its fullness, you highly blessed ones, what is the highest set. The first step has been said to be the mode of life that belongs to Brahmacharins.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जग्राह च स चैषीकां द्रौणिः सव्येन पाणिना॥ स तामापदमासाद्य दिव्यमस्त्रमुदैरयत्।
English Translation: The second step is domesticity. After this is the residence in the forcst. After that it should be known is the highest step, viz., that belongs to Adhyatma.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अमृष्यमाणस्ताञ्छूरान् दिव्यायुधवरान् स्थितान्॥ अपाण्डवायेति रुषा व्यसृजद् दारुणं वचः।
English Translation: Light, ether, sun, wind, Indra, and Prajapati, one sees these as long as one does not acquire Adhyatma.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्युक्त्वा राजशार्दूल द्रोणपुत्रः प्रतापवान्॥ सर्वलोकप्रमोहार्थं तदस्त्रं प्रमुमोच ह।
English Translation: I shall declare the means. Do you first understand them. The forest mode of life that is followed by ascetics living in the forest and subsisting upon fruits and roots and air is laid down for the three twice-born classes. The domestic mode of life is ordained for all the orders.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्तस्यामिषीकायां पावकः समजायत। प्रधक्ष्यन्निव लोकांस्त्रीन् कालान्तकयमोपमः॥
English Translation: The wise say that Religion or duty has Faith for its characteristic mark. Thus have I declared to you the paths leading to the celestials. They are adopted by the good and wise by their a 'ts. Those paihs are the causeways of picty.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच स नं दृष्ट्वा तथाभूतं राजानं घोरदर्शनम्। दीर्घश्मश्रुधरं नृणां शोणितेन समुक्षितम्॥
English Translation: That persons of rigid vows who follows any one of these modes separately, always succeeds in time to understand the production and destruction of all creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चकार न व्यथां विप्रो राजा त्वेनमथाब्रवीत्। प्रत्युत्थाय महातेजा भयकर्ता यमोपमः॥ दिष्ट्या त्वमसि कल्याण षष्ठे काले ममान्तिकम्। भक्ष्यं मृगयमाणस्य सम्प्राप्तो द्विजसत्तम॥
English Translation: I shall now declarc, accurately and with reasons, the elements which live in parts in all objects.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजन् गुर्वर्थिनं विद्धि चरन्तं मामिहागतम्। न च गुर्वर्थमुद्युक्तं हिंस्यमाहुर्मनीषिणः॥
English Translation: The great soul, the uninanifest, egoisin, the eleven organs (of knowledge and action), the five great elements, the characteristics of the five elements, these form the eternal creation. The number of clements has been said to be twenty-four and one (more).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: षष्ठे काले ममाहारो विहितो द्विजसत्तम। न शक्यस्त्वं समुत्स्रष्टुं क्षुधितेन मयाद्य वै॥
English Translation: That wise person who understands the production and destruction of all these elements, that man among all creatures, never meets with delusion.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमस्तु महाराज समयः क्रियतां त मे। गुर्वर्थमभिनिवर्त्य पुनरेष्यामि ने वशम्॥
English Translation: Hc who understands the elements accurately, all the qualities, all the celestials, succeeds in purifying himself of all sin. Freed from all fetters, such a man succeeds in enjoying all regions of spotless purity.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संश्रुतश्च मया योऽर्थो गुरवे राजसत्तम। त्वदधीनः स राजेन्द्र तं त्वां भिक्षे नरेश्वर॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said Riving through that army Karna encountered the pious king surrounded by thousands of cars, elephants, horses and footsoldiers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ददासि विप्रमुख्येभ्यस्त्वं हि रत्नानि नित्यदा। दाता च त्वं नरव्याघ्र पात्रभूतः क्षिताविह। पात्रं प्रतिग्रहे चापि विद्धि मां नृपसत्तम॥
English Translation: Sundering with hundreds of dreadful shafts the thousands of arms discharged at him by his enemies Karna fearlessly went through the army.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उपाहृत्य गुरारर्थं त्वदायत्तमरिंदम। समयेनेह राजेन्द्र पुनरेष्यामि ते वशम्॥ सत्यं ते प्रतिजानामि नात्र मिथ्या कथंचन। अनृतं नोक्तपूर्वं मे स्वैरेष्वपि कुतोऽन्यथा।॥
English Translation: The charioteer's son sundered the heads, the arms and the things of his enemies who, deprived of life, fell down on earth. Others, finding their division dispersed, took to their heels.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सौदास उवाच यदि मत्तस्तवायत्तो गुर्वथैः कृत एव सः। यदि चास्मि प्रतिग्राह्यः साम्प्रतं तद् वदस्व मे॥१११!
English Translation: The Dravida, the Andhaka and the Nishada infantry, excited by Satyaki once more rushed upon Karna with a view to kill him in that battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उत्तङ्क उवाच प्रतिग्राह्यो मतो मे त्वं सदैव पुरुषर्षभ। सोऽहं त्वामनुसम्प्राप्तो भिक्षितुं मणिकुण्डले॥
English Translation: Shorn of their arms and head-dresses and killed by Karna with his arrows they fell down all at once on earth like a forest of Sala trees cut down.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पत्न्यास्ते मम विप्रर्षे उचिते मणिकुण्डले। वरयार्थं त्वमन्यं वै तं ते दास्यामि सुव्रत॥
English Translation: Deprived of life and filling the heaven and earth with their fame, hundreds, thousands and ten thousands of warriors fell down with their bodies on earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अलं ते व्यपदेशेन प्रमाणा यदि ते वयम्। प्रयच्छ कुण्डले मह्यं सत्यवाग् भव पार्थिव॥
English Translation: The Pandus and Panchalas obstructed Karna, the son of Vikartana who proceeded in anger to battle like the destroyer himself even as people seek to obstruct a disease with incantations and drugs.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्युक्तस्त्वब्रवीद् राजा तमुत्तकं पुनर्वचः। गच्छ मद्वचनाद् देवीं ब्रूहि देहीति सत्तम॥ सैवमुक्ता त्वया नूनं मद्वाक्येन शुचिव्रता। प्रदास्यति द्विजश्रेष्ठ कुण्डले ते न संशयः॥
English Translation: Grinding all those combatants Karna once more rushed upon Yudhishthira like irresistible disease unchecked by incantations, drugs and rites.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उत्तङ्क उवाच क्व पत्नी भवतः शक्या मया द्रष्टुं नरेश्वर। स्वयं वापि भवान् पत्नी किमर्थं नोपसर्पति॥
English Translation: Then obstructed by Pandus, Panchalas and Kekayas who were all desirous of rescuing the king he could not overcome them as Death cannot those conversant with Brahman.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सौदास उवाच तां द्रक्ष्यति भवानद्य कस्मिंश्चिद् वननिर्झरे। षष्ठे काले न हि मया सा शक्या द्रष्टुमद्य वै॥
English Translation: Thereupon beholding Karna, the slayer of hostile heroes, obstructed at a distance, an Yudhishthira, with eyes reddened with anger, said-
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच उत्तङ्कस्तु तथोक्तः स जगाम भरतर्षभ। मदयन्तीं च दृष्ट्वा स ज्ञापयत् स्वप्रयोजनम्॥
English Translation: O Karna, O son of a charioteer, O you of vain seeing, hear my words, You always challenge in fight Phalguna of quick speed. Abiding by the counsel of the son of Dhritarashtra you always obstruct us.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सौदासवचनं श्रुत्वा ततः सा पृथुलोचना। प्रत्युवाच महाबुद्धिमुत्तकं जनमेजय॥
English Translation: You bring all your strength, energy and hatred to bear upon the Pandus. Do you display today all your great manliness. I will today give battle and destroy your desire for fight.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमेतद् वद ब्रह्मन् नानृतं वदसेऽनघ। अभिज्ञानं तु किंचित् त्वं समानयितुपर्हसि॥
English Translation: Having said this to Karna, the monarch, the son of Pandu, pierced him with ten arrows, made of iron and furnished with golden wings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इमे हि दिव्ये मणिकुण्डले मे देवाश्च यक्षाश्च महर्षयश्च। तैस्तैरुपायैरमहर्तुकामा श्छिद्रेषु नित्यं परितर्कयन्ति॥
English Translation: Then that Suta's son, the subduer of foes and a great bowman, pierced him in return as if smiling, O Bharata, with ten arrows furnished with heads like the calf's tooth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निक्षिप्तमेतद् भुवि पन्नगास्तु रत्नं समासाद्य परामशेयुः। यक्षास्तेथोच्छिष्टधृतं सुराश्च निद्रावशाद् वा परिधर्षयेयुः॥
English Translation: Thus placed by Suta's son in contempt the mighty-armed heroes was worked up with anger like fire with oblation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: छिद्रेष्वेतेष्विमे नित्यं ह्वियेते द्विजसत्तम। देवराक्षसनागानामप्रमत्तेन धार्यते॥
English Translation: The body of Yudhishthira surrounded by the flames of anger looked as if it was second Samvartaka fire intended to burn the whole universe, in course of the great devastation (Pralaya).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्यन्देते हि दिवा रुक्मं रात्रौ च द्विजसत्तम। नक्तं नक्षत्रताराणां प्रभामाक्षिप्य वर्ततः॥
English Translation: Then stretching his huge bow made of gold he set sharp arrows capable of breaking down the mountains.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एते ह्यमुच्य भगवन् क्षुत्पिपासाभयं कुतः। विषाग्निश्वापदेभ्यश्च भयं जातु न विद्यते॥
English Translation: With a view to kill the Suta's son he drew his bow to its fullest stretch and discharged that fatal shaft as the rod of the destroyer himself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ह्रस्वेन चैते आमुक्ते भवतो ह्रस्वके तदा। अनुरूपेण चामुक्ते जायेते तत्प्रमाणके॥
English Translation: Discharged with great velocity and making a sound like that of a thunder bolt the arrow suddenly pierced the great car-warrior Karna on his left side.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवंविधे ममैते वै कुण्डले परमार्चित। त्रिषु लोकेषु विज्ञाते तदभिज्ञानमानय॥
English Translation: Greatly assailed by the violence of that spike the powerful Karna, with weaked limbs, swooned away on his car his bow dropping from his hand.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जनमेजय उवाच अत्यद्भुतमिदं ब्रह्मन् श्रुतवानस्मि तत्त्वतः। अभिषेकं कुमारस्य विस्तरेण यथाविधि॥
English Translation: He fell down unconscious in front of Shalya as if he was dead. King Yudhishthira did not attack again on Karna by keeping in mind the interest of Arjuna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यच्छ्रुत्वा पूतमात्मानं विजानामि तपोधन। प्रहृष्टानि च रोमाणि प्रसन्नं च मनो मम॥
English Translation: Seeing Karna in that state the huge army of Dhritarashtra's son exclaimed Oh! and alas! and the faces of all the warriors became pale.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभिषेकं कुमारस्य दैत्यानां च वधं तथा। श्रुत्वा मे परमा प्रीतिर्भूयः कौतूहलं हि मे॥
English Translation: O monarch, witnessing the power of their king the Pandava army sent up leonine roars and cries of joy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपां पतिः कथं ह्यस्मिन्नभिषिक्तः पुरा सुरैः। तन्मे ब्रूहि महाप्राज्ञ कुशलो ह्यसि सत्तम।॥
English Translation: Regaining his sense in no time the dreadful son of Radha made up his mind to kill Yudhishthira.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच शृणु राजन्निदं चित्रं पूर्वकल्पे यथातथम्। आदौ कृतयुगे राजन् वर्तमाने यथाविधि॥
English Translation: Drawing his dreadful bow made of gold, Vijaya, the valiant son of Suta, began to resist Pandu's son with his sharp arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वरुणं देवताः सर्वा यमेत्येदपथाब्रुवन्। यथास्मान् सुरराट्छक्रो भयेभ्यः पाति सर्वदा॥
English Translation: Then with two razor he killed in that battle Chandradeva and Dandadhara, the two Panchalas princes who guarded the wheels of the high-souled (Pandu king).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथा त्वमपि सर्वासां सरितां वै पतिर्भव। वासश्च ते सदा देव सागरे मकरालये॥
English Translation: Each of those heroes stood by Yudhishthira shining like the constellation Punarvasu by the side of the moon.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: समुद्रोऽयं तव वशे भविष्यति नदीपतिः। सोमेन सार्धं च तव हानिवृद्धी भविष्यतः॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira again struck Karna with thirty arrows. He pierced Sushena and Satyasena each with three arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमस्त्विति तान् देवान् वरुणो वाक्यमब्रवीत्। समागम्य ततः सर्वे वरुणं सागरालयम्॥
English Translation: He pierced Shalya with ninty and struk Karna with seventy-three arrows. He also struck every one of Karna's body guards with three straight arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपां पतिं प्रचक्रुर्हि विधिदृष्टेन कर्मणा। अभिषिच्य ततो देवा वरुणं यादसां पतिम्॥
English Translation: Then laughing and shaking his bow the son of Adhiratha wounded the king's body with a Bhalla, then pierce him with sixty arrows and then sent up a loud war-cry.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जग्मुः स्वान्येव स्थानानि पूजयित्वा जलेश्वरम्। अभिषिक्तस्ततो देवैर्वरुणोऽपि महायशाः॥
English Translation: Then to rescue the king many leading Pandava warriors fell upon Karna in great anger and began to assail him with their arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सरितः सागरांश्चैव नदांश्चापि सरांसि च। पालयामास विधिना यथा देवाशतक्रतुः॥ ततस्तत्राप्युपस्पृश्य दत्त्वा च विविधं वसु। अग्नितीर्थं महाप्राज्ञो जगामाथ प्रलम्बहा॥ नष्टो न दृश्यते यत्र शमीगर्भे हुताशनः।
English Translation: Satyaki, Chekitana, Yuyutshu, Shikhandin, the sons of Draupadi, the Prabhadrakas, the twins, Bhimasena, Shishupala, the Karushas, the Matsys, the Kaikeyas the Kashis and the Kosalas, all those valiant and highly active warriors assailed Vasushena.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: लोकालोकविनाशे च प्रादुर्भूते तदानघ॥ उपतस्थुः सुरा यत्र सर्वलोकपितामहम्।
English Translation: The Panchala prince Janamejaya then struck Karna with many arrows. Encircling Karna with a view to kill him they all rushed upon him with various arrows, such as boareared, Narachas, Nalika, Nishat, calf-toothed, Vipatha, razor shaped, with diverse other weapons chariots horses, elephants.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अग्निः प्रनष्टो भगवान् कारणं च न विद्महे॥ सर्वभूतक्षयो राजन् सम्पादय विभोऽनलम्।
English Translation: Thus assailed on all sides by the leading Pandava warriors Karna invoked the assistance of the Brahma weapon and filled all the quarters with his arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जनमेजय उवाच किमर्थं भगवानग्निः प्रनष्टो लोकभावनः॥ विज्ञातश्च कथं देवैस्तन्ममाचक्ष्व तत्त्वतः।
English Translation: Like burning fire having arrows for its scorching flame Karna fought on consuming that forest of Pandava troops.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच भृगोः शापाद् भृशं भीतो जातवेदाः प्रतापवान्॥ शमीगर्भमथासाद्य ननाश भगवांस्ततः।
English Translation: Aiming some powerful weapons and laughing the noble Karna, the great bowman, sundered the bow of that best of men, Yudhishthira.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रनष्टे तु सदा वह्नौ देवाः सर्वे सवासवाः॥ अन्वैषन्त तदा नष्टं ज्वलनं भृशदुःखिताः।
English Translation: Thereupon aiming ninety straight arrows within the twinkling of an eye Karna cut-off, with those sharp arrows, the armour of his antagonist.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽग्नितीर्थमासाद्य शमीगर्भस्थमेव हि॥ ददृशुर्व्वलनं तत्र वसमानं यथाविधि।
English Translation: Made of gold and set with jewels that armour looked beautiful as if it fell down like the cloud driven by the wind and smitten by the rays of the sun.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: देवाः सर्वे नरव्याघ्र बृहस्पतिपुरोगमाः॥ ज्वलनं तं समासाद्य प्रीताऽभूवन् सवासवाः।
English Translation: The armour, adorned with jewels fallen off the body of that foremost of men, appeared like the sky in the night bespangled with stars. Having his armour sundered with those arrows the son of Pritha covered with blood.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुनर्यथागतं जग्मुः सर्वभक्षश्च सोऽभवत्॥ भृगोः शापान्महाभाग यदुक्तं ब्रह्मवादिना।
English Translation: He hurled in anger at the son of Adhiratha a dart made of iron. He too cut of that (dart) shining in the sky with seven arrows; sundered with shafts by that great bowman it reached the earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्राप्याप्लुत्य मतिमान् ब्रह्मयोनिं जगाम ह॥ ससर्ज भगवान् यत्र सर्वलोकपितामहः।
English Translation: Then striking Karna with four lances on his two arms, forehead and chest Yudhishthira again and again sent up loud shouts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्राप्लुत्य ततो ब्रह्मा सह देवैः प्रभुः पुरा॥ ससर्ज तीर्थानि तथा देवतानां यथाविधि।
English Translation: Then blood gushed out from Karna wounds. Then filled with anger breathing like a snake he cut-off his enemy's standard and struck Pandava with three Bhallas. He also cutoff his two quivers and car into pieces.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्र स्नात्वा च दत्वा च वसूनि विविधानि च।॥ कौबेरं प्रययौ तीर्थं तत्र तप्त्वा महत्तपः। धनाधिपत्यं सम्प्राप्तो राजन्नैलबिल प्रभुः॥
English Translation: Riding on the car drawn by horses white as teeth and having black hairs which used to bear Partha the king fled away from the battle-field.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्रस्थमेव तं राजन् धनानि निधयस्तथा। उपतस्थुर्नरश्रेष्ठ तत् तीर्थं लागली बलः॥ गत्वा दत्वा च विधिवद् ब्राह्मणेभ्यो धनं ददौ।
English Translation: Unable to stand before Karna, thus did the son of Pritha, with his charioteer Parshin slain, cheerlessly fly away.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ददृशे तत्र तत् स्थानं कौबेरे काननोत्तमे॥ पुरा यत्र तपस्तप्तं विपुलं सुमहात्मना। यक्षराज्ञा कुबेरेण वरा लब्धाश्च पुष्कलाः॥
English Translation: It seemed at the time when Karna, the son of Radha was chasing Yudhishthira as if he is intended to catch him forcibly so as to touch him on should with his fair colour hand having lucky marks as thunderbolt, umbrella, goad, fish, flag, tortoise and lotus etc. in order to attain purity. In the meantime, a memory of commitment he had made once before Kunti, chained his racing feet.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धनादिपत्यं सख्यं च रुद्रेणामिततेजसा। सुरत्वं लोकपालत्वं पुत्रं च नलकूबरम्॥
English Translation: King Shalya in the meantime made Karna alert by saying-"O Karna! Don't' touch king Yudhishthira at all nonetheless you should burn in the fire erupted due to anger within him. You touch may cause of death for you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यत्र लेभे महाबाहो धनाधिपतिरञ्जसा! अभिषिक्तश्च तत्रैव समागम्य मरुद्गणैः॥
English Translation: O king, said, smiling and censuring the son of Pandu-"In what family are you born? You are to observe the duties of a Kshatriya. Why do you leave the battle-field in haste, to save your life? Methinks, you do not know the duties of a Kshatriya.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वाहनं चास्य तद् दत्तं हंसयुक्तं मनोजवम्। विमानं पुष्पकं दिव्यं नैऋतैश्चर्यमेव च।॥ तत्राप्लुत्य बलो राजन् दत्त्वा दायांश्च पुष्कलान्।
English Translation: O son of Kunti, Endued with Brahma force, you are better fitted for the study of the Vedas and sacrificial rites.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जगाम त्वरितो रामस्तीर्थं श्वेतानुलेपनः॥ निषेवितं सर्वसत्त्वैर्नाम्ना बदरपाचनम्। नानर्तुकवनोपेतं सदापुष्पफलं शुभम्॥
English Translation: Do not, O son of Kunti, fight again. Do not approach heroes and use harsh words towards them and do not go to great battles.”
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नारद उवाच ततो देवर्षयः सर्वे सिद्धाश्च परमर्षयः। जग्मुस्तदा परामार्ति दृष्ट्वा तत् कदनं महत्॥
English Translation: This and another pains you would have to bear for inflicting harsh words upon the people like me. Hence, O son of Kunti, either go back to your home or march only in company of Sri Krishna and Arjuna. "O king! Karna will not slaughter you in battle-field."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेऽभिजग्मुर्जितक्रोधा जितात्मानो जितेन्द्रियाः। पितामहस्य भवनं जगतः कृपया तदा॥
English Translation: Having said this and left off the son of Pritha the highly powerful Karna began to slay Pandava like the holder of thunder-bolt, the army of Asuras.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो ददृशुरासीनं सह देवैः पितामहम्। सिद्धैर्ब्रह्मर्षिभिश्चैव समन्तात् परिवारितम्॥
English Translation: Then the king Yudhishthira, O king, took to his heels quickly in great shame. Seeing the king take to his heels, the Chedis, the Pandavas, the Panchalas and the powerful carwarrior Satyaki, the heroic sons of Draupadi and the twin sons of Madri followed him of eternal glory.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्र देवो महादेवस्तत्राग्निर्वायुना सह। चन्द्रादित्यौ च शक्रश्च पारमेष्ठ्यास्तथर्षयः॥ वैखानसा बालखिल्या वानप्रस्था मरीचिपाः। अजाश्चैवाविमूढाश्च तेजोग स्तपस्विनः॥ ऋषयः सर्व एवैते पितामहमुपागमन्। ततोऽभिगम्य ते दीनाः सर्व एव महर्षयः॥ सुन्दोपसुन्दयोः कर्म सर्वमेव शशंसिरे। यथा हृतं यथा चैव कृतं येन क्रमेण च॥ न्यवेदयंस्ततः सर्वमखिलेन पितामहे। ततो देवगणाः सर्वे ते चैव परमर्षयः॥ तमेवार्थं पुरस्कृत्य पितामहमचोदयन्। ततः पितामहः श्रुत्वा सर्वेषां तद् वचस्तदा॥ मुहूर्तमिव संचिन्त्य कर्तव्यस्य च निश्चयम्। तयोर्वधं समुद्दिश्य विश्वकर्माणमाह्वयत्॥
English Translation: Thereupon beholding the retreat of the army of Yudhishthira the heroes pursued them in great delight.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दृष्ट्वा च विश्वकर्माणं व्यादिदेश पितामहः। सृज्यतां प्रार्थनीयैका प्रमदेति महातपाः॥
English Translation: Then there arose the leonine shout of the sons of Dhritarashtra accompanied by the sound of bugles, conch, mridangas and the twang of bows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पितामहं नमस्कृत्य तद्वाक्यमभिनन्द्य च। निर्ममे योषितं दिव्यां चिन्तयित्वा पुनः पुनः॥
English Translation: O king, his horses become tired so getting upon quickly the car of Srutakirti, Yudhishthira began to witness the prowess of Karna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्रिषु लोकेषु यत् किंचिद् भूतं स्थावरजङ्गम्। समानयद् दर्शनीयं तत् तदत्र स विश्वजित्॥
English Translation: Then beholding his own army slain the pious king Yudhishthira said to his own warriors-"Kill them; why do you sit idle?"
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कोटिशश्चैव रत्नानि तस्या गात्रे न्यवेशयत्। तां रत्नसंघातमयीमसृजद् देवरूपिणीम्॥
English Translation: Thereupon obtaining the command of the king all the mighty car-warriors of the Pandavas headed by Bhimasena rushed upon your sons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सा प्रयत्नेन महता निर्मिता विश्वकर्मणा। त्रिषु लोकेषु नारीणां रूपेणाप्रतिमाभवत्॥
English Translation: O Bharata, then there arose a great tumult of the warriors, chariots, elephants, horses, infantry and weapons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न तस्याः सूक्ष्ममप्यस्ति यद् गात्रे रूपसम्पदा। नियुक्ता यत्र वा दृष्टिर्न सज्जति निरीक्षताम्॥
English Translation: “Rise, strike, face the foe" uttering those words the warriors killed one another in that great battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सा विग्रहवतीव श्रीः कामरूपा वपुष्मती। जहार सर्वभूतानां चढूंषि च मनांसि च॥
English Translation: On account of the showers of arrows discharged by them a shadow as that of clouds seemed to spread over the field abounding in the best of men killing those weaker then they.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तिलं तिलं समानीय रत्नानां यद् विनिर्मित।। तिलोत्तमेति तत् तस्या नाम चक्रे पितामहः॥
English Translation: Deprived of their standards, flags, umbrellas, horses, drivers, weapons, armas and other limbs, the kings, weakened, fell down on earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्रह्माणं सा नमस्कृत्य प्राञ्जलिर्वाक्यमब्रवीत्। किं कार्यं मयि भूतेश येनास्म्योह निर्मिता॥
English Translation: Resembling mountain summits, the best of elephants with their drivers slain, fell down like mountains clapped by thunderbolt.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पितामह उवाच गच्छ सुन्दोपसुन्दाभ्यामसुराभ्यां तिलोत्तमे। प्रार्थनीयेन रूपेण कुरु भद्रे प्रलोभनम्॥
English Translation: With their armours and other equipments torn and shattered thousands of horses and warriors fell down.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वत्कृते दर्शनादेव रूपसम्पत्कृतेन वै। विरोधः : स्याद् यथा ताभ्यामन्योन्येन तथा कुरु॥
English Translation: There fell in battle thousands of foot soldiers with their limbs wounded by weapons and deprived by hostile combatants of their elephants, horses and cars.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नारद उवाच सा तथेति प्रतिज्ञाय नमस्कृत्य पितामहम्। चकार मण्डलं तत्र विबुधानां प्रदक्षिणम्॥
English Translation: The earth was covered all over with heads of heroes, dreadful in battle, with expansive coppery eyes and with faces resembling the lotus or the moon. People heard on the earth as well as in the sky noise proceeding, from the singing and music of the band of Apsaras going in celestial cars.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्राङ्मुखो भगवानास्ते दक्षिणेन महेश्वरः। देवाश्चैवोत्तरेणासन् सर्वतस्त्वृषयोऽभवन्॥
English Translation: Having placed on their cars thousands of heroes slain in battle the Apsara went on.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कुर्वत्या तु तदा तत्र मण्डलं तत् प्रदक्षिणम्। इन्द्रः स्थाणुश्च भगवान् धैर्येण प्रत्यवस्थितौ॥
English Translation: Beholding that wonderful spectacle the heroes, desirous of attaining to heaven, quickly and delightedly killed one another.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्रष्टुकामस्य चात्यर्थं गतया पार्श्वतस्तया। अन्यदञ्चितपद्माक्षं दक्षिणं निःसृतं मुखम्॥
English Translation: In that battle the car-warriors fought wondrously with car-warriors, the infantry with infantry, the elephants with elephants and horses with horses.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पृष्ठतः परिवर्तन्त्या पश्चिमं निःसृतं सुखम्। गतया चोत्तरं पार्श्वमुत्तरं निःसृतं मुखम्॥ महेन्द्रस्यापि नेत्राणां पृष्ठतः पार्श्वतोऽग्रतः। रक्तान्तानां विशालानां सहस्रं सर्वतोऽभवत्॥
English Translation: When the battle, destructive of elephants, horses and men, thus raged on the field was enshrouded with dust raised by the troops; the enemies then killed enemies and friends killed friends.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं चतुर्मुखः स्थाणुर्महादेवोऽभवत् पुरा। तथा सहस्रनेत्रश्च बभूव बलसूदनः॥
English Translation: Then there took place a skirmish destructive of life and sins-the warriors dragging one another by their locks, biting one another with their teeth, tearing one another with their nails and striking one another with their clenched fists and fighting with one another with bare arms.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथा देवनिकायानां महर्षीणां च सर्वशः। मुखानि चाभ्यवर्तन्त येन याति तिलोत्तमा॥
English Translation: As that battle, destructive of elephants, horses and men, raged on fiercely a river of blood flew from the bodies of men, horses and elephants. That stream carried away many bodies of men, horses and elephants that fell there.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्या गात्रे निपतिता दृष्टिस्तेषां महात्मनाम्। सर्वेषामेव भूयिष्ठमृते देवं पितामहम्॥
English Translation: In that huge army abounding in men, horses and elephants, the river, formed by the blood of men, horses and elephants, became miry with flesh and that highly terrible river, striking terror into the timid, carried away the bodies of men, horses and elephants.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गच्छन्त्या तु तया सर्वे देवाश्च परमर्षयः कृतमित्येव तत् कार्य मेनिरे रूपसम्पदा॥
English Translation: Some, desirous of victory, crossed it. Some plunged into its depths and some rose above its surface.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तिलोत्तमायां तस्यां तु गतायां लोकभावनः। सर्वान् विसर्जयामास देवानृषिगणांश्च तान्॥
English Translation: Their limbs, weapons and robes became all besmeared with blood. O foremost of Bharatas, some bathed in it, some drank its liquid.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच राज्ञस्तु वचनं श्रुत्वा धृतराष्ट्रस्य संजयः। उपप्लव्यं ययौ द्रष्टुं पाण्डवानमितौजसः॥
English Translation: We saw the cars, horses, men, elephants, armours, ornaments, robes, coats of mail, earth, sky and heaven and all directions were all seen dyed in red colour.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तु राजानमासाद्य कुन्तीपुत्रं युधिष्ठिरम्। अभिवाद्य ततः पूर्वं सूतपुत्रोऽभ्यभाषत॥
English Translation: With the smell, the touch, the taste, the exceedingly redness of the blood and its gushing sound almost of the warriors became very cheerless.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रजातशत्रुमवदत् प्रतीतः। दिष्ट्या राजंस्त्वामरोगं प्रपश्ये सहायवन्तं च महेन्द्रकल्पम्॥
English Translation: The Pandava heroes headed by Bhimasena and Satyaki again attacked fiercely on Kaurava's army already destroyed in its considerable fraction.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनामयं पृच्छति त्वाऽऽम्बिकेयो वृद्धो राजा धृतराष्ट्रो मनीषी। कच्चिद् भीमः कुशली पाण्डवाग्र्यो धनंजयस्तौ च माद्रीतनूजौ॥
English Translation: Beholding the irrepressible force of their attack, the army of your sons, O king, turned their back.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कच्चित् कृष्णा द्रौपदी राजपुत्री सत्यव्रता वीरपत्नी सपुत्रा। मिष्टान् कामान् भारत स्वस्तिकामः॥
English Translation: With armours and coats of mail, displaced, weapons and bows loosened from their hands, your army, abounding in cars, horses, elephants and men, fled away in all directions, being agitated by the enemy as a herd of elephants in the forest is afflicted by lions.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच गावल्गणे संजय स्वागतं ते प्रीयामहे ते वयं दर्शनेन। अनामयं प्रतिजाने तवाहं सहानुजै:कुशली चास्मि विद्वन्॥
English Translation: I do not wish, O Brahmana, to support life by deceit or fraud. I do not seek wealth, however profuse, which is to be acquired by unfair means.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चिरादिदं कुशलं भारतस्य श्रुत्वा राज्ञः कुरुवृद्धस्य सूत। मन्ये साक्षाद् दृष्टमहं नरेन्द्र दृष्ट्वैव त्वां संजय प्रीतियोगात्॥
English Translation: In the very beginning of our present discourse I excepted these means. By adopting only such means as would not incur censure, such means as would benefit me in every respect, by doing only such acts as are not harmful, I wish to live in this world! I cannot follow these ways which you point out to me! Indeed, these instructions do not become you!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पितामहो नः स्थविरो मनस्वी महाप्राज्ञः सर्वधर्मोपपन्नः। स कौरव्यः कुशली तात भीष्मो यथापूर्वं वृत्तिरस्त्यस्य कच्चित्॥
English Translation: The sage said-These words, O Kshatriya. which you give vent to, point you out as a pious men. Indeed, you are pious by nature and understanding, O you of great experience.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कच्चिद् राजा धृतराष्ट्रः सपुत्रो वैचित्रवीर्यः कुशली महात्मा। महाराजो बाह्निकः प्रातिपेयः कच्चिद् विद्वान् कुशली सूतपुत्र॥
English Translation: I shall try for the good of you both. I shall create a union, between you and that king, which should be eternal and cannot be broken.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स सोमदत्तः कुशली तात कच्चिद् भूरिश्रवाः सत्यसंधः शलश्च। द्रोणः सपुत्रश्च कृपश्च विप्रो महेष्वासाः कच्चिदेतेऽप्यरोगाः॥
English Translation: Who is there that would not like to have a minister like you who are born of a noble family, who abstain from all unfair acts and cruelties, who are highly learned, and who are well versed in the art of government and of conciliation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वे कुरुभ्यः स्पृहयन्ति संजय धनुर्धरा ये पृथिव्या प्रधानाः। महाप्राज्ञाः सर्वशास्त्रावदाता धनुर्भूता मुख्यतमाः पृथिव्याम्॥
English Translation: I say this, O Kshatriya, because, though bereft of kingdom and plunged into great distress, still you wish to follow a pious course.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कच्चिन्मानं तात लभन्त एते धनुर्भूतः कच्चिदेतेऽप्यरोगाः। येषां राष्ट्रे निवसति दर्शनीयो महेष्वासः शीलवान् द्रोणपुत्रः॥
English Translation: The king of the Videhas, ever devoted to truth, will come to my residence soon. For sooth, he will do what I will request him to do.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महाप्राज्ञो राजपुत्रो युयुत्सुः। कर्णोऽमात्यः कुशली तात कच्चित् सुयोधनो यस्य मन्दो विधेयः॥
English Translation: Bhishma said Thereafter, inviting the king of the Videhas, the sage said these words to him,-This person is of royal birth. I know his very heart.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्त्रियो वृद्धा भारतानां जनन्यो महानस्यो दासभार्याश्च सूत। वध्वः पुत्रा भागिनेया भगिन्यो दौहित्रा वा कच्चिदप्यव्यलीकाः॥
English Translation: His soul is as pure as the surface of a mirror or the disc of the autumnal moon. He has been perfectly examined by me. I do not see any shortcoming in him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कच्चिद् राजा ब्राह्मणानां यथावत् प्रवर्तते पूर्ववत् तात वृत्तिम्। कच्चिद् दायान् मामकान् धार्तराष्ट्रो द्विजातीनां संजय नोपहन्ति॥
English Translation: Let there be friendship between him and you. Do you place confidence in him as in myself. A king who has no capable minister cannot govern his kingdom even for three days.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कच्चिद् राजा धृतराष्ट्रः सपुत्र उपेक्षते ब्राह्मणातिक्रमान् वै। मुपेक्षते तेषु सदैव वृत्तिम्॥
English Translation: The minister should be brave and highly intelligent. By these two qualities one may conquer both the worlds. Mark, O king, these two qualities well, since they are necessary for governing a kingdom.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतज्ज्योतिश्चोत्तमं जीवलोके शुक्लं प्रजानां विहितं विधात्रा। ते चेद् दोषं न नियच्छन्ति मन्दा: कृत्स्नोनाशो भविता कौरवाणाम्॥
English Translation: Pious kings have no such refuge as a minister endued with such attributes. This great person is of royal birth. He always treads the path of the righteous.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कच्चिद् राजा धृतराष्ट्रः सपुत्रो बुभूषते वृत्तिममात्यवर्गे। कच्चिन्न भेदेन जिजीविषन्ति सुहृदूपा दुर्हदैश्चैकमत्यात्।।
English Translation: This one, who always follows righteousness, has been a valuable acquisition. If treated by you with respect, he will subdue your enemies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कच्चिन्न पापं कथयन्ति तात ते पाण्डवानां कुरवः सर्व एव। द्रोणः सपुत्रश्च कृपश्च वीरो नास्मासु पापानि वदन्ति कच्चित्॥
English Translation: If he engages in battle with you, he will do what as a Kshatriya he should do. Indeed, if, following the conduct of his ancestors, he fights for conquering you, it will be your duty to fight him, for as a Kshatriya it is your duty to conquer antagonists. Without engaging in battle, however, do you, at my behest, employ him under you from desire of benefiting yourself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कच्चिद् राज्ये धृतराष्ट्र सपुत्रं समेत्याहुः कुरवः : कुरवः सर्व एव। कच्चिद् दृष्ट्वा दस्युसङ्घान् समेतान् स्मरन्ति पार्थस्य युधां प्रणेतु॥
English Translation: Have your eyes on righteousness, casting off covetousness. You should not abandon the duties of your order from lust or from desire of battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मौर्वीभुजाग्रप्रहितान् स्म तात दोधूयमानेन धनुर्धरेण। नजिह्मगान् कच्चिदनुस्मरन्ति॥
English Translation: Victory, O sire, is not certain. Defeat also is not certain. Knowing this, peace should be made with an cnemy by giving him food and other things of enjoyment.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न चापश्यं कचिदहं पृथिव्यां योधं समं वाधिकमर्जुनेन। यस्यैकषष्टिनिशितास्तीक्ष्णधाराः सुवाससः सम्मतो हस्तवापः॥
English Translation: One may witness victory and defeat his own case. They, who seek to root out an cnemy, are sometimes exterminated themselves in their endeavours!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गदापाणिर्भीमसेनस्तरस्वी प्रवेपयञ्छत्रुसङ्घाननीके। नागः प्रभिन्न इव नड्वलेषु चंक्रम्यते कच्चिदेनं स्मरन्ति॥
English Translation: Thus accosted, king Janaka, properly saluting and honouring that foremost of Brahınanas worthy of every honour, replied to him, saying,-You are highly learned and wise. What you have said from desire of benefiting us, is certainly advantageous for both of us. Such a course of conduct is highly beneficial to us. I do not hesitate to say this!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: माद्रीपुत्रः सहदेवः कलिङ्गान् समागतानजयद् दन्तकरे। वामेनास्यन् दक्षिणेनैव यो वै महाबलं कच्चिदेनं स्मरन्ति॥
English Translation: Then, addressing the prince of Koshala, the king of Videha said these words,-Following Kshatriya duties as also with the help of policy, I have conquered the world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुरा जेतुं नकुलः प्रेषितोऽयं शिबींस्त्रिगर्तान् संजय पश्यतस्ते। दिशं प्रतीची वशमानयन्मे माद्रीसुतं कच्चिदेनं स्मरन्ति॥
English Translation: I have, however, O best of kings, been conquered by you with your good qualities. Without feeling any sense of humiliation, live you with me as a victor.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पराभवो द्वैतवने य आसीद् दुर्मन्त्रिते घोषयात्रागतानाम्। यत्र मन्दाञ्छत्रुवशं प्रयातानमोचयद् भीमसेनो जयश्च।।
English Translation: I honour you intelligence, and I honour your power. I do not disregard you, saying that I have conquered you. On the other hand, live you with me as a victor.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अहं पश्चादर्जुनमभ्यरक्षं माद्रीपुत्रौ भीमसेनोऽप्यरक्षत्। गाण्डीवधन्वा शत्रुसङ्घानुदस्य स्वस्त्यागमत् कच्चिदेनं स्मरन्ति॥
English Translation: Honoured duly by me, o king, you will go to my house-Both the kings then adored that Brahmana, and trusting each other, proceeded to the capital of Mithila.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न कर्मणा साधुनैकेन नूनं सुखं शक्यं वै भवतीह संजय। न शक्नुमो धृतराष्ट्रस्य पुत्रम्॥
English Translation: Making the prince of Koshala enter his house, the king of the Videhas honoured hiin, who was worthy of every honour, with offerings of water to wash his feet, honey and curds and the usual articles.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच तस्यां निशायां व्युष्टायां गते तस्मिन् द्विजोत्तमे। निष्क्रम्य गौतमोऽगच्छत् समुद्रं प्रति भारत॥
English Translation: King Janaka also conferred upon his guest his own daughter and various kinds of gems and jewels. This is the greatest duty of king; victory and defeat are both uncertain."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सामुद्रिकान् स वणिजस्ततोऽपश्यत् स्थितान् पथि। स तेन सह सार्थेन प्रययौ सागरं प्रति॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : When that night passed away and morning appeared, those Brahmanas, who supported themselves by alms, stood before those doers of exalted deeds (the Pandavas) who were on the point of entering the forest.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तु सार्थो महान् राजन् कस्मिंश्चिद् गिरिगह्वरे। मत्तेन द्विरदेनाथ निहतः प्रायशोऽभवत्॥
English Translation: Thereupon the of Kunti, king Yudhishthira, thus spoke to them, “We are robbed to our kingdom, prosperity and everything. Living on fruits, roots and meat we go to the forest in sorrow. The forest is full of dangers and it abounds in reptiles and beasts of prey.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स कथंचिद् भयात् तस्माद् विमुक्तो ब्राह्मणस्तथा। कांदिग्भूतो जीवितार्थी प्रदुद्रोवात्तरां दिशम्॥
English Translation: It appears to me that you will have to suffer much privations and misery there. The sufferings of the Brahmanas may overwhelm even the celestials, what to speak of me! O Brahmanas, go back wherever you like.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तु सार्थपरिभ्रष्टस्तस्माद् देशात् तथा च्युतः। एकाकी व्यवरत् तत्र वने किंपुरुषो यथा।॥
English Translation: The Brahmanas said: O king, we are ready to go where you are going. You should not abandon us who are devoted to you and who follow the path of the true religion.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स पन्थानमथासाद्य समुद्राभिसरं तदा। आससाद वनं रम्यं दिव्यं पुष्पितपादपम्॥
English Translation: The celestials have compassion on their devotees, specially on the Brahmanas whose conduct is pure.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वर्तुकैराम्रवणैः पुष्पितैरुपशोभितम्। नन्दनोद्देशसदृशं यक्षकिन्नरसेवितम्।।७।
English Translation: Yudhishthira said : O Brahmanas, I have always great devotion towards the Brahmanas. But this destitution has overwhelmed me. My these brothers who are to procure fruits and roots and the deer are stupified with grief for the afflictions that have overtaken them and for the distress of Draupadi and for the loss of our kingdom. Alas, as they are distressed, I cannot employ them in painful tasks!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शालैस्तालैस्तमालैश्च कालागुरुवनैस्तथा। चन्दनस्य च मुख्यस्य पादपैरुपशोभितम्।
English Translation: The Brahmanas said : O king, do not allow any anxiety for our maintenance to find a place in your heart. Procuring our food ourselves, we shall follow you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गिरिप्रस्थेषु रम्येषु तेषु तेषु सुगन्धिषु॥ समन्ततो द्विजश्रेष्ठास्तत्राकूजन्त वै तदा।
English Translation: And we shall do you good by meditation and prayers and we shall entertain you with pleasant conversation and we shall ourselves be cheered in return.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मनुष्यवदनाश्चान्ये भारुण्डा इति विश्रुताः॥ भूलिङ्गशकुनाश्चान्ये सामुद्राः पर्वतोद्भवाः।
English Translation: Yudhishthira said: There is no doubt that it must be as you say. I am ever pleased with the company of Brahmanas. But my fallen condition makes me regard myself as an object of reproach.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तान्यतिमनोज्ञानि विहगानां रुतानि वै॥ शृण्वन् सुरमणीयानि विप्रोऽगच्छत् गौतमः।
English Translation: How shall I see you all, my well-wishers, who do not deserve to suffer any trouble, subsist on food procured by yourselves? O fie on the sons of Dhritarashtra!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽपश्यत् सुरम्येषु सुवर्णसिकताचिते॥ देशे समे सुखे चित्रे स्वर्णोद्देशसमे नृप।
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Having said this, that king (Yudhishthira) sat down weeping on the ground. Then a learned Brahmana, named Shaunaka, who was learned in the philosophy of the soul and in the Sankhya and Yoga, thus spoke to the king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रिया जुष्टं महावृक्षं न्यग्रोधं च सुमण्डलम्॥ शाखाभिरनुरूपाभिर्भूयिष्ठं क्षत्रसंनिभम्।
English Translation: Shaunaka said : Thousand causes of grief and hundred causes of fear overwhelm the ignorant day after day, but not the learned.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुखः शिवः। तस्य मूलं च संसिक्तं वरचन्दनवारिणा॥ दिव्यपुष्पान्वितं श्रीमत् पितामहसभोपमम।
English Translation: Intelligent men like you never allow themselves to be deluded by acts which are opposed to true knowledge, which is fought with every kind of evil and which is destructive of salvation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं दृष्ट्वा गौतमः प्रीतो मन:कान्तमनुत्तमम॥ मेध्यं सुरगृहप्रख्यं पुष्पितैः पादपैर्वृतम्।
English Translation: O king, the understanding with the eight attributes, which is said to be capable of providing against all evils which results from the study of the Shrutis, is in you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमासाद्य मुदा युक्तस्तस्याधस्तादुपाविशत्॥ तत्रासीनस्य कौन्तेय गौतमस्य पुष्पाणि समुपम्पृश्य प्रववावनिल: शुभः। ह्लादयन् सर्वगात्राणि गौतमस्य तदा नृप॥
English Translation: Men like you are never stupified by poverty or by meeting with difficult ways or by afflictions that overtake his friends or by bodily or mental miseries.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तु विप्रः प्रशान्तश्च स्पृष्टः पुण्येन वायुना। सुखमासाद्य सुष्वाप भास्करश्चास्तमभ्ययात्॥
English Translation: Hear, I shall recite to you the slokas which were chanted by the high-souled Janaka of old on the subject of controlling the soul.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽस्तं भास्करे याते संध्याकाल उपस्थिते। आजगाम स्वभवनं ब्रह्मलोकात् खगोत्तमः॥
English Translation: This world is afflicted with both bodily and mental sufferings. Listen to the means of allaying them as I indicate them both briefly and in detail.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नाडीजङ्घ इति ख्यातो दयितो ब्रह्मणः सखा। बकराजो महाप्राज्ञः कश्यपस्यात्मसम्भवः॥
English Translation: Disease, contact with painful things, toil and want of objects desired, these are the four causes of the sufferings of the body.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजधर्मेति विख्यातो बभूवाप्रतिमो भुवि। देवकन्यासुतः श्रीमान् विद्वान् देवसमप्रभः॥
English Translation: Disease may be allayed by the application of medicine, but mental ailments, are cured by Yoga meditation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पृष्टाभरणसम्पन्नो भूषणैरर्कसंनिभैः। षितः सर्वगात्रेषु देवगर्भः श्रिया ज्वलन्॥
English Translation: Therefore, intelligent physicians first seek to allay the mental sufferings of their patients by agreeable conversations and by the offer of desirable objects.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमागतं खगं दृष्ट्वा गौतमो विस्मितोऽभवत्। क्षुत्पिपासापरिश्रान्तो हिंसार्थी चाभ्यवेक्षत॥
English Translation: As a hot iron ball makes the water of a jar hot, so mental grief brings in bodily pains.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजधर्मोवाच स्वागतं भवतो विप्र दिष्ट्या प्राप्तोऽसि मे गृहम्। अस्तं च सविता यातः संध्येयं समुपस्थिता।॥
English Translation: As water quenches fire, so knowledge allays mental ailments. When mind enjoys' peace, body also enjoys peace.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मम त्वं निलय प्राप्तः प्रियातिथिरनिन्दितः। पूजितो यास्यसि प्रातर्विधिदृष्टेन कर्मणा॥
English Translation: It appears attachment is the root of all mental agonies; it is attachment that makes every creature miserable and brings on every kind of woe.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीमसेन उवाच ब्रह्मशानेन्द्रवरुणानवहद् यः पुरा रथः। तमास्थाय गतौ कृष्णौ न तयोर्विद्यते भयम्॥
English Translation: Attachment is the root of all misery and of all fear. Attachment produces joy and grief of every kind. From attachment spring all worldly desires and it is from attachment that springs the love of worldly goods. Both of these are evils, but the first is worse than the second.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आज्ञां तु शिरसा बिभ्रदेष गच्छामि मा शुचः। समेत्य तान् नरव्याघ्रांस्तव दास्यामि संविदम्॥
English Translation: As fire in the hollow of a tree consumes the tree itself to its roots, so attachment, however little it may be, destroys both Dharma and Artha,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच एतावदुक्त्वा प्रययौ परिदाय युधिष्ठिरम्। धृष्टद्युम्नाय बलवान् सुहद्भ्यश्च पुनः पुनः॥
English Translation: He, who has merely withdrawn from possessions, cannot be regarded as to have renounced the world. He, however, who remains in contact with the world, but sees its faults, may be said to have truly renounced the world. Such a man becomes freed from all evil passions and his soul is dependent on nothing.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृष्टद्युम्नं चेदमाह भीमसेनो महाबलः। विदितं ते महाबाहो यथा द्रोणो महारथः॥
English Translation: Therefore none should place his attachment on either friends or on wealth which he has carned. The attachment towards one's own body is destroyed by knowledge.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ग्रहणे धर्मराजस्य सर्वोपायेन वर्तते। न च मे गमने कृत्यं तादृक् पार्षत विद्यते॥
English Translation: Like the lotus leaf which is never drenched by water, souls of those men who are capable of knowing the everlasting and of men who are devoted to the pursuit of the eternal, learned in the Shastras and purified by knowledge, can never be touched by attachment.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यादृशं रक्षणे राज्ञः कार्यमात्ययिकं हि नः। एवमुक्तोऽस्मि पार्थेन प्रतिवक्तुं न चोत्सहे॥
English Translation: The man that is influenced by itachment is tortured by desire and from the desire that springs up in his heart, his thirst for worldly possessions increases. This thirst is sinful and is regarded as the source of all anxieties. It is this terrible thirst, fraught with sin, that leads to unrighteous acts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रयास्ये तत्र यत्रासौ मुमूर्षुः सैन्धवः स्थितः। धर्मराजस्य वचने स्थातव्यमविशङ्कया॥
English Translation: Those men, who can renounce this thirst, which can never be renounced by the wicked, which decays not with the decay of the body and which is a fatal disease, can be freed from misery.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यास्यामि पदवीं भ्रातुः सात्वतस्य च धीमतः। सोऽद्य यत्तो रणे पार्थ परिरक्ष युधिष्ठिरम्॥
English Translation: This thirst has neither beginning nor end. Like the fire of incorporeal origin, it destroys creatures by living within their hearts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतद्धि सर्वकार्याणां परमं कृत्यमाहवे। तमब्रवीन्महाराज धृष्टद्युम्नो वृकोदरम्॥
English Translation: As a faggot of wood is consumed by the fire that is fed by that faggot, so a person of impure soul meets with destruction from the covetousness born in his own heart.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ईप्सितं ते करिष्यामि गच्छ पार्थाविचारयन्। नाहत्वा समरे द्रोणो धृष्टद्युम्नं कथञ्चन॥
English Translation: Creatures endued with life have always a dread of death; so men having wealth are in constant dread of the king, the water, the fire, the thief and his relatives.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निग्रहं धर्मराजस्य प्रकरिष्यति संयुगे। ततो निक्षिप्य राजानं धृष्टद्युम्ने च पाण्डवम्॥
English Translation: If a piece of meat be in the air, it may be devoured by the birds, if it is on the grounds, it may be devoured by beasts of prey and if in the water, by the fishes, so a man having wealth is exposed to dangers wherever he might be.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभिवाद्य गुरुं ज्येष्ठं प्रययौ येन फाल्गुनः। परिष्वक्तश्च कौन्तेयो धर्मराजेन भारत॥
English Translation: To many men, the wealth they possess is their bane. The man, who sees happiness in wealth and becomes attached to it, knows not what true happiness is.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आघ्रातश्च तथा मूर्ध्नि श्रावितश्चाशिषः शुभाः। कृत्वा प्रदक्षिणान् विप्रानर्चितांस्तुष्टमानसान्॥
English Translation: Therefore, the accession of wealth is what increases covetousness and folly. It is the root of niggardliness, boastfulness, pride, fear and anxiety. These are the miseries that wise men see in wealth. Men have to suffer infinite miseries in the acquisition and retention of wealth. Its expenditure also is painful. Sometimes men are even killed for the sake of wealth. To abandon wealth is painful; even those men who are cherished become enemies for the sake of wealth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आलभ्य मङ्गलान्यष्टौ पीत्वा कैरातकं मधु। द्विगुणद्रविणो वीरो मदरक्तान्तलोचनः॥
English Translation: As the possession of wealth is fraught with such misery, one should not (at all) mind its loss. Ignorant men alone are discontented, but the wise men are always contented.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विप्रैः कृतस्वस्त्ययनो विजयोत्पादसूचितः। पश्यन्नेवात्मनो बुद्धिं विजयानन्दकारिणीम्॥
English Translation: The thirst for wealth can never be assuaged. Contentment is the highest happiness, therefore the wise men consider contentment to be the highest object to attain.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनुलोमानिलैश्चाशु प्रदर्शितजयोदयः। भीमसेनो महाबाहुः कवची शुभकुण्डली॥
English Translation: The learned men, knowing youth, beauty, life, treasure, prosperity and association with beloved ones to be (all) unstable, never covet them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: साङ्गदः सतलत्राणः सरथो रथिनां वरः। तस्य कार्णायसं वर्म हेमचित्रं महर्द्धिमत्॥
English Translation: Therefore one should refrain from the acquisition of wealth and thus avoid the sufferings of misery. The man of wealth can never be without dangers. For this reason virtuous men praise those who have no desire for wealth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विबभौ सर्वतः श्लिष्टं सविद्युदिव तोयदः। पीतरक्तासितसितैर्वासोभिश्च सुवेष्टितः॥
English Translation: As regards those that acquire wealth for the virtuous purposes, it is better for them not to do it at all. It is better not to touch mud than to wash it off after being besmeared with it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कण्ठमात्रेण च बभौ सेन्द्रायुध इवाम्बुदः। प्रयाते भीमसेने तु तव सैनयं युयुत्सया॥
English Translation: O Yudhishthira, you should not covet anything. It you want to acquire virtue, free yourself from all desires for the possession of wealth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पाञ्चजन्यरवो घोरः पुनरासीद् विशाम्पते। तं श्रुत्वा निनदं घोर त्रैलोक्यत्रासनं महत्॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said: O Brahmana, this my desire for wealth is not for the purpose of enjoying it when obtained. I do not desire it through avarice. I desire it only for the support of the Brahmanas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुनर्भीमं महाबाहुं धर्मपुत्रोऽभ्यभाषत। एष वृष्णिप्रवीरेण ध्मातः सलिलजो भृशम्॥
English Translation: O Brahmana, for what purpose would one like to lead a domestic life, if he cannot cherish and support those that follow him?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पृथिवीं चान्तरिक्षं च विनादयति शङ्खराट्। नूनं व्यसनमापन्ने सुमहत् सव्यसाचिनि॥
English Translation: All creatures are seen to divide their food among those that depend on them. So should person leading a domestic life give a share of his food to Brahmacharis who have given up cooking.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कुरुभियुध्यते सार्ध सर्वेश्चक्रगदाधरः। आह कुन्ती नूनमार्या पापमद्य निदर्शनम्॥ द्रौपदी च सुभद्रा च पश्यन्त्यौ सह बन्धुभिः। स भीम त्वरया युक्तो याहि यत्र धनंजयः॥
English Translation: The houses of good men can never be in want of grass, space, water and sweet words, the fourth. Bed to the tired, seat to one who is fatigued by standing, water to on who is thirsty and food to one who is hungry should be always given.
Pleasant looks, cheerful heart and sweet words are due to a guest. Rising up, the host should advance towards the guest; he should offer him a seat and duly worship him. This is the eternal Dharma. They who do not perform Agnihotra, they who do not wait upon bulls and cherish their kinsmen, guest, friends, sons, wives and servants, for such negligence are consumed with sin. None should cook his food for himself, none should kill any animal for nothing. Non should eat that food which is not duly dedicated.
By scattering morning and evening food on the earth for dogs, Chandalas and birds, a person should perform the Vishvadeva (sacrifice).
He who eats Vighasa eats ambrosia. That, which remains after dedication in a sacrifice, is (also) regarded as ambrosia.
The pleasant looks (one casts on his guests), the attention he devotes to him, the sweet words with which he addresses him, the respect with which he follows him and the food and drink with which he treats him, are the five Dakshinas in that sacrifice.
He, who gives food freely to a fatigued way. farer, whom he has never seen before, obtains grcat virtuous merit.
He, who leading domestic life, follows such practices, obtains, it is said, great religious merit. O Brahmana, what is your opinion?
Shaunaka said: Alas, alas this worlds is full of contradictions! That which makes the good and the honest ashamed gratifies the wicked.
Move by ignorance and passions and becoming slaves to their senses, ignorant men perform many acts to gratify their stomachs an sexual organs.
Men are lcd astray by their seducing senses, as a charioteer who has lost his senses (is led। astray) by wicked horses.
When any of the six senses finds its ! particular object, the desire springs up in the heart to enjoy that particular object.
Thus when one's mind proceeds to enjoy the objects of any particular sense, a wish is entertained; that wish in its turn gives birth to a resolve.
As an insect falls into a flame from love of light, man falls into the fire of temptation, as it were pierced by the arrows of the objects of enjoyments) which are discharged by the desire which is the seed of resolve.
Blinded by sensual pleasure which he freely seeks and steeped in dark ignorance and folly which he mistakes for happiness, he thenceforth knows not himself. Like a wheel that is incessantly whirling, every creature, from ignorance, acts and desire, roves in various states in the world, wandering from one birth to another, ranging from Brahma to a blade of grass, an taking birth again and again now in water, now in earth and now in the sky.
This is the career of those that are without knowledge. Listen to that of the wise, the men who are intent on virtue and who are desirous of Moksha (emancipation).
This is the word of the Vedas, act, but act with renunciation. Therefore you should act renouncing Abhimana.
Performances of sacrifices, study, gifts, penance, truth, forgiveness, subduing the senses and renunciation of desire, these are the eight Dharmas declared by the Smriti.
Of these the first four pave the way to the regions of Pitris. Therefore it is the duty of all to act by renouncing Abhimana.
The last four are always observed by the pious who aspire to attain to the region of the celestials. The men of pure soul should observe these eight (paths).
Those, who wish to subdue the world for the purposes of salvation, should always act by fully renouncing all motives and by subduing their senses, rigidly observing vows, devotedly serving their preceptors, austerely regulating their food, diligently studying the Vedas, renouncing action as mean and restraining their heart. By renouncing desire and aversions, the celestials have obtained prosperity.
It is for the virtue of their wealth of Yoga, that the Rudras, the Sadhyas, the Adityas, the Vasus and the Ashvins support all these creatures (of the world).
O son of Kunti, O descendant of Bharata, therefore you too like them, entirely renouncing actions with motive, try to obtain success in Yoga and austerities.
You have already obtained success as far as your debts to the Pitris, both male and female are concerned and you have obtained that success also which is derived from action. Try now to obtain success in from action. Try now to obtain success in penances in order to support the Brahmanas.
Those that are crowned with ascetic success can by virtue of that success do whatever they like. Therefore practising asceticism, realise all your wishes.
You best of beings, I shall now declare to you accurately what (the quality of) Darkness is. You highly blessed ones, do you understand what those qualities are that belong to Darkness.
Injuring (others), beauty, toil, pleasure and pain, cold and heat, lordship (or power), war, peace, argument, dissatisfaction, endurance, power, valour, pride, anger, exertion, quarrel (or collision), jealousy, desire, malice, battle, the sense of mineness, protection (of others), destruction fetters and affliction, buying and selling, lopping off, cutting, piercing, and cutting off the coat of mail that another has worn, fierceness, cruelty, vilifying, pointing out the faults of others, thoughts entirely devoted to worldly affairs, anxiety, animosity, vilification of others, false speech, false or vain gifts, hesitancy and doubt, boastfulness of speech dispraise and praise, laudation, prowess, defiance, attendance, obedience, servicc or ministrations, harbouring of thirst or desire, cleverness or dexterity of conduct, policy, carelessness, contumely, possessions, and various decorations which prevail in the world among men, women, animals, inanimate things, bouses, gricf, incredulousness, Vows and regulations, actions with expectation (of good results) various acts of public charity, the rites of Svaha salutations, rites of Svadha and Vashat, officiating at the sacrifices of others, imparting of instruction, performance of sacrifices, study, making of gifts, acceptance of giſts, riles of expiation, auspicious acts, the wish to have this and that, affection caused by the merits of the object for which or whom it is felt, treachery deception, disrespect and respect, theft, killing, desire of concealment, vexation, wakefulness, ostentation, pride, attachment, devotion, contentment, exultation, gambling, indulgence in scandal, all relations arising out of women, attachment to dancing, instrumental music, and songs, all these qualities, you learned Brahmanas, have been said to belong to Rajas or Darkness.
These men on Earth who meditate on the past, present, and the future, who are devoted to the threefold objects of life, viz., Religion, Profit, and Pleasure, who, acting from the impulse of desire, exult on acquiring riches in respect of every desire, are said to be covered by Darkness. These men have downward courses.
Repeatedly reborn in this world, they addict theinselves to pleasure. They covet what belongs to this world as also all those fruits of the world to come. They make gifts, accept gifts, offer oblations to the departed manes, and pour libations on the sacrificial fire.
The qualities of Darkness have (thus) been declared to you in their manifold aspects. The course of conduct also to which it leads has been properly described to you. The man who always understands these qualities, succeeds in always liberating himself from all of them which belong to Darkness.
The Brahmana said There are three enemies in the world. They are said to be minefield, according to their qualities. Exultation, satisfaction, and joy, these three qualities belong to Goodness.
Cupidity, anger and hatred, these three qualitics said to belong Darkness. Lassitude, procrastination and delusion, these three qualities belong to Ignorance.
Cutting these with showers of arrows, the intelligent man, free from idleness possessed of a tranquil soul, and with his senses under control, ventures to defeat others.
About it, persons conversant with ancient cycles recite some verses which were sung formerly by king Ambarisha who had acquired a tranquil soul.
When various kinds of faults were reigning supreme and when the righteous were afflicted, the illustrious Ambarisha put forth his strength for assuming sovereignty.
Subduing his own faults and adoring the righteous, he acquired great success and sang these verses.
I have controlled many faults. I have slain all enemies. But there is one, the greatest, vice which deserves to be destroyed but which has not been destroyed be me.
Urged by that fault, this individual soul fails to attain to freedom from desire. Possessed by desire, one runs into ditches without knowing it.
Urged by that fault, one induigcs in forbidden deeds. Do you cut off, cut off, that cupidity with sharp-edged swords.
From cupidity originates desire. From desire originates anxiety. The man who yields to desire acquires many qualities which bclong 10 Darkness,
When these have been acquired, he gets many qualities which belong to ignorance. On account of the qualities, he repeatedly takes birth, with the fetters of body united, and is moved to action. Upon the expiration of life, with body becoming separated and scattered, he once mects with death which is due to birth itself.
Hence, duly understanding this, and governing cupidity by intelligence, one should desire for sovereignty in his soul. This is (true) sovereignty. There is no other sovereignty here. The soul properly understood, is the king.
Even these were thc verses sung by the illustrious king Ambarisha, on the subject of sovereignty which he kept before him, that king who had severed the one foremost fault, viz.. cupidity.
Krishna said: O king, when Pradyumna (wounded by the arrows) became very much disheartened and aggrieved, the Vrishnis and the Andhakas began to exclaim, “Oh” and “Alas. The enemies (Shalva's men) became exceedingiy joyful.

English Translation: What will the elder brother of Keshava, the mighty-armed Baladeva, who is clad in blue and inebriated with wine, say when he will return?

Sanskrit Shloka: पुनश्चातीव वेगेन द्रोणानीकमुपाद्रवत्। तमवारयदाचार्यो वेलोद्वृत्तमिवार्णवम्॥
