English Translation: O Suta, what will that best of men, the grandson of Sini that great bowman (Satyaki), say when he will hear that I have run away from the battle? What will the ever-victorious Samba.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ललाटेऽताड्यच्चैनं नाराचेन स्मयन्निव। ऊर्ध्वरश्मिरिवादित्यो विबभौ तेन पाण्डवः॥
English Translation: O charioteer and irrepressible Charudeshna, Gada, Sarana and the mighty-armed Akrura say to me?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स मन्यमानस्त्वाचार्यो ममायं फाल्गुनो यथा। भीमः करिष्यते पूजामित्युवाच वृकोदरम्॥
English Translation: What will the wives of the Vrishni heroes when they would meet together say of me who have been hitherto considered as brave, wellconducted, respectable and possessing manly pride.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीमसेन न ते शक्या प्रवेष्टुमरिवाहिनी। मामनिर्जित्य समरे शत्रुमद्य महाबल॥
English Translation: They will say "Here comes Pradyumna, the coward, running away from the great battle. Fie on him.” They will never say “Well done?”
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदि ते सोऽनुजः कृष्णः प्रविष्टोऽनुमते मम। अनीकं न तु शक्यं मे प्रवेष्टुमिह वै त्वया॥
English Translation: O son of Suta, ridicule with the exclamation of fie is to me or to a person like me is more than dcath. Thereupon never again leave the field of battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ भीमस्तु तच्छुत्वा गुरोर्वाक्यमपेतभीः। क्रुद्धः प्रोवाच वै द्रोणं रक्तताप्रेक्षणस्त्वरन्॥
English Translation: Giving charge (of the city) to me, the slayer of Madhu, Hari (Krishna), has gone to the sacrifice of the foremost of the Bharata race (Yudhishthira). Therefore I cannot bear to be quiet now.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तवार्जुनो नानुमते ब्रह्मबन्धो रणाजिरम्। प्रविष्टः स हि दुर्धर्षः शक्रस्यापि विशेद् बलम्॥ तेन वै परमां पूजां कुर्वता मानितो ह्यसि। नार्जुनोऽहं घृणी द्रोण भीमसेनोऽस्मि॥
English Translation: O son of Suta, when the heroic Kritavarma was coming out to meet Shalva, I made his desist, saying “I will resist him (Shalva). You better stay."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पिता नस्त्वं गुरुर्बन्धुस्तथा पुत्रास्तु ते वयम्। इति मन्यामहे सर्वे भवन्तं प्रणता स्थिताः॥
English Translation: The son of Hridika (Kritavarma) desisted in order to honour me. Having left the field of battle, what shall I say to that great carwarrior?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अद्य तद्विपरीतं ते वदतोऽस्मासु दृश्यते। यदि त्वं शत्रुमात्मानं मन्यसे तत्तथास्त्विह॥
English Translation: When that irresistible and mighty-armed hero, that holder of the conch, the discuss and the club, will return, what shall I say to that lotus-eyed one?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एष ते सदृशं शत्रोः कर्म भीमः करोम्यहम्। अथोद्भाम्य गदां भीमः कालदण्डमिवान्तकः॥
English Translation: What shall I say to Satyaki, Baladeva and others of the Vrishni and the Andhaka races who always boast of me?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्रोणाय व्यसृजद् राजन् स रथादवपुप्लुवे। साश्वसूतध्वजं यानं द्रोणस्यापोथयत् तदा॥
English Translation: O son of Suta, having left the battle and having been struck at the back with arrows and carried away by you (from the field of battle) as I was insensible, I shall by no means be able to live (any longer).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रामृगाच बहून् योधान् वायुर्वृक्षानिवौजसा। तं पुनः परिवव॒स्ते तव पुत्रा रथोत्तमम्॥
English Translation: O son of Daruka, turn speedily the chariot back again. Never act in this way again, even not at the time of the greatest danger.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्यं तु रथमास्थाय द्रोणः प्रहरतां वरः। व्यूहद्वारं समासाद्य युद्धाय समुपस्थितः॥
English Translation: O son of Suta, having fled from the field like a coward and having been wounded at the back by arrows I consider life worth nothing?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः क्रुद्धो महाराज भीमसेनः पराक्रमी। अग्रतः स्यन्दनानीकं शरवर्षैरवाकिरत्॥
English Translation: O son of Suta, have you ever seen me fly from the battle like a coward?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते वध्यमानाः समरे तव पुत्रा महारथाः। भीमं भीमबला युद्धे योध्यन्ति ज्यैषिणः॥
English Translation: O son of Daruka, you ought not to have left the battle while my desire for fight had not been gratified. Therefore, go back to the battle again.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो दुःशासन क्रुद्धो रथशक्तिं समाक्षिपत्। सर्वपारसवीं तीक्ष्णां जिघांसुः पाण्डुनन्दनम्॥ आपतन्तीं महाशक्तिं तव पुत्रप्रणोदिताम्। द्विधा चिच्छेद तां भीमस्तदद्भुतमिवाभवत्॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said Tell me, O sire, that high Yoga by which, O Bharata, I may obtain liberation. O foremost of speakers, I wish to know everything about that Yoga truly.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथान्यैर्विशिखैस्तीक्ष्णैः संक्रुद्धः कुण्डभेदिनम्। सुषेणं दीर्घनेत्रं च त्रिभित्रीनवधीद् बली॥ ततो वृन्दारकं वीरं कुरूणां कीर्तिवर्धनम्। पुत्राणां तव वीराणां युध्यतामवधीत् पुनः॥ अभयं रौद्रकर्माणं दुर्विमोचनमेव च। त्रिभित्रीनवधीद् भीमः पुनरेव सुतांस्तव॥ वध्यमाना महाराज पुत्रास्तव बलीयसा। भीमं प्रहरतां श्रेष्ठं समन्तात् पर्यवारयन्॥
English Translation: Bhishma said 'Regarding it is cited the old narrative of the discourse between a preceptor and disciple on the subject of liberation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते शरैर्भीमकर्माणं ववर्षः पाण्डवं युधि। मेघा इवातपापाये धाराभिर्धरणीधरम्॥
English Translation: There was a twice-born preceptor who was the foremost of Rishis. He looked like a mass of effulgence. Endued with a high soul, he was firm in truth and a complete master of his senses.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तद् बाणमयं वर्षमश्मवर्षमिवाचलः। प्रतीच्छन् पाण्डुदायादो न प्राव्यथत शत्रुहा॥ विन्दानुविन्दौ सहितौ सुवर्माणं च ते सुतम्। प्रहसन्नेव कौन्तेयः शरैर्निन्ये यमक्षयम्॥ ततःसुदर्शनं वीरं पुत्रं ते भरतर्षभ। विव्याध समरे तूर्ण स पपात ममार च॥ सोऽचिरेणैव कालेन तद्रथानीकमाशुगैः। दिशः सर्वाः समालोक्य व्यधमत् पाण्डुनन्दनः॥ ततो वै स्थघोषेण गर्जितेन मृगा इव। भज्यमानाश्च समरे तव पुत्रा विशाम्पते॥
English Translation: Once upon a time, a highly intelligent and attentive disciple, desirous of obtaining what was for his highest good touched the preceptor's feet, and standing with joined palms before him, said,-If O illustrious one, you have been pleased with the adoration I have offered you, you should solve a great doubt of mine.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्राद्रवन् सहसा सर्वे भीमसेनभयार्दिताः। अनुयायाच कौन्तेयः पुत्राणां ते महद् बलम्॥
English Translation: Whence am I am and whence are you? Tell me this fully. Tell me also what is the final cause. Why also, O best of twice-born ones, when the material and destruction take place in such dissimilar ways? You should, O you of great learning, also explain the object of the saying in the Vedas, the meaning of the injunctions of the Smritis and of those injunctions which apply to all classes of men.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विव्याध समरे राजन् कौरवेयान् समन्ततः। वध्यमाना महाराज भीमसेनेन तावकाः॥
English Translation: Listen, O disciple, O you of great wisdom. This what you have asked me is not described even in the very Vedas and is the highest subject for thought or discourse. It is called Adhyatma and is the most precious of all branches of learning and of all sacred institutes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्यक्त्वा भीमं रणाजग्मुश्चोदयन्तो हयोत्तमान्। तांस्तु निर्जित्य समरे भीमसेनो महाबलः॥
English Translation: Vasudeva is the Supreme (cause) of the universe. He is the origin of the Vedas (viz., Om). He is Truth, Knowledge, Sacrifice, Renunciation, self-control, and Righteousness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सिंहनादरवं चक्रे बाहुशब्दं च पाण्डवः। तलशब्दं च सुमहत् कृत्वा भीमो महाबलः॥
English Translation: Persons well-read in Vedas know Him as pervading, all Eternal, Omnipresent, the Creator and the Destroyer, the Unmanifest, Brahma, Immutable.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीषयित्वा स्थानीकं हत्वा योधान् वरान् वरान्। व्यतीत्य रथिनश्चापि द्रोणानीकमुपाद्रवत्॥
English Translation: Hear now from me the story of Him who was born in the Vrishni family. A Brahmana should hear the greatness of that God of gods, called Vishnu of immeasurable energy, from the lips of Brahmanas. A Kshatriya should hear it from persons of that order. One who is a Vaishya, should hear it from Vaishyas, and a high-souled Shudra should hear it from Sudras.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सूर्य उवाच नैष देवोऽनिलसखो नासुरो न च पन्नगः। उच्छवृत्तिव्रते सिद्धो मुनिरेव दिवं गतः॥
English Translation: You deserve to hear it. Listen now to the sacred accounts of Krishna, that theme which is foremost of all themes. Vasudeva is the Wheel of Time, without beginning and without end. Existence and Non-existence are the qualities by which His real nature is known.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एष मूलफलाहारः शीर्णपर्णाशनस्तथा। अभक्षो वायुभक्षश्च आसीद् विप्रः समाहितः॥
English Translation: The universe rolls like a wheel, depending upon that Lord of all beings. O best of men, Keshava, that foremost of all beings is said to be Indestructible, unmanifest, Immortal Brahma, and Immutable.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भवश्चानेन विप्रेण संहिताभिरभिष्टुतः। स्वर्गद्वारे कृतोद्योगो येनासौ त्रिदिवं गतः॥
English Translation: The highest of the high, and without change or destruction himself, he created the departed manes, the gods, the Rishis, the Yakshas, the Rakshasas, the Nagas, the Asuras, and mankind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: असङ्गतिरनाकाङ्क्षी नित्यमुच्छशिलाशनः। सर्वभूतहिते युक्त एष विप्रो भुजङ्गम॥
English Translation: He also created the Vedas and the eternal duties and customs of men. Having reduced everything into nothing, he once more, in the beginning of a (new) cycle, creates Prakriti.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न हि देवा न गन्धर्वा नासुरा न च पन्नगाः। प्रभवन्तीह भूतानां प्राप्तानामुत्तमां गतिम्॥ एतदेवंविधं दृष्टमाश्चर्यं तत्र मे द्विज।
English Translation: As the various phenomena of the several seasons set in one after another according to the season that comes, so creatures come into being at the commencement of every cycle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संसिद्धो मानुष: कामं योऽसौ सिद्धगतिं गतः। सूर्येण सहितो ब्रह्मन् पृथिवीं परिवर्तते॥
English Translation: Corresponding with those creatures who came into being, rules and duties are paid for regulating the world's course.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्जुन उवाच ब्रह्म यत्परमं ज्ञेयं तन्मे व्याख्यातुमर्हसि। भवतो हि प्रसादेन सूक्ष्मे मे रमते मतिः॥
English Translation: At the end of every cycle the Vedas and all other scriptures disappear. Through the favour of the Self-create, the great Rishis, by mcans of their penances, first re-acquire the lost Vedas and the scriptures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वासुदेव उवाच अत्राप्युदाहरन्तीममितिहासं पुरातनम्। संवादं मोक्षसंयुक्तं शिष्यस्य गुरुणा सह॥
English Translation: The Self-create (Brahman) first acquired the Vedas. Their branches called the Angas were first acquired by Brihaspati. Bhrigu's son (Shukra) first acquired the science of ethics which is so beneficial for the universe.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कश्चिद् ब्राह्मणमासीनमाचार्यं संशितव्रतम्। शिष्यः प्रप्रच्छ मेधावी किंस्विच्छ्रेयः परंतप॥
English Translation: Narada acquired the science of music; Bharadvaja that of arms; Gargya, the history of the celestial Rishis; the dark son of Atri that of medicine.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भगवन्तं प्रपन्नोऽहं निःश्रेयसपरायणः। याचे त्वां शिरसा विप्र यद् ब्रूयां ब्रूहि तन्मम॥
English Translation: are Various other Rishis whose names connected therewith, promulgated various other sciences such as Philosophy, Logic, etc. Let that Brahma which those Rishis have described by arguments drawn from reason, by means of the Vedas, and by inferences drawn from the direct evidence of the senses, be worshipped.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तभेवंवादिनं पार्थ शिष्यं गुरुरुवाच ह। सर्वे तु ते प्रवक्ष्यामि यत्र वै संशयो द्विज॥
English Translation: Neither the gods nor the Rishis were able to grasp Brahma who is without beginning and who is the highest of the high. Only the divine creator of all things, viz., the powerful Narayana, had known of Brahma.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्युक्तः स कुरुश्रेष्ठ गुरुणा गुरुवत्सलः। प्राञ्जलिः परिपप्रच्छ यत्तच्छृणु महामते॥
English Translation: From Narayana, the Rishis the foremost of the deities, the Asuras, and the royal sages of old, acquired the knowledge of that highest panacea for the cure of sorrow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शिष्य उवाच कुतश्चाहं कुतश्च त्वं तत्सत्यं ब्रूहि यत्परम्। कुतो जातानि भूतानि स्थावराणि चराणि च॥
English Translation: When Prakriti creates through the action of Purusha, the universe with all its potencies begins to spring from it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: केन जीवन्ति भूतानि तेषामायुश्च किं परम्। किं सत्य किं तपो विप्र के गुणाः सद्भिरीरिताः॥
English Translation: From one lighted lamp thousands of other lamps are capable of being lighted. Similarly, Prakriti produces thousands of existent things. On account of its infinity, primordial matter is never exhausted,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: के पन्थान: शिवाश्च स्युः किं सुखं किं च दुष्कृतम्। एतान् मे भगवन् प्रश्चान् याथातथ्येन सुव्रत॥ वक्तुमर्हसि विप्रर्षे यथावदिह तत्त्वतः। त्वदन्यः कश्चन प्रश्चानेतान् वक्तुमिहार्हति॥
English Translation: From the Unmanifest flows the Understanding determined by acts. The Understanding creates Consciousness. From Consciousness proceeds Space. From Space proceeds Wind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्रूहि धर्मविदां श्रेष्ठ परं कौतूहलं मम। मोक्षधर्मार्थकुशलो भवाँल्लोकेषु गीयते॥
English Translation: From the Wind proceeds Heat. From Heat proceeds Water, and from Water is produced the Earth. These Eight form primordial Prakriti. The universe rests on them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वसंशयसंच्छेत्ता त्वदन्यो न च विद्यते। संसारभीरवश्चैव मोक्षकामास्तथा वयम्॥
English Translation: From those Eight have originated the five organs of knowledge, the five organs of action, the five objects of the (first five) organs, and the one, viz., the Mind, forining the sixteenth, which is the outcome of their modification.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वासुदेव उवाच तस्मै सम्प्रतिपन्नाय यथावत् परिपृच्छते। शिष्याय गुणयुक्ताय शान्ताय प्रियवर्तिने॥ छायाभूताय दान्ताय यतते ब्रह्मचारिणे। तान् प्रश्नानब्रवीत् पार्थ मेधावी स धृतव्रतः। गुरुः कुरुकुलश्रेष्ठ सम्यक् सर्वानरिंदम॥
English Translation: The car, the skin, the two eyes, the tongue, and the nose are the five organs of knowledge. The two feet, the anus, the organ of generation, the two arms, and speech, are the five organs of action.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गुरुरुवाच ब्रह्मणोक्तमिदं सर्वमृषिप्रवरसेवितम्। वेदविद्यां समाश्रित्य तत्त्वभूतार्थभावनम्॥
English Translation: Sound, touch, form, taste, and smell are the five objects of the senses, covering all things. The Mind lives upon all the senses and their objects.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ज्ञानं त्वेव परं विद्यः संन्यासं तप उत्तमम्। यस्तु वेद निराबाधं ज्ञानतत्त्वं विनिश्चयात्। सर्वभूतस्थमात्मानं स सर्वगतिरिष्यते॥ यो विद्वान् सहसंवासं विवासं चैव पश्यति। तथैवैकत्वनानात्वे स दुःखात् परिमुच्यते॥ यो न कामयते किंचिन्न किंचिदभिमन्यते। इहलोकस्थ एवैष ब्रह्मभूयाय कल्पते॥ प्रधानगुणतत्त्वज्ञः सर्वभूतविधानवित्। निर्ममो निरहङ्कारो मुच्यते नात्र संशयः॥ अव्यक्तबीजप्रभवो बुद्धिस्कन्धमयो महान्। महाहङ्कारविटप इन्द्रियाकुरकोटरः॥ महाभूतविशेषश्च विशेषप्रतिशाखवान्। सदापर्णः सदापुष्पः सदा शुभफलोदयः॥ अजीवः सर्वभूतानां ब्रह्मबीजः सनातनः। एतज्ज्ञात्वा च तत्त्वानि ज्ञानेन परमासिना॥ छित्त्वा चामरतां प्राप्य जहाति मृत्युजन्मनी।
English Translation: In the perception of taste, the Mind becomes the tongue, and in speech Mind become words. Covered with the different senses, Mind becomes all the objects.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भूतभव्यभविष्यादि धर्मकामार्थनिश्चयम्। सिद्धसंघपरिज्ञातं पुराकल्पं सनातनम्॥ प्रवक्ष्येऽहं महाप्राज्ञ पदमुत्तममद्य ते। बुद्ध्वा यदिह संसिद्धा भवन्तीह मनीषिणः॥
English Translation: These sixteen, existing in their respective forms, should be known as god. These adore Him who creates all knowledge and lives within the body.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उपगम्यर्षयः पूर्वं जिज्ञासन्तः परस्परम्। प्रजापतिभरद्वाजौ गौतमो भार्गवस्तथा॥ वसिष्ठः कश्यपश्चैव विश्वामित्रोऽत्रिरेव च। मार्गान् सर्वान् परिक्रम्य परिश्रान्ताः स्वकर्मभिः॥२६
English Translation: Taste in the attribute of water; scent is the attribute of space; vision is the attribute of fire or light; and touch is the attribute of the wind. This is the case with all creatures at all times.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ऋषिमाङ्गिरसं वृद्धं पुरस्कृत्य तु ते द्विजाः। ददृशुर्ब्रह्मभवने ब्रह्माणं वीतकल्मषम्॥
English Translation: The Mind, is the attribute of existence. Existence springs from the Prakriti which exists in That which is the Soul of all existent beings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं प्रणम्य महात्मानं सुखासीनं महर्षयः। पप्रच्छुर्विनयोपेता नैःश्रेयसमिदं परम्॥
English Translation: These existence's, resting upon the supreme Divinity that is above Prakriti and that is inactive, uphold the entire universe of the mobile and immobile objects.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कथं कर्म क्रियात् साधु कथं मुच्येत किल्बिषात्। के नो मार्गाः शिवाश्च स्युः किं सत्यं किं च दुप्कृतम्॥
English Translation: This sacred building of nine doors (body) is endued with all these existences. That which is high above them, viz., the Soul, lives within it, pervading it all over. Therefore it is called Purusha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: को चोभौ कर्मणां मार्गों प्राप्नुयुर्दक्षिणोत्तरौ। प्रलयं चापवर्गं च भूतानां प्रभवाप्ययौ॥
English Translation: The Soul is not subject to decay and death. It has knowledge of what is manifest and what is unmanifest. It is again all-pervading, endued with qualities, subtile, and the refuge of all existence and qualities.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्युत्ताः स मुनिश्रेष्ठैर्यदाह प्रपितामहः। तत् तेऽहं सम्प्रवक्ष्यामि शृणु शिष्य यथागमम्॥
English Translation: As a lamp shows all objects great or small, similarly the Soul dwells in all creatures as the principle of knowledge.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मण उवाच सत्याद् भूतानि जातानि स्थावराणि चराणि च। तपसा तानि जीवन्ति इति तद् वित्त सुव्रताः। स्वां योनि समतिक्रम्य वर्तन्ते स्तेन कर्मणा॥
English Translation: Making the car to hear what it hears, it is the Soul that hears. Likewise, making the works, it is the Soul that sees. This body supplies the means by which the Soul derives knowledge. The bodily organs are not the doers, but it is the Soul that is doer, of all acts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सत्यं हि गुणसंयुक्तं नियतं पञ्चलक्षणम्॥ ब्रह्म सत्यं तपः सत्यं सत्यं चैव प्रजापतिः।
English Translation: There is fire in wood, but it is never seen by cutting upon a piece of wood. Similarly, the Soul lives within the body, but it can never be seen by cutting the body.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सत्याद् भूतानि जातानि सत्यं भूतमयं जगत्॥ तस्मात् सत्यमया विप्रा नित्यं योगपरायणाः। अतीतक्रोधसंतापा नियता धर्मसेविन:॥ अन्योन्यनियतान् वैद्यान् धर्मसेतुप्रवर्तकान्। तानहं सम्प्रवक्ष्यामि शाश्वताल्लोकभावनान्॥ चातुर्विद्यं तथा वर्णाश्चातुराश्रमिकान् पृथक्।
English Translation: The fire which exists in wood may be seen by proper means, viz., rubbing the wood. Similarly, the Soul which lives within the body may be seen by employing proper means, viz., Yoga.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धर्ममेकं चतुष्पादं नित्यमाहुर्मनीषिणः॥ पन्थानं वः प्रवक्ष्यामि शिवं क्षेमकरं द्विजाः।
English Translation: Water must exits in rivers. Rays of light are always attached to the sun. Similarly, thc Soul has a body. This connection is not stopped because of the constant succession of bodies that Soul has to pass through.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नियतं ब्रह्मभावाय गतं पूर्वं मनीषिभिः॥ गदन्तस्तं मयाद्येह पन्थानं दुर्विदं परम्।
English Translation: In a dream, the Soul, endued with the five senses, leaves the body and moves over wide areas. Similarly, when death takes place, the Soul passes out of one body for entering another.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निबोधत महाभागा निखिलेन परं पदम्॥ ब्रह्मचारिकमेवाहुराश्रमं प्रथमं पदम्।
English Translation: The Soul is fettered by its pristine acts. Fettered by acts done by it in one state. Indeed, it is led from one into another body by its owni acts which are of very powerful consequences.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गार्हस्थ्यं तु द्वितीयं स्याद् वानप्रस्थमतः परम्। ततः परं तु विज्ञेयमध्यात्मं परमं पदम्॥
English Translation: I will not describe how the owner of a human body, casting off his body, enters another, and then again into another, and how, indeed, the whole range of beings is the result of their respective acts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ज्योतिराकाशमादित्यो वायुरिन्द्रः प्रजापतिः। नोपैति यावदध्यात्म तावदेतान् न पश्यति॥
English Translation: Vyasa said Brahma is the effulgent seed from which existing as it does by itself, has originated the entire universe consisting of two kinds of being, viz., the mobile and the immobile,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्योपायं प्रवक्ष्यामि पुरस्तात् तं निबोधत। फलमूलानिलभुजां मुनीनां वसतां वने।॥ वानप्रस्थं द्विजातीनां त्रयाणामुपदिश्यते। सर्वेषामेव वर्णानां गार्हस्थ्यं तद् विधीयते॥
English Translation: At the dawn of His day, waking up, He creates with the aid of Avidya this universe. Mahat or the principle of Greatness at first springs up. That Mahat is speedily changed into Mind which is the soul of the Manifest.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रद्धालक्षणमित्येवं धर्मं धीराः प्रचक्षते। इत्येवं देवयाना वः पन्थानः परिकीर्तिताः। सद्भिरध्यासिता धीरैः कर्मभिर्धर्मसेतवः॥
English Translation: Overwhelming the Intelligence, which is effulgent, with Ignorance, Mind creates seven great entities. Urged by the desire of creating, Mind, which is far-reaching, which has many courses, and which had desire and doubt for its leading signs, beings to create various kinds of objects by modifications of itself. Ether first originates from it. Know that its property is Sound.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतेषां पृथगध्यास्ते यो धर्मं संशितव्रतः। कालात् पश्यति भूतानां सदैव प्रभवाप्ययौ॥
English Translation: From Ether, by modification, originates the bearer of all scents, viz., the pure, and powerful Wind. It is said to possess the property of Touch.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अतस्तत्त्वानि वक्ष्यामि याथातथ्येन हेतुना। विषयस्थानि सर्वाणि वर्तमानानि भागशः॥
English Translation: From Wind also, by modification, originates Light endued with effulgence. Beautiful and called also Shukram, it is thus created, possessing the attribute of Form.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महानात्मा तथाव्यक्तमहंकारस्तथैव च। इन्द्रियाणि दशैकं च महाभूतानि पञ्च च॥ विशेषाः पञ्चभूतानामिति सर्गः सनातनः। चतुर्विंशतिरेका च तत्त्वसंख्या प्रकीर्तिता॥
English Translation: From light, by modification, originates Water having taste for its attribute. From Water originates Earth having Scent for its attribute. These are said to represent primary creation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्त्वानामथ यो वेद सर्वेषां प्रभवाप्ययौ। स धीरः सर्वभूतेषु न मोहमधिगच्छति॥
English Translation: These, in succession, acquire the attributes of the immediately preceding ones from which they have originated. Each has not only its own special attribute but each succeeding one has the attributes of all the previous ones.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्त्वानि यो वेदयते यथातथं गुणांश्च सर्वानखिलांश्च देवताः। विधूतपाप्मा प्रतिमुच्य बन्धनं स सर्वलोकानमलान् समश्नुते॥
English Translation: If anybody, perceiving Scent in Water, were from ignorance to say that it belongs to Water, he would make a mistake, for Scent is the attribute of Earth though it may exist in Water and also Wind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच विदार्य कर्णस्तां सेनां युधिष्ठिरमथाद्रवत्। रथहस्त्यश्वपत्तीनां सहस्रः परिवारितः॥
English Translation: These seven kinds of entities, possessing various kinds of energy, at first existed separately from one another. They could not create objects without all of them acting in a body.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नानायुधसहस्राणि प्रेरिततान्यरिभिर्वृषः। छित्वा बाणशतैरुगैस्तानविध्यदसम्भ्रमात्॥
English Translation: All these great entities coming together, and mixing with one another, form the constituent parts of the body which are called limbs.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निचकर्त शिरांस्येषां बाहूनूरूंश्च सूतजः। ते हता वसुधां पेतुर्भग्नाश्चान्ये विदुद्रुवः॥
English Translation: On account of the combination of those limbs,-the sum-total, invested with form and having sixteen constituent parts, becomes what is called the body, (When the gross body is thus forined), the subtile principle of greatness, with the unexhausted remnant of acts, then enters that combination called the gross body.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्राविडास्तु निषादास्तु पुनः सात्यकिचोदिताः। अभ्यद्रवञ्जिघांसन्तः पत्तयः कर्णमाहवे॥
English Translation: The original Creator of all beings, then having by His Maya divided Himself, enters that subtile form for overloO king everything. And because he is the original Creator of all beings he is called the lord of all beings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते विबाहुशिरस्त्राणाः प्रहताः कर्णसायकैः। पेतुः पृथिव्यां युगपच्छिन्नं शालवनं यथा॥
English Translation: It is he who creates all beings mobile and immobile. After having thus assumed the form the Brahman, he creates the worlds of the gods, the Rishis, the Pitris, and men; the rivers, the Seas and the oceans, the cardinal points, countries and provinces, hills and mountains, and large trees, human beings, Kinnaras, Rakshasas, birds, animals domestic and wild, and snakes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं योधशतान्याजौ सहस्राण्ययुतानि चः। तानीयुर्महीं देहैर्यशसा पूरयन्दिशः॥
English Translation: He creates both kinds of mobile and immobile; and those that are destructible and those that are indestructible. Of theses created objects each gets those attributes which it had during the previous Creation; and each obtains repeatedly the attributes at every subsequent Creation. Having a formed character by either injuriousness peacefulness, mildness fierceness, righteousness or unrighteousness, truthfulness, or untruthfulness, each creature, at every new creation, gets that particular attribute which it had got before. For this the particular attribute attaches to it. same or or
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अत वैकर्तनं कर्णं रणे क्रुद्धमिवान्तकम्। रुरुधुः पाण्डुपाञ्चाला व्यार्घि मन्त्रौषधैरिव॥
English Translation: It is the Ordained himself who attaches variety to the great entities to the objects of the senses and to size or bulk of existent matter, and settles the relations of creatures with those various entities.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तान् प्रमृद्याभ्यपतत् पुनरेव युधिष्ठिरम्। मन्त्रौषधिक्रियातीतो व्याधिरत्युल्बणौ यथा॥
English Translation: Of men who had devoted themselves to the science of things, there are some who say that, in the production of effects, Exertion is supreme. Some learned persons hold that Destiny is supreme, and some that it is Nature which is the agent.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स राजगृद्धिभी रुदः पाण्डुपञ्चालाकेकयौः। नाशकत् तानतिक्रान्तुं मृत्युब्रह्मविदो यथा॥
English Translation: Others hold that Acts flowing from Exertion and Destiny, produce effects, helped by Nature. Instead of considering any of these as alone powerful for the production of effects, they say that it is the union of all three that produces all effects.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो युधिष्ठिरः कर्णमदूरस्थं निवारितम्। अब्रवीत् परवीरनं क्रोधसंरक्तलोचनः॥
English Translation: About this subject, some say that such is the case; some, that such is not the case; some, that both of these are not the case; and some that it is not that the reverse of both are not. These, of course, are the contentions of those who depend on Acts, with reference to objects. They, however, whose see the truth consider Brahma as the causes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्ण कर्ण वृथादृष्टे सूतपुत्र वचः शृणु। सदा स्पर्धसि संग्रामे फाल्गुनेन तरस्विना॥ तथास्मान् बाधसे नित्यं धार्तराष्ट्रमते स्थितः।
English Translation: Penance is the greatest good for living creatures. The roots of penance are tranquillity and self-control. By penance one acquires all things that he longs for in his mind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यद् बलं यच ते वीर्यं प्रद्वेषो यस्तु पाण्डषु॥ तत् सर्वं दर्शयस्वाद्य पौरुषं महदास्थितः। युद्धश्रद्धां च तेऽद्याहं विनेष्यामि महाहवे॥
English Translation: By penance one attains to that Being who creates the universe. He who thus succeeds in attaining to that Being becomes the powerful lord of all beings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्त्वा महाराज कर्णं पाण्डुसुतस्तदा। सुवर्णपुबैर्दशभिर्विव्याधायस्मयैः शरैः॥
English Translation: it is by penance that the Rishis can read the Vedas without interruption. In the beginning the self-create caused those excellent Vedic sounds, that are embodiments of knowledge and that have neither beginning nor end. From those sounds have sprung all sorts of actions.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं सूतपुत्रो दशभिः प्रत्यविद्ध्यदरिंदमः। वत्सदन्तैर्महेष्वासः प्रहसन्निव भारत॥
English Translation: The names of the Rishis, all things that have been created, the varieties of form seen in things, and the course of all actions, have all originated from the Vedas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सोऽवज्ञाय तु निर्विद्धः सूतपुत्रेण मारिष। प्रजज्वाल ततः क्रोधाद्धविषेव हुताशनः॥
English Translation: Indeed, in the beginning the Supreme Lord of all beings, ceated all things from the words of the Vedas. Truly, the names of the Rishis, and all else that has been created, are seen in the Vedas. Upon the expiration of his night, the Increate Brahman creates, from models that existed before, all things which are, of course, weil-made by Him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ज्वालामालापरिक्षिप्तो राज्ञो देहो व्यदृश्यत। युगान्ते दग्धुकामस्य संवर्ताग्नेरिवापरः॥
English Translation: in the Vedas has been described the subject of the Soul's Liberation, along with the ten means formed by study of the Vedas, adoption of the domestic mode of life. penances, observance of all duties, common to all the modes of life, sacrifices, performance of all acts leading to pure fame meditation which is of three kinds, and that kind of Liberation called success (Siddhi) attainable in this life.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो विस्फार्य सुमहचापं हेमपरिष्कृतम्। समाधत्त शितं बाणं गिरीणामपि दारणम्॥
English Translation: That incomprehensible Brahma which has been described in the words of the Vedas, and which has been described more clearly in the Upanishads by those who have an insight into the Vedas, can be realised by gradually following the practices referred to above.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः पूर्णायतोत्कृष्टं यमदण्डनिभं शरम्। मुमोच त्वरितो राजा सूतपुत्रजिघांसया॥
English Translation: This consciousness of duality, fraught again with that of pairs opposites, is born only of acts in which he is engaged to a person who thinks he has a body. That person, however, who has attained to Liberation aided by his knowledge, drives off by force that consciousness of duality.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तु वेगवता मुक्तो बाणो वज्राशनिस्वनः। विवेश सहसा कर्ण सव्ये पार्श्वे महारथम्॥
English Translation: Two Brahmas should be known viz., the Brahma represented by the Vedas and that which is beyond the Vedas and is supreme. One who is conversant with Brahma represented by sound succeeds in attaining to Brahma that is Supreme.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तु तेन प्रहारेण पीडितः प्रमुमोह वै। स्त्रस्तगात्रो महाबाहुर्धनरुत्सृज्य स्यन्दने॥
English Translation: The destruction of animals is the sacrifice sanctioned for the Kshatriyas. The growing of corn is the sacrifice sanctioned for the Vaisshyas. Serving the three other orders is the sacrifice sanctioned for the Shudras. Penance is the sacrifice sanctioned for the Brahmanas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गतासुरिव निश्चेताः शल्यस्याभिमुखोऽपतत्। राजापि भूयो नाजघ्ने कर्ण पार्थहितेप्सया॥
English Translation: In the Krita age the perforinance of sacrifices was not required. Such performance became necessary in the Treta age. In the Dvapara, sacrifices have begun to fall off. In the Kali, the same is the case with them,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो हाहाकृतं सर्व धार्तराष्ट्रबलं महत्। विवर्णमुखभूयिष्ठं कर्णं दृष्ट्वा तथागतम्॥
English Translation: In the Krita age, worshipping only one Brahma, men regarded the Richs, the Samans, the Yajushas, and the rites and sacrifices that are performed from motives of advantage, as all different from the object of their worship, and practised only Yoga by means of penances.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सिंहनादश्च संजज्ञे श्वेला: किलकिलास्तथा। पाण्डवानां महाराज दृष्ट्वा राज्ञः पराक्रमम्॥
English Translation: In the Treta age, many powerful men flourished who governed all mobile and immobile objects.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रतिलभ्य तु राधेयः संज्ञा नातिचिरादिव। दने राजविनाशाय मनः क्रूरपराक्रमः॥
English Translation: Accordingly, in that age, the Vedas, and sacrifices, and the distinctions between the several orders, and the four modes of life, existed in a body. On account, however, of the decrease in the period of life in Dvapara, all these, it that age, fall off from that compact condition.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स हेमविकृतं चापं विस्फार्य विजयं महत्। अवाकिरदमेयात्मा पाण्डवं निशितैः शरै॥
English Translation: In the Kali age, all the Vedas become so scarce that they are not seen by men. Afflicted by iniquity, they become extinct along with the rites and sacrifices laid down in them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः क्षुराध्यां पाञ्चाल्यौ चक्ररक्षौ महात्मनः। जघान चन्द्रदेवं च दण्डधारं च संयुगे॥
English Translation: The righteousness which is seen in the Krita age is now seen in such Brahmanas as are of purified souls and as are devoted to penances and the study of the scriptures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तावुभौ धर्मराजस्य प्रवीरौ परिपार्श्वतः। स्थाभ्याशे चकाशेते चन्द्रस्येव पुनर्वसू॥
English Translation: As regards the other cycles, it is seen that without at once giving up the duties and acts that are consistent with righteousness, men, observing the practices of their respective orders, and conversant with the ordinances of the Vedas, are led, by the authority of the scriptures, and from motives of advantage and interest to perform sacrifices and vows and sojourns to sacred waters and places.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिरं: पुन: कर्णमविद्धयतं त्रिंशता शरैः। सुषेणं सत्यसेनं च त्रिभिस्त्रिभिरताडयत्॥
English Translation: As in the rainy reason a large variety of new objets of the immobile order are caused to come into being by the showers that fall from the clouds, so many new kinds of duty or religious observances are brought about in each new cycle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शल्यं नवत्या विव्याध त्रिसप्तया च सूतजम्। तांस्तस्य गोप्तन् विव्याध त्रिभिस्त्रिभिरजिह्मगैः॥
English Translation: As the same phenomena reappear with the reappearance of the seasons, so, at each new Creation of the same attributes appear in each new Brahman and Hara.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः प्रहस्ताधिरथिर्विधुन्वानः स कार्मुकम्। भित्वा भल्लेन राजानं विद्ध्वा षष्टयाऽनदत्तदा॥
English Translation: I have, before this, spoken to you of Time which is without beginning and without end, which ordains this variety in the universe. It is that Time which creates and destroys all creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत: प्रवीराः पाण्डूनामभ्यधावन्नमर्षिताः। युधिष्ठिरं परीप्सन्तः कर्णमभ्यर्दयञ्छरैः॥
English Translation: All the numberless creatures which exist subject to pairs of opposites and according to their respective natures, have Time for their refuge. It is Time that puts on those forms and it is Time which upholds them.]
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सात्यकिश्चेकितानश्च युयुत्सुः पाण्डव एव च। धृष्टद्युम्नः शिखण्डी च द्रौपदेयाः प्रभद्रका॥ यमौ च भीमसेनश्च शिशुपालस्य चात्मजः। कारूषा मत्स्यशेषाश्च केकथाः काशिकोसलाः॥ एते च त्वरिता वीरा वसुषेणमताडयन्।
English Translation: I have thus described to you, O son, the topics about which you had asked, viz., Creation, Time, Sacrifices and other rites, the Vedas, the real actor in the universe, action, and the results of action.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जनमेजयश्च पाञ्चाल्यः कर्णं विव्याध सायकैः॥ वाराहाकर्णनाराचैर्नालीकैर्निशितैः शरैः। वत्सदन्तैर्विपाठैश्च क्षुरप्रैश्चटकामुखैः॥ नानाप्रहरणैश्चोत्रै रथहस्तश्वसादिभिः। सर्वतोऽभ्यद्रवत् कर्णं परिवार्य जिघांसया॥
English Translation: Janamejaya said : These acts of the immeasurably effulgent Partha (Arjuna) are (no doubt) wonderful. O Brahmana, what did greatly wise Dhritarashtra say on hearing (all this)?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स पाण्डवानां प्रवरैः सर्वतः समभिद्रुतः। उदीरयन् ब्राह्ममस्त्रं शरैरापूरयद् दिशः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Having heard from the foremost of Rishis, Krishna Dvaipayana, that Partha (Arjuna) had gone to the abode of Indra, the son of Ambika, the king Dhritarashtra, thus spoke to Sanjaya.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः शरमहज्वालौ वीर्योष्मा कर्णपावकः। निर्दहन् पाण्डववनं वीरः पर्यचरद् रणे॥
English Translation: Dhritarashtra said : O charioteer, O Suta, do you know in detail the acts of the wise Arjuna which I have heard from the beginning to end?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स संधाय महास्त्राणि महेष्वासा महामनाः। प्रहस्य पुरुषेन्द्रस्य शरैश्चिच्छेद कार्मुकम्॥
English Translation: Mad in performing acts of the most vulgar kind, my wicked-minded and ever sinful son of wicked policies will destroy the earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत: संधाय नवति निमेषान्नतपर्वणाम्। बिभेद कवचं राज्ञो रणे कर्णः शितैः शरै॥
English Translation: That high-souled one (Yudhishthira) whose words are ever true and who has Dhananjaya (Arjuna) to fight for him will certainly conquer the three worlds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तद् वर्म हेमविकृतं रत्नचित्रं बभौ पतत्। सविद्युदभ्रं सवितुः श्लिष्टं वातहतं यथा॥
English Translation: Is there any one who is even beyond the influence of death and decrepitude, that will be able to stand before Arjuna when he will shower his barbed and sharp-pointed arrows sharpened on the stone?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदङ्गात् पुरुषेन्द्रस्य भ्रष्टं वर्म व्यरोचत। रत्नलंकृत चित्रैर्व्यभ्रं निशि यथा नभः॥ छिन्नवर्मा शरैः पार्थो रुधिरेण समुक्षितः।
English Translation: My wicked-minded sons, who will have to fight with the invincible Pandavas are all under the influence of Death.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः सर्वायसीं शक्तिं चिक्षेपाधिरथिं प्रति॥ तां ज्वलन्तीमिवाकाशे शरैश्चिच्छेद सप्तभिः। सा छिन्ना भूमिमगमन्महेष्वासस्य सायकैः॥
English Translation: Reflecting day and night I do not see amongst us that warrior who will be able to stand in battle before the wielder of the Gandiva (Arjuna).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो बाह्वोर्ललाटे च हृदि चैव युधिष्ठिरः। चतुर्भिस्तोमरैः कर्णं ताडयित्वानदन्मुदा॥
English Translation: Even if Drona, Karna or Bhishma advance against him in battle, there will befall a great calamity over the world. But I do not see even there any chance of our Victory.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उद्भिनरुधिरः कर्णः क्रुद्धः सर्प इव श्वसन्। ध्वजं चिच्छेद भल्लेन त्रिभिर्विव्याध पाण्डवम्॥ इषुधी चास्य चिच्छेद रथं च तिलशोऽच्छिनत्।
English Translation: Karna is kind and forgetful, the preceptor (Drona) is old and he is (also Arjuna's) tutor. But Arjuna is wrathful, strong, proud and greatly powerful. As all these heroes are invincible, all skilled in weapons and all illustrious, a fearful battle will take place between thein.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कालवालास्तु ये पार्थं दन्तवर्णावहन् हयाः॥ तैर्युक्तं रथमास्थाय प्रायाद् राजा पराङमुखः।
English Translation: They will not desire even the sovereignty of the whole world, if it is at all to be had by defeat; peace will be established only at the death of either of these (Bhishma etc.) or Falguni (Arjuna).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं पार्थोऽभ्युपायात् स निहतः पाणिंसारथिः॥ अशक्नुवन् प्रमुखतः स्थातुं कर्णस्य दुर्मनाः।
English Translation: But he, who will be able to kill Arjuna, does not exist, nor even he who will defeat him. How shall that wrath of his which has myself for its object be appeased?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभिद्रुत्य तु राधेयः पाण्डुपुत्रं युधिष्ठिरम्॥ वज्रच्छत्रांकुशैर्मतस्यैर्ध्वजकूर्मम्बुजादिभिः। लक्षणैरुपपन्नेन पाण्डुना पाण्डुनन्दनम्॥ पवित्रीकर्तुमात्मानं स्कन्धे संस्पृश्य पाणिना। ग्रहीतुमिच्छन् स बलात् कुन्तीवाक्यं च सोऽस्मरत्॥
English Translation: That hero, equal to the lord of the celestials gratified Agni at Khandava. He vanquished all the rulers of the earth at the time of the great Rajasuya sacrifice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं शल्यः प्राह मा कर्ण गृहीथाः पार्थिवोत्तमम्। गृहीतमात्रो हत्वा त्वां मा करिष्यति भस्मसात्॥
English Translation: O Sanjaya, O child, even the thunderbolt, that falls on the mountain peak, leaves a portion unburnt, but the arrows, shot by Kirti (Arjuna) do not leave anything behind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अब्रवीत प्रहसन् राजन् कुत्सयन्निव पाण्डवम्। कथं नाम कुले जातः क्षत्रधर्मे व्यवस्थितः॥ प्रजह्यात् समरं भीतः प्राणान् रक्षन् महाहवे। न भवान् क्षत्रधर्मेषु कुशलो हीति मे मतिः॥
English Translation: As the rays of the sun scorch mobile and immobile universe, so will the arrows, shot by the arins of Partha, scorch all my sons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मे बले भवान् युक्तः स्वाध्याये यज्ञकर्मणि। मा स्म युद्ध्यस्व कौन्तेय मा स्म वीरान् समासदः॥
English Translation: It seems to me that the Chamus (armies) of the Bharatas have already run away in all directions, being terrified at the clatter of Arjuna's chariot wheels.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मा चैतानप्रियं ब्रूहि मा वै व्रज महारणम्। वक्तव्या मारिषान्से तु न वक्तव्यास्तु मादृशाः॥
English Translation: Vidhata (creator) has created Kirti (Arjuna) as our all-destroying, destroyer. He stands as a foe in the battle, scattering and vomiting swarms of arrows. Who is there that will defeat him?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मादृशान् विद्वावन् युद्धे एतदन्यच्च लप्स्यसे। स्वगृहं गच्छ कौन्तेय यत्र तौ केशवार्जुनौ॥ न हि त्वां समरे राजन् हन्यात् कर्णः कथञ्चन।
English Translation: Karna said I am Karna, the son of Radha and the son of Adhiratha and I salute you. Why are you come here? Tell me what I shall do for you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्त्वा ततः पार्थ विसृज्य च महाबलः॥ न्यहनत् पाण्डवीं सेनां वज्रहस्त इवासुरीम्।
English Translation: Kunti said You are the son of Kunti and not the son of Radha; nor is Adhiratha your father; you are not born in the race of Suta; know this word of mine to be true.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽपायाद् दुतं राजन् वीडन्निव नरेश्वरः॥ अथापयति राजानं मत्वान्वीयुस्तमच्युतम्। चेदिपाण्डवपञ्चालाः सात्यक्श्चि महारथः॥ द्रौपदेयास्तथा शूरा माद्रीपुत्रौ च पाण्डवौ।
English Translation: You were begotten on me when I was an unmarried girl and you were the first held in my womb; you were born in the palace of Kuntiraja, my dear son.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो युधिष्ठिरानीकं दृष्ट्वा पराङ्मुखम्॥ कुरुभिः सहिता वीरः प्रहृष्टः पृष्ठतोऽन्वगात्।
English Translation: The god Tapana or Virochana (Surya) whose duty it is to make everything visible, begot you on me, O Karna, O you foremost of wielders of weapons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भेरीशङ्गमृदङ्गानां कार्मुकाणां च निःस्वनः॥ बभूव धार्तराष्ट्राणां सिंहनादरवस्तथा।
English Translation: O my son, you who are hard to conquer, were brought forth in my father's place by me, and you then wore earrings, and were clad in coats of mail, like a divine being endued with great beauty.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्ण: युधिष्ठिरस्तु कौरव्य रथमारुद्य सत्वरम्॥ श्रुतकीर्तेर्महाराज दृष्ट्वान् कर्णविक्रमम्।
English Translation: You, who are such, are now, without recognizing your brothers owing to ignorance (of the true story), serving the sons of Dhritarashtra; it is not proper and especially for you, my son.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: काल्यमानं बलं दृष्ट्वा धमराजो युधिष्ठिरः॥ स्वान् योधानब्रवीत् क्रुद्धो निघ्नतैतान् किमासत।
English Translation: It is certainly the duty of men inclined to virtue, my son, to gratify one's father and mother who alone can view things in their proper light.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो राज्ञाभ्यनुज्ञाताः पाण्डवानां महारथः॥ भीमसेनमुखाः सर्वे पुत्रास्ते प्रत्युपाद्रवन्।
English Translation: Snatching from the son of Dhritarashtra, the royal dignity of Yudhishthira, which was originally earned by Arjuna but has now been usurped from them by dishonest persons out of avarice, you enjoy it yourself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभवत् तुमुलः शब्दो योधानां तत्र भारत॥ रथहस्त्यश्वपत्तीनां शस्त्राणां च ततस्ततः।
English Translation: Let the Kurus see today the union between Karna and Arjuna and seeing the establishment of brotherly feelings between them let dishonest men bow down.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उत्तिष्ठत प्रहरत प्रेताभिपततेति च॥ इति ब्रुवाणा ह्यन्योन्यं जघ्नुर्योधा महारणे।
English Translation: Karna and Arjuna being united like Rama and Janardana what is there which can not be performed by you in the world?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभ्रच्छायेव तन्नासीच्छरवृष्टिभिरम्बरे॥ समावृतैर्नरवरैर्निनद्भिरितरेतरम्।
English Translation: O Karna, you will surely shine surrounded by your five brothers like Brahma surrounded by the gods seated on the dais on the occasion of a great sacrificial ceremony.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विपताकध्वच्छत्रा व्यश्वसूतायुधा रणे॥ व्यङ्गाङ्गावयवाः पेतुः क्षितौ क्षीणा:क्षितीश्वराः।
English Translation: Endued with all accomplishments you are eldest among all my best relatives; do not use again the term “the son of a Suta" for you are the son of Pritha, endued with prowess.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रवणादिव शैलानां शिखराणि द्विपोत्तमाः॥ सारोहा निहताः पेतुर्ववभिन्ना इवाद्रयः।
English Translation: Sauti said : The illustrious king having said so, the ministers expressed their approbation. The king expressed his determination of performing a Snake-sacrifice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: छिन्नभिन्नविपर्यस्तैर्वर्मालङ्कारभूषणैः॥ सारोहास्तुरगाः पेतुर्हरवीराः सहस्रशः।
English Translation: The Lord of the earth, the best of the Kurus, king (Janamejaya) the son of Parikshit, then called his priest and Ritvijas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विप्रविद्धायुधाश्चैव द्विरदाश्वरथैर्हताः॥ प्रतिवीरैश्च सम्म पत्तिसंघाः सहस्रशः।
English Translation: And that accomplished speaker spoke on the accomplishment of his great task. (He said), “I must avenge on that wretch Takshaka.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विशालायतताम्राक्षैः पद्मेन्दुसदृशाननैः॥ शिरोभियुद्धशौण्डानां सर्वतः संवृत्ता मही। यथा भुवि तथा व्योम्नि नि:स्वनं शुश्रुवुर्जनाः॥ विमानैरप्सरः सङ्गैर्गीतवादिनि:स्वनैः।
English Translation: Tell me what I must do. Do you know any act by which I can throw Takshaka with all his friends and relatives in the blazing fire? I want to burn the wretch of a snake as he burnt my father with his poison.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हतानभिमुखान् वीरान् वीरैः शतसहस्रशः॥ आरोप्यारोप्य गच्छन्ति विमानेष्वप्सरोगणाः।
English Translation: The Ritwijas said : O king, there is a sacrifice advised by the celestials for you. It is known as the Snakesacrifice and is spoken of in the Puranas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तद् दृष्ट्वा महदाश्चर्यं प्रत्यक्षं स्वर्गलिप्सया॥ प्रहष्टमनसः शूराः क्षिप्रं जघ्नुः परस्परम्।
English Translation: O king, you alone can accomplish it and no one else. The men, learned in the Puranas, have told us that there is such a sacrifice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रथिनो रथिभिः सार्धं चित्र युयुधुराहवे॥ पत्तयः पत्तिभिर्नागा: सह नागैर्हयैर्हयाः।
English Translation: Sauti said : O excellent one, thus addressed, that royal sage thought Takshaka already thrown into the blazing fire and burnt to ashes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं प्रवृत्ते संग्रामे गजवादिनरक्षये॥ सैन्येन रजसा व्याप्ते स्वे स्वाञ्जघ्नुः परे परान्।
English Translation: The king then told these Brahmanas, learned in Mantras, “I shall perform that sacrifice. Tell me the things that are necessary.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कचाकचि युद्धमासीद् दन्तादन्ति नखानखि॥ मुष्टियुद्धं नियुद्धं च देहपाप्मासुनाशनम्।
English Translation: O best of Biahmanas, thereupon his wise Ritwijas, learned in the Shastras, measured, according to the ordinances, a piece of land for the sacrificial platform.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथा वर्तति संग्रामे गजवाजिनरक्षये॥ नराश्वनागदेहेभ्यः प्रसृता लोहितापगा। गजाश्वनरदेहान् सा व्युवाह पतितान् बहून्॥
English Translation: It was graced by the presence of holy Brahmanas; it was decked with much valuable wealth; it was full of wealth and paddy. On this sacrificial platform they according to rites installed the king in the Snake-sacrifice. But before the commencement of the sacrifice happened.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नराश्वगजसम्बाधे नराश्वगजसादिनाम्। लोहितोदा महाघोरा मांसशोणितकर्दमा॥ नराश्वगजदेहानां सा वहन्ती भीरुभीषणा।
English Translation: An incident which foreboded a hindrance to it. For when the sacrificial platform was being built, a man, Suta by caste, well acquainted with the Puranas and learned in the art of masonry and of laying foundations, said,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्याः पारमपारं च व्रजन्ति विजयैषिणः॥ गाधेन चोप्लवन्तश्च निमज्योन्मज्य चापरे।
English Translation: “The land in which the platform was made and the time when it was measured indicate that this sacrifice will not be completed. A Brahmana will be its cause."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तु लोहितदिग्धाङ्गा रक्तवर्मायुधाम्बराः॥ शस्त्रुस्तस्यां पपुश्चास्यां मम्लुश्च भरतर्षभ।
English Translation: Having heard this, the king, before he was installed in the sacrifice, ordered the gate keepers, saying, “None must be allowed to enter here without my permission."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते रथानश्वान् नरान नागानायुधाभरणानि च॥ वसनान्यथ वर्माणि वध्यमानान् हतानापि। भूमि खं द्यां दिशश्चैव प्रायः पश्याम लोहिताः॥
English Translation: Brihadashva said: There was a heroic king, named Nala the son of Virasena. He was possessed of desirable attainments, handsome and well-acquainted with the management of horses.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: लोहित्य तु गन्धेन स्पर्शेन च रसेन च। रूपेण चातिरक्तेन शब्देन च विसर्पता॥ विषादः सुमहानासीत् प्राय: सैन्यस्य भारत।
English Translation: He stood at the head of all the princes, even as the king of the celestials; and exalted above all, was equal to the sun in splendour. He was the well-wisher of the Brahmanas and the lord of the Nishadhas. He was truthful, the commander of a mighty force, consisting of cavalry and infantry and a large number of chariots and elephants but fond of gaming at dice,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत् तु विप्रहतं सैन्यं भीमसेनमुखास्तदा॥ भूयः समाद्रवनं वीराः सात्यकिप्रमुखास्तदा।
English Translation: He was beloved of women, high-souled and with all passions checked. He was also the refuge of all and the best of bowmen and was like Manu himself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषामापततां वेगमविषह्यं निरीक्ष्य च॥ पुत्राणां ते महासैन्यमासीद् राजन् पराङ्मुखम्।
English Translation: Like him (Nala) there was a king among the Vidarbhas, named Bhima, who was warlike, possessor of immense power and all accomplishments and beloved of his subjects. But with all these virtues he was without an issue.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत् प्रकीर्णरथाश्वेभं नरवाजिसमाकुलम्॥ विध्वस्तवर्मकवचं प्रविद्धायुधकार्मुकम्। व्यद्रवत् तावकं सैन्यं लोड्यमानं समन्ततः। सिंहार्दितमिवारण्ये यथा गजकुलं तथा॥
English Translation: He, with a fixity of purpose, made great endeavour for obtaining issue. O Bharata, there came before him, a Brahmarishi named Damana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजोवाच न निकृत्या न दम्भेन ब्रह्मन्निच्छामि जीवितुम्। नाधर्मयुक्तानिच्छेयमर्थान् सुमहतोऽप्यहम्॥
English Translation: Thereupon, O king of kings, the virtuous prince, Bhima, assisted by his wife, satisfied that reverened sage with the most respectful offerings. Damana, thus pleased, conferred upon the king and his spouse a boon of a daughter like unto a jewel and three sons possessed of liberal heart and great fame.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुरस्तादेव भगवन् मयैतदपवर्जितम्। येन मां नाभिशङ्केत येन कृत्स्नं हितं भवेत्॥ आनृशंस्येन धर्मेण लोके ह्यस्मिन् जिजीविषुः। नाहमेतदलं कर्तुं नैतत् त्वय्युपपद्यते॥
English Translation: The daughter and the three sons were named Damayanti and Dama, Danta and the illustrious Damana. The latter were possessed of all the virtues, most fearful and of terrible might.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मुनिरुवाच उपपन्नस्त्वमेतेन यथा क्षत्रिय भाषसे। प्रकृत्या ह्युपपन्नोऽसि बुद्ध्या वा बहुदर्शनः॥
English Translation: But Damayanti of slender waist, obtained celebrity all ever the world in beauty and brightness and in good name, luck and glory.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उभयोरेव वामर्थे यतिष्ये तव तस्य च। संश्लेषं वा करिष्यामि शाश्वतं पनपायिनम्॥
English Translation: And when she attained to age, hundreds and hundreds of female servants and hand-raids, decked in ornaments, waited on her like Sachi herself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वादृशं कि कुले जातमनृशंसं बहुश्रुतम्। अमात्यं को न कुर्वीत राज्यप्रणयकोविदम्॥
English Translation: There shone in the midst of her hand-maids the daughter of Bhima, of beautiful features and decked with all ornaments like the bright lightning of the sky.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यस्त्वं प्रच्यावितो राज्याद् व्यसनं चोत्तमं गतः। आनृशंस्येन वृत्तेन क्षत्रियेच्छसि जीवितुम्॥
English Translation: The damsel was possessed of extra-ordinary beauty and large eyes and was like Lakshmi (the goddess of riches) herself. Indeed, there was none among the celestials or the Yakshasa who could be compared with her.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आगन्ता मद्गहं तात वैदेहः सत्यसंगरः। अथाहं तं नियोक्ष्यामि तत् करिष्यत्यसंशयम्॥
English Translation: No body among men or others, was possessed of such beauty, seen or heard of. In fact, the damsel was most pleasant to look at and more handsome than the celestials.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत आहूय वैदेहं मुनिर्वचनमब्रवीत्। अयं राजकुले जातो विदिताभ्यन्तरो मम॥
English Translation: That foremost of men, Nala, was peerless in the worlds; because on earth he resembled in beauty Kandarpa (the god of love) himself in his embodied form.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आदर्श इव शुद्धात्मा शारदश्चन्द्रमा यथा। नास्मिन् पश्यामि वृजिनं सर्वतो मे परीक्षितः॥
English Translation: Moved with admiration, they (the heralds) again and again uttered the praises of Nala before her (Damayanti) and those of Damayanti before the king of the Nishadhas, Nala.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेन ते संधिरेवास्तु विश्वसास्मिन् यथा मयि। न राज्यमनमात्येन शक्यं शास्तुमपि त्र्यहम्॥
English Translation: Although they had not seen each other, yet they conceived a love (for each other) produced by their repeatedly hearing each other's accomplishments. O son of Kunti, that mutual attachment began to grow very strong.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अमात्यः शूर एव स्याद् बुद्धिसम्पन्न एव वा। ताभ्यां चैवोभयं राजन् पश्य राज्यप्रयोजनम्॥
English Translation: And then Nala, incapable of holding it in his bosom, passed much of his time in solitude in the gardens adjacent to the inner apartments (of his palace).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धर्मात्मनां क्व चिल्लोके नान्यास्ति गतिरीदृशी। महात्मा राजपुत्रोऽयं सतां मार्गमनुष्ठितः॥
English Translation: There he saw, one day, a lot of swans, with golden wings, roving in those woods. Of them he caught one with his hands.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुसंगृहीतस्त्वेवैष त्वया धर्मपुरोगमः। संसेव्यमानः शत्रूस्ते गृह्णीयान्महतो गणान्॥
English Translation: Thereupon that sky-roving one spoke unto Nala. "O king, it behoves you not to kill me. I will render some good to you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यद्ययं प्रतियुद्ध्येत् त्वां स्वकर्म क्षत्रियस्य तत्। जिगीषमाणस्त्वां युद्धे पितृपैतामहे पदे॥ त्वं चापि प्रतियुद्ध्येथा विजिगीषुव्रते स्थितः। अयुध्वैव नियोगान्मे वशे कुरु हिते स्थितः॥
English Translation: O prince of the Nishadhas, I will speak of you before Damayanti and in such a manner that she will never mind to have any other person (for her lord) but yourself."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स त्वं धर्ममवेक्षस्व हित्वा लोभमसाम्प्रतम्। न च कामान्न च द्रोहात् स्वधर्मं हातुमर्हसि॥
English Translation: Thus spoken, the king liberated the swan. Thereafter the swans, spreading their wings, betook themselves to the country of the Vidharbhas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नैव नित्यं जयस्तात नैव नित्वं पराजयः। तस्माद् भोजयतिव्यश्च भोक्तव्यश्च परो जनः॥
English Translation: Arriving at the city of the Vidharbhas the birds alighted from heaven before Damayanti, who also beheld them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आत्मन्यपि च संदृश्यावुभौ जयपराजयौ। निःशेषकारिणां तात निःशेषकरणाद् भयम्॥
English Translation: Damayanti surrounded by her hand-maids, having seen those birds of extraordinary beauty, desired to catch those rovers of the skies without loss of time.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्युक्तः प्रत्युवाचेदं वचनं ब्राह्मणर्षभम्। प्रतिपूज्याभिसत्कृत्य पूजार्हमनुमान्य च॥ यथा ब्रूयान्महाप्राज्ञो यथा ब्रूयान्महाश्रुतः। श्रेयस्कामो यथा ब्रूयादुभयोरेव तत् क्षमम्॥ यद् यद् वचनमुक्तोऽस्मि करिष्यामि च तत् तथा। एतद्धि परमं श्रेयो न मेऽत्रास्ति विचारणा॥
English Translation: Thereupon the swans fled in all directions in that charming forcst; and the ladies ran after them, each pursuing one.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः कौसल्यमाहूय मैथिलो वाक्यमब्रवीत्। धर्मतो नीतितश्चैव लोकश्च विजितो मया॥
English Translation: The swan which Damayanti pursued, led her into a solitary corner of the gardens and addressed her a human speech the following words,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अहं त्वया चात्मगुणैर्जितः पार्थिवसत्तम। आत्मानमनवज्ञाय जितवद् वर्ततां भवान्॥
English Translation: “O Damayanti, there is a prince among the Nishadhas, named Nala, who is in beauty, like the Ashvins; and he has not his equal among men.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नावमन्यामि ते बुद्धिं नावमन्ये च पौरुषम्। नावमन्ये जयामिति जितवद् वर्ततां भवान्।॥
English Translation: In beauty he is like Kandarpa (the god of love) himself in his embodied form. O fair complexioned one, if you becomes his wife. O you of slender waist, your birth and also your beauty may be of some avail. We have, as a matter of fact, seen celestials, Gandharvas, men, Nagas and Rakshasas; but never have we seen one like him (Nala). As you are a jewel among the maidens, so Nala is the best among men. The best united with the best is of merit.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथावत् पूजितो राजन् गृहं गन्तासि मे भृशम्। ततः सम्पूज्य तौ विप्रं विश्वस्तौ जग्मतुर्ग्रहान्॥
English Translation: O Prince, Damayanti, was in the above way addressed by the swan. She (Damayanti) in retum said to the swan, “you also thus speak unto Nala."O Prince, the bird having uttered to the daughter of Vidharbha "So be it" returned to the country of the Nishadhas and described everything to Nala himself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैदेहस्त्वथ कौसल्यं प्रवेश्य गृहमञ्जसा। पाद्यार्घ्यमधुपर्केस्तं पूजाहँ प्रत्यपूजयत्॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said Even the most insignificant act, O grandfather, cannot be accomplished by any man without co-operation. What then need be said of the king (who has to govern a kingdom)?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ददौ दुहितरं चास्मै रत्नानि विविधानि च। एष राज्ञां परो धर्मोऽनित्यौ जयपराजयौ॥
English Translation: How should the king's minister act and behave? Upon whom should the king place confidence, and upon whom he should not?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच प्रभातायां तु शर्वर्यां तेषामक्लिष्टकर्मणाम्। वनं यियासतां विप्रास्तस्थुर्भिक्षाभुजोऽचतः॥
English Translation: Bhishma said Kings, O monarch, have four sorts of friends. They are-one who has the same object, one who is devoted, one who is related by birth, and one who has been won over (by gifts and kindness).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तानुवाच ततो राजा कुन्तीपुत्रो युधिष्ठरः। वयं हि हृतसर्वस्वा हृतराज्या हृतश्रियः॥ फलमूलाशनाहारा वनं गच्छाम दुःखिताः। वनं च दोषबहुलं बहुव्यालसरीसृपम्॥
English Translation: A righteous person, who would serve one and not both sides, is the fifth of the king's friends. Such a person follow that side on which righteousness is, and accordingly acts righteously.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: परिक्लेशश्च वो मन्येध्रुवं तत्र भविष्यति। ब्राह्मणानां परिक्लेशो दैवतान्यपि सादयेत्। किं पुनर्मामितो विप्रा निवर्तध्वं यथेष्टतः॥
English Translation: Regarding such a person, the king should never disclose such purpose of his as would not find his sympathy, Kings who wish to attain success are compelled to adopt both kinds of roads, fair and unfair.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणा ऊचु: गतिर्या भवतां राजस्तां वयं गन्तुमुद्यताः। नार्हस्यस्मान् परित्यक्तुं भक्तान् सद्धर्मदर्शिनः॥
English Translation: Of the four kinds of friends, the second and the third are superior, while the first and the fourth should always be looked upon with suspicion. Regarding those acts, however, which the king should do personally, he should always look with suspicion on all the four.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनुकम्पां हि भक्तेषु देवता ह्यपि कुर्वते। विशेषतो ब्राह्मणेषु सदाचारावलम्बिषु॥
English Translation: The king should never act carelessly in watching his friends. A king who is careless is always overpowered by others.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच ममापि परमा भक्तिर्ब्राह्मणेषु सदा द्विजाः। सहायविपरिभ्रंशस्त्वयं सादयतीव माम्॥ आहरेयुरिमे येऽपि फलमूलमधूनि च। त इमे शोकजैर्दुःखैर्धातरो मे विमोहिताः॥ द्रौपद्या विप्रकर्षण राज्यापहरणेन च। दुःखार्दितानिमान् क्लेशैर्नाहं योक्तुमिहोत्सहे॥
English Translation: A wicked man puts on the appearance of honesty, and he who is honest becomes otherwise. An enemy may become a friend, and a friend may become an enemy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणा ऊचुः अस्मत्पोषणजा चिन्ता मा भूत् ते हृदि पार्थिव। स्वयमाहत्य चान्नानि त्वानुयास्यामहे वयम्॥
English Translation: A man cannot always be of the same mind. Who is there that would trust him implicitly? All the principal works, therefore, a king should perform in his own presence.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनुध्यानेन जप्येन विधास्यामः शिवं तव। कथाभिश्चाभिरम्याभिः सह रंस्यामहे वयम्॥
English Translation: An absolute confidence (in his ministers) destroys both morality and profit. A want of confidence again in all worse is than death.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच एवमेतत्र संदेहो रमेऽहं सततं द्विजैः। न्यूनभावात् तु पश्यामि प्रत्यादेशमिवात्मनः॥
English Translation: Over-confidence is premature death. One incurs danger by over-confidence, If one trusts another completely, he is said to live by the favour of the trusted person.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कथं द्रक्ष्यामि वः सर्वान् स्वयमाहृतभोजनान्। मद्भक्त्या क्लिश्यतोऽनर्हान् धिक् पापान्धृतराष्ट्रजान्।
English Translation: Therefore every one should be trusted as also mistrusted. This rule of policy, O sire, should always be kept in view.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच इत्युक्त्वा स नृपः शोचन निषसाद महीतले। यात्मरतो विद्वाञ्छौनको नाम वै द्विजः॥ योगे सांख्ये च कुशलो राजानमिदमब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: One should always mistrust that person who would upon one's death, obtain one's wealth. The wise men describe such a person to be one's enemy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शोकस्थानसहस्राणि भयस्थानशतानि च। दिवसे दिवसे मूढमाविशन्ति न पण्डितम्॥
English Translation: From the field of any person the water enters into the other's field, the ridge should not be brocken without owner's wish.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न हि ज्ञानविरुद्धेषु बहुदोषेषु कर्मसु। श्रेयोघातिषु सज्जन्ते बुद्धिमन्तो भवद्विधाः॥
English Translation: Terrified with the fear of huge quantity of water that might fill up in the field, one who wants to break the ridge, he is said as enemy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अष्टाङ्गां बुद्धिमाहुर्यां सर्वाश्रेयोऽभिघातिनीम्। श्रुतिस्मृतिसमायुक्तां राजन् सा त्वय्यवस्थिता॥
English Translation: A person whose joy knows no limit upon seeing the advancement of the king and who feels pain upon seeing the king's decay, is one of the best friends of the king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्थकृच्छ्रेषु दुर्गेषु व्यापत्सु स्वजनस्य च। शारीरमानसैर्दुःखैन सीदन्ति भवद्विधाः॥
English Translation: He who would meet with ruin by your fall, should be trusted by you completely even as you should trust your father. You should, to the best of your power, advance him as you secure advancement for yourself. One who, in even your religious rites, tries to save you from harm, would try to save you from harm in every other transaction. Such a one should be known as your best friend. They, on the other hand, who wish one harm are one's enemies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रूयतां चाभिधास्यामि जनकेन यथा पुरा। आत्मव्यवस्थानकरा गीताः श्लोका महात्मना॥
English Translation: That friend is like your own self who is filled with fear when calamity befalls you and with joy when prosperity smiles on you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मनोदेहसमुत्थाभ्यां दुःखाभ्यमर्दितं जगत्। त्योर्व्याससमासाभ्यां शमोपायमिमं शृणु॥
English Translation: A person endued with beauty, fair complexion, sweet voice, liberality, highmindedness, and good birth, cannot be such a friend.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्याधेरनिष्टसंस्पर्शाच्छ्रमादिष्टविर्वजनात्। दुःखं चतुर्भिः शारीरं कारणैः सम्प्रवर्तते॥
English Translation: That person who is endued with intelligence and memory, who is smart in transacting business, who is by nature shorn of cruelty, who is never wrathful, and who whether honoured or neglected is never dissatisfied, be he your priest or preceptor or trusted friend, should always receive your adoration if he accepts the office of your counsellor and lives in your palace.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदा तत्प्रतिकाराच्च सततं चाविचिन्तनात्। आधिव्याधिप्रशमनं क्रियायोगद्वयेन तु॥
English Translation: You may communicate to such a person your most secret counsels and the true state of never all your affairs, spiritual or temporal. You may trust him as you may your own father.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मतिमन्तो ह्यतो वैद्याः शमं प्रागेव कुर्वते। मानसस्य प्रियाख्यानैः सम्भोगोपनयैर्नृणाम्॥
English Translation: One person should be appointed to one work, and not two or three. These may not tolerate each other. It is always seen that several persons, if engaged in one and the same work, disagree with one another.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मानसेन हि दुःखेन शरीरमुपतप्यते। अय:पिण्डेन तप्तेन कुम्भसंस्थमिवोदकम्॥
English Translation: That person who acquires fame, who observes all restraints, who is never jealous of able and competent persons, who never does any evil act, who renounces righteousness from lust or fear or covetousness or wrath, who is smart in transaction business, and who always speaks wise and weighty words, should be your foremost of ministers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मानसं शमयेत् तस्माज्ज्ञानेनाग्निमिवाम्बुना। प्रशान्ते मानसे ह्यस्य शारीरमुपशाम्यति॥
English Translation: Well-behaved persons and born in good families, who are liberal and never given to brag, who are brave and respectable, and learned and full of resources, should be appointed as ministers for supervising all your affairs. Respected by you and gratified with riches, they would act for your well-being and be of great help to you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मनसो दुःखमूलं तु स्नेह इत्युपलभ्यते। स्नेहात् तु सज्जते जन्तुर्दुःखयोगमुपैति च॥
English Translation: Appointed of offices of emolument and of other important matters, they will always secure great prosperity.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्नेहमूलानि दुःखानि स्नेहजानि भयानि च। शोकहर्षों तथाऽऽयासः सर्वं स्नेहात् प्रवर्तते॥ स्नेहाद् भावोऽनुरागश्च प्रजज्ञे विषये तथा। अश्रेयस्कावुभावेतौ पूर्वस्तत्र गुरुः स्मृतः॥
English Translation: Actuated by a feeling of healthy rivalry, they satisfy all duties regarding profit, consulting with one another when necessary.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कोटराग्निर्यथाशेषं समूलं पादपं दहेत्। धर्मार्थो तु तथाल्पोऽपि रागदोषो विनाशयेत्॥
English Translation: You should fear your kinsmen as you should death itself. A kinsman can never bear a kinsmen's prosperity even as a feudatory chief cannot bear to see the prosperity of his lord.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विप्रयोगे न तु त्यागी दोषदर्शी समागमे। विरागं भजते जन्तुर्निवैरो निरवग्रहः॥
English Translation: None but a kinsman feels joy at the destruction of a kinsman endued with sincerity, mildness, liberality, modesty and truthfulness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मात् स्नेहं न लिप्सेत मित्रेभ्योधनसंचयात्। स्वशरीरसमुत्थं च ज्ञानेन विनिवर्तयेत्॥
English Translation: They, again, who have no kinsmen, can not be happy. No man is more contemptible than he who has no kinsman. A person who has no kinsman is easily overthrown by enemies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ज्ञानान्वितेषु युक्तेषु शास्त्रज्ञेषु कृतात्मसु। न तेषु सज्जते स्नेहः पद्मपत्रेष्विवोदकम्॥
English Translation: Kinsmen are the refuge of one who is attacked by others, for kinsmen can never bear to see a kinsman assailed by other people.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रागाभिभूतः पुरुषः कामेन परिकृष्यते। इच्छा संजायते तस्य ततस्तृष्णा विवर्धते॥ तृष्णा हि सर्वपापिष्ठा नित्योद्वेगकरी स्मृता। अधर्मबहुला चैव घोरा पापानुबन्धिनी॥
English Translation: When a kinsman is persecuted by even his friends, every kinsman of his considers the injury to be inflicted upon himself. In kinsmen, therefore, there both merits and shortcomings. A person having no kinsmen never shows favours to any one nor humbles himself to any one. In kinsmen, therefore, both mcrit and demerit are seen.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: या दुस्त्यजा दुर्मतिभिर्या न जीर्यति जीर्यतः। योऽसौ प्राणान्तिको रोगस्तां तृष्णां त्यजतः सुखम्॥३६
English Translation: One should, for this reason, always honour and adore his kinsmen in words and deeds, and are do what pleases them without injuring them at any time.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनाद्यन्ता तु सा तृष्णा अन्तर्देहगता नृणाम्। विनाशयति भूतानि अयोनिज इवानलः॥
English Translation: Though one may mistrust them at heart, he should behave towards them as if he trusted them completely. Thinking of their nature, it seems that they have neither demerits nor merits.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथैधः स्वसमुत्थेन वह्निना नाशमृच्छति। तथाकृतात्मा लोभेन सहजेन विनश्यति॥
English Translation: A person who carefully conducts himself in this way finds his every enemies shorn of hostility and converted into friends.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजतः सलिलादग्नेश्चोरतः स्वजनादपि। भयमर्थवतां नित्यं मृत्योः प्राणभृतामिव॥
English Translation: One who always conducts himself in this way with his kinsmen and relatives and treats thus his friends and enemies, succeeds in acquiring everlasting fame.'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथा ह्यामिषमाकाशे पक्षिभिः श्वापदैर्भुवि। भक्ष्यते सलिले मत्स्यैस्तथा सर्वत्र वित्तवान्॥
English Translation: Bhishma said Drona's son observes well. Kripa observes well. Only for the observance of Kshatriya duties Karna wishes to fight.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्थ एव हि केषांचिदनर्थं भजते नृणाम्। अर्थश्रेयसि चासक्तो न श्रेयो विन्दते नरः॥
English Translation: No wise man can find fault with the preceptor. In my view we must fight considering time and place.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मादर्थागमाः सर्वे मनोमोहविवर्धनाः। कार्पण्यं दर्पमानौ च भयमुद्वेग एव च॥ अर्थजानि विदुः प्राज्ञा दुःखान्येतानि देहिनाम्। अर्थस्योत्पादने चैव पालने च तथा क्षये।॥ सहन्ति च महद् दुःखं प्रन्ति चैवार्थकारणात्। अर्था दुःखं परित्यक्तुं पालिताश्चैव शत्रवः॥
English Translation: Why should not a wise man be bewildered who has five adversaries effulgent as the sun, who are experts in smiting and have just come out from adversity?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुःखेन चाधिगम्यन्ते तस्मान्नाशं न चिन्तयेत्। असंतोषपरा मूढाः संतोषं यान्ति पण्डिताः॥
English Translation: Even persons, conversant with morality, are bewildered in their own interests. It is for this I tell you, O king, whether my words be acceptable to you or not.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्तो नास्ति पिपासायाः संतोषः परमं सुखम्। तस्मात् संतोषमेवेह परं पश्यन्ति पण्डिताः॥
English Translation: What Karna said to you was for inciting our energy. The preceptor's son should forgive us for a very important business is present.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनित्यं यौवनं रूपं जीवितं रत्नसंचयः। ऐश्पर्य प्रियसंवासो गृध्येत् तत्र न पण्डितः॥
English Translation: When the son of Kunti has come it is not the time for dissension. Yourself and the preceptor and Kripa should forgive everything
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्यजेत संचयांस्तस्मात्तज्जान् क्लेशान् सहेत च। न हि संचयवान् कश्चिद् दृश्यते निरुपद्रवः। अतश्चधार्मिकैः पुंभिरनीहार्थः प्रशस्यते॥
English Translation: The mastery of weapons is in you as the rays are in the sun. As Lakshmi is never separated from the moon, so the Vedas and the Brahma weapons are always established in you. It is seen that the four Vedas exist in one place and all the attributes of a Kshatriya exist in another place.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धर्मार्थं यस्य वित्तेहा वरं तस्य निरीहता। प्रक्षालनाद्धि पंकस्य श्रेयो न स्पर्शनं नृणाम्॥
English Translation: We have never heard of these two living together in any man than in the preceptor of the Bharata's race and his son. This is my conviction.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिरैवं सर्वेषु न स्पृहां कर्तुमर्हसि। धर्मेण यदि ते कार्यं विमुक्तेच्छो भवार्थतः॥
English Translation: In Vedantas, in Puranas and in Itihasas, who, O king except Jamadagni, is superior to Drona?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच नार्थोपभोगलिप्सार्थमियमर्थेप्सुता मम। भरणार्थं तु विप्राणां ब्रह्मन् काझे न लोभतः॥
English Translation: The (mastery) of Brahma weapons and (the knowledge of) the Vedas combined are not seen in any other person than that best of men, the preceptor of Bharatas. The preceptor's son should forgive us. This is not the time for disunion. Let us all united fight with the son of the chastiser of Paka (Arjuna) who has come here.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कथं ह्यस्मद्विधो ब्रह्मन् वर्तमानो गृहाश्रमे। भरणं पालनं चापि न कुर्यादनुयायिनाम्॥
English Translation: Of all the dangers to an army described by the intelligent the worst is the disunion amongst the leaders.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संविभागो हि भूतानां सर्वेषामेव दृश्यते। तथैवापचमानेभ्यः प्रदेयं गृहमेधिना॥
English Translation: Ashvatthama said O foremost of men, the words that you have spoken to us are all just. The preceptor, filled with anger, has dilated upon his (Arjuna's) accomplishments.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तृणानि भूमिरुदकं वाक् चतुर्थी च सूनृता। सतामेतानि गेहेषु नोच्छिद्यन्ते कदाचन॥ देयमार्तस्य शयनं स्थितश्रान्तस्य चासनम्। तृषितस्य च पानीयं क्षुधितस्य च भोजनम्॥
English Translation: The accomplishments even of the enemies should be mentioned and the defect of a preceptor should be pointed out. Therefore, one should, to the best of his power, describe the merit of his son or disciple.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चक्षुर्दद्यान्मनो दद्याद् वाचं दद्यात् सुभाषिताम्। उत्थाय चासनं दद्यादेषधर्मः सनातनः। प्रत्युत्थायाभिगमनं कुर्यात्र्यायेन चार्चनम्॥ अग्निहोत्रमनड्वांश्च ज्ञातयोऽतिथिबान्धवाः। पुत्रा दाराश्च भृत्याश्च निर्दहेयुरपूजिताः॥ आत्मार्थं पाचयेन्नान्नं न वृथा घातयेत् पशून्। न च तत् स्वयमश्नीयाद् विधिवद् यन्न निर्वपेत्॥
English Translation: Duryodhana said May the preceptor forgive us and establish peace. If the preceptor is not alienated everything would be done.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्वभ्यश्च श्वपचेभ्यश्च वयोभ्यश्चावपेद् भुवि। वैश्वदेवं हि नामैतत् सायं प्रातश्च दीयते॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said Thereupon, O Bharata, along with Karna, Bhishma and the high-souled Kripa Duryodhana made Drona to forgive them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विघसाशी भवेत् तस्मान्नित्यं चामृतभोजनः। विघसो भुक्तशेषं तु यज्ञशेषं तथामृतम्॥
English Translation: Drona said I have already been pleased by the words, which Bhishma, the son of Shantanu at first gave vent to. Such a procedure should now be resorted to that the son of Pritha may not approach Duryodhana in the encounter and the latter may not pass into the hands of the enemies,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चक्षुर्दघान्मनो दद्याद् वाचं दद्याच्च सूनृताम्। अनुव्रजेदुपासीत स यज्ञः पञ्चदक्षिणः॥
English Translation: Either through bravery or through foolishness. Let such a procedure be adopted. Arjuna shall not bring himself into our view before the expiration of the period of exile.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यो दद्यादपरिक्लिष्टमध्वनि वर्तते। श्रान्तायदृष्टपूर्वाय तस्य पुण्यफलं महत्॥
English Translation: By (merely) recovering the kine he will not forgive us. let therefore such a procedure be adopted that he can, by no means, vanquish the sons of Dhritarashtra and defeat our army. Similarly did Duryodhana speak before. Remembering all this, O Bhishma, tell us what you think proper.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं यो वर्तते वृत्तिं वर्तमानो गृहाश्रमे। तस्यधर्म परं प्राहुः कथं वा विप्र मन्यसे॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said You have, O grandfather, described the sacred duties of kings regarding the persons in distress. O king, you should tell me now those foremost of duties of those who lead the (four) modes of life.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शौनक उवाच अहो वत महत् कष्टं विपरीतमिदं जगत्। येनापत्रपते साधुरसाधुस्तेन तुष्यति॥
English Translation: Bhishma said Religion has many doors. The observance of the duties sanctioned by religion can never be useless. Duties have been laid down regarding every mode of life. The fruits of Penance with regard to the development of the Soul, are to be had in this worid.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शिश्नोदरकृतेऽप्राज्ञः करोति विघसं बहु। मोहरागवशाक्रान्त इन्द्रियार्थवशानुगः॥
English Translation: The object to which one devotes oneself, whatever it may be, O Bharata, and nothing else, appears to as the highest of acquisitions fraught with the greatest of blessings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ह्रियते बुध्यमानोऽपि नरो हारिभिरिन्द्रियैः। विमूढसंज्ञो दुष्टाश्वैरुद्धान्तैरिव सारथिः॥
English Translation: When one meditates properly, one comes to know that the things of this world are useless one as straw. Forsooth, one is then freed from attachment of those things.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: षडिन्द्रियाणि विषयं समागच्छन्ति वै यदा। तदा प्रादुर्भवत्येषां पूर्वसंकल्पजं मनः॥
English Translation: When the world, O Yudhishthira, which is full of shortcomings, is so framed, every intelligent man, should try to acquire the liberation of his soul.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मनो यस्येन्द्रियस्येह विषयान् याति सेवितुम्। तस्यौत्सुक्यं सम्भवति प्रवृत्तिश्चोपजायते॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said Tell me, O grandfather, by what condition of mind should one kill his grief when he loses his riches, or his wife, or son, or father.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः संकल्पबीजेन कामेन विषयेषुभिः। विद्धः पतति लोभाग्नौ ज्योतिर्लोभात् पतङ्गवत्॥
English Translation: Bhishma said, When one's wealth is lost, or one's wife or son or father is dead, he certainly says to oneself,-Alas, it is a great sorrow,-But then one should, by the help of meditation, try to kill that grief.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो विहारैराहारैर्मोहितश्च यथेप्सया। महामोहे सुखे मग्नो नात्मानमवबुध्यते॥ एवं पतति संसारे तासु तास्विह योनिषु। अविद्याकर्मतृष्णाभिर्धाम्यमाणोऽथ चक्रवत्॥ ब्रह्मादिषु तृणान्तेषु भूतेषु परिवर्तते। जले भुवि तथाऽऽकाशे जायमानः पुनः पुनः॥
English Translation: Regarding it is mentioned the old story of the speech that a twice-born friend of his, coming to Senajit's court, made to that king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अबुधानां गतिस्त्वेषा बुधानामपि मे शृणु। येधर्मे श्रेयसि रता विमोक्षरतयो जनाः॥
English Translation: Seeing the monarch stricken with grief and burning with sorrow on account of the death of his son, the Brahmana said to that king of very
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदिदं वेदवचनं कुरु कर्म त्यजेति च। तस्माद्धर्मानिमान् सर्वान् नाभिमानात् समाचरेत्।७४॥
English Translation: Why are you stupefied? You are without any intelligence. You are yourself an object of grief, why do you grieve (for others)? A few days hence others will grieve for you, and in their turn they will be grieved for by others still.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इज्याध्ययनदानानि तपः सत्यं क्षमा दमः। अलोभ इति मार्गोऽयंधर्मस्याष्टविधः स्मृतः॥
English Translation: Yourself, myself, and others who wait upon you, O king, shall all repair whence all of us have come.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अब पूर्वश्चतुर्वर्गः पितृयाणपथे स्थितः। कर्तव्यमिति यत् कार्यं नाभिमानात् समाचरेत्॥
English Translation: Senajit said What is that intelligence, what that penance, O learned Brahmana, what that concentration of mind, O you having asceticism for wealth, what that knowledge, and what that learning, by gaining which you do not give way to grief?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उत्तरो देवयानस्तु सद्भिराचरितः सदा। अष्टाङ्गेनैव मार्गेण विशुद्धात्मा समाचरेत्॥
English Translation: The Brahmana said See, all creatures-the superior, the middling, and the inferiorm-on account of their respective acts, and entangled in sorrow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सम्यक्संकल्पसंबन्धात् सम्यक् चेन्द्रियनिग्रहात् सम्यग्व्रतविशेषाच्च सम्यक च गुरुसेवनात्॥ सम्यगाहारयोगाच्च सम्यक् चाध्ययनागमात्। सम्यक्कर्मोपसंन्यासात् सम्यक्चित्तनिरोधनात्॥ एवं कर्माणि कुर्वन्ति संसारविजिगीषवः। रागद्वेषविनिर्मुक्ता ऐश्वर्यं देवता गताः॥
English Translation: I do not consider even my own self to be mine. On the other hand, I consider the whole world to be mine. I again consider all this as much mine as it belongs to others. Grief cannot attack me for this thought.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रुद्राः साध्यास्तथाऽऽदित्या वसवोऽथ तथाश्विनौ। योगैश्वर्येण संयुक्ताधारयन्ति प्रजा इमाः॥
English Translation: Having gained such an understanding, I do not give way to joy or to grief. As two pieces of wood floating on the sea meet together at one time and are again separated, so is the union of (living) creatures in this world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथा त्वमपि कौन्तेय शममास्थाय पुष्कलम्। तपसा सिद्धिमन्विच्छ योगसिद्धिं च भारत॥
English Translation: Sons, grandsons, kinsmen relatives, are all of this nature. One should One should never feel attachment for them, for separation with them is inevitable.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पितृमातृमयी सिद्धिः प्राप्ता कर्ममयी च ते। तपसा सिद्धिमन्विच्छ द्विजानां भरणाय वै॥
English Translation: Your son came from an invisible quarter. He has gone away and become invisible. He did not know you. You did not know him. Who are you and for whom do you grieve.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सिद्धा हि यद् यदिच्छन्ति कुर्वते तदनुग्रहात्। तस्मात्तपः समास्थाय कुरुष्वात्ममनोरथम्॥
English Translation: Grief is the child of the disease created by desire. Happiness again comes when the disease of desire is cured. From joy originates sorrow, and sorrow comes again and again.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मण उवाच रजोऽहं वः प्रवक्ष्यामि याथातथ्येन सत्तमाः। निबोधत महाभागा गुणवृत्तं च राजसम्॥
English Translation: Sorrow comes after joy, and joy after sorrow. The joys and sorrows of human beings are revolving on a wheel.
---
