Sanskrit Shloka: सन्तापो रूपमायास: सुखदुःखे हिमातपौ। ऐश्वर्ये विग्रहः संधिर्हेतुवादोऽरतिः क्षमा॥ बलं शौर्यं मदो रोषो व्यायामकलहावपि। ईयेप्सा पिशुनं युद्धं ममत्वं परिपालनम्॥ वधबन्धपरिक्लेशाः क्रयो विक्रय एव च। निकृन्त छिन्धि भिन्धीति परवर्मावकर्तनम्॥ उग्रं दारुणमाक्रोशः परच्छिद्रानुशासनम्। लोकचिन्तानुचिन्ता च मत्सरः परिपालनम्॥ मृषा वादो मृषा दानं विकल्पः परिभाषणम्। निन्दा स्तुतिः प्रशंसा च प्रतापः परिधर्षणम्॥ परिचर्यानुशुश्रूषा सेवा तृष्णा व्यापाश्रयः। व्यूहो नयः प्रमादश्च परिवादः परिग्रहः॥ संस्कारा ये च लोकेषु प्रवर्तन्ते पृथक्पृथक्। नृषु नारीषु भूतेषु द्रव्येषु शरणेषु च।॥ संतापोऽप्रत्ययश्चैव व्रतानि नियमाश्च ये। आशीर्युक्तानि कर्माणि पौर्तानि विविधानि च॥ स्वाहाकारो नमस्कारः स्वधाकारो वषक्रिया। याजनाध्य.पने चोभे यजनाध्ययने अपि॥ दानं प्रतिग्रहश्चैव प्रायश्चित्तानि मङ्गलम्। इदं मे स्यादिदं मे स्यात्स्नेहो गुणसमुद्भवः॥ अभिद्रोहस्तथा माया निकृतिर्मान एव च। स्तैन्यं हिंसा जुगुप्सा च परितापः प्रजागरः॥ दम्भो दर्पोऽथ रागश्च भक्तिः प्रीतिः प्रमोदनम्। द्यूतं च जनवादश्च सम्बन्धाः स्त्रीकृताश्च ये॥ ये च च केचन। नृत्यवादित्रगीतानां प्रसङ्गा सर्व एते गुणा विप्रा राजसाः सम्प्रकीर्तिताः॥
English Translation: After happiness sorrow has come to you. You will again enjoy happiness for good and no one enjoys happiness for good.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भूतभव्यभविष्याणां भावानां भुवि भावनाः। त्रिवर्गनिरता नित्यं धर्मोऽर्थः काम इत्यपि॥ कामवृत्ताः प्रमोदन्ते सर्वकामसमृद्धिभिः। अर्वाक्स्रोतस इत्येते मनुष्या रजसा वृताः॥
English Translation: The body is the abode of both sorrow and happiness. An embodied creature suffers the consequences of whatever acts he performs with the help of his body.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अस्मिँल्लोके प्रमोदन्ते जायमानाः पुनः पुनः। प्रेत्य भाविकमीहन्ते ऐहलौकिकमेव च। ददति प्रतिगृह्णन्ति तर्पयन्त्यथ जुह्वति॥
English Translation: Life comes with the creation of the body. The two exist together, and the two die together.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रजोगुणा वो बहुधानुकीर्तिता यथावदुक्तं गुणवृत्तमेव च। नरोऽपि यो वेद गुणानिमान् सदा स राजसैः सर्वगुणर्विमुच्यते॥
English Translation: Men of impure souls, attached to worldly objects by various fetters, disappear like embankments of sand in water.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मण उवाच त्रयो वै रिपवो लोके नवधा गुणतः स्मृताः। प्रहर्षः प्रीतिरानन्दस्त्रयस्ते सात्त्विका गुणाः॥
English Translation: Miseries of various sorts begotten by ignorance, act like pressers of oil-seeds, for attacking all creatures for their attachments; these press them like oil-seeds in the oilmaking machine subjecting them to the round of re-births.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तृष्णा क्रोधोऽभिसंरम्भो राजसास्ते गुणाः स्मृताः। श्रमस्तन्द्रा च मोहश्च त्रयस्ते तामसा गुणाः॥
English Translation: Man, for the sake of his wife, commits numberless evil deeds, but suffers alone various kinds of misery both in this and the next world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतान् निकृत्य धृतिमान् बाणसंधैरतन्द्रितः। जेतुं परानुत्सहते प्रशान्तात्मा जितेन्द्रियः॥
English Translation: All men, attached to children, wives kinsmen and relatives sink in the miry sea of sorrow like wild elephants, when shom of strength, sinking in a miry slough.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अत्र गाथा: कीर्तयन्ति पुराकल्पविदो जनाः। अम्बरीषेण या गीता राज्ञा पूर्वं प्रशाम्यता॥
English Translation: Indeed, O king, upon loss of wealth or son or kinsmen or relatives, man suffers great misery burning him like a forest fire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: समुदीर्णेषु दोषेषु बाध्यमानेषु साधुषु। जग्राह तरसा राज्यमम्बरीषो महायशाः॥
English Translation: All this, viz., joy and grief, existence and non-existence depend upon destiny. One having friends as well as one having none, one having enemies as well as one having none, one having wisdom as well as one shorn of it, each and every one amongst these, enjoys happiness through destiny.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स निगृह्यात्मनो दोषान् साधून् समभिपूज्य च। जगाम महतीं सिद्धिं गाथाश्चेमा जगाद ह॥
English Translation: Friends are not the root of one's happiness. Enemies are not the root of one's misery. Wisdom cannot bring on wealth; wealth cannot give happiness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भूयिष्ठं विजिता दोषा निहताः सर्वशत्रवः। एको दोषो वरिष्ठश्च वध्यः स न हतो मया॥
English Translation: Intelligence cannot give wealth, nor is stupidity the cause of poverty. Only a wise man, and none else, understands the order of the world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यत्प्रयुक्तो जन्तुरयं वैतृष्ण्यं नाधिगच्छति। तृष्णात इह निम्नानि धावमानो न बुध्यते॥
English Translation: Of the intelligent, the heroic, the foolish, the cowardly, the idiotic, the earned, the weak, or the strong, happiness comes to him only for whom it is ordained.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अकार्यमपि येनेह प्रयुक्तः सेवते नरः। तं लोभमसिभिस्तीक्ष्णैनिकृत्य सुखमेधते॥
English Translation: The cow belongs to the calf, to the cowherd who is her master, and to the thief. Indeed, she is his who drinks her milk.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: लोभाद्धि जायते तृष्णा ततश्चिन्ता प्रवर्तते। स लिप्यमानो लभते भूयिष्ठं राजसान् गुणान्। तदवाप्तौ तु लभते भूयिष्ठं तामसान् गुणान्॥
English Translation: They whose understandings are dormant, and they who have that state of the mind which lies beyond the range of the intellect, succeed in enjoying happiness. Only they who are between these two classes, suffer misery.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तैर्गुणैः संहतदेहबन्धनः पुनः पुनजार्यति कर्म चेहते। जन्मक्षये भिन्नविकीर्णदेहो मृत्युं पुनर्गच्छति जन्मनैव॥
English Translation: The wise find pleasure in the two extremes but not in the intermediate states. The sages have said that the attainment of any of these two extremes form happiness. Misery lies in the intermediate states between the two.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मादेतं सम्यगवेक्ष्य लोभं निगृह्य धृत्याऽऽत्मनि राज्यमिच्छेत्। मात्मैव राजा विदितो यथावत्॥
English Translation: Those who have succeeded in acquiring real happiness, and who have become freed from the pleasures and pains of this world, and who are shorn of envy, are never moved by either the accession of wealth or its loss.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इति राज्ञाम्बरीषेण गाथा गीता यशस्विना। अधिराज्यं पुरस्कृत्य लोभमेकं निकृन्तता॥
English Translation: Those who have not gained that intelligence which brings on real happiness, but who have got over folly and ignorance yield to excessive joy and excessive misery.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वासुदेव उवाच शाल्वबाणादित तस्मिन् प्रद्युम्ने बलिनां वरे। वृष्णयो भग्नसंकल्पा विव्यथुः पृतनागताः॥ हाहाकृतमभूत् सर्वं वृष्ण्यन्धकबलं ततः। प्रद्युम्ने मोहिते राजन् परे च मुदिता भृशम्॥
English Translation: Men who have no ideas of right or wrong, who are beside themselves with pride and with success over others, give way to transports of delight like the celestials.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं तथा मोहितं दृष्ट्वा सारथिर्जवनैर्हयैः। रणादपाहरत् तूर्णं शिक्षितो दारुकिस्तदा॥
English Translation: Happiness must terminate in misery. Idleness is misery; while cleverness (in action) is the root of felicity. Affluence and prosperity live in a clever man, but not in an idle wight.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नातिदूरापयाते तु रथे रथवरप्रणुत्। धनुर्गृहीत्वा यन्तारं लब्धसंज्ञोऽब्रवीदिदम्॥
English Translation: Be it happiness or be it misery, be it pleasant or be it otherwise, what comes to one should be enjoyed or put up with an unconquered heart.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सौते किं ते व्यवसितं कस्माद् यासि पराङ्मुखः। नैष वृष्णिप्रवीराणामाहवेधर्म उच्यते॥
English Translation: Every day a thousand occasions for sorrow, and a hundred occasions for fear attack an ignorant and foolish man but a wise man is never so affected.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कच्चित् सौते न ते मोहः शाल्वं दृष्ट्वा महाहवे। विषादो वा रणं दृष्ट्वा ब्रूहि में त्वं यथातथम्॥
English Translation: Sorrow can never touch an intelligent man, one who has acquired wisdom, one who obeys the instructions of his elders, one who has no envy, and one who has controlled his self.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सौतिरुवाच जानार्दने न मे मोहो नापि मां भयमाविशत्। अतिभारं तु ते मन्ये शाल्वं केशवनन्दन॥
English Translation: Depending upon such an understanding, and guarding his heart (against the influences of desire and the passions), the wise man should work on in this world. Indeed, sorrow cannot affect him who knows that Supreme Self from which everything emanate and to which everything disappears.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सोऽपयामि शनैर्वीर बलवानेष पापकृत्। मोहितश्च रणे शूरो रक्ष्यः सारथिना रथी॥
English Translation: The very root of grief, or heart-burning, or sorrow or of action, should, even if it be a part of one's body, the cast off.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आयुष्मंस्त्वं मया नित्यं रक्षितव्यस्त्वयाप्यहम्। रक्षितव्यो रथी नित्यमिति कृत्वापयाम्यहम्॥
English Translation: That object, whatever it may be, which one considers as his own, is a source of grief and heart-burning.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एकश्चासि महाबाहो बहवश्चापि दानवाः। न समं रौक्मिणेयाहं रणे मत्वापयामि वै॥
English Translation: If objects, of desire, are renounced they become sources of happiness. The man who follows objects of desire is ruined in that pursuit.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं ब्रुवति सूते तु तदा मकरकेतुमान्। उवाच सूतं कौरव्य निवर्तय रथं पुनः॥ दारुकात्मज मैवं त्वं पुनः कार्षीः कथंचन। व्यपयानं रणात् सौते जीवतो मम कर्हिचित्॥
English Translation: Neither the happiness which is derived from a gratification of the senses nor that great happiness which one may enjoy in heaven, even comes up to a sixteenth part of the happiness which originates from the destruction of all desire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न स वृष्णिकुले जातो यो वै त्यजति संगरम्। यो वा निपतितं हन्ति तवास्मीति च वादिनम्॥
English Translation: The consequences of pristine decds, right or wrong, affect the wise and the foolish, the brave and the mind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथा स्त्रियं च यो हन्ति बालं वृद्धं तथैव च। विरथं विप्रकीर्णं च भग्नशस्त्रायुधं तथा॥
English Translation: Thus joy and sorrow, the agreeable and the disagreeable, continually revolve among living creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वं च सूतकुले जातो विनीतः सूतकर्मणि। धर्मज्ञश्चासि वृष्णीनामाहवेष्वपि दारुके॥
English Translation: Thus knowing an intelligent and wise man lives at ease. A person should renounce all his desires, and never give way to anger.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स जानंश्चरितं कृत्स्नं वृष्णीनां पृतनामुखे। अपयानं पुनः सौते मैवं कार्षीः कथंचन॥
English Translation: This anger originates in the heart and becomes powerful there. This anger which lives in the bodies of men and is born in their minds, is described by the wise as Death.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपयातं हतं पृष्ठे भ्रान्तं रणपलायितम्। गदाचजो दुराधर्षः किं मां वक्ष्यति माधवः॥
English Translation: When a person withdraws all his desires like a tortoise withdrawing all its limbs, then its soul, which is self-luminous, can see itself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: केशवस्याचजो वापि नीलवासा मदोत्कटः। किं वक्ष्यति महाबाहुर्बलदेवः समागतः॥
English Translation: When a person himself feels no fear and is feared by no one, when he has no desire and no hatred, he is then said to attain to the state of Brahima.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किं वक्ष्यति शिनेर्नप्ता नरसिंहो महाधनुः। अपयातं रणात् सूत साम्बश्च समितिंजयः॥
English Translation: Renouncing both truth and falsehood, grief and joy, fear and courage, the agreeable and the disagreeable, you may acquire equanimity of soul.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चारुदेष्णश्च दुर्धर्षस्तथैव गदसारणौ। अक्रूरश्च महाबाहुः किं मां वक्ष्यति सारथे॥
English Translation: When a person does no wrong to any creature, in thought, word, or deed, he is then said to attain to a state of Brahma.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शूरं सम्भावितं शान्तं नित्यं पुरुषमानिनम्। स्त्रियश्च वृष्णिवीराणां किं मां वक्ष्यन्ति संहताः॥
English Translation: He alone enjoys true happiness who can renounce that thirst which cannot be cast off by the misguided, which does not decay with decrepitude, and which is considered as a fatal disease.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रद्युम्नोऽयमुपायाति भीतस्त्यक्त्वा महाहवम्। धिगेनमिति वक्ष्यन्ति न तु वक्ष्यन्ति साध्विति॥
English Translation: About it, O king, are heard the verses sung by Pingala regarding the way in which she had acquired eternal inerit even at a very unfavourable time.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धिग्वाचा परिहासोऽपि मम वा मद्विधस्य वा। मृत्युनाभ्यधिकः सौते स त्वं मा व्यपयाः पुनः॥
English Translation: Having gone to the appointed place, a fallen woman of the name of Pingala could not enjoy the company of her lover through an accident. At that time of great misery, she acquired equanimity of soul.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भारं हि मयि संन्यस्य यातो मधुनिहा हरिः। यज्ञं भारतसिंहस्य न हि शक्योऽद्य मर्षितुम्॥
English Translation: Pingala said Alas, I have for many years lived ignorantly, by the side of tha dear Self in whom there is nothing but tranquility. Death has been at my door. Ere this, I did not, however, approach that Essence of Purity.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृतवर्मा मया वीरो निर्यास्यन्नेव वारितः। शाल्वं निवारयिष्येऽहं तिष्ठ त्वमिति सूतज॥
English Translation: I shall cover this house of one column and nine doors, i.e., body, (by means of true knowledge). What woman is there who considers that dear. Supreme Soul, even when He is so near, as really dear.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स च सम्भावयन् मां वै निवृत्तो हृदिकात्मजः। तं समेत्य रणं त्यक्त्वा किं वक्ष्यामि महारथम्॥
English Translation: I am now awake. I have been roused from the sleep of ignorance. I am no longer under the influence of desire. Human lovers, who are, in fact, so many embodiments of hell, shall no longer impose upon me by approaching me lustfully.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उपयान्तं दुराधर्षं शङ्खचक्रगदाधरम्। पुरुपं पुण्डरीकाक्षं किं वक्ष्यामि महाभुजम्॥
English Translation: Evil yields good through destiny or through pristine deeds. Roused from the sleep of ignorance, I have renounced all desire for worldly objects. I have gained a complete mastery over my senses.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सात्यकिं बलदेवं च ये चान्येऽन्धकवृष्णयः। मया स्पर्धन्ति सततं किं नु वक्ष्यामि तानहम्॥
English Translation: One freed from desire and hope sleeps happily. Freedom from hope and desire is happiness. Having renounced desire and hope, Pingala sleeps happily.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्यक्त्वा रणमिमं सौते पृष्ठतोऽभ्याहतः शरैः। त्वयापनीतो विवशो न जीवेयं कथंचन॥
English Translation: Bhishma said Consoled with these and other words of the learned Brahmana, king Senajit enjoyed delight and became very happy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स निवर्त रथेनाशु पुनर्दारुकनन्दन। न चैतदेवं कर्तव्यमथापत्सु कथंचन॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said The object of Krishna having proved vrsuccessful and he having left the Kurus, the Kshattri having approached Pritha said to her slowly and sadly,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न जीवितमहं सौते बहु मन्ये कथंचन। अपयातो रणाद् भीतः पृष्ठतोऽभ्याहतः शरैः॥
English Translation: O you whose children are alive, you know that I am ever inclined to the reverse of war but though I am caring myself horse, Suyodhana does not act up to my words.
The king (Yudhishthira) has on his side the kings of the Chedis, the Panchalas, and the Kaikeyas and Bhima and Arjuna and Krishna and Yuyudhana and the twins.
Yudhishthira is staying at Upaplavya like Dharma himself and desires the good will of his kinsmen as the weak desire the good will of the strong.
This king Dhritarashtra too, old in years, does not make peace, and follows the wrong path being intoxicated with the pride of sons.
The dispute in this instance has its rise in the wicked intelligence of Jayadratha, Karna, and Dushasana, as also of the son of Subala.
These, who act with unrighteousness towards him who is righteous, have the fruit of such act of theirs.
Who is there who would not grieve at the prostitution of virtue by the Kurus? When Keshava goes without having established peace the sons of Pandu will make preparation for war.
Thereupon the misdeed of the Kurus will be the cause of a massacre of heroes; thinking of such things, I do not get sleep during day nor during night.”
Kunti too, hearing these words of his, which were spoken with the desire of benefit, began to sigh, being struck with sorrow and became depressed in mind also.
Fie on this interest" which is the cause of a great massacre of kinsmen-in this was those that are friends will meet with defeat.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कदापि सूतपुत्र त्वं जानीषे मां भयादितम्। अपयातं रणं हित्वा यथा कापुरुषं तता॥
English Translation: The sons of Pandu, the Chedis, the Panchalas and the Yadavas, united together will fight with the Bharatas; what can be a greater cause of sorrow than this?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न युक्तं भवता त्यक्तुं संग्रामं दारुकात्मज' मयि युद्धार्थिनि भृशं स त्वं याहि यतो रणम्॥
English Translation: Behold, there is certainly demerit in war, as defeat in it the death of a man who is without wealth is better for him but the loss of kinsmen is no victory.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच योगं मे परमं तात मोक्षस्य वद भारत। तमहं तत्त्वतो ज्ञातुमिच्छामि वदतां वर॥
English Translation: Thinking this, sorrow comes to my heart; this grand father, Bhishma, the son of Shantanu, the preceptor who is the foremost among soldiers,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच अत्राप्युदाहरन्तीममितिहासं पुरातनम्। संवादं मोक्षसंयुक्तं शिष्यस्य गुरुणा सह॥
English Translation: And Karna also being united with the party of the son of Dhritarashtra it enhances my fear. The preceptor Drona will by no means fight willingly with his disciple. son
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कश्चिद् ब्राह्मणमासीनमाचार्यमृषिसत्तमम्। तेजोराशिं महात्मानं सत्यसंधं जितेन्द्रियम्॥
English Translation: Why should not also the grand father show sympathy to the son of Pandu. This one man only therefore (namely Karna) follows the delusion of the of the wicked-souled of Dhritarashtra of vain foresight.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शिष्यः परममेधावी श्रेयोऽर्थी सुसमाहितः। चरणावुपसंगृह्य स्थितः प्राञ्जलिरब्रवीत्॥ उपासनात् प्रसन्नोऽसि यदि वै भगवन् मम। संशयो मे महान् कश्चित् तन्मे व्याख्यातुमर्हसि।
English Translation: The wretch also ever hates the sons of Pandu. He is obstinate in working for their injury, besides he is very powerful.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कुतश्चाहं कुतश्च त्वं तत् सम्यग्ब्रूहि यत्परम्॥ कथं च सर्वभूतेषु समेषु द्विजसत्तम। सम्यग्वृत्ता निवर्तन्ते विपराताः क्षयोदयाः॥ वेदेषु चापि यद् वाक्यं लौकिकं व्यापकं च यत्। एतद् विद्वन् यथातत्त्वं सर्वं व्याख्यातुमर्हसि॥
English Translation: Karna is ever against the sons of Pandu, and this fact now is burning me up; and I today expect. ((by the course I take) to incline the heart of Karna towards the sons of Pandu.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गुरुरुवाच शृणु शिष्य महाप्राज्ञ ब्रह्मगुह्यमिदं परम्। अध्यात्म सर्वविद्यानामागमानां च यद्वसु॥
English Translation: For I shall today approach him with a view to please him and tell him everything as it actually happened. The divinely holy Durvasa, being gratified by me, granted me a boon,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वासुदेवः परमिदं विश्वस्य ब्रह्मणो मुखम्। सत्यं ज्ञानमथो यज्ञस्तितिक्षा दम आर्जवम्॥
English Translation: Empowering me to invoke any body with the help of certain incantations ((mantras) when I was residing in my father's place, namely in the inner apartments of the king Kuntibhoja.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुरुषं सनातनं विष्णुं यं तं वेदविदो विदुः। स्वर्गप्रलयकर्तारमव्यक्तं ब्रह्म शाश्वतम्॥
English Translation: With diverse thoughts and fearing in my heart and reflecting on the strength or weakness of the incantation as also of the efficacy of the Brahmana's boon.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदिदं ब्रह्म वार्ष्णेयमितिहासं शृणुष्व मे। ब्राह्मणो ब्राह्मणैः श्राव्यो राजन्यः क्षत्रियैस्तथा॥ वैश्यो वैश्यैस्तथा श्राव्यः शूद्रः शूरैर्महामनाः। माहात्म्यं देवदेवस्य विष्णोरमिततेजसः॥
English Translation: And owing to my nature as a woman, especially owing to being a child I thought again and again, at the time being carefully guarded over by my nurse and surrounded by my companions.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्हस्त्वमसि कल्याणं वार्ष्णेयं शृणु यत्परम्। कालचक्रमनाद्यन्तं भावाभावस्वलक्षणम्॥
English Translation: How I could avoid all blame and save the reputation of my father and how I could myself be visited with good fortune without being a sinner in any way.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्रैलोक्यं सर्वभूतेशे चक्रवत्परिवर्तते। यत्तदक्षरमव्यक्तममृतं ब्रह्म शाश्वतम्। वदन्ति पुरुषव्याघ्र केशवं पुरुषर्षभम्॥
English Translation: And thinking of that Brahmana and bowing to him in my mind out of curiosity and behaving as a child at the time I came in contact with the god Surya though yet an unmarried girl.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पितृन देवानृषीश्चैव तथा वै यक्षराक्षसान्। नागासुरमनुष्यांश्च सृजते परमोऽव्ययः॥
English Translation: Why should not he therefore, whom I bore in my womb when an unmarried girl, act according to my words leading to benefit and at the same time accomplish the good of his brothers?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथैव वेदशास्त्राणि लोकधर्माश्च शाश्वतान्। प्रलयं प्रकृति प्राप्य युगादौ सृजते पुनः॥
English Translation: Kunti, thus thinking on an excellent course of action, went towards the Bhagirathi for the attainment of her objects.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथाव॒तुलिङ्गानि नानारूपाणि पर्यये। दृश्यन्ते तानि तान्येव तथा भावा युगादिषु॥
English Translation: Then on the banks of the Ganga did Pritha hear the sound of chanting the Vedas made by her son who had great kindness in him and who was attached to truth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ यद्यद् यदा भाति कालयोगाद् युगादिषु। तत् तदुत्पद्यते ज्ञानं लोकयात्राविधानजम्॥
English Translation: She waited behind Karna, who with arms upraised had his face turned to the east, till the end of the devotions of that devotee.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युगान्तेऽन्तर्हितान् वेदान् सेतिहासान् महर्षयः। लेभिरे तपसा पूर्वमनुज्ञाताः स्वयम्भुवा॥
English Translation: She the wife of the Kauravya and the daughter of the Vrishni race waited troubled by the rays of the sun behind the clothes of Karna, becoming pale like a garland of lotuses.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वेदविद् वेद भगवान् वेदाङ्गानि बृहस्पतिः। भार्गवो नीतिशास्त्रं तु जगाद जगतो हितम्॥
English Translation: That one, who used to say his prayers regularly, having been engaged in devotion till his back became heated with the rays of the sun, then turned and seeing Kunti he did honour her by saluting her and folding his hands before her.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गान्धर्वं नारदो वेद भरद्वाजो धनुर्ग्रहम्। देवर्षिचरितं गार्ग्य: कृष्णात्रेयश्चिकित्सितम्॥
English Translation: As was custom that best among men, the son of Vikartana, endued with great energy and pride, that foremost of all virtuous persons, with surprise, said to Kunti.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न्यायतन्त्राण्यनेकानि तैस्तैरुक्तानि वादिभिः। हेत्वागमसदाचारैर्यदुक्तं तदुपास्यताम्॥
English Translation: 'I shall now describe to you the means of conquering the senses as seen with the eye of the scriptures. A person, O king, will attain to the highest and by shaping his conduct accordingly.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनाद्यं तत्परं ब्रह्म न देवा नर्षयो विदुः। एकस्तद् वेद भगवान् धाता नारायणः प्रभुः॥
English Translation: Amongst all living creatures man is said to be the foremost. Among men, the twice-born, persons well read in the Vedas are the foremost.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नारायणादृषिगणास्तथा मुख्याः सुरासुराः। राजर्षयः पुराणाश्च परमं दुःखभेषजम्॥
English Translation: These last are considered as the souls of all living creatures. Indeed, those Brahmanas who have mastered the Vedas are considered as allseeing and omniscient. They are persons who have become conversant with Brahma.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुरुषाधिष्ठितान् भावान् प्रकृतिः सूयते यदा। हेतुयुक्तमतः पूर्वं जगत् सम्परिवर्तते॥
English Translation: As a blind man, without a guide, meets with many difficulties on a road, so has a person shorn of knowledge to meet with many impediments in the world. Therefore those who are endued with knowledge arc considered as superior to the rest.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दीपादन्ये यथा दीपाः प्रवर्तन्ते सहस्रशः। प्रकृतिः सूयते तद्वदानन्त्यान् नापचीयते॥
English Translation: Those who wish to acquire virtue practise various rites according to the scriptural injunctions. They do not, however, attain to Liberation. They only acquire those good qualities which I shall presently mention.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अव्यक्तकर्मजा बुद्धिरहंकारं प्रसूयते। आकाशं चाप्यहंकाराद् वायुराकाशसम्भवः॥
English Translation: Purity of speech, of body, and of mind, forgiveness, truth, firmness and intelligence,-these good qualities are shown by pious persons who observe both kinds of religion.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वायोस्तेजस्ततश्चाप अद्भ्योऽथ वसुधोद्गता। मूलप्रकृतयो ह्यष्टौ जगदेतास्ववस्थितम्॥
English Translation: What is called Brahmacharya is considered as the means of attaining to Brahma. That is the foremost of all religions. It is by the practice of that religion that one acquires the highest end.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ज्ञानेन्द्रियाण्यतः पञ्च पञ्च कर्मेन्द्रियाण्यपि। विषयाः पञ्च चैकं च विकारे घोडशं मनः॥
English Translation: Brahmacharya has no connection with the five vital airs, mind, understanding, the five senses of perception, and the five senses of action. It is, therefore, free from all the perceptions that the senses give. It is heard only as a word, and its form, is not seen, but can only be conceived.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रोत्रं त्वक्चक्षुषी जिह्वा घ्राणं ज्ञानेन्द्रियाण्यथ। पादौ पायुरूपस्थश्च हस्तौ वाकर्मणी अपि॥
English Translation: It is a state of existence only on the mind. It has no connection with the senses. That pure state should be attained to by the understanding alone.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शब्दः स्पर्शश्च रूपं च रसो गन्धस्तथैव च। विज्ञेयं व्यापकं चित्तं तेषु सर्वगतं मनः॥
English Translation: He who practises it duly attains to Brahma; he who practises it half and half, attains to the status of the gods; while be who practises it indifferently, is born among Brahmanas and possessed of learning attains to eminence.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रसज्ञाने तु जिह्वयं व्याहते वाक् तथोच्यते। इन्द्रियैर्विविधैर्युक्तं सर्वं व्यक्तं मनस्तथा॥
English Translation: Brahmacharya is highly difficult to practise. Listen now to the means thereof. That twiceborn one who follows it should subdue the quality of Darkness as soon as it begins to show itself or as soon as it begins to be powerful.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विद्यात् तु षोडशैतानि दैवतानि विभागशः। देहेषु ज्ञानकर्तारमुपासीनमुपासते।॥
English Translation: One who has taken that yow should not speak with women. He should never look at a naked woman. The sight of women, under even indifferent circumstances, excites the passion of all weak-minded men.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तद्वत् सोमगुणा जिह्वा गन्धस्तु पृथिवीगुणः। श्रोतं नभोगुणं चैव चक्षुरग्नेर्गुणस्तथा। स्पर्श वायुगुणं विद्यात् सर्वभूतेषु सर्वदा॥
English Translation: If a person feels a desire for women rising in his heart, he should observe the vow called Krichcchra and also pass three days in water. If desire is formed even in a dream, one should, diving in water, mentally repeat for three times the three Riks by Aghamarshana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मनः सत्त्वगुणं प्राहुः सत्त्वमव्यक्तजं तथा। सर्वभूतात्मभूतस्थं तस्माद् बुद्ध्येत बुद्धिमान्॥
English Translation: That wise man who follows this VOW should, with a liberal and enlightened mind, consume the sins in his mind which are created by the quality of Darkness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एते भावा जगत् सर्वं वहन्ति सचराचरम्। श्रिता विरजसं देवं यमाहुः प्रकृतेः परम्॥
English Translation: As the passage that carries away the refuge of the body is very closely connected with the body, so the embodied Soul is very closely connected with the body that confines it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नवद्वारं पुरं पुण्यमेतैर्भावैः समन्वितम्। व्याप्य शेते महानात्मा तस्मात् पुरुष उच्यते॥
English Translation: The different sorts of juices, passing through the network of arteries, nourish men's wind, bile, phlegm, blood, skin, flesh, intestines, bones, marrow, and the whole body.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अजर: सोऽमरश्चैव व्यक्ताव्यक्तोपदेशवान्। व्यापक: सगुणः सूक्ष्मः सर्वभूतगुणाश्रयः॥
English Translation: Know that there are ten principle canals. These help the functions of the five senses. From those ten issue out thousands of other passages that are minuter in form.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथा दीपः प्रकाशात्मा ह्रस्वो वा यदि वा महान्। ज्ञानात्मानं तथा विद्यात् पुरुषं सर्वजन्तुषु॥
English Translation: Like rivers filling the ocean at the proper time, all these channels, containing juices, nourish the body.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रोत्रं वेदयते वेद्यं स शृणोति स पश्यति। कारणं तस्य देहोऽयं स कर्ता सर्वकर्मणाम्॥
English Translation: There is a channel leading to the heart called Manovaha. It draws from every part of the human body the seminal fluid which is born of desire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अग्निर्दारुगतो यद्वद् भिन्ने दारौ न दृश्यते। तथैवात्मा शरीरस्थो योगेनैवानुदृश्यते॥
English Translation: Numberless other channels issuing from that principal one extend into every part of the body and bearing the element of heat cause the sense of vision (and the rest).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अग्निर्यथा झुपायेन मथित्वा दारु दृश्यते। तथैवात्मा शरीरस्थो योगेनैवात्र दृश्यते॥
English Translation: As the butter that lies within milk is churned up by churing rods, so the desires that are created in the mind draw together the vital sced that lies within the body.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नदीष्वापो यथा युक्ता यथा सूर्ये मरीचयः। संततत्वाद् यथा यान्ति तथा देहाः शरीरिणाम्॥
English Translation: In the midst of even our dreams passion originating in imagination attacks the mind, with the result that the passage already named, viz., Manovaha, throws out the seminal fluid born of desire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्वप्नयोगे यथैवात्मा पञ्चेन्द्रियसमायुतः। देहमुत्सृज्य वै याति तथैवात्मोपलभ्यते॥
English Translation: The great and divine Rishi Atri is a inaster of the subject of the generation of the vital secd. The juices that are produced by food, the passage called Manovaha, and the desire that is born of imagination,-these three are the causes which create the seminal fluid which has Indra for its presiding god. The passion that helps the passing out of this fluid is, therefore, called Indriya.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्मणा बाध्यते रूपं कर्मणा चोपलभ्यते। कर्मणा नीयतेऽन्यत्र स्वकृतेन बलीयसा॥
English Translation: Those persons, who know that the course of seminal fluid is the cause of intermixture of castes, are men of controlled passions. Their sins are considered to have been consumed, and they are never subjected to re-birth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तु देहाद् यथा देहं त्यक्त्वान्यं प्रतिपद्यते। तथान्यं सम्प्रवक्ष्यामि भूतग्रामं स्वकर्मजम्॥
English Translation: He who performs action simply for the purpose of maintaining his body, reducing with the help of the mind the qualities into a state of equilibrium, and brings at his last moments the vital airs to the channel called Manovaha, is freed from re-birth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यास उवाच ब्रह्म तेजोमयं शुक्रं यस्य सर्वमिदं जगत्। एकस्य ब्रह्मभूतस्य द्वयं स्थावरजङ्गमम्॥
English Translation: The Mind is sure to acquire Knowledge. It is the Mind which assumes the form of all things. Acquiring success through meditation, the minds of all great persons, become freed from desire, eternal, and shining.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अहर्मुखे विवुद्धः सन् सृजतेऽविद्यया जगत्। अग्र एव महद्भूतमाशु व्यक्तात्मकं मनः॥
English Translation: Therefore, for destroying the mind, one should perform only pure deeds, and frecing himself from the qualities of Darkness and Ignorance, one is sure to acquire a very desirable end.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभिभूयेह चार्चिष्मद् व्यसृजत् सप्त मानसान्। दूरगं बहुधागामि प्रार्थनासंशयात्मकम्॥ मनः सृष्टिं विकुरुते चोद्यमानं सिसृक्षया। आकाशं जायते तस्मात् तस्य शब्दं गुणं विदुः॥
English Translation: Knowledge (ordinarily) acquired in younger days becomes weakened with decrepitude. Through the good effects of past lives, a person, however, of ripe understanding succeeds in killing his desires.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आकाशात् तु विकुर्वाणात् सर्वगन्धवहः शुचिः। बलवाञ्जायते वायुस्तस्य स्पर्शो गुणो मतः॥
English Translation: Such a person, by getting over the fetters of the body and the senses like a traveller crossing a path full of impediments, and transgressing all faults he sees, succeeds in testing the ambrosia (of Liberation.)
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वायोरपि विकुर्वाणाज्ज्योतिर्भवति भास्वरम्। रोचिष्णु जायते शुक्रं तद्रूपगुणमुच्यते॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said Tell me, O grandfather, how should a poor inan, desirous of achieving his own behoof, act after having acquired the status of humanity and come into this region of acts that is so difficult to acquire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ज्योतिषोऽपि विकुर्वाणाद् भवन्त्यापो रसात्मिकाः। अद्भ्यो गन्धवहा भूमिः सर्वेषां सृष्टिरुच्यते॥
English Translation: Tell me also what is the best of all gifts, and what should be given under what circumstances? Tell me, O son of Ganga, who are truly worthy of honour and adoration. You should describe these mysteries to us.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गुणाः सर्वस्य पूर्वस्य प्राप्नुवन्त्युत्तरोत्तरम्। तेषां यावद् यथा यच्च तत्तत् तावद्गुणं स्मृतम्॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said Thus accosted by that famous king, viz., the son of Pandu, Bhishma explained to that king these great mysteries about duty.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उपलभ्याप्सु चेद्गन्धं केचिद् ब्रूयुरनैपुणात्। पृथिव्यामेव तं विद्यादपां वायोश्च संश्रितम्॥
English Translation: Bhishma said Listen to me with rapt attention, O king, as I explain to you, O Bharata, these mysteries of duties as the holy Vyasa had explained them to me formerly.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एते सप्तविधात्मानो नानावीर्याः पृथक् पृथक्। नाशक्नुवन् प्रजाः स्रष्टुमसमागम्य कृत्स्नशः॥
English Translation: This subject is a mystery to the very celestials, O king. Yama of pure deeds, with the help of vows well observed and Yoga meditation, had acquired the knowledge of these mysteries as the high fruits of his penances.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते समेत्य महात्मानो ह्यन्योन्यमभिसंश्रिताः। शरीराश्रयणं प्राप्तास्ततः पुरुष उच्यते॥
English Translation: What pleases deity, what pleases the departed manes, the Rishis, the companions of Mahadeva, the goddess Shri Chitragupta, and the powerful Elephants which rule the cardinal points of the compass, what forms the religion of the Rishis, the religion viz., which has many mysteries and which yields high fruits, the merits of what are called great gifts, and the merits of all the sacrifices he who knows these, O sinless one, and knowing acts according to his knowledge, becomes freed from stains if he has stains and acquires the inerits indicated.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शरीरं श्रयणाद् भवति मूर्तिमत् षोडशात्मकम्। तमाविशन्ति भूतानि महान्ति सह कर्मणा॥
English Translation: One oilman is equal to ten butchers. Equal to ten oilmen is one drinker of alcohol. Equal to ten drinkers of alcohol is one harlot. Equal to ten harlots is a single king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वभूतान्युपादाय तपसश्चरणाय हि। आदिकर्ता स भूतानां तमेवाहुः प्रजापतिम्॥
English Translation: A great king is said to be equal to half of these all. Hence, one should not accept gifts from these. On the other hand, one should attend to the science, which is sacred and which has virtue for its marks, of the threefold objects of life. Amongst these, Wealth and Pleasure are naturally attractive. Hence one should, with rapt attention, listen to the sacred expositions of Religion, for the fruits of listening to the mysteries of Religion are very great. One should certainly hear every subject bearing on Religion as ordained by the celestials themselves.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स वै सृजति भूतानि स्थावराणि चराणि च। ततः स सृजति ब्रह्मा देवर्षिपितृमानवान्॥ लोकान् नदी: समुद्रांश्च दिशः शैलान् वनस्पतीन्। नरकिन्नररक्षांसि वय:पशुमृगोरगान्।
English Translation: In it is contained the ritual about the Shraddha in which have been declared the mysteries of the departed Manes. The mysteries about the deities have also been explained there.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अव्ययं च व्ययं चैव द्वयं स्थावरजङ्गमम्॥ तेषां ये यानि कर्माणि प्राक्सृष्ट्यां प्रतिपेदिरे। तान्येव प्रतिपाद्यन्ते सृज्यमानाः पुनः पुनः॥ हिंस्राहिंस्र मृदुरे धर्माधर्मावृतानृते। तद्भाविताः प्रपद्यन्ते तस्मात् तत् तस्य रोचते॥
English Translation: It contains the duties and practices, productive of great merit, of the Rishis also, together with the mysteries attaching to them. It contains an exposition of the merits of great sacrifices and all kinds of gifts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महाभूतेषु नानात्वमिन्द्रियार्थेषु पूर्तिषु। विनियोगं च भूतानां धातैव विदधात्युत॥
English Translation: Those men who always read the scriptures about these subjects, those who bear them properly in their mind, and he who, having listened to them, follows them in practice, are all considered to be as holy and sinless as the powerful Narayana himself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: केचित् पुरुषकारं तु प्राहुः कर्मसु मानवाः। दैवमित्यपरे विप्राः स्वभावं भूतचिन्तकाः॥
English Translation: The merits of the gift of kine, those that belong to the performance of ablutions in sacred waters, those that are acquired by the celebration of sacrifices, all these are acquired by that man who treats guests with respect.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पौरुषं कर्म दैवं च फलवृत्तिः स्वभावतः। त्रय एतेऽपृथग्भूता न विवेकं तु केचन॥
English Translation: They who listen to these scriptures, they who are gifted with faith and they who have a pure heart, it is well known conquer many regions of felicity. Those pious men who are gifted with faith, become cleansed of all since and no sin can touch them. Such men always increase in virtue and succeed in attaining to the celestial region.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतमेव च नैवं च न चोभे नानुभे न च। कर्मस्था विषयं ब्रूयुः सत्त्वस्थाः समदर्शिनः॥
English Translation: Once on a time a celestial messenger, coming to the court of Indra of his own accord, but remaining invisible, addressed the king of the deities in these words:
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तपो निःश्रेयसं जन्तोस्तस्य मूलं शमो दमः। तेन सर्वानवाणोति यान् कामान् मनसेच्छति॥
English Translation: At the command of Ashvini Kumars (the celestial physicians) and who are gifted with every desirable quality, I have come to this place where I see human beings the departed Manes and the celestials assembled together.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तपसा तदवाप्नोति यद्भूतं सृजते जगत्। स तद्भूतश्च सर्वेषां भूतानां भवति प्रभुः॥
English Translation: Why, indeed, is sexual intercourse interdicted for the man who performs a Shraddha and for him also who eats at a Shraddha? Why are three rice balls offered separately at a Shraddha?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ऋषयस्तपसा वेदानध्यैषन्त दिवानिशम्। अनादिनिधना विद्या वागुत्सृष्टा स्वयम्भुवा।२४॥
English Translation: To whom should the first of those balls be offered? To whom should the second one be offered? And whose has it been said is the third or the remaining one? I wish to know all this!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ऋषीणा नामधेयानि याश्च वेदेषु सृश्यः। नानारूपं च भूतानां कर्मणां च प्रवर्तनम्॥
English Translation: After the celestial messenger had said these words connected with virtue and duty, the celestials who were seated towards the east and the departed Manes also, praising that ranger of the sky, began as follows:
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वेदशब्देश्य एवादी निर्मिमीते स ईश्वरः। नामधेयानि चर्षीणां याश्च वेदेषु सृश्यः॥
English Translation: The Pitris said Welcome are you and blessings upon you! Do you listen, O best of all rangers of the sky! The question you have put is a high one and fraught with deep import.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शर्वर्यन्ते सुजातानामान्येभ्यो विदधात्यजः। नामभेदतप:कर्मयज्ञाख्या लोकसिद्धयः॥ आत्मसिद्धिस्तु वेदेषु प्रोच्यते दशभिः क्रमैः।
English Translation: The departed Manes of that man who indulges in sexual intercourse on the day he performs a Shraddha or eats at a Shraddha, have to lie for a whole month on his vital seed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदुक्तं वेदवादेषु गहनं वेददर्शिभिः। तदन्तेषु यथायुक्तं क्रमयोगेन लक्ष्यते॥
English Translation: We shall explain the classification of the riccballs offered at a Shraddha, The first ricehall should be thought of as being thrown into the waters.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्मजोऽयं पृथग्भावो द्वन्द्वयुक्तोऽपि देहिनः। तमात्मसिद्धिर्विज्ञानाज्जहाति पुरुषो बलात्॥
English Translation: The second ball should be given to one of the wives to eat. The third ball should be thrown into the burning fire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्वे ब्रह्मणी वेदितव्ये शब्दब्रह्म परं च यत्। शब्दब्रह्मणि निष्णातः परं ब्रह्माधिगच्छति॥
English Translation: This is the ordinance about the Shraddha. This is the ordinance of the rites of religion. The Pitris of that man who acts according to this ordinance become pleased with him and remain always cheerful. The progeny of such a man increases and he always commands endless riches.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आलम्भयज्ञाः क्षत्राश्च हविर्यज्ञा विशः स्मृताः। परिचारयज्ञाः शूद्रास्तु तपोयज्ञा द्विजातयः॥
English Translation: The Celestial Messenger said You have explained the division of the ricc balls and their consignment one after another to the three, together with the reasons thereof.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्रेतायुगे विधिस्त्वेष यज्ञानां न कृते युगे। द्वापरे विप्लवं यान्ति यज्ञाः कलियुगे तथा॥
English Translation: Whom does that riceball which is thrown into the waters reach? How does it , by being so thrown please the deities, and how does it rescue the departed Manes?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपृथग्धर्मिणो मा ऋक्सामानि यजूंषि च। काम्या इष्टीः पृथग् दृष्ट्वा तपोभिस्तप एव च।॥
English Translation: The second ball is eaten by the wife. That has been laid down in the ordinance. How do the Pitris of that man become the eaters thereof?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्रेतायां तु समस्ता समस्ता ये प्रादुरासन् महाबलाः। संयन्तारः स्थावराणां जगमानां च सर्वशः॥
English Translation: The last ball goes into the burning fire. How does that ball succeed in finding its way to you, or who is he to whom it goes?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्रेतायां संहता वेदा यज्ञा वर्णाश्रमास्तथा। संरोधादायुषस्त्वेते भ्रश्यन्ते द्वापरे युगे॥
English Translation: I wish to hear this, that is, what are the ends attained by the balls offered at Shraddhas when thus disposed of by being thrown into the waters, given to the wife, and thrown into the burning fire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दृश्यन्ते न च दृश्यन्ते वेदाः कलियुगेऽखिला:। उत्सीदन्ते सयज्ञाश्च केवलाधर्मपीडिताः॥
English Translation: The Pitris said The question which you have asked is of deep import. It involves a mystery and is wonderful. We have been highly pleased with you, O rarger of the sky.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृते युगे यस्तु धर्मो ब्राह्मणेषु प्रदृश्यते। आत्मवसु तपोवत्सु श्रुतवत्सु प्रतिष्ठितः॥
English Translation: The very celestials and the Munis applaud acts done in honour of the departed Manes. Even they do not know what the certain conclusions are of the ordinances about the acts done in honour of the Pitris.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सधर्मव्रतसंयोगं यथाधर्म युगे युगे। विक्रियन्ते स्वधर्मस्था वेदवादा यथागमम्॥
English Translation: Excepting the great, immortal and excellent Markandeya, that learned Brahmana of great fame, who is ever devoted to the Pitris, none amongst them is conversant with the mysteries of the ordinances about the Pitris.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथा विश्वानि भूतानि वृष्ट्या भूयांसि प्रावृषि। सृज्यन्ते जङ्गमस्थानि तथा धर्मा युगे युगे॥
English Translation: Having heard from the holy Vyasa what the end is of the three riceballs offered at the Shraddha, as explained by the Pitris themselves in reply to the question of the celestial messenger, I shall explain the same to you. Do you hear, o king, what the conclusions are about the ordinances about the Shraddha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथर्तुष्वृतुलिङ्गानि नानारूपाणि पर्यये। दृश्यन्ते तानि तान्येव तथा ब्रह्महरादिषु॥
English Translation: Listen with attention, O Bharata, to me as I explain what the end is of the three rice balls. That rice ball which goes into water is considered as pleasing the deity of the Moon.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विहितं कालनानात्वमनादिनिधनं तथा। कीर्तितं तत्पुरस्तात् ते तत्सूते चात्ति च प्रजाः॥
English Translation: That deity being pleased, O you of great intelligence gratifies in return the other deities and the Pitris also with them. It has bean laid down that the second riceball should be eaten by the wife.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दधाति प्रभवे स्थानं भूतानां संयमो यमः। स्वभावेनैव वर्तन्ते द्वन्द्वयुक्तानि भूरिशः॥
English Translation: The Pitris, who always wish for progeny, bestow children on the woman of the house. Listen now to me as I tell you what becomes of the rice ball that is thrown into the burning fire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्गकालक्रिया वेदाः कर्ता कार्य क्रियाफलम्। प्रोक्तं ते पुत्र सर्वं वै यन्मां त्वं परिपृच्छसि॥
English Translation: With that ball the Pitris are pleased, and as the result thereof, grant the fruition of all desires to the person offering it. I have thus told you everything about the end of the three riceballs offered at the Shraddha and consigned to the three (viz. water, the spouse and the fire.)
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जनमेजय उवाच अत्यद्भुतमिदं कर्म पार्थस्यामितेजसः। धृतराष्ट्रो महाप्राज्ञः श्रुत्वा विप्र किमब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: That Brahmana who becomes the priest at a Shraddha forins himself by that deed, the Pitri of the person performing ine Shraddha. Hence he should abstain that day from sexual intercourse with even his own wife.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच शक्रलोकगतं पार्थं श्रुत्वा राजाम्बिकासुतः। द्वैपायनादृषिश्रेष्ठात् संजयं वाक्यमब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: O best of all rangers of the sky, the man who eats at a Shraddha should remain pure for that day. By acting otherwise one surely commits the sin I have indicated. It cannot be otherwise.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच श्रुतं मे सूत कात्स्न्र्येन कर्म पार्थस्यधीमतः। कच्चित् तवापि विदितं याथातथ्येन सारथे॥
English Translation: Hence, the Brahmana who is invited to a Shraddha for eating the offerings should eat them after purifying himself by a bath and remain pious for that day by abstaining form every kind of injury or evil. The progeny of such a person multiplies and he also who feeds him gets the same reward.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रमत्तो ग्राम्यधर्मेषु मन्दात्मा पापनिश्चयः। मम पुत्रः सुदुर्बुद्धिः पृथिवीं घातयिष्यति॥
English Translation: Bhishma said After the Pitris had said so, a Rishi of austere penances, named Vidyutprabha, whose form was effulgent like the Sun spoke.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यस्य नित्यमृता वाचः स्वैरेष्वपि महात्मनः। त्रैलोक्यमपि तस्य स्याद् योद्धा यस्यधनंजयः॥
English Translation: Having heard those mysteries of religion as explained by che Pitris, he addressed Shakra, saying, Stupefied by folly, men kill numerous creatures born in the intermediate orders, such as worms, ants, snakes, sheep, deer and birds. They commit a great sin by these acts. What, however, is the remedy?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अस्यतः कर्णिनाराचांसतीक्ष्णाग्रांश्च शिलाशितान्। कोऽर्जुनस्याग्रतस्तिष्ठेदपि मृत्युर्जरातिगः॥
English Translation: When this question was asked, all the gods and Rishis having penances for wealth and the highly blessed Pitris, praised that ascetic.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मम पुत्रा दुरात्मानः सर्वे मृत्युवशानुगाः। येषां युद्धं दुराधर्षेः पाण्डवैः प्रत्युपस्थितम्॥
English Translation: Shakra said Thinking in one's mind of Kurukshetra and Gaya and Ganga and Prabhasa and the lakes of Pushkara, one should dip his head in a piece of water.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथैव च न पश्यामि युधि गाण्डीवधन्वनः। अनिशं चिन्तयानोऽपि य एनमुदियाद् रथी।॥
English Translation: By so doing he becomes purged off of all his sins like the Moon freed from Rahu. He should thus bathe for three days successively and then fast for every day.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्रोणकर्णी प्रतीयातां यदि भीष्मोऽपि वा रणे। महान् स्यात् संशयो लोके तत्र पश्यामि नो जयम्।९॥
English Translation: Besides this, he should touch (After bathing) the back of a cow and bow his head to her tail. Vidutprabha, after this, once more addressing Vasava said, I shall describe a rite that is more subtle. Listen to me, O you of a hundred sacrifices.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: घृणी कर्णः प्रमादी च आचार्यः स्थविरो गुरुः। अमर्षी बलवान् पार्थः संरम्भी दृढविक्रमः॥ सम्भवेत् तुमुलं युद्धं सर्वशोऽप्यपराजितम्। सर्वे शस्त्रविदः शूराः सर्वं प्राप्ता महद् यशः॥
English Translation: Rubbed with the astringent powder of the hanging roots of the banian and anointed with the oil of Priyangu, one should eat the Shashtika paddy mixed with milk. By so doing he becomes purged off all his sins.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपि सर्वेश्वरत्वं हि ते वाञ्छन्त्यपराजिताः। वधे नूनं भवेच्छान्तिरेतेषां फाल्गुनस्य वा॥
English Translation: Listen now to another mystery unknown to many but which was discovered by the Rishis with the help of meditation. I heard it from Brihaspati while he recited it before Mahadeva.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न तु हन्तार्जुनस्यास्ति जेता वास्य न विद्यते। मन्युस्तस्य कथं शाम्येन्मन्दान् प्रति समुत्थितः॥
English Translation: O king of the celestials do you hear it with Rudra in your company, O lord of Shachi. If a person, ascending a mountain stands there on one foot, with arms upraised and joined together and abstaining from food, looks at a burning fire, he acquires the merits of severe penances and obtains the rewards of fasts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्रिदशेशसमो वीरः खाण्डवेऽग्निमतर्पयत्। जिगाय पार्थिवान् सर्वान् राजसूये महाक्रतौ॥
English Translation: Heated by the rays of the Sun, he becomes purged off all his sins. One who acts thus in both the summer and the winter seasons becomes freed from every sin.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शेषं कुर्याद् गिरेर्वज्रो निपतन् मूर्ध्नि संजय। न तु कुर्युः शराः शेषं क्षिप्तास्तात किरीटिना॥
English Translation: Purged off of every sin one acquires a splendour of complexion for all time. Such a man burns with energy like the Sun or shines in beauty like the Moon.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथा हि किरणा भानोस्तपन्तीह चराचरम्। तथा पार्थभुजोत्सृष्टाः शरास्तप्यन्ति मत्सुतान्॥
English Translation: After this, the king of the celestials viz., he of a hundred sacrifices, seated in the midst of the gods then sweetly addressed Brihaspati, with these excellent words:
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपि तद्रथघोषेण भयार्ता सव्यसाचिनः। प्रतिभाति विदीर्णेव सर्वतो भारती चमूः॥
English Translation: O Holy One, do you describe those mysteries of religion which are fraught with happiness to human beings, and what the faults are which they commit, together with the mysteries of them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदोद्वहन् प्रवपंश्चैव बाणान् स्थाताऽऽततायी समरे किरीटी। सृष्टोऽन्तकः सर्वहरो विधात्रा भवेद् यथा तद्वदपारणीयः॥
English Translation: Brihaspati said They who pass urine, facing the sun, they who do not show respect for the wind, they who do not pour libations on the burning fire, they who milk a cow whose calf is very young, actuated by the desire of obtaining from her as much milk as possible, commit many sins. I shall describe what those faults are, O lord of Shachi, Do you hear me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्ण उवाच राधेयोऽहमाधिरथिः कर्णस्त्वामभिवादये। प्राप्ता किमर्थं भवती ब्रूहि किं करवाणि ते॥
English Translation: The Sun, Wind, the carrier of sacrificial oblations, O Vasava, and kine who are the mothers of all creatures, were created by the self-create himself, for rescuing all the worlds, O Shakra. These are the deities of human beings. Listen all the conclusions of religion.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कुन्त्युवाच कौन्तेयस्त्वं न राधेयो न तवाधिरथः पिता। नासि सूतकुले जातः कर्ण तद् विद्धि मे वचः॥
English Translation: Those wicked men and wicked women who pass urine facing the Sun, live in great infamy for eighty six years.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कानीनस्त्वं मया जातः पूर्वजः कुक्षिणा धृतः। कुन्तिराजस्य भवने पार्थस्त्वमसि पुत्रक॥
English Translation: That man, O Shakra, who cherishes no respect for the wind, gets children that come out prematurely from the womb of his wife. These men who do not pour libations on the burning fire, find that the fire, when they do light it up for such rites as they wish to perform refuses to eat their libations.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रकाशकर्मा तपनो योऽयं देवो विरोचनः। अजीजनत् त्वां मय्येष कर्ण शस्त्रभृतां वरम्॥
English Translation: Those men who drink the milk of kire whose calves are very young, never get children for perpetuating their races.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कुण्डली बद्धकवचो देवगर्भः श्रिया वृतः। जातस्त्वमसि दुर्धर्षं मया पुत्र पितुर्गुहे॥
English Translation: Such men see their children die and their families shrink. These are consequences of the acts referred to as observed by twice born persons, venerable for age in their respective families.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स त्वं भ्रातृनसम्बुद्ध्य मोहाद् यदुपसेवसे। धार्तराष्ट्रान् न तद्युक्तं त्वयि पुत्र विशेषतः॥
English Translation: Hence, one should always avoid that which has been interdicted and do only that which has been directed to be done, if one is desirous of securing his prosperity. This that I say to you is very true.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतद् धर्मफलं पुत्र नराणां धर्मनिश्चये। यत् तुष्यन्त्यस्य पितरो माता चाप्येकदर्शिनी॥
English Translation: After the celestial preceptor had said this the highly blessed celestials, with the Maruts, and the highly blessed Rishis questioned the departed Manes saying, You Pitris with what acts of human beings, who are generally gifted with little understandings, do you become pleased? What gifts made in course of such rites as are performed for improving the position of deceased persons in the other world become inexhaustible in efficacy?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्जुनेनार्जितां पूर्वं हृतां लोभादसाधुभिः। आच्छिद्य धार्तराष्ट्रेभ्यो भुक्ष्व यौधिष्ठिरीं श्रियम्॥
English Translation: By doing what acts can men become freed from the debt they owe to their ancestors? We wish to hear this. Great is our curiosity.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अद्य पश्यन्ति कुरवः कर्णार्जुनसमागमम्। सौभ्रात्रेण समालक्ष्य संनमन्तामसाधवः॥
English Translation: The Pitris said Yoy highly blessed ones, the doubt existing in your minds has been properly explained. Listen as we describe the deeds of righteous men with which we become pleased.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्णार्जुनौ वै भवेतां यथा रामजनार्दनौ। आस्थ्यं किं तु लोके स्याद् युवयोः संहितात्मनोः।।१०।
English Translation: Blue hued bulls should be liberated. Gifts should be made to us, on the day of the new moon of sesame seeds and water. In the season of rains, lamps should be lighted. By these decds of men they can free themselves from the debt they owe to their ancestors.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्ण शोभिष्यसे नूनं पञ्चभिर्धातृभिर्वृतः। देवैः परिवृतो ब्रह्मा वेद्यामिव महाध्वरे॥
English Translation: Such gifts never become vain. On the other hand they yield great and endless fruits. The gratification we derive from them is considered to be inexhaustible.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उपपन्नो गुणैः सर्वैयेष्ठः श्रेष्ठेषु बन्धुषु। सूतपुत्रेति मा शब्दः पार्थस्त्वमसि वीर्यवान्॥
English Translation: Those men who gifted with faith, beget offspring, rescue their deceased ancestors from imiserable Hell.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सौतिरुवाच एवमुक्त्वा ततः श्रीमान्मन्त्रिभिश्चानुमोदितः। आरुरोह प्रतिज्ञां स सर्पसत्राय पार्थिवः॥
English Translation: Hearing these words of the Pitris, Vriddha Gargya, endued with penances and high energy, became filled with wonder so that the hair on his body stood erect. Addressing them he said, Ye having penances for wealth, tell us what the merits are of setting free Bulls having blue complexions. What merits, again, are of the gifts of lamps in the season of rains and the gift of water with sesame seeds?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्रह्मन्भरतशार्दूलो राजा पारिक्षितस्तदा। पुरोहितमथाहूय ऋत्विजो वसुधाधिपः॥
English Translation: The Pitris said If a bull of blue complexion upon being liberated raises a (small) quantity of water with its tail the Pitris become pleased with that water for full sixty thousand years.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अब्रवीद्वाक्यसंपन्नः कार्यसंपत्करं वचः। यो मे हिंसितवांस्तातं तक्षकः स दुरात्मवान्॥
English Translation: The mud such a bull raises with its horns from the banks (of a river or lake) succeeds, forsooth, in sending the Pitris to the region of Soma.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रतिकुर्यां तथा तस्य तद्भवन्तो ब्रुवन्तु मे। अपि तत्कर्म विदितं भवतां येन पन्नगम्॥ तक्षकं संप्रऽग्नौ प्रक्षिपेयं सबान्धवम्। यथा तेन पिता मह्यं पूर्वं दग्धो विषाग्निना। तथाऽहमपि तं पापं दग्धुमिच्छामि पन्नगम्॥
English Translation: By giving lamps in the season of rains one shines with effulgence like Soma himself. The man who gives lamps is never subject to the quality of Darkness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ऋत्विज ऊचुः अस्ति राजन्महत्सत्रं त्वदर्थं देवनिर्मितम्। सर्पसत्रमितिख्यातं पुराणे परिपठ्यते॥
English Translation: Those men who make gifts on the day of the new moon of sesame seeds and water, mixed with honey and using a vessel of copper, O you having penances for wealth, are considered as duly performing a Shraddha with all its mysteries. These men get children of sound health and cheerful minds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आहर्ता तस्य सत्रस्य त्वन्नान्योऽस्ति नराधिप। इति पौराणिकाः प्राहुरस्माकं चास्ति स ऋतुः॥
English Translation: The merit acquired by the giver of the Pinda takes the forin of the growth of his family. Indeed, he who performs these acts with faith, becomes freed from the debt he owes to the ancestors.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सौतिरुवाच एवमुक्तः स राजर्षिर्मन दग्धं हि तक्षकम्। हुताशनमुखे दीप्ते प्रविष्टमिति सत्तम॥
English Translation: Thus have been laid down the proper time for the performance of the Shraddha, the ordinances about the rites to be observed the proper person that should be fed at the Shraddha, and the merits that belong to it. I have described everything to you in due orders.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽब्रवीन्मन्त्रविदस्तानराजा ब्राह्मणांस्तदा। आहरिष्यामि तत्सत्रं संभारा: संभ्रियन्तु मे॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said The (sacrificial) horse, having wandered over the entire Earth bounded by the ocean, then ceased and turned his face toward the city of Hastinapur.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्ते ऋत्विजस्तस्य शास्त्रतो द्विजसत्तम। तं देशं मापयामासुर्यज्ञायतनकारणात्॥
English Translation: Following as he did that horse, the diademdecked Arjuna also turned his face towards the Kuru capital. Wandering at is will, the horse then came to the city of Rajagriha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथावद्वेदविद्वांसः सर्वे बुद्धेः परंगताः। ऋद्ध्या परमया युक्तमिष्टं द्विजगणैर्युतम्॥ प्रभूतधनधान्याढ्यमृत्विग्भिः सुनिषेवितम्। निर्माय चापि विधिवद्यज्ञायतनमीप्सितम्॥ राजानं दीक्षयामासुः सर्पसत्राप्तये तदा। इदं चासीस्त्रार्वं सर्पसत्रे भविष्यति॥
English Translation: Seeing him arrived within his kingdom, O monarch, the heroic of Sahadeva, following Kshatriya duties, challenged him to battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निमित्तं महदुत्पन्नं यज्ञविघ्नकरं तदा। यज्ञस्यायतने तस्मिन्क्रियमाणे वचोऽब्रवीत्॥ स्थपतिर्बुद्धिसंपन्नो वास्तुविद्याविशारदः। इत्यब्रवीत्सूत्रधारः सूतः पौराणिकस्तदा॥
English Translation: Coming out of his city, Meghasandhi, mounted on his car and equipt with bow and arrows and leathern fence, rushed towards Dhananjaya who was on foot.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यस्मिन्देशे च काले च मापनेयं प्रवर्तिता। ब्राह्मणं कारणं कृत्वा नायं संस्थास्यते क्रतुः॥
English Translation: Gifted with great energy, Meghasandhi, approaching Dhanajaya, O king, said these words from a spirit of childishness and without son any skill.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतच्छ्रुत्वा तु राजाऽसौ प्राग्दीक्षाकालमब्रवीत्। क्षत्तारं न हि मे कश्चिदज्ञातः प्रविशेदिति॥
English Translation: This horse of yours, O Bharata, seems to move about, protected by women only! I shall take away the horse. Do you try to free him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बृहदश्व उवाच आसीद् राजा नलो नाम वीसेनसुतो बली। उपपन्नो गुणैरिष्टै रूपवानश्वकोविदः॥
English Translation: Although my sires did not teach you in battle, I, however, shall do the duties of hospitality to you. Do you strike me, for I shall strike you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अतिष्ठन्मनुजेन्द्राणां मूर्ध्नि देवपतिर्यथा। उपर्युपरि सर्वेषामादित्य इव तेजसा॥ ब्रह्मण्यो वेदविच्छूरो निषधेषु महीपतिः। अक्षप्रियः सत्यवादी महानक्षौहिणीपतिः॥
English Translation: Thus addressed, the son of Pandu, smiling the while, answered him, saying, To resist him who obstructs me is the vow imposed on me by my eldest brother. Forsooth, O king, you know this. Do you strike me to the best of your power. I have no anger.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ईप्सितो वरनारीणामुदारः संयतेन्द्रियः। रक्षिताधन्विनां श्रेष्ठः साक्षादिव मनुः स्वयम्॥
English Translation: Thus addressed, the king of Magadha first struck the son of Pandu, showering his arrows on him like the thousand-eyed Indra showering a heavy downpour of rain.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथैवासीद् विदर्भेषु भीमो भीमपराक्रमः। शूरः सर्वगुणैर्युक्तः प्रजाकामः स चाप्रजः॥
English Translation: Then, Ochief of Bharata's race, the heroic wielder of Gandiva, with arrows shot of that excellent bow, baffled all the arrows shot carefully at him by his adversary.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स प्राजर्थे परं यत्नमकरोत् सुसमाहितः। तमभ्यगच्छद् ब्रह्मर्षिर्दमनो नाम भारत॥
English Translation: Having thus baffled that cloud of arrows, the ape-bannered hero shot a number of burning arrows at his enemy which resembled snakes with fiery mouths.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं स भीमः प्रजाकामस्तोषयामासधर्मवित्। महिष्या सह राजेन्द्र सत्कारेण सुवर्चसम्॥ तस्मै प्रसन्नो दमनः सभार्याय वरं ददौ। कन्यारत्नं कुमारांश्च त्रीनुदारान् महायशाः॥
English Translation: These arrows he shot at his flag and flagstaff and car and poles and yoke and the horses sparing the body of his-enemy and his cardriver.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दमयन्ती दमं दान्तं दमनं च सुवर्चसम्। उपपन्नान् गुणैः सर्वैर्भीमान् भीमपराक्रमान्॥
English Translation: Though Partha who was capable of shooting with the bow with the left-hand (as well as the right) spared the body of the king of Magadha, yet the latter, thinking that his body was protected by his own prowess, discharged many arrows at Partha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दमयन्ती तु रूपेण तेजसा यशसा श्रिया। सौभाग्येन च लोकेषु यशः प्राप्त सुमध्यमा॥
English Translation: The wielder of Gandiva, deeply struck by the king of Magadha, shone like a blossoming Palasha (Butea frondosa) in the season of spring.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ तां वयसि प्राप्ते दासीनां समलंकृताम्। शतं शतं सखीनां च पर्युपासच्छचीमिव॥
English Translation: Arjuna had no desire of killing the king of Magadha. It was for this that, having struck the son of Pandu, he succeeded in remaining before that foremost of heroes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्र स्म राजते भैमी सर्वाभरणभूषिता। सखीमध्येऽनवद्याङ्गी विद्युत्सौदामनी यथा॥
English Translation: Then Dhananjaya, becoming angry, drew his bow with great force, and killed his antagonist's horses and then struck off the head of his car-driver.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अतीव रूपसम्पन्ना श्रीरिवायतलोचना। न देवेषु न यक्षेषु तादृग् रूपवती क्वचित्॥
English Translation: With a razor-headed arruw he then cut off Meghasandhi's large and beautiful bow, and then his leathern fence. Then cutting off his flag and flag-staff, he caused it to fall down.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मानुषेष्वपि चान्येषु दृष्टपूर्वाथवा श्रुता। चित्तप्रसादनी बाला देवानामपि सुन्दरी॥
English Translation: The king of Magadha greatly afflicted, and deprived of horses and bow and driver, took up a mace and rushed with great speed at the son of Kunti.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नलश्च नरशार्दूलो लोकेष्वप्रतिमो भुवि। कन्दर्प इव रूपेण मूर्तिमानभवत् स्वयम्॥
English Translation: Arjuna, then, with many arrows of his equipt with his vulturine feathers, cut off into pieces, that mace of his advancing enemy which was adorned with bright gold.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्याः समीपे तु नलं प्रशशंसुः कुतूहलात्। नैषधस्य समीपे तु दमयन्तीं पुनः पुनः॥
English Translation: Thus cut off into pieces, that mace, with its jeweiled bonds and knots all severed, fell on the Earth, like a she-snake helplessly hurled down by somebody.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तयोरदृष्टः कामोऽभूच्छृण्वतोः सततं गुणान्। अन्योन्यं प्रति कौन्तेय स व्यवर्धत हृच्छयः॥
English Translation: When his enemy became deprived of his car, his bow, and his mace, the ape-bannered hero then, comforting his cheerless enemy who had been observant of Kshatriya duties, said to him these words: O son, you have sufficiently shorn your adherence to Kshatriya duties. Go now. Great have been the feats, O king, which you have accomplished in battle although you are very young in years.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अशक्नुवन् नलः कामं तदाधारयितुं हृदा। अन्तःपुरसमीपस्थे वन आस्ते रहोगतः॥
English Translation: The command I received from Yudhishthira was that kings who oppose me should not be killed. It is for this you live yet, O monarch, although you have offended me in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न ददर्श ततो हंसान् जातरूपपरिष्कृतान्। वने विचरतां तेषामेकं जचाह पक्षिणम्॥
English Translation: Thus addressed, the king of Magadha considered himself defeated and spared. Thinking then that it was his duty to do so, he approached Arjuna and joining his hands in respect adored him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽन्तरिक्षगो वाचं व्याजहार नलं तदा। हन्तव्योऽस्मि न ते राजन् करिष्यामि तव प्रियम्।२०॥
English Translation: And he said, Defeated have I been by you! Blessed be you, I do not venture to continue the battle. Tell me what I am to do now for you! Consider your command as already carried out.'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दमयन्तीसकाशे त्वां कथयिष्यामि नैषध। यथा त्वदन्यं पुरुषं न सा मंस्यति कर्हिचित्॥
English Translation: Comforting him again, Arjuna once more said to him. You should go to the HorseSacrifice of our king which takes place at the coming full moon of Chaitra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्तस्ततो हंसमुत्ससर्ज महीपतिः। ते तु हंसाः समुत्पत्य विदर्भानगमंस्ततः॥
English Translation: Thus addressed by him, the son of Sahadeva said, So be it, and then duly adored that horse as also Phalguna, that foremost of warriors.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विदर्भनगरौं गत्वा दमयन्त्यास्तदान्तिके। निपेतुस्ते गरुत्मन्तः सा ददर्श च तान् खगान्॥
English Translation: The sacrificial horse then, having beautiful manes, proceeded at his will along the seacoast, going to the countries of the Bangas, the Pundras, and the Kosalas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सा तानद्भुतरूपान् वै दृष्ट्वा सखिगणावृता। हृष्टा ग्रहीतुं खगमांस्त्वरमाणोपचक्रमे॥
English Translation: In those kingdoms Dhananjaya, with his bow Gandiva, O king, defeated numberless Mleccha armies one after another.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ हंसा विससृपुः सर्वतः प्रमदावने। एकैकशस्तदा कन्यास्तान् हंसान् समुपाद्रवन्॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said Of whose wealth, O foremost of Bharata's race, is the king considered to be the master? And what conduct also should the king follow? Describe to me this, O grandfather!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दमयन्ती तु यं हंसं समुपाधावदन्तिके। स मानुषी गिरं कृत्वा दमयन्तीमथाब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: Bhishma said 'The Vedas declare that the king is the master of the wealth that belongs to all persons except Brahmanas, as also of those Brahmanas who do not follow their proper duties.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दमयन्ति नलो नाम निषधेषु महीपतिः। अश्विनोः सदृशो रूपे न समास्तस्य मानुषाः॥
English Translation: The king should not spare those Brahmanas who do not follow their duties. The righteous say that this is the ancient practice of kings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कन्दर्प इव रूपेण मूर्तिमानभवत् स्वयम्। तस्य वै यदि भार्या त्वं भवेथा वरवर्णिनी॥ सफलं ते भवेज्जन्म रूपं चेदं सुमध्यमे। वयं हि देवगन्धर्वमनुष्योरगराक्षसान्॥ दृष्टवन्तो न चास्माभिर्दृष्टपूर्वस्तथाविधः। त्वं चापि रत्नं नारीणां नरेषु च नलो वरः॥ विशिष्टया विशिष्टेन संगमो गुणवान् भवेत्।
English Translation: That king, O monarch, in whose dominion a Brahmana becomes a thief, is considered to be the doer of that misdeed. The king is visited by sins on that account.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्ता तु हंसेन दमयन्ती विशांपते॥ अब्रवीत् तत्र तं हंसं त्वमप्येवं नले वद। तथेत्युक्त्वाण्डजः कन्या विदर्भस्य विशाम्पते। पुनरागम्य निषधान् नले सर्वं न्यवेदयत्॥
English Translation: For such an offence, kings consider themselves to be worthy of reproach. All righteous kings, therefore, provide Brahmanas with the means of sustenance,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच यदप्यल्पतरं कर्म तदप्येकेन दुष्करम्। पुरुषेणासहायेन किमु राज्ञा पितामह॥
English Translation: Regarding it is cited the old narrative of the speech made by the king of the Kaikeyas to a Rakshasa while the latter was about to abduct him away.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किंशील: किंसमाचारो राज्ञोऽथ सचिवो भवेत्। कीदृशे विश्वसेद् राजा कीदृशे न च विश्वसेत्॥
English Translation: Of rigid vows and well-read in the Vedas, the king of the Kaikeyas, O monarch, while living in the forest, was by force seized on a certain occasion by a Rakshasa.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच चतुर्विधानि मित्राणि राज्ञां राजन् भवन्त्युत। सहार्थो भजमानश्च सहजः कृत्रिमस्तथा॥
English Translation: The king said, There is no thief in my kingdom, nor any wicked person nor any one who drinks alcohol. There is no one in my kingdomn who does not preserve his sacred fire or who does not celebrate sacrifices. How then have you been able to possess by heart?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धर्मात्मा पञ्चमश्चापि मित्रं नैकस्य न द्वयोः यतो धर्मस्ततो वा स्याद् धर्मस्थो वा ततो भवेत्॥
English Translation: There is not Brahmana in my territories who is not learned or who does not observe Vows or who has not drunk Soma. There is no one who does not preserve his sacred fire or who does not celebrate sacrifices. How then have you been able to possess my soul?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यस्तस्यार्थो न रोचेत न तं तस्य प्रकाशयेत्। धर्माधर्मेण राजानश्चरन्ति विजिगीषवः॥
English Translation: In my kingdom no sacrifice has been celebrated without completing it by Dakshina. No one in my kingdom studies the Vedas who does not observe vows. How then have you been able to possess my soul?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चतुर्णां मध्यमौ श्रेष्ठौ नित्यं शङ्कयौ तथापरौ। सर्वे नित्यं शङ्कितव्याः प्रत्यक्षं कार्यमात्मनः॥
English Translation: The Brahmanas in my kingdom teach, study, sacrifice, officiate at others' sacrifices, give, and receive presents. All of them perform those six acts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न हि राज्ञा प्रमादो वै कर्तव्यो मित्ररक्षणे। प्रमादिनं हि राजानं लोकाः परिभवन्त्युत॥
English Translation: The Brahmanas in my kingdom devotedly follow the duties of their order. Adored and provided for, they are mild, and truthful in speech. How then have you been to possess my soul?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: असाधुः साधुतामेति साधुर्भवति दारुणः। अरिश्च मित्रं भवति मित्रं चापि प्रदुष्यति॥
English Translation: The Kshatriyas in my kingdom devotedly follow the duties of their order. They never beg but give, and are conversant with truth and virtue. They never teach but study, and celebrate sacrifices but never officiate at the sacrifices of others. They protect the Brahmanas and never fly from battlefield. How then have you been able to possess my soul,?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनित्यचित्तः पुरुषस्तस्मिन् को जातु विश्वसेत्। तस्मात्प्रधानं यत् कार्यं प्रत्यक्षं तत् समाचरेत्॥
English Translation: The Vaishyas in my kingdom all follow the duties of their order. With simplicity and without deceit they gain their livelihood from agriculture, cattle-keeping, and trade. They are all careful, observant of religious rites and excellent vows, and truthful in speech.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एकान्तेन हि विश्वासः कृत्स्नो धर्मार्थनाशकः। अविश्वासश्च सर्वत्र मृत्युना च विशिष्यते॥
English Translation: They give to their guests what is their due, are self-controlled and pure, and devoted to their relatives and kinsmen. How then have you been to possess my heart?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अकालमृत्युर्विश्वासो विश्वसन् हि विपद्यते। यस्मिन् करोति विश्वासमिच्छतस्तस्य जीवति॥
English Translation: The Shudras in my kingdom, always follow the duties of their order, humbly and duly serve and wait upon the other three orders without cherishing any inalice towards them. How then have you been able to possess my heart?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्माद् विश्वसितव्यं च शङ्कितव्यं च केषुचित्। एषा नीतिगतिस्तात लक्ष्या चैव सनातनी॥
English Translation: I support the helpless and the old, the weak, the ill, and helpless women by giving them all their necessaries. How then have you been able to possess my heart?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यं मन्येत ममाभावादिममर्थागमं स्पृशेत्। नित्यं तस्माच्छङ्कितव्यममित्रं तद् विदुर्बुधाः॥
English Translation: I have never done away with the special customs of families and of countries obtaining from days of yore. How then have you been able to possess my heart?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यस्य क्षेत्रादप्युदकं क्षेत्रमन्यस्य गच्छति। न तत्रानिच्छतस्तस्य भिघेरन् सर्वसेतवः॥
English Translation: The ascetics in my kingdom are protected and adored. They are always honoured and fed with food. How then have you been able to posses my heart?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथैवात्युदकाद् भीतस्तस्य भेदनमिच्छति। यमेवंलक्षणं विद्यात् तममित्रं विनिर्दिशेत्॥
English Translation: I never eat without feeding others from my food. I never know other people's wives. I never sport or recreate alone. How then have you been able to possess my heart?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यस्तु वृद्ध्या न तृप्येत क्षये दीनतरो भवेत्। एतदुत्तममित्रस्य निमित्तमिति चक्षते॥
English Translation: No one in my kingdom save a Brahmacharin begs his food, and no one who lives a mendicant's life desires to be a Brahmacharin. No one but a Ritwij pours libations (of clarified butter) upon the sacrificial fire. How then have you been able to possess my soul?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यन्मन्येत ममाभावादस्याभावो भवेदिति। तस्मिन् कुर्वीत विश्वासं यथा पितरि वै तथा॥ तं शक्त्या वर्धमानश्च सर्वतः परिबृंहयेत्। नित्यं क्षताद् वारयति यो धर्मेष्वपि कर्मसु॥ क्षताद् भीतं विजानीयादुत्तमं मित्रलक्षणम्। ये तस्य क्षतमिच्छन्ति ते तस्य रिपवः स्मृताः॥
English Translation: I never disrespect the learned or the old or those who practise penances. When all people are asleep, I keep up (for watching and protecting). How then have you been able to possess my heart?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यसनान्नित्यभीतो यः समृद्ध्या यो न दुष्यति। यत् स्यादेवंविधं मित्रं तदात्मसममुच्यते॥
English Translation: My priest is endued with the knowledge of self. He practises penances, and is a master of duties. Highly intelligent he has the fullest power over my kingdom.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रूपवर्णस्वरोपेतस्तितिक्षुरनसूयकः। कुलीन: शीलसम्पन्नः स ते स्यात् प्रत्यनन्तरः॥
English Translation: By presents I desire to acquire knowledge, and by truth and the protection of Brahmanas. I wish to attain blissful regions of heaven. I always strive to serve my preceptors with my services. I do not fear the Rakshasas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मेधावी स्मृतिमान् दक्षः प्रकृत्या चानृशंस्यवान्। यो मानितोऽमानितो वा न च दुष्येत् कदाचन॥ ऋत्विग्वा यदि वाऽऽचार्यः सखा वात्यन्तसंस्तुतः। गृहे वसेदमात्यस्ते स स्यात् परमपूजितः॥
English Translation: In my kingdom there are no widows, no wicked Brahmanas, no Brahmana who had not satisfied his duties, no deceitful person, no thief, no Brahmana who officiates in the sacrifices of those for whom he should never officiate, and no perpetrator of sinful deeds. I do not fear the Rakshasas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स ते विद्यात् परं मन्त्रं प्रकृतिं चार्थधर्मयोः। विश्वासस्ते भवेत् तत्र यथा पितरि वै तथा॥
English Translation: There is no space in my body, of even two fingers breadth, which does not contain the mark of a weapon-wound. I always fight for the sake of fairness. How then have you been able to possess my heart?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नैव द्वौ न त्रयः कार्या न मृष्येरन् परस्परम्। एकार्थे ह्येव भूतानां भेदो भवति सर्वदा॥
English Translation: The people of my kingdom always bless me so that I may always be able to protect kine and Brahmanas and celebrate sacrifices. How then have you been able to possess me?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कीर्तिप्रधानो यस्तु स्याद् यश्च स्यात् समये स्थितः। समर्थान् यश्च न वश् िनानर्थान् कुरुते च यः॥ यो न कामाद् भयाल्लोभात् क्रोधाद् वा धर्ममुत्सृजेत्। दक्षः पर्याप्तवचनः स ते स्यात् प्रत्यनन्तरः॥
English Translation: Since you satisfy your duties under all circumstances, therefore, O king of the Kaikeyas, go back to your palace. Blessed be you, I leave you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कुलीनः शीलसम्पन्नस्तितिक्षुरविकत्थनः। शूरश्चार्यश्च विद्वांश्च प्रतिपत्तिविशारदः॥ एते ह्यमात्याः कर्तव्याः सर्वकर्मस्ववस्थिताः। पूजिताः संविभक्ताश्च सुसहायाः स्वनुष्ठिताः॥
English Translation: They, O king of the Kaikeyas, who protect kine and Brahmanas and all their subjects, have no fear of Rakshasas, what speak of sinful persons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृत्स्नमेते विनिक्षिप्ताः प्रतिरूपेषु कर्मसु। युक्ता महत्सु कार्येषु श्रेयांस्युत्थापयन्त्युत॥
English Translation: Those kings, who yield to Brahmanas and whose might depends upon that of the Brahmanas, and whose subjects are always hospitable, always succeed in gaining heaven.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एते कर्माणि कुर्वन्ति रूपर्धमाना मिथः सदा। अनुतिष्ठन्ति चैवार्थमाचक्षाणाः परस्परम्॥
English Translation: Bhishma continued:-You should; therefore, protect the Brahmanas. Protected by you, they will protect you in return. Their blessings, O king, would, forsooth, come upon righteous kings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ज्ञातिभ्यश्चैव बुद्ध्येथा मृत्योरिव भयं सदा। उपराजेव राजर्धि ज्ञातिर्न सहते सदा॥
English Translation: For the sake of righteousness, those Brahmanas who do not follow the duties of their order should be chastised and separated from their betters.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ऋजोर्मदोर्वदान्यस्य ह्रीमतः सत्यवादिनः। नान्यो ज्ञातेर्महाबाहो विनाशमभिनन्दति॥
English Translation: A king, who behaves thus towards the people of his city and the provinces, enjoys prosperity here and lives in heaven with Indra.'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अज्ञातिनोऽपि न सुखा नावज्ञेयास्ततः परम्। अज्ञातिमन्तं पुरुषं परे चाभिभवन्त्युत॥
English Translation: Proceeding by many charming forests and lakes and sacred waters, the Brahmana at last arrived at the asylum of a certain ascetic.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निकृतस्य नरैरन्यैर्शातिरेव परायणम्। नान्यैनिकारं सहते ज्ञातिव्रते: कथञ्चन॥
English Translation: Going there, he enquired of him, in proper words, about the Naga of whom he had heard from his guest, and instructed by him he pursued his journey.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आत्मानमेव जानाति निकृतं बान्धवैरपि। तेषु सन्ति गुणाश्चैव नैर्गुण्यं चैव लक्ष्यते॥ नाज्ञातिरनुगृह्णाति न चाज्ञातिर्नमस्यति। उभयं ज्ञातिवर्गेषु दृश्यते साध्वसाधु च॥
English Translation: With a clear idea of the object of his journey the Brahman then reached the house of the Naga. Entering it duly, he announced his arrival in proper words, saying,-Ho! who is there! I am a Brahmana come here as a guest!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सम्मानयेत् पूजयेच्च वाचा नित्यं च कर्मणा। कुर्याच्च प्रियमेतेभ्यो नाप्रियं किञ्चिदाचरेत्॥
English Translation: Hearing these words, the chaste wife of the Naga, endued with great beauty and devoted to the observance of all duties, showed herself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विश्वस्तवदविश्वस्तस्तेषु वर्तेत सर्वदा। न हि दोषा गुणो वेति निरूप्यस्तेषु दृश्यते॥
English Translation: Always attentive to the duties of hospitality, she adored the guest with due rites, and welcoming him, said,-What can I do for you?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अस्यैवं वर्तमानस्य पुरुषस्याप्रमादिनः। अमित्राः संप्रसीदन्ति तथा मित्रीभवन्त्यपि॥
English Translation: The Brahmana said O lady, I am sufficiently honoured by you with the sweet words you have said unto me. The fatigue of the journey has also been removed. I wish, O blessed lady, to see your excellent husband.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: य एवं वर्तते नित्यं ज्ञातिसम्बन्धिमण्डले। मित्रेष्वमित्रे मध्यस्थे चिरं यशसि तिष्ठति॥
English Translation: This is my great object. This is the one object of my desire. It is for this reason that I have come to-day to the house of the Naga your husband.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच साधु पश्यति वै द्रौणिः कृपः साध्वनुपश्यति। कर्णस्तु क्षत्रधर्मेण केवलं योद्भुमिच्छति॥
English Translation: The Wife of the Naga said Reverend Sir, my husband has gone to drag the car of the Sun for a month. O learned Brahmana, he return in fifteen days, and will, forsooth, appear before you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आचार्यो नाभिवक्तव्यं पुरुषेण विजानता। देशकालौ तु सम्प्रेक्ष्य योद्धव्यमिति मे मतिः॥
English Translation: I have thus told you the reason of my husband's absence from home. Be that as it may, what else is there that I can do for you? Tell me this.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यस्य सूर्यसमाः पञ्च सपत्नाः स्युः प्रहारिणः। कथमभ्युदये तेषां न प्रमुह्येत पण्डितः॥
English Translation: The Brahmana said O chaste lady, I have come here with the object of seeing your husband. O reverend dame, I shall live in the adjacent forest, waiting for his return.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्वार्थे सर्वे विमुह्यन्ति येऽपि धर्मविदो जनाः। तस्माद् राजन् ब्रवीम्येष वाक्यं ते यदि रोचते॥
English Translation: When your husband returns, do kindly tell him that I have arrived at this place actuated by the desire of seeing him. You should also inform me of his return when that event takes place.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्णो हि यदवोचत् त्वां तेजः संजननाय तत्। आचार्यपुत्रः क्षमतां महत् कार्यमुपस्थितम्॥
