English Translation: O blessed lady, I shall, till then, live on the banks of the Gomati, waiting for his return and living restricted diet.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नायं कालो विरोधस्य कौन्तेये समुपस्थिते। क्षन्तव्यं भवता सर्वमाचार्येण कृपेण च॥
English Translation: Having said this repeatedly to the wife of the Naga, the foremost of Brahmanas went to the banks of the Gomati for living there till the time of Naga's return. O blessed lady, I shall, till then, live on the banks of the Gomati, waiting for his return and living restricted diet.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भवतां हि कृतास्त्रत्वं यथाऽऽदित्ये प्रभा तथा। यथा चन्द्रमसो लक्ष्मीः सर्वथा नापकृष्यते॥ एवं भवत्सु ब्राह्मण्यं ब्रह्मास्त्रं च प्रतिष्ठितम्। चत्वार एकतो वेदाः क्षात्रमेकत्र दृश्यते॥
English Translation: Having said this repeatedly to the wife of the Naga, the foremost of Brahmanas went to the banks of the Gomati for living there till the time of Naga's return.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नैतत् समस्तमुभयं कस्मिंसश्चिदनुशुश्रुम। अन्यत्र भारताचार्यात् सपुत्रादिति मे मतिः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said: Thereupon the Pandavas again thus spoke to Markandeya.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वेदान्ताश्च पुराणानि इतिहासं पुरातनम्। जामदग्न्यमृते राजन् को द्रोणादधिको भवेत्॥
English Translation: You have spoken to us about the greatness of the Brahmanas, we now desire to hear about the greatness of the royal order the Kshatriyas. To them replied the great Rishi Markandeya, "Hear now of the greatness of the royal order." A king of the Kuru dynasty named Suhotra went on a visit to the great Rishis and as he was returning he saw king Shivi, the son of Ushinara. As they met, they each saluted the other as best fitted to his age. Considering each equal to the other, they did not allow way to each other. At this time Narada came. (He said) why are, you standing here thus blocking each others way?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्रह्मास्त्रं चैव वेदाश्च नैतदन्यत्र दृश्यते। आचार्यपुत्रः क्षमतां नायं कालो विभेदने॥ सर्वे संहत्य युध्यामः पाकशासनिमागतम्॥
English Translation: They said to Narada, “O exalted one, you should not speak thus. The sages of old have said that way should be given to one who is superior or abler. We that stand blocking each other's way are equal to each other in every respect. If properly judged, there is no superiority or inferiority between us." Having been thus addressed, Narada recited the following words.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बलस्य व्यसनानीह यान्युक्तानि मनीषिभिः। मुख्यो भेदो हि तेषां तु पापिष्ठो विदुषां मतः॥
English Translation: O descendant of Kuru, he who is cruel behaves cruelly towards even those who are humble and he who is humble behaves humbly and honestly towards even those are wicked. He who is honest behaves honestly towards even those who are dishonest, why then should not he behave honestly with one who is honest.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अश्वत्थामोवाच नैव न्याय्यमिदं वाच्यमस्माकं पुरुषर्षभ। किं तु रोषपरीतेन गुरुणा भाषिता गुणाः॥
English Translation: He who is honest considers the service that is done to him, as if it were one hundred times greater than it (really) is. This is the custom amongst the celestial. The ruler of earth, the son of Ushinara, certainly possesses greater goodness than you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शत्रोरपि गुणा ग्राह्या दोषा वाच्या गुरोरपि। सर्वथा सर्वयत्नेन पुत्रे शिष्ये हितं वदेत्॥
English Translation: One should conquer the mean by charity, the untruthful by truth, the wicked by forgiveness and the dishonest by honesty.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुर्योधन उवाच आचार्य एव क्षमतां शान्तिरत्र विधीयताम्। अभिद्यमाने तु गुरौ तद् वृत्तं रोषकारितम्॥
English Translation: Both of you are generous-minded. Let one of you stand aside (giving the way to the other) according to the above words Having said this, Narada became silent. Having heard this, the descendant of Kuru, (king Suhotra), walking round Shivi and praising his many good deeds, gave him the way and went away.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच ततो दुर्योधनो द्रोणं क्षपयामास भारत। सह कर्णेन भीष्मेण कृपेण च महात्मना॥
English Translation: It is thus that Narada has described the greatness of the royal order.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्रोण उवाच यदेतत् प्रथमं वाक्यं भीष्मः शान्तनवोऽब्रवीत्। तेनैवाहं प्रसन्नो वै नीतिरत्र विधीयताम्॥ यथा दुर्योधनं पार्थो नोपसर्पति संगरे।
English Translation: Yudhishthira said : O high-souled and the exalted Brahmana, I desire to know the names of that great deity by which he is celebrated all over the three worlds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: साहसाद् यदि वा मोहात् तथा नीतिर्विधीयताम्॥ वनवासे ह्यनिर्वृत्ते दर्शयेन धनंजयः।
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Having been thus addressed by the illustrious Pandava in the midst of the Rishis, the exalted and the greatly ascetic Markandeya said-
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धनं चालभमानोऽत्र नाद्य तत् क्षन्तुमर्हति॥ यथा नायं समायद्याद् धार्तराष्ट्रान् कथंचन। न च सेनाः पराजय्यात् तथा नीतिर्विधीयताम्॥ उक्तं दुर्योधनेनापि पुरस्ताद् वाक्यमीदृशम्। तदनुस्मृत्य गाङ्गेय यथावद् वक्तुमर्हसि॥
English Translation: Markandeya said : (They are) Agneya, Skanda, Diptakirti, Anameya, Mayuraketu, Dharmatma, Bhutesha, Mahishmardana, Kamajit, Kamada, Kanta, Satyavak, Bhuvaneshvara, Shishu, Shighra, Suchi, Chanda, Dipatvarna, Shubhanana, Amogha, Anagha, Raudra, Priya, Chandranana, Diptashakti, Prashantatman, Bhadrakrit, Kutamohana, Shashtipriya, Pavitra, Matrivatsala, Kanyabharta, Vibhakta, Svaheya, Revatisuta, Prabhu, Neta, Vishakha, Naigameya, Suduschara, Suduschara, Suvrata, Lalita, Balakridanakapriya, Akashachari, Brahmachari, Shura, Shakhanodbhava, Vishvamitrapriya, Devasenapriya, Vasudevapriya, Priya and Priyakrit. These are the divine names of Kartikeya. Whoever repeats them there is no doubt he secures fame, wealth and salvation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच धर्माः पितामहेनोक्ता राजधर्माश्रिताः शुभाः। धर्ममाश्रमिणां श्रेष्ठं वक्तुमर्हसि पार्थिव॥
English Translation: O foremost of the Kurus, I shall now with devotion pray to that matchless, powerful, six faced and brave Guha who is worshipped by the celestials and the Rishis. Listen to them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच सर्वत्र विहितो धर्मः स्वर्ग्यः सत्यफलं तपः। बहुद्वारस्य धर्मस्य नेहास्ति विफला क्रिया॥
English Translation: O Skanda, you are devoted to Brahma you are begotten by Brahma, you are versed in the mysteries of Brahma, you are Brahmeshya, you are the foremost of those who possess Brahma, you are fond of Brahma, you are as austere as the Brahmanas, you are learned in the great mystery of Brahma and you are the leader of the Brahmanas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यस्मिन् यस्मिस्तु विषये यो यो याति विनिश्चयम्। स तमेवाभिजानाति नान्यं भरतसत्तम॥
English Translation: You are Guha, you are Svadha, you are the holiest of the holy. You are invoked by Mantras and you are celebrated as the six flamed fire, you are the year, you are the six seasons, you are the months, the fortnights, the solar declination and the cardinal points of firmament.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथा यथा च पर्येति लोकतन्त्रमसारवत्। तथा तथा विरागोऽत्र जायते नात्र संशयः॥
English Translation: You are lotus-eyed, you possess a lotus-like face, you have one thousand faces and one thousand arms. You are the ruler of the universe and you are the great oblations, you are the animating spirit of all the celestials and the Asuras.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं व्यवसिते लोके बहुदोषे युधिष्ठिर। आत्ममोक्षनिमित्तं वै यतेत मतिमान् नरः॥
English Translation: You are the generallissimo of armies, you are fury, you are the lord, you are the great master, you are the conqueror of your enemies, you Sahasrbhu, Sahasratushti and Sahasrbhuk.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच नष्टे धने वा दारे वा पुत्रे पितरि वा मृते। यया बुद्ध्या नुदेच्छोकं तन्मे ब्रूहि पितामह॥
English Translation: You are the Sahasrapat, you are the earth herself, you possess innumerable forms and thousands of heads, you are endued with great strength. O god, you have with your own desire are appeared as the son of Ganga, Svaha and Mahikritika.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच नष्ट धने वा दारे वा पुत्रे पितरि वा मृते। अहो दुःखमिति ध्यायशोकस्यापचितिं चरेत्॥
English Translation: O six-faced god, you play with the cock, you assume various forms according to your own will, you are Daksha, Soma, Marutas, Dharma, Vayu and the king of mountains.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अत्राप्युदाहरन्तीममितिहासं पुरातनम्। यथा सेनजितं विप्रः कश्चिदेत्याब्रवीत् सुहृत्॥
English Translation: For everlasting time you are mighty, you are the most eternal of all eternal things and you are the lord of lords, you are the origin of Truth, you are the destroyer of the children of Diti, you are the great conqueror of the enemies of the celestials.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुत्रशोकाभिसंतप्तं राजानं शोकविह्वलम्। विषण्णमनसं दृष्ट्वा विप्रो वचनमब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: You are the personation of virtue. Being yourself both vast and minute, you are acquainted with the highest and the lowest points of virtuous acts, you are the mysteries of Brahma.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किं नु मुह्यसि मूढस्त्वं शोच्यः किमनुशोचसि। यदा त्वामपि शोचन्तः शोच्या यास्यन्ति तां गतिम्।।१०
English Translation: O foremost of the celestials, O lord of the universe, this whole creation is pervaded by your spirit. I have thus prayed to you according to the best of my power. I bow to you who possess twelve eyes and twelve hands. Your remaining attributes are beyond my conception.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वं चैवाहं च ये चान्ये त्वामुपासन्ति पार्थिव। सर्वे तत्र गमिष्यामो यत एवागता वयम्॥
English Translation: The Brahmana who attentively reads this story of the birth of Skanda or narrates it to Brahmanas or hears it narrated by Brahmanas obtains wealth, long-life, fame, children, victory, prosperity, contentment and association with Skanda.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सेनजिदुवाच का बुद्धिः किं तपो विप्र कः समाधिस्तपोधना किं ज्ञानं किं श्रुतं चैव यत् प्राप्य न विषीदसि॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Having heard that the Pandavas had been banished, the Bhojas with the Vrishnis and the Andhakas went to the afflicted Pandavas in the great forest.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मण उवाच पश्य भूतानि दुःखेन व्यतिषिक्तानि सर्वशः। उत्तमाधममध्यानि तेषु तेष्विह कर्मसु॥
English Translation: The relatives of (the king) Panchala, Dhristadyumna, the king of Chedi and the greatly powerful and renowned brothers, the Kaikeyas. Went to see the sons of Pritha in the forest. Their heart inflamed with wrath, they reproaching the sons of Dhritarashtra said, “What should we do?”
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आत्मापि चायं न मम सर्वा वा पृथिवी मम। यथा मम तथाऽन्येषामिति चिन्त्य न मे व्यथा।।
English Translation: All those foremost of Kshatriyas with Vasudeva (Krishna) at their head sat around Dharmaraja Yudhishthira. Saluting that chief of the Kurus, Keshava (Krishna) spoke thus in sorrow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतां बुद्धिमहं प्राप्य न प्रहृष्ये न च व्यथे॥ यथा काष्ठं च काष्ठं च समेयातां महोदधौ। समेत्य च व्यपेयातां तद्वद्भूतसमागमः॥
English Translation: Krishna said: The earth will drink the will drink the blood of Duryodhana, Karna, Shakuni and the fourth (of their allies) Dushashana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं पुत्राश्च पौत्राश्च ज्ञातयो बान्धवास्तथा। तेषां स्नेहो न कर्तव्यो विप्रयोगो ध्रुवो हि तैः॥
English Translation: Killing all these and defeating all their followers and royal allies. We shall all install Dharmaraja Yudhishthira (on the throne). The crafty men deserve to be slain. This is 'eternal morality.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अदर्शनादापतितः पुनश्चादर्शनं गतः। न त्वासौ वेद न त्वं तं कः सन् किमनुशोचसि॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Jarsardana (Krishna) became angry for the wrongs done to the sons of Pritha and he seemed bent upon consuming all created things. But Arjuna tried to pacify him. Seeing Keshava (Krishna) angry, Falguni (Arjuna) began to recite the feats achieved in his former lives by that soul of all things who is immeasurable, who is the eternal one of infinite energy, the lord of Prajapati, the supreme ruler of the world and the greatly wise Vishnu.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तृष्णार्तिप्रभवं दुःखं दुःखार्तिप्रभवं सुखम्। सुखात् संजायते दुःखं दुःखमेवं पुनः पुनः॥
English Translation: Arjuna said: O Krishna, in the days of yore, you had wandered on the Gandhamadana mountain for ten thousand years as a Fatrashayanagriha Rishi.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुखस्यानन्तरं दुःखं दुःखस्यानन्तरं सुखम्। सुखदुःखे मनुष्याणां चक्रवत् परिवर्ततः॥
English Translation: O Krishna, living on water alone, you passed eleven thousand years in the days of yore by the side of the Pushkara (lake).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुखात् त्वं दुःखमापन्न पुनरापत्स्यसे सुखम्। न नित्यं लभते दुःखं न नित्यं लभते सुखम्॥
English Translation: O slayer of Madhu, you with your arms upraised and standing on one leg, living all the while on air, passed one hundred years on the high hills of Badari.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शरीरमेवायतनं सुखस्य दुःखस्य चाप्यायतनं शरीरम्। यद्यच्छरीरेण करोति कर्म तेनैव देही समुपाश्नुते तत्।।
English Translation: O Krishna, leaving aside your upper garment and looking like a bundle of veins, with your body emaciated you lived on the banks of the Sarasvati, employed in your sacrifice extending for twelve years.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जीवितं च शरीरेण जात्यैव सह जायते। उभे सह विवर्तेते उभे सह विनश्यतः॥
English Translation: O greatly effulgent Krishna, in observance of your vow, you stood on one leg for one thousand celestials years on the plains of Pravasha which the virtuous ought to visit. Vyasa has told me that you are the cause of the creation and its course.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्नेहपाशैर्बहुविधैराविष्टविषया जनाः। अकृतार्थाश्च सीदन्ते जलैः सैकतसेतवः॥
English Translation: O Keshava, the lord of Kshetra, you are the mover of all minds and the beginning and the end of all things. O Krishna, all asceticism rests in you; you are the embodiment of all sacrifices and you are the eternal one.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्नेहेन तिलवत् सर्वं सर्गचक्रे निपीड्यते। तिलपीडैरिवाक्रम्य क्लेशैरज्ञानसम्भवैः॥
English Translation: O Krishna, killing the fearful Naraka, the first begotten offspring of the earth, you have obtained his ear-rings by the performance of the first horse sacrifice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संचिनोत्यशुभं कर्म कलत्रापेक्षया नरः। एकः क्लेशानवाप्नोति परत्रेह च मानवः॥
English Translation: O foremost of all the worlds, having performed that feat, you have become victorious over all. You have killed all the Daityas and the Danavas mustered in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुत्रदारकुटुम्बेषु प्रसक्ताः सर्वमानवाः। शोकपङ्कार्णवे मग्ना जीर्णा वनगजा इव॥
English Translation: O mighty-armed Keshava, giving the lord of Sachi (Indra) the sovereignty of the universe, you have taken your birth among men.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुत्रनाशे वित्तनाशे ज्ञातिसम्बन्धिनामपि। प्राप्यते सुमहद् दुःखंदावाग्निप्रतिमं विभो।
English Translation: O chastiser of foes, having floated on Primordial waters, you subsequently became Hari, Brahma, Surya, Dharma, Dhatri, Yama, Anala. Vayu, Vaisravana, Rudra, Kala and the sky, the earth, the air and the directions. O foremost of Purushas, you are your own creator, you are the lord of all mobile and immobile universe.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दैवायत्तमिदं सर्वं सुखदुः :खे भवाभवौ॥ असृहत् ससुहृच्चापि सशत्रुर्मित्रवानपि। सप्रज्ञः प्रज्ञया हीनो दैवेन लभते सुखम्॥
English Translation: O slayer of Madhu, O greatly effulgent one, O Krishna, you gratified with your sacrifice in the forest of Chitraratha the chief of the celestials, the highest of the high.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नालं सुखाय सुहृदो नालं दुःखाय शत्रवः। न च प्रज्ञालमर्थानां न सुखानामलं धनम्॥
English Translation: O Janardana, at each sacrifice you offered, according to (each one's) shares, gold by hundred and thousands.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न बुद्धिर्धनलाभाय न जाड्यमसमृद्धये। लोकपर्यायवृत्तान्तं प्राज्ञो जानाति नेतरः॥
English Translation: O descendant of Yadu, becoming the son of Aditi you have been known as the younger brother of Indra, though you are the exalted one of the supreme attributes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बुद्धिमन्तं च शूरं च मूढं भीरुं जडं कविम्। दुर्बलं बलवन्तं च भागिनं भजते सुखम्॥
English Translation: O chastiser of foes, O Krishna while you are but a child, you filled by three steps the heaven, the sky and the earth in consequences of your energy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धेनुर्वत्सस्य गोपस्य स्वामिनस्तस्करस्य च। पयः पिबति यस्तस्या धेनुस्तस्येति निश्चयः॥
English Translation: O soul of all creatures, covering the heaven and the sky, you dwell in the body of the sun and afflict him with your own effulgence.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ये च मूढतमा लोके ये च बुद्धेः परं गताः। ते नराः सुखमेधन्ते क्लिश्यत्यन्तरितो जनः॥
English Translation: O exalted one, O Krishna, in your incarnations on three thousand occasions, you have killed the sinful Asuras by thousands.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्त्येषु रेमिरे धीरा न ते मध्येषु रेमिरे। अन्त्यप्राप्तिं सुखामाहुर्दुःखमन्तरमन्त्ययोः॥
English Translation: By destroying the Mansavas and the Pashas and killing Nishunda and Naraka, you have again made the road to Pragjotisha safe.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ये च बुद्धिसुखं प्राप्ता द्वन्द्वातीता विमत्सराः। तान् नैवार्था न चाना व्यथयन्ति कदाचन॥
English Translation: You killed Ahuti at Jarutha, Kratha and Shishupala with his followers and allies, Jarasandha, Saivya and Shatadhanvan.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ ये बुद्धिमप्राप्ता व्यतिक्रान्ताश्च मूढताम्। तेऽतिवेलं प्रहृष्यन्ति संतापमुपयान्ति च॥
English Translation: You defeated on your car which is as effulgent as the sun and as roaring a the clouds, Rukmi in battle and then obtained for your queen the daughter of Bhoja.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नित्यं प्रमुदिता मूढा दिवि देवगणा इव। अवलेपेन महता परिभूत्या विचेतसः॥
English Translation: You killed in fury Indradyumna and the Yavana called Kaseruman. Killing Shalva, the king of Saivya, you destroyed his city.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुखं दुःखान्तमालस्यं दुःखं दाक्ष्यं सुखोदयम्। भूतिस्त्वेवं श्रिया सार्धं दक्षे वसति नालसे॥
English Translation: At Irvati, you killed king Bhoja, who was equal to Kartavirya in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुखं वा यदि वा दुःखं प्रियं वा यदि वाप्रियम्। प्राप्तं प्राप्तमुपासीत हृदयेनापराजितः॥
English Translation: Both Gopati and Taluketu also have been killed by you. O Janardana, you have also obtained for yourself the sacred city of Dvarka which abounds in wealth and which is agreeable to all Rishis. You will submerge it into the ocean at the end.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शोकस्थानसहस्त्राणि भयस्थानशतानि च। दिवसे दिवसे मूढमाविशन्ति न पण्डितम्॥
English Translation: O slayer of Madhu, O descendant of Dasahara race, how can crookedness be in you, devoid as you are of anger, envy, untruth and cruelty? O undeteriorating one, all the Rishis come to you when seated in your glory on the sacrificial ground and seek your protection.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बुद्धिमन्तं कृतप्रज्ञं शुश्रूषुमनसूयकम्। दान्तं जितेन्द्रियं चापि शोको न स्पृशते नरम्॥
English Translation: O slayer of Madhu. O chastiser of foes, contracting all things and withdrawing this universe into your own self, you stay at the end of Yuga.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतां बुद्धिं समास्थाय गुप्तचित्तश्चरेद् बुधः। उदयास्तमयज्ञं हि न शोकः स्पष्टुमर्हति॥
English Translation: O descendant of the Vrishni race, there at the beginning of the Yuga, sprang from your lotus-like navel Brahma himself who is the lord of all mobile and immobile things and whose is this entire universe.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यन्निमित्तं भवेच्छोकस्तापो वा दुःखमेव च। आयासो वा यतो मूलमेकाङ्गमपि तत् त्यजेत्॥
English Translation: O Hari, when the fearful Danavas Madhu and Kaitava were bent on killing Brahma, seeing their impious endevour you grew angry and from your head then sprang Sambhu, the holder of trident, the deity of three eyes. Thus have these two foremost of the deities sprung from your body to accomplish your work.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किंचिदेव ममत्वेन यदा भवति कल्पितम्। तदेव परितापार्थं सर्वं सम्पद्यते तथा॥
English Translation: It was Narada who has told me (all) this. O Narayana, you performed in the forest of Chaitraratha a grand sacrifice with multitudes of rites and plentiful of gifts. O lotus-eyed deity the feats you accomplished with your prowess aided by Baladeva have never before been done by others. They are not capable of being done by others in future. You dwelt even in Kailasa accompanied by Brahmanas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यद् यत् यजति कामानां तत् सुखस्याभिपूर्यते। कामानुसारी पुरुषः कामाननुविनश्यति॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Having spoken thus to Krishna, the highsouled Pandava (Arjuna) who was his (Krishna's) soul became dumb. Janardana (Krishna) then thus replied to Partha (Arjuna).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यच्च कामसुखं लोके यच्च दिव्यं महत् सुखम्। तृष्णाक्षयसुखस्यैते नार्हतः षोडशी कलाम्॥
English Translation: You are mine and I am yours. All that is mine is yours also. He who hates you hates me and he who follows you follows me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पूर्वदेहकृतं कर्म शुभं वा यदि वाशुभम्। प्राज्ञं मूढं तथा शूरं भजते यादृशं कृतम्॥
English Translation: O irrepressible hero, you are Nara and I am Narayana (Hari). We are the Rishis Nara and Narayana born in the world of men for a special purpose.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमेव किलैतानि प्रियाण्येवाप्रियाणि च। जीवेषु परिवर्तन्ते दुःखानि च सुखानि च॥
English Translation: O Partha, you are from me and I am from you. O best of the Bharata race, none can understand the difference that exists between us.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतां बुद्धिं समास्थाय सुखमास्ते गुणान्वितः। सर्वान् कामान् जुगुप्सेत कामान् कुर्वीत पृष्ठतः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said: When the high-souled Krishna said this in the midst of that assembly of the heroic kings, who were all excited with anger. The Panchala princess (Draupadi), surrounded by Dhristadyumna and her other heroic brothers, came to the lotus-eyed one (Krishna) who was seated with his cousins. Desirous of getting protection, she spoke thus to the refuge of all (Krishna) in angry words.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वृत्त एष हृषि प्रौढो मृत्युरेष मनोभवः। क्रोधो नाम शरीरस्थो देहिनां प्रोच्यते बुधैः॥
English Translation: Draupadi said : Asita and Devala have said that in the matter of creation of things you have been indicated as the only Prajapati and the creator of all the worlds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदा संहरते कामान् कूर्मोऽङ्गानीव सर्वशः। तदाऽऽत्मज्योतिरात्मायमात्मन्येव प्रपश्यति॥
English Translation: O irrepressible one, Jamadagni says you are Vishnu. O slayer of Madhu, you are the sacrifice, you are the sacrificer and you are he for whom the sacrifice is performed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न बिभेति यदा चायं यदा चास्मान्न बिभ्यति। यदा नेच्छति न दृष्टि ब्रह्म सम्पद्यते तदा॥
English Translation: O best of Purushas (male beings), the Rishis call you Forgiveness and Truth. Kashyapa has said that you are the sacrifice sprung from Truth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उभे सत्यानृते त्यक्त्वा शोकानन्दौ भयाभये। प्रियाप्रिये परित्यज्य प्रशान्तात्मा भविष्यति॥
English Translation: O lord, Narada says that you are the God of the Sadhyas and of the Shivas, you are the creator and the lord of all.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदा न कुरुते धीरः सर्वभूतेषु पापकम्। कर्मणा मनसा वाचा ब्रह्म सम्पद्यते तदा॥
English Translation: O foremost of men, as children sport with their toys, you repeatedly sport with the celestials including Brahma, Shankara (Shiva) and Shakra (Indra).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: या दुस्त्यजा दुर्मतिभिर्या न जीर्यति जीर्यतः। योऽसौ प्राणान्तिको रोगस्तां तृष्णां त्यजतः सुखम्।।५५
English Translation: O lord, the firmament is covered by your head and the earth by your feet. These worlds are your womb and you are the Eternal one.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अत्र पिङ्गलया गीता गाथाः श्रूयन्ति पार्थिव। यथा सा कृच्छ्रकालेऽपि लेभे धर्मं सनातनम्॥
English Translation: You are the best of all objects to those Rishis who have been sanctified by ine Vedic lore and asceticism, whose souls have been purified by penance and who are contended with some visions.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संकेते पिङ्गला वेश्या कान्तेनासीद् विनाकृता। अथ कृच्छ्रगता शान्ता बुद्धिमास्थापयत् तदा॥
English Translation: O best of Purushas, you are the refuge of all royal sages, who are devoted to piety, who never turn their looks on the field of battle and who possess every accomplishment. You are the lord of all; you are omnipresent, you are the soul of all things, you are the active power pervading everything.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पिङ्गलोवाच उन्मत्ताहमनुन्मत्तं कान्तमन्ववसं चिरम्। अन्तिके रमणं सन्तं नैनमध्यगमं पुरा॥
English Translation: The rulers of the several worlds, those worlds themselves, the steller-conjunctions, the ten points of horizon, the firmament, the moon and the sun are all established in you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एकस्थूणं नवद्वारमपिधास्याम्यगारकम्। का हि कान्तमिहायान्तमयं कान्तेति मंस्यते॥
English Translation: O mighty armed hero, the mortality of all creatures and the immortality of the universe are established in you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अकामां कामरूपेण धूर्ता नरकरूपिणः। न पुनर्वञ्चयिष्यन्ति प्रतिबुद्धास्मि जागृमि॥
English Translation: O slayer of Madhu, impelled by the affection, you bore for me, I shall relate to you my grief's. You are the supreme lord of all creatures, both celestials and human.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनर्थो हि भवेदर्थो दैवात् पूर्वकृतेन वा। सम्बुद्धाहं निराकारा नाहमद्याजितेन्द्रिया॥
English Translation: O Krishna, how could one like me, the wife of Pritha's sons (the Pandavas), the sister of Dhristadyumna and the friend of yours, be dragged to the assembly?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुखं निराशः स्वपिति नैराश्यं परमं सुखम्। आशामनाशां कृत्वा हि सुखं स्वपिति पिङ्गला॥
English Translation: Alas, in my season,. stained with blood, with but a single cloth on, trembling and weeping, I was dragged into the court of the Kurus!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच एतैश्चान्यैश्च विप्रस्य हेतुमद्भिः प्रभाषितैः। पर्यवस्थापितो राजा सेनजिन्मुमुदे सुखी॥
English Translation: Seeing me stained with blood (standing) in the presence of the kings in that assembly, the wicked-minded sons of Dhritarashtra laughed at me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच असिद्धानुनये कृष्णे कुरुभ्यः पाण्डवान् गते। अभिगम्य पृथां क्षत्ता शनैः शोचन्निवाब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: O slayer of Madhu, though the Pandavas, the Panchalas and the Vrishnis were present, yet they (the sons of Dhritarashtra) dared express their desire of making me their slave.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जानासि मे जीवपुत्रि भावं नित्यमविग्रहे। क्रोशतो न च गृह्णीते वचनं मे सुयोधनः॥
English Translation: O Krishna, I am the daughter-in-law of both Bhishma and Dhritarashtra according to the ordinance, yet, О slayer of Madhu, they wished to make me their slave by force.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उपपन्नो ह्यसौ राजा चेदिपाञ्चालकेकयैः। भीमार्जुनाभ्यां कृष्णेन युयुधानयमैरपि।॥
English Translation: I blame the Pandavas who are mighty and the foremost (heroes) in battle, for they (silently) looked at the cruel treatment that was offered to their renowned wedded wife.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उपप्लेव्य निविष्टोऽपि धर्ममेव युधिष्ठिरः। काक्षते ज्ञातिसौहार्दाद् बलवान् दुर्बलो यथा॥
English Translation: O Janardana, fie to the prowess of Bhimasena and fie to the Gandiva of Arjuna, for they both suffered me to be thus disgraced by men of no importance!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजा तु धृतराष्ट्रोऽयं वयोवृद्धो न शाम्यति। मत्तः पुत्रमदेनैव विधर्मं पथि वर्तते॥
English Translation: This eternal course of morality is ever followed by the pious men, namely the husband, however weak he might be, should protect his wedded wife.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जयद्रथस्य कर्णस्य तथा दुःशासनस्य च। सौबलस्य च दुर्बुद्ध्या मिथो भेदोः प्रपत्स्यते॥
English Translation: By protecting his wife one protects his offspring and by protecting the offspring one protects his own self.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अधर्मेण हि धर्मिष्ठं कृतं वैकार्यमीदृशम्। येषां तेषामयं धर्मः सानुबन्धो भविष्यति॥
English Translation: One's own self is begotten on one's wife and therefore wife is called Jaya. A wife should also protect her husband, remembering that he would take his birth in her womb.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क्रियमाणे बलाद् धर्मं कुरुभिः को न संज्वरेत्। असाम्ना केशवे याते समुद्योक्ष्यन्ति पाण्डवाः॥
English Translation: The Pandavas never forsake the persons who ask for their protection, but they abandoned me who asked for their protection.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः कुरूणामनयो भविता वीरनाशनः। चिन्तयन् न लभे निद्रामहः सु च निशासु च॥
English Translation: Five greatly powerful sons have been born of me by my five husbands; O Janardana, for their sake it was necessary to protect me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रुत्वा तु कुन्ती तद्वाक्यमर्थकामेन भाषितम्। सा निःश्वसन्ती दुःखार्ता मनसा विममर्श ह॥
English Translation: Prativindhya (was begotten) by Yudhishthira, Satasoma by Vrikodara (Bhima), Shrutakirti by Arjuna, Satanika by Nakula. Shrutakarman by the youngest (of my husbands) Sahadeva. They are all of irrepressible prowess. O Krishna, they are all as great car-warriors as Pradyumna (Krishna's son).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धिगस्त्वर्थं यत्कृतेऽयं महान् ज्ञातिवधः कृतः। वय॑ते सुहृदां चैवं युद्धेऽस्मिन् वै पराभवः॥
English Translation: They are all foremost of all bowmen and they are all invincible in battle by any foe. Why do they (silently) bear the wrongs inflicted (on me) by the weak sons of Dhritarashtra?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पाण्डवाश्चेदिपञ्चाला यादवाश्च समागताः। भारतैः सह योत्स्यन्ति किं नु दुःखमतः परम्॥
English Translation: Having been deprived of their kingdom by deception, the Pandavas were made slaves and I myself in my season and in one cloth was dragged into the Sabha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पश्ये दोषं ध्रुवं युद्धे तथाऽयुद्धे पराभवम्। अधनस्य मृतं श्रेयो न हि ज्ञातिक्षयो जयः॥
English Translation: O slayer of Madhu, fie to the Gandiva, which none else can string except Arjuna; Bhima and yourself!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इति मे चिन्तयन्त्या वै हृदि दुःखं प्रवर्तते। पितामहः शान्तनव आचार्यश्च युधां पतिः॥
English Translation: O Krishna, fie to the strength of Bhima and to the prowess to Partha (Arjuna) for Duryodhana lived for even a moment (after what he did).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्णश्च धार्तराष्ट्रार्थं वर्धयन्ति भयं मम। आचार्यः कामवान् शिष्यैोणो युद्धयेत जातुचित्॥
English Translation: O slayer of Madhu, it was he who formerly drove the guileless Pandavas with their mother from the kingdom while they were but boys engaged in study and in the observance of their VOWS.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पाण्डवेषु कथं हार्द कुर्यान्न च पितामहः। अयं त्वेको वृथादृष्टिर्धार्तराष्ट्रस्य दुर्मतेः॥
English Translation: It was that sinful wretch who mixed fresh, virulent, horrible and excessive poison with the food of Bhimasena.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मोहानुवर्ती सततं पापो द्वेष्टि च पाण्डवान्। महत्यनर्थं निर्बन्धो बलवांश्च विशेषतः॥
English Translation: O Janardana, but Bhima without sustaining any injury digested that poison with the food. O mighty armed hero, O best of men, Bhima's days had not (then) ended.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्णः सदा पाण्डवानां तन्मे दहति सम्प्रति। आशंसे त्वद्य कर्णस्य मनोऽहं पाण्डवान् प्रति॥
English Translation: O Krishna, it was Duryodhana, who at the house that stood by the banian tree, called Pramana, bound the sleeping and unsuspecting Bhima; and then throwing him into the Ganges, he returned to the city,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रसादयितुमासाद्य दर्शयन्ती यथातथम्। तोषितो भगवान् यत्र दुर्वासा मे वरं ददौ॥
English Translation: But the son of Kunti, the greatly strong and mighty armed Bhima, on waking from his sleep, tore his bonds and rose from the water.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आह्वानं मन्त्रसंयुक्तं वसन्त्याः पितृवेश्मनि। साहमन्तःपुरे राज्ञः कुन्तिभोजपुरस्कृता॥
English Translation: It was he (Duryodhana) who caused venomous snakes to bite all over the body of Bhimasena, but that slayer of foes did not die.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चिन्तयन्ती बहुविधं हृदयेन विदूयता। बलाबलं च मन्त्राणां ब्राह्मणस्य च वाग्बलम्॥
English Translation: Awaking, the son of Kunti (Bhima) killed all the serpents with his left hand; and he killed his (Duryodhana's) favorite charioteer (also).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्त्रीभावाद् बालभावाच्च चिन्तयन्ती पुनः पुनः। धाच्या विस्रब्धया गुप्ता सखीजनवृता तदा॥
English Translation: Again, while the children (the Pandavas) were sleeping unsuspicious with the revered one (their mother), he set fire to the house (Jatugriha). Who is there who is capable of doing such an act?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मे दोषं परिहरन्ती च पितुश्चारित्र्यरक्षिणी। कथं नु सुकृतं स्यानापराधवती कथम्॥
English Translation: It was then the revered madam (Kunti), overtaken by this calamity and surrounded by the flames, began to cry in terrors.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भवेयमिति संचिन्त्य ब्राह्मणं तं नमस्य च। कौतूहलात् तु तं लब्ध्वा बालिश्यादाचरं तदा। कन्या सती देवमर्कमासादयमहं ततः॥
English Translation: Kunti said: Alas, I am undone! How shall we today escape from this fire! Alas, I shall meet with detraction my sons who are but children!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: योऽसौ कानीनगर्भो मे पुत्रवत् परिरक्षितः। कस्मान्न कुर्याद् वचनं पथ्यं भ्रातृहितं तथा॥
English Translation: Draupadi said : Thereupon the mighty-armed Bhima Vrikodara whose prowess is like that of wind, comforted the revered madam (Kunti) and his brothers. I will spring up into the air like the son of Vinata that best of birds, Garuda. We have no fear from this fire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इति कुन्ती विनिश्चित्य कार्यनिश्चयमुत्तमम्। कार्यार्थमभिनिश्चित्य ययौ भागीरथी प्रति॥
English Translation: Then taking the revered lady (his mother) on his left flank and the king (Yudhishthira) on the right, the twins on each shoulder and Vivatsu (Arjuna) on his back. The powerful hero (Bhima), taking all of them, cleared off the fire at one leap and thus delivered his mother and brothers from the conflagration.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आत्मजस्य ततस्तस्य घृणिनः सत्यसङ्गिनः। गङ्गातीरे पृथाऽश्रौषीद् वेदाध्ययननिःस्वनम्॥
English Translation: Setting out that night with their illustrious mother, they (the Pandavas) came near the great forest, the forest of Hidimba.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्राङ्मुखस्योर्ध्वबाहोः सा पर्यतिष्ठत पृष्ठतः। जप्यावसानं कार्यार्थं प्रतीक्षन्ती तपस्विनी॥
English Translation: Fatigued and distressed they fell asleep with their mother. A Rakshasas woman, named Hidimba then came to them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अतिष्ठत् सूर्यतापार्ता कर्णस्योत्तरवाससि। कौरव्यपत्नी वार्ष्णेयी पद्ममालेव शुष्यती॥
English Translation: Seeing the Pandavas asleep on the ground with their mother and being influenced by desire, she sought to have Bhimasena as her lord.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आपृष्ठतापाज्जप्त्वा स परिवृत्य यतव्रतः। दृष्ट्वा कुन्तीमुपातिष्ठदभिवाद्य कृताञ्जलिः॥
English Translation: That weak and blessed one (the Rakshasas woman), thereupon taking up Bhima's feet on her lap, began to press them with her soft hands.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथान्यायं महातेजा मानी धर्मभृतां वरः। उत्समयन् प्रणतः प्राह कुन्तीं वैकर्तनो वृषः॥
English Translation: The immeasurably energetic, irrepressibly powerful and greatly strong Bhima then awoke and asked, “O faultless one, what do you wish (here)?"
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच अत्रोपायं प्रवक्ष्यामि यथावच्छास्त्रचक्षुषा। तत्त्वज्ञानाच्चरन् राजन् प्राप्नुयात्परमां गतिम्॥
English Translation: Having been thus addressed by Bhima, the faultless Rakshasas woman, who could assume any form at will, thus replied to the high-souled Bhimasena.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वेषामेव भूतानां पुरुषः श्रेष्ठ उच्यते। पुरुषेभ्यो द्विजानाहुर्द्विजेभ्यो मन्त्रदर्शिनः॥
English Translation: Speedily fly from this place; my powerful brother will (soon) come to kill you. Therefore speed away, do not stay here any longer.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वभूतात्मभूतास्ते सर्वज्ञाः सर्वदर्शिनः। ब्राह्मणा वेदशास्त्रज्ञास्तत्त्वार्थगतनिश्चयाः॥
English Translation: Thereupon Bhima spoke thus in haughtiness, "I do not fear him. If he comes here, I shall kill him."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नेत्रहीनो यथा ह्येकः कृच्छ्राणि लभतेऽध्वनि। ज्ञानहीनस्तथा लोके तस्माज्ज्ञानविदोऽधिकाः॥
English Translation: Having heard their conversations, that worst of Rakshasas of fearful form and dreadful appearance uttered a loud cry as he came.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तांस्तानुपासते धर्मान् धर्मकामा यथागमम्। न त्वेषामर्थसामान्यमन्तरेण गुणानिमान्॥
English Translation: The Rakshasas said: O Hidimba, with whom are you talking? Bring him to me; I will eat hin up. You ought not to tarry.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वाग्देहमनसां शौचं क्षमा सत्यं धृतिः स्मृतिः। सर्वधर्मेषु धर्मज्ञा ज्ञापयन्ति गुणाञ्छुभान्॥
English Translation: Draupadi said : But move I by compassion. the faultless featured and pure hearted Rakshasas woman did not speak a word out of pity.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदिदं ब्रह्मणो रूपं ब्रह्मचर्यमिति स्मृतम्। परं तत् सर्वधर्मेभ्यस्तेन यान्ति परां गतिम्॥
English Translation: Then the man-eating Rakshasas, uttering dreadful cries, rushed with great force at Bhimasena.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: लिङ्गसंयोगहीनं यच्छब्दस्पर्शविवर्जितम्। श्रोत्रेण श्रवणं चैव चक्षुषा चैव दर्शनम्॥
English Translation: Coming furiously and angrily at him, the mighty Rakshasas caught hold of Bhimasena's hand by his own. Catching hold of his other hand and making it as hard as the thunder of Indra, he suddenly struck Bhima a blow that descended with the force of lightning.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वाक्सम्भाषाप्रवृत्तं यत् तन्मनःपरिवर्जितम्। बुद्ध्या चाध्यवसीयीत ब्रह्मचर्यमकल्मषम्॥
English Translation: His hand having been seized by the Rakshasas, the mighty-armed Vrikodara (Bhima), without being able to brook it, flew into rage.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सम्यग्वृत्तिर्ब्रह्मलोकं प्राप्नुयान्मध्यमः सुरान्। द्विजाग्रयो जायते विद्वान् कन्यसी वृत्तिमास्थितः॥
English Translation: Then a fearful combat took place between Bhimasena and Hidimba, both skilled in all sorts of weapons, like the battle between Vasava (Indra) and Vritra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुदुष्करं ब्रह्मचर्यमुपायं तत्र मे शृणु। सम्प्रदीप्तमुदीर्णं च निगृह्णीयाद् द्विजो रजः॥
English Translation: O sinless one, after playing with (the strength of) the Rakshasas for a long time, the powerful and greatly energetic Bhima killed him when he became exhausted and weak.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: योषितां न कथा श्राव्या न निरीक्ष्या निरम्बराः। कथञ्चिद् दर्शनादासां दुर्बलानां विशेद्रजः॥
English Translation: Having thus killed Hidimba, Bhima proceeded with his brothers, placing Hidimba in their front, (Hidimba) of whom Ghatotkacha was born.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रागोत्पन्नश्चरेत् कृच्छं महार्तिः प्रविशेदपः। मग्नः स्वप्ने च मनसा विर्जपेदघमर्षणम्॥
English Translation: Thereupon all those chastisers of foes, accompanied by their mother and surrounded by many Brahmanas, proceeded towards Ekachakra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पाप्मानं निर्दहेदेवमन्तर्भूतरजोमयम्। ज्ञानयुक्तेन मनसा संततेन विचक्षणः॥
English Translation: In their this journey, Vyasa, ever engaged in their welfare, became their counsellor. Then the Pandavas of rigid vows, arriving at Ekachakra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कुणपामध्यसंयुक्तं यद्वदच्छिद्रबन्धनम्। तद्वद् देहगतं विद्यादात्मानं देहबन्धनम्॥
English Translation: Killed there a greatly strong man eating monster, named Baka, who was as terrible as Hidimba.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वातपित्तकफाद् रक्तं त्वडमांसं स्नायुमस्थि च। मज्जां देहं शिराजालैस्तर्पयन्ति रसा नृणाम्॥
English Translation: Having killed him, that foremost of smiters, Bhima, with all his brothers went to the capital of Drupada.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दश विद्याद् धमन्योऽत्र पञ्चेन्द्रियगुणावहाः। याभिः सूक्ष्माः प्रतायन्ते धमन्योऽन्याः सहस्रशः॥
English Translation: O Krishna, as you have obtained Rukmani, the daughter of Bhishmaka, so Savyasachi (Arjuna) obtained me while he lived there (at Draupada's capital).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमेताः शिरा नद्यो रसोदा देहसागरम्। तर्पयन्ति यथाकालमापगा इव सागरम्॥
English Translation: O slayer of Madhu, I was thus obtained in the Saimvara by Partha (Arjuna) who performed a feat difficult of achievment by others and who fought with the assembled kings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मध्ये च हृदयस्यैका शिरा तत्र मनोवहा। शुक्र संकल्पजं नृणां सर्वगात्रैर्विमुञ्चति॥
English Translation: O Krishna, thus afflicted with numerous grief's, I am living in sorrow and in great distress with Dhaumya at our head, but deprived of the company of the revered lady (Kunti).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वगात्रप्रतायिन्यस्तस्या ह्यनुगताः शिराः। नेत्रयोः प्रतिपद्यन्ते वहन्त्यस्तैजसं गुणम्॥
English Translation: Why do these (Pandavas), who are gifted with strength and who possess the prowess of the lion, sit silently on seeing me afflicted by so despicable enemies (as the Kurus).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पयस्यन्तर्हितं सर्पिर्यद्वन्निर्मथ्यते खजैः। शुक्र निर्मथ्यते तद्वद् देहसंकल्पजैः खजैः॥
English Translation: Suffering such wrongs at the hands of the sinful, evil-doing and weak foes, am I to suffer misery so long?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्वप्नेऽप्येवं यथाभ्येति मन:संकल्पजं रजः। शुक्र संकल्पजं देहात् सृजत्यस्य मनोवहा॥
English Translation: I was born in a great race and I came to the world in an extraordinary way. I am the beloved wife of the Pandavas and the daughterin-law of the illustrious Pandu.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महर्षिर्भगवानत्रिर्वेद तच्छुक्रसम्भवम्। त्रिबीजमिन्द्रदैवल्यं तस्मादिन्द्रियमुच्यते॥
English Translation: O Krishna, O slayer of Madhu, being the foremost of women and devoted to my husbands, even I was seized by the hair in the very sight of the Pandavas, each of whom was like an Indra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ये वै शुक्रगति विद्युभूतसंकरकारिकाम्। विरागा दग्धदोषास्ते नाप्नुयुर्देहसम्भवम्॥
English Translation: Having said this, the mild-speeched Krishna (Draupadi) hid her face with her soft hands which were like the buds of lotus and began to weep.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गुणानां साम्यमागम्य मनसैव मनोवहम्। देहकर्मा नुदन् प्राणानन्तकाले विमुच्यते॥
English Translation: The tears of the Panchala princess, the outpourings of her grief, washed her deep, plump and graceful breasts, which were crowned with auspicious marks.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भविता मनसो ज्ञानं मन एव प्रजायते। ज्योतिष्मद्विरजो नित्यं मन्त्रसिद्धं महात्मनाम्॥
English Translation: Wiping her eyes and sighing frequently she thus spoke in anger and in a choked voice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मात् तदभिघाताय कर्म कुर्यादकल्मषम्। रजस्तमश्च हित्वेह यथेष्टां गतिमाप्नुयात्॥
English Translation: Draupadi said : O slayer of foes, husbands, sons, friends, brothers, father or you, I have none.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तरुणाधिगतं ज्ञानं जरादुर्बलतां गतम्। विपक्वबुद्धिः कालेन आदत्ते मानसं बलम्॥
English Translation: For you all, seeing me treated so cruelly, by inferior foes, (still) sit unmoved in silence. My grief at Karna's ridicule is capable of being assuaged.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुदुर्गमिव पन्थानमतीत्य गुणबन्धनम्। यथा पश्येत् तथा दोषानतीत्यामृतमश्नुते॥
English Translation: O Keshava, O Krishna, I always deserve to be protected by you for four reasons, namely for our relationship, for the respect you bear for me, for our friendship and for your lordship over me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच जन्म मानुष्यकं प्राप्य कर्मक्षेत्रं सुदुर्लभम्। श्रेयोऽर्थिना दरिद्रेण किं कर्तव्यं पितामह॥
English Translation: Thereupon Krishna thus spoke to her in that assembly of heroes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दानानामुत्तमं यच्च देयं यच्च यथा यथा। मान्यान् पूज्यांश्च गाङ्गेय रहस्यं वक्तुमर्हसि॥
English Translation: Krishna said: O fair lady, the wives of those with whom you are angry will weep like you on seeing their husbands lying dead on the ground, their bodies covered with the arrows of Vivatsu and weltering in blood. Do not grieve; I shall do for the Pandavas whatever lies in my power.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच एवं पृष्टो नरेन्द्रेण पाण्डवेन यशस्विना। धर्माणां परमं गुह्यं भीष्मः प्रोवाच पार्थिवम्॥
English Translation: I tell you the truth; you shall be the queen of kings. The heavens might fall and the Himalayas might split, the earth might be rent. And the waters of the ocean might be dried up, but, O Krishna (Draupadi), my words shall never be futile. Having heard these words of Achyuta (Krishna), as a reply to her, Draupadi. The princess of Panchala, glanced obliquely at her third husband (Arjuna). O great king, Arjuna then thus spoke to Draupadi.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच शृणुष्वावहितो राजन् धर्मगुह्यानि भारत। यथा हि भगवान् व्यासः पुरा कथितवान् मयि॥
English Translation: O copper-colour-eyed lady, do not weep. What the slayer of Madhu (Krishna) has said will (surely) happen. O lady, O beautiful one, it cannot be otherwise.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: देवगुह्यमिदं राजन् यमेनाक्लिष्टकर्मणा। नियमस्थेन युक्तेन तपसो महतः फलम्॥
English Translation: Dhristadyumna said : I shall kill Drona, Sikhandi will kill the Grandsire (Bhishma), Bhimasena will kill Duryodhana and Karna will be killed by Dhananjaya (Arjuna). O sister, with the assistance of Rama (Baladeva) and Krishna we are invincible even in a battle with the slayer of Vritra (Indra), what (to speak of a battle) with the sons of Dhritarashtra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: येन यः प्रीयते देवः प्रीयन्ते पितरस्तथा। ऋषयः प्रमथा: श्रीश्च चित्रगुप्तो दिशां गजाः॥ ऋषिधर्मः स्मृतो यत्र सरहस्यो महाफलः। महादानफलं चैव सर्वयज्ञफलं तथा॥ यश्चैतदेवं जानीयाज्ज्ञात्वा वा कुरुतेऽनघ। सदोषोऽदोषवांश्चेह तैर्गुणैः सह युज्यते॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said: When this was spoken, all the heroes turned their faces towards Vasudeva and the mighty armed Keshava (Krishna) thus spoke in their midst.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दशसूनासमं चक्रं दशचक्रसमो ध्वजः। दशध्वजसमा वेश्या दशवेश्यासमो नृपः॥
English Translation: When the great Brahman has created thousands of creatures why is it that only these five elements which he created first, which permeate the entire universe and which are great creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्धेनैतानि सर्वाणि नृपतिः कथ्यतेऽधिकः। त्रिवर्गसहितं शास्त्रं पवित्रं पुण्यलक्षणम्॥ धर्मव्याकरणं पुण्यं रहस्यश्रवणं महत्। श्रोतव्यं धर्मसंयुक्तं विहितं त्रिदशैः स्वयम्॥
English Translation: Bhrigu said All things which belong to the Infinite or the Vast are known by the name of Great. Therefore these five clements are called Great creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पितॄणां यत्र गुह्यानि प्रोच्यन्ते श्राद्धकर्मणि। देवतानां च सर्वेषां रहस्यं कथ्यतेऽखिलम्॥
English Translation: Activity is wind. The sound is space. The heat that lives within it is fire. The liquid juices cc:itained in it are water. The solidified matter, viz., flesh and bones from the Earth. The bodies are thus made of the five elements.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ऋषिधर्मः स्मृतो यत्र सरहस्यो महाफलः। महायज्ञफलं चैव सर्वदानफलं तथा॥
English Translation: All mobile and immobile objects are formed of these five elements. The five senses also made of the give clements. The car is formed of the properties of space. The nose of earth; the tongue of water; touch of wind; and eyes of tire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ये पठन्ति सदा मा येषां चैवोपतिष्ठति। श्रुत्वा च फलमाचष्टे स्वयं नारायणः प्रभुः॥
English Translation: Bharadwaja said If all mobile and immobile objects be made of these five elements, why is it that in all immobile objects those elements are not seen.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गवां फलं तीर्थफलं यज्ञानां चैव यत् फलम्। एतत् फलमवाप्नोति यो नरोऽतिथिपूजकः॥
English Translation: Trees do not appear to have possessed any heat. They appear to have no motion. They are again formed of thick particles. The five elements are not seen in them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रोतारः श्रद्दधानाश्च येषां शुद्ध च मानसम्। तेषां व्यक्त जिता लोकाः श्रद्दधनेन साधुना॥ मुच्यते किल्बिषाच्चैच न सा पापेन लिप्यते। धर्मे च लभते नित्यं प्रेत्य लोकगतो नरः॥
English Translation: Trees do not hear; they do not sec; they cannot smell or taste. They cannot touch. How then can they be regarded as formed of the five elements.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कस्यचित् त्वथ कालस्य देवदूतो यदृच्छया। स्थितो ह्यन्तर्हितो भूत्वा पर्यभाषत वासवम्॥
English Translation: It appears to me that for the absence of any liquid matter in them, of any heat, of any earth, of any wind, and of any empty space, trees cannot be considered as compounds of the five primary elements.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यौ तौ कामगुणोपेतावश्विनौ भिषजां वरौ। आज्ञयाहं तयोः प्राप्तः सनरान् पितृदैवतान्॥
English Translation: Bhrigu said Forsooth, though possessed of density, trees have space within them. They always bear flowers and fruits.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कस्माद्धि मैथुनं श्राद्धे दातुर्भोक्तुश्च वर्जितम्। किमर्थं च त्रयः पिण्डाः प्रविभक्ताः पृथक् पृथक्।।
English Translation: They have heat within them for which leaf, bark, fruit, and flower are seen to fall off. They sicken and dry up. This indicates that they have perception of touch.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रथमः कस्य दातव्यो मध्यमः क्व च गच्छति। उत्तरश्च स्मृतः कस्य एतदिच्छागि वेदितुम्॥
English Translation: By sound of wind and fire and thunder, their fruits and flowers fall down. Sound is perceived through the ear. Trees have, therefore, ears and do hear.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रद्दधनेन दूतेन भाषितं धर्मसंहितम्। पूर्वस्थास्त्रिदशाः सर्वे पितरः पूज्य खेचरम्॥
English Translation: A creeper entwines a tree all around. A blind thing cannot see its way. Therefore it is evident that trees have vision.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पितर ऊचुः स्वागतं तेऽस्तु भद्रं ते श्रूयतां खेचरोत्तम। गूढार्थः परमः प्रश्नो भवता समुदीरितः॥
English Translation: Again trees regain vigour and put forth flowers for good and bad smell, of the sacred incense of all sorts. It is evident that trees have scent.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्राद्धं दत्त्वा च भुक्त्वा च पुरुषो यःस्त्रियं व्रजेत्। पितरस्तस्य तं मासं तस्मिन् रेतसि शेरते।॥
English Translation: They draw water by their roots. They catch all sorts of diseases. Those diseases again are cured by various operations. From this it is clear that trees have perception of taste.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रविभागं तु पिण्डानां प्रवक्ष्याम्यनुपूर्वशः। पिण्डो ह्यधस्ताद् गच्छंस्तु अप आविश्य भावयेत्।।
English Translation: As one can draw water through the hole of a lotus-stalk, trees also, with the help of wind, drink through their roots.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पिण्डं तु मध्यमं तत्र पत्नी त्वेका समश्नुते। पिण्डस्तृतीयो यस्तेषां तं दद्याज्जातवेदसि॥
English Translation: They are subject to pleasure and pain, and grow when cut or lopped off. These facts clearly prove that trees have life. They are not manimate.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एष श्राद्धविधिः प्रोक्तो यथा धर्मो न लुप्यते। पितरस्तस्य तुष्यन्ति प्रहृष्टमनसः सदा॥ प्रजा विवर्धते चास्य अक्षयं चोपतिष्ठति।
English Translation: Fire and wind cause the water thus drawn up to be digested. The tree grows and becomes humid proportionate to the quantity of the water taken up.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: देवदूत उवाच आनुपूर्वेण पिण्डानां प्रविभागः पृथक् पृथक्॥ पितॄणां त्रिषु सर्वेषां निरुक्तं कथितं त्वया।
English Translation: In the bodies of all mobile things the five elements reside. The proportions are different in each. Mobile objects can move for these five elements.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एक:समुद्धृतः पिण्डो ह्यधस्तात् कस्य गच्छति॥ कं वा प्रीणयते देवं कथं तारयते पितॄन।
English Translation: Skin, fresh, bones, marrow, and arteries and veins, that exist together in the body are formed of earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मध्यमं तु तदा पत्नी भुङ्क्तेऽनुज्ञातमेव हि॥ किमर्थं पितरस्तस्य कव्यमेव च भुञ्जते।
English Translation: Energy, anger, eyes, internal heat, and the heat which digests the good taken, these five, form the fire that exists in all embodied creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अत्र यस्त्वन्तिमः पिण्डो गच्छते जातवेदसम्॥ भवते का गतिस्तस्य कं वा समनुगच्छति।
English Translation: The cars, nostrils, mouth, heart, and Stomach, these five, form the element of space that exists in the bodies of living creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतदिच्छाम्यहं श्रोतुं पिण्डेषु त्रिषु श गतिः॥ फलं वृत्तिं च मार्गं च यश्चैनं प्रतिपद्यते।
English Translation: Phlegm, bile, sweat, fat, blood are the five kinds of water that exist in inobile bodies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पितरः ऊचुः सुमहानेष प्रश्नो वै यस्त्वया समुदीरितः॥ रहस्यमद्भुतं चापि पृष्टाः स्म गगनेचर।
English Translation: Through the vital breath called Prana, a living creature is capable of moving about. Through that called Vyana they act. That called Apana goes downward. That called Samana lives within the heart.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतदेव प्रशसंन्ति देवाश्च मुनयस्तथा॥ तेऽप्येवं नाभिजानन्ति पितृकार्यविनिश्चयम्।
English Translation: Through that called Udana one passes exertion and is enabled to speak by virtue of its going through (the lungs, the throat, and the mouth). These are the five sorts of vital airs that cause an embodied creature to live and Imove.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वर्जयित्वा महात्मानं चिरजीविनमुत्तमम्॥ पितृभक्तस्तु यो विप्रो वरलब्धो महायशाः।
English Translation: Through the earth-element an embodied creature perceives the properties of scent. From the water-element he perceives taste. From the fire-element as represented by the eyes, he perceives forms, and from the wind-element he perceives touch.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्रयाणामपि पिण्डानां श्रुत्वा भगवतो गतिम्॥ देवदूतेन यः पृष्टः श्राद्धस्य विधिनिश्चयः।
English Translation: Scent, touch, taste, vision and sound, are considered as the common properties of all mobile and immobile objects. I shall first describe the several sorts of scent.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गतिं त्रयाणां पिण्डानां शृणुष्वावहितो मम॥ अपो गच्छति यो ह्यत्र शशिनं ह्येष प्रीणयेत्।
English Translation: They are pleasant, unpleasant, sweet, pungent, far-reaching, varied, dry, indifferent.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शशी प्रीणयते देवान् पितश्चैव महामते॥ भुङ्क्ते तु पत्नी यं चैषामनुज्ञाता तु मध्यमम्।
English Translation: Scent which is formed of the earth element, consists of these nine sorts. Light is seen by the eyes, and touch through the wind-clement.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुत्रकामाय पुत्रं तु प्रयच्छन्ति पितामहाः॥ पिण्डो दीयते तन्निबोध मे।
English Translation: Sound, touch, vision and taste are the properties of water. I shall describe fully that now the perception of taste. Listen to me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पितरस्तेन तृष्यन्ति प्रीताः कामान् दिशन्ति च॥ एतत् ते कथितं सर्वे त्रिषु पिण्डेषु या गतिः।
English Translation: Great Rishis have mentioned various sorts of taste. They are sweet, saltish, bitter, astringent, sour, and pungent.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ऋत्विग्यो यजमानस्य पितृत्वमनुगच्छति॥ हव्यवाहे तु यः तस्मिन्नहनि मन्यन्ते परिहार्ये हि मैथुनम्।
English Translation: These are the six sorts of taste belonging to the water-element. The light is the combind result of sound, touch and forin
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शुचिना तु सदा श्राद्धं भोक्तव्य खेचरोत्तम॥ ये मया कथिता दोषास्ते तथा स्युर्न चान्यथा।
English Translation: Through light one perceives forins. Form is of various kinds, Short, tall, thick square, round, white, black, red, blue, yellow, reddish, hard, bright, smooth, oily, soft and terrible.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मात् स्नातः शुचिः क्षान्तः श्राद्धंभुञ्जीत वै द्विजः।। प्रजा विवर्धते चास्य यश्चैवं सम्प्रयच्छति।
English Translation: These are the sixteen sorts of forin which forms the property of light or vision. The property of the wind element is touch. Touch is of various sorts; warm, cold, agreeable and disagrecable, indifferent, burning, mild, soft, light and heavy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच ततो विद्युत्प्रभो नाम ऋषिराह महातपाः॥ आदित्यतेजसा तस्य तुल्यं रूपं प्रकाशते। स च धर्मरहस्यानि श्रुत्वा शक्रमथाब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: Both sound and touch form the two properties of the wind-element. These are the eleven properties which belong to the wind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तिर्यग्योनिगतान् सत्त्वान् मा हिंसन्ति मोहिताः। कीटान् पिपीलिकान् सर्पान् मेषान् समृगपक्षिणः।। किल्बिषं सुबहु प्राप्ताः किंस्विदेषां प्रतिक्रिया। ततो देवगणाः सर्वे ऋषयश्च तपोधनाः॥
English Translation: Space has only one property, namely sound. I shall now describe to you the different sorts of sound.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पितरश्च महाभागाः पूजयन्ति स्म तं मुनिम्।
English Translation: They are the seven original notes called Shadaja, Rishabha, Gandhara, Maddhyaina, Dhaivata, Panchama, and Nishada.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शक्र उवाच कुरुक्षेत्रं गयां गङ्गां प्रभासं पुष्कराणि च॥ एतानि मनसा ध्यात्वा अवगाहेत् ततो जलम्। तथा मुच्यति पापेन राहुणा चन्द्रमा यथा॥
English Translation: These are the seven sorts of the property which belongs to space. Sound pervades like the Supreme Being the entire space though attached especially to drums drums and other instruments.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्र्यहं स्नातंः स भवति निराहारश्च वर्तते। स्पृशते यो गवां पृष्ठं बालधिं च नमस्यति॥
English Translation: Whatever sound is heard from small and large drums and conch-shells, and cloucis, and cars, and animate and inanimates creatures, are all contained in these seven sorts of sound already mentioned.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो विद्युत्प्रभो वाक्यमभ्यभाषत वासवम्। अयं सूक्ष्मतरो धर्मस्तं निबोध शतक्रतो॥
English Translation: Thus sound, which is the property of space, is of various sorts. The learned have described sound to be born of space. When created by the various kinds of touch, which is the property of the wind, it may be heard. It cannot, however, be heard, when the different kinds of touch are not used. Mixed with their counter parts in the body, the elements increase and grow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: घृष्टो वटकषायेण अनुलिप्तः प्रियंगुणा। क्षीरेण षष्टिकान् भुक्त्वा सर्वपापैः प्रमुच्यते॥
English Translation: Water, fire, wind, always live in the bodies of living creatures. They form the roots of the body. Pervading the five vital airs they live in the body.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रूयतां चापरं गृह्यं रहस्यमृषिचिन्तितम्। श्रुतं मे भाषमाणस्य स्थाणोः स्थाने बृहस्पतेः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said Like a person reluctant to forgive an insult, the highly energetic Arjuna of keen speech and prowess, betraying great fierceness and licking the corners of his mouth, said smilingly these
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रुद्रेण सह देवेश तन्निबोध शचीपते। पर्वतारोहणं कृत्वा एकपादो विभावसुम्॥ निरीक्षेत निराहार उर्ध्वबाहुः कृताञ्जलिः। तपसा महता युक्त उपवासफलं लभेत्॥
English Translation: 'O how painful, how distressing, I am sorry to see this great agitation of your heart, since having performed such a superhuman feat, you are deterinined to forsake the world,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रश्मिभिस्तापितोऽर्कस्य सर्वपापमपोहति। ग्रीष्मकालेऽथ वा शीते एवं पापमपोहति॥
English Translation: Having killed your enemies, and having the sovereignty of the Earth, which has been won ever by observing of the duties of your own order, why should you give up everything through fickleness of heart?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः पापत् प्रमुक्तस्य द्युतिर्भवति शाश्वती। तेजसा सूर्यवद् दीप्तो भ्राजते सोमवत् पुनः॥
English Translation: Where on Earth has a eunuch or a procrastinating person acquired sovereignty? Why then did you beside yourself with anger, slay all the kings of the Earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मध्ये त्रिदशवर्गस्य देवराजः शतक्रतुः। उवाच मधुरं वाक्यं बृहस्पतिमनुत्तमम्॥
English Translation: He that would lead the life of a mendicant, cannot, by any act of his, enjoy the good things of Earth. Shorn of prosperity and other resources, he can never acquire fame on Earth or sons and animals.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धर्मगुह्यं तु भगवन् मानुषाणां सुखावहम्। सरहस्याश्च ये दोषास्तान् यथावदुदीरय॥
English Translation: If, O king, abandoning this prosperous kingdom, you lead the wretched life of a mendicant, what will the world say of you?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बृहस्पति रुवाच प्रतिमेहन्ति ये सूर्यमनिलं द्विषते च ये। हव्यवाहे प्रदीप्ते च समिधं ये न जुह्वति॥ बालवत्सां च ये धेनुं दुहन्ति क्षीरकारणात्। तेषां दोषान् प्रवक्ष्यामि तान् निबोध शचीपते॥
English Translation: Why do you say that leaving aside all the good things of the Earth, shorn of prosperity, and of resources, you will live like a mendicant and a vulgar person.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भानुमाननिलश्चैव हव्यवाहश्च वासव। लोकानां मातरश्चैव गावः सृष्टाः स्वयम्भुवा॥ लोकांस्तारयितुं शक्ता मत्र्येष्वेतेषु देवताः। सर्वे भवन्तः शृण्वन्तु एकैकं धर्मनिश्चयम्॥
English Translation: You are born in a royal family. Having conquered the whole Earth, do you foolishly wish to live in the forest after for-saking everything of virtue of profit?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वर्षाणि षडशीति तु दुर्वत्ताः कुलपांसनाः। स्त्रियः सर्वाश्च दुर्वृत्ता:प्रतिमेहन्ति या रविम्॥
English Translation: In your absence, dishonest men will despoil sacrifices. That sin will certainly contaminate you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनिलद्वेषिणः शक्र गर्भस्था च्यवते प्रजा। हव्यवाहस्य दीप्तस्य समिधं ये न जुह्वति।॥
English Translation: Having perpetrated many wicked acts in a state of poverty, king Nahusha spoke ill of that state and said that poverty is for recluses.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अग्निकार्येषु वै तेषां हव्यं नाश्नाति पावकः। क्षीरं तु बालवत्सानां ये पिबन्तीह मानवाः॥
English Translation: To make no provision for the morrow is a practice that suits Rishis. You know this well! The religion of kings, however, depends entirely on wealth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न तेषां क्षीरपाः केचिज्जायन्ते कुलवर्धनाः। प्रजाक्षयेण युज्यन्ते कुलवंशक्षयेण च॥
English Translation: One who robs another of riches, robs him of his religion as well. Who amongst us, therefore, O king, would forgive an act of depriving us of our wealth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमेतत् पुरा दृष्टं कुलवृद्धौर्द्विजातिभिः। तस्माद् वानि वानि कार्यं कार्यं च नित्यशः।।
English Translation: It is seen that a poor man, even when he stands hard by, is accused falsely. Poverty is a sin. You should not, therefore, speak high of poverty.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भूतिकामेन म]न सत्यमेतद् ब्रवीमि ते। ततः सर्वा महाभाग देवताः समरुद्गणाः॥ ऋषयश्च महाभागाः पृच्छन्ति स्म पितूंस्ततः। पितरः केन तुष्यन्ति मर्त्यानामल्पचेतसाम्॥ अक्षयं च कथं दानं भवेच्चैवोर्ध्वदेहिकम्।
English Translation: A degraded man as also a poor man, O king, have both to rue their fate, I see no difference between these two.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आनृण्यं वा कथं मा गच्छेयुः केन कर्मणा॥ एतदिच्छामहे श्रोतुं परं कौतूहलं हि नः।
English Translation: The increased and deposited wealth like rivers from mountain begets all kinds of meritorious acts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पितर ऊचुः न्यायतो वै महाभागाः संशयः समुदाहृतः॥ श्रूयतां येन तुष्यामो मानां साधुकर्मणाम्।
English Translation: From wealth originate all religious acts, all pleasures, and heaven itself, O king, Without wealth, a man cannot find the very means of maintaining his life.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नीलपण्डप्रमोक्षेण अमावास्यां तिलोदकैः :॥ वर्षासु दीपकैश्चैव पितॄणामनृणो भवेत्।
English Translation: The acts of a person who, endued with little intelligence allows himself to be divested of wealth, are all dried up like shallow rivers in the summer.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अक्षयं निळलीकं च दानमेतन्महाफलम्॥ अस्माकं परितोषश्च अक्षयः परिकीर्त्यते।
English Translation: He who has wealth has friends. He who has wealth has kinsmen. He who has wealth is considered as a sincere man in the world. He who has wealth is regarded as a learned man.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रद्दधानाश्च ये मर्त्या आहरिष्यन्ति संततिम्॥ दुर्गात् ते तारयिष्यन्ति नरकात् प्रपितामहान्।
English Translation: If a person who has no wealth desires to accomplish a particular object, he meets with failure. Wealth Wealth accumulates wealth, like elephants capturing (wild) elephants.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पितॄणां भाषितं श्रुत्वा हृष्टरोमा तपोधनः॥ वृद्धगार्यो महातेजास्तानेवं वाक्यमब्रवीत्। के गुणा नीलपण्डस्य प्रमुक्तस्य तपोधनाः॥ वर्षासु दीपदानेन तथैव च तिलोदकैः।
English Translation: Religious acts, pleasures, joy, courage, anger, learning, and sense of dignity, all originate from wealth, O king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पितर ऊचुः नीलषण्डस्य लाङ्गुलं तोयमभ्युद्धरेद् यदि॥ षष्टिं वर्षसहस्राणि पितरस्तेन तर्पिता:।
English Translation: Wealth begets family prestige. wealth multiples one's religious merit. He who is without wealth has neither this world, nor the next,O foremost of men.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यस्तु शृङ्गगतं पदं कूलादूद्धृत्य तिष्ठति।॥ पितरस्तेन गच्छन्ति सोमलोकमसंशयम्।
English Translation: The man who has no wealth cannot celebrate religious acts, for these originate from wealth, like rivers from a mountain.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वर्षासु दीपदानेन शशिवच्छोभते नरः॥ तमोरूपं न तस्यास्ति दीपकं यः प्रयच्छति।
English Translation: He whose limbs are lean is not truly a lean man, but he who is lean in respect of horses and kine and servants and guests is truly so.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अमावास्यां तु ये माः प्रयच्छन्ति तिलोदकम्॥ पात्रमौदुम्बरं गृह्य मधुमिश्रं तपोधन। कृतं भवति तैः श्राद्धं सरहस्यं यथार्थवत्॥ हृष्टपुष्टमनास्तेषां प्रजा भवति नित्यदा।
English Translation: Judge truly, O kihg, and mark the conduct of the gods and the Danavas. O king, do the gods ever seek anything else than the destruction of their kinsmen (the Asuras)?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कुलवंशस्य वृद्धिस्तु पिण्डदस्य फलं भवेत्। श्रद्दधानस्तु यः कुर्यात् पितॄणामनृणो भवेत्॥
English Translation: If the appropriation of another's wealth be not regarded as right, how, O monarch, will kings practise virtue on this Earth? Learned men have, in the Vedas, laid down this injunction.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमेव समुद्विष्टः श्राद्धकालक्रमस्तथा। विधिः पात्रं फलं चैव यथावदनुकीर्तिमम्॥
English Translation: The learned man have decreed that kings should live, reciting every day the three Vedas, seeking to acquire wealth, and carefully celebrating sacrifices with the wealth thus acquired.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच स तु वाजी समुद्रान्तां पर्येत्य वसुधामिमाम्। निवृत्तोऽभिमुखो राजन् येन वारणसाह्वयम्॥
English Translation: The gods, through civil war, have secured footing in the celestial region. When the very gods have won their prosperity through civil war, what fault can there be in such quarrels?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनुगच्छंश्च तुरगं निवृत्तोऽथ किरीटभृत्। यदृच्छया समापेदे पुरं राजगृहं तदा॥
English Translation: Verily the gods, even behave thus. The eternal precepts of the Vedas also approve of it. To learn, teach, sacrifice, and assist at others sacrifices,-these are our primary duties. The wealth that kings appropriate from others, becomes the instrument of their prosperity. Wealth is never acquired without doing some injury to others.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमभ्याशगतं दृष्ट्वा सहदेवात्मजः प्रभो। क्षत्रधर्मे स्थितो वीरः समरायाजुहाव ह॥
English Translation: It is even thus that kings conquer this world. Having conquered, they are justified to regard that wealth as theirs, just as sons speak of the wealth of their fathers as their own, The royal sages that have gone to heaven have described this to be the duty of kings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः पुरात् सनिष्क्रम्य रथी धन्वी शरी तली। मेघसन्धिः पदाति तं धनंजयमुपाद्रवत्॥
English Translation: Like water flowing on every direction from a rising ocean, wealth goes on all sides from the treasuries of kings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आसाद्य च महातेजा मेघसन्धिर्धनंजयम्। बालभावान्महाराज प्रोवाचेदं न कौशलात्॥
English Translation: This Earth formerly belonged to king Dvilipa, Nahusha, Ambarisha, and Mandhatri. She is now yours.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किमयं चार्यते बाजी स्त्रीमध्य इव भारत। ह्यमेनं हरिष्यामि प्रयतस्व विमोक्षणे॥
English Translation: You should, therefore, celebrate a great sacrifice with enough presents of all sorts and a sufficient quantity of the Earth's produce. If you do not perform that sacrifice, O king, then the sins of this kingdom will visit you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अदत्तानुनयो युद्धे यदि त्वं पितृभिर्मम। करिष्यामि तवातिथ्यं प्रहर प्रहरामि च॥
English Translation: Those subjects whose king performs a horse-sacrifice with enough presents, are all freed from sins and sanctified by witnessing the ablutions at the end of the sacrifice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्युक्तः प्रत्युवाचैनं प्रहसन्निव पाण्डवः। विनकर्ता मया वार्य इति मे व्रतमाहितम्॥ भ्रात्रा ज्येष्ठेन नृपते तवापि विदितं ध्रुवम्। प्रहरस्व यथाशक्ति न मन्युर्विद्यते मम॥
English Translation: In a great sacrifice requiring libations of all kinds of flesh, Mahadeva himself, poured all creatures as sacrificial libations and then his own self.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्युक्तः प्राहरत् पूर्वे पाण्डवं मगधेश्वरः। किरन् शरसहस्राणि वर्षाणीव सहस्रदृक्॥
English Translation: This is the eternal and holy road. Its fruits are never destroyed. This is the great road called Dasharatha. Abandoning it, 'O king, what other path would you follow"? called Dasharatha. Abandoning it, 'O king, what other path would you follow"?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो गाण्डीवभृच्छूरो गाण्डीवप्रहितैः शरैः। चकार मोघांस्तान् बाणान् सयलान् भरतर्षभ॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : When at the command of the king, Dhritarashtra and the son of Shantanu, (Bhishma), the Pandavas had taken up their abode at Indraprastha, they brought under their sway many other kings and monarchs.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स मोघं तस्य बाणौधं कृत्वा वानरकेतनः। शरान् मुमोच ज्वलितान् दीप्तास्यानिव पन्नगान्॥१२
English Translation: As a soul lives happily depending on the body blessed with auspicious marks and pious deeds, so all the subjects lived most happily, depending on Dharmaraja (Yudhishthira).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ध्वजे पताकादण्डेषु रथे यन्त्रे हयेषु च। अन्येषु च रथाङ्गेषु न शरीरे न सारथौ॥
English Translation: O best of the Bharata race, he (Yudhishthira) served equally Dharma, Artha and Kama, as if each of them was a friend as dear to him as his own soul.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संरक्ष्यमाणः पार्थेन शरीरे सव्यसाचिना। मन्यमानः स्ववीर्यं तन्मागधः प्राहिणोच्छरान्॥
English Translation: It appeared as if the three pursuits, Dharma, Artha and Kama, became personified on earth; and with them the king shined as the fourth (pursuit).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो गाण्डीवधन्वा तु मागधेन भृशाहतः। बभौ वसन्तसमये पलाशः पुष्पितो यथा॥
English Translation: Having obtained him as their king, they obtained a monarch who was devoted to the study of the Vedas, who was a performer of great sacrifices and who was the protector of all good works.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अवध्यमानः सोऽभयनन्मागधः पाण्डवर्षभम्। तेन तस्थौ य कौरव्य लोकवीरस्य दर्शने॥
English Translation: (During his reign) Lakshmi became stationary and hearts became devoted to the Supreme Spirit. Virtue itself began to grow all over the world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सव्यसाची तु संक्रुद्धो विकृष्य बलवद् धनुः। हयांश्चकार निर्जीवान् सारथेश्च शिरोऽहरत्॥
English Translation: Surrounded by his four brothers the king looked as resplendent as a great sacrifice depending upon and assisted by the four Vedas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धनुश्चास्य महच्चित्रं क्षुरेण प्रचकर्त ह। हस्तावापं पताकां च ध्वजं चास्य न्यपातयत्॥
English Translation: Many learned Brahmanas with Dhaumya at their head, each equal to Brihaspati, waited upon the king, as the celestial wait upon the Lord of creation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स राजा व्यथितो व्यश्वो विधनुर्हतसारथिः। गदामादाय कौन्तेयमभिदुद्राव वेगवान्॥
English Translation: On account of the excessive affection of the people, both their hearts and eyes equally took great delight in Dharmaraja (Yudhishthira) who was like a full moon without a stain.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्यापतत एवाशु गदां हेमपरिष्कृताम्। शरैश्चकर्त बहुधा बहुभिर्गृध्रवाजितैः॥
English Translation: The people took delight in him, not only because he was their king, but because they bore for him a great affection. The king also did not was agreeable to them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सा गदा शकलीभूता विशीर्णमणिबन्धना। व्याली विमुच्यमानेव पपात धरणीतले॥
English Translation: The sweet-speeched and greatly intelligent son of Pritha (Yudhishthira) never uttered any was improper, or untrue unbearable or disagreeable.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विरथं विधनुष्कं च गदया परिवर्जितम्। सान्त्वपूर्वमिदं वाक्यमब्रवीत् कपिकेतनः॥ पर्याप्तः क्षत्रधर्मोऽयं दर्शितः पुत्र गम्यताम्। बह्वेतत् समरे कर्म तव बालस्य पार्थिव॥
English Translation: or That greatly powerful and best king of the Varata race happily passed his days in seeking the good of every body, as if every one was his own self.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिरस्य संदेशो न हन्तव्या नृपा इति। तेन जीवसि राजंस्त्वमपराद्धोऽपि मे रणे।॥
English Translation: (His brothers) the Pandavas brought by their great powers many kings under their sway; they passed their days in happiness, having nothing to disturb their peace.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इति मत्वा तदात्मानं प्रत्यादिष्टं स्म मागधः। तथ्यमित्यभिगम्यैनं प्राञ्जलिः प्रत्यपूजयत्॥
English Translation: After a few days, Vivatsu (Arjuna) thus spoke to Krishna, “O Krishna, the summer is come, let us go to the Yamuna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पराजितोऽस्मि भद्रं ते नाहं योधुमिहात्सहे। यद् यत् कृत्यं मया तेऽद्य तद् ब्रूहि कृतमेव तु॥
English Translation: O Janardana, O slayer of Madhu, if you like, let us sport their with out friends and then return in the evening.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमर्जूनः समाश्वास्य पुनरेवेदमब्रवीत्। आगन्तव्यं परां चैत्रीमश्वमेधे नृपस्य नः॥
English Translation: Krishna said : O son of Kunti, this is also my wish. O Partha, let us sport with our friends in the waters( of the Yamuna).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्युक्तः स तथेत्युक्त्वा पूजयामास तं हयम्। फाल्गुनं च युधि श्रेष्ठं विधिवत् सहदेवजः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said: O descendant of Bharata, having consulted with each other and after receiving Yudhishthira's permission, Partha (Arjuna) and Govinda (Krishna) in company with their friends set out (for the Yamuna).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो यथेष्टमगमत् पुनरेव स केसरी। ततः समुद्रतीरेण वङ्गान् पुण्ड्रान् सकोसलान्॥
English Translation: And arrived at a charming spot, fitted for the purpose of pleasure, overgrown with numerous tall trees and adorned with high mansions and looking like the city of Indra. O descendant of Bharata, in these houses were collected for the descendants of Vrishni and Pritha (Arjuna and Krishna) numerous wellflavoured and costly viands, drinks and other articles of enjoyments and floral wreathes and various perfumes. The party soon entered the inner apartments (of the house), adorned with many precious gems of pure brilliancy. Entering these apartments, every one of them began to sport at his pleasure.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्र तत्र च भूरीणि म्लेच्छसैन्यान्यनेकशः। विजिग्ये धनुषा राजन् गाण्डीवेन धनंजयः॥
English Translation: The women with beautiful full hips and rising breasts with handsome eyes and unsteady gait for drink began to sport.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच केषां प्रभवते राजा वित्तस्य भरतर्षभ। कया च वृत्त्या वर्तेत तन्मे ब्रूहि पितामह॥
English Translation: Some sported at their pleasure in the woods, some in the waters and some within the houses as directed and commanded by Krishna and Partha (Arjuna).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच अब्राह्मणानां वित्तस्य स्वामी राजेति वैदिकम्। ब्राह्मणानां च ये केचिद् विकर्मस्था भवन्त्युत॥
English Translation: O king, Draupadi and Subhadra, exhilarated with wine, gave away costly robes and ornaments to the women that were sporting there.

Sanskrit Shloka: विकर्मस्थाश्च नोपेक्ष्या विप्रा राज्ञा कथञ्चन। इति राज्ञां पुरावृत्तमाभिजल्पन्ति साधवः॥
English Translation: Some amongst them danced in joy and some began to sing; some laughed and jested and some drank excellent wines.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यस्य स्म विषये राज्ञः स्तेनो भवति वै द्विजः। राज्ञ एवापराधं तं मन्यन्ते किल्बिषं नृप॥
English Translation: Some obstructed one another's progress, some fought with one another and some again talked with one another in private and some cut jokes at one another.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभिशस्तमिवात्मानं मन्यन्ते येन कर्मणा। तस्माद् राजर्षयः सर्वे ब्राह्मणानन्वपालयन्॥
English Translation: Those woods, filled with the charming music of the flute, guitars and drums, became the scene of prosperity itself.

Sanskrit Shloka: अत्राप्युदाहरन्तीममितिहासं पुरातनम्। गीतं कैकेयराजेन ह्रियमाणेन रक्षसा॥
English Translation: When such was the state of things there, the descendants of Kuru and Dasharha (Krishna and Arjuna) went to a certain charming spot near by.

Sanskrit Shloka: केकयानामधिपतिं रक्षो जग्राह दारुणम्। स्वाध्यायेनान्वितं राजन्नरण्ये संशितव्रतम्॥

Sanskrit Shloka: न च मे ब्राह्मणोऽविद्वान्नाव्रती नाप्यसोमपः। नानाहिताग्नित यज्वा मामकान्तरमाविशः॥

English Translation: He looked like an old Shala tree, his complexion was like that of heated gold, his beard with bright yellow tinged with green, the height and thickness of his body were in just proportion.

Sanskrit Shloka: नासं विभज्य भोक्तास्मि नाविशामि परस्त्रियम्। स्वतन्त्र जातु न क्रीडे मामकान्तरमाविशः॥
English Translation: The whole of this world was enveloped with darkness; and neither the cardinal nor subsidiary points of the earth could be known on account of the dust that was raised.

Sanskrit Shloka: नावजानाम्यहं वैद्यान्न वृद्धान्न तपस्विनः। राष्ट्रे स्वपति जागर्मि मामकान्तरमाविशः॥

English Translation: Wherever he went, the giver of wealth was praised by the Brahmanas by thousands by laudatory words; and they served him with curds, honey, clarified butter and riches.

English Translation: Women coming out on the highways threw on the great-souled one attached to the good of all creatures wild flowers of great fragrance.

Sanskrit Shloka: गोब्राह्मणेभ्यो यज्ञेभ्यो नित्यं स्वस्त्ययनं मम। आशासते जना राष्ट्रे मामकान्तरमाविशः॥

Sanskrit Shloka: राक्षस उवाच यस्मात् सर्वास्ववस्थासु धर्ममेवान्ववेक्षसे। तस्मात् प्राप्नुहि कैकेय गृहं स्वस्ति व्रजाम्यहम्॥
English Translation: After having seen many animals and beautiful villages enchanting the heart and after traversing diverse cities and kingdoms.

English Translation: Ever of cheerful hearts, of good minds and well protected by the Bharatas and therefore not caring for the designs of the enemies and incognizant of all sorts of calamities, the people and the inhabitants of the city of Upaplavya, coming out of the city, stood on the roads desirous of beholding Vishvaksena.

Sanskrit Shloka: येषां पुरोगमा विप्रा येषां ब्रह्म परं बलम्। अतिथिप्रियास्तथा पौरास्ते वै स्वर्गजितो नृपाः॥

Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच तस्माद् द्विजातीन् रक्षेत ते हि रक्षन्ति रक्षिताः। आशीरेषां भवेद् राजन् राज्ञां सम्यक्प्रवर्तताम्॥
English Translation: Keshava, the slayer of heroes on the enemy's side, having come near Vrikasthala, the sky was reddened by the rays shot by the sun.

Sanskrit Shloka: तस्माद् राज्ञा विशेषेण विकर्मस्था द्विजातयः। नियम्याः संविभज्याश्च तदनुग्रहकारणात्॥
English Translation: Quickly getting down from his chariot and having undergone the purifactory rites according to the usual custom and ordering for his chariot to be unyoked, he sat down for the customary evening duties.

English Translation: All this being done, the slayer of Madhu said-with view to the attainment of Yudhishthira's object must we pass the night here.

Sanskrit Shloka: अहमप्यत्र वत्स्यामि गोमत्याः पुलिने शुभे। कालं परिमिताहारो यथोक्तं परिपालयन्॥
English Translation: Have you been defeated in battle? You look like one shorn of prosperity! I do not know that you have been defeated by any one. Why then, O chief Bharata's race, this exceedingly dejected look! You should O of Pritha, tell me all, if, indeed, there be no harm in telling it.

Sanskrit Shloka: ततः स विप्रस्तां नागी समाधाय पुनः पुनः। तदेव पुलिनं नद्याः प्रययौ ब्राह्मणर्षभः॥

Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच ततः पाण्डवाः पुनर्मार्कण्डेयमूचुः॥
English Translation: The heroes of the Bhoja, the Andhaka, and the Vrishni races, O Brahmana, who were all gifted with high-souls, great might, and leonine pride, have killed one another in battle. Possessed of arms which looked like maces of iron, and capable of bearing the strokes of heavy clubs and darts, alas they have all been killed with blades of Eraka grass. See the perverse course of Time. Five hundred thousand mighty-armed warriors have thus been killed. Encountering one another, they have met with destruction.

Sanskrit Shloka: कथितं ब्राह्मणमहाभाग्यं राजन्यमहाभाग्यमिदानी शुश्रूषामह इति तानुवाच मार्कण्डेयो महर्षिः श्रूयतामिति इदानीं राजन्यानां महाभाग्यमिति। कुरूणामन्यतमः सुहोत्रो राजा महर्षीनभिगम्य निवृत्य रथस्थमेव नमौशीनरं शिबिं ददर्शाभिमुखं तौ समेत्य परस्परेण यथावयः पूजां प्रयुज्य गुणसाम्येन परस्परेण तुल्यात्मानौ विदित्वान्योन्यस्य पन्थानं न ददतुस्तत्र नारदः प्रादुरासीत् किमिदं भवन्तौ परस्परस्य पन्थानमावृत्य तिष्ठत इति॥ नाम
English Translation: Thinking repeatedly of this destruction of the Yadava warriors of immeasurable energy and of the illustrious Krishna, I cannot get peace of mind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तावूचतुर्नारदं नैतद् भगवन् पूर्वकर्मकादिभि-विशिष्टस्य पन्था उपदिश्यते समर्थाय वा आवां च सख्यं परस्परेणोपगतौ तच्चावधानतोऽत्युत्कृष्टमधरोत्तरंपरिभ्रष्टं नारदस्त्वेवमुक्तः श्लोकत्रयमपठयत्॥
English Translation: The death of the holder of Sharnga is as incredible as the drying up of the ocean, the displacement of a mountain, the falling down of the heaven, or the cooling property of fie. Deprived of the company of the Vrishni heroes, I wish not to live in this world.
