Sanskrit Shloka: क्रूरः कौरव्य मृदवे मृदुः क्रूरे च कौरव। साधुश्चासाधवे साधुः साधवे नाप्नुयात् कथम्॥
English Translation: Another event has taken place that is more painful than this, O you having penances for wealth. Repeatedly thinking of it, my heart is breaking.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृतं शतगुणं कुर्यान्नास्ति देवेषु निर्णयः। औशीनरः साधुशीलो भवतो वै महीपतिः॥
English Translation: In my very sight, O Brahmana, thousands of Vrishni ladies were carried away by the Abhiras of the country of the five waters, who attacked us.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जयेत् कदर्यं दानेन सत्येनानृतवादिनम्। क्षमया क्रूरकर्माण-मसाधु साधुना जयेत्॥
English Translation: Taking up my bow, I found myself unequal to even string it. The power that had existed in my arms seemed to have disappeared on that occasion.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदुभावेव भवन्तावुदारौ य इदानीं भवद्भ्यामन्यतमः सोऽपसर्पतु एतद् वै निदर्शनमित्युक्त्वा तूष्णीं नारदो बभूव। एतच्छ्रुत्वा तु कौरव्यः शिबिं प्रदक्षिणं कृत्वा दत्त्वा पन्थानं बहुकर्मभिः प्रशस्य प्रययौ॥
English Translation: O great ascetic, my weapons of various kinds failed to appear. Soon, again, my arrows became exhausted.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदेतद् राज्ञो महाभाग्यमप्युक्तवान् नारदः॥
English Translation: That person of immeasurable soul, of four arms, holding the conch, the discus, and the mace, clad in yellow robes, dark of complexion, and possessing eyes resembling lotus-petals, is no longer seen by me! Alas, reft of Govinda, what have I to live for, dragging my life in sorrow?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच भगवन् श्रोतुमिच्छामि नामान्यस्य महात्मनः। त्रिषु लोकेषु यान्यस्य विख्यातानि द्विजोत्तम॥
English Translation: He who used to stalk in advance of my car, that divine form gifted with great splendour and unfading power, consuming as he proceeded all hostile warriors, can no longer be seen by me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच इत्युक्तः पाण्डवेयेन महात्मा ऋषिसंनिधौ। उवाच भगवांस्तत्र मार्कण्डेयो महातपाः॥
English Translation: No longer seeing him who by his energy first burnt all hostile troops whom I afterwards killed with arrows shot off Gandiva, I am filled with grief and my head swims, O best of men! Penetrated with cheerlessness and despair, I cannot get peace of mind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मार्कण्डेय उवाच आग्नेयश्चैव स्कन्दश्च दीप्तकीर्तिरनामयः। मयूरकेतुर्धर्मात्मा भूतेशो महिषार्दनः॥ कामजित् कामदः कान्तः सत्यवाग् भुवेनश्वरः। शिशुः शीघ्रः शुचिश्चण्डो दीप्तवर्णः शुभाननः॥ अमोघस्त्वनधो रौद्रः प्रियश्चन्द्राननस्तथा। दीप्तशक्तिः प्रशान्तात्मा भद्रकृत् कूटमोहनः॥ षष्ठीप्रियश्च धर्मात्मा पवित्रो मातृवत्सलः। कन्याभर्ता विभक्तश्च स्वाहेयो रेवतीसुतः॥ प्रभुर्नेता विशाखश्च नैगमेयः सुदुश्चरः। सुव्रतो ललितश्चैव बालक्रीडनकप्रियः॥ खचारी ब्रह्मचारी च शूरः शरवणोद्भवः। विश्वामित्रप्रियश्चैव देवसेनाप्रियस्तथा।॥ वासुदेवप्रियश्चैव प्रिय: प्रियकृदेव तु। नामान्येतानि दिव्यानि कार्तिकेयस्य यः पठेत्। स्वर्ग कीर्तिं धनं चैव स लभेन्नात्र संशयः॥
English Translation: I dare not live, reft of the heroic Janardana. As soon as I heard that Vishnu had left the earth, my eyes became dim and all things disappeared from my vision.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्तोष्यामि देवैर्ऋषिभिश्च जुष्टं शक्त्या गुहं नामभिरप्रमेयम्। षडाननं शक्तिधरं सुवीरं निबोध चैतानि कुरुप्रवी॥
English Translation: O best of men, you should tell me what is good for me now, for I am now a wanderer with an empty heart, despoiled of my kinsmen and of my prowess.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्रह्मण्यो वै ब्रह्मजो ब्रह्मविच्च ब्रह्मेशयो ब्रह्मवतां वरिष्ठः। ब्रह्मप्रियो ब्राह्मणसव्रती त्वं ब्रह्मज्ञो वै ब्राह्मणानां च नेता॥
English Translation: Vyasa said The powerful car-warriors of the Vrishni and the Andhaka races have all been consumed by the Brahmanas' course. O chief of Kuru's race, you should not grieve for their destruction.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्वाहा स्वधा त्वं परमं पवित्रं मन्त्रस्तुतस्त्वं प्रथितः षडर्चिः। संवत्सरस्त्वमृतवश्च घड् वै मासार्धमासावयनं दिशश्च॥
English Translation: That which has taken place, had been ordained. It was the destiny of those great warriors. Krishna allowed it to take place although he was fully competent to befell it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वं पुष्कराक्षस्त्वरविन्दवक्त्रः सहस्रवक्त्रोऽसि सहस्रबाहुः। त्वं लोकपालः परमं हविश्व त्वं भावनः सर्वसुरासुराणाम्॥
English Translation: Govinda was able to after the very course of the universe with all its mobile and immobile creatures. What need then be said of the curse of even great Brahmanas?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वमेव सेनाधिपतिः प्रचण्डः प्रभुर्विभुश्चाप्यथ शत्रुजेता। सहस्रभूस्त्वं धरणी त्वमेव सहस्रतुष्टिश्च सहस्रभुक् च॥
English Translation: for you He who used to proceed in front of your car, arined with discus and mace, through affection was the four-armed Vasudeva, that ancient Rishi.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सहस्रशीर्षस्त्वमनन्तरूपः सहस्रपात् त्वं गुह शक्तिधारी। गङ्गासुतस्त्वं स्वमतेन देव स्वाहामहीकृत्तिकानां तथैव॥
English Translation: That great one of expansive eyes, viz., Krishna, having lightened the burthen of the Earth and cast off his (human) body, has attained to his own high seat.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वं क्रीडसे षण्मुख कुक्कुटेन यथेष्टनानाविधकामरूपी। दीक्षासि सोमो मरुतः सदैव धर्मोऽसि वायुरचलेन्द्र इन्द्रः॥
English Translation: By you also, O foremost of men, with Bhima for your helpmate and the twins, O mighty-armed hero, has the great work of the gods been done.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सनातनानामपि शाश्वतस्त्वं प्रभुः प्रभूणामपि चोचधन्वा। ऋतस्य कर्ता दितिजान्तकस्त्वं जेता रिपूणां प्रवरः सुराणाम्॥
English Translation: O foremost one of Kuru's race, I regard you and your brothers as crowned with success, for you have accomplished the great purpose of your lives! The Time has come for your departure from the world. Even this, O powerful one, is what is beneficial for you now.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सूक्ष्मं तपस्तत् परमं त्वमेव परावरज्ञोऽसि परावरस्त्वम्। धर्मस्य कामस्य परस्य चैव त्वत्तेजसा कृत्स्त्रमिदं महात्मन्॥
English Translation: Even thus, understanding and prowess and foresight. O Bharata, arise when days of prosperity have gone. These very acquisitions disappear when the hour of adversity comes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्याप्तं जगत् सर्वसुरप्रवीर शक्त्या मया संस्तुत लोकनाथ। नमोऽस्तु ते द्वादशनेत्रबाहो अतः परं वेद्मि गतिं न तेऽहम्॥
English Translation: All this has Time for its root. Time is, indeed, the seed of the of the universe, O not FINISH MA Dhananjaya! It is Time, again, which withdraws everything at its pleasure.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्कन्दस्य य इदं विप्रः पठेज्जन्म समाहितः। श्रावयेद् ब्राह्मणेभ्यो यः शृणुयाद् वा द्विजेरितम्॥ धनमायुर्यशो दीप्तं पुत्राञ्छत्रुजयं तथा। स पुष्टितुष्टी सम्प्राप्य स्कन्दसालोम्यमाप्नुयात्॥
English Translation: One becomes powerful, and, again, losing that power, becomes weak. One becomes a master and rules others, and again, losing that position, becomes a servant for obeying the order of others.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच भोजाः प्रव्रजिताञ्छ्रुत्वा वृष्णयश्चान्धकैः सह। पाण्डवान् दुःखसंतप्तान् समाजग्मुर्महावने॥
English Translation: Your weapons, having achieved success, have gone away to the place they came from. They will, again, come into your hands when the Time for their coming approaches.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पाञ्चालस्य च दायादोधृष्टकेतुश्च चेदिपः। केकयाश्च महावीर्या भ्रातरो लोकविश्रुताः॥ वने द्रष्टुं ययुः पार्थान् क्रोधामर्षसमन्विताः। गर्हयन्तोधार्तराष्ट्रान् किं कुर्म इति चाब्रुवन्॥
English Translation: The Time has come, O Bharata, for you all to attain to the highest end. This is what I consider to be highly beneficial for you all, O chief of Bharata's race.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वासुदेवं पुरस्कृत्य सर्वे ते क्षत्रियर्षभाः। परिवार्योपविविशुर्धर्मराज युधिष्ठिरम्।। अभिवाद्य कुरुश्रेष्ठं विषण्णः केशवोऽब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: Having heard these words of Vyasa of great energy, the son of Pritha, receiving his permission, returned to the city of Hastinapur.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वासुदेव उवाच दुर्योधनस्य कर्णस्य शकुनेश्च दुरात्मनः। दुःशासनचतुर्थानां भूमिः पास्यति शोणितम्॥
English Translation: Entering it, the hero approached Yudhishthira and informed him of all that had taken place about the Vrishnis. JSALA PARVA
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतान् निहत्य समरे ये च तस्य पदानुगाः। तांश्च सर्वान् विनिर्जित्य सहितान् सनराधिपान्॥ ततः सर्वेऽभिषिञ्चामोधर्मराज युधिष्ठिरम्। निकृत्योपचरन् वध्य एषधर्मः सनातनः॥
English Translation: Narada said By listening to such sacred scriptures, as bring about tranquillity, as remove grief, and as yield happiness, one acquired (a pure) understanding, and, having acquired it; obtains to great happiness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच पार्थानामभिषङ्गेण तथा क्रुद्धं जनार्दनम्। अर्जुनः शमयामास दिधक्षन्तमिव प्रजाः॥ संक्रुद्धं केशवं दृष्ट्वा पूर्वदेहेषु फाल्गुनः। कीर्तयामास कर्माणि सत्यकीर्तेर्महात्मनः॥ पुरुषस्याप्रमेयस्य सत्यस्यामिततेजसः। प्रजापतिपतेविष्णोर्लोकनाथस्यधीमतः॥
English Translation: A thousand causes of sorrow, a hundred causes of fear, from day to day, attack one who is shorn of understanding but not one who is endued with wisdom and learning.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्जुन उवाच दश वर्षसहस्राणि यत्रसायंगृहो मुनिः। व्यचरस्त्वं पुरा कृष्ण पर्वते गन्धमादने॥
English Translation: Do you, therefore, listen to some old narratives as I recount them to you, for the object of removing your sorrow, If one can subjugate his understanding, he is sure to acquire happiness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दश वर्षसहस्राणि दश वर्षशतानि च। पुष्करेष्ववसः कृष्ण त्वमपो भक्षयन् पुरा॥
English Translation: By accession of what is undesirable and dissociation from what is agreeable, only men of little intelligence yield to mental sorrow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ऊर्ध्वबाहुर्विशालायां बदर्यां मधुसूदन। अतिष्ठ एकपादेन वायुभक्षः शतं समाः॥
English Translation: When things are passed, one should not grieve, thinking of their merits. He who thinks of such past things with affection can never liberate himself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अवकृष्टोत्तरासङ्गः कृशोधमनिसंततः। आसीः कृष्ण सरस्वत्यां सत्रे द्वादशवार्षिके॥
English Translation: One should always try to find out the faults of those things to which one becomes attached, One should always consider such things to be fraught with much evil, By doing so, one should soon free him therefrom.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रभासमप्यथासाद्य तीर्थं पुण्यजनोचितम्। तथा कृष्ण महातेजा दिव्यं वर्षसहस्रकम्॥ अतिष्ठस्त्वमथैकेन पादेन नियमस्थितः। लोकप्रवृत्तिहेतुस्त्वमिति व्यासो ममाब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: The man who grieves for what is past, cannot acquire either riches or religious merit or fame. What exists no longer cannot be acquired. When such things go away, they do not return.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क्षेत्रज्ञः सर्वभूतानामादिरन्तश्च केशव। निधानं तपसां कृष्णा यज्ञस्त्वं च सनातनः॥
English Translation: Creatures sometimes acquire and sometimes lose earthly objects. No man in this world can be grieved by all the events that befall him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निहत्य नरकं भौममाहत्य मणिकुण्डले। प्रथमोत्पतितं कृष्णा मेध्यमश्वमवासृजः॥
English Translation: Dead or lost, he who grieves for what is gone only gets sorrow for sorrow. Instead of one sorrow, he gets two.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृत्वा तत् कर्म लोकानामृषभः सर्वलोकजित्। अवधीस्त्वं रणे सर्वान् समेतान् दैत्यदानवान्॥
English Translation: Those men who, seeing the course of life and death in the world with the help of their intelligence, do not shed tears, are said to see properly. Such persons have never to shed tears.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः सर्वेश्वरत्वं च सम्प्रदाय शचीपतेः। मानुषेषु महाबाहो प्रादुर्भूतोऽसि केशव॥
English Translation: When any such calamity comes, which creates either their physical or mental grief, as is incapable of being prevented by even his best endeavours, one should cease to think on it with sorrow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स त्वं नारायणो भूत्वा हरिरासीः परंतप। ब्रह्मा सोमश्च सूर्यश्चधर्मोधाता यमोऽनलः॥ वायुर्वैश्रवणो रुद्रः कालः खं पृथिवी दिशः। अजश्चराचरगुरुः स्रष्टा त्वं पुरुषोत्तम॥
English Translation: Not to think of it is the panacea for sorrow. By thinking of it, one can never remove it; on the other hand, by thinking upon sorrow, one only increases it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: परायणं देवमूर्धा क्रतुभिर्मधुसूदन। अयजो भूरितेजा वै कृष्ण चैत्ररथे वने॥
English Translation: Mental sorrow should be destroyed by wisdom; while physical sorrow should be removed by medicines. This is the power of knowledge. One should not, in such matters, act like men of little understandings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शतं शतसहस्राणि सुवर्णस्य जनार्दन। एकैकस्मिंस्तदा यज्ञे परिपूर्णानि भागशः॥
English Translation: Youth, beauty, life, hoarded riches, health, association with those that are loved, these all are fickle. One endued with wisdom should never covet them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अदितेरपि पुत्रत्वमेत्य यादवनन्दन। त्वं विष्णुरिति विख्यात इन्द्रादवरजो विभुः॥
English Translation: One should not lament individually for a sorrowful incident that concerns an entire community. Instead of indulgence in grief when it comes, one should try to avert it and apply a remedy as soon as he finds the opportunity for doing it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शिशुर्भूत्वा दिवं खं च पृथिवीं च परंतप। त्रिभिर्विक्रमणैः कृष्ण क्रान्तवानसि तेजसा॥
English Translation: There is no doubt that in this life misery is much greater than that of happiness. There is no doubt in this that all men show attachment for objects of the senses and that death is considered as disagreeable.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सम्प्राप्य दिवमाकाशमादित्यस्यन्दने स्थितः। अत्यरोचश्च भूतात्मन् भास्करं स्वेन तेजसा॥
English Translation: That man who renounces both joy and sorrow, is said to attain to Brahma. When such a man dies, men of wisdom never indulge in any grief for him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रादुर्भावसहस्रेषु तेषु तेषु त्वया विभो। अधर्मरुचयः कृष्ण निहताः शतशोऽसुराः॥
English Translation: There is pain in spending wealth. There is pain in protecting it. There is pain in acquiring it. Hence, when one's wealth is lost, he should not grieve for it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सादिता मौरवाः पाशा निसुन्दनरको हतौ। कृतः क्षेमः पुनः पन्थाः पुरं प्राग्ज्योतिषं प्रति॥
English Translation: Men of little understandings, in their efforts to acquire different grades of wealth, lose their contentment and at last die broken-hearted. Wise men, however, are always contented.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जारूथ्यामाहुतिः क्राथः शिशुपालो जनैः सह। जरासंधश्च शैब्यश्च शतधन्वा च निर्जितः॥
English Translation: All combinations are sure to end in dissolution. All things that are high are destined to fall down and become low. Union is sure to end in disunion, and life is certain to end in death.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथा पर्जन्यघोषेण रथेनादित्यवर्चसा। अवाप्सीमहिषीं भोज्यां रणे निर्जित्य रुक्मिणम्॥
English Translation: Thirst can never be satiated. Contentment is the greatest happiness. Hence, wise men regard contentment as the most valuable wealth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इन्द्रद्युम्नो हतः कोपाद् यवनश्च कसेरुमान्। हतः सौभपतिः शाल्वस्त्वया सौभं च पातितम्॥
English Translation: One's lease of life is running continually. It stops not in its course for even a single moment. When one's body itself is not durable, what other thing is there which one should consider as durable?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमेते युधि हता भूयश्चान्याञ्छृणुष्व ह। इरावत्यां हतो भोजः कार्तवीर्यसमो युधि।॥
English Translation: Those persons who, meditating on the nature of all creatures and, concluding that it is beyond the grasp of the mind, direct their attention to the highest path, and, starting, acquire a fair progress in it, have not to indulge in sorrow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गोपतिस्तालकेतुश्च त्वया विनिहतावुभौ। तां च भोगवतीं पुण्यामृषिकान्तां जनार्दन॥ द्वारकामात्मसात् कृत्वा समुद्रं गमयिष्यसि।
English Translation: Like a tiger seizing and running away with its prey, Death seizes and runs away with the man, who is engaged in such occupation and which is still not satiated with objects of desire and enjoyment.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न क्रोधो न च मात्सर्यं नानृतं मधुसूदन। त्वयि तिष्ठति दाशार्ह न नृशंस्यं कुतोऽनृजु॥ आसीनं चैत्यमध्ये त्वां दीप्यमानं स्वतेजसा। आगम्य ऋषयः सर्वेऽयाचन्ताभयमच्युत॥
English Translation: One should always try to liberate himself from sorrow. One should try to remove sorrow by beginning his work with cheerfulness, that is without indulging, in sorrow, having freed himself from a particular sorrow, one should act in such a way as to keep sorrow at a distance by abstaining from all shortcomings of conduct.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युगान्ते सर्वभूतानि संक्षिप्य मधुसूदन। आत्मनैवात्मसात् कृत्वा जगदासीः परंतप॥
English Translation: The rich and the poor alike find nothing in sound and touch and form and scent and taste, after the immediate enjoyment thereof.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युगादौ तव वार्ष्णेय नाभिपद्मादजायत। ब्रह्मा चराचरगुरुर्यस्येदं सकलं जगत्॥
English Translation: Before union, creatures never suffer sorrow. Hence, one who has not deviated from his original nature, never grieves when that union comes to an end.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं हन्तुमुद्यतौ घोरौ दानवौ मधुकैटभौ। तयोर्व्यतिक्रमं दृष्ट्वा क्रुद्धस्य भवतो हरेः॥ ललाटाज्जातवाञ्छम्भुः शूलपाणिस्त्रिलोचनः। इत्थं तावपि देवेशौ त्वच्छरीरसमुद्भवौ॥४०
English Translation: One should control his sexual appetite and the stomach with the help of patience. One should protect his hands and feet with the help of the eye. One's eyes and ears and the other senses, should be protected by the mind. One's mind and speech should be governed with the help of wisdomn.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वन्नियोगकरावेताविति मे नारदोऽब्रवीत्। तथा नारायण पुरा क्रतुभिर्भूरिदक्षिणैः॥ इष्टवांस्त्वं महासत्रं कृष्ण चैत्ररथे वने। नैवं परे नापरे वा करिष्यन्ति कृतानि वा॥ कृतवान् पुण्डरीकाक्ष बलदेवसहायवान्। कैलासभवने चापि ब्राह्मणैर्व्यवस: सह॥
English Translation: Renouncing love and affection for persons that are known as well as for those that are unknown, one should act with humility. Such a person is said to be endued with wisdom, and such a one surely finds happiness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच एवमुक्त्वा महात्मानमात्मा कृष्णस्य पाण्डवः। तूष्णीमासीत् ततः पार्थमित्युवाच जनार्दनः॥
English Translation: That man who is pleased with his own Soul, who is given to Yoga, who depends upon nothing out of self, who is without cupidity, and who acts without the help of anything but his self, succeeds in acquiring happiness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ममैव त्वं तवैवाहं ये मदीयास्तवैव ते। यस्त्वां द्वेष्टि स मां द्वेष्टि यस्त्वामनु समामनु॥
English Translation: Duryodhana said In all the worlds, Vasudeva is spoken of as the Highest Being; O grandsire, I desire to know all about his nativity and his glory.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नरस्त्वमसि दुर्धर्ष हरिर्नारायणो ह्यहम्। काले लोकमिमं प्राप्तौ नरनारायणावृषी॥
English Translation: Bhishma said Vasudeva is the Supreme Being, the God of all gods. There is to be seen none, O foremost of the Bharata, superior to Him of eyes resembling lotus petals.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनन्यः पार्थ मत्तस्तवं त्वत्तश्चाहं तथैव च। नावयोरन्तरं शक्यं वेदितुं भरतर्षभ॥
English Translation: Markandeya speaks of Govinda as the great mystery, as all beings, as the Soul of all, as the Highest Soul and as the Foremost of all male beings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्ते तु वैशम्पायन उवाच वचने केशवेन महात्मना। तस्मिन् वीरसमावाये संरब्धेष्वथ राजसु॥ धृष्टद्युम्नमुखैवीरैर्धातृभिः परिवारिता। पाञ्चाली पुण्डरीकाक्षमासीनं भ्रातृभिः सह। अभिगम्याब्रवीत् क्रुद्धा शरण्यं शरणैषिणी॥
English Translation: He created these three things viz., Water, Air, and Fire. Having created this Earth, that Divine Master, the Lord of all the worlds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्रौपद्युवाच पूर्वे प्रजाभिसर्गे त्वामाहुरेकं प्रजापतिम्। स्रष्टारं सर्वलोकानामसितो देवलोऽब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: That Highest Soul, that Foremost of all Beings, laid himself down on the waters. Therein, that Divine One composed of all energies, was lulled in sleep through his Yoga.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विष्णुस्त्वमसि दुर्धर्ष त्वं यज्ञो मधुसूदन। यष्टा त्वमसि यष्टव्यो जामदग्न्यो यथाब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: He created Fire from his mouth, and wind from His vital breath. That undeteriorating One created Words and the Vedas from his mind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ऋषयस्त्वां क्षमामाहुः सत्यं च पुरुषोत्तम। सत्याद् यज्ञोऽसि सम्भूतः कश्यपस्त्वां यथाब्रवीत्।
English Translation: At first, He created these worlds as also the celestials along with all the sages, He also created decrepitude and death of all creatures and also their growth and birth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: साध्यानामपि देवानां शिवानामीश्वरेश्वर। भूतभावन भूतेश यथा त्वां नारदोऽब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: He is righteousness itself and is versed in all duties. He is the giver of boons and the gratifier of all our desires. He is the Actor himself as well as the Act itself, and he is the Divine and the Sole Master.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्रह्मशंकरशक्राद्यैर्दैववृन्दैः पुनः पुनः। क्रीडसे त्वं नरव्याघ्र बालः क्रीडनकैरिव॥
English Translation: That undeteriorating Lord of illustrious soul, as first created the Past, the Present and the Future and also the creator of the worlds viz., (Brahma).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्यौश्च ते शिरसा व्याप्ता पद्भ्यां च पृथिवी प्रभो। जठरं त इमे लोकाः पुरुषोऽसि सनातनः॥
English Translation: That perfect supreme soul Sri Krishna very first originated Samkarsana, the elder to all living beings. Narayana, the everlasting god of gods was then emerged from him. A lotus was appeared from the navel zone of Narayana. Brahma, grandfather to all and sole cause for creation of this entire world, appeared from that lotus flower. All species of the living organisms have originated then from god Brahina. He created the divine Shesha who is otherwise known as Ananta.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विद्यातपोऽभितप्तानां तपसा भावितात्मनाम्। आत्मदर्शनतृप्तानामृषीणामसि सत्तमः॥
English Translation: And who supports all creatures and upholds the Earth with all her mountains. Through devout mediation, the Vipras come to know him of supreme energy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजर्षीणां पुण्यकृतामाहवेष्वनिवर्तिनाम्। सर्वधर्मोपपन्नानां त्वं गतिः पुरुषर्षभ। त्वं प्रभुस्त्वं विभुश्च त्वं भूतात्मा त्वं विचेष्टसे॥
English Translation: That Foremost of all make beings slew the mighty Asura named Madhu who was born out of the secretion of His ears, who was furious and of fierce actions and fierce intentions, when he was on the point of destroying Brahma. In consequence of His slaying that Asura, the celestials, the Danavas, and the mortals.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: लोकपालाश्च लोकाच नक्षत्राणि दिशो दश। नभश्चन्द्रश्च सूर्यश्च त्वयि सर्वं प्रतिष्ठितम्॥
English Translation: And the sages call Janardana by the name of the Slayer of Madhu. The great Boar, the Lion and the three treaded Lord.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मर्त्यता चैव भूतानाममरत्वं दिवौकसाम्। त्वयि सर्वं महाबाहो लोककार्यं प्रतिष्ठितम्॥
English Translation: Hari is the Father, and the Mother of all living creatures. Neither there was nor there will be, any one superior to Him of eyes like lotus petals.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सा तेऽहं दुःखमाख्यास्ये प्रणयान्मधुसूदन। ईशस्त्वं सर्वभूतानां ये दिव्या ये च मानुषाः॥
English Translation: From His mouth, O monarch, He created, the Regenerate, from His arms the Kshatriya, from His thighs the Vaishyas and from His legs the Shudras.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कथं नु भार्या पार्थानां तव कृष्ण सखी विभो। धृष्टद्युम्नस्य भगिनी सभां कृष्येत मादृशी॥
English Translation: With ascetic austerities devoutly serving in the days of the full moon and the new moon Keshava the Divine, the creator of all corporal creatures, the Essence of Brahma and of Yoga, one surely attains to Him. Keshava has been called the Supreme energy and the Grandsire of the worlds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्त्रीधर्मिणी वेपमाना शोणितेन समुक्षिता। एकवस्त्रा विकृष्टास्मि दुःखिता कुरुसंसदि॥
English Translation: The sages, O ruler of men, call Him Hrishikesha or the Lord of the senses, Know Him also to be the supreme Teacher, the Father, and the Preceptor.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राज्ञां मध्ये सभायां तु रजसातिपरिप्लुता। दृष्ट्वा च मांधार्तराष्ट्रा प्राहसन् पापचेतसः॥
English Translation: Regions of undeteriorating blessedness is secured by him on whom Krishna becomes gracious. He that seeks protection from Keshava in seasons of danger, and
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दासीभावेन मां भोक्तुमीषुस्ते मधुसूदन। जीवत्सु पाण्डुपुत्रेषु पञ्चालेषु च वृष्णिषु॥
English Translation: He that always reads of His themes, becomes happy and attended will all blessings. Those who attain to Krishna are never again befouled.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नन्वहं कृष्ण भीष्मस्यधृतराष्ट्रस्य चोभयोः। स्नुषा भवामिधर्मेण साहं दासीकृता बलात्॥
English Translation: That Janardana ever saves those who are overwhelmed with great terror. O descendant of the Bharata race, perfectly aware of this fact, Yudhishthira,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गर्हये पाण्डवांस्त्वेव युधि श्रेष्ठान् महाबलान्। यत्क्लिश्यमानां प्रेक्षन्तेधर्मपत्नी यशस्विनीम्॥
English Translation: With his whole soul, has sought shelter in Keshava, the Supreme God, the Lord of the worlds, the Master of all Yoga and the Lord of this Earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धिग् बलं भीमसेनस्य धिक् पार्थस्य च गाण्डिवम्। यौ मां विप्रकृतां क्षुद्रमर्षयेतां जनार्दन॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said: O Bhimasena, O Panchala princess, O twins, hear. Nothing of creatures perishes. Behold, we are now rangers of forest.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शाश्वतोऽयंधर्मपथः सद्भिराचरितः सदा। यद् भार्यां परिरक्षन्ति भर्तारोऽल्पबला अपि॥
English Translation: Weak and fatigued as we are, we have to help one another and pass over difficult places. Though incapable, yet we must proceed in order to see Dhananjaya (Arjuna).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भार्यायां रक्ष्यमाणायां प्रजा भवति रक्षिता। प्रजायां रक्ष्यमाणायामात्मा भवति रक्षितः॥
English Translation: It (his absence) burns my body as fire does a heap of cotton. I do not see the heroic Dhananjaya at my side.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आत्मा हि जायते तस्यां तस्माज्जाया भवत्युत। भर्ता च भार्यया रक्ष्यः कथं जायान्ममोदरे॥
English Translation: With the thirst for seeing him, I live with my younger brothers in the forest. O hero, the great oppression committed on Yajnaseni (Draupadi) also burns me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नन्विमे शरणं प्राप्तं न त्यजन्ति कदाचन। ते मां शरणमापन्नां नान्वपद्यन्त पाण्डवाः॥
English Translation: O Vrikodara, I do not see the immediate elder of Nakula, the immeasurably powerful Partha (Arjuna) who is invincible and who is the wielder of the strongest bow. For this, O Vrikodara, I am miserable.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पञ्चभिः पतिभिर्जाताः कुमारा मे महौजसः। एतेषामप्यवेक्षार्थं त्रातव्यास्मि जनार्दन॥
English Translation: In order to see that hero, Dhananjaya firm in truthfulness, I have been wandering with you for these five years in various Tirthas, in charming forests and lakes. As I do not still see Vibhatsu (Arjuna)O Vrikodara I am miserable.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रतिविन्ध्यो युधिष्ठिरात् सुतसोमो वृकोदरात्। अर्जुनाच्छ्रुतकीर्तिश्च शतानीकस्तु नाकुलिः॥ कनिष्ठाच्छुतकर्मा च सर्वे सत्यपराक्रमाः। प्रद्युम्नो यादृशः कृष्ण तादृशास्ते महारथाः॥
English Translation: As I do not see the long armed, black, curlyhaired, lion-like (Arjuna), O Vrikodara, I am miserable.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नन्विमेधनुषि श्रेष्ठा अजेया युधि शात्रवैः। किमर्थंधार्तराष्ट्राणां सहन्ते दुर्बलीयसाम्॥
English Translation: As I do not see that foremost of the Kurus, accomplished in arms, skillful in fight and matchless among bowmen, O Vrikodara I am miserable.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अधर्मेण हृतं राज्यं सर्वे दासाः कृतास्तथा। सभायां परिकृष्टाहमेकवस्त्रा रजस्वला॥
English Translation: As I, though very much distressed, do not see that son of Pritha, Dhananjaya who was born under the influence of the constellation Falguni, who ranges amidst enemies like angry Yama at the time of the universal dissolution, who possesses the prowess of an elephant with the juice trickling down its temple, who has lion-like shoulder, who is in no way inferior to Sakra (Indra) in energy and prowess, who is elder of the twins, who rides on white horses, who is immeasurably powerful, invincible and the wielder of the strongest bow, O Vrikodara, I am miserable.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नाधिज्यमपि यच्छक्यं कर्तुमन्येन गाण्डिवम्। अन्यत्रार्जुनभीमाभ्यां त्वया वा मधुसूदन॥
English Translation: He is forgiving, even when he is insulted by the meanest foe. He confers benefit and protection upon the men who follow the righteous path.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धिग् बलं भीमसेनस्य धिक् पार्थस्य च पौरुषम् यत्र दुर्योधनः कृष्ण मुहूर्तमपि जीवति॥
English Translation: To crafty men who want to injure him, even if he be the wielder of thunder (Indra), he is like a virulently poisonous snake.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: य एतानाक्षिपद् राष्ट्रात् सह मात्राविहिंसकान्। अधीयानान् पुरा बालान् व्रतस्थान् मधुसूदन॥
English Translation: The high-souled and Immeasurably powerful Vivatsu shows mercy and extends protection even to an enemy when he is fallen.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भोजने भीमसेनस्य पापः प्राक्षेपयद् विषम्। कालकूटं नवं तीक्ष्णं सम्भूतं लोमहर्षणम्॥
English Translation: He is the refuge of us all and he destroys his enemies in battle. He can gather all wealth and he keeps us all happy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तज्जीर्णमविकारेण सहान्नेन जनार्दन। सशेषत्वान्महाबाहो भीमस्य पुरुषोत्तम॥
English Translation: It was through his prowess I formerly possessed various kinds of precious jewels which Suyodhana (Duryodhana) has now got.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रमाणकोट्यां विश्वस्तं तथा सुप्तं वृकोदरम्। बद्ध्वैनं कृष्ण गङ्गायां प्रक्षिप्य पुरमाव्रजत्॥
English Translation: O hero, O son of Pandu, it was through his prowess I formerly possessed the Assembly Hall adorned with all sorts of jewels and celebrated over the three worlds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदा विबुद्धः कौन्तेयस्तदा संच्छिद्य बन्धनम्। उदतिष्ठन्महाबाहुर्भीमसेनो महाबलः॥
English Translation: He is like Vasudeva in prowess, he is invincible and matchless in battle like Kartavirya. I do not (now) see that Falguni.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आशीविषैः कृष्णसीमसेनपदंशयत्। सर्वेष्वेवाङ्गदेशेषु च ममार च शत्रुहा॥
English Translation: That chastiser of foes (Arjuna) is equal to the invincible and most powerful Sankarsana (Baladeva) and Vasudeva (Krishna).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रतिबुद्धस्तु कौन्तेयः सर्वान् सर्पानपोथयत्। सारथिं चास्य दयितमपहस्तेन जनिवान्॥
English Translation: He is equal to Purandara (Indra) in strength of arms and prowess; he is equal to the wind in speed, to the moon in beauty and to the eternal Death in anger.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुनः सुप्तानुपाधाक्षीद् बालकान् वारणावते। शयानानार्यया साधु को नु तत् कर्तुमर्हति॥
English Translation: O mighty armed one, in order to see that hero, that foremnost of men, we shall all go to the Gandainadana mountain.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यत्रार्या रुदती भीता पाण्डवानिदमब्रवीत्। महद् व्यसनमापन्ना शिखिना परिवारिता॥
English Translation: In which is situated the hermitage Nara and Narayana and on which stands the great Badari tree. It is inhabited by the Yakshas. We shall see that excellent mountain.

Sanskrit Shloka: हा हतास्मि कुतोन्वद्य भवेच्छान्तिरिहानलात्। अनाथा विनशिष्यामि बालकैः पुत्रकैः सह॥
English Translation: Practising great asceticism, we shall go walking to the charming lake of Kubera guarded by the Rakshashas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्र भीमो महाबाहुर्वायुवेगपराक्रमः। आर्यामाश्वासयामास भ्रातूंश्चापि वृकोदरः॥ वैनतेयो यथा पक्षी गरुत्मान् पततां वरः। तथैवाभिपतिष्यामि भयं वो नेह विद्यते॥
English Translation: O Vrikodara, no vehicle can go to that place. O descendant of Bharata, no cruel, avaricious and hot-tempered man can go there.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आर्यामथेन वामेन राजानं दक्षिणेन च। अंसयोश्च यमौ कृत्वा पृष्ठे बीभत्सुमेव च॥ सहसोत्पत्य वेगेन सर्वानादाय वीर्यवान्। भ्रातृनार्यां च बलवान् मोक्षयामास पावकात्॥
English Translation: O Bhima, in order to see Arjuna, we shall all go there guiding on our swords and wielding our bows. We shall be accompanied by Brahmanas of strict vows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते रात्रौ प्रस्थिताः सर्वे सह मात्रा यशस्विनः। अभ्यगच्छन्महारण्ये हिडिम्बवनमन्तिकात्॥
English Translation: O son of Pritha, the sinful men meet there flies, gad-flies, mosquitoes, tigers, lions and reptiles, but pure-souled men do not meet them.

Sanskrit Shloka: श्रान्ताः प्रसुप्तास्तत्रेमे मात्रा सह सुदुःखिताः। सुप्तांश्चैनानभ्यगच्छद्धिडिम्बा नाम राक्षसी॥
English Translation: Therefore with regulated diet and with subdued passions, we to the Gandamadana with the desire of seeing Dhananjaya. shall go

Sanskrit Shloka: सा दृष्ट्वा पाण्डवांस्तत्र सुप्तान् मात्रा सह क्षितौ हृच्छयेनाभिभूतात्मा भीमसेनमकामयत्॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said : O foremost of celestials Rishis, I do not think that I am not endued with some merit. But I am still afflicted with so much sorrow that (I believe) there is no other king like me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीमस्य पादौ कृत्वा तु स्व उत्सङ्गे ततोऽबला। पर्यमर्दत् संहृष्टा कल्याणी मृदुपाणिना॥
English Translation: O Lomasha, I think my enemies have no merit and no virtuous tendencies. Why then do they proper in this world?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तामबुध्यदमेयात्मा बलवान् सत्यविक्रमः। पर्यपृच्छत तां भीमः किमिहेच्छस्यनिन्दिते॥
English Translation: Lomasha said : O king, O Partha, never grieve that sinful men should prosper in consequence of the sins they commit.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्ता तु भीमेन राक्षसी कामरूपिणी। भीमसेनं महात्मानमाह चैवमनिन्दित॥
English Translation: A man may be seen to prosper by his sins, obtain good fruits or vanquish his enemies, but he is finally destroyed to the root.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पलायध्वमितः क्षिप्रं मम भ्रातैष वीर्यवान्। आगमिष्यति वो हन्तुं तस्माद् गच्छत मा चिरम्॥
English Translation: O ruler of earth, I have seen many Daityas and Danavas prosper by sin, but I have also seen that destruction has again ever taken them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ भीमोऽभ्युवाचैनां साभिमानमिदं वचः। नोद्धिजेयमहं तस्मानिहनिष्येऽहपागतम्॥
English Translation: O lord, I have seen all this formerly in the Deva Yuga. The celestials practised virtue whereas the Asuras practised sin.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तयोः श्रुत्वा तु संजल्पमागच्छद् राक्षसाधमः। भीमरूपो महानादान् विसृजन् भीमदर्शनः॥
English Translation: O descendant of Bharata, the celestials visited the Tirthas whereas the Asuras did not visit them. Those sinful ones were first filled with pride.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राक्षस उवाच केन सार्धं कथयसि आनयैनं ममान्तिकम्। हिडिम्बे भक्षयिष्यामो न चिरं कर्तुमर्हसि॥
English Translation: Pride begot vanity and vanity begot wealth. From wealth arose every king of evil propensity and from evil propensities arose shamelessness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सा कृपासंगृहीतेन हृदयेन मनस्विनी। नैनमैच्छत् तदाख्यातुमनुक्रोशादनिन्दिता॥
English Translation: From shamelessness good behaviour disappeared from among them. From their shamelessness, from their evil propensities, from their want of good conduct and virtuous vows, forgiveness, propensity and morality all forsook them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स नादान् विनदन् घोरान् राक्षस: पुरुषादकः। अभ्यद्रवत वेगेन भीमसेनं तदा किल॥
English Translation: O king, Lakshmi (the goddess of prosperity) then sought the celestials while a Lakshmi (goddess of adversity) sought the Asuras. When they were possessed by adversity they became senseless out of pride.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमभिदुत्त्य संक्रुद्धो वेगेन महता बली। अगृहणात् पाणिना पाणिं भीमसेनस्य राक्षसः॥ इन्द्राशनिसमस्पर्श वज्र संहननं दृढम्। संहत्य भीमसेनाय व्याक्षिपत् सहसा करम्॥
English Translation: Then Kali possessed the Daityas and the Danavas. Being thus possessed by adversity, the Danavas were destroyed by Kali.

Sanskrit Shloka: गृहीतं पाणिना पाणि भीमसेनस्य रक्षसा। नामृष्यत महाबाहुस्तत्राक्रुध्यद् वृकोदरः॥
English Translation: O son of Kunti, as they were filled with pride they became destitute of rites and sacrifices, devoid of reason, overwhelmed with vanity and they soon met with their destruction.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदाऽऽसीत् तुमुलं युद्धं भीमसेनहिडिम्बयोः। सर्वास्त्रविदुषो?रं वृत्रवासवयोरिव॥
English Translation: Covered with infamy the Daityas were soon destroyed. O son of Pandu, the celestials, however, who were all of virtuous character, going to the seas, rivers and lakes and other sacred places, cleansed themselves of all their sins by means of asceticism and sacrifices, by gifts and blessings; and O Pandava, they obtained great prosperity. Because they thus abandoned all evil deeds and practised all good deeds,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विक्रीड्य सुचिरं भीमो राक्षसेन सहानघ। निजघान महावीर्यस्तं तदा निर्बलं बली॥
English Translation: And visited all the Tirthas, they obtained great good fortune. O king of kings, you will too therefore, bathing with your younger brothers in the Tirthas, obtain again great good fortune. This is the eternal road.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हत्वा हिडिम्बं भीमोऽथ प्रस्थितो भ्रातृभिः सह। हिडिम्बामग्रतः कृत्वा यस्यां जातो घटोत्कचः॥
English Translation: As kings, Nriga, Shibi, Ushinara, Bhagiratha, Vasumana, Gaya, Puru and Pururava, by always practising austerities and touching the sacred waters and visiting the Tirthas and seeing the illustrious holy men, O king, obtained fame, virtue and great wealth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः सम्प्राद्रवन् सर्वे सह मात्रा परंतपाः। एकचक्रामभिमुखाः संवृता ब्राह्मणव्रजैः॥
English Translation: So will you obtain by acquiring exceedingly great prosperity. As Ikshvaku with his sons, friends and followers, Muchukunda, Mandhata and king Maruta, as the celestials through their power of asceticism, as the celestials Rishis also have obtained fame, so will you also obtain great fame. The sons of Dhritarashtra, enslaved as they are by sin and ignorance, will certainly be destroyed like Daityas. as
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रस्थाने व्यास एषां च मन्त्री प्रियहिते रतः। ततोऽगच्छन्नेकचक्रां पाण्डवाः संशितव्रताः॥
English Translation: Bhishma said You have been told what the duties of a householders are as ordained by the wise. Listen now, O Yudhisthira, to the next class of duties.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्राप्यासादयामासुर्बकं नाम महाबलम्। पुरुषादं प्रतिभयं हिडिम्बेनैव सम्मितम्॥
English Translation: Gradually leading off the domestic mode, one should enter the third mode which is good. It is the mode which is followed by persons who living with their wives pain themselves by means of austerities. It is the mode followed by those who live in forest as hermits.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं चापि विनिहत्योचं भीमः प्रहरतां वरः। सहितो भ्रातृभिः सर्दुपदस्य पुरं ययौ॥
English Translation: Blessed be you, O son, listen to the duties observed by those who follow this mode of life in which are set forth the practices of all men and all modes of life. Listen, indeed, to the duties of those who live in sacred spots and who have adopted this mode after proper consideration.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: लब्धाहमपि तत्रैव वसता सव्यसाचिना। यथा त्वया जिता कृष्ण रुक्मिणी भीष्मकात्मजा।११५॥
English Translation: Vyasa said When the householder sees his body wrinkled and hair white on his head, and children of his children, he should then retire into the forest.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं सुयुद्धे पार्थेन जिताहं मधुसूदन। स्वयंवरे महत् कर्म कृत्वा न सुकरं परैः॥
English Translation: He should pass the third portion of his life as Vanaprastha. He should worship those sacred fires to which he had attended while a householder. Desirous of performing sacrifices, he should also worship the gods.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं क्लेशैः सुबहुभिः क्लिश्यमाना सुदुःखिता। निवसाम्यार्यया हीना कृष्णधौम्यपुरःसरा॥
English Translation: Observing vows and being sparing in diet, he should eat only once, during the sixth part of the day. He should be always careful. Adoring his fires, he should keep some kine, serving them dutifully. He should perform all the rituals of a sacrifice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त इमे सिंहविक्रान्ता वीर्येणाभ्यधिकाः परैः। विहीनैः परिक्लिश्यन्ती समुपैक्षन्त म कथम्॥
English Translation: He should live upon rice and wheat which grows indigenously, and upon other sorts of grains, growing wildly. He should eat the remnant after feeding guests. In the third mode of life, he should make offerings of clarified butter in the five celebrated Sacrifices.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतादृशानि दुःखानि सहन्ती दुर्बलीयसाम्। दीर्घकालं प्रदीप्तास्मि पापानां पापकर्मणाम्॥
English Translation: Four courses of conduct have been laid down for the Vanaprastha mode of life. Some gather only what is necessary for the day. Some store up things for a month.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कुले महति जातास्मि दिव्येन विधिना किला पाण्डवानां प्रिया भार्या स्नुषा पाण्डोर्महात्मनः॥
English Translation: Some collect grain and other necessaries sufficient to last for twelve years. Hermits may act thus for adoring guests and performning sacrifices.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कचग्रहमनुप्राप्ता सास्मि कृष्ण वरा सती। पञ्चानां पाण्डुपुत्राणां प्रेक्षतां मधुसूदन॥
English Translation: They should during the rains, expose themselves to rain and go to water during the autumn. In summer, they should sit in the midst of four fires with the sun burning overhead. Throughout the year, however, they should be sparing in deit.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्युक्त्वा प्रारुदत् कृष्णा मुखं प्रच्छाद्य पाणिना। पद्मकोशप्रकाशेन मृदुना मृदुभाषिणी॥
English Translation: They should sit and sleep on the naked earth. They stand on only their toes. They should be satisfied with the bare earth and with small mats of grass. They perform their ablutions morning, noon, and evening.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्तनावपतितौ पीनौ सुजातौ शुभलक्षणौ। अभ्यवर्षत पाञ्चाली दुःखजैरश्रुबिन्दुभिः॥
English Translation: Some amongst them use only their teeth for cleaning grain. Others use only stones for the same, Some amongst them drink, only during the light fortnight, boiled very lightly, gruel of wheat (or other, grain).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चक्षुषी परिमार्जन्ती निःश्वसन्ती पुनः पुनः। बाष्पपूर्णेन कण्ठेन क्रुद्धा वचनमब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: Others drink similar gruel only during the dark fortnight. Some eat what only comes of itself. Some practising rigid vows, live upon only roots, some upon only fruits, some upon only flowers, duly following the method followed by the Vaikhanashas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नैव मे पतयः सन्ति न पुत्रा न च बान्धवाः। न भ्रातरो न च पिता नैव त्वं मधुसूदन॥
English Translation: These and various other observances are practised by those wise and pious men. The fourth mode of life is based upon the Upanishads. The duties prescribed for it may be observed in all the modes of life equally. Differing from the others this mode comes afler domestic and forest life.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ये मां विप्रकृतां क्षुद्रसपेक्षध्वं विशोकवत्। न च मे शाम्यते दुःखं कर्णो यत् प्राहसत् तदा।
English Translation: In this very cycle, O son, many learned Brahmanas knowing the truths of all things, have been known to observe this mode. Agastya, the seven Rishis Madhuchchhandas, Aghamarshana, Sankriti, Sudivatandi who lived with her soever he pleased and was content to take what came (without ever secking for anything), Ahovirya, Kavya, Tandya, the learned medhatithi, the highly energetic Karnanirvaka, and Shunyapala who had worked hard (for acquiring Yoga powel), were the authors of this course of duties, and themselves practising them, have all gone to heaven.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चतुर्भिः कारणैः कृष्ण त्वया रक्ष्यास्मि नित्यशः। सम्बन्धाद् गौरवात् सख्यात् प्रभुत्वेनैव केशव॥
English Translation: Many great Rishis, O son, who had the power to see immediately the fruits of their ascetic merit, those numberless ascetics who pass by the appellation of Yayavaras, many Rishis of very austere penances and endued with accurate knowledge about distinctions of duty, and many other Brahınanas too numerous to mention, adopted the forest mode of life. The Vaikhanasas, the Valikhilyas, the Saikatas, all of whom were given to austere penances, who were firm in virtue, who had controlled their senses, and who used to see the fruits of their penances immediately, adopted this mode of life and finally went to heaven.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच अथ तामब्रवीत् कृष्णस्तस्मिन् वीरसमागमे।
English Translation: Freed from fear and not counted with the stars and planets, these have become visible in the sky as luminaries. When the fourth or last part of life is got at, and when one is weakened by decrepitude and possessed by disease, one should leave off the forest mode of life. Performing a sacrifice capable of being completed in a single day and in which the sacrificial fee should be everything he has, he should himself perforin his own funeral rite. Withdrawn from every other object, he should devote himself to his own self, taking pleasure in himself, and depending also on his own self. He should put up all his sacrificial fires (thenceforth) upon his ownself, and sever all sorts of bonds and attachments.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वासुदेव उवाच रोदिष्यन्ति स्त्रियो ह्येव येषां क्रुद्धासि भाविनि। बीभत्सुशरसंच्छन्नाञ्छोणितौघपरिप्लुतान्॥ निहतान् वल्लभान् वीक्ष्य शयानान् वसुधातले। यत् समर्थं पाण्डवानां तत् करिष्यामि मा शुचः।।
English Translation: He should always celebrate such sacrifices and rites as are completed in a single day. When, however, from performance of the (ordinary) sacrifices of sacrificers, the Sacrifice in Self begins, then for liberation he should sacrifice his own self in the three fires. Without linding fault with his food he should take five or six mouthfuls, offering them duly to the five vital airs uttering Mantras of the Yajurveda.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सत्यं ते प्रतिजानामि राज्ञां राज्ञी भविष्यसि। पतेद् द्यौर्हिमवाञ्छीर्येत् पृथिवी शकलीभवेत्॥ शुष्येत् तोयनिधिः कृष्णे न मे मोघं वचो भवेत्। तच्छ्रुत्वा द्रौपदी वाक्यं प्रतिवाक्यमथाच्युतात्॥ साचीकृतमवेक्षत् सा पाञ्चाली मध्यमं पतिम्। आबभाषे महाराज द्रौपदीमर्जुनस्तदा॥
English Translation: Practising austerities while living like a forest recluse, one should shave off and having purified himself by acts, pass into the fourth and the last holy mode of life.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मा रोदीः शुभताम्राक्षि यदाह मधुसूदनः। तथा तद् भविता देवि नान्यथा वरवर्णिनी॥
English Translation: That twice-born one who enters the fourth mode of life, giving pledges of assurance to all creatures, succeeds in acquiring many effulgent regions hereafter and ultimately attains to the Infinite.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृष्टद्युम्न उवाच अहं द्रोणं हनिष्यामि शिखण्डी तु पितामहम्। दुर्योधनं भीमसेनः कर्णं हन्ताधनंजयः॥ रामकृष्णौ व्यपाश्रित्य अजेयाः स्म रणे स्वसः। अपि वृत्रहणा युद्धे किं पुनधृतराष्ट्रजे॥
English Translation: Of excellent disposition and conduct, with sins all purged off the person who is conversant with his own self never wished to perform any act for either this or the other world. Shorn of anger, error, anxiety and without friendship, such a person live in this world like one having nothing to do with it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच इत्युक्तेऽभिमुखा वीरा वासुदेवमुपास्थिताः। तेषां मध्ये महाबाहुः केशवो वाक्यमब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: One in the (observance of Sannyasa) should not be unwilling in satisfying the duties included in Yama and those also that walk behind them. Such a person should live energetically according to the ordinances laid down his own mode, and leave off Vedic study and the sacred thread which marks his birth. Given to righteousness and having his senses under complete control, such a person endued with knowledge of self, attains forsooth, to the end for which he tries.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भरद्वाज उवाच त एते धातवः पञ्च ब्रह्मा यानसृजत् पुरा। आवृता यैरिमे लोका महाभूताभिसंज्ञिताः॥ यदासृजत सहस्राणि भूतानां स महामतिः। पञ्चानामेव भूतत्वं कथं समुपपद्यते॥
English Translation: After the third is the fourth mode of life. It is very superior, and has numberless high virtues. In merit it reigns supreme over the three other modes of life. It is said to occupy the very highest place. Listen to me as I describe the duties belonging to that mode which is very supreme and which is the high refuge of all.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भृगुरुवाच अमितानां महाशब्दो यान्ति भूतानि सम्भवम्। ततस्तेषां महाभूतशब्दोऽयमुपपद्यते॥
English Translation: Kunti said-What you say, O mighty-armed son of Pandu, is indeed, true! O kings, formerly, when you were all dispirited, indeed, I cxcited you all.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चेष्टा वायुः खमाकाशमूष्माग्निः सलिलं द्रवः। पृथिवी चात्र संघातः शरीरं पाञ्चभौतिकम्॥
English Translation: Seeing that your kingdom was taken away from you by a match at dice, seeing that you all fell from happiness, seeing that you were governed over by kinsmen, I instilled courage and high thoughts into your minds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्येतैः पञ्चमिर्भूतैर्युक्तं स्थावरजङ्गमम्। श्रोत्रं घ्राणं रसः स्पर्शो दृष्टिश्चेन्द्रियसंज्ञिताः॥
English Translation: O foremost of men, I encouraged you so that the sons of Pandu might not be lost, so that their fame might not be lost.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भरद्वाज उवाच पञ्चभिर्यदि भूतैस्तु युक्ताः स्थावरजङ्गमाः। स्थावराणां न दृश्यन्ते शरीरे पञ्च धातवः॥
English Translation: You are all equal to Indra. Your prowess resembles that of the very celestials. I acted thus so that you might not live, depending upon others.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनूष्मणामचेष्टानां घनानां चैव तत्त्वतः। वृक्षाणां नोपलभ्यन्ते शरीरे पञ्च धातवः॥
English Translation: I instilled courage into your hearts so that you who are the foremost of all righteous persons, who are equal to Vasava, might not again go into the forest and live in misery.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न शृण्वन्ति न पश्यन्ति न गन्धरसवेदिनः। न च स्पर्श विजानन्ति ते कथं पाञ्चभौतिकाः॥
English Translation: I instilled courage into your hearts so that this Bhima who has the strength of ten thousand elephants and whose prowess and manliness are widely known, might not sink into insignificance and ruin.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अद्रवत्वादनग्नित्वादभूमित्वादवायुतः। आकाशस्याप्रमेयत्वाद् वृक्षाणां नास्ति भौतिकम्॥
English Translation: I instilled courage into your hearts so that this Vijaya, who was born after Bhimasena, and who is equal to Vasava himself, might not be cheerless.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भृगुरुवाच घनानामपि वृक्षाणामाकाशोऽस्ति न संशयः। तेषां पुष्पफलव्यक्तिर्नित्यं समुपपद्यते॥
English Translation: I instilled courage into your hearts so that Nakula and Sahadeva, who are always devoted to their elders, may not be weakened and rendered cheerless by hunger.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उष्मतो म्लायते पण त्वक् फलं पुष्पमेव च। म्लायते शीर्यते चापि स्पर्शस्तेनात्र विद्यते॥
English Translation: I acted thus in order that this lady of welldeveloped forms and of large eyes might not suffer the wrongs inflicted on her in the public hall without being avenged.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वाय्वग्न्यशनिनिर्घोषैः फलं पुष्पं विशीर्यते। श्रोत्रेण गृह्यते शब्दस्तस्माच्छृण्वन्ति पादपाः॥
English Translation: Before you all, O Bhima, trembling all over like a plantain trce during her catamenial period, and after she had been won at dicc, Dushasana, through folly, dragged her as if she were a slave. I knew all this, Indeed, the family of Pandu had been subjugated (by focs).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वल्ली वेश्यते वृक्षं सर्वतश्चैव गच्छति। न ह्यदृष्टेश्च मार्गोऽस्ति तस्मात् पश्यन्ति पादपाः॥
English Translation: The Kurus, viz., my father-in-law and others, were cheerless when she, desirous of a protector, bewailed like a she-osprey.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुण्यापुण्यैस्तथा गन्धैर्दू पैश्च विविधैरपि। अरोगाः पुष्पिता: सन्ति तस्माज्जिघ्रन्ति पादपाः॥
English Translation: When she was dragged by her fair locks by the sinful Dushasana without little intelligence, I lost my senses, O king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पादैः सलिलपानाच्च व्याधीनां चापि दर्शनात्। व्याधिप्रतिक्रियत्वाच्च विद्यते रसनं दुमे॥
English Translation: Know, that for increasing your energy, I instilled that courage into your hearts by reciting the words of Vidula, O my sons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वक्त्रेणोत्पलनालेन यथोर्ध्वं जलमाददेत्। तथा पवनसंयुक्तः पादैः पिबति पादपः॥
English Translation: I instilled courage into your hearts, O my sons, so that the family of Pandu, represented by my children, might not be lost.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुखदुःखयोश्च ग्रहणाच्छिन्नस्य च विरोहणात्। जीवं पश्यामि वृक्षाणामचैतन्यं न विद्यते॥
English Translation: The sons and grandsons of that person who brings a family to infamy never succeed in acquiring the regions of the righteous. Indeed, the ancestors of the Kaurava race, were in danger of losing those happy regions which had become theirs.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेन तज्जलमादत्तं जरयत्यग्निमारुतौ। आहारपरिणामाच्च स्नेहो वृद्धिश्च जायते॥
English Translation: As for myself, O my sons, I have, before this, enjoyed the grcat fruits of that sovereignty which my husband had won. I have made large gifts. I have duly drunk the Soma-juice in sacrifice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जङ्गमानां च सर्वेषां शरीरे पञ्च धातवः। प्रत्येकशः प्रभिद्यन्ते यैः शरीरं विचेष्टते॥
English Translation: It was not for my own sake that I had urged Vasudeva with the stirring words of Vidula. It was for your sake that I had asked you to follow that advice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वद् च मांसं तथास्थीनि मज्जा स्नायुश्च पञ्चमम्। इत्येतदिह संघातं शरीरे पृथिवीमयम्॥
English Translation: O my sons, I do not wish for the fruits of that sovereignty which has been acquired by my children. O you of great power, I wish to attain, by my penances, to those happy regions which have been acquired by my husband.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेजो ह्यग्निस्तथा क्रोधश्चक्षुरूष्मा तथैव च। अग्निर्जस्यते यश्च पञ्चाग्नेयाः शरीरिणः॥
English Translation: By rendering obedient service to my fatherin-law and mother-in-law both of whom with to take up their residence in the forest, and by penances, I wish, O Yudhishthira, to exhaust my body.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रोत्रं घ्राणं तथाऽऽस्यं च हृदयं कोष्ठमेव च। आकाशात् प्राणिनामेते शरीरे पञ्च धातवः॥
English Translation: Do you cease to follow me, O foremost one of Kuru's race, along with Bhima and others. Let your understanding be always devoted to virtue. Let your mind be always great.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्लेष्मा पित्तमथ स्वेदो वसा शोणितमेव च। इत्यापः पञ्चधा देहे भवन्ति प्राणिनां सदा॥
English Translation: Shalya said The god, being thus spoken to, thus addressed Sachi in reply-'This is not the time for (showing) strength, Nahusha is stronger.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्राणात् प्रणीयते प्राणी व्यानाद् व्यायच्छतेतथा। गच्छत्यपानोऽधश्चैव समानो हृद्यवस्थितः॥
English Translation: He has grown up to his present position by the virtue of the offerings made him by the Rishis. In this instance, I shall prescribe a politic course and it is proper that it should be followed by you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उदानादुच्छ्वसिति च प्रतिभेदाच्च भाषते। इत्येते वायवः पञ्च चेश्यन्तीह देहिनम्॥
English Translation: It should be done by you with secrecy and on no account should you give it out. O you of slender waist, go to Nahusha and speak thus to him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भूमेर्गन्धगुणान् वेत्ति रसं चाभ्यः शरीरवान्। ज्योतिषा चक्षुषा रूपं स्पर्श वेत्ति च वाहिना॥
English Translation: O lord of the universe, come near me riding a conveyance suitable for the gods and borne by Rishis. By thus showing yourself attached to me, shall I be pleased with you speak thus to him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गन्धः स्पृशो रसो रूपं शब्दश्चात्र गुणाः स्मृताः। तस्य गन्धस्य वक्ष्यामि विस्तराभिहितान् गुणान्॥
English Translation: Being thus spoken to by the king of the gods his queen of lotus-like eyes, replied “Be it so" and went to Nahusha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इष्टश्चानिष्टगन्धश्च मधुरः कटुरेव च। निर्हारी संहतः स्निग्धो रूक्षो विशद एव च॥
English Translation: Nahusha surprised at seeing her, spoke these words-Welcome to you, O you of beautiful hips, what shall I do, O you of lovely smiles?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं नवविधो ज्ञेयः पार्थिवे गन्धविस्तरः। ज्योतिः पश्यति चक्षुर्त्या स्पर्श वेत्ति च वायुना॥
English Translation: Accept me devoted to you; O blessed one, what do you wish, O maiden of independent spirit? O blessed one, O you of slender waist.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शब्दः स्पर्शश्च रूपं च रसञ्चापि गुणा: स्मृताः। रसज्ञानं तु वक्ष्यामि तन्मे निगदतः शृण॥
English Translation: You need not be shy; O you of slender waist, have confidence in me. I swear by truth, O goddess, I shall do your bidding.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रसो बहुविधः प्रोक्त ऋषिभिः प्रथितात्मभिः। मधुरो लवणास्तिक्तः कषायोऽम्लः कटुस्तथा॥
English Translation: The queen of Indra said O lord of the world, I only want time-the favour that has already been accorded to me. After that you shall become my husband, O lord of the gods.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एष पड्विधविस्तारो रसो वारिमयः स्मृतः। शब्दः स्पर्शश्च रूपं च त्रिगुणं ज्योतिरुच्यते॥
English Translation: The subject that is in my mind is this listen, O lord of the gods; I shall speak it to you, O king, fulfill my desire. The boon, that I demand of you, has connection with your love.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ज्योतिः पश्यति रूपाणि रूपं च बहुधा स्मृतम्। ह्रस्वो दीर्घस्तथा स्थूलश्चतुरस्रोऽनृवृत्तवान्॥ शुक्ल: कृष्णस्तथा रक्तः पीतो नीलारुणस्तथा। कठिनश्चिक्कणः श्लक्ष्ण: पिच्छिलो मृदुदारुणः॥
English Translation: Indra had for his conveyance, horses, elephants and a car. I wish that you, O lord of the gods should have a conveyance, the like of which was never seen before, which was never owned by Vishnu, nor by Rudra, nor by the Asuras and the Rakshasas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं पोडशविस्तारो ज्योतीरूपगुणः स्मृतः। शब्दस्पर्शी च विज्ञेयौ द्विगुणो वायुरित्युत॥ वायव्यस्तु गुणः स्पर्श: स्पर्शश्च बहुधा स्मृतः। उष्णः शीत: सुखो दुःखः स्निग्धो विशद एव च॥
English Translation: O Lord, to see yourself being borne by the Rishis having good attributes, united together in a palankin, is my wish, oking.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथा खरो मृदु रूक्षो लघुर्गुरुतरोऽपि च। एवं द्वादशधा स्पर्शो वायव्यो गुण उच्यते॥
English Translation: You should not be (merely) equal to the Asuras or the gods. By your own strength do you absorb that of all beings the moment you set your eyes on them. No one can stand face to face with you, O you powerful being.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्रैकगुणमाकाशं शब्द इत्येव तत्स्मृतम्। तस्य शब्दस्य वक्ष्यामि विस्तरं विविधात्मकम्॥
English Translation: Shalya said Nahusha, being thus spoken to became well pleased and the king of the gods said these words to that blameless one.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: षड्ज ऋषभगान्धारौ मध्यमो धैवतस्तथा। पञ्चमश्चापि विज्ञेयस्तथा चापि निषादवान्॥
English Translation: Nahusha said 0 you of bright complexion, the conveyance spoken of by you has never before been in existence. I have taken a strong fancy to it O goddess. I am at your disposal, O lovely faced one.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एष सप्तविधः प्रोक्तो गुण आकाशसम्भवः। ऐश्वर्येण तु सर्वत्र स्थितोऽपि पटहादिषु॥
English Translation: The one who makes the Rishis his bearers cannot be of little strength. I am a devotee, strong and lord of what has been, what is to be and what is.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मृदङ्गभेरीशङ्खानां स्तनयित्नो रथस्य च। यः कश्चिच्छ्रयते शब्दः प्राणिनोऽप्राणिनोऽपि वा। एतेषामेव सर्वेषां विषये सम्प्रकीर्तितः॥
English Translation: At my being angry the world will be annihilated; everything depends on me. The gods, the Danavas and the Gandharvas, the Kinnaras, the serpents and the Rakashasas, not all of these, not all the world even can stand against me when I am angry. Whoever I see by my eyes, his strength do I absorb.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं बहुविधाकारः शब्द आकाशसम्भवः। आकाशजं शब्दमाहुरेभिर्वायुगुणैः सह॥ अव्याहतैश्चेतयते न वेत्ति विषमस्थितैः। आप्याय्यन्ते च ते नित्यं धातवस्तैस्तु धातुभिः॥
English Translation: Therefore O goddess, shall I do your bidding, there is no doubt about it. Seven Rishis shall bear me, Brahmarshis all see, my powers and influence, having thus said to that goddess.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आपोऽग्निर्मारुतश्चैव नित्यं जाग्रति देहिषु। मूलमेते शरीरस्य व्याप्य प्राणानिह स्थिताः॥
English Translation: Shalya said O king! O you of bright complexion and having dismissed that lovely face one, he yoked, to car, Rishis who used to observe the rules of their class. The habits of his life being unworthy of a Brahmana, having come to the possession of power, vain of his strength, willful and of a vicious nature, he made the Rishis carry him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच अथार्जुन उवाचेदमधिक्षिप्त इवाक्षमी। अभिनीततरं वाक्यं दृढवादपराक्रमः॥ दर्शयन्नैन्द्रिरात्मानमुग्रमुग्रपराक्रमः। स्पयमानो महातेजाः सृक्किणी परिसंलिहन्॥
English Translation: Being dismissed by Nahusha, she said to Brihaspati-“But little remains to fulfill in its entirety the boon granted by Nahusha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्जुन उवाच अहो दुःखमहो कृच्छ्रमहो वैक्लव्यमुत्तमम्। यत् कृत्वामानुषं कर्म त्यजेथाः श्रियमुत्तमाम्॥
English Translation: Be quick in hunting out Indra and do me who am devoted to you, a favour and the god Brihaspati said to her-"Be it so."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शत्रून् हत्वा महीं लब्ध्वा स्वधर्मेणोपपादिताम्। एवंविधं कथं सर्वं त्यजेथा बुद्धिलाघवात्॥
English Translation: The evil minded Nahusha need not be feared by you. He will not exist till eternity; indeed he is already gone.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क्लीबस्य हि कुतो राज्यं दीर्घसूत्रस्य वा पुनः। किमर्थं च महीपालानवधीः क्रोधमूर्छितः॥
English Translation: He is regardless of virtue so to say, having employed the great Rishis as his bearer, O lovely lady; and I shall perform sacrifices for the destruction of this evil minded one. I shall approach Shakra. You need not have any fears, I wish you well.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यो ह्याजिजीविषेद् भैक्ष्यं कर्मणा नैव कस्यचित्। समारम्भान् बुभूषेत हतस्वस्तिरकिंचनः। सर्वलोकेषु विख्यातो न पुत्रपशुसंहितः॥
English Translation: Then having lighted up a fire he offered the best offerings in the prescribed form. Brihaspati of great strength, in order to get the gods, having made offerings to Agni (the God of fire) said to him-Oking search out Shakra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कापाली नृप पापिष्ठां वृत्तिमासाद्य जीवतः। संत्यज्य राज्यमृद्धं ते लोकोऽयं किं वदिष्यति॥
English Translation: From that place, the god (of fire) the consumer of offerings having himself assumed the wonderful form of a female vanished from sight.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वारम्भान् समुत्सृज्य हतस्वस्तिरकिंचनः। कस्मादाशंससे भक्ष्यं कर्तुं प्राकृतवत् प्रभो॥
English Translation: Having searched in all countries and provinces, mountains and forest, the earth and the sky, with the speed of the mind, he in a moment came back to Brihaspati.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अस्मिन् राजकुले जातो जित्वा कृत्स्नां वसुंधराम्। धर्मार्थावखिलौ हित्वा वनं मौढ्यात् प्रतिष्ठसे॥
English Translation: The god of fire said O Brihaspati, nowhere, in this world do I see the king of the gods. The waters (alone) remain (to be searched). I have never been able to enter the waters.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदीमानि हवींषीह विमथिष्यन्त्यसाधवः। भवता विप्रहीणानि प्राप्तं त्वामेव किल्बिषम्॥
English Translation: I have no ingress there O Brahmana, what else shall I do for you. The preceptor of the gods said to him-"O you of great luster, enter the waters."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आकिंचन्यं मुनीनां च इति वै नहुघोऽब्रवीत्। कृत्वा नृशंसं ह्यधने धिगस्त्वधनतामिह॥
English Translation: The god of fire said I cannot enter the water there I am destroyed. I throw myself under your protection. O you of great luster, I wish you well.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अश्वस्तनमृषीणां हि विद्यते वेद तद् भवान्। यं त्विमं धर्ममित्याहुर्धनादेष प्रवर्तते॥
English Translation: From the waters rose fire, from the Brahmana, the Kshatriya and from stone, the iron. Its strength penetrates everywhere; only in its birth-place is it powerless.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धर्मं संहरते तस्य धनं हरति यस्य सः। ह्रियमाणे धने राजन् वयं कस्य क्षमेमहि॥
English Translation: Janamejaya said : Krishna being thus abducted the Pandavas experienced very great sorrow. What did they next do after having rescued her?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभिशस्तं प्रपश्यन्ति दरिद्रं पावतः स्थितम्। दरिद्रं पातकं लोके न तच्छंसितुमर्हति॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Having felt great distress for the abduction of Krishna, the undeteriorating king Yudhishthira together with his brothers leaving Kamayaka returned to the charming and delightful Dvaiytvana, full of fruits and roots of delicious taste and abounding in various picturesque trees.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पतितः शोच्यते राजन् निर्धनश्चापि शोच्यते। विशेष नाधिगच्छामि पतितस्याधनस्य च॥
English Translation: And all the Pandavas together with their wife Krishna began to dwell there observant of vows, living on fruits and partaking of frugal fares.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्थेभ्यो हि विवृद्धेभ्यः सम्भृतेभ्यस्ततस्ततः। क्रियाः सर्वाः प्रवर्तन्ते पर्वतेभ्य इवापगा:॥
English Translation: And while king Yudhishthira, the son of Kunti, Bhimasena, Arjuna and the other two Pandavas, the sons of Madri, were dwelling in Dvaiytvana, those powerful and virtuous observers of vows, those tormentors of foes, experienced, for the sake of a Brahmana a great trouble which resulted in their (ultimate) happiness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्थाद् धर्मश्च कामश्च स्वर्गश्चैव नराधिप। प्राणयात्रापि लोकस्य विना ह्यर्थं न सिद्ध्यति॥
English Translation: I will now tell you of the trouble, which those most exalted of the Kurus went through and which led to their ultimate happiness. Listen to it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्थेन हि विहीनस्य पुरुषस्याल्पमेधसः। विच्छिद्यन्ते क्रियाः सर्वा ग्रीष्मे कुसरितो यथा।॥
English Translation: Once, the two sticks for making fire together with a churning rod of an ascetic Brahmana stuck fast to the horns of a deer as it was butting about.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यस्यार्थास्तस्य मित्राणि यस्यार्थास्तस्य बान्धवाः। यस्यार्थाः स पुमॉल्लोके यस्यार्थाः स च पण्डितः।।
English Translation: And O monarch, taking those (articles) away that great deer of exceeding fleetness, with great leaps very soon distanced itself (a great way) from the hermitage.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अधनेनार्थकामेन नार्थः शक्यो विधित्सितुम्। अर्थरर्था निबध्यन्ते गजैरिव महागजाः॥
English Translation: O best of the Kurus, beholding those (articles) carried away, that Brahmana desirous of preserving his Agnihotra speedily came there,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धर्मः कामश्च स्वर्गश्च हर्षः क्रोधः श्रुतं दमः। अर्थादेतानि सर्वाणि प्रवर्तन्ते नराधिप।॥
English Translation: Where Ajatashatru together with his brothers was seated in the forest. And the Brahmana quickly approaching spoke (thus) sorrowfully.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धनात् कुलं प्रभवति धनाद् धर्म प्रवर्धते। नाधनस्यास्त्ययं लोको न परः पुरुषोत्तम॥
English Translation: My fire-sticks together with the churning rod placed against a large tree were stuck to the horns of a deer as it was butting about.
And, O king, that great deer endued with great speed, soon distanced itself (a great way) from the hermitage with long leaps.
And following the foot-prints of that great deer, O king, O Pandavas, bring those (articles) to me so that my Agnihotra may not be stopped.”
Hearing the words of the Brahmana, Yudhishthira, the son of Kunti, became very sorry and taking his bow sallied out together with his brothers.
Taking great care for the sake of the Brahmana, all those foremost of men, taking up their bows and doing their corslets speedily went out in pursuit of the deer.
Beholding that deer at a short distance, those mighty car-warriors the Pandavas hurled barbed darts, javelins and arrows (at it) but they could not pierce it.
When they were thus exerting (their utmost to slay it) that great deer went out of sight. That deer disappearing (from sight) those highsouled ones became fatigued and disappointed.
And afflicted with hunger and thirst, the Pandavas coming to a banian tree in that forest sat down in its cool shade.
When they were seated, Nakula with a heavy heart and through impatience addressed his (eldest) brother, the best of the sons of the Kuru race, (thus)
In our race virtue has never been sacrificed nor there has been any loss of wealth through idleness. Again, we have never refused anything to any creature. How is it, then, O king, that this disaster has befallen us?"
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नाधनो धर्मकृत्यानि यथावदनुतिष्ठति। धनाद्धि धर्मः स्त्रवति शैलादभि नदी यथा॥
English Translation: Vyasa said A qualified preceptor should, first of all, describe the most capacious subject of spirituality, that has been explained in the previous chapter, to a disciple who wishes to enquire after Liberation after having transcended all pairs of opposites and performed the concerns of both profit and religion.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यः कृशार्थः कृशगवः कृशभृत्यः कृशातिथिः। सवै राजन् कृशो नाम न शरीरकृशः कृशः॥
English Translation: Ether, wind, light, water, and earth as the fifth, and existence and non-existence and time, exist in all living creatures having the five for their component ingredients.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अवेक्षस्व यथान्यायं पश्य देवासुरं यथा। राजन् किमन्यज्जातीनां वधाद् गृद्ध्यन्ति देवताः॥
English Translation: Space is unoccupied interstice. The organs of hearing consist of space. One knowing the science of elements endued with form should know that ether has sound for its attribute.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न चेद्धर्तव्यमन्यस्य कथं तद्धर्ममारभेत्। एतावानेव वेदेषु निश्चयः कविभिः कृतः॥
English Translation: Wind is essence of the feet. The vital airs are made of wind. Wind is the essence of the sense of touch, and touch is the attribute of wind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अध्येतव्या त्रयी नित्यं भवितव्यं विपश्चिता। सर्वथा धनमाहार्यं यष्टव्यं चापि यत्नतः॥
English Translation: Heat, the digestive fire in the stomach, light that manifests all things, the heat of the body, and eye as the fifth, are all of light which has forin of various colours for its attribute.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्रोहाद् देवैरवाप्तानि दिवि स्थानानि सर्वशः। द्रोहात् किमन्यज्ज्ञातीनां गृद्ध्यन्ते येन देवताः॥
English Translation: Solubility, and all kinds of liquid matter partake of water. Blood, marrow, and all else that is cool, have water for their essence. The longue is the sense of taste, and taste is known as the attribute of water
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इति देवा व्यवसिता वेदवादाश्च शाश्वताः। अधीयतेऽध्यापयन्ते यजन्ते याजयन्ति च॥ कृत्स्नं तदेव तच्छेरूयो यदप्याददतेऽन्यतः। न पश्यामोऽनपकृतं धनं किंचित् क्वचिद् वयम्॥
English Translation: All solid substances partake of earth, as also bones, teeth, nails, beard, the hairs on the body, hair, nerves, sinews, and skin.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमेव हि राजानो जयन्ति पृथिवीमिमाम्। जित्वा ममेयं ब्रुवते पुत्रा इव पितुर्धनम्॥
English Translation: The nose is known as the organ of smell. The object of that senses, viz., scent, is known as the attribuite of earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजर्षयोऽपि ते स्वर्यो धर्मो ह्येषां निरुच्यते। यथैव पूर्णादुदधेः स्यन्दन्त्यापो दिशो दश॥
English Translation: Each subsequent element partakes of the attribute or attributes of the preceding one in addition to its own. The (three) supplementary entities exist in all living creatures. The Rishis thus described the five elements and the effects and qualities emanating from or belonging to them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं राजकुलाद् वित्तं पृथिवीं प्रति तिष्ठति। आसीदियं दिलीपस्य नृगस्य नहुषस्य च।॥
English Translation: The mind is the ninth, and the understanding is the tenth. The Soul, which is infinite, is the eleventh. It is considered as the highest of all.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अम्बरीषस्य मान्धातुः पृथिवी सा त्वयि स्थिता। स त्वां द्रव्यमयो यज्ञः सम्प्राप्तः सर्वदक्षिणः॥
English Translation: The mind has doubt or its essence. The understanding discriminates and produces certainty. The Soul becomes known as Jiva or individual soul when invested with body through the consequences of acts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं चेन्न यजसे राजन् प्राप्तस्त्वं राज्यकिल्बिषम्। येषां राजाऽश्वमेधेन यजते दक्षिणावता॥
English Translation: That man who regards all living creatures as unsullied though endued with all these entities having time for their essence, has never to perform acts moved on by error.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उपेत्य तस्यावभृथे पूताः सर्वे भवन्ति ते। विश्वरूपो महादेवः सर्वमेधे महामखे। जुहाव सर्वभूतानि तथैवात्मानमात्मना॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said Tell me, O grandfather, what reply was given by either the Brahmana or the king to Virupa after he had finished his speech.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शाश्वतोऽयं भूतिपथो नास्यान्तमनुशुश्रुम। महान् दाशरथः पन्था मा राजन् कुपथं गमः॥
English Translation: What king of end was it, amongst those described by you, that they acquired? What, indeed, was the conversation that took place between them, and what did they do there?"
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच इन्द्रप्रस्थे वसन्तस्ते जघ्नुरन्यान् नराधिपान्। शासनाद् धृराष्ट्रस्य राज्ञः शान्तनवस्य च॥
English Translation: Saying,-Let it be as you have said, the Brahmana, adored Dharma and Yama and Time and Mrityu and Heaven all of whom deserved adorations.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आश्रित्य धर्मराजानं सर्वलोकोऽवसत् सुखम्। पुण्यलक्षणकर्माणं स्वदेहमिव देहिनः॥
English Translation: He also adored all those foremost of Brahmanas that had come there by bending his head to them. Addressing the king then, he said,-Gifted with the reward of my recitation, O royal sage, acquire an eminent position. With your permission I shall set myself to my recitations again.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स समं धर्मकामार्थान् सिषेवे भरतर्षभ। त्रीनिवात्मसमान् बन्धून नीतिमानिव मानयन्॥
English Translation: O you of great power, the goddess Savitri gave me a boon, saying,-Let, your devotion to recitation be continuous.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषां समविभक्तानां क्षितौ देहवतामिव। बभौ धर्मार्थकामानां चतुर्थ इव पार्थिवः॥
English Translation: If your success has become futile, and if your heart is bent upon practising again, go, O learned Brahmana, half and half with me, and you alone enjoy the reward of the recitations.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अध्येतारं परं वेदान् प्रयोक्तारं महाध्वरे। रक्षितारं शुभाँल्लोकान् लेभिरे तं जनाधिपम्॥
English Translation: The Brahmana said You have exerted your best before all these men. Let us then become equal regarding our rewards, and let us go to receive our end.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अधिष्ठानवती लक्ष्मीः परायणवती मतिः। वर्धमानोऽखिलो धर्मस्तेनासीत् पृथिवीक्षिताम्॥
English Translation: Apprised of these determination, the king of the celestials came there, accompanied by the gods and the Regents of the world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भ्रातृभिः सहितो राजा चतुर्भिराधिकं बभौ। प्रयुज्यमानैर्विततो वेदैरिव महाध्वरः॥
English Translation: The Sadhyas, the Vishvas, the Mantras, various sorts of loud and sweet music, the Rivers, the Mountains, the Seas, the Sacred Waters, the Penances, the Ordinances about Yoga, the Vedas, the Sounds accompanying the singing of the Samans, Sarasvati, Narada, Parvata, Vishvavasu, the Hahas, the Huhus, the are Gandharva Chitrasena with all the members of his family, the Nagas, the Siddhas, the Munis, the god of gods, viz., Prajapati, and the inconceivable and thousand-headed Vishnu himself, came there. Drums and trumpets were beat and blown in the sky.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं तु धौम्यादयो विप्राः परिवार्योपतस्थिरे। बृहस्पतीसमा मुख्याः प्रजापतिमिवामराः॥
English Translation: Celestial flowers were poured upon those great beings. Bevies of Apsaras danced all around.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धर्मराजे ह्यतिप्रीत्या पूर्णचन्द्र इवामले। प्रजानां रेमिरे तुल्यं नेत्राणि हृदयानि च॥
English Translation: Heaven, in his embodied form, came there. Addressing the Brahmana, he said,-You have acquired Success. You highly blessed.-Then addressing the king, said,-You have also, O king acquired success.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न त केवलदैवेन प्रजा भावेन रेमिरे। यद् बभूव मन:कान्तं कर्मणा स चकार तत्॥
English Translation: O king having done good to each other, the king and the Brahmana, withdrew their senses from the objects of the world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न ह्ययुक्तं न चासत्यं नासह्यं न च वाप्रियम्। भाषितं चारुभाषस्य जज्ञे पार्थस्य धीमतः॥
English Translation: Fixing the vital airs Prana, Apana Samana, Udana, and Vyana in the heart, they fixed the mind in Prana and Apana united together.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स हि सर्वस्य लोकस्य हितमात्मन एव च। चिकीर्षन् सुमहातेजा रेमे भरतसत्तम।॥
English Translation: They then placed the two united airs in the abdomen, and fixed their eyes on the tip of the nose and then immediately below the nose and then immediately below the two eye-brows. They next saw the two airs, with the help of the mind, in the interstice between the two eyebrows, bringing them there by and by.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथा तु मुदिताः सर्वे पाण्डवा विगतज्वराः। अवसन् पृथिवीपालांस्तापयन्तः स्वतेजसा॥
English Translation: With bodies perfectly motionless they were absorbed with fixed gaze. Having controlled their souls, they then placed the soul within the brain.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः कतिपयाहस्य बीभत्सुः कृष्णमब्रवीत्। उष्णानि कृष्ण वर्तन्तं गच्छावो यमुनां प्रति॥
English Translation: Then passing the crown of the great Brahmana a fiery flame of great effulgence went up to heaven,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुहृज्जनवृतौ तत्र विहृत्य मधुसूदन। सायाह्ने पुनरेष्यावो रोचतां ते जनार्दना॥
English Translation: Loud exclamations of sorrow, uttered by all creatures, were then heard on all sides. Lauded by all, that splendour then entered Brahmana's self.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वासुदेव उवाच कुन्तीमातर्ममाप्येतद् रोचते यद् वयं जले। सुहज रनवृतः पार्थ विहरेम यथासुखम्॥
English Translation: Coming forward, the great grandfather addressed that splendour which had become like a span in size saying,-Welcome.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशंपायन उवाच आमन्त्र्य तौ धर्मराजमनुज्ञाष्य च भारत। जग्मतुः पार्थगोविन्दौ सुहृज्जनवृतौ ततः॥
English Translation: And again he uttered these sweet words: Verily, Reciters acquire the same end with the Yogins.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विहारदेशं सम्प्राप्य नानाद्रुममनुत्तमम्। गृहैरुच्चावचैयुक्तं पुरन्दरपुरोपमम्॥ भक्ष्यैर्भोज्यैश्च पेयैश्च रसवद्भिर्महाधनैः। माल्यैश्च विविधैर्गधैर्युक्तं वार्ष्णेयपार्थयोः॥ विवेशान्तःपुरं तूर्णं रत्नैरुच्चावचैः शुभैः। यथोपजोषं सर्वश्च जनश्चिनीड भारत॥
English Translation: When the Yogins attains his end he gets a direct vision unto all these (here assembled). Regarding Reciters, however, there is this distinction, that they are honoured by Brahmana's advancing forward to receive them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्त्रियश्च विपुलश्रोण्यश्चारुपीनपयोधराः। मदस्खलितगामिन्यश्चिक्रीडुर्वामलोचनाः॥
English Translation: Live you in me,-Thus spoke Brahman and once more gave consciousness to that splendour. Indeed, then, freed from all anxieties, the Brahmana entered the mouth of the Creator.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वने काश्चिज्जले काश्चित् काश्चिद् वेश्मनु चाङ्गनाः। यथायोग्यं यथाप्रीति चिक्रीडुः पार्थकृष्णयोः॥
English Translation: The king Ikshvaku, too, in the same way, entered the divine Grandfather like that best of Brahmanas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्रौपदी च सुभद्रा च वासांस्याभरणानि च। प्रायच्छतां महाराज ते तु तस्मिन् मदोत्कटे॥
English Translation: The deities saluted the self-create and said, A very superior end is, indeed, laid down for Reciters.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: काश्चित् प्रहृष्टा ननृतुश्चक्रुशुश्च तथापराः। जगुश्चान्या वरस्त्रियः॥
English Translation: This your exertion is for Reciters. We only came here for seeing it. You have made these two equal, honoured them equally, and granted them an equal end.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रुरुधुश्चापरास्तत्र प्रजघ्नुश्च परस्परम्। मन्त्रयामासुरन्याश्च रहस्यानि परस्परम्॥
English Translation: We have seen to-day the high end that is reserved for both. Yogins and Reciters. Transcending all happy regions, these two are capable of going wherever they like.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जहसुश्च परा नार्यो वेणुवीणामृदङ्गानां मनोज्ञानां च सर्वशः। शब्देन पूर्यते हh तद् वनं सुमहर्द्धिमत्॥
English Translation: Brahmana said-He also who would read the great Smriti (viz., the Vedas) and he too who would read the other sacred Smritis that follow the former, (viz., Manu's and the rest), would, similarly allain to the same region with me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मिंस्तदा वर्तमाने कुरुदाशार्हनन्दनौ। समीपं जग्मतुः कंचिदुद्देशं सुमनोहरम्॥
English Translation: He also, who is devoted to Yoga, will, forsooth, acquire likewise, after death, my own regions. I go hence. Go ye all to your respective abodes for the accomplishment of your ends.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्र गत्वा महात्मानौ कृष्णौ परपुरंजयौ। महार्हासनयो राजंस्ततस्तौ संनिषीदतुः॥
English Translation: Having said so that foremost of gods disappeared there and then. Having obtained a leave from him beforehand the gods returned to their respective quarters.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्र पूर्वव्यतीतानि विक्रान्तानीतराणि च। बहूनि कथयित्वा तौ रेमाते पार्थमाधवौ॥
English Translation: Having honoured Dharma, all those great beings proceeded with well-pleased hearts, O king, walking behind that great god.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्रोपविष्टौ मुदितौ नाकपृष्ठेऽश्विनाविव। अभ्यागच्छत् तदा विप्रो वासुदेवधनंजयौ॥
English Translation: These are the rewards of reciters and this their end. I have described them to you as ] myself had heard of them. What else, O king, do you wish to hear of?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बृहच्छालप्रतीकाशः प्रतप्तकनकप्रभः। हरिपिङ्गोज्जवलश्मश्रुः प्रमाणायामतः समः॥
