Sanskrit Shloka: नाहं राज्यफलं पुत्राः कामये पुत्रनिर्जितम्। पतिलोकानहं पुण्यान् कामये तपसा विभो॥
English Translation: And lastly Partha, having white steeds, has held, for sixty five years, this highly powerful, heavenly and most excellent bow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्वश्रूश्वशुरयोः कुत्वा शुश्रूषां वनवासिनोः। तपसा शोषयिष्यामि युधिष्ठिर कलेवरम्॥
English Translation: This beautiful bow has come to Partha from Varuna. Worshipped by god and men it has taken a handsome form.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निवर्तस्व कुरुश्रेष्ट भीमसेनादिभिः सह। धर्मे ते धीयतां बुद्धिर्मनस्तु महदस्तु च॥
English Translation: That bow of beautiful sides and golden handle belongs to Bhima with which, the son of Pritha, the slayer of enemies, conquered the entire eastern region.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शल्य उवाच एवमुक्तः स भगवाञ्छच्या तां पुनरब्रवीत्। विक्रमस्य न कालोऽयं नहुषो बलवत्तरः॥
English Translation: the other most excellent and beautiful bow, variegated with insects, belongs to the king Yudhishthira.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विवर्धितश्च ऋषिभिर्हव्यकव्यैश्च भाविनि। नीतिमत्र विधास्यामि देवि तां कर्तुमर्हसि॥
English Translation: The other, in which golden suns of brilliant effulgence shed lustre all around, belongs to Nakula.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गुह्यं चैतत् त्वया कार्यं नाख्यातव्यं शुभे क्वचित्। गत्वा नहुषमेकान्ते ब्रवीहि च सुमध्यमे॥
English Translation: The bow, embellished with golden images of insects and set also with jems and stones, belongs to that son of Madri who is called Sahadeva.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ऋषियानेन दिव्येन मामुपैहि जगत्पते। एवं तव वशे प्रीता भविष्यामीति तं वदा॥
English Translation: The thousand winged shafts, sharp as razors and dreadful like the venom of snakes, belong to Arjuna, O son of Virata.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्युक्त्वा देवराजेन पत्नी सा कमलेक्षणा। एवमस्त्वित्यथोक्त्वा तु जगाम नहुषं प्रति॥
English Translation: These swift arrows, of the hero burning in energy in battle when discharged against the enemies, become inexhaustible.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नहुषस्तां ततो दृष्ट्वा सस्मितो वाक्यमब्रवीत्। स्वागतं ते वरारोहे किं करोमि शुचिस्मिते॥
English Translation: These sharp, long and heavy arrows, resembling the crescent of the moon in shape and capable of destroying the enemies, belong to Bhima.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भक्तं मां भज कल्याणि कमिच्छसि मनस्विनि। तव कल्याणि यत् कार्यं तत् करिष्ये सुमध्यमे॥
English Translation: The quiver, having the five images of tigers full of yellow, gold winged shafts whetted on stone, belongs to Nakula.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न च व्रीडा त्वया कार्या सुश्रोणि मयि विश्वसेः। सत्येन वै शपे देवि करिष्ये वचनं तव॥
English Translation: This quiver belongs to the intelligent son of Madri with which he had conquered the entire western region.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इन्द्राण्युवाच यो मे कृतस्त्वया कालस्तमाकाङ्क्षे जगत्पते। ततस्त्वमेव भर्ता मे भविष्यसि सुराधिप॥
English Translation: These arrows, lustrous like the sun, painted all over with various colours and capable of destroying enemies by thousands, belong to Sahadeva.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कार्यं च हृदि मे यत् तद् देवराजावधारय। वक्ष्यामि यदि मे राजन् प्रियमेतत् करिष्यसि॥ वाक्यं प्रणयसंयुक्तं ततः स्यां वशगा तव।
English Translation: These great arrows, sharpened, yellow, heavy, long, gold feathered and consisting of three knots, belong to the king (Yudhishthira).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इन्द्रस्य वाजिनो वाहा हस्तिनोऽथ रथास्तथा॥ इच्छाम्यहमथापूर्वं वाहनं ते सुराधिप। यन्न विष्णोर्न रुद्रस्य नासुराणां न रक्षसाम्॥
English Translation: This long sword, with the emblem of a bee on its back and sharp as the sting of a bee, firm and capable of bearing heavy weight in battle, belongs to Arjuna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वहन्तु त्वां महाभागा ऋषयः संगता विभो। सर्वे शिबिकया राजन्नेतद्धि मम रोचते॥
English Translation: This celestials huge sword, cased in tiger skin, capable of bearing heavy weight and dreadful to the enemies, belongs to Bhimasena.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नासुरेषु न देवेषु तुल्यो भवितुमर्हसि। सर्वेषा तेज आदत्से स्वेन वीर्येण दर्शनात्। न ते प्रमुखतः स्थातुं कश्चिच्छक्नोति वीर्यवान्॥
English Translation: This most excellent sword, of a sharp blade, golden hilt and cased in a painted sheath, belongs to the intelligent Dharmaraja of the Kuru race.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शल्य उवाच एवमुक्तस्तु नहुषः प्राहृष्यत् तदा किल। उवाच वचनं चापि सुरेन्द्रस्तामनिन्दिताम्॥
English Translation: This strong sword, capable of bearing heavy weight intended for various forms of fight and cased in a sheath of goat-skin belongs to Nakula.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नहुष उवाच अपूर्वं वाहनमिदं त्वयोक्तं वरवर्णिनि। दृढं मे रुचितं देवि त्वद्वशोऽस्मि वरानने॥
English Translation: This huge, strong and dreadful sword, capable of bearing heavy weight and put in a sheath of cow-skin, belongs to Sahadeva.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न ह्यल्पवीर्यो भवति यो वाहान् कुरुते मुनीन्। अहं तपस्वी बलवान् भूतभव्यभवत्प्रभुः॥
English Translation: Janamcjaya said After having conferred that boon on Utanka, O foremost of twice-born persons, what did the mighty-armed. Govinda of great celebrity next do?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मयि क्रुद्धे जगन्न स्यान्मयि सर्वं प्रतिष्ठितम्। देवदानवगन्धर्वाः किन्नरोरगराक्षसाः॥ न मे क्रुद्धस्य पर्याप्ताः सर्वे लोकाः शुचिस्मिते। चक्षुषा यं प्रपश्यामि तस्य तेजो हराम्यहम्॥
English Translation: Having granted that boon to Utanka, Govinda, accompanied by Satyaki, went to Dwraka on his car, drawn by his large quickcoursing horse.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मात् ते वचनं देवि करिष्यामि न संशयः। सप्तर्षयो मां वक्ष्यन्ति सर्वे ब्रह्मर्षयस्तथा। पश्य महात्म्ययोगं मे ऋद्धिं च वरवर्णिनि॥
English Translation: Passing many lakes and rivers and forests and hills, he at last came upon the charming city of Dvaravati.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शल्य उवाच एवमुक्त्वा तु तां देवीं विसृज्य च वराननाम्। विमाने योजयित्वा च ऋषीन् नियममास्थितान्॥ अब्रह्मण्यो बलोपेतो मत्तो मदबलेन च। कामवृत्तः स दुष्टात्मा वाहयामास तानृषीन्॥
English Translation: It was at the time, O king, when the festival of Raivataka had begun, that he having eyes like lotus-petals arrived with Satyaki as his companion.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नहुषेण विसृष्टा च बृहस्पतिमथाब्रवीत्। समयोऽल्पावशेषो मे नहुषेणेह यः कृतः॥
English Translation: Adorned with many beautiful things and covered with various Koshas made of jewels and gems, the Raivataka hill shone, O king, with great splendour.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शक्रं मृगय शीघ्रं त्वं भक्तायाः कुरु मे दयाम्। बाढमित्येव भगवान् बृहस्पतिरुवाच ताम्॥
English Translation: That high mountain, decked with excellent garlands of gold and gay festoons of flowers, with many large trees which looked like the Kalpa trees of Indra's garden, and with many golden poles on which were lighted lamps, shone in beauty through day and night. By the caves and fountains the light was so great that it appeared like a broad day.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न भेतव्य त्वया देवि नहुषाद् दुष्टचेतसः। न होष स्थास्यति चिरं गत एष नराधमः॥
English Translation: On all sides beautiful flags waved on the air with little bells that jingled continuously. The entire hill resounded with the sweet songs of men and women.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अधर्मज्ञो महर्षीणां वाहनाच्च ततः शुभे। इष्टिं चाहं करिष्यामि विनाशायास्य दुर्मतेः॥ शक्रं चाधिगमिष्यामि मा भैस्त्वं भद्रमस्तु ते।
English Translation: Raivataka presents a most delightful appearance like Meru with all his jewels and gems. Men and women excited and filled with delight, O Bharata, sang aloud. The swell of music which thus arose from that foremost of mountains appeared to touch the very heavens. Everywhere were heard spouts and loud whoops of men who were in all forms of excitement.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः प्रज्वाल्य विधिवज्जुहाव परमं हविः॥ बृहस्तपतिर्महातेजा देवराजोपलब्धये। हुत्वाग्निं सोऽब्रवीद् राजञ्छक्रमन्विष्यतामिति॥
English Translation: The cackle of thousands of voices made that mountain delightful and charming. It was adorned with many shops and stalls filled with various foods and enjoyable article.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्माच्च भगवान् देवः स्वयमेव हुताशनः। स्त्रीवेषमद्भुतं कृत्वा तत्रैवान्तरधीयत॥
English Translation: There were heaps of cloths and garlands, and the music of Vinas and flutes and Mridangas was heard everywhere. Food mixed with wines of various kinds was stored here and there.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स दिशः प्रदिशश्चैव पर्वतानि वनानि च। पृथिवीं चान्तरिक्षं च विचिन्त्याथ मनोगतिः। निमेषान्तरमात्रेण बृहस्पतिमुपागमत्॥
English Translation: Gifts were being continually given to those that were distressed, or blind or helpless. For all this, the festival of that mountain became highly auspicious.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अग्निरुवाच बृहस्पते न पश्यामि देवराजमिह क्वचित्। आपः शेषाः सदा चापः प्रवेष्टुं नोत्सहाम्यहम्॥
English Translation: There were many sacred houses built on the breast of that mountain, O hero, within which lived many pious men. Even thus did the Vrishni heroes sport in that festival of Raivataka.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न मे तत्र गतिर्ब्रह्मन् किमन्यत् करवाणि ते! तमब्रवीद् देवगुरुरपो विश महायुते॥
English Translation: Equipt with those palaces that mountain appeared like second Heaven. At the arrival Krishna, O chief of Bharata's race, that prince of mountains resembled the blessed mansion of Indra himself. Adored (by his relatives), Krishna then entered a beautiful palace. Satyaki also went to his own quarters with a delighted soul. Govinda entered his residence after a long absence, having accomplished deeds of great difficulty like Vasava amid the Danava host. The heroes of the Bhoja, Vrishni, and Andhaka races, all came forward to receive that great one like the deities advancing to receive the deity of a hundred sacrifices.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अग्निरुवाच नापः प्रवेष्टुं शक्ष्यामि क्षयो मेऽत्र भविष्यति। शरणं त्वां प्रपन्नोऽस्मि स्वस्ति तेऽस्तु महाद्युते॥
English Translation: Gifted with great intelligence, he honoured them in return and enquired after their wellbeing. With a pleased heart he then saluted his father and mother.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अद्भयोऽग्निर्ब्रह्मतः क्षत्रमश्मनो लोहमुत्थितम्। तेषां सर्वत्रगं तेजः स्वासु योनिषु शाम्यति॥
English Translation: The mighty-armed hero was embraced by both of them and comforted too. He then took his seat with all the Vrishnis sitting around him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जनमेजय उवाच एवं हृतायां भार्यायां प्राप्य क्लेशमनुत्तमम्। प्रतिपद्य ततः कृष्णां किमकुर्वत पाण्डवाः॥
English Translation: Having washed his feet and removed his fatigue, Krishna of mighty energy, as he sat there, then described the chief events of the great battle in answer to the questions put to him by his father.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच एवं हृतायां कृष्णायां प्राप्य क्लेशमनुत्तमम्। विहाय काम्यकं राजा सह भ्रातृभिरच्युतः॥ पुनद्वैतवनं रम्यमाजगाम युधिष्ठिरः। स्वादुमूलफलं रम्यं विचित्रबहुपादपम्॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Thereupon King Duryodhana with his brothers began slowly to win over the people to his side by bestowing on them wealth and honours. One day in the (royal) Court, some clever ministers, as instructed by Dhritarashtra, described the city of Varanavata as a (most) charming place. (They said), "The festival of Pashupati (Siva) has begun in the city of Varanavata and the concourse of people there is now great.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनुभुक्तफलाहाराः सर्व एव मिताशनाः। न्यवसन् पाण्डवास्तत्र कृष्णया सह भार्यया॥
English Translation: The procession is the most grand in the world; and all gems and jewels (now) there delight the heart." Thus did they (counsellors) under instruction from Dhritarashtra, speak (of the city). O sons,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वसन् द्वैतवने राजा कुन्तीपुत्रो युधिष्ठिरः। भीमसेनोऽर्जुनश्चैव माद्रीपुत्रौ च पाण्डवौ॥ ब्राह्मणार्थे पराक्रान्ता धर्मात्मानो यतव्रताः। क्लेशमार्छन्त विपुलं सुखोदक परंतपाः॥
English Translation: O king, while they were speaking of the charming city of Varanavata, the Pandavas desired in their mind to go there.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मिन् प्रतिवसन्तस्ते यत् प्रापुः कुरुसत्तमाः। वने क्लेशं सुखोदकं तत् प्रवक्ष्यामि ते शृणु॥
English Translation: When the king Dhritarashtra knew that their (Pandavas) curiosity had been awakened, then the son of Ambika, (Dhritarashtra) spoke thus to the Pandavas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अरणीसहितं मन्थं ब्राह्मणस्य तपस्विनः। घर्षमाणस्य विषाणे विषाणे समसज्जतः॥
English Translation: Dhritarashtra said: My men tell me daily again and again that the city of Varanavata is the most charming in the world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदादाय गतो राजंस्त्वरमाणो महामृगः। आश्रमान्तरितः शीघ्रं प्लवमानो महाजवः॥
English Translation: if you desire to see the festival of Varanavata, go (there) with your friends and followers and enjoy yourselves like the celestial.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ह्रियमाणं तु तं दृष्ट्वा स विप्रः कुरुसत्तम। त्वरितोऽभ्यागमत् तत्र अग्निहोत्रपरीप्सया॥
English Translation: Bestow gems and jewels on all the Brahmanas and the musicians (there), sport there as the effulgent celestial. Enjoy there for sometime as much happiness as you like at pleasure and then return to Hastinapur.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मृगस्य घर्षमाणस्य अजातशत्रुमासीनं भ्रातृभिः सहितं वने। आगम्य ब्राह्मणस्तूर्णं संतप्तश्चेदमब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Yudhisthira, understanding the motives of Dhritarashtra and knowing himself weak and friendless, said, “Be it so."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अरणीसहितं मन्यं समासक्तं वनस्पतौ। मृगस्य घर्षमाणस्य विषाणे समसज्जत॥
English Translation: Then addressing the son of Shantanu, Bhishma, the wise Vidura, Drona, Valhika, the Kaurava Somadatta, Kripa, Ashvathama, Bhurisrava and other respected counsellors, Brahmanas, ascetics, priests, citizens and the illustrious Gandhari, Yudhisthira slowly and humbly spoke thus-
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमादाय गतो राजंस्त्वरमाणो महामृगः। आश्रमात् त्वरितः शीघ्रं प्लवमानो महाजवः॥
English Translation: Yudhisthira said : We go with our friends and followers to the charming and populous city of Varanavata at the command of Dhritarashtra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य गत्वा पदं राजन्नासाद्य च महामृगम्। अग्निहोत्रं न लुप्येत तदानयत पाण्डवाः॥
English Translation: Give us cheerfully your benedictions, so that acquiring prosperity with it, we may not be touched by sin.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणस्य वचः श्रुत्वा संतप्तोऽथ युधिष्ठिरः। धनुरादाय कौन्तेयः प्राद्रवद् भ्रातृभिः सह॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : Having been thus addressed by the son of Pandu, all the Kauravas cheerfully pronounced blessings on them, saying, "O sons of Pandu, let all the elements bless you on your way and let not the slightest evil befall you."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सन्नद्धा धन्विनः सर्वे प्राद्रवन् नरपुङ्गवाः। ब्राह्मणार्थे यतन्तस्ते शीघ्रमन्वगमन् मृगम्॥
English Translation: Having performed propitiatory rites for obtaining the kingdom and making all other preparations, the princes (the Pandavas) started for Varanavata.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्णिनालीकनाराचानुत्सृजन्तो महारथाः। नाविध्यन् पाण्डवास्तत्र पश्यन्तो मृगमन्तिकात्॥
English Translation: Narada said Forsooth, O Shalmali, the dreadful and irresistible god of wind always protects you friendliness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषां प्रयतमानानां नादृश्यत महामृगः। अपश्यन्तो मृगं शान्ता दुःखं प्राप्ता मनस्विनः॥
English Translation: It seems, O Shalmali, that a close intimacy exists between you and the Wind. It seems, you have said him these words, viz.,-I. am yours-and it is, therefore, that the Wind-god protects you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शीतलच्छायमागम्य न्यचोधं गहने वने। क्षुत्पिपासापरीताङ्गाः पाण्डवाः समुपाविशन्॥
English Translation: I do not see the tree or mountain or palace in this world which may not, I think, be broken by the Wind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषां समुपविष्टानां नकुलो दुःखितस्तदा। अब्रवीद् भ्रातरं श्रेष्ठममर्षात् कुरुनन्दनम्॥
English Translation: Forsooth, you stand here with all your branches and twigs and leaves, simply because, O Shalmali, you are protected by the Wind for some reason or reasons (unknown to us)!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नास्मिन् कुले जातु ममज्ज धर्मो न चालस्यादर्थलोपो बभूव। अनुत्तराः सर्वभूतेषु भूयः सम्प्राप्ताः स्मः संशयं किं नु राजन्॥
English Translation: The Wind, O twice-born one, is either my friend nor companion nor well-wisher. Nor is he iny great Creator that he should protect me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यास उवाच द्वन्द्वानि मोक्षजिज्ञासुरर्थधर्मावनुष्ठितः। वक्त्रा गुणवता शिष्यः श्राव्यः पूर्वमिदं महत्॥
English Translation: My terrific energy and power, O Narada, are the greater than the Wind's. In sooth, the strength of the Wind is only an eighteenth part of mine.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आकाशं मारुतो ज्योतिरापः पृथ्वी च पञ्चमी। भावाभावौ च कालश्च सर्वभूतेषु पञ्चसु॥
English Translation: When the Wind blows fearfully, tearing up trees and mountains and other things, I abate his strength by displaying mine.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्तरात्मकमाकाशं तन्मयं श्रोत्रमिन्द्रियम्। तस्य शब्दं गुणं विद्यान्मूर्तिशास्त्रविधानवित्॥
English Translation: Indeed, the Wind that breaks many things has himself been again and agair broken by me. Therefore, O celestial Rishi, I am not afraid of him even when he comes in fury.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चरणं मारुतोत्मेति प्राणापानौ च तन्मयौ। स्पर्शनं चेन्द्रियं विद्यात् तथा स्पर्श च तन्मयम्॥
English Translation: Narada said-O Shalmali, what you think seems to be quite the reverse of truth. There is no doubt in this. There is no created thing which is so strong as the Wind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ताप: पाकः प्रकाशश्च ज्योतिश्चक्षुश्च पञ्चमम्। तस्य रूपं गुणं विद्यात् ताम्रगौरासितात्मकम्॥
English Translation: Even Indra, Yama, Vaishravana, of Varuna the king of the waters, is not equal to the god of wind in might. What to speak of you who are only a tree.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रक्लेदः क्षुद्रता स्नेह इत्यपामुपदिश्यते। असृङ्मज्जा च यच्चान्यत् स्निग्धं विद्यात् तदात्मकम्॥६
English Translation: The illustrious Wind-god is always the root of all the acts of creatures in this world, since it is he that is the giver of life.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रसनं चेन्द्रियं जिह्वा रसश्चापां गुणो मतः। संघातः पार्थिवो धातुरस्थिदन्तनखानि च।॥
English Translation: When the god does his work properly, he makes all living creatures live at their ease. When, however, he does it improperly, calamities visit the Earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्मश्रु रोम च केशाश्च शिरा स्नायु च चर्म च। इन्द्रियं घ्राणसंज्ञातं नासिकेत्यभिसंज्ञिता॥
English Translation: What else can it be but weakness of understanding which induces you not to adore the god of wind, that foremost of beings in the universe, and worthy of adoration.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गन्धश्चेवेन्द्रियार्थोऽयं विज्ञेयः पृथिवीमयः। उत्तरेषु गुणाः सन्ति सर्वसत्त्वेषु चोत्तराः॥ पञ्चानां भूतसंघानां संततिं मुनयो विदुः।
English Translation: You are worthless and of a wicked understanding, you are but making an idleboast. Your intelligence being confounded by anger and other passions, you indulge in untruths, O Shalmali.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मनो नवममेषां तु बुद्धिस्तु दशमी स्मृता॥ एकादशस्त्वनन्तात्मा स सर्वः पर उच्यते।
English Translation: I am certainly angry with you, for your giving vent to such words. I shall myself communicate to the Windgod all these derogatory words of yours.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिर्मनो व्याकरणात्मकम्। कर्मानुमानाद् विज्ञेयः स जीवः क्षेत्रसंज्ञकः॥
English Translation: Chandanas, Syandanas, Shalas, Saralas, Devadarus, Vetasas and Dhanvanas and other noble trees that are far stronger than you, have never, you of wicked understanding, spoken such evil words against the Wind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एभिः कालात्मकैर्भावैर्यः सर्वैः सर्वमन्वितम्। पश्यत्यकलुषं कर्म स मोहं नानुवर्तते॥
English Translation: All of them are cognisant of the power of the Wind as also the power that each of them possesses. For these reasons those foremost of trees respectfully salute that god.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच किमुत्तरं तदा तौ स्म चक्रतुस्तस्य भाषिते। ब्राह्मणो वाथवा राजा तन्मे ब्रूहि पितामह॥
English Translation: However, through folly, you are only unaware of the infinite power of the Wind, I shall, therefore, go to that god.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथवा तौ गतौ तत्र यदेतत् कीर्तितं त्वया। संवादो वा तयोः कोऽभूत् किं वा तौ तत्र चक्रतुः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said: O great king, when he (Duryodhana) was entering (the city) the bards and penegyrists eulogised that undeteriorating one. Other people also eulogised that great bow man, that foreinost of kings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच तथेत्येवं प्रतिश्रुत्य धर्मं सम्पूज्य च प्रभो। यमं कालं च मृत्युं च स्वर्ग सम्पूज्य चार्हतः॥
English Translation: Sprinkling over him fried paddy and sandal paste; the people said “By good luck, O king, your sacrifice has been completed without obstruction.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पूर्वं ये चापरे तत्र समेता ब्राह्मणर्षभाः। सर्वान् सम्पूज्य शिरसा राजानं सोऽब्रवीद् द्विजः॥ फलेनानेन संयुक्तो राजर्षे गच्छ मुख्यताम्। भवता चाभ्यनुज्ञातो जपेयं भूय एव ह॥
English Translation: Some who were present and who were not very careful in their speech said to that lord of earth, “Surely this sacrifice cannot be compared with that of Yudhishthira.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वरच मम पूर्वं हि दत्तो देव्या महाबला श्रद्धा ते जपतो नित्यं भवत्विति विशाम्पते॥
English Translation: It does not come to the sixteenth part of that (sacrifice); thus spoke to that king some that were reckless in their speech.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजोवाच यद्येवमफला सिद्धिः श्रद्धा च जपितुं तव। गच्छ विप्र मया साधु जापकं फलमाप्नुहि॥
English Translation: His friends said, “your this sacrifice has surpassed all others. Yayati, Nahusa, Mandhata and Bharata having been sanctified by performing such a sacrifice have all gone to heaven”.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मण उवाच कृतः प्रयत्नः सुमहान् सर्वेषां संनिधाविह। सह तुल्यफलावावां गच्छावो यत्र नौ गतिः॥
English Translation: O foremost of the Bharatas, hearing such pleasing words from the friends, that ruler of men (Duryodhana) cheerfully entered the city and his iron palace.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच व्यवसायं तयोस्तत्र विदित्वा त्रिदशेश्वरः। सह देवैरुपययौ लोकपालैस्तथैव च॥
English Translation: O king, then worshipping the feet of his father and mother and others headed by Bhishma, Drona and the wise Vidura and being worshipped also by his younger brothers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: साध्याश्च विश्वे मरुतो वाद्यानि सुमहान्ति च। नद्यः शैला: समुद्राश्च तीर्थानि विविधानि च।॥ तपांसि संयोगविधिर्वेदाः स्तोभाः सरस्वती। नारदः पर्वतश्चैव विश्वावसुर्हहाहुहूः॥ गन्धर्वश्चित्रसेनश्च परिवारगणैर्युतः। नागाः सिद्धाश्च मुनयो देवदेवः प्रजापतिः॥ विष्णुः सहस्रशीर्षश्च देवोऽचिन्त्यः समागमत्। अवाद्यन्तान्तरिक्षे च भेर्यस्तूर्याणि वा विभो॥
English Translation: He sat on an excellent seat surrounded by all his brothers. Then O great king, Suta's son (Karna) rose and thus spoke to him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुष्पवर्षाणि दिव्यानि तत्र तेषां महात्नाम्। ननृतुश्चाप्सरःसंघास्तत्र तत्र समन्ततः॥
English Translation: “O foremost of the Bharata race, by good luck you have completed the great sacrifice. When the Pandavas will be killed in battle and when you will thus complete Rajasuya sacrifice, then at that time again I shall thus honour you."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ स्वर्गस्तथा रूपी ब्राह्मणं वाक्यमब्रवीत्। संसिद्धस्त्वं महाभाग त्वं च सिद्धस्तथा नृप॥
English Translation: The greatly illustrious son of Dhritarashtra, that great king (Duryodhana) thus spoke to him, "Truly has this been said by you. When, O foremost of men, the wicked-minded Pandavas have been killed and when the great Rajasuya has been performed by me, then O hero, you shall again thus honour me."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ तौ सहितौ राजन्नन्योन्यविधिना ततः। विषयप्रतिसंहारमुभावेव प्रचक्रतुः।।१६
English Translation: O great king, O descendant of Bharata, having said this, he embraced Karna. That Kuru prince then began to think of that foremost of sacrifices Rajasuya.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्राणापानौ तथोदानं समानं व्यानमेव च। एवं तौ मनसि स्थाप्य दधतुः प्राणयोर्मनः॥
English Translation: That best of kings then thus spoke to the Kurus who were near him. O Kurus, when shall I celebrate that costly and foremost of sacrifices Rajasuya after having killed all the Pandavas?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उपस्थितकृतौ तौ च नासिकाग्रमधो भ्रुवोः। भृकुट्या चैव मनसा शनैर्धारयतस्तदा॥
English Translation: Thereupon Karna said to the king, "O foremost of kings, hear what I say? As long I sons do not kill Arjuna, so long I shall not wash my feet. Nor shall I taste meat. I shall observe the Asura vow. Whoever will ask from me any thing, I shall never say “I have it not.”
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निश्चेष्टाभ्यां शरीराभ्यां स्थिरदृष्टी समाहितौ। जितात्मानौ तथाऽऽधाय मूर्धन्यात्मानमेव च॥
English Translation: When Karna had thus vowed to kill Arjuna in battle those mighty car-warriors and bowmen, the sons of Dhritarashtra, sent up a loud shout.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तालुदेशमथोद्दाल्य ब्राह्मणस्य महात्मनः। ज्योतिर्चाला सुमहती जगाम त्रिदिवं तदा॥
English Translation: Dhritarashtra's thought that the Pandavas were already killed. O king of kings, Duryodhana, then leaving those foremost of men, that handsome one entered his house as Kubera the lord' enters the garden of Chitraratha. O descendant of Bharata, those great bow-men also went to their own houses.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हाहाकारस्तथा दिक्षु सर्वेषां सुमहानभूत्। तज्ज्योतिः स्तूयमानं स्म ब्राह्मणं प्राविशत् तदा॥
English Translation: (Meanwhile) those great bowmen, the Pandavas, moved by the words of the messenger, became anxious and they did not experience the least happiness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः स्वागतमित्याह तत् तेजः प्रपितामहः। प्रादेशमात्रं पुरुषं प्रत्युद्गम्य विशाम्पते॥
English Translation: O king of kings, the news had been brought to him by spies that the Suta's son (Karna) had aken the vow to kill Vijaya (Arjuna).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भूयश्चैवापरं प्राह वचनं मधुर तदा। जापकैस्तुल्यफलता योगानां नात्र संशयः॥
English Translation: O ruler of men, having heard this the son of Dharma (Yudhishthira) became filled with great anxiety; thinking of the impenetrable armour of the greatly powerful Karna. Remembering all their misery, he felt no peace of mind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: योगस्य तावदेतेभ्यः प्रत्यक्षं फलदर्शनम्। जापकानां विशिष्टं तु प्रत्युत्थानं समाहितम्॥
English Translation: That high-souled hero, filled with anxiety, made up his mind to abandon the forest of Dvaitavana abounding in wild animals.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उष्यतां मयि चेत्युक्त्वाचेतयत् सततं पुनः। अथास्यं प्रविवेशास्य ब्राह्मणो विगतज्वरः॥
English Translation: The king, the son of Dhritarashtra, meanwhile began to rule the earth, along with his heroic brothers as also with Bhishma, Drona and Kripa. With the assistance of the Suta's son crowned with martial glory.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजाप्येतेन विधिना भगवन्तं पितामहम्। यथैव द्विजशार्दूलस्तथैव प्राविशत् तदा॥
English Translation: Duryodhana remained ever intent on the welfare of the ruler of earth. He worshipped the foremost of Brahmanas by celebrating sacrifices with large Dakshinas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्वयम्भुवमथो देवा अभिवाद्य ततोऽब्रुवन्। जापकानां विशिष्टं तु प्रत्युत्थानं समाहितम्॥
English Translation: O king, that hero, that chastiser of foes was engaged in doing good to his brothers, concluding in his mind that giving and enjoying are the only (proper) uses of the wealth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जापकार्थमयं यत्नो यदर्थं वयमागताः। कृतपूजाविमौ तुल्यौ त्वया तुल्यफलाविमौ॥
English Translation: Shalya said Then Shakra being glorified by the Gandharvas and the celestial nymphs, ascended on the Airavata, the chief among elephants, which bore auspicious marks. The god of fire, of very great strength and the great Rishi Brihaspati, Yama, Varuna and Kubera, the god of wealth, surrounded by all these gods and by the Gandharvas and the celestial nymphs Shakra, the slayer of Vritra and the lord of the three worlds, went round.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: योगजापकयोदृष्टं फलं सुमहदद्य वै। सर्वा ल्लोकानतिक्रम्य गच्छेतां यत्र वाञ्छितम्॥
English Translation: Being united with his queen the great Indra, the king of the gods, the performer of a hundred sacrifices, highly pleased ruled over the gods.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्रह्मोवाच महास्मृतिं पठेद् यस्तु तथैवानुस्मृतिं शुभाम्। तावप्येतेन विधिना गच्छेतां मत्सलोकताम्॥
English Translation: Then the god there Angira propitiating the king of the gods by chanting hymns from the Atharvaveda.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यश्च योगे भवेद् भक्तः सोऽपि नास्त्यत्र संशयः। विधिनानेन देहान्ते मम लोकानवाप्नुयात्। साधये गम्यतां चैव यथास्थानानि सिद्धये॥
English Translation: saw Then the god Indra became highly pleased and he granted a boon to Angiras who was chanting the Atharvaveda.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच इत्युक्त्वा स तदा देवस्तत्रैवान्तरधीयता आमन्त्र्य च ततो देवा ययुः स्वं स्वं निवेशनम्॥
English Translation: To this Veda, there will be given the name of Atharvangirasa; this is an example; and you will also get a share of the offerings in a sacrifice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते च सर्वे महात्मानो धर्म सत्कृत्य तत्र वै। पृष्ठतोऽनुययू राजन् सर्वे सुप्रीतचेतसः॥
English Translation: The god having thus greeted Angirasa, the king of the gods, the performer of a hundred sacrifices dismissed him, O great king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतत् फलं जापकानां गतिश्चैषा प्रकीर्तिता। यथाश्रुतं महाराज किं भूयः श्रोतुमिच्छसि॥
English Translation: Doing due honours to all, to the thirteen Rishis and those whose wealth consisted in devotion alone and well pleased, Indra ruled over his subjects with virtue, O king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच गते तस्मिन् हरिवरे भीमोऽपि बलिनां वरः। तेन मार्गेण विपुलं व्यचरद् गन्धमादनम्॥
English Translation: Such was the trouble experienced by Indra in company with his queen; he had also to remain unknown in exile through his wishing for the downfall of his enemies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनुस्मरन् वपुस्तस्य श्रियं चाप्रतिमां भुवि। माहात्म्यमनुभावं च स्मरन् दाशरथेर्ययौ॥
English Translation: You should not, for this reason, mind the troubles that you experienced in the great forest in company with Draupadi, O chief among kings and your noble minded brothers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तानि रमणीयानि वान्युपवनानि च। विलोकयामास तदा सौगन्धिकवनेप्सया॥ फुल्लद्रुमविचित्राणि सरांसि सरितस्तथा। नानाकुसुमचित्राणि पुष्पितानि वनानि च॥
English Translation: O chief among kings, O son of Bharata, you too will get your kingdom in the same way as Shakra got his by slaying Vritra, O you who cause rejoicing among the race of Kurus.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मत्तवारणयूथानि पङ्कक्लिन्नानि भारत। वर्षतामिव मेघानां वृन्दानि ददृशे तदा॥
English Translation: Nahusha, of evil habits, the enemy of Brahmanas, of vicious mind, was overthrown through the curse of Agastya and absolutely ruined for a long period.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हरिणैश्चपलापाङ्गैर्हरिणीसहितैर्वनम्। सशष्पकवलैः श्रीमान् पथि दृष्ट्वा द्रुतं ययौ॥
English Translation: So shall your evil minded foes, Karna, Duryodhana and others, O subduer of enemies, soon meet with ruin.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महिषैश्च वराहैश्च शार्दूलैश्च निषेवितम्। व्यपेतभीर्गिरि शौर्याद् भीमसेनो व्यगाहत॥ कुसुमानन्तगन्धैश्च ताम्रपल्लवकोमलैः।। याच्यमान इवारण्ये दुमैर्मारुतकम्पितैः॥ कृतपद्माञ्जलिपुटा मत्तषट् पदसेविताः। प्रियतीर्थवना मार्गे पद्मिनी: समतिक्रम॥
English Translation: Then will you come into the possess of this world ending with the ocean, in company with your brothers, O hero and this lady Draupadi.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मज्ज्मानमनोदृष्टिः फुल्लेषु गिरिसानुषु। द्रौपदीवाक्यपाथेयो भीमः शीघ्रतरं ययौ॥
English Translation: This story of the victory of Shakra is of the same rank, as the Veda, with regard to its sanctity and it ought to be listened to by a king who is desirous of a victory and who has his army ready for battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: परिवृत्तेऽहनि ततः प्रकीर्णहरिणे वने। काञ्चनैर्विमलैः पौर्ददर्श विपुलां नदीम्॥
English Translation: Therefore do I make it listened to by you so that you may gain a victory, O best of victors. The great minded increase (in strength) by being glorified, O Yudhishthira.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हंसकारण्डवयुतां चक्रवाकोपशोभिताम्। रचितामिव तस्याद्रेर्मालां विमलापङ्कजाम्॥
English Translation: O Yudhishthira, the destruction of large minded Kshatriyas, through the crimes of Duryodhana and the strength of Bhima and Arjuna, is approaching.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्यां नद्यां महासत्त्वः सौगन्धिकवनं महत्। अपश्यत् प्रीतिजननं बालार्कसदृशद्युति॥
English Translation: He who constantly reads this story of the victory of Indra becomes free from (the effects of) his crimes and goes to heaven and passes his life pleasantly in this world and in another.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तद् दृष्ट्वा लब्धकामः स मनसा पाण्डुनन्दनः। वनवासपरिक्लिष्टां जगाम मनसा प्रियाम्॥
English Translation: He need not have any fear from his enemy and he will never become sonless. He will never meet with any danger and he will live a long life. Everywhere he will get victories and seldom defeat.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: लोमश उवाच द्रष्टारः पर्वताः सर्वे नद्यः सपुरकाननाः। तीर्थानि चैव श्रीमन्ति स्पृष्टं च सलिल करैः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said The king being thus encouraged by Shalya, O you best of the race of Bharata, that chief among the supporters of virtue did due honours to Shalya.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पर्वतं मन्दरं दिव्यमेष पन्थाः प्रयास्यति। समाहिता निरुद्विग्नाः सर्वे भवत पाण्डवाः॥
English Translation: And Yudhishthira, the son of Kunti, having heard the speech of Shalya, said these words in reply to the king of Madra of long arms.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अयं देवनिवासो वै गन्तव्यो वो भविष्यति। ऋषीणां चैव दिव्यानां निवासः पुण्यकर्मणाम॥
English Translation: The post of charioteer of Karna will be field by you no doubt and from that position shall you destroy the spirit of Karna by chanting the glories of Arjuna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एषा शिवजला पुण्या याति सौम्य महानदी। बदरीप्रभवा राजन् देवर्षिगणसेविता॥
English Translation: Shalya said I shall do this, even as you dictate to me; and whatever else that I am able to do I shall do for you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एषा वैहायसैनित्यं बालखिल्यैर्महात्मभिः। अर्चिता चोपयाता च गन्धर्वैश्च महात्मभिः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said The ruler of Madra, Shalya, having bade farewell to the sons of Kunti, that beautiful man went with his army to Duryodhana, O subduer of foes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अत्र साम स्म गायन्ति सामगाः पुण्यनि:स्वनाः। मरीचिः पुलहश्चैव भृगुश्चैवाङ्गिरास्तथा॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said Then Krishna, who was on the car said to Karna-"Fortunate it is, O son of Radha, that you remember virtue. It is always seen that men, when they are in distress, speak ill of the providence and not of their own evil deeds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अत्राछिकं सुरश्रेष्ठो जपते समरुद्गणः। साध्याश्चैवाश्विनौ चैव परिधावन्ति तं तदा॥
English Translation: You, Duryodhana, Dushasana and Subala's son Shakuni, brought Draupadi, clad in one piece of cloth, before the court. Then O Karna, this virtue of yours, did not display itself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चन्द्रमाः सह सूर्येण ज्योतीषि च ग्रहैः सह। अहोरात्रविभागेन नदीमेनामनुव्रजन्॥
English Translation: When Shakuni, a clever hand at dice, defeated Kunit's son Yudhishthira who was innocent of the game where was this virtue of yours?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतस्याः सलिलं मूर्ध्नि वृषाङ्कः पर्यधारयत्। गङ्गाद्वारे महाभाग येन लोकस्थितिर्भवेत्॥
English Translation: When the period of exile and the thirteenth year (of concealment) was over and you did not return the Pandavas their kingdom where was his virtue of yours.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतां भगवती देवीं भवन्तः सर्व एव हि। प्रयतेनात्मना तात प्रतिगम्याभिवादत॥
English Translation: When at your advice the Kuru king attempted to kill Bhima through snakes and poisoned food where was this virtue of yours?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य तद् वचनं श्रुत्वा लोमशस्य महात्मनः। आकाशगङ्गां प्रयताः पाण्डवास्तेऽभ्यवादयन्॥
English Translation: When you set fire to the wax-house at Varanavata for burning the sleeping Pandavas to death where was this virtue of yours?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभिवाद्य च ते सर्वे पाण्डवाधर्मचारिणः। पुनः प्रयाताः संहृष्टाः सर्वैर्ऋषिगणैः सह॥
English Translation: When you laughed at Draupadi while she, spare dressed and in her season, stood before the court at Dusasana's will where was this virtue of yours?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो दूरात् प्रकाशन्तं पाण्डुरं मेरुसंनिभम्। ददृशुस्ते नरश्रेष्ठा विकीर्णं सर्वतोदिशम्॥
English Translation: O son of Radha! Where your religion (rule) was slipped when you once observed Draupadi getting torture in the hands of mean Kauravas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तान् प्रष्टुकामान् विज्ञाय पाण्डवान् स तु लोमशः। उवाच वाक्यं वाक्यज्ञः शृणुध्वं पाण्डुनन्दनाः॥
English Translation: When you spoke to the Princess Draupadi, of dignified elephantine gait, “O Draupadi, the Pandavas are lost into eternal hell, choose another husband" and looked on the scene with glee where was this virtue of yours?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतद् बिकीर्णं सुश्रीमत् कैलासशिखरोपमम्। यत् पश्यसि नरश्रेष्ठ पर्वतप्रतिमं स्थितम्॥ एतान्यस्थीनि दैत्यस्य नरकस्य महात्मनः। पर्वतप्रतिमं भाति पर्वतप्रस्तराश्रितम्॥
English Translation: When thirsting for the kingdom and relying on the king of Gandharas you invited the Pandavas to a game at dice where was this virtue of yours?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुरातनेन देवेन विष्णुना परमात्मना। दैत्यो विनिहतस्तेन सुरराजहितैषिणा॥
English Translation: When encircling the boy Abhimanyu in battle a number of powerful car-warriors killed him where was the virtue of yours.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दशवर्षसहस्राणि तपस्तप्यन् महामनाः। ऐन्द्रं प्रार्थयते स्थानं तप:स्वाध्यायविक्रमात्॥
English Translation: If this your virtue, the aid of which you now solicit, was no where on all those Occasions what is the use of drying up your tongue by uttering that word? You now wish to practise virtue, O Suta, but you shall not escape with your life.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तपोबलेन महता बाहुवेगबलेन च। नित्यमेव दुराधर्षोधर्षयन् स दितेः सुतः॥
English Translation: Like Nala who was vanquished by Pushkara at a game of dice, but who regained his kingdom by dint of his power, the Pandavas, who are free from cupidity, will regain their kingdom by the force of their arms and help of their friends. Having killed their powerful enemies they with the Somakas will regain their kingdom. The sons of Dhritarashtra will be killed by those best of men who are always shielded by virtues.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तु तस्य बलं ज्ञात्वाधर्मे च चरितव्रतम्। भयाभिभूतः संविग्नः शक्र आसीत् तदानघ॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said Thus accosted by Krishna, O descendant of Bharata, Karna hung down his head in shame and made no reply.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेन संचिन्तितो देवो मनसा विष्णुरव्ययः। सर्वत्रगः प्रभुः श्रीमानागतश्च स्थितौ बभौ॥
English Translation: With lips trembling in anger, he, of great energy and prowess, took up his bow and began to fight with Arjuna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ऋषयश्चापि तं सर्वे तुष्टुवुश्च दिवौकसः। तं दृष्ट्वा ज्वलमानश्रीभगवान् हव्यवाहनः॥ नष्टतेजाः समभवत् तस्य तेजोऽभिभर्त्सितः। तं दृष्ट्वा वरदं देवं विष्णुं देवगणेश्वरम्॥
English Translation: Then Vasudeva's son said to Phalguna, that best of men-"Strike Karna down with a celestial weapon."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्राञ्जलिः प्रणतो भूत्वा नमस्कृत्य च वज्रभृत्। प्राह वाक्यं ततस्तत्त्वं यतस्तस्य भयं भवेत्॥
English Translation: Thus accosted by the deity Arjuna was worked up with anger. And recollecting all the incidents Dhananjaya was possessed by a terrific rage.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विष्णुरुवाच जानामि ते भयं शक्र दैत्येन्द्रान्नरकात् ततः। ऐन्द्रं प्रार्थयते स्थानं तप:सिद्धेन कर्मणा॥
English Translation: Then, O king, as if scintillations of fire began to come put from the pores of the angry Partha's body. The scene was exceedingly wondrous.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सोऽहमेनं तव प्रीत्या तप:सिद्धमपिध्रुवम्। वियुनज्मि देहाद् देवेन्द्र मुहूर्त प्रतिपालय॥
English Translation: Seeing it Karna invoked the Brahma weapon, shot arrows on Dhananjaya and tried once more to get rid of his car. arrOWS son
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य विष्णुर्महातेजाः पाणिना चेतनां हरत्। स पपात ततो भूमौ गिरिराज इवाहतः॥
English Translation: Partha, also, by his Brahma weapon made a down pour of upon Karna. Counteracting the arrows of his enemy with those of his own Pandu's son continued to strike him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्यैतदस्थिसंघातं मायाविनिहतस्य वै। इदं द्वितीयमपरं विष्णोः कर्म प्रकाशते॥
English Translation: Then aiming at Karna Kunti's discharged another favourite weapon of his powerful as the fire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नष्टा वसुमती कृत्स्ना पाताले चैव मज्जिता। पुनरुद्धरिता तेन वाराहेणैकङ्गिणा॥
English Translation: Karna, however, put out that fire with Varuna (watery) weapon. Suta's son covered all the directions with clouds created by his arrows and it appeared like a rainy day.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच भगवन् विस्तरेणेमां कथां कथय तत्त्वतः। कथं तेन सुरेशेन नष्टा वसुमती तदा॥ योजनानां शतं ब्रह्मन् पुनरुद्धरिता तदा। केन चैव प्रकारेण जगतोधरणीध्रुवा॥ शिवा देवी महाभागा सर्वसस्यप्ररोहिणी। कस्य चैव प्रभावाद्धि योजनानां शतं गता॥ केन तद् वीर्यसर्वस्वं दर्शितं परमात्मनः। एतत् सर्वं यथातत्त्वमिच्छामि द्विजसत्तम। श्रोतुं विस्तरशः सर्वं त्वं हि तस्य प्रतिश्रयः॥
English Translation: Then before the very presence of Karna, the powerful son of Pandu scattered those clouds with his Vayavya weapon.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: लोमश उवाच यत् तेऽहं परिपृष्टोऽस्मि कथामेतां युधिष्ठिर। तत् सर्वमखिलेनेह श्रूयतां मम भाषतः॥ पुरा कृतयुगे तात वर्तमाने भयंकरे। यमत्वं कारयामास आदिदेवः पुरातनः॥
English Translation: Then for killing the son of Pandu, the charioteer's son took up another dreadful arrows shining like the fire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यमत्वं कुर्वतस्तस्य देवदेवस्यधीमतः। न तत्र म्रियते कश्चिज्जायते वा तथाप्युत॥
English Translation: When that arrow was set on the bow-string, O king, the earth shook with her mountains, watery expanses and forests.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वर्धन्ते पक्षिसंघाश्च तथा पशुगवेडकम्। गवांश्वं च मृगाश्चैव सर्वे ते पिशिताशनाः॥
English Translation: Violent winds blew scattering pebbles. All the directions were covered with dust and cries of lamentation arose amongst the celestials in the sky.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथा पुरुषशार्दूल मानुषाश्च परंतप। सहस्रशो ह्ययुतशो वर्धन्ते सलिलं यथा।॥
English Translation: Seeing that arrows aimed by Karna, the Pandavas were worked with depression and sorrow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतस्मिन् संकुले तात वर्तमाने भयंकरे। अतिभाराद् बसुमती योजनानां शतं गता॥
English Translation: The keen arrows, effulgent like Shakra's thunder-bolt shot off Karna's hands, fell upon Dhananjaya's breast and went into it like a serpent penetrating an ant-hill.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सा वै व्यथतसर्वाङ्गी भारेणाक्रान्तचेतना। नारायणं वरं देवं प्रपन्ना शरणं गता॥
English Translation: Thus wounded that chastiser of enemies, the high-souled Vibhatsu began to reel. His grasp became loosened and his bow Gandiva, dropped off his hands. He shook there like the king of mountain in an earth-quake.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पृथिव्युवाच भगवंस्त्वत्प्रसादाद्धि तिष्ठेयं सुचिरं त्विह। भारेणास्मि समाक्रान्ता न शक्नोमि स्म वर्तिमुम्॥
English Translation: During this opportunity the great carwarrior Vrisha leaped down from his chariot to extricate the wheel that had been sunk underneath the earth. Holding it with his two hands he tried his best of get it out. But unfortunately for his bad luck he failed through he was possessed of great strength.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ममेमं भगवन् भारं व्यपनेतुं त्वमर्हसि। शरणागतास्मि ते देव प्रसादं कुरु मे विभो॥
English Translation: In the interval regaining his consciousness the diadem-decked and the high-souled Arjuna took his arrow Anjalika which was fatal as the rod of Death. Thereupon Krishna said to Partha-"Cut-off with this arrow the head of your enemy before he gets upon his car.”
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्यास्तद् वचनं श्रुत्वा भगवानक्षरः प्रभुः। प्रोवाच वचनं हृष्टः श्रव्याक्षरसमीरितम्॥
English Translation: Praising highly those words of Lord Krishna and while the wheel of his enemy was still under the earth the great car-warrior Arjuna took up a highly effulgent, razorheaded arrow and struck down Karna's standard bearing the emblem of an elephant and shining like the spotless sun.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विष्णुरुवाच न ते महि भयं कार्यं भारार्ते वसुधारिणि। अहमेवं तथा कुर्मि यथा लघ्वी भविष्यसि॥
English Translation: That standard bearing the elephant was decorated with gold, pearls, gems and diamonds and was made with great skill by the best of artizans. It was highly beautiful and made of pure gold.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: लोमश उवाच स तां विसर्जयित्वा तु वसुधां शैलकुण्डलाम्। ततो वराहः संवृत्त एकशृङ्गो महाद्युतिः॥
English Translation: That standard always used to inspire your soldiers with courage and fill your enemies with fear. Its form was highly praiseworthy. Known all over the world it was effulgent like the sun.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रक्ताभ्यां नयनाभ्यां तु भयमुत्पादयन्निव। धूमं च ज्वलयल्ल्क्ष्म्या तत्र देशे व्यवर्धत॥
English Translation: With that keen, gold-winged razor, headed arrow effulgent like fire, fed with libations of clarified butter the diadem-decked Arjuna cutoff that standard of Adhiratha's son, the great car-warrior.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स गृहीत्वा वसुमती शृङ्गेणेकेन भास्वता। योजनानां शतं वीर समुद्धरति सोऽक्षरः॥
English Translation: With that standard fell the glory, pride, hope of success and everything dear unto the hearts of the Kurus. And cries of lamentations arose in your army.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्यां चोद्धार्यमाणायां संक्षोभः समजायत। देवाः संक्षुभिताः सर्वे ऋषयश्च तपोधनाः॥ हाहाभूतमभूत् सर्वं त्रिदिवं व्योम भूस्तदा। न पर्य वस्थितः कश्चिद् देवो वा मानुषोऽपि वा॥
English Translation: Seeing that standard struck down by the light-handed Kuru hero your soldiers gave up all hopes of Karna's success.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो ब्राह्मणामासीनं ज्वलमानमिव श्रिया। देवाः सर्षिगणाश्चैव उपतस्थुरनेकशः॥
English Translation: Then wishing to kill Karna quickly Arjuna took out from his quiver an Anjlika arrow that was effulgent like Indra's thunder-bolt, Agni's rod or the thousand-rayed sun.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उपसर्प्य च देवेशं ब्रह्माणं लोकसाक्षिकम्। भूत्वा प्राञ्जलयः सर्वे वाक्यमुच्चारयंस्तदा।॥
English Translation: Capable of cutting to the quick, covered with flesh and blood, effulgent like the sun or fire, made of precious ingredients, straightcoursing, impetuous, destructive of men, horses and elephants it was three cubits and six feet in length. Powerful as the thousand-eyed Indra's thunder-bolt, irresistible as the night rangers, the trident or the discus it was highly terrible and capable of destroying all creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: लोकाः संक्षुभिताः सर्वे व्याकुलं च चराचरम्। समुद्राणां च संक्षोभस्त्रिदशेश प्रकाशते।॥
English Translation: Partha cheerfully took up that arrow which could not be withstood even by the celestials. This great weapon, capable of discomfiting the celestials and Asuras, was always adored by the son of Pandu.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सैषा वसुमती कृत्स्ना योजनानां शतं गता। किमेतद् किं प्रभावेण येनेदं व्याकुलं जगत्। आख्यातु नो भवाशीघ्रं विसंज्ञाः स्मेह सर्वशः॥
English Translation: Seeing that arrow taken up by Partha in battle, the entire universe trembled with its mobile and immobile creations. Beholding that arrow about to be discharged the Rishis cried aloud "Peace be to the universe.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्रह्मोवाच असुरेभ्यो भयं नास्ति युष्माकं कुत्रचित् क्वचित्। श्रूयतां यत्कृतेष्वेष संक्षोभो जायतेऽमराः॥
English Translation: The holder of the Gandiva then set that peerless arrows his bow united with another highly powerful weapon. Then drawing his Gandiva bow he said.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: योऽसौ सर्वत्रगः श्रीमानक्षरात्मा व्यवस्थितः। तस्य प्रभावात् संक्षोभस्त्रिदिवस्य प्रकाशते॥
English Translation: If I have ever practised penances, if I have ever respected my elders and listened to the counsels of well-wishers let this arrow be powerful enough to destroy the body and heart of my enemy. Let his sharp arrow, adored by me, slay my enemy Karna." Saying this Dhananjaya discharged the arrow for destroying Karna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यैषा वसुमती कृत्स्ना योजनानां शतं गता। समुद्धता पुनस्तेन विष्णुना परमात्मना।॥
English Translation: It was a terrific arrows, efficacious as a rite of the Atharvan of Angiras, effulgent and incapable of being borne by Death himself in battle. Desirous of slaying Karna Partha again cheerfully said-“May this arrow bring on my victory. May it, effulgent like the fire or sun, shot by me, dispatch Karna to the abode of Death.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्यामुद्धार्यमाणायां संक्षोभः समजायत। एवं भवन्तो जानन्तु छिद्यतां संशयश्च वः॥
English Translation: Saying this, Arjuna, adorned with crown and garlands, ever inimical towards Karna and desirous of killing him, struck his enemy with that best of arrows, effulgent like the sun of moon capable of giving victory.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: देवा ऊचुः क्व तद् भूतं वसुमती समुद्धरति हृष्टवत्। तं देशं भगवन् ब्रूहि तत्र यास्यामहे वयम्॥
English Translation: Discharged by that mighty heroic that arrow, effulgent like the sun, emblazoned all the quarters. With that arrow Arjuna struck off his enemy's head like Indra striking the head of Vritra with his thunder.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्रह्मोवाच हन्त गच्छत भद्रं वो नन्दने पश्यत स्थितम्। एषोऽत्र भगवाश्रीमान् सुपर्णः सम्प्रकाशते॥
English Translation: With that powerful Anjalika weapon inspired with mantras Indra's son cut-off the head of Vaikartana in the afternoon.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वाराहेणैव रूपेण भगवॉल्लोकभावनः। कालानल इवाभाति पृथिवीतलमुद्धरम्॥
English Translation: Thus sundered with Anjalika arrow Karna's trunk dropped down on earth. The head also of the commander of the Kuru army, effulgent like the risen, sun and the meridian sun of the autumn, dropped down on earth like the crimson sun falling down from the setting hill.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतस्योरसि सुव्यक्तं श्रीवत्समभिराजते। पश्यध्वं विबुधाः सर्वे भूतमेतदनामयम्॥
English Translation: The head of the illustrious Karna reluctantly left the body, highly beautiful and brought up in luxury like a person unwillingly leaving a big house filled with riches.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: लोमश उवाच ततो दृष्ट्वा महात्मानं श्रुत्वा चामन्त्र्य चामराः। पितामहं पुरस्कृत्य जग्मुर्देवा यथागतम्॥
English Translation: Cut-off with Arjuna's arrows and shorn of life the tall and shining body of Karna, with blood gushing out of every wound, looked like the summit of a red chalk mount clapped by a thunder-bolt with red streams running down after a shower. Then a light came out of Karna's body, passed though the sky and entered into the sun.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच श्रुत्वा तु तां कथां सर्वे पाण्डवा जनमेजय। लोमशादेशितेनाशु पथा जग्मुः प्रहृष्टवत्॥
English Translation: This wonderful spectacle was wiinessed by all the on-lookers after Karna's fall. Then seeing Karna slain by Phalguna the Pandavas blew their conchs.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शौनक उवाच यदपृच्छत्तदा राजा मन्त्रिणो जनमेजयः। पितुः स्वर्गगतिं तन्मे विस्तरेण पुनर्वद॥
English Translation: Likewise Krishna and Dhananjaya, overflowing with joy, blew their conchs. Seeing Karna slain and lying on the battle-field the Somakas were filled the joy and sent-up loud shouts with other soldiers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सौतिकवाच शृणु ब्रह्मन्यथापृच्छन्मन्त्रिणो नृपतिस्तदा। यथा चाख्यातवन्तस्ते निधनं तत्परीक्षितः॥
English Translation: With great joy the struck their trumphets and shook their arms and garments. Then, O king, approaching Partha, all the warriors began to praise him; other powerful heroes danced embracing each other; and others sending loud shouts said-"By good luck Karna has slain prostrate on earth wounded with arrows."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जनमेजय उवाच जानन्ति स्म भवन्तस्तद्यथा वृत्तं पितुर्मम। आसीद्यथा स निधनं गतः काले महायशाः॥
English Translation: Karna's head, separated off the body, looked like a mountain top loosened by a storm or like fire put out after the completion of a sacrifice, or the sun after it has risen the setting hill.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रुत्वा भवत्सकाशाद्धि पितुर्वृत्तमशेषतः। कल्याणं प्रतिपत्स्यामि विपरीतं न जातुचित्॥
English Translation: Karna's body filled with all parts arrow penetrated and soaked in blood was getting the grace of sun, the holder of beams and illuminated.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सौतिरुवाच मन्त्रिणोऽथाब्रुवन्वाक्यं पृष्टास्तेन महात्मना। सर्वे धर्मविदः प्राज्ञा राजानं जनमेजयम्॥
English Translation: After having scorched his enemy's army the Karna-like sun, having arrows for its rays, was caused to be set by Arjuna time.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मन्त्रिणः ऊचुः शृणु पार्थिव यद्भषे पितुस्तव महात्मनः। चरितं पार्थिवेन्द्रस्य यथा निष्ठां गतश्च सः॥
English Translation: As while moving towards the setting hill the sun withdraws all its rays so (Arjuna's) arrow passed of taking Karna's vital breaths.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धर्मात्मा च महात्मा च प्रजापाल: पिता तव। आसीदिह यथावृत्तः स महात्मा शृणुष्व तत्॥
English Translation: In the afternoon cut-off with Anjalika in battle the head of the charioteer's son dropped down earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चातुर्वर्यं स्वधर्मस्थं स कृत्वा पर्यरक्षत। धर्मतो धर्मविद्राजा धर्मो विग्रहवानिव॥
English Translation: Before the very presence of the Kaurava troops that weapon speedily took away Karna's head and body.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ररक्ष पृथिवीं देवीं श्रीमानतुलविक्रमः। द्वेष्टारस्तस्य नैवासन्स च द्वेष्टि न कंचन॥
English Translation: Beholding the brave Karna prostrated on earth wounded with shafts and bathed in blood the king of Madras left the battle field on the car deprived of the standard.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: समः सर्वेषु भूतेषु प्रजापतिरिवाभवत्। ब्राह्मणः क्षत्रिया वैश्याः शूद्राश्चैव स्वकर्मसु॥
English Translation: After Karna's fall the Kuru soldiers, wounded with arrows and filled with fear, took to their heels looking again and again on the lofty and shining standard of Arjuna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्थिताः सुमनसो राजंस्तेन राज्ञा स्वधिष्ठिताः। विधवानाथविकलान्कृपणांश्च बभार सः॥
English Translation: The beautiful head, having a countenance like a loutus of a thousand petals, of Karna, whose exploits like those of the thousand eyes Indra, drooped down on earth like the thousand-rayed sun in the end of day.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुदर्शः सर्वभूतानामासीत्सोम इवापरः। तुष्टपुष्टजनः श्रीमान्सत्यवाग्दृढविक्रमः॥
English Translation: Dhritarashtra said O Sanjaya, those heroic sovereigns who now returned to the charge, being headed by Vrikodara, were capable of crushing even the host of the celestials themselves.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धनुर्वेद तु शिष्योऽभून्नृपः शारद्वतस्य सः। गोविन्दस्य प्रियश्चासीत्पिता ते जनमेजय॥
English Translation: Led by Destiny, man surely engages in any action and it is through the decrees of Destiny that his various acts are attended with various results.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: लोकस्य चैव सर्वस्य प्रिय आसीन्महायशाः। परिक्षीणेषु कुरुषु सोत्तरायामजीजनत्॥
English Translation: That Yudhishthira, who wandered exiled in woods, for a long time, wearing matted locks and black deer-skin and who also had to wander incognito.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: परिक्षिदभवत्तेन सौभद्रस्यात्मजो बली। राजधर्मार्थकुशलो युक्तः सर्वगुणैर्वृतः॥
English Translation: Even that very Yudhishthira is now leading this mighty host in battle! What else but evil. can befall my son through this adverse influence of Destiny?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जितेन्द्रियश्चात्मवांश्च मेधावी धर्मसेविता। षड्वर्गजिन्महाबुद्धिर्नीतिशास्त्रविदुत्तमः॥
English Translation: Surely man is born subject to the decrees of Destiny; and so he is compelled by it to do what he does not at all desire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रजा इमास्तव पिता षष्टिवर्षाण्यपालयत्। ततो दिष्टान्तमापन्नः सर्वेषां दुःखमावहन्॥ ततस्त्वं पुरुषश्रेष्ठ धर्मेण प्रतिपेदिवान्। इदं वर्षसहस्राणि राज्यं कुरुकुलागतम्। बाल एवाभिषिक्तस्त्वं सर्वभूतानुपालकः॥
English Translation: Becoming addicted to the vice of gambling at dice, Yudhishthira reaped great affliction; but now through the agency of Destiny, he has again been united to his supporters.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जनमेजय उवाच नास्मिन्कुले जातु बभूव राजा यो न प्रजानां प्रियकृत्प्रियश्च। विशेषतः प्रेक्ष्य पितामहानां वृत्तं महद्वृत्तपरायणानाम्॥
English Translation: *Today the Kekayas are rallying to me; the Kausikas, the Kosalas, the Chedis, the Vangas and others are all betaking to me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कथं निधनमापन्नः पिता मम तथाविधः। आचक्षध्वं यथावन्मे श्रोतुमिच्छामि तत्त्वतः॥
English Translation: All this extensive earth has taken my side, O sire and not that of the sons of Pritha.' 0 Suta, these were the words that were spoken to ine by the wicked Duryodhana before.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सांतिरुवाच एवं संचोदिता राज्ञा मन्त्रिणस्ते नराधिपम्। ऊचुः सर्वे यथावृत्तं राज्ञः प्रियहितैषिणः॥
English Translation: Drona, guarded amidst this host of his warriors, as slain by the son of Prisata in battle; what can it be but there decree of Fate?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मन्त्रिणः ऊचुः स राजा पृथिवीपालः सर्वशस्त्रभृतां वरः। बभूव मृगयाशीलस्तव राजन् पिता सदा॥ यथा पाण्डुर्महाबाहुर्धनुर्धरवरो युधि। अस्मास्वासज्य सर्वाणि राजकार्याण्यशेषतः॥
English Translation: Amidst that royal host how could Death approach that mighty-armed Drona who ever delighted in battle and who was accomplished in the use of all sorts of weapons?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स कदाचिद्वनगतो मृगं विव्याध पत्रिणा। विद्धवा चान्वसरतूर्णं तं मृगं गहने वने॥
English Translation: I am plunged in distress and a swoon overwhelms me. Oh, I cannot live hearing both Bhishma and Drona slain.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पदातिबद्धनिस्त्रिंशस्ततायुधकलापवान्। न चाससाद गहने मृगं नष्टं पिता तव॥
English Translation: O Suta, that which the prophetic Khatva said to me, seeing me, infatuated with the affection for my son, O sire, everything of that has now overtaken me and Duryodhana himself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: परिश्रान्तो वयस्थश्च षष्टिवर्षो जरान्वितः। क्षुधितः स महारण्ये ददर्श मुनिसत्तमम्॥
English Translation: It would have been very cruel had I saved the rest of my progeny by abandoning Duryodhana, but then the rest could have lived.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तं पप्रच्छ राजेन्द्रो मुनि मौनव्रते स्थितम्। न च किंचिदुवाचेदं पृष्टोऽपि स मुनिस्तदा॥
English Translation: The monarch, that abandoning righteousness, pursues interest, is debarred from the enjoyment of felicity and imbibes meanness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो राजा क्षुच्छ्रमार्तस्तं मुनि स्थाणुवस्थितम्। मौनव्रतधरं शान्तं सद्यो मन्युवशंगतः॥
English Translation: O Sanjaya, today, when the hump of this kingdom has been crushed, I see that nothing will be left of it, as it has lost all energy (by the death of Drona).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न बुबोध च तं राजा मौनव्रतधरं मुनिम्। स तं क्रोधसमाविष्टो धर्षयामास ते पिता॥
English Translation: When those two foremost of men, viz. Bhishma and Drona of forgiving nature who used to be our primary support, when they both have been killed, how can any thing remain of this kingdom?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मृतं सर्प धनुष्कोट्या समुत्क्षिप्य धरातलात्। तस्य शुद्धात्मनः प्रादात्स्कन्धे भरतसत्तम॥
English Translation: Relate to me, in detail, as to how that battle raged: who were they that fought, who assaulted (the enemy) and what mean fellows fled, out of terror?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न चोवाच स मेधावी तमथो साध्वसाधु वा। तस्थौ तथैव चाक्रुद्धः सर्प स्कन्धेन धारयन्॥
English Translation: Tell me also what that foremost of carwarriors, namely, Dhananjaya, did? We are much afraid of him and of his brother, Vrikodara, who is our (implacable) enemy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच एवं दुर्योधने राजन् गर्जमाने मुहुर्मुहुः। युधिष्ठिरस्य संक्रुद्धो वासुदेवोऽब्रवीदिदम्॥
English Translation: Tell me, O Sanjaya, of the terrible collusion that took place between the Pandava hosts and the remnant of my army, when the former returned to the charge?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदि नाम ह्ययं युद्धे वरयेत् त्वां युधिष्ठिर। अर्जुनं नकुलं चैव सहदेवमथापि वा॥ किमिदं साहसं राजंस्त्वया व्याहृतमीदृशम्। एकमेव निहत्याजौ भव राजा कुरुष्विति॥
English Translation: What also, O sire, was the state of your mind when they returned to the attack. What heroes of our army with stood them on the field of battle?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न समर्थानहं मन्ये गदाहस्तस्य संयुगे। एतेन हि कृता योग्या वर्षाणीह त्रयोदश॥ आयसे पुरुषे राजन् भीमसेनजिघांसया।
English Translation: Narada said The son of Vinata, seeing Galava, said to him thus laughing. “It is by good luck that I see you successful here, O twice-born one".
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कथं नाम भवेत् कार्यमस्याभिर्भरतर्षभ॥ साहसं कृतवास्त्वं तु ह्यनुक्रोशानृपोत्तम।
English Translation: Galava too, hearing those words spoken by the son of Vinata, informed him that a fourth part of the work yet remained to be done.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नान्यमस्यानुपश्यामि प्रतियोद्धारमाहवे॥ ऋते वृकोदरात् पार्थात् स च नातिकृतश्रमः।
English Translation: Suparna, the foremost among speakers then said to Galava. “No pains should be taken by you for this for you will not get it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदिदं द्यूतमारब्धं पुनरेव यथा पुरा॥ विषमं शकुंनेश्चैव तव चैव विशाम्पते।
English Translation: In days of old, in Kanyakubja, Richika chose the damsel Satyavati, the daughter of Gadhi, for his wife and he was thus spoken to by Gadhi.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बली भीमः समर्थश्च कृती राजा सुयोधनः॥ बलवान् वा कृती वेति कृती राजन् विशिष्यते।
English Translation: You give me a thousand horses white as the moon and black of one ear.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सोऽयं राजंस्त्वया शत्रुः समे पथि निवेशितः॥ न्यस्तश्चात्मा सुविषमे कृच्छ्रमापादिता वयम्।
English Translation: Richika too saying “very-well” went to the abode of Varuna and from there obtaining the horses from the Ashvatirtha gave them to the ruler of the earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: को नु सर्वान विनिर्जित्य शत्रूनेकेन वैरिणा॥ कृच्छप्राप्तेन च तथा हारयेद् राज्यमागतम्।
English Translation: They were presented to the twice-born one by king Pundarika who performed a sacrificial ceremony; and of them, (the horses) the rulers of the earth (to whom you have applied) obtained two hundred each by purchase from the Brahmanas at the time.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पणित्वा चैकपाणेन रोचयेदेवमाहवम्॥ न हि पश्यामि तं लोके योऽद्य दुर्योधनं रणे।
English Translation: The other four hundred, O best among the twice-born while being led across (the Vitasta river) were robbed by the river.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गदाहस्तं विजेतुं वै शक्तः स्यादमरोऽपि हि॥ न त्वं भीमो न नकुलः सहदेवोऽथ फाल्गुनः। जेतुं न्यायेन शक्तोः वै कृती राजा सुयोधनः॥
English Translation: Such being the case, you will not beadle to obtain what is unobtainable by all means; present, therefore, this damsel as a substitute for the two hundred horses to him,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स कथं वदसे शत्रु युध्यस्व गदयेति हि। एकं च नो निहत्याजौ भव राजेति भारत॥
English Translation: Namely, Vishvamitra, O virtuous-souled one, along with the six hundred horses; then will you be beyond the reach of grief and your desire will be successful, o best among the twice the twice born."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वृकोदरं समासाद्य संशयो वै जये हि नः। न्यायतो युध्यमानानां कृती ह्येष महाबलः॥
English Translation: Galava then saying to him “very well” along with Suparna, taking the horses and the maiden with him, went to Vishvamitra and said.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एकं वास्मान् निहत्य त्वं भव राजेति वै पुनः। नूनं न राज्यभागेषा पाण्डोः कुन्त्याश्च संततिः॥ अत्यन्तवनवासाय सृष्टा भैक्ष्याय वा पुनः।
English Translation: Of the horses asked for by you there are six hundred here and this damsel is a substitute for the other two hundred. Let these be accepted by you.
On her by Rishis of royal descent three virtuous sons have been begotten; you too beget the fourth who will be the best among mankind.
Then will you get the full complement of eight hundred horses asked for by you and I too, after having paid off my debt, shall perform asceticism as I please.
Vishvamitra, seeing Galava along with the bird and also that girl with beautiful hips, said these words.
Why was not this girl presented to me beforehand, OGalava? Then would all the four sons have been mine, every one of whom would have perpetuated a dynasty.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीमसेन उवाच मधुसूदन मा कार्षीर्विषादं यदुनन्दन॥ अद्य पारं गमिष्यामि वैरस्य भृशदुर्गमम्।
English Translation: I shall accept this girl from you to beget on her one son and let the horses having been taken to my hermitage roam about at their will in all directions.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अहं सुयोधनं संख्ये हनिष्यामि न संशयः॥ विजयो वै ध्रुवः कृष्ण धर्मराजस्य दृश्यते।
English Translation: Vishvamitra, of great effulgence, then roaming and sporting with her, Madhvi brought forth a male child named Ashtaka.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अध्यर्धेन गुणेनेयं गदा गुरुतरी मम॥ न तथा धार्तराष्ट्रस्य मा कार्षीर्माधव व्यथाम्।
English Translation: At the moment he was born, the great Muni Vishvamitra instructed him in both virtue and worldly good and presented to him those horses.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अहमेनं हि गदया संयुगे योद्धमुत्सहे॥ भवन्तः प्रेक्षकाः सर्वे मम सन्तु जनार्दन।
English Translation: Then did Ashtaka go to the city which was like the city of the moon and the son of Kushika (Vishvamitra) too went to the woods after having returned the damsel to his disciple.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सामरानपि लोकांस्त्रीन् नानाशस्त्रधरान् युधि॥ योधयेयं रणे कृष्ण किमुताद्य सुयोधनम्।
English Translation: Galava too, along with Suparna, was light of heart having succeeded in making the final present he had promised, and said this to the girl.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच तथा सम्भाषमाणं तु वासुदेवों वृकोदरम्॥ हृष्टः सम्पूजयामास वचनं चेदमब्रवीत्। त्वामाश्रित्य महाबाहो धर्मराजो युधिष्ठिरः॥ निहतारिः स्वकां दीप्ता श्रियं प्राप्तो न संशयः।
English Translation: By you has been brought forth a son who is the foremost among the givers of wealth, a second one who is a great hero, another who is ever attached to virtue and another who is ever attached to virtue and truth and the fourth who is a great performer of sacrificial ceremonies.
Therefore do you come, O you of beautiful hips, your father has obtained salvation by your sons and also the four kings (their fathers) and so also have been I, O you of slender waist.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वया विनिहताः सर्वे धृतराष्ट्रसुता रणे॥ राजानो राजपुत्राश्च नागाश्च विनिपातिताः।
English Translation: Galava, then having permitted Suparna who subsisted on serpents to go away and returning the damsel to his father, went to the forest.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कलिङ्गा मागधाः प्राच्या गान्धाराः कुरवस्तथा॥ त्वामासाद्य महायुद्धे निहतः पाण्डुनन्दन।
English Translation: Dhritarashtra said “While Drona's son, that great car-warrior, thus proceeded towards the enemy's camp, did Kripa and Bhoja stop from fear.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हत्वा दुर्योधन चापि प्रयच्छोर्वी ससागराम्॥ धर्मराजाय कौन्तेय यथा विष्णुः शचीपतेः।
English Translation: I hope those two great car-warriors, stopped by mean guards, did not fly away secretly, considering their opponents irresistible.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वां च प्राप्य रणे पापो धार्तराष्ट्रो विनडक्ष्यति॥ त्वमस्य सक्थिनी भक्त्वा प्रतिज्ञा पालयिष्यसि।
English Translation: Or, have they, after despoiling the camp, the Somakas, and the Pandavas, followed, while still fighting, the highly illustrious path in which Duryodhana has gone.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्तु सात्यकी यत्नेन तु सदा पार्थ योद्धव्यो धृतराष्ट्रजः॥ कृती च बलवांश्चैव युद्धशौण्डश्च नित्यदा।
English Translation: Are those heroes, killed by the Panchalas, sleeping on the naked Earth? Did they perforin any feat? Tell me all this, O Sanjaya.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजन् पूजयामास पाण्डवम्॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said "When the great son of Drona proceeded towards the camp, Kripa and Kritavarman waited at the gate.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पञ्चालाः पाण्डवेयाश्च धर्मराजपुरोगमाः। तद् वचो भीमसेनस्य सर्व एवाभ्यपूजयन्॥
English Translation: Seeing them ready to work Ashvatthaman was overjoyed, and addressing them whisperingly, O king, said,-'If you two exert, you can exterminate all the Kshariyas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो भीमबलो भीमो युधिष्ठिरमथाब्रवीत्। संजयैः सह तिष्ठन्तं तपन्तमिव भास्करम्॥ अहमेतेन संगम्य संयुगे योद्धमुत्सहे। न हि शक्तो रणे जेतुं मामेष पुरुषाधमः॥
English Translation: What should I say, therefore, of this remnant of the (Pandava) ariny, particularly when it is asieep.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अद्य क्रोधं विमोक्ष्यामि निहितं हृदये भृशम्। सुयोधने धार्तराष्ट्रे खाण्डवेऽग्निमिवार्जुनः॥
English Translation: I shall enter the camp and move about like Yama. I am sure that you two will act in such a way that no man may escape alive.'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शल्यमद्योद्धरिष्यामि तव पाण्डव हृच्छयम्। निहत्य गदया पापमद्य राजन् सुखी भव॥
English Translation: Having said so, the son of Drona entered the extensive camp of the Parthas. Shorn of fear, he entered into it by a spot where there was no door.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अद्य कीर्तिमयीं माला प्रतिमोक्ष्ये तवानघ। प्राणाश्रियं च राज्यं च मोक्ष्यतेऽद्य सुयोधनः॥
English Translation: Having entered the camp the great hero proceeded, guided by sings, very softly towards Dhrishtadyumna's quarters.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजा च धृतराष्ट्रोऽद्य श्रुत्वा पुत्रं मया हतम्। स्मरिष्यत्यशुभं कर्म यत् तच्छकुनिबुद्धिजम्॥
English Translation: Having displayed great feats the Panchalas had been much exhausted in battle. They were sleeping confidently collected together, and by the side of one another.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्युक्त्वा भरतश्रेष्ठो गदामुद्यम्य वीर्यवान्। उदतिष्ठत युद्धाय शक्रो वृत्रमिवाह्वयन्॥
English Translation: Entering into Dhrishtadyumna's apartment, OBharata, Drona's son saw the prince of the Panchalas sleeping before him on his bed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदाह्वानममृष्यन् वै तव पुत्रोऽतिवीर्यवान्। प्रत्युपस्थित एवाशु मत्तो मत्तमिव द्विपम्॥
English Translation: He lay on a beautiful sheet of silk upon a rich and excellent bed. Excellent wreaths of flowers were scattered upon that bed and it was perfumed with the powder of incense.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गदाहस्त तव सुतं युद्धाय समुपस्थितम्। ददृशुः पाण्डवाः सर्वे कैलासमिव शृङ्गिणम्॥
English Translation: Having received a kick from Ashvatthaman the high-souled prince who was sleeping trustfully and fearlessly on his bed, awoke.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमेकाकिनमासाद्य धार्तराष्ट्र महाबलम्। वियूथमिव मातङ्गं समहष्यन्त पाण्डवाः॥
English Translation: Feeling that kick, the great prince,! irresistible in battle, got up and recognised Drona's son standing before him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न सम्भ्रमो न च भयं न च ग्लानिन च व्यथा। आसीद् दुर्योधनस्यापि स्थितः सिंह इवाहवे॥
English Translation: As he was rising from his bed, the great Ashvatthaman caught him by the hair of his ! head and began to press him down on the Earth with his hands.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: समुद्यतगदं दृष्ट्वा कैलासमिव शृङ्गिणम्। भीमसेनस्तदा राजन् दुर्योधनमथाब्रवीत्॥ राज्ञापि धृतराष्ट्रेण त्वया चास्मासु यत् कृतम्। स्मर तद् दृष्कृतं कर्म यद् भूतं वारणावते॥
English Translation: Thus pressed by Ashvatthaman with grea! force the prince, from fear as also from sleepiness, was not able to exert his might at that time.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्रौपदी च परिकिष्टा सभामध्ये रजस्वला। द्यूते यद् विजितो राजा शकुनेबुद्धिनिश्चयात्॥
English Translation: Striking him with his foot, O king, on both his throat and breast while his victim roared, Drona's son tried to kill him as if he were an animal.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यानि चान्यानि दुष्टात्मन् पापानि कृतवानसि। अनाग:सु च पार्थेषु तस्य पश्य महत् फलम्॥
English Translation: The Panchala prince tore Ashvatthaman with his nails and at last slowly said, — 'O preceptor's son, kill me with a weapon, do not delay. O best of men, let me, through you go to the blessed regions.'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वकृते निहतः शेते शरतल्पे महायशाः। गाङ्गेयो भरतश्रेष्ठः सर्वेषां नः पितामहः॥
English Translation: Having said this much, that slayer of foes, viz., the son of the Panchala king, assailed by that great hero, became silent.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हतो द्रोणश्च कर्णश्च हतः शल्यः प्रतापवान्। वैरस्त चादिकर्ताऽसौ शकुनिनिहतो रणे॥
English Translation: Hearing those indistinct sounds of his, Drona's son said,-'O wretch of your race, there is no region for those that kill their preceptor. For this, O wicked man, you do not deserve to be killed with any weapon.'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भ्रातरस्ते हताः शूराः पुत्राश्च सहसैनिकाः। राजानश्च हताः शूराः समरेष्वनिवर्तिनः॥
English Translation: While saying so, Ashvatthaman, worked up with rage, began to strike the vital parts of his victim with his heels, and killed his foe like a lion killing an infuriate elephant.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एते चान्ये च निहता बहवः क्षत्रियर्षभाः। प्रातिकामी तथा पापो द्रौपद्याः केशकृद्धतः॥
English Translation: At the cries of that hero, while he was being slain, his wives and guards that were in his tent all got up, O king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अवशिष्टस्त्वमेवैकः कुलमोऽधमपूरुषः। त्वामप्यद्य हनिष्यामि गदया नात्र संशयः॥
English Translation: Seeing some body crushing the prince with superhuman force, they took the assailant for a supernatural being, and, therefore, made no noise from fear.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अद्य तेऽहं रणे दर्पं सर्वं नाशयिता नृप। राज्याशां विपुला राजन् पाण्डवेषु च दुष्कृतम्॥
English Translation: Having sent him to Yamas abode by such means the greatly energetic, Ashvatthaman went out and getting upon his beautiful car waited there.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुर्योधन उवाच किं कत्थितेन बहुना युद्ध्यस्वाद्य मया सह। अद्य तेऽहं विनेष्यामि युद्धश्रद्धां वृकोदर॥
English Translation: Indeed, coming out of Dhrishtadyumna's camp, O king, Ashvatthaman made all the points of the horizon resound with his roars, and then proceeded on his car to other parts of the camp for killing his enemies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किं न पश्यमि मां पाप गदायुद्धे व्यवस्थितम्। हिमवच्छिखराकारां प्रगृह्य महतीं गदाम्॥
English Translation: After Drona's son, that great car-warrior, had gone away, the women and all the guards began to bewail.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गदिनं कोऽध मां पाप हन्तुमुत्सहते रिपुः। न्यायतो युद्ध्यमानश्च देवेष्वपि पुरन्दरः॥
English Translation: Secing their king killed, all the wives of Dhrishtady!mna, cried aloud sorrowfully.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मा वृथा गर्ज कौन्तेय शारदाभ्रमिवाजलम्। दर्शयस्व बलं युद्धे यावत् तत् तेऽद्य विद्यते॥
English Translation: Hearing their lamentations many powerful, Kshatriyas, awaking, put on their armour and came there for inquiring after the cause of their lamentations.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य तद् वचन् श्रुत्वा पाण्डवाः सहसंजयाः। सर्वे सम्पूजयामासुस्तद्वचो विजिगीषवः॥
English Translation: Terrified at seeing Ashvatthaman, those ladies in piteous tones asked the man to follow him without delay.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उन्मत्तमिव मातङ्गं तलशब्देन मानवाः। भूयः सहर्षयामासू राजन् दुर्योधनं नृपम्॥
English Translation: They said, we know not whether he is a Rakshasa or a human being. Having killed the Panchala king he wait there.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बृंहन्ति कुञ्जरास्तत्र हया द्वेषन्ति चासकृत्। शस्त्राणि सम्प्रदीप्यन्ते पाण्डवानां जयैषिणाम्॥
English Translation: Thereat those foremost of warriors suddenly surrounded Drona's son. The latter killed them ail the means of the Rudra weapon.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच धनंजयोत्सुकानां तु भ्रातृणां कृष्णया सह। श्रुत्वा वाक्यानि विमनाधर्मराजोऽप्यजायत्॥
English Translation: Having killed Dhrishtadyumna and all those followers of his, he saw Uttamaujas sleeping on his bed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथापश्यन्महात्मानं देवर्षि तत्र नारदम्। दीप्यमानं श्रिया ब्राह्मया हुतार्चिषमिवानलम्॥
English Translation: Attacking him with his foot on the throat and chest, Drona's son killed that great hero also while the latter suffered greatly.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमागतमभिप्रेक्ष्य भ्रातृभिः सहधर्मराट्। प्रत्युत्थाय यथान्यायं पूजां चक्रे महात्मने॥
English Translation: Coming up and taking his comrade for being slain by a Rakshasa, Yudhamanyu speedily struck Drona's son in the chest with a mace.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तैः परिवृतः श्रीमान् भ्रातृभिः कुरुसत्तमः। विबभावतिदीप्तौजा देवैरिव शतक्रतुः॥
English Translation: Rushing towards him, Ashvatthaman seized him and brought him down to the ground and killed him like an animal while the latter cried aloud.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथा च वेदान् सावित्री याज्ञसेनी तथा पतीन्। न जहौधर्मतः पार्थान् मेरुमर्कप्रभा यथा॥
English Translation: Having killed Yudhamanyu thus, that hero went against the other car-warriors of the king, who were all asleep.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रतिगृह्य च तां पूजां नारदो भगवानृषिः। आश्वासयद् धर्मसुतं युक्तरूपमिवानघ॥
English Translation: He killed those trembling heroes like animals in a sacrifice. Taking up his sword then, he killed many others.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उवाच च महात्मानंधर्मराज युधिष्ठिरम्। ब्रूहिधर्मभृतां श्रेष्ठ केनार्थः किं ददानि ते॥
English Translation: Proceeding along the various roads of the camp one after another, Ashvatthaman, an expert in the use of the sword, saw various Gulmas and killed no time the unarmed and tied warriors sleeping with them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथधर्मसुता राजा प्रणम्य भ्रातृभिः सह। उवाच प्राञ्जलिर्भूत्वा नारदं देवसम्मितम्॥
English Translation: With that excellent sword he cut off combatants and horses and elephants. bathed in blood, he appeared like dcah himself commissioned by them.
