Sanskrit Shloka: त्वयि तुष्टे महाभाग सर्वलोकाभिपूजिते। कृतमित्येव मन्येऽहं प्रसादात् तव सुव्रत॥
English Translation: Making his foes to tremble by the repeated blows of his sword, Ashvatthaman was covered with blood.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदि त्वहमनुग्राह्यो भ्रातृभिः सहितोऽनघ। संदेहं मे मुनिश्रेष्ठ तत्त्वतश्छेत्तुमर्हसि॥
English Translation: Covered as he was with blood, and holding a blazing sword, his form, as he moved about in battle, became exceedingly terrible and superhuman.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रदक्षिणां यः कुरुते पृथिवीं तीर्थतत्परः। किं फलं तस्य कात्स्येन तद्भवान् वक्तुमर्हति॥
English Translation: Those who got up from sleep, O Kuruhero, became stupefied with the loud noise they heard. Seeing Drona's son, they looked at each other's faces and trembled with fear.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नारद उवाच शृणु राजन्नवहितो यथा भीष्मेणधीमता। पुलस्त्यस्य सकाशाद् वै सर्वमेतदुपश्रुतम्॥
English Translation: Seeing the form of that crusher of foes, those Kshatriyas took him to be a Rakshasa and shut up their eyes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुरा भागीरथीतीरे भीष्मोधर्मभृतां वरः। पित्र्यं व्रतं समास्थाय न्यवसन्मुनिभिः सह॥ शुभे देशे तथा राजन् पुण्ये देवर्षिसेविते। गङ्गाद्वारे महाभाग देवगन्धर्वसेविते॥
English Translation: Of terrible form, he moved about in the camp like Yama himself, and at last saw the sons of Draupadi and the residue of the Somakas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स पितॄस्तर्पयामास देवांश्च परमद्युतिः। ऋषींश्च तर्पयामास विधिदृष्टेन कर्मणा॥
English Translation: Terrified by the noise, and learning that Dhrishtadyumna had been killed those great car-warriors, viz., the sons of Draupadi, armed with bows, shot arrows on Drona's son.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कस्यचित् त्वथ कालस्य जपन्नेव महायशाः। ददर्शाद्भुतसंकाशं पुलस्त्यमृषिसत्तमाम्॥
English Translation: Aroused by their noise the Prabhadrakas with Shikhandin at their head, began to strike the son of Drona with their arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तं दृष्ट्वोग्रतपसं दीप्यमानमिव श्रिया। प्रहर्षमतुलं लेभे विस्मयं परमं ययौ॥
English Translation: Seeing them cast their arrows on him, Drona's son uttered a loud roar and became desirous of killing those great car-warriors.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उपस्थितं महाभागं पूजयामास भारता भीष्मोधर्मभृतां श्रेष्ठो विधिदृष्टेन कर्मणा॥
English Translation: Remembering the death of his father, Ashvatthaman became furious with rage, getting down from his car, he made a desperate rush against his enemies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शिरसा चार्घ्यमादाय शुचिः प्रयतमानसः। नाम संकीर्तयामास तस्मिन् ब्रह्मर्षिसत्तमे॥
English Translation: Taking up his bright shield decked with a thousand moons and his massive and celestial sword decked with god, the great Ashvatthaman rushed against the sons of Draupadi.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्मोऽहमस्मि भद्रं ते दासोऽस्मि तव सुव्रत। तव संदर्शनादेव मुक्तोऽहं सर्वकिल्बिषैः॥
English Translation: Then that foremost of men, in that dreadful battle, struck Prativindhya in the abdomen at which the latter, O king, fell down lifeless on the Earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्त्वा महाराज भीष्मोधर्मभृतां परः। वाग्यतः प्राञ्जलिर्भूत्वा तृष्णीमासीद् युधिष्ठिर॥
English Translation: Having pierced the son of Drona with a lance, the brave Sutasoma rushed at him with his uplifted sword.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं दृष्ट्वा नियमेनाथ स्वाध्यायाम्नायकर्शितम्। भीष्मं कुरुकुलश्रेष्ठ मुनिः प्रीतमनाभवत्॥
English Translation: Ashvatthaman, however, cut off Sutasoma's hand holding the sword, and once more struck him on the back. Thereat Sutasoma dropped down dead.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गालव उवाच महावीर्यो महीपाल: काशीनामीश्वरः प्रभुः। दिवोदास इति ख्यातो भैमसेनिनराधिपः॥
English Translation: Taking up a car-wheel with his two hands, the brave Shatanika, the son of Nakula, violently struck Ashvatthaman on the breast.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्र गच्छावहे भद्रे शनैरागच्छ मा शुचः। धार्मिकः संयमे युक्तः सत्ये चैव जनेश्वरः॥
English Translation: The great Ashvatthaman violently assailed Shatanika after he had discharged that carwheel. Exceedingly agitated, Nakula's son dropped down upon the earth, upon which Drona's son severed his head from his body.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नारद उवाच तमुपागम्य स मुनिया॑यतस्तेन सत्कृतः। गालव: प्रसवस्यार्थं तं नृपं प्रत्यचोदयत्॥
English Translation: Then taking up a spiked bludgeon, Shrutakarman attacked Ashvatthaman. Furiously rushing at Drona's son, he struck him violently on the left part of his forehead.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दिवोदास उवाच श्रुतमेतन्मया पूर्वं किमुक्त्वा विस्तरं द्विज। काक्षितो हि मयैषोऽर्थः श्रुत्वैव द्विजसत्तम॥
English Translation: Ashvatthaman struck Shrutakarman with his excellent sword on the face. Senseless and his face disfigured, he dropped down dead on the Earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतच्च मे बहुमतं यदुत्सृज्य नराधिपान्। मामेवमुपयातोऽसि भावि चैतदसंशयम्॥
English Translation: At this noist, the heroic Shutakirti that great car-warrior, coming up made a downpour of arrows on Ashvatthaman.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स एव विभवोऽस्माकमश्वानामपि गालव। अहमेप्येकमेवास्यां जनयिष्यामि पार्थिवम्॥
English Translation: Counteracting those arrowy shower with his shield, Ashvatthaman sundered from his enemy's trunk his beautiful head bedecked with ear-rings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथेत्युक्त्वा द्विजश्रेष्ठः प्रादात् कन्यां महीपतेः। विधिपूर्वां च तां राजा कन्यां प्रतिगृहीतवान्॥
English Translation: the destroyer of Bhishma, viz., the great Shikhandin, with all the Prabhadrakas, assailed the hero from every side with various sorts of Weapors. Shikhandin struck Ashvatthaman with an arrow in the midst of his two eyebrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रेमे स तस्यां राजर्षिः प्रभावत्यां यथा रविः। स्वाहायां च यथा वह्निर्यथा शच्यां च वासवः॥
English Translation: Worked up with anger at this, the powerful son of Drona, approached Shikhandin and cut him in two parts with his sword.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथा चन्द्रश्च रोहिण्यां यथा धूमोर्णया यमः। वरुणश्च यथा गौर्यां यथा चा धनेश्वरः॥
English Translation: Having killed Shikhandin, Ashvatthaman, filled with rage, rushed furiously against the other Prabhadrakas. He proceeded also against the residue of Virata's force.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथा नारायणो लक्ष्यां जाह्रव्यां च यथोदधिः। यथा रुद्रश्च रुद्राण्यां यता वेद्यां पितामहः॥
English Translation: Gifted with great strength, Drona's son killed the sons, the grandsons, and the followers of Draupada, taking them out one after another.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अदृश्यन्त्यां च वासिष्ठो वसिष्ठश्चाक्षमालया। च्यवनश्च सुकन्यायां पुलस्त्यः संध्यया यथा॥
English Translation: An expert in the use of the sword, Ashvatthaman then, rushing against other warriors, cut them down with his sword.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अगस्त्यश्चापि वैद( सावित्र्यां सत्यवान् यथा। यथा भृगुः पुलोमायामदित्यां कश्यपो यथा।॥
English Translation: The warriors in the Pandava camp saw that embodiment as representing Death-night, of black visage, and having bloody mouth and bloody eyes, wearing crimson garlands and smeared with crimson unguents, clad in a single piece of red cloth, with a noose in hand, and resembling an elderly lady, singing a dreadful song, and standing erect before their eyes, and about to lead away men and horses and elephant all bound in a strong rope.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रेणुकायां यथाऽऽर्चीको हैमवत्यां च कौशिकः। बृहस्पतिश्च तारायां शुक्रश्च शतपर्वणा॥
English Translation: She appeared to take away various kinds of spirits, with disheveled hair and bound together in a chord, as also, O king, many powerful carwarriors divested of their weapons
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथा भूम्यां भूमिपतिसर्वश्यां च पुरूरवाः। ऋचीकः सत्यवत्यां च सरस्वत्यां यथा मनुः॥
English Translation: On previous days, ( sire the leading warriors, of the Pandava camp used to see in their dreams that figure carrying away the sleeping warriors and Drona's son striking them behind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शकुन्तलायां दुष्यन्तो धृत्यां धर्मश्च शाश्वतः। दमयन्त्यां नलश्चैव सत्यवत्यां च नारदः॥
English Translation: The Pandava soldiers dreamt that lady and Drona's son every night from the day when the battle between the Kurus and the Pandavas first began.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जरत्कारुर्जरत्कार्वां पुलस्त्यश्च प्रतीच्यया। मेनकायां यथोर्णायुस्तुम्बुस्श्चैव रम्भया॥
English Translation: Assailed before by Destiny, they were now struck by Drona's son who terrified them all with the dreadful cries.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वासुकिः शतशीर्षायां कुमार्यां च धनंजयः। वैदेह्यां च यथा रामो रुक्मिण्यां च जनार्दनः॥
English Translation: Assailed by Destiny, and remembering the spectacle they had dreamt, the brave warriors of the Pandavas camp, identified it with what they now saw.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथा तु रममाणस्य दिवोदासस्य भूपतेः। माधवी जनयामास पुत्रमेकं प्रतर्दनम्॥
English Translation: At the noise made, hundreds and thousands of Pandava bowmen in the camp awoke from their sleep.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथाजगाम भगवान् दिवोदासं स गालवः। समये समनुप्राप्ते वचनं चेदमब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: Ashvatthaman cut of the legs of some, and the hips of others, and cut some in their back, moving about like the Destroyer himself let loose by Time.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निर्यातयतु मे कन्यां भवांस्तिष्ठन्तु वाजिनः। यावदन्यत्र गच्छामि शुल्कार्थं पृथिवीपते॥
English Translation: The Earth, O lord, was soon strewn with human beings that were disfigured or trampled down by elephants and horses.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दिवोदासोऽथ धर्मात्मा समये गालवस्य ताम्। कन्यां निर्यातयामास स्थितः सत्ये महीपतिः॥
English Translation: Many of them loudly cried-What is this?-Who is this one!-What is this noise?-Who is doing what?-While crying thus Drona's son killed them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बृहन्नलोवाच यन्मां पूर्वमिहापृच्छः शत्रुसेनापहारिणम्। गाण्डीवमेतत् पार्थस्य लोकेषु विदितं धनुः॥
English Translation: That best of strikers, viz., the son of Drona, sent to the abode of Yama all those Pandus and Srinjayas who were deprived of armour and weapons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वायुधमहामात्रं शातकुम्भपरिष्कृतम्। एतत् तदर्जुनस्यासीद् गाण्डीवं परमायुधम्॥
English Translation: Terrified at that noise many got up from sleep. Stricken with fear, and beside themselves with sleep, those warriors seemed to disappear before the fury of Ashvatthaman.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यत् तच्छतसहस्रेण सम्मितं राष्ट्रवर्द्धनम्। येन देवान् मनुष्यांश्च पार्थो विजयते मृधे॥
English Translation: The thighs of many were paralysed and some were so stupefied that they lost their। energy. Crying and stricken with fear, they : began to kill on another.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चित्रमुच्चावचैवर्णैः श्लक्ष्णमायतमव्रणम्। देवदानवगन्धर्वैः पूजितं शाश्वतीः समाः॥
English Translation: Drona's son once more mounted his car, and taking up his bow sent many with his arrows to Yama's abode.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतद् वर्षसहस्रं तु ब्रह्मा पूर्वमधारयत्। ततोऽनन्तरमेवाथ प्रजापतिरधारयत्॥ त्रीणि पञ्चशतं चैव शक्रोऽशीति च पञ्च च। सोमः पञ्चशतं राजा तथैव वरुणः शतम्।
English Translation: Other brave warriors and foremost of men, that got up from sleep, as they came towards Ashvatthaman, were killed before they could approach him and were thus given as victims to that Death-night.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पार्थः पञ्च च षष्टिं च वर्षाणि श्वेतवाहनः॥ महावीर्यं महादिव्यमेतत् तद् धनुरुत्तमम्।
English Translation: Crushing many with that best of cars, he moved through the encampment, and enshrouded his foes with repeated showers of arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतत् पार्थमनुप्राप्तं वरुणाच्चारुदर्शनम्॥ पूजितं सुरमत्र्येषु बिभर्ति परमं वपुः।
English Translation: Again with that beautiful shield of his, bedecked with a hundred moons, and with that sky-colored sword of his, he moved about amidst his enemics.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुपार्श्व भीमसेनस्य जातरूपग्रहं धनुः। येन पार्थोऽजयत् कृत्स्नां दिशं प्राची परंतपः॥
English Translation: Like an elephant agitating a large lake, Drona's son who cannot be checked in battle, agitated the camp of the Pandavas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इन्द्रगोपकचित्रं च यदेतच्चारुदर्शनम्। राज्ञो युधिष्ठिरस्यैतद् वैराटे धनुरुत्तमम्॥
English Translation: Awaked by the noise, O king, many warriors, still possessed by sleep and fear ran hither and thither.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सूर्या यस्मिंस्तु सौवर्णाः प्रकाशन्ते प्रकाशिनः। तेजसा प्रज्वलन्तो वै नकुलस्यैतदायुधम्॥
English Translation: Many cried and many uttered unmeaning jargon. Many could not secure their weapons and armour.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शलभा यत्र सौवर्णास्तपनीय विचित्रिताः। एतन्माद्रीसुतस्यापि सहदेवस्य कार्मुकम्॥
English Translation: The hairs of many were disheveled, and many could not recognise one another. Having got up from sleep, many fell down, fatigued; some walked purposely here and there.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ये त्विमे क्षुरसंकाशाः सहस्रा लोमवाहिनः। एतेऽर्जुनस्य वैराटे शराः सर्पविषोपमाः॥
English Translation: Breaking their chords, elephants and horses passed excreta and urine.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एते ज्वलन्तः संग्रामे तेजसा शीघ्रगामिनः। भवन्ति वीरस्याक्षय्या व्यूहतः समरे रिपून्।॥
English Translation: Many huddled together, set up a great confusion, some stricken with fear, prostrated themselves on the Earth. The animals of the camp crushed them there.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ये चेमे पृथवो दीर्घाश्चन्द्रबिम्बार्धदर्शनाः। एते भीमस्य निशिता रिपुक्षयकराः शराः॥
English Translation: While the camp was in this state of confusion, Rakshasas, O king, cried aloud in joy, O Bharata-chief.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हारिद्रवर्णा ये त्वेते हेमपुङ्खाः शिलाशिताः। नकुलस्य कलापोऽयं पञ्चशार्दूललक्षणः॥
English Translation: That loud noise, O king, of the ghostly beings, filled all the points of the horizon and the sky.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: येनासौ व्यजयत् कृत्स्ना प्रतीची दिशमाहवे। कलापो ह्येष तस्यासीन्माद्रीपुत्रस्य धीमतः॥
English Translation: Hearing the piteous cried of elephants, horses, breaking their chords, rushed hither and thither, crushing the warriors in the camp.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ये त्विमे भास्कराकाराः सर्वपारसवाः शराः। एते चित्रक्रियोपेताः : सहदेवस्य धीमतः॥
English Translation: As those animals rushed here and there, the dust raised by them made the night doubly dark.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ये त्विमे निशिताः पीताः पृथवो दीघवाससः। हेमपुङ्खास्त्रिपर्वाणो राज्ञ एते महाशराः॥
English Translation: When that thick darkness set in, the warriors in the camp became perfectly bewildered; fathers recognised not their sons, brothers recognised not their brothers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यस्त्वयं सायको दीर्घः शिलीपृष्ठः शिलीमुखः। अर्जुनस्यैष संग्रामे गुरुभारसहो दृढः॥
English Translation: Elephants, striking riderless elephants, and horses, striking riderless horses, assailed and broke and crushed the people that stood in their way.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैयाघ्रकोशः सुमहान् भीमसेनस्य सायकः। गुरुभारसहो दिव्यः शात्रवाणां भयंकरः॥
English Translation: Confused combatants rushed and killed one another, and felling those that stood in their way crushed them into pieces.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुफलचित्रकोशश्च हेमत्सरुरनुत्तमः। निस्त्रिंशः कौरवस्यैष धर्मराजस्य धीमतः॥
English Translation: Senseless and overcome with sleep, and covered with darkness, men, urged on by fate, killed their own comrades.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यस्तु पाञ्चनखे कोशे निहिताश्चित्रयोधने। नकुलस्यैष निस्त्रिंशो गुरुभारसहो दृढः॥
English Translation: The guards, living the gates in their charge, and those at duty at the outposts leaving their posts, fled away for their lives, senseless, and not knowing where they proceeded.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यस्त्वयं विपुलः खड्गो गव्ये कोशे समर्पितः सहदेवस्य विद्ध्येनं सर्वभारसहं दृढम्॥
English Translation: They killed one another, the slayers, O lord, not recognising the killed. Assailed by fate, they cried after their fathers and sons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जनमेजय उवाच उत्तङ्कस्य वरं दत्त्वा गोविन्दो द्विजसत्तम। अत ऊर्ध्वं महाबाहुः किं चकार महायशाः॥
English Translation: While they fled, leaving behind their friends and relatives, they called upon one another, mentioning their families and names.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच उत्तङ्कस्य वरं दत्त्वा प्रायात् सात्यकिना सह। द्वारकामेव गोविन्दः शीघ्रवेगैर्महाहयैः॥
English Translation: Uttering cries of lamentation others dropped down on the Earth. In the thick of the battle Drona's son, recognising them, killed them all.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सरांसि सरितश्चैव वनानि च गिरीस्तथा। अतिक्रम्याससादाथ रम्यां द्वारवतीं पुरीम्॥
English Translation: While being killed, other Kshatriyas lost their senses, and, stricken with fear, tried to fly away from the camps.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वर्तमाने महाराज महे रैवतकस्य च। उपायात् पुण्डरीकाक्षो युयुधानानुपस्तदा॥
English Translation: Those men that tried to fly away from the camp for saving their lives wee killed by Kritavarman and Kripa at the gate.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अलंकृतस्तु स गिरि नारूपैर्विचित्रितैः। बभौ रत्नमयैः कोशैः संवृतः पुरुषर्षभ॥
English Translation: Having no weapons, instruments and armour, and with disheveled hair, they clasped their hands. Trembling with fear, they stood on the ground, The two Kuru-warriors. however, (who were on their cars) gave none an opportunity.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: काञ्चनस्रग्भिरग्र्याभिः सुमनोभिस्तथैव च। वासोभिश्च महाशैलः कल्पवृक्षैस्तथैव च॥ दीपवृक्षैश्च सौवर्णैरभीक्ष्णमुपशोभितः। गुहानिर्झरदेशेषु दिवाभूतो बभूव ह॥
English Translation: None amongst those that escaped from the camp was allowed to go by those two wicked persons, viz., Kripa and Kritavarman.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पताकाभिर्विचित्राभिः सघण्टाभिः समन्ततः। पुम्भिः स्त्रीभिश्च संघुष्टः प्रगीत इव चाभवत्॥
English Translation: Then again for pleasing Drona's son, those two set fire to the Pandava camp in three places.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अतीव प्रेक्षणीयोऽभून्मेरुर्मुनिगणैरिव। मत्तानां हृष्टरूपाणां स्त्रीणां पुंसां च भारत॥ गायतां पर्वतेन्द्रस्य दिवस्पृगिव निःस्वनः। प्रमत्तमत्त सम्मत्तक्ष्वेडितोत्क्रुष्टसंकुलः॥
English Translation: When the camp was lighted, Ashvatthaman, O king, moved about sword in hand, and crushing his foes with great skill.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथा किलकिलाशब्दैर्भूधरोऽभून्मनोहरः। विपणापणवान् रम्यो भक्ष्यभोज्यविहारवान्॥
English Translation: Some of his brave enemies rushed furiously towards him and some ran here and there. That foremost of men, with his sword, deprived all of them of their lives.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वस्त्रमाल्योत्करयुतो वीणावेणुमृदङ्गवान्। सुरामैरैयमिश्रेण भक्ष्यभोज्येन चैव ह॥
English Translation: Filled with rage the brave son of Drona, struck down some of the warriors, cutting them in two with his sword like sesame stalks.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दीनान्धकृपणादिभ्यो दीयमानेन चानिशम्। बभौ परमकल्याणो महस्तस्य महागिरेः॥
English Translation: The Earth, O Chief of Bharata was covered with the bodies of foremost of men, and horses and elephants huddled together and bewailing.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुण्यावसथवान् वीर पुण्यकृद्भिर्निषेवितः। विहारो वृष्णिवीराणां महे रैवतकस्य ह॥
English Translation: When thousands of men had fallen down lifeless, numberless headless trunks stood up and fell down.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स नगो वेश्मसंकीर्णो देवलोक इवाबभौ। तदा च कृष्ण सांनिध्यमासाद्य भरतर्षभ॥ शक्रसद्मप्रतीकाशो बभूव स हि शैलराट्। ततः सम्पूज्यमानः स विवेश भवनं शुभम्॥ गोविन्दः सात्यकिश्चैव जगाम भवनं स्वकम्। विवेश च प्रहृष्टात्मा चिरकालप्रवासतः॥ कृत्वा नसुकरं कर्म दानवेष्विव वासवः। उपायान्तं तु वार्ष्णेयं भोजवृष्ण्यन्धकास्तथा।॥ अभ्यगच्छन् महात्मानं देवा इव शतक्रतुम्।
English Translation: Ashvatthaman, O Bharata, cut off arms, adorned with armlets and holding weapons, and heads, and things resembling trunks of elephants, and hands, and feet.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तानभ्यर्च्य मेधावी पृष्ट्वा च कुशलं तदा। अभ्यवादयत प्रीतः पितरं मातरं तदा॥
English Translation: The great son of Drona wounded the backs of some, cut off the heads of some, and caused some to retreat from the fight.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ताभ्यां स सम्परिष्वक्तः सान्त्वितश्च महाभुजः। उपोपविष्टैः सर्वैस्तैर्वृष्णिभिः परिवारितः॥
English Translation: He cut off some at the middle, and cut off the ears of others, and struck others on the shoulders, and pressed down the heads of some into their trunks.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स विश्रान्तो महातेजाः कृतपादावनेजनः। कथयामास तत्सर्वं पृष्टः पित्रा महाहवम्॥
English Translation: As Ashvatthaman moved about in this way killing thousands of men, the deep night became more dreadful for the darkness that set in.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच ततो दुर्योधनो राजा सर्वाः प्रकृतयः शनैः। अर्थमानप्रदानाभ्यां संजहार सहानुजः॥ धृतराष्ट्रप्रयुक्तास्ते केचित् कुशलमन्त्रिणः। कथयांचक्रिरे रम्यं नगरं वारणावतम्॥ अयं समाजः सुमहान् रमणीयतमो भुवि। उपस्थितः पशुपतेनगरे वारणावते॥
English Translation: The Earth became terrible to look at, covered with thousands of human beings, dead and dying, and numberless horses and elephants.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वरत्नसमाकीर्णे पुंसां देशे मनोरमे। इत्येवं धृतराष्ट्रस्य वचनाच्चक्रिरे कथाः॥
English Translation: Severed by the angry son of Drona, his enemies dropped down on the Earth that was then covered with Yakshas and Rakshasas and rendered frightful with (broken) cars and killed horses and elephants.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कथ्यमाने तथा रम्ये नगरे वारणावते। गमने पाण्डुपुत्राणां जज्ञे तत्र मतिर्नुप॥
English Translation: Some called upon their brothers, and some upon their fathers and some upon their sons. And some said'The son of Dhritarastra in anger could never perform such acts in battle as these which wicked Rakshasas have done during the hour of our sleep! It is only for the absence of the Parthas that this great destruction is going on!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदा त्वमन्यत नृपो जातकौतूहला इति। उवाचैतानेत्य तदा पाण्डवानम्बिकासुतः॥
English Translation: That son of Kunti who and Janarddana for his protector, is incapable of being defeated even by celestials. Asuras, Gandharvas. Yakshas, and Rakshasas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ममैते पुरुषा नित्यं कथयन्ति पुनः पुनः। रमणीयतमं लोके नगरं वारणावतम्॥
English Translation: Devoted to Brahma, truthful in speech, selfcontrolled, and kind to all creatures, that son of Pritha, called Dhananjaya never killed one who is asieep, or one who is careless, or one who has thrown off his weapons, or one who joins his hands for protection, or one who is retreating, or one whose hairs have been disheveled.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते ताता यदि मन्यध्वमुत्सवं वारणावते। सगणाः सान्वयाश्चैव विहरध्वं यथामराः॥
English Translation: Alas, they are wicked Rakshasas, who are perpetrating such terrible acts upon ourselves!'-Saying so, many laid themselves down.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणेभ्यश्च रत्नानि गायकेभ्यश्च सर्वशः। प्रयच्छध्वं यथाकामं देवा इव सुवर्चसः॥ कंचित् कालं विहृत्यैवमनुभूय परां मुदम्। इदं वै हास्तिनपुरं सुखिनः पुनरेष्यत॥
English Translation: The loud sound caused by the cries and groans of men stopped within a short time.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच धृतराष्ट्रस्य तं काममनुबुध्य युधिष्ठिरः। आत्मनश्चासहायत्वं तथेति प्रत्युवाच तम्॥
English Translation: The earth being drenched with blood, O king, that thick and dreadful dust soon disappeared.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो भीष्मं शान्तनवं विदुरं च महामतिम्। द्रोणं च बाह्निकं चैव सोमदत्तं च कौरवम्॥ कृपमाचार्यपुत्रं च भूरिश्रवसमेव च। मान्यानन्यानमात्यांश्च ब्राह्मणांश्च तपोधनान्॥ पुरोहितांश्च पौरांश्च गान्धारी च यशस्विनीम्। युधिष्ठिरः शनैर्दीन उवाचेदं वचस्तदा॥
English Translation: Thousands of men who were writhing in agnoy, stricken with anxiety, and filled with despair were killed by Ashvatthaman like Rudra killing living animals.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रमणीये जनाकीर्णे नगरे वारणावते। सगणास्तत्र यास्यामो धृतराष्ट्रस्य शासनात्॥
English Translation: Many who laid themselves down on the ground clasping one another, and many who tried to fly away, and many who tried to hide themselves, and many who fought, were all killed by the son of Drona.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रसन्नमनसः सर्वे पुण्या वाचो विमुञ्चत। आशीभिबृंहितानस्मान् न पापं प्रसहिष्यते॥
English Translation: Burnt by fire and killed by Ashvatthaman, the men, beside themselves, killed one another.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्तास्तु ते सर्वे पाण्डुपुत्रेण कौरवाः। प्रसन्नवदना भूत्वा तेऽन्ववर्तन्त पाण्डवान्॥ स्वस्त्यस्तु वः पथि सदा भूतेभ्यश्चैव सर्वशः। मा च वोऽस्त्वशुभं किंचित् सर्वशः पाण्डुनन्दनाः।१८।
English Translation: Before half the night was over, the son of Drona, O king, killed the large army of the Pandavas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः कृतस्वस्त्ययना राज्यलम्भाय पार्थिवाः। कृत्वा सर्वाणि कार्याणि प्रययुर्वारणावतम्॥
English Translation: That night, so terrible and destructive of men and elephants and horses filled with joy all creatures and range in darkness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नारद उवाच बन्धुत्वादथवा सख्याच्छाल्मले नात्र संशयः। पालयत्येव सततं भीमः सर्वत्रगोऽनिलः॥
English Translation: Many Rakshasas and Pishachas were secn there, eating human flesh and drinking the blood.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न्यग्भावं परमं वायोः शाल्मले त्वमुपागतः। तवाहमस्मीति सदा येन रक्षति मारुतः॥
English Translation: They dreadful, twany-colored, terrible, of adamantine teeth, and covered with blood. With matted locks on their heads, their thighs were long and massive; they had five fect, their stomachs were huge. were
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न तं पश्याम्यहं वृक्षं पर्वतं वेश्म चेदृशम्। यं न वायुबलाद् भग्नं पृथिव्यामिति मे मतिः॥
English Translation: Their fingers were set backwards. They had harsh temper and ugly features, and their voice was loud and terrible. They had rows of tinkling bells tied to their persons. They had blue throats, they looked very frightful.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वं पुनः कारणैनं रक्ष्यसे शाल्मले यथा। वायुना सपरीवारस्तेन तिष्ठस्यसंशयम्॥
English Translation: High cruel and incapable of being looked at without fear, and hating nothing, they came there with their children and wives. Rakshasas of various forms that came there.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शाल्मलिरुवाच न मे वायुः सखा ब्रह्मन्न बन्धुर्न च सुहृत्। परमेष्ठी तथा नैव येन रक्षति वानिलः॥ मे
English Translation: Drinking the blood that flowed in streams, they were filled with joy and began to dance in separate parties. This is excellent!-This is pure! This is very sweet!'-these were the words they gave expression to.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मम तेजो बलं भीमं वायोरपि हि नारद। कलामष्टादशी प्राणैर्न मे प्राप्नोति मारुतः॥
English Translation: Having lived upon fat, marrow, bones and blood, other carnivorous creatures, began toe act the delicate parts of corpses. Others, drinking the fat that ran in streams, ran about naked over the field. Tens of thousands and millions of other carnivorous beings having different faces of great ferocity, and living upon dead flesh, came there. Grim and gigantic Rakshasas came there in numerous bands. Other ghostly creatures overjoyed with eating enough also came there in that dreadful carnage.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आगच्छन् परुषो वायुर्मया विष्टम्भितो बलात्। भञ्जन् दुमान् पर्वतांश्च यच्चान्यदपि किंचन॥
English Translation: When morning came, Ashvatthaman wanted to leave the camp. He was then covered with human blood, and he held of sword so firmly that his hand and sword, O Fing, becaine one.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स मया बहुशो भग्नः प्रभञ्जन् वै प्रभञ्जनः। तस्मान्न बिभ्ये देवर्षे क्रुद्धादपि समीरणात्॥
English Translation: Having walked in the path of wicked warriors, Ashvatthaman, after that destruction, looked like the blazing fire at the end of the cycle, reducing all creatures to ashes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नारद उवाच शाल्मले विपरीतं ते दर्शनं नात्र संशयः। न हि वायोर्बलेनास्ति भूतं तुल्यबलं क्वचित्॥
English Translation: Having perpetrated that massacre according to his promise, and having trodden that untrodden way, Drona's son, O king, forgot his sorrow for the death of his father.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इन्द्रो यमो वैश्रवणो वरुणश्च जलेश्वरः। नैतेऽपि तुल्या मरुतः किं पुनस्त्वं वनस्पते॥
English Translation: The Pandavas camp, was perfectly calm when Drona's son had entered it in the night, because all the inmates were asleep. After the slaughter of the night, when all became once more quit, Ashvatthaman came out from it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यच्च किंचिदिह प्राणी चेष्टते शाल्मले भुवि। सर्वत्र भगवान् वायुश्चेष्टाप्राणकरः प्रभुः॥
English Translation: Having come out of thc encampinent, the brave Ashvatthaman met his two companions and, filled with joy, communicated to them his achievement gladdening them, O king, by the news.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एष चेश्यते सम्यक् प्राणिनः सम्यगायतः। असम्यगायतो भूयश्चेष्टते विकृतं नृषु॥
English Translation: Those two, in return, who always sought his good, gave him the pleasant news of how they also had killed thousands of Panchalas and Srinjayas at the gates.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स त्वमेवंविधं वायुं सर्वसत्त्वभृतां वरम्। न पूजयसि पूज्यं तं किमन्यद् बुद्धिलाघवात्॥
English Translation: Thus did that night bring on the destruction of the Somakas who were carelessly sunk in sleep.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: असारश्चापि दुर्मेधाः केवलं बहु भाषसे। क्रोधादिभिरवच्छन्नो मिथ्या वदसि शाल्मले॥
English Translation: The course of time, forsooth, is irresistible. Those who had rooted us out were themselves exterminated now."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मम रोषः समुत्पन्नस्त्वय्येवं सम्प्रभाषति। ब्रवीम्येष स्वयं वायोस्तव दुर्भाषितं बहु॥
English Translation: Dhritarashtra said “Why is it that great car-warriors, viz., the son of Drona, did not perform such an act before, although he had tried his best for conferring victory upon Duryodhana?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चन्दनैः स्यन्दनैः शालैः सरलैर्देवदारुभिः। वेतसैर्धन्वनैश्चापि ये चान्ये बलवत्तराः॥
English Translation: Why did that bowmen do this after the death of the wretched Duryodhana? You should tell me all this!"
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तैश्चापि नैवं दुर्बुद्धे क्षिप्तो वायुः कृतात्मभिः। तेऽपि जानन्ति वायोश्च बलमात्मन एव च॥ तस्मात् तं वै नमस्यन्ति श्वसनं तरुसत्तमाः।
English Translation: Sanjaya said "Through fear of the Parthas, O descendant of Kuru, Ashvatthaman could not perform such a fear then! It was for the absence of the Partha and the intelligent Keshava as also of Satyaki, that Drona's son could achieve it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वं तु मोहान्न जानीषे वायोर्बलमनन्तकम्। एवं तस्माद् गमिष्यामि सकाशं मातरिश्वनः॥
English Translation: Who is there, not even excluding the lord Indra, that can kill them before these heroes? Besides, O king Ashvatthaman could achieve this only because the men were all asleep.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच प्रविशन्तं महाराज सूतास्तुष्टुवुरच्युतम्। जनाश्चापि महेष्वासं तुष्टुवू राजसत्तम॥
English Translation: Having caused that great destruction of the Pandava forces, those three great car-warriors, viz., Ashvatthaman and Kripa and Kritavarman, meeting together, said, — 'Good luck,'—His two companions congratulated Ashvatthaman, and embraced him. Joyfully the latter said:-'All the Panchalas, as also all the sons of Draupadi, have been killed. All the Somakas and that remnant of the Matsyas, have been killed by me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: लाजैश्चन्दनचूर्णैश्च विकीर्य च जनास्ततः। ऊचुर्दिष्ट्या नृपाविघ्नः समाप्तोऽयं क्रतुस्तव॥
English Translation: Crowned with success, let up soon go there where the king is! If the king be still alive, we will communicate to him this joyful news.'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपरे त्वब्रुवंस्तत्र वातिकास्तं महीपतिम्। युधिष्ठिरस्य यज्ञेन न समो ह्येष ते क्रतुः॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said 0 grandfather, learmed men praise truth, self-control, forgiveness and wisdom. What is your opinion about these virtues?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नैव तस्य क्रतोरेष कलामर्हति षोडशीम्। एवं तत्रानुवन् केचिद् वातिकास्तं जनेश्वरम्॥
English Translation: Bhishma said Regarding it I shall recite to you an old narrative, O Yudhishthira, of the discourse between the Sadhyas and a Swan.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुहृदस्त्वब्रुवंस्तत्र अति सर्वानयं क्रतुः। ययातिनहुषश्चापि मान्धाता भरतस्तथा॥ क्रतुमेनं समाहत्य पूताः सर्वे दिवं गताः।
English Translation: Once on a time the uncreate and eternal Lord of all creatures, assuming the form of a golden Swan, passed through the three worlds till in course of his ramblings he came upon the Sadhyas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एता वाचः शुभाः शृण्वन् सुहृदां भरतर्षभ॥ प्रविवेश पुरं हृष्टः स्ववेश्म च नराधिपः।
English Translation: The Saddhyas said 0 lord, we are the gods called Sadhyas. We like to question you. Indeed, we would ask you about the religion of liberation. You are well acquainted with it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभिवाद्य ततः पादौ मातापित्रोविशाम्पते।॥ भीष्मद्रोणकृपादीनां विदुरस्य च धीमतः। अभिवादितः कनीयोभिर्धातृभिर्धातनन्दनः॥
English Translation: We have heard, O bird, that you are endued with great learning, and eloquent and wise of speech. O bird, what do you think is the highest of all objects? O great one, in what does your mind find pleasure?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निषसादासने मुख्य भ्रातृभिः परिवारितः। तमुत्थाय पहाराजं सूतपुत्रोऽब्रवीद् वचः॥
English Translation: Do you, therefore, O foremost of birds, instruct us as to what that one act is which you consider as the foremost of all acts, and by doing which, O king of birds, one may soon be freed from all fetters.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दिष्ट्या ते भरतश्रेष्ठ समाप्तोऽयं महाक्रतुः। हतेषु युधि पार्थेषु राजसूये तथा त्वया॥ आहतेऽहं नरश्रेष्ठ त्वां सभाजयिता पुनः।
English Translation: The Swan said O nectar-drinking ones, I have heard that one should follow these, viz., penances, selfcontrol, truth, and subjugation of the mind. Losing all the knots of the heart, one should also bring under his control both what is pleasant and what is unpleasant.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमब्रवीन्महाराजो धार्तराष्ट्रो महायशाः॥ सत्यमेतत् त्वयोक्तं हि पाण्डवेषु दुरात्मसु। निहतेषु नरश्रेष्ठ प्राप्ते चापि महाक्रतौ॥ राजसूये पुनर्वीर त्वमेवं वर्धयिष्यसि।
English Translation: One should not cut the vitals of others. One should not utter cruel words. One should never receive scriptural lectures from a mean person. one should never utter such words as pain others, as make others miserable, and as lead to hell.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्त्वा महाराज कर्णमाश्लिष्य भारत।॥ राजसूयं क्रतुश्रेष्ठं चिन्तयामास कौरवः।
English Translation: Wordy arrows fall from the lips. Pierced therewith one burns always. Those arrows do not cut any other part than the very vitals of the person aimed. Hence he who is a learned man, should never aim them at others.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सोऽब्रवीत् कौरवांश्चापि पार्श्वस्थान् नृपसत्तमः॥ कदा तु तं क्रतुवरं राजसूयं महाधनम्। निहत्य पाण्डवान् सर्वानाहरिष्यामि कौरवाः॥
English Translation: If a person deeply cuts a wise man with wordy arrows, the wise man should remain silent. The man who, though sought to be angered, rejoices without giving way to anger, takes away from the provoker all his merits,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमब्रवीत् तदा कर्णः शृणु मे राजकुञ्जर। पादौ न धावये तावद् यावन्न निहतोऽर्जुनः॥ कीलालजं न खादेयं करिष्ये चासुरव्रतम्। नास्तीति नैव वक्ष्यामि याचितो येन केनचित्॥
English Translation: That man of virtuous soul, who, full of joy and shom of malice, control his burning ire which, if indulged, would lead him to speak ill of others and verily become his enemy, takes away the merits of others.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथोत्क्रुष्टं महेष्वासैर्धार्तराष्ट्रैर्महारथैः। प्रतिज्ञाते फाल्गुनस्य वधे कर्णेन संयुगे॥
English Translation: As for myself, I never answer when another speaks ill of me. If attacked, I always forgive the assault. The righteous hold that forgiveness, truth, sincerity and compassion are the foremost (of all virtues).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विजितांश्चाप्यमन्यन्त पाण्डवान् धृतराष्ट्रजाः। दुर्योधनोऽपि राजेन्द्र विसृज्य नरपुङ्गवान्॥ प्रविवेश गृहं श्रीमान् यथा चैत्ररथं प्रभुः। तेऽपि सर्वे महेष्वासा जग्मुर्वेश्मानि भारत॥
English Translation: Truth is the essence of the Vedas. The essence of Truth is self-control. The essence of self-control is Liberation. This is the teaching of all the scriptures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पाण्डवाश्च महेष्वासा दूतवाक्यप्रचोदिताः। चिन्तयन्तस्तमेवार्थं नालभन्त सुखं क्वचित्॥
English Translation: I know that person as a Brahmana and Muni who governs the rising impulse of speech, the impulse of anger appearing in the mind, the impulse to thirst, and the impulses of the stomach and the organ of pleasure.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भूयश्च चारै राजेन्द्र प्रवृत्तिरुपपादिता। प्रतिज्ञा सूतपुत्रस्य विजयस्य वधं प्रति॥
English Translation: One who does not give way to anger is superior to one who does. One who practises renunciation is superior to one who does nol. One who possesses the virtues of manhood is superior to one who has them not. One who has knowledge is superior to one who has not got it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतच्छ्रुत्वा धर्मसुतः समुद्विग्नो नराधिप। अभेद्यकवचं मत्वा कर्णमद्भुतविक्रमम्॥ अनुस्मरंश्च संक्लेशान् न शान्तिमुपयाति सः।
English Translation: Assailed with harsh words, one should not assail in return. Indeed, one who, under such circumstances, renounces anger, succeeds in burning the assailer and taking away all his merits.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य चिन्तापरीतस्य बुद्धिर्जज्ञे महात्मनः॥ बहुव्यालमृगाकीर्णं त्यक्तुं द्वैतवनं वनम्।
English Translation: That person who when attacked with harsh words, does not utter a harsh word in reply, who when lauded does not say what is pleasant to him who praise, who is gifted with such fortitude as not to strike in return when struck and not to even wish evil to the striker, finds his company always sought after by the gods.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धार्तराष्ट्रोऽपि नृपतिः प्रशशास वसुन्धराम्॥ भ्रातृभिः सहितो वीरैर्भीष्मद्रोणकृपैस्तथा। सङ्गम्य सूतपुत्रेण कर्णेनाहवशोभिना॥
English Translation: A sinful man should be forgiven as if he were righteous by one who is insulted, struck, and calumniated. By acting in this way one gains success.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुर्योधन: प्रिये नित्यं वर्तमानो महीभृताम्। पूजयामास विप्रेन्द्रान् क्रतुभिर्भूरिदक्षिणैः॥
English Translation: Though all my objects have been fulfilled, yet I always wait respectfully on the righteous. I have no thirst. My anger has been suppressed. Seduced by covetousness I do not deviate from the path of virtue. I do not also approach any one with prayers for riches.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भ्रातृणां च प्रियं राजन् स चकार परंतपः। निश्चित्य मनसा वीरो दत्तभुक्तफलं धनम्॥
English Translation: If cursed I do not curse in return. I know that self-control is the door of immortality. I disclose to you a great mystery. There is no position that is superior to that of humanity.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शल्य उवाच ततः शक्रः स्तूयमानो गन्धर्वप्सरसां गणैः। ऐरावतं समारुह्य द्विपेन्द्रं लक्षणैर्युतम्॥ पावकः सुमहातेजा महर्षिश्च बृहस्पतिः। यमश्च वरुणश्चैव कुबेश्च धनेश्वरः॥ सर्वैर्देवैः परिवृतः शक्रो वृत्रनिषूदनः। गन्धर्वैरप्सरोभिश्च यातस्त्रिभुवनं प्रभुः॥
English Translation: Freed from sin like the Moon from misty clouds, the wise man, shining in resplendence, acquires success by patiently waiting for his time.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स समेत्य महेन्द्राण्या देवराजः शतक्रतुः। मुदा परमया युक्तः पालयामास देवराट्॥
English Translation: A person of controlled soul, who becomes the object of worship with all by becoming the foremost of the pillars of the universe, and to whom only agreeable words are addressed by all, acquires the companionship of the gods.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः स भगवांस्तत्र अङ्गिराः समदृश्यता अथर्ववेदमन्त्रैश्च देवेन्द्रं समपूजयत्॥
English Translation: Revilers never speak of the merits of a person as readily as they speak of his demerits.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्तु भगवानिन्द्रः संहृष्टः समपद्यत। वरं च प्रददौ तस्मै अथर्वाङ्गिरसे तदा॥
English Translation: That person whose speech and mind are properly controlled and always devoted to the Supreme, gets the fruits of the Vedas, Penances, and Renunciation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथर्वाङ्गिरसो नाम वेदोऽस्मिन् वै भविष्यति। उदाहरणमेतद्धि यक्षभागं च लप्स्यसे॥
English Translation: The wise man should never revile (in return) those who have no merit, by speaking out their dispraise and by insults. He should not extol others and should never injure themselves.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं सम्पूज्य भगवानथर्वाङ्गिरसं तदा। व्यसर्जयन्महाराज देवराजः शतक्रतुः॥
English Translation: The wise and learned man considers revilement as nectar. Reviled, he sleeps without anxiety. The reviler, on the other hand, meets with destruction.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सम्पूज्य सर्वास्त्रिदशानृषीश्चापि तपोधनान्। इन्द्रः प्रमुदितो राजन् धर्मेणापालयत् प्रजाः॥
English Translation: The sacrifices that one celebrates angrily, the gifts one makes in angrily, the penances one practices angrily, and the offerings and libations one makes to the sacred fire angrily, are such that their merits are robbed by Yama. The toil of an angry man becomes entirely frutile.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं दुःखमनुप्राप्तमिन्द्रेण सह भार्यया। अज्ञातवासश्च कृतः शत्रूणां वधकाझ्या॥
English Translation: You foremost of immortals, that person is said to be conversant with virtue whose four doors, viz., the organ of generation, the stoinach, the two arms, and speech, are well governed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नात्र मन्युस्त्वया कार्यो यत् क्लिष्टोऽसि महावने। द्रौपद्या सह राजेन्द्र भ्रातृभिश्च महात्मभिः॥
English Translation: That person who, always practising truth and self-control and sincerity and mercy and patience and renunciation, becomes devoted to the study of the Vedas, does not covet others possession, and pursues what is good with a singleness of purpose, succeeds in going to heaven.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं त्वमपि राजेन्द्र राज्यं प्राप्स्यसि भारता वृत्रं हत्वा यथा प्राप्तः शक्रः कौरवनन्दन॥
English Translation: Like a calf sucking all the four teets of its dam's udders, one should devote himself to the practice of all these virtues. I do not know whether anything exists more sacred than Truth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुराचारश्च नहुषो ब्रह्मविट् पापचेतनः। अगस्त्यशापाभिहतो विनष्टः शाश्वती: समाः॥
English Translation: Having walked among both human beings and the gods, I say that Truth is the only means for reaching heaven even as a ship is the only means for crossing deep.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं तव दुरात्मानः शत्रवः शत्रुसूदन्। क्षिप्रं नाशं गमिष्यन्ति कर्णदुर्योधनादयः॥
English Translation: A person becomes like those with whom he lives, and like those whom he respects, and like to what he wishes to be.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः सागरपर्यन्तां भोक्ष्यसे मेदिनीमिमाम्। भ्रातृभिः सहितो वीर द्रौपद्या च सहानया॥
English Translation: If a person waits respectfully on him who is good, or him who is otherwise, if he waits respectfully on a sage endued with ascetic merit or on a thief, passes under his control and gets his colour like a piece of cloth catching the dye in which it is washed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उपाख्यानमिदं शक्रविजयं वेदसम्मितम्। राज्ञा व्यूढेष्वनीकेषु श्रोतव्यं जयमिच्छता॥
English Translation: The gods always talk with those who are good and wise. They, therefore, never entertain the desire for even seeing the enjoyments in which men take pleasure. The person who knows that all objects of enjoyment are subject to changes, has few rivals, and is superior to the very Moon and Wind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मात् संश्रावयामि त्वां विजयं जयतां वर। संस्तूयमाना वर्धन्ते महात्मानो युधिष्ठिर॥
English Translation: When the Purusha that lives in one's heart is pure, and walks in the path of the righteous, the gods take a pleasure in him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क्षत्रियाणामभावोऽयं युधिष्ठिर महात्मनाम्। दुर्योधनापराधेन भीमार्जुनबलेन च॥
English Translation: The gods shun from a distance those who are always devoted to the gratification of their senses of pleasure and the stomach, who are given to thieving, and who always indulge in harsh words, even if they expiate their offences by performing the proper rites.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आख्यानमिन्द्रविजयं य इदं नियतः पठेत्। धूतपाप्मा जितस्वर्गः परत्रेह च मोदते॥
English Translation: The god are never gratified with one of mean soul, with one who observes no restraint in the matter of food, and with one who is of sinful deeds. On the other hand, the gods associate with those men who observe the vow of truth, who are grateful, and who are engaged in the practice of virtue.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न चारिजं भयं तस्य नापुत्रो वा भवेन्नरः। नापदं प्राप्नुयात् कांचिदं दीर्घमायुश्च विन्दति। सर्वत्र जयमाप्नोति न कदाचित् पराजयम्॥
English Translation: Silence is better than speech. To speak the truth is better than silence. To speak, again, truth what is connected with virtue is better than to speak the truth. To speak what, besides being true and righteous is agrecable, is better than to speak truth connected with virtue.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच एवमाश्वासितो राजा शल्येन भरतर्षभ। पूजयामास विधिवच्छल्यं धर्मभृतां वरः॥
English Translation: The Saddhyas said, By what is this world covered? Why does one fail to shine? For what cause do people renounce their friends? Why do people fail to go to heaven.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रुत्वा तु शल्यवचनं कुन्तीपुत्रो युधिष्ठिरः। प्रत्युवाच महाबाहुर्मद्रराजमिदं वचः॥
English Translation: The world is covered by Ignorance. Men fail to shine on account of malice. People renounce friends, actuated by covetousness. Men fail to attain to heaven on account of attachment.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भवान् कर्णस्य सारथ्यं करिष्यति न संशयः। तत्र तेजोवधः कार्यः कर्णस्यार्जुनसंस्तवः॥
English Translation: Who alone among the Brahmanas is always happy? Who alone amongst them can practise the vow of silence though living in the midst of many? Who alone amongst them, though weak, is still considered as strong? And who alone amongst them does not quarrel.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शल्य उवाच एवमेतत् करिष्यामि यथा मां सम्प्रभाषसे। यच्चान्यदपि शक्ष्यामि तत् करिष्याम्यहं तव।॥
English Translation: He alone amongst the Brahmanas who is endued with wisdom is always happy. He alone. amongst the Brahmanas who is endued with wisdom, succeeds in practising the vow of silence though living in the midst of many. He alone amongst the Brahmanas who is endued with wisdom, thought actually weak, is considered as strong. He alone amongst them who has wisdom succeeds in avoiding quarrel.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच ततस्त्वामन्त्र्य कौन्तेयाञ्छल्यो मद्राधिपस्तदा। जगाम सबलः श्रीमान् दुर्योधनमरिंदम॥
English Translation: The Saddhyas said Wherein lies the divinity of the Brahmanas? In what their purity? In what their impurity? And in what their status of humanity?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच तमब्रवीद वासुदेवो रथस्थो राधेय दिष्ट्या स्मरसीह धर्मम्। प्रायेण नीचा व्यमनेषु मग्ना निन्दति दैवं कुकृतं न तु स्वम्॥
English Translation: The Swan said The divinity of the Brahmanas consists in the study of the Vedas. Their purity is in their status of humanity?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मानाययेस्त्वं च सुयोधनश्च। दुःशासनः शकुनिः सौबलश्च न ते कर्ण प्रत्यभात्तत्र धर्म:॥
English Translation: Bhishma said Thus have I recited to you the excellent discourse between the Saddhyas (and the Swan). The body is the origin of acts, and existence or individual Soul is truth.

Sanskrit Shloka: यदा सभायां राजानमनक्षज्ञं युधिष्ठिरम्। अजैषीच्छकुनि नात् क्व ते धर्मस्तदा गतः॥

English Translation: Their praises sung by eulogists and Sutas and Magadhas and bards, and supported by their own army, they appeared like so many Suns adorned with their own rays.

English Translation: With the white umbrella held over his head, king Yudhishthira shone with beauty like the lord of the stars on the night when he is at full.

Sanskrit Shloka: यद् वारणावते पार्थान सुप्ताञ्जतुगृहे तदा। आदीपयस्त्वं राधेय क्व ते धर्मस्तदा गतः॥
English Translation: That foremost of men, the eldest son of Pandu, accepted, with due forms, the blessings and cheers of his gladdened subjects as he went on his way.

Sanskrit Shloka: यदा रजस्वलां कृष्णां दुःशासनवशे स्थिताम्। सभायांन प्राहसः कर्ण क्व ते धर्मस्तदा गतः॥
English Translation: About the soldiers who followed the king, their confused murmurs seemed to fill the entire sky.

Sanskrit Shloka: तदनार्यैः पुरा कृष्णां क्लिश्यमानामनागसम्। उपप्रेक्षसि राधेय क्व ते धर्मस्तदा गतः॥
English Translation: That army crossed many lakes and rivers and forests and pleasure gardens. They at last came upon the mountains.

Sanskrit Shloka: विनष्टाः पाण्डवः कृष्णे शाश्वतं नरकं गता। पतिमन्यं वृणीष्वेति वदंस्त्वं गजसामिनीम्॥ उपप्रेक्षसि राधेय क्व ते धर्मस्तदा गतः।
English Translation: Arrived at that region where that wealth was buried. O king, Yudhishthira fixed his camp with all his brothers and troops.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राज्यलुब्धः पुनः कर्ण समाव्यथसि पाण्डवान्। यदा शकुनिमाश्रित्य क्क ते धर्मस्तदा गतः॥
English Translation: The region selected for the purpose, O chief of Bharata's race, was perfectly level and auspicious. There the king pitched his camp, placing in his van such Brahmanas as were gifted with penances and learning and selfcontrol, as also his priest Agniveshya, O you of Kurus' race, who was well-conversant with the Vedas and all their branches. Then the royal sons of Pandu, and the other kings, and the Brahmanas and priests well-skilled in sacrificial rites, having duly performed same propitiatory ceremonies, spread themselves all over that spot. Having duly placed the king and his ministers in the middle, the Brahinanas caused the camp to be pitched by laying out six roads and nine divisions. King Yudhishthira caused a separate encampment to be duly made for the infuriate elephants who accompanied his army. When everything was complete, he addressed the Brahmanas, saying, You foremost of Brahmanas, do that which you think should be done in view of the matter at hand. Indeed, let an auspicious day and constellation be fixed for it. Let not a long time pass away over our heads as we wait in suspense here. You foremost of learned Brahmanas, having formed this resolution, do what should be done after this! Hearing these words of the king, the Brahmanas with those amongst them who were well-skilled in the performance of religious rites, became filled with gladness and desirous of doing that was agrecable to king Yudhishthira the just, said these words in reply, This very day is an auspicious one with a auspicious constellation. We shall, therefore, try to celebrate those high rites we propose. We shall today, O king, live upon water alone. Do you all fast also today.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदाभिमन्युं बहवो युद्दे जघ्नुर्महारथाः। परिवार्य रणे बालं क्क ते धर्मस्तदा गतः॥
English Translation: Hearing those words of those foremost Brahmanas, the royal sons of Pandu passed that night, abstaining from all food, and lying confidently on beds of Kusha-grass, like burning fires in a sacrifice.

Sanskrit Shloka: यद्येष धर्मस्तत्र न विद्यते हि किं सर्वथा तालुविशोषणेन। अद्येह धाणि विधत्स्व सूत तथापि जीवन विमोक्ष्यसे हि॥
English Translation: And the night wore away as they listened to the discourses of the learned Brahmanas. When the cloudless morning came, those foremost of Brahmanas addressed the royal son of Dharma, (saying as follows).

Sanskrit Shloka: नलो ह्यक्षैर्निर्जितः पुष्करेण पुनर्यशो राज्यमवाप वीर्यात्। सर्वेः समेताः परिवृत्तलोभाः॥ निहत्य शूत्रन् समरे प्रवृद्धान् ससोमका राज्यमवाप्नुयुस्ते। तथा गता धार्तराष्ट्रा विनाशं धर्माभिगुप्तैः सततं नृसिंहः॥
English Translation: Kripa said O son of Radha, your crooked mind is always for the war. You do not understand the time and nature of things as well as their consequences.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच एवमुक्तस्तदा कर्णो वासुदेवेन भारत। लज्जयावनतो भूत्वा नोत्तरं किञ्चिदुक्तवान्॥
English Translation: There are many contrivances mentioned in the scriptures. Of them persons acquainted with the past history have mentioned battle as the most sinful.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क्रोधात् प्रस्फुरमाणैष्टो धनुरुद्यम्य भारत। योधयामास वै पार्थ महावेगपराक्रमः॥
English Translation: It is only when undertaken in (proper) time and place that a battle produces success. This is not a favourable time and you will get no good fruit. Prowess, when manifested in proper hour and place, leads to well-being.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽब्रवीद् वासुदेव: फाल्गुनं पुरुर्षभम्। दिव्यास्त्रेणैव निर्भिद्य पातयस्व महाबल॥
English Translation: It is by favourable signs that the advisability of an action is determined upon. Learned men never act depending upon the words of a car maker. Taking all this into consideration it is not proper for us to enter into an encounter with Partha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्तस्तु देवेन क्रोधमागातदार्जुनः। मन्युमभ्याविशद् घोरं स्मृत्वा तत्तु धनंजयः॥
English Translation: Alone did he save the Kurus from the Gandharvas) and alone did he gìatify fire. And alone did he for five years lead the life of a Brahmacharin.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य क्रुद्धस्य सर्वेभ्यः स्रोतोभ्यस्तेजसोऽतिषः। प्रादुरासंस्तदा राजंस्तदद्भुतमिवाभवत्॥
English Translation: Taking Subhadra on his car alone did he challenge Krishna to a duel. And alone did he fight with Rudra who came before him in the disguise of a hunter.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत् समीक्ष्य ततः कर्णो ब्रह्मास्त्रेण धनंजयम्। अभ्यवर्षत् पुनर्यनमकरोद् रथसर्जने॥
English Translation: It was in this forest that he rescued Draupadi when she was being carried away (by Jayadratha). It is alone he that for five years studied the science of arms under Indra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्रह्मास्त्रेणैव तं पार्थो ववर्ष शरवृष्टिभिः। तदस्त्रमस्त्रेणावार्य प्रजहार च पाण्डवः॥
English Translation: Defeating alone all the enemies he has spread the glory of the Kurus. Alone did that chastiser of foes defeat in battle Chitrasena, the king of the Gandharvas and in a moment his invincible army also. He defeated alone in battle the dreadful Nivatakavachas and Kalakhanjas who were both incapable of being slain even by the celestials. What however, O Karna, have you accomplished single-handed like any one of the sons of Pandu each of whom had vanquished many kings? Even Indra is unable to face Partha in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽन्यदस्त्रं कौन्तेयो दयितं जातवेदसः। मुमोच कर्णमुद्दिश्य तत् प्रजज्वाल तेजसा॥
English Translation: He who wishes to fight with Arjuna should take some medicine. You desire to take out the fangs of an angry, venomous snake by stretching out your right hand and extending your fore-finger. Or going alone in the forest you wish to ride an infuriated elephant and go to a town without a hook in hand. Or rubbed over with clarified butter and clad in silken raiment you wish to go through a burning fire blazing with fat, tallow and clarified butter.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वारुणेन ततः कर्णः शमयामास पावकम्। जीमूतैश्च दिशः सर्वाश्चके तिमिरदुर्दिनाः॥
English Translation: Who, binding himself hand and foot and tying a huge stone to his neck, would wish to swim across the ocean with his bare arms? What manliness is there? O Karna, a fool is he, who, without strength and skill in arms, desires to fight with Partha who is so powerful and skilled in weapons? Oppressed by us and freed from thirteen years' exile, will he not destroy us like a lion liberated from the noose? Having unknowingly come to a place where Partha lay hidden like fire we have been exposed to a great danger. Although dreadful in battle we should fight against him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पाण्डेवयस्त्वसम्भ्रातो वायव्यास्त्रेण वीर्यवान्। अपोवाह तदाभ्राणि राधेयस्य प्रपश्यतः॥
English Translation: Let our army, clad in coats of mail, stand here in battle array ready to strike. Let Drona, Duryodhana, Bhishma, yourself, Drona's son and ourselves all fight with Partha. Do not, O Karna, act rashly. If we six are united and set forth our energy we may fight with or stand before Partha, fierce like the wielder of thunderbolt. With our soldiers in battle array, we, great bowmen as we are, will fight carefully with Arjuna as the Danavas fought with Vasava.

Sanskrit Shloka: ततः शरं महाघोरं ज्वलन्तमिव पावकम्। आददे पाण्डुपुत्रस्य सूतपुत्रो जिघांसयां॥

Sanskrit Shloka: स गाढविद्धः समरे महात्मा विघूर्णमानः श्लथहस्तगाण्डिवः॥ चचाल बीभत्सुरमित्रमर्दनः क्षितेः प्रकम्पे च यथा चलोत्तमः।

Sanskrit Shloka: तदन्तरं प्राप्य वृषो महारथो रथाङ्गमुर्वीगतमुज्जिहीषुः॥ रथादवल्पुत्य निगृह्य दोर्ध्या शशाक दैवान महाबलोऽपि।

Sanskrit Shloka: ततः किरीटी प्रतिलभ्य संज्ञा जग्राह बाणं यमदण्डकल्पम्॥ ततोऽर्जुनः प्राञ्जलिकं महात्मा ततोऽब्रवीद् वासुदेवोऽपि पार्थम्। छिन्थ्यस्य मूर्धानमरेः शरेण न यावदारोहति वै रथं वृषः॥

Sanskrit Shloka: स्तत: शरं प्रज्वलितं प्रगृह्य। जघान कक्षाममलार्कवर्णा महारथे रथचक्रे विमग्ने॥

Sanskrit Shloka: तं हस्तिकक्षाप्रवहं च केतुं सुवर्णमुक्तामणिवज्रपृष्ठम्। ज्ञानप्रकर्षोत्तमशिल्पियुक्तैः कृतं सुरूपं तपनीयचित्रम्॥

Sanskrit Shloka: जग्राह पार्थः स शरं प्रहृष्टो यो देवसङ्घरपि दुर्निवार्यः। सम्पूजितो यः सततं महात्मा देवासुरान् यो विजयेन्महेषुः॥

Sanskrit Shloka: तं वै प्रमृष्टं प्रसमीक्ष्य युद्धे चचाल सर्वं सचराचरं जगत्। स्तमुद्यतं प्रेक्ष्य महाहवेषुम्॥
English Translation: You have also told me O grandfather, of great intelligence, the exceedingly painful character of the misfortune that befell the great king Nriga on account of a single transgression of his.

Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्तु तं वै शरमप्रमेयं गाण्डीवधन्वा धनुषि व्ययोजयत्। युक्तवा महास्त्रेण परेण चापं विकृष्य गाण्डीवमुवाच सत्वरम्॥
English Translation: He had to live for a long time at Dvaravati (in the form of a mighty lizard) and how Krishna became the instrument of his rescue from that miserable condition.

Sanskrit Shloka: अयं महास्त्रप्रहितो महाशरः शरीरहवासुहरश्च दुर्हदः। तपोऽस्ति तप्तं गुरवश्च तोषिता पया यदीष्टं सुहृदां श्रुतं तथा॥ अनेन सत्येन निहन्त्वयं शरः सुसंहितः कर्णमरिं ममोर्जितम्। इत्यूचिवांस्तं प्रमुमोच बाणं धनंजयः कर्णवधाय घोरम्॥
English Translation: I have, however one doubt. About the regions of kine. I wish to hear particularly about those regions which are reserved for the residence of persons who make gifts of kine.

Sanskrit Shloka: कृत्यामथर्राङ्गिरसीमिवोग्रां दीप्तामसह्यां युधि मृत्युनापि। ब्रुवन किरीटी तमतिप्रहृष्टो ह्ययं शरो मे विजयावहोस्तु॥ जिघांसुरर्कन्दुसमप्रभावः कर्ण मयास्तो नयतां यमाय।
English Translation: Bhishma said Regarding it is cited the old discourse between him who sprang from the primeval lotus and him who performed a hundred sacrifices.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेनेषुवर्येण किरीटमाली प्रहृष्टरूपो विजयावहेन॥ जिघांसुरर्केन्दुसमप्रभेण चक्रे विषक्तं रिपुमाततायी।
English Translation: Shakra said I see, O grandfather, that those who live in the region of kine transcend by their effulgence the prosperity of the celestial dwellers and pass them by. This has created a doubt in my mind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथा विमुक्तो बलिनार्कतेजाः प्रज्वालयामास दिशो नभश्च। ततोऽर्जुनस्तस्य शिरो जहार वृत्रस्य वज्रेण यथा महेन्द्रः॥
English Translation: Of what kind, O holy one, are the regions of kine? Tell me all about them, O sinless one. Indeed, what is the nature of those regions that are inhabited by givers of kine? I wish to know this.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्तदा महास्त्रप्रतिमन्त्रितेन। पाथोऽपराह्ने शिर उच्चकर्त वैकर्तनस्याथ महेन्द्रसूनुः॥
English Translation: Of what kind are those regions? What fruits do they yield? What is the highest object there which the inhabitants thereof succeed in acquiring? What are its virtues. How also do men, shorn of anxiety, succeed in going to those regions?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मथास्य कायो निपपात पश्चात्। तदुद्यतादित्यसमानतेजसं शरन्नभोमध्यगभास्करोपमम्॥ वराङ्गमुक्मपतञ्चमूमुखे दिवाकरोऽस्तादिवरक्तमण्डलः।
English Translation: For what period does the giver of a cow enjoy the fruits of his gift? How may persons make gifts of many kine and how may they make gifts of a few kine?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽस्य देहं सततं सुखोचितं सुरूपमत्यर्थमुदारकर्ममः॥ परेण कृच्छ्रेण शिरः समत्यजद् गृहं महर्धीव सुसङ्गमीश्वरः।
English Translation: What are the merits of the gifts of many kine and what those of the gifts of a few only. How also do persons become givers of kine without really giving any kine? Do you tell me all this.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शरैर्विभिन्नं व्यसु तत् सुवर्चसः पपात कर्णस्य शरीरमुच्छ्रितम्॥ स्त्रवव्रणं गैरिकतोयविस्त्रवं गिरेर्यथा वज्रहतं महाशिरः। देहाच कर्णस्य निपातितस्य तेजः सूर्य खं वितत्याविवेश॥
English Translation: How does one making gifts of even many kine, O powerful lord, become the equal of one who has made gifts of only a few kine? How also does one who has made gifts of only few kine equal one who has made gifts of many kine?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदद्भुतं सर्वमनुष्ययोधाः संदृष्टवन्तो निहते स्म कर्णे। दृष्ट्वा कर्णं पातितं फाल्गुनन॥
English Translation: What kind of present is considered and distinguished for preeminence in the matter of gifts of kine? You should, O holy one, describe to me all this according to truth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथैव कृष्णश्च दनंजयश्च हृष्टौ यमौ दध्मतुर्वारिजातौ। तं सोमकाः प्रेक्ष्य हतं शयानं सैन्यैः सार्ध सिंहनादान् प्रचक्रुः॥
English Translation: Vibhavasu (The Sun) said : There are two offerings. One of these consists of a palmful of water and the other called Akshata consists of rice grains with clarified butter. One should on the day of the full moon, stand facing that bright orb and make to him the two offerings mentioned viz., a palmful of water and the rice grains with clarified butter called Akshata. The man who presents these offerings is said to worship his sacred fire. Indeed, he is considered as one who has poured libations the three (principal) fires.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तूर्याणि संजघ्नुरतीव हृष्टा वासांसि चैवादुधुवर्भुजांश्च। संवर्धयन्तश्च नरेन्द्र योधाः पार्थं समाजग्मुरतीव हृष्टाः॥ नन्योन्यमाश्लिष्य नदन्त ऊचुः। दृष्ट्वा तु कर्ण भुवि वा विपन्नं कृतं रथात् सायकैरर्जुनस्य॥
English Translation: That man of little understanding who cuts down a large tree on the day of the new moon, becomes sullied with the sin of Brahmanicide. By killing even a single leaf one commits that sin.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महानिलेनादिमिरापविद्धं यज्ञावसानेऽग्निमिव प्रशान्तम्। मस्तं गतं भास्करस्येव बिम्बम्॥
English Translation: That foolish man who chews a toothbrush on the day of the new moon is considered as on injuring the god of the moon by such a deed. The departed Manes of such a person become annoyed with him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शरैराचितसर्वाङ्गः शोणितैधपरिप्लुतः। विभाति देहः कर्णस्य स्वरश्मिभिरिवांशुमान्॥
English Translation: The celestials do not accept the libations poured by such a man on days of the full moon and the new moon. His departed Manes, become enraged with him and his family become extinct.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रताप्य सेनामामित्री दीप्तैः शरगभस्तिभिः। बलिनार्जुनकालेन नीतोऽस्तं कर्णभास्करः॥
English Translation: Shree said The celestials and departed Manes leave that sinful house, in which eating and drinking vessels and seats and beds lie scattered and in which women are beaten. Without accepting the offerings made to them by the owners of such houses, the celestials and the departed Manes fly away from such a sinful house.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अस्तं गच्छन् यथादित्यः प्रभामादाय गच्छति। तथा जीवितमादाय कर्णस्येषुर्जगाम सः॥
English Translation: Angirasa said The offspring of that man multiplies who stands every night for a full year under a Karanjaka tree with a lamp for lighting it and holds in his hands the roots of the Suvarchala plant.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपराह्नेऽपराहोऽस्य सूतपुत्रस्य मारिष। छिन्नमञ्जलिकेनाजौ सोत्सेधमपतच्छिरः॥
English Translation: Gargya said One should always do the duties of hospitality to his guests. One should give lamps in the hall or shed where sacrifices are celebrated. One should avoid sleep during the day, and abstain from all sorts of flesh or food. never
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उपर्युपरि सैन्यानामस्य शत्रोस्तदञ्जसा। शिर: कर्णस्य सोत्सेधमिषुः सोऽप्यहरद् द्रुतम्॥
English Translation: One should injure kine and Brahmanas. One should always recite the names of the Pushkara lakes and the other sacred waters. Such a course of duty is the foremost. Even this forms a high religion with its mysteries. If observed in practice, it is sure lo yield great results.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्णं तु शूरं पतितं पृथिव्यां शराचितं शोणितदिग्धगात्रम्। श्छिन्नध्वजेनाथ ययौ रथेन॥
English Translation: If a person celebrated even a hundred sacrifices, he is doomed to see the exhaustion of the merits belonging to the libations poured therein. The duties, however which I have mentioned are 'such that when observed by persons having faith their merit becomes endless.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हते कर्णे कुरवः प्राद्रवन्त भयार्दिता गाढविद्धाश्च संख्ये। अवेक्षमाणा मुहुरर्जुनस्य ध्वजं महान्तं वपुषा ज्वलन्तम्॥
English Translation: Listen to another great mystery unknown to many. The celestials do not eat the libations on occasions of Shraddhas and rites in their honour or on occasions of those rites which are performed on ordinary lunar days or on the especially sacred days of the full moon and the new moon, if they see a woman in her menses or one who is the daughter of a mother suffering from leprosy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सहस्रनेक्षप्रतिमानकर्मणः सहस्रपत्रप्रतिमाननं शुभम्। सहस्ररश्मिर्दिनसंक्षये यथा तथापतत् कर्णशिरो वसुंधराम्॥
English Translation: The ancestors of the man who allows such a woman to come near to place where the Shraddha is being performed by him do not become pleased with him for thirteen years.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच व्यथयेयुरिमे सेनां देवानामपि संजय। आहवे ये न्यवर्तन्त वृकोदरमुखा नृपाः॥
English Translation: Clad in white clothes, and becoming pure in body and mind, one should invite Brahmanas and make them utter their benedictions. On such occasions one should also recite the 110W Bharata. It is by observing all these that the offerings made at Shraddhas become endless.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सम्प्रयुक्तः किलैवायं दिष्टैर्भवति पूरुषः। तस्मिन्नेव च सर्वार्थाः प्रदृश्यन्ते पृथग्विधाः॥
English Translation: Broken utensils broken bedsteads, cocks and dogs as also such trees as have grown within dwelling houses, are all in auspicious objects. Dhaumya said
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दीर्घ विप्रोषितः कालमरण्ये जटिलोऽजिनी। अज्ञातश्चैव लोकस्य विजहार युधिष्ठिरः॥
English Translation: In a broken utensil exists Kali himself, while in a broken bedstead is loss of money. When a cock or a dog is seen, the celestials do not eat the offerings made to them. Scorpions and snakes find shelter under the roots of a tree. Hence one should never plant a tree within his house.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स एव महतीं सेनां समावर्तयदाहवे। किमन्यद् दैवसंयोगान्मम पुत्रस्य चाभवत्॥
English Translation: Jamadagni said That man whose heart is not pure is sure to go to Hell even if he worships the celestials in a Horse sacrifice or in hundred Vajapeya Sacrifices, or if he practises the severes austerities with head down most. Purity of heart is considered as equal to Sacrifices and Truth.

Sanskrit Shloka: युक्त एव हि भाग्येन ध्रुवमुत्पद्यते नरः। स तथाऽऽकृष्यते तेन न यथा स्वयमिच्छति॥
English Translation: A very barley with a pure heart to a Brahmana, acquired poor Brahmana by giving only a portion of powered the region of Brahman himself. This is a sufficient proof.

English Translation: Vaishampayana said : The foremost of men, Dhritarashtra, the son of Ambika, having heard this most extraordinary and wonderful account (the mode of life of the Pandava king in the Kamyaka forest) became filled with grief and anxiety; and overwhelmed with melancholy and breathing hot and long he addressing his charioteer Sanjaya said,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अद्य मे केकया लब्धाः काशिका: कोसलाश मे। चेदयश्चापरे वङ्गा मामेव समुपाश्रिताः॥
English Translation: “O charioteer, I do not enjoy a moment's rest either during the day or in the night, thinking of the terrible misconduct of my sons resulting from their past gambling;

Sanskrit Shloka: पृथिवी भूयसी तात मम पार्थस्य नो तथा। इति मामब्रवीत् सूत मन्दो दुर्योधनः पुरा॥
English Translation: And thinking of the heroism, patience superior fortitude and the extraordinary mutual love of those brothers of unbearable prowess.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य सेनासमूहस्य मध्ये द्रोणः सुरक्षितः। निहतः पार्षतेनाजौ किमन्यद् भागधेयतः॥
English Translation: When the two Pandavas, Nakula and Sahadeva who are of divine origin, most exalted, equal to the king of the gods in splendour, invincible in battle, steady in management of weapons, able to shoot at a great distance indefatigable in battle, lighthanded, of inextinguishable wrath, persevering, of untiring activity, mighty as the lions, unbearable as the Ashvins themselves will come to the field of battle placing Bhima and Arjuna in the front, then I see, O Sanjaya, that my soldiers will be slain to a mass; and those mighty and matchless warriors of divine origin will not show mercy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मध्ये राज्ञां महाबाहुं सदा युद्धाभिनन्दिनम्। सर्वास्त्रपारगं द्रोणं कथं मृत्युरुपेयिवान्॥
English Translation: As they are very angry at the insult upon Draupadi. And the most powerful warriors of the Vrishni race and the Panchalas of great strength and the sons of Pritha themselves guarded by Vasudeva of indomitable strength, will defeat my son's legions.

Sanskrit Shloka: समनुप्राप्तकृच्छोऽहं मोहं परममागतः। भीष्मद्रोणौ हतौ श्रुत्वा नाहं जीवितुमुत्सहे॥
English Translation: O son of charioteer, my assembled forces are incapable of standing the push as given by the Vrishnis, when commanded by Rama and Krishna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यन्मां क्षत्ताब्रवीत् तात प्रपश्यन् पुत्रगृद्धिनम्। दुर्योधनेन तत् सर्वे प्राप्तं सूत मया सह॥
English Translation: The mighty-warrior Bhima of terrible prowess, armed with his uplifted mace, capable of crushing every hero, will rove about in their midst. The kings on my side will not be able to stand against the twang of Gandiva, as loud as the thunder of heaven and the push of the mace of Bhima.

Sanskrit Shloka: नृशंसं तु परं नु स्यात् तयक्त्वा दुर्योधनं यदि। पुत्रशेषं चिकीर्षेयं कृत्स्नं न मरणं व्रजेत्॥
English Translation: It is then that I, ever obedient to the counsels of Duryodhana, shall call to my memory the advices of my friends, which, I should have listened to beforehand.

Sanskrit Shloka: यो हि धर्मं परित्यज्य भवत्यर्थपरो नरः। सोऽस्माच्च हीयते लोकात् क्षुद्रभावं च गच्छति॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said : O king, you did not care for this, your great fault was that though capable you did not prevent out of affection your son from doing what he had done.

English Translation: Having heard the defeat at dice of the Pandavas, the slayer of Madhu, that hero of imperishable fame, went at once to the forest of Kamyaka.

English Translation: So also Dhristadyumna at the head of the sons of Drupada and Virata and Dhristaketu and those mighty warriors, the Kaikeyas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यक्तमेव च मे शंस यथा युद्धमवर्तत। केऽयुध्यन् के व्यापकुर्वन् के क्षुद्राः प्राद्रवन् भयात्॥१७
English Translation: O king, I have learnt through the spies whatever they talked of after they had seen the sons of Pandu defeated at dice.

Sanskrit Shloka: धनंजयं च मे शंस यद् यच्चक्रे रथर्षभः। तस्माद् भयं नो भूयिष्ठं भ्रातृव्याच्च वृकोदरात्॥

English Translation: And Krishna, beholding the sons of Pritha, gone to the woods and dressed in the skins of black deer, became greatly annoyed and addressing Yudhishthira, said,

Sanskrit Shloka: कथं च वो मनस्तात निवृत्तेष्वभवत् तदा। मामकानां च ये शूराः के कांस्तत्र न्यवारयन्॥

Sanskrit Shloka: नारद उवाच गालवं वैनतेयोऽथ प्रहसन्निदमब्रवीत्। दिष्ट्या कृतार्थं पश्यामि भवन्तमिह वै द्विज।।।।
English Translation: At the Rajasuya I saw also all the kings those of the Bangas and Angas, Paundras and Odras, Cholas and Dravidas and Andhakas; and the rulers of several islands and the countries on the sea-coast and the kings of the frontier dominions i.e. the chiefs of the Sinhalas, the barbarians Mlechchhas, the aboriginal tribes of Lanka and hundreds of the kings of the west and the chiefs of the sea-coast principalities and all those of the Pahlavas and the Daradas. Sanskrit Shloka: गालवस्तु वचः श्रुत्वा वैनतेयेन भाषितम्। चतुर्भागावशिष्टं तदाचख्यौ कार्यमस्य हि॥
English Translation: That prosperity, so very ephemeral was taken away by your enemies and now rests upon them, which I shall recover from them for you by depriving them of their very life.

Sanskrit Shloka: सुपर्णस्त्वब्रवीदेनं गालवं वदतां वरः। प्रयत्नस्तेन कर्तव्यो नैष सम्पत्स्यते तव॥
English Translation: O chief of the Kurus, I shall, with the help of Rama, Bhima and Arjuna and the twins and of Akrura, Gada and Samba and Pradyumna and Ahuka and also with the assistance of the heroic Dhristadyumna and the of Shishupala, kill Duryodhana and Karna in a day and so also Dushasana, Subala's son and all others who will stand against us in battle.
