---
Sanskrit Shloka: इष्ट्वा ते पुण्डरीकेण दत्ता राज्ञा द्विजातिषु। तेभ्यो द्वे द्वे शते क्रीत्वा प्राप्ते तैः पार्थिवैस्तदा॥
English Translation: Sanjay Said: Hearing these words of the most righteous, Yudhishthira his courtiers headed by Dhristadyumna instantly pacified the indignant Keshava with sweet words most suitable to the occasion.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपराण्यपि चत्वारि शतानि द्विजसत्तम। नीयमानानि संतारे हृतान्यासन् वितस्तया॥
English Translation: They, (the courtiers) in the hearing of Vasudeva, said to the daughter of Panchala (Draupadi), “O lady, Duryodhana shall certainly give up his life on account of your wrath.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं न शक्यमप्राप्यं प्राप्तुं गालव कर्हिचित्। इमामश्वशताभ्यां वै द्वाभ्यां तस्मै निवेदय॥
English Translation: O fair-complexioned one, we make this promise unto you and therefore grieve no more. O Krishna, the flesh of those that laughed on beholding the victory at dice will be devoured by the wolves and birds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विश्वामित्राय धर्मात्मन् षड्भिरश्वशतैः सह। ततोऽसि गतसम्मोहः कृतकृत्यो द्विजोत्तम॥
English Translation: They themselves will be mocked; and their blood will be drunk by the jackals and vultures. ( daughter of Panchala, you shall see the bodies of those that dragged you by the hair at once dragged and devoured by the carnivorous animals.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गालवस्तं तथेत्युक्त्वा सुपर्णसहितस्ततः। आदायाश्वांश्च कन्यां च विश्वामित्रमुपागमत्॥
English Translation: Krishna, the blood, of those with severed heads, by whom you were much aggrieved and neglected, will be drunk by the earth.”
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अश्वानां काक्षितार्थानां षडिमानि शतानि वै। शतद्वयेन कन्येय भवता प्रतिगृह्यताम्॥
English Translation: The foremost ones of the Bharata race uttered these and various other speeches (in order to console Draupadi). Yudhishthira made this request to those brave heroes who were all impressed with the marks of battle, that they should after the expiration of the thirteenth year (of life in the forest), come to the field (of battle) keeping Vasudeva at their head.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अस्यां राजर्षिभिः पुत्रा जाता वै धार्मिकास्त्रयः। चतुर्थं जनयत्वेकं भवानपि नरोत्तमम्॥
English Translation: Who is there that, desiring to have his existence in earth, will appear in the field of battle and encounter these most illustrious and invincible heroes (like the furious lions with erect manes) viz. Rama and Krishna and Dhananjaya, Pradyumna and Samba and Yuyudhana and Bhima and the sons of Madri and the Kaikeya and Panchala princes, attended by the king of Matsya, who will come to the battle with all their troops and attendants.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पूर्णान्येवं शतान्यष्टौ तुरगाणां भवन्तु ते। भवतो ह्यनृणो भूत्वा तपः कुर्यां यथासुखम्॥
English Translation: Dhritarashtra said: Vidura in the occasion of the past gambling told me this “O king, you shall surely defeat the Pandavas at dice; but certainly there will ensue a terrible bloodshed, resulting in the total destruction of the Kurus."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विश्वामित्रस्तु तं दृष्ट्वा गालवं सह पक्षिणा। कन्यां च तां वरारोहामिदमित्यब्रवीद् वचः॥
English Translation: O charioteer, I think it is now almost certain what Vidura had told me of old, that undoubtedly you would happen, a most fearful battle with the Pandavas just after the expire of the said period of thirteen years.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किमियं पूर्वमेवेह न दत्ता मम गालवा पुत्रा ममैव चत्वारो भवेयुः कुलभावनाः॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said The son of Subala (i.e. Shakuni), excited with wrath, rushed against Nakula who was slaughtering your troops with (great) impetuosity in battle and said (to him) “Wait, wait."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रतिगृह्णामि ते कन्यामेकपुत्रफलाय वै। अश्वाश्चाश्रममासाद्य चरन्तु मम सर्वशः॥
English Translation: Those two heroes, between whom was excited a bitter enmity, desirous of slaying each other, struck each other with arrows discharged (from their bows) drawn to their fullest stretch.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तया रममाणोऽथ विश्वामित्रो महाद्युतिः। आत्मजं जनयामास माधवी पुत्रमष्टकम्॥
English Translation: In (that) battle, O king, the son of Subala displayed as much dexterity in discharging showers of arrows as Nakula (god).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जातमात्रं सुतं तं च विश्वामित्रो महामुनिः। संयोज्यार्थस्तथा धर्मैरश्वैस्तैः समयोजयत्॥
English Translation: With arrows stricking (to their bodies) like prickly thorms, they, O mighty monarch, looked, in (that) engagement, like a couple of porcupines with erect quills.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथाष्टकः पुरं प्रायात् तदा सोमपुरप्रभम्। निर्यात्य कन्यां शिष्याय कौशिकोऽपि वनं ययौ॥
English Translation: Their coats of mail cut-off with shafts having straight points and wings of gold and themselves covered all over with blood, (those two heroes) looked as beautiful as.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गालवोऽपि सुपर्णेन सह निर्यात्य दक्षिणाम्। मनसाऽतिप्रतीतेन कन्यामिदमुवाच ह॥
English Translation: A fair of beautiful Kalpa trees or a couple of handsome Kinsuka trees laden with flowers, on the field of battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जातो दानपतिः पुत्रस्त्वया शूरस्तथापरः। सत्यधर्मरतश्चान्यो यज्वा चापि तथाऽपरः॥
English Translation: Then, O great king, both the heroes pierced with shafts (sticking to their bodies) looked beautiful like a couple of Salmali trees (covered) with prickly thorns.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदागच्छ वरारोहे तारितस्ते पिता सुतैः। चत्वारश्चैव राजानस्तथा चाहं सुमध्यमे॥
English Translation: O king, looking delightedly at each other with expanded eyes which became red in wrath, they seemed to consume each other (with their fiery glances).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गालवस्त्वभ्यनुज्ञाय सुपर्णं पन्नगाशनम्। पितुर्निर्यात्य तां कन्यां प्रययौ वनमेव ह॥
English Translation: Inflamed with wrath, your brother-in-law, pierced, as it were with a smile, the son of Madri in the chest with keen and barbed dart.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच तथा प्रयाते शिविरं द्रोणपुत्रे महारथे। कच्चित् कृपश्च भोजश्च भयार्ती न व्यवर्तताम्॥
English Translation: Your brother-in-law wielder of bow, wounded Nakula extremely. He fell down on his chariot and filled with very grief.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कच्चिन्न वारितौ क्षुदै रक्षिभर्नोपलक्षितौ। असह्यमिति मन्वानौ न निवृत्ती महारथौ॥
English Translation: Beholding his bitter and haughty foe in that (pitiable) plight, Shakuni roared there like the clouds at the end of summer.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कच्चिदुन्मथ्य शिविरं हत्वा सोमकपाण्डवान्। दुर्योधनस्य पदवीं गतौ परमिको रणे॥
English Translation: Then, Nakula, the son of Pandu, recovering his senses once again rushed against the son of Subala like death itself with gaping mouth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पञ्चालैनिहतौ वीरौ कच्चिन्नास्वपतां क्षितौ। कच्चित् ताभ्यां कृतं कर्म तन्ममाचक्ष्व संजय॥
English Translation: He, (then), O best of the Bharatas, wrathfully pierced Shakuni with six (arrows) and again with a hundred long shafts, in the centre of the chest.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच तस्मिन् प्रयाते शिविरं द्रोणपुत्रे महात्मनि। कृपश्च कृतवर्मा च शिविरद्वर्यतिष्ठताम्॥
English Translation: (He then cut-off) his bow with the arrow fixed (on the string) into two fragments, at the points at which it is grasped. (Then), quickly cutting off his standard, (he) caused it to fall from his car to the ground.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अश्वत्थामा तु त. दृष्ट्वा यत्नवन्तौ महारथौ। प्रहृष्टः शनकै राजन्निदं वचनमब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: Nakula, the son of Pandu, (then), having pierced his thigh with a sharpened, will tempered and keen dart.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यत्तौ भवन्तौ पर्याप्तौ सर्वक्षत्रस्य नाशने। किं पुनर्योधशेषस्य प्रसुप्तस्य विशेषतः॥
English Translation: Caused him to fall down as a hunter (causes) a winged hawk to drop down. O great king, (thus) pierced deeply, he sark down on the terrace of his car.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अहं प्रवेक्ष्ये शिविरं चरिष्यामि च कालवत्। यथा न कश्चिदपि वा जीवन् मुच्येत मानवः॥
English Translation: Clasping the flag-staff, like a lustful person (embracing) his lady-love. O sinless one, seeing your brother-in-law lose his senses and drop down.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथाभवद्भ्या कार्यं स्यादित मे निश्चितामतिः। इत्युक्तवाप्राविशद् द्रौणिः पार्थानां शिविरं महत्॥ अद्वारेणाभ्यवस्कन्ध विहाय भयमात्मनः।
English Translation: His charioteer quickly carried him away on his car from the van of battle. Then sons of Pritha and all those who followed them gave utterance to a loud roar.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स प्रविश्य महाबाहुरुद्देशज्ञश्च तस्य ह॥ धृष्टद्युम्नस्य निलयं शनकैरभ्युपागमत्।
English Translation: On the defeat of his foe in battle, Nakula. the scorcher of foes, said to his charioteer "convey me towards Drona's division."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते तु कृत्वा महत् कर्म श्रान्ताच बलवद् रणे॥ प्रसुप्ताश्चैव विश्वस्ताः स्वसैन्यपरिवारिताः।
English Translation: Hearing those words of the son of Madri, his charioteer, conveyed him to the spot where, O king, Drona took his stand.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ प्रविश्य तद् वेश्म धृष्टद्युम्नस्य भारत॥ पाञ्चाल्यं शयनेद्रौणिपश्यत् सुप्तमन्तिकात्।
English Translation: Kripa, the son of Saradvata, rushed with great impetuosity and resoluteness, against the highly-powerful Sikhandi who was advancing in order to slay Drona.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क्षौमावदाते महति स्पास्तरणसंवृते॥ माल्यप्रवरसंयुक्ते धूपैश्चूर्णैश्च वासिते।
English Translation: Sikhandi, the subduer of foes, pierced as it were with a smile the son of Goutama advancing furiously (again him) towards the vicinity of Drona, with nine arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं शयानं महात्मानं विश्रब्धमकुतोभयम्॥ प्राबोधयत पादेन शयनस्थं महीपते।
English Translation: The preceptor, devoted to the welfare of your sons, having, O great monarch, pierced him with five shafts, struck him again with twenty (more).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सम्बुध्य चरणस्पर्शादुत्थाय रणदुर्मदः॥ अभ्यजानादमेयात्मा द्रोणपुत्रं महारथम्।
English Translation: (Then), O lord of the earth, the encounter that ensued between them was as dreadful as that between the (Asura) Samvara and the lord of the immortals in the war between the celestials and the Asuras.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमुत्पतन्तं शयनादश्वत्थामा महाबलः॥ केशेष्वालभ्य पाणिभ्यां निष्पिपेष महीतले।
English Translation: Invincible in battle, those two heroic and great car-warrior covered the firmament with arrowy nets like the clouds (covering the sky) at the end of summer,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सबलं तेन निष्पिष्टः साध्वसेन च भारत॥ निद्रया चैव पाञ्चाल्यो नाशकच्चेष्टितुं तदा।
English Translation: That night which was naturally of a terrible aspect became more dreadful, o best of the Bharatas, to the combatants engaged in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमाक्रम्य पदा राजन् कण्ठे चोरसि चोभयोः॥ नदन्तं विस्फुरन्तं च पशुमापममारयत्। तुदन्नखैस्तु स द्राणिं नातिव्यक्तमुदाहरत्॥
English Translation: That awfully-dreadful night striking terror (into very heart) seemed to be the death-night (of all the combatants). Then, O great monarch, Shikandi cut-off the great bow of the son of Goutama with a crescent-shaped (dart) and poured down sharpened arrows (at him). Kripa, then, O monarch, excited with rage, hurled a formidable dart.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आचार्यपुत्र शस्त्रेण जहि मां मा चिरं कृथाः। त्वत्कृते सुकृताँल्लोकान् गच्छेयं द्विपदां वर॥
English Translation: Furnished with a golden handle, having keen point and polished by a black-smith. (But) Shikhandin severed it, as it was making for him, with ten darts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्त्वा तु वचन विरराम परंतपः। सुतः पाञ्चालराजस्य आक्रान्तो बलिना भृशम्॥
English Translation: That dart ornamented with gold, dropped down to the ground. Thereupon, the son of Goutama, that best of speakers, taking up a fresh bow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्याव्यक्तां तु तां वाचं संश्रुत्य द्रौणिरब्रवीत्। ते आचार्यघातिना लोका न सन्ति कुलपांसन॥ तस्माच्छस्त्रेण निधनं न त्वमर्हसि दुर्मते।
English Translation: Covered Shikhandin, Ogreat monarch, with sharpened arrows. (Thus) covered (with shafts) by the high-souled son of Goutama in that battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं ब्रुवाणस्तं वीरं सिंहो मत्तमिव द्विपम्॥ मर्मस्वभ्यवधीत् क्रुद्धः पादाष्ठीलैः सुदारुणैः।
English Translation: Shikhandin, the foremost of car-warriors, sank down exhausted on the terrace of his car. Kripa, the son of Saradvata, seeing himself exhausted in that engagement.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य वीरस्य शब्देन मार्यमाणस्य वेश्मनि॥ अबुध्यन्त महाराज स्त्रियो ये चास्य रक्षिणः।
English Translation: Struck him with numerous arrows, 0 Bharata, (actuated) with the desire of slaying him. Witnessing defeat of that great carwarrior, the son of Jajnasena in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दृष्ट्वा धर्षयन्तं तमतिमानुषविक्रमम्॥ भूतमेवाध्यवस्यन्तो न स्म प्रव्याहरन् भयात्।
English Translation: The Panchalas as well as the Somakas surrounded him on all sides (for rescuing him). In like manner, your sons also surrounded that excellent Brahmana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं तु तेनाभ्युपायेन गमयित्वा यमक्षयम्॥ अध्यतिष्ठत तेजस्वी रथं प्राप्य सुदर्शनम्।
English Translation: With a vast force. Then there took place a battle again, o king, between car-warriors engaged in striking one another.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तस्य भवनाद् राजन् निष्क्रम्यानादयनंदिशः॥ रथेन शिविरं प्रायाज्जिघांसुर्द्विषतो बली।
English Translation: And O lord of the earth, O Bharata, there arose a tumultuous uproar, like the roar of the clouds, as the horse-man and elephants rushed against.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपक्रान्ते ततस्तस्मिन् द्रोणपुत्रे महारथे।॥ सहित रक्षिभिः सर्वैः प्राणेदुर्योषितस्तदा।
English Translation: And slaughtered one another. The battle, the. 0 monarch, became terrific. In consequence of the tread of foot-soldiers rushing along, the earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजानं निहतं दृष्ट्वा भृशं शोकपरायणाः॥ व्याक्रोशन् क्षत्रियाः सर्वे धृष्टद्युम्नस्य भारत।
English Translation: O great king, began to tremble like an affrighted lady. Ascending their cars, carwarriors rushed furiously against.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तासां तु तेन शब्देन समीपे क्षत्रियर्षभाः॥ क्षिप्रं च समनह्यन्त किमेतदिति चाब्रुवन्।
English Translation: And, O king, attacked numerous (other carwarriors), as crows (attack) winged insects. In the same manner, elephants, with the juice trickling down their bodies, resolutely attacked great elephants (of the opposite side) with juice trickling down their bodies, O Bharata. Horsemen approaching horsemen and foot soldiers (approaching) foot soldiers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्त्रियस्तु जन् वित्रस्ता भारद्वाजं निरीक्ष्य ताः॥ अब्रुवन् दीनकण्ठेन क्षिप्रमाद्रवतेति वै।
English Translation: In that battle, angrily encountered one another, without getting the better of one another. Terrific indeed as the sound caused by the rush, retreat and return of the combatants at dead of night. (Innumerable) blazing lamps placed upon cars, elephants and horses.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राक्षसो वा मनुष्यो वा नैनं जानीमहे वयम्॥ हत्वा पञ्चालराजानं रथमारुह्य तिष्ठति।
English Translation: Looked, O great king, like large meteors drooping from the firmament. O foremost of the Bharatas, that night blazed up by those lamps.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्ते योधमुख्याश्च सहसा पर्यवारयन्॥ स तानापततः सर्वान् रुद्रास्त्रेण व्यपोथयत्।
English Translation: Looked as (bright as) day, O king, on the field of battle. As the sun dispels dense darkness hanging all over.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृष्टद्युम्नं च हत्वा स तांश्चैवास्य पदानुगान्॥ अपश्यच्छयने सुप्तमुत्तमौजसमन्तिके।
English Translation: So that pitchy darkness pervading the field of battle was destroyed by those blazing lamps. The firmament, the earth, the cardinal and the minor points.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तपप्यक्रम्य पादेन कण्ठे चोरसि तेजसा॥ तथैव मारयामास विनर्दन्तमरिंदमम्।
English Translation: (Hitherto) buried in darkness and dust, again blazed with the lustre (of those lamps). The lustre of weapons, armours and gems belonging to the high-souled (combatants).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधामन्युश्च सम्प्राप्तो मत्वा तं रक्षसा हतम्॥ गदामुद्यम्य वेगेन हृदि द्रौणिमताडयत्।
English Translation: Was cast into shade by the light of those blazing (lamps), when during that night, the battle was raging hot and furious.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमभिदुत्य जग्राह क्षितौ चैनमपातयत्॥ विस्फुरन्तं च पशुवत् तथैवेनममारयत्।

English Translation: This Kshatriya said You seem, O Chandala, to be old in years, but your conduct appears to be like that of a boy! Sanskrit Shloka: आक्षेपणेन चैवासेस्त्रिधा रक्तोक्षितोऽभवत्॥ तस्य लोहितरक्तस्य दीप्तखड्गस्य युध्यतः।
English Translation: It is plain that such acts as are censured by the pious are ordained for the Chandala. Why, indeed, do you seek to wash off the spots of milk from your body.

Sanskrit Shloka: अमानुष इवाकारो बभौ परमभीषणः॥ ये त्वजाग्रन्त कौरव्य तेऽपि शब्देन मोहिताः। निरीक्ष्यमाणा अन्योन्यं दृष्ट्वा दृष्ट्वा प्रविव्यथुः॥
English Translation: The Chandala said Formerly, O king, certain kine belonging to a Brahmana were stolen, While they were being carried away, some milk from their udders dropped upon a number of Soma plants that grew by the roadside. Those Brahmanas who drank the juice of the plants thus bedewed with milk, as also the king who celebrated the sacrifice in which that Soma was drunk, had to sink in hell. Indeed, for having thus appropriated something belonging to a Brahmana, the king with all the Brahmanas who had helped him had to go to hell.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तद् रूपं तस्य ते दृष्ट्वा क्षत्रिया: शत्रुकर्षिणः। राक्षसं मन्यमानास्तं नयनानि न्यमीलयन्॥
English Translation: All those men also, Brahmanas and Kshatriyas, who drank milk or clarified butter or curds, in the palace of the king who had stolen the Brahmana's kine, had to fall into hell.

Sanskrit Shloka: स घोररूयो व्यचरत् कालवच्छिविरे ततः। अपश्यद् द्रौपदीपुत्रानवशिष्टांश्च सोमकन्॥
English Translation: The stolen kine also, shaking their bodies, killed with their milk the sons and grandsons of those who had stolen them, as also the king and the queen although the latter treated the animals, with great care and attention.

Sanskrit Shloka: तेन शब्देन वित्रस्ता धनुर्हस्ता महारथाः। धृष्टद्युम्नं हतं श्रुत्वा द्रौपदेया विशाम्पते॥
English Translation: As for myself, O king, I used to live the life of a celibate in that place where these kine were placed after they had been stolen away. The food I had got by begging became sprinkled over with the milk of those kine.

Sanskrit Shloka: अवाकिरशरवातैर्भारद्वाजदमभीतवत्। ततस्तेन निनादेन सम्प्रबुद्धाः प्रभद्रकाः॥
English Translation: Having taken that food, O Kshatriya, I have, in this life, become a Chandala. The king who had stolen the kine belonging to a Brahmana came by a wretched end.

Sanskrit Shloka: शिलीमुखैः शिखण्डी च द्रोणपुत्रं समादयन्। भारद्वाजः स तान् दृष्ट्वा शरवर्षाणि वर्षतः॥ ननाद बलवन्नादं जिघांसुस्तान् महारथान्।
English Translation: Hence, one should never steal or appropriate anything belonging to a Brahmana. Mark, to what state I am reduced on account of my having eaten food that had been sprinkled over with milk belonging to a Brahmana.

Sanskrit Shloka: ततः परमसंक्रुद्धः पितुर्वधमनुस्मरन्॥ अवरुह्य रतोपस्थात् त्वरमाणोऽभिदुद्रुवे।
English Translation: It is for this reason that Soma plants should never be destroyed by wise men. They who sell the Soma plant are held in low esteem by the wise.

English Translation: Indeed, O son, they who purchase Soma and they who sell it, both sink in the hell called Raurava after death.

Sanskrit Shloka: ततः स नरशार्दूलः प्रतिविन्ध्यं महाहवे। कुक्षिदेशेऽवधीद् राजन् स हतो न्यपतद् भुवि॥
English Translation: That man who, possessing a knowledge of the Vedas, duly sells Soma, becomes in his next life a usurer and speedily meets with destruction.

Sanskrit Shloka: प्रासेन विद्ध्वा द्रौणिं तु सुतसोमः प्रतापवान्। पुनश्चासिं समुद्यम्य द्रोणपुत्रमुपाद्रवत्॥
English Translation: For threehundred times he has to sink into hell and become changed into an animal which subsists upon human excreta. Sanskrit Shloka: सुतसोमस्य सासिं तं बाहुं छित्त्वा नरर्षभ। पुनरप्याहनत् पार्श्वे स भिन्नहृदयोऽपतत्॥
English Translation: It is through pride that living creatures come by such a miserable end. On account of such conduct and such food, I have come by this state. Mark, the। reverses engendered by Time! Like a person whose cloth has caught fire at one end, or who is pursued by bees, see, I am running, filled with fear, and smeared with dust! The householders are rescued from all sins by a study of the wise. Sanskrit Shloka: नाकुलिस्तु शतानीको रथचक्रेण वीर्यवान्। दोामुक्षिप्य वेगेन वक्षस्येनमताडयत्॥

Sanskrit Shloka: अताडयच्छतानीकं मुक्तचक्रं द्विजस्तु सः। स विह्वलो ययौ भूमिं ततोऽस्पाहरच्छिरः॥

Sanskrit Shloka: श्रुतकर्मा तु परिघं गृहीत्वा समताडयत्। अभिद्रुत्य ययौ द्रौणिं सव्ये सफलके भृशम्॥

Sanskrit Shloka: ततो भीष्मनिहन्ता तं सह सर्वैः प्रभद्रकैः। अहनत् सर्वतो वीरं नानाप्रहरणैर्बली॥ शिलीमुखेन चान्येन भ्रुवोर्मध्ये समार्पयत्।

Sanskrit Shloka: स तु क्रोधसमाविष्टो द्रोणपुत्रो महाबलः॥ शिखण्डिनं समासाद्य द्विधाचिच्छेद सोऽसिना।

Sanskrit Shloka: स्वप्ने सुप्तान्नयन्तीं तां रात्रिष्वन्यासु मारिष। ददृशुर्योधमुख्यास्ते जन्तं द्रौणिं च सर्वदा॥

Sanskrit Shloka: पुनश्च सुविचित्रेण शतचन्द्रेण चर्मणा। तेन चाकाशवर्णेन तथाचरत सोऽसिना॥
English Translation: I have now come to you, you are both great experts in arms. I shall be able to consume Khandava with your help. This is the food I desire to have from you.

Sanskrit Shloka: विस्वरं चुक्रुशुश्चान्ये बह्ववद्धं तथा वदन्। न च स्म प्रत्यपद्यन्त शस्त्राणि वसनानि च॥
English Translation: When Agni consumed the Khandava in wrath, there was certainly a grave cause for it. I desire to hear from you all this in detail. O Rishi, tell me why the Khandava (forest) was consumed (by fire) in the days of yore.

Sanskrit Shloka: विमुक्तकेशाश्चाग्यन्ये नाभ्यजानन्, परस्परम्। उत्पतन्तोऽपतश्रान्ताः केचित् तत्राभ्रमंस्तदा॥
English Translation: O king, hear I am telling you the whole story of why Khandava forest was consumed by the fire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुरीषमसृजन् केचित् केचिन्मूत्रं प्रसुस्रुवुः। बन्धनानि च राजेन्द्र संच्छिद्य तुरगा द्विपाः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said : O best of men, I shall narrate to you the story of the destruction of the Khandavas as told by the Rishis in the Puranas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: समं पर्यपतंश्चान्ये कुर्वन्तो महदाकुलम्। तत्र केचिन्नरा भीता व्यलीयन्त महीतले॥
English Translation: O king, it has been heard in the Puranas that there was a king named Shvetaki who was endued with both strength and prowess and who was a rival to Indra himself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथैव तान् निपतितानपिंघन् गजवाजिनः। तस्मिंस्तथा वर्तमाने रक्षांसि पुरुषर्षभ॥
English Translation: None has equalled him in sacrifices, charity and intelligence. He performed five great sacrifices and many other smaller ones, in all of which Dakshinas (presents to Brahmanas) were very large.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हृष्टानि व्यनदनुच्चैर्मुदा भरतसत्तम। स शब्दः पूरितो राजन् भूतसंधैर्मुदायुतैः॥
English Translation: O king, the heart of that monarch was always set upon sacrifices, religious rites and gifts of all kind. That greatly intelligent king performed sacrifices for many years, assisted by the Ritvijas till they, becoming weak and their eyes afflicted with smoke, left that king, wishing never more to assist him at his sacrifices. The king, however, again and again asked them to come to him, but on account of their sore eyes, they did not come.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपूरयद् दिशः सर्वा दिवं चातिमहान् स्वनः। तेषामार्तरवं श्रुत्वा वित्रस्ता गजवाजिनः॥
English Translation: Thereupon the king with the permission of the Ritvijas completed his sacrifices with the assistance of other Ritvijas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मुक्ताः पर्यपतन् राजन् मृद्नन्तः शिविरे जनम्। तैस्तत्र परिधावद्धिश्चरणोदीरितं रजः॥
English Translation: Some days after, he desired to perform another sacrifice which would extend for one hundred years. But the illustrious king did not get any Ritvijas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अकरोच्छिविरे तेषां रजन्यां द्विगुणं तमः। तस्मिस्तमसि संजाते प्रमूढाः सर्वतो जनाः॥ नाजानन् पितरः पुत्रान् भ्रातॄन् भ्रातर एव च।
English Translation: They high-souled king with his friends and relatives again and again courted them by bowing down to them, by conciliatory speeches and by the gifts of wealth. But they refused to accomplish the purpose of that greatly effulgent (king).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गजा गजानतिक्रम्य निर्मनुष्या हया हयान्॥ अताड्यंस्तथाभजंस्तथामृद्रश्च भारत।
English Translation: Thereupon that royal sage thus spoke to them in anger, sitting in their own hermitage, “O Brahmanas, if I were a fallen person, if I were in wanting in service to you, I should then deserve to be abandoned by you and other Brahmanas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते भग्नाः प्रपतन्ति स्म निघ्नन्तश्च परस्परम्॥ न्यपातयंस्तथा चान्यान् पातयित्वा तदापिषन्।
English Translation: O excellent Brahmanas, as I am neither degraded, nor wanting in homage to you, you should not obstruct sacrifice performed by me and abandon me thus without sufficient reason. O Brahmanas, I seek your protection, you should be propitious to me. () excellent Brahmanas, if you abandon me from enmity alone, I shall go to other Brahmanas and I shall ask for their assistance at my sacrifice. Conciliating them with sweet words and speeches, I shall tell them what is my business to be done so that they may accomplish it."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विचेतसः सनिद्राश्च तमसा चावृता नरः॥ जग्मुः स्वानेव तत्राथ कालेनैव प्रचोदिताः।
English Translation: Having said this, the king became silent. The Brahmanas knew well that they could not assist that chastiser of foes at his sacrifice; therefore they pretended to be angry with that best of kings and they said, "O best of kings, your sacrifices are incessant.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्यक्त्वा द्वाराणि च द्वाःस्थास्तथा गुल्मानि गौल्मिकः॥ प्राद्रवन्त यथाशक्ति कांदिशीका विचेतसः।
English Translation: We have been fatigued by assisting you (at your sacrifices). We are tried in consequence of this labour; therefore, you should give us leave (to go away). O sinless one, from your loss of judgement only you cannot wait. Go to Rudra (Shiva); he will assist you at your sacrifice."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विप्रणष्टाश्च तेऽन्योन्यं नाजानन्त तथा विभो॥ क्रोशन्तस्तात पुत्रेति दैवोपहतचेतसः।
English Translation: Having heard these words of censure and wrath, the king Shvetaki became angry. Going to the Kailasa mountain, he begin to worship the God (Shiva), observing rigid vows and performing austere penances. Giving up all food, he passed many years.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पलायतां दिशस्तेषां स्वानप्युत्सृज्य बान्धवान्॥ गोत्रनामभिरन्योन्यमाक्रन्दन्त ततो जनाः।
English Translation: He only ate fruits and roots sometimes at the twelfth and sometimes at the sixteenth hour of the day.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हाहाकारं च कुर्वाणाः पृथिव्यां शेरते परे॥ तान् बुद्ध्वा रणमत्तोऽसौ द्रोणपुत्रो व्यपोथयत्।
English Translation: He stood like the trunk of a tree. For six months with upraised arms and eyes fixed, the king performed the severest penances there (on the Kailasa mountain).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्रापरे वध्यमाना मुहुर्मुहुरचेतसः॥ शिविरान् निष्पतन्ति स्म क्षत्रिया भयपीडिताः।
English Translation: O descendant of Bharata, Shankara (Shiva) was greatly pleased; and he at last appeared before him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तांस्तु निष्पतितांस्रस्तान् शिविराजीवितैषिणः॥ कृतवर्मा कृपश्चैव द्वारदेशे निजघ्नतुः।
English Translation: He said," O chastiser of foes, O best of men, I have been much pleased with your asceticism.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विस्रस्तयन्त्रकवचान् मुक्तकेशान् कृताञ्जलीन्॥ वेपमानान् क्षितौ भीतान् नैव कांश्चिदमुञ्चताम्।
English Translation: O king, now ask the boon you desire," Hearing these words of the immeasurably effulgent Rudra (Shiva). The royal sage bowed to him and thus replied to him,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नामुच्यत तयोः कश्चिन्निष्क्रान्तः शिविराद् बहिः। कृपश्चैव महाराज हार्दिक्यश्चैव दुर्मतिः।
English Translation: O illustrious one, O chief of the celestial, O god of gods, if you are pleased with me, assist me then in my sacrifices.” Having heard these words of the king, the deity was pleased and smilingly replied,
We ourselves do not assist at scarifics. But O king, O chastiser of foes, as you have undergone the severest of penances with the desire of obtaining a boon, I shall assist you at your sacrifice on this condition.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भूयश्चैव चिकीर्षन्तौ द्रोणपुत्रस्य तौ प्रियम्॥ त्रिषु देशेषु ददतुः शिविरस्य हुताशनम्।
English Translation: Rudra said: O king of kings, if for full twelve years you can incessantly pour libations of ghee into the sacrificial fire, you yourself leading all the while the life of a Brahmachari. Then, o king, you can obtain me, for the purpose for which you ask me."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः प्रकाशे शिविरे खड्डेन पितृनन्दनः॥ अश्वत्थामा महाराज व्यचरत् कृतहस्तवत्।
English Translation: Having been thus addressed by Rudra, the king Shvetaki did what he was asked to do by the wielder of Shula (Shiva). When twelve years were completed, he again came to Maheshwara (Shiva).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कांश्चिदापततो वीरानपरांश्चैव धावतः॥ व्ययोजयत खड्ड्रेन प्राणैर्दिवरोत्तमः।
English Translation: On seeing the king and being much pleased with him, the creator of the world Shankara (Shiva) spoke thus to that best of monarchs, Shvetaki.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कांश्चिद् योधान् स खड्ड्रेन मध्ये संछिद्य वीर्यवान्।। ११२ अपातयद् द्रोणपुत्रः संरब्धस्तिलकाण्डवत्।
English Translation: O best of kings, I have been pleased with your (great) act. O chastiser of foes, the duty of assisting at scarifies belongs to the Brahmanas.
O chastiser of foes, therefore, I shall not myself assist you at your sacrifice today. There is one earth a greatly illustrious and best of Brahmanas who is a portion of my own self.
He is known by the name of Durvasa. He will assist you at your sacrifice. He is endued with ascetic powers, he will assist you. Therefore, let every preparation be made (by you).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निनदद्भिर्भूशायस्तै राश्वद्विरदोत्तमैः॥ पतितैरभवत् कीर्णा मेदिनी भरतर्षभ।
English Translation: Having heard these words of Rudra, the king returned to his capital and begin to collect all that were necessary for his sacrifice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मानुषाणां सहस्रेषु हतेषु पतितेषु च॥ उदतिष्ठन् कबन्धानि बहून्युत्थाय चापत्तन्।
English Translation: When every thing had been collected, the king again appeared before Shankara and said, “Every necessary things has been collected. And through your grace all my preparations are ready. O god of gods, let me, therefore be installed in the sacrifices tomorrow.” Having heard these words of the illustrious king. Rudra summoned Durvasa and spoke to him thus, O best of Brahmanas, this is the high-souled king Shvetaki. O chief of Brahmanas assist him at his sacrifice at my command." The Rishi said to Rudra, “Be it so."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सायुधान्साङ्गदान्बाहून विचकर्त शिरांसि च॥ हस्तिहस्तोपमानूरून हस्तान् पादांश्च भारत।
English Translation: Thereupon the sacrifice for which the illustrious king made preparations who performed according to the ordinance, at the proper season and a with large amount of Dakshinas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पृष्ठच्छिन्नान् पार्श्वच्छिन्नाशिरश्छिन्नांस्तथा परान्।। ११६ स महात्माकरोद् द्रौणिः कांश्चिचापि पराङ्मुखान्।
English Translation: When the sacrifice of that illustrious king came to an end, all the other priests that assisted at it went away with the permission of Durvasa. All other greatly effulgent Sadasyas also, who had been installed in that sacrifice, went away. O king, then that high-souled (royal sage) entered his own palace.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मध्यदेशे नरानन्यांश्चिच्छेदान्यांश्च कर्णतः॥ अंसदेशे निहत्यान्यान् काये प्रावेशयच्छिरः।
English Translation: The Brahmanas well-versed in the Vedas adorned him and singers praised him. The people of the city welcomed him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं विचरतस्तस्य निघ्नतः सुबहून् नरान्॥ तमसा रजनी घोरा बभौ दारुणदर्शना।
English Translation: The great king Shvetaki was always righteous. After a long time, adorning by all, he went to the herven accompanied by all members and Ritvijas of the sacrifice. Agni drank ghee for twelve years in his sacrifice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किञ्चित्प्राणैश्च पुरुषैर्हतैश्चान्यैः सहस्रशः॥ बहुना च गजाश्वेन भूरभूद् भीमदर्शना।
English Translation: In that unique sacrifice Agni drank large quantity of Ghee, which provided him enormous satisfaction.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यक्षरक्षःसमाकीर्णे रथाश्वद्विपदारुणे॥ क्रुद्धेन द्रोणपुत्रेण संछन्नाः प्रापतन् भुवि।
English Translation: Now, he had no desire to take more oblation from others. Thereupon the illustrious Agni became pale, (because he drank a very large quantity of ghee in that sacrifice). He could not shine as before.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भातृनन्ये पितॄनन्ये पुत्रानन्ये विचुक्रुशुः॥ केचिदूचुर्न तत् क्रुद्धैर्धार्तराष्ट्रः कृतं रणे। कृतं यत् नः प्रसुप्तानां रक्षोभिः क्रूरकर्मभिः॥
English Translation: Then the lord Agni brought some mistransformations in his stomach. Being lusterless he felt hatred.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: असांनिध्याद्धि पार्थानामिदं नः कदनं कृतम्। न चासुरैर्न गन्धर्वैर्न च यक्षैर्न च राक्षसैः॥
English Translation: Seeing himself pale, Agni went to the sacred abode of Brahma ever adorned by all.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शक्यो विजेतुं कौन्तेयो गोप्ता यस्य जनार्दनः। ब्रह्मण्यः सत्यवाग् दान्तः सर्वभूतानुकम्पकः॥ न च सुप्तं प्रमत्तं वा न्यस्तशस्त्रं कृताञ्जलिम्। धावन्तं मुक्तकेशं वा हन्ति पार्थो धनंजयः॥
English Translation: Coming to Brahma seated (on his throne), he spoke to him thus, King Svetaki satisfied me by his sacrifice. O lord of the universe, I am reduced both in splendour and strength. I desire to regain my own permanent nature through your grade."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदिदं नः कृतं घोरं रक्षोभिः क्रूरकर्मभिः। इति लालप्यमानाः स्म शेरते बहवो जनाः॥
English Translation: Having heard these words of Agni, the illustrious creator of all the worlds. Smilingly thus spoke to Agni, “You have drunk continuously for twelve years a very large quantity of ghee poured into your mouth. O exalted Deity, it is for this you have been affected with illness. O Agni, you have, therefore, suddenly lost both your splendour strength. O Agni, do not grieve for it. You shall soon regain your own nature. I shall dispel you this malady.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्तनतां च मनुष्याणामपरेषां च कूजताम्। ततो मुहूर्तात् प्राशाम्यत् स शब्दस्तुमुलो महान्।। १२७
English Translation: O Agni, the abode of the enemies of the celestial, the fearful forest of Khandava, which at the request of the celestial you reduced to washes in the days of yorc has again been filled with numerous creatures. When you will eat the fat of all those creatures (now living in the Khandava), you will then regain your own nature.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शोणितव्यतिषिक्तायां वसुधायां च भूमिप। तद्रजस्तुमुलं घोरं क्षणेनान्तरधीयत॥
English Translation: Go there soon to consume it with all its living creatures. You will then certainly be cured of your malady." Having heard these words that were uttered by the Supreme Deity, Agni proceeded with great speed (towards that great forest). Arriving at the fearful Khandava forest in full vigour, he suddenly blazed up with the help of the wind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स चेष्टमानानुद्विग्नान् निरुत्साहान् सहस्रशः। न्यपातयनरान् क्रुद्धः पशून् पशुपतिर्यथा॥
English Translation: Seeing the Khandava on fire, the dwellers of that forest made great efforts to extinguish it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्योन्यं सम्परिष्वज्य शयानान् द्रवतोऽपरान्। संलीनान् युद्ध्यमानांश्च सर्वान् द्रौणिरपोथयत्॥
English Translation: Hundreds and thousands of elephants speedily brought water in their trunks and they scattered it over the fire in great wrath.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दह्यमाना हुताशेन वध्यमानाश्च तेन ते। परस्परं तदा योधा अनयन् यमसादनम्॥
English Translation: Many-headed snakes, becoming mad with anger, speedily scattered on the fire water from their many hoods.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्या रजन्यास्त्वर्धन पाण्डवानां महद् बलम्। गमयामास राजेन्द्र द्रौणिर्थमनिवेशनम्॥
English Translation: O best of the Bharata race, they and the other creatures that lived in that forest soon extinguished the fire by various means and efforts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निशाचराणां सत्त्वानां रात्रिः सा हर्षवर्धिनी। आसीन्नरगजाश्वानां रौद्री क्षयकरी भृशम्॥
English Translation: Thus Agni blazed forth again and again in the Khandava (forest), but the blazing fire was again and again extinguished by the dwellers of that forest.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्रादृश्यन्त रक्षांसि पिशाचाश्च पृथग्विधाः। खादन्तो नरमांसानि पिबन्तः शोणितानि च॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said Beholding the troops broken and routed Kunti's son Dhananjaya of illustrious soul, rallied them from a desire of slaying the son of Drona.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: करालाः पिङ्गलाश्चैव शैलदन्ता रजस्वला:। जटिला दीर्घशङ्खाश्च पञ्चपादा महोदराः॥
English Translation: Rallied with effort by Arjuna and Govinda. O king, the troops stayed on the field of battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पश्चादगुलयो रूक्षा विरूपा भैरवस्वनाः। घण्टाजालावसक्ताश्च नीलकण्ठा विभीषणाः॥
English Translation: Then Vibhatsu, supported by the Somakas, Matsyas, Andhas and Kouravas returned to the charge.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सपुत्रदाराः सक्रूराः सुदुर्दर्शाः सुनिघृणाः। विविधानि च रूपाणि तत्रादृश्यन्त रक्षसाम्॥
English Translation: Then the fierce bowman Savyasachin, rushing quickly upon Ashvatthaman having the lions tail as the device on his banner, spoke these words to the latter.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पीत्वा च शोणितं हृष्टाः प्रानृत्यन् गणशोऽपरे। इदं परमिदं मेध्यमिदं स्वाद्विति चाब्रुवन्॥
English Translation: All your might, your energy, your knowledge, your manliness, you partiality for the sons of Dhritarashtra, you hostility against us.

Sanskrit Shloka: मेदोमज्जास्थिरक्तानां वसानां च भृशाशिताः। परमांसानि खादन्तः क्रव्यादा मांसजीविनः॥ वसाश्चैवापरे पीत्वा पर्यधावन् विकुक्षिकाः। नानावक्त्रास्तथा रौद्राः क्रव्यादाः पिशिताशनाः।। १४० अयुतानि च तत्रासन् प्रयुतान्यर्बुदानि च। रक्षसां घोररूपाणां महतां क्रूरकर्मणाम्॥ मुदितानां वितृप्तानां तस्मिन् महति वैशसे। समेतानि बहून्यासन् भूतानि च जन धिप॥
English Translation: And all your fiercest prowess do you now display to me. Even that son of Prisata who has slain Drona, your sire, will also humiliate your pride.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रत्यूषकाले शिविरात् प्रतिगन्तुमियेष सः। नृशोणितावसिक्तस्य द्रौणेरासीदसित्सरुः॥ पाणिना सह संश्लिष्ट एकीभूत इव प्रभो।
English Translation: Encounter now the prince of the Panchalas, who is like the fire at the universal destruction or like the Destroyer of his foes, as also me accompanied by Kesava. Today in battle I shall humiliate the pride of your haughty self.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुर्गमां पदवीं गत्वा विरराज जनक्षये॥ युगान्ते सर्वभूतानि भस्म कृत्वेव पावकः।
English Translation: Dhritarashtra said The son of the preceptor is, O Sanjaya, worthy of honour and possessed of prowess; he loved Dhananjaya and enjoys the love of that high-souled warrior.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथाप्रतिज्ञं तत् कर्म कृत्वा द्रौणायनिः प्रभो॥ दुर्गमा पदवीं गच्छन् पितुरासीद् गतज्वरः।
English Translation: Ere this Vibhatsu had never addressed such words to him; why then did the son of Kunti address his friend in that harsh language.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथैव संसुप्तजने शिविरे प्राविशनिशि॥ तथैव हत्वा निःशब्दे निश्चकाम नरर्षभः।
English Translation: Sanjaya said Upon the slaughtering of the youthful Chedi prince, of Vrihatkshatra of Puru's race and O king, of Sudarshana the chief of the Malavas, who was accomplished in the use of all weapons and conversant with the rules of military science.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निष्क्रम्य शिविरात् तस्मात् ताभ्यां संगम्य वीर्यवान्॥ आचख्यौ कर्म तत् सर्वं हृष्टः संहर्षयन् विभो।
English Translation: Upon the defeat of Dhristadyumna, Satyaki and Bhima and cut to the quick by those words of king Yudhishthira.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तावथाचख्यतुस्तस्मै प्रियं प्रियकरौ तदा॥ पञ्चालान् सृञ्जयांश्चैव विनिकृत्तान् सहस्रशः।
English Translation: And agitated at heart and remembering all his former woes, O lord, Vibhatsu was possessed by an anger engendered of brief, the like of which had never possessed him before.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रीत्या चोच्चैरुदक्रोशंस्तथैवास्फोटयंस्तलान्॥ एवंविधा हि सा रात्रि: सोमकानां जनक्षये।
English Translation: For this reason it was that like a mean fellow, he then addressed Ashvatthaman, the son of his preceptor and worthy of his respect in such a vale, cruel, disagreeable and undeserving language.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रसुप्तानां प्रमत्तानामासीत् सुभृशदारुणा॥ असंशयं हि कालस्य पर्यायो दुरतिक्रमः।
English Translation: Thus wrathfully addressed, o king, by Partha in that indecent and harsh language, that foremost of all best bowmen.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच तादृशा निहता यत्र कृत्वास्माकं जनक्षयम्॥ प्रागेव सुमहत् कर्म द्रौणिरेतन्महारथः। नाकरोदीदृशं कस्मान्मत्पुत्रविजये धृतः॥
English Translation: Namely the son of Drona, became extremely angry with Dhananjaya and specially with Krishna. Then that highly puissant hero, staying carefully on his car ruiced his mouth with water.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ कस्माद्धते क्षुद्रं कर्मेदं कृतवानसौ। द्रोणपुत्रो महात्मा स तन्मे शंसितुमर्हसि॥
English Translation: And then invoked into existence this Agneya weapon incapable of being resisted even by the gods. Aiming that weapon at this visible and hidden foes the preceptor's son.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच तेषां नूनं भयान्नासौ कृतवान् कुरुनन्दन। असांनिध्याद्धि पार्थानां केशवस्य च धीमतः॥ सात्यकेश्चापि कर्मेदं द्रोणपुत्रेण साधितम्।
English Translation: That slayer of hostile heroes, filled with extreme raged, let go with due Mantras that shaft that looked resplendent like fire without a curl of smoke.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: को हि तेषां समक्षं तान् हन्यादपि मरुत्पतिः॥ एतदीदृशकं वृत्तं राजन् सुप्तजने विभो।
English Translation: Then from the welkin a thick shower of arrows began to fall and wrapt up in fiery flames those arrows then surrounded Pritha's son on all sides.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो जनक्षयं कृत्वा पाण्डवानां महात्ययम्॥ दिष्ट्या दिष्ट्यैव चान्योन्यं समेत्योचुर्महारथाः। पर्यष्वजत् ततो द्रौणिस्ताभ्यां सम्प्रतिनन्दितः॥ इदं हर्षात् तु सुमहदाददे वाक्यमुत्तमम्। पञ्चाला निहताः सर्वे द्रौपदेयाश्च सर्वशः॥ सोमका मत्स्यशेषाश्च सर्वे विनिहता मया।
English Translation: Meteors dropped down from the concave dome and the points of the compass did not any longer shine; and suddenly a dreadful gloom enveloped the army in its sober folds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इदानीं कृतकृत्याः स्म याम तव मा चिरम्। यदि जीवति नो राजा तस्मै शंसमहे वयम्॥
English Translation: The Rakshasa and the Pisachas, joining together to utter fierced yells; inauspicious winds began to blow and the Sun ceased to shine and give heat.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच सत्यं दमं क्षमा प्रज्ञा प्रशंसन्ति पितामह। विद्वांसो मनुजा लोके कथमेतन्मतं तव॥
English Translation: Ravens fiercely croaked on all sides; on the sky clouds emitted roars of thunder and showered torrents of blood.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच अत्र ते वर्तयिष्येऽहमितिहासं पुरातनम्। साध्यानामिह संवादं हंसस्य च युधिष्ठिर॥
English Translation: Birds, breasts, kine, sages of illustrious vows and tranquil soul, could not then find any peace.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हंसो भूत्वाथ सौवर्णस्त्वजो नित्यः प्रजापतिः। स वै पर्येति लोकांस्त्रीनथ साध्यानुपागमत्॥
English Translation: The very elements became perturbed and the Sun appeared to evolve in an opposite course. The triune world seemed as if afflicted in consequence of being under the influence of a corroding fever.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: साध्या ऊचुः शकुने वयं स्म देवा वै साध्यास्त्वामनुयुक्ष्महे। पृच्छामस्त्वां मोक्षधर्मं भवांश्च किल मोक्षवित्॥
English Translation: Afflicted with the energy of that weapon elephants and other creatures of the land fled with precipitation, breathing heavily and desirous of saving themselves from that fierce energy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रुतोऽसिः न पण्डितो धीरवादी साधुशब्दश्चरते ते पतत्रिन्। किं मन्यसे श्रेष्ठतमं द्विज त्वं कस्मिन्मनस्ते रमते महात्मन्॥
English Translation: The watery expouses being heated, the acquatic creatures, scorched with the heat, O Bharata, could not find any ease.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तन्नः कार्यं पक्षिवर प्रशाधि यत्कार्याणां मन्यसे श्रेष्ठमेकम्। विमुच्यते विहगेन्द्रेह शीघ्रम्॥
English Translation: Showers of shafts, swift-flying as Garuda or the wind itself, fell from all points of the compass, cardinal and subsidiary from the welkin and out of earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हंस उवाच इदं कार्यममृताशाः शृणोमि तपो दमः सत्यमात्माभिगुप्तिः। ग्रन्थीन् विमुच्य हृदयस्य सर्वान् प्रियाप्रिये स्वं वशमानयीत॥
English Translation: Wounded with those arrows of Drona's son, arrows endued with the energy of the thunder, his foes, scorched and consumed began to fall down like trees consumed by fire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नारुन्तुदः स्यान्न नृशंसवादी न हीनतः परमभ्याददीत। ययास्य वाचा पर उद्विजेत न तां वदेद्रुषती पापलोक्याम्॥
English Translation: Dreadfully scorched mighty elephants fell on the ground uttering terrible roars resembling the rumble of clouds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वाक्सायका वदनानिष्पतन्ति यैराहतः शोचति रात्र्यहानि। परस्य नामर्मसु ते पतन्ति तान्पण्डितो नावसृजेत् परेषु॥
English Translation: Other huge elephants scorched with the burning heat fled and careered in fear in battlefield as if in a forest set on fire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भृशं विध्येच्छम एवेह कार्यः। संरोष्यमाणः प्रतिहष्यते यः स आदत्ते सुकृतं वै परस्य॥
English Translation: O Sire, divisions of steeds and hosts of cars were seen there burnt like the tops of trees during a forest conflagration.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क्षेपायमाणमभिषगव्यलीकं निगृह्णाति ज्वलितं यश्च मन्युम्। अदुष्टचेता मुदितोऽनसूयुः स आदत्ते सुकृतं वै परेषाम्॥
English Translation: Thousands and thousands of car divisions then fell on that field; and ( Bharata, the illustrious God of fire then consumed that army of the Pandavas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आक्रुश्यमानो न वदामि किंचित् क्षमाम्यहं ताड्यमानश्च नित्यम्। श्रेष्ठं ह्येतद् यत्क्षमामाहुरार्याः सत्यं तथैवार्जवमानृशंस्यम्॥
English Translation: Like the Samvartaka fire consuming all creatures at the end of a Yuga. Beholding the Pandava troops consumed in that terrible battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वेदस्योपनिषत् सत्यं सत्यस्योपनिषद् दमः। दमस्योपनिषन्मोक्ष एतत् सर्वानुशासनम्॥
English Translation: Your warriors became filled with joy and they uttered loud and defiant war-cries. Then ) Bharata, thousands of drums of various sorts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वाचो वेगं मनसः क्रोधवेगं विधित्सावेगमुदरोपस्थवेगम्। स्तं मन्येऽहं ब्राह्मणं वै मुनिं च॥
English Translation: Were quickly struck up by your troops when victory then appeared sure. The complete host of the Panavas and Sabyasachin himself O king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्तथा तितिक्षुरतितिक्षोर्विशिष्टः। स्तथाज्ञानाज्ज्ञानविद् वै विशिष्टः॥
English Translation: Could not be seen in that dreadful battle in consequence of the darkness that then enveloped the world; O king, we neither heard of, nor beheld the like of the that weapon that a a the revengeful son of Drona then invoked into existence. Thereupon, O mighty monarch, Arjuna invoked into existence the Brahma weapon.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आक्रुश्यमानो नाक्रुश्येन्मन्युरेनं तितिक्षतः। आक्रोष्टारं निर्दहति सुकृतं चास्य विन्दति॥
English Translation: That had been created by lotus-born Brahma for baffling all weapons. Then in a moment only that darkness was dispelled.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यो नात्युक्तः प्राह रूक्षं प्रियं वा यो वा हतो न प्रतिहन्ति धैर्यात्। स्तस्येह देवाः स्पृहयन्ति नित्यम्॥
English Translation: Cold breeze began to blow and the points of the compass became clear and bright. We then beheld wonderful sight, namely, Askshouhini of the Pandavas laid bow.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पापीयसः क्षमेतैव श्रेयसः सदृशस्य च। विमानितो हतोत्क्रुष्ट एवं सिद्धिं गमिष्यति॥
English Translation: Their forms could not be distinguished, so horribly were they scorched by the energy of Ashvatthaman's weapon. Then the two heroic bowmen, Kesava and Arjuna, freed from that darkness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सदाहमार्यान्निभृतोऽप्युपासे न मे विधित्सोत्सहते न रोषः। न वाप्यहं लिप्समानः परैमि न चैव किंचिद् विषयेण यामि॥
English Translation: Appeared like the two dispellers of darkness, the Sun and the Moon, rising in conjunction. The wielder of the Gandiva and Kesava were not at all wounded or injured.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नाहं शप्तः प्रतिशपामि कंचिद् दमं द्वारं ह्यमृतस्येह वेद्मिा गुह्यं ब्रह्म तदिदं ब्रवीमि न मानुषाच्छ्रेष्ठतरं हिं किंचित्॥
English Translation: Freed from that fie with their car, their banners and flags and steeds and excellent weapons, they the shone resplendent inspiring terrors at the heart of your troops.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निर्मुच्यमानः पापेभ्यो घनेभ्य इव चन्द्रमाः। विरजाः कालमाकाङ्क्षन् धीरो धैर्येण सिद्ध्यति॥
English Translation: Then from among the Pandava troops filled with delight, various confused sounds of life mingled with the sounds of drums and the blast of conchs.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यः सर्वेषां भवति ह्यर्चनीय उत्सेधनस्तम्भ इवाभिजातः। यस्मै वाचं सुप्रसन्नां वदन्ति स वै देवान् गच्छति संयतात्मा॥
English Translation: Both the armies had thought Kesava and Arjuna to be destroyed. Beholding Kesava and Arjuna (freed from that fire of the weapon and that darkness) and seeing them quickly reappear.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न तथा वक्तुमिच्छन्ति कल्याणान् पुरुषे गुणान्। यथैषां वक्तमिच्छन्ति नैर्गुण्यमनुयुञ्जकाः॥
English Translation: Both uninjured and cheerful and blowing their excellent conches, the Pandava troops were filled with delight whilst those of yours were greatly pained.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यस्य वाङ्मनसीगुप्ते सम्यक् प्रणिहिते सदा। वेदास्तपश्च त्यागश्च स इदं सर्वमाप्नुयात्॥
English Translation: Then Drona's son also beholding those illustrious warriors free and un-injured, became cheerless and O sire, for a moment only be thought. 'What is this?'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आक्रोशनविमानाभ्यां नाबुधान् बोधयेद् बुधः। तस्मान्न वर्धयेदन्यं न चात्मानं विहिंसयेत्॥
English Translation: Thus reflecting, O king and over-whelmed with grief and anxious contemplation and sighing hot and heavily, he became cheerless in mind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अमृतस्येव संतृप्यदेवमानस्य पण्डितः। सुखं ह्यवमतः शेते योऽवमन्ता स नश्यति॥
English Translation: Then Drona's son throwing aside his bow and leaping down with agility from his car, fled from the field of battle-saying-"O Fie, 0 fie, everything is un-true.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यत् क्रोधनो यजति यद् ददाति यद् वा तपस्तप्यति यज्जुहोति। वैवस्वतस्तद्धरतेऽस्य सर्वं मोघः श्रमो भवति हि क्रोधनस्य॥
English Translation: Then as he was flying, he came across the sinless Vyasa, that compiler of the Vedas, that receptacle of Sarasvati, that habitation of the Vadas, who possess the hue of rain clouds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चत्वारि यस्य द्वाराणि सुगुप्तान्यमरोत्तमाः। उपस्थमुदरं हस्तौ वाक चतुर्थी स धर्मवित्॥
English Translation: O perpetuator of the Kuru race, then Drona's son beholding him stand before him, saluted and then in a voice choked in grief nor
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सत्यं दम ह्यार्जवमानृशंस्यं धृति तितिक्षामतिसेवमानः। मेकान्तशील्यूर्ध्वगतिर्भवेत् सः॥
English Translation: O sire, O sire, is this an illusion or a caprice (on the part of the weapon)? I do not know what this may be? Why has this weapon been repulsed? What has been my fault in the method of its invocation?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वांश्चैनाननुचरन् वत्सवच्चतुरः स्तनान्। न पावनतमं किंचित् सत्यादध्यगमं क्वचित्॥
English Translation: Or is it something beyond the natural order of things or is it the defeat of the three worlds, inasmuch as the two Krishnas are still alive. Time indeed, is irresistible.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आचक्षेऽहं मनुष्येभ्यो देवेभ्यः प्रतिसंचरन्। सत्यं स्वर्गस्य सोपानं पारावारस्य नौरिव॥
English Translation: Neither Asuras, nor Gandharvas, Pisachas, nor Rakshasa, nor Snakes, nor Jakshas, nor insects, nor men.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यादृशैः संनिवसति यादृशांश्योपसेवते। यादृगिच्छेच्च भवितुं तादृग् भवति पूरुषः॥
English Translation: Dare baffle this weapon invoked by me. This weapon however has become pacified having slain only one Akshauhini of troops.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदि सन्तं सेवति यद्यसन्तं तपस्विनं यदि वा स्तेनमेव। वासो यथा रंगवशं प्रयाति तथा स तेषां वशमभ्युपैति॥
English Translation: I discharged this fierce weapon capable of slaying all things but why and how then did it not siay Kesava and Arjuna both possessed of attributes of the human kind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सदा देवाः साधुभिः संवदन्ते न मानुषं विषयं यान्ति द्रष्टुम्। रुच्चावचं विषयं यः स वेद॥
English Translation: O you possessor of the six qualities the Bhagas, explain to me all this truly as I have questioned you on the matter. O great sage, I want to hear the truth about the subject.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अदुष्टं वर्तमाने तु हृदयान्तरपूरुषे। तेनैव देवाः प्रीयन्ते सतां मार्गस्थितेन वै॥
English Translation: Vyasa said What you have asked me from curiosity is a matter of great significance. I shall speak to you everything. Hear me attentively.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शिश्नोदरे ये निरताः सदैव स्तेना नरावाक्परुषाश्च नित्यम्। अपेतदोषानपि तान् विदित्वा दूराद् देवाः सम्परिवर्जयन्ति॥
English Translation: He that is called Narayana is the most ancient of the ancient; that creator of the worlds took his birth as the son of Dharma for accomplishing a certain mission.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न वै देवा हीनसत्त्वेन तोष्याः सर्वाशिना दुष्कृतकर्मणा वा। सत्यव्रता ये तु नराः कृतज्ञा धर्मे रतास्तैः सह सम्भजन्ते॥
English Translation: On the Himalaya hills, he performed severe austerities; possessed of great energy and resembling the Sun or the fire, he stood there with his arms upraised.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अव्याहृतं व्याहृताच्छ्रेय आहुः सत्यं वदेद् व्याहृतं तद् द्वितीयम्। वदेद् व्याहृतं तत् तृतीयं प्रियं धर्मं वदेद् व्याहृतं तच्चतुर्थम्॥
English Translation: Endowed with eyes like lotus petals he reduced his bodily strength, by the observance of austerities for six and sixty thousand years living all the while upon air only.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: साध्या ऊचुः केनायमावृतो लोकः केन वा न प्रकाशते। केन त्यजति मित्राणि केन स्वर्गं न गच्छति॥
English Translation: Again undergoing severe austerities of another kind for twice that period, he filled the space intervening between heaven and earth with his energy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हंस उवाच अज्ञानेनावृतो लोको मात्सर्यान्न प्रकाशते। लोभात् त्यजति मित्राणि संगात् स्वर्ग न गच्छति॥
English Translation: When in virtue of those austerities, O son, he became equal to Brahma: he then obtained a sight of that master, origin and Protector, of the universe, the Lord of all the gods, the paramount Deity, who is highly difficult of being looked at; who is smaller then the smallest and larger than the largest;
---
Sanskrit Shloka: साध्या ऊचुः कः स्विदेको रमते ब्राह्मणानां कः स्विदेको बहुभिर्जोषमास्ते। क: स्विदेको बलवान् दुर्बलोऽपि कः स्विदेषां कलह नान्ववैति॥
English Translation: Who is denominated the Rudra, who is the Lord of all the superior ones, who is called Hara and Shambhu; who wears matted looks on his head; who imparts vital energy to the all beings, who is the primordial cause of all the mobile and immobile things.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हंस उवाच प्राज्ञ एको रमते ब्राह्मणानां प्राज्ञश्चैको बहुभिर्जोषमास्ते। प्राज्ञ एको बलवान् दुर्बलोऽपि प्राज्ञ एषां कलहं नान्ववैति॥
English Translation: Who is incapable of being resisted and of dreadful aspect, who possesses fierce anger and magnanimous soul, who is the all-destroyer and of generous heart, who bears the celestial bow and a pair of quivers, who is covered in a golden coat of mail and whose energy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: साध्या ऊचुः किं ब्राह्मणानां देवत्वं किं च साधुत्वमुच्यते। असाधुत्वं च किं तेषां किमेषां मानुषं मतम्॥
English Translation: Who wields the Pinaka, who is armed with the thunderbolt, the blazing trident, the battle axe, mace and a large sword. Whose eye-brows are fair, whose locks are matted, who wields the heavy bludgeon, who bears the moon on his forehead, who is clad in tiger-skin and who is armed with the heavy short club.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हंस उवाच स्वाध्याय एषां देवत्वं व्रतं साधुत्वमुच्यते। असाधुत्वं परीवादो मृत्युर्मानुष्यमुच्यते॥
English Translation: Who is furnished with beautiful Angadas, who has got snakes round his neck in the shape of the sacred thread, who is surrounded by various creatures and numerous ghosts of the universe, who is the One, who is the receptacle of ascetic rites and who is greatly admired by persons of venerable age.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच संवादं इत्ययं श्रेष्ठः साध्यानां परिकीर्तितः। क्षेत्रं वै कर्मणां योनिः सद्भावः सत्यमुच्यते॥
English Translation: Who is water, heaven, sky, earth, sun, moon, wind and fire and who is the measure of the duration of the universe. Beings of evil mode of life can never obtain a sight of that unborn one, that slayer of ali contemners of Brahmanas, that origin of immorality.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच ततस्ते प्रययुर्हष्टा: प्रहष्टनरवाहनाः। रथघोषेण महता पूरयन्तो वसुंधराम्॥
English Translation: Only Brahmanas of pious mode of life, when purged of their sins and liberated from the influence of grief's obtain a sight of him, in their mind. Through the merits of his severe ascetic austerities Narayana beheld that undeteriorating, that most venerable one, that Being having the universe for his form. Beholding that best receptacle of all kinds of splendour, that divinity with a garland of Akshasas round his neck, Vasudeva with gratified soul became filled with delight, which he tried to express by his words, heart and understanding and body. Then Narayana worshipped that divine Lord, that primordial cause of the universe.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संस्तूयमानाः स्तुतिभिः सूतमागधवन्दिभिः। स्वेन सैन्येन संवीता यथादित्याः स्वरश्मिभिः॥
English Translation: That giver of boons, that lord of illustrious soul engaged in sporting with the beautifullimbed Parvati and surrounded by hosts of ghost.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पाण्डुरेणातपत्रेण ध्रियमाणेन मूर्धनि। बभौ युधिष्ठिरस्तत्र पौर्णमास्यामिवोडुराट्॥
English Translation: That unborn one and paramount. lord, that unmanifest one, that essence of all causes and that undeteriorating one ; then Narayana of eyes like lotus petals, having saluted Rudra, that 'slayer of Andhaka, reverentially began to praise that god of three-eyes. from you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जयाशिषः प्रहृष्टानां नराणां पथि पाण्डवः। प्रत्यगृहाद् यथान्यायं यथावत् पुरुषर्षभः॥
English Translation: Narayana said O most adorable one, O first of all the gods, the creators (the Prajapatis) who are protectors of the world and who having entered the earth, your first creation-had, O lord, protected it before, having all sprung
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथैव सैनिका राजन् राजानमनुयान्ति ये। तेषां हलहलाशब्दो दिवं स्तब्वा व्यतिष्ठत॥
English Translation: The celestials, the Asuras, the Nagas, the Rakshasas, the Pisachas, human beings, birds, the Gandharvas, Yakshas and all other creatures, with the whole of this universe, we know have all originated from you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सरांसि सरितश्चैव वनान्युपवनानि च। अत्यक्रामन्महाराजो गिरिं चाप्यन्वपद्यत॥
English Translation: All acts done for gratifying Indra, Yama, Varuna, Kubera, the Pitris and Tashtri and the Moon, all are done to propitiate you. Form and light, sound and the etherial space, wind and touch, taste and water, scent and earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मिन् देशे च राजेन्द्र यत्र तद् द्रव्यमुत्तमम्। चक्रे निवेशनं राजा पाण्डवः सह सैनिकैः।
English Translation: Time, Brahma and the Vedas and the Brahmanas and all the mobile and immobile creatures have all sprung from you. Vapours rising up from expanses of water are turned into rain drops and which falling upon the earth, are separated from one another. When the hour of the universal dissolution comes, those separated individual drops once more : unite together and make the earth one vast sheet of water.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शिवे देशे समे चैव तदा भरतसत्तम॥ अग्रतो ब्राह्मणान् कृत्वा तपोविद्यादमान्वितान्। पुरोहितं च कौरव्य वेदवेदाङ्गपारगम्। आग्निवेश्यं च राजानो ब्राह्मणा: सपुरोधसः॥ कृत्वा शान्तिं यथान्यायं सर्वशः पर्यवारयन्। कृत्वा तु मध्ये राजानममात्यांश्च यथाविधि॥ षट्पदं नवसंख्यानं निवेशं चक्रिरे द्विजाः। मत्तानां वारणेन्द्राणां निवेशं च यथाविधि॥ कारयित्वा स राजेन्द्रो ब्राह्मणनिदमब्रवीत्। अस्मिन् कार्ये द्विजश्रेष्ठा नक्षत्रे दिवसे शुभे॥ यथा भवन्तो मन्यन्ते कर्तुमर्हन्ति तत् तथा। न न: कालात्ययो वै स्यादिहैव परिलम्बताम्॥ इति निश्चित्य विप्रेन्द्राः क्रियतां यदनन्तरम् श्रुत्वैतद् वचनं राज्ञो ब्राह्मणाः सपुरोधसः। इदमूचुर्वचो हृष्टा धर्मराजप्रियेप्सवः॥ अद्यैव नक्षत्रमहश्च पुण्यं यतामहे श्रेष्ठतमक्रियासु। नुपोष्यतां चापि भवद्भिरद्य॥
English Translation: He who is conversant with the nature of things, thus observing the origin and destruction of all things from you, comprehends your unity and oneness. Two birds (Isvara and Jiva), four Ashvathas with their branches (the Vedas and the auxiliaries), the seven guardians (the five elements and the heart and the understanding).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रुत्वा तु तेषां द्विजशत्तमानां कृतोपवासा रजनी नरेन्द्रः। ऊषुः प्रतीताः कुशसंस्तरेषु यथाध्वरे प्रज्वलिता हुताशाः॥
English Translation: And the then others (the ten senses) that constitute the city, the body) have all been created by you; but you are separate from and independent of them all; the past, the present and the future, beyond the sway of any body, have all originated from you, as also the seven worlds and this universe.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो निशा सा व्यगमन्महात्मनां संशृण्वतां विप्रसमीरिता गिरः। ततः प्रभाते विमले द्विजर्षभा वचोऽब्रुवन् धर्मसुतं नराधिपम्॥
English Translation: Out of a desire for paying homage O you, I am euiogising you, with a view to ascertain your real nature, O you that are beyond the comprehension of all gods. Worshipped by me, accord me the boons I desire to have, although they may be difficult of being acquired. Do not allow your illusion to shade you from me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृप उवाच सदैव तव राधेय युद्धे क्रूरतरा मतिः। नार्थानां प्रकृति वेत्सि नानुबन्धमवेक्षसे॥
English Translation: Vyasa said Then that god of inconceivable soul, possessed of blue throat and the wielder of the Pinaka bow, that divinity always eulogised by the sages, accorded boons to Vasudeya, who deserved then all.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: माया हि बहवः सन्ति शास्त्रमाश्रित्य चिन्तिताः। तेषां युद्धं तु पापिष्ठं वेदयन्ति पुराविदः॥
English Translation: The auspicious Lord said O Narayana, through my grace, among human beings, among the celestials and the Gandharavas, you shall be one whose soul and strength will be immeasurable.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: देशकालेन संयुक्तं युद्धं विजयदं भवेत्। हीनकालं तदेवेह फलं न लभते पुनः। देशे काले च विक्रान्तं कल्याणाय विधीयते॥
English Translation: The celestials, the Asuras and the mighty serpents the Pisachas, the Gandharvas, men and Rakshasas, none among these will be able to withstand you (in battle).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आनुकूल्येन कार्याणामन्तरं संविधीयते। भारं हि रथकारस्य न व्यवस्यन्ति पण्डिताः॥ परिचिन्त्य त पार्थेन संनिपातो न नः क्षमः।
English Translation: Neither Suparna, nor any Naga, nor any other creature born in the universe, nor even any of the gods shall be able to vanquish you in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एकः कुरूनभ्यगच्छदेक्श्चाग्निमतर्पयत्॥ एकश्च पञ्च वर्षाणि ब्रह्मचर्यमधारयत्।
English Translation: By weapons or thunder-bolt or fire or wind or with any object that is wet or dry or with any mobile and or immobile things.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एकः सुभद्रामारोप्य द्वैरथे कृष्णमाह्वयत्॥ एकः किरातरूपेण स्थितं रुद्रमयोधयत्।
English Translation: None will be able to cause you pain, in consequence of my grace. You will be superior in battle even to me, if perchance you ever fight with me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अस्मिन्नेव वने पार्थो हतां कृष्णामवाजयत्॥ एकश्च पञ्च वर्षाणि शनादस्त्राण्यशिक्षत।
English Translation: From the ascetic observances of the great Narayana, a mighty sage, called by the name of Nara was born. This latter is equal to the god Narayana himself. Know that Nara to be Arjuna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एकः सोऽयमरि जित्वा कुरूणामकरोद् यशः॥ एको गन्धर्वराजानं चित्रसेनमरिंदमः। विजिग्ये तरसा संख्ये सेनां प्राप्य सुदुर्जयाम्॥ तथा निवातकवचाः कालखढाश्च दानवाः। दैवतैरप्यवध्यास्ते एकेन युधि पातिताः॥ एकेन हि त्वया कर्ण किं नामेह कृतं पुरा। एकैकेन यथा तेषां भूमिपाला वशे कृताः॥ इन्द्रोऽपि हि न पार्थेन संयुगे योद्धुमर्हति।
English Translation: These two sages, said to be older than the older gods, take their births in every Yuga for carrying on the easy rule of the universe.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यस्तेनाशंसते योद्धं कर्तव्यं तस्य भेषजम्॥ आशीविषस्य क्रुद्धस्य पाणिमुद्यम्य दक्षिणम्। अवमुच्य प्रदेशिन्या दंष्ट्रामादातुमिच्छसि॥ अथवा कुद्द्वारं मत्तमेकं एव चरन् वने। अनङ्कुशं समारुह्य नगरं गन्तुमिच्छसि॥ समिद्धं पावकं चैव घृतमेदोवसाहुतम्। घृताक्तश्चारवासास्त्वं मध्येनोत्तर्तुमिच्छसि॥ आत्मानं कः समुद्बद्ध्य कण्ठे बद्ध्वा महाशिलम्।
English Translation: You endued in energy and wrath also, O you of generous heart, have sprung from a portion of Rudra, through the merits of all your pious deeds and as a consequence of high ascetic austerities.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: समुद्रं तरते दोभ्यां तत्र किं नाम पौरुषम्॥ अकृतास्त्रः कृतास्त्रं वै बलवन्तं सुदुर्बलः। तादृशं कर्ण यः पार्थं योद्धुमिच्छेत् स दुर्मतिः॥ अस्माभिर्वेष निकृतो वर्षाणीह त्रयोदश। सिंहः पाशविनिर्मुक्तो न नः शेषं करिष्यति॥ एकान्ते पार्थमासीनं कूपेऽग्निमिव संवृतम्। अज्ञानादभ्यवस्कन्ध प्राप्ताः स्मो भयमुत्तमम्॥ सह युध्यामहे पार्थमागतं युद्धदुर्मदम्।
English Translation: Being embodied, your intelligent self considered the world to be pervaded by Mahadeva; and then for propitiating that god you emaciated your body by the observance of hard vows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सैन्यास्तिष्ठन्तु संनद्धा व्यूढानीकाः प्रहारिणः॥ द्रोणो दुर्योधनो भीष्मो भवान् द्रौणिस्तथा वयम्। सर्वे युध्यामहे पार्थं कर्ण मा साहसं कृथाः॥ वयं व्यवसितं पार्थं वज्रपाणिमिवोद्यतम्। षड्रथाः प्रतियुध्येम तिष्ठेम यदि संहताः॥ व्यूढानीकानि सैन्यानि यत्ताः परमधन्विनः। युध्यामहेऽर्जुनं संख्ये दानवा इव वासवम्॥
English Translation: Creating a white image of that foremost of male beings, O Bestower of honor, you adored him with homage, offerings and reiterating prayers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शौनक उवाच ये सर्पाः सर्पसत्रेऽस्मिन्पतिता हव्यवाहने। तेषां नामानि सर्वेषां श्रोतुमिच्छामि सूतज॥
English Translation: Thus adored by you, the god became gratified on you in your previous life; and he then accorded to you, O learned one, excellent boons that you cherished in your heart.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सौतिरुवाच सहस्राणि बहून्यस्मिन्प्रयुतान्यर्बुदानि च। न शक्यं परिसंख्यातुं बहुत्वाद्विजसत्तम॥
English Translation: In him are eternally present Atma Yuga and the undeteriorating Sashtra Yoga. The celestials, the Sidhas and the foremost sages all adore him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथास्मृति तु नामानि पन्नगानां निबोध मे। उच्यमानानि मुख्यानां हुतानां जातवेदसि॥
English Translation: With a view to obtain that highest object in the world viz., Sthanu or Mahadeva; He is the creator of all. The eternal Krishna ought to be adored in all sacrifices.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वासुकेः कुलजातांस्तु प्राधान्येन निबोध मे। नीलरक्तान्सितान्योरान्महाकायान्विषोल्बणान्॥
English Translation: Knowing the Phallic from of Siva to be the origin of all forms, the lord Kesava adores him. The god having the bull for him emblem entertains great respect for Kesava.
