Sanskrit Shloka: अवशान्मातृवाग्दण्डपीडितान्कृपणान्हुतान्। कोटिशो मानसः पूर्णः शल: पालो हलोमकः॥ पिच्छलः कौणपश्चक्रः कालवेगः प्रकालनः। हिरण्यबाहुः शरणः कक्षकः कालदन्तकः॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said Hearing those words of his, that mighty carwarrior viz., the son of Drona, saluted Rudra and conceived a great regard for Kesava.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एते वासुकिजा नागाः प्रविष्टा हव्यवाहने। अन्ये च बहवो विप्र तथा वै कुलसंभवाः। प्रदीप्ताग्नौ हुताः सर्वे घोररूपा महाबलाः॥ तक्षकस्य कुले जातान्प्रवक्ष्यामि निबोध तान्।
English Translation: That one of controlled soul bowed also to that mighty sage (Krishna) and had the downs of his body erect. Then looking at his own divisions he withdrew them from the field of battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुच्छाण्डको मण्डलकः पिण्डसेक्ता रभेणकः। उच्छिखः शरभो भङ्गो बिल्वतेजा विरोहणः॥ शिली शलकरो मूकः सुकुमारः प्रवेपनः। गरः शिशुरोमा च सुरोमा च महाहनुः॥
English Translation: Thereupon, O ruler of men, the Pandava and the Kaurava troops were both withdrawn, the latter highly defeated in consequence of the overthrow of Drona.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ए? तक्षकजा नागाः प्रविष्टा हव्यवाहनम्। पारावतः पारियातः पाण्डरो हरिणः कृशः॥ विहङ्गः शरभो मेदः प्रमोदः संहतापनः। ऐरावतकुलादेते प्रविष्टा हव्यवाहनम्॥
English Translation: Fighting only for the days and spreading carnage among the Pandava troops, o king, that Brahmana Drona, conversant with the contents of all the Vedas, attained to the posthumous region of the Brahmanas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कौरव्यकुलजान्नाञ्छृणु मे त्वं द्विजोत्तम। एरकः कुण्डलो वेणी वेणीस्कन्धः कुमारकः॥ बाहुकः शृङ्गवेश्च धूर्तकप्रातरातको। कौरव्यकुलजास्त्वेते प्रविष्टा हव्यवाहनम्॥
English Translation: Bhishma said Thus addressed by that messenger, O king, the king Drupada, like a thief caught (red handed), could not utter a word.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्रकुले जाताञ्च्छणु नागान्यथातथम्। कीर्त्यमानान्मया ब्रह्मन्वातवेगान्विषोल्बणान्॥
English Translation: He made great efforts, for the purpose of pacifying his son's (daughter) father-in-law, by means of messengers, instructing them to say sweetly and persuasively, 'It is not so.'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शंकुकर्णः पिठरकः कुठारमुखसेचकौ। पूर्णाङ्गदः पूर्णमुखः प्रहासः शकुनिर्दरिः॥ अमाहठः कामठकः सुषेणो मानसोऽव्ययः। भैरवो मुण्डवेदाङ्गः पिशङ्गश्चोद्रपारकः रकः॥ ऋषभो वेगवान्नागः पिण्डारकमहाहनू। रक्ताङ्गः सर्वसारङ्गः समृद्धपटवासकौ॥ वराहको वीरणकः सुचित्रश्चित्रवेगिकः। पराशरस्तरुणको मणिः स्कन्धस्तथारुणिः॥
English Translation: That king (Hiranyavarman), thereupon once more ascertained the real fact, that the offspring of the king of the Panchalas was a daughter, and went forth (out of his city) without delay.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इतिनागा मया ब्रह्मन्कीर्तिताः कीर्तिवर्धनाः। प्राधान्येन बहुत्वात्तु न सर्वे परिकीर्तिताः॥
English Translation: He then sent information to all his friends (who were) of immeasurable strength, regarding the deception that had been practiced upon his daughter, according to the massage of the nurses.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतेषां प्रसवो यश्च प्रसवस्य च संततिः। न शक्यं परिसंख्यातुं ये दीप्तं पावकं गताः॥
English Translation: Then that best of kings, having mustered a large army, formed the resolution of marching against the king Drupada, O Bharata.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्रिशीर्षाः सप्तशीर्षाश्च दशशीर्षास्तथापरे। कालानलविषा घोरा हुताः शतसहस्रशः॥
English Translation: Then that ruler of the earth, Hiranyavarman held a consultation with his ministers, O great king (as to the course to be taken) against the king of the Panchalas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महाकाया महावेगाः शैलशृङ्गसमुच्छ्रयाः। योजनायामविस्तारा द्वियोजनसमायताः॥
English Translation: It was then and there resolved with certainly among those high-souled kings "If this be really true that Shikhandin is a daughter, O king, then having bound the king of the Panchalas, we shall drag him (here) and having installed another king who will rule over the people,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कामरूपाः कामबला दीप्तानलविषोल्बणाः। दग्धास्तत्र महासत्रे ब्रह्मदण्डनिपीडिताः॥
English Translation: We will slay thịś king of the Panchalas along with Shikhandin. Knowing this to be the fixed resolve the king (Hiranyavarman) once more sent messengers to the son of Prishata, (with the message). “I shall slay you, wait a little."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच उक्तं ते गोप्रदानं वै नाचिकेतमृषि प्रति। माहात्म्यमपि चैवोक्तमुद्देशेन गवां प्रभो॥
English Translation: Bhishma said That king was by nature not courageous, and was quiet. King Drupada, through a ruler of the earth, was dreadfully alarmed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नृगेण च महदुःखमनुभूतं महात्मना। एकापराधदज्ञानात् पितामह महामते॥
English Translation: Having despatched messengers of the Dasharna king, king Drupada, fainting with grief, approached his wife in secret and spoke these words.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्वारवत्यां यथा चासौ निविशन्त्यां समुद्धतः। मोक्षहेतुरभूत् कृष्णस्तदप्यवधृतं मया।॥
English Translation: Being filled, as the Panchala king was, with great fear and struck with grief at his heart, he said to the beloved mother of Shikhandin.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किं त्वस्ति मम संदेहो गवां लोकं प्रति प्रभो। तत्त्वतः श्रोतुमिच्छामि गोदा यत्र वसन्त्युत॥
English Translation: “My son's father-in-law, king Hiranyavarman, having mustered a large army, is advancing against me with anger, powerful as he is.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच अत्राप्युदाहरन्तीममितिहासं पुरातनम्। यथापृच्छत् पद्मयोनिमेतदेव शतक्रतुः॥
English Translation: Fools that we both (of us) are, what are we to do now, as regards this daughter of ours? Your son Shikhandin is very much suspected to be a daughter.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शक्र उवाच स्वर्लोकवासिनां लक्ष्मीमभिभूय स्वयार्चिषा। गोलोकवासिनः पश्ये व्रजतः संशयोऽत्र मे॥
English Translation: Under this suspicion, (king Hiranyavarman), thinking, I have been deceived, wants to slay me with his friends and army carefully mustered.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कीदृशा भगवॅल्लोका गवां तद् ब्रूहि मेऽनघ। यानावसन्ति दातार एतदिच्छामि वेदितुम्॥
English Translation: ( you of beautiful hips, tell me what is truth is (this case) and O beautiful lady, what is false. O auspicious one, having heard from you, I will make arrangements (how to act).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कीदृशाः किंफलाः किंस्वित् परमस्तत्र को गुणः। कथं च पुरुषास्तत्र गच्छन्ति विगतज्वराः॥
English Translation: I have been thrown in danger, as well this daughter Shikhandin. You also, O imperial lady of the finest complexion, are in great danger.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कियत्कालं प्रदानस्य दाता च फलमश्नुते। कथं बहुविधं दानं स्यादल्पमपि वा कथम्॥
English Translation: As I ask you, tell me that the truth is, for the relief of all (of us). O lady with beautiful hips and fair smiles, it depends on your words as to what ought to be speedily done.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बह्वीनां कीदृशं दानमल्पानां वापि कीदृशम्। अदत्त्वा गोप्रदाः सन्ति केन वा तच्च शंस मे॥
English Translation: Do you not fear, neither (let) Shikhandin (fear), for I will make suitable arrangements through kindness through I have been deprived from the duties to a son.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कथं वा बहुदाता स्यादल्पदात्रा समः प्रभो। अल्पप्रदाता बहुदः कथं स्वित् स्यादिहेश्वर॥
English Translation: That ruler of the earth, the king of the Dasharna country has been deceived by me. Speak, therefore O highly blessed lady, so that I may do what should be for the benefit (of all).'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कीदृशी दक्षिणा चैव गोप्रदाने विशिष्यते। एतत् तथ्येन भगवन् मम शंसितुमर्हसि॥
English Translation: That goddess-like lady, being thus addressed before all the ministers by the king, for the proclamation of his innocence to others, though he knew everything, replied to the lord of the earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विभावसुरुवाच सलिलस्याञ्जलिं पूर्णमक्षताश्च घृतोत्तराः। सोमस्योत्तिष्ठमानस्य तज्जलं चाक्षतांश्च तान्॥ स्थितो ह्यभिमुखो मर्त्यः पौर्णमास्यां बलिं हरेत्। अग्निकार्यं कृतं तेन हुताश्चास्याग्नयस्त्रयः॥
English Translation: Drupada said Of all beings, those that have life are superior. Of those that have life, those that live with the help of their intelligence are superior, those that have intelligence man is superior and among men, those that are twice-born are superior.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वनस्पतिं च यो हन्यादमावास्यामबुद्धिमान्। अपि टेकेन पत्रेण लिप्यते ब्रह्महत्यया।॥
English Translation: Among the twice-born, those that know the Vedas are superior and among the Vedaknowing people whose understanding is cultured are superior and among people with cultured understanding those living practical lives are superior and among practical people those that know Brahma are superior.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दन्तकाष्ठं तु यः खादेदमावास्यामबुद्धिमान्। हिंसितश्चन्द्रमास्तेन पितरचोद्विजन्ति च॥
English Translation: I am of opinion that you are the chief among those who have cultured understanding, you come of a respectable family and you are aged both in years and in learning.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हव्यं न तस्य देवाश्च प्रतिगृह्णन्ति पर्वसु। कुप्यन्ते पितरश्चास्य कुले वंशोऽस्य हीयते॥
English Translation: Your wisdom is equal to that of Shukra or the son of Angirasa and it is known to you what sort of a man the Kaurava is.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रीरुवाच प्रकीर्णं भाजनं यत्र भिन्नभाण्डमथासनम्। योषितश्चैव हन्यन्ते कश्मलोपहते गृहे॥ देवताः पितरश्चैव उत्सवे पर्वणीषु वा। निराशा:प्रतिगच्छन्ति कश्मलोपहताद् गृहात्॥
English Translation: Also what sort of a man Yudhishthira and the son of Kunti the descendant of Pandu is. The sons Pandu were dispossessed (of their kingdom) with the help of the knowledge of Dhritarashtra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अङ्गिरा उवाच यस्तु संवत्सरं पूर्णं दद्याद् दीपं करञ्जके। सुवर्चलामूलहस्तः प्रजा तस्य विवर्धते॥
English Translation: Though he is advised by Vidura, he follows the instructions of his son and it was at the instigation of Shakuni that he challenged the son of Kunti.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गार्ग्य उवाच आतिथ्यं सततं कुर्याद् दीपं दद्यात् प्रतिश्रये। वर्जयानो दिवा स्वापं न च मांसानि भक्षयेत्॥
English Translation: Adepts at the play, they robbed the virtuous king Yudhishthira who was holy, attached to the rules of the Kshatriya class and unskillful at the game of dice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गोब्राह्मणं न हिंस्याच्च पुष्कराणि च कीर्तयेत्। एष श्रेष्ठतमो धर्मः सरहस्यो महाफलः॥
English Translation: On no account whatever will they give back the kingdom voluntarily. You, too who will speak words of virtue to Dhritarashtra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपि क्रतुशतैरिष्ट्वा क्षयं गच्छति तद्धविः। न तु क्षीयन्ति ते धर्माः श्रद्दधानैः प्रयोजिताः॥
English Translation: Will certainly gain the hearts of his soldiers. And Vidura also by men of your words will try to create disaffection in minds the minds of Bhishma, Drona Kripa and others. With difference opinion among the ministers and disaffection in the soldiers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इदं च परमं गुह्यं सरहस्यं निबोधत। श्राद्धकल्पे च दैवे च तैर्थिके पर्वणीषु च॥ रजस्वला च या नारी वित्रिकापुत्रिका च या।
English Translation: It will be their duty to make them agree and join one another; and in the meantime the very wise sons of Pritha will easily make preparations for the war and collect stores.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एताभिश्चक्षुषा दृष्टं हविर्नाश्नन्ति देवताः॥ पितरश्च न तुष्यन्ति वर्षाण्यपि त्रयोदश।
English Translation: While you are still there and their men are delaying, they no doubt will not be able to make preparations. This is necessary and here it seems imperative.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शुक्लवासाः शुचिर्भूत्वाः ब्राह्मणान् स्वस्ति वाचयेत्। कीर्तयेद् भारतं चैव तथा स्यादक्षयं हविः॥
English Translation: Yourself, being virtuous, should behave virtuously with them and Dhritarashtra, on your meeting him, may act in conformity with your virtuous words.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धौम्य उवाच भिन्नभाण्डं च खट्वां च कुक्कुटं शुनकं तथा। अप्रशस्तानि सर्वाणि यश्च वृक्षो गृहेरुहः॥
English Translation: By detailing those that are kind the hardships of the Pandavas and telling before old people the virtuous acts in the family done by their ancestors,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भिन्नभाण्डे कलिं प्राहुः खट्वायां तु धनक्षयः। कुक्कुटे शुनके चैव हविर्नाश्नन्ति देवताः। वृक्षमूले ध्रुवं सत्त्वं तस्माद् वृक्षं न रोपयेत्॥
English Translation: I have no doubt you will estrange the minds of the men and you need not have any fear for them for you are a Veda knowing Brahmin,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जमदग्निरुवाच यो यजेदश्वमेधेन वाजपेयशतेन ह। अवाशिरा वा लम्बेत सत्रं वा स्फीतमाहरेत्॥ न यस्य हृदयं शुद्धं नरकं स ध्रुवं व्रजेत्। तुल्यं यज्ञश्च सत्यं च हृदयस्य च शुद्धता॥
English Translation: And engaged in the post of an ambassador especially as you are aged. You therefore set out quick for the accomplishment of the interests of the son of Kunti the moment called Jaya and at the position of the planets named Pushya.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शुद्धेन मनसा दत्त्वा सक्तुप्रस्थं द्विजातये। ब्रह्मलोकमनुप्राप्तः पर्याप्तं तन्निदर्शनम्॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said Being instructed in this way by the noblehearted Drupada the priest went to the city called after the elephant.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच तेषां तच्चरितं श्रुत्वा मनुष्यातीतमद्भुतम्। चिन्ताशोकपरीतात्मा मन्युनाभिपरिप्लुतः॥ दीर्घमुष्णं च निःश्वस्यधृतराष्ट्रोऽम्बिकासुतः। अब्रवीत् संजयं सूतमामन्त्र्य पुरुषर्षभ॥
English Translation: The priest, who was learned in scriptures of ethics and economy went to the city of Kauravas with his disciples.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न रात्रौ न दिवा सूत शान्ति प्राप्नोमि वै क्षणम्। संचिन्त्य दुर्नयं घोरमतीतं द्यूतजं हि तत्॥
English Translation: Bhishma said The duties of all the four modes of life, those of Yatis, O son of Pandu and the customs followed by men in general, are all comprised in kingly duties.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषामसह्यवीर्याणां शौर्यधैर्यधृति पराम्। अन्योन्यमनुरागं च भ्रातृणामतिमानुषम्॥
English Translation: All these acts, O chief of Bharatas are in Kshatriya duties. If the functions of royalty are disturbed, all creatures meet with evil.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: देवपुत्रौ महाभागौ देवराजसमद्युती। नकुलः सहदेवश्च पाण्डवौ युद्धदुर्मदौ॥ दृढायुधौ दूरपातौ युद्धे च कृतनिश्चयौ। शीघ्रहस्तौ दृढक्रोधौ नित्ययुक्तौ तरस्विनौ॥ भीमार्जुनौ पुरोधाय यदा तौ रणमूर्धनि। स्थास्येते सिंहविक्रान्तावश्विनाविव दुःसहौ॥ न शेषमिह पश्यामि मम सैन्यस्य संजय। तौ ह्यप्रतिरथौ युद्धे देवपुत्रौ महारथौ॥
English Translation: The duties of men are not clear. They have, again, many exceptions. Guided by many (false) systems, their true nature is sometimes spoiled.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्रौपद्यास्तं परिक्लेशं न ऑस्यते त्वमर्षिणौ। वृष्णयोऽथ महेष्वासाः पञ्चाला वा महौजसः॥ युधि सत्याभिसंधेन वासुदेवेन रक्षिताः। प्रधक्ष्यन्ति रणे पार्थाः पुत्राणां मम वाहिनीम्॥
English Translation: Others, who implicitly believe the decisions of men, without really knowing anything about the true nature of duties (as described in the scriptures), are at last constrained to believe in faiths whose ultimate ends are unknown.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रामकृष्णप्रणीतानां वृष्णीनां सूतनन्दन। न शक्यः सहितुं वेगः सर्वैस्तैरपि संयुगे॥
English Translation: The duties of the Kshatriyas are plain, conducive to great happiness, evident in their results, free from deceit, and beneficial to the whole world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषां मध्ये महेष्वासो भीमो भीमपराक्रमः। शैक्यया वीरघातिन्या गदया विचरिष्यति॥ तथा गाण्डीवनिर्घोषं विस्फूर्जितमिवाशनेः। गदावेगं च भीमस्य नालं सोढुं नराधिपाः॥
English Translation: As the duties of the orders, as also of Brahmanas and of those that have retired from the world, O Yudhishthira, have before this been described as being included within those of that sacred mode of life viz., that of a householder so, the whole world, with all actions, is subject to kingly duties.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽहं सुहृदां वाचो दुर्योधनवशानुगः। स्मरणीयाः स्मरिष्यामि मया या न कृताः पुरा॥
English Translation: I have told you, O monarch, how many brave kings had, in days of yore, repaired to lord of all creatures, viz., the divine and powerful Vishnu of great prowess for removing their doubts about the science of punishment.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच व्यतिक्रमोऽयं सुमहांस्त्वया राजन्नुपेक्षितः। समर्थेनापि यन्मोहात् पुत्रस्ते न निवारितः॥
English Translation: Those kings, always observant of the injunctions of the scriptures enforced by examples, waited in days of yore, upon Narayana, after having compared their acts with the duties of each of the modes of life.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रुत्वा हि निर्जितान् द्यूते पाण्डवान् मधुसूदनः। त्वरितः काम्यके पार्थान् समभावयदच्युतः॥
English Translation: Those deities, viz., the Saddhyas, the Vasus, the Ashvins, the Rudras, the Vishvas, the Maruts, and the Siddhas, created in days of yore by the first of gods, always practise Kshatriya duties.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्रुपदस्य तथा पुत्राधृष्टद्युम्नपुरोगमाः। विराटोधृष्टकेतुश्च केकयाश्च महारथाः॥
English Translation: I shall now recite to you a history consisting of the conclusions of both religion and profit. In days of yore when the Danavas had multiplied and done away with all impediments and distinctions, the powerful Mandhatri, O monarch, became king. That lord of the Earth, viz., king Mandhatri, celebrated a great sacrifice with a view to see the powerful Narayana, that god of gods, without beginning, middle, and end.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तैश्च यत् कथितं राजन् दृष्ट्वा पार्थान् पराजितान् चारेण विदितं सर्वं तन्मयाऽऽवेदितं च ते॥
English Translation: In that sacrifice he adored humbly the great Vishnu, assuming the form of Indra. The supreme Lord appeared before him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: समागम्य वृतस्तत्र पाण्डवैर्मधुसूदनः। सारथ्ये फाल्गुनस्याजौ तथेत्याह च तान् हरिः॥
English Translation: Accompanied by Many good kings he offered his adorations to that powerful god. This high discourse took place between that foremost of kings and that illustrious god in the form of Indra, regarding the highly effulgent Vishnu.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अमर्षितो हि कृष्णोऽपि दृष्ट्वा पार्थांस्तथा गतान्। कृष्णाजिनोत्तरासंगानब्रवीच्च युधिष्ठिरम्॥
English Translation: Indra said What is your object, О foremost of virtuous persons, in thus trying to see that Ancient and First of gods, viz., Narayana, of inconceivable power, and numberless illusions.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: या सा समृद्धिः पार्थानामिन्द्रप्रस्थे बभूव ह। राजसूये मया दृष्टा नृपैरन्यैः सुदुर्लभा॥
English Translation: Neither myself, nor Brahman himself, can acquired a view of that god of universal from. I shall grant you what other objects you may desire to have for you are the foremost of mortals.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यत्र सर्वान् महीपालाञ्छस्त्रतेजोभयातिान्। सवङ्गाङ्गान् सपौण्ड्रोड्रान् सचोलद्रवाडिा-ध्रकान्॥ सागरानूपकांश्चैव ये च प्रान्ताभिवासिनः। सिंहलान् बर्बरान् म्लेच्छान् ये च लङ्कानिवासिनः।। पश्चिमानि च राष्ट्राणि शतशः सागरान्तिकान्। पह्नवान् दरदान् सर्वान् किरातान् यवनाञ्छकान्॥ हारहूणांश्च चीनांश्च तुषारान् सैन्धवांस्तथा। जागुडान् रामठान् मुण्डान् स्त्रीराज्यमथ तङ्गणान्॥ केकयान् मालवांश्चैव तथा काश्मीरकानपि। अद्राक्षमहमाहूतान् यज्ञे ते परिवेषकान्॥
English Translation: Your soul rests on peace; you are devoted to righteousness; you have your senses under control; and you are heroic. You always try your best to do what is agreeable to the gods. For the sake also of your intelligence, devotion, and great faith, I shall grant you whatsoever boons you may with to have.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सा ते समृद्धिरात्ता चपला प्रतिसारिणी। आदाय जीवितं तेषामहरिष्यामि तामहम्॥
English Translation: Mandhatri said I bend my head for pleasing you; forsooth however, I wish to see the first of gods, O divine lord. Renouncing all (earthly) desires, I wish to acquire religious merit, and to lead the foremost mode of life, that path of the good held in highest esteem by all.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रामेण सह कौरव्य भीमार्जुनयमैस्तथा। अक्रूरगदसाम्बैश्च प्रद्युम्नेनाहुकेन च।॥ धृष्टद्युम्नेन वीरेण शिशुपालात्मजेन च। दुर्योधनं रणे हत्वा सद्यः कर्णं च भारत॥ दुःशासनं सौबलेयं यश्चान्यः प्रतियोत्स्यते। ततस्त्वं हास्तिनपुरे भ्रातृभिः सहितो वसन्।॥ धार्तराष्ट्रीं श्रियं प्राप्य प्रशाधि पृथिवीमिमाम्।
English Translation: By performing the great duties of a Kshatriya, I have acquired many regions of endless merit in the other world, and I have also, through those duties, spread my fame. I do not, however, know how to satisfy those duties the highest in the world emanating from the first of gods.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथैनमब्रवीद् राजा तस्मिन् वीरसमागमे॥ शृण्वत्स्वेतेषु वीरेषुधृष्टद्युम्नमुखेषु च।
English Translation: Indra said Those who are not kings, even if then satisfy their duties, cannot easily attain the highest meed of duty. Kingly duties first emanated from the original god. Other duties sprang afterwards from his body.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच प्रतिगृहणामि ते वाचमिमां सत्यां जनार्दन॥
English Translation: Numberless other duties, with those of the Vanaprastha mode of life, were created afterwards. The fruits of all those are endless. Kingly duties however, are superior to them. They include all other duties. Therefore Kshatriya duties are described to be the foremost of all.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अमित्रान् मे महाबाहो सानुबन्धान् हनिष्यसि। वर्षात् त्रयोदशादूर्ध्वं सत्यं मां कुरु केशव॥ प्रतिज्ञातो वने वासो राजमध्ये मया ह्ययम्।
English Translation: In days of yore Vishnu, by acting according to Kshatriya duties, forcibly suppressed and killed his enemies. Accordingly he have relief to the gods and the Rishis of immeasurable power.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तद्धर्मराजवचनं प्रतिश्रुत्य सभासदः॥ धृष्टद्युम्नपुरोगास्ते शमयामासुरञ्जसा। केशवं मधुरैर्वाक्यैः कालयुक्तैरमर्षितम्॥
English Translation: If the divine Vishnu of inconceivable energy had not killed all his enemies among the Asuras, then the Brahmanas, and (Brahman) the Creator of the worlds and Kshatriya duties, and the duties that first originated from the Supreme deity, would all have been lost.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पाञ्चालीं प्राहुरक्लिष्टां वासुदेवस्य शृण्वतः। दुर्योधनस्तव क्रोधाद् देवि त्यक्ष्यति जीवितम्॥
English Translation: If that first and foremost of gods had not, by displaying his prowess, subjugated the Earth with all her Asuras, then all the duties of the four orders and all the duties of the four modes of life would all have been destroyed owing to the destruction of Brahmanas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रतिजानीमहे सत्यं मा शुचो वरवर्णिनी। ये स्म तेऽक्षजितां कृष्णे दृष्ट्वा त्वां प्राहसंस्तदा मांसानि तेषां खादन्तो हरिष्यन्ति वृकद्विजाः॥
English Translation: The eternal duties (of men) had all been destroyed but by the exercise of Kshatriya duties they were revived. In every cycle of duties of Brahmanas regarding the atainment to Brahma first set in. These however, are all protected by kingly duties. The later, on this account, are regarded as highest.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पास्यन्ति रुधिरं तेषां गृध्रा गोमायवस्तथा। उत्तमाङ्गानि कर्षन्तो यैः कृष्टासि सभातले॥ तेषां द्रक्ष्यसि पाञ्चाली गात्राणि पृथिवीतले। क्रव्यादैः कृष्यमाणानि भक्ष्यमाणानि चासकृत्॥
English Translation: Casting away life in battle, mercy for all creatures, knowledge of earthly affairs, protection of men, saving them from danger, relieving the distressed and the oppressed,-all these are included in the category of Kshatriya duties. Persons that do not obey healthy restraints and who are under the influence of anger and lust, do not openly sin from fear of kings. Others who are docile and righteous succeed, for the same influence, in satisfying all their duties. Therefore the Kshatriya duties are regarded to be righteous.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: परिक्लिष्टासि यैस्तत्र यैश्चासि समुपेक्षिता। तेषामुत्कृत्तशिरसां भूमिः पास्यति शोणितम्॥
English Translation: Forsooth, all creatures live happily in the world, protected by kings exercising Kshatriya duties like children protected by their parents.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं बहुविधा वाचस्त ऊचुर्भरतर्षभ। सर्वे तेजस्विनः शूराः सर्वे चाहतलक्षणाः॥ तेधर्मराजेन वृता वर्षादूर्ध्वं त्रयोदशात्। पुरस्कृत्योपयास्यन्ति वासुदेवं महारथाः॥
English Translation: Kshatriya duties are the highest of all duties. Those eternal duties, regarded as the first in the world, include the protection of every creature. Themselves eternal, they bring on liberation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रामश्च कृष्णश्चधनंजयश्च प्रद्युम्नसाम्बौ युयुधानभीमौ। माद्रीसुतौ केकयराजपुत्राः पाञ्चालपुत्राः सह मत्स्यराज्ञा॥ एतान् सर्वान् लोकवीरानजेयान् महात्मनः सानुबन्धान ससैन्यान्। को जीवितार्थी समरेऽभ्युदीयात् क्रुद्धान् सिंहान् केसरिणो यथैव॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said Whence has this universe, consisting of mobile and immobile creatures, originated? Whom does it go to when it is destroyed? Tell me this, O grandfather.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच यन्माब्रवीद विदुरो द्यूतकाले त्वं पाण्डवाञ्जेष्यसि चेन्नरेन्द्र। ध्रुवं कुरूणामयमन्तकालो महाभयो भविता शोणितौघः॥
English Translation: Indeed, by whom has this universe with its oceans, its sky, its mountains, its clouds, its lands, its fire, and its wind, been created.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मन्ये तथा तद् भवितेति सूत यथा क्षत्ता प्राह वचः पुरा माम्। असंशयं भविता युद्धमेतद् गते काले पाण्डवानां यथोक्तम्॥
English Translation: How were all objects created? Whence has this division of creatures originated? Whence are their purity and impurity, and the laws about virtue and vice?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच नकुलं रभसं युद्धे निघ्नतं वाहिनी तव। अभ्ययात् सौबलः क्रुद्धस्तिष्ठ तिष्ठेति चाब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: Of what nature is the life of living creatures? Where also do they go who die? Tell us everything about this and the next world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृतवैरौ तु तौ वीरावन्योन्यवधकाङ्क्षिणौ। शरैः पूर्णायतोत्सृष्टैरन्योन्यमभिजघ्नतुः॥
English Translation: Bhishina said Regarding it is cited the old discourse of the sacred words the Bhrigu said in reply to the questions of Bharadwaja addressed him thusकैलासशिखरे दृष्ट्वा दीप्यमानं महौजसम्।
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथैव नकुलो राजन् शरवर्षाण्यमुञ्चत्। तथैव सोबलश्चापि शिक्षा संदर्शयन् युधि॥
English Translation: Seeing the sage Bhrigu, endued with high power and effulgent seated on the peak of Kailasa mountain, Bharadvaja said him
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तावुभौ समरे शूरौ शरकण्टकिनौ तदा। व्यराजेतां महाराज श्वाविधौ शललैरिव॥
English Translation: Bharadwaja said By whom was this world its ocean, its sky, its mountains, its clouds, its lands, its fire, and its wind, created?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रुक्मपुरजिह्माणैः शरैश्छिन्नतनुच्छदौ। रुधिरौघपरिक्किन्नौ व्यभ्राजेतां महामृधे॥
English Translation: How were all creatures first created? Whence originated this distinction of castes? Whence the purity and the impurity of conduct, and whence the laws about virtue and vice, for living creatures?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तपनीयनिभौ चित्रौ कल्पवृक्षाविव दुमौ। किंशुकाविव चोत्फुल्ली प्रकाशेते रणाजिरे॥
English Translation: What type of individual soul is of the living creatures? Where they go after the death. What is this and next world? You are able to explain all the things.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तावुभैः समरे शूरौ शरकण्टकिनौ तदः। व्यराजेता महाराज कण्टकैरिव शाल्मलीः॥
English Translation: Thus accosted about his doubts by Bharadwaja, the illustrious and twice-born Rishi Bhrigu who took after Brahma itself, replied to him thus.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुजिप्तां प्रेक्षमाणौ च राजन् विवृतलोचनौ। क्रोधसंरक्तनयनौ निर्दहन्तौ परस्परम्॥
English Translation: Bhrigu said There is a Primeval Being, known to the great Rishis, by the name of Manasa. He is without beginning and without end. That Divine being cannot be cut by weapons. he is without decay and is immortal.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्यालस्तु तव संक्रुद्धो माद्रीपुत्रं हसन्निव। कर्णिनैकेन विव्याध हृदये निशितेन ह॥
English Translation: He is Unmanifest. he is Eternal, Undecaying, and Unchangeable. By Him are crcatures born and through Him they die.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नकुलस्तु भृशं विद्धः श्यालेन तव धन्विना। निषसाद रथोपस्थे कश्मलं चाविशन्महत्॥
English Translation: He first created a Divine Being known by the name of Mahat (Great). Mahat created Consciousness, who created Space. That powerful Being holds all created objects.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अत्यन्तवैरिणं दृप्तं दृष्ट्वा शत्रु तथागतम्। ननाद शकुनी राजंस्तपान्ते जलदो यथा॥
English Translation: From Space was born Water, and from Water were born Fire and Wind. Through the union of Fire and Wind was born the Earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रतिलभ्य ततः संज्ञां नकुलः पाण्डुनन्दनः। अभ्ययात् सौबलं भूयो व्यात्तानन इवान्तकः॥
English Translation: Self-born Manasa then created a divine Lotus of Energy. From that Lotus originated Brahmana, that Ocean of Veda.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संक्रुद्धः शकुनि षष्ट्या विव्याध भरतर्षभा पुनश्चैनं शतेनैव नाराचानां स्तनान्तरे॥
English Translation: The Shrutis say that as soon as born, that divine Being uttered the words—I am He. For this He passed by the name of Consciousness. All created things are his body and He is their Creator. These five elements that we see are the Brahman of great energy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथास्य सशरं चापं मुष्टिदेशेऽच्छिनत् तदा। ध्वजं च त्वरितं छित्त्वा रथाद् भूमावपातयत्॥
English Translation: The Mountains from his bones. the Earth forins his fat and flesh. the Oceans constitute his blood. space is his stomach.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विशिखेन च तीक्ष्णेन पीतेन निशितेन च। ऊरू निर्भिद्य चैकेन नकुलः पाण्डुनन्दनः॥
English Translation: The Wind forins his breath. Fire his energy. The rivers forms his arteries and veins. Agni and Soma, otherwise called the Sun and the Moon, are his eyes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्येनं सपक्षं व्याधेन पातयामास तं तदा। सोऽतिविद्धो महाराज रथोपस्थ उपाविशत्॥
English Translation: The sky is above his head. The Earth is his two feet. The cardinal and minor points of compass are his arms, Forsooth, He is incapable of being known and His Soul cannot be conceived even by successful ascetics.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ध्वजयष्टिं परिक्तिश्य कामुकः कामिनी यथा। तं विसंज्ञं निपतितं दृष्ट्वा श्यालं तवानघ॥
English Translation: That Divine Being, who pervades the entire universe, passes also by the name of Ananta (Infinite). He lives in Consciousness, and persons of impure souls cannot know him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपोवाह रथेनाशु सारथिर्ध्वजिनीमुखात्। ततः संचुक्रुशुः पार्था ये च तेषां पदानुगाः॥
English Translation: Asked by you I have now told you of Him who created objects, and from whom this universe had originated.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निर्जित्य च रणे शत्रु नकुलः शत्रुतापनः। अब्रवीत् सारथिं क्रुद्धो द्रोणानीकाय मां वह॥
English Translation: Bharadwaja said What is the extent of the sky, of the points of the horizon, of the surface of this Earth, and of the Wind? By telling me the truth, remove my doubts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य तद् वचनं श्रुत्वा माद्रीपुत्रस्य सारथिः। प्रायात् तेन तदा राजन् यत्र द्रोणो व्यवस्थितः॥
English Translation: The sky you see above is infinite. It is the abode of successful ascetics and of celestial beings. It is lovely and consists of various regions. Its limits cannot be determined.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शिखण्डिनं तु समरे द्रोणप्रेप्सुं विशाम्पते। कृपः शारद्वतो यत्तः प्रत्यगच्छत् सवेगितः॥
English Translation: The Sun and Moon cannot sec, above or below, beyond the range of their own rays. There where are rays of the Sun and the Moon cannot go are luminaries which are selfeffulgent and shining like the Sun or the fire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गौतमं द्रुतमायान्तं द्रोणानीकमरिंदमम्। विव्याध नवभिर्भल्लैः शिखण्डी प्रहसन्निव॥
English Translation: Know this, O giver of honours, that even these luminaries which have great effulgence, do not see the limits of the sky for the inaccessibility and infinity of those limits.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमाचार्यो महाराज विद्ध्वा पञ्चभिराशुगैः। पुनर्विव्याध विंशत्या पुत्राणां प्रियकृत् तव॥
English Translation: This Space which even the very celestials cannot measure contains many shining and self-luminous worlds each above the other.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महद् युद्धं तयोरासीद् घोररूपं भयानकम्। यथा देवासुरे युद्धे शम्बरामरराजयोः॥
English Translation: Beyond the limits of land are oceans, Beyond water is darkness. Beyond darkness is water again, and beyond water is fire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शरजालावृतं व्योम चक्रतुस्तौ महारथौ। मेघाविव तपापाये वीरौ समरदुर्मदौ॥
English Translation: Underneath, beyond the neither regions is water. Beyond water is the region of the great serpents. Beyond that is sky once more, and beyond the sky is water again.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रकृत्या घोररूपं तदासीद् घोरतरं पुनः। रात्रिश्च भरतश्रेष्ठ योधानां युद्धशालिनाम्॥
English Translation: Thus exist water and sky alternately without end. Such are the limits of the god of water. The very gods cannot determine the limits of fire and wind and water.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कालरात्रिनिभा ह्यासीद् घोररूपा भयानका। शिखण्डी तु महाराज गौतमस्य महद् धनुः॥ अर्धचन्द्रेण चिच्छेद सज्यं सविशिखं तदा। तस्य क्रुद्धः कृपो राजशक्तिं चिक्षेप दारुणाम्॥
English Translation: The nature of fire, wind, water, and land, is like that of space. It is the absence of true knowledge that draws distinction between them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्वर्णदण्डामकुण्ठाग्रां कर्मारपरिमार्जिताम्। तामापतन्तीं चिच्छेद शिखण्डी बहुभिः शरैः॥
English Translation: Sages read in various scriptures the limits of the three worlds and the ocean.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: साऽपतन्मेदिनी दीप्ता भासयन्ती महाप्रभा। अथान्यद् धनुरादाय गौतमो रथिनां वरः॥
English Translation: Who is there, however, who can set limits to what cannot be seen and what is inaccessible?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्राच्छादयच्छितैर्बाणैर्महाराज शिखण्डिनम्। च च्छाद्यमानः समरे गौतमेन यशस्विना॥
English Translation: If even it becomes possible to learn the limits of the sky which is the region of the gods and successful ascetics, it is not possible to set limits to that which is limitless and passes by the name of the Infinite, to that which answers its name, viz., the high-souled Manasa?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न्यषीदत रथोपस्थे शिखण्डी रथिनां वरः। सीदन्तं चैनमालोक्य कृपः शारद्वतो युधि॥
English Translation: When again His form is sometimes contracted and sometimes expanded, how can any one else save one who is equal to him, perceive his limits?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आजघ्ने बहुभिर्वाणैर्जिघांसन्निव भारत। विमुखं तु रणे दृष्ट्वा याज्ञसेनिं महारथम्॥
English Translation: From the Lotus sprang first the Omniscient lord Brahman, endued with form, of the essence of Righteousness, and the Creator of all mobile and immobile things.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पञ्चाला: सोमकाश्चैव परिव्रवुः समन्ततः। तथैव तव पुत्राश्च परिवर्द्धिजोत्तमम्॥
English Translation: Bharadwaja said If Brahman originated from the Lotus, then it is the Lotus that should be considered as the first-born and not Brahman. Why, however, is Brahman said to be the first? Do you dispel this doubt of mine.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महत्या सेनया सार्धं ततो युद्धमवर्तत। स्थानां च रणे राजन्नन्योन्यमभिधावताम्॥
English Translation: Bhrigu said The Earth is called that Lotus. It was created for giving a seat to that form of Manasa which became Brahman.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बभूव तुमुलः शब्दो मेघानां गर्जतामिव। द्रवतां सादिनां चैव गजानां च विशाम्पते। ३६॥
English Translation: Extending up to heaven itself, the Sumeru became the pericarp of that Lotus. Remaining within it, the powerful Lord of the Universe created all the worlds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्योन्यमभितो राजन् क्रूरमायोधनं बभौ। पत्तीनां द्रवतां चैव पादशब्देन मेदिनी॥
English Translation: Janamejaya said When that foremost person among the Kauravas, viz., Bhishma was lying on a bed of arrows—a bed that is always coveted by heroes and when the Pandavas were sitting around him, my great Grandfather Yudhishthira of much wisdom, heard these expositions of mysteries about the subject of duty and had all his doubts removed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अकम्पत महाराज भयत्रस्तेव चाङ्गना। रथिनो रथमारुह्य प्रदुता वेगवत्तरम्॥
English Translation: He heard also what the ordinances are about gifts, and thus had all his doubts removed about the topics of virtue and wealth. You should, O learned Brahmana, tell me now what else did the great Pandava king do.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अगृह्णन् बहवो राजशलभान् वायसा इव। तथा गजान् प्रभिन्नांश्च सम्प्रभिन्ना महागजाः॥ तस्मिन्नेव पदे यत्ता निगृह्णन्ति स्म भारत। सादी सादिनपासाद्य पत्तयश्च पदातिनम्॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said When Bhishma became silent, the entire body of kings became perfectly silent. Indeed, they all sat motionless there, like figures painted on canvas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: समासाद्य रणेऽन्योन्यं संरब्धा नातिचक्रमुः। धावतां द्रवतां चैव पुनरावर्ततामपि॥ बभूव तत्र सैन्यानां शब्दः सुविपुलो निशि। दीप्यमानाः प्रदीपाश्च रथवारणवाजिषु॥
English Translation: Then Vyasa the son of Satyavati, having thought for a moment, addressed the royal son of Ganga, saying, O king, the Kuru king Yudhishthira has been restored to his own nature, with all his brothers and followers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अदृश्यन्त महाराज महोल्का इव खाच्च्युताः। सा निशा भरतश्रेष्ठ प्रदीपैरवभासिता॥
English Translation: With highly intelligent Krishna by his side he bends his head in respect to you. You should give him leave for returning to the city.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दिवसप्रतिमा राजन् बभूव रणमूर्धनि। आदित्येन यथा व्याप्तं तमो लोके प्रणश्यति॥
English Translation: Thus addressed by the holy Vyasa, the royal son of Shantanu and Ganga dismissed Yudhishthira and his counsellors.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथा नष्टं तमो घोरं दीपैर्दीप्तरितस्ततः। द्योश्चैव पृथिवी चापि दिशश्च प्रदिशस्तथा॥
English Translation: Addressing his grandson in a sweet voice, the royal son of Shantanu, also said, Do you return to your city, O king, Let the fever of your heart be removed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रजसा तमसा व्याप्ता द्योतिताः प्रभया पुनः। अस्त्राणां कवचानां च मणीनां च महात्मनाम्॥
English Translation: Do you adore the celestials in various sacrifices distinguished by large gifts of food and riches like Yayati himself, O foremost of kings, gifted with devotion and selfcontrol.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्तर्दधुः प्रभाः सर्वा दीपैस्तैरवभासिताः। तस्मिन् कोलाहले युद्धे वर्तमाने निशामुखे॥
English Translation: Devoted to the practices of the Kshatriya do you, O son of Pritha, please the departed manes and the celestials. You shall then acquire great benefits. Indeed let the fever of your heart be removed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न किंचिद् विदुरात्मानमयमस्मीति भारत। अवधीत् समरे पुत्रं पिता भरतसत्तम्॥
English Translation: Do you please all your subjects. Do you assure them and establish peace among all. Do you also honour all your wellwishers with such rewards as they deserve.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुत्रश्च पितरं मोहात् सखायं च सखा तथा। स्वस्नीयं मातुलश्चापि स्वस्रीयश्चापि मातुलम्॥
English Translation: Let all your friends and wellwishers live, depending on you for their means, as birds live, depending for their means upon a full grown tree laden with fruits and standing on a sacred spot.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्वे स्वान् परे परांश्चापि निजत्रुरितरेतरम्। निर्मर्यादमभूद् युद्धं रात्रौ भीरुभयानकम्॥
English Translation: When the hour comes for departure from this world, do you come here, O king, I shall relinquish my body when the Sun, stopping in his southward course, will begin to return northwards.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच ब्राह्मणस्वानि ये मन्दा हरन्ति भरतर्षभ। नृशंसकारिणो मूढाः क्व ते गच्छन्ति मानवाः॥
English Translation: The son of Kunti answered, 'So be it!' and saluted his grandfather with respect and then started with all his relatives and followers, for the city of Hastinapur.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच अत्राप्युदाहरन्तीममितिहासं पुरातनम्। चाण्डालस्य च संवादं क्षाबन्धोश्च भारत॥
English Translation: Headed by Dhritarashtra and also Gandhari who was greatly devoted to her husband and accompanied by the Rishis and Keshava as also by the citizens and the inhabitants of the country and by his counsellors, O monarch, that foremost one of Kuru's race entered the city of Hastinapur.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वृद्धरूपोऽसि चाण्डाल बालवच्च विचेष्टसे। श्वखराणां रज:सेवी कस्मादुद्विजसे गवाम्॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said Hearing this, the son of Kunti (Yudhishthira) summoned all his brothers. Having summoned (them), O best of the Bharata race, he spoke these words.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: साधुभिर्गर्हितं कर्म चाण्डालस्य विधीयते। कस्माद् गोरजसाध्वस्तमपां कुण्डे निषिञ्चसि॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said The spies, whom I have in the army of the son of Dhritarashtra, brought me this news when the night has passed away.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चाण्डाल उवाच ब्राह्मणस्य गवां राजन् हियतीनां रजः पुरा। सोममुध्वंसयामास तं सोमं येऽपिबन् द्विजाः॥ दीक्षितश्च स राजापि क्षिप्रं नरकमाविशत्। सह तैर्याजकैः सर्वैर्ब्रह्मस्वमुपजीव्य तत्॥
English Translation: 'Duryodhana asked the son of Ganga of high vows, "O lord! in what time can you annihilate the army of the sons of Pandu?"
---
Sanskrit Shloka: येऽपि तत्रापिबन् क्षीरं घृतं दधि च मानवाः। ब्राह्मणाः सहराजन्याः सर्वे नरकमाविशन्॥
English Translation: And the wicked son of Dhritarashtra was answered, "In a month." And in that same time Drona also has promised.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जनस्ताः पयसा पुत्रांस्तथा पौत्रान् विधुवन्तीः। पशूनवेक्षमाणाश्च साधृवृत्तेन दम्पती॥
English Translation: And we have heard that the son of Gautama has promised the same in double that time, and the son of Drona has promised (the same) in ten nights, acquainted as he is with mighty weapons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अहं तत्रावसं राजन् ब्रह्मचारी जितेन्द्रियः। तासां मे रजसा ध्वस्त भैक्षमासीन्नराधिप॥
English Translation: Then Karna, who knows (the use of) celestial weapons, being asked in the army of the Kurus, has pledged himself to slay us with our armies in five days.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चाण्डालोऽहं ततो राजन् भुक्त्वा तदभवं नृप। ब्रह्मस्वहारी च नृपः सोऽप्रतिष्ठां गतिं ययौ।॥
English Translation: On this account, I also desire, to hear your words, O Arjuna, in what time you are able to destroy our enemies, O Falguna.'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्माद्धरेन विप्रस्वं कदाचिदपि किंचन। ब्रह्मस्वं रजसा ध्वस्तुं भुक्त्वा मां पश्य यादृशम्॥
English Translation: Thus addressed Dhananjaya, with thick hair, looking towards Vasudeva, spoke these words.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मात् सोमोऽप्यविक्रेयः पुरुषेण विपश्चिता। विक्रयं त्विह सोमस्य गर्हयन्ति मनीषिणः॥
English Translation: All these high-minded heroes accomplished in arms, and capable of fighting in desire ways, and they can, no doubt O great king, slay us.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ये चैनं क्रीणते तात ये च विक्रीणते जनाः। ते त वैवस्वतं प्राप्य रौरवं यान्ति सर्वशः॥
English Translation: But let your mind be free from anxiety; I say truly that I can with the aid of Vasudeva, root out, on a single car,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सोमं तु रजसा ध्वस्तं विक्रीणन् विधिपूर्वकम्। श्रोत्रियो वाधुषी भूत्वा न चिरं स विनश्यति॥
English Translation: The three words with all their celestial and all things movable, and all beings that were, or are to b, in the twinkling of an eye; such is what I think.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नरकं त्रिंशतं प्राप्य स्वविष्ठामुपजीवति। श्रुचर्यामभिमानं च सखिदारे च विप्लवम्॥ तुलया धारयन् धर्ममभिमान्यतिरिच्यते। श्वानं वै पापिनं पश्य विवर्णं हरिण कृशम्॥
English Translation: That terrible and mighty weapon which the lord of all gods bestowed on me in the combat are hand-to-hand, with (Mahadeva in the guise of) a hunter, even that (weapon) is with me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभिमानेन भूतानामिमां गतिमुपागतम्। अहं वै विपुले तात कुले धनसमन्विते॥ अन्यस्मिजन्मनि विभो ज्ञानविज्ञानपारगः। अभवं तत्र जानानो ह्येतान् दोषान् मदात् सदा॥ संरब्ध एव भूतानां पृष्ठमांसमभक्षयम्। सोऽहं तेन च वृत्तेन भोजनेन च तेन वै॥ इमामवस्थां सम्प्राप्तः पश्य कालस्य पर्ययम्। आदीप्तमिव चैलान्तं भ्रमरिव चार्दितम्॥ धावमानं सुसंरब्धं पश्य मां रजसान्वितम्। स्वाध्यायैस्तु महात्पापं हरन्ति गृहमेधिनः॥ दानैः पृथग्विधैश्चापि यथा प्राहुर्मनीषिणः। तथा पापकृतं विप्रमाश्रमस्थं महीपते॥ सर्वसङ्गविनिर्मुक्तं छन्दांस्युत्तारयन्त्युत। अहं हि पापयोन्यां वै प्रसूतः क्षत्रियर्षभ। निश्चयं नाधिगच्छामि कथं मुच्येयमित्युत॥
English Translation: That (weapon) which the lord of all gods uses when he annihilates all forms of existence, even that O best among men, is with me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जातिस्मरत्वं च मम केनचित् पूर्वकर्मणा। शुभेन येन मोक्षं वै प्राप्तुमिच्छाम्यहं नृप।॥
English Translation: The son of Ganga does not know the (weapon), nor Drona, nor the son of Gautama, neither also the son of Drona; O king, whence, then, can the son of Suta (know)?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वमिमं सम्प्रपन्नाय संशयं ब्रूहि पृच्छते। चाण्डालत्वात् कथमहं मुच्येयमिति सत्तम॥
English Translation: It is not, however, proper to annihilate in a battle, by means of celestial weapons ordinary men. We will by artless fighting vanquish our foes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजन्य उवाच चाण्डाल प्रतिजानीहि येन मोक्षमवाप्स्यसि। ब्राह्मणार्थे त्यजन् प्राणान् गतिमिष्टामवाप्स्यसि॥
English Translation: Again, these foremost among men are your allies, O king. They are all acquainted with celestial weapons, and all of them, are desirous of battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दत्त्वा शरीरं क्रव्याद्भयो रणाग्नौद्विजहेतुकम्। हत्वा प्राणान् प्रमोक्षस्ते नान्यथा मोक्षमर्हसि॥
English Translation: All of them have performed sacrificial rites in company with their wives, after they had become versed respectively in Vedas, and have never been conquered. They can destroy the army of even the gods in battle, O son of Pandu.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच इत्युक्तः स तदा तेन ब्रह्मस्वार्थे परंतप। हत्वा रणमुखे प्राणान् गतिमिष्टामवाप ह॥
English Translation: And Shikhandin, Yuyudhana, and Dhrishtadyumna, of Prishata's race, and Bhimasena, and these twins, Yudhamanyu and Uttamaujas,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्माद् रक्ष्यं त्वया पुत्र ब्रह्मस्वं भरतर्षभ। यदीच्छसि महाबाहो शाश्वतीं गतिमात्मनः॥
English Translation: And both of them viz., Virata and Drupada, who are equal to Bhishma and Drona (respective) in battle, and the powerful Shankha and the son of Hidimba of great strength,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शुक्र उवाच यः परेषां नरो नित्यमतिवादांस्तितिक्षते। देवयानि विजानीहि तेन सर्वमिदं जितम्॥ उच्यते॥ यः समुत्पतितं क्रोधं निगृह्णाति हयं यथा। स यन्तेत्युच्यते सद्भिर्न यो रश्मिषु लम्बते॥२१.
English Translation: And his son Anjanaparva, of great strength and prowess, and the descendant of Shini's race, well versed in fighting, and who is your ally,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यः समुत्पतितं क्रोधमक्रोधेन निरस्यति। देवयानि विजानीहि तेन सर्वमिदं जितम्॥
English Translation: And the powerful Abhimanyu, and the five sons of Draupadi are also at your service. And you to are alone capable of annihilating even the three words.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यः समुत्पतितं क्रोधं क्षमयेह निरस्यति। यथोरगस्त्वचं जीर्णा स वै पुरुष
English Translation: O you of effulgence equal to Shakra (Indra), that person on whom you cast a look of anger, surely meets with death for it has been seen and so I know, O Kaurava.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यः संधारयते मन्यु योऽतिवादांस्तितिक्षते। यश्च तप्तो न तपति दृढं सोऽर्थस्य भाजनम्॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said Having careered round Jishnu slaughtered again innumerable number of the Samsaptakas; even as the Planet Mercury destroys a large number of people by traveling in an exceedingly curved line. an
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यो यजेदपरिश्रान्तो मासि मासि शतं समाः। न क्रुद्धेयद् यश्च सर्वस्य तयोरक्रोधनोऽधिकः॥
English Translation: O monarch, O descendant of the Bharata race, the men, horses, cars and elephants, having been struck by the arrows of the son of Pritha, wavered, roved about, lost their color, fell down and died.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यत् कुमाराः कुमार्यश्च वैरं कुर्युरचेतसः। न तत् प्राज्ञोऽनुकुर्वीत न विदुस्ते बलाबलम्॥
English Translation: The son of Pandu severed in the field of battle, with his broad-headed, razor-like and crescent-shaped arrows, as well as with those equipt with the teeth of calves, the best of horses yoked to the cars, drivers, standards, bows and arrows, hands and the weapons held in the hands, the arms and heads of heroic warriors of the side of the enemies, who were fighting against him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: देवयान्युवाच वेदाहं तात बालापि धर्माणां यदिहान्तरम्। अक्रोधे चातिवादे च वेद चापि बलाबलम्॥
English Translation: The mighty heroes fell upon Arjuna by hundreds and thousands, even as the mighty bulls fight with another bull in order to gain a cow during season.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शिष्यस्याशिष्यवृत्तेस्तु न क्षन्तव्यं बुभूषता। तस्मात् संकीर्णवृत्तेषु वासो मम न रोचते॥
English Translation: The battle that took place between him and them made the hairs to stand on points. This battle resembled the great war between the Daityas and the wielder of the thunder-bolt at the time of the conquest of the three worlds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुमांसो ये हि निन्दन्ति वृत्तेनाभिजनेन च। न तेषु निवसेत् प्राज्ञः श्रेयोऽर्थी पापबुद्धिषु॥
English Translation: Thereupon the son of Ugrayudha pierced him (the son of Pritha) with three arrows that were like the Dandashuka snakes. He (the son of Pritha) on the other hand, severed his head from his body.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ये त्वेनपभिजानन्ति वृत्तेनाभिजनेन वा। तेषु साधुषु वस्तव्यं स वासः श्रेष्ठ उच्यते॥
English Translation: Then they (the heroic warriors), highly enraged, shrouded Arjuna from all sides with innumerable weapons, even as the masses of clouds being urged by the winds cover the Himavat at the expiration of the summer.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वाग् दुरुक्तं महाघोरं दुहितुर्वृषपर्वणः। मम मनाति हृदयमग्निकाम इवारणिम्॥
English Translation: Arjuna, after having restrained the weapons of his antagonists coming from all sides with the weapons of his own, slaughtered a large number of the foes with well-shot arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यः सपत्नश्रियं दीप्तां हीनश्रीः पर्युपासते। मरणं शोभनं तस्य इति विद्वज्जना विदुः॥
English Translation: Afterwards Arjuna made in-numerable cars severed of their Trivenus; and slaughtered the horses, the drivers and the Parshnis (driver of another class) of them; and again, displaced their weapons and quivers, and also destroyed their wheels and standards; and cut-off their chords, traces and axes; and moreover despoiled their bottoms and yokes; and at last displaced their equipments from their proper place with a large number of his shafts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच सोऽब्रवीदर्जुनं चैव वासुदेवं च सात्वतम्। लोकप्रवीरौ तिष्ठन्तौ खाण्डवस्य समीपतः॥
English Translation: Those cars, lying there (on the field of battle) in innumerable numbers, having been broken into pieces and injured (by Arjuna), looked like the mansions of the rich men, smitten down either by the fire, or wind, or the rains.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणो बहुभोक्तास्मि भुञ्जेऽपरिमितं सदा। भिक्षे वार्ष्णेयपार्थो वामेकां तृप्तिं प्रयच्छतम्॥
English Translation: The elephants, having their vital parts penetrated with the arrows that were like the thunderbolt in speed, fell down like the mansions on the summits of a mountain shattered by the blasts of lightning.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्तौ तमब्रूतां ततस्तौ कृष्णपाण्डवौ। केनान्नेन भवांस्तृप्येत् तस्यान्नस्य यतावहे॥
English Translation: Having been afflicted by Arjuna, large number of horses, that had their tongues and entrails driven out and that were greatly weakened and that were smeared with blood and also that had held and awful appearance, fell down upon the ground along with their riders.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्तः स भगवानब्रवीत् तावुभौ ततः। भाषमाणौ तदा वीरौ किमन्नं क्रियतामिति॥
English Translation: O sire, having been pierced by Savyasachin with the keen arrows, the men, horses and elephants wandered about, with tottering steps, fell down, roared most loudly and died.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मण उवाच नाहमन्नं बुभुक्षे वै पावकं मां निबोधतम्। यदन्नमनुरूपं मे तद् युवां सम्प्रयच्छतम्॥
English Translation: The son of Pritha and slaughtered his antagonists with innumerable arrows, that were sharpened on stones and also that were as deadly as the thunderbolt or the poison; even as Mahendra slays the Danavas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इदमिन्द्रः सदा दावं खाण्डवं परिरक्षति। न च शक्रोम्यहं दग्धुं रक्ष्यमाणं महात्मना॥
English Translation: Many heroes, who had put on valuable coats of armour and who were adorned with various kinds of ornaments and who had diverse forms and who, again, were equipt with innumerable weapons of the best kinds, are lying, with their cars and standards, on the field of battle, having been slaughtered by the son of Pritha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वसत्यत्र सखा तस्य तक्षकः पन्नगः सदा। सगणस्तत्कृते दावं परिरक्षति वज्रभृत्॥
English Translation: The warriors, who were vanquished, of noble deeds and of high parentage and learning departed to paradise on account of their noble deeds, whereas their bodies only lay upon the earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्र भूतान्यनेकानि रक्षतेऽस्य प्रसङ्गतः। तं दिधक्षुर्न शक्नोमि दग्धुं शक्रस्य तेजसा॥
English Translation: Thereupon several kings of many countries, who were accompanied by their attendants and who, again, were highly enraged, belonging to your army, proceeded most rapidly against Arjuna, that foremost of car-warriors.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स मां प्रज्वलितं दृष्ट्वा मेघाम्भोभिः प्रवर्षति। ततो दग्धुं न शक्नोमि दिधक्षुर्दावमीप्सिताम्॥
English Translation: Conveyed by their cars, horses and elephants, several warriors and foot-soldier who were all very desirous of slaying (Arjuna), advanced most rapidly against their antagonist (Arjuna), letting off innumerable weapons of great speed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स युवाभ्यां सहायाभ्यामस्त्रविद्भ्यां समागतः। दहेयं खाण्डवं दावमेतदन्नं वृतं मया॥
English Translation: Thereupon Arjuna, who was like winds, had done away with the showers of weapons, that resembled the showers of rains and that were let off by the warriors resembling the masses of clouds, by means of sharp arrows, shot with great readiness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युवां ह्यदकधारास्ता भूतानि च समन्ततः। उत्तमास्त्रविदौ सम्यक् सर्वतो वारयिष्यथः॥
English Translation: Then the people saw him (Arjuna) crossing that bridgeless ocean, which was constituted by the horses, infantry, elephant and cars and whose waves were formed by the most powerful weapons of the foes, by means of a bridge composed of his offensive and defensive weapons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जनमेजय उवाच किमर्थं भगवानग्निः खाण्डवं दग्धुमिच्छति। रक्ष्यमाणं महेन्द्रेण नानासत्त्वसमायुतम्॥
English Translation: Then Vasudeva said-"O son of Pritha, O sinless one, why do you play thus? Having crushed down this army of the Samsaptakas, then make haste to slay Karna.”
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न ह्येतत् कारणं ब्रह्मन्नल्पं सम्प्रतिभाति मे। यद् ददाह सुसंक्रुद्धः खाण्डवं हव्यवाहनः॥ एतद् विस्तरशो ब्रह्मञ्छ्रोतुमिच्छामि तत्त्वतः। खाण्डवस्य पुरा दाहो यथा समभवन्मुने॥
English Translation: Having uttered-so be it, to Krishna, Arjuna then forcibly struck down the rest of the army of the Samsaptakas; and slaughtered them, even as Indra had slaughtered the Daityas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच शृणु मे ब्रुवतो राजन् सर्वमेतद् यथातथम्। यनिमित्तं ददाहाग्निः खाण्डवं पृथिवीपते॥
English Translation: It could not be seen by the people with even the greatest attention, when Arjuna had taken up, or aimed the arrows, or shot the shafts with rapidity in the field of battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हन्त ते कथयिष्यामि पौराणीमृषिसंस्तुताम्। कथामिमां नरश्रेष्ठ खाण्डवस्य विनाशिनीम्॥
English Translation: O descendant of the Bharata race, Govinda considered this event to be most wonderful. Those arrows (shot by Arjuna) looking white like swans and possessed of great impetuosity, entered into the hostile army, even as the swans enter into a lake.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पौराणः श्रूयते राजन् राजा हरिहयोपमः। श्वेतकिर्नाम विख्यातो बलविक्रमसंयुतः॥
English Translation: Thereupon, Govinda, after having observed the field of battle during the course of the slaughter of men, addressed Savyasachin, sayingएष
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यज्वा दानपतिर्थीमान् यथा नान्योऽस्ति कञ्चन। ईजे च स महायज्ञैः क्रतुभिश्चाप्तदक्षिणैः॥
English Translation: “O son of Pritha, this formidable and great destruction of the kings of the Bharata race, as well as of the rulers of entire earth has taken place on account of the (foolish) actions of Duryodhana.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य नान्याभवद् बुद्धिर्दिवसे दिवसे नृप। सत्रे क्रियासमारम्भे दानेषु विविधेषु च॥ ऋत्विग्भिः सहितो धीमानेवमीजे स भूमिपः। ततस्तु ऋत्विजश्चास्य धूमव्याकुललोचनाः॥ कालेन महता खिन्नास्तत्यजुस्ते नराधिपम्। ततः प्रचोदयामास ऋत्विजस्तान् महीपतिः॥ चक्षुर्विकलतां प्राप्ता न प्रपेदुश्च ते क्रतुम्।
English Translation: O descendant of the Bharata race, behold these bows, having their backs decked in gold, of the mighty bowmen, so also the girdles and quivers, that were displaced from their bodies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्तेषामनुमते तद् विप्रैस्तु नराधिपः॥ सत्रं समापयामास ऋत्विग्भिपरैः सह।
English Translation: (Again, behold), the straight shafts adorned with the golden wings, as well as the long arrows, washed with oil, even like the snakes coming out of their sioughs.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्यैवं वर्तमानस्य कदाचित् कालपयये॥ सत्रमाहर्तुकामस्य सवंत्सरशतं किल। ऋत्विजो नाभ्यपद्यन्त समाहर्तुं महात्मनः॥
English Translation: O descendant of the Bharata race, (behold also) ihe lances of diverse kinds, that are adorned with gold and scattered on all sides, as well as the coats of mail, having golden backs and loosened from the bodies of the warriors.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स च राजाकरोद् यत्नं महान्तं ससुहृज्जनः। प्रणिपातेन सान्त्वेन दानेन च महायशाः॥ ऋत्विजोऽनुनयामास भूयो भूयस्त्वतन्द्रितः। ते चास्य तमभिप्रायं न चक्रुरमितौजसः॥
English Translation: (Behold) the spears adorned with gold and the Sakti-arrows also decorated with gold, as well as the huge maces bound with the threads of gold and chords of hemp.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स चाश्रमस्थान् राजर्षिस्तानुवाच रुषान्वितः। यद्यहं पतितो विप्राः शुश्रूषायां न च स्थितः॥ आशु त्याज्योऽस्मि युष्माभिर्ब्राह्मणैश्च जुगुप्सितः। तन्नार्हथ क्रतुश्रद्धां व्याघातयितुमद्य ताम्॥
English Translation: (Behold) the swords ornamented with the workmanship of gold, the axes decorated with gold, as also the battle-axes equipt with the handles made of bright gold.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अस्थाने वा परित्यागं कर्तुं मे द्विजसत्तमाः। प्रपन्न एव वो विप्राः प्रसादं कर्तुमर्हथ॥ सान्त्वदानादिभिर्वाक्येस्तत्त्वतः कार्यवत्तया। प्रसादयित्वा वक्ष्यामि यन्नः कार्यं द्विजोत्तमाः॥ अथवाहं परित्यक्तो भवद्भिदे॒षकारणात्। ऋत्विजोऽन्यान् गमिष्यामि याजनार्थं द्विजोत्तमाः॥
English Translation: (Again behold) the spiked maces, the short arrows, the Bhushandis, the Kanayas, the Kuntas, made of iron, scattered about and the huge musalas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतावदुक्त्वा वचनं विरराम स पार्थिवः। यदा न शेकू राजानं याजनार्थं परंतपः॥ ततस्ते याजकः क्रुद्धास्तमूचुर्नृपसत्तमम्। तव कर्माण्यजस्रं वै वर्तन्ते पार्थिवोत्तम॥
English Translation: The mighty warriors most desirous of victory and possessed of immense activity, after having taken up weapons of diverse kinds, although dead, still looked as if they were living.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो वयं परिश्रान्ताः सततं कर्मवाहिनः। श्रमादस्मात् परिश्रान्तान् स त्वं नस्त्यक्तुमर्हसि॥ बुद्धिमोहं समास्थाय त्वरासम्भावितोऽनघ। गच्छ रुद्रसकाशं त्वं स हि त्वां याजयिष्यति॥
English Translation: Behold those thousands of warriors, who had their limbs crushed by the maces and who had their heads severed by the Mushalas and again, who were highly pressed by the elephants, horses and cars.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: साधिक्षेपं वचः श्रुत्वा संक्रुद्धः श्वेतकिर्नृपः। कैलास पर्वतं गत्वा तप उग्रं समास्थितः॥ आराधयन् महादेवं नियतः संशितव्रतः। उपवासपरो राजन् दीर्घकालमतिष्ठत॥
English Translation: O destroyer of foes, the fields of battle were scattered over the dead bodies of the elephants, horses and men, that had been torn into fragments with the shafts, the arrows called Sakti, swords and lances and scimitars, axes, spears and the Nakharas and clubs; and also those bodies were sineared with the torrents of blood.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कदाचिद् द्वादशे काले कदाचिदपि षोडशे। आहारमकरोद् राजा मूलानि च फलानि च॥
English Translation: O descendant of the Bharata race, the earth shines most brilliantly with the arms scattered over her, that are smeared with the soft sandal and that are ornamented with the Angadas and also that are marked with the auspicious signs and that are furnished with the leathern protections and that are adorned with the Keyuras.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ऊर्ध्वबाहुस्त्वनिमिषस्तिष्ठन् स्थाणुरिवाचलः। षण्मासानभवद् राजा श्वेतकिः सुसमाहितः॥
English Translation: (Again, the earth looks most resplendent), strewn over with the hands furnished with the well-protected fingers, severed from their arms and adorned with innumerable ornaments and also with the thighs severed from their bodies and resembling the trunks of elephants and again, with the heads of the most skillful and active warriors, that are adorned with the turbans set with the most valuable gems and furnished with the handsome ear-rings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं तथा नृपशार्दूलं तप्यमानं महत् तपः। शंकरः परमप्रीत्या दर्शयामास भारत॥
English Translation: Now do you behold the most handsome cars, equip with golden bells and broken into numberless fragments, so also the large number of horses, that are smeared with blood; and again the bottoms of cars and long quivers; as well as several kinds of flags and standards. (Again do you behold) the large conches of the warriors; the yak-tails that are perfectly white; and the elephants whose tongues have come out (of the mouths) and that are lying on the field, resembling the hills.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उवाच चैनं भगवान् स्निग्धगम्भीरया गिरा। प्रीतोऽस्मि नरशार्दूल तपसा ते परंतप॥
English Translation: (Also behold) the variegated the triumphal banners and the elephants, warriors, slain in the battle, the beautiful coverlets of elephants; and the innumerable blankets with excellent (needle) workmanship.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वरं वृणीष्व भद्रं ते यं त्वमिच्छसि पार्थिव। एतच्छ्रुत्वा तु वचनं रुद्रस्यामिततेजसः॥
English Translation: (Moreover behold) the blankets, that are most handsome, variegated and torn into fragments and as well as the bells, broken into minute particles by the falling elephants and loosened from their bodies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रणिपत्य महात्मानं राजर्षिः प्रत्यभाषत। यदि मे भगवान् प्रीतः सर्वलोकनमस्कृतः॥ स्वयं मां देवदेवेश याजयस्व सुरेश्वर। एतच्छ्रुत्वा तु वचनं राज्ञा तेन प्रभाषितम्॥
English Translation: (Also behold) the hooks, that are furnished with handles, decked with precious stones called Vaidurya and lying on the ground; and the most handsome yokes of horses, as well as the armours for theirs breast, that are decked with diamonds; and the valuable pieces of cloth, that are adorned with gold and tied to the suimit of the standards carried by horsemen.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उवाच भगवान् प्रीतः स्मितपूर्वमिदं वचः। नास्माकमेष विषयो वर्तते याजनं प्रति॥ त्वया च सुमहत् तप्तं तपो राजन् वरार्थिना। याजयिष्यामि राजांस्त्वां समयेन परंपत॥
English Translation: (Behold) the coverlets of horses upon their backs lying upon the ground, that are most beautiful and that are set with the precious jewels and that are adorned with gold and made of the skins of Ranku (a kind of deer).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रुद्र उवाच समा द्वादश राजेन्द्र ब्रह्मचारी समाहितः। सततं त्वाज्यधाराभिर्यदि तर्पयसेऽनलम्॥ कामं प्रार्थयसे यं त्वं मत्तः प्राप्स्यसि तं नृप।
English Translation: (Behold) the headgears of the lords of men and the beautiful garlands made of gold and the umbrellas fallen from their proper places and also the white yak-tails and fans.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्तश्च रुद्रेण श्वेतकिर्मनुजाधिपः॥ तथा चकार तत् सर्वं यथोक्तं शूलपाणिना। पूर्णे तु द्वादशे वर्षे पुनरायान्महेश्वरः॥
English Translation: (Behold) the earth scattered over with the faces, that resemble either the moon or the stars in splendour and that are furnished with handsome ear-rings and that are ornamented with well-cut bcards and that are as brilliant as the full moon.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दृष्ट्वैव च स राजानं शंकरो लोकभावनः। उवाच परमप्रीतः श्वेतकिं नृपसत्तमम्॥
English Translation: As the lake is adorned with the assemblage of white and pink lilies and lotuses, so the earth strewn ever with those faces resembling the lilies and lotuses in splendour is decked with thcim.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तोषितोऽहं नृपश्रेष्ठ त्वयेहाद्येन कर्मणा। याजनं ब्राह्मणानां तु विधिदृष्टं परंतप॥
English Translation: Behold this (the earth), that resembles the clear moon in splendour and that is variegated with the myriads of stars and also that looks like the autumnal firmament sprinkled over with the millions of stars.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अतोऽहं त्वां स्वयं नाद्य याजयामि परंतय। ममांशस्तु क्षितितले महाभागो द्विजोत्तमः॥
English Translation: O Arjuna, deeds that had been wrought by you today in this dreadful battle are proper for you, or for the lord of the celestials in heaven.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुर्वासा इति विख्यातः स हि त्वां याजयिष्यति। मन्नियोगान्महातेजाः सम्भाराः सम्भ्रियन्तु ते॥
English Translation: While Krishna was thus showing that field of battle to the diadem-decked Arjuna and going to their camp, he heard a loud roar in the army of Duryodhana. (In the army of Duryodhana were heard) the blare of conches and the best of drums and cymbals and the rattle of elephants and the dreadful class of innumerable weapons.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतच्छ्रुत्वा तु वचनं रुद्रेण समुदाहृतम्। स्वपुरं पुनरागम्य सम्भारान् पुनरार्जयत्॥
English Translation: Having entered that army with horses swift as the wind and also having seen your force crushed down by the chief of the Pandayas, Krishna became highly astonished,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः सम्भृतसम्भारो भूयो रुद्रमुपागमत्। सम्भृता मम सम्भारा: सर्वोपकरणानि च॥ त्वत्प्रसादान्महादेव श्वो मे दीक्षा भवेदिति। एतच्छ्रुत्वा तु वचनं तस्य राज्ञो महात्मनः॥ दुर्वाससं समाहूय रुद्रो वचनमब्रवीत्। एष राजा महाभागः श्वेतकिर्द्विजसत्तम॥ एनं याजय विप्रेन्द्र मन्नियोगेन भूमिपम्। बाढमित्येव वचनं रुद्रं त्वृषिरुवाच ह॥
English Translation: That foremost of heroes, who was skilled in the management of arrows and weapons in battle, slaughtered large throngs of enemies with different kinds of shafts, even as Yama (Death) destroys the creatures, deprived of their lives.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः सत्रं समभवत् तस्य राज्ञो महात्मनः। यथाविधिः यथाकालं यथोक्तं बहुदक्षिणम्॥
English Translation: That foremost of smiters, after having penetrated the bodies of the elephants, horses and soldiers, with keen arrows, had struck down the foes, who were deprived of both their bodies and lives.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मिन् परिसमाप्ते तु राज्ञः सत्रे महात्मनः। दुर्वाससाभ्यनुज्ञाता विप्रतस्थुः स्म याजकः॥ ये तत्र दीक्षिताः सर्वे सदस्याश्च महौजसः। सोऽपि राजन् महाभागः स्वपुरं प्राविशत् तदा॥
English Translation: Then the chief of the Pandavas after having cut-off the innumerable offensive weapons shot by the most dreadful of his enemies with his own arrows had slaughtered those enemies, even as Shakra had slain the Asuras (in the battle of old).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पूज्यमानो महाभागैाह्मणैर्वेदपारगैः। वन्दिभिः स्तूयमानश्च नागरैश्चाभिनन्दितः॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said Upon Partha's desire for advancing against the division of Drona, Krishna urged his steeds covered with golden caparisons, fleet as the mind and white in hue.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवंवृत्तः स राजर्षिः श्वेतकिर्नृपसत्तमः। कालेन महता चापि ययौ स्वर्गमभिष्टुतः॥ ऋत्विग्भिः सहितः सर्वैः सदस्यैश्च समन्वितः। तस्य सत्रे पपौ वह्निर्हविदश वत्सरान्॥
English Translation: Beholding that foremost of the Kurus make towards his brothers afflicted sore by Drona, king Susarman with his brothers followed him, desirous of battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सततं चाज्यधाराभिरैकात्म्ये तत्र कर्मणि। हविषा च ततो वह्निः परां तृप्तिमगच्छत॥
English Translation: The invincible Arjuna owning white steeds then thus addressed Krishna Krishna saying:-'O Achyuta, this Susarman assisted by his brother challenges me (to fight).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न चैच्छत् पुनरादातुं हविरन्यस्य कस्यचित्। पाण्डुवर्णो विवर्णश्च न यथावत् प्रकाशते॥
English Translation: O slayer of foes, on the other hand, the ranks of my troops are being shattered, (by Drona); today my mind is undecided in its purposes, which is caused by the Samshaptakas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो भगवतो वह्नर्विकारः समजायत। तेजसा विप्रहीणश्च ग्लानिश्चैनं समाविशत्॥
English Translation: Shall I slay the Samshaptakas or shall I save my own army afflicted by the foe. Know this to be what I am thinking of; tell me what would be beneficial for me?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स लक्षयित्वा चात्मानं तेजोहीनं हुताशनः। जगाम सदनं पुण्यं ब्रह्मणो लोकपूजितम्॥
English Translation: Thus spoken to, the descendant of the Dasharhas (viz., Krishna), turned the car and drove the son of Pandu to the spot whence the ruler of the Trigarttas was summoning Arjuna.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्र ब्रह्माणमासीनमिदं वचनमब्रवीत्। भगवन् परमा प्रीतिः कृता मे श्वेतकेतुना॥ अरुचिश्चाभवत् तीव्रा तां न शक्नोभ्यपोहितुम्। तेजसा विप्रहीणोऽस्मि बलेन च जगत्पते॥ इच्छेय त्वत्प्रसादेन स्वात्मनः प्रकृति स्थिराम्।
English Translation: Thereat Arjuna piercing Susarman with seven swift-coursing arrows, cut down his standard, bow and chariot with a couple a razor-sharp arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतच्छ्रुत्वा हुतवहाद् भगवान् सर्वलोककृत॥ हव्यवाहमिदं वाक्यमुवाच प्रहसन्निव। त्वया द्वादश वर्षाणि वसोर्धाराहुतं हविः॥ उपयुक्तं महाभाग तेन त्वां ग्लानिराविशत्। तेजसा विप्रहीणत्वात् सहसा हव्यवाहन॥ मा गमस्त्वं यथा वह्ने प्रकृतिस्थो भविष्यसि। अरुचिं नाशयिष्येऽहं समयं प्रतिपद्य ते॥
English Translation: Then with six swift-flying arrows Partha speedily dispatched to the mansion of Death the brother of the ruler of the Trigarttas, with his steeds and charioteers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुरा देवनियोगेन यत् त्वया भस्मसात् कृतम्। आलयं देवशत्रूणां सुघोरं खाण्डवं वनम्॥ तत्र सर्वाणि सत्त्वानि निवसन्ति विभावसो। तेषां त्वं मेदसा तृप्तः प्रकृतिस्थो भविष्यसि॥
English Translation: Thereat Susarman, aiming at Arjuna, hurled an iron dart resembling a snake and he threw a lance at the son of Vasudeva.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गच्छ शीघ्रं प्रदग्धुं त्वं ततो मोक्ष्यसि किल्बिषात्। एतच्छ्रुत्वा तु वचनं परमेष्ठिमुखाच्च्युतम्॥ उत्तमं जवमास्थाय प्रदुद्राव हुताशनः। आगम्य खाण्डवं दावमुत्तमं वीर्यमास्थितः। सहसा प्राज्वलच्चाग्निः क्रुद्धो वायुसमीरितः॥
English Translation: Having cut down the dart with three shafts and the lance also with another three, Arjuna compelled Susarman to turn back, depriving him of his senses my means of an arrowy down-pour.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रदीप्तं खाण्डवं दृष्ट्वा ये स्युस्तत्र निवासिनः। परमं यत्नमातिष्ठन् पावकस्य प्रशान्तये॥
English Translation: None among your host ventured to oppose him, O monarch, as he came looking fierce and showering arrows like Vasava pouring rain.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: करैस्तु करिणः शीघ्रं जलमादाय सत्वराः। सिषिचुः पावकं क्रुद्धाः शतशोऽथ सहस्रशः॥
English Translation: Then Dhananjaya advanced slaying all the mighty car-warriors of the Kauravas, with his arrows, just as fire advances consuming heaps of straw and fuel.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बहुशीर्षास्ततो नागाः शिरोभिर्जलसंततिम्। मुमुचुः पावकाभ्याशे सत्वराः क्रोधमूर्च्छिताः॥
English Translation: Like the touch of fire, people were unable to bear the unbearablc impetuosity of that intelligent son of Kunti.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथैवान्यानि सत्त्वानि नानाप्रहरणोद्यमैः। विलयं पावकं शीघ्रमनयन् भरतर्षभ॥
English Translation: The son of Pandu overwhelming with his arrowy showers the hostile host, made, O monarch, towards the rulers of the Pragjyotisas, like Suparna pouncing down (upon his prey).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनेन तु प्रकारेण भूयो भूयश्च प्रज्वलन्। सप्तकृत्वः प्रशमितः खाण्डवे हव्यवाहनः॥
English Translation: Then the ever-victorious Arjuna held in his grasp the bow, that was prolific of benefit for the sinless Pandavas and that was capable of enhancing the grief of the enemy in battle, for the destruction of the Kshatriyas, brought about, O king, by your son's recourse to the deceitful fame at dice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच तत् प्रभग्नं बलं दृष्ट्वा कुन्तीपुत्रो धनजयः। न्यवारयदमेयात्मा द्रोणपुत्रजयेप्सया॥
English Translation: Then, () monarch, your troops being thus agitated by the son of Pritha, was broken like a frail bark grounded on a rock.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्ते सैनिका राजन् नैव तत्रावतस्थिरे। संस्थाप्यमाना यत्नेन गोविन्देनार्जुनेन च॥
English Translation: Thereupon, ten thousand bowmen, brave and inflamed with a fierce determination for battle and disregardful of victory or defeat, turned upon (Arjuna).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एक एव च बीभत्सुः सोमकावयवैः सह। मत्स्यैरन्यैश्च संधाय कौरवान् संन्यवर्तत॥
English Translation: With their hearts shorn of fear, those mighty warriors completely encompassed him. Thereat Partha capable of bearing all burdens how heavy sover, took up that burden in that battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो द्रुतमतिक्रम्य सिंहलाङ्कलकेतनम्। सव्यसाची महेष्वासमश्वत्थामानमब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: Then Partha began to crush your forces just as an infuriatc elephant of six years of age, with rent temples crushes and tears an assemblage of lotus plants.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: या शक्तिर्यच विज्ञानं यद् वीर्य यच पौरुषम्। धार्तराष्ट्रेषु या प्रीतिर्द्धषोऽस्मासु च यश्च ते॥
English Translation: When the troops were being thus crushed, Bhagadatta, the ruler of men, riding on the selfsame elephant, rushed suddenly at Dhananjaya.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यच भूयोऽस्ति तेजस्ते तत् सर्वं मयि दर्शय। स एव द्रोणहन्ता ते दर्प छेत्स्यति पार्षतः॥
English Translation: Thereupon Dhananjaya that foremost of men, received him. (Bhagadatta), opposing him with his car. Then a fierce encounter raged between that car and that elephant.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कालानलसमप्रख्यं द्विषतामन्तकोपमम्। समासादय पाञ्चाल्यं मां चापि सहकेशवम्। दर्प नाशयितास्म्यद्य तवोत्तस्य संयुगे॥
English Translation: Riding their and elephant respectively which were equipped according to the rules of the military science, those two heroes Dhananjaya and Bhagadatta careered through the field of battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच आचार्यपुत्रो मानार्हो बलवांश्चापि संजय। प्रीतिधनंजये चास्य प्रियश्चापि महात्मनः॥
English Translation: Then staying on his elephant that resembled a mass of clouds, the mighty down-pour of arrows, like Indra showering rain.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न भूतपूर्वं बीभत्सोर्वाक्यं परुषमीदृशम्। अथ कस्मात् स कौन्तेयः सखायं रूक्षमुक्तवान्॥
English Translation: Then the son of Vasava (Arjuna) endued with prowess, cut-off with his arrowy showers, the arrows of Bhagadatta, before they could even reach him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच युवराजे हते चैव वृद्धक्षत्रे च पौरवे। इष्वस्रविधिसम्पन्ने मालवे च सुदर्शने॥
English Translation: Oll car Then, O sire, the king of the Pragjyotisas, baffling that shower of arrows, pierced the mighty-armed son of Pritha, as also Krishna, with his arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृष्टद्युम्ने सात्यकौ च भीमे चापि पराजिते। युधिष्ठिरस्य तैर्वाक्यैर्मर्मण्यपि च घट्टिते॥
English Translation: Thereafter covering Krishna and Partha with a thick net-work of arrows, Bhagadatta urged his elephant towards them in order to slay them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्तर्भेदे च संजाते दुःखं संस्मृत्य च प्रभो। अभूतपूर्वो बीभत्सोर्दुःखान्मन्युरजायत॥
English Translation: Thereat beholding that infuriate elephant make towards themselves like Death himself, Janardana with swiftness moved his car in a manner as to leave the elephant on the left.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मादनहमश्लीलमप्रियं द्रौणिमुक्तवान्। मान्यमाचार्यतनयं रूक्षं कापुरुषं यथा॥
English Translation: Thus Dhananjaya, though he got an opportunity of slaying that mighty elephant and its rider from the right side, yet did not avail himself of it, recollecting the laws of fair combat.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्तः श्वसन क्रोधान्महेष्वासतमो नृप। पार्थेन परुषं वाक्यं सर्वमर्मभिदा गिरा॥
English Translation: The elephant, O sire, trampling down upon other elephants, cars and steeds, sent them all to the regions of Death. Thereat Dhananjaya was inflamed with wrath.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्रौणिश्चुकोप पार्थाय कृष्णाय च विशेषतः। स तु यत्तो रथे स्थित्वा वार्युपस्पृश्य वीर्यवान्॥
English Translation: Vyasa said Blessed be you, O Gandhari, you shall see your sons and brothers and friends and kinsmen along with your sires this night like men risen from sleep.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: देवैरपि सुदुर्धर्षमस्रमाग्नेयमाददे। दृश्यादृश्यानरिंगणानुद्दिश्याचार्यनन्दनः॥
English Translation: Kunti also shall see Karna, and she of Yadu's race shall see her son Abhimanyu. Draupadi shall see her five sons, her fathers and her brothers also.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सोऽभिमन्व्य शरं दीप्तं विधूममिव पावकम्। सर्वतः क्रोधमाविश्य चिक्षेप परवीरहा॥
English Translation: Even before you had asked me, this was the thought in my mind. I entertained this purpose when I was urged to that effect by the king, by you, O Gandhari, and by Kunti:
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्तुमुलमाकाशे शरवर्षमजायत। पावकार्चिः परीतं तत् पार्थमेवाभिपुप्लुवे॥
English Translation: You should not grieve for those foremost of men. They met with death on account of their devotion to the practices of Kshatriyas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उल्काश्च गगनात् पेतुर्दिशश्च न चकाशिरे। तमश्च सहसा रौद्रं चमूमवततार ताम्॥
English Translation: O faultless one, the work of the gods could not but be done. It was for accomplishing that object that those heroes came down on earth. They were all portions f the celestials.

Sanskrit Shloka: रक्षांसि च पिशाचाश्च विनेदुरतिसङ्गताः। ववुश्चाशिशिरा वाताः सूर्यो नैव तताप च॥
English Translation: Gandharvas, Apsaras, Pishachas, Guhyakas and Rakshasas, many pure persons, many individuals crowned with (of penances), celestial Rishis, deities ad Danavas, and heavenly Rishis of spotless character, met with death on the battle field of Kurukshetra.

Sanskrit Shloka: वायसाश्चापि चाक्रन्दन् दिक्षु सर्वासु भैरवम्। रुधिरं चापि वर्षन्तो विनेदुस्तोयदा दिवि॥

Sanskrit Shloka: पाणिः पशवो गावो विनेदुश्चापि सुव्रताः। परमं प्रयतात्मानो न शान्तिमुपलेभिरे॥
English Translation: success Know that Pandu of unfading glory and distinguished above all others, originated from the Maruts, Kshatta and Yudhishthira are both portions of the deity of Virtue.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भ्रान्तसर्वमहाभूतमावर्तितदिवाकरम्। त्रैलोक्यमभिसंतप्तं ज्वराविष्टमिवाभवत्॥
English Translation: Know that Duryodhana was Kali, and Shakuni was Dvapara. O you of good features, know that Dushasana and others were all Rakshasas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अस्रतेजोऽभिसंतप्ता नागा भूमिशयास्तथा। निःश्वसन्तः समुत्पेतुस्तेजो घोरं मुमुक्षवः॥
English Translation: Bhimasena of great power that chastiser of enemies, is from the Maruts. Know that this Dhananjaya, the son of Pritha, is the ancient Rishi Nara.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जलजानि च सत्त्वानि दह्यमानानि भारत। न शान्तिमुपजग्मुर्हि तप्यमानैर्जलाशयैः॥
English Translation: Hrishikesha is Narayana, and the wins are the Ashvins. That foremost of heat-giving ones, viz., Surya, having divided his body in two parts continued with one portion to give heat to the worlds and with another to live as Karna. He who was born as the son of Arjuna, that gladdener of all, that heir of the properties of the Pandavas, who was killed by six carwarriors (fighting together) was Soma. He was of born Subhadra. Through Yoga power he had divided himself in two parts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दिग्भ्यः प्रदिग्भ्यः खाद् भूमेः सर्वतः शरवृष्ट्यः। उच्चावचा निपेतुर्वै गरुडानिलरंहसः॥
English Translation: Dhrishtadyumna who originated with Draupadi from the sacrificial fire, was an auspicious portion of the deity of fire, Shikhandin was a Rakshasa.

Sanskrit Shloka: तैः शरैर्दोणपुत्रस्य वज्रवेगैः समाहताः। प्रदग्धा रिपव: पेतुरग्निदग्धा इव द्रुमाः॥
English Translation: Know that Drona was a portion of Brihaspati, and that Drona's son is born of a portion of Rudra. Know that Ganga's son Bhishma was one of the Vasus who became born as a men.

Sanskrit Shloka: दह्यमाना महानागाः पेतुरुआं समन्ततः। नदन्तो भैरवान् नादाञ्जलदोपमनि:स्वनान्॥
English Translation: Thus, O you of great wisdom, the deities had taken birth as human beings, and after having accomplished their purposes have returned to the celestial region.

Sanskrit Shloka: अपरे प्रद्रुता नागा भयत्रस्ता विशाम्पते। भ्रेमुर्दिशो यथा पूर्वं वने दावाग्निसंवृताः॥
English Translation: I shall today, dispel that sorrow which is in the hearts of you all, about the return of these to the other world.

Sanskrit Shloka: तूर्णमाजजिरे हृष्टास्तावका जितकाशिनः। कृत्स्ना ह्यक्षौहिणी राजन् सव्यसाची च पाण्डवः।। ३४

Sanskrit Shloka: वरदं पृथुचावड्या पार्वत्या सहितं प्रभुम्। क्रीडमानं महात्मानं भूतसङ्घगणैर्वृतम्॥
English Translation: Were sent by the diadem-decked Shetavahana to the domains of Death. Deeply pierced with straight-coursing arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अजमीशानमव्यक्तं कारणात्मानमच्युतम्। अभिवाद्याथ रुद्राय सद्योऽन्धकनिपातिने। पद्माक्षस्तं विरूपाक्षमभितुष्टाव भक्तिमान्॥
English Translation: The tuskers dropped (dead) on the ground like mountain peaks, with the chopped-off trunks of elephants, still moving to and fro (in convulsions).
---
