Sanskrit Shloka: श्रीनारायण उवाच त्वत्सम्भूता भूतकृतो वरेण्य गोप्तारोऽस्य भुवनस्यादिदेव। आविश्येमां धरणीं येऽभ्यरक्षन्। पुरा पुराणी तव देवसृष्टिम्॥
English Translation: The earth, being strewn all over, seemed to be full of snakes, moving about, with the fallen royal umbrellas decked with gold.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुरासुरान् नागरक्षः पिशाचान् नरान् सुपर्णानथ गन्धर्वयक्षान्। पृथग्विधान् भूतसंघांश्च विश्वां स्त्वत्सम्भूतान् विद्म सर्वांस्तथैव। ऐन्द्रं याम्यं वारुणं वैत्तपाल्यं पैत्रं त्वाष्ट्रं कर्म सौम्यं च तुभ्यम्॥
English Translation: The field, being scattered all over looked (beautiful) like the firmament studded with (innumerable) suns, moons and stars at the end of a Yuga. "Slay, strike dauntlessly, pierce and cut to pieces."
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रूपं ज्योतिः शब्द आकाशवायुः स्पर्शः स्वाद्यं सलिलं गन्ध उर्वी। कालो ब्रह्मा ब्रह्म च ब्राह्मणाश्च त्वत्सम्भूतं स्थास्नु चरिष्णु चेदम्॥
English Translation: These (and similar other) tumultuous uproars arose near the car of Shonasva (i.e. Drona). Getting terribly enraged, Drona also, by means of Vayaveya weapon, in that encounter.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अद्भ्यः स्तोका यान्ति यथा पृथक्त्वं ताभिश्चैक्यं संक्षये यान्ति भूयः। एवं विद्वान् प्रभवं चाप्ययं च मत्वा भूतानां तव सायुज्यमेति॥
English Translation: Began, like a furious hurricane (chasing away) the clouds, to destroy his enemies. (Thus slaughter by Drona, the Panchalas fled away from terror.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दिव्यामृतौ मानसौ द्वौ सुपर्णी वाचा शाखाः पिप्पलाः सप्त गोपाः। दशाप्यन्ये ये पुरं धारयन्ति त्वया सृष्टास्त्वं हि तेभ्यः परोहि॥
English Translation: In the very presence of Bhimasena and of the high-souled Partha. (Then) that one who wore a coronet (i.e. Arjuna and Bhimasena, rallying (their troops) all on a sudden.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भूतं भव्यं भविता चाप्यधृष्यं त्वत्सम्भूता भुवनानीह विश्वा। भक्तं च मां भजमानं भजस्व मा रीरिषो मामहिताहितेन॥
English Translation: Attacked the large army (of Drona) with a mighty car force. Vibhatsu attacking the right and Vrikodara the left flank (of Drona's army).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आत्मानं त्वामात्मनोऽनन्यबोधं विद्वानेवं गच्छति ब्रह्म शुक्रम्। अस्तौषं त्वां तव सम्मानमिच्छन् विचिन्वन् वै सदृशं देववर्य। नभिष्टुतः प्रविकार्षीश्च मायाम्॥
English Translation: They rained upon the son of Bharadvaja two mighty downpours of arrows. Then the Srinjayas and those great car-warriors, the Panchalas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यास उवाच तस्मै वरानचिन्त्यात्मा नीलकण्ठः पिनाकधृत्। अर्हते देवमुख्याय प्रायच्छदृषिसंस्तुतः॥
English Translation: And the Matsyas together with the Somakas followed. In like manner, (many) car-warriors, who wore (efficient) smiters on the side of your son.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रीभगवानुवाच मत्प्रसादान्मनुष्येषु देवगन्धर्वयोनिषु। अप्रमेयबलात्मा त्वं नारायण भविष्यसि॥
English Translation: (Followed) by a vast army, O king, proceeded towards the car of Drona. Then that Bharata army slaughtered by Kiriti (i.e., Arjuna who wore a coronet).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न च त्वां प्रसहिष्यन्ति देवासुरमहोरगाः। न पिशाचा न गन्धर्वा न यक्षा न च राक्षसाः॥
English Translation: (Overcome) with sleep and bewildered by darkness began once more to disperse. In spite of (the endeavours of) Drona and your son himself to prevent (their fight),
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न सुपर्णास्तथा नागा न च विश्वे वियोनिजाः। न कश्चित् त्वां च देवोऽपि समरेषु विजेष्यति॥
English Translation: They were unable to rally the combat ts, O mighty monarch. That vast army, slaughter with arrows by the son of Pandu.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न शस्त्रेण न वज्रेण नाग्निना न च वायुना। न चाट्टैण न शुष्केण ब्रसेन स्थावरेण च॥ कश्चित् तव रुजां कर्ता मत्प्रसादात् कथंचना अवि वै समरं गत्वा भविष्यसि ममाधिकः॥
English Translation: Took to flight in all directions when the world was enveloped in darkness. Hundreds of kings, leaving their conveyances, fled away, O great monarch, in terror, on all side.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमेते वरा लब्धाः पुरस्ताद् विद्धि शौरिणा। स एष देवश्चरति मायया मोहयञ्जगत्॥
English Translation: Took to flight in all directions when the world was enveloped in darkness. Hundreds of kings, leaving their conveyances, fled away, O great monarch, in terror, on all side.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्यैव तपसा जातं नरं नाम महामुनिम्। तुल्यमेतेन देवेन तं जानीह्यर्जुनं सदा॥
English Translation: Let offerings be made to the great Mahadeva of three eyes. eyes. Having duly dedicated those offerings, O king, we shall then try to gain our objet.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तावेतौ पूर्वदेवानां परमोपचितावृषी। लोकयात्राविधानार्थं संजायेते युगे युगे॥
English Translation: Hearing these words of those Brahmanas, Yudhishthira caused offerings to be duly made to that deity who loved to lie down on mountain-breasts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथैव कर्मणा कृत्स्नं महतस्तपसोऽपि च। तेजो मन्युं च विभ्रत्त्वं जातो रौद्रो महामते॥
English Translation: Pleasing the (sacrificial) fire with (libations of) sanctified butter according to the ordinance, the priest (Dhaumya) cooked Charu with the aid of Mantras and performed the necessary rites.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स भवान् देववत् प्राज्ञो ज्ञात्वा भवमयं जगत्। अवाकर्षस्त्वमात्मानं नियमैस्तत्प्रियेप्सया॥
English Translation: He took up many flowers and sanctified them with Mantras, O king. With Modakas and frumenty and meat, he made offerings to the deity.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शुभ्रमत्र भवान् कृत्वा महापुरुषविग्रहम्। ईजिवांस्त्वं जपैोमैरुपहारैश्च मानद॥
English Translation: With various kinds of flowers and with fried paddy, of very superior kind, Dhaumya, well-versed in the Vedas, performed the remaining rites.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जन्मकर्ततपोयोगास्तयोस्तव च पुष्कलाः। ताभ्यां लिङ्गेऽर्चितो देवस्त्वयार्चायां युगे युगे॥ सर्वरूपं भवं ज्ञात्वा लिङ्गे योऽर्चयति प्रभुम्।
English Translation: He next presented offerings according to the ordinance to those ghostly beings who formed Mahadeva's train. And offerings were next made to Kubera the king of the Yakshas, and to Manibhadra also.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आत्मयोगाश्च तस्मिन् वै शास्त्रयोगाश्च शाश्वताः॥ एवं देवा यजन्तो हि सिद्धाश्च परमर्षयः।
English Translation: To the other Yakshas also and to them who were the foremost ones among the ghostly companions of Mahadeva, the priest offered due adoration, having filled many jugs with food, with Krisharas and meat and Nivapas mixed with sesame seeds. The king gave away unto the Brahmanas thousands of kine.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रार्थयन्ते परं लोके स्थाणुमेकं स सर्वकृत्॥ स एष रुद्रभक्तश्च केशवो रुद्रसम्भवः। कृष्ण एव हि यष्टव्यो यज्ञैश्चैव सनातनः॥
English Translation: He then directed the presentation, according to due rites, of offerings to those night-ranging beings (who live with Mahadeva). Surcharged, as it were, with the scent of Dhupas, and filled with the fragrance of flowers, that region, sacred to the deity of deities, O king, became highly delightful. Having performed the adoration of Rudra and of all the Ganas, the king, placing Vyasa ahead went towards the place where the treasure was buried. Once more adoring the Lord of riches, and bowing to hiin with respect and saluting himn properly, with various kinds of flowers and cakes and Krishara, having adored those foremost of gems, viz., Shankha and Nidhi and those Yakshas who are the lords of gems, and having adored many foremost of Brahmanas and caused them to utter blessings, the king gifted with great power, strengthened by the energy and the auspicious benedictions of those Brahmanas, caused that spot to be excavated. Then numerous vessels of various and delightful forms, Bhringaras, Katahas, Kalasas, Bardhamanakas, and innumerable Bhajanas of beautiful forms, were dug out by king Yudhishthira the just, The wealth thus dug out was placed in large has Karaput (wooden chests united with each other by chains or cords, and carried by bullocks or camels) for protection.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वभूतभवं ज्ञात्वा लिङ्गमर्चति यः प्रभोः। तस्मिन्नभ्यधिकां प्रीतिं करोति वृषभध्वजः॥
English Translation: A portion of the wealth was caused to be carried upon the shoulders of men it stout balances of wood with baskets slung like scales at both ends. Indeed, O king, there were other methods of conveyance there for carrying away that wealth of the son of Pandu.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच तस्य तद् वचनं श्रुत्वा द्रोणपुत्रो महारथः। नमश्चकार रुद्राय बहु मेने च केशवम्॥
English Translation: There were sixty thousands of camels, and a hundred and twenty thousand horses, and of elephants, O king, there were one hundred thousand.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हृष्टरोमा च वश्यात्मा सोऽभिवाद्य महर्षये। वरूथिनीमभिप्रेक्ष्य ह्यवहारमकारयत्॥
English Translation: Of cars there were as many, and of carts too as many and of she elephants as many. Mules and men were of unlimited number.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः प्रत्यवहारोऽभूत् पाण्डवानां विशाम्पते। कौरवाणां च दीनानां द्रोणे युधि निपातिते॥
English Translation: That wealth which Yudhishthira caused to be dug out was even so much. Sixteen thousand coins were placed on the back of each camel; cight thousand on each car; and twentyfour thousand on each elephant.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युद्धं कृत्वा दिनान् पञ्च द्रोणो हत्वा वरूथिनीम्। ब्रह्मलोकं गतो राजन् ब्राह्मणो वेदपारगः॥
English Translation: Having loaded these vehicles with that wealth and once more adoring the great deity Shiva, the son of Pandu started for the city of Hastinapur, with the perinission of the Islandborn Rishi, and placing his priest Dhaumya in the van. That foremost of men, viz., the royal son of Pandu, made short marches of four miles every day.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच एवमुक्तस्य दूतेन दुपदस्य तदा नृप। चोरस्येव गृहीतस्य न प्रावर्तत भारती॥
English Translation: That powerful army, o king, afflicted with the weight they bore, returned, carrying that wealth, towards the capital, phasing the hearts of all those perpetuators of the Kuru-race.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स यत्नमकरोत् तीव्र सम्बन्धिन्यनुमानने। दूतैर्मधुरसम्भाषैर्न तदस्तीति संदिशन्॥
English Translation: Markandeya said : Continuously meditating upon that wonder, which the woman had told and reproaching himself very often, he appeared as if he was a criminal.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स राजा भूय एवाथ ज्ञात्वा तत्त्वमथागमत्। कन्येति पाञ्चालसुतां त्वरमाणो विनिर्ययौ।॥
English Translation: Thus meditating upon the fine way of virtue, he said, I should, indeed, respectfully agree to her speech; and, therefore, go at once to Mithila.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः सम्प्रेषयामास मित्राणाममितौजसाम्। दुहितुर्विप्रेलम्भं तं धात्रीणां वचनात् तदा॥
English Translation: Surely there lives in that city a fowler, who possess a soul under complete control and who also is thoroughly versed in the principles of morality. This day I will go to him, who possesses wealth of asceticism in order to ask him about the principles of morality.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः समुदयं कृत्वा बलानां राजसत्तमः। अभियाने मतिं चक्रे दुपदं प्रति भारत॥
English Translation: Thus meditating in his mind and relying upon the statement of the woman, which was ensured by her knowledge of the death of the female crane, as also by her happy discourse bearing upon the principles of virtue, he (Kaushika), being filled with curiosity.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः सम्मन्त्रयामास मन्त्रिभिः स महीपतिः। हिरण्यवर्मा राजेन्द्र पाञ्चाल्यं पार्थिवं प्रति॥
English Translation: (He) departed to Mithila and crossed over forests, villages and cities. Then at last he came to Mithila, which was governed by king Janaka. The city was decorated with the flags hoisted by men of various creeds. It was echoed with the sound of sacrifices and festive celebrations. Also the city looked most beautiful.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्र वै निश्चितं तेषामभूद् राज्ञां महात्मनाम्। तथ्यं भवति चेदेतत् कन्या राजन् शिखण्डिनी॥ बद्ध्वा पञ्चालराजानमानयिष्यामहे गृहम्। अन्यं राजानमाधाय पञ्चालेषु नरेश्वरम्॥
English Translation: Having entered that beautiful city, he saw that it was adorned with magnificent porches, buildings and splendid palaces, and protected on all sides by lofty walls and also filled with numberless cars.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: घातयिष्याम नृपतिं पाञ्चालं सशिखण्डिनम्॥ तत् तदाऽनृतमाज्ञाय पुनर्वृतान्नराधिपः। प्रास्थापयत् पार्षताय निहन्मीति स्थिरो भव॥
English Translation: The city was traversed by several broad roads, lined with innumerable shops. It was also covered over with innumerable horses, cars, elephants and warriors.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच स हि प्रकृत्या वै भीतः किल्बिषी च नराधिपः। भयं तीव्रमनुप्राप्तो दुपदः पृथिवीपतिः॥
English Translation: The Brahmana saw the town full of men, who were enjoying health and cheer and were always engaged in the celebration of festivities; as also he saw there various other things.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विसृज्य दूतान् दाशार्णे दुपदः शोकमूर्छितः। समेत्य भार्या रहिते वाक्यमाह नराधिपः॥
English Translation: Having entered the city, he searched after the virtuous Fowler. Some regenerate persons pointed out to him the place, where he repaired and saw the Fowler seated in the midst of a butcher's yard.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भयेन महताऽऽविष्टो हृदि शोकेन चाहतः। पाञ्चालराजो दयितां मातरं वै शिखण्डिनः॥
English Translation: The twice-born person stood at a distant corner; for the fowler, devoted to asceticism, was then selling venison and the flesh of the buffalo; and a large number of buyers gathered round him in right earnest.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभियास्यति मां कोपात् सम्बन्धी सुमहाबलः। हिरण्यवर्मा नृपतिः कर्षमाणो वरूथिनीम्॥
English Translation: Understanding that the twice-born one had come to him, he (fowler) suddenly got up from his seat and went to the place, where the Brahmana was standing in seclusion.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किमिदानीं करिष्यावो मूढौ कन्यामिमां प्रति। शिखण्डी किल पुत्रस्ते कन्येति परिशङ्कितः॥
English Translation: The Fowler said: O virtuous one, O foremost of the regenerate ones, I salute you. You are welcome! I am the fowler. Indeed, be you happy! Command me what I will do for you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इति संचिन्त्य यत्नेन समित्रः सबलानुगः। वञ्चितोऽस्मीति मन्वानो मां किलोद्धर्तुमिच्छति॥
English Translation: The words, that a woman told to you, viz., you go to Mithila, are all known to me. I know also with what object you have come here.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किमत्र तथ्यं सुश्रोणि मिथ्या किं ब्रूहि शोभने। श्रुत्वा त्वत्तः शुभं वाक्यं संविधास्याम्यहं तथा॥
English Translation: Hearing these words of his, the Brahmana became greatly astonished. The regenerate person went on meditating-Oh! this is the second marvel!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अहं हि संशयं प्राप्तो बाला चेयं शिखण्डिनी। त्वं च राज्ञि महत् कृच्छ्रे सम्प्राप्ता वरवर्णिनि॥
English Translation: The fowler then addressed the Brahmana, saying-Indeed, you are now staying at a place, that is not at all proper for you. O holy one, O faultless one, should you like, let us go to my own abode.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सा त्वं सर्वविमोक्षाय तत्त्वमाख्याहि पृच्छतः। तथा विदध्यां सुश्रोणि कृत्यमाशु शुचिस्मिते॥
English Translation: Markandeya said : The Brahmana, highly gratified, addressed him, saying, "So be it". Making the Brahmana proceed before him, he (fowler) departed towards his own abode.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शिखण्डिनि च मा भैस्त्वं विधास्ये तत्र तत्त्वतः। कृपयाऽहं वरारोहे वञ्चितः पुत्रधर्मतः॥
English Translation: Having entered his beautiful abode, he honoured him with a seat. Accepting the water that was given to him for washing the feet and face, the foremost of the regenerate ones.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मया दाशार्णको राजा वञ्चितः स महीपतिः। तदाचक्ष्व महाभागे विधास्ये तत्र यद्धितम्॥
English Translation: Seated himself at his ease. Thereupon he addressed the fowler, saying, "It appears to me that this business is not really suitable to you. O father, I greatly regret that you should adopt such a dishonourable profession",
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जानता हि नरेन्द्रेण ख्यापनार्थं परस्य वै। प्रकाशं चोदिता देवी प्रत्युवाच महीपतिम्॥
English Translation: The Fowler said: This profession belongs to my race; and it has descended to me from my father and grandfather. O twice-born one, do not be sorry for the reason of my adopting the profession that belongs to my own family.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुपद उवाच भूतानां प्राणिनः श्रेष्ठाः प्राणिनां बुद्धिजीविनः। बुद्धिमत्सु नराः श्रेष्ठा नरेष्वपि द्विजातयः॥
English Translation: Fulfilling the duties of my own trade, to which I am already destined by the creator, I carefully devote myself, O best of the regenerate ones, to the service of my superiors as well as the old men.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्विजेषु वैद्याः श्रेयांसो वैद्येषु कृतबुद्धयः। कृतबुद्धिषु कर्तारः कर्तृषु ब्रह्मवादिनः॥
English Translation: I always speak the truth; and I never envy other persons. As also I give away to the best of my power; and live upon what is left after the service of the gods, the guests and my own dependents.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स भवान् कृतबुद्धीनां प्रधान इति मे मतिः। कुलेन च विशिष्टोऽसि वयसा च श्रुतेन च॥
English Translation: I never speak evil of anything; neither I hate anything, however great. O best of the twiceborn persons, the actions done in the past existence always follow the doer.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रज्ञया सदृशश्चासि शुक्रेणाङ्गिरसेन च। विदितं चापि ते सर्वं यथावृत्तः स कौरवः॥
English Translation: In this world the chief professions of men are agriculture, the rearing of cows and trade. But in the next world, the acquaintance in ethics and the three special branches of knowledge (the three Vedas) prove most conducive.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पाण्डवश्च यथावृत्तः कुन्तीपुत्रो युधिष्ठिरः। धृतराष्ट्रस्य विदिते वञ्चिताः पाण्डवाः परैः॥
English Translation: Service of other three classes has been the fixed duty of the Shudra. Agriculture has been fixed for the Vaishyas; and fighting has been ordained for the Kshatriyas. The vow of Brahmacharya, devotion, repetition of the mantras and truthfulness are always to be observed by the Brahmanas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विदुरेणानुनीतोऽपि पुत्रमेवानुवर्तते। शकुनिर्बुद्धिपूर्वं हि कुन्तीपुत्रं समाह्वयत्॥
English Translation: The king should govern, in accordance with the dictates of virtue, the subjects, who always stick to their fixed profession. He should also appoint men to their own profession, who have really fallen from it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनक्षज्ञं मताक्षः सन् क्षत्रवृत्ते स्थितं शुचिम्। ते तथा वञ्चयित्वा तु धर्मराज युधिष्ठिरम्॥
English Translation: The king should always be feared by his subjects; because he is their lord. The kings, again, should check their subject, who has gone away from his fixed profession, even as they restrain the deer by the arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न कस्याञ्चिदवस्थायां राज्यं दास्यन्ति वै स्वयम्। भवांस्तु धर्मसंयुक्तं धृतराष्ट्र ब्रुवन् वचः॥
English Translation: O twice-born sage, O best of the Brahmanas, there is none here in the kingdom of king Janaka, who has fallen from his ordained duties. In fact, all the four classes strictly follow their respective duties.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मनांसि तस्य योधानां ध्रुवमावर्तयिष्यति। विदुरश्चापि तद् वाक्यं साधयिष्यति तावकम्॥ भीष्मद्रोणकृपादीनां भेदं संजनयिष्यति। अमात्येषु च भिन्नेषु योधेषु विमुखेषु च॥
English Translation: Janaka is such a king that, even if his son be a cruel and a criminal one, he puts him under punishment. But he never inflicts penalty upon the virtuous.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुनरेकत्रकरणं तेषां कर्म भविष्यति। एतस्मिन्नन्तरे पार्थाः सुखमेकाग्रबुद्धयः॥ सेनाकर्म करिष्यन्ति द्रव्याणां चैव संचयम्। विद्यमानेषु च स्वेषु लम्बमाने तथा त्वयि॥
English Translation: With the assistance of the spies appointed by him, he casts a virtuous look upon all things. O best of the regenerate ones, prosperity, kingdom and the power of inflicting punishment rest with the Kshatriyas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न तथा ते करिष्यन्ति सेनाकर्म न संशयः। एतत् प्रयोजनं चात्र प्राधान्येनोपलभ्यते॥
English Translation: Indeed, the kings, practising their own special virtues, crave for immense prosperity. In fact, the king is the preserver of all the four classes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संगत्या धृतराष्ट्रश्च कुर्याद् धर्म्यं वचस्तव। स भवान् धर्मयुक्तश्च धन॑ तेषु समाचरन्॥
English Translation: O regenerate one, I never slay the hogs and buffaloes myself. They are slain by others. O twice-born sage, only I always sell their flesh afterwards.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृपालुषु परिक्लेशान् पाण्डवीयान् प्रकीर्तयन्। वृद्धेषु कुलधर्मं च ब्रुवन् पूर्वैरनुष्ठितम्॥
English Translation: I never eat flesh myself. Really I have an intercourse with my wife during her season. O twice-born one, I always fast during the day and eat only during the night.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विभेत्स्यति मनांस्येषामिति मे नात्र संशयः। न च तेभ्यो भयं तेऽस्ति ब्राह्मणो ह्यसि वेदवित्॥
English Translation: A person, being born bad, may be of good character. Again, he may turn out virtuous, even if he be a slayer of animals by birth or profession.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दूतकर्मणि युक्तश्च स्थविरश्च विशेषतः। स भवान् पुष्ययोगेन मुहूर्तेन जयेन च। कौरवेयान् प्रयात्वाशु कौन्तेयस्यार्थसिद्धये॥
English Translation: Virtue diminishes in strength on account of the misconduct of the kings, and sin becomes predominant. Thereon the subjects grow less.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच तथानुशिष्टः प्रययौ दुपदेन महात्मना। पुरोधा वृत्तसम्पन्नो नगरं नागसाह्वयम्॥
English Translation: Then also the formidable monsters, dwarfs and those, who have crooked backs and wide heads and those, who have lost the power of procreation, the dead and blind persons as also those, who have their eye-sight paralysed, begin to take birth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शिष्यैः परिवृतो विद्वान् नीतिशास्त्रार्थकोविदः। पाण्डवानां हितार्थाय कौरवान् प्रति जग्मिवान्॥
English Translation: In consequence of the criminality of the rulers of the earth, the subjects undergo continuous harms. But Janaka is such a monarch, that he looks upon his subjects with virtuous eyes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच चातुराश्रम्यधर्माश्च यतिधर्माश्च पाण्डव। लोकवेदोत्तराश्चैव क्षात्रधर्मे समाहिताः॥
English Translation: He is ever kind to all his subjects, who perform their fixed duties. As for myself, those who praise me or those men who blame me, all of them I satisfy with deeds well done.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वाण्येतानि कर्माणि क्षात्रे भरतसत्तम। निराशिषो जीवलोकाः क्षत्रधर्मेऽव्यवस्थिते॥
English Translation: But those kings, who lead their lives in the strict observance of their duties and are ever busy (in the performance of honest deeds) and who can bear austerity and possess smartness and promptitude, never depend upon anything for their support.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अप्रत्यक्षं बहुद्वारं धर्ममाश्रमवासिनाम्। प्ररूपयन्ति तद्भावमागमैरेव शाश्वतम्॥
English Translation: Giving away food incessantly to the best of one's power, patience and firm belief in virtue, necessary regard for all creatures always, these virtues are present only in that person, who has wholly abandoned the world (the worldly pleasures); but in none else.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपरे वचनैः पुण्यैर्वादिनो लोकनिश्चयम्। अनिश्चयज्ञा धर्माणामदृष्टान्ते परे हताः॥
English Translation: One should do away with falsehood. He should render good to all without being asked. He should never forsake virtue out of lust or anger or malice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रत्यक्षं सुखभूयिष्ठमात्मसाक्षिकमच्छलम्। सर्वलोकहितं धर्मं क्षत्रियेषु प्रतिष्ठितम्॥
English Translation: One should not express unnatural joy at good fortune or succumb under calamities. He should not grow dispirited, when overpowered by poverty or forsake his virtue when so overpowered.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धर्माश्रमेऽध्यवसिनां ब्राह्मणानां युधिष्ठिर। यथा त्रयाणां वर्णानां संख्यातोपश्रुतिः पुराः॥
English Translation: If on a certain occasion one commits a wrong, he should not commit it again. One should direct his soul to what contributes to the happiness of others.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजधर्मेष्वनुमता लोकाः सुचरितैः सह। उदाहृतं ते राजेन्द्र यथा विष्णुं महौजसम्॥
English Translation: There should be no wrong over wrong; rather one should deal honestly. The sinful person, who desires to commit a crime, is slain by himself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वभूतेश्वरं देवं प्रभुं नारायणं पुरा। जग्मुः सुबहुशः शूरा राजानो दण्डनीतये॥ एकैकमात्मनः कर्म तुलयित्वाऽऽश्रमं पुरा। राजानः पर्युपासन्त दृष्टान्तवचने स्थिताः॥
English Translation: By committing a crime one becomes wicked and dishonest. Those who consider that there is no virtue or those, who laugh at the pure and good, these vicious men undoubtedly find decay in the long run. The wicked person daily grows flatulent, even as the leather bag inflated with wind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: साध्या देवा वसवश्चाश्विनौ च रुद्राश्च विश्वे मरुतां गणाश्च। सृष्टाः पुरा ह्यादिदेवेन देवाः क्षात्रे धर्मे वर्तयन्ते च सिद्धाः॥
English Translation: The ideas of those, who are destitute of all sensibilities and who also are most worldly, are worthless. The inner soul points him out (as a fool), even as the sun discovers all features during the day.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अत्र ते वर्तयिष्यामि धर्ममर्थविनिश्चयम्। निर्मर्यादे वर्तमाने दानवैकार्णवे पुरा॥ बभूव राजा राजेन्द्र मान्धाता नाम वीर्यवान्। पुरा वसुमतीपालो यज्ञं चक्रे दिदृक्षया॥ अनादिमध्यनिधनं देवं नारायणं प्रभुम्। स राजा राजशार्दूल मान्धाता परमेश्वरम्॥
English Translation: The fool cannot shine in this world only by praising himself. Rather the learned man, even if he be dirty and anointed, shines gloriously in this world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जगाम शिरसा पादौ यज्ञे विष्णोर्महात्मनः। दर्शयामास तं विष्णू रूपमास्थाय वासवम्॥
English Translation: He never speaks ill of any one; nor does he utter his own praise. No person is found on earth, who shines with all the excellent qualities.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स पार्थिवैर्वृतः सद्भिरर्चयामास तं प्रभुम्। तस्य पार्थिवसिंहस्य तस्य चैव महात्मनः। संवादोऽयं महानासीद् विष्णुं प्रति महाद्युतिम्॥
English Translation: The person, who repents for his sins, is freed from them. If one declares that he would not commit the sin again, he is delivered from committing a second one.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इन्द्र उवाच किमिष्यते धर्मभृतां वरिष्ठ यद् द्रष्टुकामोऽसि तमप्रमेयम्। अनन्तमायामितमन्त्रवीर्य नारायणं ह्यादिदेवं पुराणम्॥
English Translation: O best and foremost of the Brahmanas, he may also be saved from sin by the performance of any one of the ordained acts. O Brahmana, this is Shruti, which may be referred to as one this relating to virtue.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नासौ देवो विश्वरूपो मयापि शक्योद्रष्टुं ब्रह्मणा वापि साक्षात्। येऽन्ये कामास्तव राजन् हृदिस्था दास्ये चैतांस्त्वं हि मर्येषु राजा॥
English Translation: A person, who was formerly virtuous, having committed sins out of ignorance, can destroy those sins afterwards. O monarch, the virtue of persons shines again (drives off all sins), if sins are committed out of mistake.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सत्ये स्थितो धर्मपरो जितेन्द्रियः शूरो दृढप्रीतिरत: सुराणाम्। बुद्ध्या भक्त्या चोत्तमश्रद्धया च ततस्तेऽहं दधि वरान् यथेष्टम्॥
English Translation: After having committed a sin, one should consider that he is no longer a man. The gods behold his sin, as also the monitor that is within him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मान्धातोवाच असंशयं भगवन्नादिदेवं द्रक्ष्यामित्वाहं शिरसा सम्प्रसाद्य। त्यक्त्वा कामान् धर्मकामो ह्यरमे मिच्छे गन्तुं सत्पथं लोकदृष्टम्॥
English Translation: The person, who with piety and without detestation, hides the faults of the honest, like holes in his own garment surely desires to provide for the means of salvation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क्षात्राद् धर्माद् विपुलादप्रमेय ल्लोकाः प्राप्ताः स्थापितं स्वं यशश्च। धर्मो योऽसावादिदेवात् प्रवृत्तो लोकश्रेष्ठं तं न जानामि कर्तुम्॥
English Translation: After having committed the sin, if a person really seeks salvation, he is delivered from all his sins, even as the moon looks bright after it has come out of the clouds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इन्द्र उवाच असैनिका धर्मपराश्च धर्म परां गतिं न नयन्ते ह्ययुक्तम्। क्षात्रो धर्मो ह्यादिदेवात्प्रवृत्तः पश्चादन्ये शेषभूताश्च धर्माः॥
English Translation: Thus seeking salvation, a man is freed from all his sins, even as the sun, upon rising, displays its lustre after it has driven off all darkness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शेषाः सृष्टा ह्यन्तवन्तो ह्यनन्ताः सप्रस्थानाः क्षात्रधर्मा विशिष्टाः। स्तस्माद् धर्मं श्रेष्ठमिमं वदन्ति॥
English Translation: O best of the twice-born ones, do you know that temptation forms the ground-work of all sins. Men, that are destitute of enough of knowledge, having been given to temptation, commit sins.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्मणा वै पुरा देवा ऋषयश्चामितौजसः। त्राता: सर्वं प्रसह्यारीन्क्षत्रधर्मेण विष्णुना॥
English Translation: Sinful persons hide themselves under the guise of virtue, even as the wells remain undiscovered on account of the grasses growing over and covering them. The selfcontrol, which they seem to possess, their holiness, their speeches regarding virtue, all these are witnessed in them. But good behaviours are hardly found in them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदि ह्यसौ भगवान्नाहनिष्यद् रिपून् सर्वानसुरानप्रमेयः। न ब्राह्मणा न च लोकादिकर्ता नायं धर्मो नादिधर्मोऽभविष्यत्॥
English Translation: Markandeya said : Indeed, that greatly wise Brahmana asked the virtuous flower, saying, "O foremost of men, how shall I know the the virtuous behaviours?"
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इमामुर्वी नाजयद्विक्रमेण देवश्रेष्ठः सासुरामादिदेवः। चातुर्वण्र्यं चातुराश्रम्यधर्माः सर्वे न स्युर्ब्राह्मणानां विनाशात्॥
English Translation: O best of virtuous persons, you are blessed! I desire to hear this from you. O lofty-minded one, O Fowler, tell me the details of it truly.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नष्टा धर्माः शतधा शाश्वतास्ते क्षात्रेण धर्मेण पुनः प्रवृद्धाः। युगे युगे ह्यादिधर्माः प्रवृत्ता लोकज्येष्ठं क्षात्रधर्मं वदन्ति॥
English Translation: The Fowler said : O foremost of the regenerate ones, sacrifice, gift, austerity, the study of the Vedas and truthfulness, these five holy things are always noticed. in . virtuous conduct. over
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आत्मत्यागः सर्वभूतानुकम्पा लोकज्ञानं पालनं मोक्षणं च। विषण्णानां मोक्षणं पीडिताना क्षात्रे धर्मे विद्यते पार्थिवानाम्॥ निर्मर्यादा: काममन्युप्रवृत्ता भीता राज्ञो नाधिगच्छन्ति पापम्। शिष्टाश्चान्ये सर्वधर्मोपपन्नाः साध्वाचाराः साधु धर्मं वदन्ति॥
English Translation: Having control desires, anger, haughtiness, avarice and wickedness, those who take pleasure in virtue because it is virtue, are, in the opinion of the honest and wise, really reckoned to be virtuous.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुत्रवत् पाल्यमानानि राजधर्मेण पार्थिवैः। लोके भूतानि सर्वाणि चरन्ते नात्र संशयः॥
English Translation: Those persons who perform sacrifices and are ever devoted to the study of Vedas, have no behaviours other than what are practised by the virtuous. Indeed good behaviours form the second attribute of the pious.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वधर्मपरं क्षात्रं लोकश्रेष्ठं सनातनम्। शश्वदक्षरपर्यन्तमक्षरं सर्वतोमुखम्॥
English Translation: O Brahmana, rendering services to the superiors, truthfulness, worthlessness and gift, these four are ever present in those, who are really virtuous.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच कुत: सृष्टमिदं विश्वं जगत् स्थावरजङ्गमम्। प्रलये च कमभ्येति तन्मे ब्रूहि पितामह॥
English Translation: Once can wholly obtain credit by directing the heart towards virtuous behaviours. This he gains only be practising the above four; Otherwise to gain this becomes impossible.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ससागरः सगगन सशैलः सबलाहकः। सभूमिः साग्निपवनो लोकोऽयं केन निर्मित:॥
English Translation: Truth constitutes the essence of the Vedas. Control over passions constitutes the essence of truth. And self-denial (refraining from the worldly enjoyments) forms the essence of selfcontrol. These attributes are always present in a virtuous conduct.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कथं सृष्टानि भूतानि कथं वर्णविभक्तयः। शौचशौचं कथं तेषां धर्माधर्मविधिः कथम्॥
English Translation: Those persons, who, being intelligent and full of delusions, hate these virtues, surely tread in the sinful path. The men who follow them fall in the abyss of decay.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कीदृशो जीवतां जीवः क्व वा गच्छन्ति ये मृताः। अस्माल्लोकादमुं लोकं सर्वं शंसतु नो भवान्॥
English Translation: They, who are virtuous and are devoted to the observance of the vows, to the Shrutis and to self-denial; and they who have ascended the paths of virtue and are engaged in speaking truth and observing virtues;
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच अत्राप्युदाहरन्तीममितिहासं पुरातनम्। भृगुणाभिहितं शास्त्रं भरद्वाजाय पृच्छते॥
English Translation: They, who are endued with the virtuous behaviours; they, who follow the orders of the preceptors; and they, who minutely observe the import of the scriptures, obtain the highest intelligence.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भृगु महर्षिमासीनं भरद्वाजोऽन्वपृच्छत्॥
English Translation: Forsake the atheists, who are notorious, wicked and always entertain cruel ideas. Take shelter under knowledge and always worship those, that are virtuous.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ससागर: सगगनः सशैल: सबलाहकः। सभूमिः साग्निपवनो लोकोऽयं केन निर्मितः॥
English Translation: By means of the boat of endurance you cross over that river, which is replete with such creatures as the desires and temptations. Its waters are the fine senses and the shoals found therein are the successive births.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कथं सृष्टानि भूतानि कथं वर्णविभक्तयः। शौचाशौचं कथं तेषां धर्माधर्मविधिः कथम्॥
English Translation: As great is virtue or as it consists in the practice of intelligence and yoga, it looks very beautiful, when acquired and added to a virtuous behaviour, like the dye on a white garment.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कीदृशो जीवतां जीवः क्व वा गच्छन्ति ये मृताः। परलोकमिमं चापि सर्वं शंसितुमर्हसि॥
English Translation: Absence of malice and truthfulness are most beneficial to all creatures. Absence of malice constitutes the chief virtue, which, again, is founded upon truth. Indeed, all our desirabilities find their scope, when they are all based upon truth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं स भगवान् पृष्टो भरद्वाजेन संशयम्। ब्रह्मर्षिर्ब्रह्मसंकाशः सर्वं तस्मै ततोऽब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: Truth is the supreme virtue, which is specially adopted by the the pious. Good behaviour forms the peculiar virtue of the honest and the wise. Those, that are holy, possess good conduct.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भृगुरुवाच मानसो नाम विख्यातः श्रुतपूर्वो महर्षिभिः। अनादिनिधनो देवस्तथाभेद्योऽजरामरः॥
English Translation: Every creature frames principles of his own according to his inherent tendency. The vicious man, who can not restrain his own self, becomes subject to these vices, viz., desires, wrath and others.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अव्यक्त इति विख्यातः शाश्वतोऽथाक्षयोऽव्ययः। यतः सृष्टानि भूतानि जायन्ते च म्रियन्ति च॥
English Translation: It is an immortal maxim that justice constitutes virtue. The virtuous say that evil behaviours constitute sin.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सोऽसृजत् प्रथमं देवो महान्तं नाम नामतः। महान् ससर्जाहंकारं स चापि भगवानथ॥ आकाशमिति विख्यातं सर्वभूतधरः प्रभुः।
English Translation: Those men are reckoned to be virtuous, who never show wrath, pride or haughtiness and malice or whose conduct is ever marked by simplicity and quiet due.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आकाशादभवद् वारि सलिलादग्निमारुतौ। अग्निमारुतसंयोगात् ततः समभवन्मही॥
English Translation: Those again, are said to possess virtuous conduct, who carefully follow the rites laid down in the three Vedas; who are holy; who possess piety and sacred character; who serve the superiors; and who also have the power of restraining the self.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्तेजोमयं दिव्यं पद्मं सृष्टं स्वयम्भुवा। तस्मात् पद्मात् समभवद् ब्रह्मा वेदमयो निधिः॥
English Translation: The actions and behaviours of those great men are difficult of acquisition. The sins of those men, who are made pure by means of their own actions, die out of themselves.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अहंकार इति ख्यातः सर्वभूतात्मभूतकृत्। ब्रह्मा वै स महातेजा य एते पञ्च धातवः॥
English Translation: This pious behaviour is most wonderful, ancient, inchangeable and eternal. The wise men's who with sanctity lead a virtuous life secure heaven.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शैलास्तस्यास्थिसंज्ञास्तु मेदो मांसं च मेदिनी। समुद्रास्तस्य रुधिरमाकाशमुदरं तथा॥
English Translation: The holy men, who are atheists, as also who are unaustentatious and who are respectful towards the degenerate persons and who, again, are familiar with the holy rites, are deserved to live in heaven.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पवनश्चैव निःश्वासस्तेजोऽग्निर्निम्नगाः शिराः। अग्नीषोमौ तु चन्द्रार्को नयने तस्य विश्रुते॥
English Translation: The explanation of virtue is threefold. The first is called the supreme virtue, which is inculcated in the Vedas. The second is what is laid down in Dharmashastras. The third is called the honest behaviour, which is observed by the pious.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नभश्चोर्ध्वं शिरस्तस्य क्षितिः पादौ भुजौ दिशः। दुर्विज्ञेयो ह्यचिन्त्यात्मा सिद्धैरपि न संशयः॥
English Translation: Crossing over (the ocean of) knowledge, the performance of ablutions in the places of pilgrimage, forgiveness, truthfulness, simplicity, sacredness are the characteristics of virtuous conduct.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स एष भगवान् विष्णुरनन्त इति विश्रुतः। सर्वभूतात्मभूतस्थो दुर्विज्ञेयोऽकृतात्मभिः॥
English Translation: Those who, are king to all creatures and who are never malignant and who never speak ill of anybody, are always dear to the twice-born ones.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अहंकारस्य यः स्रष्टा सर्वभूतभवाय वै। यतः समभवद् विश्वं पृष्टोऽहं यदिह त्वया॥
English Translation: Who are familiar with the results of good or evil actions, are reckoned by the wise to be virtuous. Again, those who are just and virtuous and well disposed towards all and who are honest and have obtained heaven, who possess sacred characters and constantly tread in the path of virtue.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भरद्वाज उवाच गगनस्य दिशां चैव भूतलस्यानिलस्य वा। कान्यत्र परिमाणानि संशयं छिन्धि तत्त्वतः॥
English Translation: Who are liberal in gifts and unselfish, who show favour to the distressed and who are revered by all, who possess the wealth of knowledge, who are devotees and who are kind to all creatures, are virtuous according to the honest and wise.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भृगुरुवाच अनन्तमेतदाकाशं सिद्धदैवतसेवितम्। रम्यं नानाश्रयाकीर्णं यस्यान्तो नाधिगम्यते॥
English Translation: The persons, who are charitable, secure prosperity in this world and abodes of happiness, in the next. The virtuous men, if approached and solicited by the honest and wise, give away alms to them with the best of his power, even at the denial of the comforts of his wife and dependents. Looking to their own interest and having an eye upon virtue and the ways of the world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उर्ध्वं गतेरधस्तात्तु चन्द्रादित्यौ न दृश्यतः। तत्र देवाः स्वयं दीप्ता भास्वराभाग्निवर्चसः॥
English Translation: The men, who thus practise virtue, obtain the greatest amount of virtue through eternal ages. Persons, who possess the attributes of truthfulness, abstention from injuring others, modestly and simplicity and who are not malicious and proud, who are mild and selfsacrificing, who have self-control and forbearance, intelligence and patience, who are kind towards all creatures and who are free from desires and malice, are said to be the witnesses of the world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते चाप्यन्तं न पश्यन्ति नभसः प्रथितौजसः। दुर्गमत्वादनन्तत्वादिति मे विद्धि मानद॥
English Translation: These three are reckoned to constitute the highest way of the pious, viz., a man must not offend anybody. He must be charitable. Also he must speak the truth always. Those great men of highest virtue.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उपरिष्टोपरिष्टात्तु प्रज्वलद्भिः स्वयंप्रभैः। निरुद्धमेतदाकाशमप्रमेयं सुरैरपि॥
English Translation: Who are kind on all occasions and who are filled with compassion, obtain the greatest contentment and ascend the superior path of virtue; and whose acquisition of virtue is most certain.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पृथिव्यन्ते समुद्रास्तु समुद्रान्ते तमः स्मृतम्। तमसोऽन्ते जलं प्राहुर्जलस्यान्तेऽग्निरेव च॥
English Translation: Harmlessness, forgiveness, peacefulness, contentment, agreeable speech, giving away passions and excitements, the service of the virtuous characters and actions performed in accordance with the dictates of the Shastra constitute the superior path of the honest and the wise.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रसातलान्ते सलिलं जलान्ते पन्नगाधिपाः। तदन्ते पुनराकाशमाकाशान्ते पुनर्जलम्॥
English Translation: Those who constantly follow the path of virtue and daily worship the virtuous, can ascend the palace of knowledge. It is they only who are freed from that greatest terror (rebirth). O best of Brahmanas, it is they only who have the power of observing the several aspects of human nature.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमन्तं भगवतः प्रमाणं सलिलस्य च। अग्निमारुततोयेभ्यो दुर्जेयं दैवतैरपि॥
English Translation: O foremost of Brahmanas I have thus related to you all about the virtuous as well as the vicious, behaviours according to my own knowledge or as I have heard on the matter. O Brahmana, O foremost of the twice-born ones, I have done justice to the subject of virtuous conduct, which I had introduced.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अग्निमारुततोयानां वर्णाः क्षितितलस्य च। आकाशादवगृह्यन्ते भिद्यन्तेऽतत्त्वदर्शनात्॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said If a person, after having given dower for a maiden, goes away, how should the maiden's father or other kinsmen who can bestow her, act? Do tell me this, O grandfather?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पठन्ति चैव मुनयः शास्त्रेषु विविधेषु च। त्रैलोक्ये सागरे चैव प्रमाणं विहितं यथा॥
English Translation: Bhishma said Such a maiden, if she be the daughter of a sonless and rich father, should be maintained by the father. Indeed, if the father does not return the dower to the kinsmen of the giver, the maiden should be considered as belonging to the giver of the dower.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अदृश्याय त्वगम्याय कः प्रमाणमुदाहरेत्। सिद्धानां देवतानां च यदा परिमिता गतिः॥
English Translation: She may even raise children for the giver by any of those means that are laid down in the scriptures. No person, however, can marry her according to due rites.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदा गौणमनन्तस्य नामानन्तेति विश्रुतम्। नामधेयानुरूपस्य मानसस्य महात्मनः॥
English Translation: Commanded by her father, the princess Savitri had in days of old chosen a husband and united herself with him. This act of hers is praised by some; but others, conversant with the scriptures, condemn it'.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदा तु दिव्यं तद् रूपं ह्रसते वर्धते पुनः। कोऽन्यस्तद्वेदितुं शक्तो योऽपि स्यात् तद्विधोऽपरः॥३४
English Translation: Others who are righteous have not acted thus. Others maintain that the conduct of the righteous should ever be considered as the foremost evidence of duty or morality.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः पुष्करतः सृष्टः सर्वज्ञो मूर्तिमान् प्रभुः। ब्रह्मा धर्ममयः पूर्वः प्रजापतिरनुत्तमः॥
English Translation: Upon this subject, Sukratu, the grand son of the great Janaka, the king of the Videhas, has declared the following opinion.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भरद्वाज उवाच पुष्कराद् यदि सम्भूतो ज्येष्ठं भवति पुष्करम्। ब्रह्माणं पूर्वजं चाह भवान् संदेह एव मे॥
English Translation: There is the wellknown injunction of the scriptures that women can enjoy freedom at any period of their life. If this were not the path of the virtuous, how could this scriptural saying exist? As regards the pious, therefore, how can there be any question or doubt about it? How can people condemn that saying by choosing to conduct themselves otherwise?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भृगुरुवाच मानसस्येह या मूर्तिर्ब्रह्मत्वं समुपागता। तस्यासनविधानार्थं पृथिवी पद्ममुच्यते॥
English Translation: The impious violation of eternal practice is considered as the practice of the Asuras. We never hear of such practice in the conduct of the ancients.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्णिका तस्य पद्मस्य मेरुर्गगनमुच्छ्रितः। तस्य मध्ये स्थितो लोकान् सृजते जगतः प्रभुः॥
English Translation: The relationship of husband and wife is very subtile. It is different from the natural relationship of male and female which consists only in the desire for sexual intercourse. This also was said by ihe king of Janaka's race.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जनमेजय उवाच शरतल्पगते भीष्मे कौरवाणां धुरन्धरे। शयाने वीरशयने पाण्डवैः समुपस्थिते॥ युधिष्ठिरो महाप्राज्ञो भम पूर्वपितामहः। धर्माणामागमं श्रुत्वा विदित्वा सर्वसंशयान्॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said Under what authority is the property of men inherited (by others when they happen to have daughters)? As for her father the daughter should be considered the same as the son.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दानानां च विधिं श्रुत्वा च्छिन्नधर्मार्थसंशयः। यदन्यदकरोद् विप्र तन्मे शंसितुमर्हसि॥
English Translation: Bhishma said The son is even as one's own self, and the daughter is like the son. How, therefore, can another take the riches when one lives in his ownself in the form of his daughter?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच अभून्मुहूर्ते स्तिमितं सर्वं तद्राजमण्डलम्। तूष्णीभूते ततस्तस्मिन् पटे चित्रमिवार्पितम्॥
English Translation: Whatever is the own property of the mother, is due to the maiden daughter. If the maternal grandfather happens to die without leaving sons, the daughter's son should inherit it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मुहूर्तमिव च ध्यात्वा व्यासः सत्यवतीसुतः। नृपं शयानं गाड्यमिदमाह वचस्तदा॥ राजन् प्रकृतिमापन्नः कुरुराजो युधिष्ठिरः। सहितो भ्रातृभिः सर्वैः पार्थिवैश्चानुयायिभिः॥
English Translation: The daughter's son offers funeral cakes to his own father and the father of his mother. Hence, for the ends of justice, there is no difference between the son and their daughte son.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उपास्ते त्वां नरव्याघ्र सह कृष्णेन धीमता। तमिमं पुरयानाय समनुज्ञातुमर्हसि॥
English Translation: When a person has got only a daughter and she has been invested by him with the position of a son, if he then happens to have a son, such son shares the inheritance with the daughter. When, again, a person has got a daughter and she has been invested by him with the position of a son, if he then happens to take a son by adoption or purchase, then the daughter is considered superior to such son.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्तो भगवता व्यासेन पृथिवीपतिः। युधिष्ठिरं सहामात्यमनुजज्ञे नदीसुतः॥
English Translation: In the following case I do not see any reason why the daughter's son should be considered as the proper heir. The case is that of the daughter who has been sold by her father. The sons born of a daughter who has been sold by her sire for actual price, belong exclusively to their father. Such sons can never belong, even as daughter's sons, to their maternal grandfather on account of his having sold their mother for price and lost all his rights in or to her by that deed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उवाच चैन मधुरं नृपं शान्तनवो नृपः। प्रविशस्व पुरीं राजन् व्येतु ते मानसो ज्वरः॥
English Translation: Such sons, again, become full of malice, impious in conduct, the misappropriators of other people's riches, and full of deceit and cunning. Having originated from that sinful form of marriage called Asura, the offspring becomes wicked in conduct.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यजस्व विविधैर्यज्ञैर्वबन्नेः स्वाप्तदक्षिणैः। ययातिरिव राजेन्द्र श्रद्धादमपुरःसरः॥
English Translation: Persons acquainted with ancient history, conversant with duties, devoted to the scriptures and firm in maintaining the restrictions therein laid down, recite in this connection some verses sung in days of yore by Yama.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क्षत्रधर्मरतः पार्थ पितॄन् देवांश्च तर्पय। श्रेयसा योक्ष्यसे चैव व्येतु ते मानसो ज्वरः॥
English Translation: That man who acquires riches by selling his own son, or who bestows his daughter after accepting a dower for his own livelihood, has to sink in seven dreadful hells one after another, known by the name of Kalas. There that wretch has to feed upon sweat and urine and stools during that period.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रञ्जयस्व प्रजाः सर्वाः प्रकृती: परिसान्त्वय। सुहृदः फलसत्कारैरर्चयस्व यथार्हतः॥
English Translation: In that form of marriage which is called Arsha, the person who marries has to give a bull and a cow and the father of the maiden accepts the gift. Some characterise this gift as a dower (or price), while some are of opinion that it should not be considered in that light. The true opinion, however, is that a gift for such a purpose, be it of small value or large, should, O king, be considered as dower or price, and the bestowal of the daughter under such circumstances should be considered as a sale.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनु त्वां तात जीवन्तु मित्राणि सुहृदस्तथा। चैत्यस्थाने स्थितं वृक्षं फलवन्तमिव द्विजाः॥
English Translation: Despite the fact of its having been practised by a few persons it can never be taken as the eternal practice. Other forms of marriage are seen, practiced by men, such as marrying girls after carrying them away by force from amidst their kinsmen.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आगन्तव्यं च भवता समये मम पार्थिव। विनिवृत्ते दिनकरे प्रवृत्ते चोत्तरायणे॥
English Translation: Those persons who have sexual intercourse with a maiden, by force are considered as perpetrators of sin. They have to sink in darkest hell.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथेत्युक्त्वा च कौन्तेयः सोऽभिवाद्य पितामहम्। प्रययौ सपरीवारो नगरं नागसाह्वयम्॥
English Translation: Even a human being who is not a relation of blood should not be sold. What need then be said of one's own child? With the riches that is acquired by doing sinful deeds, no meritorious deed can be performed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्र पुरस्कृत्य गान्धारी च पतिव्रताम्। सह तैर्ऋषिभिः सर्वैतृभिः केशवेन च॥ पौरजानपदैश्चैव मन्त्रिवृद्धैश्च पार्थिव। प्रविवेश कुरुश्रेष्ठः पुरं वारणसाह्वयम्॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said Seeing those kings-lords of Earth-all conversant with the Vedas, arrive, king Yudhishthira, addressing Bhimasena, said, O chief of men, let proper honors be paid to these kings who have come, for these foremost of men are all worthy of the highest honors.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच एतच्छ्रुत्वा तु कौन्तेयः सर्वान् भ्रातृनुपह्वरे। आहूष भरतश्रेष्ठ इदं वचनमब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: Thus addressed by the illustrious king Yudhishthira, Pandu's son Bhiinasena of mighty energy did as he was ordered, assisted by the twins.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच धार्तराष्ट्रस्य सैन्येषु ये चारपुरुषा मम। ते प्रवृत्तिं प्रयच्छन्ति ममेमां व्युषितां निशाम्॥
English Translation: The foremost of all men, viz., Govinda, came there, accompanied by the Vrishnis, and with Baladeva in the van.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुर्योधनः किलापृच्छदापगेयं महाव्रतम्। केन कालेन पाण्डूनां हन्याः सैन्यमिति प्रभो॥
English Translation: He was accompanied by Yuyudhana and Pradyumna and Goda, and Nishatha and Shamba and Kritavarman.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मासेनेति च तेनोक्तो धार्तराष्ट्रः सुदुर्मतिः। तावता चापि कालेन द्रोणोऽपि प्रतिजज्ञिवान्॥
English Translation: The powerful car-warrior Bhima offered them the most respectful adoration. Those princes then entered the palaces, adorned with gems, which were assigned to them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गौतमो द्विगुणं कालमुक्तवानिति नः श्रुतम्। द्रोणिस्तु दशरात्रेण प्रतिजज्ञे महास्त्रवित्॥
English Translation: At the end of a conversation he ad with Yudhishthira, the destroyer of Madhu referred to Arjuna who had been emaciated on account of many fights.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथा दिव्यास्त्रवितं कर्णः सम्पृष्टः कुरुसंसदि। पञ्चमिर्दिवसैर्हन्तुं ससैन्यं प्रतिजज्ञिवान्॥
English Translation: The son of Kunti repeatedly asked Krishna, that chastiser of enemies, about Arjuna. To Dharma's son, the lord of all the universe began to speak about Jishnu, the son of Shakra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मादहमपीच्छामि श्रोतुमर्जुन ते वचः। कालेन कियता शत्रून् क्षपयेरिति फाल्गुन॥
English Translation: O king, a confidential agent of mine living in Dwarka came to me. He had seen Arjuna, that foremost of Pandu's sons. Indeed, the latter has been very much emaciated with the fatigue of many battles,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्तो गुडाकेशः पार्थिवेन धनंजयः। वासुदेवं समीक्ष्येदं वचनं प्रत्यभाषत॥
English Translation: powerful monarch, that agent of mine inforned me that the mighty-armed hero is very near to us. You begin to celebrate your Horse-Sacrifice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्व एते महात्मानः कृतास्त्राश्चित्रयोधिनः। असंशयं महाराज हन्युरेव न संशयः॥
English Translation: Thus addressed, king Yudhishthira the just said him, By good luck, O Madhava, Arjuna comes back safely!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपैतु ते मनस्तापो यथा सत्यं ब्रवीम्यहम्। हन्यामेकरथेनैव वासुदेवसहायवान्॥
English Translation: I wish to ascertain from you, O delighter of the Yadavas, what has been said in this matter by that mightiest of heroes amongs the sons of Pandu!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सामरानपि लोकांस्त्रीन् सर्वान् स्थावरजङ्गमान्। भूतं भव्यं भविष्यं च निमेषादिति मे मतिः॥
English Translation: Thus addressed by king Yudhishthira the just, the lord of the Vrishnis and the Andhakas, that foremost of eloquent men, said these words to that inonarch of righteous soul, My agent, reported the words of Partha thus to me, O great king, Yudhishthira, O Krishna, should be told these words of mine when the time comes!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तद् घोरं पशुपतिः प्रादादस्त्रं महन्मम। कैराते द्वन्द्वयुद्धे तु तदिदं मयि वर्तते॥
English Translation: O chief of the Kauravas, many kings will come (to your sacrifice)! When they arrive, high honours should be paid to them. This would, indeed, be worthy for us.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यद् युगान्ते पशुपतिः सर्वभूतानि संहरन्। प्रयुङ्क्ते पुरुषव्याघ्र तदिदं मयि वर्तते॥
English Translation: O giver of honours, the king should further be informed at iny request that he should do what is necessary for preventing a distinction similar to what occurred at the time of presenting the Arghya (on the occasion of the Rajasuya-Sacrifice). Let Krislina also approve of this. Let not, O king, through the ill-feeling of kings, the people be destroyed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तन्न जानाति गाङ्गेयो न द्रोणो न च गौतमः। न च द्रोणसुतो राजन् कुत एव तु सूतजः॥
English Translation: My man further reported, o king, these words of Dhananjaya, Listen as I repeat them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न तु युक्तं रणे हन्तुं दिव्यैरस्त्रैः पृथग्जनम्। आर्जवेनैव युद्धेन विजेष्यामो वयं परान्॥
English Translation: O monarch, the king of Manipura, my dear son Babhruvahana, will come at the sacrifice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथेमे पुरुषव्याघ्राः सहायास्तत्र पार्थिव। सर्वे दिव्यास्त्रविद्वांसः सर्वे युद्धाभिकाक्षिणः॥
English Translation: Do you honour him duly for my sake, O powerful one, he is always attached and deeply devoted to me.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वेदान्तावभृथस्नाताः सर्व एतेऽपराजिताः। निहन्युः समरे सेनां देवानामपि पाण्डवः॥
English Translation: Hearing these words, king Yudhishthira the just approved of them and said as follows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शिखण्डी युयुधानश्च धृष्टद्युम्नश्च पार्षतः। भीमसेनो यमौ चोभौ युधामन्यूत्तमौजसौ॥
English Translation: Nobody in this world does good to another. Nobody makes gifts to others. All persons are seen to act for their own selves.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विराटदुपदौ चोभौ भीष्मद्रोणसमौ युधि। शङ्खश्चैव महाबाहु डिम्बश्च महाबलः॥
English Translation: People are seen to abandon their very parents and their uterine brothers when these cease to love them. What need be said then of relatives of other grades.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुत्रोऽस्याञ्जनपर्वा तु महाबलपराक्रमः। शैनेयश्च महाबाहुः सहायो रणकोविदः॥
English Translation: Gifts a distinguished person and acceptance of the gifts made by a distinguished person both produce equal merit. Of these two acts, however, the making of a gift is superior to the acceptance thereof.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभिमन्युश्च बलवान् द्रौपद्याः पञ्च चात्मजाः। स्वयं चापि समर्थोऽसि त्रैलोक्योत्सादनेऽपि च॥
English Translation: to That wealth is gained by fair means and is multiplied by fair means, should be protected with care for the sake of acquiring virtue. This is an accepted truth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क्रोधाद् यं पुरुषं पश्येस्तथा शकसमाते। स क्षिप्रं न भवेद् व्यक्तमिति त्वां वेनि कौरव॥
English Translation: One desirous of gaining virtue, should never gain riches by means involving injury to others. One should perform his acts according to his power, without zealously seeking riches.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच प्रत्यागत्य पुनर्जिष्णुर्जघ्ने संशप्तकान् बहून्। वक्रादिवक्रगमनादङ्कारक इव ग्रहः॥
English Translation: By giving water, whether cold or heated by fire, with a devoted mind, to a (thirsty) guest, according to the best of his might, one acquires the merit of the act of giving food to a hungry man.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पार्थबाणहता राजन् नराश्वरथकुञ्जराः। विचेलुर्बभ्रमर्नेशुः पेतुर्मम्लुश्च भारत॥
English Translation: The great Rantideva acquired success in all the worlds by adoring the ascetics with offerings of only roots and fruits and leaves.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धुर्यान् धुर्यगतान् सूतान् ध्वजो श्वापानिसायकान्। पाणीन् पाणिगतं शस्त्रं बाहूनपि शिरांसि च॥ भल्लैः क्षुरैरर्धचन्द्रैर्वत्सदन्तैश्च पाण्डवः। चिच्छेदमित्रवीराणां समरे प्रतियुध्यताम्॥
English Translation: The royal son of Shaivi also acquired the highest regions of happiness by having pleased the Son-god along with his companion with offerings of the same sort.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वासितार्थे युयुत्सन्तो वृषभा वृषभं यथा। निपतन्यर्जुनं शूराः शतशोऽथ सहस्रशः॥
English Translation: All men, by being born, become indebted to gods, guests, servants, Pitris, and their own selves. Every one should, therefore do his best for satisfying those debts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषां तस्य च तद् युद्धमभवल्लोमहर्षणम्। त्रैलोक्यविजये यादृग् दैत्यानां सह वज्रिणा॥
English Translation: One frees oneself from his debt to the great Rishis by studying the Vedas. One satisfies his debts to the gods by celebrating sacrifices. By performing the rites of the Shraddha one satisfies the debts to the Pitris. One satisfies the debt to his fellow men by doing good to them. son son
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमविध्यत् त्रिभिर्बाणैर्दन्दशूकैरिवाहिभिः। उग्रायुधसुतस्तस्य शिरः कायादपाहरत्॥
English Translation: One satisfies the debts he owns to one's own self by listening to Vedic recitations and reflecting on their meaning, by eating the remnants of sacrifices, and by supporting his body. One should duly perform all the acts, from the beginning, that he owes to his servants.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेऽर्जुनं सर्वतः क्रुद्धा नानाशस्त्रैरवीवृषन्। मरुद्भिः प्रेरिता मेघा हिमवन्तमिवोष्णगे।॥
English Translation: Through shorn of wealth, men are seen to attain to success by great exertions. Ascetics by duly adoring the gods, and by duly pouring libations of clarified butter on the sacred fire, have been seen to acquire ascetic success.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अस्त्रैरस्त्राणि संवार्य द्विषयां सर्वतोऽर्जुनः। सम्यगस्तैः शरैः सर्वानहितानहनद् बहून्॥
English Translation: Richika's became the of Vishvamitra. By worshipping the gods who have shares in sacrificial offerings, with Riches, (he acquired success in after life).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: छिन्नत्रिवेणुसंघातान् हताश्वान् पार्ष्णसारथीन्। विस्त्रस्तहस्तूणीरान् विचक्ररथकेतनान्॥ संछिन्नरश्मियोक्त्राक्षान् व्यनुकर्षयुगान् रथान्। विद्ध्वस्तसर्वसंनाहान् बाणैश्चक्रेऽर्जुनस्तदा॥
English Translation: Ushanas became Shukra by having pleased the god of gods. Indeed, by singing the praises of the goddess (Uma), he sports in the sky, in the great effulgence.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ते रथास्तत्र विद्ध्वस्ताः परार्ध्याभान्त्यनेकशः। धनिनामिव वेश्मानि हतान्यग्न्यनिलाम्बुभिः॥
English Translation: Then, again, Asita and Devala, and Narada and Paravata, and Kakshivat, and Jamadagni's son Rama, and Tandya possessed of purified soul, and Vashishtha, and Jamadagni, and Vishvamitra, and Atri, and Bharadvaja, and Harishmashru, and Kundadhara, and Shrutashravas,-these great Rishis, by worshipping Vishnu with concentrated minds with the help of Richs, and by penances, acquired success through the grace of that great god gifted with intelligence.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्विपाः सम्भिन्नवर्माणो वज्रशानिसमैः शरैः। पेतुर्गिर्यप्रवेश्मानि वज्रवाताग्निभिर्यथा॥
English Translation: Many undeserving men, by worshipping that good god, won great distinction. One should not seek for advancement by committing any wicked or censurable deed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सारोहास्तुरगाः पेतुर्बहवोऽर्जुनताडिताः। निर्जिह्वात्राः क्षितौ क्षीणा रुधिराद्रौः सुदुर्दशः॥
English Translation: That wealth which acquired by fair means is true wealth. Fie on that wealth however, which is acquired by unfair means. Virtue is eternal. It should never, in this world, be renounced from desire of riches.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नराश्वनागा नाराचैः संस्यूताः सव्यसाचिना। बभ्रमुश्चस्खलुः पेतुर्नेदुर्मम्लुश्च मारिष॥
English Translation: That pious person who keeps his sacred fire and offers his daily adorations to the gods is considered as the foremost of righteous persons. All the Vedas, O foremost of kings, are established on the three sacred fires.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनेकैश्च शिलाधौतैर्वज्राशनिविषोपमैः। शरैर्निजनिवान् पार्थो महेन्द्र इव दानवान्॥
English Translation: That Brahmana is said to possess the sacred fire whose acts exist in full. It is better to at once leave off the sacred fire than to keep it, abstaining from acts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महार्हवर्माभरणा नानारुपाम्बरायुधाः। सरथा: सध्वजा वीरा हताः पार्थेन: शेरते॥
English Translation: The sacred fire, the mother, the father who has begotten, and the preceptor, O foremost men, should all be duly attended and served with humility.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विजिताः पुण्यकर्माणो विशिष्टाभिजनश्रुताः। गताः शरीरैर्वसुधामूर्जितैः सर्मभिर्दिवम्॥
English Translation: That man, who, renouncing all feelings of pride, humbly attends upon and serves them who are venerable for age, who is endued with learning and shorn of lust, who regains all creatures equally with an eye of love, who nas no riches, who is righteous in his acts, and who is shorn of the desire of inflicting any kind of injury, that truly respectable man is adored in this world by the good and pious.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथार्जुनं रथवरं त्वदीयाः समभिद्रवन्। नानाजनपदाध्यक्षा: सगणा जातमन्यवः॥
English Translation: Lomaharshana's son Ugrashrava Sauti, well-read in the Puranas, being present at the twelve years' sacrifice of Kulapati Shaunaka in the forest of Naimisha, stood before the Rishis in attendance.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उह्यमाना रथाश्वेभैः पत्तयश्च जिघांसवः। समभ्यधावन्नस्यन्तो विविधं क्षिप्रमायुधम्॥
English Translation: Having read the Puranas with great pains he was very learned in them. Now with joined hands he addressed them thus, "What, Reverend Sirs, do you wish to hear? What am I to relate?"
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदायुधमहावर्षं मुक्तं योधमहाम्बुदैः। व्यधमनिशितैर्बाणैः क्षिप्रमर्जुनमारुतः॥
English Translation: The Rishis replied, "O son of Lomaharshana, we shall ask you and you will relate to us, who are anxious to hear, some excellent stories.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: साश्वपत्तिद्विपरथं महाशस्त्रैघसम्लवम्। सहसा संतितीर्षन्त पार्थ शस्त्रास्त्रसेतुना॥
English Translation: But noble Kulapati Shaunaka is now engaged in the room of the holy fire,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथाब्रवीद् वासुदेवः पार्थ किं क्रीडसेऽनघ। संशप्तकान् प्रमथ्यैनांस्ततः कर्णवधे त्वर॥
English Translation: He knows the divine stories relating to the Devas and Asuras. He also knows the stories relating to men, Nagas and Gandharvas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथेत्युक्त्वार्जुनः कृष्णं शिष्टान् संशप्तकांस्तदा। आक्षिप्य शस्त्रेण बलाद् दैत्यानिन्द्र इवावधीत्॥
English Translation: O Sauti, that Kulapati Brahmana is the chief in this sacrifice; he is able, faithful to his vows, wise and a master of the Shastras and Aranyakas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आददत् संदधन्नेषून् दृष्टः कैश्चिद् रणेऽर्जुनः। विमुञ्चन् वा शराशीघ्र दृश्यन्तेऽवहितैरपि॥
English Translation: He is truthful, a lover of peace, a Rishi of hard austerities and an observer of the ordained penances. He is respected by all of us and we should, therefore, wait for him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आश्चर्यमिति गोविन्दो सममन्यत भारत। हंसाशुगौरास्ते सेनां हंसाः सर इवाविशन्।॥
English Translation: When he will sit on the highly honoured seat for the preceptor, you will reply to what best of the twice born will ask you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः संग्रामभूमिं च वर्तमाने जनक्षये। अवेक्षमाणो गोविन्दः सव्यसाचिनामब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: Sauti said: So be it. When the noble Rishi will be seated, I shall relate sacred stories relating to variety of subjects as I shall be asked by him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पार्थ महारौद्रो वर्तते भरतक्षयः। पृथिव्यां पार्थिवानां वै दुर्योधनकृते महान्॥
English Translation: The best of Brahmanas (Shaunaka) after having performed all his Prayers to Devas and the Pitris by offering water, came back to the place of sacrifice where Sauti was seated before the assembly of Rishis of rigid vows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पश्य भारत चापानि रुक्मपृष्ठानि धन्विनाम्। महतां चापविद्धानि कलापानिषुधींस्तथा॥
English Translation: When Shaunaka was seated in the midst of Ritviks and Sadasyas (members) who also had come to their places, Sauti spoke as follows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जातरूपमयैः पुजैः शराश्च नतपर्वणः। तैलधौतांश्च नाराचान् विमुक्तानिव पन्नगान्॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said Then engaged in depriving the heroes of their lives, the son of Arjuna resembled the Destroyer of all creatures snatching their lives out of them, at the time of the universal annihilation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आकीर्णांस्तोमरांश्चपि विचित्रान् हेमभूषितान्। चर्माणि चापविद्धानि रुक्मपृष्ठानि भारत॥
English Translation: Endued with prowess equal to that of Shakra, that grandson of Shakra, namely Abhimanyu of infinite might, agitating your forces, appeared highly beautiful.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुवर्णविकृतान् प्रासशक्तीः कनकभूषिताः। जाम्बूनदमयैः पट्टर्बद्धाश्च विपुला गदाः॥
English Translation: Then, O foremost of kings, entering into the very heart of the hostile army, that slayer of those best among the Kshatriyas, fell upon Satyashravas like a fierce tiger falling upon a deer.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जातरूपमयीश्चष्टी: पट्टिशान् हेमभूषितान्। दण्डैः कनकचित्रैश्च विप्रविद्धान् परश्वघान्॥
English Translation: When Satyashravas had thus been pounced upon, the other mighty car-warriors, with haste taking up various kinds of weapons, rushed against Abhimanyu.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: परिधान् भिंदिपालांश्च भुशुण्डी: कुणपानपि। अयस्कुन्तांश्च पतितान् मुसलानि गुरूणि च॥
English Translation: 'I shall meet him first, I shall meet him first'-boasting in this way, those foremost Kshatriyas then encountered Arjuna's son, out of a desire for slaying him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नानाविधानि शस्त्राणि प्रगृह्य जयगृद्धिनः। जीवन्त इव दृश्यन्ते गतसत्त्वास्तरस्विनः॥
English Translation: Then beholding the divisions of those rushing Kshatriyas advance towards him, Abhimanyu met them, even like a whale meeting a shoal of small fishes in the sea.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गदविमथितैर्गात्रैर्मुसलैर्भिन्नमस्तकान्। जगवाजिरथैः क्षुण्णान् पश्य योधान् सहस्रशः॥
English Translation: Just as rivers never course back from the ocean they fall in, so no one among them who did not fly, returned back with his life, after having encountered Abhimanyu.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मनुष्यगजवाजीनां शरशक्तवृष्टितोमरैः। निस्त्रिंशैः पट्टिशैः प्रासैनखरैर्लगुडैरपि॥ शरीरैर्बहुधा छिन्नः शोणितौघपरिप्लुतैः। गतासुभिरमित्रघ्न संवृत्ता रणभूमयः॥
English Translation: Then the ariny began to reel like a boat on the ocean, overtaken by a mighty tempest and having its crew afflicted with fear through the violence of the wind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बाहुभिश्चन्दनादिग्धैः साङ्गदैः शुभभूषणैः। सतलत्रैः सकेयूरै ति भारत मेदिनी॥
English Translation: Thereafter the mighty Rukmaratha, a son of the ruler of the Madras, dauntlessly spoke these words, with a view to inspire confidence into the hearts of the panic-struck troops.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: साङ्गलित्रैर्भुजायैश्च विप्रविबैरलंकृतैः। हस्तिहस्तोपमैश्छिन्नैरुरुभिश्च तरस्विनाम्॥ बद्धचूडामणिवरैः शिरोभिश्च सकुण्डलैः।
English Translation: O heroes, you need not fear; Abhimanyu is nothing so long as I am here. For certain, I will capture him alive (today).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रथांश्च बहुधा भग्नन् हेमकिङ्किणिनः शुभान्॥ अश्वांश्च बहुधा पश्य शोणितेन परिप्लुतान्। अनुकर्षानुपासङ्गान् पताका विविधान् ध्वजान्॥ योधानां च महाशङ्खान् पाण्डुरांश्च प्रकीर्णकान्। निरस्तजिह्वान् मातङ्गान् शयानान् पर्वतोपमान्॥
English Translation: Having thus spoken that highly puissant hero rushed upon Abhimanyu, borne on a resplendent chariot duly furnished with the implements of war.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैजयन्तीविचित्राश्च हताश्च जलयोधिनः। वारणानां परिस्तोमान् संयुक्तानेककम्बलान्॥
English Translation: Piercing Abhimanyu on the breast with three shafts, he uttered his war-cry; and then again, he pierced him on the right and the left arms with three sharp shafts each.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विपाटितविचित्राश्च रूपचित्राः कुथास्तथा। भिन्नाश्च बहुधा घण्टाः पतद्धिश्चूर्णिता गजैः॥
English Translation: But the son of Phalguna cutting off his bow, his right and left arms and his head graced with beautiful eyes and eye-brows, soon felled them on the earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैदूर्यमणिदण्डाश्च पतितांश्चाङ्गुशान् भुवि। अश्वानां च युगापीडान् रत्नचित्रानुरश्छदान्॥
English Translation: Beholding Rukshmaratha the illustrious son of Shalya, who had promised to capture alive or consume Abhimanyu, slain by this latter.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विद्धाः सादिध्वजाग्रेषु सुवर्णविकृताः कुथाः। विचित्रान् मणिचित्रांश्च जातरूपपरिष्कृतान्॥ अश्वास्तरपरिमस्तोमान् राङ्कवान् पतितान् भुवि।
English Translation: Many princely warriors, 0 king, accomplished in smiting down and formidable in battle, all friends of Shalya's SOD (Rukshmaratha), came upon Abhimanyu, with their standards decked with gold, raised high.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चूडामणीन् नरेन्द्राणां विचित्राः काञ्चनस्त्रजः॥ छत्राणि चापविद्धानि चामरव्यजनानि च।
English Translation: Then those mighty car-warriors stretching their bows huge like palmyra trees, covered the son of Arjuna on all sides with showers of arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चन्द्रनक्षत्रभासैश्च वदनैश्चारुकुण्डलैः॥ क्लृप्तश्मश्रुभिराकीर्णा पूर्णचन्द्रनिभैर्महीम्।
English Translation: Beholding Subhadra's heroic and invincible son encountered, single-handed as he was, by many brave, youthful, irate princes endued with skill acquired through practices and teaching and also beholding him covered with a shower of arrows (shot by his adversaries), Duryodhana became highly gratified; and thought Abhimanyu already a visitor of the mansion of Vivasvata's son (Death).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कुमुदोत्पलपद्मानां खण्डैः फुल्लं यथा सरः॥ तथा महीभृतां वक्त्रैः कुमुदोत्पलसंनिभैः।
English Translation: Within a wink's time, all those youthful princes, each shooting sharp shafts of various shapes and furnished with golden wings, intercepted the son of Arjuna from the view.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तारागणविचित्रस्य निर्मलेन्दुद्युतित्विषः॥ पश्येमां नभसस्तुल्यां शरनक्षत्रमालिनीम्।
English Translation: Then, O sire, we beheld Abhimanyu;s car and driver and his standard, covered with arrows, as if by flights of locusts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतत् तवैवानुरूपं कमार्जुन महाहवे॥ दिवि वा देवराजस्य त्वया यत् कृतमाहवे।
English Translation: Thereupon like an elephant pierced deeply, the son of Arjuna, deeply pierced with those arzows, became inflamed with rage; and he then invoked into existence, the Gandharva weapon and its consequent illusions, 0 Bharata.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं तां दर्शयन् कृष्णो युद्धभूमि किरीटिने॥ गच्छन्नेवाशृणोच्छब्दं दुर्योधनबले महत्। शङ्खदुन्दुभिनिर्घोषं भेरीपणवनिःस्वनम्॥ स्थाश्वगजनादांश्च शस्त्रशब्दांश्च दारुणान्।
English Translation: This weapon was secured by Arjuna from the Gandharvas Tamburu and others, through bis ascetic austerities. Now Abhimanyu confounded his foes with that weapon.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रविश्य तद् बलं कृष्णस्तुगैर्वातवेगितैः॥ पाण्ड्येनाभ्यदित सैन्यं त्वदीयं वीक्ष्य विस्मितः।
English Translation: He was then seen, O King, sometimes as a single individual, sometimes as a hundred and sometimes as a thousand. He then moved over the field, displaying his weapons, like a circle of fire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स हि नानाविधैर्बाणैरिष्वस्त्रप्रवरो युधि॥ न्यहनद् द्विषता पूगान् गतासूनन्तको यथा।
English Translation: Then, O king, confounding the kings hostile to him with the illusions caused by his car, his coat of mail and his weapons, he mangled, O king, their bodies in hundred pieces.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गजवाजिमनुष्याणां शरीराणि शितैः शरैः॥ भित्वा प्रहरतां श्रेष्ठो विदेहासूनपातयत्।
English Translation: The vital breaths of living creatures were then snatched out of them by his arrows; and, O king, they reached the other world when their bodies fell down on earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शत्रुप्रवीरैरस्त्राणि नानाशस्त्राणि सायकैः छित्त्वा तानवधीच्छत्रून् पाण्ड्यः शक्र इवासुरान्॥५८
English Translation: The son of Phalguna with sharp broadheaded shafts, cut-off their bows, their steeds, their charioteers, their standards and arms with bracelets and also their graceful heads.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच यियासतस्ततः कृष्णः पार्थस्याश्वान् मनोजवान्। सम्प्रेषीद्धेमसंछन्नान् द्रोणानीकाय संत्वरन्॥
English Translation: Like a grove of mango trees, five years old and on the point of bearing fruit, laid low by the tempest those hundred princes were slain and felled by the son of Subhadra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं प्रयान्तं कुरुश्रेष्ठं स्वान् भ्रातृन् द्रोणतापितान्। सुशर्मा भ्रातृभिः सार्धं युद्धार्थी पृष्ठतोऽन्वयात्॥
English Translation: Beholding those young and delicate heroes reared up with all possible care and resembling furious snakes of virulent poison, slain by the single-headed son of Subhadra, Duryodhana became filled with fear.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः श्वेतहयः कृष्णमब्रवीदजितं जयः। एव मां भ्रातृभिः सार्धं सुशर्माऽऽह्वयतेऽच्युत॥
English Translation: Then beholding his car-warriors, his elephants, his steeds and foot-soldiers, smashed, the enraged Duryodhana quickly rushed at Abhimanyu.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दीर्यते चोत्तरेणैव तत् सैन्यं मधुसूदन। द्वैधीभूतं मनो मेऽद्य कृतं संशप्तकैरिदम्॥
English Translation: For a moment only a fierce battle raged between them, which virtually remained unfinished when your son, afflicted with arrows turned away from the field of battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किं नु संशप्तकान् हन्मि स्वान् रक्षाम्यहितार्दितान्। इति मे त्वं मतं वेत्सि तत्र किं सुकृतं भवेत्॥
English Translation: Yudhisthira said Tell me, O grandfather, by adopting what sort of intelligence may a king, who has been divested of prosperity and crushed by Time's heavy bludgeon, still live on this Earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्तस्तु दाशार्हः स्यन्दनं प्रत्यवर्तयत्। येन त्रिगर्ताधिपतिः पाण्डवं समुपाह्वयत्॥
English Translation: Regarding it is cited the old discourse between Vasava and Virochana's son Vali.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततोऽर्जुनः सुशर्माणं विद्ध्वा सप्तभिराशुगैः। ध्वजं धनुश्चास्य तथा क्षुराभ्यां समकृन्तत॥
English Translation: After having defeated all the Assuras, one day Vasava went to the Grandfather and joining his hands bowed to him and enquired after the whereabouts of Vali.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्रिगर्ताधिपतेश्चापि भ्रातरं षड्भिराशुगैः। साश्वं ससूतं त्वरितः पार्थः प्रैषीद् यमक्षयम्॥
English Translation: Tell me, O Brahman, where may I now find that Vali whose wealth continued undiminished even though he used to distribute it as largely as he wished.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो भुजगसंकाशां सुशर्मा शक्तिमायसीम्। चिक्षेपार्जुनमादिश्य वासुदेवाय तोमरम्॥
English Translation: He was the god of wind. He was Varuna. He was Surya. He was Soma. He was Agni that used to warm all creatures. He became water. I do not find where he now is. Indeed, O Brahmana, tell me where I may find Vali now.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शत्ति त्रिभिः शरैश्छित्त्वा तोमरं त्रिभिरर्जुनः। सुशर्माणं शरव्रातैर्मोहयित्वा न्यवर्तयत्॥
English Translation: Formerly, it was he who used to light up all the cardinal points and to set. Shaking off idieness, it was he who used to pour rain upon all creatures at the proper season. I do not now see that Vali. Indeed, tell me, O Brahman, where I may find that king of the Asuras now.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं वासवमिवायान्तं भूरिवर्षं शरौघिणम्। राजस्तावकसैन्यानां नोग्रं कश्चिदवारयत्॥!
English Translation: Brahman said You should not, O Maghavat, thus enquire after Vali now! One should not, however, speak a falsehood when he is questioned by another. I shall tell you the whereabouts of Vali.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो धनंजयो बाणैः सर्वानेव महारथान्। आयाद् विनिघ्नन् कौरव्यान् दहन कक्षमिवानलः।। १२
English Translation: O husband of Sachi, Vali may now have taken his birth among camels or bulls or asses or horses, and having become the foremost of his species may now be living in an empty room.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्य वेगमसह्यं तं कुन्तीपुत्रस्य धीमतः। नाशक्नुवंस्ते संसोढुं स्पर्शमग्नेरिव प्रजा॥
English Translation: Shakra said 'If, O Brahman, I happen to meet with Vali in an empty room, shall I kill him or spare him? Tell me how I shall act!'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संवेष्टयननीकानि शरवर्षेण पाण्डवः। सुपर्णपातवद् राजन्नायात् प्राग्ज्योतिषं प्रति॥
English Translation: Brahma said 'Do not, O Shakra, injure Vali! Vali does not deserve death. You should, on the other hand, O Vasava, seek instruction from him about morality, O Shakra, as you wish,'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यत् तदानामयज्जिष्णुर्भरतानामपापिनाम्। धनुः क्षेमकरं संख्ये द्विषतामश्रुवर्धनम्॥ तदेव तव पुत्रस्य राजन् दुर्दूतदेविनः। कृते क्षत्रविनाशाय धनुरायच्छदर्जुनः॥
English Translation: ‘Thus addressed by the divine Creator, Indra travelled over the Earth, seated on Airavata in great splendour.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथा विक्षोभ्यमाणा सा पार्थेन तव वाहिनी। व्यशीर्यत महाराज नौरिवासाद्य पर्वतम्॥
English Translation: He succeeded in meeting with Vali, who, as the Creator had said, was living in an empty room, clothed in the form of an ass.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो दशसहस्राणि न्यवर्तन्त धनुष्मताम्। मतिं कृत्वा रणे क्रूरां वीरा जयपराजये॥
English Translation: 'You are now, O Danava, born as an ass living on chaff. This your birth is certainly a low one. Do you or do you not grieve for it?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यपेतहृदयत्रासा आवद्रूस्तं महारथाः। आर्छत् पार्थो गुरुं भारं सर्वभारसहो युधि॥
English Translation: I see what I had never seen before, viz., yourself brought under the control of your enemies, divested of prosperity and friends, and shorn of energy and prowess.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथा नलवनं क्रुद्धः प्रभिन्नः षष्टिहायनः। मृद्गीयात् तद्वदायस्तः पार्थोऽमृद्गाच्चमू तव॥
English Translation: Formerly you used to march through the words, with your train consisting of thousands of carriages and thousands of kinsmen, and to move along, burning, everybody with your splendour and disregarding us all.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मिन् प्रमथिते सैन्ये भगदत्तो नराधिपः। तेन नागेन सहसा धनंजयमुपाद्रवत्॥
English Translation: Considering you as their protector the Daityas lived under your sway! Through your power, the Earth used to yield crops without waiting for tillage. To-day, however, I behold you overtaken by this dire calamity! Do you or do you not grieve for this.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं रथेन नरव्याघ्रः प्रत्यगृह्णाद् धनंजयः। स संनिपातस्तुमुलो बभूव स्थनागयोः॥
English Translation: When formerly you used with pride beaming on your face, to divide on the eastern shores of the ocean your vast wealth among thy kinsmen, what then was the state of your mind?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कल्पिताभ्यां यथाशास्त्रं रथेन च गजेन च। संग्रामे चेरतुर्वीरौ भगदत्तधनञ्जयौ॥
English Translation: Formerly, for many years, when shining with splendour, you used to sport, thousands of celestial damsels used to dance before you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो जीमूतसंकाशान्नागादिन्द्र इव प्रभुः। अभ्यवर्षच्छरौघेण भगदत्तो धनंजयम्॥
English Translation: All of them were decorated with garlands of lotuses and all had companions bright as gold. What, O king of Danavas, was the state of your mind then and what is it now.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: च चापि शरवर्षं तं शरवर्षेण वासविः। अप्राप्तमेव चिच्छेद भगदत्तस्य वीर्यवान्॥
English Translation: You had a very large golden umbrella set with jewels and gems. Fully forty-two thousand Gandharvas used in those days to dance before you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः प्राग्ज्योतिषो राजा शरवर्षे निवार्यत्। शरैर्जघ्ने महाबाहुं पार्थे कृष्णं च मारिष॥
English Translation: In your sacrifices you had a very large stake made entirely of gold. On such occasions you used to give away millions and millions of kine. What, O Ditya, was the state of your mind then?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततस्तु शरजालेन महताऽभ्यवकीर्य तौ। चोदयामास तं नाग वधायाच्युतपार्थयोः॥
English Translation: Formerly, engaged in sacrifice, you had gone round the whole Earth, following the rule of the hurling of the Shamya. What was the state of your mind then?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमापतन्तं द्विरदं दृष्ट्वा कुद्धमिवान्तकम्। चक्रेऽपसव्यं त्वरितः स्यन्दनेन जनार्दनः॥
