English Translation: I do not now see that golden jar of yours, nor that umbrella of yours, nor those fans. I behold not also, O king of the Asuras, that garland which was given given to you by Grandfather.'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं प्राप्तमपि नेयेष परावृत्तं महाद्वित्तं महाद्विपम्। सारोहं मृत्युसात्कर्तुं स्मरन् धर्म धनंजयः॥
English Translation: Bali said. 'You do not behold now, O Vasava, my jar and umbrella and fans. You do not see also my garland, that was given by the Grandfather.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तु नागो द्विपरथान् हयांश्चामृद्य मारिष। प्राहिणोन्मृत्युलोकाय ततः क्रुद्धो धनंजयः॥
English Translation: Those valuable possessions of mine about which you ask are now buried in the darkness of a cave. When my time comes again, you will, forsooth, behold them again.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यास उवाच भद्रे द्रक्ष्यसि गान्धारि पुत्रान् भ्रातॄन् सखींस्तथा। वधूश्च पतिभिः सार्धं निशि सुप्तोत्थिता इव॥
English Translation: This conduct of yours, however, does not become your fame or birth. Yourself enjoying prosperity, you wish to mock me that am sunk in adversity.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्णं द्रक्ष्यति कुन्ती च सौभद्रं चापि यादवी। द्रौपदी पञ्च पुत्रांश्च पितॄन् भ्रातूंस्तथैव च॥
English Translation: They who acquired wisdom, and have won contentment therefrom, they who are of tranquil should, who are virtuous and good among creatures, never grieve in misery nor rejoice in happiness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पूर्वमेवैष हृदये व्यवसायोऽभवन्मम। यदास्मि चोदितो राज्ञा भवत्या पृथयैव च॥
English Translation: Guided, however, by a vulgar intelligence, you are bragging, O Purandara. When you will become like me you will not then give vent to speeches like these.'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न ते शोच्या महात्मानः सर्व एव नरर्षभाः। क्षत्रधर्मपराः सन्तस्तथा हि निधनं गताः॥
English Translation: Guided, however, by a vulgar intelligence, you are bragging, O Purandara. When you will become like me you will not then give vent to speeches like these.'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भवितव्यमवश्यं तत् सुरकार्यमनिन्दिते। अवतेरुस्ततः सर्वे देवभागा महीतलम्॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said King Yudhishthira the son of Kunti then welcoming the son of Devaki, that assuager of the grief of men, cheerfully addressed the following words to himसुखेन रजनी व्युष्टा कच्चित् ते मधुसूदन।
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गन्धर्वाप्सरसश्चैव पिशाचा गुह्मराक्षसाः। तथा पुण्यजनाश्चैव सिद्धा देवर्षयोऽपि च॥ देवाश्च दानवाश्चैव तथा देवर्षयोऽमलाः। त एते निधनं प्राप्ताः कुरुक्षेत्रे रणाजिरे॥
English Translation: Having you, O slayer of Madhu, passed the night in happiness? Are all your senseorgans, O undeteriorating one, as keen as ever?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गन्धर्वराजो यो धीमान् धृतराष्ट्र इति श्रुतः। स एव मानुषे लोके धृतराष्ट्र: पतिस्तव॥
English Translation: The son of Vasudeva also put similar questions to Yudhishthira. Then an orderly came there and said that other Kshatriya warriors were waiting to be ushered in.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पाण्डुं मरुद्गणाद् विद्धि विशिष्टतममच्युतम्। धर्मस्यांशोऽभवत् क्षत्ता राजा चैव युधिष्ठिरः॥
English Translation: Permitted by the king, the orderly introduced that influx of men, numbering it, Virat, Bhimasena, Dhristadyumna and Satyaki and the ruler of the Chedis, Dhrishtaketu the mighty car-warriors Drupada, Sikhandin, the twins Nakula and Sahadeva, Chekitana with the prince of the Kekayas. As also Yuyutsu of Kuru race and Uttamaujas of the Panchala tribe and Yudhamanyu and Subahu and the five sons of Draupadi.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कलिं दुर्योधनं विद्धि शकुनि द्वापरं तथा। दुःशासनादीन् विद्धि त्वं राक्षसाशुभदर्शने॥
English Translation: These and many other Kshatriyas approached that best of Kshatriyas of illustrious fame; and they sat down on auspicious seats.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मरुद्गणाद् भीमसेनं बलवन्तमरिंदमम्। विद्धि त्वं तु नरमृषिमिमं पार्थं धनञ्जयम्॥
English Translation: The two mighty heroes, Krishna and Yuyudhana, of illustrious souls and great effulgence, both sat on a single seat.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नारायणं हृषीकेशमश्विनौ यमजौ तथा। यः स वैरार्थमुद्भूतः संघर्षजननस्तथा। तं कर्णं विद्धि कल्याणि भास्करं शुभदर्शने॥ यश्च पाण्डवदायादो हतः षड्भिर्महारथैः। स सोम इह सोभद्रो योगादेवाभवद् द्विधा॥ द्विधा कृत्वाऽऽत्मनो देहमादित्यं तपतां वरम्। लोकांश्च तापयानं वै विद्धि कर्णं च शोभने॥
English Translation: Thereafter king Yudhishthira, at the hearing of those assembled Kshatriyas, said these sweet words addressing that slayer of Madhu, who
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्रौपद्या सह सम्भूतं धृष्टद्युम्नं च पावकात्। अग्नेर्भागं शुभं विद्धि राक्षसं तु शिखण्डिनम्॥
English Translation: Like celestials depending on the strength of the thousand-eyed (Indra), we relying on you alone, seek victory in battle and eternal happiness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्रोणं बृहस्पतेर्भागं विद्धि द्रौणिं च रुद्रजम्। भीष्मं च विद्धि गाङ्गेयं वसुं मानुषतां गतम्॥
English Translation: You, () Krishna, know all about the despoliation of our kingdom, our exile by the that, my enemy and also all the miseries we had to suffer.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमेते महाप्रज्ञे देवा मानुष्यमेत्य हि। ततः पुनर्गताः स्वर्गं कृते कर्मणि शोभने।॥
English Translation: O Lord of everything, O you who are merciful to all devoted to you, upon you rest all our happiness and even our existence, O slayer of Madhu.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यच्च वै हृदि सर्वेषां दुःखमेतच्चिरं स्थितम्। तदद्य व्यपनेष्यामि परलोककृताद् भयात्॥
English Translation: O descendant of the Vrishni race, so do you manage heart may always rely on you and Arjuna's oath may remain inviolate.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वे भवन्तो गच्छन्तु नदीं भागीरथी प्रति। तत्र द्रक्ष्यथ तान् सर्वान् ये हतास्तत्र संयुगे॥
English Translation: Help us to cross this veritable ocean of grief and wrath. O Madhava, be you our raft today, as we desire to cross this ocean (of troubles).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच इति व्यासस्य वचनं श्रुत्वा सर्वो जनस्तदा। महता सिंहनादेन गङ्गामभिमुखो ययौ॥
English Translation: A car-warrior desirous of slaying his adversary cannot, in battle, do that (to achieve his purpose) which, O Krishna, his driver can do, if this latter strides with due caution.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्राश्च सामात्यः प्रययौ सह पाण्डवैः। सहितो मुनिशार्दूलैर्गन्धर्वैश्च समागतैः॥
English Translation: O mighty-armed Janardana, as you save the Vrishnis from all calamities, so also, it behoves you to save us from this impending ruin.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो गङ्गां समासाद्य क्रमेण स जनार्णवः। निवासमकरोत् सर्वो यथाप्रीति यथासुखम्॥
English Translation: O you the bearer of the conch, the discus and the mace, do you save the sons of Pandu sunk in the deep and boatless Kurn ocean, by becoming even a boat to them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजा च पाण्डवैः सार्धमिष्टे देशे सहानुगः। निवासमकरोद् धीमान् सस्त्रीवृद्धपुरःसरः॥
English Translation: Salutations unto you, the Lord of the foremost of celestials, the eternal one, the supreme destroyer, O Vishnu, O Jishnu, O Hari, O Krishna, O Vaikuntha and.O foremost of all male beings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जगाम तदहश्चापि तेषां वर्षशतं यथा। निशां प्रतीक्षमाणानां दिदृक्षूणां मृतान् नृपान्॥
English Translation: Narada had pronounced you to be that best and most ancient of sages viz., (Narayana), who accord boons, who wields the Sharnga bow and who are the foremost of all. Make, O Madhava, all these words true.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ पुण्यं गिरिवरमस्तमभ्यगमद् रविः। ततः कृताभिषेकास्ते नैशं कर्म समाचरन्॥
English Translation: Thus spoken to in the midst of the assembly by the very virtuous king Yudhishthira, that most fluent speaker Keshava replied to the former, in a voice sonorous like the rumbling of clouds charged with rain.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच प्रातरुत्थाय कृष्णस्तु कृतवान् सर्वमाह्निकम्। ब्राह्मणैरभ्यनुज्ञात: प्रययौ नगरं प्रति॥
English Translation: Krishna said In all the worlds, including the regions of celestials, there is no such wielder of bow who can equal Dhananjaya the son of Pritha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं प्रयान्तं महाबाहुमनुज्ञाप्य महाबलम्। पर्यवर्तन्त ते सर्वे वृकस्थलनिवासिनः॥
English Translation: Endowed with energy, accomplished in the use of weapons, possessed of great prowess and might, ever brave in battle and wrathful and agile, he is the foremost of all men.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धार्तराष्ट्रास्तमायान्तं प्रत्युज्जग्मुः स्वलंकृताः। दुर्योधनादृते सर्वे भीष्मद्रोणकृपादयः॥
English Translation: Moreover is youthful, of shoulders strong like those of the bull, of long-arms and mighty prowess; his gait resembles that of the lion itself. That handsome hero will slay all your enemies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पौराश्च बहुला राजन् हृषीकेशं दिदृक्षवः। यानैर्बहुविधैरन्यैः पन्दिरेव तथा परे॥
English Translation: On my part, I shall so act as Kunti's son Arjuna may be able to consume the troops of Dhritarashtra's son, like raging conflagration.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स वै पथि समागम्य भीष्मेणाक्लिष्टकर्मणा। द्रोणेन धार्तराष्ट्रश्च तैर्वृतो नगरं ययौ॥
English Translation: even Even this very day, with the help of his arrows, Arjuna will compel that one of sinful acts, that mean-minded slayer of Subhadra's son viz., Jayadratha, to travel on a road from which no traveller ever returns.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृष्णसम्माननार्थं च नगरं समलंकृतम्। बभूव राजमार्गश्च बहुरत्नसमाचितः॥
English Translation: The vultures, the hawks, the fierce jackals and other carnivorous animals, will today hold a feast on the flesh of that one.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न च कश्चिद् गृहे राजंस्तदाऽऽसीद् भरतर्षभ। न स्त्री न वृद्धो न शिशुर्वासुदेवदिदृक्षया।॥
English Translation: O Yudhishthira, even if the Gods with Indra at their head today become the protectors of Jayadratha, yet, slain in the thick of the fight, he shall undoubtedly be borne to the capital of Death's domain.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजमार्गो नरास्तस्मिन् संस्तुवन्त्यवनिं गताः। तस्मिन् काले महाराज हृषीकेशप्रवेशने॥
English Translation: The victorious Arjuna shall this day come to you, having slain in battle the ruler of the Sindhus. Dismiss the grief of your heart and free yourself of the fever of anxiety and O king, be you attended with prosperity!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आवृतानि वरस्त्रीभिर्गृहाणि सुमहान्त्यपि। प्रचलन्तीव भारेण दृश्यन्ते स्म महीतले॥
English Translation: Dhritarashtra said Describ: fully to me the ways of that intelligence by which this wilderness of duties may be safely crossed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथा च गतिमन्तस्ते वासुदेवस्य वाजिनः। राजमार्गे नरैर्वृते॥
English Translation: Vidura said “Having saluted the Self-create, I will obey your command by telling, you how the great sages speak of the wilderness of life.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स गृहं धृतराष्ट्रस्य प्राविशच्छत्रुकर्शनः। पाण्डुरं पुण्डरीकाक्षः प्रासादैरुपशोभितम्॥
English Translation: A cretin Brahmana, living in the great world, found himself on one occasion in a large inaccessible forest abounding with beasts of prey.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तिस्रः कक्ष्या व्यतिक्रम्य केशवो राजवेश्मनः। वैचित्रवीर्यं राजानमभ्यगच्छदरिंदमः॥ प्रनष्टगतयोऽभूवन्
English Translation: It was full of lions and tigers and other animals looking like elephants, all of which were roaring aloud. Such was the view of that forest that Yama himself would be frightened.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभ्यागच्छति दाशार्हे प्रज्ञाचक्षुर्नराधिपः। सहैव द्रोणभीष्माभ्यामुदतिष्ठन्महायशाः॥
English Translation: Seeing the forest, the heart of the Brahmana was greatly agitated. His hairs stood erect, and other signs of fear manifested themselves, O destroyer of enemies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृपश्च सोमदत्तश्च महाराजश्च बाह्निकः। आसनेभ्योऽचलन् सर्वे पूजयन्तो जनार्दनम्॥
English Translation: Entering it, he began to run hither and thither, looking every side for finding out somebody whose shelter he might seek.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो राजानमासाद्य धृतराष्ट्रं यशस्विनम्। स भीष्मं पूजयामास वार्ष्णेयो वाग्भिरञ्जसा॥
English Translation: Wishing to avoid those terrible creatures, he ran about in fear. He could not go far away from them or free himself from their presence.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषु धर्मानुपूर्वी तां प्रयुज्य मधुसूदनः। यथावयः समीयाय राजभिः सह माधवः॥
English Translation: He then saw that terrible forest was surrounded with a net, and that a dreadful woman stood there, stretching her arms.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ द्रोणं सबाह्रीकं सपुत्रं च यशस्विनम्। कृपं च सोमदत्तं च समीयाय जनार्दनः॥
English Translation: That large forest was also beset with many five-headed snakes of dreadful forms, tall as mountain summits touching the very sky.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्रासीदूर्जितं मृष्टं काञ्चनं महदासनम्। शासनाद् धृतराष्ट्रस्य तत्रोपाविशदच्युतः॥
English Translation: Within it was a pit whose mouth was covered with many hard and strong creepers and herbs.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ गां मधुपर्कं चाप्युदकं च जनार्दने। उपजह्वर्यथान्यायं धृतराष्ट्रपुरोहिताः॥
English Translation: While wandering the Brahmana dropped into that invisible pit. He was entangled in those creepers that were interwoven with one another, like the large fruit of a jack tree hanging by its stalk. He remained there hanging with feet upwards and head downwards.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृतातिथ्यस्तु गोविन्दः सर्वान् परिहसन् कुरुन्। आस्ते साम्बन्धिकं कुर्वन् कुरुभिः परिवारितः॥
English Translation: While in that state, he was visited by various other calamities. He saw a large and mighty snake within the pit. He also saw a gigantic elephant near its mouth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सोऽचितो धृतराष्ट्रेण पूजितश्च महायशाः। राजानं समनुज्ञाप्य निर्कामदरिंदमः॥
English Translation: The elephant, was dark coloured and had six faces and twelve feet. And the animal gradually approached that pit overgrown with creepers and trees.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तैः समेत्य यथान्यायं कुरुभिः कुरुसंसदि। विदुरावसथं रम्यमुपातिष्ठत माधरः॥
English Translation: About the twigs of the tree which was at the mouth of the pit. moved about many bees of dreadful forms, engaged from before in drinking the honey gathered in their comb.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विदुरः सर्वकल्याणैरभिगम्य जनार्दनम्। अर्चयामास दाशार्ह सर्वकामैरुपस्थितम्॥
English Translation: They repeatedly desired, O foremost of Bharata's race, to taste that honey which though sweet to all creatures could, however, attract children only. was not
---
Sanskrit Shloka: या मे प्रीतिः पुष्कराक्ष त्वदर्शनसमुद्भवा। सा किमाख्यायते तुभ्यमन्तरात्मासि देहिनाम्॥
English Translation: The honey (in the comb) fell in many gets below. The person who was hanging in the pit continually drank those jets.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृतातिथ्यं तु गोविन्दं विदुरः सर्वधर्मवित्। कुशलं पाण्डुपुत्राणामपृच्छन्मधुसूदनम्॥
English Translation: Drinking that honey in such a pitiable condition, his thirst, however, appeased. Unsatiated with repeatedly drinking the same the person desired for more.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रीयमाणस्य सुहृदो विदुरो बुद्धिसत्तमः। धर्मार्थनित्यस्य सतो गतरोषस्य धीमतः॥ तस्य सर्वं सविस्तारं पाण्डवानां विचेष्टितम्। क्षत्तुराचष्ट दाशार्हः सर्वं प्रत्यक्षदर्शिवान्॥
English Translation: Even then, O king, he could not give up hopes of life. Still, the man expected to live. A number of black and white rates were eating away the roots of that tree.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच ततो युधिष्ठिरश्चैव भीमसेनश्च पाण्डवः। द्रोणपुत्रं महाराज समन्तात् पर्यवारयन्॥
English Translation: There was fear from the beasts of prey, from that dreadful woman on the outskirts of that forest, from that snake at the bottom of the well, from that elephant near its top, from the fall of the tree brought about by the rats, and lastly from those bees flying about for drinking the honey.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो दुर्योधनो राजा भारद्वाजेन संवृतः। अभ्ययात् पाण्डवान् संख्ये ततो युद्धमवर्तत॥
English Translation: He lived in that condition, deprived of his senses, in that forest, never losing at any time the hope of continuing his life.”
---
Sanskrit Shloka: घोररूपं महाराज भीरूणां भयवर्धनम्। अम्बष्ठान् मालवान् वङ्गाञ्छिबींस्त्रगर्तकानपि॥
English Translation: Janamejaya said You should, O learned Brahmana, tell me what was next done by Yudhishthira the mighty-armed son of Dharma after he had regained his kingdom.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्राहिणोन्मृत्युलोकाय गणान् क्रुद्धो वृकोदरः। अमीषाहाञ्छूरसेनान् क्षत्रियान् युद्धदुर्मदान्॥ निकृत्य पृथिवीं चक्रे भीमः शोणितकर्दमाम्। यौधेयानद्रिजान् राजन् मद्रकान्मालवानपि॥
English Translation: You should tell me also, O Rishi, what the heroic Hrishikesha, the supreme lord of the three worlds, did after this.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्राहिणोन्मृत्युलोकाय किरीटी निशितैः शरैः। प्रगाढमञ्जोगतिभिर्नाराचैरभिताडिताः॥
English Translation: Hear me, O king, as I narrate fully, O sinless one, what the Pandavas, headed by Vasudeva did after this.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निपेतुर्विरदा भूमौ द्विशृङ्गा इव पर्वताः। निकृत्तैर्हस्तिहस्तैश्च चेष्टमानैरितस्ततः॥
English Translation: Having regained his kingdom, O monarch, Kunti's son Yudhishthira made each of the four orders of men perform their respective duties.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: रराज वसुधाऽऽकीर्णा विसर्पद्भिरिवोरगैः। क्षिप्तैः कनकचित्रैश्च नृपच्छत्रैः क्षितिर्वभौ॥
English Translation: The (eldest) son of Pandu gave a thousand great Brahmanas of the Snataka order a thousand gold coins each.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: द्यौरिवादित्यचन्द्राधैर्ग्रहैः कीर्णा युगक्षये। हत प्रहरताभीता विध्यत व्यवकृन्तत॥
English Translation: He then pleased the servants who were dependent on him and the guests who came to him, including persons who were undeserving, by satisfying their wishes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्यासीत् तुमुलः शब्दः शोणाश्वस्य रथं प्रति। द्रोणमस्तु परमक्रुद्धो वायव्यारेण संयुगे॥
English Translation: He gave to his priest Dhaumya kine in thousands, and immense wealth and gold and silver and dresses of various kinds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यधमत् तान् महावायुर्मेघानिव दुरत्ययः। ते हन्यमाना द्रोणेन पञ्चालाः प्राद्रवन् भयात्॥
English Translation: O monarch, the king treated Kripa like a preceptor. Ever observing vows the king continued to honour Vidura highly.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पश्यतो भीमसेनस्य पार्थस्य च महात्मनः। ततः किरीटी भीमश्च सहसा संन्यवर्तताम्॥
English Translation: That foremost of charitable men satisfied all persons with presents of food and drink and dresses of various kinds and beds and seats.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महता रथवंशेन परिगृह्य बलं महत्। बीभत्सुदक्षिणं पार्श्वमुत्तरं तु वृकोदरः॥
English Translation: Having restored peace to his kingdom the highly illustrious king, O best of monarchs, paid due honours to Yuyutsu and Dhritarashtra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भारद्वाजं शरौघाभ्यां महद्भ्यामभ्यवर्षताम्। तौ तथा संजयाश्चैव पञ्चालाश्च महौजसः॥
English Translation: Placing his kingdom at the disposal of Dhritarashtra, of Gandhari, and of Vidura, king Yudhishthira spent his days happily.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्वगच्छन् महाराज मत्स्यैश्च सह सोमकैः। तथैव तव पुत्रस्य रथोदाराः प्रहारिणः॥
English Translation: Having pleased everybody, including the citizens, in this way, Yudhishthira, O foremost of Bharata's race, approached with joined hands the presence of the great Vasudeva.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महत्या सेनया राजन् जग्मुर्दोणरथं प्रति। ततः सा भारतो सेना हन्यमाना किरीटिना॥
English Translation: He saw Krishna, of the hue of a blue cloud, seated on a large sofa bedecked with gold and gems.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमसा निद्रया चैव पुनरेव व्यदीर्यत। द्रोणेन वार्यमाणास्ते स्वयं तव सुतेन च॥
English Translation: Clad in yellow silk robes and adorned with celestial ornaments, his person shone effulgent like a jewel set on gold.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नाशक्यन्त महाराज योधा वारयितुं तदा। सा पाण्डुपुत्रस्य शरैदीर्यमाणा महाचमूः॥
English Translation: His bosom adorned with the Kaustubha gem, he shone like the mountain with the rising Sun.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तमसा संवृते लोके व्यद्रवत् सर्वतोमुखी। उत्सृज्य शतशो वाहांस्तत्र केचिन्नराधिपाः। प्राद्रवन्त महाराज भयाविष्टाः समन्ततः॥
English Translation: There was no equal of his beauty in three worlds, Approaching the great one who was an incarnation of Vishnu, king Yudhishthira addressed him sweetly and smilingly saying,-'O foremost of intelligent men, have you passed the night happily?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्राद्रवन्त महाराज भयाविष्टाः समन्ततः॥
English Translation: O you of unfading glory, have all your faculties been fully invigorated? O foremost of intelligent persons, is it all right with your understanding?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणः ऊचुः क्रियतामुपहारोऽद्य त्र्यम्बकस्य महात्मनः। दत्त्वापहारं नृपते ततः स्वार्थं यतामहे।।।।
English Translation: We have regained our kingdom and the whole Earth has come under our sway, O divine lord, through your favour, O refuge of the three worlds and, O you of three steps. Through your favour we have gained victory and obtained great fame and have not transgressed the duties of our order.'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रुत्वा तु वचनं तेषां ब्राह्मणानां युधिष्ठिरः। गिरीशस्य यथान्यायमुपहार मुपाहरत्॥
English Translation: The divine Krishna did not speak a single word to that chastiser of enemies, king Yudhishthira, for he was then rapt in meditation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आज्येन तर्पयित्वाग्निं विधिवत्संस्कृतेन च। मन्त्रसिद्धं चक्रं कृत्वा पुरोधाः स ययौ तदा॥
English Translation: Utatthya said If the god of the clouds pours rain in season and the king acts virtuously, the prosperity that comes keeps the subjects in happiness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स गृहीत्वा सुमनसो मन्त्रपूता जनाधिप। मोदकैः पायसेनाथ मांसैश्चोपाहरद् बलिम्॥
English Translation: That washerman who does not know how to wash away the dirt of cloth without destroying its dye, is very unskilful in his profession.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुनोभिश्च चित्राभिर्लाजैरुच्चावचैरपि। सर्वे स्विष्टतमं कृत्वा विधिवद् वेदपारगः॥
English Translation: That person among Brahmanas Kshatriyas or Vaishyas who, having deviated from the proper duties of his caste, has become a Shudra, is truly to be compared to such a washerman.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: किंकराणां ततः पश्चाच्चकार बलिमुत्तमम्। यक्षेन्द्राय कुबेराय मणिभद्राय चैव ह॥
English Translation: Menial service is the duty of the Shudra; agriculture is that of the Vaishya; the science of punishment of the Kshatriya and Brahmacharya, penances, Mantras, and truth, belong to the Brahmana. or
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथान्येषां च यक्षाणां भूतानां पतयश्च ये। कृसरेण च मांसेन निवापैस्तिलसंयुतैः॥ ओदनं कुम्भशः कृत्वा पुरोधाः समुपाहरत्। ब्राह्मणेभ्यः सहस्राणि गवां दत्त्वा तु भूमिपः॥
English Translation: That Kshatriya who knows how to correct the wrong-doings of the other castes and to wash them clean like a washerman, is really their father and deserves to be their king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नक्तंचराणां भूतानां व्यादिदेश बलि तदा। धूपगन्धनिरुद्धं तत् सुमनोभिश्च संवृतम्॥ शुशुभे स्थानमत्यर्थ देवदेवस्य पार्थिव। कृत्वा पूजां तु रुद्रस्य गणानां चैव सर्वशः॥ ययौ व्यासं पुरस्कृत्य नृपो रत्ननिधि प्रति। पूजयित्वा धनाध्यक्षं प्रणिपत्याभिवाद्य च॥ सुमनोभिर्विचित्राभिरपूपैः कृसरेण च। शंखादींश्च निधीन् सर्वान् निधिपालांश्च सर्वशः॥ अर्चयित्वा द्विजाग्र्यान् स स्वस्ति वाच्य च वीर्यवान्। तेषां पुण्याहघोषेण तेजसा समवस्थितः॥ प्रीतिमान् स कुरुश्रेष्ठः खानयामास तद् धनम्। ततः पात्री: सकरका बहुरूपा मनोरमाः॥ भृङ्गराणि कटाहानि कलशान् वर्धमानकान्। बहूनि च विचित्राणि भाजनानि सहस्रशः॥ उद्धारयामास तदा धर्मराजो युधिष्ठिरः। तेषां रक्षणमप्यासीन्महान् करपुटस्तथा॥
English Translation: The various cycles called Krita, Treta, Dvapara, and Kali, O foremost of Bharata's race, all depend on the conduct of the king. It is the king who makes the cycles.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नद्धं च भाजनं राजंस्तुलाधर्मभवन्नृप। वाहनं पाण्डुपुत्रस्य तत्रासीत् तु विशाम्पते॥
English Translation: The four castes, the Vedas, and the duties of the four modes of life, all suffer from confusion and weakness when the king becomes heedless.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: षष्टिरुष्ट्रसहस्राणि शतानि द्विगुणा हयाः। वारणाश्च महाराज सहस्रशतसम्मिताः॥
English Translation: The three kinds of fire, the three Vedas, and sacrifices with Dakshina, all disappear when the king becomes careless.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शकटानि रथाश्चैव तावदेव करेणवः। खराणां पुरुषाणां च परिसंख्या न विद्यते॥
English Translation: The king is the creator of all creatures, and is their destroyer. That righteous king is regarded as the creator, while the sinful one is regarded as the destroyer.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतद् वित्तं तदभवद् यदुद्दघे युधिष्ठिरः। षोडशाष्टौ चतुर्विंशत्सहस्रं भारलक्षणम्॥
English Translation: The king's wives, sons, kinsmen, and friends, all become unhappy and grieve when the king becomes careless.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतेष्वादाय तद् द्रव्यं पुनरभ्यर्च्य पाण्डवः। महादेवं प्रति ययौ पुरं नागाह्वयं प्रति॥ द्वैपायनाभ्यनुज्ञातः पुरस्कृत्य पुरोहितम्। गोयुते गोयुते चैव न्यवसत् पुरुषर्षभः॥
English Translation: Elephants, horses, kine, camels, mules, asses and other animals all lose their vigour when the king becomes sinful.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सा पुराभिमुखा राजन्नुवाह महती चमूः। कृच्छ्राद् द्रविणभारार्ता हर्षयन्ती कुरूद्वहान्॥
English Translation: It is said, O Mandhatri, that the Creator created Power for for protecting Weakness. Weakness is, really, a great being, for every thing depends upon it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मार्कण्डेय उवाच चिन्तयित्वा तदाश्चर्यं स्त्रिया प्रोक्तमशेषतः। विनिन्दन् स स्वमात्मानमागस्कृत इवाबभौ॥
English Translation: All creatures adore the king. All creatures are the children of the king. If, therefore, O monarch, the king becomes unrighteous, all creatures meet with ruin.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चिन्तयानः स्वधर्मस्य सूक्ष्मां गतिमथाब्रवीत्। श्रद्दधानेन वै भाव्यं गच्छामि मिथिलामहम्॥
English Translation: The eyes of the Weak, of the Muni, and of the venomous snake, should be considered as unbearable. Do not, therefore, meet the Weak as you would do an enemy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृतात्मा धर्मवित् तस्यां व्याधो निवसते किला तं गच्छाम्यहमद्यैव धर्मं प्रष्टुं तपोधनम्॥
English Translation: You should regard the Weak as being subject to humiliation. Take care that the eyes of the Weak do not burn you with your kinsmen.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इति संचित्य मनसा श्रद्दधानः स्त्रिया वचः। बलाकाप्रत्ययेनासौ धयश्च वचनैः शुभैः॥ सम्प्रतस्थे स मिथिलां कौतूहलसमन्वितः।
English Translation: In a family scorched by the eyes of the Weak, no children are born. Such eyes burn the family to its very roots. Do not, therefore, treat the weak inimically.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अतिक्रामनरण्यानि ग्रामांश्च नगराणि चा॥ ततो जगाम मिथिलां जनकेन सुरक्षिताम्। धर्मसेतुसमाकीर्णां यज्ञोत्सववती शुभाम्॥
English Translation: Weakness is more powerful than even the greatest Power, for that Power which is scorched by Weakness is absolutely rotted out.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गोपुराट्टालकवती हर्म्यप्राकारशोभनाम्। प्रविश्य नगरी रम्यां विमानैर्बहुभिर्युताम्॥
English Translation: If a person, who has been humiliated or struck, fails, while crying for help, to get a protector, divine punishment over takes the king and brings about his fall.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पण्यैश्च बहुभिर्युक्तां सुविभक्तमहापथाम्। अश्वै रथैस्तथा नागैर्योधैश्च बहुभिर्युताम्॥
English Translation: Do not, 'O sire, while excersing Power, take wealth from the Weak, Take care that the eyes of the Weak do not burn you like a burning fire.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हृष्टपुष्टजनाकीर्णां नित्योत्सवसमाकुलाम्। सोऽपश्यद् बहुवृत्तान्तां ब्राह्मण: समतिक्रमन्॥
English Translation: The tears shed by weeping men afflicted with falsehood kill the children and animals of those that have uttered those lies.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धर्मव्याधमपृच्छच्च स चास्य कथितो द्विजैः। अपश्यत् तत्र गत्वा तं सूनामध्ये व्यवस्थितम्॥
English Translation: Like a cow a sinful act does not yield immediate truits. If the fruit is not seen in the perpetrator himself, it is seen in his son or in his grand-son or daughter's son.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मार्गमाहिषमांसानि विक्रीणन्तं तपस्विनम्। आकुलत्वाच्च क्रेतृणामेकान्ते संस्थितो द्विजः॥
English Translation: When a Weak person fails to find a protector the great rod of divine punishment overtakes the king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तु ज्ञात्वा द्विजं प्राप्तं सहसा सम्भ्रमोत्थितः। आजगाम यतो विप्रः स्थित एकान्तदर्शने॥
English Translation: When all the subjects of a king are compelled by distress to live like Brahmanas, by begging, such mendicancy brings destruction upon the king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्याध उवाच अभिवादये त्वां भगवन् स्वागतं ते द्विजोत्तम्। अहं व्याधो हि भद्रं ते किं करोमि प्रशाधि माम्॥
English Translation: When all the officers of the king living in the provinces unite together and act unfairly, the king is then said to bring about a state of unredeeming evil upon his kingdom.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एकपल्या यदुक्तोऽसि गच्छ त्वं मिथिलामिति। जानाम्येतदहं सर्वं यदर्थं त्वमिहागतः॥
English Translation: When the officers of the king extort money, hy unfair mean, or acting from lust or avarice, from persons pitcously praying for mercy, a great destruct' on, jorsooth, be.ails the king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: श्रुत्वा च तस्य तद् वाक्यं स विप्रो भृशविस्मितः द्वितीयमिदमाश्चर्यमित्यचिन्तयत द्विजः॥
English Translation: A huge tree, just growing, assumes large proportions, Numberless creatures then come and seek its shelter. When, however, it is cut down or burnt, those who had taken its shelter become all houseless.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अदेशस्थं हि ते स्थानमिति व्याधोऽब्रवीदिदम्। गृहं गच्छाव भगवन् यदि ते रोचतेऽनघ॥
English Translation: When the denizens of a kingdom perform pious acts and all religious rites, and praise the good qualities, of the king, the latter acquires riches. When, however, the residents, out of ignorance forsake righteousness and act unrighteously, the king suffers from misery.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मार्कण्डेय उवाच बाढमित्येव तं विप्रो हृष्टो वनचमब्रवीत्। अचतस्तु द्विजं कृत्वा स जगाम गृहं प्रति॥
English Translation: When sinful men of known acts are allowed to move among the righteous, Kali then overtakes the kings of those kingdoms. When the king punishes all wicked people, his kingdom prospers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रविश्य च गृहं रम्यमासनेनाभिपूजितः। अर्येण च स वै तेन व्याधेन द्विजसत्तमः॥
English Translation: Forsooth, the kingdom of that king certainly prospers who honours his ministers and employs them in policy and in battles. Such a king enjoys the wide Earth or ever.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततः सुखोपविष्टस्तं व्याधं वचनमब्रवीत्। कर्मैतद् वै न सदृशं भवतः प्रतिभाति मे। अनुतप्ये भृशं तात तव घोरेण कर्मणा॥
English Translation: That king who duly honours at good acts and good speeches acquires great merit.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्याध उवाच कुलोचितमिदं कर्म पितृपैतामहं परम्। वर्तमानस्य मे धर्मे स्वे मन्युं मा कृथा द्विज॥
English Translation: The enjoyment of good things with others, paying proper honours to the ministers, and subjugations of persons who are proud of their strength, are the great duty of a king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विधात्रा विहित पूर्वं कर्म स्वमनुपालयन्। प्रयत्नाच्च गुरू वृद्धौ शुश्रूषेऽहं द्विजोत्तम॥
English Translation: Protecting all men by words, body, and deeds, and never forgiving even his offending son himself, form the duty of the king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सत्यं वदे नाभ्यसूये यथाशक्ति ददामि च। देवतातिथिभृत्यानामवशिष्टेन वर्तये॥
English Translation: The maintenance of the Weak by sharing with them the things he has and thereby increasing their strength, form the duty of the king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न कुत्सयाम्यहं किंचिन्न गर्हे बलवत्तरम्। कृतमन्वेति कर्तारं पुरा कर्म द्विजोत्तम॥
English Translation: Protection of the kingdom, extermination of robbers, and conquest form the duty of the king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृषिगोरक्ष्यवाणिज्यमिह लोकस्य जीवनम्। दण्डनीतिस्त्रयी विद्या तेन लोको भवत्युत॥
English Translation: Not to forgive a person, however dear if he has committe an offence, by act or word, forms the duty of the king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्म शूद्रे कृषिर्वैश्ये संग्रामः क्षत्रिये स्मृतः। ब्रह्मचर्यं तपो मन्त्राः सत्यं च ब्राह्मणे सदा॥
English Translation: Protecting those who seek refuge with him as he would protect his own children, and never depriving one of the honours to which he is entitled, form the duty of the king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजा प्रशास्ति धर्मेण स्वकर्मनिरताः प्रजाः। विकर्माणश्च ये केचित् तान् युनक्ति स्वकर्मसु॥
English Translation: Adoring the gods, with devotion in sacrifices completed by presents, and subduing lust and envy, from the duty of the king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भेतव्यं हि सदा राज्ञः प्रजानामधिपा हि ते। वारयन्ति विकर्मस्थं नृपा मृगमिवेषुभिः॥
English Translation: Wiping the tears of the distressed, the helpless, and the old, and filling them with joy, form the duty of the king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जनकस्येह विप्रर्षे विकर्मस्थो न विद्यते। स्वकर्मनिरता वर्णाश्चत्वारोऽपि द्विजोत्तम॥
English Translation: Advancing friends, weakening enemies, and honouring the good, form the duty of the king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स एष जनको राजा दुर्वृत्तमपि चेत् सुतम्। दण्ड्यं दण्डे निक्षिपति तथा न ग्लाति धार्मिकम्।२९॥
English Translation: Cheerfully adhering to truth, always making presents of land, entertaining guests, and maintaining dependents, form the duty of the king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुयुक्तचारो नृपतिः सर्वं धर्मेण पश्यति। श्रीश्च राज्यं च दण्डश्च क्षत्रियाणां द्विजोत्तम॥
English Translation: That king who favours those who deserve favours, and punishes those who deserve chastisement, acquires great merit both here and hereafter.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजानो हि स्वधर्मेण श्रियमिच्छन्ति भूयसीम्। सर्वेषामेव वर्णानां त्राता राजा भवत्युत॥
English Translation: The king is Yama himself. He is, O Mandhatri, the god (incarnate) to all righteous persons. By controlling his senses he acquires great riches. By not subduing them he commits sin.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: परेण हि हतान् ब्रह्मन् वराहमहिषानहम्। न स्वयं हन्मि विप्रर्षे विक्रीणामि सदात्वहम्॥
English Translation: Paying proper honours to Ritwijas and priests and preceptors, and doing them good, form the duty of the king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न भक्षयामि मांसानि ऋतुगामी तथा ह्यहम्। सदोपवासी च तथा नक्तभोजी सदा द्विज॥
English Translation: Yama governs all creatures without any distinction. The king should imitate him in his conduct by restraining all his subjects duly.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अशीलश्चापि पुरुषो भूत्वा भवति शीलवान्। प्राणिहिंसारतश्चापि भवते धार्मिकः पुनः॥
English Translation: The king is said to resemble the Thousandeyed (Indra). O foremost of men, that which is regarded by the king as Righteousness is accepted as such by all.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यभिचारानरेन्द्राणां धर्मः संकीर्यते महान्। अधर्मो वर्धते चापि संकीर्यन्ते ततः प्रजाः॥
English Translation: You should diligently cultivate forgiveness, intelligence, patience and the love of all creatures. You should also determine the strength and weakness of all men and learn to distinguish between right and wrong.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भेरुण्डा वामनाः कुब्जाः स्थूलशीर्षास्तथैव च। क्लीबाश्चान्धाश्च बधिरा जायन्तेऽत्युच्चलोचनाः॥
English Translation: You should behave properly towards all creatures, make gifts, the utter agreeable and sweet words. You should maintain the residents of your city and the provinces in happiness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पार्थिवानामधर्मत्वात् प्रजानामभवः सदा। स एष राजा जनकः प्रजा धर्मेण पश्यति॥
English Translation: A king, who is not clever, can never protect his subjects. Sovereignty, O sire, is a very heavy burden.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनुगृहणन् प्रजाः सर्वा स्वधर्मनिरताः सदा। ये चैव मां प्रशंसन्ति ये च निन्दन्ति मानवाः॥ सर्वान् सुपरिणीतेन कर्मणा तोषयाम्यहम्।
English Translation: Only that king who is endued with wisdom and courage, and who is a master of the science of punishment, can protect a kingdom. He, on the other hand, who is devoid of energy and intelligence, and who is not versed in the great science, cannot bear the burden of sovereignty.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ये जीवन्ति स्वधर्मेण संयुञ्जन्ति च पार्थिवाः॥ न किंचिदुपजीवन्ति दान्ता उत्थानशीलिनः।
English Translation: Helped by ministers of beautiful features and good birth, clever in business, devoted to their masters, and highly learned, you should examine the hearts and acts of all men including the very hermits.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शक्त्यानदानं सततं तितिक्षा धर्मनित्यता॥ यथार्ह प्रति पूजा च सर्वभूतेषु वै सदा। त्यागान्नान्यत्र मर्त्यानां गुणास्तिष्ठन्ति पूरुषे॥
English Translation: Behaving thus, you will be able to learn the duties of all orders of men. This will help you in observing your own duties whether when you are in your country or when you go to other kingdoms.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मृषा वादं परिहरेत् कुर्यात् प्रियमयाचितः। न च कामान्न संरम्भान्न द्वेषाद् धर्ममुत्सृजेत्॥
English Translation: Amongst these three objects, viz., Virtue, Profit, and Pleasure, Virtue is the foremost. He, who is of virtuous soul, acquires great happiness both here and hereafter.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्रिये नातिभृशं हृष्येदप्रिये न च संज्वरेत्। न मुह्येदर्थकृच्छ्रेषु न च धर्मं परित्यजेत्॥
English Translation: If men are treated with honour, they can abandon their very wives and sons. By winning over good men, by gifts, sweet words, carefulness, and purity of conduct, a king may acquire for himself great prosperity. Do not, therefore, O Mandhatri, be negligent of these qualities and acts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्म चेत्किंचिदन्यत् स्यादितरन्न तदाचरेत्। यत् कल्याणमभिध्यायेत् तत्रात्मानं नियोजयेत्॥
English Translation: The king should never neglect to look after his own weak points as also after those of his foes. He should act in such a way that his enemies may not be able to discover his weak points, and he should himself assail them when theirs are seen.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न पापे प्रतिपाप: स्यात् साधुरेव सदा भवेत्। आत्मनैव हतः पापो यः पापं कर्तुमिच्छति॥
English Translation: In this way Vasava, and Yama, and Varuna and all the great royal sages have acted. Do you follow the same conduct.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्म चैतदसाधूनां वृजिनानामसाधुवत्। न धर्मोऽस्तीति मन्वानाः शुचीनवहसन्ति ये॥ अश्रद्दधाना धर्मस्य ते नश्यन्ति न संशयः। महादृतिरिवाघ्मातः पापो भवति नित्यदा॥
English Translation: Do you, O great king, follow the conduct of those royal sages. Do you soon, O foremost of Bharata's race, follow this heavenly road.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मूढानामवलिप्तानामसारं भावितं भवेत्। दर्शयत्यन्तरात्मा तं दिवा रूपमिवांशुमान्॥
English Translation: The gods, the Rishis, the Pitris, and the Gandharvas, possessed of great energy, chant the praises, both here and hereafter, of that king who is righteous!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न लोके राजते मूर्खः केवलात्मप्रशंसया। अपि चेह श्रिया हीनः कृतविद्यः प्रकाशते॥
English Translation: Bhishma said nus spoken to by Utatthya, O Bharata, Mandhatri unhesitatingly did as he as he was directed, and became the soul king of the wide Earth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अब्रुवन् कस्यचिनिन्दामात्मपूजामवर्णयन्। न कश्चिद् गुणसम्पन्नः प्रकाशो भुवि दृश्यते॥
English Translation: Do you also, O king, act righteously like Mandhatri. You will then, after ruling the Earth, live in heaven!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विकर्मणा तप्यमानः पापाद् विपरिमुच्यते। न तत् कुर्यां पुनरिति द्वितीयात् परिमुच्यते॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said If one cannot thus win over one's kinsmen and relatives, the intending friends become foes. How should one, then, behave so that the hearts of both friends and enemies may be won?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्मणा येन तेनेह पापाद् द्विजवरोत्तमा एवं श्रुतिरियं ब्रह्मन् धर्मेषु प्रतिदृश्यते॥
English Translation: Bhishma said Regarding it is cited the old history of a discourse between Vasudeva and the divine saint Narada.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पापान्यबुद्धवेह पुरा कृतानि प्राग् धर्मशीलोऽपि विहन्ति पश्चात्। धर्मो राजन् नुदते पूरुषाणां यत् कुर्वते पापमिह प्रमादात्॥
English Translation: Once on a time Vasudeva said-Neither an illiterate and foolish friend, nor a learned friend of fickle mind, deserves, O Narada, to know one's secret counsels.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पापं कृत्वा हि मन्येत नाहमस्मीति पूरुषः। तं तु देवाः प्रपश्यन्ति स्वस्यैवान्तर पूरुषः॥
English Translation: Relying on your friendship for me, I shall say something to you, O sage! O you who can go to heaven at your pleasure, one should speak to another if he is convinced of the intelligence of that other.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चिकीर्षेदेव कल्याणं श्रद्दधानोऽनसूयकः। वसनस्येव छिद्राणि साधूनां विवृणोति यः॥
English Translation: I never behave with slavish tendency towards my kinsmen by flattering speeches about their prosperity, I give them half of what I have, and forgive their evil words.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पापं चेत् पुरुषः कृत्वा कल्याणमभिपद्यते। मुच्यते सर्वपापेभ्यो महाभ्रेणेव चन्द्रमाः॥
English Translation: As a fire-stick is grinded by a person who seeks to get fire, so my heart is grinded by my kinsmen with their cruel words. Indeed, O celestial Rishi, those cruel words consume my heart every day.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथाऽऽदित्यः समुद्यन् वै तमः पूर्वं व्यपोहति। एवं कल्याणमातिष्ठन् सर्वपापैः प्रमुच्यते॥
English Translation: Power lives in Sankarshana; mildness in Gada; and as regards Pradyumna, he excels even myself in beauty. Still I am helpless, O Narada!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पापानां विद्ध्यधिष्ठान् लोभमेव द्विजोत्तम। लुब्धाः पापं व्यवस्यन्ति नरा नातिबहुश्रुताः॥
English Translation: Many others among the Andhakas and the Vrishnis are endued with great prosperity, might, daring courage and constant perseverance.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अधर्मा धर्मरूपेण तृणैः कूपा इवावृताः। तेषां दमः पवित्राणि प्रलापा धर्मसंश्रिताः। सर्वं हि विद्यते तेषु शिष्टाचारः सुदुर्लभः॥
English Translation: He, with whom they do not side, meets with destruction. He, on the other hand, with whom they side, acquires everything. Dissuaded by both Ahuka and Akrura, I do not side either of them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मार्कण्डेय उवाच स तु विप्रो महाप्राज्ञो धर्मव्याधमपृच्छत। शिष्टाचारं कथमहं विद्यामिति नरोत्तम॥
English Translation: What can be more distressing for a person than to have both Ahuka and Akrura on his side? What, again, is more painful for one than not to have both of them on his side?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतदिच्छामि भद्रं ते श्रोतुं धर्मभृतां वर। त्वत्तो महामते व्याध तद् ब्रवीहि यथातथम्॥
English Translation: I am like the mother of two brothers gambling against each other, praying for victory to both.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्याध उवाच यज्ञो दानं तपो वेदाः सत्यं च द्विजसत्तम। पञ्चैतानि पवित्राणि शिष्टाचारेषु सर्वदा॥
English Translation: I am thus, O Narada, afflicted by both. You should tell me that which is for the behoof of both myself and my kinsmen.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कामक्रोधौ वशे कृत्वा दम्भं लोभमनार्जवम्। धर्ममित्येव संतुष्टास्ते शिष्टाः शिष्टसम्मताः॥
English Translation: Narada said Calamities, O Krishna, are of two sorts, viz., external and internal. They are begotten, O you of Vrishni's race, by one's own acts or by the acts of others.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न तेषां विद्यतेऽवृत्तं यज्ञस्वाध्यायशीलिनाम्। आचारपालनं चैव द्वितीयं शिष्टलक्षणम्॥
English Translation: The calamity that has now overtaken you is an internal one and is begotten of your own acts. Valadeva and others, of the Bhoja race, are partisans of Akrura, and have sided him either for wealth, or for mere caprice, or actuated by words or by hatred. As for you, you have given away wealth obtained by you to another.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गुरुशुश्रूषणां सत्यमक्रोधो दानमेव च। एतच्चतुष्टयं ब्रह्मन् शिष्टाचारेषु नित्यदा॥
English Translation: Though having many friends, you have, however, by your own act, invited calamity over your head. You cannot take back that wealth, even as one cannot swallow again the food that he has vomited himself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शिष्टाचारे मनः कृत्वा प्रतिष्ठाप्य च सर्वशः। यामयं लभते वृत्तिं सा न शक्या हतोऽन्यथा॥
English Translation: The kingdom cannot be taken back from Babhru and Ugrasena. You, O Krishna, cannot, in particular, take it back from fear of creating intestine feuds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वेदस्योपनिषत् सत्यं सत्यस्योपनिषद् दमः। दमस्योपनिषत् त्यागः शिष्टाचारेषु नित्यदा॥
English Translation: Supposing the attempt succeeds, it will do so after move trouble and after the achievement of the most difficult works. A great slaughter and a great loss of wealth will take place, perhaps, even total destruction.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ये तु धर्मानसूयन्ते बुद्धिमोहान्विता नराः। अपथा गच्छतां तेषामनुयाता च पीड्यते॥
English Translation: Use then a weapon which is not made of steel, which is very mild and yet capable of piercing all hearts. Sharpening that weapon again and again rectify the tongues of your kinsmen!
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ये तु शिष्टाः सुनियताः श्रुतित्यागपरायणाः। धर्मपन्थानमारूढाः सत्यधर्मपरायणाः॥
English Translation: Vasudeva said What is that weapon, O sage, which is not made of steel, which is mild, which still cuts all hearts, and which I must use for correcting the tongues of my kinsmen?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नियच्छन्ति परां बुद्धिं शिष्टाचारान्विता जनाः। उपाध्यायमते युक्ताः स्थित्या धर्मार्थदर्शिनः॥
English Translation: Narada said The giving of food to the best of your ability, forgiveness, sincerity, mildness, and honour to whom honour is due,-these make a weapon which is not made of steel.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नास्तिकान् भिन्नमर्यादान् क्रूरान् पापमतौ स्थितान्। त्यज तान् ज्ञानमाश्रित्य धार्मिकानुपसेव्य च॥
English Translation: With soft words alone turn away the anger of kinsmen about to utter cruel words, and please their hearts and minds and slanderous words.

Sanskrit Shloka: कामलोभग्रहाकी) पञ्चेन्द्रियजला नदीम्। नावं धृतिमयीं कृत्वा जन्मदुर्गाणि संत॥
English Translation: None who is not a great man with purified soul and endued with accomplishments and having friends can bear a heavy burden. Take up this great weight and bear it on your shoulders.

Sanskrit Shloka: क्रमेण संचितो धर्मो बुद्धियोगमयो महान्। शिष्टाचारे भवेत् साधू रागः शुक्लेव वाससि।॥
English Translation: All oxen can carry heavy loads on a level road. The stronger ones only among them can carry such loads on a difficult road.

Sanskrit Shloka: अहिंसा सत्यवचनं सर्वभूतिहतं परम्। अहिंसा परमो धर्मः स च सत्ये प्रतिष्ठितः। सत्ये कृत्वा प्रतिष्ठां तु प्रवर्तन्ते प्रवृत्तयः॥
English Translation: Disunion will create destruction which will befall all the Bhojas and the Vrishnis! You, O Keshava, are the foremost of them. Do you act in such a way that the Bhojas and the Vrishnis may not meet with destruction.

Sanskrit Shloka: सत्यमेव गरीयस्तु शिष्टाचारनिषेवितम्। आचारश्च सतां धर्मः संतश्चाचारलक्षणाः॥
English Translation: Nothing but intelligence and forgiveness, control of the senses, and liberality, reside in a person of wisdom.

Sanskrit Shloka: यो यथाप्रकृतिर्जन्तुः स स्वां प्रकृतिमश्नुते। पापात्मा क्रोधकामादीन् दोषानापनोत्यनात्मवान्॥
English Translation: The advancement of one's own race is always praiseworthy and glorious and conducive to long life. Do you, O Krishna, act in such a way that destruction may not overtake your kinsmen.

Sanskrit Shloka: आरम्भो न्याययुक्तो यः स हि धर्म इति स्मृतः। अनाचारस्त्वधर्मेति एतच्छिष्टानुशासनम्॥
English Translation: Use of the six qualities and riding on car (at the time of war), there is nothing about policy and art of war, O lord, which you do not know?

Sanskrit Shloka: अक्रुद्ध्यन्तोऽनसूयन्तो निरहकारमत्सराः। ऋजवः शमसम्पन्नाः शिष्टाचारा भवन्ति ते॥
English Translation: The Yadavas, the Kukuras, the Bhojas, the Andhakas, and the Vrishni, all depend on you even as all the worlds and all the regents of their quarters, O mighty-armed one! The Rishis, O Madhava always pray for your advancement.

Sanskrit Shloka: विद्यवृद्धाः शुतयो वृत्तवन्तो मनस्विनः। गुरुशुश्रूषवो दान्ताः शिष्टाचारा भवन्त्युत॥
English Translation: You are the lord of all creatures. You know the past, the present, and the future. You are the foremost of all the Yadavas. Depending on you, they expect to live happily.

Sanskrit Shloka: तेषामहीनसत्त्वानां दुष्कराचारकर्मणाम्। स्वैः कर्मभिः सत्कृतानां घोरत्वं सम्प्रणश्यति॥

Sanskrit Shloka: आस्तिका मानहीनाश्च द्विजातिजनपूजकाः। श्रुतवृत्तोपसम्पन्नाः सन्तः स्वर्गनिवासिनः॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said Beholding the presence of Rama, your valiant son Duryodhana of mighty arms, desirous of battle, was gladdened.

Sanskrit Shloka: वेदोक्तः परमो धर्मो धर्मशास्त्रेषु चापरः। शिष्टाचारश्च शिष्टानां त्रिविधं धर्मलक्षणम्।
English Translation: Seeing Vala, king Yudhishthira, O Bharata, stood up and duly and gladly honored him. He gave him a seat and enquired after his welfare.

Sanskrit Shloka: धारणं चापि विद्यानां तीर्थानामवगाहनम्॥ क्षमा सत्यार्जवं शौचं सतामाचारदर्शनम्।
English Translation: Rama then answered Yudhisthira, in these sweet and righteous words, viz.-I have heard it said by the Rishis, O best of kings, that Kurukshetra is a highly sacred and sindestroying spot, equal to heaven itself, worshipped of gods and Rishis and great Brahmanas.

Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वभूतदयावन्तो अहिंसानिरताः सदा॥ परुषं च न भाषन्ते सदा सन्तो द्विजप्रियाः।
English Translation: Those men that renounce their bodies, while engaged in battle on this field, are sure to live in heaven with Shakra himself.

Sanskrit Shloka: शुभानामशुभानां च कर्मणां फलसंचये॥ विपाकमभिजानन्ति ते शिष्टाः शिष्टसम्मताः। न्यायोपेता गुणोपेताः सर्वलोकहितैषिणः॥ सन्तः स्वर्गजितः शुक्लाः संनिविष्टाश्च सत्पथे।

Sanskrit Shloka: दातारः संविभक्तारो दीनानुग्रहकारिणः॥ सर्वपूज्याः श्रुतधनास्तथैव च तपस्विनः। सर्वभूतदयावन्तस्ते शिष्टाः शिष्टसम्मताः॥

Sanskrit Shloka: दानशिष्टाः सुखाँल्लोकानाप्नुवन्तीह च श्रियम्। पीडया च कलत्रस्य भृत्यानां च समाहिताः॥ अतिशक्त्या प्रयच्छन्ति सन्त: सद्भिः समागताः। लोकयात्रां च पश्यन्तो धर्ममात्महितानि च॥

Sanskrit Shloka: एवं सन्तो वर्तमानास्त्वेधन्ते शाश्वतीः समाः। अहिंसा सत्यवचनमानृशंस्यमथार्जवम्॥ अद्रोहो नाभिमानश्च ह्रीस्तितिक्षा दमः शमः। धीमन्तो धृतिमन्तश्च भूतानामनुकम्पकाः॥ अकामद्वेषसंयुक्तास्ते सन्तो लोकसाक्षिणः।

Sanskrit Shloka: त्रीण्येव तु पदान्याहुः सतां व्रतमनुत्तमम्॥ न चैव दुह्येद् दद्याच्च सत्यं चैव सदा वदेत्।
English Translation: While going thus, armed with mace and clad in armour, the celestial in the sky applauded him, saying-Excellent, excellent! Sanskrit Shloka: सर्वत्र च दयावन्तः सन्तः करुणवेदिनः॥ गच्छन्तीह सुसंतुष्टा धर्मपन्थानमुत्तमम्। शिष्टाचाराः महात्मानो येषां धर्मः सुनिश्चितः॥
English Translation: Proceeding with face westwards to the appointed spot, with your son (in their midst), they spread themselves on all sides when they reached it.

Sanskrit Shloka: अनसूया क्षमा शान्तिः संतोष: प्रियवादिता। कामक्रोधपरित्याग: शिष्टाचारनिषेवणम्॥ कर्म च श्रुतसम्पन्नं सतां मार्गमनुत्तमम्।
English Translation: That was an excellent Tirtha on the southern side of the Sarasvati. The ground there was not sandy, and was therefore, selected for the battle.

Sanskrit Shloka: शिष्टाचार निषेवन्ते नित्यं धर्ममनुव्रताः॥ प्रज्ञाप्रासादमारुह्य मुच्यन्ते महतो भयात्। प्रेक्षन्तो लोकवृत्तानि विविधानि द्विजोत्तम॥ अतिपुण्यानि पापानि तानि द्विजवरोत्तम।

Sanskrit Shloka: एतत् ते सर्वमाख्यातं यथाप्रज्ञं यथाश्रुतम्। शिष्टाचारगुणं ब्रह्मन् पुरस्कृत्य द्विजर्षभ॥
English Translation: With head-gear on his head, and wearing a golden armour licking the corners of his mouth, O king, with eyes redened in wrath, and breathing hard, your son on that field, O king, shone like the golden Sumeru.

English Translation: O king! In the midst of war-field both the brothers, foremost among the men were looked like a rising moon and the sun.

Sanskrit Shloka: तस्यार्थेऽपत्यमीहेत येन न्यायेन शक्नुयात्। न तस्मान्मन्त्रवत्कार्यं कश्चित् कुर्वीत किंचन॥

Sanskrit Shloka: स्वयंवृतेन साऽऽज्ञप्ता पित्रा वै प्रत्यपद्यता तत् तस्यान्ये प्रशंसन्ति धर्मज्ञा नेतरे जनाः॥

Sanskrit Shloka: अस्मिन्नेव प्रकरणे सुक्रतुर्वाक्यमब्रवीत्। नप्ता विदेहराजस्य जनकस्य महात्मनः॥
English Translation: Duryodhana and Bhima, with uplifted maces, shone in that battle like two mountains with tall sumınits.

Sanskrit Shloka: असदाचरिते मार्गे कथं स्यादनुकीर्तनम्। अत्र प्रश्नः संशयो वा सतामेवमुपालभेत्॥
English Translation: Both of them were highly worked up with anger; both were possessed of awful prowess; in mace encounter both were disciples of Rohini's intelligent son; both resembled each other in their feat and looked like Maya and Vasava. ---
Sanskrit Shloka: असदेव हि धर्मस्य प्रदानं धर्म आसुरः। नानुशुश्रुम जात्वेतामिमां पूर्वेषु कर्मसु॥

Sanskrit Shloka: भार्यापत्योर्हि सम्बन्धः स्त्रीपुंसोः स्वल्प एव तु। रतिः साधारणो धर्म इति चाह स पार्थिवः॥
English Translation: Those two of foes appeared like Kala and Mrityu. Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच अथ केन प्रमाणेन पुंसामादीयते धनम्। पुत्रवद्धि पितुस्तस्य कन्या भवितुमर्हति॥
English Translation: Those two chastisers of foes looked angrily upon each other. Both were foremost of Bharata's race, endued with great prowess.

Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच यथैवात्मा तथा पुत्रः पुत्रेण दुहिता समा। तस्यामात्मनि तिष्ठन्त्यां कथमन्यो धनं हरेत्॥
English Translation: In mace encounters those two scorchers of foes were invincible like lion. Those heroes were unbearable like two tigers having teeth and claws. They were like two uncrossable and furious oceans, or like two angry Suns risen for consuming everything. Those two great and powerful heroes, both possessed of great effulgence, looked like two Suns risen at the hour of the Universal dissolution.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मातुश्च यौतकं यत् स्यात् कुमारीभाग एव सः। दौहित्र एव तद् रिक्थमपुत्रस्य पितुर्हरेत्॥
English Translation: Looking like two enraged tigers or like two roaring masses of clouds, they became glad like two manned lions. Like two angry or two blazing fires, those two great ones appeared like two mountains with tall summits. Sanskrit Shloka: ददाति हि स पिण्डान् वै पितुर्मातामहस्य च। पुत्रदौहित्रयोरेव विशेषो नास्ति धर्मतः॥

English Translation: Having addressed each other with unpleasant words, those two heroes of Kuru's race stood, looking angrily upon each other, like Shakra and Vritra in fight."

Sanskrit Shloka: यद्यप्याचरित: कैश्चिन्नैष धर्मः सनातनः। अन्येषामपि दृश्यन्ते लोकतः सम्प्रवृत्तयः॥

Sanskrit Shloka: अन्योऽप्यथ न विक्रेयो मनुष्यः किं पुनः प्रजाः। अधर्ममूलैर्हि धनैस्तैर्न धर्मोऽथ कश्चन॥

Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच समागतान् वेदविदो राज्ञश्च पृथिवीश्वरान्। दृष्ट्वा युधिष्ठिरो राजा भीमसेनमभाषत॥ उपयाता नरव्याघ्रा य एते पृथिवीश्वराः एतेषां क्रियतां पूजा पूजार्हा हि नराधिपाः॥
English Translation: It has been heard by us that the sacred hermitage of Rishi Vishvasrava stood there and there the lord of wealth, Kubera, having man as his vehicle, was born.

Sanskrit Shloka: इत्युक्तः स तथा चक्रे नरेन्द्रेण यशस्विना। भीमसेनो महातेजा यमाभ्यां सह पाण्डवः॥
English Translation: There is also that foremost of hills, the sacred and auspicious Vaidurya mountain, which is always abounding in trees that are green and that are always adorned with flowers and fruits.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथाभ्यगच्छद्गोविन्दो वृष्णिभिः सह धर्मजम्। बलदेवं पुरस्कृत्य सर्वप्राणभृतां वरः॥
English Translation: O ruler of men, O great king, on the top of the mountain there is a sacred lake adorned with full blossomed lotuses and frequented by the celestials and the Gandharvas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युयुधानेन सहितः प्रद्युम्नेन गदेन च। निशठेनाथ साम्बेन तथैव कृतवर्मणा।॥
English Translation: O great king, many wonders are to be seen on that sacred mountain which is like heaven itself and which is visited by the celestials Rishis.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषामपि परां पूजां चक्रे भीमो महारथः। विविशुस्ते च वेश्मानि रत्नवन्ति च सर्वशः॥
English Translation: O king, O conqueror of hostile cities, there is the sacred river called Vishvamitra belonging to the royal sage of that name and which abounds in many sacred Tirthas. It was on the banks of this river, the son of Nahusha, Yayati, fell (from heaven) among the pious and obtained again the eternal region of the virtuous.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिरसमीपे तु कथान्ते मधुसूदनः। अर्जुनं कथयामास बहुसंग्रामकर्षितम्॥
English Translation: There is also the sacred lake known by the name of Punya, the mountain called Mainaka and that other mountain called Asita abounding in fruits and roots.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तं पप्रच्छ कौन्तेयः पुनः पुनररिंदमम्। धर्मजः शक्रजं जिष्णुं समाचष्ट जगत्पतिः॥
English Translation: O Yudhishthira, O son of Pandu, there is also the sacred hermitage of Kakshasena and also the hermitage of Chyavana known every where.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आगमद् द्वारकावासी ममाप्तः पुरुषो नृप। योऽद्राक्षीत् पाण्डवश्रेष्ठ बहुसंग्रामकर्षितम्॥
English Translation: O lord, here men obtain success in their asceticism with less austerities. O great king, here also is Jambumarga, the herinitage of Rishis of subdued soul. O foremost of selfcontrolled men, the hermitage is frequented by birds and deer.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: समीपे च महाबाहुपाचष्ट च मम प्रभो। कुरु कार्याणि कौन्तेय हयमेधार्थसिद्धये॥
English Translation: O king, there is the very sacred and ascetic surrounded, Ketumela, Medhaya also Gangadvara and the celebrated forest of Saindhava, frequented by the Brahmanas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्युक्तः प्रत्युवाचैनं धर्मराजो युधिष्ठिरः। दिष्ट्या स कुशली जिष्णुरुपायाति च माधव॥
English Translation: Then there is the sacred lake of the Grandsire, known by the name of Pushkara, the favourite hermitage of Valkhilyas, the Siddhas and the Rishis.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदिदं संदिदेशास्मिन् पाण्डवानां बलाग्रणी: तदा ज्ञातुमिहेच्छामि भवता यदुनन्दन॥
English Translation: O foremost of Kurus, O best of all virtuous men, moved by the desire to get its shelter, the lord of creatures recited this verse at Pushkara.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्युक्तो धर्मराजेन वृष्ण्यन्धकपतिस्तदा। प्रोवाचेदं वचो वाग्मी धर्मात्मानं युधिष्ठिरम्॥ इदमाह महाराज पार्थवाक्यं स्मरन् नरः। वाच्यो युधिष्ठिरः कृष्ण काले वाक्यमिदं मम॥
English Translation: If a pure souled man wishes to go to the Pushkara even in his imagination, he is cleansed of all his sins and he rejoices in heaven.
Dhritarashtra said O Sanat-Sujata, what you have been saying regarding the attainment of emancipation and the origin of the universe is the best (discourse I have heard). Speak to me such words, (treating of subjects) rarely to be attained by men of desire, O you who have observed celibacy!
Sanat-Sujata said This supreme soul regarding which you ask me with such exaltation cannot be attained by him who is in a hurry. When the mind (desire) has been lost in the intellect (i.e. when intellect has gained a control over desire), the mind of man becomes indifferent to worldly things and this state is attainable only by asceticism.
Dhritarashtra said The true knowledge, that you are speaking of attainable by hard asceticism, is unborn in the mind and needs not any efforts for its manifestation and is manifested during the seeking of Brahma. How then can that immortality which is connected with a knowledge of the Supreme soul be obtained?
Sanat-Sujata said This true knowledge that is unborn is said to be undeveloped and is developed by asceticism. On obtaining the true knowledge, men leave this world. True knowledge is ever present in the old and eminent preceptors.
Dhritarashtra said That knowledge is capable of being gained by asceticism without difficulty. What sort of asceticism must be that? O Brahma, speak to me that.
Sanat-Sujata said Those who having entered into the dwelling of a preceptor and residing therein serve them and practice asceticism become Brahma himself, as it were; and casting off their bodies are united with Him.
Those who are in this world desirous of obtaining emancipation, subdue their desires. Those virtuous men get their souls separated from their body like a blade of grass from a marshy plot of ground.
The father and the mother, O Bharata, these two create the body; but the state gained from the instructions of the preceptor is sacred, free from death and without old age.
He (the preceptor) who discoursing on the Supreme Soul frees a man from untruth and distributes nectar should be regarded as father and mother. No injury should ever be done to him, knowing what he does.
A disciple should every day pay due respects to his preceptor and engage himself in study with a pure mind and concentrated attention. He should not be annoyed (at the humble and menial services he is called upon to perform) and not feel wrathful. This is the first step of asceticism.
He who gains knowledge (of his duties) by observing the duties of other disciples is said to observe the first step of the vow of asceticism.
What is agreeable to a preceptor should be done at the expense of life and wealth, by the mind, by actions or by speech. Doing this is said to be the second step.
A similar behaviour like that towards a preceptor should be adopted towards the preceptor's woke and the same should be done to his son. Doing this is said to be the second step.
Fully, appreciating what has been done to one's self by his preceptor and knowing the object thereof, a disciple should with exaltation in his heart think-I have been developed by him. This is the third step of asceticism.
A wise man should not remove himself (from the preceptor's abode) without requesting the preceptor; nor should he even speak or think “I do this” (i.e. I make this gift). This is the fourth step of asceticism.
A man obtains the object of the first step of asceticism by the aid of time (i.e. in due course), the second step by contact with the preceptor, the third by the energy of his own intellect and the next by discussion with others.
The effects of the practice of asceticism, which is made up of twelve constituent elements including righteousness and the effects of Angas and Balam (particular forms of asceticism) are said to be obtained by contact with the preceptor and by an earnest desire to know the Supreme Soul.
While in the position of a disciple, whatever wealth is earned should be given to the preceptor. It is by this means that he (the preceptor) earns his honest livelihood graced with many virtues. Such should also be the conduct of the preceptor's son.
With this rule of life one prospers in every way and obtains many sons and fame; to such a man, wealth is poured from all sides and to that place many people come for practicing asceticism.
By means of such asceticism, the gods attained their divine character and the wise Rishis of heavenly qualities attained to the regions of Brahma.
By this also did the beauty of the Gandharvas and Apsaras spring up; by such asceticism does the sun rise to make the day.
on These (i.e. Gandharvas, etc.) completion of their asceticism by this means attained to the state of the seekers of the Rasabheda (a fabulous gem supposed to grant every desire of the possessor) through the obtainment of the object of their desire.
He, who attached to austerities has recourse to asceticism and thereby purifies his body, comes to the condition of a child (free from passions, etc., characteristic of the old men) and that learned man in the end conquers death.
By pure work men obtain the perishable worlds, O Kshatriya-but that learned man, by means of his knowledge, obtains emancipation. There is no other path to emancipation.
Dhritarashtra said Of what form is the Supreme Soul, which is immortal and omnipresent and which the learned man sees in this world. Does he shine as white, red, black, blue or purple?
Sanat-Sujata said (The Supreme Soul) may appear as white, red, black, brown or like the sun; but its like is not to be met with in the earth, the sky, nor in the water of the sea.
It cannot be found among the stars, nor is it shut up in the lightning and its form cannot be seen among the clouds, nor in the air, nor among the gods, nor in the moon, nor in the sun,
Nor in the Rich, nor in the Yajush, nor in the Atharva, nor in the sacred Sama (Vedas). It is certain, O king, that it cannot be seen in the Rathantara, nor in the Barhadrath, nor in the great vows.
Incapable of being reached by our ignorance, even the king of Death, at the time of his end, is lost in it. Its form cannot be gazed at; it is like the edge of a razor and its form is like that of a high mountain.
It is the foundation of everything; it is nectar; it is the universe; it is vast and delightful. From it are born all creatures and there do they come to their end.
Having no duality, it is manifest in the form of the universe. Poets speak of it as having no change but in the language and form used for its description. That on which all this world stands-those who know this become immortal.
Bhishma said When they had passed away, I awoke. O Bharata; I was filled with great joy as I thought of the dream.
Then begin that mighty battle between him and me, O Bharata, which was wonderful and which made the hairs of all creatures stand on end.
Then Bhargava rained on me a shower of arrows, which I baffled by a (like) shower of arrows, O Bharata.
Thereupon he, of great asceticism, was greatly incensed and remembering what had happened the day before, he hurled, with anger, a dart at me,
Which was as hard as Indra's thunderbolt, was equal in effulgence, to the mace of Yama, (god of death) blazing like a flaming fire and licking as it were with its tongue, all quarters of the battle-field.
Then, O best among Kurus, it struck me on my shoulder, even then, O perpetuator of Kuru's race, like a lightning ranging in the sky.
Thus wondered by Rama, O red-eyed one of mighty arms, blood flowed freely like streams of red earth from a mountain.
Greatly incensed , I darted, at the son of Jamadagni, a deadly shaft, comparable to the poison of a serpent only.
That hero, the best of the twice-born, struck by it on the forehead, shone beautiful as a mountain with its peak.
Filled with great wrath he turned round, and drawing his bow with great strength aimed at me a terrible shaft, resembling death himself and capable of grinding all enemies.
That fierce shaft struck me on the breast hissing (through the air) like a serpent, and I fell down to the earth, O king, covered with blood.
Regaining my consciousness, I hurled at that intelligent son of Jamadagni a dart, bright and blazing as the lighting flesh.
That dart fell on the chest of that best of Brahmanas. And, O king, having fainted (from pain) he began to tremble all over.
Then his friend, that twice-born and great ascetic named Akritavrana, embraced him again and again and soothed him with words of auspicious import.
Thus comforted, Rama was filled with anger and vindictiveness, and that keeper of all observances brought forth a mighty weapon of Brahma.
Then, for the purpose of baffling also, I aimed the same excellent weapon of Brahma, which blazed forth, appearing like what happens at the end of the Yuga (at the final destruction).
Then those two Brahmic weapons met each other in mid-air, without being able to reach either Rama or myself, 0 best of Bharata's race.
Thereupon, in mid-welkin, only a flame blazed forth, and 0 lord of earth, all creatures becomes greatly afflicted,
The Rishis, and the gods together with the Gandharvas, 0 Bharata, became greatly afflicted, struck by the blazing effulgence.
Then the earth, with the mountains, forests and trees, began to tremble, and all creatures, becoming heated, became highly afflicted.
The firmament, О king, began to burn the ten points of the compass were filled with smoke. At that moment, those creatures that range the sky could not stay there.
While during this time all creatures, with the gods, the Asuras and Rakshasas began uttering exclamations of woe, O Bharata, “This is the time,” thought I and become desirous of shooting,
That weapon Prasvapa speedily, according to the words of command of the speakers of Brahma. And the Mantras also for using that weapon suddenly came to my mind.
Vaishampayana said : O descendant of Bharata, when the king thus addressed the sons of Pandu, the wickedminded Duryodhana became exceedingly happy. O best of the Bharata race, he summoned in private, Purochana and taking up his right hand, he thus spoke to that counsellor. O Purochana, this world, full of wealth, is mine. It is equally yours with me. (Therefore), you should protect it. I have no other more trustworthy supporter and counsellor than you with whom I can consult.
O sire, keep my counsel (a secret) and destroy my enemy by some clever device. Accomplish, what I ask you to do.
The Pandavas have been sent by Dhritarashtra to Varanavata. They will sport there in the festival at the command of Dhritarashtra.
Do that by with you can reach Varanavata this very day on a car drawn by swift asses.
Going there, erect a quadrangle palace at the outskirts of the city, (which should be) rich in materials and furniture. Guard it (also) well.
Use in it (in erecting that house,) hemp, resin and all other inflammable materials that are procurable.
Mixing a little earth with ghee, oil, fat and a large quantity of lac, plaster the wall with it.
Place carefully all over that house hemp, oil, ghee, lac and wood. In such a way that the Pandavas and other men may not even with scrutiny see them or conclude that it is made of inflammable materials. Erecting such a house and worshipping the Pandavas with great reverence, make them live in it with Kunti and all their friends.
Place there for the Pandavas seats, conveyances and beds of best workmanship, as ordered my father. Manage all this in a way so that none in the city of Varanavata may know it, till the end we have in view is accomplished.
Knowing that they are sleeping in that house in confidence and without fear, set fire to it, beginning from the gate.
The people will think that they have been burnt to death in that burning house; and therefore none will be able to blame us for the death of the Pandavas,
Purochana promised to that Kaurava (Duryodhana) to carry out all by saying, “Be it so and he then went (away) on a swift car drawn by asses.

Sanskrit Shloka: आगमिष्यन्ति राजानः सर्वे वै कौरवर्षभ। प्राप्तानां महतां पूजा कार्या ह्येतत् क्षमं हि नः॥
English Translation: O king, ever obedient to Duryodhana, he went without loss of time. Purochana did all that the prince said, (asked him to do).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्येतद्वचनाद् राजा विज्ञाप्यो मम मानद। यथा चात्ययिकं न स्याद् यदाहरणऽभवत्॥ कर्तुमर्हति तद राजा भवांश्चाप्यनुमन्यताम्। राजद्वषान्न नश्येयुरिमा राजन् पुनः प्रजाः॥
English Translation: Janamejaya said "Why is the current of the tirtha known as Vashishthapavaha so rapid? For why did the foremost of rivers carry away Vashishtha?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इदमन्यच्च कौन्तेय वचः स पुरुषोऽब्रवीत्। धनंजयस्य नृपते तन्मे निगदतः शृणु॥
English Translation: What, O lord, was the cause of the quarrel between Vashishtha and Vishvamitra? Asked by me, O you of great wisdom, tell me all this. I am never satiated with hearing your account.”
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उपायास्यति यज्ञं नो मणिपूरपतिर्नृपः। पुत्रो मम महातेजा दयितो बभ्रुवाहनः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said A great enemity arose between Vishvamitra and Vashishtha, O Bharata, on account of their rivalry regarding ascetic penances.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं भवान् मदपेश्चार्थ विधिवत् प्रतिपूजयेत्। स तु भक्तोऽनुरक्तश्च मम नित्यमिति प्रभो॥
English Translation: The hermitage of Vashishtha was in the tirtha called Sthanu on the eastern bank of the Sarasvati. On the opposite bank was the hermitage of the intelligent Vishvamitra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्येतद् वचनं श्रुत्वा धर्मराजो युधिष्ठिरः। आभनन्द्यास्य तद् वाक्यमिदं वचनमब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: There, in that tirtha, O king, Mahadeva had practised the hardest penances. Sages still speak of those penances.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पराशर उवाच कः कस्य चोपकुरुते कश्च कस्मै प्रयच्छति। प्राणी करोत्ययं कर्म सर्वमात्मार्थमात्मना॥
English Translation: Having performed a sacrifice there and adored the river Sarasvati, Sthanu established that tirtha there. Therefore it is known by the name Sthanu-tirtha, O lord.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गौरवेण परित्यक्तं निःस्नेहं परिवर्जयेत्। सोदर्यं भ्रातरमपि किमुतान्यं पृथग्जनम्॥
English Translation: In that tirtha, the celestials had, formerly, ) king, appointed Skanda, that destroyer of the enemies of the celestials, as the generalissimo of their army.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विशिष्टस्य विशिष्टाच्च तुल्यौ दानप्रतिग्रहौ। तयोः पुण्यतरं दानं तद् द्विजस्य प्रयच्छतः॥
English Translation: The great Rishi Vishvamitra, by the help of his austere penances, brought Vashishtha, to that tirtha of the Sarasvati, listen to that account.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न्यायागतं धनं चैव न्यायेनैव विवर्धितम्। संरक्ष्यं यत्नमास्थाय धर्मार्थमिति निश्चयः॥
English Translation: The two ascetics Vishvamitra and Vashishtha, O Bharata, competed keenly with each other in respect of superiority of their penances.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न धर्मार्थी नृशंसेन कर्मणा धनमर्जयेत्। शक्तितः सर्वकार्याणि कुर्यान्नर्द्धिमनुस्मरेत्॥
English Translation: Being jealous of the power of Vashishtha, the great Muni Vishvamitra began to think seriously.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अपो हि प्रयतः शीतास्तापिता ज्वलनेन वा। शक्तितोऽतिथये दत्त्वा क्षुधार्तायाश्नुते फलम्॥
English Translation: Thought devoted to the performance of his duties, O Bharata, he formed the resolution, viz., This Sarasvati shall speedily bring, by force of her current, that foremost of ascetics, viz., Vashishtha, to my presence. After he shall have been brought hither, I shall forsooth kill that greatest of ascetics.

Sanskrit Shloka: रन्तिदेवेन लोकेष्टा सिद्धिः प्राप्ता महात्मना। फलपत्रैरथो मूलैर्मुनीनर्चितवांश्च सः॥
English Translation: Having formed this resolution, the illustrious and great Rishi Vishvamitra, with eyes red in ire, thought of that foremost of rivers.

Sanskrit Shloka: तैरेव फलपत्रैश्च स माठरमतोषयत्। तस्माल्लेभे परं स्थानं शैब्योऽपि पृथिवीपतिः॥
English Translation: Thus remembered by the ascetic, she became exceedingly agitated. The fair lady, repaired to that energetic and wrathful Rishi.

Sanskrit Shloka: देवतातिथिभृत्येभ्यः पितृभ्यश्चात्मनस्तथा। ऋणवान् जायते मर्त्यस्तस्मादनृणतां व्रजेत्॥
English Translation: Pale and trembling, Sarasvati, with clasped hands, appeared before that best of sages.

Sanskrit Shloka: स्वाध्यायेन महर्षिभ्यो देवेभ्यो यज्ञकर्मणा। पितृभ्यः श्राद्धदानेन नृणामभ्यर्चनेन च॥
English Translation: Indeed, the lady was greatly afflicted with sorrow, even like a woman who has lost her powerful husband. And she said to that best of sages-"Tell me what I can do for you.'

Sanskrit Shloka: वाचा शेषावहार्येण पालनेनात्मनोऽपि च। यथावद् भृत्यवर्गस्य चिकीत् कर्म आदितः॥
English Translation: Filled with ire, the ascetic said her-Bring here Vashishtha without delay, so that I my kill him.' Hearing these words, the river became agitated.

Sanskrit Shloka: प्रयत्नेन च संसिद्धा धनैरपि विवर्जिताः। सम्यग्घुत्वा हुतवहं मुनयः सिद्धिमागताः॥
English Translation: With clasped hands the lotus-eyed lady began to tremble in fear, like a creeper shaken by the wind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विश्वामित्रस्य पुत्रत्वमृचीकतनयोऽगमत्। ऋग्भिः स्तुत्वा महाबाहो देवान् वै यज्ञभागिनः॥
English Translation: Beholding the great river in that condition, the ascetic said to her-"Bring Vashishtha before me without any scruple.'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गतः शुक्रत्वमुशना देवदेवप्रसादनात्। देवीं स्तुत्वा तु गगने मोदते यशसा वृतः॥
English Translation: Hearing these words of his and knowing the evil he meant and acquainted also with the matchless power of Vashishtha she went to Vashishtha and informed him of what the intelligent Vishvamitra had said to her.

Sanskrit Shloka: असितो देवलश्चैव तथा नारदपर्वतौ। कक्षीवान् जामदग्न्यश्च रामस्ताण्ड्यस्तथाऽऽत्मवान्।। वसिष्ठो जमदग्निश्च विश्वामित्रोऽत्रिरेव च। भरद्वाजो हरिश्मश्रुः कुण्डधारः श्रुतश्रवाः॥ एते महर्षयः स्तुत्वा विष्णुमृग्भिः समाहिताः। लेभिरे तपसा सिद्धिं प्रसादात् तस्य धीमतः॥
English Translation: Fearing the course of both, she trembled again and again. Indeed, she stood in fear of both.

Sanskrit Shloka: अनश्चिाहतां प्राप्ताः सन्तः स्तुत्वा तमेव ह। न तु वृद्धिमिहान्विच्छेत् कर्म कृत्वा जुगुप्सितम्॥
English Translation: Seeing her pale and anxious, the righteous Vashishtha, that foremost of men, O king, said to her.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: येऽर्था धर्मेण ते सत्या येऽधर्मेण धिगस्तु तान्। धर्मं वै शाश्वतं लोके न जह्याद् धनकाझ्या॥
English Translation: Vashishtha said O foremost of rivers, save yourself, O you of rapid current, bear me away, otherwise Vishvamitra will curse you! Do not feel the least scruple.'

Sanskrit Shloka: आहिताग्निर्हि धर्मात्मा यः स पुण्यकृदुत्तमः। वेदा हि सर्वे राजेन्द्र स्थितास्त्रिष्वग्निषु प्रभो॥
English Translation: Hearing these words of that compassionate Rishi, the river began to think, O Kuru-chief, as to what she should do.

Sanskrit Shloka: स चाप्यग्न्याहितो विप्रः क्रिया यस्य न हीयते। श्रेयो ह्यनाहिताग्नित्वमग्निहोत्रं न निष्क्रियम्॥
English Translation: The thought Vashishtha shows great mercy for me. It is proper for me that I should serve him.'

Sanskrit Shloka: अग्निरात्मा च माता च पिता जनयिता तथा। गुरुश्च नरशार्दूल परिचर्या यथातथम्॥
English Translation: Seeing then that best of Rishis, viz., Vashishtha engaged in silent recitation of Mantras on her bank and seeing Kushika's son Vishvamitra also engaged in homa, Sarasvati thought, this is my opportunity.' Sanskrit Shloka: मानं त्यक्त्वा यो नरो वृद्धसेवी विद्वान् क्लीबः पश्यति प्रीतियोगात्। दाक्ष्येण हीनो धर्मयुक्तो नदान्तो लोकेऽस्मिन् वै पूज्यते सद्भिरार्यः॥

Sanskrit Shloka: लोमहर्षणपुत्र उग्रश्रवाः पौराणिको नैमिषारण्ये शौनकस्य कुलपतेादशवार्षिक सत्रे ऋषीनभ्यागतानुपतस्थे॥
English Translation: Passing through the sky, O Goddess, thou impartest thy waters to the clouds! All the waters are thee! Through thee we exercise our thinking faculties!

Sanskrit Shloka: पौराणिकः पुराणे कृतश्रमः स कृताञ्जलिस्तानुवाच। किं भवन्तः श्रोतुमिच्छन्ति किमहं ब्रवाणीति॥
English Translation: Thou art Pushti and Dyuti, Kiriti and Siddhi and Uma! Thou art Speech and thou art Svaha! This entire universe depends on thee. Thou dwellest in all creatures, in four forms."

Sanskrit Shloka: तमृषयः ऊचुः परमं लोमहर्षणे वक्ष्यामस्त्वां नः प्रतिवक्ष्यसि वचः शुश्रूषतां कथायोगं न: कथायोगे॥
English Translation: Thus lauded by that great Rishi, Sarasvati, O king, speedily bore that Brahmana towards the hermitage of Vishvamitra and repeatedly announced to the latter the arrival of the former.

Sanskrit Shloka: तत्र भगवान् कुलपतिस्तु मध्यास्ते॥
English Translation: Seeing Vashishtha thus brought before him by Sarasvati, Vishvamitra, worked up with ire, began to look for a weapon where with to kill that Brahmana.

Sanskrit Shloka: योऽसौ दिव्या:कथा वेद देवतासुरसंश्रिताः। मनुष्योरगगन्धर्वकथा वेद च सर्वशः॥
English Translation: Seeing him wrathful, the river, fearing to behold a Brahmana's slaughter, quickly bore Vashishtha away to her eastern bank once more. She thus had obeyed the words of both, although she deceived Vishvamitra by her act.

Sanskrit Shloka: स चाप्यस्मिन्मखे सौते विद्वान् कुलपतिर्द्विजः। दक्षोधृतव्रतो धीमान् शास्त्रे चारण्यके गुरुः॥

Sanskrit Shloka: सत्यवादी शमपरस्तपस्वी नियतव्रतः। सर्वेषामेव नो मान्यः स तावत्प्रतिपाल्यताम्॥
English Translation: Since, O best of rivers, thou hast gone away and deceived me, let thy current be changed into blood liked of Rakshasas!'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मिन्नध्यासति गुरावासनं परमार्चितम्। ततो वक्ष्यसि यत्त्वां स प्रक्ष्यति द्विजसत्तमः॥
English Translation: Thus cursed by the intelligent Vishvamitra, Sarasvati flowed for a whole year, bearing blood mixed with water.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सौतिरुवाच एवमस्तु गुरौ तस्मिन्नुपविष्टे महात्मनि। तेन पृष्टः कथा: पुण्या वक्ष्यामि विविधाश्रयाः॥
English Translation: Beholding the Sarasvati in that plights the gods, the Gandharvas and the Apsaras became filled with great sorrow.

Sanskrit Shloka: सोऽथ विप्रर्षभः सर्वं कृत्वा कार्यं यथाविधि। देवान्वाग्भिः पितॄनद्भिस्तर्पयित्वाजगाम ह। यत्र ब्रह्मर्षयः सिद्धाः सुखासीना धृतव्रताः। यज्ञायतनमाश्रित्य सूतपुत्रपुरःसराः॥
English Translation: For this reason, O king, the tirtha passed by the name of Vashishthapavaha on Earth. The best of rivers, however, once more regained her own proper condition.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ऋत्विक्ष्वथ सदस्येषु स वै गृहपतिस्तदा। उपविष्टेषूपविष्टः शौनकोऽथाब्रवीदिदम्॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said Then those foremost of men, shorn of anger and jealousy and purged of every sin, met with another, according to those high and auspicious ordinances which have been laid down by regenerate Rishis. ---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच आददानस्तु शूराणामायूंष्यभवदार्जुनिः। अन्तकः सर्वभूतानां प्राणान् काल इवागते॥
English Translation: Son met with father or mother, wives with husbands, brother with brother, and friend with friend, O king.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स शक्र इव विक्रान्तः शक्रसूनोः सुतो बली। अभिमन्युस्तदानीकं लोडयन् समदृश्यत॥
English Translation: The Pandavas full of joy, inet with the powerful bowman Karna as also with the son of Subhadra, and the children of Draupadi.

English Translation: With pleased hearts the son of Pandu approached Karna, O king, and became reconciled with him.

Sanskrit Shloka: सत्यवसि चाक्षिसे त्वरमाणा महारथाः। प्रगृह्य विपुलं शस्त्रमभिमन्युमुपाद्रवन्॥
English Translation: All those warriors, O chief of Bharata's race, meeting with one another through the favour of the great ascetic, became reconciled with one another.
