Sanskrit Shloka: अहं पूर्वमहं पूर्वमिति क्षत्रियपुङ्गवाः। स्वर्धमानाः समाजग्मुर्जिघांसन्तोऽर्जुनात्मजम्॥

Sanskrit Shloka: क्षत्रियाणामनीकानि प्रदुतान्यभिधावताम्। जग्रास तिमिरासाद्य क्षुद्रमत्स्यानिवार्णवे॥
English Translation: Indeed, the Kshatriya warriors, on account of the happiness they experienced, considered that place as Heaven itself. Indeed, that foremost of ascetics dismissed that collection of warriors.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ये केचन गतास्तस्य समीपमपलायिनः। न ते प्रतिन्यवर्तन्त समुद्रादिव सिन्धवः॥
English Translation: Within the twinkling of an eye that large crowd disappeared in the very sight of all those persons. Some went to the regions of the gods, some to the region of Brahman, some to the region of Varuna, and some to the region of Kubera. Some among those kings went to the region of Surya.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महाग्राहगृहीतेव वातवेगभयार्दिता। समकम्पत सा सेना विभ्रष्टा नौरिवार्णवे॥
English Translation: Amongst the Rakshasas and Pishachas, some proceeded to the country of the UttaraKurus. Others, moving delightfully, went in the company of the celestials.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ रुक्मरथो नाम मद्रेश्वरसुतो बली। त्रस्तामाश्वासयन् सेनामत्रस्तो वाक्यमब्रवीत्॥
English Translation: Thus did all those great persons disappear with their vehicles and animals and with all their followers. After all of them had departed, the great sage, who was standing in the waters of the sacred rivers, viz., Vyasa of great virtue and energy, that benefactor of the Kurus, then addressed those Kshatriya ladies who had become windows, and said these words, 'Let those amongst these foremost of women who are desirous of attaining to the regions acquired by their husbands cast away all idleness and quickly plunge into the sacred Bhagirathi. Hearing these words of his, those foremost ladies, placing faith in them, took the permission of their father-in-law and then plunged into the waters of the Bhagirathi.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अलं त्रासेन वः शूरा नैष कश्चिन्मयि स्थिते। महमेनं ग्रहीष्यामि जीवग्राहं न संशयः॥
English Translation: Freed from human bodies, those chaste ladies then went, O king, with their husbands to the regions acquired by the latter.

Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्त्वा तु सौभद्रमभिदुद्राव वीर्यवान्। सुकल्पितेनोह्यमानः स्यन्दनेन विराजता॥

Sanskrit Shloka: सौऽभिमन्यु त्रिभिर्बाणैर्विद्ध्वा वक्षस्यथानदत्। त्रिभिश्च दक्षिणे बाहौ सव्ये च निशितैस्त्रिभिः॥

English Translation: Devoted to the duties of piety, Vyasa, at that time, becoming a giver of boons, granted to all the men there collected the fruition of the desires they respectively cherished.

Sanskrit Shloka: संग्रामदुर्मदा राजन् राजपुत्राः प्रहारिणः। वयस्याः शल्यपुत्रस्य सुवर्णविकृतध्वजाः॥
English Translation: People of various kingdoms hearing of this meeting between the hallowed dead and living human beings, became highly pleased.

Sanskrit Shloka: तालमात्राणि चापानि विकर्षन्तो महाबलाः। आर्जुनि शरवर्षेण समन्तात् पर्यवारयन्॥
English Translation: That man who duly listens to this discourse meets with everything that is dear to him. Indeed, he obtains all agreeable objects both in this world and in the next.

Sanskrit Shloka: शूरैः शिक्षाबलोपेतैस्तरुणैरत्यमर्षणैः। दृष्टिकं समरे शूरं सौभद्रमपराजितम्॥ छाद्यमानं शरव्रातैइष्टो दुर्योधनोऽभवत्। वैवस्वतस्य भवनं गतं ह्येनममन्यत॥
English Translation: That man of learning and science that foremost of pious persons, who recites this narrative for the hearing of others wins great fame here and an auspicious end hereafter, as also a union with kinsmen and all desirable objects. Such a man has not to work hard for his maintenance and meets with all sorts of auspicious objects in life. These are the rewards reaped by a person who gifted with devotion to Vedic studies and with penances, recites this narrative in the hearing of others.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सुवर्णपुङरिषुभिर्नानालिङ्गैः सुतेजनैः। अदृश्यमार्जुनिं चक्रुर्निमेषात् ते नृपात्मजाः॥
English Translation: Those persons who endued with good conduct, devoted to self-control, purged of all sins by the gifts they make, endued with sincerity, having tranquil souls, freed from falsehood and the desire of injuring others, adorned with faith, belief in the scriptures, and intelligence, listen to this wonderful book, surely attain to the highest end hereafter.

Sanskrit Shloka: सूताश्वध्वजं तस्य स्यन्दनं तं च मारिष। आचितं समपश्याम श्वाविधं शललैरिव॥

Sanskrit Shloka: स गाढविद्धः क्रुद्धश्च तोत्रैर्गज इवादितः। गान्धर्वमस्त्रमायच्छद् रथमायां च भारत॥

---
Sanskrit Shloka: स वायुर्वरुणश्चैव स रविः स च चन्द्रमाः। सोऽग्निस्तपति भूतानि जलं च स भवत्युत॥
English Translation: He grows with truth, self-respect, tranquillity of heat, mercy, and gifts. He is always engaged in penances, and is eternal.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं बलिं नाधिगच्छामि ब्रह्मन्नाचक्ष्व मे बलिम्। स एव ह्यस्तमयते स स्म विद्योतते दिशः॥ स वर्षति स्म वर्षाणि यथाकालमतन्द्रितः। तं बलिं नाधिगच्छामि ब्रह्मन्नाचक्ष्व मे बलिम्॥
English Translation: From that deity of Virtue, through YogaPower, the Kuru king Yudhishthria also took his birth. Yudhishthira, therefore, O king, is Dharma of great wisdom and immeasurable intelligence.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्रह्मोवाच नैतत् ते साधु मघवन् यदेनमनुपृच्छसि। पृष्टस्तु नानृतं ब्रूयात् तस्माद् वक्ष्यामि ते बलिम्॥
English Translation: Dharma exists both in this world and in the next, and is like fire or wind or water or earth or space.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उष्टेषु यदि वा गोषु खरेष्वश्वेषु वा पुनः। वरिष्ठो भविता जन्तुः शून्यागारे शचीपते॥
English Translation: He is, o king of kings, capable of going everywhere and exists, pervading the entire universe. He is capable of being seen by only those who are the foremost of the deities and those who are purged of every sin and crowned with ascetic success.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शक्र उवाच यदि स्म बलिना ब्रह्मशून्यागारे समेयिवान्। हन्यामेनं न वा हन्यां तद् ब्रह्मन्ननुशाधि माम्॥
English Translation: He who is Dharma, is Vidura and he who is Vidura is the (eldest) son of Pandu. That son of Pandu, O king, is capable of being perceived by you. He is before you as your servitor.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्रह्मोवाच मा स्म शक्र बलिं हिंसीन बलिर्वधमर्हति। न्यायस्तु शक्र प्रष्टव्यस्त्वया वासव काम्यया॥
English Translation: Gifted with great Yoga-Power, your highsouled brother, that foremost of intelligent men, seeing the high-souled Yudhishthira, the son of Kunti has entered into his body.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमुक्तो भगवता महेन्द्रः पृथिवीं तदा। चचारैरावतस्कन्धमधिरुह्य श्रिया वृतः॥
English Translation: O chief of Bharata's race, I shall unite you also with great benefit. Know, O son, that I am come here for removing your doubts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो ददर्श स बलिं खरवेषेण संवृतम्। यथाऽऽख्यातं भगवता शून्यागारकृतालयम्॥
English Translation: I shall show you some feat which has never been accomplished before by any of the great Rishis-some wonderful effect of my penances.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: शक्र उवाच खरयोनिमनुप्राप्तस्तुषभक्षोऽसि दानव। इयं ते योनिरधमा शोचस्याहो न शोचसि॥
English Translation: What object is that, O king, whose accomplishment you wish from me? Tell me what is that which you wish to see or ask or hear? O sinless one, I shall accomplish it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अदृष्टं बत पश्यामि द्विषतां वशामागतम्। श्रिया विहीनं मित्रैश्च भ्रष्टवीर्यपराक्रमम्॥
English Translation: Parashara said The lowest order, it is proper, should derive their maintenance from the three other orders. Such service, rendered with love and respect, makes them pious.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यत् तद् यानसहौस्त्वं ज्ञातिभिः परिवारितः। लोकान् प्रतापयन् सर्वान् यास्यस्मानवितर्कयन्॥
English Translation: If the ancestors of any Shudra were not engaged in service, he should not still engage himself in any other occupation. Truly, he should take up service as his occupation.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वन्मुखाश्चैव दैतेय व्यतिष्ठंस्त्व शासने। अकृष्टपच्या च मही तवैश्वर्ये बभूव ह॥
English Translation: In my opinion, it is proper for them to mix under all circumstances, with good men devoted to virtue, but never with the wicked.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इदं च तेऽद्य व्यसनं शोचस्याहो न शोचसि। यदाऽऽतिष्ठः समुद्रस्य पूर्वकूले विलेलिहन्॥
English Translation: As in the Eastern hills, jewels and metals blaze with greater effulgence on account of their nearness to the Sun, so the lowest order shines on account of their association with the good.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ज्ञातीन् विभजतो वित्तं तदाऽऽसीत् ते मनः कथम्। यत् ते सहस्रसमिता ननृतुर्देवयोषितः॥
English Translation: A piece of white cloth assumes that colour with which it is dyed. Such is the case with Shudras.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कथमद्य तदा चैव मनस्ते दानवेश्वर। छत्रं तवासीत् सुमहत् सौवर्णं रत्नभूषितम्॥
English Translation: Therefore, one should also attach him to all good qualities but never to bad qualities. The life of human beings in this world is fickle and transitory.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बहूनि वर्षपूगानि विहारे दीप्यतः श्रिया। सर्वाः पुष्करमालिन्यः सर्वाः काञ्चनसप्रभाः॥
English Translation: That wise man who, in happiness as also in misery, acquire only what is good, is considered as a true observer of the scriptures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ननृतुस्तत्र गन्धर्वाः षट् सहस्राणि सप्तधा। यूपस्तवासीत् सुमहान् यजतः सर्वकाशनः॥
English Translation: That man who is gifted with intelligence would never do an act which is alienated from virtue, however great may that advantages be of that act. Indeed, such an act is not considered as truly wholesome.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यत्राददः सहस्राणि अयुतानां गवां दश। अनन्तरं सहस्रेण तदाऽऽसीद् दैन्य का मतिः॥
English Translation: That lawless king who, taking thousands of kine from their lawful owners, gives them away acquires on fruit save an empty sound. On the other hand, he cominits the sin of theft.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदा च पृथिवीं सर्वां यजमानोऽनुपर्यगाः। शम्याक्षेपेण विधिना तदाऽऽसीत् किं तु ते हृदि॥ न ते पश्यामि भृङ्गारं न च्छत्रं व्यजने न च। ब्रह्मदत्तां च ते मालां न पश्याम्यसुराधिप॥
English Translation: The Self-create at first created the Being called Dhatri held in universal esteem. Dhatri created a son who was engaged in maintaining all the worlds.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बलिरुवाच न त्वं पश्यसि भृङ्गारं न च्छत्रं व्यजने न च। ब्रह्मदत्तां च मे मालां न त्वं द्रक्ष्यसि वासव॥
English Translation: Adoring that God, the Vaishya engages for the means of his support, in agriculture and the tending of cattle. The Kshatriyas should undertake the task of protecting all the other classes. The Brahmanas should only enjoy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: गुहायां निहितानि त्वं मम रत्नानि पृच्छसि। यदा मे भविता कालस्तदा त्वं यानि द्रक्ष्यसि॥
English Translation: As regards the Shudras, they should take up the task of humbly and honestly collecting together the articles that are to be offered in sacrifices, and in cleaning altars and other places where sacrifices are to be celebrated. If each order acts in this way, virtue would not suffer any decrease.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न त्वेतदनुरूपं ते यशसो वा कुलस्य च। समृद्धार्थोऽसमृद्धार्थं यन्मां कस्थितुमिच्छसि॥
English Translation: If virtue is preserved in its full, all creatures inhabiting the Earth would be happy, Seeing the happiness of all creatures on Earth, the gods in heaven become filled with gladness.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न हि दुःखेषु शोचन्ते न प्रहृष्यन्ति चर्धिषु। कृतप्रज्ञा ज्ञानतृप्ताः क्षान्ताः सन्तो मनीषिणः॥
English Translation: Hence, that king, who, according to the duties laid down for his order, protects the other classes, becomes worthy of respect. similarly, the Brahmana who is employed in studying the scriptures, the Vaishya who is engaged in acquiring riches, and the Shudra who is always engaged in serving the three other classes with rapt attention, become objects of reverence. By acting in other ways, O king, each order is said to deviate from virtue.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वं तु प्राकृतया बुद्ध्या पुरन्दर विकत्यसे। यदाहमिव भावी स्यास्तदा नैवं वदिष्यसि॥
English Translation: Keeping aside gifts by thousands, even twenty cowries that one may give painfully, having acquired them righteously, will yield great benefit.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वं तु प्राकृतया बुद्ध्या पुरन्दर विकत्यसे। यदाहमिव भावी स्यास्तदा नैवं वदिष्यसि॥
English Translation: Those persons, O king, who make gifts to Brahmanas after respecting them duly, reap excellent fruits proportionate to those gifts.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच ततो युधिष्ठिरो राजा प्रतिनन्द्य जनार्दनम्। उवाच परमप्रीतः कौन्तेयो देवकीसुतम्॥
English Translation: The gift is highly valued which the donor inakes after seeking out the done and respecting him properly. That gift is middling which the donor makes upon being prayed for it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कच्चिज्ज्ञानानि सर्वाणि प्रसन्नानि तवाच्युत॥
English Translation: That gift, however, which is made contemptuously and without any respect, is said to be very inferior. This is what the truthful sages say.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वासुदेवोऽपि तद्युक्तं पर्यपृच्छद् युधिष्ठिरम्। ततश्च प्रकृतीः क्षत्ता न्यवेदयदुपस्थिताः॥
English Translation: While sinking in this ocean of life, man should always try to cross that ocean by various means. Indeed, he should so exert himself that he might be released from the fetters of this world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनुज्ञातश्च राज्ञा स प्रावेशयत तं जनम्। विराटं भीमसेनं च धृष्टद्युम्नं च सात्यकिम्॥ चेदिपं धृष्टकेतुं च द्रुपदं च महारथम्। शिखण्डिनं यमो चैव चेकितानं सकेकयम्॥ युयुत्सुं चैव कौरव्यं पाञ्चाल्यं चोत्तमौजसम्। युधामन्युं सुबाहुं च द्रौपदेयांश्च सर्वशः॥
English Translation: The Brahmana shines by self-control; the Kshatriya by victory; the Vaishya by riches; while the Shudra always shines in glory through clever serving.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एते चान्ये च बहवः क्षत्रियाः क्षत्रियर्षभम्। उपतस्थुर्महात्मानं विविशुश्चासने शुभे॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said King Yudhishthira gifted with humility, once again asked the royal son of Shantanu on the subject of gifts of kine in full.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एकस्मिन्नासने वीरावुपविष्टौ महाबलौ। कृष्णश्च युयुधानश्च महात्मानौ महाद्युती॥
English Translation: The king said Do you, O Bharata, once more describe to me in full merits of giving away kine. Indeed, O hero, I have not been satiated with hearing your nectarlike words.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो युधिष्ठिरस्तेषां श्रृण्वतां मधुसूदनम्। अब्रवीत् पुण्डरीकाक्षमाभाष्य मधुरं वचः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said Thus accosted by king Yudhishthira the just, Shantanu's son began to describe to him once again, in full, the merits of the gift of kine.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एकं त्वां वयमाश्रित्य सहस्राक्षमिवामराः। प्रार्थमायो जयं युद्धे शाश्वतानि सुखानि च॥
English Translation: Bhishma said By giving to a Brahmana a cow having a calf, gifted with docility and other virtues, young in years and covered round with a piece of cloth, one is purged of all his sins.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वं हि राज्यविनाशं न द्विषद्भिश्चनिराक्रियाम्। क्लेशांश्च विविधान् कृष्ण सर्वांस्तानपि वेद नः॥
English Translation: There are many regions which have no sun. One who makes the gift of a cow has not to go there.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वयि सर्वेश सर्वेषामस्माकं भक्तवत्सल। सुखमायत्तमत्यर्थे यात्रा च मधुसूदन॥
English Translation: That man, however, who gives to a Brahmana a cow that cannot drink or eat, that has her milk dried up, that has weakened senses and that is diseased and overcome with decrepitude, and that may, therefore, be compared to a tank whose water has been dried upindeed, the man who gives such cow to a Brahmana and thereby inflicts only pain and disappointment upon him, has certainly to enter into dark Hell.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तथा कुरु वार्ष्णेय यथा त्वयि मनो मम। अर्जुनस्य यथा सत्या प्रतिज्ञा स्याच्चिकीर्षिता॥
English Translation: That cow which is wrathful and vicious, or diseased, or weak, or which has been brought without the price agreed upon having been paid, or which would only afflict the twiceborn recipient with distress and disappointment, should never be given. The regions such a man may acquire would not give him any happiness or energy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स भवांस्तारयत्वस्माद् दुःखामर्षमहार्णवात्। पारं तितीर्षतामद्य प्लवो नो भव माधव॥
English Translation: Only such kine as are strong, gifted with good behaviour, young in years, and possessed of odour, are highly spoken of by all. Indeed, as Ganga is the foremost of all rivers, so is a Kapila cow the foremost of all kine.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न हि तत् कुरुते संख्ये रथी रिपुवधोद्यतः। यथा वै कुरुते कृष्ण सारथिर्यलमास्थितः॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said Why, O grandfather, do the righteous highly speak of the gift of a Kapila cow when all good kine that are given away should be considered as equal? O you of great power, I wish to hear what the superiority is of a Kapila cow. You are indeed, competent to discourse to me on this subject.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यथैव सर्वास्वापत्सु पासि वृष्णीञ्जनार्दन। तथैवास्मान् महाबाहो वृजिनात् त्रातुमर्हसि॥
English Translation: Bhishma said I have, O son, heard old men recite this history about the circumstances under which the Kapila cow was created. I shall recite that old history to you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वमगाधेऽप्लवे मग्नान् पाण्डवान् कुरुसागरे। समुद्धर प्लवो भूत्वा शङ्खचक्रगदाधर॥
English Translation: Formerly the Selfcreate Brahman commanded the Rishi Daksha, saying, Do you create living creatures, For doing good to creatures, Daksha, first of all created food.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नमस्ते देवदेवेश सनातन विशातन। विष्णो जिष्णो हरे कृष्ण वैकुण्ठ पुरुषोत्तम॥
English Translation: As the deities live upon nectar, so all living creatures, O powerful one, live upon the food assigned by Daksha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नारदस्त्वां समाचख्यौ पुराणमृषिसत्तमम्। वरदं शाङ्गिणं श्रेष्ठं तत् सत्यं कुरु माधव॥
English Translation: Among all objects mobile and immobile, the mobile are superior. Among mobile creatures, Brahmanas are superior. The sacrifices are all set upon them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: इत्युक्तः पुण्डरीकाक्षो धर्मराजेन संसदि। तोयमेघस्वनो वाग्मी प्रत्युवाच युधिष्ठिरम्॥
English Translation: It is by sacrifice that Soma is got. Sacrifice has been fixed upon kine. The gods become pleased through sacrifices. The means of livelihood were created first, creatures came next.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वासुदेव उवाच सामरेष्वपि लोकेषु सर्वेषु न तथाविधः। शरासनधरः कश्चिद् यथा पार्थो धनजंयः॥
English Translation: As soon as creatures were born, they began to cry aloud for food. All of them then approached their creator who was to give them food, like children approaching their parents.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वीर्यवानस्त्रसम्पन्नः पराक्रान्तो महाबलः। युद्धशोण्डः सदामर्षी तेजसा परमो नृणाम्॥
English Translation: Approved of the desire of all his creatures, the holy lord of all creatures, viz., Daksha, for the sake of his creatures, himself drank a quantity of nectar.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स युवा वृषभस्कन्धो दीर्घबाहुर्महाबलः। सिंहर्षभगतिः श्रीमान् द्विषतस्ते हनिष्यति॥
English Translation: He became pleased with the nectar, he drank and thereupon an eructation came out, spreading an excellent odour all around. That cruciation, Daksha saw gave birth to a cow which he named Surabhi. This Surabhi was thus a daughter of his, that had come out of his inouth.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अहं च तत् करिष्यामि यथा कुन्तीसुतोऽर्जुनः। धार्तराष्ट्रस्य सैन्यानि धक्ष्यत्यग्निरिवेन्धनम्॥
English Translation: That cow called Surabhi gave birth to a number of daughters who became the mothers of the world. They were goldhued, and were all Kapilas. They were the means of livelihood for all crcatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अद्य तं पापकर्माणं क्षुद्रं सौभद्रघातिनम्। अपुनर्दर्शनं मार्गमिषुभिः क्षेप्स्यतेऽर्जुनः॥
English Translation: As those kine, whose complexion resembled that of nectar, began to pour milk, the forth of that inilk arose and began to spread on all sides as when the waves of a running river dashing against one another, sufficient froth is produced that spreads on all sides.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्याद्य गृध्राः श्येनाश्च चण्डगोमायवस्तथा। भक्षयिष्यन्ति मांसानि ये चान्ये पुरुषादकाः॥
English Translation: Some of that froth fell, from the mouths of the calves that were sucking, upon the head of Mahadeva who was then sitting on the Earth. The powerful Mahadeva thereupon, stricken with anger, looked at those kine.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यद्यस्य देवा गोप्तारः सेन्द्राः सर्वे तथाप्यसौ। राजधानी यमस्याद्य हतः प्राप्स्यति संकुले॥
English Translation: With that third eye of his which adorns his forehead, he seemed to burn those kine as he espied them. Like the Sun living masses of clouds with various colours, the energy that, came out from the third eye of Mahadeva produced, O king, various complexions in those kine. Those amongst them, however, which succeeded in escaping from the looks of Mahadeva by entering the region of Soma, remained of the same colour with which they were born, for no change was produced in their colour. Seeing that Mahadeva had become highly wroth, Daksha, the lord of all creatures, addressed him, saying, You have, O great deity, been drenched with nectar. The milk or the froth that escapes from the mouths of calves sucking their dams is never considered as impure. The Moon, after drinking the nectar, pours it once more. It is not, therefore, regarded as impure.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निहत्य सैन्धवं जिष्णुरद्य त्वामुपयास्यति। विशोको विज्वरो राजन् भव भूतिपुरस्कृतः॥
English Translation: Likewise, the milk that these kine give, being born of nectar, should not be considered as impure. The wind can never become impure. Fire can never become impure. Gold can never become impure. The Ocean can never become impure.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच यदिदं धर्मगहनं बुद्ध्या समनुगम्यते। तद्धि विस्तरतः सर्वं बुद्धिमार्ग प्रशंस मे॥
English Translation: The Nectar, even when drunk by the gods, can never become impure. Likewise, the milk of a cow, even when her udders are sucked by her calf, can never become impure. These kine will support all these worlds with the milk they will give and the clarified butter that will be inade from it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विदुर उवाच अत्र ते वर्तयिष्यामि नमस्कृत्वा स्वयंभुवे। यथा संसारगहनं वदन्ति परमर्षयः॥
English Translation: All creatures wish to enjoy the sacred wealth, at one with nectar, that kine possess. Having said these words, the lord of creatures, Daksha, made a present to Mahadeva of a bull with certain kine.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कश्चिन्महति कान्तारे वर्तमानो द्विजः किल। महद् दुर्गमनुप्राप्तो वनं क्रव्यादसंकुलम्॥
English Translation: Daksha pleased Rudra, O Bharata, with that present. Mahadeva, thus pleased, made that bull his career, And it was after the form of that bull that Mahadeva adopted the emblem on the standard floating on his battlecar. Therefore it is that Rudra came to be known as the bullbannered deity.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सिंहव्याघ्रगजौघैरतिघोरं महास्यनैः। पिशितादैरतिभयैर्महोग्राकृतिभिस्तथा॥ समन्तात् संपरिक्षिप्तं यत् स्म दृष्ट्वा त्रसेद् यमः।
English Translation: It was on that occasion also that the celestials, in a body, made Mahadeva the lord of animals. Indeed, the great Rudra became the Master of kine and is named as the bullemblemed deity.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तदस्य दृष्ट्वा हृदयमुद्वेगमगमत् परम्॥ अभ्युच्छयश्च रोम्णां वै विक्रियाच परंतप।
English Translation: Hence, O king, the gift of kine is considered as primarily desirable of Kapila kine which are endued with great energy and possessed of unchanged colour.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तद् वनं व्यनुसरन् सम्प्रधावन्नितस्ततः॥ वीक्षमाणो दिशः सर्वाः शरणं व भवेदिति।
English Translation: Thus are kine the foremost of all creatures in the world. It is from them that the food of all the worlds has emanated. They have Rudra for their lord. They yield (nectar) in the form of milk. They are auspicious and sacred, and grantors of every wish and givers of life. A person by making a gift of a cow is considered as making a gift of every article that is to be enjoyed by men.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स तेषां छिद्रमन्विच्छन् प्रद्रुतो भयपीडितः॥ न च निर्याति वै दूरं न वा तैर्विप्रमोच्यते।
English Translation: That who, wishing to acquire prosperity, reads with a pure heart and body these Verses on the origin of kine, becomes purged of all his sins and acquires prosperity and children and wealth and animals.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथापश्यद् वनं घोरं समन्ताद् वागरावृतम्॥ बाहुभ्यां सम्परिक्षिप्त स्त्रिया परमघोरया।
English Translation: man He who makes a gift of a cow. O king, always succeeds in winning the merits of gifts of Havya and Kavya, of the offer of oblations of water to the departed Manes, of religious acts whose performance brings peace and happiness, of the gift of vehicles and cloths, and of cherishing of children and the old.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पञ्चशीर्षधरै गैः शैलैरिव समुन्नतैः॥ नभःस्पृशैर्महावृक्षः परिक्षिप्तं महावनम्।
English Translation: Vaishampayana said Hearing these words of his grandfather, Pritha's son, viz., the royal Yudhishthira of Ajamidha's race, uniting with his brothers, began to make gifts of both bulls and kine of different colours to foremost of Brahmanas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वनमध्ये च तत्राभूदुदपानः समावृतः॥ वल्लीभिस्तृणछन्नाभिर्दूढाभिरभिसंवृतः।
English Translation: Indeed, for getting regions of felicity in the next, and acquiring great fame, king Yudhishthira celebrated many sacrifices and, as sacrificial presents, gave away hundreds of thousands of kine to such Brahmanas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पपात स द्विजस्तत्र निगूढे सलिलाशये।॥ विलग्नश्चाभवत् तस्मिन् लतासंतानसंकुले। पनसस्य यथा जातं वृन्तवद्धं महाफलम्॥ स तथा लम्बते तत्र रार्ध्वपादो ह्यधःशिराः।
English Translation: Jarasandha said I do not recollect when I have ever done you any injury. After careful reflection, I cannot recollect the injury I have done you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अथ तत्रापि चान्योऽस्य भूयो जात उपद्रवः॥ कूपमध्ये महानागमपश्यत महाबलम्।
English Translation: O Brahmanas, when I have never done you any harm, why do you consider me, who am innocent, as your enemy? Tell me truly, for this is the rule followed by the honest.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कूपवीनाहवेलायामपश्यत महागजम् ॥ षड्वक्त्रं कृष्णशुक्लं च द्विषट्कपदचारिणम्।
English Translation: If injury is done to one's Dharma and Artha, the mind feels pain. Even a great carwarrior, well versed in all the precepts of morality, gets the fate of sinners and falls off from prosperity, if he injures an innocent man.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: क्रमेण परिसर्पन्तं वल्लीवृक्षसमावृतम्॥ तस्य चापि प्रशाखासु वृक्षशाखावलम्बिनः। नानारूपा मधुकरा घोररूपा भयावहाः॥ आसते मधु संवृत्य पूर्वमेव निकेतजाः।
English Translation: For honest men the practices of the Kshatriyas are the best in the three worlds. The men that are learned in the precepts of virtue praise nothing else (then the practices of the Kshatriyas).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भूयो भूयः समीहन्ते मधूनि भरतर्षभ॥ स्वादनीयानि भूतानां यैर्बालो विप्रकृष्यते।
English Translation: I adhere to the practices of my order with a steadily soul. I never injure any of my subjects. In bringing this charge against me, it appears you speck in error.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत्रैव च मनुष्यस्य तेषां मधूनां बहुधा धारा प्रस्रवते तदा॥ आलम्बमानः स पुमान् धारां पिबति सर्वदा।
English Translation: Krishna said O mighty-armed (hero), there is one who upholds the dignity of a (royal) line. We have come against you at his command.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न चास्य तृष्णा विरता पिबमानस्य संकटे॥ अभीप्सति तदा नित्यमतृप्तः स पुनः पुनः।
English Translation: O king, the Kshatriyas of the world have been brought captive by you. Having done this cruel wrong, how do you consider yourself innocent?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न चास्य जीविते राजन् निर्वेदः समजायत॥ जीविताशा प्रतिष्ठिता। कृष्णाः श्वेताश्च तं वृक्षं कुट्टयन्ति च मूषिकाः॥
English Translation: O best of kings, how can a man, being a king himself, act cruelly against other virtuous kings? After persecuting them, you want to offer them as sacrifices to Rudra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: व्यालैश्च वनदुर्गान्ते स्त्रिया च परमोग्रया। कूपाधस्ताच नागेन वीनाहे कुञ्जरेण च॥ वृक्षप्रपाताच भयं मूषिकेभ्यश्च पञ्चमम्। मधुलोभान्मधुकरैः षष्ठमाहुर्महद् भयम्॥
English Translation: O son of Brihadratha, this sin, committed by you, may even touch us. We practise virtue, and we are capable of protecting virtue.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवं स वसते तत्र क्षिप्तः संसारसागरे। न चैव जीविताशायां निर्वेदमुपगच्छति॥
English Translation: The slaughter of human beings as sacrifice to the gods is never seen. Why do you then desire to sacrifice human beings to the god Sankara?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जनमेजय उवाच प्राप्य राज्यं महाबाहुर्धर्मपुत्रौ युधिष्ठिरः। यदन्यदकरोद् विप्र तन्मे वक्तुमिहार्हसि॥
English Translation: You are calling all men belonging to your own orders as beasts. O Jarasandha, foolish as you are, who else is capable of doing it?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भगवान् वा हृषीकेशस्त्रैलोक्यस्य परो गुरुः। ऋषे यदकरोद्वीरस्तच्च व्याख्यातुमर्हसि॥
English Translation: Whatever actions are performed by a man under whatever circumstances, he gets the fruits of those those actions under whatever circumstances they may be performed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच शृणु तत्त्वेन राजेन्द्र कीर्त्यमानं मयानघ। वासुदेवं पुरस्कृत्य यदकुर्वत पाण्डवाः॥
English Translation: We are desirous of helping all distiessed people. For the Prosperity of our race, we have come here to kill you, the slayer of our relatives.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: प्राप्य राज्यं महाराज कुन्तीपुत्रो युधिष्ठिरः। चातुर्वण्र्यं यथायोग्यं स्वे स्वे स्थाने न्यवेशयत्॥
English Translation: O king, you consider there is not a Kshatriya equal to you in the world; it is a great error of your judgement.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ब्राह्मणानां सहस्रं च स्नातकानां महात्मनाम्। सहस्रं निष्कमेकैकं दापयामास पाण्डवः॥
English Translation: O king, what Kshatriya is there who, possessing greatness of mind and recollecting the dignity of his own parentage, would not ascend the unrivalled heaven by falling on the field of battle?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथाऽनुजीविनो भृत्यान् संश्रितानतिथीनपि। कामैः संतर्पयामास कृपणांस्तर्ककानपि॥
English Translation: O best of men, know that Kshatriyas, being installed in the sacrifice of war with the view of heaven before them, conquer the whole world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पुरोहिताय धौम्याय प्रादादयुतशः स गा:। धनं सुवर्ण रजतं वासांसि विविधान्यपि॥
English Translation: The study of Brahma, great fame ascetic penances and death in battle are acts that lead men to heaven. The attainment of heaven by the three other acts may be uncertain, but death in battle has heaven for its certain result.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृपाय च महाराज गुरुवृत्तिमवर्तत। विदुराय च राजासौ पूजां चक्रे यतव्रतः॥
English Translation: It is graced with many merits; it is through this, Shatakratu (Indra) has became what he is; he rules the universe by vanquishing the Asuras.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भक्ष्यानपानैर्विविधसैर्वासोभिः शयनासनैः। सर्वान् संतोषयामास संश्रितान् ददतां वरः॥
English Translation: Fighting with you is the certain path to heaven, for you are proud of your prowess of arms and of the excessive might of your large Magadha army.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: लब्धप्रशमनं कृत्वा स राजा राजसत्तम। युयुत्सोर्धार्तराष्ट्रस्य पूजां चक्रे महायशाः॥
English Translation: O king, do not disregard others; velour exists in every man. O king of men, there are men whose velour is equal or superior to yours.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्राय तद् राज्यं गान्धार्थ विदुराय च। निवेद्य सुस्थवद् राजा सुखमास्ते युधिष्ठिरः॥
English Translation: So long it is not known (to the world) so long only you are famous. O king, I tell you, your prowess can be borne by us.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तथा सर्वं स नगरं प्रसाद्य भरतर्षभ। वासुदेवं महात्मानमभ्यगच्छत् कृताञ्जलिः॥
English Translation: O Magadha king, throw away your superiority and pride in the presence of those that are your equals. Do not go to the abode of Yama with your sons, ministers, and troops.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो महति पर्यङ्के मणिकाञ्चनभूषिते। ददर्श कृष्णमासीनं नीलमेघसमद्युतिम्॥
English Translation: Dambhodhva, Kartavirya, Uttara, and Brihadratha, all these kings met with their destruction, along with all their troops for disregarding their superiors.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: जाज्वल्यमानं वपुषा दिव्याभरणभूषितम्। पीतकौशेयवसनं हेम्नेवोपगतं मणिम्॥
English Translation: We are desirous of liberating the captive monarchs from you. Know that we are certainly not Brahmanas. I am Hrishikesha Shauri, and these two are the Pandavas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कौस्तुभेनोरसिस्थेन मणिनाभिविराजितम्। उद्यतेवोदयं शैलं सूर्येणाभिविराजितम्॥
English Translation: O king, O monarch of the Magadha kingdom, we challenge you (to a. single combat). Fight with us with steadiness. Either liberate the kings (now kept prisoner by you) or go the abode of Yama.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नौपम्यं विद्यते तस्य त्रिषु लोकेषु किंचन। सोऽभिगम्य महात्मानं विष्णुं पुरुषविग्रहम्॥ उवाध मधुरं राजा स्मितपूर्वमिदं तदा। सुखेन ते निशा कच्चिद् व्युष्टा बुद्धिमतां वर॥
English Translation: Jarasandha said I never make a king prisoner without first defeating him. Who is kept prisoner here who has not been defeated (by me)?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कच्चिज्ज्ञानानि सर्वाणि प्रसन्नानि तवाच्युत। तथैवोपश्रिता देवी बुद्धिर्बुद्धिमतां वर॥
English Translation: O Krishna, it has been said that the duty of the Kshatriya is to bring others under his sway by displaying his own prowess, and then to treat them in the way he likes.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वयं राज्यमनुप्राप्ताः पृथिवी च वशे स्थिता। तव प्रसादाद् भगवंस्त्रिलोकगतिविक्रम॥ जयं प्राप्ता यशश्चयं न च धर्मच्युता वयम्।
English Translation: O Krishna, recollecting the duty of a Kshatriya, how can I from fear to day liberate the kings collected by me for the purpose of the god?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तं तथा भाषमाणं तु धर्मराजमरिंदमम्। नोवाच भगवान् किंचिद् ध्यानमेवान्वपद्यत॥
English Translation: I am ready to fight with troops against troops placed in a battle array, or alone against (you) one, two or three, either at the sometime or separately.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: उतथ्य उवाच कालवीं च पर्जन्यो धर्मचारी च पार्थिवः। सम्पद् यदेषा भवति सा बिभति सुखं प्रजाः॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said Having said this, and being willing to fight with those heroes of fearful deeds (Krishna etc.), Jarasandha ordered his son Sahadeva to be installed on the throne.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यो न जानाति हर्तुं वा वस्त्राणां रजको मलम्। रक्तानां वा शोधयितुं यथा नास्ति तथैव सः॥
English Translation: O best of the Bharata race, when the day for the combat came, the king thought of his commanders-in-chief, Kaushika and Chitrasena.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एवमेतद् द्विजेन्द्राणां क्षत्रियाणां विशां तथा। शूद्रश्चतुर्थो वर्णानां नानाकर्मस्ववस्थितः॥
English Translation: O king, they were formerly called by the ever renowned names of Hansa and Dimbhaka by every body in the world.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कर्म शूद्रे कृषिवैश्ये दण्डनीतिश्च राजनि। ब्रह्मचर्यं तपो मन्त्राः सत्यं चापि द्विजातिषु॥
English Translation: O king, that foremost of all powerful men, the self-controlled lord Shauri (Krishna), that best of men, that slayer of Madhu, ever de:oted to truth, the younger brother of Haladhara, knowing that the king of Magadha was destined to be killed in battle by Bhima and not by the destroyer of Madhu, did not at the command of Brahma desire to kill that foremost of all powerful men, that hero as powerful as the tiger, that warrior of terrible valour, king Jarasandha.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तेषां यः क्षत्रियो वेद वस्त्राणामिव शोधनम्। शीलदोषान् विनिर्हर्तुं स पिता स प्रजापतिः॥
English Translation: Yudhishthira said 'Wonderful it is, o you of immeasurable prowess, that you are rapt in meditation. O great refuge of the universe, is it all well with the three worlds?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृतं त्रेता द्वापरं च कलिश्च भरतर्षभ। राजवृत्तानि सर्वाणि राजैव युगमुच्यते॥
English Translation: When you have, O god, withdrawn yourself from the world, having, O foremost of men, adopted the fourth state (of perfect unconsciousness of the world) my mind has been filled with wonder.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: चातुर्वण्र्यं तथा वेदाश्चातुराश्रम्यमेव च। सर्वं प्रमुह्यते ह्येतद् यदा राजा प्रमाद्यति॥
English Translation: The five vital airs which act within the body have been controlled by you. You have controlled your senses within your mind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अग्नित्रेता त्रयी विद्या यज्ञाश्च सहदक्षिणाः। सर्व एव प्रमाद्यन्ति यदा राजा प्रमाद्यति॥
English Translation: Both words and mind, O Govinda, have been concentered within your understanding. All your senses, have been withdrawn into your self.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राजैव कर्ता भूतानां राजैव च विनाशकः। धर्मात्मा यः स कर्ता स्यादधर्मात्मा विनाशकः॥
English Translation: The hair on your body stands erect. Your mind and understanding are both calm. You are as immobile now, O Madhava, as an wooden post or a stone?
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राज्ञो भार्याश्च पुत्राश्च बान्धवाः सुहृदस्तथा। समेत्य सर्वे शोचन्ति यदा राजा प्रमाद्यति॥
English Translation: O illustrious god, you are as calm as the flame of a lamp burning in a place where there is no wind. You are as immobile as a rock.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: हस्तिनोऽश्वाश्च गावचाप्युष्ट्राश्वतरगर्दभाः। अधर्मभूते नृपतौ सर्वे सीदन्ति जन्तवः॥
English Translation: If I am fit to hear the cause, and if it is no secret, remove, O god, my doubt, for I beg this। favour from you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुर्बलार्थं वलं सृष्टं धात्रा मान्धातरुच्यते। अबलं तु महद्भूतं यस्मिन् सर्वं प्रतिष्ठितम्॥
English Translation: You are the Creator and you are the Destroyer. You are destructible and you indestructible. You are without beginning and you are without end. You are the first and the foremost of beings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यच्च भूतं सम्भजते ये च भूतास्तदन्वयाः। अधर्मस्थे हि नृपतौ सर्वे शोचन्ति पार्थिव॥
English Translation: O foremost of pious men, tell me the cause of this abstraction. I solicit your favour, and am your devoted worshipper, and am bending my head to you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुर्बलस्य च यच्चक्षुर्मुनेराशीविषस्य च। अविषह्यतमं मन्ये मा स्म दुर्बलमासदः॥
English Translation: Thus accosted the illustrious younger brother of Vasava, reinstating his mind, understanding and the senses in their proper places, said these words similingly.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दुर्बलांस्तात बुध्येथा नित्यमेवाविमानितान्। मा त्वां दुर्बलचढूंषि प्रदहेयुः सबान्धवम्॥
English Translation: Vasudeva said 'That foremost men, viz., Bhishma, who is now lying on a bed of arrows, and who is now like a fire that is about to be extinguished, is thinking of me. It is therefore my mind also was concentrated on him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न हि दुर्बलदग्धस्य कुले किंचित् प्ररोहति। आमूलं निर्दहन्त्येव मा स्म दुर्बलमासदः॥
English Translation: My mind was fixed in him the twang of whose bow and the sound of whose palms Indra himself was unable to bear.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अबलं वै बलाच्छ्रेयो यच्चातिबलवबलम्। बलस्याबलदग्धस्य न किंचिदवशिष्यते॥
English Translation: I was thinking of him who having defeated in a moment all the assembled kings, carried the three princesses of Kashi for the marriage of his brother Vichitravirya.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विमानितो हतः क्रुश्स्त्रातारं चेन विन्दति। अमानुषकृतस्तत्र दण्डो हन्ति नराधिपम्॥
English Translation: I was thinking of him who fought continually for twenty-three days with Rama himself of Bhrigu's race and whom Rama could not defeat.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: मा स्म तात रणे स्थित्वा भुञ्जीथा दुर्बलं जनम्। मा त्वां दुर्बलचक्षूषि दहन्त्वग्निरिवाश्रयम्॥
English Translation: Controlling all his senses and concentrating his mind by the aid of his understanding, he sought my refuge. It was for this that I had fixed my mind upon him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यानि मिथ्याभिशस्तानां पतन्त्यश्रूणि रोदताम्। तानि पुत्रान् पशून् नन्ति तेषां मिथ्याभिशंसनात्॥
English Translation: I was thinking of him whom Ganga conceived and gave birth to, according to ordinary human laws and whom Vasishtha took as a pupil.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदि नात्मनि पुत्रेषु न चेत् पौत्रेषु नप्तृषु। न हि पापं कृतं कर्म सद्यः फलति गौरिव॥
English Translation: I was thinking of that powerful hero of great intelligence who is a master of all the celestial weapons as also of the four Vedas with all their auxiliaries.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यत्राबलो वध्यमानस्त्रातारं नाधिगच्छति। महान् दैवकृतस्तत्र दण्डः पतति दारुणः॥
English Translation: I was thinking of him, O son of Pandu, who is the favourite disciple of Rama the son of Jamadagni, and who is the master of all the sciences.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युक्ता यदा जानपदा भिक्षन्ते ब्राह्मणा इव। अभीक्ष्णं भिक्षुरूपेण राजानं मन्ति तादृशाः॥
English Translation: I was thinking of that best of all persons conversant with morality and duty, of him, O foremost of Bharatas, who knows the Past, the Future, and the Present.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: राज्ञो यदा जनपदे बहवो राजपूरुषाः। अनयेनोपवर्तन्ते तद् राज्ञः किल्बिषं महत्॥
English Translation: After the ascension to heaven of that foremost of kings for his own achievements the Earth, O son of Pritha, will took like a moonless night.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदा युक्त्या नयेदर्थान् कामादर्थवशेन वा। कृपणं याचमानानां तद् राज्ञो वैशसं महत्॥
English Translation: Therefore, O Yudhishthira, humbly approaching Ganga's son, viz., Bhishma, ask him about what you may wish to learn.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: महान् वृक्षो जायते वर्धते च तं चैव भूतानि समाश्रयन्ति। यदा वृक्षश्छिद्यते दह्यते च तदाश्रया अनिकेता भवन्ति॥
English Translation: O king enquire of him about the four branches of knowledge, about sacrifices and the rites sanctioned for the four castes, about the four modes of life, and about the duties of kings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदा राष्ट्रे धर्ममयं चरन्ति संस्कारं वा राजगुणं ब्रुवाणा:। तैरेवाधर्मश्चरितो धर्ममोहात् तूर्णं जह्यात् सुकृतं दुष्कृतं च॥
English Translation: When Bhishma, that foremost one of Kuru's race, will disappear from the world every kind of knowledge will go away with him. It is, therefore, that I urge you to do it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यत्र पापा ज्ञायमानाश्चरन्ति सतां कलिविन्दते तत्र राज्ञः। स्तदा राज्यं वर्धते भूमिपस्य॥
English Translation: Hearing these wholesome and pregnant words of Vasudeva, the righteous Yudhishthira, with voice suppressed with tears, answered Janardana saying—'What you have said, O Madhava, about the greatness of Bhishma, is perfectly true. I have not the least doubt about it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यश्चामात्यान् मानयित्वा यथार्थ मन्त्रे च युद्धे च नृपो नियुङ्ग्यात्। विवर्धते तस्य राष्ट्र नृपस्य भुक्के महीं चाप्यखिलां चिराय॥
English Translation: I had heard of the piety and greatness, of the illustrious Bhishma from great Brahmanas talking about it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यच्चापि सुकृतं कर्म वाचं चैव सुभाषिताम्। समीक्ष्य पूजयन् राजा धर्मं प्राप्नोत्यनुत्तमम्॥
English Translation: You, O killer of foes, are the Creator of all the worlds, There, cannot, therefore, O delighter of the Yadavas, be the least doubt in what you say.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संविभज्य यदा भुक्के नामात्यानवमन्यते। निहन्ति बलिनं दृप्तं स राज्ञो धर्म उच्यते॥
English Translation: If you are pleased to show us favour, O Madhava, then we shall go to Bhishma with yourself at our head.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्रायते हि यदा सर्वं वाचा कायेन कर्मणा। पुत्रस्यापि न मृष्येच्च स राज्ञो धर्म उच्यते॥
English Translation: When the divine Sun shall have turned towards the north, Bhishma will leave (this world) for those blissful regions which he has acquired. That descendant of Kuru's race, therefore, O mighty-armed one, deserves to see you.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संविभज्य यदा भुक्के नृपतिर्दुर्बलान् नरान्। तदा भवन्ति बलिनः स राज्ञो धर्म उच्यते॥
English Translation: Bhishina will then see you who are the first of gods, and who destructible and indestructible. Indeed, O lord, you are the vast receptacle of Brahma.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदा रक्षति राष्ट्राणि यदा दस्यूनपोहति। यदा जयति संग्रामे स राज्ञो धर्म उच्यते॥
English Translation: Vaishampayana said Hearing these words of king Yudhishthira, the destroyer of Madhu addressed Satyaki who was sitting by him, saying,–'Let my car be yoked.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: पापमाचरतो यत्र कर्मणा व्याहृतेन वा। प्रियस्यापि न मृष्येत स राज्ञो धर्म उच्यते॥
English Translation: are At this Satyaki quickly left Keshava's company and going out, ordered Daruka, saying,-'Let Krishna's car be made ready.'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदा शारणिकान् राजा पुत्रवत् परिरक्षति। भिनत्ति च न मर्यादां स राज्ञो धर्म उच्यते॥
English Translation: Hearing the words of Satyaki, Daruka immediately yoked Krishna's car. That best of cars, adorned with gold, decked with profuse emeralds, and moon-gems and sun-gems furnished with golden wheels, effulgent, fleet as the wind, set in the middle with various other kinds of jewels, beautiful as the morning sun, equipped with a beautiful standard bearing the emblem of Gar::da, and numberless other banners, was yoked with those best of horses quick coursing as thought, viz., Sugriva and Saivya and the other two, in trappings of gold. Having yoked it, О tiger among kings, Daruka with joined palms, informed Krishna of the fact
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यदाऽऽप्तदक्षिणैर्यज्ञैर्यजते श्रद्धयान्वितः। कामद्वेषावनादृत्य स राज्ञो धर्म उच्यते॥
English Translation: Surya said : O Karna, never do such acts as will lead to the injury of your own self, your friends, your sons, your wives, your mother and your father.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: कृपणानाथवृद्धानां यदाश्रु परिमार्जति। हर्ष संजनयन् नृणां स राज्ञो धर्म उच्यते॥
English Translation: O best of those that bear life, creatures do not wish to sacrifice their bodies for renown in this world and everlasting fame in heaven.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: विवर्धयति मित्राणि तथारीश्चापि कर्षति। सम्पूजयति साधूंश्च स राज्ञो धर्म उच्यते॥
English Translation: There is no doubt that the everlasting renown which you long for at the cost of your life, will deprive you of it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सत्यं पालयति प्रीत्या नित्यं भूमिं प्रयच्छति। पूजयेदतिथीन् भृत्यान् स राज्ञो धर्म उच्यते॥
English Translation: O most exalted of men, so long as a person is alive, his father, mother, son and other relations in this world are useful to him.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: निग्रहानुग्रहौ चोभौ यत्र स्यातां प्रतिष्ठितौ। अस्मिन् लोके परे चैव राजा स प्राप्नुते फलम्॥
English Translation: The kings also, O best of men, can avail themselves of their prowess, so long as they are alive. Do understand it. O highly-resplendent being, fame is serviceable to living beings only.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यमो राजा धार्मिकाणां मान्धातः परमेश्वरः। संयच्छन् भवति प्राणानसंयच्छंस्तु पातुकः॥
English Translation: As regards a dead person whose frame has been reduced to ashes, what necessity is there for fame? It is not the dead but living persons that can enjoy fame.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ऋत्विक्पुरोहिताचार्यान् सत्कृत्यानवमन्य च। यदा सम्यक् प्रगृह्णाति स राज्ञो धर्म उच्यते॥
English Translation: The fame of a dead person is like a garland (round the neck) of a man whose life is extinct. For the reason that you are a worshipper of mine I am telling you all this for your good,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यमो यच्छति भूतानि सर्वाण्येवाविशेषतः। तथा राज्ञानुकर्तव्यं यन्तव्या विधिवत् प्रजाः॥
English Translation: And for this further reason that all my devotees should be protected protected by me. Considering, O mighty-amed one, that this person is a great devotee to me, I have been inclined to revere you. Therefore accept my advice.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सहस्राक्षेण राजा हि सर्वथैवोपमीयते। स पश्यति च यं धर्म स धर्मः पुरुषर्षभ॥
English Translation: A deep mystery ordained by fate, underlies all this. It is on this account that I am addressing you thus. Act (according to my words) and let no doubts cross your mind.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अप्रमादेन शिक्षेथाः क्षमां बुद्धिं धृति मतिम्। भूतानां चैव जिज्ञासा साध्वसाधु च सर्वदा॥
English Translation: O best of men, you are not fit to learn this which even the gods do not know. It is why I do not reveal it to you. You will, however know it in time.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संग्रहः सर्वभूतानां दानं च मधुरं वचः। पौरजानपदाचैव गोप्तव्यास्ते यथासुखम्॥
English Translation: O Radha's son, I am telling you again what I have already said. Pay attention to it. You will by no means give the ear-rings to the wielder of the thunderbolt when he will beg them (of you).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: न जात्वदक्षो नृपतिः प्रजाः शक्नोति रक्षितुम्। भारो हि सुमहांस्तात राज्यं नाम सुदुष्करम्॥
English Translation: Adorned with your beautiful ear-rings you shine like the moon in the azure sky between the Vishakha constellations, O highly effulgent creature.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तद्दण्डविन्नृपः प्राज्ञः शूरः शक्नोति रक्षितुम्। न हि शक्यमदण्डेन क्लीबेनाबुद्धिनापि वा॥
English Translation: Know that fame is useful to a person so long as he is alive. Therefore, O son, you must refuse the lord of the celestials when he will beg the ear-rings.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अभिरूपैः कुले जातैर्दक्षैर्भक्तैर्बहुश्रुतैः। सर्वा बुद्धीः परीक्षेपास्तापसाश्रमिणामपि॥
English Translation: O sinless one, you will be able to do away with the eager desire of the lord of the gods for the ear-rings by repeatedly addressing him in various words coupled with reason.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अतस्त्वं सर्वभूतानां धर्मं वेत्स्यसि वै परम्। स्वदेशे परदेशे वा न ते धर्मो विनक्षयति॥
English Translation: O Karna, remove the desire of Purandara by sweet and reasonable words consequence. of great
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तस्मादर्थाच्च कामाच्च धर्म एवोत्तरो भवेत्। अस्मिल्लोके परे चैव धर्मात्मा सुखमेधते॥
English Translation: O most valiant of men, you always challenge Savyasachi (i.e. Arjuna who can draw the bow with his left hand) and the warlike Savyasachi too, will no doubt, encounter you in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्यजन्ति दारान् पुत्रांश्च मनुष्याः परिपूजिताः। संग्रहश्चैव भूतानां दानं च मधुरा च वाक्॥ अप्रमादश्च शौचं च राज्ञो भूतिकरं महत्। एतेभ्यश्चैव मान्धातः सततं मा प्रमादिथाः॥
English Translation: But arrayed in your ear-rings Arjuna, even with the assistance of Indra himself shall not be able to defeat you in battle.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अप्रमत्तो भवेद् राजा छिद्रदर्शी परात्मनोः। नास्यच्छिद्रं परः पश्येच्छिद्रेषु परमन्वियात्॥
English Translation: Therefore, O Karna, if you are at all desirous of defeating. Arjuna in battle, do not give your auspicious ear-rings to Shakra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: एतद् वृत्तं वासवस्य यमस्य वरुणस्य च। राजर्षीणां च सर्वेषां तत् त्वमप्यनुपालय॥
English Translation: Sanjaya said Beholding the host of the Samsaptakas one more return to battle, Arjuna thus addressed the high-souled son of Vasudeva.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तत् कुरुष्व महाराज वृत्तं राजर्षिसेवितम्। आतिष्ठ दिव्यं पन्थानमह्नाय पुरुषर्षभ॥
English Translation: 'O Hrishikesha urge my steeds against this host of the Samshaptakas. I think they will not give up the battle so long life will be extant in them.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धर्मवृत्तं हि राजानं प्रेत्य चेह च भारत। देवर्षिपितृगन्धर्वाः कीर्तयन्ति महौजसः॥
English Translation: Behold, today, the terrible prowess of my two arms as also that of my bow. This day I will slay them, like Rudra slaying creatures (at the time of the universal annihilation).'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच स एवमुक्तो मान्धाता तेनोतथ्येन भारत। कृतवानविशङ्कश्च एकः प्राप च मेदिनीम्॥
English Translation: Thereupon Krishna smiling and greeting the invincible Arjuna with auspicious words, pushed in the chariot where-so-ever the latter desired it to go.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भवानपि तथा सम्यङ्मान्धातेव महीपते। धर्म कृत्वा महीं रक्ष स्वर्गे स्थानमवाप्स्यसि॥
English Translation: That chariot, borne in that battle by white steeds, appeared excessively effulgent, like a celestial car borne through the firmament.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: युधिष्ठिर उवाच एवमग्राह्यके तस्मिज्ञातिसम्बन्धिमण्डले। मित्रेष्वमित्रेष्वपि च कथं भावो विभाव्यते॥
English Translation: O monarch, like the chariot of Shakra in the battle between the gods and the Asuras in the days of yore, that car moved in circular, backward and forward motions.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भीष्म उवाच अत्राप्युदाहरन्तीममितिहासं पुरातनम्। संवादं वासुदेवस्य सुरर्षेर्नारदस्य च॥
English Translation: Then the Narayana soldiers inflamed with rage and holding various weapons in their hands, encompassing Dhananjaya, covered him with showers of arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वासुदेव उवाच नासुहृत् परमं मन्त्रं नारदार्हति वेदितुम्। अपण्डितो वापि सुहृत् पण्डितो वाप्यनात्मवान्॥
English Translation: O foremost of the Bharata, in a moment they, in that battle, made the son of Kunti namely Dhananjaya, together with Krishna, disappear from the sight.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स ते सौहृदमास्थाय किञ्चिद् वक्ष्यामि नारद। कृत्स्नं बुद्धिबलं प्रेक्ष्य सम्पृच्छेस्त्रिदिवंगम॥
English Translation: Wrought up with wrath, Phalguna, doubling his energy in that battle, rubbed his bow Gandiva and quickly grasped it.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दास्यमैश्वर्यवादेन ज्ञातीनां न करोम्यहम्। अर्धं भोक्तास्मि वाग्दुरुक्तानि च क्षमे॥
English Translation: Causing a frown indicative of wrath to gather on his brow, the son of Pandu charged his mighty conch called Devadatta with his breath.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अरणीमग्निकामो वा मनाति हृदयं मम। वाचा दुरुक्तं देवर्षे तन्मे दहति नित्यदा॥
English Translation: Thereafter Arjuna discharged the weapon called Tashtra that is capable of slaying large divisions of the enemy. Thereupon thousands of separate forms (of Arjuna and Vasudeva) started into existence there.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बलं संकर्षणे नित्यं सौकुमार्य पुनर्गदे। रूपेण मत्तः प्रद्युम्नः सोऽसहायोऽस्मि नारद॥
English Translation: Confounded by the various images of Arjuna's self, they fell to slay one another each considering the other to be Arjuna himself.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अन्ये हि सुमहाभागा बलवन्तो दुरुत्सहाः। नित्योत्थानेन सम्पन्ना नारदान्धकवृष्णयः॥
English Translation: 'This is Arjuna, this is Govinda, these two are the son of Pandu and the descendant of Yadu', uttering these exclamations, and stupefied, they slow each other in that fight,
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यस्य न स्युर्न वै स स्याद् यस्य स्युः कृत्स्नमेव तत्। द्वाभ्यां निवारितो नित्यं वृणोम्येकतरं न च॥
English Translation: Confounded by virtue of that weapon, they courted destruction through one another's agency. In that battle those warriors shone like flowering Kinshuka trees.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: स्यातां यस्याहुकाक्रूरौ किं नु दुःखतरं ततः। यस्य चापि न तौ स्यातां किं नु दुःखतरं ततः॥
English Translation: Then that weapon. consuming the thousands of shafts discharged by the enemy, conveyed those heroes to the regions of Death.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सोऽहं कितवमातेव द्वयोरपि महामते। एकस्य जयमाशंसे द्वितीयस्यापराजयम्॥
English Translation: Thereafter Vibhatsu, with a smile, crushed with his arrows the war-like Lalithyas, the Malavas, the Mavelakas and the Trigarttas.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ममैवं क्लिश्यमानस्य नारदोभयतः सदा। वक्तुमर्हसि यच्छ्रेयो ज्ञातीनामात्मनस्तथा॥
English Translation: Those Kshatriyas, doomed by fate to die, being smitten by the heroic son of Pritha, discharged at him a net-work of diverse arrows.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नारद उवाच आपदो द्विविधाः कृष्ण बाह्याश्चाभ्यन्तराश्च ह। प्रादुर्भवन्ति वार्ष्णेय स्वकृता यदि वान्यतः॥
English Translation: Thereupon, neither Arjuna, nor his car, nor Keshava was to be seen on the field, being covered over by that terrible arrowy showers.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सेयमाभ्यन्तरा तुभ्यमापत् कृच्छा स्वकर्मजा। अक्रूरभोजप्रभवा सर्वे ह्येते त्वदन्वयाः॥
English Translation: Then finding their arrows strike the aim, they exclaimed to one another saying 'Krishna and Arjuna are both slain’; and out of delight they waived their garments in the air.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अर्थहेतोहि कामाद् वा वाचा बीभत्सयापि वा। आत्मना प्राप्तमैश्वर्यमन्यत्र प्रतिपादितम्॥ कृतमूलमिदानीं तज्ज्ञातिवृन्दं सहायवन्। न शक्यं पुनरादातुं वान्तमनमिव त्वया॥
English Translation: Then those heroes sounded, by thousands, drums and Mridangas and conchs; and, O sire, they also gave forth war-cries resembling the roars of lions.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: बभूग्रसेनयो राज्यं नाप्तुं शक्यं कथंचन। ज्ञातिभेदभयात् कृष्ण त्वया चापि विशेषतः॥
English Translation: Then Krishna greatly perspiring, addressed Arjuna covered with sweat, saying 'Where are you, O son of Pritha, I do not see you, do you live, O siayer of your foes.'
---
Sanskrit Shloka: तच्च सिध्येत् प्रयत्लेन कृत्वा कर्म सुदुष्करम्। महाक्षयं व्ययो वा स्याद् विनाशो वा पुनर्भवेत्॥
English Translation: Hearing those words of his (Krishna's), Dhananjaya quickly dispelled that arrowy shower poured by the enemy, by means of the Vavabha weapon.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: अनायसेन शस्त्रेण मृदुना हृदयच्छिदा। जिह्वामुद्धर सर्वेषां परिमृज्यानुमृज्य च॥
English Translation: Then the almighty Vayu blew away hosts of the Samshaptakas consisting of steeds elephants, chariots and weapons like heaps of dry leafs.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वासुदेव उवाच अनायसं मुने शस्त्रं मृदु विद्यामहं कथम्। येनैषामुद्धरे जिह्वां परिमृज्यानुमृज्य च।॥
English Translation: Borne away by the god Vayu, they appeared highly beautiful like flights of birds, O sire, flying up from trees at the hour of dawn.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नारद उवाच शक्त्यान्नदानं सततं तितिक्षार्जवमार्दवम्। यथार्हप्रतिपूजा च शस्त्रमेतदनायसम्॥
English Translation: Thus causing great anxiety in them, Dhananjaya with great lightness of hands slew, with keen pointed shafts, hundreds and thousands of the enemy.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ज्ञातीनां वक्तुकामानां कटुकानि लघूनि च। गिरा त्वं हृदयं वाचं शमयस्व मनांसि च॥
English Translation: He struck their heads and arms hearing weapons, with broad-headed shafts; and with his arrows he cut down on the ground their thighs resembling the trunks of elephants.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नामहापुरुषः कश्चिन्नानात्मा नासहायवान्। महतीं धुरमाधत्ते तामुद्यम्योरसा वह॥
English Translation: Some had their backs lacerated, some were deprived of their legs, some were hit on the arms, backs and eyes; thus Dhananjaya made his enemies deprived of their various limbs.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: सर्व एव गुरुं भारमनड्वान वहते समे। दुर्गे प्रतीतः सुगवो भारं वहति दुर्वहम्॥
English Translation: Shattering into pieces with his arrows, chariots resembling a real castle and equipped according to rule, he deprived them of their steeds, warriors and elephants.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: भेदाद् विनाशः संघानां संघमुख्योऽसि केशव। यथा त्वां प्राप्य नोत्सीदेदयं संघस्तथा कुरु॥
English Translation: At places several crowds of chariots, having their flag-staffs severed, looked like forests of palmyra trees deprived of their heads.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: नान्यत्र बुद्धिक्षान्तिभ्यां नान्यत्रेन्द्रियनिग्रहात्। नान्यत्र धनसंत्यागाद् गणः प्राज्ञेऽवतिष्ठते॥
English Translation: Elephants furnished with excellent weapons, banners, hooks and standards fell down like woody mountains rent asunder by the thunder-bolt of Indra.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धन्यं यशस्यमायुष्यं स्वपक्षोद्भावनं सदा। ज्ञातीनामविनाशः स्याद् यथा कृष्ण तथा कुरु॥
English Translation: Smitten with the arrows of Partha, steeds, graced with tails like those of the yak, protected with coats of mail and with their entrails, eyes and vitals dragged out, rolled on the ground along with their riders.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: आयत्यां च तदात्वे च न तेऽस्त्यविदितं प्रभो। पाड्गुण्यस्य विधानेन यात्रायानविधौ तथा॥
English Translation: Dropping from their grasps the swords that had served the purposes of their nails, having their armours torn and the joints of their limbs smashed, foot soldiers, with their vital parts cut open, helplessly laid themselves down (on the field) being slain (by Partha).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: यादवाः कुकुरा भोजाः सर्वे चान्धकवृष्णयः। त्वय्यासक्ता महाबाहो लोका लोकेश्वराश्च ये॥ उपासते हि त्वबुद्धिमृषयश्चापि माधव।
English Translation: The field of battle assumed an awful aspect in consequence of those warriors slain or in course of being slaughtered fallen and falling, wheeling round or staying motionless.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: त्वं गुरुः सर्वभूतानां जानीषे त्वं गतागतम्। त्वामासाद्य यदुश्रेष्ठमेधन्ते यादवाः सुखम्॥
English Translation: The cloud of dust that had arisen was now cleared away by means of the shower of blood. The ground became slipper and was strewn with numerous headless trunks.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: वैशम्पायन उवाच एवं तदभवद् युद्धं तुमुलं जनमेजय। यत्र दुःखान्वितो राजा धृतराष्ट्रोऽब्रवीदिदम्॥
English Translation: Then the chariot of Vibhastsu shone fierce and dreadful in that battle, like the chariot of Rudra himself when at the end of a Yuga he slays all creatures.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: धृतराष्ट्र उवाच रामं संनिहितं दृष्ट्वा गदायुद्ध उपस्थिते। मम पुत्रः कथं भीम प्रत्ययुध्यत संजय॥
English Translation: Thus being slaughtered by the son of Pritha, those warriors, with their steeds, cars and elephants in distress and their ranks thinned, rushed at him and thus were made the guests of Shakra (i.e. were transported to the regions of Indra).
---
Sanskrit Shloka: संजय उवाच रामसांनिध्यमासाद्य पुत्रो दुर्योधनस्तव। युद्धकामो महाबाहुः समहष्यत वीर्यवान्॥
English Translation: O foremost of the Bharatas, that field of battle then strewn with many a slain carwarrior of renown, shone like the region of Death swarming with the spirits of the departed.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: दृष्टवा लागलिनं राजा प्रत्युत्थाय च भारत। प्रीत्या परमया युक्तः समभ्यर्च्य यथाविधि॥ आसनं च ददौ तस्मै पर्यपृच्छदनामयम्।
English Translation: During this period when Savyasachin was furiously engaged (with the Samshaptakas) Drona, at the head of his divisions formed in battle-array, charged Yudhishthira.
---
Sanskrit Shloka: ततो युधिष्ठरं रामो वाक्यमेतदुवाच ह॥ मधुरं धर्मसंयुक्तं शूराणां हितमेव च। मया श्रुतं कथयतामृषीणां राजसत्तम॥ कुरुक्षेत्रं परं पुण्यं पावनं स्वर्गमेव च। दैवतैऋषिभिर्जुष्टं ब्राह्मणैश्च महात्मभिः॥
English Translation: Many a warrior, arranged in order of battle and accomplished in striking quickly formed Drona's support, out of a desire for capturing Yudhishthira. There-upon a dreadful fight ensued.
---
